title: TEXAS AIR SEEKING BETTER DEAL
description: The Texas Air Corporation said today that it was seeking additional financial concessions from People Express Inc. to reduce the cost of its proposed $125 million acquisition.

title: VOLUNTEERS MARK 20 YEARS OF RETIREES PROGRAM
description: Retired people from across the city gathered yesterday in Radio City Music Hall for the ''All-American Salute to Senior Volunteers.''

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a change in pension accounting rules which increased the quarter net by $81,000 and the 9-month net by $110,000. The company said that the year-to- date benefit of the accounting change on after-tax earnings was more than offset by a higher provision for taxes in the 1986 period due to a change in the company's effective rate.

title: PARADYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $50,000 and a pretax provision of $8,300,000 for slow moving and obsolete inventory for the quarter, and the 9 months include an extraordinary credit of $393,000.

title: CRUDE OIL PRICES STEADY
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products steadied yesterday on world markets, as the oil community awaited further ramifications of the dismissal of Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani as the Saudi oil minister.

title: STEWART INFORMATION SERVCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Cuts Savings Bond Rate
description: The Government today reduced the minimum guaranteed interest rate for new United States savings bonds from 7.5 percent to 6 percent, effective Saturday, reducing the appeal of what had been one of the best investments for small savers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Episcopal Bishop Visits Church After Warning
description: Bishop Graham Leonard of London led a confirmation service Thursday for 21 members of a church whose pastor has been separated from the Episcopal Diocese of Oklahoma in a dispute over church tenets.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW BEST-SELLING NOVEL AT NAVAL INSTITUTE PRESS
description: With another best-selling novel to its credit, the Naval Institute Press is now batting a thousand as a publisher of fiction. Its new book, only the second novel the press has published in its 114-year history, is ''Flight of the Intruder'' by Stephen Coonts, an account of Naval aviators at war over Vietnam.

title: British Gas Issue
description: British Gas said it will issue more than 4 billion shares for the pound equivalent of up to $2.10 each in what financial experts say will be the biggest sale of a state-owned industry to the public. Market analysts said Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government could earn around $8.4 billion when shares in British Gas go on sale. Investors will have to apply by Dec. 3 for at least 100 shares but pay only one-third the value of the shares, or about 70 cents, at first, with second and third installments, payable in June 1987 and April 1988.

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trouble Spots Listed For Weekend Traffic
description: These are among the most severe traffic trouble spots in the New York metropolitan region this weekend, according to the City Transportation Department:

title: VLAHO BRUER
description: Vlaho Bruer, retired chairman of the Alpine Group of Hackensack, N.J., a holding company for manufacturers of apparel accessories and industrial products, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: TCF BANKING & SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,055,000. c-Net loss and includes a reversal of a tax credit of $257,000. d-After an extraordinary gain of $383,000. e-After a charge of $3,802,000. The latest 9 months gain consists of $8,626,000 in penalties on early repayment of FHLB advances and tax credits of $9,009,000. The year-ago 9 months charge consists of penalties of $4,080,000 and a tax credit of $278,000.

title: EXXON BUILDING PUT ON AUCTION BLOCK
description: The owners of the Exxon Building - the Exxon Corporation and subsidiaries of the Rockefeller Group Inc. - said yesterday that they would put the 54-story tower at the Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street on the auction block. Exxon plans to retain a long-term lease on seven floors and to maintain its headquarters in New York.

title: Return to Center Stage
description: In the aftermath of the Mets' World Series victory, after consecutive Monday Night Football appearances by the Jets and the Giants, with the odds improving that at least one of those teams will be participating on Super Bowl Sunday, is it really fair to impose another New York City celebration on the nation at this time? Can any of us living within a commuter railroad ride of Manhattan even bear listening to another chorus of ''Start spreading the news''? Will political opponents begin calling the Mayor a jock?

title: CYCARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April. The company said a change in accounting for pensions increased its earnings for the latest periods by 1 cent a share and 3 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: ARTHUR A. COHEN, AUTHOR, DIES AT 58
description: Arthur A. Cohen, a novelist, a publisher and an author of many works on the history of modern Jewish thought, died yesterday morning of cancer at his home in New York City. He was 58 years old.

title: Fire Disrupts IRT Service
description: A track fire interrupted service during the morning rush yesterday on the Lexington Avenue line of the IRT.

title: G.O.P. CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR GAINS IN ALABAMA
description: The campaign to elect Alabama's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction has received an important lift from the announcement that Attorney General Charles Graddick, who had been running as an independent write-in candidate, was dropping out of the race.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN HOLD WAR GAMES AS MILITARY COOPERATION INCREASES
description: All this week, fighter planes creased the skies above this city and infantrymen crawled across muddy fields in the most comprehensive military maneuvers ever held jointly by the United States and Japan.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In his team's 30-20 loss to Fresno State Thursday night, Kevin Sweeney of Fresno State became the third player in N.C.A.A. Division I-A history to pass for more than 10,000 yards. The senior quarterback completed 13 of 20 passes for 189 yards, lifting his total to 10,116.

title: 11.5% STAKE IN GOODYEAR REPORTED BY GOLDSMITH
description: Sir James Goldsmith has acquired an 11.5 percent stake in the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the British financier said in a filing made late yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SEPTEMBER FACTORY ORDERS UP
description: Orders to the nation's factories jumped 3.4 percent in September, the biggest increase in almost two years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: MCENROE LOSES AND IS FINED
description: John McEnroe was upset by both his opponent and the officiating today, winding up with a defeat, a fine and a suspension.

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $1,110,428. The company went public in December; therefore year-ago per share earnings are not available.

title: FOR CHILDREN, PLAYTIME WITH A PURPOSE
description: Prepare yourself for 3-month-olds lifting barbells, 6-year-olds cranking rowing machines and television-cartoon addicts bouncing to aerobics videotapes. Some American businesses and physicians want little children to exercise, and simple playtime may lose its innocence forever.

title: COUNTY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
End Albany's Legal Influence Peddling
description: A member of Congress who accepts a fee to represent a private client before a Federal agency commits a Federal crime. New Jersey and several other states also forbid private lobbying by public servants. Not New York. A state senator is free to appear before agencies like the State Liquor Authority - whose budget he approves and whose members he has voted to confirm or reject - seeking a liquor license for a client.

title: Randolph Files as Free Agent
description: Willie Randolph, who with Ron Guidry could leave the Yankees without their co-captains if they were to leave as free agents, took the first step yesterday by filing for free agency. Randolph, however, isn't preparing to leave.

title: THOUSAND TRAILS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: c-Net income

title: Unicorp Purchases 12.6% of Purolator
description: The Toronto-based utility and natural resources concern, Unicorp Canada Corporation, said in a regulatory filing yesterday that it has bought 12.6 percent of the ailing Purolator Courier Corporation and intends to acquire or restructure Purolator.

title: MARTIN STILL A VALUABLE GIANT
description: After the 1984 season, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants sat down with George Martin. The defensive end was almost 32 years old and had played 10 seasons with the Giants. He thought it was time to retire.

title: REAGAN, IN THE NORTHWEST, SEEKS TO ALLAY FEARS ON NUCLEAR DUMP
description: President Reagan today sought to ease local concern over a radioactive site in Washington state as he continued his campaign to retain a Republican Senate majority in next Tuesday's elections.

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings reflects the retroactive effect of a 10 percent stock dividend effected May 15, 1986 and a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Aug. 20, 1986.

title: Drug Checks Are Challenged
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit yesterday challenging the constitutionality of recent police drug checkpoints on the New Jersey side of the George Washington Bridge.

title: COLUMN ONE: STORIES OF THE CITY
description: Menagerie

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,151,226 for the quarter and $5,605,670 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $591,245 and $1,260,281 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Woman Gets Life Terms In Philadelphia Shootings
description: The mentally ill woman who killed three people and tried to kill seven others in a shopping mall shooting rampage a year ago was sentenced to three consecutive life terms today by a judge who said ''she should not be put back on the street.''

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Thursday's, Oct. 30, editions.

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $1,433,000 and $2,170,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized capital gains of $270,000 and $279,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: IMMIGRATION BILL LIKELY TO HAVE A WIDE IMPACT ON FARM LABOR AND ALIENS
description: Farm experts say the immigration bill Congress passed this month assures that American agriculture will have a continuing long-term supply of inexpensive field hands for the forseeable future.

title: AFFILIATED BANK CORP OF WYOING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEW DATA ON HALLEY'S COMET SHOW IT HAS 10-MILE NUCLEUS
description: Intensive analysis of data sent to Earth by two Soviet spacecraft as they flew past Halley's comet last March has shown the comet's nucleus to be 10 miles long and considerably larger than recent estimates. Having now determined its size, the Russians believe that for the first time they can estimate its density.

title: HENRY J. DiROCCO
description: Henry J. DiRocco, who was the official photographer for the Queens Borough President for 33 years, died at his home in Levittown, L.I., over the weekend. He was 71 years old.

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $632,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $5,909,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $514,000 for the quarter and $2,253,000 for the 9 months.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS (CALIF) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 28, 1986.

title: ALASKA MUTUAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: TRANSTECH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $291,478. c-Net loss and includes a loss from continuing operations of $415,087.

title: COLLEGE GAMES AT A GLANCE
description: Home teams are listed first. Season records are in parentheses. LOCAL TEAMS Columbia (0-6) vs. Villanova (5-1) Coach Larry McElreavy of Columbia said, ''We're at a really low ebb.'' Hofstra (6-1) vs. Albany St. (4-3) Alan Squeri of Hofstra has 16 touchdown passes in a big year.

title: 3 Armenians Convicted In Attack in Ottawa
description: Three Armenians charged with killing a security guard during the seizure of the Turkish Embassy here last year were found guilty today of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison.

title: The Measure of Republican 'Integrity'
description: Republicans call their ''ballot integrity'' campaign a legitimate program to prevent voter fraud. Democrats say it's a ploy to reduce the participation of black voters. A memo released on the order of a Federal judge last week suggests, sadly, that the Democrats are right.

title: U.S. TO SEND TOP TEAM TO VIENNA TALKS
description: Senior Administration arms-control officials will accompany Secretary of State George P. Shultz to a meeting next week with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: BURRITT INTERFINANCIAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $181,600. c-After an extraordinary gain of $76,300.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Akai America Ltd., Compton, Calif., said that after Dec. 31, Akai audio-video products would be distributed by Mitsubishi Electric Sales America Inc.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Until there is substantial Soviet progress in the vital area of human rights, advances in other areas of the relationship are bound to be constrained.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ 1:1. ]

title: Aaron Resnick Dies; Architect and Engineer
description: Aaron L. Resnick, an engineer and architect who put Frank Lloyd Wright's theories into practice in helping to create the Westchester County community of Usonia, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 72 years old and lived in Usonia in a house he designed and built in 1949.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an $8,060,000 special gain for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page Oct. 23 about the retirement of Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. misstated the situation in his House district. Joseph P. Kennedy, the Democratic candidate, is opposed in the election by Clark Abt, a Republican.

title: Intergroup Posts Loss
description: National Intergroup Inc., which operates the nation's sixth-largest steel producer, yesterday reported a loss of $23.9 million for its second quarter ended Sept. 30. In contrast, the company earned $16.9 million in the period last year. National Intergroup, the parent of the National Aluminum Corporation, owns the National Steel Company jointly with Nippon Kokan K.J. of Japan.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss is attributable to the following non-recurring items: a reduction in an estimated claim due on the cancellation of a government program and an additional provision made for an extraordinary writedown of the value of equipment in connection with the discontinuance of Array Devices Corp.

title: DETROIT EFFORTS FAIL TO STEM ARSON ON EVE OF HALLOWEEN
description: Orange plumes rose into the night air from vacant houses and abandoned automobile late Thursday despite the city's efforts to contain a wave of arson that plagues Detroit each year the night before Halloween, which is called Devil's Night here.

title: How 'Star Wars' Is, and Isn't, Like an Ack-Ack Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Greek Cabinet Installed
description: A new Cabinet was sworn in today under Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou. The changes were seen as an attempt to present a new image after the governing Socialists' serious losses in municipal elections this month. The number of Cabinet members was reduced from 48 to 36, but no changes were made in the key ministries of defense, foreign affairs and economy.

title: SURGE OF TIMES SQ. PROJECTS RAISES QUESTIONS ON EFFECTS
description: The recent start of demolition of the Pussycat Theater opened an era of potentially explosive development on Times Square.

title: TENTATIVE PACT FOR BRONX ENSEMBLE
description: Freelance orchestra musicians have reached a tentative settlement with the Bronx Arts Ensemble, one member of the consortium of orchestras being struck by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians.

title: Fixing the Law
description: A tiny paragraph in the recent comprehensive Pentagon reorganization act removed an obstacle to James F. McGovern's becoming Under Secretary of the Air Force, and the Senate then quickly confirmed him for the post, the No. 2 job in the Air Force.

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $540,000 and $2,204,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After tax credits of $407,000 for the quarter and $2,178,000 for the year.

title: SEAHAWKS' SURPRISE WILL BE NOTHING NEW FOR JETS
description: Five years ago, almost to the day, the Seattle Seahawks put in an untested free-agent quarterback against the Jets. He killed them. Now, in one of the most stunning moves of the season, that quarterback, Dave Krieg, has been benched and another untested free-agent quarterback will face the Jets Sunday in the Kingdome.

title: Maryland Suspension
description: The University of Maryland basketball program received another jolt yesterday when Keith Gatlin was ruled ineligible for the upcoming season.

title: GAS SUPPLIER WINS LAWSUIT
description: A Federal District Court jury awarded the Colorado Interstate Gas Company more that $500 million in damages Thursday in what is believed to be the largest settlement ever in a natural gas contract dispute.

title: TV: 'JAY LENO SPECIAL,' TONIGHT AT 11:30 ON NBC
description: Jay Leno, this year's hot young comedian, recently signed a long-term contract with NBC, and the network is clearly eager, perhaps too eager, to cash in. Pre-empting this week's edition of ''Saturday Night Live,'' the first ''Jay Leno Special'' can be seen tonight at 11:30. Mr. Leno is fine, deftly taking aim at everything from television's ''People's Court'' (''Law and laughter, they go hand and hand'') to a new magazine called ''Walking: The Healthy Alternative'' (''To what? Astral projection?''). The show, however, is a clumpy mess.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,549,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $437,000 and $1,544,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: CITY SCHOOLS TO SHOW NEW VIDEOTAPE ON AIDS
description: After a six-month delay, the New YormmCity Board of Education plans to distribute a videotape about AIDS, the president of the board, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday.

title: O'Neill Predicts Democrats Will Win the Senate Tuesday
description: Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the retiring House Speaker, said today that he expected the Democrats to win control of the Senate in the elections Tuesday despite President Reagan's cross-country campaign trip in behalf of Republicans.

title: AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $21,940,000 and $22,710,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and losses from discontinued operations of $2,829,000 for the quarter and $3,535,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,427,000 for the quarter and $2,667,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest third quarter and 9-month losses are attributable to contribution losses by Amfac distribution of $44,168,000 and $61,428,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The quarter's loss included a previously announced $30 million pre-tax charge associated with a reorganization involving the closure of 29 branches and an accelerated inventory reduction program.

title: Sudan Accuses U.N. Official Of Dealing With Insurgents
description: The Government has declared a United Nations official persona non grata because of his contacts with rebels to safeguard the delivery of emergency supplies to the southern Sudan, according to the Sudanese press agency.

title: Laotian President Quits; Health Reasons Cited
description: Prince Souphanouvong has stepped down as President of Laos for health reasons, the Laotian state radio said today.

title: Quebec's Acid Rain> Harvest
description: I live in a war zone, although it doesn't look like one. At first glance, it's just the Kemp family farm, outside Brigham, Quebec, where 28 Holsteins graze in fall's last green fields.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $35 million writedown in the carrying value of a unit's oil and gas properties. c-Includes a $10 million writedown related to a joint venture exploration program for both the quarter and 9 months. d-Net income

title: MANES IS STILL AN ISSUE, QUEENS SUCCESSOR FINDS
description: In September, after winning the Democratic nomination to seek a full term, Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens announced: ''I am not Donald Manes.''

title: LEISURE & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,823,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income

title: PITTSBURG-DES MOINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: TORIES ACCUSE OF BBC OF ANTI-U.S. REPORTS ON LIBYA
description: Britain's governing party has challenged the integrity of the British Broadcasting Corporation, accusing it of distorted anti-American news coverage of the United States raid on Libya in April.

title: ALUMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $4.5 million.

title: KANSAS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
METROPOLITAN FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $432,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $645,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE VOW TO COOPERATE IN ECONOMIC MOVES
description: Against the backdrop of the American elections on Tuesday, the United States and Japan announced a broad agreement today to coordinate their economic policies and bolster both economies.

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Tway Falls Short Twice
description: Bob Tway suffered a double defeat yesterday, losing to Steve Pate in the second round of the Seiko Tucson Match Play Championship and failing by $516 to gain the PGA Tour's money-winning title.

title: IDAHO POWER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Moslem Fundamentalists Fight Police in Egypt
description: Hundreds of Moslem fundamentalists battled with policemen outside a mosque today in a melee involving guns, knives, clubs and tear gas, witnesses said.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This seat remained conspicuously empty. What were the circumstances? 2. An ''AIDS Awareness Week'' has been declared in a conservative state where many residents believed there was no problem with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Name the state. 3. New Jersey officials announced plans for a new rail line along the Hudson that will be the first of its kind in the Metropolitan region in half a century. What kind is it? 4. At first it seemed that the long-awaited ''Big Bang'' would be a bust. Explain. 5. The Boston Red Sox lost the seventh game of the World Series to the New York Mets by a score of 8-5. In how many previous Series have the Red Sox lost the seventh game? 6. New Vatican guidelines for Roman Catholic pastors will recommend that homosexuals (be encouraged/not be encouraged) to practice the sacraments, according to senior church officials. 7. ''It's laudatory that we can do something in the interests of national defense,'' said New York's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward. To what was he referring? 8. A tweedy men's clothier, a favorite of Ivy League graduates for more than 80 years, has been purchased by a Japanese marketing and licensing company. What clothier is it? 9. This is an illustration of ''Bambi.'' What was it? 10. In an unusual step, the Soviet Union released quotations attributed to President Reagan in confidential talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Iceland summit.

title: SHOOTING TOUCH IS MISSING
description: Recent reports of the Knicks' resurrection may be somewhat premature.

title: JOHNSTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $33,000. The company said year-ago quarter net includes life insurance proceeds of about $3,266,000.

title: HORIZON BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in August.

title: HASENFUS REFUSES COURT TESTIMONY
description: The American air-freight handler whose arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua Oct. 5 refused to testify today before a Nicaraguan court.

title: FISERV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $70,000 and $920,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $83,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the 9 months.

title: BROOKFIELD FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted to stock form in December 1985.

title: 55 EXPELLED RUSSIANS LEAVE WASHINGTON
description: A total of 55 Soviet diplomats left Washington with their families today under an expulsion order intended to reduce the ability of the Soviet Embassy to conduct espionage. The diplomats were told last week to leave the country by Nov. 1.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX POSTS 0.4% RISE FOR SEPTEMBER
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in September, reversing the slight decline of August, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BREDDERS' CUP UPSETS LIKELY
description: The Breeders' Cup at Santa Anita Saturday, matching most of the world's best horses in seven races worth $10 million, seems filled with short-priced favorites seeking to solidify their championship bids.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. CHICAGO BULLS, home opener, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.). NETS VS. HAWKS, at Atlanta (Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.).

title: Text of Statement on Economic Cooperation
description: Following is the text of the statement on economic cooperation released today in Tokyo and Washington by Japanese Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and United States Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d:

title: DAMON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $128,000 for the quarter and $111,000 for the year. c-After extraordinary gains of $2,902 and $146,922 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gain of $130,000 from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Rejecting a Client
description: Before Griffin B. Bell was hired to defend Eugene Hasenfus, the American who was captured after a rebel supply plane was shot down in Nicaragua, Mr. Hasenfus's hometown lawyers had approached Walter F. Mondale for the job, ac-cording to Legal Times, a Washington lawyers newspaper.

title: GREEN ADVISERS DENY CHARGES BY REPUBLICANS
description: Advisers to Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, yesterday denied charges by the state Republican committee that Mr. Green might have violated Federal election and tax laws by using a tax-exempt organization to help his campaign.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR, IN A TIGHT RACE, EVEN HAS TO COURT 'YELLOW DOGS'
description: Gov. Mark White has chosen to spend three of his last campaign days here in deepest East Texas, land of loblolly pines, red clay dirt, staggering unemployment and people who, it used to be said, would rather vote for a yellow dog than a Republican.

title: ANGLICAN ENVOY RENEWS EFFORT ON BEIRUT HOSTAGES
description: A special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, Terry Waite, arrived here unexpectedly today in a fresh effort to secure the release of American hostages held by Moslem extremists.

title: COUPLE WINS $2.6 MILLION
description: A Camden County couple today claimed their New Jersey Pick-6 Lotto prize of $2.6 million. William and Vera Smith of Audobon park won the Pick-6 drawing Monday evening , and will receive the prize in annual installments over the next 20 years.

title: UNIVERSAL FURNITURE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $95,000 and $320,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $369,000.

title: Celtics Trounce Bullets in Opener
description: Larry Bird and Dennis Johnson scored 24 points each, and Kevin McHale and Robert Parish added 22 each tonight as the Boston Celtics routed the Washington Bullets, 120-102, in their season opener.

title: GIBSON GREETING CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,360,000.

title: Talks Are Held On Allied Sale
description: Top managements of both the Allied Stores Corporation and the Campeau Corporation met yesterday, along with their respective investment bankers, in an effort to resolve Campeau's seven-week old hostile bid for Allied. Sources close to the situation said last night that ''the entire range of options'' was discussed.

title: FARMERS' PRICES FELL IN OCTOBER
description: Prices farmers get for raw products averaged eight-tenths of 1 percent lower in October, dropping the monthly index to one of its lowest readings in eight years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Improving the World
description: The Better World Society, a Washington-based group founded last year by Ted Turner to use television to explore the issues of environment, population and nuclear arms control. is working with the British Broadcasting Corporation to produce a 12-part television series, ''Only One Earth.''

title: PENN MAY TEAM TWO STAR RUNNERS
description: Except for a handful of plays, the Dallas Cowboys have yet to put Tony Dorsett and Herschel Walker on the field at the same time because of a series of minor injuries to Dorsett.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MODERN TIMES The movie business mushroomed in the 1920's and 30's, and this is one reason that films of the period are being shown Sundays at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, near the northern end of Prospect Park (638-5000). They are special movies that reflect this growth and also tell about man and the machine.

title: NV Homes Set To Add Ryan
description: Ryan Homes Inc., the nation's third-largest home builder, said it has agreed to be acquired by NV Homes, for $48 a share, or $312 million, ending a monthlong takeover battle.

title: Ward Joins Yanks' Staff
description: The Yankees have completed the reorganization of their coaching staff by naming Jay Ward hitting instructor for next season.

title: UNICORP AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $11.4 million on the sale of an office building, a shopping center and an industrial property, and this gain was partially offset by an income tax provision of $5.9 million.

title: OPERA: 'ROSENKAVALIER'
description: In prospect, the Metropolitan Opera's first ''Rosenkavalier'' of the season on Thursday night aroused modest expectations. And, sorry to say, the evening lived up to its promise. It was difficult to imagine any opera administrator writing down this cast and thinking it would work well, let alone live up to this production's glorious tradition.

title: CLEVELAND QUARTET
description: The Cleveland Quartet and the pianist Emanuel Ax will present a program of works by Schumann and Bartok at the 92nd Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tonight at 8. Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. Information: 996-1100.

The quarter also includes income from discontinued operations of $28,936,000 for the quarter and $47,872,000 for the 9 months. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago 9 months, therefore no share earnings.

title: U.S. EMBASSY MEETS SOVIET REALITY
description: In quiet corners and subdued tones, American diplomats bade farewell today to Soviet workers who had stopped by the United States Embassy to pick up their personal belongings and penultimate paychecks.

title: CITY CRITICIZED FOR WAY IT SELECTS SHELTER GUARDS
description: Advocates for the homeless and security industry experts said yesterday that the city's policy of selecting the least costly private security companies to patrol its homeless shelters has resulted in the hiring of guards who are poorly educated, poorly trained, unstable or themselves homeless.

description: A member of Congress from California, citing documents she said were provided by an insider, said today that the Army had illegally used its reservists for construction projects in Honduras and Panama.

title: Eager to Set Pace
description: One runner who's not conceding first-place prize money of $25,000 to Rob de Castella in the men's division of tomorrow's New York City Marathon is Robleh Djama of Djibouti who, like the favored Australian, will be running in New York for the first time. ''If my legs do not fail me, I will not let him win,'' Djama said through an interpreter yesterday.

title: MANILA CHIEF OF STAFF SEEMS TO SIDE WITH DEFENSE MINISTER ON REBELS
description: The armed forces Chief of Staff said today that in the eight months since President Corazon C. Aquino took power, the Communist insurgency in the Philippines had grown larger, was better armed and might be capable of inflicting more serious economic and political damage to the country.

title: FEMINISTS' FILM LOOKS AT SEXIST ATTITUDES
description: There is a scene in ''Rate It X,'' a critically praised new documentary about the way men look at women, in which a baker is asked about one of the cakes he sells in his shop.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Soviet Nearly Shuts Out Mets
description: If the Kremlin really wants peace, why doesn't it broadcast the World Series scores?

title: Rail Service To Expand
description: Rail passenger service will be expanded along the eastern shoreline of Connecticut and possibly along the inland route between New Haven and Springfield, Mass., state officials said yesterday.

title: Soviet Said to Back Syria Against Britain
description: Syria said today that it had received a letter from the Soviet Union expressing firm support for Damascus after Britain's decision to break diplomatic relations with Syria.

title:
PATENTS;
Driverless Vehicle
description: A so-called intelligent driverless vehicle, patented this week for S.I. Handling Systems Inc. of Easton, Pa., is controlled by a computer. It is to carry a microcomputer that regulates its speed. Patent No. 4,620,280 was granted to Barry C. Conklin, a former employee.

title: BONN HAILS RATE TRIM BY TOKYO
description: West German finance officials today welcomed Japan's decision to cut its key discount rate, but added that they had no immediate intention of following suit.

title: Dow Drops a Fraction; Gain for Week Is 45.65
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday on Wall Street, as a cut in interest rates in Japan failed to help the market extend its recent rally.

title: ECONOMIC GAINS SPUR THE DOLLAR
description: The dollar moved sharply higher in foreign exchange markets yesterday, lifted by reports indicating a strengthening United States economy and by Japan's decision to cut its discount rate. Trading volume, which had been high all week, remained strong.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHIRLWIND. By James Clavell. 1147 pages. William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: TRANSACTIONSMETS (NL) - Sent Tom McCarthy, pitcher, outright to Tidewater of the International League. Added the following players to the 40-man winter roster: Reggie Dobie and Dave West, pitchers; Terry Blocker, Mark Carreon and Marcus Lawton, outfielders, and Zoilo Sanchez, third baseman.ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Jack Clark, first baseman, to a one-year contract.  FOOTBALL   SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived Jim Stuckey, defensive end. Signed Dana McLemore, cornerback.  HOCKEY  RANGERS (NHL) - Reassigned Dave Gagner and Chris Jensen, forwards, to New Haven of the American Hockey League.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $353,521,000. c-Net income

title: LEONARD ROSE BENEFIT
description: Leonard Rose, who died in 1984, was not only a distinguished cellist but also one of the most influential music teachers of his time. He taught cello at the Juilliard School of Music from 1947 until his death and at the Curtis Institute from 1952 to 1962. At one point, four of the cellists in the Philadelphia Orchestra, five in the New York Philharmonic, six in the Cleveland Orchestra and seven in the Boston Symphony Orchestra had been proteges of Mr. Rose. Indeed, the conductor Erich Leinsdorf used to refer to the Boston cellists as the ''Rose section.''

title: Nurses Are a Precious New York City Resource
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDEN VALLEY MICROWAVE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company said results for the 1985 quarter and 9 months include extraordinary gains of 4 cents a share and 8 cents a share, respectively.

title: Loan Shoppers: Kick The Tires
description: WHEN seeking a loan for an automobile, appliance or other large purchase, most people apply to a bank or a consumer finance company. Lately, the finance companies - also known as personal finance or small-loan companies - have been making an aggressive bid for more of the market by trying to convince the public that their interest rates are comparable to those of many banks and that their service is faster and more convenient.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. He is Lee M. Thomas.

title:
PATENTS;
Stimulating Immune System
description: THE National Foundation for Cancer Research in Bethesda, Md., holds rights to patents that were granted this week for inventions by two Nobel laureates and two other scientists who serve as project directors for the foundation.

title: U.S. STARTS INQUIRY ON A KEY FILIPINO
description: The Justice Department is investigating real estate transactions involving the Philippine Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, and his wife, Christina, Federal officials said today.

title: POLICE TRANSFER 27 SUPERVISORS AMID INQUIRY AT 77TH PRECINCT
description: The Police Department's response to allegations of corruption in the 77th Precinct reached the highest level of the uniformed forces in Brooklyn yesterday with the transfer of four senior commanders in the borough.

title: Louis XVI Secretary Is Sold for $2 Million
description: A Louis XVI secretary - lavishly embellished with gilded bronze mounts and porcelain plaques and signed by Martin Carlin, a master cabinetmaker - was sold at Sotheby's yesterday for $2,090,000. It was the highest price paid at auction in New York for a piece of furniture.

title: STRUTHERS WELLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $18,078 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: NEW CENTURY BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAGE: 'TRANSPOSED HEADS'
description: The novella, ''The Transposed Heads,'' is Thomas Mann's philosophical version of an Indian legend about the conflict between mind and body. In a twinned paroxysm, two friends, the intellectual Shridaman and the earthy Nanda, behead themselves. Magically, their severed heads are restored - but to the wrong body, and Shridaman's wife, Sita, is unable to decide which combination represents her real husband. The story is further complicated by the fact that Sita happens to be in love with both men.

title: Greyhound Pact Extended
description: Negotiators, hoping to avoid a repetition of the bitter 47-day strike by Greyhound bus drivers and mechanics in 1983, agreed today to extend the current contract seven days past midnight, when it was to have expired. The company said that at the end of the extension, either party could end the agreement with 72 hours notice. The Amalgamated Transit Union, which represents 7,500 Greyhound employees, including bus drivers and mechanics, is seeking a new three-year contract.

title: JEFFERSON NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Judge Orders Bonanno Freed
description: Joseph Bonanno, who refused to answer questions last year about a Mafia ''commission,'' was ordered released from prison yesterday.

title: CHICAGO BLUES
description: Two Chicago blues guitarists, Hubert Sumlin and Little Johnny Littlejohn, will lead a band tonight at the Abilene Cafe, 359 Second Avenue, at 21st Street (473-8908). Shows are around 9:30 P.M. and midnight, with John Campbell opening. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Heptagonal Run To Midshipman
description: Ron Harris of Navy, who finished 36th last year, won the 49th Heptagonal Games Association cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Lowering Milk Prices In the City
description: THE price of a gallon of milk dropped 40 cents to around $1.90 on Staten Island when the New York State government allowed a New Jersey dairy to sell its milk there last January. A price survey earlier this month by the city's Consumer Affairs Department showed that a gallon of milk was still cheaper on Staten Island than in the rest of the city, by 29 cents on average.

title: It's Not Promiscuity That Causes AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: NETS, IN OPENER, DEFEAT KNICKS
description: How would Dwayne (Pearl) Washington perform as a playmaker in his first National Basketball Association game? Could Albert King, a small forward throughout his pro career, play the big guard position? Would the smaller Nets be able to rebound against the Knicks' 7-foot tandem of Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright?

title: FRAUD INDICTMENTS HIT CHILD-ABUSE PROGRAM
description: Three officials of an upstate child-abuse program - financed almost entirely by the state at the behest of two legislators - have been indicted on charges that they defrauded it of tens of thousands of dollars.

title: INTERMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAKE SUNAPEE SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in May.

title: ALOIS FABRY, ARTIST AND AUTHOR
description: Alois Fabry, an artist, a teacher and an author, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Chestnut Hill, Mass. He was 74 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: NEW LONDON WATCHDOG
description: The British Parliament today approved complex legislation designed to safeguard investors in London's remodeled financial markets. The Financial Services Bill creates a central watchdog agency, the Securities and Investments Board, to authorize, monitor and set standards for government-recognized self-regulatory organizations. Both financial professionals and lay people will serve on the nonstatutory body.

title: AETNA EARNINGS CLIMB
description: Aetna Life and Casualty Company today said that third-quarter earnings more than doubled to $265 million, or $2.31 a share, compared with $109 million, or 97 cents a share, in the comparable 1985 period.

title: Jury Finds Teen-Ager Guilty Of '85 Murder of His Mother
description: A jury in Erie County Court tonight found 18-year-old John D. Justice Jr. guilty of two counts of second degree murder in the deaths of his mother and a neighbor, the authorities said.

title: Campaigners for House Seats Stress Local Concerns and Efficient Service
description: The campaign for the 435 seats in the House of Representatives that ends on Tuesday has typically found candidates stressing local concerns, not national ones, and promising to deliver Federal dollars and more efficient services to their home districts.

title: 2 Guilty in Rabbi's Slaying
description: Two men were convicted yesterday of second-degree murder in the slaying of a retired rabbi, Joshua Rubin, during a burglary at his home in Fresh Meadows, Queens, last year. The defendants, Victor Poywing, 34 years old, and Robert Biggerstaff, 32, both of Queens, are to be sentenced Nov. 24.

title: 3 West Coast Papers Try to Avoid a Strike
description: Union and management representatives negotiated past a strike deadline today to try to avert a walkout at San Francisco's two major daily newspapers and The San Jose Mercury News.

title: UNION CARBIDE TO CLEAN UP URANIUM SITE IN WEST
description: The State of Colorado and the Union Carbide Corporation agreed today on a $40 million plan to clean up the site that produced uranium for the first atomic bomb.

title: JAPANESE AGREE TO CUTS ON ALUMINIM TARIFFS
description: After years of resistance, Japan has agreed to make deep cuts in aluminum tariffs, which are expected to lead to more business for American exporters, Clayton Yeutter, the United States trade representative, announced today.

title: Jean Harris Rejects Money
description: Jean Harris has formally renounced her claim to $220,000 left to her by Dr. Herman Tarnower, the former lover she shot to death in 1980, court papers showed.

title: FIRST BANCSHARES OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
How 'Star Wars' Is, and Isn't, Like an Ack-Ack Gun; ABM Treaty Language
description: To the Editor:

title: SLOW COMEBACK FOR 22-ACRE SITE OF PASSAIC FIRE
description: More than a year after a fire destroyed an industrial complex here, little work has been done to rebuild the 22-acre rubble-strewn site.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS WINS CONTRACT FOR JET FIGHTER
description: The Air Force, deciding a long and bitter battle between the Northrop Corporation and the General Dynamics Corporation, chose today to buy the General Dynamics F-16 fighter plane in a deal that will be worth billions of dollars.

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss

title: Higher Tax Tab For Expenses
description: When employees and executives begin work next year, the Federal Government will no longer be picking up as much of the tab for wining and dining clients or for employee business expenses, such as work uniforms, office supplies, professional publications and association dues.

title: Mexico Bank Deadline Passes
description: Mexico's creditor banks yesterday failed to meet an initial deadline to subscribe to a $6 billion loan.

title: Police Officers Placed At Indian Headquarters
description: A group of Kiowa Indians who have taken over their tribal headquarters greeted Federal police officers today as they were stationed outside the building.

title: U.S. Arms Proposal Restated by Reagan
description: President Reagan, adding to confusion over the summit talks in Iceland, said today that his proposal to Moscow remained the elimination of ''all offensive nuclear weapons'' if the superpowers come to terms on his missile defense plan, popularly known as Star Wars.

title: U.S. SUBPOENAS DEFENSE LAWYER AND HIS CLIENT
description: Federal prosecutors issued subpoenas yesterday to Marvin B. Kaplan, one of the defendants in the trial stemming from New York City's corruption scandal, and his attorney, seeking tapes of conversations they may have had with a Government witness.

title: It's Time the Soviet Union Let Vladimir Slepak Go
description: How often have you heard the name Vladimir Slepak?

description: Prices of most Government coupon securities eased yesterday, while the discount rates on Treasury bills were largely unchanged.

HBO INCREASING PRODUCTION OF ITS OWN CABLE TV FILMS
description: Officials at Home Box Office, the nation's largest pay cable service, say they are increasing HBO's original programming by offering television movies made exclusively for the cable network.

title:
N.B.A.;
Big Men Take N.B.A. to New Heights
description: Red Holzman tells the story about the time he was playing for the Rochester Royals and, in an experimental game, the baskets were raised from the standard 10 feet to 12 feet.

title: Two Bombs Explode in Paris; Leftists Take Responsibility
description: Two bombs exploded early today in Paris, causing damage but no injuries, the Interior Ministry said.

title: PUBLISHER IS CITED AS UNREGISTERED AGENT
description: A conservative Michigan newspaper publisher was charged today with acting as an unregistered foreign agent for South Africa since 1974.

title: PROGRESSIVE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $186,000 on securities sales for the latest quarter and for the 9 months includes a capital gain of $8,545,000. c-Includes a capital gain of $3,093,000 and a charge of $241,000 from a capital loss carryforward for the quarter and for the 9 months includes a capital gain of $5,082,000 and an extraordinary credit from a capital loss carryforward. Share earnings are adjusted for a 9-for-4 stock split in May.

title: FOR A 49th ST. RESIDENT, HOME HAS JAZZ AGE FEEL
description: The conversation took place across an East Side piano bar in the wee hours of a May morning eight years ago.

title: A Coach's Season of Change
description: Bob Wade sat in his office at Dunbar High School, sighed, then took the 10th phone call of a workday that was a mere 15 minutes old. The previous two days had been among the most hectic of his 15-year coaching career, and yesterday, from all indications, would be no different.

title: Bid for Utility In Indiana Seen
description: The First City Financial Corporation, controlled by the Belzberg family of Vancouver, made an offer to acquire the Public Service Company of Indiana, according to a report in the Indianapolis Star.

title: A Proposition for New Yorkers
description: On Nov. 4, New Yorkers will have a rare opportunity to improve their quality of life. If approved by voters, the Environmental Quality Bond Act (Proposition One on the statewide ballot) will authorize $1.45 billion for hazardous-waste cleanup, land conservation and historic preservation throughout the state. It is the most important environmental vote in New York in more than a decade.

title: Suzanne Farrell Retiring After Winter Season
description: Suzanne Farrell, principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has announced that she will retire from dancing in February 1987, at the end of the coming winter season. Ms. Farrell's decision was prompted by a recurrent hip injury, although she expects to perform this winter.

title: FPL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

PATENTS;
A System to Sharpen Color TV Picture
description: A color image display system that was patented this week for the RCA Corporation is already used in most of the company's television receivers.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. At a Cabinet meeting, President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines offered the vacant seat of Vice President Salvador H. Laurel to Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile, who declined. Mr. Laurel proposed a nationwide vote of confidence in the Government; Mr. Enrile questioned the Government's legitimacy under a proposed new constitution. 2. Utah. 3.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS UNIT'S STAFF CHIEF RESIGNS AND FAULTS CONGRESS
description: The staff director of the United States Civil Rights Commission, J. Al Latham Jr., resigned today, complaining that Congressional action had crippled the agency.

title: FIREFIGHTER IS CLEARED IN ARSON
description: Arson charges filed against a New York City firefighter were dismissed today when a judged ruled that the prosecution lacked evidence and was relying solely on suspicion for its case.

title: OGILVY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents commission and fee income.

title: Lear Siegler Stock Up $4.75
description: The shares of Lear Siegler Inc. rose $4.75, to $85.75 today, in the wake of an $85-a-share offer for the aerospace, automotive and industrial concern.

title: MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Erving Says He'll Retire
description: Julius Erving, who has dazzled fans and confounded opponents with his leaping, acrobatic style, announced tonight that he is playing his final season of pro basketball.

title: Penury Gets You Nowhere
description: We drove all day to New England. Desperate for rest, we came in the gray New England night to Hyannis, a vast conurbation of motels occupying what once was Cape Cod.

title: Applauding the Audience
description: When Michael Feinstein, the pianist and cabaret singer who got rave reviews in his New York debut at the Algonquin last January, was invited to appear at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Washington, he hesitated.

title: EL DIARIO IS SUPPORTING REGAN OVER BADILLO IN STATE CONTEST
description: For the first time in his career, Herman Badillo, the Democratic candidate for State Comptroller, failed to win the endorsement of El Diario-La Prensa, New York City's largest Spanish-language daily.

title: RISE BEGAN IN TOKYO
description: In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to 161.45 yen, from 159.90 yen at Thursday's close.

title: 'Yes' on Environmental Bonds
description: At least 500 solid-waste dumps in New York State are so toxic that they constitute a serious danger to soil and ground water. Yet the state and Federal funds now available under existing programs would clean up only about half of them.

title: BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $5.3 million for the quarter and income of $1.3 million from discontinued operations for the 9 months. The company said the loss in the latest quarter includes after-tax charges of $150 million for additions to reserves for reinsurance losses and $10.4 million for certain reinsurance accruals.

title: SJW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Three From New York Area Stand Tall in Stature and Skill
description: Players from the New York metropolitan area have long stood tall on the national scene, physically as well as figuratively.

PATENTS;
A Device for Haircuts
description: A device called Cut & Style, intended for fashionable haircutting, was patented this week by Ludmila Yampolskaya of New York, a designer.

title: NANCY REAGAN URGES TV ROLES THAT REJECT DRUGS
description: Flanked by the heads of nearly every Hollywood studio and major television production company, Nancy Reagan asked them today to create characters ''who firmly reject drugs in any form'' and not to collaborate ''in the illusion that drugs are fun.''

title: POLITICS INTRUDE ON STREET NAME HEARING
description: It was to be a routine session of a City Council committee about renaming streets. But the names included David Ben-Gurion, Gamal Abdel Nasser and Yasir Arafat, and decorum quickly degenerated into anger and outrage.

title: SURROGATE CASE DELAYED
description: The presiding judge today delayed for 10 days the trial over custody of a child born under contract to a surrogate mother. Judge Harvey R. Sorkow of Superior Court postponed the trial, which was to start Monday, until Nov. 13 to give lawyers more time to prepare. The lawsuit was filed by MaryBeth Whiltehead, 29 years old, of Brick Township, who had agreed to accept $10,000 to bear the child for William and Elizabeth Stern of Tenafly, both 40.

title: CITY SAVINGS BANK OF MERIEN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public on Sept. 4, 1986.

title: American Express
description: The American Express Company said that a subsidiary had signed an agreement to sell the stock of the Fireman's Fund Employers Insurance Company of Green Bay, Wis., to the Lincoln National Corporation for $215 million.

description: b-After extraordinary gains for the quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain.

description: A solar cooking device with the trademark of SunCooker was patented this week by Alvin M. Marks, president of Advanced Research Development Inc., in Athol, Mass.
