INSIDE
description: Local Focus in House Races Local issues, not national ones, are typically the focus of this year's races for the 435 seats in the House of Representatives.

title: Five Citadel Cadets Confined To Campus for Hazing Black
description: The Citadel military college said Friday that five white cadets would be confined to the campus for the rest of the school year and must perform about 10 hours a week of extra marching as punishment for hazing a black freshman.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $190,000 for the quarter and $303,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $104,000 for the quarter and $160,000 for the 9 months.

title: Made in America: Even Foie Gras
description: Ten years ago the only kind of goat cheese available in this country came from abroad, usually France. Today every region of the country, from New York to California, from Tennessee to Texas, has its own local supply.

title: ON 7TH AVE., LIVELY OPENINGS
description: Extravagantly bouffant skirts had hardly disappeared from the runways in Europe when they began their whirl on Seventh Avenue. Not only big circles over layers of petticoats, but simpler skirts rippling with a few tiers or a flounce at the hemline are adding zest to the New York spring fashion openings that started this week.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday listing stocks with the biggest percentage declines among New York Stock Exchange issues carried incorrect data supplied by the Pacific Stock Exchange for Allied Supermarkets Inc. Allied's stock closed at $7.75 a share, unchanged. The price was also incorrect in the stock listings.

title: UNITED VERMONT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Checking the Record
description: Democratic aides on the Senate Judiciary Committee checked their files the other day after President Reagan, in a campaign speech in Alabama, asserted, ''Over and over, the Democratic leadership has tried in the Senate to torpedo our choice of judges.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Boyd Charges Dropped
description: City attorneys in Chelsea, Mass., have dropped charges of assault and battery and disorderly conduct that were filed last July 16 by city detectives against Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Boston Red Sox.

title: Singapore's Side of Press-Freedom Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ, IN 2 TALKS, LINKS ARMS PACT TO HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned the Soviet Union today that what he called its continuing human-rights abuses ''can only jeopardize'' the chances of achieving arms control and other agreements with the United States.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $247,000.

title: Devils' Success Spurred by No. 1 Line
description: The Devils are off to the best start in the 13-year history of the franchise, and their success is underlined by the performance of their main line: Kirk Muller as center for Aaron Broten on the left and Pat Verbeek on the right.

title: TAUNTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings for the latest 9 months and the year-ago periods were not given because the bank went public in June 1986.

title: Feeding Fat Farmers
description: Back in 1981, President Reagan's first budget bravely proposed ending the $4 billion in annual farm subsidies that David Stockman, the Budget Director, reviled as ''organized larceny.'' Five years later, those subsidies are up to $30 billion and the Administration is still stumbling from plan to plan in an effort to appease wrathful farmers.

title: NATIONAL HEALTH CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $354,000 on the sale of a health center and $400,000 in costs associated with the financing of debt and the closing of a wholesale food operation. c-Includes a gain of $1.2 million on the exchange of stock.

title: Services for Sherman Adams Prompt Warm Recollections
description: Sherman Adams, a onetime logger and former Governor who became known as the ''assistant President'' in Dwight D. Eisenhower's White House, was remembered by friends, family and politicians at funeral services Friday.

title: Japan Discount Rate Cut to a Low of 3%
description: The Bank of Japan officially announced today, as expected, that it was cutting its discount rate to a low of 3 percent in the hope of stimulating economic growth.

title: Championing the Music of Today
description: Before Speculum Musicae, before the New Music Consort, before Parnassus, before the New York New Music Ensemble, there was the Group for Contemporary Music. Founded by the composers Charles Wuorinen and Harvey Sollberger while they were both graduate students at Columbia University, the Group for Contemporary Music - or GCM, as it is customarily abbreviated - will begin its 25th-anniversary season Tuesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall with a program of music by Mr. Wuorinen, Mr. Sollberger, Wayne Peterson, Silvestre Revueltas and Morton Gould.

title: CHICAGO VOTE PLAN UPSET
description: The Illinois Supreme Court has ruled that a proposed referendum to make Chicago's mayoral election nonpartisan is too ambiguous to be constitutionally valid.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: HOLLYWOOD HUSBANDS. By Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Before rushing to sex therapists to find out what's wrong with them, readers of ''Hollywood Husbands'' should bear in mind that it's a work of fiction and few people in real life possess the insatiable copulative urge Jackie Collins's characters display.

title: Catering to Midtown Office Needs
description: STUDENTS of the city's office market have rarely been content to divide Manhattan merely into the two commercial districts of midtown and downtown. They see submarkets within each, especially in the midtown area.

title: THE WAR AGAINST INDIVIDUALISM
description: THE MORNING AFTER American Successes and Excesses 1981-1986. By George F. Will. 430 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: From Policeman To Scofflaw
description: HOURS after 41-year-old Ralph Poulson retired from the New York City Police in February on a $24,000 disability pension, city officials appeared embarrassed.

title: Nicaragua's U.N. Voice
description: I would like to thank Elaine Sciolino for reminding us that women can bring their unique style, as well as strength and competence to the arena of national and international politics.

title: HUSSEIN PLAN IN WEST BANK LACKS MONEY
description: The centerpiece of King Hussein's new strategy for the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, a five-year development plan costing $150 million to $240 million a year, has a major flaw: it has no money.

title: Tunis Jails 14 in Illicit Party
description: Fourteen members of an opposition party, including its leader, were jailed for six months today, on the eve of Tunisia's general election, for belonging to an illegal organization. The 14 are members of the Socialist Progressive Assembly, which until now had been tolerated by the authorities without being officially recognized.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes: Photos and 'White Suit'
description: Phil Collins: No Jacket Required EP Stereo hi-fi Atlantic Video 28 minutes. $19.98

title: Martha Taylor Is Wed To Joseph D'Ambrosio
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y., yesterday Martha Wenzel Taylor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Taylor Jr. of Bronxville and Lyme, Conn., was married to Joseph J. D'Ambrosio Jr., the son of Mrs. D'Ambrosio of Brooklyn and the late Mr. D'Ambrosio. The Rev. J. Timothy Collins performed the ceremony Susan Axelrod was the maid of honor.

title: CONCERT: MUTI CONDUCTS STRAUSS'S 'AUS ITALIEN'
description: THERE is something about the light of Italy that evokes the awe and envy of German tourists from the north. Richard Strauss as a young man was one of them and, indeed, his ''Aus Italien,'' which Riccardo Muti and the Philadelphia Orchestra played at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, seems less a description of a place than a response to it -a series of elaborate postcards in the hand of a young man deeply touched. Looking at these colorful missives, the average Italian would recognize the pictures but find the sentiments written on the back quite foreign.

title: Gang Said to Aid Libyan Terrorism
description: El Rukns, a force to be feared in Chicago since the 1960's, has broadened its horizons, according to law-enforcement officials. Four members of the street gang have been charged with conspiring to engage in terrorism in the United States on behalf of the Libyan Government.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cincinnati;
Course Change For a Developer
description: PHILIP R. ADELMAN moved here from Canton, Ohio, in 1973 partly because he wanted to help renovate dilapidated row houses in struggling inner-city neighborhoods.

title: Recent Sales
description: Recent Sales Amityville $260,000 223 Ocean Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 90-year-old colonial; finished basement, den, 4 fireplaces, deck; taxes $4,600. Freeport $147,000 118 Harrison Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 82-year-old two-family colonial; wrap-around porch, attic; taxes $2,600.

title: Ex-Saudi Oil Minister Says 'Everything Is Fine'
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, ousted this week as Saudi Oil Minister after a quarter-century in that post, said today that ''everything is just fine'' and that he was reflecting on his future.

title: Nicaragua's U.N. Voice
description: In her article ''Nicaragua's U.N. Voice'' (Sept. 28), Elaine Sciolino seemed more interested in making a case against ''Sandinista rhetoric'' than in examining United States-Nicaragua relations. If Nora Astorga seems more interested in selling her country or its revolution, that is no more than the work that many diplomats do.

title: 'Hi, Voter. This Is Your President'
description: LESS than 20 miles from his birthplace, near a computer in Schaumburg, Ill., Ronald Reagan - or more accurately, his voice - lies waiting.

title: PLENTY OF FRENCH ARE ALSO JEWISH
description: Apropos Betty Krasne's ''Reflections at Rosh ha-Shanah'' (Westchester Opinion, Oct. 5), I would like to answer Betty's quest as to whether one can be both French and Jewish.

title: STEPHANIE AND JENNIFER DECRANE PLAN TO BE MARRIED IN FEBRUARY AND MAY
description: Stephanie Ann DeCrane plans to marry Paul Kevin Cavanor in February and her younger sister, Jennifer Ann DeCrane, is to marry Francis Page Johns Langford in May. The engagements were announced by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Public Reaction to a Terrorist
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Charged in L.I. Hit-Run
description: A Hempstead man was arrested today in a hit-and-run accident Thursday in which a 70-year-old man in a wheelchair was killed, the police said. The suspect, Rene Selaya, 21 years old, was charged in the death of John Betts of Hemstead, who the police said was being pushed across Henry Street at 5:45 P.M. when he was struck by a car that dragged him 50 feet and sped off.

title: Baseball Notebook; Warning to Conquering Mets: Uneasy Lies the Crown
description: THE Mets should eat, drink and be merry this winter because, based on recent history, once the next pennant race begins, they will die. On the other hand, maybe they will be the team to find the solution to the repeater syndrome. They better work quickly, though, because the syndrome has become an epidemic.

title: 'WE WILL MAKE YOU AN INVALID'
description: ALONE TOGETHER By Elena Bonner. Translated by Alexander Cook. Illustrated. 270 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: A SHORT, BUT THRILLING, TURNPIKE TOUR
description: HI THERE, and welcome to the New Jersey Turnpike tour. My name is John, and I'm your guide for the next half-hour. We are now at the northern end of our famous toll road and we'll be heading south.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: JAZZ IN NEW JERSEY McCoy Tyner and his trio will kick off the opening of the Jazz Series today at 2 P.M. in the Maurice Levin Theater of the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey, 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange.

title: NOBEL OR NOT, SELF-INTEREST ISN'T ALL THERE IS
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.A. CONSIDERING A NEW STRATEGY
description: Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, is debating whether to end its 64-year-old policy of boycotting the Irish Republic's Parliament in the hope that it can win enough seats to become a bargaining force.

title: WOMEN'S GAINS IN LOCAL POLITICS FOUND TO BE SLOW
description: ALTHOUGH the number of women holding elective municipal offices in New Jersey has more than doubled in the last decade, women must still be considered the new politicians on the block.

title: PHILANTHROPIES STARTING DRIVE FOR 5% TITHING
description: The country's largest philanthropic coalition wants to adopt the ancient practice of tithing in an effort to double private charitable giving by 1991.

title: Miami Rallies To Go 8-0
description: In the five seasons he has traveled from the status of a substitute quarterback to an apparent landslide winner of the Heisman Trophy, Vinny Testaverde has had to deal with the complexity of major-college football and the anguish of being forgotten. Only recently has he been confronted with the obstacle of pain.

title: A TURNAROUND IN TOYLAND?
description: THIS Thursday, with Mayor Koch cutting the ribbon, F.A.O. Schwarz will move its Manhattan flagship store to the General Motors building, 93 feet away from the famous toy emporium that has been its home for 54 years. The auto showroom where G.M. once parked its finest has been transformed, at a cost of $6 million, into a home for talking bears, dinosaurs, Inhumanoids - and even a fleet of miniature Mercedes and Lamborghinis. It is a spectacular showcase intended to make even nostalgic long-time customers put aside their preference for the antique charms of the old store.

title: WHERE THE IVY LEAGUE FIGHTS ON
description: You don't have to be a football fan to appreciate a stadium. If a society reveals itself through its literature or its music, it also does it through its edifices. Today, there are few things that attest more to the place that sports has attained in our culture than the colossal football stadiums that dot the landscape from coast to coast. Often, they have become central to their communities or schools - sources of pride, as well as enormous revenue.

title: NOT A DETERRENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Verbatim; Bigotry, 1818
description: 'your sect by it's sufferings has furnished a remarkable proof of the universal spirit of religious intolerance, inherent in every sect, disclaimed by all while feeble, and practised by all when in power. our laws have applied the only antidote to this vice, protecting our religious as they do our civil rights by putting all on an equal footing. but more remains to be done.'

title: RECLUSIVE MRS. NHU IS FILLED WITH BITTERNESS TOWARD U.S.
description: Mrs. Ngo Dinh Nhu is probably best remembered for her sleek silk dresses and the fearsome way she wielded power in a city then called Saigon nearly a quarter of a century ago.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS WIEGHING IMPACT OF NEW U.S. LAW
description: In Chinese and in Spanish, in Korean and in Hindi, from the Lower East Side of Manhattan to Corona in Queens, the estimated 750,000 to 1 million illegal aliens in New York City are asking how life will change for them and their families under the nation's sweeping new immigration law.

title: 17 DIE IN ACCIDENT AT BULGARIAN PLANT MAKING CHEMICALS
description: An accident today at a chemical plant in Bulgaria killed 17 people and sent 19 to the hospital for ''urgent medical attention,'' the Government-run Radio Sofia reported.

title: N.F.L. Players Win Drug Test Ruling
description: If Commissioner Pete Rozelle wants National Football League players to undergo unscheduled drug tests, an arbitrator held last week, he will have to talk to their union.

title: Two Cultures United
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
FOR THE VARIED VIRTUES OF SPRING BULBS
description: ALTHOUGH they are not exceptionally demanding, spring bulbs depend the right planting techniques and conditions. The site is most important. Such earlier-flowering sorts as snowdrops and crocus will do well beneath deciduous trees and shrubs, because they mature before the leaves reappear in the spring.

title: New Giant Learns Through Mistakes
description: In last April's National Football League draft, the Giants chose six defensive players in the first three rounds. Of the six, only Mark Collins is starting, which should please him. But if he is pleased by that, he is pleased by little else.

title: MANILA'S TROJAN HORSEMAN
description: When Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile led the military revolt that ousted President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, there was euphoria and hosannas. Little thought was given to the implications, to what might have been sown.

title: HELPING 'TOUGH KIDS' TURN AROUND
description: IN the backyard of the William Paca Junior High School in Mastic Beach are four portable classrooms connected to one another, but not to the main school. The shrill bells that begin and end each 40-minute period sound muted in these rooms.

title: Is Opera Incompatible With Serious Argument?
description: The other day in this space I brought up the question of political operas and wondered why so few examples of the genre have managed to lodge themselves in the repertory. By political operas, I made clear, I did not mean works based on historical or legendary events, such as Wagner's ''Ring,'' Verdi's ''Nabucco,'' Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' or Monteverdi's ''Coronation of Poppea.'' Agreed, the composers of those operas may well have hoped that their audiences would see certain political parallels to their own times. That is one of the timeless strengths of such powerfully allusive works: they do not preach but influence our thinking and feeling by art's indirection.

title: JUNKED CARS LITTER TOWNS
description: THE state's roadsides and woods are becoming increasingly cluttered with the rusting remains of abandoned cars, and local officials say there is no solution in sight.

title: Writing to Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: Kiowas End Protest As Vote Is Canceled
description: A dissident group of Kiowa Indians who had taken over tribal headquarters for two days vacated it today after an election opposed by the faction was canceled, Federal and tribal officials said.

title: 12% OF STORES INSPECTED EVADED TAX, STUDY SAYS
description: In the first widespread store-to-store search for sales tax evaders, state investigators say they uncovered cheating by about 12 percent of retail businesses inspected in midtown Manhattan and four upstate cities.

title: The Competition For a Sharper Image Comes up Against Realistic Limits
description: The notion of progress makes us sstand up and cheer. Progress is, after all, an article of modern faith, born in France about 200 years ago during the Age of Enlightenment. Before that, odd as it may seem, the idea of progress did not exist as a common concept, and things were expected to stay pretty much the same.

title: DISCLOSURE AMID CONTROVERSY
description: A certain course on Egyptian culture is unavailable at the University of South Carolina this fall, not because of its content but because of questions about its cost. Jehan el-Sadat, the 52-year-old widow of Anwar el-Sadat, the slain Egyptian President, decided earlier this year not to return to the school because of controversy over her salary, which rose from $50,000 for the spring semester of 1985 to $75,000 each for the fall of 1985 and spring of 1986.

title: Jets Aim to Duplicate First-Half Success
description: One game at a time? That's coaching talk. But for Jet fans, gleeful at the prospect of a playoff year - and a long one, at that - a look at the second half of the schedule is irresistible.

title: Future King's English
description: There's His Royal Highness faced with the problem of making a speech on erstwhile Empire soil - something that sounds princely but not patronizing, amusing but not facetious, informative but not pedantic (''Hail to the C.E.O,'' by William Safire, On Language, Sept. 28). For a bit of local color, he researches the American scene - catches up on television, glances at a few magazines for the current expressions.

title: Beware the Short Term
description: Exerpts from the revised and expanded edition of ''The Dilemma of Reform in the Soviet Union,'' by Timothy J. Colton, published by the Council on Foreign Relations this year:

title: AUTHOR LOOKS BEYOND A FENCE
description: DAVID LEAVITT, the 25-year-old author of the controversial new novel ''The Lost Language of Cranes,'' in which a son reveals his homosexuality to his parents, lives in East Hampton behind a white picket fence.

title: Writing Letters to Those Who Care
description: TO a voter, the computer is a machine. To a computer, the voter is a collection of numerical coefficients, calculated through a series of algorithms, revealing a pattern of daily behavior that reflects actions likely to be taken while inside a booth in the first week of November.

title: Deng Meets Italian Leader
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy today discussed the Iceland summit meeting and China's new domestic policies with the Chinese leader,eneng Xipiping, andMHu obobang, theeaead of theomommunt t Party. M C Craxi, a a news conference, said he and the Chinese leaders agreed achievements were made at the meeting in Iceland, which he said the Chinese described as ''dialogue and confrontation at the same time.''

title: COMMUTERS CHANGE PATTERN OF SETTLEMENTS IN WEST BANK
description: The movement to set up Jewish settlements on the occupied West Bank has undergone a radical change.

title: COLLEGES OFFERING HUNAGARIAN COURSES
description: SINCE Oct. 23, Hungarians around New Jersey have been holding bittersweet celebrations marking the 30th anniversary of the Hungarian Revolution, when for 12 days that country briefly knew democracy before the Russians brought their tanks into Budapest on Nov. 4, 1956.

title: PARIS TRIES CONCILIATION AND EXPULSION
description: TEN days ago, the French Government disclosed that since the passage of an emergency anti-terrorist law in September it had clandestinely deported some 1,700 illegal aliens.

title: MORE FACTS, PLEASE, ON GROUP HOMES
description: The publication of the essay ''Welcome Home, Jenny'' [ Opinion page, Oct. 12 ] was personally very timely. Several days before, the house next to mine was sold to the State of Connecticut for use as a group residence for the mentally retarded. The actual sale, coupled with the article, has left me with many unanswered questions that need to be documented before I can just accept the humane and socially conscious attitude that Janice M. Gruendel solicits in her article.

title: BOUNCING ACROSS AMERICA
description: The plan was to pick up the Morgan in San Francisco, where it's imported from the factory in England, and drive it back home to Brooklyn.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Seattle; A New Look For the Harbor
description: THE Port of Seattle has proposed a monumental facelift designed to help restore the long-neglected harbor in this trade-dependent city.

title: Candidates for Senator on Key Issues
description: Here are the views, based on interviews, campaign statements and position papers, of the major party candidates for United States Senate in Connecticut's election Tuesday. CHRISTOPHER J. DODD 42-year-old Democrat running for re-election to a second term. LEADERSHIP ROLE

title: The S.R.O. Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: First Black Federal Judge In Virginia Takes Office
description: James Spencer, sworn in Friday as Virginia's first black Federal judge, told well-wishers he hoped to ''contribute something of value to the flow of human events.''

title: REAGAN URGES CALIFORNIANS TO PROTECT GAINS OF G.O.P.
description: President Reagan today sought to generate a high Republican voter turnout on Tuesday, appealing to conservative supporters to protect the party's political gains.

title: INDIA FIGHTING SALES OF UNION CARBIDE ASSETS
description: The Indian Government is urging a district court in Bhopal to restrain the Union Carbide Corporation from selling any more of its assets, saying such sales could reduce any eventual settlement for victims of the 1984 gas tragedy.

title: Hiring Teen-Ager As Police Chief
description: EIGHT men had failed to stay on as police chief in less than four years in the tiny municipality of Laurel Hill, Fla., when the City Council tried a new approach in March. It hired a 19-year-old college student to run the one-officer department.

title: Cynthia Kaplan Is Married
description: Cynthia Gail Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kaplan of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married last night to Stephen Patton Rooney, a son of Mrs. William T. Rooney Jr. of Garden City, Kan., and the late Mr. Rooney. Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in New York. Mrs. Kaplan-Rooney, who will keep her maiden name professionally, is a freelance film editor. Mr. Rooney is a member of the New York architectural firm of Stephen B. Jacobs & Associates.

title: For One Complainant, 'Nothing Has Changed'
description: VERY few buyers who have been rejected by a cooperative's board of directors challenge the decision. Edward Mapp, a black professor in the City University system, was one of the 14 people who complained last year to the city's Commission on Human Rights.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: MCMAHON! By Jim McMahon with Bob Verdi. (Warner, $16.95.) The Chicago Bears' quarterback Jim McMahon says it took equal doses of craziness, beer and being ''deranged'' to guide the football team to the Super Bowl championship last January.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: BAKE-FACE AND OTHER GUAVA STORIES. By Opal Palmer Adisa. (Kelsey St. Press, P.O. Box 9235, Berkeley, Calif. 94709, Paper, $7.50.) The conflict between obligation and personal desire is vividly portrayed throughout Opal Adisa's four keenly felt fictions of Jamaican women struggling to be understood by the men they love.

title: Mexico Makes A Big Drug Arrest
description: Under the anti-drug legislation signed by President Reagan last week, a foreign country that is a major drug producer may lose half its American aid unless the President certifies that it is trying to discipline itself.

title: TEACHING ABOUT SEX IN AN EXPLICIT SOCIETY
description: WHEN Frances Schaefer introduces her Brooklyn eighth graders to their sex education course, she asks them to write questions they have about themselves, their family, their friends. A common question, said Ms. Schaefer, a gently spoken 17-year veteran of the school system, is: ''How do you say no to your boyfriend without hurting his feelings?''

title: Israel's Leadership Problem
description: Thomas Friedman fails to discuss the critical impact of Israel's election law on its leadership vacuum.

title: CANDIDATE GETS DEATH THREAT
description: Officials of the New Alliance Party have reported that Dr. Lenora B. Fulani, the party's candidate for governor, received anonymous death threats by telephone this weekend, one of them from someone claiming to represent the Jewish Defense League, according to the police.

title: Everything Is O.K. at the Cowboys' New High-Tech Corral
description: SO you look around here at the Dallas Cowboys' new state-of-the-art training facility, complete with modular dressing rooms, three practice fields, 10,000 square feet of space for weight-lifting equipment, two racquetball courts, an indoor track, a rehearsal hall for the cheerleaders to practice in, a television studio, and who knows what else, and you think this is the natural extension of computer-age football, which, of course, the Cowboys like to think they invented.

title: IN STATE, 8 KEY CONGRESSIONAL RACES
description: Bella S. Abzug's bid for a political comeback and the impact of Jack F. Kemp's margin on his presidential aspirations are among the Congressional-election results being watched in eight key races across New York State.

title: Washington or Bust
description: SHELDON CLARK, a Republican challenging Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, has been driving a taxi in Phoenix since he lost his job as a metallurgical engineer. Asked the other day what he would do if he hailed a cab and got Mr. Clark's, the Democratic Congressman, who is known for his quick wit, said: ''I'd get in and tell him to take me to Washington.''

title: MOFFETT READY FOR THE OTHER SIDE OF NEWS
description: AFTER more than a month of voice lessons, relaxation classes and rehearsals of reading and writing news scripts, Toby Moffett is to start tomorrow as an anchor on WVIT-TV, Channel 30.

title: Carter in Bangladesh
description: Former President Jimmy Carter arrived here today on a visit in which is he expected to hold talks on establishing a philanthropic center. Mr. Carter is the chairman of Global 2000, an organization dedicated to ''eradicating poverty, injustice and social conflicts that plague the world.''

title: Marathon Forecast
description: OCCASIONAL light showers, high humidity and temperatures in the mid-50's were forecast for today's New York City Marathon. Fred Lebow, the race director, said a total of 20,391 runners had checked in for the race by 4 P.M yesterday, well over the record 16,705 starters last year, and with another 3,000 expected by the 10:45 A.M. starting time. Among the late entries yesterday was Pete Pfitzinger, a 29-year-old Cornell University graduate from Alford, N.Y., who turned in a personal best of 2 hours 11 minutes 43 seconds in winning the marathon at the 1984 United States Olympic Trials.

title: Getting a Fix On Halley's Comet
description: The information cannot be confirmed for some time, perhaps not for 75 years, but Soviet scientists have a steadily resolving picture of Halley's Comet, based on data recorded by spacecraft when the comet flew by last spring.

title: Upstate Glitter
description: Determined to make itself a little livelier, Syracuse is creating a glittering, seven-story complex that will include 80 stores and restaurants, three cinemas, offices and a county library.

title: A 'YIDDISH COWBOY' RETURNS
description: AS JOYOUSLY as a scholar proudly showing a hitherto unknown Shakespearean sonnet, Dr. Nathaniel Shapiro of Westfield sits before a group of elderly people, reading lines from a novel originally in Yiddish.

title: OPERA: CHAMBER GROUP IN 3-PART BILL
description: THE New York opera world makes us choose too often between quality of repertory and quality of performance. In the material world, of course, ideas and imagination cost nothing, but the realization of them can be dear.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Rural Township Faces a Transformation
description: SITUATED amid the densely wooded hills of Warren County in the northwestern tip of New Jersey, Oxford Township is rich in natural beauty and open space. Developers have bypassed the rural community for decades because it was considered too far from employment centers.

title: 'Channel Crossings' Brings Sense of Surprise
description: Although it occupies only a small piece of television's sprawling turf, WNET's ''Channel Crossings'' has been steadily developing into the kind of offbeat quality showcase that gets viewers watching intently and talking animatedly. These are not little escapist confections that pass forgettably in the night. We are not, obviously, talking about still another episode of ''L.A. Law.'' Seen on Channel 13 Thursdays at 11 P.M., the series features what the station hopes will be ''foreign television features of distinction.'' The program is now in its second season, and the record so far is singularly impressive.

title: Recent Sales
description: Farmington, Conn. $235,000 183 Warterville Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; in-ground pool, river frontage, 3.6 acres; taxes $1,986.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THEORY met practice in Edison recently, when three of the state's leading environmental actors and thinkers discussed how to settle disputes over siting environmental facilities.

title: U.S. MILITARY SALES TO INDIA HIT SNAGS
description: When Bharat Electronics Ltd., an Indian state manufacturing company, wanted to buy ITT Corporation's technology for military night vision, the deal took two years to piece together.

title: CHANNEL 55 AND CABLEVISION
description: The article ''Cable TV: Major Changes Loom'' on Oct. 5 was certainly a well-written, in-depth look at the mighty empire of Cablevision.

title: WHAT TO NAME THE CAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospecting in the Gold Mining Stocks
description: While the overall stock market rallied in the first half of 1986, gold mining stocks were in the doghouse. By midyear, they had fallen 24 percent from their 1985 close and were 33 percent below their 1986 highs reached in February.

title: Riding Waves of New Adventure
description: The irresistible dash of salt that has impelled untold generations to test themselves on the deep waters of the world is not absent from my psyche. Those deep-throated, primordial bellowing whistles of liners about to leave the West Side waterfront to rush across the Atlantic were for me maritime clarion calls, incitements to chuck it all, shoulder the seabag and dash to a stringpiece for a pierhead jump to adventure.

title: Real Estate Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Tableware's New Romance
description: THERE IS A NEW APPRECIA-tion of the Wiener Werkstatte, that group of artists and designers who produced everything from paintings to teaspoons in Vienna around 1900. As a result, contemporary designers of utilitarian objects are suddenly discovering that they have an eager audience. A coffee pot by the architect Aldo Rossi, flatware by the designer Ward Bennett, even glasses by the fashion designer Oscar de la Renta are finding an exalted place at the American table. ''Most of these people have been designing for a while now, but it has only been in the last year that they've been seriously recognized by the consumer,'' says Julian Tomchin, senior vice president and fashion director of home furnishings at Bloomingdale's.

title: U.S. IDEAS ON ARMS OFFERED IN ICELAND ARE BEING REFINED
description: The United States has refined an arms proposal it made to the Soviet Union at the Iceland summit meeting and has developed a detailed plan for reducing long-range nuclear weapons, Administration officials said today.

title: Candidates for Governors on Key Issues
description: Here are the views, compiled from interviews, campaign statements and position papers, of the major party candidates for governor in Connecticut's election Tuesday. WILLIAM A. O'NEILL 56-year-old Democrat seeking re-election to a second full term. THE ECONOMY

title: PHILIPPINE COMMUNISTS CALL FOR A 100-DAY CEASE-FIRE
description: The Communist New People's Army today offered the Aquino Government a plan for a 100-day cease-fire starting Dec. 10.

title: Kathryn Ewald Engaged to Wed David C. Adams
description: The engagement of Kathryn Cassandra Ewald to David Creswell Adams has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Roy Tolleson Jr. of New York, Charlottesville, Va., and Delray Beach, Fla., stepfather and mother of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Sarah Austen Adams and David Clark Adams, both of Houston.

title:
INVESTING;
An Overpriced American Eagle
description: ''IT makes a nice gift.'' That is about as much enthusiasm as John P. Norris, the 31-year-old who runs Citibank's precious metals department could work up for the American Gold Eagle, the selling-like-hotcakes coin now being issued by the United States Mint.

title: Libyans Said to Wound Chadian Rebel Leader
description: A Chadian rebel leader who has been allied with Libya was seriously wounded this week when he resisted arrest by Libyan soldiers, his spokesman in Paris said today.

title: RENOVATION STIRS FEARS IN ESSEX-MARKET
description: Amid peeling paint, narrow concrete aisles and colorful stands spilling fresh vegetables, Allen Ruhalter sells meats in his stall in the Essex Street Market, as his father did for a generation.

title: DELAWARE PROGRAM TO ADDRESS PROBLEMS OF EARLY CHILDHOOD
description: Gov. Michael N. Castle of Delaware has started a major program to address problems experienced by children 5 years of age and younger.

title: Hazardous Campaign Trail
description: THE television commercial may be the principal campaign vehicle for most candidates in 1986, but in Alaska it is the airplane. Campaigning in Alaska, whose 291,000 voters are scattered across a vast and mostly roadless state, can be an arduous and hazardous undertaking.

title: Erasing a Rembrandt
description: AS THERE MUST SURE-ly be a Paradise, so surely must Rembrandt van Rijn be in residence there. Doubtless he belongs to a club. That may be where he learned about the deattribution.

title: THE INDECISIVE ELECTION
description: The 1986 Congressional elections, an embarrassing episode in our recent history, are likely to produce about what they deserve, which is very little. Though these contests were supposed to determine ''control of the Senate,'' the chances are that the margin of victory will be so slim that neither party will be able to control anything but its temper, and maybe not even that.

title: COURTING THE CHINESE WITH MILITARY FLOWERS AND CANDY
description: QINGDAO, a city naval officers regard as China's best deep-water port but perhaps better known to sailors for its popular beer, will be checked out by the United States Navy on both counts this week. A cruiser, a frigate and a destroyer will make the first port call to the People's Republic by American military vessels since the Communists took over in 1949.

title: CD Recipe Calls For Many Pits, No Pittfalls
description: With CD's becoming regular household items, it is surprising that the genesis of these records remains a mystery even to otherwise well-informed listeners. Of course, a disk or a dish can be savored without knowing the recipe for making it. But in either instance, a peek into the kitchen can heighten appreciation, and in the case of CD's it leads to a fascinating point of contact between the frontiers of applied science and everyday life.

title: ROME
description: The superstitious can rest easy: The 18th-century bronze sculpture of Rome's protector, St. Michael the Archangel, is back where it belongs, atop the Castel Sant' Angelo, after more than two years of restoration.

title: VISIONS OF BLACKFOOT
description: FOOLS CROW By James Welch. Illustrated. 391 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: U.S. Will Pay Only $100 Million In U.N. Dues
description: The United States told Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar last week that it would contribute $100 million to the United Nations' 1986 budget. The amount is less than half of what the United States is supposed to pay under the United Nations Charter formula based on gross national product.

title: The Other Weinberger Is a Publisher
description: Like many publishers, Jane Weinberger, owner of Windswept House, a tiny concern based in Maine, is sometimes partial to high-priced talent. In her case, she especially finds that having the Secretary of Defense on call can come in handy.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CHARLIE MALARKEY AND THE BELLY-BUTTON MACHINE By William Kennedy and Brendan Kennedy. Illustrated by Glen Baxter. 20 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Margaret Cain Is Engaged To Edward George Hynes
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Barry of New Vernon, N.J., have announced the engagement of her daughter Margaret Helen Cain to Edward George Hynes, a son of Mrs. Thomas M. Hynes of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Hynes. A May wedding is planned.

title: CAN REPUBIC SURVIVE THE T-46 DEBACLE
description: JUST before it adjourned last month, the 99th Congress slashed $321 million that had been earmarked for the production of the Fairchild Republic Company's T-46A jet trainer.

title: Islanders Bounce Back and Defeat Jets
description: On Friday, the Islanders' coach treated them to a movie after a grueling two-hour practice. The film was of their 7-6 loss to the Devils on Thursday night, and reliving the memory was painful.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: FIRST OFF, 'LEARN TO BE STUPID';
The Fine Art of Managing Creativity
description: ALMOST two years ago, we embarked on a study of extraordinarily successful creativity. Our journey began in a conference room where, with the help of other Arthur D. Little Inc. technology and industry specialists, we catalogued and attacked the myths that have grown up around innovation. In stripping away the myths, we found ourselves undressing the emperor. The supermanager of the 80's, who claims to have a methodology to control everyone and everything, lacks a formula for the creative process.

title: Lucky Luciano's 'Testament'
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Say Toxic Tide In Texas Has Receded
description: The red tide of toxic organisms that killed about 15 million fish on the Texas coast over the last two months has receded and the Gulf of Mexico again is ''clear and green,'' state officials report.

title: OWL DECOYS FACE OFF AGAINST PIGEONS
description: THE ''pigeon war'' in White Plains escalated recently when the county government erected 13 plastic owls along the parapet of the County Office Building and its parking garage. This brings the number of plastic owl decoys in the city to more than 30. The number of feral pigeons is undetermined, although one county official estimates it to be 5,000.

title: ROCK-SOUL STARS OF THE 60'S HAVE A STRATEGY FOR THE 80'S
description: Aretha Franklin and Tina Turner, two definitive rock-soul singers of the 1960's, are still hit-making contenders in the 1980's. Ms. Turner's new album, ''Break Every Rule'' (Capitol album PJ-12530 and cassette CD 7-46323-2), follows up on the blockbuster, multimillion-selling ''Private Dancer,'' released in 1984. Meanwhile, the new ''Aretha,'' (Arista AL-8442 album, cassette and CD) catches Ms. Franklin on one of her career's periodic upswings, sparked by the 1985 album ''Who's Zoomin' Who.''

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: SAM PATCH: Ballad of a Jumping Man. By William Getz. (Franklin Watts, $17.95.) Sam Patch, who enjoyed brief fame for jumping off waterfalls before plunging to his death over the Genesee Falls in 1829, was a decidedly minor figure in American popular history. Making him the subject of a 361-page novel is a risky business -especially when the story is told by Sam's pet bear, Bruin. Luckily, Bruin is very likable. Honest, loyal and brave, he has a knack for knockabout, punning narration, well suited to his creator's (perhaps debatable) vision of Jacksonian America as a place where people jes' natur'ly jumped off waterfalls, shot b'ars in public places and fell down drunk a lot. Unluckily, Bruin also tends without warning to start sounding like a furry Wittgenstein: ''Was [Sam] saying . . . that the old quantitative, spatial way of looking at things was as primitive and false as the related error of thinking that we in fact do endure?'' A 500-pound bear who writes that way might be funny in some contexts, but William Getz takes him seriously. Set in a world where the men all talk like Mike Fink on his keelboat, the effect is jarring - Davy Crockett meets Davy Hume. Something else slows the fun of ''Sam Patch''; like Bruin's faithful, bedraggled she-bear (whose ''low, plaintive whine'' opens the book), its women are generally sad and dependent. A heroine as bold as Sam (or Bruin) could have helped justify the novel's considerable length.

title: LOADING OF FUEL IS DELAYED AT UPSTATE A-PLANT
description: Frogmen were called in tonight to try to correct a problem in the loading of the first batch of nuclear fuel into Nine Mile Point 2, the most expensive nuclear power plant in the country.

title: LETTERS OF BOSS TWEED FORETELL POLITICAL CRIMES
description: Out of the attic of a country house in Bridgehampton, L.I., has come a cache of 15 letters signed ''W. M. Tweed'' that foretell the corruption that linked crooked public officeholders to New York City's buccaneering businessmen after the Civil War.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
New Ports of Call And Shift to Pacific
description: As the fall and winter seasons get under way, the cruise industry is adding new ports of call and seeing a major shift of interest to the Far Pacific. Some of this is seasonal, but much of it is the result of the threat of terrorism in the Mediterranean.

title: PAC'S TURNING TO INDIRECT WAY TO AID HOPEFULS
description: Several political action committees are promoting candidates by spending millions of dollars on activities that they would be forbidden to spend if they consulted the candidates.

title: Public Reaction To a Terrorist
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT MASTERPIECE WAS WRITTEN IN A BUICK?
description: VN The Life and Art of Vladimir Nabokov. By Andrew Field. Illustrated. 417 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $19.95.

title: Ann M. Freeman Planning to Wed Andrew Schoder
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William G. Freeman Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Ann Mitchell Freeman to Andrew Owen Schoder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barron W. Schoder Jr. of Winnetka, Ill. The wedding is planned for Jan. 3.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA ASKS HOW FAR U.S. WILL GO
description: WHILE the Reagan Administration seems eager to climb back into the driver's seat of the Nicaraguan guerrilla movement, Central American military and political leaders appear to view the growing war against the Sandinistas with decidedly mixed feelings.

title: 'MOTEL CHILDREN' POSE PROBLEM FOR SCHOOLS
description: WHEN Oakside Elementary School in Peekskill lets out, most of the children walk home, talking and laughing in pairs and threes. But a group of 12 or 15 sits quietly on a wall near the street, waiting for taxis and vans to take them home to a motel.

title: WHITE, PINK AND NOTHING BUT PASTA
description: PASTA PRESTO in Great Neck, the third restaurant serving only pasta main courses to open on Long Island in recent years, is the suburban branch of a place of the same name in Manhattan. Like other pasta restaurants, this one offers relatively inexpensive dining in a pleasant, contemporary setting.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MRS. ABERCORN AND THE BUNCE BOYS By Liza Fosburgh. 115 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $11.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: NEW SCHOOL TO TEACH TECHNIQUES OF RESCUE
description: HOW do you rescue an injured climber who is trapped high above the ground in a crag of a cliff? How do you find someone buried under the earth when a trench caves in?

title: Nazi Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Bergen Catholic Wins in Shutout
description: Tom Kearney, a senior fullback, carried 26 times for 143 yards and three touchdowns to propel Bergen Catholic (6-0) past St. Joseph of Montvale, 34-0, yesterday in Montvale.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: Continue bulb planting and rake leaves . . . If air temperature is warm, apply anti-desiccants. . . . Keep mowing if the grass is growing. Still Colorful

title: Miss Kurtz Weds M. D. Greenstein
description: The marriage of Anne Nettie Kurtz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kurtz of Washington, to Michael David Greenstein, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Fred Irwin Greenstein of Princeton, N.J., took place last evening. Rabbi Herman Blumberg performed the ceremony at the DeCordova Museum in Lincoln, Mass.

title: NADER, '58, STARTS STUDY OF HARVARD, '86
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, is starting a new project in which Harvard University and its relationship with corporations will be monitored, he says.

title: 'SHE WAS AS PURE AS SNOW AND SHE DRIFTED'
description: THE PIANOPLAYERS By Anthony Burgess. 208 pp. New York: Arbor House. $16.95.

title: WALKING ALONG THE GREAT BARRIER REEF
description: Of the hundreds of islands that dot Australia's Great Barrier Reef, very few sit astride the coral reef itself. One that does is tiny Heron Island, and its felicitous location makes it an ideal spot for one of the gentlest of all ocean sports, reef walking.

title: Public Reaction To a Terrorist
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. DECIDES TO SHIFT PRIORITY TO ARMED STRUGGLE
description: In a shift in strategy, the Palestine Liberation Organization under Yasir Arafat has decided to give armed struggle against Israel priority over the peace process, P.L.O. spokesmen say.

title: LEGISLATIVE CANDIDATES WOO DISTRACTED VOTERS
description: As the election campaign dwindled to its final days, New York State legislators, their political strategists and independent analysts were preoccupied with two concerns: Were the voters interested in their races? And would the governor's contest affect theirs?

title: ADAM DALGLIESH SEES EVERYTHING
description: A TASTE FOR DEATH By P. D. James. 459 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: ROMANTIC TONIC IN TEANECK
description: NEW plays are plentiful, or so it was reported in last week's theater column.

title: TURNING AWAY FROM PASTA, LET'S TAKE A LOOK AT RICE
description: SO much attention is being paid to pasta (and more recently to such esoteric starches as blue-corn tortillas) that we seem to have quite forgotten about rice. There are many imaginative ways to serve this vegetable apart from steaming or boiling it.

title: PARENTS DON'T HEAR PLEAS FOR GUIDANCE
description: AT family gatherings my father used to remark that everyone talked and no one listened. It often seems that this is a national failing. In Ridgefield recently, 599 freshmen and juniors answered questions in a voluntary survey by representatives of the Connecticut Department of Education. I think we should listen to the results, which appeared Sept. 25 in The Ridgefield Press.

title: AFTER FATAL ACCCIDENT, HIGH SCHOOL CURBS STUDENT TRIPS OFF CAMPUS
description: FOR 15 years, sophomores, juniors and seniors at New Canaan High School have been permitted to leave campus during free and lunch periods and then return for their next class.

title: Tonia Falconer Is Married To Joseph Vinson, Painter
description: The marriage of Tonia Widmann Falconer and Joseph Hjalmar Vinson, a painter, took place yesterday at the home of Alexandra W. Falconer, mother of the bride, in Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence M. Horton performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR THE VARIED VIRTUES OF SPRING BULBS
description: ALTHOUGH they are not exceptionally demanding, spring bulbs depend the right planting techniques and conditions. The site is most important. Such earlier-flowering sorts as snowdrops and crocus will do well beneath deciduous trees and shrubs, because they mature before the leaves reappear in the spring.

title: Striking a Deal For More Judges
description: It might be hard to explain to a visitor, but New Yorkers should have understood perfectly: Governor Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature agreed last week to avert gridlock in New York City's Criminal Court, where misdemeanor cases are tried, by creating 23 new judgeships for the State Court of Claims.

title: 4 Manca Kicks Lift 8-0 Nittany Lions
description: Penn State gained 422 yards on offense and shut out West Virginia, 19-0, tonight despite the fact that the Nittany Lions squandered numerous scoring opportunities.

title: EXHIBIT TELLS TALE OF A FAMOUS YACHT
description: WITH trials for the America's Cup race now under way in Australia, Mystic Seaport has opened an exhibit tracing the history of the schooner that started it all. ''America: the Low Black Schooner 1851-1945'' is a joint effort with the New York Yacht Club, which owns many of the pieces being shown publicly for the first time.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If you put a new monkey in the zoo, people queue up to see it.'' - Sir Nicholas Goodison, chairman, London Stock Exchange, on the fascination with deregulation.

title: STATE DEPT. SUITE WITH TOBACCO MOTIF ANGERS SMOKING FOES
description: A ceremonial suite at the State Department has been given a tobacco motif, prompting criticism from antismoking activists.

title: MISHIMA: A VISION OF THE VOID
description: IT is always difficult to judge a great contemporary writer: we lack the proper distance. It is even more difficult to judge him if he belongs to a culture different from our own, a culture colored by our fondness for or distrust of the exotic. The chances of misunderstanding him are compounded when, as in the case of Yukio Mishima, the elements of the writer's own culture and those of the culture of the West, which he had avidly absorbed -that is to say, for us, the commonplace and the bizarre - mingle in each separate book in different proportions and with varying effects and degrees of success. It is, however, this admixture that makes him, in many of his books, a true representative of a Japan which was, like Mishima himself, violently Westernized, and yet remained distinguished by certain immutable characteristics. The way in which, in Mishima, the traditionally Japanese elements rose to the surface and burst in his death make him, furthermore, a witness to and - in the etymological sense of the word - a martyr of the heroic Japan to which he had returned, so to speak, against the tide.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 37 OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 37 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: WHERE ARE YOU NOW, BO DIDDLEY? The Stars Who Made Us Rock and Where They Are Now. By Edward Kiersh. (Doubleday, Paper, $9.95.)

title: Martha Ball Is Married to William Heppenheimer
description: Martha Jane Ball, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Rushbrook Ball of New York, was married yesterday to William Sands Heppenheimer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Heppenheimer 3d of East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Davis Given performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Ball home.

title: Suits For Glittering Fall Nights
description: IN the 1930's designers with names like Schiaparelli, Molyneux and Mainbocher were making long, slender jacket-and-skirt combinations that were the last word in evening-wear elegance. Now a newer generation of designers, with names like Lagerfeld, Karan and Saint Laurent, has brought back that fetching ensemble.

title: Scarsdale Surge Tops Mahopac
description: With only five minutes remaining in the game and trailing Mahopac by 21-7, Scarsdale seemed perilously close to losing both the game and the possibility of a postseason bowl game berth. When Scarsdale's Larry Holloway caught a kickoff on the 12-yard line and ran backward to the 4, those fears seemed to be confirmed.

title:
MUSIC;
AMERICAN MUSIC CELEBRATION
description: THE music director of the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra, Keith Clark, will lead it next Sunday afternoon in a program celebrating American Music Week, being observed nationwide tomorrow through next Sunday.

title: Mary Keane To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Keane Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Keane to Whitney Hayes Baldwin, a son of Geraldine W. Baldwin of Morristown, N.J., and Robert H. B. Baldwin of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for May. Miss Keane, an institutional saleswoman for Kidder Peabody & Company in New York, graduated from Endicott College and attended American University.

title: Writing to Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH SENTENCE AT 16 REKINDLES DEBATE ON JUSTICE FOR JUVENILES
description: On a warm May afternoon last year, four teen-age girls in this factory town east of Chicago skipped class, drank a bottle of Wild Irish Rose wine and concocted a robbery scheme that led to one of the most brutal and widely publicized murders in the town's history.

title: IN EIGHT DECADES OF PHOTOS, WORLD OF CHILDHOOD IN THE BRONX IS PRESERVED
description: The buildings may be hollow now, cold shells with lightless windows. But the old neighborhoods never die. As long as there is memory and an album with sepia faces, the Bronx will be a place of children.

title: FALL SALMON RUN HIGHEST IN WEST IN DECADES
description: Chinook and coho salmon are returning to the Pacific Northwest's Columbia River system in numbers unparalleled in decades, officials say.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTION SOFTWARE
description: DEMOCRACY is a growth business,'' said John Phillips, president of Aristotle Industries Inc.

title: Kissinger Plans a Suit On Magazine Article
description: Henry A. Kissinger plans to file suit tomorrow against Penthouse magazine to stop the distribution of its December issue, which contains an interview with the former Secretary of State, a lawyer for Mr. Kissinger said yesterday.

title: SHOWERS OF FLOWERS FROM HANGING PLANTS
description: For many years, a bushy New Guinea hybrid impatiens sat sedately in the corner of the greenhouse. It was a tolerably good-looking plant, but it never collected compliments. Then, I potted it into a hanging basket. Suddenly, it was transformed. Its life as a wallflower was over.

title: CRACK ATTACK
description: He had been pounding an undercover beat on the streets of New York City, arresting drug dealers and lecturing teen-agers on street corners and in schools. But despite those efforts, he saw the attraction of ''crack '' - the newest version of cocaine - growing, enticing youngsters as easily as candy once did.

title: Bridge Records: A Haven for New Music Honors the Old
description: Bridge Records is a small, New York-based label that has built a compact but fascinatingly varied catalogue in the last five years. Its founder, David Starobin, is considered to be this country's pre-eminent interpreter of contemporary guitar works and of chamber works (old and new) that include guitar parts; in fact, he is giving a concert of unusual and rarely heard guitar works today at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y. Although a few of Bridge's first disks featured Mr. Starobin's work, the guitarist and his wife, Rebecca, who runs the label's business side, were intent on keeping Bridge from turning into a vanity press. Thus, Mr. Starobin's recordings account for less than a third of the label's catalogue, and Bridge's first CD's are devoted to electronic and orchestral works by Tod Machover, and to two installments of an ''American Pianists'' series. And while Bridge has focused largely on contemporary works, its catalogue also includes music of Grieg, Chopin and Schumann; and Mr. Starobin says that there is more standard repertory in the offing.

title: Nicaragua's U.N. Voice
description: I do not see the relevance of describing what Ms. Astorga chooses to wear to the opera, what color her nail polish is or including an observation on her ''ungraceful walk.''

title: Jill N. Grossman Wed To David C. Denowitz
description: Jill N. Grossman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Grossman of Westport, Conn., was married last night to David C. Denowitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Denowitz of Annapolis and Easton, Md. Cantor Vicki Axe performed the ceremony at the Fenway Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Barbara Cushman Plans a Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ettlinger McFadden of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara McFadden Cushman, to Anthony A. Sirna 3d. The wedding is planned for Dec. 20.

title: Scoring Pass With 4:43 Left Sinks Cadets
description: Shawn Halloran hit Peter Casparriello with an 8-yard touchdown pass with 4 minutes 43 seconds to go that gave Boston College a 27-20 victory today over Army.

title: 'GIN GAME' IS REBORN AS A MUSICAL, 'JOKERS'
description: ''THE GIN GAME'' played at New Haven's Long Wharf Theater before it became a Broadway hit and a Pulitzer Prize-winner. Almost a decade later, the two-character playcan once again be seen on a Connecticut stage - this time as a musical with 10 characters, eight of whom represent playing cards.

title: Shari Goodstein Marries
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue last evening Shari M. Goodstein, a second-year student at the New York University School of Law, was married to Craig N. Lambert, an account executive at DDB Needham Worldwide Advertising.

title: Flour of Etymology
description: Tracing its own origin to the paragraphs on etymology sprinkled through Webster's II New Riverside University Dictionary, WORD MYSTERIES & HISTORIES: From Quiche to Humble Pie (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95) offers more than 500 short narratives of invention, extension and incomprehension. Whom the editors of the American Heritage Dictionaries see as their audience is unclear - probably high school students, to judge by the jokey, digressive style.

title: Deals Proliferate in Softer Manhattan Office Market
description: MIDTOWN and downtown Manhattan still stand tall as the strongest office markets in the country, but their skyscrapers no longer cast as long a shadow. Tenants are looking at attractive deals elsewhere, while owners are looking at empty floors and stagnant rents.

title: BRAZIL ELECTIONS PROMISE CHANGES
description: Brazil is in the midst of its first national election campaign since civilian rule returned last year. But a long-anticipated debate on Brazil's political future is overshadowed by regional issues and personality clashes.

title: Sheila Ruggles Weds
description: Sheila Ruggles, an administrative assistant at DDB Needham Worldwide, and Steven A. Landsberg, a creative supervisor at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, advertising agencies in New York, were married last night at the Village Temple in New York by Rabbi Dennis Math. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John G. Tonnochy of Walnut Creek, Calif., and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Landsberg of West Orange, N.J. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Favorites Win at Aqueduct
description: Favorites scored popular victories in yesterday's Aqueduct co-features, the mile-and-an-eighth Stuyvesant Handicap for 3-year-olds and up and the mile-and-a-half Long Island Handicap for fillies and mares, on the turf course.

title: Why We Should Be Excited by Dinosaurs
description: To the Editor:

title: IS THE ROAD TO A THEATER CAREER ROCKIER FOR WOMEN?
description: THEY had assembled to talk about ''Women on Broadway,'' but at first some of the panelists argued that the issue of gender shouldn't even be raised.

title: Undefeated Penn Posts 7th Victory
description: Rich Comizio and Chris Flynn, Penn's two tailbacks, took turns hammering at the inside of the Princeton defense today. Comizio rushed for 154 yards and Flynn for 117, but the yards came easier than the touchdowns as the undefeated Quakers, favored by as many as 19 points, beat the Tigers, 23-10, before a crowd of 18,500 at Palmer Stadium.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: UNDER THE COVER OF A HAT: Montages and Sequences and GREEN-SEALED MESSAGE: 90 Dreams. By H. C. Artmann. Translated by Derk Wynand.

title: Toys For Children
description: Afour-year theme in Switzerland's Pro Juventute series will conclude with the Nov. 25 release of a quartet of semi-postal stamps illustrating children's toys. ''The Child and Its World'' theme began in 1983 with a set of antique toys. The 1984 and 1985 sets depicted scenes from popular children's stories.

title: THE WORM IN THE APPLE: Turned On; CLEAN MACHINES
description: It may be hard to recall in an era of subway graffiti, toxic waste and factory closures, but there was a time when America's romance with the machine was innocently full of hope and energy. For its intriguing evocation of that time, a streamlined apple to the Brooklyn Museum.

title: New Wing Conquers the Los Angeles County Museum
description: In the vast flurry of postwar museum-building in America, one building had to come out at the bottom of the pile, and it is probably the original complex of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Indeed, this is arguably the least distinguished major museum building in the country. Designed by William Pereira and completed in 1965, it is a complex of three fussily decorated boxes placed around a central court, an arrangement that over the years has proven neither practical nor attractive. The buildings are an unhappy mix of corporate modernism and small-time, provincial glitz, and they do not display art very well, either. Moreover, their lack of sophistication belies the importance Los Angeles now possesses on the national art scene. The museum is a relic of an age, less than a generation ago, when Los Angeles was something of a cultural backwater.

title: MISSOURI STUDENTS FIGHT TOWN'S DANCING BAN
description: For decades there has been no dancing in the schools of this rural community in southwestern Missouri. Now a possible legal challenge from students determined to have their prom in their high school has divided the town's 1,000 residents.

title: ONCE-MIGHTY U.M.W. IS SEEKING MORE MUSCLE
description: AMONG the memorabilia in the lobby of A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters in Washington is a handwritten letter sent nearly 40 years ago by John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers of America, to William Green, the labor federation's president. It reads: ''Green. We disaffiliate. Lewis.'' That was a momentous breach in the ranks of organized labor, and since then, the miners have viewed themselves as staunchly independent renegades. But last week, at a mine workers' convention here, Rich Trumka, the 37-year-old lawyer who is now the union's president, took steps that will probably mean a return to the fold.

title: STRIVERS AND DEFEATISTS
description: In a poignant reflection on the great northward migration of blacks after World War II, the poet Langston Hughes wrote: ''I've seen them come dark, wondering, wide-eyed, dreaming, out of Penn Station - but the trains are late. The gates open -yet there're bars at each gate.''

title: Nazi Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Update
description: (Source: HSH Associates)*Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: Elizabeth Krug Is Married to William Daniel Sparks
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J., yesterday Elizabeth Anne Krug, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hoffmann Krug of Englewood, was married to William Daniel Sparks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sparks of Lindenhurst, L.I. The Rev. James Steele performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Ernest F. Krug 3d, a brother of the bride.

title: Miss Novak Wed to Donald Hertzmark
description: At Temple Israel in Waterbury, Conn., last evening Sally Jane Novak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Novak of Middlebury, Conn., was married to Donald Ian Hertzmark, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Hertzmark of Milton, Mass. Rabbi Arnold Miller and Cantor Alan Lefkowitz officiated.

title: 'HISTORY CANNOT BE SHRUGGED OFF'
description: GERMANY in autumn. At this moment, the country should be quivering with tension; emotions should be rising.

title: GAS TEST ASSAILED FOR PENNSYLVANIA
description: Despite state recommendations that real estate companies in Pennsylvania use federally approved tests to detect a dangerous gas, the companies have been using a method the Federal Government stopped using three years ago, according to state and Federal officials and environmental experts.

title: The Post-Summit Spat Cools Off
description: After three weeks of dispute and no little confusion over who agreed to what in Iceland, relations between the United States and the Soviet Union seemed to relax a bit.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IN the late summer of 1946 I knew almost nothing about Long Island, except that you had to go through about half of it to get to Bay Shore and the Fire Island ferries on a rickety railroad or, when I was younger and my parents had money, in their car from Greenwich, Conn., to the Bridgeport-Port Jefferson ferry and then to Bay Shore.

title: ROLLING ALONG ON ANTIQUE BICYCLES
description: TOM WAY GREEN and his fellow Wheelmen take their bike riding seriously, even though their bicycles are often 100 years old.

title: Yamani, the Sheik Of OPEC, Gets His Walking Papers
description: The most prominent, and possibly most influential official in the Arab oil industry, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, was dismissed last week by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia.

title: Ann Evans Coates Becomes Bride of Tom Davis
description: Ann Evans Coates and Warren Thomas Davis 3d were married yesterday at the home of Margaret Pawska in Bloomfield, N.J., by the Rev. Kenneth Ironside, a Presbyterian minister.

title: A Play of Emotional Density, Full of Comedy and Wit
description: Today, Simon Gray is commonly regarded as an exponent of the cool, disengaged, intellectual anti-hero - but this was not always the case. Because of the heightened comedy and the confused sexual identities of characters in his early plays, he was, at one point, considered to be a possible successor to Joe Orton. In fact, in his 1971 study of new English playwrights, John Russell Taylor dismissed Mr. Gray as ''sub-Orton.'' But he added these hopeful words: ''With a stronger and more original subject Gray might very easily surprise us, perhaps in 'Butley,' a new play in rehearsal under the direction of Harold Pinter.''

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: IN THE SHADOW OF THE POORHOUSE: A Social History of Welfare in America. By Michael B. Katz. (Basic Books, $22.95.) Michael B. Katz's review of social welfare policy from 1750 to 1986 lends perspective to a domestic debate that has raged fitfully in America for nearly two centuries.

title: Jeanne Comeau Bride Of Victor R. Coudert 3d
description: Jeanne Ann Comeau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Comeau Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Tuckers Town, Bermuda, was married yesterday to Victor Raphael Coudert 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Coudert Jr., also of Greenwich. The Rev. John Collins performed the ceremony at the St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: IS 'MORAL OUTRAGE' GEORGIA'S TERM FOR RACISM?
description: To the Editor:

title: THINKING AS WELL AS A MAN
description: THE CELEBRATED MARY ASTELL An Early English Feminist. By Ruth Perry. Illustrated. 549 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $19.95.

title: A Cape Cod Bounty: Flowers and Beads
description: No less an authority than Henry David Thoreau, in his book, ''Cape Cod,'' recommended the fall as the best season for a Cape visit, citing the clarity of the air, the drama of the tides and storms -- which lend every outing a fillip of adventure -- and the colors of the countryside. ''I never saw an autumnal landscape so beautifully painted as this was. It was like the richest rug imaginable spread over an uneven surface.''

title: EDUCATION DOESN'T INDOCTRINATE OR TRAIN FOR JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Clinic
description: THERE IS NOTHING HERE TO suggest that this is, in any way, a man's place. Though we men have been equal partners in the act itself, though the throbbing, nearly-human thing whose life is about to be prematurely expunged is of our own blood, nothing suggests that we have had anything at all to do with this choice.

title: SEX-CRIME UNIT SHIFT IS ASSAILED
description: THE disbanding of a special bureau in the District Attorney's office to handle sex offenses in Nassau County has led to criticism by public agencies, advocate groups and legislators who say that victims often are not getting fair and sensitive hearings.

title: RETURN TO PRINCETON IN A CHANGED ROLE
description: BEHIND the door, one expects to find a regal young woman occupying lavishly appointed chambers. But no one is at the desk. The basement office in the East Pyne Humanities Building, known to Princeton students as ''The Gulag'' because Russian classes meet there, is spartan.

title: ESSENCES AND SENTIMENTS
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS By Edwin Denby. Edited, and with introduction, by Ron Padgett. With essays by Frank O'Hara and Lincoln Kirstein. Photographs by Rudy Burckhardt. 194 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95. SELECTED POEMS, 1935-1985 By James Laughlin. 248 pp. San Francisco: City Lights Books. Cloth, $25.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: THE LINEUP FOR TUESDAY
description: Following is a list of candidates for statewide office and Congress appearing on ballots in Tuesday's election. The incumbents are marked with an asterisk (*). The abbreviations are: D-Democrat, R- Republican, L-Libertarian, U-Unaffiliated Party. GOVERNOR, LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR William A. O'Neill, D * Joseph J. Fauliso, D Julie D. Belaga, R E. title: On House Spending
description: In the last days of the Congressional campaign, it should surprise few voters to learn that members of the House who were elected by narrow margins spend more of their office allowances communicating with their constituents back in the district than those who occupy relatively secure seats.

title: TOYS AS ART: A MIX OF FUN AND WHIM
description: THE exhibit ''Not for Children Only,'' now through Nov. 16 at The Silo Gallery in New Milford, features a colorful collection of whimsical objects created by area craftsmen and artists.

title: Where to Get More Details On Cruises
description: Admiral Cruises, Post Office Box 010882, Miami, Fla. 33101 (305-373-7501). American Canadian Line, Post Office Box 368, Warren, R.I. 02885 (401-247-0955; 800-556-7450 outside Rhode Island). American Cruise Lines, 1 Marine Park, Haddam, Conn. 06438 (203-345-8551; 800-243-6755 outside Connecticut). American Hawaii Cruises, 550 Kearny Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94108 (415-392-9400; 800-227-3666).

title: Wilkins Scores 39 To Help Rout Nets
description: The Atlanta Hawks, with plenty of brawn up front to complement the prolific scoring of Dominique Wilkins and an improved running game, overwhelmed the Nets, 131-111, tonight at the Omni.

title: 10-YEAR-LONG SEARCH SOLVES MYSTERY OF 18TH-CENTURY NEW ENGLAND BALLAD
description: After years of searching old graveyards and musty records for the origins of one of New England's oldest folk ballads, a professor of English has finally tracked the ghosts to upstate New York.

title: Mary A. Rauscher Planning to Wed
description: Mary A. Rauscher and Dr. Charles H. Bowden plan to be married next month. Dr. and Mrs. Frank J. Rauscher Jr. of Weston, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Patricia J. Butler of Austin, Tex., and Howard E. Bowden Jr. of San Antonio.

title: Jaunt in Park Now a Run for Money
description: ONCE upon a marathon, they gathered in Central Park, a runner's oasis in an asphalt city, 126 men and one woman, each determined to complete four loops that marked the course. Long distance runners were considered eccentrics when the first New York City Marathon was held in 1970, their achievements greeted with indifference, their sport an object of derision. Who in their right mind would want to run 26 miles 385 yards. That was even a long way to drive.

title: A FARM BECOMES A CAUSE
description: THE sight of the sprawling Froehlich Farm from a Long Island Rail Road train rounding the bend into Huntington is one of the last reminders of the rich agricultural heritage of Long Island.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It looks like there might be some hope. One wouldn't be here if there is no possibility.

title: MUSIC: LIBERTY POTPOURRI
description: WILLIAM SCHUMAN'S cantata ''On Freedom's Ground,'' which received its first performance Tuesday night during a potpourri concert at Avery Fisher Hall on the actual 100th birthday of the Statue of Liberty, has now been incorporated into the current New York Philharmonic subscription program, the final installment of which is tonight at 8.

title: TAKE APRIL AS SHE IS
description: UNEXPECTED PLEASURES By Phyllis Naylor. 270 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: MINOR MONUMENTS: Selected Essays. By Howard Moss. (Ecco, $20.) Howard Moss, a poet and the poetry editor of The New Yorker, has assembled 27 reviews and critical pieces written over the last 30 years.

title: STAGE: 'THE FRANKENSTEIN MUSICAL'
description: SEMINA DE LAURENTIS, who stars as Nurse Mary Phillips in ''Have I Got a Girl for You! (The Frankenstein Musical),'' possesses a million-dollar smile. When the actress, who lighted up the stage as Sister Mary Amnesia in the Off-Broadway show ''Nunsense,'' flashes her goofy ear-to-ear overbite, she pushes an audience's laugh buttons. And in ''Have I Got a Girl for You!'' a wildly campy spoof of ''The Bride of Frankenstein,'' the actress's incandescent sense of fun holds together a project that has the rickety internal logic of a Marx Brothers farce.

title: Corrected History
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: FROM THE REALMS OF MORPHEUS by Steven Millhauser. William Morrow & Company. 370 pages. $17.95.

title: Cen Mets Outbid Cards?
description: THE Mets finished 28 1/2 games ahead of the third-place St. Louis Cardinals this year. But now the Cardinals might be slightly ahead of the Mets, if only out of desperation, in each club's pursuit of happiness for 1987, otherwise known as Kevin McReynolds, the San Diego Padres' slugger.

title: Poll Finds Tie in Dakota
description: A new poll indicates a virtual tie in the Senate race in North Dakota. The Republican incumbent, Mark Andrews, was favored by 44 percent and the Democrat, Kent Conrad, by 43 percent among 507 residents telephoned Wednesday and Thursday, and the margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points. The poll was taken by the University of North Dakota's Bureau of Governmental Affairs for several news organizations.

title: THE GOOD AND THE BAD IN OYSTER BAY WALKING TOUR
description: THE Village of Oyster Bay has some striking architectural landmarks and some equally striking eyesores. A walking tour this afternoon will offer visitors a glimpse of both.

title: Denise S. Berman Weds Peter Rose
description: Denise S. Berman, a daughter of Mala Berman of Potomac, Md., and Frederick S. Berman of Alexandria, Va., was married last night to Peter S. Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Zeldon E. Rose of West Long Branch, N.J., and St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. Rabbi Jonathan Waxman, assisted by Cantor Arnold Saltzman, officiated at the Holiday Inn in Crystal City, Va.

title: Devils Falter on Power Plays
description: The power play, which had been so successful for the Devils in recent games, proved their downfall tonight against the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Student Dies in Cave After the Walls Collapse
description: A college student was trapped and killed when the ceiling of an abandoned cave collapsed after he and four other broke into the cavern.

title: WHEN TO REMAIN IN A POLITICAL PARTY
description: The tone of Stan Lipton's letter to the editor, ''When to Leave a Political Party,'' on Oct. 5, was more sad than mad.
