Mr. Lipton, a lifelong Republican, changed his registration to independent when his party first engaged in the practice of cross-endorsing candidates with the Conservative Party, and vice versa, some years ago. While he has no quarrel with the formation of minor parties when they run their own candidates and advance their own political philosophy, such is not usually the case.

title: PROJECT DOCUMENTS THE ERA OF GREENWICH'S GREAT ESTATES
description: WHEN Ernest Thompson Seton, the naturalist and father of the Boy Scout movement, began searching for a wilderness-like homestead near New York City, he rejected Staten Island because of the ferries, New Jersey for its mosquitoes and Long Island and Westchester County because real-estate costs were too high.

title: COHORT OF THE AMERICAN CENTURY
description: THE WISE MEN Six Friends and the World They Made: Acheson, Bohlen, Harriman, Kennan, Lovett, McCloy. By Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas. Illustrated. 853 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Intrigue Shrouds A Missing Israeli
description: While Scotland Yard said it had no evidence that he had ''come to any harm,'' speculation grew last week about the whereabouts of a former Israeli technician who gave a British newspaper reports of a secret nuclear installation in the Negev desert.

title: FOREST TRACTS ARE ACQUIRED BY NEW YORK
description: The state has bought 17 parcels of wilderness land for $2.7 million to add to the Adirondack Forest Preserve.

title: Of Men and Asteroids
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Rivals' History Is Set Straight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AGENCY ASKING U.S. CARE IN 'CATASTROPHIC' ILLS
description: The Department of Health and Human Services is drafting a report that urges President Reagan to consider expanding Medicare to cover a larger portion of the costs of long, severe illnesses.

title: ART: HENRI MATISSE IN NICE, 1916-1930, AN EXHIBITION AT THE NATIONAL GALLERY
description: If ever there was an exhibition to set grown men and women dancing in the streets, it is ''Henri Matisse: The Early Years in Nice 1916-1930,'' which can be seen at the National Gallery of Art in Washington through March 29 and which will not be seen anywhere else.

title: Abby M. Wenzel Becomes a Bride
description: Abby Maude Wenzel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wenzel of Sea Cliff, L.I., was married last night to Lawrence Steven Hirsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hirsh of Floral Park, Queens. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Mill River Country Club in Upper Brookville, L.I.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
'Surveillance' Looks at Tools and Ethics of Eavesdropping
description: ''C an you ever feel sure or secure if you can be watched at every moment?''

title: Syracuse Rallies 3 Times to Overcome Pitt, 24-20
description: Scott Schwedes caught a 2-yard touchdown pass from a scrambling Don McPherson midway through the final quarter as Syracuse rallied three times for a 24-20 victory over Pitt today.

title: BUREAUCRACY AND THE ENVIRONMENT
description: TWO longtime and faithful members of the environmental community have recently received shabby, if not shameful, treatment at the hands of people in power. The circumstances of the two lamentable situations are not exactly similar, but both Robert Boyle of Cold Spring and Henry Neale of Scarsdale share in common a track record marked by dedication and competence.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Mexico City on Oct. 26 about the arrival of the new United States Ambassador misstated the circumstances under which his predecessor, John Gavin, left his post. He resigned as Ambassador, effective at the end of May, to enter private business.

title: O'ROURKE IS LOW KEY IN QUEENS VISIT
description: Outside the neo-classical Queens Borough Hall, where Donald R. Manes presided as Borough President for 14 years, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican candidate for governor, focused yesterday on corruption and called for a Republican victory Tuesday to assure honesty through a strong, two-party system.

title: THE SPY WHO GOT AWAY
description: IN THE SILENCE JUST BEFORE TWI-light in the desert near Santa Fe, the sky changes colors, shading to pinks and reds, and the sunset casts an orange glow on the golden snakeweed, the prickly pear cactuses and the juniper trees. The Sangre de Cristo mountains turn purple, then swiftly black.

title: Scott Not So Great
description: MAYBE he needs the pressure of a pennant race to shine, or perhaps it was his unfamiliarity with an array of top Japanese League batters, but whatever the reason, Mike Scott, the 18-game winner for the Houston Astros who held the Mets to one run in two playoff victories, was pounded yesterday for six hits and two runs in three innings of an exhibition game against a team of Japanese all-stars in Tokyo.

title: PUBLIC TV STAIONS SEEK JOINT VENTURE
description: Executives of public television stations, increasingly concerned that much of their major prime-time programming is in jeopardy, have began to collaborate in unprecedented ways.

title: EXECUTIVE IS FINED $25 MILLION
description: A concrete company executive convicted in a $9.2 billion check-kiting scheme has been fined a record $25 million in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: TOWN SETS HEARING ON NEWMAN'S CAMP FOR SICK CHILDREN
description: RESIDENTS of Ashford will get their first chance to comment on plans by the actor Paul Newman and his friend and business associate, the author A. E. Hotchner, to establish in their town a 260-acre camp for critically ill children.

title: 'War of Roses' In Rhode Island
description: WHAT was described as the war of the roses began in Barrington, R.I., in August 1985 when Karl Jones sold his garden containing thousands of rose bushes to developers. The five-acre garden was a tourist attraction that drew thousands each year.

title: RESIDENTS OF LYME AREA SEEK STATE FUNDS TO FIGHT LYME DISEASE
description: IN Lyme, where a mysterious disease was discovered 10 years ago that later took the town's name, 2,000 people have signed petitions asking the state to pay for increased research and public education about the illness, which they fear is growing.

title: Policemen Rally Round C.I.A. Flag
description: The C.I.A. did not issue a press release, but last week the word got out: police officers from 18 cities are being recruited to help fight terrorism abroad.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture credit last week with the article about Caroline Hunt Schoellkopf was incorrect. The photographer was Zigy Kaluzny.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MUSEUM-HOPPING
description: A new brochure, ''Aim for Art,'' is a colorful and compact directory of galleries and museums in Westchester and Fairfield Counties, designed to serve as a valuable resource to anyone who wants to spend a day of museum-hopping in the suburbs.

title: Seoul Protesters Hurl Firebombs at Police
description: Students protesting the arrests of 1,500 anti-Government demonstrators hurled firebombs today at hundreds of riot police officers, who retaliated with tear gas, the police and witnesses said.

title: WHY MICHAEL BENNETT HAS SAID GOODBYE, FOR NOW, TO BROADWAY
description: By the standards of Manhattan real-estate deals it may have been small change, but when Michael Bennett last month sold the building on Broadway between 19th and 20th Streets that has been his base of operations since 1978, the intricate family that is New York's theater and dance community shivered. Less important than the $15 million price tag was the fact that at age 43 the pre-eminent director and choreographer of his generation in the musical theater was stepping out of the Broadway spotlight. At least for the time being.

title: A PENCHANT FOR GOLD LAME KNICKERS
description: BUT ENOUGH ABOUT YOU By Cynthia Heimel. 190 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $11.95.

title: '85 KIDNAPPING OF NEWBORN BABY IS STILL A MYSTERY
description: Marlene Santana was 3 days old and weighed 7 pounds when she and her mother, Francesca, left Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn one night last fall. A woman approached, pointed a pistol at Mrs. Santana, her baby and two relatives, and forced them to a deserted street corner six blocks away.

title: DEFENSE READIES CASE IN 8-WEEK-OLD MOB COMMISSION TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors have virtually finished presenting their evidence against eight men accused of conducting the racketeering activities of a ruling Mafia ''commission.''

title: Protection Gone Awry
description: Prentice Rasheed said that when he installed a homemade booby trap in his Miami store earlier this year, he intended only to discourage repeated burglaries, not to carry out the harshest of sentences for the crimes. But his trap, a metal grate bolted above a door and wired to an electrical outlet, both caught and killed a would-be burglar.

title: Judith Wiener Weds Stephen Goodhue
description: The marriage of Judith R. Wiener, a vice president of the Board of Cooperative Educational Services of Southern Westchester, to Stephen Van Rensselaer Goodhue, the senior vice president in charge of the Wall Street department of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, took place last evening in Katonah, N.Y. Judge Kenneth H. Lange of the County Court of Westchester in White Plains performed the ceremony at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR THE VARIED VIRTUES OF SPRING BULBS
description: ALTHOUGH they are not exceptionally demanding, spring bulbs depend the right planting techniques and conditions. The site is most important. Such earlier-flowering sorts as snowdrops and crocus will do well beneath deciduous trees and shrubs, because they mature before the leaves reappear in the spring.

title: AMERICAN DREAM DASHED FORMANY LAOS REFUGEES
description: For six years as a political prisoner of the Communist Governent of Laos, the former Laotian official said, he was sustained by memories of Cornell University, where he studied in the 1970's.

title: Israel's Leadership Problem
description: Thomas L. Friedman's thoughtful article on today's sad lack of leadership in Israel left me with wonder and dismay: what has happened to Israeli women in politics (''Israel's Leadership Problem,'' Oct. 12)?

title: 'UNTITLED ART CLASS' FINDS A LOCAL POINT IT CAN CALL HOME
description: THE room is silent except for the sound of pens scratching on paper. ''Change,'' calls the timekeeper, and the model shifts her weight to a new pose.

title: POLITICKING GOES HIGH-TECH
description: WHEN THE SEN-ate race in Missouri entered the homestretch early last month, campaign strategists for Republican Christopher S. (Kit) Bond began to take nightly readings of the voters' mood. As soon as they learned that the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting in Iceland had collapsed on Sunday, Oct. 12, they inserted three new questions into their polls. On Monday night, the President spoke to the nation about the meeting; by Tuesday night, Don Sipple, Mr. Bond's media adviser, sensed he was onto something big.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: TO BE A SLAVE IN BRAZIL: 1550-1888. By Katia M. de Queiros Mattoso. (Rutgers University, $35.) We have grown accustomed to thinking about slavery as a singularly brutal institution, the slave as commodity, totally subjugated to the will of a master. Historical research, however, has unveiled a far more complex story, albeit one rarely made available to a general reading public. Katia M. de Queiros Mattoso's book was written for a popular audience, in laymen's language and without scholarly references and footnotes. A masterly text, nicely translated from the original French (1979) by Arthur Goldhammer, ''To Be a Slave in Brazil'' traces slavery in Brazil over 300 years, from the capture of slaves in Africa to the abolition of the institution in 1888. Ms. Mattoso, a social historian of Brazil, describes in rich detail the day-to-day lives of that country's slaves. She reconstructs their lives from a lode of official and private documents - government regulations, police and tax records, licenses, wills, estate inventories, manumission papers, religious archives, marriage contracts and dowry statements. What emerges is a stunning tale of social and economic relations, of extraordinary cruelty occasionally mitigated by human circumstance and of class and regional diversity based on types of economic activity. The book discusses the demography of slavery and European immigration, and the attribution of status according to shadings of color, education, language and skill. Brazil's famous law of the ''free womb'' (1885) theoretically freed all children born to slave mothers, but only to be servant-wards of the master or the state.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes: Photos and 'White Suit'
description: The Man in the White Suit Starring Alec Guinness and Joan Greenwood; directed by Alexander Mackendrick. 1952. Thorn EMI Video. 82 minutes.

title: BOTH RIVAL PARTIES GIRD TO COMBAT VOTE FRAUD
description: Democratic and Republican officials said today that they had made elaborate preparations to assure that all votes are counted, and counted equally, on Election Day.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1986
description: The World The U.S. has refined the arms plan that it proposed to the Soviet Union in Iceland and has developed a detailed new plan for reducing long-range arms, the Reagan Administration said. Page 1 A Soviet team is polling Americans to elicit views about the role of Soviet studies in the United States. U.S. scholars believe the opinion poll is the first of its kind. #19 Soviet commandos spy on the West regularly, according to West German intelligence. Disguised as truck drivers and tourists, the units photograph areas that would become targets in tense times. #23 Philippine rebels offered a cease-fire plan to the Aquino Government. The Commmunist New People's Army outlined a 5-point plan for a 100-day truce starting Dec. 10. #3 Manila traces Marcos assets 4 U.S. starts inquiry on Enrile 5 India wants to block Union Carbide from selling any more of its assets. Speaking in a Bhopal court, Government officials said such sales could reduce any eventual settlements for victims of the 1984 gas tragedy. #6 Uruguay is suffering a political crisis that leaders say is the worst since the return of democracy. Political parties have failed to agree whether to try former military rulers for rights abuses. #16 A crucial Brazil election 17 The P.L.O. has shifted its strategy. The organization has decided to give armed struggle against Israel priority over the peace process, spokesmen say. #14 Changing pattern in West Bank 1 Hussein's plan lacks money 15 The I.R.A.'s political arm is debating whether to stop boycotting the Irish Republic's Parliament.

title: Rates Finally Drop On Savings Bonds
description: As it has been hinting since April that it might do, the Treasury last week announced a substantial cut in the guaranteed 7 1/2 percent interest rate on United States Savings Bonds.

title: Miss Schneider Weds E. J. Morton
description: Matthild Catherine Schneider and E. James Morton, the president and chief operating officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company in Boston, were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. James D. Ford, a Lutheran minister and chaplain of the House of Representatives, officiated at the Willard Hotel.

title: NO 'INTERMISSIONS' FOR PROLIFIC PLAYWRIGHT
description: MICHAEL ABBENSETTS is a writer on a roll. The Guyanese playwright's comedy ''Alterations'' opened Oct. 25 at the Crossroads Theatre here, he has one play in production and is working on another commissioned by the Hampstead Theater in London and two more for British television.

title: Ferment at State Dept.
description: The State Department has begun putting into effect an ''up-or-out'' program that an employees association says will lead to 90 percent of all Foreign Service officers being dropped before reaching normal retirement age.

title: NEW 'STAR TREK' PLAN REFLECTS SYMBIOSIS OF TV AND MOVIES
description: When Paramount executives speak of ''Star Trek,'' it is with a mixture of religious fervor and awe. ''Star Trek'' is ''our crown jewel,'' ''our priceless asset,'' a precious resource that ''must not be squandered.''

title: DAY-CARE CENTER FACING EVICTION
description: BARRING any last-minute legal action, Long Island's only day-care facility that handles both children and the elderly will be forced to shut down on Tuesday, leaving most of the 139 youngsters and seniors with no alternative care.

title: Writing to Authors
description: To the Editor:

title: HATCHERY PLAN ON LAKE STIRS A VERMONT DISPUTE
description: Environmentalists and lakefront landowners are squaring off against the state over its plan to build a fish hatchery on a spit of land jutting into Lake Champlain.

title: AFGHAN WAR IS NOT JUST A MATTER OPF TIMETABLES
description: PAKISTANI and American officials were voicing some optimism earlier this year about the possibility of a negotiated settlement to end the war in Afghanistan and bring a withdrawal of more than 100,000 Soviet troops. But now the consensus in Pakistan is that the diplomatic and military stalemate is so severe that it is likely to prolong the war, which began months before Soviet troops moved across the border in large numbers in December 1979.

title: Murray Rallies Texas A&M
description: Keith Murray passed for three touchdowns, including the 34-yard game-winner with 1 minute 48 seconds left, to rally Texas A&M to a 39-35 Southwest Conference victory today over Southern Methodist.

title: THE OLD-FASHIONED BUMPER STICKER IS STILL HOLDING UP ITS END
description: MY favorite bumper sticker of all time was mounted on the back of an aging Ford pickup, traveling south on a highway near Knoxville, Tenn. A rifle was visible in the rear window. The bumper sticker proclaimed: ''God, Guns and Grits Made America Great.''

title: POSTINGS: 15,000 Realtors; Conventioneers
description: The theme of this year's National Association of Realtors convention is networking, and opportunities to make friends and deals ought to abound as 15,000 brokers, developers and sales agents meet here from Thursday through Nov. 11. The 79th annual convention of the trade association, said to be the biggest in the United States, will be divided between the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and the New York Hilton, with special workshops going on at other hotels as well.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: WASHINGTON BEDTIME STORIES: The Politics of Money and Jobs. By Herbert Stein. (Free Press, $19.95.) ''Washington Bedtime Stories'' is a collection of essays that range from earnest luncheon speeches and articles written for academic journals to downright goofy satires.

title: HETERODOXY WAS HIS DOXY
description: VOLTAIRE By A. J. Ayer. 182 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: YORK COLLEGE IN QUEENS GETS A PERMANENT HOME
description: After 20 years of growing pains, York College of the City University of New York, a symbol of upward mobility for working-class students and a cornerstone of the hopes for redevelopment of Jamaica, Queens, finally has a permanent, $100 million home.

title: Savoring The Art And Mystery of Flamenco
description: Just when it seemed time to lament that Spain's great flamenco dancers had all died out, along comes ''Flamenco Puro,'' an assembly of various flamenco singers, dancers and guitarists who are completely superb. The production that Claudio Segovia and Hector Orezzoli have put together at the Mark Hellinger Theater might seem to take a cue from their previous hit, ''Tango Argentino'' - the dancers again do not belong to one company but are loosely linked through a series of numbers.

title: YES, I ADMIT, GOD IS GOD
description: CLIVE STAPLES LEWIS A Dramatic Life. By William Griffin. Illustrated. 507 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $24.95.

title: FOR CECILIA GASDIA, SINGING AND ACTING ARE INSEPARABLE
description: The Metropolitan Opera has come under fire recently for its failure to engage important new singers quickly enough. But in the case of Cecilia Gasdia, perhaps the most widely admired of the younger Italian sopranos, the Met has moved with some alacrity.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Shoe Prices Are Off And Falling Fast The Shoe Bazaar has two county locations, in Briarcliff Manor and Hartsdale, plus Stamford and Westport stores in Connecticut with shoes, boots, slippers and sneakers in women's sizes 5 1/2 to 10, with 10 to 15 percent off suggested retail prices.

title: Resignation and Disaffection
description: If the trend persists, all that will be left of the Ethiopian Government will be all that are left. The latest in a series of resignations by Ethiopian officials protesting their Government's authoritarian brand of Marxism came last week when the Foreign Minister, Goshu Wolde, announced his resignation at the United Nations. Mr. Wolde, a member of the Ethiopian Communist Party's Central Committee, said he could not ''continue to serve a Government whose short-sighted and rigidly doctrinaire policies are leading the country into misery and destruction.''

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Cluster Laws Gain as a Preservation Tool
description: ASURGE of new home construction is under way in central and east Brookhaven and in the Town of Riverhead. But the thousands of acres of pine woods and farmland that remain undeveloped in Suffolk County will not be engulfed by the kind of suburban sprawl that has overtaken most of the rest of the Island.

title: BEHT HENLEY WRITES A 'REAL, REAL PERSONAL' MOVIE
description: A touring Shakespearean troupe arrives in a small town at the start of ''Nobody's Fool,'' the new film written by the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Beth Henley. The play they perform is ''The Tempest,'' a choice that adroitly alludes to the theme of the movie itself. ''The Tempest,'' Shakespeare's final play, was his valedictory to the world of theater, his tribute to the power of what he deprecatingly called ''this insubstantial pageant'' to elevate the human soul.

title: OFFSHORE DISPUTE IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: A small grant from the University of Texas to the State of New Hampshire and ultimately the University of New Hampshire has touched off a sharp environmental dispute here.

title: STATE WEIGHS CATCHING TOLL CHEATS
description: AN EXPERIMENTAL program designed to catch toll cheaters on the Garden State Parkway appears to have been successful, but New Jersey Highway Authority officials say more time is needed to determine if it is effective enough to use regularly.

title: Headliners; Departure Amid Scandal
description: Perhaps political science will one day explain why official scandal in Great Britain so often centers not on a public figure accused of making money illicitly but on one accused of spending it questionably. Last week, in an affair that dredged up memories of the Profumo case in 1963 and the 1983 case of Cecil Parkinson, the Conservative Party Chairman, Jeffrey Archer, the best-selling author and deputy chairman of the Conservatives, resigned from his party post after a newspaper reported that he had paid off a prostitute, one Monica Coghlan.

title: Kenya Seizes Elephant Tusks
description: Custom agents seized nearly 1,000 elephant tusks valued at $250,000 Friday after finding the ivory hidden among bags of wheat at the port of Mombasa, an official said today.

title: POLICE CLASH WITH MOSLEMS IN CAPE TOWN PROTEST
description: Groups of Moslems stoned policemen who used whips to break up a protest meeting in downtown Cape Town today, and the police fired tear gas at mourners at a funeral in a segregated black township outside the city, the Government said.

title: Should All Series Games Be At Night?
description: At least one World Series game should be a day game, because few things in life satisfy as completely as the sight of a trimmed green baseball diamond under a blue sky. The feeling of playing hookey is unavoidable. Come out into the sunlight and play. The rest of the world can attend to its chores. We, lucky us, are going to play. JOHN AVERILL New York

title: Exotic Weavings Of Ancient Peru
description: What the Pre-Columbian Peruvians expressed in textiles woven 2,000 years ago confounds many 20th-century experts, who admit they are unable to fathom how some of these masterpieces were crafted. The public may well agree, on viewing the sophistication of the weaving skills and the wide-ranging esthetic sensibilities documented in ''Ancient Peruvian Textiles,'' selected by Jack Lenor Larsen, installed at Edward H. Merrin, 724 Fifth Avenue (at 57th Street), through Nov. 22.

title: STATE BANS FISHING AT 9 TAINTED PONDS
description: NINE ponds and small reservoirs on Long Island have been declared off-limits for fishing by the State Department of Environmental Conservation because of the presence of PCB's and the pesticide chlordane in fish.

title: Vying For the America's Cup
description: In his article ''Racing to Bring Home the Cup'' (Oct. 5), Christopher Buckley's assertion that ''the Australian's dazzling innovation may well have been illegal'' has long been put to rest as incorrect by all international-class experts, including the Rules Committee, ''absent'' the New York Yacht Club.

title: HOT LINE ON RISK IN PREGNANCY
description: PREGNANT women who are concerned that they may have eaten, breathed or been exposed to a substance that could harm their unborn child can call a toll-free telephone number for up-to-date information on such substances.

title: An Urgent Call For Help on AIDS
description: The National Academy of Sciences last week cited danger and even predicted ''catastrophe'' in the absence of a much-improved Federal effort to fight AIDS.

title: Land Sale Troubles The Preservationists
description: THE announcement a few weeks ago that the Hydraulic Company, a private water utility based in Bridgeport, was seeking permission from Connecticut's regulatory authorities to sell off part of its vast land holdings in Fairfield County has set off waves of controversy and confusion.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE STORIES OF MURIEL SPARK. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Many of Muriel Spark's stories turn on events that are supernatural or preternatural, our reviewer, David Lodge, said in 1985. The most ''stunningly original'' piece in this collection, he said, is ''The First Year of My Life,'' a view of World War I through the eyes of a baby, which ''achieves its effect by a breathtaking compression.'' PIONEER JEWS: A New Life in the Far West, by Harriet Rochlin and Fred Rochlin. (Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) The Jewish immigrant experience may conjure up visions of the Lower East Side, but in fact thousands of Jews were living in the mining towns, ranches and trading posts of the American West in 1880. There were Jewish 49ers in California, Jewish members of the Tombstone, Ariz., Fire Department, a Jewish mayor of Tucson, Jewish cowboys and even a Jew who fought at the Alamo. In this illustrated social history, Harriet Rochlin and Fred Rochlin document how Jews participated in frontier development, concentrating mainly on the territory between the Pacific and the Rockies before 1912. Our reviewer, Henry Mayer, said last year that while the book presents facts more successfully than it analyzes them, the work is ''packed with information and anecdotes likely to surprise most readers.'' AUTHOR FROM A SAVAGE PEOPLE, by Bette Pesetsky. (G. K. Hall, $5.95.) May Alto, a successful ghostwriter, has just helped one of her famous clients win the Nobel Prize and threatens to expose him unless he gives her the award money.

title: POP: CRACK-DOWN, AN ECLECTIC BENEFIT CONCERT
description: HEAVILY policed and not quite sold out, the Crack-Down concert Friday night at Madison Square Garden was more like an indoor rock festival than a concert for a cause.

title: TV GUIDE TO ELECTION
description: LONG Island television viewers can choose from an assortment of election-night programs presented by public television, UHF stations and cable systems.

title: Designs for Living From Two Different Eras
description: In most museums, great or not so great, life moves on tiptoe in the rooms devoted to the decorative arts.

title: Q AND A
description: Inheritance Tax Question: My sister and I recently inherited the house we live in; there were no other claims against the will. Will we have to go to Probate Court? Also, how can I find out the inheritance-tax rate? . . . A. T., Brooklyn Answer: Stephen Mighdoll, a Manhattan real-estate lawyer, says that, for proper transfer of title to the property, the will must be probated, at which time the executor will deliver a document known as an executor's deed to the beneficiaries. To protect your interest in the property as beneficiaries, you and your sister should then record the deed with the County Clerk in the county where the property is situated.

title: PINE BARRENS: MAN AS THE PROBLEM
description: WHEN Governor Cuomo and other officials recently trekked to the Long Island pine barrens to campaign for the state's $1.45 billion environmental bond issue on Tuesday's ballot, they proclaimed great concern for the environment.

title: Meg Ann Mortimer Is Bride
description: Meg Ann Mortimer, the daughter of Irene Davidson of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Bruce Mortimer of New York, was married last evening to David Mordechai Schreier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Schreier of Birmingham, Mich. Rabbi Israel Halpern performed the ceremony at the Eden Roc Hotel in Miami Beach. The bride is an owner of Ambrosio-Mortimer & Associates Inc., a talent agency in New York. Mr. Schreier is an associate in the New York law firm of Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen.

title: ITHACA, UNION STAY UNBEATEN
description: George Mack, a senior split end, became Ithaca's career reception leader today as the Bombers remained unbeaten with their seventh victory, 28-3 over Hobart (4-3). Ithaca, ranked third among Division III teams, improved its record to 7-0. Mack caught six passes for 82 yards, surpassing Jim Duncan on Ithaca's career reception list. Mack has 85 catches for a school-record 1,544 receiving yards.

title: For Skywalkers
description: With brisk weather expected as the year's busiest shopping season approaches, Lord & Taylor has more on its mind than its customers and their tastes in holiday decor. The 160-year-old department store on Fifth Avenue between 38th and 39th Streets is also concerned about its employees and their comfort.

title: Cuomo, O'Rourke Cross Swords But Shed No Blood
description: It was boring, as political debates go, but then that was what made it interesting. After months of implying dreadful things about each other, Governor Cuomo and his chief challenger, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, said they really had not meant to.

title: Enrile Turns Up The Flame
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile's presidential ambitions were frustrated for years by the Philippine strongman, Ferdinand E. Marcos. Now, under the terms of a draft constitution, Mr. Enrile's chance would be postponed for at least six more years while Corazan C. Aquino remains President.

title: Caroline Reed to Wed Frederick Taylor
description: The engagement of Caroline Stevens Reed to Frederick Blackburn Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Taylor of Denver, has been announced by Mrs. Roslyn Thomas Reed Jr. of New York and North Haven, Me., mother of the future bride.

title: ANGLICAN HOPEFUL ABOUT HOSTAGES
description: Terry Waite, a special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, says he is cautiously optimistic that some of the American and French hostages being held in Lebanon might be freed, a spokesman for the Archbishop said today.

title: HEADING FOR A SHOWDOWN WITH THE VOTERS
description: AFTER almost a year of campaigning and squabbling among the candidates, Connecticut voters will get their chance Tuesday to choose an administration to run the state for the next four years and to pick a United States Senator for the next six years.

title: Brothers Work as a Team
description: When Rich Aube caught a touchdown pass on John Jay's first possesion this year, a feeling of relief swept over him and his teammates. The Indians were being directed by a new quarterback, Rich's brother Andy, a junior without experience at the varsity level. So any pregame jitters, particularly fraternal ones, were to be expected.

title: Kevin P. Sweeney Is Wed To Meredith Ann Everett
description: Meredith Ann Everett, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Morris Everett of Holmdel, N.J., and Kevin Patrick Sweeney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Sweeney of Avon-by-the-Sea, N.J., were married yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd in Holmdel. The Rev. George J. Frank Jr. performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Herman G. Stuempfle, president of the Lutheran Theological Seminary in Gettysburg, Pa.

title: Natt Out for Season
description: THE first big victory of the season turned out to be a major loss for the Denver Nuggets. As Denver was on its way to a 134-104 rout of the San Antonio Spurs in the season opener Friday night, Calvin Natt, a veteran forward who averaged 17.5 points a game last season, suffered a ruptured Achilles' tendon that is expected to knock him out for the season.

title: Miss Kessler To Marry Jonathan Gabriel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Kessler of Pomona, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia-Anne Kessler, to Jonathan Howard Grabel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Grabel of Scarsdale, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Australia Enters the Gold Bullion Market
description: The Perth Mint is producing proof versions of the new Australian Nugget gold bullion coins. Orders are now being taken. The Australian Nuggets come in the same four sizes as the gold American Eagles. Unlike their American cousins, all four are being struck in proof. The coins derive their name from the fact that each depicts a famous gold nugget found by Australian miners. The 1-ounce piece portrays the ''Welcome Stranger'' nugget thought to be the largest ever recorded. It was found in 1869 in Moliagul, Victoria, and weighed 2,284 net ounces. The smaller coins feature the ''Hand of Faith,'' ''Golden Eagle'' and ''Little Hero'' nuggets. Each coin carries a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II by artist Stuart Devlin.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE DARKLING SEASON...
description: UPON awakening in the first days of November, there is a sense that something irrevocable has happened. In the Northeast, although the sun has sunk lower daily since June, the world seems suddenly changed.

title: DID SUGAR GET TO BE TOO GOOD A DEAL?
description: OCTOBER was always a special month in Fort Morgan, Colo.

title: Taking the 'Ma' out of 'Ma Siemens'
description: THE news last July that France's leading telephone company was buying the ITT Corporation's telecommunications business made headlines in the United States and Europe. But few people read the reports as attentively as Karlheinz Kaske, chief executive of Siemens A.G., the giant West German electrical company. The deal posed a threat to Siemens, since the ITT package included Standard Elektrik Lorenz, a major Siemens competitor in German telecommunications. Worse still, it was taking place just as the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was angling to buy a share in France's second-largest telecommunications company - thus raising the prospect of two French-American telecommunications partnerships.

title: COLLEGES IN U.S. NEED OVERHAUL, STUDY CONTENDS
description: The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching called yesterday for an overhaul of undergraduate education, including the dropping of standardized admission tests as a requirement at most colleges and universities.

title: It's Not What's Said, But Who Hears
description: FOR months, Senator Paula Hawkins, caught in a very tight race for re-election in Florida, has been filming campaign commercials on issues ranging from Social Security to drug abuse. While Robert Goodman, her media consultant, worried about what her positions should be, a few computer consultants, hunkered down over six I.B.M. personal computers in Virginia, were deciding when and onw hat progams they would be heard.

title: STATE APPLE CROP DOWN 15% AND PRICES RISE
description: With the apple harvest just completed, the State Crop Reporting Service said today that New York's crop would be down 15 percent from last year.

title: A Microscopic Look at Macro Lenses
description: WHAT does it mean when a lens carries the designation ''macro''? If you don't know the answer to the question, don't feel ashamed; most camera and lens makers don't know what ''macro'' means, either.

title: Making Tracks Around the Globe
description: I jog. Not in quest of a spiritual high, not to win marathon trophies, not to become a Senator from California, not to recapture the zest of my 20's (a myth in any case) - but largely out of crass instincts of self-preservation. A decade ago, I sped wildly through Madrid at the wheel of a Volkswagen station wagon with one of my best friends stretched out in the back stricken with a heart attack; colleagues, we had shared the stresses, and joys, of the reporter's existence in Saigon and Beirut, the same type-A, roller-coaster life style. It didn't take much analysis to realize that if I didn't do something about taking care of the one body God gave me I would probably meet a similar fate. (My friend recovered and is doing fine.) So I started to run. The first time around the block in suburban Madrid - in tennis shoes - I thought I wouldn't make it. But, as any jogger knows, the beginning is the most daunting part, and soon I was making a 25-minute trot down my street in Aravaca, through the underpass of the highway leading to Avila and Segovia (past a ferocious but mercifully chained yapping watchdog), left past a cemetery (visited on the weekends by black-creped families bearing bright flowers) and along a broad open space of hayfields to the walls of the Zarzuela Palace, where King Juan Carlos and his family resides. (Palace is a misnomer: It's really a mock-Tudor country house enveloped in an oversize park inhabited by deer.)

title:
ART;
WORKS BY A VICTORIAN ARTIST WHO KNEW AND LOVED BOATS
description: THERE is genuine pleasure in discovering an artist who works in a genre little known to you and to realize that there's a whole rich and resonant world involved in your discovery.

title: MEESE, THE LAWMAN, CALLS FOR ANARCHY
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d asserted last week that legislatures and government officials are not bound by the Supreme Court's interpretation of the Constitution. They may contradict the Court and follow their own interpretations when enacting laws or adopting policies, he said. Although Mr. Meese's position is untenable, the reasons are more complicated than appear at first glance.

title:
GARDENING;
FOR THE VARIED VIRTUES OF SPRING BULBS
description: ALTHOUGH they are not exceptionally demanding, spring bulbs depend the right planting techniques and conditions. The site is most important. Such earlier-flowering sorts as snowdrops and crocus will do well beneath deciduous trees and shrubs, because they mature before the leaves reappear in the spring.

title: PARTIES HEIGHTEN EFFORTS TO BRING VOTERS TO POLLS
description: Seeking to break the deadlock in a campaign that has involved enormous expenditures but little passion, the nation's politicians, including President Reagan, implored their partisans yesterday to cast ballots Tuesday.

title: SONG OF PEACE FROM PRETORIA STIRS RANCOR
description: The South African Government issued a $1.9 million song for peace this week that has run into strong criticism from opposition groups.

title: Hill Routs Blair, 31-6
description: Andres Nevares ran for three first-half touchdowns of 31, 6 and 6 yards, and John Gvodes added a 35-yard touchdown run as the Hill School trounced Blair Academy, 31-6, at Blairstown yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TERRORISM DEBATE G. Gordon Liddy - ex-lawyer, ex-prosecutor, ex-F.B.I. agent and ex-convict - will debate Dr. Hatem I. Hassaini, an educator and former Palestinian observer at the United Nations, at Rutgers-Camden Thursday. The subject will be terrorism. Of all the convicted Watergate conspirators, only Mr. Liddy refused to plea-bargain or incriminate others; because of this, he was imprisoned longer than anyone else involved in the 1972 break-in at the Democratic Party's national headquarters in Washington. He was released from prison in 1977, when President Jimmy Carter reduced his 21-year-sentence.

title: The Physical Eds
description: At 1 P.M. on Sundays, when virtually all Washingtonians seem to be glued to their television sets to watch the Redskins play football, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett leads a team of his own, called the Physical Eds, in a sandlot football game at a public playground.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Evanston, Ill.; Cutting Risks At Science Park
description: DEVELOPING a research park is a risky business, often costing more time and money than it yields in jobs and tax dollars. But, after a year, Northwestern University and Evanston officials think they have come up with a successful formula to create a 26-acre park west of the campus, although it faces a referendum Tuesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, captions last week on page 45 of Home Entertaining, part 2 of The Times Magazine, describing table settings were reversed. It was the upper picture that included an etched decanter with silver stopper; the Victorian sterling-silver biscuit warmer was in the lower grouping.

title: PUPILS ASK TO SMOKE AT SCHOOLS
description: DESPITE a School Board ban on students' smoking at school, some administrators and teachers at Longwood High School in Yaphank are supporting a student petition to permit outdoor smoking at the school.

title: THE GUIDE
description: MUSIC WEEK EVENTS More than 800 events are scheduled nationwide in celebration of American Music Week today through next Sunday. Three of them will take place at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.

title: F.A.A. Tightens Rules on Planes Near Big Airports
description: High on the list of questions raised by the Aug. 31 collision of a commercial jet and a private plane over the Los Angeles suburb of Cerritos, which killed 82 people, was whether restrictions on small aircraft near busy airports should be tightened.

title: CHARITY'S WAYS CHANGE, BUT NOT THE NEED
description: THOUGH the way Americans show their charity has changed over the years, John H. Filer, a Hartford philanthropist, is optimistic that we will continue to be generous - despite such things as the new tax law and the impersonal nature of much of modern life.

title: Auburn Is Upset By Florida, 18-17
description: Kerwin Bell, still hobbling with a knee sprain, capped an 18-point fourth-quarter rally today by scrambling for a 2-point conversion with 36 seconds remaining to give Florida an 18-17 upset of fifth-ranked Auburn.

title: FINE CELTIC HARPS VICTIMS OF FLOOD The New York Times Regional Newspapers
description: Chris and Theresa Caswell's backyard shop had gained recognition worldwide as the birthplace of some of the finest Celtic harps available, until the Caswells abruptly stopped taking new orders.

title: FLORIDA GOVERNOR RACE REVIVES 2-PARTY POLITICS
description: Even in the days when northern Florida was ruled by local sheriffs and the backroom boys, Lafayette County rated low in rural power and just about everywhere else except in the hearts of the few thousand people who lived there.

title: ANTI-SEXUAL HARASSMENT UNIT AIDS TENANTS
description: New York State has created a special unit to assist victims of sexual harassment by landlords and their employees in rent-regulated housing throughout the state.

title: EVERYONE'S A CRITIC
description: PUBLIC art frequently breeds public controversy, say such commentators as Judith Sneddon, the director of East Hampton's Guild Hall and former head of Suffolk County's Office of Cultural Affairs.

title: Maneuvering a Modified Endgame
description: As the American Contract Bridge League has belatedly recognized during the past two years, young players in this country get far less encouragement to take up the game than they would on the other side of the Atlantic. Many European countries have programs in schools and interscholastic competitions. For the enthusiast there is a summer camp in a different country each year and the goal of international competition: The European Junior Championships, for national teams with an age limit of 26.

title: Q & A
description: Money Belts

title: EXCERPTS FROM CARNEGIE FOUNDATION REPORT ON EDUCATION AT U.S. COLLEGES
description: Following are excerpts from ''College: The Undergraduate Experience in America,'' released yesterday by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching:

title: CAMPAIGNING DRAWS TO A CLOSE ACROSS THE COUNTY
description: WITH two days left before the election, there are no signs that campaigning for Congress in the 20th District in Westchester - perhaps the most hotly contested local race in the metropolitan area - will slacken off.

title: ENVY IN THE AFTERNOON
description: SURVIVING SEXUAL CONTRADICTIONS A Startling and Different Look at a Day in the Life of a Contemporary Professional Woman. By Muriel Dimen. 257 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY: THE COUNTRY WINS
description: I HAVE always been a city zealot. I spent my childhood in cities, at 10 took what was then the Hudson Tube from downtown Jersey City to fifth grade in the West Village. My father, a clergyman who fled upper-class country life for a ministry among the urban poor, trained his children to thrive on city adversity. As the oldest, I was the pioneer. I moved to New York in my early 20's in 1969, ignored the squalor, made a life rich in feminism, poetry, theater and like-minded friends in the urban landscape I fiercely loved.

title: STUDENT JOURNALISTS TO MEET AT RUTGERS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Daniel Jackson and Christopher Ogle, a sophomore at Spotswood High School, Spotswood, where Mr. Jackson teaches journalism.

title: Lincoln Wins to CLinch Title
description: Lincoln (8-0) clinched a Brooklyn Division A title with a 25-21 come-from-behind victory over Madison (4-3). The Railsplitters drove 98 yards with less than 2 minutes left in the game to score the winning touchdown.

title: OLFACTORY VIGILANCE
description: THE FOUL AND THE FRAGRANT Odor and the French Social Imagination. By Alain Corbin. 307 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: NOBEL LAUREATE IN CHEMISTRY
description: Dr. Robert S. Mulliken, a University of Chicago scientist and Nobel laureate who helped propel chemistry into the atomic era, died Friday in Arlington, Va., at the home of his daughter. He was 90 years old and had moved there from Chicago a year ago after 58 years on the university's faculty.

title: DANCE: THE REBECCA KELLY COMPANY
description: THE works by Rebecca Kelly that the Rebecca Kelly Dance Company brought to Symphony Space Thursday night contained striking images. Yet in these choreographic pictures important details were occasionally blurred.

title: Lancaster and Douglas: A Chemistry Lesson
description: ''They don't make them like they used to,'' Kenny Rogers sings over the opening titles of ''Tough Guys.'' Viewers may find the lyrics to that title tune rather corny, but when Burt Lancaster and Kirk Douglas stroll on screen in their stylish 40's suits and hats, few will feel inclined to argue with the sentiment. Watching the grace and panache with which Mr. Lancaster, 72, and Mr. Douglas, 69, make mincemeat of a variety of thugs and buffoons half their age, most viewers will probably agree with the 17-year-old boy who wrote on his preview card, ''I can't wait to get old.''

title: ALL TYPES AT ALL HOURS
description: Jubilation Dance Nov. 2 - The five-year-old Jubiliation! Dance Company not only nourishes young black dancers in an artistic environment, it also involves them in the administration and management of the company. A 4 P.M. benefit performance for the company followed by a buffet supper will be held at Aaron Davis Hall at City College, 134th Street and Convent Avenue, with free parking available. Tickets, $35, at the door. Artistic Jubilee Nov. 3 - Opera and dance stars and companies will be out in force at the American Guild of Musical Artists' 50th anniversary benefit for its relief fund, which provides aid to dancers, singers and stage personnel throughout the United States. Alvin Ailey, Grace Bumbry, Merce Cunningham, Robert Joffrey, James McCracken, Anna Moffo, Renata Scotto along with performers from Mummenschanz, the American Ballet Theater, the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera are among those expected at the 7:30 P.M. performance at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. A supper follows at the theater. Tickets, $500 for supper and prefered seating and $25 to $250 for performance alone. Tickets, 212-944-9300. Recalling the '60's... Nov. 3 - The Youth Counseling League is a voluntary agency in New York City and Westchester that counsels emotionally troubled adolescents and young adults at low or no cost. A masked ball benefit for the league with a 1960's theme of go-go dancers, a samba band and ''The Commuters,'' aimed at the 21-to-35 year age group, starts at 9 P.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street.

title: First Day on the Job
description: NOTING the team had suffered ''deep scars'' that only time could heal, Bob Wade conducted his first practice yesterday as the head basketball coach at the University of Maryland, two days after being hired to replace Charles G. (Lefty) Driesell, who had coached the Terrapins for 17 years. The practice emphasized running: half-court, quarter-court, full-court, side to side.

title: TAPES BY BENNY GOODMAN TO FINANCE HIS ARCHIVES AT YALE
description: FOR three decades before his death this year, Benny Goodman, the ''King of Swing,'' had close ties to Yale University's music department, and those ties continue.

title: Life After Politics
description: PATRICK H. CADDELL, a Democratic poll-taker and strategist, has announced that this is his last political campaign, at least as a paid consultant and unless ''a personal friend'' of his, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, seeks the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL STUDIES HISTORY, RULES ON THE FUTURE
description: SUBJECT: Skyscraper planned for 250 Water Street in lower Manhattan. Finding: ''The proposed scale, size, mass and volume of the 30-story tower would dominate and overwhelm the neighboring buildings.'' Status: Application denied.

title: DRUG LAW RAISES MORE THAN HOPE
description: AT the Customs Service's annual awards ceremony in September, Commissioner William von Raab called Adm. Paul A. Yost Jr. to the podium. Ceremoniously, he presented the Coast Guard commandant with a plastic model of a Navy E2-C radar plane, a tiny bottle of red paint and a brush.

title: 'Colorization' Is Defacing Black and White Film Classics
description: In the nearly 50 years since its release, ''Topper'' has not aged especially well. It's a movie best rerun in the memory. Its trick photography, by which the recently dead George and Marion Kerby can fade into translucence, then to complete invisibility and back again, has long since lost its comic surprise. The film's pacing now seems elephantine and the dialogue arch. Yet George and Marion Kerby, as played by the young, already incomparable Cary Grant and the feline-sleek Constance Bennett, somehow retain the madcap appeal they had in 1937.

title:
ART;
BRACH RETROSPECTIVE: MORE AND LESS THAN NEEDED
description: MORE often than not, one-person exhibitions billed as ''retrospectives'' either tell you more than you ever wanted to know about an artist's career, or they do not tell you enough. In the case of the current exhibition of paintings by Paul Brach at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, the imbalance in favor of recent work gives us more than enough of the past decade and less than we need of the preceding two.

title:
ART;
DREWES OILS, WATERCOLORS AND PRINTS AT THE PRINCETON GALLERY
description: IN AN interview in 1984, the year before he died, Werner Drewes compared himself with Picasso, who had been a child prodigy.

title: HOTELS DISPUTE CHARGES IN SUIT
description: THE use of hotels as emergency shelters for homeless people in New York City is deemed satisfactory by almost no one involved in the process. But if the Koch administration would prefer not to have to use more of them, it does want the option to do so.

title: HOTTEST RACE? A LOCAL JUDGESHIP
description: IN New Canaan, as in so many other towns where most local elections inspire little more than polite yawns, Dick Stewart has been waging an aggressive campaign.

title: CUOMO CAMPAIGNS IN LEGISLATIVE RACES
description: Governor Cuomo - in one of the few times this fall that he has taken to the streets to campaign - asked a Brooklyn rally yesterday to help him do a better job in a second term by electing Democratic legislators.

title: A VARIED FIELD VIES FOR FOUR STATE POSTS
description: IN addition to electing a governor, lieutenant governor, senator and representatives to Congress, Connecticut voters across the state will cast ballots on Tuesday for a secretary of the state, treasurer, comptroller and attorney general.

title: TERRIFIED AND FASCINATED BY HIS OWN LIFE
description: HIS WAY The Unauthorized Biography of Frank Sinatra. By Kitty Kelley. Illustrated. 575 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: LOCAL ISSUES WILL DECIDE OUTCOMES ON ELECTION DAY
description: THE ballot for Tuesday's election will be a busy one, with contests for the House of Representatives and county and local offices and two public questions dealing with hazardous waste, but the outcomes of the races will generally be decided on local issues.

title: MAN GULITY IN '75 DEATH OF WIFE
description: Relatives of Donna Howard, a rodeo trick rider, spent 11 years trying to refute a coroner's report that she was killed when she was kicked in the head by a horse.

title: Vietnam Giving Up Remains Of 3 More American G.I.'s
description: Vietnam said it would soon hand over to the United States authorities what appeared to be the remains of three Americans missing since the Vietnam War, an American official said today.

title: ELECTRONIC JAIL
description: To reduce jail overcrowding, a Florida manufacturer recently suggested to county legislators, Westchester homes could be converted into ''electronic prisons.'' Representatives of the Controlled Activities Corporation, in a meeting with members of the Board of Legislators' Committee on Public Safety, explained that the key is an electronic ''supervisor,'' a contact radio transmitter attached to a prisoner's ankle.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CONVIVIAL CAFE IN IRVINGTON
description: OF the pretty old towns that stretch along the Hudson, Irvington is special. Westward from Broadway the town's main street runs in a cozy stretch perpendicular to the river and packs shoulder to shoulder a handful of galleries, crafts shops and boutiques with stores offering more functional items and services. The charm spills to the side streets as well, where many of the town's old Victorian residences, modest in size though they may be, have been restored if not faithfully, then with a nod to the original architectural intention.

title: Measure Setting Standards On Energy Efficiency Vetoed
description: President Reagan today vetoed a bill that would have established minimum energy-efficiency standards for home appliances, arguing that it would cost consumers $1.4 billion.

title: A LOOK BACK AND A LOOK FORWARD FIND THE VIEW BLEAK FOR APPALACHIA
description: On the 25th anniversary of its writing, a celebration here of one of the most powerfully successful muckraking books of the century, Harry M. Caudill's ''Night Comes to the Cumberlands,'' turned into a dreary forecast of more, and perhaps worse, deprivation for the people of Appalachia.

title: FLEXIBLE BENEFITS: A GROWING CHOICE
description: WHEN it comes to employee benefits, one size no longer fits all. Conventional plans that provide standard benefits to all employees are losing ground to flexible plans that let employees custom-tailor the benefits to fit individual needs.

title: U.S. AND STATE POLICIES ON WASTE HELD FLAWED
description: EVEN $1.6 billion will not clean up all 228 sites in New Jersey's hazardous-waste cleanup program, so how well that money is spent is as important as how much is spent.

title: ...OR A BOUQUET OF ROTTEN EGGS
description: I would like Jonathan M. Weisberg to know - he is obviously blissfully unaware of it - that there are many people (and not only pregnant women) who are so inconvenienced by cigars that their stomach literally turns over at what their senses perceive as untolerable stench - not unlike skunk or rotten egg bouquet.

title: Anne Vlahos Engaged To F. Michael Zachara
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Zachary J. Vlahos of Saltsburg, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Anne Wagner Vlahos to F. Michael Zachara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Zachara of Ridgewood, N.J., and Chester, N.Y.

title: G.O.P. SEEN RETAINING LOCAL EDGE
description: JUST two years after a Republican President won a landslide victory on Long Island, most politicians expect that Governor Cuomo, a Democrat, will sweep Nassau and Suffolk Counties in Tuesday's election.

title:
ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS;
Saving for Uncle Sam
description: Every Tuesday was War Bond day at the small elementary school in Leesburg, Fla., where Fred and Kay Ross grew up. Like millions of schoolchildren during World War II, they participated in the Government's savings stamp program.

title: NATIONAL ROLE IS SEEN FOR ARIZONA NOMINEE
description: After a run of horrendously bad luck, Representative John McCain has been blessed with good fortune of an extraordinary kind, and he now seems poised to emerge as a significant figure in national politics, as a member of the United States Senate.

title: Garden City Ties West Hempstead
description: Garden City and West Hempstead entered yesterday's game tied for the lead of Nassau County's Conference 2 with 5-0 records. By the end of the game, neither could claim even a slight edge, finishing in a scoreless tie.

title: America's Profile Shifts
description: The exodus from suburbs and cities to rural areas bespeaks deep-rooted American desires for new frontiers, independence and open spaces (''America's Profile Shifts,'' by John Herbers, Sept. 28). But in the headlong rush to occupy the remaining quiet corners that private wealth will buy, we will do to the land what we have always done.

title: Luxury on a Sea of Champagne
description: The first view we had of the Sea Goddess was at the Riva Dei Martini near St. Mark's Square in Venice.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: When Barbara Howar hears about someone who is fanatically neat, she's likely to look smug and sprinkle ''tsks tsks'' around like confetti. She can do this, she said, only because she's worked hard at controlling her own ''dreadful neatness phobia,'' so much so that she can now legitimately say that she is just this side of any and all ''tsks.'' ''I'm a part-time compulsive neat person,'' is how she describes herself, which isn't too bad for a Libra ''who gets really upset if I open my eyes and see chaos around me.''

title: The Joy of Buying
description: To the Editor:

title: Tav Holmes Is Engaged to Peter Berry
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. James Edward Holmes of Fort Worth of the engagement of Dr. Holmes's daughter Mary Tavener Holmes to Peter Chamberlain Berry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rynn Berry of Oyster Bay, L.I., and New York. A February wedding is planned.

title: ...BRINGS A FIRE TO THE SOUL
description: AMONG the several things I would do better than the Deity, if I could replace Him and do anything, would be the minor improvement of making leaves so that we could burn them without polluting the environment.

title: MAN)EATING SYMBOLS
description: THE WEDDING AT PORT-AU-PRINCE By Hans Christoph Buch. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 259 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: ART OF IMPAIRED TO GO ON VIEW
description: AN EXHIBITION of artwork by students who are deaf, blind, multi-handicapped, autistic, learning disabled, neurologically impaired, mentally retarded, paraplegic or otherwise impaired opens Dec. 7 at the Jewish Community Center here.

title: No Headline
description: MAYOR Koch's proposal last week to build 20 new shelters for the homeless over the next two years came when the city's emergency shelter programs were under increasing pressure from courts and community groups, when hotel owners were beginning to balk at accepting the homeless and when winter was just weeks away.

title: A PRODUCER OF DOCUMENTARIES FINDS HAPPINESS IN THE MOVIES
description: ''A bCREENPLAY and a novel are different creatures,'' said Janet Roach of Shelter Island and Manhattan's East Side. ''A novel is much more expansive, and a screenplay is closer to haiku. Everything has to be foreshortened. You don't establish things necessarily with words. You establish things visually.''

title: CUSTOMERS RALLY TO SAVE SNACK BAR
description: CARMEN'S snack bar is not the kind of place that attracts attention, except perhaps as a relic of Somer's disappearing small town days. Little more than a hotdog stand, whose only landscaping consists of a row of dinette chairs facing the window, it is located on Route 100, half way between the sprawling campuses of the International Business Machines and Pepsico headquarters.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: PECKHAM'S MARBLES. By Peter De Vries. (Putnam, $17.95.) Earl Peckham, an essayist and novelist, writes minimalist prose for minute audiences. During a rest-home stay tending a faltering liver (''Nothing like a bout of hepatitis to make a chap look on the world with a jaundiced eye''), fortune offers him simultaneously a wealthy widow resembling Margaret Dumont and her genially bibulous niece resembling a lot more fun.

title: Future King's English
description: Although he cautioned readers to be on their guard about using like as a conjunction, Porter G. Perrin, in his 1939 ''Writer's Guide and Index to English,'' went on to say that ''this construction is worth careful observation to see if like gains sufficient reputability so that it can be safely used in writing.''

title: DANCE: BARRUNTO TROUPE IN BERRY'S 'WORKERS'
description: TALLER LATINOAMERICANO describes itself as providing ''cross-cultural programming in an open environment.'' A program presented on Thursday, as part of a continuing ''North-South Dance Festival,'' certainly lived up to that description. Quiet intelligence and an open-minded view of dance were hallmarks of this evening of dance by Jim Self, Ricardo Viviani and Barrunto Dancers.

title: KNICKS BESTED BY JORDAN'S 50
description: The joke circulating during the preseason concerning the talent-poor Chicago Bulls was that their games would all come down to exhibitions of one-on-five basketball. Their one is Michael Jordan.

title: HASENFUS TRIAL A FORUM FOR A FOE OF SANDINISTAS
description: Defending a captured American before a people's tribunal in Nicaragua is not a challenge many lawyers would relish.

title: SERVICE TRIES TO PUT ZEST INTO MEETINGS
description: EVERY year, the Dexter Corporation in Windsor Locks holds a securities analysts' meeting. And every year it's the same thing - ''old tired businessmen parading to the podium one by one to present their speeches,'' in the words of Worth Loomis, president of the corporation.

title: Jack Ascher Engaged To Jill M. Rosenbaum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Rosenbaum of Rochester and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Margret Rosenbaum to Jack S. Ascher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nino Ascher of Zurich.

title: POSTINGS: Completing Cadman Plaza; Condos for Bridge Watchers
description: It has been almost two decades since the completion of the vast majority of the buildings on the Cadman Plaza urban-renewal site in Brooklyn Heights. Now, after years of delays because of scarce funds and changing developers, the last project in the eight-block site is finally nearing completion.

title: Best Sellers: November 2, 1986
description: Fiction

title: 7 Religious Sect Members Burned to Death in Japan
description: Seven women from a religious sect doused themselves with kerosene today, set themselves on fire and burned to death on a beach, after their spiritual leader died, the police said.

title: PHILADEPHIA BOMBING SEQUEL: NEIGHBORS IN AN INSURANCE AD
description: Earl and Pearl Watkin, who lost their home in the confrontation between the police and a radical group here last year, are appearing in an advertisement for an insurance company.

title: Kathleen Sampson to Wed David Dixon Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Olin Sampson of Rye, N.Y., and Palm Desert, Calif., have announced that their daughter Kathleen Lynn Sampson and David Michael Dixon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dixon of Glendale, Calif., plan to be married Dec. 6.

title: Ouster of Yamani May Placate OPEC
description: Saudi Arabia replaced its very visible oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, in a surprise move that created turmoil in world oil markets. As OPEC squabbled over ways to get prices back up, Sheik Yamani was often the moderating voice. But now many OPEC members want to return to fixed prices, rather than production quotas, and Sheik Yamani had been perceived by some as an impediment. Saudi Arabia gave no reason for the Sheik's dismissal after 24 years, but many analysts believe the kingdom was under pressure from other OPEC members - particularly Iran, which needs higher oil revenues to finance its war with Iraq.

title: MOTHER AND SON, LOST IN A CONTINENT
description: TO THE LAND OF THE CATTAILS By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 148 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $14.95.

title: PROGRAMMABLE THERMOSTATS: BLOWING HOT OR COLD MADE EASY
description: MOST homeowners know that turning down the thermostat at night when everyone is asleep, and during the day when no one is home, saves money and energy.

title: RUSSIANS CANVASS AMERICAN EXPERTS
description: For the first time in memory, a Soviet research team is conducting an opinion poll among Americans. The purpose is to elicit views about the role of Soviet studies in the United States.

title: COMING WEEK IS SURE TO PLEASE FANS OF CHORAL MUSIC
description: THIS promises to be a good week for aficionados of choral music, and the listening pleasures begin today at 4 P.M. when the Pro Arte Singers of Connecticut perform at St. John's Episcopal Church in Stamford.

title: Skywalker Captures The Classic
description: The popular filly Lady's Secret probably earned the Horse of the Year title today with a routine victory on an afternoon of Breeders' Cup races marked by the defeats of the world's other top horses.

title: MIECZYSLAW MOCZAR, A LEADER IN POLAND'S COMMUNIST PARTY
description: Gen. Mieczyslaw Moczar, a former member of the Polish Politburo and a contender for leadership of the Communist Party, died today, the Polish press agency said. He was 72 years old.

title: FAVORITE HOLIDAY, BY A LANDSLIDE
description: EVERYONE has a favorite holiday.

title: Marshalling Forces
description: ''I had been analyzing the variation for many years and came to the conclusion that the attack must be sound. I am still of the same opinion. By this I do not mean that Black necessarily wins; I merely claim that the attack gives Black many winning chances and should be good for at least a draw.''

title: GLORIOUS NEW SUMMERS AWAIT CONEY ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTECTING WHISTLEBLOWERS
description: THE Conscientious Employee Protection Act - ''The Whistleblower Bill'' - was enacted in September, but it came too late to help Sgt. Trent Davis.

title: Tentative Pact Reached By 3 West Coast Papers
description: A tentative agreement on wages has been reached, averting a strike by 5,000 employees at The San Francisco Chronicle, The San Francisco Examiner and The San Jose Mercury News.

title: Going Private For Profit
description: THOUSANDS of tenant-shareholders in Mitchell-Lama co-ops in New York have enjoyed years of tax abatements and subsidized mortgages that kept their maintenance charges low, but now many of them are hoping for windfall profits, too.

title: FIGHTING TO SAVE HER SON
description: THE GIFT OF LIFE By Parichehr Yomtoob and Ted Schwarz. 229 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Test Pilot on Pointe

title: Saving on Sailing
description: Theoretically, one of the simplest vacations to arrange is a cruise. One ticket wraps it all up: transportation, accommodations, meals, entertainment, recreation - just about everything except optional shore excursions and tips.

title: FRENCH ELEGANCE IN STAMFORD
description: ''DEJA VU!'' one of our guests exclaimed on entering the long, softly lighted and L-shaped dining room of Le Mistral in Stamford. And indeed, we had been here before, when the restaurant had a different chef and name, but the same ownership. (Le Mistral, the cold, dry wind that sweeps through southern France, eludes us as the name for a pleasant restaurant.) While the configuration and decor remain much the same, with framed French posters on the wall, the setting has greater elegance. Tables are sparkling, set with violet and white china and a single fresh flower. Service, too, seems more upbeat and attentive.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CLASSIC ART Art lovers who yearn for something other than items hot off the easel have three opportunities these days to see what's new among the classics. Tomorrow the Hillwood Art Gallery at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville opens an exhibition of 60 drawings by 16 European masters. On loan from local residents, ''Drawing the Fine Line: Discovering European Drawings in Long Island Private Collections,'' features works by Cezanne, Daumier, Kandinsky, Leger, Matisse, Rubens, Picasso and Van Gogh. It will be on display from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekdays and 1 to 5 P.M. weekends through Nov. 28. A reception at 4 P.M. Saturday officially inaugurates the show.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Valet Parking, Pro and Con ''VALET parking in residential areas is fraught with peril,'' says Edwin L. Eaton, the Long Beach City Manager. That's why he and other city officials want to ban it.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW LIFE FOR AN OLD FARHOUSE
description: WE HAVE often wished we could award half-stars to restaurants, but we have never wished it more than when writing about the Van Blarcom Inn, a restaurant in the Bergen County community of Franklin Lakes that deserves two and a half stars rather than the two we are obliged to give it.

title: THE AVANT-GARDE COURTS CORPORATIONS
description: KAREN BROOKS HOPKINS looked satisfied - so many people had wanted to attend this year. The chief fund-raiser for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, an institution usually known as BAM, Karen Hopkins was standing in what was once the academy's ballroom, spotting lots of important people in the crowd. They were so crammed around extra tables that the waiters could hardly squeeze by with their trays of duckling and champagne. Over there was Richard Gere, laughing it up with the painter Julian Schnabel. Dianne Brill, the Valkyrie of the downtown disco set, was table hopping. Candice Bergen and her husband, Louis Malle, were chatting with Bianca Jagger.

title: Former Sergeant Held in Spy Case
description: As Government officials finished questioning John A. Walker Jr. about his spy ring, another noncommissioned officer, a Californian who spent 10 years in the Air Force, was arrested last week on espionage charges.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC OF AMERICA A dozen musical events taking place this week in Hartford, New Haven, New London, Storrs and West Hartford will mark Connecticut's participation in American Music Week, the second annual celebration of the United States contribution to the world body of music.

title: MORTGAGE PAYMENTS: EASING THE PAIN
description: ALTHOUGH many New Jerseyans are refinancing their homes to take advantage of interest rates of slightly more than 10 percent, a financial writer from Red Hook, N.Y., says that combining refinancing with a mortgage prepayment plan can save thousands of dollars and hasten the lifting of debt.

title: U.N. AIDES WORRIED ON FAMINE RELIEF
description: Relief officials and African diplomats here have expressed concern that the closing this week of the United Nations agency that oversaw famine programs in Africa could hamper relief and rehabilitation efforts on that continent.

title: Easing Entry to the Islands, Hot-Footing It in Bermuda
description: Train to Plane In Europe

title: TO SAVE EL SALVADOR
description: DUARTE My Story. By Jose Napoleon Duarte with Diana Page. Preface by Theodore M. Hesburgh. Illustrated. 284 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: PENN STATE DORMITORY OFFERS NEW HOPE TO KIDNEY PATIENTS
description: Guy Martin and Steve Katona long thought their debilitating kidney diseases, requiring time-consuming dialysis treatment, would make going to college impossible, but they now attend Pennsylvania State University, living in a dormitory for dialysis patients in an experimental program.

title: SINKING HOMES SHOCK NEIGHBORHOOD
description: There may be no one clearly to blame for the nightmare that has engulfed Anita Haynes and scores of her neighbors in the Logan section of north Philadephia. It is not much clearer when the bad dream will end.

title: Researching Ada Byron
description: To the Editor:

title: A War of Words Between Seattle And the Vatican
description: The Vatican's quarrel with Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle was taking on the look of a press release war last week: The Vatican issued a statement describing years of bargaining with the Archbishop, and he issued a statement saying that his recollection of events ''differs significantly'' from that of his church superiors.

title: Indictment in 6 Road Deaths
description: A Pembertown Township man has been indicted on murder charges in the deaths of six people, including two children, who were killed in a traffic accident on their way to a church service on July 20.

title: Generic Goods
description: To the Editor:

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
In the Series of Darkness, A Yankee Fan Finds the Light
description: WELL, was it good or bad for us Yankee fans?

title: The D.H. Rule Is Obsolete
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A GOOD MAN, FARMER BROWN
description: AS the developers' steam shovels plow under the farmlands of the East End, our local Farmer Brown (his name is Polish and begins with a ''z'') has become the hardy signalman of a disappearing era.

title: WIT AND WISDOM FROM A 17-YEAR-OLD
description: David Vecsey's recent article, ''Seeing the Mets Larger and Smaller Than Life,'' was full of wit and wisdom. That he's 17 and has something to say - in print - makes me think that we're not in such bad shape. It would be refreshing to hear from that point of view - 17 - regularly. HARRIET GARZERO

title: COMING FROM BEHIND
description: Wearing a blue Duke University windbreaker, Terry Sanford, the university's 69-year-old former president, stood outside the center gate of Cone Mills' White Oak plant the other day, shaking hands with workers coming off the 7 A.M. to 3 P.M. shift.

title: The Erroneous Eagle and the Cross-Eyed Bear
description: WHERE DOES IT say we can do testing?'' President Reagan asked his advisers at the Iceland summit meeting, reviewing their draft of a United States proposal to adhere to the antiballistic missile treaty in return for reductions in offensive ballistic missiles. That draft began, I am told, something like this: ''Both sides would agree to the continuance of the ABM treaty for a period of five years . . . .''

title: CARNEGIE HERO FUND CITES 19
description: Nineteen people from 12 states and a Canadian province have been honored as heroes by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

title: WIDOW OF THE ANARCHIST
description: DEAD ALIVE By Eva Demski. Translated by Jan van Heurck. 293 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: BATTLE TO BE COOK COUNTY SHERIFF IS FOUGHT ON A NATIONAL SCALE
description: For a simple county election race, the battle for Sheriff of Cook County is attracting a lot of money and national attention.

title: Marie Lefton Becomes Bride in Boston Of Arthur Young 3d, a Fellow Lawyer
description: Marie Lefton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Al Paul Lefton Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday to Arthur William Young 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Young Jr. of Edgartown, Mass., and Florence. The Rev. Stanley E. Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Gamble Building in Boston.

title:
FOCUS: Atlanta;
Midtown Challenges Downtown
description: OVER the last year, enterprising businessmen have restored gargoyles on once fading Downtown historic structures, a small but significant number of firms have begun to return from the suburbs because of unprecedented congestion there and one or two new office towers have been discussed.

title: CHAIM POTOK, MAN OF CONTRASTS, AT THE VILLAGE GATE
description: THE appearance of a distinguished author, Chaim Potok, at the top of the bill tomorrow night at one of Greenwich Village's most popular and longest-lived nightclubs, the Village Gate, does not portend a radical change in the fare of the club, any more than in the life style of the writer. It's only for that one evening that the Gate's audience will be beating time to thoughts rather than to the rhythms of jazz.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Vermont City's Stroke of Luck

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: THE TRANSLATOR'S WIFE. By Deena Linett. (Humanities and Arts Press, San Jose State University, 1 Washington Square, San Jose, Calif. 95192.

title: When a Co-op Board Rejects a Buyer
description: THREE separate individuals tried to buy a cooperative duplex apartment at 39 East 79th Street on Manhattan's Upper East Side last year, but the board of directors rejected each without explanation.

title: C.I.A. HAS $100 MILLION, A POINT TO PROVE
description: OVER the next year, the Central Intelligence Agency will undergo one of the most public tests in its largely secret history. With day-to-day responsibility for directing $100 million of American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the agency will have a chance to silence critics who say it is not up to running paramilitary operations.

title: How the New 1040 Will Affect 401(k)'s
description: WHILE the new tax law has been touted as a major step toward simplification, and a boon to wage earners, it contains a web of complex, interrelated provisions that will have a sweeping impact on financial planning for retirement.
