Many middle-income workers will find they are subject not only to new limits on how much money they can put into traditional savings vehicles for retirement, but also face new restrictions on how much they can take out - and how soon.

title: SESTINAS AND WISECRACKS
description: ANAGRAMS By Lorrie Moore. 225 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Nicaragua Leader Tells Of Fighting on Border
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Government forces had been involved in ''five days of uninterrupted combat'' near the northern border with Honduras.

title: 60 CELLS TO EASE PROBLEM AT JAIL
description: THE Board of Legislators has voted to spend $1 million for construction of 60 modular jail cells, a measure officials said last week that will ease record overcrowding in the county's prison system.

title: Glassboro State Routs Kean
description: Brian Adkisson returned punts 44 and 85 yards for touchdowns and Clint Gaskin sprinted 43 yards with an intercepted pass for another score as Glassboro State crushed Kean, 56-14, yesterday at Zweidinger Field, in Union, N.J., to remain undefeated in the New Jersey State Conference.

title: Dance
description: In the early 70's Christopher Beck attracted attention not only for dancing with the companies of Cliff Keuter, Elina Mooney and Phoebe Neville, but also for his own mysterious choreography. In 1975, however, he moved to San Francisco, where he founded a new company.

title: N.J. 'Transitway' Is On the Track
description: An effective public transit system has long been seen as the key to the multibillion-dollar development of the Hudson River waterfront opposite Manhattan, and last week New Jersey unveiled its plan to provide one. The system, called the Hudson Transitway, would be capable of carrying 14,000 people an hour in trolley cars and buses over a 15-mile route between Jersey City and Edgewater, near the George Washington Bridge.

title:
WINE;
INVESTING IN 1985 VINTAGE
description: LIKE the well-known wine shops in Manhattan, some area retail outlets are offering customers an opportunity to put down cash now for cases of red Bordeaux from the 1985 vintage that will not be available for delivery until the spring or fall of 1988. While a number of critics contend that investing in these Bordeaux futures is more snobbery than sound financial planning, local consumers should evaluate the options before writing off investing in the 1985 pre-release products.

title: DISABLED OFFERED MUSIC AS THERAPY
description: THE Westchester Conservatory of Music in White Plains recently established a new music-therapy program for physically, emotionally and learning-disabled individuals of all ages.

title: Mario Cuomo, Then and Now
description: Barely 12 years after leaving a Brooklyn law practice and part-time professorship, Mario Cuomo stands forth as an odds-on favorite to win a second term as Governor of New York, perhaps by as much as 50 percentage points. The nation, which heard his electrifying speech to the 1984 Democratic convention, thinks it knows him. New Yorkers may be less certain.

title: Comings and Goings
description: GREG NORMAN, looking for his seventh consecutive tournament victory, shot a six-under-par 66 to take a two-stroke lead in the Australian P.G.A. Golf Championship in Sydney. If he holds on to win today, he will need just four more victories to match the record of 11 straight set by Byron Nelson in 1945. . . . Paul Fenton, a left wing for New Haven in the American Hockey League, was called up by the Rangers. . . . Kelvin Bryant, the Redskin running back who has missed six games with a knee injury, was activated in time for today's game against the Minnesota Vikings. . . . By a unanimous vote, the Virginia Tech Board of Visitors approved a settlement of Coach Bill Dooley's $3.5 million suit against the school for what the football coach, who is leaving after this season, said was a breach of his contract when he was removed from his second role as athletic director. The amount of the settlement has not been announced, but published reports said it amounted to a seven-year annuity worth just over $1 million and the use of two cars.

title: THE CASE FOR ARBITRATION
description: THE ''fix'' of arbitration in the form of ''New Jersey Procedure for Alternative Dispute Resolution,'' now being considered by the State Senate, may be worse than the problems it purports to remedy and harmful to some of the public interest.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Scotch Plains
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, a suburban community in the shadow of New Jersey's Watchung Mountains with an abundance of open space and wooded lots, seems insulated from the rush of traffic on nearby Route 22.

title: TAILGUNNER HELMS
description: HARD RIGHT The Rise of Jesse Helms. By Ernest B. Furgurson. 302 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: A New Track to High-Tech Growth
description: CAN we save our leadership position in the semiconductor industry? More to the point, must we choose between the two competing ''solutions'' that are typically advanced - either direct, governmental involvement through research and trade subsidies, or no action at all in the blind faith that the free market will make the right choice?

title: Bonanno Freed From Prison After U.S. Judge Lifts Charge
description: Joseph Bonanno, the 81-year-old retired crime boss, was released from prison today after spending more than a year there for refusing to testify about a so-called Mafia commission, prison officials said.

title: Next Week; Should Mets And Yanks Go for Free Agents?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: JUNIOR RIDER WON FIRST RIDE AT 3
description: ASHLEY SAUNDERS of nearby Oldwick won her first horse show blue ribbon when she was 3 years old, sitting on a horse in a lead-line class. Now at 10, she is a leading contender among junior riders in the National Horse Show, which opens Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.

title: JEWISH GROUP AIDS THIRD-WORLD DEVELOPMENT
description: Eighteen months ago, a small group of American Jews gathered in New York and formed an organization to aid the poor in third-world countries.

title: Series On Radio Was Below Par
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Clues Scarce in Slayings Of 3 Queens Homosexuals
description: Pedro Gonzalez, a 43-year-old restaurant worker, was found bound and strangled in his apartment in Corona, Queens, last March 21. Six days later, the police said there were striking similarities between his murder and two other killings in the area since July 1985.

title: Fond Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: OPPONENTS OF GAS PIPELINE RAISE A STORM AT FIRST U.S. HEARING
description: BY helicopter and limousine and other means, nearly all the top officials in the state descended on Torrington last week. They were lending their voices to those of first selectmen, business executives, farmers and homemakers opposing the construction of a natural gas pipeline through the northwestern part of the state.

title: SCREEN: 'ROUGE BAISER,' PARIS AND POLITICS IN '52
description: VERA BELMONT'S semi-autobigraphical French film, ''Rouge Baiser,'' is set mostly in 1952 in Paris and is about Nadia, the pretty, teen-age daughter of Polish emigre working-class parents. Nadia's tastes are thoroughly eclectic. She loves, in ascending order of heat, Apollinaire, Rita Hayworth and Josef Stalin, to whom she writes long letters, though he's too busy to answer.

title: BULLET TAGGED FOR PRESIDENT
description: A bullet tagged ''For you Mr. President,'' a loaded pistol, stolen credit cards and notes about President Reagan's security personnel were found in the hotel room and car of a man arrested before Mr. Reagan's visit here Friday, Secret Service agents say.

title: Hoi State Topples Iowa, 31-10
description: Jim Karsatos, the quarterback, began a 72-yard touchdown pass play to Cris Carter, the wide receiver, for a touchdown during a 21-point second quarter that carried Ohio State to a 31-10 upset of Iowa in a Big Ten Conference game today.

title: Dr. Dale, Intern At St. Vincent's, Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Randolph Dale of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Kristan Charline Dale to Victor L. Zimmermann Jr., a son of Aileen Hynes Zimmermann of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Zimmermann. A January wedding is planned.

title: URUGUAY FACING A CRISIS OVER EX-MILITARY RULERS
description: The failure of Uruguay's political parties to agree on whether to try former military rulers for human-rights abuses has thrown the country into what political leaders call the worst political crisis since the return of democracy 18 months ago.

title: FILM: BARRETO'S 'HAPPILY EVER AFTER'
description: FERNANDA (Regina Duarte) is a pretty, well-heeled Brazilian with a career, a big house, two nice children and the kind of husband who likes to work out beside his wife on the family's exercise equipment every morning. She's happy. Or at least she thinks she's happy. Or at least she smiles a lot. But one day, Fernanda dreams she is dancing with a very handsome young man who's wearing women's clothes. The very next day, she runs into this young man quite literally, with her car.

title: ASSETS OF MARCOS TRACED BY MANILA
description: A member of a panel seeking recovery of the assets of Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that Mr. Marcos had transferred $100 million in Philippine Government funds to private Swiss bank accounts during his last 90 days in office.

title: DEBATE OVER PUBLIC ART GROWING
description: IF EAST Hampton Town officials have their way, by spring the town will be the first on Long Island to have a formal policy on ''public art.''

title: Julia Tuchler Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Julia Elizabeth Tuchler to Steven Charles Guggenheimer has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Dennis Tuchler of St. Louis, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer Jr. of New York.

title: Recent Sales
description: Recent Sales Boonton $235,000 12 North Main Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace in living room, riverfront property; taxes $1,798. Hillsborough $121,500 107-4B Bluebird Drive 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old town house; cathedral ceiling, deck, 1-car attached garage; taxes $1,900.

title: THE 60's ARE GONE, BUT VALUES ENDURE
description: WHAT continues to amaze me about yuppies is not that they can't ''find'' themselves: it's that they aren't looking. Dressed for every success imaginable - money and social prestige heading the list - they are a trim and fast-moving lot who clutch their daybooks for dear life as they buzz from work to exercise class, then back to work, then out to eat with contacts or business associates within their spiraling entrepreneurial networks.

title: Cable TV
description: Some interesting film newcomers to cable are on hand this week, like ''Insignificance'' (1985), Nicholas Roeg's bold, mythic fantasy-satire set in the 1950's. Vincent Canby of The Times called it surprising and ''almost consistently entertaining,'' with a solid cast - Michael Emil, Theresa Russell, Gary Busey and especially Tony Curtis. It's showing on WHT on Monday at 9 A.M. and 8 P.M. and Friday on Bravo at 8 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.

title: LILCO BEGINS POWER TALKS WITH STATE
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company has agreed with Governor Cuomo to study ways to assure adequate electricity for Long Island without power from the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: GOVERNOR'S RACE TAKES TO STREETS IN THE CAMPAIGN'S LAST WEEKEND
description: Only three days before the election, New York's gubernatorial race finally turned to some old-fashioned street campaigning yesterday.

title: Nancy C. Pattillo To Wed Ensign
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Gilchrist Pattillo 3d of West Suffield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Craig Pattillo to Ens. Christopher Brian Soltis, U.S.N., a son of Judith Soltis Krawski of East Windsor, Conn., and the late Lieut. Col. Ronald Bruce Soltis, U.S.A.F. An April wedding is planned.

title: VILLAGE MOVING ON POLLUTED WELLS
description: AFTER 13 years of advising that pregnant women and infants not drink water from its municipal water system because of high nitrate levels in two of its 11 wells, the Village of Greenport has started to explore ways to solve the problem.

title: PACT FOR WESTCHESTER BUS LINE
description: The company that provides nearly all the bus service in Westchester County reached a tentative agreement on a new contract with its drivers and mechanics today, four hours after the previous contract expired at midnight, officials on both sides said.

title: A NEW GENERATION OF NON-SAVERS
description: ''The habit of saving is in itself an education that fosters every virtue, teaches self denial, cultivates the sense of order, trains to forethought and so broadens the mind.''

title: LONGO'S MESSAGE: I'M RUNNING, TOO
description: FRANK J. LONGO, uninvited to three of this campaign's four debates despite being the Unaffiliated candidate for governor, has been struggling to get attention.

title: Finally, an Issue!
description: IT has not been easy for Republicans to find an issue against Representative Buddy Darden, a conservative Democrat from Georgia's Seventh District. Mr. Darden has been a loyal supporter of President Reagan on major issues, from economic policy to the proposed space-oriented missile shield.

title: FRIENDS ACROSS TIME, ACROSS SPACE, ACROSS ETERNITY
description: IT was a year ago last Friday that my mother died. She had lived in Westchester for only a few months, having moved here from Long Island in the late spring of 1985. Advancing age and my father's death two years earlier had taken their toll on her, and our old family home in Garden City had become too much for her to manage.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THIS past summer and so far this fall, New Jersey appears to have recorded an average season in its volume of crops. However, the final accounting is expected to indicate that the state remains one of the nation's top growers of fruit and vegetables.

title: Columbia, Up by 14 At Halftime, Is Beaten Again
description: Columbia, in desperate need of a ''breather'' after going without victory in 30 straight games, appeared to have found one in yesterday's contest with Villanova, a school that returned to varsity football competition last year after abandoning the sport following the 1980 season.

title: DATA BANK: NOVEMBER 2, 1986

title: BEETHOVEN EXPONENT
description: Arthur Grumiaux, a violinist known for his aristocratic style and musical integrity, died Oct. 16 in Brussels of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE: Turned On; OZ COMES TO QUEENS
description: A Newton's apple to the new New York Hall of Science, open for business in the shadow of Shea Stadium in Queens. After decades of neglect, the reborn gallery boasts a hundred hands-on displays for youngsters and their parents, ending New York's embarrassment at being America's only large city without a big-league science museum.

title: Laura Liptrot and Douglas D. Duke Are Engaged to Be Married in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Atherton Liptrot of Wilton, Conn., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Lee Liptrot, to Douglas Drexel Duke, a son of Anthony Drexel Duke of Glen Head and East Hampton, L.I., and Mrs. Hunter Goodrich Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Classical Music
description: One of the noblest and most moving musical works of the 20th century is Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem,'' which he composed in 1961 for the dedication of the cathedral at Coventry. A new cathedral had to be built because the 12th-century original was wantonly destroyed by bombs during World War II.

title: Award to Titanic Discoverer
description: Robert Ballard, who headed the team that found the wreck of the luxury liner Titanic 73 years after she sank in the North Atlantic, was awarded the Washburn Award Wednesday by the Boston Museum of Science. The award, including a gold medal and $5,000, is given annually to ''an individual who has made an outstanding contribution toward public understanding of science.'' Past recipients include Chuck Yeager and Walter Cronkite.

title: Curling Up With a Good Novel
description: FOR all the advances that have been made in personal computing, the traditional typewriter-like keyboard has remained critical not only to the operation of the machines but also to the all-important task of pulling data together for them in the first place. Computers may be lightning fast, but most users are still hunting and pecking at 40 words or less a minute to feed them.

title:
A SPECIAL GUIDE TO CRUISES WORLDWIDE;
DIRECTORY OF FALL-WINTER SAILINGS
description: The following directory of cruise ships is arranged by destination and basically covers sailings from Nov. 3 to March 31. The next directory will be published on Feb. 8, 1987. Information for the directory was supplied by the individual cruise companies, but dates, ports of call and fares are all subject to change. Unless otherwise noted, the fares quoted are for one person in double occupancy, exclusive of port taxes, and some fares may be subject to currency fluctuations.

title: EIGHT WAYS TO DIE
description: MURDER IN MANHATTAN By Thomas Chastain, Mary Higgins Clark, Dorothy Salisbury Davis, Lucy Freeman, Joyce Harrington, Warren Murphy, Bernard St. James and Whitley Strieber. 307 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: Mary Joyce Farr To Become Bride
description: The engagement of Mary Joyce Hull Farr to Todd Douglas Colwell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas A. Colwell of Birmingham, Mich., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hull Farr of Chevy Chase, Md., parents of the bride-to-be. A January wedding is planned.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Oct. 26 about the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act misstated the number of regional native land corporations established by the act. There are 13.

title: Price's Last House Race
description: Representative Melvin Price, an 81-year-old Democrat, said Friday that his current bid for a 22d consecutive term in the House would be his last campaign. Robert Gaffner, who is challenging Mr. Price for the third time, said the announcement was a plea for sympathy among the voters. Mr. Price was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee from 1974 to 1984, when he was voted out by fellow Democrats.

title: AN OFF YEAR FOR SERIOUS ISSUES, BUT NOT FOR IMPACT
description: The electorate will deliver its verdict Tuesday after a paradoxical political campaign - a campaign in which great national and international issues played no large part, a campaign that aroused so little public interest that it seems likely to produce the smallest turnout on record, a campaign that will nevertheless do much to shape the political landscape for the next two years and beyond.

title: A TRUCE IS CALLED IN HISTORICAL BATTLE
description: HOW many headquarters did General George Washington have on Oct. 28, 1776, during the one-hour Battle of White Plains?

title: RADIO TALK PROGRAM BORN OF A COMMUTER ALLIANCE
description: TWO businessmen who met three years ago on a commuter train have become hosts of a weekly radio program entitled ''Successful Living,'' designed, they said, to help listeners solve problems, improve relationships and live happier lives.

title: SOVIET BLOC COMMANDOS SAID TO INFILTRATE WEST
description: Commando units from the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact countries regularly penetrate Western Europe to familiarize themselves with the terrain and reconnoiter strategic military targets, according to West German military intelligence.

title: Public Reaction To a Terrorist
description: To the Editor: Mr. Copeland's article on collaboration (''Mixing and Matching Is Enlivening the Arts'') in the Oct. 5, 1986 issue definitely points out the trend in contemporary theater arts movement, yet he never really seems to address the question of why it is occurring with such prevalence these days. I think the answer can be found in the article, but in a context not aimed directly at this question, and that is his reference to the ''ism'' of the 80's, careerism.

title: MUSIC: ZORN VARIATIONS ON THEMES BY MORRICONE
description: THE East Village improvisational scene reached some sort of apotheosis at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Friday night (and presumably last night, as well, when a repeat was scheduled). John Zorn and a 25-member ''big band'' consisting of nearly every well-known name on that scene who happened to be in town addressed themselves to the film music of Ennio Morricone as arranged, insofar as an arranger can be said to arrange improvisation, by Mr. Zorn. The event, rather too cutely entitled ''Once Upon a Time in the East Village,'' was part of the Next Wave Festival.

title: More Sparring On The Falklands
description: Britain asserted jurisdiction within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands last week and said that it would restrict fishing within 150 miles.

title: Appeal on Emigration From Soviet Is Planned
description: Five Soviet emigres will leave New York today for Vienna, where they will make an appeal at an East-West conference this week for a renewal of Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union.

title: Plaintiff in a Landmark Case Joins Staff of Medical Group
description: Allan Bakke, who charged he suffered discrimination 13 years ago when his application for medical school was passed over in favor of applicants who are members of minority groups, is a practicing anesthesiologist.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Article in The Week in Review Oct. 19 misstated some points about a relationship between the Cablevision Systems Corporation and Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader. Sheila A. Mahoney, a vice president of Cablevision, said the company had talked with Mr. Friedman about the possibility of retaining him as its lawyer for $10,000 a month. But she did not suggest that those talks were related to the selection a year earlier of the company to provide cable television service in the Bronx.

title: Rattling the Brass In Brooklyn's 77th
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward last week ordered the transfer of all supervisors from Brooklyn's 77th Precinct, where 13 officers were suspended without pay in September after an internal investigation uncovered thefts of money and drugs from narcotics dealers.

title: CIGARS ARE THE SAME AS BODY ODOR, FISH. . .
description: Jonathan M. Weisberg does not understand the objection to cigars (''What This County Needs . . . ,'' Westchester Opinion, Oct. 19). Nonsmokers (and many cigarette smokers) avoid cigar smoke for the same reason we avoid a dog that has rolled in rotten fish: the odor is nauseating and almost unbearable.

title: Family Traditions
description: WHAT'S THE OUTLOOK FOR the future of French cuisine?

title: TRAUMA TIME ON NETWORK TV
description: IN an office on the 20th floor of Black Rock, the polished-granite CBS headquarters building on Sixth Avenue, there toils a balding, middle-aged man who has no nameplate on his door, no one to answer his telephone and who has, indeed, no permanent job at the company. And yet, just now, he may be the most influential person at CBS. He is Thomas C. Flanagan, management consultant, of the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand. Less formally, he has also been referred to in the halls as ''Larry's big stick'' -the man that Laurence A. Tisch hired to make good on his promise to make CBS more efficient. ''Downsizing,'' it is called in current network parlance.

title: HELP FOR HOMELESS
description: FOUR Westchester agencies learned last week that they will receive $893,000 in state aid to provide housing for 80 homeless people. The grants, announced by Governor Cuomo, are part of a $20 million allocation to 36 agencies in the state.

title: DEATH OF A DAUGHTER
description: JANE EMILY WAS 18 WHEN SHE DIED. AL-though she occasionally had a beer or a glass of champagne, she was fiercely critical of efforts nationally to raise the drinking age. Not only young people drove drunk, she said. Instead, she thought drunken drivers of any age should be thrown in jail and have their licenses taken away.

title: Steeplechase to Census
description: Census, an 8-year-old gelding ridden by Jeff Teter and trained by Janet Elliot, won the first Breeders' Cup Steeplechase today, covering the 16-fence, 2 3/4-mile course at Fair Hill in 4:27 3/5.

title: Peggy Meineke Bride Of Richard John Nidds
description: Peggy Leah Meineke and Richard John Nidds were married yesterday at the Palmer Memorial Episcopal Church in Houston by the Rev. Jeffrey Walker.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Will Durables Endure?

title: INSIDE
description: Envoy Hopeful on Hostages An Anglican envoy is cautiously optimistic that some Western hostages in Lebanon might be freed, a church spokesman said.

title: UPDATING THE HONDURAN AIR FORCE
description: WHEN the Reagan Administration asks Honduras for more facilities for the Nicaraguan rebels, Honduran military officials often point to the possibility of reprisals by Nicaragua and ask for increased United States aid. Last week, Administration officials suggested that Honduras might indeed be threatened by Nicaragua as the insurgency accelerates, now that Congress has approved $100 million in aid for the rebels.

title: 2 DIE, 9 HURT IN SEPARATE ATTACKS
description: Two people were killed and nine others injured in three unrelated attacks in Brooklyn and Queens Friday night and yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes: Photos and 'White Suit'
description: Ansel Adams: Photographer Directed by John Huszar.1981 Pacific Arts Video. 60 minutes. $29.95

title: 2 DIE IN CITY APARTMENT FIRES
description: Two women, one in Greenwich Village and one in Queens, died yesterday morning at their homes in fires that were both apparently caused by smoking in bed, the authorities said.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
YOUNG SCHOLARS
description: IT isn't Harvard or Yale, perhaps, but the campus of the State University of New York here can be impressive in a stark, contemporary way. There may be no ivy-covered stone, no old-fashioned fortresses of knowledge, but on a recent autumn evening, with the trees red and lacy and the students scurrying across its vast spaces, it seemed a true college campus setting.

title: Pop Music
description: Karen Akers will return on Tuesday to the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, for what has quickly developed into a semi-annual series of visits to the midtown cabaret. A year ago, after an absence of four years from New York night life, she appeared at the Ballroom for the first time, returned last spring and is now making it a steady round of spring and fall appearances by opening there Tuesday for a two-week stay.

title: THE LIFE OF ONE FAMILY IS CHRONICLED IN MUSIC
description: A CONCERT that chronicles the 150-year musical life of one English family, using instruments similar to those the family would have listened to, will be presented on Friday at 8 P.M. at Wesleyan University.

title: VOTES IN JERSEY TO FILL 14 SEATS IN HOUSE RACES
description: Two hotly contested races for county executive in Essex and Bergen Counties and the election of the state's 14-member Congressional delegation face voters in New Jersey on Tuesday.

title: TEARS OF DISBELIEF AT FUNERAL OF SLAIN YESHIVA STUDENT
description: ''I have a question for the Holy One, blessed be His name,'' Rabbi Emanuel Pollack, his eyes red from crying, said yesterday as he stood before the plain pine coffin of Chaim Weiss. ''How could He take from us a young child, a sweet, beloved boy? A face that laughed all the time?''

title: Big Cut in Bid By Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation said yesterday that it would offer the holders of People Express Inc. substantially less for their common shares than had been originally proposed.

title: TUPAMAROS OF URUGRAY: THE MYSTIQUE SURVIVES
description: The first among them are on the far side of middle age now, quiet men who recall the years in jail and the guerrilla underground in near monotones, their mystique enveloping them like comfortable old sweaters.

title: 4 Minor Quakes Jolt Coast
description: Four minor earthquakes shook northern California on Saturday, but no injuries or damages were reported, the authorities said.

title: ADELAIDE L. GAYLORD
description: Adelaide Lawson Gaylord, a New York artist who with her husband, Wood Gaylord, spearheaded the modernist movement in the early years of this century, died last Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. She was 97 years old and lived in Glenwood Landing, L.I.

title: FUND DRIVE MARKS L.I.U.'S 60TH YEAR
description: Long Island University, which held its first classes in an old electric company building, celebrated its 60th anniversary yesterday and began a $100 million fund-raising campaign.

title: Becker Winner At Paris Open
description: Boris Becker today won his third tournament in three weeks, beating Sergio Casal of Spain, 6-4, 6-3, 7-6, in the final of the $625,000 Paris Open tennis tournament.

title: LONG-BUILT DREAMS CRUSHED AS PRETORIA RAZES TOWNSHIP
description: To build a house, Kenneth Ranuga explained, you need sand and cement to make the bricks, and three-ply wood from crating for the ceiling and, most of all, time.

title: Advertising; Wyse to Polish Image Of General Dynamics
description: After an agency competition, the St. Louis-based General Dynamics Corporation has selected Wyse Advertising's Cleveland office to create the first major corporate image campaign in recent memory. The budget is $6 million.

title: LADY'S SECRET IN STEP FOR TITLE
description: When the voters for racing's Eclipse Awards mark their Horse of the Year ballots next month, most will probably write down the name of Lady's Secret, but only after hesitating and trying to make a case for someone else.

title: STAGE: 'COLORED MUSEUM,' SATIRE BY GEORGE C. WOLFE
description: THERE comes a time when a satirical writer, if he's really out for blood, must stop clowning around and move in for the kill. That unmistakable moment of truth arrives about halfway through ''The Colored Museum,'' the wild new evening of black black humor at the Public Theater. In a sketch titled ''The Last Mama-on-the-Couch Play,'' the author, George C. Wolfe, says the unthinkable, says it with uncompromising wit and leaves the audience, as well as a sacred target, in ruins. The devastated audience, one should note, includes both blacks and whites. Mr. Wolfe is the kind of satirist, almost unheard of in today's timid theater, who takes no prisoners.

title: Marathon Runner Collapses and Dies
description: A 32-year-old Marine staff sergeant collapsed at the 15-mile mark of the Marine Corps Marathon today and later died, race officials said.

title: Early-Music Concert
description: The 17-member English Concert ensemble, under the direction of Trevor Pinnock, will open the ''Music on Original Instruments'' series today at Alice Tully Hall. Mr. Pinnock, who will play harpsichord and organ, will lead the group in works by Purcell, Corelli and Handel. The soprano Silvia McNair will be guest soloist in cantatas by Handel and Bach. Tickets for the concert, which begins at 2 P.M., are $20.

title: Playing From Memory Is Overrated
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting Hours In the Region
description: New York - 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. New Jersey - 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Connecticut - 6 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: ANGRY DISPUTE LEFT FOR NEW SENATE
description: A nomination that died in the final days of the Congressional session appears likely to provoke one of the early battles in the next Congress.

title: INSIDE
description: Bus Passengers Dwindling Ridership on New York City buses has dropped 45 percent since the mid-1960's, a decline that is worrying Transit Authority officials.

title: ILLEGAL ALIENS HOPING TO CLAIM THEIR DREAMS
description: When the dreaded ''migras,'' the immigration police, picked up Marcelino Castro a few years ago in suburban Conroe, he thought the game was finally over.

title: 2 SENATORS IN DAKOTAS BATTLING TO SAVE SEATS AND A REPUBLICAN MAJORITY
description: Only about one American in 200 lives in the Dakotas, two of the least-known and least-visited states in the Union, and yet they could well play a central role in Tuesday's elections.

title: 'BLUEBELL,' 8-PART TALE OF DANCER
description: THE eight-part BBC series ''Bluebell,'' getting under way tonight at 10 on the Arts & Entertainment Network, has a little bit of everything - drama, music and dance - as its noble heroine goes from the chorus line to stardom against a backdrop of the rise and fall of Hitler's Nazis. The only problem is that ''Bluebell'' isn't quite able to pull all of these ingredients together. One episode is as light and silly as an old Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers romp. Another aims to be horrifying. More often than not, the result is merely disconcerting.

title: PURCHASERS SEE SLOWER GROWTH
description: Economic growth slowed in October and could slow even more the rest of the year, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in releasing its latest survey today.

title: Chief Leaving McLouth To Head Steel Institute
description: The American Iron and Steel Institute, the troubled steel industry's trade and lobbying association, is getting a new president.

title: REPORT RELEASED ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: Fewer than half of the women engaging in sexual intercourse for the first time use contraceptives, according to a study recently published by the Government.

title: The Hard Sell
description: Remember the story of the broker whose naive client complained about some department-store stock? ''It's a terrible store,'' the investor told him. ''It's always crowded.

title: Armco in Tentative Pact With Steelworkers
description: Negotiators for Armco Inc. and the United Steelworkers union reached a tentative agreement today on a contract for workers in steel plants in three states, a company spokesman said.

title: 82D AIRBORNE DIVISION TRAINING FOR LATIN COMBAT
description: The 82d Airborne Division, the Army's only division equipped to invade hostile territory, has just completed a large-scale field maneuver to train its paratroopers for combat in Central America.

title: DANCE: BERNHARD'S 'PERPETUAL ORIGIN'
description: SUE BERNHARD'S ''Perpetual Origin: New Dances,'' a program presented on Saturday night at the Nikolais-Louis Dancespace, started out promisingly with a new duet called ''Beginning.'' The piece set big, blocky movement and a distanced physical relationship against the intimate warmth of a score by Vivaldi.

title: Leader of Beverly Plans to Keep Post
description: Robert Van Tuyle, the energetic, 74-year-old chairman and chief executive of Beverly Enterprises, says he has no thoughts of stepping aside from the top post of the nation's largest nursing home company.

title: TREASURY ISSUES TAKING CENTER STAGE
description: Treasury financings are on center stage in the credit markets this week, and analysts expect only a modest supply of new investment-grade corporate debt issues to compete with Government offerings.

title: PERSONALITITES DOMINATE CONNECTICUT CAMPAIGNS
description: In a windup of campaigns dominated more by personalities and style than by issues, Connecticut voters will choose their top state officials on Tuesday, along with a United States Senator and six United States Representatives.

title: MANO A MANO IN TRENCHES
description: IN the National Football League, a game seldom boils down to two players, much less two linemen in the trenches. But yesterday it did. During the final 75 seconds of the Giants' 17-14 victory, their longtime left defensive end, No. 75 in the white jersey, 33-year-old George Martin, and the Cowboys' huge right offensive tackle, No. 75 in the blue jersey, 6-foot-9-inch Phil Pozderac, were at center stage on three plays. One way or another, all three turned on Martin's experience: a holding penalty on Pozderac that nullified a 30-yard gain to the Giants' 6-yard line, a 14-yard sack by Martin that pushed the Cowboys back to the Giants' 41, and an illegal-procedure penalty on Pozderac that nullified a 30-yard gain to the Giants' 11 with 27 seconds remaining.

title: Americans Still Missing in Beirut
description: Edward Austin Tracy A self-described world traveler, poet and author of children's books . . . 56 years old from South Burlington, Vt. . . . Reported kidnapped in West Beirut on Oct. 21 . . . Accused by his abductors, the Revolutionary Justice Organization, of being a spy for Israel and the United States . . . A resident of Lebanon for several years . . . Speaks Arabic and has a certificate from Al Azhar University in Cairo documenting his conversion to Islam . . . Has lived abroad for the last 21 years and is said to have traveled to Iran, Iraq, Australia, Italy, Ethiopia, the Canary Islands and Trinidad as well as Lebanon. Joseph James Cicippio

title: 2,000 Rally to Back Hanford Nuclear Site
description: About 2,000 supporters of the Hanford nuclear reservation joined hands across the Columbia River today in a show of solidarity for projects at the Federal installation near here.

title: SAUDI ARABIA: FAMILY BUSINESS
description: When Saudi Arabia's oil minister of 24 years, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, was abruptly dismissed last week, worldwide attention was drawn to one of the world's more secretive royal families, the House of Saud.

title: Nobelists Assemble
description: Nine winners of the Nobel Prize are to participate this week in a conference that is thought to be the largest such gathering in Washington since the Kennedy Administration.

title: BRONCOS GO TO 8-1 BY BEATING RAIDERS
description: John Elway completed 11 of 12 passes and Mike Harden returned an interception for the clinching score with 1 minute 49 seconds remaining today as the Denver Broncos defeated the Los Angeles Raiders, 21-10.

title: Plutocracy And The Law
description: Political analysts have had a hard time finding a theme in the 1986 election campaign. It is all so local, they say; national issues have hardly developed. But there is a theme in this election, one running right across the country. It is the power of money.

title: Bichon Frise Best
description: JoAnn Failla's homebred Bichon Frise, Ch. Unicorn's Nickoles Nickelbee, today led a field of 1,000 at the Union County Kennel Club Show in Dunn Sports Center.

title: Jack Wilson's Piano And Ed Schuler's Bass
description: Like Erroll Garner, Jack Wilson is a two-telephone-book pianist. At Zinno, 126 West 13th Street, where he played through Saturday, Wilson sat on two New York City telephone directories so that he was above the keyboard, in a dominant position.

title: NOW, BRAZIL GROWTH IS CREATING WORRY
description: Eight months after Brazil adopted a drastic anti-inflationary package known as the Cruzado Plan, euphoria over its success in stimulating consumer spending is now giving way to alarm that the economy has become dangerously overheated.

title: Jersey to Bar Sale of Stripers
description: The State Department of Environmental Protection plans to submit a new regulation Monday that would ban the commercial sale of striped bass and limit recreational fishermen to stripers at least 33 inches long.

title: Pajama Game: R.I.P.
description: Georgia Tech is juggling its football schedule, and skivvies salesmen all over east central Alabama couldn't be more depressed. Let us explain.

title: NEW YORK REGION LOSING TEACHERS
description: Within three to five years, nearly half of the teachers on Long Island are expected to retire. And while the numbers are not so dramatic elsewhere, educators throughout the New York region say they are worried about severe teacher shortages and intense competition for qualified applicants.

title: THE NATURAL AIMS FOR NATIONAL TITLE
description: LAST Christmas Eve, a horse originally named Donald 158 and rechristened two years ago as The Natural, arrived at Old Salem Farm. He was a costly present - indeed the most expensive jumper ever bought - from Paul and Edie Greenwood to themselves.

title: AQUINO CHALLENGER DENIES ACCUSATIONS OF STEALING U.S. AID
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile today denied accusations that he had diverted American military aid to the Philippines for his personal use, and he accused his critics of trying to blackmail him into stopping his agitation against the Government.

title: REPUBLICANS LEAD IN CAMPAIGN CASH
description: As United States Senate campaigns enter the final stretch, Republican candidates in several key races continued to outpace Democrats in raising money and had more cash available for final blitzes.

title: THE ELUSIVE INSPIRATION OF FLAMENCO
description: An inquiry into the wellspring of creativity, as it applies to virtuosity in the flamenco of Andalusian gypsies, brought a rush of words and an answer as compact as a drop of pure water. But it left little hope for outsiders who aspire to top rank in the art.

title: OFFICIALS TRY TO BLUNT DEMOCRATS' USE OF U.S. ECONOMY AS A POLITICAL ISSUE
description: With some lucky breaks, real accomplishments and a push to make the most of the power of the Presidency, the Reagan Administration is attempting to blunt efforts by Democratic candidates to turn the performance of the economy in their favor.

title: SOVIET-FRENCH SPACE FLIGHT
description: The Soviet Union and France will conduct a joint monthlong space flight in the second half of 1988, according to Tass, the official Soviet press agency. Tass said last week that the decision was made at a meeting in the Armenian capital of Yerevan, where a meeting on cooperation in space the week before.

title: AMNESTY: WHO IS ELIGIBLE
description: Under the new immigration legislation, which President Reagan has said he will sign, legal status will be available for illegal aliens who have been ''continuously physically present'' in the United States since before Jan. 1, 1982, except for ''brief, casual and innocent absences.''

title: SINN FEIN TO END DUBLIN BOYCOTT
description: Leaders of Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing, voted today to overturn the longstanding policy of abstaining from the Irish Parliament, but the decision splintered the organization and led to the establishment of a breakaway party.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Peking dispatch Oct. 13 on Queen Elizabeth's visit to China misidentified the Chinese emperor who ruled at the time of George III. The emperor was named Qianlong, and he was the fourth ruler in the Qing dynasty.

title: At Last, a Bold Plan for the Homeless
description: Crisis management: for years, that has been New York Mayor Koch's only response to the homeless. His administration has hastily refurbished old schools and armories; appealed to church and community groups for help, and surrendered to the extortionate terms of squalid hotels. The only long-term hope he would acknowledge lay in gradual renovation of buildings seized for tax delinquency. Any more elaborate plan would be futile, the Mayor argued, because the large pool of potential homeless would quickly overwhelm it.

title: THE PERILS OF SHARING A HOME
description: AFTER she had moved into her husband's house Mary Moyer would wait until he had fallen asleep at night, then slip out of bed and change things: rearrange her glass sculptures, maybe move some furniture. If her husband did not like what she had done, he would simply change it back. Nothing was said about it.

title: U.S. Team Inspects A Site in Vietnam
description: United States officials investigating American servicemen listed as missing in action in the Vietnam War have inspected a site in northern Vietnam where an American warplane might have crashed, officials said today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 3, 1986: MONDAY Airborne Freight Kroger Co Carpenter Tech Corp Lockheed Corp Data-Design Labs NCH Corp General Motors Oakite Products Jefferson-Pilot Corp Stride Rite Corp TUESDAY Adams-Millis Corp Liberty Corp Emerson Electric Co Monarch Machine Tool Hershey Foods Sealed Air Corp JWT Group Inc Source Capital Kansas City Pwr & Lt Timken Co WEDNESDAY Cameron Iron Works Ingersoll-Rand Carlisle Cos Lear-Siegler Cincinnati Milacron Leggett-Platt Eagle-Picher Indus Reichhold Chemicals Goodyear Tire Scientific-Atlanta Great Northern Nekoosa Thomas & Betts Corp IE Industries Utilicorp United Inc THURSDAY Avon Products Interstate Securities Chemed Corp Koger Properties Coastal Corp Leaseway Transportation Contel Corp Lincoln Natl Corp Dart & Kraft MDU Resources Group Dover Corp Munford Inc El Torito Restaurants Outboard Marine GTE Corp Planning Research Gulf State Utilities Ranco Inc IU International FRIDAY Deluxe Check Printers Sterling Drug Inc Florida Steel Corp Temple Inland State Mutual Securities Washington Water Pwr SATURDAY Gfford-Hill & Co

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Citizen Denny ...
description: Given his 4.20 earned run average this season, the Reds weren't about to pick up the 1987 option on John Denny's $1 million-a-year contract. Whether they try to re-sign him more cheaply now that he's a free agent is an unresolved question, because one other thing that bothers Cincinnati's front office is his good citizenship, or rather the lapses in it.

title: Coldest Air of Season Moving West to East
description: Up to 2 feet of snow blanketed Colorado yesterday as a mass of cold Canadian air on its way East brought wintry temperatures to the Great Lakes and dumped snow and freezing rain over the Rockies and the Great Plains.

title: EX-KOREAN WAR PRISONER BATTLES TO RECOVER HIS U.S. CITIZENSHIP
description: The America of the 1950's branded Cpl. Harold H. Webb of the Army a traitor, labeled him an informer and gave him a dishonorable discharge from the military when he refused to return to the United States from a prisoner-of-war camp after the Korean War. Now Mr. Webb wants to come home. Mr. Webb is one of the 21 American prisoners of war who chose to stay with the Chinese nearly 33 years ago. And the State Department says he is not a United States citizen anymore. State Department officials said they could not discuss Mr. Webb's case because of Federal privacy laws.

title: Crowds Flocking to See Moose Courting a Cow
description: Thousands of people have been stopping at a central Vermont farm to see a moose try to woo an unwilling cow, the cow's owner said today.

title: Nancy J. Maurice Marries Lee Rogers in Greenwich
description: The marriage of Nancy Joy Maurice, the director of programs and marketing at the Wooster Community Art Center in Danbury, Conn., and Courtenay Lee Rogers, a freelance photographer, took place yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Homestead Inn.

title: Of Two Young New York Women Whose Good Fortune Ran Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah A. Schoen Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Sarah A. Schoen, the daughter of Carol Schoen and Andrew J. Schoen, both of New York, to Kenneth W. Rothstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua A. Rothstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., took place yesterday. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite in New York.

title: NETWORKS TO CURB EARLY CALLS ON RACES IN VOTE COVERAGE
description: Honoring a pledge to Congress, the three major television networks' news divisions will project state winners only after polls close Tuesday, but ABC News and NBC News said last week that they would not wait to predict which party will control the Senate.

title: 4 TEAMS STILL UNDEFEATED IN DIVISION I-A
description: Now there are only four major undefeated teams - Miami, Penn State and Michigan, all 8-0, and Arizona State at 7-0-1.

title: CONCERT: A GAMBIAN MIXED BILL
description: NEW Yorkers heard an exceptionally varied concert of music from Gambia, in West Africa, on Thursday at the Washington Square Church. There have been a number of solo concerts here by Gambian griots, singers who accompany themselves on the kora (harp-guitar); this time the griot Foday Musa Suso was joined by his uncle, Surakata Suso, on balafon (xylophone) and vocals, and his cousin Mahamadou Suso on second kora - lending the music even more depth and intricacy.

title: REGAN, THE JOINT CHIEFS OF STAFF AND ARMS CONTROL
description: The scene was the White House Situation Room. The occasion was a meeting involving President Reagan, senior Administration officials and Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: 200 Reported Injured In Bangladesh Protest
description: Clashes between demonstrators and security forces during a protest against purported police brutality in the northern town of Jaipurhat have left at least 200 people wounded, the police said today.

title: REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES CAMPAIGN TOGETHER TO ROUSE UPSTATE VOTE
description: On the last weekend before the election, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, campaigned together today with the party's other statewide candidates at four upstate airport rallies.

title: Walesa Says Poland Must Solve Crisis Soon
description: Lech Walesa, founder of the outlawed Solidarity labor union, warned in an interview published here today that time is running out for Poland's Government to solve severe economic and social problems.

title: GOODMAN PROPOSES CUTS IN INCOME TAX TO OFFSET WINDFALL
description: Roy M. Goodman, the chairman of the State Senate Taxation, Investigations and Government Operations Committee, yesterday proposed broad cuts in New York State's personal income taxes.

title: JOHNSON GETS WARM WELCOME IN JAPAN
description: BOBBY VALENTINE, his voice big and chirpy like a carnival barker's, called out to all who'd gathered to bear witness. ''Here he is,'' Valentine bellowed. ''Davey's back.''

title: BRITAIN'S BARONETS UNITE
description: Think of a baronet, and what comes to mind are the villainous baronets of Victorian fiction or the bumbling, scatterbrained aristocrats depicted by the British humorist P. G. Wodehouse.

title: CALIFORNIA KILLER ATTACKS HOMELESS
description: A killer who apparently stalks the most vulnerable of Los Angeles's large homeless population has shot 10 people to death in the last two months, according to the police.

title: Domingo to Conduct
description: Placido Domingo will conduct the Metropolitan Opera orchestra on Thursday in the season's first performance of Gounod's ''Romeo et Juliette.'' The soprano Cecilia Gasdia will make her Metropolitan Opera debut as Juliette and the tenor Alfredo Kraus will sing his first Romeo in the house, with a cast that includes Brian Schexnayder as Mercutio, Paul Plishka as Friar Laurence, Dimitri Kavrakos as Capulet, Hilda Harris as Stephano, Geraldine Decker as Gertrude and Allan Glassmann as Tybalt. The performance begins at 8 P.M. Information: 362-6000.

title: HASENFUS TEMPERS COMMENTS ON C.I.A.
description: Eugene Hasenfus, an American air-cargo specialist who was shot down in a rebel supply plane over Nicaragua last month, acted today to distance himself from earlier remarks that seemed to implicate the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PLAY IT AGAIN Revivals of plays are New York commonplaces, but the revival tonight at 8 in the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Seventh Street and Third Avenue, is a radically different sort of recall. It will put you in the middle of a union meeting, reconstructed, of 50 years ago, a stormy seamen's session that erupted at a time of tumultuous labor realignments.

title: BRAZIL TO SET UP BASES ON BORDERS
description: The Brazilian Government, citing both national security and development objectives, has decided to set up small army bases along the country's borders with Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname and French Guiana as a way of drawing settlers to those remote regions.

title: Jobs for the Off Years
description: What do former Democratic Cabinet officers do during a long Republican Administration? Some of them make broadcast commercials. Washington listeners tuned to the radio station WASH may have been startled recently to hear a familiar voice declare: ''Hello, I'm former Secretary of State Ed Muskie, and I want to tell you it's entirely compatible with the Constitution of the United States for you to continue to listen to Washington's newest radio station, EZ-97.''

title: Gains Expected on Japan Cut
description: The reduction in the Japanese discount rate announced late last week was a boon to the Treasury securities market, but analysts find much less to cheer about when they assess prospects of a similar move by the Federal Reserve to reduce short-term rates.

title: Advertising; Kornhauser Chosen By Genovese Drugs
description: The Genovese Drugs chain, based in Melville, L.I., has switched its $3 million advertising account to Kornhauser & Calene from Popofsky Advertising.

title: Pentagon Toughening Policy On Use of Organs in Research
description: The Pentagon, in a little-noticed change of policy, is clarifying its regulations concerning the taking of organs from the remains of service personnel for scientific research.

title: PELLUER PROVIDES SOME RELIEF
description: Only the next seven weeks of play will determine just how seriously Danny White, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, was injured today.

title: PARTNERSHIP AIRS PLAN FOR SIEGLER
description: Principals in AFG Partners, which has offered $85 per share in a friendly bid to acquire Lear Siegler Inc., said today they fully intend to take control of the company and disclosed their plan for paring down the aerospace, automotive and industrial conglomerate.

title: FUJITSU, A MATCH FOR I.B.M., MAKING FURTHER INROADS IN U.S.
description: If I.B.M. has an equal, it is Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's largest computer maker. Some years ago, this company surpassed the formidable International Business Machines Corporation for the top share of the computer market, and it has scored successes with supercomputers, too.

title: Ms. Schneider Weds Dr. Steven Levine
description: At Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Robin Paula Schneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Schneider of North Bellmore, L.I., was married to Dr. Steven Brian Levine, a son of Hannah Tankell of Merrick, L.I., and the late Louis Levine. Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg performed the ceremony.

title: Advertising; J. Walter Thompson Wins 6 Gold Medals
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company walked away from the International Film and TV Festival at the Sheraton Centre Hotel Friday night with six gold medals - four won by the New York office and one each by London and Tokyo.

title: 16 Czechs Defect in Hamburg
description: Sixteen Czechoslovak tourists defected Saturday from the Soviet cruise ship Mikhail Kalinin docked in Hamburg harbor, the West German police said today.

title: A SYMBOL, A BOTHER, AN HONOR
description: A bronze fist nearly the size of a city bus has been hanging over a downtown intersection here for the past few weeks.

title: Staring at College
description: What's the purpose of a college education? A new report by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching offers lofty statements about preparing the young ''to live with dignity and purpose,'' but then goes on to recommend sensible, if sometimes familiar, reforms. It deserves wide attention.

title: Washington Watch; Tax Overhaul: New 1987 Panel
description: THE House Ways and Means Committee is going to look considerably different when the 100th Congress convenes in January, even if all of the members seeking re-election tomorrow are successful.

title: BALLET: 'ESTEEMED GUESTS'
description: ALTHOUGH Mark Morris has occasionally been flamboyant as a modern-dance choreographer, when he created his first work for the Joffrey Ballet he seems to have wished to demonstrate that he was essentially a serious artist who did not have to resort to freakishness or gimmickry to achieve effects. The result was ''Esteemed Guests,'' his ballet to Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach's Concerto in A major for Violoncello and String Orchestra, which received a repeat performance with a new set of leading dancers on Friday night at the City Center.

title: COLGATE REVAMPING ITS STODGY IMAGE
description: Reuben Mark, the chairman and chief executive of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, jumps around his Park Avenue office, hands waving, talking excitedly about his company.

title: Grant Johannesen Plays Faure and Schumann
description: The pianist Grant Johannesen began a three-part series devoted to the music of Gabriel Faure and Robert Schumann Wednesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall. If the succeeding concerts, scheduled to take place at Merkin Hall on Dec. 3 and Jan. 28, can maintain this level of achievement, they should be worth the attention of anybody who loves these composers - or, for that matter, Romantic-era music in any guise.

title: WEST COAST CITICORP BID IS REPORTED
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, has made an overture about buying the BankAmerica Corporation, according to Wall Street and banking industry sources.

title: Of Two Young New York Women Whose Good Fortune Ran Out
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Die in Basque Gun Battle
description: An industrialist being held in a cave by Basque separatists was freed in a gun battle today in which a guerrilla and a policeman were killed. A regional government spokesman said the Basque police freed Lucio Aguinagalde unharmed from a hideout in a remote wooded area of Vitoria province.

title: EXPERTS DEBTE THEORY ON COLUMBUS
description: A new theory of where Columbus first landed in the New World has run into strong opposition from historians, geographers and other experts meeting here to ponder the many questions about his life and voyage.

title: An Incredible Endorsement for the Senate; What Is He Delivering?
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESS IS TO FILL GAPS FOR U.S. IN BRIBE TRIAL
description: The top executive of the Datacom Systems Corporation, the New York City government's largest debt-collection contractor, will be called upon tomorrow to reinforce and fill gaps in the Federal Government's case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and his co-defendants on charges stemming from the municipal corruption scandal.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CITY OF NETS. A Portrait of Hollywood in the 1940's. By Otto Friedrich. 495 pages. Illustrated. Harper & Row. $25.

title: A FAMILY'S REJOICING IS TEMPERED...
description: The family of David P. Jacobsen celebrated his release today, but relatives said their joy was tempered by thoughts of the six Americans who are still missing and their lack of confidence that the Reagan Administration has done all it could to obtain their release.

title: QUOTE OF THE DAY
description: ''I Fell great, absolutely great. Would anyone like to challenge me to a six-mile jog arund the airport?'' David Jacobsen, former Beirut hostage, in Cyprus A1:6

title: EDMOND R. DOAK
description: Edmond R. Doak, an aviation executive and inventor who attracted the military's interest in 1958 with a vertical takeoff and landing plane that was never produced, died Oct. 20. He was 88 years old.

title: Washington Watch; Bankruptcy Law Change
description: The banking lobby, perhaps overly absorbed with tax-code overhaul, seems to have slipped up in a little-noticed but important scrap over bankruptcy law.

title: An Incredible Endorsement for the Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Why Isolate Syria?
description: Calls for tougher action against Syria were inevitable after the conviction of Nezar Hindawi for his attempt to blow up an Israeli airliner. So far, all the United States has done is to recall its ambassador from Damascus and offer support to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain as she struggles to persuade the rest of Europe to show some solidarity. What we must decide before too long is whether we want to isolate Syria diplomatically - and risk pushing it further into the arms of Moscow - or use more sophisticated and possibly devious methods to press Damascus to stop supporting terrorism.

title: AMERICAN IS FREED AFTER 18 MONTHS AS BEIRUT CAPTIVE
description: David P. Jacobsen, an American held hostage in Lebanon for nearly 18 months, was released Sunday and stopped here briefly today on his way to West Germany.

title: ...BECAUSE OTHERS CONTINUE TO WAIT
description: Relatives and friends of American hostages still held in Lebanon expressed a mixture of joy and regret yesterday after learning of the release of David P. Jacobsen after nearly 18 months in captivity in Lebanon.

title: KNICKS' PROGRESS APPEARS TO STALL
description: ''I never, ever, coach from fear.''

title: Eric D. Bieber Married To Dr. Susan L. Cohen
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday Dr. Susan L. Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Cohen of Roslyn, was married to Eric Douglas Bieber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Bieber of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster performed the ceremony.

title: CAMPEAU TO DIVEST SOME ALLIED ASSETS
description: Bonwit Teller, Garfinckel's and other less-profitable divisions of the Allied Stores Corporation may soon go on the block, according to analysts, if the Campeau Corporation, which yesterday won its long takeover battle for Allied, decides to move quickly to strengthen the giant retailer.

title: Nine Mile 2 Loading Fuel
description: Workers began a five-week process of loading fuel at the Nine Mile 2 nuclear power plant yesterday after a one-day delay caused by a mechanical problem that divers corrected.

title: Karen Siegelman Wed To Jeffrey B. Steinfeld
description: Karen Gail Siegelman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Siegelman of Great Neck, L.I., and Jeffrey B. Steinfeld, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian S. Steinfeld of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Southampton, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman officiated at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I.

title: CONCERT: BAUDO AND ORCHESTRE NATIONAL DE LYON
description: THE Orchestre National de Lyon retains a pleasing hint, though only that, of the distinctive tone quality that makes French orchestras of a generation and more ago such piquant listening matter on records. The group came to Avery Fisher Hall Friday night with its music director Serge Baudo, and showed itself an ensemble of fine though not exceptional technical attainments, stronger than average in the kind of participatory musicality that gives an orchestra a coherence beyond simply responding to the interpretation of whatever maestro stands before it.

title: POLITICS
description: On the Home FrontTrailing far behind in polls statewide, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, is confronted with the possible loss of his home county in tomorrow's election for governor.

title: Swedes Say Embassy In Moscow Is Bugged
description: The Swedish Embassy building in Moscow has been bugged since it opened in 1972, the Foreign Ministry says.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
... and Citizen Kapp
description: Like John Denny, Joe Kapp hasn't helped himself any with an instance of behavioral failing.

title: Chip Makers Said to Meet
description: Executives of several United States semiconductor manufacturers held a special meeting Friday night to discuss the planned merger of Schlumberger Ltd.'s Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation unit with the American semiconductor unit of Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, according to industry sources.

title: Notre Dame Organist Gives New York Recital
description: Traditionally, the post of organist at Notre Dame in Paris has been a prized one, bestowing special cachet upon the incumbent. The most recent longtime holder of the coveted assignment was Pierre Cochereau, who served from 1955 until his death in 1984.

title: Radar Rules
description: The drug law that President Reagan signed recently is so large that many of its provisions are just coming to light. Take, for example, a section that will allow some small communities in Kentucky to trick highway speeders by leaving radar speed detectors turned on although no police officers are around to write tickets.

title: 2 SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENTS, 2 STRATEGIES
description: Prominently displayed in the office of Dr. J. Jerome Harris is a plaque that reads, ''God so loved the world that he did not send a committee.''

title: Advertising; Needham Quits Crayola Maker
description: DDB Needham Worldwide announced Friday that it had resigned the Binney & Smith account that it worked on for two and a half years.

title: SUPPORTERS OF AQUINO KEEP FAITH
description: Yellow balloons rose against a gray sky the other day as supporters of President Corazon C. Aquino gathered in the rain for a rally meant to revive the popular support that forms her political base.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. GOLDEN STATE WARRIORS, at Oakland, Calif., 10:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M.; Radio - WPAT AM, 10:20 P.M.) FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAMS VS.

title: WOMEN AND AIDS: DISCUSSING PRECAUTIONS
description: How can women protect themselves and others from AIDS? Women's concerns about acquired immune deficiency syndrome were addressed in unusual detail and explicitness in speeches, panel discussions and workshops at recent conferences in New York and Boston.

title: SANCTUARY CLOSING HIGHLIGHTS CULTURAL TENSION IN SOUTH TEXAS
description: When Casa Oscar Romero opened four years ago, it was envisioned as a modest refuge where perhaps four or five Central American aliens at a time would stay for a few days before leaving for the interior of the United States.

title: Eleven Dealers Of Crack Held
description: A dozen people, including 11 high-level crack dealers, were arrested over the weekend on drug charges after a four-month undercover investigation, the police said yesterday.

title: A Quick Quiz for Congress
description: Ask almost any of the people running for Congress in tomorrow's election about the Federal deficit and the answer is likely to be wondrous doubletalk. While local issues and personalities dominate many contests, polls find that the budget deficit is the big national issue. What's the remedy? The incumbents' invariable response is something like, ''I'm okay on that issue.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch last Wednesday on Justice Department inquiries into Administration handling of Nicaraguan rebel aid misidentified a department official in charge of Congressional relations. He is Assistant Attorney General John Bolton, not Roger Bolton.

title: MOST COMPANIES POSTED MODEST GAINS IN QUARTER
description: The combined impact of a weaker dollar and a strong housing market has resulted in slightly higher corporate profits for the third quarter compared with the same period in 1985, economists said. But despite the gains posted by most companies, they added, earnings as a whole were unsatisfactorily low because of continued stiff foreign competition and a general sluggishness in the economy.

title: AFTER RACE, TESTING STARTS
description: THAT was not just any bottle that Mary Nicholas carried with her on the way back to the University of Connecticut last night. That was the official bottle of water from which Gianni Poli took his approved, verified United States Olympic Committee swigs immediately after the Italian won the New York City Marathon yesterday.

title: THE CANDIDATES AND PROPOSITION IN NEW YORK STATE ELECTIONS
description: Following is a list of candidates appearing on ballots in the New York metropolitan area in tomorrow's election. Incumbent candidates are marked with an asterisk (*). Unopposed candidates are marked (U). The abbreviations are: D-Democrat, R-Republican, C-Conservative, L-Liberal, RTL-Right to Life, ATR-Concerned Citizens for Property/School Tax Relief (Act Tax Party), B-Libertarian Party, BSI-Better Staten Island Party, CAP- Clean Air Party, CCL-Concerned Citizens against LILCO, CP-Concerned Party, CVP-Citizens Voice Party, EC-Effective Congress Party, EP-Experience Party, FT-Fair Trade Party, GF-Good Faith Party, HP-Hudson Party, I-Independent Party, IC-Independence Party, ICP-Independent Citizens Party, IL-Independent Legislature Party, IN-Independent Neighty.bors Party, JFA-Justice for All Party, NA-New Alliance Party, PPA-Public Power Alternative to LIKCO Party, RAL-Ratepayers Against LILCO, RI-Rainbow Independent Party, SDA-Stop Drug Abuse Party, SW-Socialist Workers Party, WI-Westchester Independent Party, VP-Veterans Party. GOVERNOR Mario M. Cuomo*, D,L Andrew P. O'Rourke, RC Denis E. Dillon, RTL Lenora B. Fulani, NA ATTORNEY GENERAL Robert Abrams*, D,L Peter T. King, RC,RTL Michael A.
