title: G.O.P. IS EXPECTED TO PICK UP SEATS IN GOVERVOR RACES
description: Republican officials are predicting gains of six or more governorships in this Tuesday's elections, a significant expansion of their party's power in a realm where the Democrats have long held sway.

title: Earnhardt Wins To Clinch 2d Title
description: Dale Earnhardt easily won the Atlanta Journal 500 stock car race to clinch the Nascar Winston Cup championship by shattering a track record today in his fifth victory of the season.

title: Herman Edelsberg, 77, Dies; Was Official of B'Nai B'rith
description: Herman Edelsberg, a former executive director of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and a retired official of B'nai B'rith, has died at the age of 77.

title: 2 NETWORKS TRIM ELECTION COVERAGE
description: In a departure from longstanding tradition, ABC and NBC have cut back their Election Night coverage for tomorrow, in a year that will determine the control of the United States Senate. Executives at both networks said the cuts were made for journalistic, not budgetary, reasons.

title: New York Hospitals Need Reinvestment
description: The cost of health care services, and hospital services in particular, has been a major concern locally and nationally. The hospital community in New York City believes it is time to face an indisputable fact: at some point, continued pressures to cut hospital costs will damage the quality or availability of services. In New York, we are approaching that point.

title: AGENDA: Nov. 3, 1986
description: New Officers at the Top Twenty-seven replacement supervisors will take command today as part of the Police Department's response to allegations of corruption at the 77th Precinct in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, where 13 officers have been suspended. In the largest mass shift of superior officers the department has seen in recent years, designed to strengthen public confidence, John P. McCabe takes over as commander of Brooklyn North, with Philip G. Sheridan becoming the precinct's commander. 127 Utica Avenue, Brooklyn Court Date in Brooklyn Richard L. Rubin, once the second most powerful figure in the Queens Democratic Party after Borough President Donald R. Manes, is to be arraigned on 14 counts of mail fraud and tax evasion. The 46-year-old special counsel to the New York State Assembly Speaker is charged with defrauding the state of more than $49,000. He is accused of inducing two members of the State Assembly to put two of his law firm's secretaries on their state office payrolls. 9:30 A.M. U.S. District Court, 225 Cadman Plaza East, Brooklyn

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1986
description: Companies

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Focus section of the Weather Report on Saturday gave an incorrect date for the winter solstice. The solstice occurs Dec. 21.

title: Postal Worker Union Elects Its President to Third Term
description: Moe Biller has ben elected to a third term as president of the American Postal Workers Union, the union said Friday, despite heavy criticism for his defense of the indicted president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: WAITZ STILL FAR AHEAD
description: Ever since 1978, when she entered and won her first New York City Marathon, Grete Waitz has so thoroughly dominated the competiton that it often seems as if she is running against herself.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1986
description: The World

title: VANISHING BREED OF EDITORS WITH AN INSTINCT FOR ORDER
description: IN David Leavitt's recently published novel, ''The Lost Language of Cranes,'' there is an evocative description of that most unusual breed of human being, the copy editor.

title: Advertising; Magazine Publishers' Group Honors Maurer
description: This year's Publisher of the Year is Gilbert C. Maurer, president of the Hearst Magazine division, the Magazine Publishers Association has announced.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * The Treasury, which on Friday cut the guaranteed minimum interest rate on saving bonds to 6 percent, from 7.5 percent, is to announce today the rate it will pay for the next six months.

title: 12 PAKISTANIS KILLED AS CLASHES CONTINUE BETWEEN ETHNIC FOES
description: Soldiers fired on rival ethnic groups that stoned policemen and attacked each other with guns and knives here today. Hospital officials said at least 12 people had been killed and about 150 wounded.

title: Of Two Young New York Women Whose Good Fortune Ran Out
description: To the Editor:

title: REDSKINS RALLY, WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Gary Clark caught a 38-yard touchdown pass from Jay Schroeder 1 minute 46 seconds into overtime today to give the Washington Redskins a 44-38 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Abominable No-Man
description: Sherman Adams died last week at 87, and I am at last ready to write about the Great Three-President Cover-up.

title: Fluor-Homestake Deal
description: The Fluor Corporation and the Homestake Mining Company are combining their Missouri-based lead operations into a venture named the Doe Run Company, the companies announced. The new concern will be 57.5 percent-owned by the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, Fluor's natural resources subsidiary, with the rest owned by Homestake. Assets provided by Homestake include its Buick Lead mine, mill and smelter at Boss, Mo. St. Joe contributed its smelter at Herculaneum, Mo., and five mines and three mills at Viburnum, Mo.

title: JERSEY'S LAST LAY JUDGE USES COMMON TOUCH
description: On Monday nights the last of New Jersey's lay judges, James T. Leonard Sr. of Municipal Court here, claims the Mayor's office as his chambers and the adjacent Borough Council chambers as his courtroom.

title: FEWER RIDERS TAKE CITY BUSES, AND OFFICIALS AREN'T SURE WHY
description: Bus ridership in New York City has dropped precipitously since the days when Ralph Kramden was behind the wheel, a decline experts cannot fully explain but one they said they feared might make the city's traffic problems even worse.

title: GUATEMALA REBELS SAY, THEY ARE WILLING TO NEGOTIATE
description: Leftist guerrillas fighting in Guatemala say they are willing to open peace talks with the new civilian Government.

title: Market Place; Stock Picking In Oil Services
description: SCHLUMBERGER LTD. is the troubled giant of an oilfield service and equipment industry that is going through a period of intense cost-cutting, restructuring and consolidation. Moreover, when it comes to investment suggestions by security analysts, Schlumberger often takes a back seat to smaller companies in its field.

title: LAST-DITCH FLURRIES ON FINAL WEEKEND
description: On the campaign trail around the nation yesterday, there were exchanges between football players over who should be Senator from Wisconsin, arguments over transcendental meditation in Pennsylvania, impassioned speeches at Sunday morning church services. There were, as well, the debuts of some new negative political commercials.

title: Thorpe Captures Match-Play Event
description: Jim Thorpe defeated Scott Simpson by four shots today in the Seiko Tucson match-play championship.

title: CARNEGIE REPORT: BETTER-SCHOOLS MOVEMENT IS OFF TO COLLEGE
description: A major report urging substantial overhaul of the ''troubled institution'' of undergraduate education is a signal that the school improvement movement, thus far concentrated on primary and secondary schools, is now taking aim at higher education as well.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS DEMOCRATS IN SPEECH
description: President Reagan tonight portrayed the election Tuesday as ''one of choice and direction,'' as he urged the electorate to vote Republican for a ''better future.''

title: THE BEAT GETS STRONGER FOR JETS (8-1) AND GIANTS (7-2)
description: In the Jets' wonderous season, the quarterback woke up this morning with an upset stomach. But this is no ordinary quarterback on what, obviously, is no ordinary team.

title: An Incredible Endorsement for the Senate; 'Fair and Splendid'
description: To the Editor:

title: Black & Decker Change
description: Laurence J. Farley has retired as a director and chairman of the Black & Decker Corporation to form a consulting and investment firm, the company announced Friday. Mr. Farley had relinquished the title of chief executive in March to Nolan D. Archibald, who continued as company president. Black & Decker, which is based in Towson, Md., makes power tools and small appliances.

title: CANADIAN WINS ALLIED RETAILERS FOR $3.6 BILLION
description: Ending a tumultuous struggle to remain independent, the Allied Stores Corporation, which operates such chains as Bonwit Teller, Brooks Brothers and Ann Taylor, agreed yesterday to be acquired by a Canadian concern.

title: Israeli-Born Pianist Makes Debut at the Y
description: The 26th season of Young Concert Artists presentations opened at the 92d Street Y last Tuesday night with the New York debut of a pianist, Yuval Fichman. Born in Tel Aviv, Mr. Fichman - now 21 - was 2 years old when his family moved to Toronto, where he studied at the Royal Conservatory of Music.

title: DANCE: PUNGMUL NORI MADANG, FROM SOUTH KOREA
description: WHAT promises to be one of the most charming programs of the season took place on Friday at Town Hall, when Pungmul Nori Madang presented an evening of Korean folk music and dance. Neither the music nor the dance was entirely unfamiliar, but the program stood out for the amiable high spirits that matched the performers' impressive technique.

title: The Staggering Human Cost of Suez and Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: HUNT TO BEGIN FOR RECIPIENTS OF AIDS BLOOD IN THE REGION
description: Charles Cavaliere, a 68-year-old retired home builder from the Bronx, received a blood transfusion five years ago during heart surgery at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. On Aug. 5 he died there, of AIDS.

title: ENGINEERS EXPRESS DOUBTS ON ROCKET DESIGN
description: Plans to add 100 bolts to a crucial joint in space shuttle booster rockets carry a ''potential for disaster'' by introducing 100 new locations for dangerous flame leaks, according to internal space agency documents.

title: EXPERTS EXPECT SURGE IN TAKEOVERS TO GO ON
description: The steady stream of takeover attempts and restructurings that have hit corporate America recently could become a torrent this week and next, as anxiety over the upcoming tax changes grows.

title: HEARST TO BOW OUT ON AFGHAN SERVICE
description: Afghan refugees, working from Pakistan as the Afghan News Service, could begin generating and distributing news dispatches abroad by mid-March under a controversial program financed by Congress through the United States Information Agency.

title: POP: BRITAIN'S WOODENTOPS
description: BRISK, earnest and professional, the Woodentops, a fast-rising British band, came to the Bottom Line last Tuesday night. Led by the breathy-voiced songwriter Rolo McGinty, the Woodentops play uptempo pop songs that start as if they'd fallen together on the spot, cued by the strumming of Mr. McGinty's guitar.

title: ROUTE BECOMES OUTDOOR PARTY AS POLI, WAITZ WIN
description: New Yorkers demonstrated yet again that they have an unusually high tolerance for celebration.

title: ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY EARNINGS AND SALES AT 303 COMPANIES
Outdoors: Bluefish Amid Solitude
description: AN ominous yellow light suffused the western sky when I arrived at Lobsterville on Martha's Vineyard Island in late afternoon and there were only three other anglers ahead of me - at the beach's west end. Their rods, inserted in sand spikes with lures dangling from them, signaled that they were doing nothing.

title: Topics: Morale Boosters; Pentagon Prizes
description: The Army is considering a new lottery that has nothing to do with the draft. This one would be the usual dollar-a-bet variety with outlandish odds; the proceeds would support ''morale, welfare, recreation and family programs'' for overseas personnel.

title: RANGERS LOSE IN OVERTIME, 5-4
description: There was the high-flying comeback with two late goals and all sorts of frantic attacks at the opposition net. So the cursory review could show that the Rangers had character last night in defeat.

title: Advertising; Hotels Pick New Agencies
description: A COUPLE of hotel chains checked out of their ad agencies over the weekend.

title: Myra Mayman Weds Alexander Bernhard
description: Myra A. Mayman, the master of Cabot House at Harvard University and the director of the Office of the Arts at Harvard and Radcliffe, was married yesterday to Alexander A. Bernhard, a senior partner in the Boston law firm Hale & Dorr. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, a Presbyterian minister and the Plummer Professor of Christian Morals at Harvard, performed the ceremony at the Agassiz House in the Radcliffe Yard in Cambridge, Mass.

title: We Need a Health Policy For Care of the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., Japan Set India Terms
description: The Reagan Administration and Japan have settled on the ground rules under which they would allow their industries to compete in the sale of a powerful computer to India, officials from the Administration and from India said today.

title: Grist for the Cable
description: With Congress out of town, C-SPAN, the cable television service that provides gavel-to-gavel coverage of both the Senate and House of Representatives, has had to find other things to transmit. On Tuesday, what better to show than the elections of the people who will be turning up next year on the Senate and House floors?

title: DANCERS JOINING DIVAS IN ARTISTS' GUILD GALA
description: Star appearances and big production numbers will be the order of the evening when the American Guild of Musical Artists celebrates its 50th anniversary tonight in a ''Golden Jubilee Gala'' at the New York State Theater. There will be plenty of music, as befits a benefit for a union that represents opera performers and musicians. But the union also represents dancers, and present and former stars of dance will perform and speak in the closing half of the evening, in an unusual coming together of leading dance companies and dance figures from New York City and around the nation.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: BEIRUT CAPTORS' STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of the Islamic Holy War statement today on the release of the American hostage David P. Jacobsen, as translated by The Associated Press from the Arabic:

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Bridge: Minihouse Play Kept Going For 35 Hours in Rotterdam
description: Among the competitors in the New York Marathon yesterday were a handful of bridge players, including this writer, exerting themselves in unaccustomed fashion. The Europeans, however, favor a more sedentary marathon stretched over a much longer time period.

title: Deborah Trilling Marries
description: Deborah Eve Trilling, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lionel Trilling of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Leon M. Feder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Josef Feder of Bronxville, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Ephraim Wolf performed the ceremony at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue. Mrs. Feder is a campaign professional for the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York. Her husband is a programmer analyst for Crosslands Savings Bank in Brooklyn Heights.

title: BLACKALLER DEFEATS CONNER IN ROUND 2
description: The 12-Meter USA opened the second series of America's Cup challenger trials today by toppling Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes by 39 seconds.

title: Film on Coach to Be Studied
description: Commissioner Robert C. James of the Atlantic Coast Conference said yesterday that he will review the films and the officials' reports of the Maryland-North Carolina game at Chapel Hill, N.C., Saturday to see if any disciplinary action should be taken against the Maryland coach, Bobby Ross, who charged after the referee when the final gun sounded.

title: Ann Arbor Delegation Leaves for Nicaragua
description: The city of Ann Arbor has sent a 17-member delegation to Nicaragua with medical supplies and a message of condemnation for American support of the rebels fighting the Managua Government.

title: THE DANCE: 'CELL ONE'
description: MONIQUE ERNST and Nadine Helstroffer were in no visible prison. Yet they were certainly locked together in Ms. Helstroffer's ''Cell One,'' which she presented Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: Topics: Morale Boosters; Back to Berry
description: It was one of the cleverest twists in the movie ''Back to the Future'': the idea that the rock-and-roll legend Chuck Berry learned his distinctive guitar sound from a teen-ager transported back in time from the 1980's to the 1950's.

title: D'AMATO SEEKS WIDE-BASED SUPPORT
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato heads toward Election Day tomorrow with an overwhelming lead in the polls over his Democratic challenger, Mark Green, born of a popularity that crosses party lines.

title: WAITZ TAKES 8TH TITLE IN 9 YEARS
description: They ran side by side up First Avenue, past the enthusiastic brunchtime East Side crowds that provide the New York City Marathon with much of its glamour and appeal.

title: QUARTERBACK RETAINS LESSONS OF VIETNAM CHILDHOOD
description: THE chill autumn shadows and lime-green artificial turf of William J. Conrad Stadium are a far cry from the steamy, war-swept Mekong Delta region of South Vietnam where Todd Payton spent the first seven and a half years of his life. Yet for Payton, the junior quarterback at Appalachian State University, the memories and lessons of those formative years remain as vivid as the crackling colors that coat the horizons of this mountainous resort community.

title: Pickled Peppers Mislabeled
description: The Food and Drug Administration has announced the recall of Pandora brand pickled peppers because the labels do not note that they contain sulfites. A spokesman for the agency said Friday that the mislabeled peppers were found in an inspection of the Stamoolis Brothers plant in Pittsburgh, where the peppers are packed. Although sulfites are safe for most consumers, some people suffer an allergic reaction.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Was Connie Mack or Burt Shotton the last manager in the major leagues not to wear a uniform in the dugout? What about Ted Turner: Didn't he manage the Braves one time?

title: MANY CHANGES COMING FOR PENSION PROGRAMS
description: Sweeping changes in employer retirement plans and the way pension benefits are taxed will be wrought by the new tax law over the next few years.

title: CUOMO OPPOSES DECONTROLLING RENTS
description: Governor Cuomo, on a campaign swing across New York State, said today that he opposed any effort to remove New York City apartments from rent stabilization, even as the apartments become vacant.

title: 3 FEWER EXECUTIONS IN 1985, GOVERNMENT REPORTS
description: Eighteen men were executed in eight states in 1985 after an average of about six years on death row, while 80 prisoners were spared, their death sentences vacated or commuted, according to a Federal Government study made public today.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy and Grey Widen Net Income Slightly
description: The Ogilvy Group and Grey Advertising reported their third-quarter earnings Friday.

title: REAGAN APPLAUDS HOSTAGE'S RELEASE
description: President Reagan hailed the release of David P. Jacobsen in Lebanon today and warned that the captors of the remaining American hostages would be held responsible for their safety.

title: FAMILY STEAK HOUSES OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REPORT TO SENATORS FAULTS U.S. INQUIRY ON MARITIME UNION VOTE
description: A Senate subcommittee staff report made available today sharply criticizes the Labor Department's investigation of a contested election of a maritime union.

title: Military Officials Disclose Damage to Submarine
description: One of the Navy's newest nuclear-powered attack submarines sustained dents in its hull two weeks ago in an underwater accident and is undergoing repairs, the Navy and Pentagon officials said today.

title: G.M. SALE: AMERICAN HEADS UNIT
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has announced plans to disengage from this divided land, said today that an American chief executive would continue to run its South African subsidiary after it is sold to its local management this year.

title: 2 Series of Obligations Feature Floating Rates
description: A $490 million issue of collateralized mortgage obligations with floating interest rates was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PORTRAITURE Inge Morath is a photographer, a professional member of Magnum Photos since 1953, with many pictorial essays in magazines and books to her credit. She particularly enjoys taking portraits of friends, which, in the case of her exhibition opening today at the Gotham Book Mart's one-flight-up gallery at 41 West 47 Street (719-4448), is of more than limited family-circle interest.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $31.4 million and $183.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After a realized capital loss of $6.7 million for the quarter and realized capital gain of $50.1 million for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes income from discontinued operations of $1.9 million.

title: CUOMO PLEADS FOR BIG TURNOUT AT POLLS TODAY
description: Governor Cuomo, addressing a rally of several hundred lunch-hour pedestrians in lower Manhattan yesterday, pleaded for voters to disprove predictions of a low turnout at the polls today.

title: COMPUTERVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago quarter loss includes unusual charges of $9.1 million for establishing reserves for employee severance payments, loss on disposal of surplus facilities and adjustments to asset valuations, and the year-ago 9-month includes unusual charges of $16 million.

title: 2 Workers Are Killed After Scaffold Gives Way
description: A scaffold collapsed under two construction workers who were caulking windows on the 25th floor of a downtown project, sending the men plunging to their deaths, officials said.

title: HARLEY-DAVIDSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $847,000 on refinancing for the quarter and 9 months and an extraordinary loss of $805,000 from a reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $893,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary loss of $592,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $959,000 for the 9 months.

title: LEGENDS BECOME NEIGHBORS
description: John Houseman turned to Douglas Fairbanks Jr. yesterday afternoon in the lobby of New York's newest theater and said, ''Well, we're neighbors now.''

title: HORSE SHOW AT GARDEN
description: The million-and-a-half pounds of dirt this event requires are coating the floor of Madison Square Garden and the 30 tons of hay its participants use for fuel have been delivered. Temporary quarters for the 500 horses who will compete here for the next six days are ready to welcome the elite of the equine world. The National Horse Show, the final test of the year for riders ranging from school-aged Pony Club members to those with Olympic credentials, begins with its customary flourish today at the Garden.

title: Advertising; Growth At Hicks Agency
description: SINCE its top management changed in June, the Hicks & Greist agency has pulled in eight new accounts with total billings of about $25 million. And that, exclaimed its prideful president, Hank Seiden, pushes the agency into the $125 million class.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim Witherspoon will defend his World Boxing Association heavyweight title against Tony Tubbs Dec. 12 at Madison Square Garden. . . A hairline fracture of a back vertebra suffered in Pitt's loss to Syracuse Saturday has knocked out Pitt's quarterback, John Congemi, for the rest of the season. . . . The New England Patriots said their All-Pro outside linebacker, Andre Tippett, may miss only three games with a right-knee injury he suffered Sunday in the game against the Falcons. He underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday.

title: Conservation Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: ROYAL INTERNATIONAL OPTIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures for 1985 are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: NAC RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $165,000 and $2,243,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and for both periods includes a pre-tax charge of $1.5 million resulting from the previously-announced commutation of certain retrocessional agreements with Universal Reinsurance Corp., a subsidiary of Armco Inc., completed in October 1986; the company has received immediate payment for the agreed upon cash settlement and has recorded undiscounted claims and claims expense liabilities, including a provision for incurred but not reported losses, of about $6 million in the 1986 third-quarter financial statement; as a result of this transaction, the company has eliminated its single largest reinsurance recoverable. c-Net loss and includes investment gains of $199,000. d-Includes investment gains of $2,311,000.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chancellor Corp., Boston, said it had received a proposal to be acquired for $12 a share for each of the 2.3 million common shares. The company did not name its suitor.

title: GREEN CROSSES THE STATE IN A CLOSING-DAY WHIRL
description: While Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato took a respite from the campaign trail today, apparently comfortable with his lead in the polls, his Democratic challenger, Mark Green, was making a hectic, last-day whirl around the state.

title: Bargaining Power Of 'Star Wars'
description: To the Editor:

title: TO EXPERT EYES, CITY STREETS ARE OPEN MENTAL WARDS
description: BROADWAY from Columbus Circle through the West Side is filled with new condominiums and well-dressed shoppers come to sample the sparkling pleasures of gourmet delicatessens and designer boutiques.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $326,000 for the quarter and $194,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $314,000 and $1,043,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago results are restated by $2,156,000 due to the sale of assets.

title: GOODYEAR WEIGHS SALE OF CELERON UNIT
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it might sell Celeron, the oil and gas exploration company it purchased just three years ago, as part of a defensive restructuring.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month results include a $3,095,000 gain from a settlement with Lionel Corp., a $666,000 provision for factory consolidation and restructuring of the company's farm equipment business and a $1,171,000 reserve for unrealized losses on marketable securities.

title: AMERICAN CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,135,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $1,089,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,645,000 and $11,412,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: AQUINO CALLS REBELS TRUCE OFFER 'A STEP FORWARD'
description: President Corazon C. Aquino today called a Communist cease-fire proposal ''a step forward'' and said negotiators for both sides would meet this week to discuss details.

title: Grab a Post-Election Scorecard: Changes Ahead
description: As President Reagan completed his campaign on the West Coast for Republican candidates today, his chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, quietly slipped out of the White House for a brief game of golf.

title: DOTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $4,052,000 for the quarter and $7,363,000 for the 9 months. c-After a capital loss of $42,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $124,000 for the 9 months.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $5,905,000 and $7,738,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $1,357,000 and $4,822,000 for the same periods. c-Net income and includes income of $$38,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $735,000. d-Includes a loss of $17,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $2,680,000. Figures for 1985 are restated to reflect the restructuring of the company.

title: COMPUTER FRAUD FOUGHT IN TEXAS
description: The Secretary of State of Texas has ordered ''additional security'' procedures in Tuesday's election to prevent fraud in the 40 or so counties that use computerized vote counting and reporting.

title: CANDIDATES MAKE APPEALS TO GET OUT VOTERS TODAY
description: With a last hurrah of rallies, speeches and blustery predictions, candidates made final campaign swings through New York, New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday, appealing to voters for support and a big turnout in today's election.

title: People Express Seen Lacking Choice in Bid
description: People Express Inc., which had few alternatives and little time remaining, had little choice but to accept the Texas Air Corporation's revised bid, analysts said today.

title: SOVIET TO HEAR A 'BORIS' FROM MAINE
description: Next Sunday, 122 carpenters, secretaries, artists, schoolchildren, an architect, a lawyer, a sawyer, a cook, a fisherman, a veterinarian and others - all of them amateur singers - are scheduled to depart this tiny coastal village of 900 to sing a classic Russian opera in the Soviet Union.

title: VLI Ponders Sale
description: The VLI Corporation said it was discussing the sale of the company, but Robert A. Elliott, VLI's president and chief executive, did not identify the potential buyer. VLI makes the vaginal contraceptive sponge called Today, the leading over-the-counter vaginal contraceptive, with about 30 percent of the market. VLI, which is based in Irvine, Calif., lost $3.3 million on sales of $13.5 million through the first nine months of 1986.

title: COURT UPHOLDS FUNDS FOR FAMILY PLANNING CLINIC
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not deny family planning grants to private groups merely because they use money from other sources to offer abortions and abortion counseling.

title: MORRIS AND GIANTS ARE MAKING A RUN
description: The Giants have just beaten the Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys, their major division rivals, six days apart. They share the division lead with the Redskins at 7-2, and they have earned a breather.

title: SIPPIE WALLACE, BLUES SINGER KNOWN AS 'TEXAS NIGHTINGALE'
description: Sippie Wallace, a major blues singer and songwriter of the 1920's, died Saturday at Sinai Hospital in Detroit. She was 88 years old.

title: FAMOUS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
description: b-Includes expenses for closed restaurants of $90,000 for the quarter and $369,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $67,000 and $572,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $30,000 for the quarter and $382,000 for the 9 months and the 9 months also includes gains from real estate transactions of $140,000.

title: HOUSE PANEL QUESTIONS U.S. RULES ON GENETICALLY ALTERED PRODUCTS
description: The House Science and Technology Committee has questioned the soundness of scientific principles underlying the Reagan Administration's new program for regulating pesticides and other products made from genetically engineered microorganisms.

title: HBO'S 'FLORIDA STRAITS' WITH RAUL JULIA AS STAR
description: ''FLORIDA STRAITS'' is the kind of adventure yarn that hopes the audience won't have time to begin asking questions. The action takes place not off Florida but in and around Cuba. The filming was actually done in the Myrtle Beach area of South Carolina. Authenticity is not at a premium in this Home Box Office presentation, which can be seen on the pay-cable service tonight at 11 o'clock.

title: Pepsico Plans Pizza For Soviet
description: Pepsico Inc., which introduced American soft drinks to the Soviet Union on a wide scale 13 years ago, now wants to put its own brand of pizza on the Soviet menu as well.

title: DRESHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraorordinary gains of $167,000 for the quarter and $402,000 for the 9 months.

title: Police Chief Will Quit If Pay Initiative Passes
description: Police Chief Daryl Gates and nearly 600 police and fire department employees have submitted resignations that are to take effect if voters approve an initiative to roll back public sector salaries and benefits.

title: WHITE HOUSE MAID IS CLEARED IN MUNITIONS SMUGGLING CASE
description: The munitions smuggling case against a White House maid, Anita Sanabria Castelo, was dismissed today as her trial was to begin in Federal District Court.

title: P&F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $281,000 and $776,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $229,000 and $611,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: BIG MONEY AND SCIENCE
description: THE sums of taxpayer money typically appropriated for Federal projects are so numbingly large that attention tends to glide right past the numbers themselves. But the treasure available to the human species is not infinite, and all too often, the world's big spenders inadvertently starve Peter to pay Paul.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARKLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $110,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $306,000 and a gain of $9,813,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOSTAGE'S RELEASE IS LINKED TO SHIFT IN IRANIAN POLICY
description: A power struggle in Iran is believed to be one element that cleared the way for release of an American hostage in Lebanon and improved chances for freeing the remaining captives, according to Arab diplomats here and reports in the Arab press.

title: Inside the Themeless Election
description: What is today's election all about? It's surprising that the question remains open on Election Day. Off-year Congressional campaigns usually send a message. In 1974 it was outrage about Watergate; in 1978, rapidly rising inflation; in 1982, the Reagan recession. What's this year's theme?

title: THE WORLD, BRUTALLY, INTRUDES ON A YESHIVA
description: At the yeshiva the boys do not watch television or listen to the radio. ''We have a family rule,'' said Michael Burr, who has two sons at Torah High School of Long Beach. ''I order them to read Time magazine every week. They have to know a little of what's going on in the world.'' Yonah and Shmuel tell their father they'd rather spend time studying Talmud.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2.3 million compared with a similar credit of $709,000 in the year-ago quarter. c-Includes a tax credit of $5.2 million for the latest year, compared with a similar credit of $3.2 million a year ago, as well as a gain of $4.8 million from discontinued operations for fiscal 1985.

title: Shaklee to Buy RJR Nabisco Unit
description: The Shaklee Corporation said that it had agreed to purchase the Bear Creek Corporation, a direct marketing company, from RJR Nabisco Inc. for $123 million.

title: Kissinger Files Magazine Suit
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger failed yesterday in a bid to stop distribution of the December issue of Penthouse magazine, but has filed a $10 million suit over an ''unauthorized'' interview that was promoted as an exclusive.

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
description: b-After special pre-tax charges of $128.7 million related to a reduction in force program, restructuring of Verbatim operations in the U.S., the closure of certain facilities in Canada, and charges from the expansion of Kodak marketing activities in Japan for the quarter and included special pre-tax charges of $545.5 million for the 9 months. c-Included pre-tax charges of $563 million, of which $494 million was associated with Kodak's withdrawal from instant photography.

title: KEY HOSPITAL ACCREDITING AGENCY TO START WEIGHING MORTALITY RATES
description: The principal agency that accredits the nation's hospitals said today that it would soon begin using surgical mortality and complication rates, along with other measures of medical outcome, as a central tool in accreditations.

title: Farley Rethinks Its Public Offering
description: Farley Apparel Inc. will delay its $510 million initial public offering and will lower its price, having received a lackluster response from Wall Street, industry officials said.

title: President Is Criticized Over Clean Water Bill
description: Consumer and environmental groups today accused President Reagan of deliberately delaying a veto of legislation to strengthen the Clean Water Act until after the election.

title: THE STAGE: 'MAMA'
description: MORE than hope emerges from the suffering and struggles of six black women created by Pauline Myers in ''Mama'' at the Ernie Martin Studio Theater. Her deft skill in portraying them, with few props and little costume change, is admirable, and it is her triumph as a writer to leave one with a surprising joy at the end of the performance.

title: DEVON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $88,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $431,000 for the quarter and $654,000 for the 6 months.

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCARFO AND 11 INDICTED IN JERSEY AS CRIME CONSPIRATORS
description: Twelve men, including Nicodemo Scarfo, said by prosecutors to be the boss of a Philadelphia organized-crime family, have been indicted on charges of loan sharking, extortion and conducting an illegal gambling business in a racketeering conspiracy, Attorney General W. Cary Edwards announced today.

title: MASTER OF MOZAMBIQUE: JOAQUIM ALBERTO CHISSANO
description: A few years back, Joaquim Chissano led a delegation of foreign diplomats on a tour of a Mozambican province that was making impressive economic strides in this impoverished nation. Addressing a crowd of about 5,000 people at one village, Mr. Chissano asked if they had a rich bounty of goats, chickens and food.

title: LINKED SMOKING AND DISEASE
description: Dr. E. Cuyler Hammond, the biologist and epidemiologist who did early research showing that cigarette smokers had a high risk of death from lung cancer, heart disease and other causes, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. His family said he had died of cancer of the lymph system. He was 74 years old.

title: BRIGHT LIGHTS, BIG TOYS: F.A.O. SCHWARZ TO REOPEN
description: Come Thursday at noon, it won't be surprising to see normally sedate adults running down Fifth Avenue with a child in one hand and a credit card in the other. That's the day the new F.A.O. Schwarz opens. Set back on the General Motors Plaza is the famous toy store's gleaming new headquarters - a 40,000-square-foot store on two levels that stretches from Fifth to Madison Avenue. There's nothing understated about the new store. Flashing lights, catchy music, a Noah's ark of stuffed animals and a 28-foot-high clock tower that can sing a personalized birthday greeting are part of the emporium, which will surely be a tourist attraction.

title: Bail Is Set for Suspect Accused of Espionage
description: A Federal magistrate today refused to hold without bail a man accused of espionage, saying the case represented a ''serious charge'' but was not ''high-level espionage that we have had in recent years.''

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures in U.S. funds.

title: Honda Made in Canada
description: The first Honda car made in Canada, an Accord XL, rolled off the assembly line here today. Honda Canada Inc. said the assembly plant would probably produce 20,000 vehicles in its first full year.

title: AGENDA: Nov. 4, 1986
description: Races in 3 States Voters in the metropolitan region will go to the polls today, ending an election season in which many incumbents seemed even more secure than usual. There are gubernatorial and senatorial races in New York and Connecticut, two county executive posts at stake in New Jersey, bond issues to clean up toxic waste in New York and New Jersey and competition for Congressional seats in all three states. Polls open in New York, 6 A.M to 9 P.M; in New Jersey, 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.; and in Connecticut, 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. New Testimony in Fraud Trial

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Praise From the Chaplain
description: The chaplain of the Senate, the Rev. Richard C. Halverson, has written a letter praising a Connecticut official of the American Civil Liberties Union for his role in defending the right of a Stratford contractor to hold small prayer meetings in his home without government approval. Mr. Halverson was elected to his post in 1981, after the Republicans had taken majority control of the Senate.

title: Going to Bulgaria
description: Rozanne L. Ridgway, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, is due in Sofia, Bulgaria, this weekend on an unannounced visit.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $37,000 from the sale of a 50-percent interest in a subsidiary. c-Net loss

title: Snake Shuts Indian Factory
description: An engineering factory near the beach resort of Goa has been closed for more than two months because a venomous cobra occupies the owner's office, according to the Press Trust of India. In an account that appeared in newspapers today, the news agency said the snake was first seen spread on the factory owner's chair in the village of Revoda Nadoda on Aug. 28. Since snakes are worshiped by many Hindus, the workers ran to a temple for advice and were told not to disturb the ''cobra god,'' the agency said.

title: Gianettino & Meredith Gets Resorts Casino
description: While Hicks & Greist, as noted above, was picking up the Taj Mahal hotel and casino that Resorts International is building in Atlantic City, Gianettino & Meredith of Mountainside, N.J., was being named agency for the Resorts International Hotel Casino in that same city. As with Taj Mahal, the former agency is Al Paul Lefton.

title: Worth the Wait
description: Raymond Berry, coach of the New England Patriots, tells why he didn't mind waiting five minutes for the replay officials to nullify an Atlanta touchdown Sunday: ''The purpose of the replay is to keep an injustice from happening, especially when the injustice is against us.''

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
U.S.-Iraq Trade
description: Trade between Iraq and the United States will probably top $915 million this year, an official at the Baghdad Trade Fair said today. American imports, mainly crude oil, are expected to exceed $425 million; American exports, mainly farm products, are expected to exceed $490 million. The two countries restored diplomatic ties in late 1984 after a 17-year break.

title: Intertec Adds 3 Journals
description: The Intertec Publishing Corporation, a subsidiary of Macmillan Inc., has acquired three publications from Wiesner Publishing of Denver. All controlled-circulation publications, they are Mobile Radio Technology, Mobile Radio Technology International and Telecarrier. That leaves Wiesner with five magazines.

title: EMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
What About Dinner?
description: Shortly after the Mets won the World Series, they were invited to the White House by President Reagan. They will go to the White House Nov. 12 to be honored in a Rose Garden ceremony.

title: FRAUD OF CENTURY?
description: Behind the curtain, Sugar Ray Leonard, in a white leather double-breasted blazer, had to wait a few minutes for Marvelous Marvin Hagler to arrive. When the undisputed world middleweight champion, in a black suit with a red tie, finally appeared, according to Irving Rudd, a Top Rank aide-de-fight-camp who was back there, the two gladiators shook hands. ''Warmly,'' Rudd reported. But then each boxer wanted to know why they were backstage yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria hotel's grand ballroom behind that thick cream-colored curtain.

title: LSI LIGHTING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $8,452,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,318,000 and $7,360,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. d-Net loss The company said the latest 9-month includes a pre-tax gain of $21.5 million from the settlement of obligations of terminated pension plans. The 1985 results have been restated to reclassify certain businesses to discontinued operations.

title: LONG-TERM CHERNOBYL FALLOUT: COMPARISON TO BOMBS ALTERED
description: IN the aftermath of a dramatic assertion in September that the amount of long-term cesium radiation emitted into the environment from the Chernobyl disaster equaled that of all previous nuclear bombs and tests, a number of scientists have concluded that the assertion was wrong.

description: b-After tax credits of $296,000 for the quarter and $393,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $440,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Royal Caribbean Cruise To Chiat/Day
description: The New York office of Chiat/Day has won the $17 million Royal Caribbean Cruise Lines account in a victory that was particularly sweet.

title: Careers; University Teaches By Satellite
description: A MASTER'S degree from the world's first ''satellite'' university, the National Technological University, will be granted on Nov. 19, according to its president, Dr. Lionel V. Baldwin. The school, which operates without campus in Fort Collins, Colo., beams graduate courses to students by satellite.

title: BANK ASKS THAT BID BE WITHDRAWN
description: The board of the BankAmerica Corporation today asked the First Interstate Bancorp to withdraw its takeover proposal until new management at BankAmerica can complete a thorough review of the bank's strategic plans.

title: DALLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,218,000 for the quarter and $5,162,000 for the 9 months.

title: British Roads Are Among the Safest in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO PARTIES FOCUS ON SENATE CONTROL IN ELECTION TODAY
description: With Democrats hoping to take control of the United States Senate after six years in opposition, Americans vote today in national elections that will measure how deeply President Reagan has affected the nation's political climate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1986
description: Companies

title: Mayor Barry's Opponent Faces the Music
description: At a recent candidates' forum, Carol Schwartz, the Republican candidate for Mayor of the District of Columbia, walked up to a crowded podium and sat comfortably in one of two available seats. The seat had been reserved for her Democratic opponent, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. ''Look at her - she's so anxious to move Marion out, she hasn't even noticed that she's sitting in his chair,'' said Hazel Woods, a Barry supporter.

title: ARMS CONTROL AGENCY EMPLOYEE INVESTIGATED OVER SECURITY LAPSES
description: An employee of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency is under investigation for ''allegations of improper handling of highly classified material'' and has been on paid leave for more than a year, a Government official said early today.

title: BROOK'S HINDU EPIC TO TOUR IN U.S.
description: Peter Brook's nine-hour theatrical adaptation of a Hindu epic is being translated into English and will embark on a yearlong world tour starting next summer.

title: FINANCING BY U.S. AWAITED
description: Prices of notes and bonds rose modestly yesterday in advance of the Treasury's three-part financing, totaling $29 billion, which begins today and will conclude on Thursday.

title: OMAHA MAYOR'S OPPONENTS PRESS ANOTHER RECALL EFFORT
description: Mayor Michael Boyle, recently regarded as a rising star among Nebraska Democrats, is now facing a fight for his political life against a determined band of Omahans who have never before figured prominently in politics.

title: WAGNER URGES NEW CONTRACT FOR QUINONES
description: The Board of Education president, Robert F. Wagner Jr., said yesterday that he would ask the board to renew the contract of Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones.

description: Bob Valesente, Kansas football coach, after the 64-3 thrashing administered by Oklahoma: ''It was like David and Goliath, except that Goliath brought along his 60 bothers.''

title: Airlines Face Losses in '86
description: The world's major airlines could lose up to $800 million this year, the first collective deficit since 1982, because of a weak dollar and passenger fear of terrorism, the president of the International Air Transport Association told the I.A.T.A. annual meeting here.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Includes a $500,000 gain from life insurance proceeds received as a result of the death of a former director.

description: Nathan's Famous Inc., whose hot dogs have been attracting New Yorkers for 70 years, has now drawn the attention of a corporate suitor.

title: JUSTICES AGREE TO DECIDE PRETRIAL DETENTION ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a 1984 law in which Congress authorized pretrial detention of defendants considered to be dangerous.

description: With dozens of personal tax benefits set to be curtailed one way or another in a few weeks - including the deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses - individuals will need to do more than mourn the cutbacks.

title: MOZAMBIQUE GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Foreign Minister Joaquim A. Chissano was named President of Mozambique today.

The company said that revenue represents gross revenue which excludes revenue from sales of properties and investments.

title: Bulgaria Blames Neglect For Chemical Disaster
description: Bulgaria gave the first details today of an explosion that killed 17 people at the country's biggest chemical complex, blaming a lack of safety checks.

title: Guilty Plea in Theft of $13.5 Million
description: An investment banker based in Greenwich, Conn., has pleaded guilty to stealing $13.5 million from two banks and attempting to steal $23 million from three other banks in a complex scheme that involved faked documents and impostors who posed as bank officers and brokers.

title: THE HOUSE WITH A PICKET FENCE IS YIELDING TO CONDOS
description: The condominium complex - a type of residence that has been spreading around the metropolitan area like autumn leaves - is replacing the old concept of ''home as castle'' with a new sense of home as collective.

title: AMERICAN CABLESYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Black Protesters Occupy Hattiesburg Board Office
description: Black protesters in their fourth day of a sit-in at a school administration building expanded their demands today to include more hiring and job promotions for blacks by area businesses.

title: Talking Business with Nitzberg of Equitec; Shelters Seen As 'Dinosaurs'
description: The Tax Reform Act of 1986 cracks down on tax shelters by mandating that the so-called passive losses from this type of investment cannot be used to shelter income from salary, dividends and other non-passive sources.

title: NEWS AGENCY DISSEMINATES AND RETRACTS REPORT OF ROOFTOP SNIPER
description: At 10:15 A.M. yesterday, the Reuters news agency transmitted what appeared to be an important news report: a sniper on a New York City rooftop, firing at aircraft and shouting pro-Iranian slogans, had been shot by the police ''in a daring helicopter assault.''

title: Gedman Injured
description: Rich Gedman was rushed to the hospital yesterday after being hit on the cheek by a ball during practice in Tokyo and will miss the rest of the major-league All-Stars goodwill series. The Red Sox catcher, who was warming up the Pittsburgh pitcher Rick Rhoden, needed two stitches.

title: COUNCIL OPPOSES COLORING OLD FILMS
description: The National Council on the Arts has passed a resolution opposing the practice of applying color to black-and-white films.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $14,299 and $44,041 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $40,131 for the quarter and $111,675 for the 9 months.

title: STOMACH BALLOON ALERT
description: The maker of a stomach balloon used to treat obesity has warned doctors to curtail its use after scores of people who used the device developed serious medical problems and one died.

title: GANDER MOUNTAIN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $270,000.

title: THAI PLANE INCIDENT PROMPTS A NEW LOOK AT JAPAN GANGS
description: A midair explosion that crippled a Thai jetliner bound for Japan a week ago has provided Japanese with an unexpected glimpse into the often deadly, sometimes slapstick world of their organized criminals, the yakuza.

title: BEAR, STEARNS CHIEF FELT HE BOUGHT FOR BELZBERGS
description: The chairman of Bear, Stearns & Company, Alan C. Greenberg, has said in an affidavit that he bought Ashland Oil Company stock on the assumption that he was buying it for the Belzberg family investment company.

title: Chamber Music Society In Schuman Premiere
description: William Schuman is one of our most skillful composers: even when he seems to have nothing to say, he says it adeptly. Mr. Schuman's ''Dances: Divertimento for Wind Quintet and Percussion,'' written for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, which played the work's world premiere performances over the weekend at Alice Tully Hall, is what Richard Strauss called a ''wrist exercise'' - a demonstration of the composer's craft and little more. Mr. Schuman has yoked together jigs, schottisches, waltzes, Charlestons and other dance styles into a miniature suite, expertly voiced for the winds and spiced by trap drums and mallet instruments. The results are slight, with no sense of urgency or statement.

title: GUILFORD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
COLUMBIA FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

There are no 1985 share earnings because the company converted to the stock form of onwership in November 1985.

title: Albania Opens Party Parley
description: Albania's ruling Communist Party began its first congress today without Enver Hoxha, who died last year. The new leader, Ramiz Alia, paid tribute to Mr. Hoxha in a keynote speech. The 1,500 delegates are expected to concentrate on ways to stimulate and modernize the economy.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net loss

Rated triple-A by Moody's and S.&P., the notes are noncallable for life and yield 15-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury notes with a similar maturity.

title: CONGRESSMAN IN HARD, COSTLY RACE IN RHODE ISLAND
description: The race for the House seat here in the eastern half of Rhode Island has become the most expensive in state history as the long-time incumbent, Fernand J. St Germain, has opened the checkbook to counter a strong Republican challenge that stresses allegations of personal misconduct.

title: RAMS EDGE BEARS BY 20-17 ON LATE KICK 8M1>
description: Mike Lansford kicked a 50-yard field goal with four seconds remaining tonight to give the the Los Angeles Rams a victory over the Chicago Bears, 20-17.

title: CLUES TO SEEK WHILE RESULTS UNFOLD ON TV
description: So close is the tussle for control of the Senate in Tuesday's general election that television viewers who want to make their own analyses or compare theirs with those of the commentators are in for a long and perhaps confusing evening.

HOECHST TO ACQUIRE CELANESE
description: In a merger that would form the world's largest chemical company, Hoechst A.G. of West Germany said yesterday that it would acquire the New York-based Celanese Corporation for $2.84 billion.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations. As always, our strongest recommendation is nonpartisan: Vote. Polls are open in New York from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. and Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. NEW YORK GOVERNOR AND LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR Mario Cuomo and Stanley Lundine (D-L) UNITED STATES SENATE Alfonse D'Amato (R-C-RTL) COMPTROLLER Edward Regan (R-C) ATTORNEY GENERAL Robert Abrams (D-L) QUESTION A $1.45 billion environmental bond issue to clean up contaminated waste dumps, expand state forests, preserve historic buildings and improve municipal parks. Yes.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is the sun lower in the sky this time of year? A.In the Northern Hemisphere, the sun appears lower in the sky as it heads toward its winter solstice - the time when the sun is farthest south of the Equator, according to Sherwood Harrington, an astronomer with the Astronomical Society of the Pacific. Because the earth's axis is tilted about 21 degrees, the Northern Hemisphere is tilted away from the sun in winter. As a result, the sun appears lower in the sky, Mr. Harrington said. At the same time, the Southern Hemisphere is tilted toward the sun; to people who live there, the sun appears higher in the sky. Q.What is mitral valve prolapse, and what dangers does it pose? A.Mitral valve prolapse is a common heart condition in which the mitral valve, between the left atrium and the left ventricle, is deformed. Normally, the mitral valve prevents blood from flowing back from the ventricle to the atrium instead of on to the rest of the body. A deformed mitral valve has excessive motion and moves past the normal ''closed'' position, thus allowing backflow of blood. The condition affects about 15 percent of the population but is most common in women. For the most part, the condition is innocuous, according to Dr. Richard H. Kay of New York Medical College. But he said mitral valve prolapse had been associated with heart murmurs, palpitations, infections and other conditions.

title: MUSIC: LATIN CRACK-DOWN
description: THE second Crack-Down concert, Saturday at the Felt Forum, was a salsa summit meeting. Like Friday's pop Crack-Down concert at Madison Square Garden, the five-hour show raised money for anti-crack education; no figures were available as of yesterday. One group, Bobby Rodriguez and Company, sang a bilingual anti-crack song, while the musicians Willie Colon, Ray Barretto (who did not perform) and Ruben Blades spoke about the threat of drugs. ''We must show a country that's already trying to keep us down that we have dignity,'' said Mr. Barretto.

title: A WAY WITH WORDS
description: THE early Apple Macintosh was cute. It had a great personality, it was easy to get to know, and its little mouse was lots of fun to play with. But could a serious writer have a meaningful relationship with it?

title: European Satellite Plan
description: European Community ministers today approved technical standards for direct satellite broadcasts. The standards will be used for satellites launched in the next few years and are meant to keep American and Japanese competitors, who chose a different system, out of Europe.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ben Kahn Furs Corp. named Edward Graf president of production and retail and Joseph Barlow president of the wholesale division.

title:
WHY VOTER TURNOUT IS TURNING OFF;
Registration Creates An Obstacle
description: One postmortem on the 1986 general election can be written before a single vote is counted: voter turnout was shockingly low. Turnout is always low in the United States. Only the Swiss vote less. It is a mistake to think that Americans stay home on Election Day because they are less interested in politics than are citizens of other democracies. Research shows that compared to people elsewhere, we are more interested in public affairs, more politically active in ways other than voting, prouder of our governmental institutions, more satisfied with the way the system works and less suspicious of politicians.

title: JACKSON SUSPECTS SABOTAGE IN MACHEL'S DEATH

This music for recorder and harpsichord, played in the lovely and acoustically gracious Corpus Christi Church near Columbia University, began in a world harmonically confined but wonderfully free in its florid melody - with such composers as Clemens non Papa, Bassano and Fontana.

Others were Doyle Alexander of Atlanta, Ernie Whitt of Toronto, Sammy Stewart of Boston, Doug Corbett of California, Rudy Law of Kansas City, Jerry Royster of San Diego, Enos Cabell of Los Angeles, Tom Hume of Philadelphia and Charlie Lea of Montreal, who has not pitched for two years because of arm problems.

title: Swiss Watch Exports
description: Swiss watch exports are unlikely to rise much above current levels in the next few months after increasing only eight-tenths of 1 percent in the first nine months of this year over the corresponding 1985 period, the Swiss Watchmakers Federation said in its newsletter. It attributed the slow growth to the strong Swiss franc, depression in the oil-producing countries and slowness of the economic reovery generally. The fall in tourism also slowed sales to foreigners here, it said.

title: PHYSICISTS TRY TO GLIMPSE THE UNIVERSE AT BIRTH
description: Using the most powerful collisions of subatomic particles ever produced in a laboratory, physicists hope to recreate conditions they believe existed briefly after the explosive birth of the universe, before the formation of matter as it exists today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Bridge column yesterday, about the Minihouse Bridgemarathon in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, misidentified an operetta and its lyricist. The operetta is ''Cox and Box,'' with music by Sir Arthur Sullivan and words by Sir Francis Burnand, not Sir W. S. Gilbert.

title: City Opera 'Mefistofele' Stars Harry Dworchak
description: Harry Dworchak, whose bass voice is one of the finest to be heard in New York these days, took on that curious pinnacle of the Italian bass repertory, Boito's Mefistofele, at the New York City Opera Saturday evening. From a purely vocal standpoint the part is a far cry from what Italian composers traditionally asked of this voice: It calls for strong output of solid tone, little more. Mr. Dworchak gave that. Indeed his prodigality with the upper middle range seemed to cost him a bit at the extremes. But for the most part it was a pleasure to hear such juicy, flowing sound projected out so easily into the big house.

title: Kodak's Net Rises by 6.9%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest producer of photographic equipment, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter rose 6.9 percent, as sales increased 7.7 percent.

title: Queens Figure Denies Charges
description: Richard L. Rubin, a close political associate of Donald R. Manes, the late Queeens Borough President, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to 14 counts of mail fraud and tax evasion.

title: ERROR ADMITTED ON HELICOPTER THAT CRASHED
description: A 48-year-old mechanic admitted yesterday that he had accidentally installed the wrong clutch in the helicopter that plunged into the Hudson River on Oct. 22 killing a radio traffic reporter.

title: MOSCOW SEES A GOOD EXAMPLE IN A BIG MAC
description: Television today showed a flattering portrait of a McDonald's restaurant, and the commentator said, ''Maybe there is something we can learn from this.''

title: International Pastime
description: With 19 million players in the United States alone, baseball already claims between 150 million and 200 million active participants around the globe. They are scattered among some 70 nations, almost half the 164 members of the International Olympic Committee, whose vote last month to make baseball an official Olympic sport seems to have pushed the game well on its way toward world-pastime status.

description: Quietly and with little ceremony, the cremated remains of the seven astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded last January have been buried in a small common grave in Arlington National Cemetery.

title:
Why Voter Turnout Is Turning Off;
Candidates Avoid The Public
description: With each election year, one-way campaigning by both Republicans and Democrats, especially on television, is replacing traditional stumping. What's getting lost, to the detriment of democracy, is the old-fashioned practice of going directly to the people - to whom, after all, candidates and officials are answerable.

title: The Honor of Network News

title: VERMONT GOVERNOR MAY FAIL TO GET MAJORITY SHE NEEDS TO WIN

Revised figures showed a record 20,502 runners were at the starting line on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge Sunday morning, with a record 19,412 finishing the race. ''Our success has created a problem,'' said Lebow, the race director. ''We've reached our limit.''

For this last, you need 45 minutes of instruction. Then you sign a waiver, and sail off at 26 miles an hour. ''Innovation,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M., is a pleasant half-hour.

title: MUSIC: LIONEL RICHIE
description: IF today's pop-music pantheon were a high-school-yearbook hall of fame, Lionel Richie would probably be the hands-down winner in a number of categories, including best mixer, most school spirit and best all-around. The singer-songwriter-pianist, who appeared at Madison Square Garden last week through Thursday with a seven-member band, has amassed an audience that includes sizable pop-soul, country and rock constituencies. As pop music's Mr. Nice Guy, Mr. Richie oozes sincerity and drips with superlatives. Appropriating the word ''outrageous'' as his motto, he has personally redefined it to mean polite, outgoing, caring and enthusiastic.

title: U.S. LOOKS FOR SIGN IN CAPTORS' MOVE
description: Senior Administration officials said today that they were uncertain why Islamic Holy War had decided to release one of its American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Knife Found Near Site Of Murder of Student
description: The police found a knife today behind some debris in the backyard of the dormitory where a 16-year-old student was found stabbed to death Saturday morning.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a capital loss of $217,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $3,475,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $788,000 for the quarter and $13,152,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago figures adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in June.

title: MARTEN TRANSPORT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''I ALWAYS wonder how many clothes people can look at,'' Willi Smith said as New York's spring fashion shows began just days after the European collections ended. But even red-eyed, fashion-weary souls found reason to raise their dark glasses here last week. Already, New York has offered drama, news, designer debuts, comedy and nostalgia. THE cancellation of the Marc

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books: Complex Castro
description: FIDEL: A Critical Portrait. By Tad Szulc. 703 pages. William Morrow. $19.95.

title: Labatt Acquisition
description: John Labatt Ltd., the Canadian brewery and food concern, agreed to acquire the Pasquale Food Company for $18.50 a share, or about $165 million. Pasquale, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., is a supplier of fresh pizza and pasta to supermarket delicatessens.

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September.

title: Snow Job
description: Not long ago in these pages, Sal Yvars, an old teammate of Bobby Thomson, was reminiscing about the old days on the occasion of a party that marked the 35th anniversary of Thomson's miraculous home run. Yvars also told another story at that party, and what brings it to mind now is the sight of Bobby Ross, the Maryland football coach, charging headlong after the referee at the final gun of the loss to North Carolina on Saturday. If Ross thinks he got jobbed, he should have been in Denver one spring day in 1953, when the New York Giants and the Cleveland Indians were barnstorming their way back east from their Arizona camps.

title: FROM GAMBLING TO ECOLOGY, VOTERS IN 43 STATES TAKE UP BALLOT ISSUES TODAY
description: Voters in several states where moral opposition to gambling has been strong in the past must decide Tuesday whether to turn to it as a way to offset declining tax revenue.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. NUGGETS, at Denver, 9:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 9:30 P.M.) NETS VS. WASHINGTON BULLETS, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) HOUSTON ROCKETS VS.

title: BULLOUGH DISMISSED BY BILLS
description: Last season, Ralph Wilson, the owner of the Buffalo Bills, waited four games before dismissing his coach, Kay Stephenson. This season, he showed more restraint.

title: ITT, C.G.E. Add to Deal
description: The ITT Corporation said it and Compagnie Generale d'Electricite of France had expanded the number of businesses that would be included in a joint venture the two plan to form by the end of the year. ITT said C.G.E.'s cable and its own United States fiber optical cable operations would be included in the venture first announced in July.

title: Doctor Guilty In Wife's Death
description: A West Hartford cardiologist was found guilty of first-degree manslaughter yesterday in the 1985 bludgeoning death of his wife.

title: GENERAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
POOR PLAY ANGERS ESPOSITO
description: As the Rangers went in the first weeks of the season, so went their general manager, Phil Esposito. The team teetered on a ledge, going into overtime again and again and again and Esposito teetered with them - he said that he saw good and bad. The tempestuous former player and former broadcaster had been replaced by a reasonable executive, who, if still filled with emotions, said neutral things such as ''I'm not going to make a trade just for the sake of making it,'' and ''let's give it a little time.''

title: LEINER, P NUTRITIONAL PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
4 Bodies Recovered After Helicopter Crashes
description: Search teams today recovered four bodies from the wreckage of a Coast Guard helicopter that crashed into a hillside on Ugak Island during a medical mission.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAKING YOUR OWN TOYS
description: ONE of the least publicized successes in software publishing is a company called Broderbund.

title: FLORIDA EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $449,000.

title: More Time Off At Christmas
description: With Christmas this year falling on a Thursday, nearly half the companies surveyed by a private group plan to give their employees an extra paid holiday on Friday, Dec. 26.

title: RESIGNATIONS UPSET HISPANIC TV NEWS PROGRAM
description: Resignations by some 20 key news staff personnel in the last few days have shaken the only nightly network television news program produced for the Hispanic audience in the United States.

title: Going to Houston?
description: The Democrats have not held a national convention in Houston since 1928, when they nominated Alfred E. Smith. But prospects for a return to the Texas city in 1988 looked promising after a three-day weekend visit there by the national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., and the party committee that is charged with selecting a convention site.

title: AIDS: SCIENTISTS VOICE CONCERN OVER RESEARCH
description: SCIENTISTS say important new avenues of research will be cut off unless the expanded Federal attack against AIDS called for last week is carried out.

title: CABARET: 2 CONTEST WINNERS
description: FREDDY'S Supper Club, the popular cabaret at 308 East 49th Street that has specialized in bringing veteran pop singers back to the New York nightclub scene, has also helped to nurture up-and-coming performers through its annual talent contest. Through Nov. 15, the club is featuring two entrants from its most recent competition, Jerry Sheldon and Michael McAssey, performing back-to-back sets at 8 and 9:30 P.M., Tuesdays through Saturdays.

title: Bridge: College Teams Will Be Vying For a North American Title
description: An old and important bridge tradition will be revived in two weeks' time. Some 30 colleges throughout the continent will compete in the first stage of the Intercollegiate Championships, and the eventual winners will represent North America in the first World Junior Championships in Amsterdam next July.

title: Former Head of NL Unit Designated for Vernitron
description: John R. Slowik, who resigned as president of NL Chemicals in August when the parent company, NL Industries, was taken over, has been designated to become the chief operating officer of the Vernitron Company by the investment company that is seeking control of Vernitron.

title: SATELLITE MUSIC NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $114,174 and $323,991 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $54,235 and $129,382 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WITNESS DISPUTES HUSBAND IN MOB TRIAL
description: The wife of a key prosecution witness testified for the defense yesterday, repeatedly contradicting her husband's testimony, in a trial focusing on a ruling commission of the Mafia.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $146,000 for the quarter and $270,000 for the 6 months.

title: Americans' Papers, Eminent and Otherwise
description: Lester R. Brown, president of the Worldwatch Institute, recently received a letter from the manuscripts division of the Library of Congress asking if he would like to donate his personal papers to the library.

title: CHIRAC HAS TAKEN THE REINS OF POWER FROM MITTERAND
description: After nearly eight months of the power-sharing arrangement known as ''cohabitation,'' real authority and initiative in France have fallen into the hands of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, officials and others say.

title: 'ENTRPRENEURS,' DOCUMENTRY ON 13
description: ''ENTREPRENEURS,'' a 90-minute documentary on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, is meant to celebrate excellence in business, the entrepreneurial spirit and good old get-up-and-go. It really doesn't. The problem is that its heroes of American capitalism no longer build better mouse traps; they talk and talk and hold meetings.

title: Goodbye and Good Riddance to Revenue Sharing
description: To the Editor:

title: 70% RISE IN HOSPITAL ROOM COSTS SINCE 1980
description: The daily cost of a typical American hospital room was $212 last year, with California the most expensive state to be hospitalized in and Mississippi the least costly.

title: Du Pont Gain On Plastics
description: E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it had developed processing technology that would allow it to market a family of plastics known as polyarylates for a wide variety of applications in the automotive, aerospace, appliance, electronics and recreation industries.

title: THE ELECTIONS: In the Region, Victorious Incumbents; How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times/CBS News exit poll is based on questionnaires completed by 935 voters as they left polling places in 188 randomly selected precincts around the country.

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
description: b-After a tax credit of $392,000.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 5, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DAYTIME PITCH ONLY A FLICKER
description: It was not exactly a giant leap for mankind, but Peter Ueberroth took a small step in the right direction when he said that baseball would explore the possibility of playing a World Series game during daylight hours next year.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MORE EMIGRES SEEK RETURN TO SOVIET
description: The Soviet Embassy here presented a dozen more emigres today who said they could not adjust to American society and were returning to the Soviet Union.

title: SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INSIDE
description: Friedman Linked to Bribes A former debt-collection official testified that Stanley M. Friedman demanded a $35,000 bribe to grant a New York City contract.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL SEATTLE (AL) - Named Billy Connors pitching coach, Bobby Tolan batting coach and Frank Howard first-base coach.
