GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $30 million for the estimated cost to redesign and repair the F-14 main landing gear bulkhead.

title: HOT HEARTY SOUPS, A FALL HARVEST
description: ''BEAUTIFUL Soup! Who cares for fish, game, or any other dish? Who would not give all else for two pennyworth only of beautiful soup?''

title: Litvack Plans to Resign From Donovan Leisure
description: Sanford M. Litvack, the managing partner at the law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, has told his partners that he is planning to resign.

title: SHAMIR DEFENDS NUCLEAR SILENCE
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Israel ''has its reasons'' for not saying anything publicly about the fate of a missing nuclear technician, who reportedly sold the secrets of Israel's atomic arsenal to a British newspaper.

title: THE BOORS, A TASTING CLUB THAT TOLERATES NO WINESPEAK
description: MEET the Boors - the Bronx Order of Oenological Recidivists. Arnold (everybody calls him Arnie) Eisen, the organizer, dreamed up this $10 name. ''My hunch,'' he said, ''is that there are hundreds of wine groups like ours.''

title: MALONE AND MALONE TOO MUCH FOR NETS
description: The Washington area, noted for law and accounting firms, got a new one tonight, Malone & Malone. This firm, excelling on court instead of in court, accounted for 58 points, and made a strong case for the defense as well as the offense by scoring the winning basket with four seconds remaining and then thrwarting the opposition. It enabled the Washington Bullets to edge the Nets, 102-101, at the Capital Centre.

title: UNLIKELY ROOTERS FOR CLIPPER ROOKIE
description: A rooting interest in the Los Angeles Clippers has developed among many of the more than 200 detectives assigned to the Manhattan North precinct of the New York City Police Department. The reason: Maureen Kempton, a detective assigned to the Career Criminal unit at the precinct, is the mother of Tim Kempton, who made the Clipper roster the hard way.

title: PROFIT PRESSURE AT TOP BANKS
description: Many corporations cite the drowsy economy for their mediocre profits. The nation's biggest banks, however, largely have themselves to blame for another quarter of lackluster results.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Camp Beverley Hills, an apparel and accessories marketer, to Scali, McCabe, Sloves/West.

title: A PRESIDENT'S LIMITS
description: Despite a strong push in the closing days of the campaign, President Reagan was unable to hold enough of his supporters in the Republican column to retain control of the Senate, and he had only partial success in his effort to make the Republican Party fully competitive in the South.

title: STAGE: RICHARD LIBERTINI IN 'NEAPOLITAN GHOSTS'
description: Richard Libertini is a master of what could be called the comedy of madness. His funniest characters are furious and at least on the borderline of delirium. Those of us who have been enjoying his performances since he and MacIntyre Dixon first created the ''Stewed Prunes'' comedy team in the 1960's - through his appearances in films such as ''The In-Laws'' - have been waiting to see him play a leading role in a classic farce, perhaps by Moliere or Feydeau.

title: Dividend Canceled
description: Mcorp, the second-largest bank holding company in Texas, suspended payment of the quarterly dividend on common stock because of poor earnness in the Southwest.

title: Officer Held In Drug Sale
description: A 34-year-old police offi-cer was suspended from duty yesterday after his arrest on charges of selling marijuana to an undercover narcotics division officer.

title: F.A.A. Begins Inquiry On Close Call in Chicago
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today it was investigating an incident in which a small plane came within a mile of an American Airlines jet carrying 50 passengers.

title: Coming Clean About Steroids
description: A supposed crackdown on what the police characterized in late September as ''widespread'' steroid use among high school athletes in two Atlanta-area counties hasn't yielded any arrests as yet. But the publicity surrounding it has prompted surprisingly frank acknowledgment of prior use by two of the city's most highly visible sports figures: Bill Curry, the Georgia Tech football coach, and Bill Fralic, the Falcons' prized offensive lineman.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $13.3 million from the sale of a royalty interest in a Utah coal property, as well as a $7.2 million credit from the capitalization of prior period exploration expenditures related to a newly operational gold project offshore Nome, Alaska. c-After a gain of $7.5 million from the cumulative effect of an acccounting change. d-Net loss e-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.3 million for the quarter and $500,000 for the 9 months.

title: TOWER FEDERAL SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in June.

title: IN REGION'S STORES, ANGER AS SERVICE FALLS
description: With a dire shortage of workers at stores and restaurants in the New York region, customers are beginning to complain more loudly about poor service - sometimes walking angrily, and empty-handed, out the door.

title: AT PRINCETON, A BID TO DRAW MORE WOMEN
description: Officials of Princeton University, which admitted its first female undergraduates in 1969, are concerned by the school's continuing difficulties in attracting more of them.

title: QUINTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Quadruplets Born in Jersey
description: A Wantage woman has given birth to quadruplets at a hospital here, and the infants were in stable condition yesterday.

title: THE ELECTIONS: A Challenge Is Rebuffed, a Comeback Fails; WESTCHESTER COUNTY: Abzug Beaten by DioGuardi In House Race
description: Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, the Republican incumbent, defeated his Democratic challenger, Bella S. Abzug, today in the Congressional race in Westchester County's 20th District.

title: KRUG INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $34,000.

title: WITNESS SAYS FRIEDMAN SOUGHT BRIBE
description: The former president of a major debt-collection agency testified today that Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, had demanded $35,000 to be split between two city officials in order to obtain a contract from New York City's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: CPC SEEKS CORPORATE RESHAPING
description: CPC International, the New Jersey-based food products company, said yesterday that it was considering a corporate restructuring that would include the sale of some assets.

title: MET OPERA IS A HITS AT THE BOX OFFICE
description: The Metropolitan Opera so far this season is enjoying a box-office success that its new management can't quite take credit for, but from which it is determined to learn. Two weeks ago, the Met sold out all seven performances in a week - the first time this has happened in 10 years; 12 sellouts are expected in the 14 performances last week and this one.

title: Pakistani Is Gloomy On an Afghan Settlement
description: United Nations negotiations show ''no sign'' of achieving the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan, Pakistan's Foreign Minister declared today.

title: ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,003,000 and $1,494,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $415,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; D'Arcy's Zurich Office
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles will open a Zurich office Feb. 1 bringing its worldwide presence to 55 offices in 47 cities in 27 countries. The first account there will be Fiat, for all of Switzerland. Urs Gysin will be leaving the GGK agency to be its managing director.

title: 'Song & Dance' to Close
description: ''Song & Dance,'' a musical by Andrew Lloyd Webber, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Royale Theater. The play, directed by Richard Maltby Jr., will have run for 15 previews and 474 regular performances.

title: S.E.C. RULE FOR BANKS OVERTURNED
description: In a rebuff to the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Federal appeals court panel struck down today an S.E.C. rule that requires banks engaged in the securities business to register with the commission as broker-dealers.

title: Advertising; Jacques Jaunet Drops Agency
description: Jacques Jaunet, the French apparel company, has split with its United States agency, Altschiller Reitzfeld, which it retained in February 1983.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS CRITICIZED ON POOR
description: The country's Roman Catholic Bishops, who have focused their attention on poverty for the last two years, have placed ''far too much faith'' in Government intervention as a means of helping the poor, a commission of conservative lay Catholics asserted in a report issued yesterday.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split in September.

title: MORTGAGE RATES IN OCTOBER AMONG LOWEST IN 80'S
description: Mortgage rates fell again last month, with two Government surveys yesterday reporting rates that were among the lowest of the 1980's.

title: MAJOR REFINANCING PLANNED FOR CARBIDE
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, culminating a year of restructuring, outlined a sweeping recapitalization plan yesterday to slash debt, strengthen its financial profile and increase its freedom to buy and sell assets.

title: High-Roller Physicians
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokers Seek Conrail Role
description: About two dozen brokerage firms have submitted bids to become a co-leader in the $1.7 billion sale of Conrail, the largest public stock offering ever attempted, the Transportation Department announced today.

title: Real Estate; Mineola's Mini-Boom In Building
description: MINEOLA, the Nassau County seat, is experiencing a small building boom.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Articles in Business Day on Saturday and yesterday about the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company incorrectly characterized the relationship between Sir James Goldsmith and the Crown Zellerbach Corporation. Sir James, the British-French investor who now holds a stake in Goodyear, took control of Crown Zellerbach last year, but most of the company has since been sold to the James River Corporation.

title: RATES ON U.S. ISSUES UP A BIT
description: Interest rates on short- and long-term Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday as the Treasury completed the first portion of its three-part, $29 billion note and bond financing.

title: BOTHA SHUFFLING PRETORIA CABINET
description: President P. W. Botha shuffled his Cabinet today, replacing the officials responsible for security and information.

title: Late October Car Sales Off 6%
description: The big American auto makers today reported lackluster sales for the final 10 days of October, a reversal from record-breaking sales in September and early October.

title: Continental Illinois Can Buy 3 Banks
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said it had received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to purchase three small banks in suburban Chicago. Many Illinois bank officials had objected to the acquisitions because Continental Illinois, which was bailed out two years ago in a $4.50 billion Federal rescue plan, was receiving Federal assistance.

description: Madison and 'Faction'

title: Florida Hospital Bonds Yield From 4% to 7.45%
description: A $73.5 million financing by the Dade County Health Facilities Authority of Florida for the Baptist Hospital of Miami offers a maximum yield of 7.45 percent for a 7 3/8 percent bond, due in 2013, at a price of 99.127. The underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Gillette Shares Climb $4.375
description: Shares of the Gillette Company, maker of Gillette razor blades, rose $4.375 yesterday, to $52.50, in the third day of heavy trading.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. PARTIES: QUICK EXITS, ROASTED GOATS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 4 - It began as just another staid lunch among 30 diplomats at Le Perigord: fish mousse and roast veal washed down with a chilled Macon-Lugny and garnished with words of welcome by the host, Mihalis Dountas, the chief delegate from Greece.

title: Oil Ministers Meet
description: Oil ministers of Saudi Arabia and its Persian Gulf allies met today to develop a common front on oil production and pricing policies, the official United Arab Emirates news agency, WAM, said. The agency said Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Hisham Nazer, met behind closed doors with the oil ministers of Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Bahrain. It gave no other details.

title: Butterflying a Fish
description: My preferred method for broiling fresh fish is to butterfly it and season the inside with salt, pepper and, perhaps, fresh herbs and breadcrumbs. The butterflied fish cooks faster and comes out crispy on the exterior and moist within.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE cholesterol-conscious American is eating less red meat, fewer eggs, more poultry and slightly more fish than two decades ago. Chicken and turkey franks, turkey ham and turkey pastrami have taken their place beside the fattier beef and pork versions, and ground turkey has begun to invade the market for ground beef.

title: DRUGS SUSPECTED
description: Two Rikers Island jail guards were found dead in their homes last weekend from what the police believe were drug overdoses, officials said yesterday.

title: Nuclear Plant Employees Disciplined in Overload
description: A supervisor has been dismissed and three other employees disciplined for improperly storing reactor fuel rods at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, officials said today.

title: Pan Am Profits Down 73.9%
description: The Pan Am Corporation said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter plunged 73.9 percent on a 12.9 percent decline in revenues, which it attributed in part to foreign exchange losses and to a decline in trans-Atlantic travel. Pan Am, the parent of Pan

description: In balloting decided by one first-place vote, John McNamara yesterday was named the American League manager of the year by the Baseball Writers' Association of America.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AKALAITIS'S 'DEAD END KIDS'
description: AGITPROP theater doesn't transfer easily to the screen - remember Richard Attenborough's pious, monumental bore based on Joan Littlewood's small, vicious and funny ''Oh! What a Lovely War.'' Yet the attempt is made so infrequently that almost any such film deserves a certain respect. Thats's exactly what's due ''Dead End Kids: A Story of Nuclear Power,'' JoAnne Akalaitis's screen adaptation of her Mabou Mines production, which was done at the Public Theater in 1980.

title: BEST BUY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AGENDA: NOV. 5, 1986
description: Medical Rights

title: MUSIC: STAROBIN, GUITARIST
description: IN its own modest way, the guitarist David Starobin's Sunday-afternoon concert at the 92d Street Y was one of the seasons's most satisfying. Mr. Starobin chose a program of unusual diversity, encompassing works by the contemporary American composers John Anthony Lennon and Barbara Kolb, by the Hungarian composers Gyorgy Kurtag and Sandor Jemnitz, by the Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos, by four Russian composers from the 19th and 20th centuries, and, for the traditionalists in the audience, just a little bit of Fernando Sor. A bold effort, indeed, but Mr. Starobin, surely one of the most diligent and adaptive musicians around, seemed completely comfortable with whatever music was at hand.

description: Iran said today that Robert C. McFarlane, the former White House national security adviser, and four other Americans recently went to Teheran on a secret diplomatic mission.

title: In South Dakota, Old Autumn Ghosts
description: Halloween isn't over in this farming community. As children elsewhere put away their costumes, and ghosts and goblins climb back into their tombs, the children around here prepare for more horrors to come. For theirs is a nightmare world of uncertainty and fear, a world of farm foreclosures and bankruptcies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIME
description: BLUEBEARD'S EGG AND OTHER STORIES. By Margaret Atwood. 281 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. ''IT was years later too that I realized Buddy had used the wrong word,'' says the narrator of one of Margaret Atwood's new stories. ''It wasn't an identity bracelet, it was an identification bracelet. The difference escaped me at the time. But maybe it was the right word after all, and what Buddy was handing over to me was his identity, some key part of himself that I was expected to keep for him and watch over.''

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: The company declared a 3-for-2 stock split on Oct. 17, 1986, and the shares oustanding have been retroactively adjusted to reflect this split.

title: Goodyear Writes About Sir James
description: Sir James Goldsmith is ''obsessed with pursuing his targets with determination,'' wrote Robert E. Mercer, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company chairman, in a letter to employees dated yesterday. The letter is the first indication of Mr. Mercer's feelings toward Sir James, the British-French investor who on Friday disclosed that a group he controls owns 11.5 percent of Goodyear's stock.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $357,000 from settlement of a pension fund matter.

description: In this, the age of the fish farm, the nursery-grown mussel deserves consideration because it is beardless, gritless, but not tasteless. Likewise the sterile oyster: it won't turn milky or mushy.

FIVE BROOKLYN OFFICERS SAID TO FACE INDICTMENT
description: At least five police officers from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn have been ordered to surrender for indictment tomorrow by a grand jury investigating reported corruption, the lawyer for the police union said yesterday.

description: Although Democratic and Republican candidates were locked in tight races in several key contests for the New York State Senate late last night, Republicans said they would maintain control of the chamber.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Oct. 29 misstated the new title for Gordon J. Bingham, an executive with Ryder System Inc. He was named senior vice president of strategic planning for Ryder System's Vehicle Leasing and Services division.

description: Foreign ministers from most of the 35 nations that signed the Helsinki accords in 1975 today inaugurated the third full-dress conference to review and strengthen the document.

Bridge: On a Rare Occasion Indeed, Opening Bid May Reveal All
description: If your opponent opens the bidding in a suit, you have a crumb of information about the distribution. With a few more crumbs you may discover the complete pattern of the suit around the table.

title: BANK REPLY ANGERS BIG INVESTORS
description: Institutional shareholders of the BankAmerica Corporation reacted angrily today to the decision by the bank's board to ask First Interstate Bancorp to withdraw its takeover bid.

title: PATTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMOCRATIC SENATE MAY IMPEDE REAGAN
description: The Democrats' victory in the Senate yesterday created an obstacle for President Reagan's legislative agenda for the final two years of his Presidency.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A review on Oct. 8 of ''World Without Walls: Beryl Markham's African Memoir,'' a television documentary, misstated the credit for a segment of film photographed in Kenya. That segment was produced by Barry Shlachter and directed by Andrew Maxwell-Hyslop.

title: U.S. REPORT PREDICTS RISE IN SKIN CANCER WITH LOSS OF OZONE
description: A draft assessment by the Environmental Protection Agency warns that Americans could suffer 40 million cases of skin cancer and 800,000 cancer deaths in the next 88 years because of depletion of atmospheric ozone.

title: CALVIN KLEIN FLIRTS WITH SHORT SKIRTS
description: AT a time when many fashion designers are engaged in a frantic search for something new and fanciful, Calvin Klein stunned his audience yesterday with a spring show that was clean and classic - the kind of clothes that made his reputation as a leading exponent of the American look.

title: THE DANCE: JUBILEE GALA FOR GUILD
description: A LABOR union that includes Beverly Sills, Jascha Heifetz, Agnes de Mille and Suzanne Farrell must have something solid behind it, and so it was solidarity forever at a gala performance Monday night celebrating the 50th anniversary of the American Guild of Musical Artists.

title: COLUMBIA IN THE ELITE OF DEFEAT
description: Morgan State ended its 29-game losing streak when it beat the University of the District of Columbia, 21-16, Saturday. But Columbia University, which led at halftime, suffered its 28th straight loss when Villanova won, 42-34. The Lions are fast catching up to the college record as they moved into fourth place among the teams with the most losses in football history, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: CUOMO TO BE PRESSED TO DECIDE ON RACE FOR PRESIDENT IN '88
description: With his landslide re-election victory, Governor Cuomo faces increased pressure to make a decision on running for President in 1988.

title: Topics: Bombs/Bones; Critical Oversight
description: What should better focus one's attention than working in a nuclear bomb factory? Yet such is the leaden weight of routine on the human mind that workers and managers at the Hanford plutonium finishing plant have become numb to danger.

title: Managing the Empire of Misfortune
description: William Grinker, Mayor Koch's choice to head the Human Resources Administration in New York City, calls the assignment ''the toughest job that one could imagine.'' As municipal jobs go, he's probably right.

title: Economic Scene; The Monetary System Shift
description: WITH the agreement on economic cooperation reached last week between Japan and the United States, a major piece in the reordering of the world monetary system has been put in place.

title: VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 are adjusted to reflect the 10-percent stock dividend paid Aug. 29, 1986.

title: THE ELECTIONS: A Challenge Is Rebuffed, a Comeback Fails; Shulman Victor in Queens Race For Manes Post
description: Queens Borough President Claire Shulman last night easily won her bid to finish the remaining three years of the term of the late Donald R. Manes, defeating her challenger by a 2-to-1 ratio.

title: FILM DEATHS WITNESS TESTIFIES SAFETY WAS IGNORED
description: A camera operator testified today that John Landis, director of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' was a tyrannical film maker who felt no responsibility for the people he used in a ''very dangerous'' war scene that killed the actor Vic Morrow and two children.

title: NEW BOSTON HIT A THROWBACK TO 70'S
description: THE 1970's aren't over yet.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The 15 goals and 14 assists that Mario Lemieux accumulated in 11 games during October have earned the Pittsburgh Penguin center National Hockey League player-of-the-month honors. . . . For the third time this season, Ken O'Brien, who completed 26 of 32 passes for 431 yards and 4 touchdowns without an interception when the Jets beat Seattle, 38-7, Sunday, has been voted the American Conference offensive player of the week.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of real estate limited partnerships of $102,000 for the quarter and $382,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes equity in earnings of real estate limited partnerships of $702,000 and $1,027,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE was frost on the gamay vines here, the first of the year. The grapes had long been picked and the vines, red and gold only a few days earlier, had changed to orange and yellow and a rich, reddish brown. The clouds scudded overhead, and it was gray except for an occasional break in the overcast when the late, low-angled sunlight set the ancient hills of Beaujolais ablaze with a brief incandescent shaft of light.

title: Siegler Bid Gets Response
description: Lear Siegler Inc., in its first response to a friendly $1.51 billion acquisition offer from the AFG Partners, said today that it would consider meeting with that group and other unidentified parties that have expressed an interest in the company.

title: HOPE VOICED ON THE REMAINING HOSTAGES
description: The Anglican go-between in the Lebanon hostage affair said today that there were ''reasonably strong'' expectations that the release of two more Americans held there might be imminent.

title: Gun-Waving Troops Greet Stray Hopeful
description: A last-minute campaign swing left a Congressional candidate, Faye Williams, looking down gun barrels after her helicopter landed by mistake in maneuvers at England Air Force Base, officials said.

title: THE ELECTIONS: Changes in Jersey; Continuity in Connecticut; CONNECTICUT: O'Neill Wins and Lifts Party's Assembly Hopes
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, Connecticut's Democratic Governor who had built his campaign on the state's current economic prosperity, was elected yesterday to a second full four-year term over his Republican challenger, State Representative Julie D. Belaga.

title: OPERA: NEWARK GROUP IN LEONCAVALLO'S 'ZAZA'
description: Ruggiero Leoncavallo and Pietro Mascagni are generally thought of as one-opera composers, because nothing else by either has caught on like the heated double bill of ''Cav and Pag'' (''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''I Pagliacci''). But both wrote other vital scores, and our age of operatic revivalism is bound to turn to them soon. One of the best is Leoncavallo's ''Zaza'' (1900), a typically steamy verismo tale of an actress, her mother, her old lover, her new lover and the latter's wife and daughter. But if the operatic world takes up ''Zaza'' again, as the New Jersey State Opera did in a well-rehearsed and creditable revival here this evening, it will take some thought to decide precisely what to perform. Like ''Don Carlo,'' ''Candide,'' ''Tales of Hoffmann'' and a few others, ''Zaza'' exists in versions with substantial and important differences.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For us this is not a festival. Because the Hungarian experience of 30 years ago includes bitter memories, we lower our flags modestly when we mark the day, and we do not make it a holiday.''

title: RACES FOR CONGRESS ARE CLOSE UPSTATE
description: Two upstate Republican representatives were locked in tight battles last night to decide whether the Democrats expand their hold on New York State's Congressional delegation.

title: GIANT GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $239,000 for the quarter and $447,000 for the 9 months.

title: HAMILTON OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Because of AIDS, Prostitutes Are Urged Not to Give Blood
description: The Food and Drug Administration, seeking to further reduce the risk of AIDS, has added prostitutes and their recent heterosexual customers to its list of those who should not donate blood.

title: WHY LEFTY GOT FIRED
description: Lefty Driesell said the other day that he's still not sure why he no longer is the University of Maryland's basketball coach.

title: STOCKS ARE MIXED IN BRISK TRADING
description: Trading volume was brisk yesterday on Wall Street, but stock prices closed narrowly mixed as investors remained preoccupied with the outcome of yesterday's Congressional elections.

title: 'Soul Man' Called Racist By Black Law Students
description: The Black Law Students Association at Harvard yesterday denounced the motion picture ''Soul Man'' as ''racist'' and ''insulting.'' The film is about a wealthy white student who wins a scholarship to Harvard Law School by masquerading as black.

title: BARRY WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $100,000 and $388,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: DISENCHANTED VOTERS OUST TWO G.O.P. INCUMBENTS
description: Voters in North and South Dakota today registered their displeasure with the Reagan Administration's farm program, defeating one incumbent Republican Senator as another was in an extremely close race for re-election.

title: At a Glance
description: THE SENATE

title: Reward Posted By Yeshiva
description: A Long Island yeshiva posted a $25,000 reward yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer of a 16-year-old rabbinical student who was slain Saturday in his dormitory room.

title: CONGRESS'S REAL BICENTENNIAL AWAITS 1989
description: There is no major celebration planned for the occasion of the 100th Congress. That will wait until the 200th anniversary of the first Congress in 1989.

title: That Covers It
description: Coach Rod Dowhower, after a 24-9 loss to Cleveland left his Indianapolis Colts with a record of 0-9: ''Offensively, we were inept. Defensively, we gave up the big play. Over all, I'm disappointed.''

title: WILLIAM P. DORNEY
description: William P. Dorney, the Superintendent of Schools in Haworth, N.J., and a former New York City school district superintendent, died Sunday at West Hudson Hospital in Kearny, N.J. He was 64 years old and lived in Bergenfield, N.J.

title: LEONARD NOT COUNTED OUT OF IT
description: At the news conference Monday to announce the Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Sugar Ray Leonard match on April 6, Bob Halloran, an executive of Caesars Palace, where the bout will be held, said that the early betting line at his casino made Hagler a 4-1 favorite.

title: BISCAYNE HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $815,000 for the quarter and $1,335,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $33,000 and $150,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: DANCE: SENTA DRIVER TROUPE
description: ALTHOUGH Senta Driver is noted for her choreographic experiments with weighted movement, she devises more than exercises in ingenuity. Her dances combine inventiveness with emotional expressiveness.

title: 150 RESIDENTS FLEE BIG BLAZE IN BALTIMORE INDUSTRIAL AREA
description: A nine-alarm fire swept through a row of warehouses in an industrial area tonight, forcing 150 people from their homes into a rainstorm. An elderly resident died of a heart attack, the authorities said.

title: 'ADDERLY,' A CANADIAN LATE-NIGHT ACTION SERIES
description: CHOOSING to ignore the talking heads of Johnny Carson and David Letterman on NBC and Ted Koppel and David Brenner on ABC, the folks at CBS have been stuffing their nightly 11:30 time slot with a combination of old network action series and new syndicated action series. Among the latter is ''Adderly,'' which runs on Wednesdays for 70 minutes - about 20 of them devoted to commercials.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months both include a charge of $4,575,000 related to proposed sale of steel and non-residential construction businesses, which was rejected by shareholders. The company said the year-ago quarter includes a gain of $1,766,000 from an insurance settlement and the 9-month includes a gain of $5,573,000 from an accounting estimate change.

title: THE ELECTIONS: Changes in Jersey; Continuity in Connecticut; Shapiro's Defeat Is Tied to a Revolt on Taxes
description: Essex County Executive Peter Shapiro's defeat today in a bid for a third term as head of New Jersey's largest county came as a classic tax revolt by the voters prodded by his Republican opponent, Nicholas R. Amato, the former County Surrogate.

title: Your Congress at Work
description: For anyone who wonders why it takes Senate-House conference committees many hours or days to reconcile two versions of the same legislation, the House Armed Services Committee has a startling statistic: Before they completed work on the National Defense Authorization Act of 1987 on Oct. 14, the conferees had to settle 2,003 differences between the Senate and House bills.

title: VOTERS AUTHORIZE $1.5 BILLION TO CLEAN TOXIC-WASTE SITES
description: New York State voters voted overwhelmingly yesterday to authorize public borrowing of $1.45 billion to clean up hazardous waste sites and improve environmental quality throughout the state.

title: MECHANIC WHO PUT IN BAD CLUTCH WAS AN OWNER OF COPTER CONCERN
description: The mechanic who admitted installing the wrong clutch in a helicopter that crashed into the Hudson River two weeks ago, killing a traffic reporter for WNBC radio, was a part owner of the company that operated the helicopter, a Federal safety official said last night.

title: THE STAGE: 'AN ACUTE OBSESSION'
description: PAIN is the real protagonist of ''An Acute Obsession,'' a work by two California playwrights being presented at the Harold Clurman Theater. But it is a dramatically ineffective one; it overwhelms each of the six characters in turn but changes none of them, and it leaves the viewer none the wiser for the experience.

title: THEATER: 'PAJAMA GAME'
description: THERE are pleasures available in the Equity Library Theater's production of ''The Pajama Game,'' but they have to battle their way through the book by George Abbott and Richard Bissell, casually stitched from Mr. Bissell's novel ''7 1/2 Cents.'' Like a line of shoddy pajamas, a comedy without a single clever piece of dialogue requires a high order of salesmanship, which is only intermittently on display on the Equity stage. Here's a joke out of the 1950's, when the show was first produced: ''Who's Fulton Lewis Jr.?'' ''He plays third base for the Chicago White Sox.'' You have to have been there to realize it wasn't worth being there. The evening's big laugh comes when somebody picks up the phone and says, ''Give me ladies' pants.'' With that level of comedy, it's difficult to rouse interest in the romance of an executive of Sleep-Tite Pajamas and a union maid.

title: WURLITZER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a capital loss of $55,131 for the quarter and a capital gain of $2,828,591 for the 9 months. c-After a capital loss of $206,714 for the quarter and a capital gain of $1,108,234 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July 1986.

title: CAVEATS FOR THE POSTAL SHOPPER
description: WHEN things go awry with mail-order purchases, consumers have recourse, through a Federal Trade Commission regulation, if the order was placed and paid for by mail, or if the order was placed by telephone and paid for by mail.

title: Adolf Busemann, 85, Dead; Designer of the Swept Wing
description: Adolf Busemann, whose design of the swept wing for aircraft helped make supersonic flight possible, died Monday at the Fraiser Meadows Manor Health Care Center here. He was 85 years old.

title: JOSEPH WEINSTEIN
description: Joseph Weinstein, a New York real- estate developer, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Female Drivers in Hasidic Bus Case Have Cause to Complain
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN HEALTH COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include operations of American Health Products Inc., acquired March 31, 1986.

title: SPRY ON THE HOOF THE 103D TIME AROUND
description: The proceedings were called to order by the foggy notes of the ringmaster's brass hunting horn, and the National Horse Show opened its 103d session Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. The crowd was sparse but elegant, in keeping with the sleek performers they came to watch.

title: Tactical Alliances And the A.C.L.U.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has sometimes been portrayed by its critics as a left-wing lobby that is soft on law and order and many other causes favored by conservatives. But increasingly in the last two years it has formed strategic alliances with groups from the conservative side of the political spectrum.

title: UNION TEXAS PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes adverse effects from a $105 million writeoff of an equity investment in an oil and gas partnership, a $9 million provision for undeveloped lease abandonments, a $6 million provision for operating losses related to a long-term drilling contract; and includes a favorable effect from a $97 million gain from the sale of a subsidiary and related operations. c-Includes 9 months of financing costs related to the July 1985 leveraged buyout transaction, compared with only 3 months of such costs in the net income for the year-ago 9 months, which resulted in an unfavorable variance of $44 million. d-Net income and for the quarter, which was adversely affected by $13 million for future operating and divestiture losses related to an equity interest in a drilling-rig partnership and by $5 million for one-time reorganizational costs for the quarter. Union Texas is a privately owned company. Share earnings are not reported.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COWARD REVISITED It has been said that the opening of ''Oh Coward!'' at the New Theater on East 54th Street in October 1972 was the last performance the ailing Noel Coward, consummate master of all theater trades, attended before his death early in 1973. True or not, his presence added to the joy occasioned by the show itself, essentially a revue that paid tribute to his music and his incomparably clever lyrics.

title: Homecoming
description: It's not that Kenny Lambiotte has anything against the University of Virginia. Indeed, when he graduated from high school in Woodstock, Va., he chose the Cavaliers over others who tried to recruit him, and joined the basketball team.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $32.5 million and $55.5 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $20.6 million for both periods. c-Includes realized investment losses of $4.4 million for the quarter and includes realized investment gains of $11.9 million for the 9 months.

title: THE ELECTIONS: A Challenge Is Rebuffed, a Comeback Fails; LONG ISLAND: L.I. Voters Return 5 to Congress; Cohalan Appears Victor in Suffolk
description: Long Island voters returned five incumbent Representatives to Congress yesterday and selected a Democrat, George J. Hochbrueckner, to fill the seat being vacated by Republican William Carney in Eastern Suffolk County.

title: FOR 100TH CONGRESS, MANY OF THE PROBLEMS THAT FACED THE 99TH
description: The Congress elected today is the 100th, and that has the ring of history about it.

title: BOTH SIDES IN CIGARETTE FIGHT HOLD NATIONAL ESSAY CONTEST
description: A pair of essay contests sponsored by bitter rivals in the battle over cigarette smoking have the same goal of increasing public awareness of the issue, the sponsors said Monday.

title: Mozambicans Raid Malawi's Embassy
description: Hundreds of youths attacked the Malawian Embassy and the South African Trade Mission here today to protest the death of President Samora M. Machel in a plane crash in South Africa two weeks ago.

title: SPECTER TURNS BACK CHALLENGER; GOVERNSHIP TAKEN BY DEMOCRAT
description: Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican, today turned back a spirited challenge by Representative Bob Edgar, a Democrat, to win a second term.

title: The Senate's First 100 Days
description: At the end of the movie ''The Candidate,'' as exuberant supporters celebrate election night, Senator-elect McKay plaintively asks his campaign manager, ''What do we do now?''

title: Indiana Progress Awaits Invitation
description: Indiana Progress Inc., an investor group that has expressed an interest in buying the Public Service Company of Indiana, said today that it would not make a formal offer unless invited to do so by the utility. Last month, the group, which includes William D. Ruckelshaus, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, offered to pay about $1 billion for the Public Service Company.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a capital loss of $6,279,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $63,415,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $2,956,000 and $51,297,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: LEAHY AND KUNIN DEFEAT CHALLENGERS
description: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin won re-election early this morning when her Republican opponent conceded defeat, though she fell short of the 50 percent majority required by the Vermont State Constitution to avoid throwing the race into the State Legislature.

title: THE ELECTIONS: Changes in Jersey; Continuity in Connecticut; NEW JERSEY: Shapiro Loses in Essex County; McDowell Is Winner in Bergen
description: Peter Shapiro, the Essex County Executive who lost to Governor Kean in the New Jersey gubernatorial election last year, was defeated again yesterday, in a bid for a third term in Essex, In Bergen County, where voters were choosing their first county executive under a new system of government approved by voters last year, Sheriff William D. McDowell, a Republican, defeated State Senator Matthew Feldman, a Democrat.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
HEALTHFUL SNACKS
description: OVER the years, the word ''snack'' has been twisted into an evil, heavy-breathing, antinutrition Darth Vader of ''Star Wars'' infamy who walks home from school with children, swirling his black cape around them and making them stop at the corner store for potato chips, soda and maybe wax lips.

title: GOTTI, IN COURTROOM OUTBURST, DENIES COMMENT ON WITNESS
description: John Gotti, in a brief outburst in court yesterday, heatedly denied a Federal prosecutor's contention that he had made sarcastic comments about a Government witness in a voice loud enough to be heard by jurors.

title: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $135,000. The company said the results for the latest quarter and 9-month includes gains of $666,000 and $1,998,000, respectively, from a change in accounting for retirement costs.

title: DEVILS SCORE FIRST, THEN FALL APART
description: For the second consecutive game, the Devils were limited tonight to one goal, and again the consequences were unavoidable.

title: AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INESTMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $5,282,030 for the quarter and $5,792,376 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $42,918 and $120,402 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: THE ELECTIONS: In the Region, Victorious Incumbents; Governor to Face Tax and Service Issues
description: New Yorkers voted yesterday to elect a governor who, in the term ahead, will have to rewrite the state tax code while balancing the clamor for tax cuts against the pressure for spending on social welfare, prisons, transit and other public services.

title: PARENTS AND STUDENTS FACE STRICTER TAX RULES
description: Some of the ways parents save for their children's college education are likely to change under the new tax law as younger children become subject to different and stiffer tax treatment.

title: IRENE HAWTHORNE
description: Irene Hawthorne, former prima ballerina of the Metropolitan Opera and of the Opera Nacional in Mexico City, died of lung cancer Oct. 24 at St. Rose's Home in New York City.

title: A Derek Walcott Reading
description: Derek Walcott, the Caribbean poet and playwright, will read from his forthcoming collection, ''The Arkansas Testament,'' today at 6:15 P.M. at the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street. The reading is open to the public. Admission is $10. Mr. Walcott will be introduced by the poet Joseph Brodsky.

title: CONTRAS TO START NEW RADIO STATION
description: The Nicaraguan rebels are planning to operate a clandestine radio station that would be as powerful as any AM-band station in the United States, according to Administration officials.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After writedowns of $502.9 million of oil and gas services and marine, engineering and construction operations. c-Net income d-Includes a writedown of $257,830,000 and after an extraordinary charge of $328,012,000 for settlement of a lawsuit.

title: THE ELECTIONS: Tallying Winner and Losers; D'Amato Wins Easily in Race for Senate
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato won easy re-election last night, largely on the strength of the image he cultivated as the ''pothole Senator'' who ''brings home the bacon for New York.''

title: MODEST GAINS IN HOUSE ACHIEVED BY DEMOCRATS
description: The Democrats, already firmly in control of the House of Representatives, scored modest gains yesterday, spokesmen for both the Democratic and Republican Congressional campaigns said early this morning.

title: GREYHOUND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an unusual charge of $19.4 million resulting from a special loss provision made by Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corp. for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a gain of $89.5 million from the sale of Conagra shares, a loss of $14.8 million for a terminal conversion program, European shipping losses of $43.8 million, and an anticipated loss of $8.1 million related to Pine Top Insurance Co. of Illinois.

title: HORIZON AIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $1,185,000 for the quarter and $2,168,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Village Invokes Water Rules
description: A water emergency was in effect here yesterday as the village's operating reservoir dropped to a 45-day supply.

title: BEEF SUPPLIER TO SCHOOLS IS FINED
description: The parent company of a concern that sold up to a million pounds of beef a year to New York City public schools has been fined $500,000 by a Federal judge in Boston for conspiring to put filler into ground beef sold to school lunch programs in 10 states.

title: Clampdown on Case
description: State District Judge Joe Kegans, who is presiding over the assault cases in Houston against Ron Darling and Tim Teufel of the Mets, has issued a gag order after a prosecutor and a defense attorney called each other a liar.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIERRA SPRING WATER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE HUNGARIANS, GINGERLY, RECALL DAY IN '56 WHEN IT ALL CHANGED
description: The Hungarian Government of Janos Kadar today modestly recalled its origins in this provincial town where it proclaimed itself 30 years ago as Soviet tanks rumbled past to quell a popular uprising in Budapest.

title: Scarfo Remains In Jersey Jail
description: The reputed leader of organized crime in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey remained in jail yesterday along with his nephew, but 16 other accused mob associates were out on bail, the authorities said.

title: RAMS' UNDERSTUDY EARNS THE APPLAUSE
description: ''My stats were probably horrible. What were they?''

title: Inside the Suit, a Man!
description: When I was a boy they had live politicians. Yes sir. Human flesh contained inside double-breasted suits. Not like nowadays when all you see is an empty suit on television and hear one of those oily voices trying to tell you there's a man in there.

title: Guilty Verdict In Sex Abuse
description: A former elementary school principal was convicted Monday of sexually assaulting five female students.

title: Debentures Issued By Mountain Fuel
description: Mountain Fuel Resources Inc., a subsidiary of the Questar Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent debentures due in 2016 at a price of 98.75, yielding 9 1/2 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: NASA OFFICIAL ADVISED AGAINST LIFTOFF
description: The head of a space agency team that inspected the shuttle Challenger before liftoff recommended that there be no launching that day because of dangers posed by heavy ice on the launching pad, according to a Congressional report released yesterday.

title: Seaver Free, for a While
description: Tom Seaver and the Boston Red Sox are working out an agreement that will enable the pitcher to be a free agent and sign a new contract with the team, if he desires.

title: David Mack, Who Emerged From Long Coma in '81, Dies
description: David Mack, a police officer who made medical history by regaining consciousness after being in a coma for 22 months, has died after being hospitalized with a fever. He was 43 years old.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: WAS FORENSIC ANTHROPOLOGIST
description: Dr. J. Lawrence Angel, a forensic anthropologist whose expert analytical skills were used to examine the skeletal remains of ancient Greeks, Turks and Cypriots as well as modern-day murder victims, died Monday at George Washington University Hospital of hepatitis. He was 71 years old.

title: Ruland Is Sidelined
description: Jeff Ruland, whose history of injuries was a concern when the Philadelphia 76ers acquired him from Washington in the trade for Moses Malone, managed to play in the first two games this season but was not with the team in Indiana last night because of continuing pain in his left knee and lower back. Ruland, who missed 97 games over the last two seasons because of injury, played 27 of 48 minutes in the 76ers' first game this season and 25 minutes in the second, averaging 9.5 points and 7.5 rebounds. His playing status is described as day-to-day.

title: Hasenfus Says Agents Didn't Work on Flights
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American air freight handler whose arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua last month, testified today that none of the people he worked with in the operation were agents of the United States Government.

title: MONTANA BACK, READY TO START
description: Bill Walsh, the coach of the San Francisco 49ers, said today that Joe Montana, who had back surgery to repair a ruptured disk seven weeks ago and was not expected to return this season, ''likely would start'' at quarterback Sunday when the 49ers play the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: J. P. Morgan Sells 7.1% Notes at Par
description: J. P. Morgan & Company is offering $300 million of 7.1 percent notes due in 1991 at par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: BERNARD CHAUS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the net income and share earnings for 1985 have been adjusted on a pro forma basis for income taxes based on income before income taxes as if the company had formerly not been subject to S corporation tax status which terminated on June 30, 1986.

title: CALIFORNIA: TOP JUDGE REMOVED BY VOTERS
description: Chief Justice Rose Elizabeth Bird of the California Supreme Court, whose resistance to the death penalty aroused a bitter campaign against her by political conservatives and prosecuting attorneys, was removed from office today by the state's voters.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Honoring James Beard Tonight the James Beard Foundation will officially inaugurate the James Beard House at 167 West 12th Street with a champagne reception for its members. Six months ago, a fund-raiser was held on the late Mr. Beard's 83d birthday to raise money for a $100,000 down payment for the house, which, according to Julia Child, honorary chairman of the Beard Foundation, is to become a gastronomic center. ''It's something that does not exist anywhere yet,'' Mrs. Child said. ''I see it as a professional headquarters, a place for meetings, conferences, receptions, tastings and other events.''

title: Palestinian-Shiite Fight Erupts Anew in Beirut
description: After a two-day lull, gun battles broke out today around a Palestinian quarter in the southern suburbs, and the police said five people were killed and 22 wounded.

description: The Democrats won control of the Senate yesterday, dealing a major blow to President Reagan, who had criss-crossed the country pleading for a Republican victory.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IN the back room the boys are playing, a study in brotherly love. The younger one has the fire engine and the older one has the tow truck and, although entire minutes have passed, neither has made a grab for the other's toy. The younger one is babbling to himself in pidgin English and the older one is singing ceaselessly, tonelessly, as though chanting a mantra. It is not until I move closer to the two of them, toe to toe on the tile floor, that I catch the lyrics to the melody: ''Get out of here. Get out of here. Get out of here.''

title: Club Recalls Its Tie

Its officers have discovered that the yellow stripes on the blue club tie, which has been in use for decades, run from upper right to lower left and thus ''offend heraldry'' and ''also denote bastardy,'' the club said in a bulletin to all members.

title: Dialogue in Vienna: The Issues
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, are in Vienna for a 35-nation meeting reviewing the Helsinki accords. In private talks outside the meeting, they are expected to take up these Soviet-American issues: Arms Control 1. ''Star Wars'': The Soviet Union and the United States are talking about a commitment to adhere for 10 more years to the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. They differ about how to interpret the treaty and how much research would be allowed on the ''Star Wars'' space-based missile defense program. At the Iceland meeting, the Soviet Union said it wanted to limit research on space-based systems to the laboratory. Since then, the Soviet Union has hinted that it may take a more flexible position, and American officials want to follow up these hints. It remains to be seen whether the United States will agree to strict limits. The United States is insisting on the right to interpret the ABM Treaty in a loose way that would allow testing and development of space-based systems. Amerian negotiators of the 1972 treaty do not believe that this loose interpretation is valid. 2. Medium-Range Missiles: In Iceland, the two sides agreed to eliminate all American and Soviet medium-range missiles from Europe. The Soviet Union would be allowed to keep 100 warheads on medium-range missiles in Asia and the United States 100 warheads on medium-range missiles within its own territory. The Soviet Union now inists that such an accord be linked to a resolution of the dispute over ''Star Wars.''

Orbanco, which had been troubled by nonperforming loans in timber and other depressed industries, was in liquidation proceedings last year. It had agreed to sell its main unit, the Oregon Bank, to the BankAmerica Corporation for $57 million, but BankAmerica dropped the plan because of its own mounting financial pressures.

title: Growing Up, in Three-Minute Segments
description: For a time, the 45 r.p.m. record was the ultimate adolescent artifact. It was as cheap as an allowance and easily transportable; it set just the right tempo for Saturday night. For a couple of American generations, a stack of 45's on a chubby spindle evokes a time of sweaty hands and quickened heartbeats, blue lights in the basement rec room or Japanese lanterns around the carport; a time when the whole world lay ahead. For them, the news is harsh: The day of the 45 is just about over.

title: Generations United
description: Conventional wisdom has held that young people and old people have diametrically opposed political interests and that a candidate or party cannot appeal to both of them simultaneously. Challenging this theory is Generations United, a coalition of 70 groups that represent either the young or the old, whose formation will be announced today.

title: MAIL CALL: FIRST-CLASS FOODS FOR TASTY HOLIDAY GIFTS
description: ORDERING food gifts for the holiday by mail is: (a) a timesaver for the overextended, underorganized working person; (b) a restorative to the spirit weary of department-store madness; (c) a way to sample regional specialties from around the country yourself; (d) all of the above. Answer: all of the above. The appeal of this year's list of mail-order holiday food gifts is that it includes some extraordinary foods and all are from the United States. In the past, imported products have been included in the annual New York Times survey, but this year's list of 23 edible ideas is all-American, with entries from some remote areas. Shoppers can find wild chokecherry jelly from Miles City, Mont., as well as smoked salmon from Port Angeles, Wash.

title: The Story Behind the Hostage Story

The easiest to grasp is the ordeal of five Americans still missing. ''Those guys are in hell,'' says Mr. Jacobsen. ''We've got to get them home.'' At what price? Though nobody official wants to confirm it, the presumed quid pro quo is some limited accommodation on the part of the United States with Iran, long isolated and now evidently desperate..

title: WARMING UP FOR WINTER
description: WHETHER you are a suburban or country homeowner battling drafts, or a city dweller recovering from icy streets in an overheated apartment, winter conjures up two contradictory views. One is of a season to be lived through with wet feet and short tempers, the other is of a Currier & Ives vision of pristine snow and snug, welcoming rooms with the family gathered by the fire. We suggest using the 10 possibilities illustrated here, or your own ingenuity, to find the comforts that will increase your well being at home. Sitting by a fire, even if it's fake, serving tea in oversized cups or hibernating under a down comforter on a quiet snowy night are some of the more appealing domestic possibilities of the coming season.

title: RALPH LAUREN: NOT A PETTICOAT TO BE SEEN
description: A FRESH spirit is sweeping through the New York spring fashion shows, spurred in part by the emphasis of many designers here and abroad on exaggerated puffed and flared skirts, short enough to have emerged from the 1960's. Reacting to the bouffant miniskirts, Ralph Lauren has developed his own unique brand of glamour showing long graceful skirts. Oscar de la Renta, never a stranger to ruffles and flounces, offers some bouffant dresses that have the extravagance of couture clothes in the 1950's. Then he balances them with some of the simplest, most severe styles he has ever shown. Carolyne Roehm shows she is ready for the big time with a collection that, though spotty, includes many sprightly, wearable clothes.

Stripped of their concealing grillwork covers, old-fashioned radiators stand proudly in restored Victorian houses, and industrial loft conversions. Their lavishly embellished forms have a new ornamental value in sparsely decorated spaces or in rooms filled with 19th-century furniture.

title: AN 1880 HOUSE GETS A FIREPLACE FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: FOR David and Miriam Ansell, a fireplace is one of life's necessities. Especially in a country house. But there was no fireplace in the 1880 Victorian farmhouse they bought in New Hope, Pa. Originally the house had been warmed by a coal-burning stove, but that was long gone, and the existing hot-water baseboard heat was efficient but charmless. Installing a new fireplace was a major remodeling priority. ''I loved the house, but I couldn't have lived there without one,'' said Mrs. Ansell. Mr. Ansell added, ''We're fireplace people.''

title: Central African Republic To Try Former Leader

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the President's Committee on the Arts and the Humanities and the American Express Company.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COMPOSITE CITY ''Imaginary Cities: European Views From the Photographic Collection of the Art Commission of the City of New York'' is the name of the new exhibition that opens today at the Hunter College Art Gallery, on the ground floor of the new building on the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 68th Street. These 48 pictures are real views of urban beauty spots of European cities, from Moscow to Manchester, including Vienna, Paris, Copenhagen, Berlin, St. Petersburg, Liverpool, Dresden and Brussels. Seen in these special contexts, the photographs create unblemished cities, imaginary ones that mankind dreams about but seldom, if ever, achieves.

title: INCOGNITO, GOVERNOR CALLS SHOW
description: Governor Cuomo - identifying himself as Glendy LaDuke, a moniker he used in his professional baseball days - telephoned a Westchester radio call-in program yesterday, discussing for 10 minutes his landslide re-election victory and sounding very much like a Presidential candidate.

title:

title: AGENDA: Nov. 6, 1986
description: Officers to Surrender Some of the police officers suspended last month in Brooklyn's 77th Precinct, as well as at least two others, are expected to surrender today after being indicted by a grand jury, officials say. The grand jury was 'Insider's' Sentencing One of the investment bankers who admitted sharing stolen information in the largest insider trading case ever will be sentenced. Ira B. Sokolow, a former employee of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said he shared information on pending takeovers and buyouts with Dennis B. Levine. Mr. Sokolow, 32, pleaded guilty to two Federal felony counts, each carrying a possible sentence of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. 10 A.M., Federal District Court, 40 Foley Square, Manhattan Reagan and Clean Water President Reagan has until midnight to decide whether to sign legislation strengthening the Clean Water Act. A veto, which his advisers have recommended, would cost New York City about $700 million earmarked for improvements in sewage treatment systems. City officials say at least four major construction projects would be severely delayed by such a loss, including one to stop raw sewage discharges from Tottenville, S.I.

title: OF GARY CARTER, THE BIG SPIT, NUCLEAR BALL GAMES AND BEING SEEN
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. Several years ago I successfully darkened the flagstones in my foyer floor with linseed oil. There are other flagstone floors in the house that I did not coat with linseed oil at the time and I would like to do these now. However, I have forgotten whether I used boiled linseed oil or raw linseed oil. A.If you are going to use linseed oil for this, then boiled oil is better rather than raw (raw oil may not dry properly). However, I would not recommend either. Linseed oil is subject to mildew, especially if applied too heavily, and it will darken with age. Also, if the excess is not thoroughly removed from the surface it may get sticky and will attract and hold dirt. You're better off using a penetrating sealer formulated with synthetic resins. Sold in paint stores and by dealers who sell flagstone, there are a number of these products on the market to treat and seal (and darken) the stones the same way linseed oil will, but they are easier to apply and will generally last longer. Q.I recently wallpapered a large hall with a ''string-type'' wall covering. Although I tried to avoid it, some shading occurred. In addition, there are stains along the edges or seams, even though I used the vinyl paste recommended by the manufacturer (apparently the edges of the paper soaked up more of the adhesive). Is there a stain, paint, dye or other material I can use to eliminate this shading and discoloration without ruining the texture of the paper? A.When you speak of a ''string-type'' paper I assume you mean an imported grass cloth or something similar.

title: THEATER: 'THE WAR PARTY,' ON BLACK STRUGGLES
description: AS Leslie Lee views the aftermath of the black revolution of the 1960's, little has actually changed. On the battle ground of Mr. Lee's new play, ''The War Party,'' blacks are still forced to fight for their rights and they are vitiating their own cause through internecine combat. At the same time, public awareness has not led to greater progress. In one of the play's several paradoxes, a poverty program is itself a victim of poverty, forced to scrounge for life support. In response to new issues, old platforms are raised and old anthems are sung. The playwright's attitude is that of regret bordering on sorrow.

EXCITEMENT AND RESTRAINT IN ELECTION COVERAGE
description: SAY this about the television coverage of the election: It was a show. In fact, it was several shows, depending on which network you watched. Raw vote totals were obsolete. Projections and exit polls took over. CBS was zippy, sometimes even dizzy. NBC was calm, although it also committed the night's biggest blunder. ABC, on balance, was the most measured. Political analysis, meanwhile, was everywhere.

title: The S.O.S. Band, Atlanta Pop-Funk
description: Among the numerous pop-funk dance bands that have come and gone since the heyday of disco, the S.O.S. Band, from Atlanta, has consistently made records that boast an extra measure of textural subtlety. Although the group, which appeared at the Apollo Theater on Monday evening, has dabbled in jazzy flavored pop-soul, it is best-known for its smooth, airy dance-floor hits, produced by Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis, that recall the elegant detachment of the late-70's disco group Chic.

title: A Texan Way With Words
description: Raymond Strother, a Washington political consultant, says he has come up with the best quotation of the campaign. It occurred in the gubernatorial contest in Texas, when a local television station held on-the-street interviews asking people whether they were going to support Bill Clements, the Republican, or Mark White, the Democrat. One passer-by, Mr. Strother said, answered, ''I guess I'll just decide between the evil of two lessers.''

title: WHEN A ROCK HIT BRINGS THE BLUES
description: THREE years ago, it looked as if rock's commercial and creative energies were coming into a new alignment. A handful of blockbuster albums took the market by storm, with television exposure via video clips boosting sales into the millions. This year, one by one, the follow-ups to those blockbuster albums are appearing, among them ''Fore'' by Huey Lewis and the News, ''Break Every Rule,'' by Tina Turner, and ''True Colors,'' by Cyndi Lauper. While they are well-made efforts that have duly risen into the Top 10, they also leave a palpable feeling of letdown - among fans and especially among critics. As has happened time and again in popular music, yesterday's breakthrough has become today's shtick. And within the record business, only higher list prices are keeping sales income steady.

The aerospace and military equipment contractor said its profit for the three months ended Sept. 30 came to $161.8 million, or $1.11 a share, compared with $140 million, or 94 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Sales increased to $3.33 billion from $3.18 billion.

title: JOHN KELLY, A MASTER OF MELANGE
description: The performance artist John Kelly has always been drawn toward art that goes to romantic extremes. Five years ago, the 29-year-old dancer, choreographer, singer and director took grand opera to the East Village club world, singing well-known arias in a pure, untrained falsetto at the Pyramid Cocktail Lounge. Since then, in his many performance pieces, Mr. Kelly has impersonated legendary figures ranging from St. Sebastian to Narcissus and Leonardo da Vinci to the Mona Lisa, in tableaux vivants that depict artistic icons in a seriocomic style that is too exalted to be called camp.

title: THEATER: 'BROWNSTONE,' A MUSICAL
description: THE occupants of ''Brownstone,'' the new musical about life and love in contemporary Manhattan, are forever doing just what real people in real brownstones do. They read their mail, leave and receive phone messages, repaint the living room, rearrange the furniture, defrost the refrigerator and take out the garbage. And if these chores are tedious in one's own home, I'm afraid they're scarcely more scintillating when accompanied by music and performed onstage by the first-rate cast that has been assembled at the Roundabout Theater. Defrosting the refrigerator is nothing to sing about, even when the singer is as radiant as Liz Callaway.

title: OPERA: 'ROMEO ET JULIETTE'
description: OPERA casting is often discussed in terms of chemistry: which elements unite successfully and which ones do not. But the black art of alchemy might be a better way to approach the problem. There was no way to tell in advance, for instance, that last night's principals in the Metropolitan Opera's first ''Romeo et Juliette'' of the season would combine or set off dramatic sparks. The Juliette of Gounod's gloss on Shakespeare's tragedy was a young and comparatively green Italian soprano, Cecilia Gasdia, while her lover was Alfred Kraus, a distinguished Spaniard veteran who may be the finest exponent of French opera among active tenors. Both singers were new to their parts in this house; in fact, it was Miss Gasdia's Metropolitan debut. Since the night also was a Metropolitan first for the conductor, Placido Domingo, it might easily have turned out to be one of those getting-to-know-you affairs.

title: PENALTIES TO BE HARSHER FOR CARELESS TAXPAYERS
