description: THREE years after deciding to upgrade the audience of the magazine by upgrading the magazine, Conde Nast's House & Garden is about to realize the kind of advertising revenues it did before the change. But that will be with half the circulation and the attendant cost of paper and ink.

title: TEXT OF SOVIET PROPOSAL ON HOW TO PRECEED
description: Following is the text of a Soviet proposal on how to proceed in the arms negotiations. The Soviet text was presented at a meeting of senior Soviet and American officials here. The United States proposed an alternative text, and no agreement was reached.

title: TOBACCO PLANT WITH FIREFLY GENE IMPLANT GROWS
description: Tobacco plants have been genetically altered so that they emit light on orders from a gene transplanted from fireflies, a research team reported yesterday.

title: Fela Anikulapo Kuti, Nigeria's Musical Activist
description: THE Nigerian band leader Fela Anikulapo Kuti has been writing and singing angry political songs since the early 1970's. He calls his music Afro-Beat; it uses saxophone and brass-section vamps that suggest a rawer version of James Brown as well as African percussion, call-and-response singing and Mr. Kuti's own saxophone solos and gruff voice; the lyrics are in pidgin English and African. Tomorrow, along with the 26 musicians and 6 dancers of his band, Egypt 80, Mr. Kuti will perform at the Felt Forum - a concert that is two years and two months overdue.

title: CONSUMER BORROWING JUMPED IN SEPTEMBER
description: Americans, borrowing heavily to finance new-car purchases, took out $8.37 billion more in consumer debt than they paid in September, for the biggest advance in a year, the Government reported today.

title: NEW BOOK FAIR WITH A PAST
description: FOR thousands of years, the Jews, a people who started out with the Good Book, have surrounded themselves with books. That makes it even more surprising that this weekend will mark the first time that New York, with the largest Jewish population of any city in the world, has gotten around to having a major Jewish book fair.

title: No Bank Loans for Pinochet
description: The Reagan Administration is playing an increasingly determinative role in Chilean politics. Unfortunately, its policy is potentially more helpful to Gen. Augusto Pinochet than to Chile's democratic prospects. While many Chileans wait expectantly for the United States to vote against multilateral loans up for approval this month, human rights abuses continue unabated, as they are bound to continue until democracy is restored.

title: OFF L.I., A LETHAL 'BROWN TIDE' PUZZLES MARINE SCIENTISTS
description: Eighteen months after it began, an algae bloom known here as the ''brown tide'' continues to baffle the experts.

title: Citicorp Offers Perpetual Issues
description: Citicorp offered $500 million of perpetual floating-rate notes yesterday, through Goldman, Sachs & Company, the first such issue by an American banking company.

title: GOLDSMITH IN BID FOR GOODYEAR
description: Sir James Goldsmith privately offered to buy the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for $49 a share, or $4.6 billion, on Wednesday night, and the company countered yesterday by announcing that its board had authorized a repurchase of up to 18 percent of its stock.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map yesterday with an article about gubernatorial elections around the country omitted designations for some states with governorships that switched parties. In addition to those shown, Nebraska and Oklahoma shifted from the Democrats to the Republicans and Oregon shifted from the Republicans to the Democrats.

title: Police Identify Two Women Who Were Beaten to Death
description: Two women who were beaten to death in an apartment in Washington Heights Wednesday night were identified yesterday by the police.

title: DEVILS, DOWN BY 4, STAGE LATE REVIVAL
description: Just when the crowd started to chant ''bor-ring, bor-ring'' in the middle of the third period, the Devils came alive with four unanswered goals tonight and gained a 5-5 tie with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: SCREEN: '52 PICK-UP,' A NO-FRILLS THRILLER
description: ELMORE LEONARD'S thrillers leap so easily to the screen that it's astounding so few of them have gotten there. Even with the kind of slapdash, unsightly production that's been given ''52 Pick-Up,'' Mr. Leonard's stories make terrific, unself-conscious B-movies of the sort that are more and more rare. Unlike Burt Reynolds's recent film of another Leonard book, ''Stick,'' which aspired to a certain solemnity, ''52 Pick-Up,'' a no-frills Cannon Group production, has no pretensions at all. It's fast-paced, lurid, exploitative and loaded with malevolent energy. John Frankenheimer, who directed, hasn't done anything this darkly entertaining since ''Black Sunday.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1986
description: The World

title: RIVAL AFGHANS COME TO BLOWS AT U.N.
description: The two sides in the Afghan war came to blows in the halls of the United Nations today, as Afghan diplomats assaulted visitors who represent an Afghan guerrilla group. The diplomats were trying to stop the representatives from holding a news conference.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Named Stan Kasten president. BASKETBALL

title: FINDING MAY COMPLICATE TREATMENT OF AIDS
description: The AIDS virus attacks different types of cells in the brain and central nervous system than in the rest of the body, a finding that may complicate treatment of the deadly infection, Government scientists reported today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about business executives' reaction to the election misidentified the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee for the 99th Congress, which adjourned recently. The chairman was Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon.

title: ABRAHAM MULTER, EX-CONGRESSMAN
description: Abraham J. Multer, a 10-term Representative from Brooklyn and a former State Supreme Court justice, died Tuesday at the Hebrew Home and Hospital in Hartford, where he had moved recently. He was 85 years old.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $16.1 million and $24 million for quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes an extraordinary credit of $4,300,000. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $15.3 million for the quarter and $18.2 million for the 9 months.

title: ELSEWHERE, THE LINK IS NOT SO CLEAR
description: To Bill Sorenson, campaign manager for Mark Andrews up in North Dakota, the picture seemed painfully clear. The farm issue had cost his Republican candidate a second term in the Senate.

title: BIRD FELLS A COPTER, INJURING PILOT
description: A bird shattered the windshield of a helicopter flying over Staten Island yesterday evening, forcing the pilot, whose head and left eye were cut by flying glass, to make an emergency landing in the parking lot of a restaurant, the police said.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After pre-tax gains of $258,281 for the quarter and $2,384,001 for the 9 months from the sale of the company's Worldwide Computer Services Inc. subsidiary. The 9 months also includes a tax credit of $100,000. c-Net loss

title: FATHER AND SON GET SPYING TERMS
description: John A. Walker Jr., who confessed he ran one of the most damaging spy rings in American history, was sentenced today to life in prison, with a Federal judge recommending that he never be paroled.

title: A BREEZE FOR THE BEARS, A BUMMER FOR THE NINERS
description: With the homestretch of the N.F.L. season straight ahead, whom does the schedule favor the rest of the way? Here are the cumulative records of remaining opponents for all 28 teams, which are ranked within each division from easiest remaining schedule to most difficult (without regard, of course, to the home-or-away breakdown):

title: Eyes on New Hampshire
description: Now that the 1986 Congressional elections are over, with sizable Democratic gains in the Senate and small ones in the House, all red-blooded politician-watchers should be ready to turn to 1988, anxious to know how potential Democratic Presidential contenders are lining up for the first primary contest in the country in New Hampshire, only 15 months away.

title: GARTNER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from a distributed subsidiary of $51,000 for the quarter and $140,000 for the 6 months.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized capital gains of $24,620,000 and $45,267,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized capital gains of $13,054,000 for the quarter and $35,192,000 for the 9 months. The company said the pre-tax foreign exchange gain for the latest quarter was $605,000 and the 9-month had a pre-tax foreign exchange loss of $264,000. The company said the 1985 quarter and 9-month had a loss of $100,000 and a gain of $920,000, respectively. The company said the shares outstanding include the common stock equivalent of the series B preferred stock redeemed Oct. 1.

title: W.R. Grace Names 3 Vice Chairmen
description: In a move to create a new line of succession, W.R. Grace & Company said yesterday that three vice chairmen had been elected, following the retirement of its president and a vice chairman.

title: KROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
A FALL ART SCENE THAT'S BRISTLING WITH ENERGY
description: REPORTS of SoHo's demise have been greatly exaggerated. SoHo may no longer be the place where much of the best new art is made, but it remains one of the most vital exhibition centers in the world. There is no place else in New York now where recent developments in European and American contemporary art are as well represented.

title: BLOW TO MICHIGAN'S RECOVERY
description: The closing of seven General Motors Corporation plants in Michigan and the impending layoff of thousands of auto workers may severely set back the state's economic recovery, economists and officials here said today.

title: Judge Pays Visit To Ailing Priest
description: A state judge met yesterday with an 83-year-old priest who had been refusing food and medication to help decide whether the priest was competent to make decisions about his medical care.

title: STATEMENT BY SHULTZ AT NEWS CONFERENCE
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference here today, as distributed by the American delegation:

title: LILI KRAUS, HUNGARIAN PIANIST
description: Lili Kraus, a Hungarian-born pianist much admired in the music of Mozart, died yesterday morning at the Memorial Mission Hopital in Asheville, N.C., of complications after intestinal surgery. She was 83 years old.

title: ABU NIDAL TIED TO TURKISH ATTACK
description: Prosecutors today accused the Abu Nidal group of the Sept. 6 massacre of 21 worshippers at an Istanbul synagogue.

title: Bowman Steps Aside
description: Scotty Bowman, who has won more games than any other National Hockey League coach - and has probably retired and come back more than any other coach as well -stepped down again as coach of the Buffalo Sabres yesterday and said this time it was for good.

title: Bridge: Brother, Sister and Father Have Sought World Titles
description: To have two members of the same family, related by blood rather than marriage, qualify for world championship play with different partners is quite rare.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A RAREFIED ATMOSPHERE IN THE FEISTY EAST VILLAGE
description: WHEN it began as an art scene, the East Village was synonymous with neo-Expressionism. The raucous feelings and emotions of that style were matched by the rawness of the tenement neighborhood. But lately there has been a shift. More and more East Village galleries are becoming as crisp, angular and white as anything uptown or in SoHo, save for an occasional nostalgic detail such as a patterned tin ceiling.

title: 2 KEY EXECUTIVES DEPART FROM U.P.I.
description: Two of United Press International's most visible and key executives announced yesterday that they were leaving the news agency immediately. They were Maxwell McCrohon, president, and Ronald E. Cohen, managing editor.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TIME PULLS THE PLUG ON PICTURE WEEK
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it was abandoning efforts to start a new mass-market magazine, Picture Week, and instead would concentrate on introducing a host of special interest publications ranging from Home Office to Cooking Life.

title: Grand Metropolitan
description: Grand Metropolitan, the British brewing, hotels and leisure group, has named Alan Sheppard chief executive.

title: Bond Prices Decline Sharply
description: The Treasury's three-part, $29 billion financing ended on a sour note yesterday, as bond prices fell sharply in the face of weak investor demand that left dealers holding more securities than they would like.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A former Tennessee quarterback, Tony Robinson, was ordered to spend 90 days at the Knox County Penal Farm after pleading no contest to three charges of delivering cocaine to an undercover officer last January. A co-defendant, Kenneth (B. B.) Cooper, a Volunteer fullback from 1981 to 1984, pleaded no contest to four counts of cocaine delivery and one charge of selling cocaine and was ordered to spend 150 days at the penal farm. . . . Stan Kasten, president of the Atlanta Hawks basketball team, will assume the additional responsibility as president of the Atlanta Braves baseball team, replacing Ted Turner, who owns both clubs, and freeing the general manager, Bobby Cox, to concentrate on player personnel. . . . Petur Gudmundsson, the Los Angeles Lakers' 7-foot-2-inch backup center who is a native of Iceland, will undergo surgery Monday to repair a herniated disk and is out for the season.

title: 35 Catholics Seek Archbishop's Return
description: Thirty-five local Roman Catholics, most of them priests and nuns, have asked that Archbishop Raymond Hunthausen be given back all responsibilities taken away by the Vatican in a dispute over Church teachings.

title: RIFT AMONG IRAN'S LEADERS APPERARS TO WIDEN
description: A rift among those who rule Iran is apparently widening, with the heir apparent to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini publicly attacking his opponents and saying relations between Teheran and Washington cannot be normalized unless Washington changes its policies.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''AN AMERICAN TAIL,'' the first animated feature film to be produced by Steven Spielberg's Amblin Entertainment film company, is the story of a mouse family that finds its way to the new world, plucking the emotional chord of America's immigrant history in this anniversary year of the Statue of Liberty.

title: FILM: 'SOMETHING WILD'
description: ONE radiantly beautiful, late spring day in lower Manhattan, Charles Driggs (Jeff Daniels), a proper young tax consultant, walks out of a lunchroom without paying his check. It's just a whim - a vestige of the rebel that exists within Charlie. The act goes unnoticed by the cashier, but not by another patron (Melanie Griffith), an eccentrically dressed young woman who wears a Louise Brooks wig of bobbed black hair and initially calls herself Lulu.

title: DEPARTURE STATEMENT BY MOSCOW OFFICIAL
description: Following are excerpts from a departure statement by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze here today, as distributed in translation by the Soviet delegation:

title: JUDGE EXPANDS PRESS PROTECTION IN LIBEL ACTIONS
description: A Federal judge ruled today that a public figure cannot sue for punitive damages in libel cases against news organizations unless he can show actual injury to his reputation.

title: INDICTED DEMOCRAT DEFEATED IN BID TO BE GUAM GOVERNOR
description: Gov. Ricardo J. Bordallo, a Democrat indicted on Federal charges of bribery, extortion, conspiracy and fraud, has lost his bid for re-election to his Republican rival, Joseqh Ada.

title: Girl Says Mother Abused Drugs
description: A woman whose 5-year-old daughter told a kindergarten teacher she had seen her mother using drugs has been arrested, the police said yesterday.

title: Golf, but Barely
description: The second annual Cheap Shot Pro-Am is set for today and tomorrow at the Pine Needles resort in Southern Pines, N.C., where 18 pros from the PGA Tour will team with 54 amateurs paying $1,800 each to benefit junior golf. No purse, no pressure and, come to think of it, not much legitimate play either.

title: TACO VIVA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 14
IRAN IS SAID TO GET U.S. WEAPONS AID IN A HOSTAGE DEAL
description: The United States sent military spare parts to Iran as part of a secret operation intended to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon, American intelligence sources said today. It also persuaded Israel to do the same, the sources said.

title: ENTEX ENERGY DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Nuclear Plant Plans Dropped
description: The owners of the Seabrook nuclear power project in New Hampshire announced yesterday that they would return the construction permit for the Seabrook 2 plant to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and try to sell all salvageable components and equipment.

title: CITY AND STATE TO SUE TO RESTORE FOOD AID FOR HOMELESS PEOPLE
description: The city and state will sue the Federal Government next week to try to force the restoration of cuts in food-stamp benefits to homeless people being housed in New York hotels, according to the State Social Services Commissioner, Cesar A. Perales.

title: GIANT PIPER EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Includes a $2,839,000 charge due to new accounting guidelines.

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-percent stock dividend distributed April 1986 and a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 10, 1986.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN GETS 25 YEARS IN BOMBING
description: A white South African woman was sentenced to 25 years in prison today for bombing police stations and political party offices on behalf of the outlawed African National Congress.

title: Copter in Prison Escape Is Found Abandoned
description: PLEASANTON, Calif., Nov. 6 (UPI) -

title: THE SCREEN: TARKOVSKY'S 'SACRIFICE
description: ''The Sacrifice'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Walter Goodman's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 26. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway and 63d Street.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday STREAM OF IMAGES ''Images of Culture: The Films of Trinh T. Minh-ha,'' is not the usual documentary fare. In two of the films, which are being shown this weekend at the Whitney Museum of American Art, there are no interviews, voice-overs or translated subtitles. Instead, the Vietnamese-born film maker composes images into a rhythmic montage, not confined by a classical narrative pattern. ''Reassemblage,'' a 1982 film shot in Senegal, will be shown today and tomorrow at noon and Sunday at 1 P.M. ''Naked Spaces: Living Is Round,'' a 1985 film shot in remote areas of six West African countries, will be screened today and tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and Sunday at 3:30 P.M. The museum is on Madison Avenue at 75th Street. Admission $4 ($2 for the elderly; free for students and those under 12.) Information: 570-3676.

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 30
description: b-Includes $605,000, or 9 cents a share from the sale of land. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 10-percent stock dividend declared and issued during the quarter ended March 1, 1986.

title: USA WINS AFTER RIVAL DROPS OUT
description: White Crusader came close to be being dismasted today when a backstay block blew apart in a 20-knot southwest breeze during its race against USA in the America's Cup challenger series.

title: PERSICO JURY IS TOLD OF 'VAST CRIMINAL ENTERPRISE'
description: A prosecutor summed up the Government's case yesterday in a major racketeering trial by describing a ruling Mafia commission as ''the board of directors of a vast criminal enterprise.''

title: WOMEN ASSESS THE VOTE: SOME LOSSES, A BIG GAIN
description: Women are accustomed to measuring their political progress in inches, not miles. So those who track this evolution were not surprised that the election that had a record number of women running did not yield a record number of women winning.

title: Cuomo Has Back Test In Hospital in Albany
description: Governor Cuomo entered a hospital here briefly tonight to undergo tests for what his aides described as chronic back pain.

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a reduction by $9 million, net of income taxes, relating to estimated losses to be incurred on U.S. government contracts. c-Includes reduction of provision for income taxes by a $2.3 million after- tax credit realted to a refund received for state income taxes, and also includes a charge of $3 million, net of income taxes, relating to certain U.S. government contracting matters. d-Net income e-Includes losses of $144,000 and $402,000 from discontinued operations, net of income tax benefits, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results for the first 9 months of 1985 have been restated to reflect the reclassification of discontinued operations announced in 1985.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $351,000 and $589,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes capital gains of $52,000 and $96,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: GROUPS SEEK TO BAR TOP-OFFICER SWITCH AT HARLEM PRECINCT
description: During his two years as commander of the 28th Precinct in Harlem, Deputy Inspector Phillip G. Sheridan would accompany each new beat patrolman on his first day, knocking on doors and introducing the new officer to several people who live on his beat.

title: 3 Are Killed in Robbery
description: An elderly bar owner and two other people were bludgeoned to death with an unknown weapon and the tavern set on fire early today during a robbery, homicide detectives said. One of the victims was identified as Martha Gruttadauria, 75 years old, of Rochester, owner of Dick's 43 Lounge, said Sgt. Al Joseph.

title: Stanford Bans The Band
description: The Stanford marching band has never been one of your more traditional marching bands. Over the years, its members have acquired a just reputation as renegades whose halftime performances are really spoofs of traditional routines, and not always respectful spoofs at that.

title: BROADWAY
description: FIRST it was on, then it was off - a not unusual sequence for scheduled Broadway plays at any time. The happy news is that it's on again, and this time it seems as certain as these things ever are. It's the shortest play written by William Shakespeare - a drama called ''Macbeth'' - and it will star (get ready for this) Christopher Plummer and Glenda Jackson.

title: Carbide Agrees To Sell Offices
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Danbury headquarters building and the 650-acre headquarters site to Related Companies of New York for about $340 million. The price includes the leaseback of the headquarters building, the company said.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTENT INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $4,860,000. c-Net loss

title: Nissan Posts Operating Loss
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest automobile maker, today reported its first operating loss since the end of World War II, saying the poor April-September showing resulted from the strong yen and slow domestic car sales.

title: Why Does Milk Still Cost So Much?
description: Most New Yorkers pay substantially more for milk than they ought to, and it's in Governor Cuomo's power to do something about it. Yet his administration stalls and stalls, and if the delay lasts much longer, people will start to wonder whether it has anything to do with the $58,700 the Governor received in campaign contributions from local dairies and their union workers.

title: A Free Market in Housing for New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Sentenced In Theft Series
description: A Bronx man who became known as the ''silver-gun bandit'' in a six-month series of robberies and burglaries in Manhattan last year and early this year was sentenced to 67 1/2 to 135 years in state prison yesterday by a judge in Manhattan.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEM (DANISH, CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 WEST SIDE HOSPITALS TO REBUILD
description: A $467 million rebuilding plan for both locations of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center on the West Side was approved by the state yesterday.

title: FIDELITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (PHILA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings are adjusted for a 6-for-5 stock split on Oct. 1, 1986.

title: SCREEN: 'NOBODY'S FOOL,' COMEDY
description: ''NOBODY'S FOOL,'' written by Beth Henley, is a not-great comedy about the emotional liberation of a pretty, lonely young woman named Cassie (Rosanna Arquette), who works as a waitress in the Elk Lounge and whom everybody else in Buckeye Basin regards as a kook.

title: CSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $850,000 for the quarter and $1,957,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $544,000 and $3,894,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: SCREEN: 'BETTY BLUE,' BY JEAN-JACQUES BEINEIX
description: THE title character in Jean-Jacques Beineix's ''Betty Blue'' is a lissome, free-spirited young beauty, and she is the very soul of inspiration to her boyfriend, Zorg (when we first see them, Betty and Zorg are making love under a poster of the ''Mona Lisa''). Betty likes to egg Zorg on with his artistic efforts, and to rail against the forces that keep him in submission. Whenever possible, and that's very often, she likes to do these things in the raw. Whenever possible, Zorg likes to second Betty's actions by grabbing her and demonstrating his appreciation. Nine scenes out of 10 seem to end this way.

title: ITALIAN ENTERS PARIS FASHION
description: Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian industrialist who runs the Olivetti office equipment group, announced today that he had purchased a 25 percent stake in Yves St. Laurent, one of the world's leading fashion designers.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
BILL MOYERS IS EXPECTED TO KEEP TIE TO CBS NEWS
description: Bill Moyers, the journalist whose public disaffection with CBS helped precipitate a change in management at the news division, is now expected to remain associated with CBS News, according to several people at the network.

title: Uniworld Going Back To Avon Products
description: The Uniworld Group is returning to Avon Products' agency roster, where it was in residence from 1975 to 1980.

title: JULIAN SCHNABEL EXHIBITION IS A HIGHLIGHT OF UPTOWN GALLERY HOPPING
description: AS usual for this time of year, there's a lot of art to be seen along the axis formed by 57th Street and Madison Avenue. So much, in fact, that gallery hopping, as it is sometimes called, may soon qualify as an aerobic activity. Exhibitions worth visiting before they end include ''Landscape'' at Luhring, Augustine & Hodes Gallery (41 East 57th Street, through Nov. 15), which defines the term broadly but credibly and includes an abstraction by Brice Marden, a wood sculpture by Richard Long and a terrific Robert Smithson watercolor. At Emmerich Gallery (also at 41 East 57th Street, through tomorrow) is an exhibition of Al Held's drawings, a rare show of hand from an artist whose painted surfaces are obsessively perfect. Meanwhile, uptown at Vanderwoude Tananbaum (24 East 81st Street, through tomorrow) is the second one-person show by Elena Sisto, an artist who is navigating the not unpopulated terrain influenced by Marsden Hartley, Arthur Dove and Philip Guston with skill and promise.

title: MLX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a provision for federal income taxes of $558,000 and $888,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which would be payable except for the existence of the company's pre-organization federal tax net operating loss carryforward. c-Net loss

title: . . . Capitol Hill's Day After
description: Alice Hooker describes herself as a faithful Democrat who for six years has been an ''exile'' from Capitol Hill.

title: AMERICAN RELIANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $74,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $7,000 and $69,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest quarter and 9 months include gains on the termination of pension plan of $301,000 and $303,000, respectively.

title: CPC Stock Sold
description: The financier Ronald O. Perelman confirmed that he sold his 7.6 percent stake, or 3.68 million shares, in CPC International Inc. Wednesday for $88.50 a share, making an estimated profit of $40.6 million. Mr. Perelman told the Securities and Exchange Commission he sold his shares to Salomon Brothers Inc., representing CPC, after refusing two previous offers. Arbitragers were reported to have been caught with several million shares, but Goldman, Sachs & Company was understood to have been left with fewer than 250,000 shares, not nearly as many as originally estimated.

title: EASTERN PILOT IN OWN PLANE DIES IN RUNWAY CRASH
description: An Eastern Airlines captain trying to land his own small twin-engine plane in thick fog flew into a Boeing 727 airliner on a taxiway at Tampa International Airport in Florida yesterday morning and was killed as his craft burst into flames.

title: ENTERTAINER'S MANAGER TELLS JURY OF HIS FEAR OF MOBSTERS
description: The business manager for Wayne Newton, the entertainer, testified today that he feared for his own life as well as Mr. Newton's family after a business arrangement deteriorated, and that he became entangled with crime figures when he took action to halt the threats.

title: AN ART SCENE BRISTLING WITH ENERGY
description: ART in New York is the great unquantifiable source of energy. Walking along Museum Mile, which runs northward on Fifth Avenue from the Metropolitan Museum of Art at 82d Street to the Museum of the City of New York at 103d Street, we feel that distinctive energy coming up through the sidewalk. Walking down Madison Avenue from the high 80's to 57th Street, that same agreeable sensation keeps in step with us. As for 57th Street between Park and Seventh Avenues, it is like a long continuous secret forest of art - most of it invisible from the street - in which we can swing from branch to branch from morning till night and barely come to the end of it.

title: DEFICIT LOOMS AS KEY ISSUE IN NEXT CONGRESS
description: As the dust from the election Tuesday started to settle today, Congressional leaders and White House officials began work on their legislative strategies, and both sides immediately focused on the Federal deficit as a key point of conflict.

title: DEMOCRAT WINS A CLOSE CONTEST FOR HOUSE SEAT
description: A Democrat was declared the winner of one of the most closely contested races for the House of Representatives today, but Republicans apparently won three others.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gain on retirement of debt, net of tax, of $2,071,000.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 18
CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,824,000 from early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $37,642 and $77,570 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, and $21,185 and $137,159 for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: COMMERICAL FEDERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary prepayment penalty charge of $357,000.

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the share earnings and shares outstanding for the 1985 period are restated for distribution of series A preferred stock, which effectively reduces the share earnings amounts by one-half.

title: South African Strikers Ousted
description: The General Motors Corporation dismissed 500 of 2,400 black strikers at two Port Elizabeth auto plants and called in police and soldiers to evict them, the company said today.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $1,620,000 for restructuring the consumer products operations for the quarter and includes an after-tax charge of $4,555,000 for restructuring the operation of the engineering, manufacturing and construction group for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: G.M. Closings Surprise Perot
description: Ross Perot, the head of the General Motors Corporation's Electronic Data Systems subsidiary and the auto maker's largest individual stockholder, said yesterday that he was ''surprised'' at the number of plant closings announced yesterday.

title: J.W.T. and Bozell Cut Back on Personnel
description: The latest chapter in the continuing story of an economically pinched agency business concerns the personnel trimming at both J. Walter Thompson and Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: IT LOOKS EASY, SO WATCH OUT
description: The Giants have a 7-2 record, and the Eagles are 3-6. The Giants have the second-best rushing defense in the league, and the Eagles are next to last in total offense. The Giants have been rushing for big yardage while the Eagles' rushing defense has often been porous.

title: COMING TO DEFENSE OF JET PASS DEFENSE
description: The Jets have an 8-1 record and lead the American Conference East. They have won a club-record seven straight games as they prepare to face the Falcons - the league's best running team - on Sunday in Atlanta.

title: SAFETY AIDE TELLS OF FILM SET BLAST
description: The fire safety officer in charge of the set for the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' said today that he had feared explosions might hurl debris into a helicopter's mechanism but was assured the pilot would be able to handle such a circumstance.

title: Burroughs Selling Part of Memorex
description: The Burroughs Corporation, to reduce the debt resulting from its merger with the Sperry Corporation, said yesterday that it would sell part of its Memorex subsidiary for $550 million in cash and preferred stock. The buyers are company executives and the New York investor Eli S. Jacobs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Los Angeles dispatch yesterday about California election results characterized the state's Peace and Freedom Party incorrectly. Its orientation is leftist, not conservative.

title: INFINITY BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-Net loss c-After a charge of $6,806,000 on the extinguishment of debt. d-Net income

title: Diner's Journal
description: MAXIM'S, the lavish belle epoque restaurant on Madison Avenue at 61st Street, is trying to offset its reputation as an extravagantly expensive haunt for aristocrats and the expense account crowd. A dinner menu introduced this week eliminates the $65 prix fixe and its numerous double-digit supplements for an a la carte card. Budget dining it's not, but compared with the previous menu, where a $100 dinner tab was effortlessly achieved, it is more in line with reality.

title: MARATHONER'S 99TH IS HIS FINEST HOUR
description: Swinging himself along on his hands, Bob Wieland, the legless Vietnam veteran who had continued to run the New York City Marathon long after officials had thought the race was over, finally made it to a hastily re-erected finish line in Central Park yesterday, 98 hours 48 minutes 17 seconds after he started on Staten Island Sunday morning.

title: Falling Soviet Rocket Glows Over Western Sky
description: A fireball that startled people from New Mexico to California as its glowing tail burned across the sky was a Soviet rocket, the authorities said yesterday.

title: SCREEN: MARLENE
description: ''Marlene'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 21. The film opens today at Cinema 3, 2 West 59th Street. ALFRED HITCHCOCK, who never took kindly to suggestions from actors, once said of Marlene Dietrich: ''She's a professional.''

title: CBS OFFERS 'MONTE CARLO,' STARRING JOAN COLLINS
description: ''MONTE CARLO'' gives us the beginnings of World War II as they might have been conceived and executed by a couturier. The setting is fashionable Monaco (actually Nice and other areas of the French Riviera), where the only character wearing rumpled clothes is a stereotyped ''little Jewish man'' trying to get his friends out of Nazi Germany. Everyone else, even as each hears radio reports about Poland and France falling, is too busy trying to decide which gown or black-tie ensemble to wear for dinner. And reigning firmly over all this is Katrina Petrovna, a Russian-born spy for the British, who is played -or, more accurately, displayed - by Joan Collins.

title: SCREEN: BRYAN BROWN IN 'TAI-PAN'
description: YOU have to say this for ''Tai-Pan'': it's ridiculous - but in a big way. It's two hours of Super Comics: Bearded Brutes! Busty Belles! Bloody Blades! Exotic Settings! Colorful Costumes! A Beheading! A Castration! A Typhoon!

title: PANCHO'S MEXICAN BUFFET reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (SERING, FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $46,463. The share earnings were not reported because the company just went public in August.

title: Easler Seeks Trade
description: Mike Easler, the Yankees' designated hitter, yesterday became the first player to demand a trade in this off-season. His agent said the move was primarily protective and was aimed at Easler's effort to negotiate a contract extension with the Yankees, who have exercised their option for 1987.

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Company to Offer Bond Reinsurance
description: The capacity of the financial insurance industry was increased recently by the creation of the Enhance Reinsurance Company, which specializes in reinsurance of municipal bonds.

title: STEEL TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
45 FEARED KILLED IN BRITISH HELICOPTER CRASH
description: Forty-five people were feared killed today when a civilian helicopter carrying 47 people from an oil rig in the icy waters of the North Sea crashed off the Shetland Islands.

title: BIOCRAFT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cynthia Jaffee McCabe Dies; Curator at Hirshhorn Was 43
description: Cynthia Jaffee McCabe, a curator at the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden of the Smithsonian Institution, died Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro, where she was doing preliminary work on a proposed Hirshhorn exhibition of contemporary Latin American art.

title: AGENDA: NOV. 7, 1986
description: Health Options One million active and retired municipal workers face a deadline for choosing health-care coverage for the coming year, and for the first time a series of profit-making plans are among their options. The workers' choices, which account for $500 million in business, are considered the biggest health-care prize in the state and could shape the competition among insurers. Jails Chief

title: INSIDE
description: Copter Crashes in North Sea A civilian helicopter carrying 47 people from an oil rig in the North Sea crashed off the Shetland Islands, and 45 were feared killed.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $8,174,000 from consolidation and inventory adjustments.

title: Dining Out Guide; New, Midtown
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BRIVE, #405 East 58th Street (838-9393) -**(Sept. 5, 1986) It is almost impossible to keep up with the scores of new restaurants that open each year in the city, but a sampling would have to include this softly upholstered new dining room in a midtown town house. The long, narrow dining area begins in the front room and ends overlooking a small garden in the rear. Although the menu is overly cute, the food is often arresting. The fall menu features appetizers of veal tongue, braised with ginger and orange-flavored spaetzle; sweetbread torte with black olive cream, and mussels with garlic butter.

title: U.S. MOVES TO STAFF EMBASSY
description: The Government has awarded a $10 million contract to a Los Angeles-based company to furnish support staff for the United States Embassy in Moscow and the American Consulate General in Leningrad, the State Department announced today.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Share earnings for 1985 reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected August 26, 1986.

title: ACME STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said as a result of LTV Corp.'s July 17 Chapter 11 reorganization filing, it recognized a $16.8 million pre-tax charge in the latest third quarter to reflect the combined impact of the bankruptcy petition on certain company assets.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ALMI Group L.P said Michael Spiegler had joined the company as executive vice president, corporate development.

title: Don't Panic, Yet, Over AIDS
description: The vast majority of AIDS victims continue to be male homosexuals and intravenous drug addicts. But in African countries like Zaire and Uganda, the disease spreads differently, affecting men and women alike. Is AIDS about to become epidemic among the general public in America, too?

title: Chrysler, A.M.C. Deny Sale Report
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation denied reports in The Detroit Free Press that Chrysler was planning to buy assets of A.M.C., most likely A.M.C.'s assembly plants in Wisconsin and Ohio.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Surgeon General in Hospital
description: C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States, entered the Bethesda Naval Medical Center Wednesday night because of neck pain from a nerve injury sustained in a skiing accident in his college days, the Navy said today. Dr. Koop, who is 70 years old, was listed in good condition. Tests will be conducted for the next five days to determine whether surgery will be required, a hospital spokesman said.

title: EXECUTIVE TESTIFIES HE URGED THAT SOME BRIBES BE ENDED
description: An executive of a major debt-collection agency testified today that he urged a former city transportation chief to stop paying bribes to Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the former deputy director of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau. He also called Mr. Lindenauer ''an accident waiting to happen.''

title: RECORD SPENDING IN CONGRESSIONAL CAMPAIGN HAD MIXED RESULTS AT POLLS
description: The most expensive Congressional campaign in the nation's history ended Tuesday with a mixed financial result: the Democrats gained control of the Senate even though they were outspent, and they picked up a few more seats in the House while outspending the Republicans in those contests.

title: HIGH PLAINS OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRAMA AND DANGER FROM WALL TO WALL
description: The spectacle that awes horse show audiences most, the meeting between the willing jumper and an ever-growing wall, was won by Barney Ward of the United States riding Rex Forever in the $10,000 Puissance Stake last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Victim of AIDS To Stay in School
description: The Board of Education Wednesday night unanimously upheld a school administration decision to permit a student with AIDS to attend classes.

title: BIG BOARD-CHICAGO MERC LINK STUDIED
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that they were considering a trading link between the two markets, a potentially significant step in the growing integration of the equity and futures markets.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After special gains of $25,690,000 for the quarter and $45,237,000 for the 9 months. c-After special gains of $651,000 for the quarter and $11,653,000 for the 9 months.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1986
description: G.M.'s Plant Closings

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Includes a $2,220,000, or 33 cents a share, non-recurring gain in connection with the acquisition of Debron for the quarter and 9 months.

title: E.P.A. STIFFENS RULE FOR DUMPING OF TOXIC WASTES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced a ban on the dumping of wastes containing concentrated amounts of dioxins and industrial solvents in landfills, starting Saturday.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IN some ways Menage a Trois seems a deja vu - if you will pardon le francais - which is to say that this most contemporary of French restaurants produces a host of highly stylized dishes that flash back to the dainty days of nouvelle cuisine. Antony Worrall-Thompson, the jet-propelled chef-owner who presides over this and sister establishments in London, Bombay, Stockholm and Melbourne, is an intelligent and opinionated fellow. While his sculpted food presentation harkens to earlier days, his recipes are forward looking and, for the most part, solidly grounded.

title: Quake Near Reagan Ranch
description: A moderate earthquake shook rural Santa Barbara County near President Reagan's ranch today but caused no damage or injuries, the authorities said. The temblor, which registered 4.0 on the Richter scale of severity, came at 1:20 A.M. and was centered 33 miles northwest of Santa Barbara, said Dennis Meredith, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. An earthquake registering 4.0 can cause moderate damage in its immediate area.

title: 29,000 WORKERS WILL BE AFFECTED
description: In a sweeping move to cut costs and regain its competitive edge, the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would close 11 plants in the United States that employ about 29,000 people, or more than 5 percent of its work force in this country.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIAT BESTS FORD IN BID FOR ALFA
description: Italy's largest privately held corporation, Fiat S.p.A, won the battle for control of Alfa Romeo S.p.A. today, defeating a bid from the Ford Motor Company.

title: CLYDE AND PEARL FOR HOOP HALL
description: In the evening of that winter in what now seems so long ago Bobby Fischer, a man of prodigiously solitary affairs, was taken to a Knicks basketball game at Madison Square Garden, and nearly bolted.

title: NAPCO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 374 money market mutual funds declined by $2.97 billion, to $234.63 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3,259,000 and $3,259,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and for both periods includes a one-time charge of $15 million taken in anticipation of presenting a proposal to resolve a dispute with the environmental protection agency over the Waukegan Harbor.

title: WEINBERGER IS DETERMINED ON ARMS BUDGET
description: Facing a new Congress controlled by Democrats, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he would continue to submit military budgets that were big enough to meet the needs of national security.

title: MCINTYRE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes special gains of $6,842 and $16,096,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss The company said the special gains are from its share of income recorded by Falconbridge Ltd. on the sale of various subsidiaries, and McIntyre holds a 15.7-percent stake in Falconbridge.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE AFTERNOON SUN. By David Pryce-Jones. 214 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95. STOUT, bald, little more than 5 feet tall - no one can ever have called Gustav Ellingen handsome. But Ellingen, whom we meet in the opening pages of David Pryce-Jones's new novel, didn't have to be. As master of the Concordia engineering works he was one of the most powerful men in the Austrian Empire. After he had been ennobled it was enough for a letter to be addressed to ''Baron Ellingen, Vienna'' for it to be delivered; he dominated those around him, and he dominates the early chapters of ''The Afternoon Sun.''

title: PRETORIA ACCUSES NEIGHBORS OF A PLOT
description: South Africa said tonight that it had evidence that two of its black-ruled neighbors had plotted to overthrow an ally of Pretoria, President Hastings Kamuzu Banda of Malawi.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1.3 million.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $71,927,000, or 88 cents a share, and $85,409,000, or 1.04 a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: SOKOLOW SENTENCED AS INSIDER
description: In the first sentencing to come out of the Dennis B. Levine insider trading scandal, Ira B. Sokolow, a 32-year-old former investment banker, was given a term of one year and a day in a Federal prison and three years of probation after admitting to having sold inside information about pending corporate takeovers to Mr. Levine.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $2,785,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,367,000 and $5,106,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: AMC ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $30,035,000. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split of the company's common stock distributed in March 1986.

title: The Consultants' Day After . . .
description: When Tommy Griscom woke up early Wednesday morning, for a few moments he thought that maybe Tuesday had been a dream and that Election Day still lay before him.

title: WARD OUTLINES INTEGRITY MEASURES
description: Twelve current or former police officers from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn were arrested and arraigned yesterday on charges ranging from stealing garbage cans to stealing and selling drugs.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1985 quarter results included a non-recurring gain of 6 cents a share from an insurance claim. The company said it had acquired the laser scanning microscope business of IBT Dubilier Ltd.

title: Women's Squash Tour
description: Female professional squash racquets players bring their newly established tour to New York City for the first time when the Loews United States Open Women's Squash Championships begin today in Manhattan.

title: Jamaican Withdraws Notice He Will Quit
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga has announced that he is reversing his decision to resign, saying economic recovery and a new International Monetary Fund agreement depend on his remaining in office.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ROBIN WILLIAMS was fearless, as usual. He stepped to the microphone and, before an audience that included much of the New York theater community, dared to deliver his interpretation of Sylvester Stallone as Hamlet. ''To be,'' he intoned, ''or - what?'' Mr. Williams, who was dressed for a black-tie dinner party in a baggy jacket ''from my Hefty bag collection,'' was one of many people paying tribute to John Houseman - ''a man who is not afraid to use vowels'' - in the packed ballroom of the Plaza.

title: Purdue Coach Resigns
description: With his team's record at 2-6 and Michigan coming up tomorrow, Leon Burtnett has announced his resignation as football coach of Purdue, effective at the end of the season. Burtnett said he would remain at Purdue indefinitely, working under the athletic director, George King. He has four years remaining on a five-year-contract and had a 20-32-1 record in his five years at Purdue.

title: The Prize: A Mercedes
description: A new Mercedes equipped with an air bag will be given away tomorrow at a raffle in the Russell Senate Office Building. But because such games of chance are not allowed in Federal buildings, the winning number actually will be drawn in Richmond and telephoned to Washington.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., Eden, N.C., said it would acquire Bigelow-Sanford Inc., of Greenville, S.C., maker of broadloom carpets for residential and commercial use, for about 525,000 shares of Fieldcrest common stock and an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: U.A.W. IS SET BACK OVER JOB SECURITY
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers acknowledged today that their efforts to assure job security for their members had been dealt a blow by the General Motors Corporation's decision to shut several plants.

title: THE LANDFILL PATROL COUNTS EVERY SCRAP OF EVIDENCE
description: ''Whoops,'' said Mary Ellen Oliver as her foot sunk into the garbage. ''Soft spot.'' She wiggled her leg free and again climbed up the fresh pile of garbage a truck had just dumped at the landfill. In a few moments, Mrs. Oliver was ripping open plastic trash bags. ''This could be something,'' she said, rooting out an envelope with a Jackson Heights, Queens, address.

title: SCREEN: SIGOURNEY WEAVER IN 'HALF MOON STREET'
description: THE key scene that opens Paul Theroux's novella ''Doctor Slaughter'' and is buried in the early sections of the film version, entitled ''Half Moon Street,'' introduces the story's heroine to a charmingly opinionated dinner-party companion named Van Arkady, who voices the idea that there are only 5,000 people in the world - or at least, only 5,000 who matter. It's a sentiment that the elitist Dr. Lauren Slaughter, a onetime beauty contestant nee Mopsy Fairlight, can wholeheartedly share.

title: BEARS LEANING TO TOMCZAK
description: Let's see, whose turn is it to start at quarterback for the Chicago Bears Sunday when they play the Buccaneers in Tampa?

title: BRIEFS
description: Debts

title: Expulsions by France Anger Basques in Spain
description: Protests broke out in the Spanish Basque region today against the expulsion by France of six people suspected of being separatist guerrillas as Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France paid his first official visit to Madrid.

title: Politics And the Courts
description: The Democrats who will control the Senate for the next two years might - or might not -reduce or shift priorities in military expenditures, stop aid to the ''contras'' in Nicaragua, pass a trade bill, or fall into the political trap of trying to raise taxes. But almost surely they'll put a brake on President Reagan's effort to pack the Federal courts with far-right conservatives.

title: VIENNA PARLEY SHOWS ICELAND MEETING LEFT ARMS TALKS COMPLICATED AND TIES STRAINED
description: The inconclusive Soviet-American discussions here suggest that the arms control breakthroughs nearly achieved in the Iceland summit meeting have, at least temporarily, complicated and even strained relations between the two superpowers.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. MILWAUKEE BUCKS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) CHICAGO BULLS VS.

title: Bid Report Sends Resorts Up $21.75
description: Shares of Resorts International Inc. rose sharply following a report that a new bidder for the hotel and casino concern had emerged. Resorts' class B shares rose $21.75 yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, closing at $130, after reports that the Seatex Group had offered $180 a share for the class B stock held by the estate of James M. Crosby, the late chairman of Resorts.

title: TOYS FOR NOSTALGIC ADULTS
description: Lisa Smith hadn't ventured 10 feet into the Urban Outfitters store at 20 University Place before she saw something she wanted in a plastic bin: a six-inch replica of Dudley Do-Right, the television-cartoon Mountie, in his red and blue uniform.

title: Bert Shapiro, Director In Film and Television
description: Bert Shapiro, a cinematographer who produced and directed films on many subjects for television and institutions, died of cancer Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RUMMAGE SALE
description: Clothing, books and home-baked goods will be among the fare at a rummage sale tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street. Proceeds will benefit the church's after-school program. Information: 246-7277.

title: South Africa's Expulsion of Red Cross Bodes Ill for Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Relief at Plants In Northeast
description: Officials of the General Motors Corporation in the Northeast expressed relief that their plants were not affected by yesterday's announcement of closings and layoffs. But they said they lacked confidence that their operations would not someday join the ranks of those to be closed.

title: Dow Loses 7.45 Points; Volume Falls
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday in concert with a weaker bond market, and a wave of profit taking. The market was also hurt by the psychological impact of another decline in the International Business Machines Corporation's price, which fell 1 3/4 points, to 121 3/8.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Wayne Shorter, the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Now that a new generation of jazz musicians is paying homage to the obliquely brilliant music Wayne Shorter made in the 1960's, Mr. Shorter himself has moved on. But he hasn't left his knotty originality or his virtuosity on the saxophone behind him; he is still the best interpreter of his unmistakably personal compositions. Mr. Shorter is appearing through Sunday at 9 and 11:30 P.M., with third sets at around 1:30 A.M. on Friday and Saturday. Admission is $15, with a $5 minimum.

title: Dr. Harry Rose Dead at 80; Developed Test for Arthritis
description: Dr. Harry M. Rose, a microbiologist who developed the first accurate diagnostic test for rheumatoid arthritis in 1948 with Erik Waaler, a Norwegian bacteriologist, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Meredith, N.H. He was 80 years old and lived in Sandwich, N.H.

title: Wedtech Woos the White House
description: What began as an investigation into possible bribery by New York contractors has spread to other cities and even to the White House. The investigation at least implicates Government contracts to minority-owned businesses. Now two former White House aides have come under the same cloud, creating a challenge for Attorney General Edwin Meese. It's one he can meet best by stepping aside.

title: CENTRAL JERSEY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST OF MICHIGAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 11
description: b-Net loss and the quarter loss is after a pre-tax charge of $14 million from the settlement of litigation.

title: Step Back From Folly
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez will visit Cuba during his Latin American trip starting this weekend, making him the first head of an allied government to go to Havana.

title: Macy's Malls Sold
description: Westfield Holdings Ltd. of Australia agreed to acquire the three shopping centers wholly owned by R.H. Macy & Company for $363.5 million. The three malls are the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J.; the South Shore Mall in Bay Shore, L.I., and the Bay Fair Mall in San Leandro, Calif. The deal also includes a 44-acre parcel adjacent to the Garden State Plaza.

title: Tri-Star Sale Talks
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable company, is negotiating to buy a part of Tri-Star Pictures Inc., Wall Street sources said. Tele-Communications would first complete its purchase of 51 percent of United Artists Communications.

title: Auditors Settle Suit
description: Alexander & Alexander Services said it had reached a settlement with certain former auditors of its Alexander Howden Group subsidiary in England, under which it would receive $24.8 million. The agreement settles a suit brought against the auditors over reported irregularities in Howden's books, which Alexander & Alexander discovered after acquiring Howden in 1982. Alexander & Alexander said it would receive $14.2 million from Josolyne Layton-Bennett & Company, $5 million from De Paula Turner Lake & Company and $4.8 million from Peat Marwick International.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quotations of the Day
description: ''I cannot say that the meetings have moved arms control matters along in any significant way, and I regret this.''

title: C-TEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $48,000 for the quarter and $89,000 for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests and a disposition accounted for as discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June that resulted in a new class of stock.

title: STATE PANEL MOVES TO DISMISS A JUDGE WHO PROCRASTINATES
description: Procrastination may cost an upstate dairy and potato farmer his job as a part-time town justice.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
FELA ANIKULAPO KUTI, NIGERIA'S MUSICAL ACTIVIST
description: THE Nigerian band leader Fela Anikulapo Kuti has been writing and singing angry political songs since the early 1970's. He calls his music Afro-Beat; it uses saxophone and brass-section vamps that suggest a rawer version of James Brown as well as African percussion, call-and-response singing and Mr. Kuti's own saxophone solos and gruff voice; the lyrics are in pidgin English and African. Tomorrow, along with the 26 musicians and 6 dancers of his band, Egypt 80, Mr. Kuti will perform at the Felt Forum - a concert that is two years and two months overdue.

title: FROM 7TH AVENUE: COLOR, CLARITY AND CLASS
description: The Anne Klein collection was noteworthy for its defined shapes and the clarity of its colors. Gloria Sachs deftly mixed silk paisley prints with leathers in richly glowing shades. And the first Perry Ellis collection without the designer - he died a few weeks after his fall show last May -recalled the gentle refinement of early American sportswear.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Pop Life column on Wednesday gave incorrect dates for concerts by Beausoleil at the Washington Square Church. They will take place today through Sunday.

title: ELDEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
HOSPOSABLE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VESTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BROWN'S OTHER SIDE
description: Of all the things Hubie Brown has done to try to revive his foundering team, the most effective may have been the simplest thing of all: being himself.

title: ATLANTIC PERMANENT FEDRAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,271,000. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $397,000. The company said the latest year results include a non-recurring gain of $7,100,000 from sale of certain asset.

title: CONTINENTAL GENERAL INSURNCE COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $4,273 for the quarter and $37,486 for the 9 months. c-After capital losses of $85,335 and $328,642 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Barry Elected to Third Term As Mayor of Nation's Capital
description: Marion S. Barry Jr. was elected Tuesday to a third term as Mayor, defeating five challengers who sought to portray him as an inept leader of a wasteful government.

title: Cable TV Doesn't Need Any More Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND SOVIET FAIL TO ADVANCE ARMS ISSUE BEYOND ICELAND GAINS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union said today that they had failed to make gains on arms control in two days of talks.

title: ECONOMIC BILLS CALLED LIKELY IN DEMOCRATIC SENATE
description: The new Democratic-controlled Senate is likely to propose major legislation affecting banking, corporate mergers, welfare, research and wages soon after the 100th Congress begins work, the probable chairmen of the Senate's economic policy committees and staff members said today.

title: A VARIED AND BOUYANT SEASON IN THE MUSEUMS
description: OUR museums come in all sizes. Glimpsed from above, the Met looks as big as a small town (which it is). The Frick, the Morgan Library, the Cooper-Hewitt look what they are -great town houses, well-adapted relics of a time when domesticity was written in marble and touched with gold. The Jewish Museum was once a Warburg town house. The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park is a medieval pastiche stuffed and truffled with genuine souvenirs of a European past that predates the discovery of America. At least two of our museums - the Guggenheim and the Whitney - have themselves been claimed as works of individual genius. The Japan Society at 333 East 47th Street is the East in microcosm, and the new headquarters of the Museum of American Crafts, opposite the Museum of Modern Art on West 53d Street, is just as big and buoyant as it should be, given the sass that is built into so much of what is on view there.

title: New Post for Kingon?
description: President Reagan is planning to name Alfred H. Kingon, Assistant to the President for Cabinet Affairs, as United States Representative to the European Community in Brussels, according to White House sources. Mr. Kingon is a former Wall Street investment adviser and was publisher of Financial World, where he made money, and Saturday Review, where he did not. He worked for President Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign, as did the man he is succeeding in Brussels, J. William Middendorf 2d. The post carries the rank of ambassador.

title: Newell Bids For Hocking
description: The Newell Company, a manufacturer of hardware and housewares, offered to buy the Anchor Hocking Corporation for $34 a share, or about $330 million. J. Ray Topper, Anchor Hocking's chief executive, called the unsolicited bid ''a real non-offer if I've ever seen one.''

title: Changing Times Finds 'New Realism'
description: Nicholas Niles, publisher of Changing Times, is about to assault the advertising community with a new study that he, of course, believes will be beneficial to his print vehicle.

The 1986 results include Fidelity Bankers Life Insurance Co., acquired in November, and reflect Pilgrim Group Inc.'s 60 percent increase in assets under management since Dec. 31, to more than $1.7 billion at Sept. 30.

title: Orpheus Orchestra
description: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, a 26-member ensemble, will give the first of three concerts in New Jersey tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. in the Glenfield Auditorium, Bloomfield and Maple Avenues, Montclair, N.J. The group will perform works by Haydn, Mozart, Brahms and Stravinsky.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Jonathan Schwartz, Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). The author, disk jockey and keeper of the flame for traditional songwriting values turns his attention to the lyrics of Lorenz Hart in his 13th appearance at Michael's Pub. Anecdotes and reflections segue into intelligent, finely shaded renditions of standards that run from swingers (''I Wish I Were in Love Again'') to pensive ballads (a murmured, intimate ''My Romance''). Literate, suave and charming as always, Jonathan Schwartz receives solid understated backing by a quartet that includes Tony Monte on piano, Jimmy Mitchell, guitar, Jerry Bruno, bass, and Tony Tedesco, drums. Show times tonight and tomorrow are 9 and 11 P.M. There is a $10 music charge and a $12.95 minimum.

title: NO-FRILLS COSMETICS ARE AN ANSWER TO HIGH PRICE
description: Does beauty have a price? When it comes to makeup and skin care products, the answer is yes - and the price is often high. High enough, in fact, to shake an otherwise hard-boiled shopper.

title: Better Pay for SUNY's Chief
description: Consider the following corporate profile. Company X is the largest in its field. With 30,000 employees and an annual budget of $2 billion, it serves 370,000 customers. Its policies are set by a board of directors that is also responsible for hiring its chief executive officer and other top management. But the board lacks the authority to set management salaries, which are determined not by the needs of the marketplace but instead are limited by unrelated external factors. As a result, key managers are lured away and important openings remain unfilled because the corporation cannot meet the competition.

title: Waiting for Kennedy

THEATER: 'BLUTWURST,' PORTRAIT OF EGON SCHIELE
description: Through his art, using himself as his model, Egon Schiele painted a lacerating self-portrait, which John Kelly re-creates with fierce intensity in his performance piece, ''Pass the Blutwurst, Bitte.'' Mr. Kelly's play, which opened last night at Dance Theater Workshop, captures both the narcissism and the masochism that made Schiele such an extravagant figure in the Viennese art scene in the early years of the 20th century.

title: I Am 82 and Beset By My Landlord
description: At 82 years of age, I have come to realize that the threat of homelessness frightens me more than death itself. For the last three years, I have been resisting the determined efforts of my landlord to turn me out of my apartment. My friends, my lawyer, even judges who have briefly presided over the case have all assured me that there is little likelihood that an elderly widow can be forced to vacate her premises. It is entirely possible they are right. But the ordeal has been physically, psychologically and financially debilitating, and I still see no end to it.

title: Indiana Player Dropped
description: Although he satisfied the academic standards of the N.C.A.A. for athletic eligibility, Daryl Thomas of Indiana University has not met those laid down by Coach Bobby Knight and he has been cut from the basketball team. Thomas, a 6-foot-7-inch senior forward from Westchester, Ill., who averaged 14.5 points and 4.8 rebounds for the Hoosiers last season, became the second player in three seasons (Mike Giomi in 1985 was the other) to be dropped after failing to meet Knight's personal standards. . . . Todd Ziegler, a University of Kentucky forward, yesterday pleaded guilty to shoplifting charges and entered a pretrial diversion program, but probably won't return to the team for more than a month. Ziegler admitted to pocketing a charger for an electric razor in a department store.

title: Jackson a Free Agent
description: October has been a special month in Reggie Jackson's career because he has made a name for himself -Mr. October - by producing significant hits in postseason games. November has become significant too, however, at least in a five-year cycle. For the third time in his career, Jackson filed yesterday for free agency. He did it first in 1976, leaving the Baltimore Orioles for the Yankees, and he did it again in 1981, leaving the Yankees for the California Angels. The Yankees didn't want to keep him five years ago and the Angels apparently aren't interested in re-signing him now. His age - 40 - and his 1986 performance - .241 average, 18 home runs, 58 runs batted in - are two reasons teams might shy away from signing him. Another possible reason: He is a Type A free agent, which means that a team that signs him would have to give up its first- or second-round choice in the amateur draft next June. . . . The Angels also announced that Ruppert Jones, the 31-year-old outfielder who is a former Yankee, would not be offered a contract next season. Jones batted .229 with 17 homers and 49 r.b.i. in 126 games with the Angels last season. . . . Other players who filed for free agency yesterday were Doug DeCinces, Jackson's Type A teammate, who hit 26 homers and drove in 96 runs; Terry Forster, whose option the Angels chose not to pick up; Larry Herndon of Detroit and Lynn Jones of Kansas City.

title: UNEMPLOYEMENT IN NEW YORK AND JERSEY DOWN SLIGHTLY FROM 1985

title: Mozambique Asserts Pretoria Is Impeding Air-Crash Inquiry

description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has bought a major stake in Hong Kong's largest English-language newspaper, its shareholders said today. The Hongkong and Shanghai

title: Tragedy of College Sports
description: In college gyms around the country, the sound of basketballs thumping and sneakers squeaking can again be heard as preseason practice is underway. As the last leaves fall, hopeful college football teams make their final push for a bowl bid, trying to impress backslapping representatives in pumpkin- , banana- and lime-colored blazers.

description: The restored Wollman ice skating rink in Central Park will reopen at 11 A.M. Thursday, after seven years of construction failures and delays, according to the developer Donald J. Trump.

title: Who Will Bail Out America?
description: Chalk one up for Treasury Secretary Baker, who has finally persuaded Japan to reduce domestic interest rates. But don't break out the champagne. The agreement is just one step on the long road toward balanced world growth and stable trade. Neither Japan nor West Germany will stimulate their economies enough to make a real dent in their gigantic trade surpluses until America shows its will to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Emerson Electric
description: The Emerson Electric Company has agreed to sell its outdoor power products division, Beaird-Poulan Weed Eater, to A.B. Electrolux of Stockholm, Emerson announced. No terms of the agreement were disclosed. Beaird-Poulan Weed Eater makes portable garden tools and chain saws.

title: Dinosaur Mysteries

THE GREAT DYING. Cosmic Catastrophe, Dinosaurs, and the Theory of Evolution. By Kenneth J. Hsu. 292 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: MISSING IDICTED OFFICER FOUND DEAD IN MOTEL
description: A police officer from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn who had been indicted on charges of stealing and selling drugs was found shot to death in a Long Island motel yesterday afternoon, apparently a suicide, the police said.

title: Flip of Coin to Settle Dead Heat for Sheriff
description: A dead heat in the race for Bond County sheriff will be decided by a flip of a coin next week under a seldom-used Illinois statute.

title: RADIO MERGER PLAN: F.C.C. GETS BRIEFING
description: The National Broadcasting Company and Westinghouse Broadcasting and Cable Inc. briefed key members of the Federal Communications Commission staff today about a possible merger of their radio operations.

title: IN PRAISE OF SPECIAL POPCORN
description: Another fancy food show has come and gone in New York. First, the bad news: chocolate-covered potato chips. One of the manufacturers is Yuppie Gourmet Inc., and that's the market for which the chips are intended.

title: Systemic Failure, and Support: California's Loss
description: In Tuesday's voting, Californians removed three Justices of their Supreme Court after a raucous, irresponsible campaign that exposes the deficiency of their judicial selection process far more than the conduct of any judge.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Slight Breach of Protocol
description: Edward J. Derwinski, the State Department counselor who is to become Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, Science and Technology, committed a slight breach of protocol the other night. At an Italian-American conference on international competition and cooperation in science and technology, he referred to the Italian Minister for Science and Technology, Luigi Granelli, as a Socialist.

title: DEFEATED JUSTICE FEARFUL OF ATTACKS ON JUDICIARY
description: Chief Justice Rose Elizabeth Bird said today that her defeat in the election Tuesday would embolden leaders of the New Right, corporations and both political parties to seek control of many state courts through the ballot box.

title: BLACK AND JEWISH SEMINARIANS MEET TO FIND AMITY
description: First the Jewish choir sang its tuneful melodies and then the black gospel chorus performed its soulful songs. And before the concert of sacred music was over, both groups joined hands and together sang a song of praise.

title: Atari's Stock Sold
description: The Atari Corporation, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., made its initial public offering of 4.5 million shares, or 16 percent of the company.

title: Review Seen On Chip Deal
description: A Government group that examines foreign investments in the United States decided privately today to review the proposed sale of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, a Silicon Valley computer chip manufacturer, to a Japanese company, Administration officials said.

title:
PATENTS;
Methods to Produce Human Cell Proteins
description: A Japanese inventor was granted four patents this week for methods of producing various human cell proteins regarded as useful in medication.

title: KHOMEINI DEPUTIES DIFFER IN OUTLOOK
description: Some outsiders are quick to characterize two former students of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as political rivals locked in a bitter power struggle as they position themselves for the post-Khomeini era in Iran.

title: Systematic Failure, and Support: Allies
description: Most school-based drug education efforts are aimed at students. New York's United Federation of Teachers makes its contribution with a pitch to critical allies in the fight against drugs: parents.
