description: b-Net income

Israelis Curtail Books By Singer and Others
description: The Education Ministry has banned from religious schools books by the Nobel Prize winning author Isaac Bashevis Singer and several other prominent writers. A ministry official said today that the books were not suitable for religious students.

title: No. 1 AND 2 ONLY MILES APART
description: Don Nehlen, the West Virginia coach, watched as his Mountaineers were rendered helpless twice this season, first against Miami in a 58-14 loss four weeks ago, then three weeks later against Penn State in a 19-0 loss last Saturday night.

title: REAL ESTATE FIRM DISMISSES AGENT FOR COMMENTS ON DISCRIMINATION
description: A large Manhattan real estate brokerage, which last year rewarded one its employees for her ''relentless'' efforts to sell a cooperative apartment on the Upper East Side, has dismissed her for discussing those same sales efforts in a newspaper interview about discrimination in the co-op market.

title: 2 Yachts Meet Challenges
description: Both America II and New Zealand tore spinnakers in their separate challenger races in the America's Cup trials today. But the crews managed to hoist new ones within seconds of the mishaps and go on to win their matches.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page article yesterday about plant closings announced by the General Motors Corporation misstated G.M.'s stock action Thursday. It rose $1 a share, to $74.25.

title: The Pollsters Look Back
description: ''I don't think it was a great year for pollsters,'' said John Brennan, ''but I wouldn't call it a debacle.''

title: VIOLENCE ERUPTS AT A DEMONSTRATION IN HAITI
description: An anti-Government demonstration involving thousands of protesters erupted in violence this afternoon with one policeman reported killed and at least six other people wounded.

title: Sweeney Closing In
description: Kevin Sweeney, the Fresno State senior quarterback who is aiming to set a Division I-A National Collegiate Athletic Assocation record for career yards gained by passing, moved to within 304 yards of his goal Thursday night as the Bulldogs defeated Nevada-Las Vegas, 36-7.

description: Through the bus windows, the New England countryside was already dusted with white. There had been enough snow that when the varsity football team from Columbia reached Memorial Field for its practice the day before the game against Dartmouth, the Lions discovered they would have to go inside because the field was being cleared.

title: SIZABLE OBSTACLE FOR GIANTS
description: Reggie White may be the only 6-foot-5-inch, 285-pound Baptist minister who has preached in more than 100 churches, plays the sousaphone, does impressions of guard dogs and celebrities, and worries Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants.

title: Why Save Tropical Forests?
description: Many Americans feel that saving the world's tropical forests warrants about as much concern as the snail darter. In Europe and the United States, they say, deforestation was the inevitable and desirable consequence of economic progress; why, therefore, should it be any different in the largely underdeveloped nations where the world's tropical forests are to be found?

title: 28 Youths Arrested In Scavenger Hunt
description: Twenty-eight high school students were arrested early today when the police broke up a scavenger hunt before the youths could obtain item 29 on the list: an unrelated human baby.

title: Driesell Looks to Pros
description: Lefty Driesell, who was removed as basketball coach and reassigned as assistant athletic director at the University of Maryland last week, is already investigating other coaching possibilities. Although the city of Charlotte, N.C., does not have a professional team, a group of businessmen is attempting to buy a National Basketball Association franchise or move an existing team to Charlotte.

title: Reflections on School Birth Control
description: A proposal to distribute contraceptives in New York City school clinics has been put on ice for at least six months. Robert F. Wagner Jr., who heads the Board of Education, has put off a vote till a calmer moment. The six-month hiatus gives all New Yorkers the chance to reflect on the need for such a plan, properly administered.

THE SCREEN: 'QUIET COOL'
description: ''Quiet Cool'' is an action film set in the leafy Northwest, in a town whose marijuana growers object mightily to the efforts of one New York City policeman (James Remar) to cramp their style. It's an ordinary formula film in most ways, though an especially violent one. The policeman and a teen-age sidekick (Adam Coleman Howard), acting as a kind of Rambo and Son, execute a wide variety of impalings, hookings and garrotings, not to mention the usual gunplay. There's more than enough ugliness for this to have been a horror film, if only there'd been a couple of ski masks on hand.

description: It is a melancholy fact that in North America the under-30 generation, attracted by computers and television, seldom sits down to a game of social bridge. Half a century ago, it was normal to find some bridge activity in schools, colleges and the armed forces.

title: TV. VIEWS OF GUINNESS ON ACTING
description: ''I hate talking about acting, you know,'' muses Sir Alec Guinness, two-thirds of the way through a long, articulate interview about his career with Melvyn Bragg. In the hourlong profile of the elusive master of disguise, which will be shown tonight at 10 on Channel 13's ''Film on Film'' series, the actor talks about nothing but acting, in a quietly lofty tone. Though interrupted by snippets of footage from ''Great Expectations,'' ''Oliver Twist,'' ''The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' ''Our Man in Havana'' and other movies, the program -produced and directed by Nigel Wattis - centers reverently on the words of a living legend who rarely gives interviews.

title: DEMOCRATS GAIN GROUND IN LEGISLATURES OF STATES
description: Democrats scored modest gains in state legislatures around the country in the elections Tuesday, basically regaining the ground the party lost in the Reagan landslide two years ago.

title: PLEAS FOR SILENCE ON MIDEAST DEALS
description: With President Reagan at his side, David P. Jacobsen, the former American hostage, pleaded with journalists today ''in the name of God'' to ''back off'' and refrain from reporting the details of hostage negotiations.

title: Saudi at Soviet Fete
description: Among the guests at the Soviet Embassy party Thursday night marking the 69th anniversary of the Russian Revolution was the Saudi Ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar bin Sultan. Because Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union do not have diplomatic ties, some guests wondered whether some kind of reconciliation might be in the wind.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SECOND AIDS VIRUS SAID TO BE DEADLY
description: A new AIDS virus discovered in west Africa last year may be as deadly as the original virus and could pose an international health threat, according to a prominent French researcher.

title: Bears' Perry Hobbled
description: William (Refrigerator) Perry of the Chicago Bears, who suffered several kicks to the left knee during a loss to the Los Angeles Rams on Monday night, was unable to walk during a practice Thursday as the Bears prepared to play the Buccaneers at Tampa Bay tomorrow.

title: Gandhi and Foe Form Kashmir Government
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi joined today with a longtime political foe to form a new government in the Moslem-dominated state of Kashmir.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERA: MET SEASON'S FIRST 'ROMEO AT JULIETTE'
description: Opera casting is often discussed in terms of chemistry: which elements unite successfully and which ones do not. But the black art of alchemy might be a better way to approach the problem. There was no way to tell in advance, for instance, that last night's principals in the Metropolitan Opera's first ''Romeo et Juliette'' of the season would combine or set off dramatic sparks. The Juliette of Gounod's gloss on Shakespeare's tragedy was a young and comparatively green Italian soprano, Cecilia Gasdia, while her lover was the veteran Alfredo Kraus, a distinguished Spaniard who may be the finest exponent of French opera among active tenors. Both singers were new to their parts in this house; in fact, it was Miss Gasdia's Metropolitan debut. Since the night also was a Metropolitan first for the conductor, Placido Domingo, it might easily have turned out to be one of those getting-to-know-you affairs.

title: FOULED-UP NETS SUFFER FOURTH STRAIGHT DEFEAT
description: Dave Wohl shook up his starting lineup tonight. In an effort to snap the Nets' three-game losing streak, the coach put Tony Brown at the shooting-guardspot in place of Albert King and played Darryl Dawkins at center instead of Mike Gminski.

title: METERING ERRORS AND FRAUD
description: THE meters that measure how much gas a stove draws, how long a phone call lasts, how much heating oil a furnace burns and how much water runs through a tap are cheating consumers of billions of dollars, according to a study to be made public today by Ralph Nader.

title: SELECTIVE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $1,240,000 and $4,841,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a reversal of a tax credit of $263,000 for the quarter, and a tax credit of $2,499,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $805,000 and $1,579,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a provision for the disposition of the company's old computer hardware and closing of unprofitable store locations, and professional-service expenses related to the changeover to the new computer system.

title:
Patents;
New Way To Hunt Arctic Oil
description: AN improved method of exploring Arctic regions for oil and gas was patented this week for the Chevron Research Company of San Francisco. William J. Ostrander, a senior staff geophysicist, was granted patent No. 4,621,347.

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $4,657,000 for the quarter and $19,426,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment losses of $2.6 million for the quarter and realized investmemt gains of $11,038,000 for the 9 months.

title: ALOHA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JAPAN CENSORS A BBC FILM
description: A censored version of a British Broadcasting Corporation film based on the life of Franz Kafka was shown this week at a festival of television movies held in Tokyo.

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KOCH UNWELCOME, GREECE SAYS
description: A senior government official said today that Mayor Koch would not be welcome in Greece because of remarks he made about a toppled statue of former President Harry S. Truman.

title: S CORPORATIONS: A NEW LUSTER
description: MANY lawyers and accountants are advising their clients who own small businesses to convert to S corporation status before the end of 1986. The major reason: The Tax Reform Act of 1986 will make this form of business ownership much more attractive than in the past.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,600,000 and $19,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: GENEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Hawks Remain Unbeatable
description: The Atlanta Hawks, playing without Dominique Wilkins, trounced the Phoenix Suns tonight, 106-86, behind Kevin Willis and Mike McGee, who scored 22 points each. The victory raised the Hawks' record to 4-0, leaving Atlanta as the only team in the league without a loss.

title: BOROUGH CHIEFS CONSULTED ON NEW HOMELESS SHELTERS
description: The Koch administration has begun negotiations with the city's five borough presidents over the sites for 20 new shelters for the homeless.

title: Milstein Postpones Recital
description: A recital by Nathan Milstein, scheduled for Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall, has been postponed because of the illness of Mr. Milstein. The recital has been rescheduled for Dec. 9 at 8 P.M. Tickets will be honored on the new date.

title: Israeli Police Summon 4 Who Met With P.L.O.
description: The police have summoned for questioning 4 of the 27 Israelis who returned today from a meeting with Palestine Liberation Organization representatives in Rumania, the Israeli radio reported.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $3,432,000 from the redemption of debentures. The company said the retroactive repeal of the investment tax credit reduced earnings in the latest quarter and 9 months by 4 cents a share.

title: SOVIET DEFENSE CHIEF MISSES KEY PARADE
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Sergei L. Sokolov, who has been out of public view for the last two months, failed to review the Revolution Day parade in Red Square today, increasing the speculation that he is seriously ill.

title: Husband Seized In Wife Stabbing
description: A 23-year-old Bronx man cut his estranged wife with a glass shard yesterday and struggled with the police until an officer shot him, the authorities said.

title: GRAHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses of $1,053,000 from discontinued operations and $135,000 from unusual items for the quarter and losses of $2,250,000 from discontinued operations and $965,000 from unusual items for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $351,000 for the quarter and $576,000 for the 9 months.

title: Air Turbulence Forces Jetliner to Turn Back
description: High winds shook a Continental Airlines DC-10 bound for Tahiti Friday, slightly injuring three flight attendants and jostling several passengers before the plane was forced to turn back to the Los Angeles International Airport.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $558,000 from the settlement of litigation for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: The 'Crack Judges,' by Merit
description: The crack epidemic has overloaded New York City's courts, especially its depleted Criminal Court. The Democratic Assembly has been eager to create more judges but Republican senators have held out for a piece of the patronage. Now their stalemate has been broken by a three-way deal with Governor Cuomo. It could dramatically advance Mr. Cuomo's brand of judicial selection reform.

title: RJ FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
HEIST, C. H. CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
IVERSON TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAWFUL U.S. ALIENS CRITICIZE EXCLUSION UNDER THE NEW LAW
description: When President Reagan signed the landmark immigration bill Thursday he brought joy to millions of illegal aliens who may now claim amnesty and remain in this country legally.

title: NELSON RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dun Selling Magazine
description: Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Dun's Business Review magazine to the Goldhirsch Group for an undisclosed sum.

title: BEACH-EROSION AID ADVANCES
description: AN ITEM tucked into a multibillion-dollar water resources development bill expected to be signed soon by President Reagan may bring more than $100 million worth of sand to an erosion-wracked stretch of barrier beach in Westhampton Beach.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; Public Library Left in Limbo
description: THE third plan for a permanent home for the Chicago Public Library was shot down recently, leaving the collection in the ''temporary'' quarters it has occupied for the last 11 years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's nothing wrong with secret diplomacy, but if you are doing it as a way to get around specific laws, then everything is wrong.'' - Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: THE HOUSE ON MOON LAKE. By Francesca Duranti. Translated by Stephen Sartarelli. (Random House, $15.95.) The Italian novelist Francesca Duranti has written a tale that is part mystery, part ghost story.

title: A Grueling Struggle For Equality
description: UNTIL last June's landmark Supreme Court decision, sexual harassment was not an urgent issue for American business. Now that the court has ruled that it is a form of sex discrimination forbidden by Federal law, many employers, worried about potential liability, are adopting tough anti-harassment policies.

title: O'ROURKE TO UNVEIL BUDGET PROPOSAL
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke will have little spare time to brood over his unsuccessful campaign for Governor. This week he is scheduled to release his proposed 1987 county budget.

title: 11 More Bodies Found From North Sea Crash
description: Divers recovered 11 more bodies overnight and raised a large section of the Chinook helicopter that crashed into the North Sea off Sumburgh Head in the Shetlands, killing 45 people, officials said today.

title: Polly King Hahn To Become Bride Of Matthew Ernst
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Hahn Jr. of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Polly King Hahn to Matthew Abbott Ernst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Calvin Bradley Ernst of Ann Arbor, Mich. The wedding is planned for May.

title: DANCE: 'SALON PROJECT' BY WORK WITH TROUPE
description: THE Workwith Dancers Company had an interesting idea in its ''Salon Project,'' which opened on Wednesday at the Dia Foundation space on Mercer Street. The idea was to bring performers together in a relatively expensive and informal production that would offer audiences a chance to explore new work. The project will offer new programs by other choreographers on Nov. 12 and 24. Perhaps by then the problems of Wednesday's program will be ironed out. But it must be said that the evening was one of numbing pretension and very little lively work.

title: Is a College Football Playoff Needed?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Kelly G. Palmer Becomes a Bride
description: Kelly Germaine Palmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren George Palmer of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married there yesterday to W. Garrison Jackson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Garrison Jackson of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Mashpee, Mass. The Rev. Rayner W. Hesse Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: A Film About Sex That's All Talk
description: In the country kitchen of a lakeside cottage, four men are preparing a coulibiac and talking about sex: a philandering husband's fear of an unexpected late-night telephone call, the subtly varied fragrances of different women, the compulsion to seduce and the indignities (''Dancing!'') endured in the process. ''Lying is the basis of all love affairs,'' muses one man.

title: Loose and Baggy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nouveau Mania
description: IT TOOK ME A DOZEN YEARS to catch on. Every Nov. 15, the Beaujolais nouveau would be released. Everyone knew about the midnight frenzy: the bottling lines still rattling, the frantic loading of the trucks under the glare of the television lights and then the careering journey off through the night to the bars of Paris, to the planes at De Gaulle and the ships waiting impatiently at the Channel ports. All over the world, thirsty fans were waiting.

title: Amal Saliba Is Bride of Gregory Dalack
description: Amal Saliba, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nassif Saliba of Schreen, Lebanon, was married yesterday to Dr. Gregory W. Dalack, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John D. Dalack of West Brighton, S.I. Metropolitan Archbishop Philip Saliba, the bride's uncle and Primate of the Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese of North America, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Antiochian Orthodox Church in Brooklyn. He was assisted by the Very Rev. Paul W. S. Schneirla, pastor of the church.

title:
MUSIC;
EUROPEAN TOUR SET FOR YOUTH ORCHESTRA
description: THE New Jersey Youth Symphony, which will perform a free Young People's Concert at 3 P.M. today at New Providence High School, is preparing for its third European tour.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief report last week about sugar as a political lever incorrectly described the fate of amendments proposed by Senator Jesse Helms to the anti-drug act. The act does, as Senator Helms proposed, eliminate the sugar quota from any country suspected of aiding the trafficking of drugs to the United States.

title: Leonore Shiland Taylor Dies; Philadelphis Charity Worker
description: Leonore Shiland Taylor, for many years a fund-raiser for charity in Philadelphia who was the wife of the former president and publisher of The Philadelphia Evening and Sunday Bulletin, died at her home yesterday after a long illness. She was 66 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa., near Philadelphia.

title: IS SEABROOK ANOTHER SHOREHAM?
description: AT the front gate of the newly completed nuclear reactor here, a small band of determined protesters carries placards. Inside, workers are preparing for a full-scale operation that may never come.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ALTHOUGH the state's Department of Environmental Protection has claimed victory in its battle to clean up International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. of Union Beach, several environmental groups have charged that the D.E.P. surrendered.

title: COME ON, BABY, DO THE MASHED POTATOES
description: HIGH on the list of ''comfort foods'' is mashed potatoes.

title: FUND HELPS RESOTRE CITY'S CHURCHES
description: When high winds from Hurricane Gloria buckled the old wooden steeple of the 134-year-old Reformed Church of South Bushwick in Brooklyn last year, leaving it tilting precariously, the tiny congregation quickly found that it could not finance the extensive repairs.

title: Sandwiches In Orbit
description: TO SPACE & BACK By Sally Ride with Susan Okie. Illustrated. 96 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $14.95. (Ages 6 and up) YOUR FUTURE IN SPACE The U.S. Space Camp Training Program. By Flip and Debra Schulke and Penelope and Raymond McPhee. Illustrated. 143 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. Paper, $14.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: Fortress Of Fantasy
description: The scarlet of a Coldstream Guardsman, the blue of a British regimental flag, the steel gray of a cuiras-sier's breastplate - a panoply of color salutes visitors to the Soldier Shop.

title: C.I.A. Chief Outlines Effort to Aid 3d World
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is trying to help developing countries solve their economic problems in a new approach to competing with the Soviet Union for influence, William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today.

title: Bishop A.P. Stokes Jr. Of Boston Is ead at 81
description: Anson Phelps Stokes Jr., the retired Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, died Friday after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Meet The 'Bad Cop' on U.S. Trade Policy
description: To negotiators from Japan, Europe, South Korea and other United States trading partners, the name Michael B. Smith is synonymous with what Theodore Roosevelt called the big stick.

title: ORANGE IS USING A 4-HORSE, 4-MAN MOUNTED POLICE PATROL
description: THEIR names are Brick, Chris, Star and Clancey, and they are the quarter horses in the Orange Police Department's recently formed mounted patrol, believed to be the only suburban unit of its kind in the state.

title: Islanders Win in Overtime
description: Sharp goaltending by Kelly Hrudey of the Islanders and Glen Hanlon of Detroit kept the game deadlocked until Patrick Flatley gave the Islanders a 2-1 victory with 49 seconds left in overtime.

title: Cooney May Fight
description: FOR someone who says he wants to fight Michael Spinks for the International Boxing Federation's world heavyweight championship, Gerry Cooney hasn't been very active lately. He hasn't fought since scoring a first-round knockout of Eddie Gregg last May 29.

title: VICTORY ON PARKWAY ISSUE LEADS TO NEW WATCHDOG RULE
description: IT all began when Lillian Yozzo called a local newspaper to find out why the machines she observed from her Hastings kitchen window were counting cars on the Saw Mill River Parkway.

title: Nuclear Panel Backs License
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Friday authorized a full-power operating license for the Perry nuclear power plant in northeastern Ohio, clearing the way for the agency to issue a license for the plant.

title: 'Carmen' in Dance and Dylan on Tour
description: Carmen Directed by Carlos Saura. Produced by Emiliano Piedra. Choreography by Carlos Saura and Antonio Gades. 1984. Cinematheque Collection. 99 minutes.

title: Buying a Car
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretoria Persists In Confrontation
description: South Africa pursued its tactics of confrontation last week, threatening neighboring countries and closing 40 more black schools.

title: SOUP KITCHENS PRESSED TO MEET NEED
description: They arrive at 11 A.M. - mothers with children, old men alone or in groups. Inside the church, which is sandwiched between a shelter for the homeless and a pornographic movie house, children help a bald man called Curly set up tables and bring out the food for the day's meal.

title: Busoni Composed A 'Turandot' Too
description: Opera composers tend to share similar attractions to the same stories. Rossini composed ''The

title: In England, The Top Talent Is Back Doing The Classics
description: The most significant event of a busy autumn season in English theater has been the return of Trevor Nunn, the country's most successful director, from the field of popular musicals to Elizabethan classics. After directing a string of musical hits (''Cats,'' ''Starlight Express,'' ''Les Miserables'' and ''Chess'' as well as ''Porgy and Bess'' at Glyndebourne), Mr. Nunn is back at Stratford-on-Avon with a production of a little-known Elizabethan comedy, Thomas Heywood's ''The Fair Maid of the West,'' at the Royal Shakespeare Company's new Swan Theater. The prodigal son was not more welcome on his return; for Mr. Nunn's latest production has an inventive skill and humanist warmth that flows out from the stage and takes over the entire auditorium.

title: Securities Dealer Censured, Fined
description: First Jersey Securities, a Manhattan-based company that has repeatedly come under investigation by regulating authorities, has been fined and censured by the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: GREATER 'GLASNOST' TURNS SOME SOVIET HEADS
description: ''GLASNOST'' is one of those Russian words with no direct equivalent in English. It is usually translated as ''openness'' or ''publicity,'' but both fall short of the broad Russian meaning derived from ''glas,'' the poetic word for ''voice.'' To give glasnost is to give voice, to speak out boldly and openly.

title: AN INSIDER'S GUIDE TO GUIDANCE COUNSELING
description: FROM November until mid-April (or beyond if they wheel in the torture rack called a waiting list), the tension-pressure-suspense mix is in the air at any college-oriented high school. You can smell it. You can feel it. It's alive. I call it the Cobra.

title: Turning the PC Into Speed Reader
description: CONVERTING traditional, typed data into something a computer can digest is shaping up as a major problem in the age of personal computers. The quandary will probably lead to the greatest cleanout of files American business has ever seen. Information not crucial may sit around gathering dust for a few more years before ending up unread in the dumpster. However, there are a lot of corporate records to which this easy solution simply cannot be applied.

title: LIBERAL ARTS STUDIES, IN DECLINE SINCE 1970'S, ARE REVIVING AROUND NATION
description: Liberal arts are making a comeback on the American college campus after more than a decade of battering by business, engineering and other vocational fields of study.

title: Victorian Condos
description: There will be gingerbread, cedar fish-scale shingles, oval windows, spindled cornices, even etched glass on the front doors. ''We wanted a true Victorian look and we achieved it,'' said Ronald Acquaviva, the developer of Holmdel Mews, the first condominium town-house complex in Holmdel, N.J.

title: THE COURT SEES NO EVIL IN ENDING A BUSING PLAN
description: SOMETIMES the Supreme Court lays down the law in bold, black letters.

title: A LOVE AFFAIR WITH SILENCE
description: LAST POEMS By Paul Celan. Translated by Katharine Washburn and Margret Guillemin. 212 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $20. COLLECTED PROSE By Paul Celan. Translated by Rosmarie Waldrop. 67 pp. New York: P.N. Review/Carcanet. $14.95.

title: Mastering the Wilderness
description: The Wilderness Society is the latest nonprofit organization to lend its name and mailing list to the marketing of bank credit cards in return for a ''royalty'' from the is-suing bank. The Washington-based society has sent its 160,000 conservationist members, on its letterhead, an offer under which they can receive a gold MasterCard from Maryland Bank of Delaware, with the society's name and logo on the it.

title: New York Gave This Marathoner's Feet a Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: ZOLLAR'S 'TRILOGY'
description: MARGE PIERCY once wrote a novel called ''Braided Lives.'' That phrase was brought to mind by Jawole Willa Jo Zollar's ''LifeDance Trilogy,'' which was performed on Thursday and again last night at the Kitchen. Inspired by Tarot cards, the piece braids the performing and presences of its three collaborators. Stages of life and facets of character are brought vividly alive, then woven together into a provocative whole.

title: Unexpurgated Nin
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: RED EARTH, WHITE EARTH. By Will Weaver. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Writers can always count on racial tension to dramatize social and political disease.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: VAN GOGH TALK Reva Wolf, who has been a guest lecturer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, will preview the Met's Vincent Van Gogh exhibition for Westchester residents at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow in the Greenburgh Town Hall. ''Van Gogh in Saint-Remy and Auvers'' opens Nov. 25 in Manhattan and runs through March 22. It is limited to works painted during the 14 tragic last years of the artist's life.

title: PRINCIPLE AND PRAGMATISM IN FOREIGN POLICY
description: SHORTLY before the release last week of David P. Jacobsen, an American who had been held hostage in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems, a Danish freighter reported to be carrying military supplies left the Israeli port of Eilat bound for Bandar Abbas, Iran. According to officials in Jerusalem and Washington, it was the latest episode in a secret program by the Reagan Administration to use shipments of military equipment for two purposes: in the short run to buy freedom for American hostages, and in the longer term to maintain contact with moderate elements in the Iranian officer corps in the hope of repairing relations with whatever rulers follow Iran's fundamentalist leader, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: THE LONG HARD BOUNCE
description: He shot me. I turned just in time. It caught me in the chest, it was a flesh wound about an inch and a half long. Then he came into the club and began firing.

title: NUCLEAR ARSENALS APPEAR TO SPREAD TO OTHER NATIONS
description: While the superpowers negotiate possible cuts in nuclear weapons, some nations are expanding their nuclear arsenals and others are joining the ranks of those possessing or able to build such arms.

title: The Sound Of Music Boxes
description: From the moment you open the door, you are greeted by a tinkling and a chiming and a trilling and a tintinnabulation in a crystalline shower of sound. ''That's what there is about them,'' says Rita Ford, the elfin proprietor, ''the sound.''

title: Spanish Civilian Jailed in '81 After Coup Attempt Is Dead
description: Juan Garcia Carres, the sole civilian charged after a military coup attempt in Spain five years ago, died of a heart attack at his home Friday night, relatives said today.

title: Airport
description: To the Editor: The Kansas City International Airport is not on the north side of the Missouri River, as depicted on the map with the ''What's Doing in Kansas City'' (Travel, Oct. 26).

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: THIS WEEK

title: Dr. Aran Ron Is Wed To Dr. Deborah Levitt
description: Dr. Deborah Levitt, a psychologist for the New York City Police Department, and Dr. Aran Ron, chief medical resident at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital, were married yesterday at the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Queens. Rabbi Joy Levitt, the bride's cousin, officiated, assisted by Rabbi Lee Friedlander.

title: The Myth of Warsaw Pact Superiority Debunked
description: To the Editor:

title: Gizmos Great And Small
description: It began almost by accident. Thirteen years ago, Bill Bailey was an artist working in a street-level studio on Columbus Avenue and people kept dropping in, thinking it was a store. So he started to sell hand-screened T-shirts and posters. By 1984, Mr. Bailey and his partner, Laurie Eichengreen, had 723 suppliers and offered 22,724 different items in a 600-square-foot shop called Mythology Unlimited. About a year ago they doubled the space to accommodate their expanding collection of curious wares, as well as their growing clientele.

title: A WAR AND DROUGHT EXTEND THE FAMINE IN MOZAMBIQUE
description: WHEN the rain finally came last week, the first rain in 12 months, the people here began clearing the land for planting. Their efforts were born more of dogged hope than realism: The rain was meager, as all rains have been since 1978, and there were no seeds to plant.

title: Tricks Of The Trade
description: One moment you are at ground level in a block with nothing more exotic to it than Korean restaurants and street vendors hawking hankies in Spanish. Then you push a button and poof! You are almost instantly transported into a Merlinesque world where things are seldom what they seem.

title: 4 Workers Contaminated At Nuclear Reservation
description: Four employees were contaminated on the hands or face with plutonium at the closed Plutonium Finishing Plant at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, forcing plant officials to test 60 other workers, a spokesman said Friday.

title: SAN FRANCISCANS VOTE PLAN TO EASE PAY INEQUITIES
description: San Francisco has apparently become the nation's first city to give voter approval to the concept of equal pay for jobs of comparable worth among city workers.

title: Social Conscience At Jersey Track
description: NEW JERSEY'S Sports and Exposition Authority, concerned that its race track might be encouraging compulsive gamblers, moved a year ago this month to fulfill what its director called ''a social responsibility.''

title: Rutgers Is Upset By West Virginia
description: When a team has lost six straight games and most of its morale, even the smallest victory can redeem a dismal season. Unfortunately for Rutgers, West Virgina chose to make today's game its high-water mark.

title: One Man's World Of World Theater
description: If you want to find a rare, esoteric or lost volume, object or ephemera dealing with theater, Richard Stoddard is the man to contact. As soon as he opens for business in his neat but tightly packed bookstore on East 16th Street, the telephone starts to ring. A man from Germany wants him to put a hold on a copy of ''Strasberg at the Actors Studio.'' Someone else calls for Stanislavsky's promptbook edition of ''The Sea Gull.'' A third wants a copy of ''Four Jills in a Jeep,'' a book by Carole Landis describing the adventures of four Hollywood stars entertaining the troops overseas.

title: Pace of Condos Picks Up in Westchester
description: MORE than a third of all dwellings built in Westchester County from 1982 to 1985 were condominiums, and the rate of their construction is speeding up, according to a new survey by the County Department of Planning.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Hicksville
description: NEW maple trees cast thin shadows in the early aerial photographs of the raw suburban neighborhoods that sprang up suddenly, beginning in 1948, in the once far-reaching potato fields of Hicksville.

title: Punched in a Fight, City Inmate, 18, Dies
description: An 18-year-old city jail inmate with a history of heart problems died Friday night after he was punched in the chest by another inmate, the Correction Department reported yesterday.

title: The Year's Best Illustrated Books
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1986.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 39 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 39 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: CZECH WAS SURVIVOR OF '52 STALIN PURGE
description: Artur London, a former Czechoslovak Deputy Foreign Minister who survived the Stalinist purges of the early 1950's and later emigrated, died today in Paris. He was 71 years old.

title: Comings and Goings
description: BERNARD HINAULT, who has won the Tour de France five times in his 12-year professional cycling career, will retire today after competing in a cross-country event in his hometown of Quessoy, France. Hinault, 32 years old, plans to run a dairy farm in Brittany and become a technical consultant to the Tour de France. . . . Martinez Jackson, the 80-year-old father of Reggie Jackson, was hospitalized with chest pains in Philadelphia shortly after he was arrested and charged with shooting at a pedestrian who had thrown a tire iron through the rear window of his car, the police said.

title: Children Of Affluence
description: Yeah, when I was a kid I thought I should have everything (''The Right Age at the Right Time,'' by William Hamilton, About Men, Oct. 12). Money. Girls. Cars. But the young people Mr. Hamilton so enviously observed at Le Cirque remind me of an East Coast version of the gang in Bret Ellis's ''Less Than Zero,'' in which money merely shrouds and exacerbates a lot of fundamental unhappiness. Money as happiness? Thank goodness my circumstances at that age were considerably more modest. MARK STEVENS Chicago

title: NEW DATA EXTEND ERA OF DINOSAURS
description: New fossil evidence, especially discoveries in China, is showing that dinosaurs did not die out suddenly and that they apparently survived at least a million years after they were generally thought to have become extinct, according to recent findings.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: ALL THAT GLITTERS. By Thomas Tryon. (Knopf, $18.95.) The overlapping lives and times of five movie actresses whose careers span the history of motion pictures are described in high style in this entertaining fifth work of fiction by Thomas Tryon, the actor-turned-author.

title: RANKE'S PLACE IN (WRITING) HISTORY: THE KEY IS 'WHAT ACTUALLY HAPPENED'
description: There is a story about Leopold von Ranke, the 19th-century German historian regarded as the father of modern ''professional'' history writing - that at the age of 91 he lay down on his pine bed and gently chided his amanuensis, Theodor Wiedemann, for having fallen asleep at his pen the night before. Ranke had been trying to finish dictating the eighth volume of his sweeping ''Universal History,'' which he had begun writing at the age of 82. But the eyes would not stay open and the ''Universal History'' would never be finished.

title: Susan P. Kass to Wed Samuel Gilbert
description: Susan Pamela Kass and Samuel S. Gilbert plan to be married in February. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon B. Mesnick of Brooklyn, the future bride's mother and stepfather.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: CRACKPOT: The Obsessions of John Waters. By John Waters. (Macmillan, $14.95.) John Waters's obsessions aren't quite on the order of, say, Captain Ahab's.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Albertson $205,000 3 Miles Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; basement, 2-zone heating; taxes $2,300. Massapequa $280,000 304 Clearview Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; fireplace, den, new kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $4,600.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
ART;
A JURIED SHOW THAT EXPLORES THE CONTEMPORARY
description: ADVENTUROUS artists try to re-invent the language of their medium, whether it be painting, sculpture, graphics or photography.

title: Christina Elizabeth Steck Is the Bride Of Stephen Young in Jersey Ceremony
description: Christina Elizabeth Steck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Steck of Summit, N.J., and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Nelson Young, a son of Paula Nelson Young of Philadelphia and Donald V. Young of Cincinnati. The Rev. Mark Wakefield, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Summit.

title: BOSTON CONVENTION CENTER: HIGH HOPES AND CRITICS
description: The meeting rooms and registration area are now steel beams and planks of raw wood. The ballroom floor is cement, coated with watery mud.

title: Susan Hillary Alpern Is Married to Richard Fisch
description: Susan Hillary Alpern, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Alpern of Englewood, N.J., and Amagansett, L.I., and Richard Fisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Fisch of North Brunswick, N.J., were married yesterday at the Westbury Hotel in New York. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated. Mrs. Fisch, a graduate of the Dwight-Englewood School and Cornell University, received a master's degree in legislative affairs from George Washington University.

title: Sarah Tabell Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Weber Tabell of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Elizabeth Tabell to Steven McKinsey Nocka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Nocka of Ridgewood, N.J. The wedding is planned for February.

title: Keeping Out of Touch
description: I USED TO KEEP UP with things. Keeping up with things seemed important. Vital. American. People who did it were on the ball, with it, on their toes, wide awake. No moss grew on them. They had moxie. They were in touch, au courant, plugged in. They knew the score.

title: An Orphan Tracks a Giant
description: BAD MAN BALLAD By Scott R. Sanders. 241 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: MENCKEN: DON'T BE SO BULLHEADED. LOVE AND KISSES, DREISER
description: WHEN H. L. Mencken and Theodore Dreiser met in 1908, Mencken was a young, ambitious journalist from Baltimore and Dreiser, in his late 30's, was just reaching the end of a long abstinence from the writing of fiction, brought about in part by the poor reception accorded ''Sister Carrie'' in 1900. The two men corresponded until Dreiser's death in 1945, and the letters record a fruitful literary collaboration - the initially better-known Dreiser opened doors for Mencken; Mencken the critic gave Dreiser a theoretical structure that both supported and fed on the novelist's renewed output, beginning with ''Jennie Gerhardt'' in 1911. But as the excerpts below suggest, the men's friendship was also fraught with conflict. Mencken often criticized Dreiser's writing, and Dreiser was equally critical of Mencken's editorial leadership of two prominent periodicals of the teens and 20's, Smart Set and The American Mercury. The two men also disagreed on such issues as the nature of Soviet Communism and the political significance for America of the Great Depression. Most of the 1,200 letters the two men are known to have exchanged between 1907 and 1945, many of them previously unpublished, will be issued in January by the University of Pennsylvania Press as ''Dreiser-Mencken Letters,'' edited by Thomas P. Riggio, an associate professor of English at the University of Connecticut. The Power of ''Jennie Gerhardt'' Baltimore, April 23rd. [ 1911 ] Dear Dreiser:-

title: CREATIVE STAGES
description: For one night only, Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center is a cultural crossroads, or maybe a cloverleaf.

title: Why I Still Treasure The Little House
description: On October of 1945, for my 4th birthday, I was given a plaster doll, a tin suitcase and a copy of "The Little House" by Virginia Lee Burton. The doll was later passed on to someone else and the suitcase was lost in a move, but I still have "The Little House." I don't mean I just keep it stashed away somewhere; I mean I still use it. It stays where I can pull it out any time I want to. And I often do want to.

title: New Washington Museum, Old London Sleuth
description: Home for Art By Women Opens in April When spring arrives, the National Museum of Women in the Arts will have a new and permanent home in Washington in a renovated landmark building two blocks from the White House.

title: 'Carmen' in Dance and Dylan on Tour
description: The Abduction From the Seraglio By Mozart. Starring Armin Uhde, Rolf Tomaszewski, Uwe Peper and Carolyn Smith-Meyer. Directed by Harry Kupfer.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
Inge's 'Picnic' Undergoes Updating
description: It's a varied basket that was packed for the adaptation of William Inge's play ''Picnic'' that will have its debut on Showtime tomorrow evening at 8. Winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 1953, the play tells of a handsome young drifter who pulls into a tranquil Kansas town and proves unsettling for the several women he encounters there, as the routines and rhythms of their backwater lives are disrupted by his smoldering presence.

title: DUBLIN'S ARRAY OF MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES
description: Ireland enjoys a tradition of literary and artistic excellence disproportionate to its size. Figures such as James Joyce in literature, John McCormack in music and Francis Bacon in art have contributed to its stature through the years. The country continues to foster its arts; the Government has a policy of exempting working artists from income tax, and there is an energetic corps of young Irish artists producing work of a high standard.

title: VIRGIL THOMSON'S 'SAINTS' GOES MARCHING ON
description: One of this century's most famous works of insouciant avant-gardism returns for a rare New York production starting Wednesday - the opera ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' by Gertrude Stein and Virgil Thomson. It has now been 52 years since its premiere, and 58 years since the completion of the actual composition. Yet this seemingly nonsensical assemblage of childlike rhymes (''Pigeons in the grass alas''), amiable vocalized conversation and sing-song music retains a freshness and a nose-thumbing vivacity that so many trendy succes de scandale lose within minutes.

title: Bonnie Jo Zalkin Weds Gary Richard Goldberg
description: Bonnie Jo Zalkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Zalkin of Martinsville, N.J., was married last night to Gary Richard Goldberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Goldberg of Scranton, Pa. Rabbi Ronald Isaacs and Cantor Natan Fetman performed the ceremony at the Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club in Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: Francoise Jackson Is to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jay W. Jackson of West Hartford and Madison, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Francoise Catherine Jackson, to John Stanton Williams 3d, a son of Mrs. Williams Jr. of New York and Walpole, Me., and the late Mr. Williams. A May wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'TREASURES' ON DISPLAY
description: ''Treasures!'' That's what the Council for the Arts in Westchester is calling its yearly benefit gala this year - and with good reason. The event, which will be held Saturday at 7 P.M. at Reader's Digest headquarters in Chappaqua, features a tour of the Reader's Digest Art Collection.

title: The Varied Crop of Newsletters
description: For those with a strong interest in a particular aspect of travel and willing to pay $30 to $65 a year and occasionally even more, newsletters provide a chance to get some solid advice. Some of them attempt to cover travel as a whole, indiscriminately cramming tidbits of all sorts, most of them gleaned from industry press releases, into 4 to 12 pages that profess to disseminate news. Others are incisive accounts of the editor's or contributors' own travels, meting out both praise and criticism according to the author's point of view. Still others concentrate on particular countries or regions or are aimed at particular types of travelers, such as hikers, frequent fliers or aficionados of country inns. Some newsletters are dedicated to sharing experiences, others to giving practical advice.

title: A PARK, AFTER ALL
description: Reluctantly, but unanimously, the Mount Kisco Board of Trustees voted last week to accept the gift Laura Flewellyn had offered them.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
Who's Getting the Ph.D.'s?
description: More and more, it's women and foreign students who are studying for doctorates.

title: A Compassionate Camera
description: When I saw the group photograph accompanying Cornell Capa's article ''A Compassionate Camera'' (Oct. 19), I thought: how far we've come since then! After reading the article, however, I realized that the author had intended the photographs to convey something quite different: that those with retardation can live ''fruitful lives'' in segregated communities. Mr. Capa goes on to say that, although more communal villages are being established, relatively few people with handicaps can be accommodated.

title: Recent Sales
description: Arsdley, N.Y. $260,000 582 Ashford Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 81-year-old frame colonial; 2-car garage, attic; taxes, $4,202. Larchmont, N.Y. $282,000 3 Soundview Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 59-year-old frame colonial; attached 1-car garage, walk to station, 0.25 acre; taxes $5,123.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: CONTACT, by Carl Sagan. (Pocket, $4.95.) Following instructions sent by extraterrestrials, five scientists voyage to the stars for an encounter with the world beyond. In his first novel, the astronomer Carl Sagan ''keeps his tone clear, precise, unsensational,'' our reviewer, Gregory Benford, said last year. Although the narrative occasionally ''sputters out under another lecture,'' the ''range and depth of ideas here . . . reward the considerable labor needed.'' THE CRUISE OF THE SNARK: A Pacific Voyage, by Jack London. (Routledge & Kegan Paul/Methuen, $12.95.) In the spring of 1907 Jack London sailed from San Francisco in the Snark, a ship he had designed himself, exploring the South Seas for two years and visiting ports he had read about as a boy in the writings of Melville and Stevenson. ''The author has ably brought out the excitement of his cruise and presents vividly the periods . . . when danger threatened,'' our reviewer said in 1911. The same publisher has reissued another in its Pacific Basin series, Robert Louis Stevenson's IN THE SOUTH SEAS:

title: Kuwait Has Deported 26,898 In Major Security Crackdown
description: Kuwait has deported 26,898 people in the last year in a sustained security crackdown after an unsuccessful attempt to assassinate its head of state, a top security official said in remarks published today.

title: Ann LaSala to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bruce LaSala of Tenafly, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Ann Victoria LaSala, to Robert Malcolm Cumming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm J. Cumming of Melbourne, Australia.

title: Irish, Sooners Roll 'Em Up
description: Tim Brown had 235 all-purpose yards and two touchdowns, including an 84-yard reception, as Notre Dame evened its record at 4-4 by defeating Southern Methodist, 61-29, today.

title: WINTER SURVIVAL PLAN: HIBERNATION
description: IT is not too early to notice that winter will soon be upon us, and this year - positively - I have made up my mind to go into Haydn for the season. This will also require going into hiding, and that's all right with me, too, for I have had it with Long Island winters.

title: People's Porcupine
description: HUGH PINE AND THE GOOD PLACE By Janwillem van de Wetering. Illustrated by Lynn Munsinger. 64 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Leslie Jane Turley Wed
description: Leslie Jane Turley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Turley of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Nathan Gibbons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Gibbons of New Lebanon, N.Y. The Rev. William K. Galvin performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. Mrs. Gibbons graduated cum laude from Georgetown University. Her father is a partner in the New York securities firm of Mabon Nugent & Company. Mr. Gibbons graduated from Denison University. His father is a postal worker.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Jack Frost's Amnesia
description: THE STRANGER Written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95. (Ages 4 and up)

title: AFTER A BATTLE BEREFT OF IDEAS, NO CLEAR AGENDA
description: On the eve of the 1960 election, Daniel Bell wrote a book titled ''The End of Ideology.'' Mr. Bell's prediction was premature, followed as it was by the rise of New Left in the 1960's and the New Right in the 1970's. But Wedneday morning, the social thinker's arguments looked rather good again, especially in his subtitle's reference to ''the exhaustion of political ideas.'' In 1980, the vogue was that liberals had run out of ideas; in 1986, everyone had, or so it seemed.

title: AS HOMEWORK INCREASES, SO DOES THE ANXIETY
description: PERHAPS the most commonly asked parental question in America is ''Have you done your homework today?'' The answer can make parents smile, grip them with frustration or drive them into a shouting fury.

title: More Bread, Fewer Circuses
description: To the Sports Editor: rrIra Berkow's story on the marathon (''Route Becomes Outdoor Party as Poli, Waitz Win'' The New York Times, Nov. 3) talked of other recent celebrations: the parade for the Mets, the Statue of Liberty centennial, the Halloween festivities, and now the marathon as an ''outdoor party.'' All he says is true.

title: MARATHON DE NEW YORK
description: ''It's a very good chemistry,'' Eleanor Wakin said of last week's houseguest. ''It's as though we have our cousins with us.''

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: CASSIDY. By Morris West. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Just when you thought Australia was an unsullied paradise of koalas, chummy tough guys and great sopranos, along comes this saga of corruption and vice to set you straight, mate.

title: ACTS OF CONTINUANCE
description: AFTER THE LAST SKY Palestinian Lives. By Edward W. Said. Photographs by Jean Mohr. 174 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: Shamir's No. 1 Problem
description: The most acute and urgent problem facing the new Government established last month in Israel will be the populations and territories in the West Bank and Gaza. If Israel were able to disengage safely from the task of ruling the 1.3 million Palestinians in these territories, it would not only be making a concession to the Palestinian people, it would also be serving its own values and interests.

title: Fulfilled Dream Of a Lightweight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW YORK NEEDS TAX REFORM, TOO
description: NOW that Federal tax reform has become law, it is time to turn our thoughts to state tax changes.

title: INCUMBENCY, TURNOUT AND OTHER RECORDS
description: PARSING THE NUMBERS. In the elections of 1986, incumbency was once again a powerful weapon. So was money. Of the 392 members of the House running for re-election only 6 lost, 5 of them Republicans. A total of $342 million was reportedly spent on races for House and Senate, $80 million more than in 1984.

title: JAZZ: SVEND ASMUSSEN
description: THE veteran Danish jazz violinist Svend Asmussen is appearing through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue near 17th Street, with the Dave Grisman Quintet, turning it into one of the finest jazz string ensembles since the Quintet of the Hot Club of France in which Django Reinhardt and Stephane Grappelli played 50 years ago.

title: ODDLY TEPID WORK AT THE CROSSROADS
description: ALTHOUGH ''Alterations'' has been evolving since 1978, the Crossroads Theatre Company production, described in the program as the American premiere of the work ''in its most developed form,'' gives the impression of a play in the rough.

title: The Customer Cometh
description: It is when you are off form -- when you are not winning your winning positions, when you are blundering away some of them, when you are losing inferior end games that could have been drawn with stubborn resistance -- that you must appreciate encountering a 'customer.'

title: GROUP HOMES OPPOSED FOR SOME RETARDED
description: The article ''Welcome Home, Jenny,'' [ Opinion page, Oct. 12 ] presents a rosy picture of what is hoped for in the placing of mentally retarded citizens into group homes in the towns and cities of Connecticut.

title: WOMEN RANK HIGH IN PHOTO JOURNALISM
description: THE photographs are tough pictures of torn lives: Brazilian Indians driven from their homes by a new highway; Salvadoran mothers at the graves of children they say were slain by death squads; beggars at a hospital for the dying in India; Vietnam veterans suffering illness and deformity they say was caused by exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: Tools of the Scholar's Craft From China's Past
description: RALPH M. Chait's only indulgence in collecting was a category of Chinese artifacts known as works from the scholar's study: bamboo brush pots, wrist rests, ink stones, ivory seals, root sculptures and gilded, dragon-embellished ink cakes that date from the 16th century to the early 19th century. These offbeat materials were, until recently, far too esoteric for most Chinese-art enthusiasts and were therefore suited for this art dealer who decided never to compete with his customers in collecting what they admired.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S CORPORATE ACTIVISTS
description: FOR American companies operating in South Africa, social responsibility has become a bread-and-butter board room issue. They are under constant scrutiny not only from people on both sides of the apartheid issue here, but from anti-apartheid, pro-disinvestment groups in Europe and the United States. And they have taken on social responsibility projects as both a means of addressing what they see as a need for change and a ticket that allows them to fend off political pressure at home.

title: Finding Solace In a Game Vision
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: KENNEDY, PICKING LABOR POST, CITES BROTHERS
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy invoked the memory of his brothers in announcing here today that he had decided to serve as chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources.

title: McEnroe Fills In
description: SICKNESS and injury have knocked two big-name players out of a $375,000 tennis tournament in London this week, but a quirk in the rules has allowed another big gun to help fill the celebrity gap.

title: London Leaps Ahead - Into the 1970's
description: FOR almost two centuries, the New York Stock Exchange has been the centerpiece of the capital raising system supporting this country's tremendous economic growth. As securities markets become more global, international capital markets will be served best by a trading system embodying the auction market principles embraced by the Big Board.

title: DISPUTE UNROLLS AT 7-ELEVEN STORES
description: SUFFOLK County shoppers who go to 7-Eleven stores for cigarette rolling papers may find themselves leaving empty-handed.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MODERN-ART ROOTS Holding to the theory that modern art had to start somewhere other than just in artists' imaginations, yet another exhibition examining those roots opens today. This time it's at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor and it explores ''The Artists' Language: African Traditional and Modern Art.''

title: TOUGH NEW POLICE POLICIES AIM AT ACCOUNTABILITY
description: When Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward announced a series of transfers and what he called the most sweeping anticorruption measures since the Knapp Commission of the early 70's, he took pains to add that the measures were not meant as punishment and that he did not believe that corruption was still widespread.

title: When Is the Employer Liable?
description: THE Supreme Court's ruling left open the question of exactly when companies will be held liable for sexual harassment.

title: A Dire Warning on Ozone Depletion
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has been studying the potential health effects of the thinning of the stratospheric ozone layer, which shields the earth from most of the sun's ultraviolet radiation. A draft assessment disclosed by agency officials last week included a stark warning: Over the next 88 years, ozone depletion could result in 40 million cases of skin cancer in the United States, 800,000 of which would end in death.

title: 1 Killed, 3 Hurt in Crash Of Plane Bound for L.I.
description: A Government-owned twin-engine plane carrying two acid rain researchers crashed in a clearing near a hospital this afternoon, killing one of the two pilots aboard, the authorities said.

title: 'GUNG HO' OLIVER NORTH: REAGAN'S MAN OF ACTION
description: As a major in the Marine Corps in April 1980, Oliver L. North covertly led a detachment of marines to the remote mountains of eastern Turkey near the border with Iran. Their task: to assist in freeing the American hostages held in Teheran.

title: Arizona St. Goes To Rose Bowl, 49-0
description: A flanker, Bruce Hill, had three touchdowns, one on a 96-yard kickoff return to open the second half and two on passes from Jeff Van Raaphorst, as Arizona State routed California, 49-0, tonight to clinch the Pacific-10 Conference championship and a Rose Bowl berth.

title: DO THE CALIFORNIA DIP
description: POPULUXE By Thomas Hine. Illustrated. 184 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95.

title: Rimsky's Lyric Gifts Enhance 'The Tsar's Bride'
description: Progress is widely regarded as a good thing, though like the perfect circle it cannot be proved to exist. Even the pop philosophers of positive thinking generally do not insist on progress as a linear reality. It is enough, they imply, if we accept the illusion of progress as a tool for success. The healthy human animal, it seems, needs to perceive all change as forward movement, which is logically as defensible an idea as the dogma propounded by the Flat Earth Society.

title: Headliners; Good Intentions Respected
description: Anita Sanabria Castelo apparently will be going back to the White House instead of to jail. Mrs. Castelo, who is on administrative leave from her job as Nancy Reagan's maid, walked out of court in Richmond, Va., a free woman last week after charges against her in a munitions smuggling case were dismissed. Mrs. Reagan was said to be ''anxious to have her back at work.'' Mrs. Castelo was charged last summer after helping two fellow Paraguayan natives purchase 350,000 rounds of .22-caliber ammunition for shipment to Paraguay. Charges against her were dropped when the prosecutor declared there was no illegal intent on her part. Her two friends pleaded guilty to attempting to export munitions without a license, saying the ammo was to be used for hunting.

title: More on The Zumwalts
description: I am writing in regard to the Sept. 21 letter from Si Lewen, responding to the article ''Agent Orange and the Anguish of an American Family'' (by Elmo Zumwalt Jr. and Elmo Zumwalt 3d, with John Pekkanen, Aug. 24). If Mr. Lewen has had a chance to read ''My Father, My Son,'' not just the excerpts, he will be aware that my father and my brother did express compassion for the other Americans who are battling to survive the horrors of Agent Orange.

title: COACH LEARNING TO LIVE WITH LAW OF AVERAGES
description: CONSIDERING that he ended the 1985 season with only 25 players, Jack LaPlante, the football coach at Hartford Public High School, was delighted when 50 boys turned out for spring practice last May.

title: PUSHING FASHION IN THE FAST LANE
description: FASHION just doesn't move fast enough for Mohan Murjani.

title: Ex-Watergate Felon Cleared
description: Testimony from an agent of the United States Customs Department that Frank A. Sturgis, who was convicted in the 1972 burglary of the Watergate office building, often worked for him persuaded a jury to acquit Mr. Sturgis of charges of dealing in stolen property, a juror said Friday. Mr. Sturgis, 62 years old, was arrested June 18 and charged with accepting stolen property. He was acquitted Thursday after the agent, John McCutcheon, testified.

title: Love Those Universities
description: Any special interest group that spends enough time lobbying Congress and the executive branch, it is said, comes to think and sound a lot like the politicians.

title: L.S.U.'s Defense Shocks Alabama, 14-10
description: Greg Jackson claimed two turnovers and forced another to stop three threats tonight as Louisiana State upset Alabama, 14-10, to turn the Southeastern Conference race into a four-team scramble.

title: 'Carmen' in Dance and Dylan on Tour
description: Love in the Afternoon Starring Gary Cooper, Audrey Hepburn, Maurice Chevalier. Directed by Billy Wilder CBS/Fox Video. 130 minutes. $59.98.

title: NEW CHAPPAQUA CONDUCTOR
description: WHEN the Chappaqua Orchestra opens its new season at the Horace Greeley School Saturday at 8:30 P.M., there will be a new man on the podium. Jesse Levine, who has done a splendid job of raising symphonic standards as music director of the Norwalk Symphony in Connecticut (and who is also coordinator of the string department at Yale University) expresses anticipation about taking on this further challenge.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TURKEY SHOOT

title: AVIATION EXPERTS VISIT MOZAMBIQUE
description: Two crash experts from the International Civil Aviation Organization have arrived in Maputo to help the Mozambican Government investigate the crash that killed the country's President, Samora M. Machel. Another expert was to arrive by Monday.

title: A FRUSTRATED ATHLETE SCORES
description: LOTS of people may think the Mets' centerfielder, Lenny Dykstra, put Strat-O-Matic baseball on the map after walloping the ninth-inning home run that beat Houston in the third game of the National League Championship Series this fall.

title: Strengthen Families to Break the Welfare Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: RECENT SALES
description: Recent Sales Hamilton Square $109,900 11 Wickom Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; family room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $1,494. Landing $140,000 32 Conduct Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old contemporary; central vacuum, wood-burning furnace, skylights; taxes $1,773.

title: Carol Vaness Recital
description: The soprano Carol Vaness will sing her first East Coast recital on Thursday, at the Terrace Theater of the Kennedy Center in Washington. Accompanied by Warren Jones, she will sing works by Handel, Rossini, Mozart, Chausson, Kander and Turina. Tickets, at $15, are available at the box office or through Centercharge, (202) 857-0900 or (202) 432-0200.

title: ON LOWER EAST SIDE, AN INNOVATIVE SCHOOL
description: Genard Howard Perry, 11 years old, is taking three foreign languages this fall - French, Spanish and Swahili.

title: TAPPING THE INTENSITY OF THE CITY
description: I am lucky. I have been all around the world, basically to places I wanted to see. A couple of years ago I went to China and Russia. I lived in Rome for a while, and London, and Paris. But for me, the center of the world is here. New York. There is no other place. Maybe it's no coincidence that Bernard Tavernier chose me to play the role of Goodley, the fast-talking owner of Birdland in the 40's, in his film ''Around Midnight.'' At one point in the film Goodley says about Paris: ''It's a pretty town, those fancy bridges, and I hear they steam-clean all the buildings. . . . But it's just not New York. The music's better here. Tougher. Because there's tougher things going on. It's not for everybody. Am I right?'' No matter what they have in other cities, no matter what the life style, life here seems to be the best, the most informative, the most exciting.

title: ANATOMY OF A FIERCE ACADEMIC FEUD
description: HARVARD Prof.

title: GROWING UP SAVVY
description: Moments before the 3 o'clock school bell rings, the race for the subway is on. Knapsacks, hobo bags and pockets are stuffed. Books and note pads join the spare violin string, house keys, papervacks and current movie timetable already at the bottom of the sack. Stairs are taken in a single leap, first out of school buildings and then down into the canyons of the city. Some stop long enough to falsh a bus pass before they jump the turnstiles; noe approach the underground maze with trepidation.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
On Route 1, Housing Is in the Fast Lane
description: FROM the edges of New Brunswick stretching 20 miles south to Trenton lies the Route 1 corridor, home to more flashy new corporate centers and office buildings per square mile than in most other comparable areas in the state.

title: EAVESDROPPER'S DELIGHT
description: ''I've been on automatic pilot here for four years - sitting in restaurants and listening to people talk about deals/films/agents/grosses/ below-the-line - and longing to overhear something real.'' James Woods, the actor, explaining why he was moving back to New York from Los Angeles.

title: Drink, Drink and Drink
description: Concern for safety if not necessarily for temperance appears in invitations to an Evening of Scottish Hospitality at the British Embassy on Wednesday. The affair is co-sponsored by the Scotch Whisky Association, and an engraved ''programme of events'' invites guests to join in Highland Party Games: to ''sip autumnal cocktails,'' ''participate 'hands on' in the art of blending Scotch whisky'' and ''revel in an after-dinner tasting of exceptional single malts.'' The invitation closes with this announcement: ''Transportation, for those who wish it, will be available at the end of the evening.''

title: FREEPORT OFFICIALS SEEK TO REZONE SHORELINE
description: IN A major shift of direction, the Freeport Board of Trustees is recommending that a new zoning category, marine commerce, replace the industrial and manufacturing classifications that now govern the village's waterfront area, most notably the strip of land along Woodcleft Avenue that comprises the ''Nautical Mile.''

title: Australia Skipper Leads Strong Team
description: At age 28, Iain Murray cuts a muscle-bound, burly figure, more like a pro football quarterback than an America's Cup helmsman. His game is sailboat racing. But if it were football, the Australian yachtsman would be the one passing for all the touchdowns.

title: Man, 58, Is Discovered Slain In Apartment on West Side
description: Police are investigating the death of a 58-year-old man, who was found in an Upper West Side apartment with numerous stab wounds. A search of the apartment, at 115 West 71st Street, also found a machete, feathers arranged near an altar, several dead chickens and one live chicken, the police said.

title: What the Democrats Won
description: ''We can say it all in four words: The Democrats are back.'' That was Democratic Chairman Paul Kirk's summary of the election that restored his party's control of the Senate, as well as the House. His four words didn't quite say it all. The election reflected voter dissatisfaction with Reagan economic policies, but the Democrats were passive beneficiaries. They offered no compelling vision of their own and nowhere is the void more embarrassing to the party - and dangerous to the country -than on trade.

title: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Accountability for Realty Agents
description: THE purchase by Gerald and Letitia Easton of a luxurious house in the mountains 25 miles east of San Francisco a decade ago unexpectedly triggered a series of legal battles, court decisions and legislative actions that is having a growing national impact on the real-estate and insurance industries.

title: IN THE DOCK: THE PRESS AND THE LAW
description: RECKLESS DISREGARD Westmoreland v. CBS et al.; Sharon v. Time. By Renata Adler. 243 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title:
GARDENING;
BULBS FOR INDOOR WINTER BLOOM
description: FORCING spring bulbs for indoor winter bloom does require a bit of effort, but there is nothing difficult or tricky about the procedures involved.

title: Dr. Young Weds Fellow Physician
description: The marriage of Dr. Constance Anne Young and Dr. Gary Kanter Schwartz took place yesterday at the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, a nondenominational Protestant church in Westchester County, N.Y. The Rev. Robert F. Dorer performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Drs.

title: Aviator Authors
description: Here's another name for David McCullough's list of pioneering aviators (''Aviator Authors,'' Oct. 12).

title: REAGAN VETO SEEN DELAYING 4 CITY SEWAGE PLANTS
description: President Reagan's veto of amendments to the Clean Water Act could ''substantially delay'' four sewage treatment plants under construction or renovation in Brooklyn and Staten Island, according to city officials.

title: Small Planes
description: To the Editor:

title: GREEK ROW GLOWS GOLDEN AGAIN
description: One evening not too long ago 75 neatly coiffed young women gathered in the hall of the Greek Revival mansion of Phi Mu, one of the 21 sororities at Ohio State University in Columbus. They were assembling for a formal dinner held every Monday night and valued for its elegance and style. Each guest was greeted with a smile and handshake by Mary Ellen Butler, the chapter president. Miss Butler, a senior majoring in marketing and international business, was attired conservatively like the other members, wearing a gray tweed suit. The women then filed into a dining room resplendent with delicate floral wallpaper, lace tablecloths, cut-glass stemware and antique chairs. They remained standing and recited an ecumenical grace led by the sorority's house mother. Then they sat down to eat in this carefully orchestrated atmosphere of refinement.

title: MONTREAL TO VOTE FOR MAYOR TODAY
description: In an election that will end an era of Montreal politics, citizens will vote Sunday to pick a successor to Jean Drapeau, the city's Mayor for the last 26 years.

title: Headliners; A Mother's Faith Vindicated
description: Finally, somebody besides his mother believed Nathaniel Walker. For nearly 12 years, Mr. Walker maintained his innocence of the kidnapping, rape and sodomy charges on which he was sent to Trenton State Prison in 1976 for life plus 50 years.

title: Morris's Rushin' Roulette
description: IN the Giants' important victories over the Washington Redskins and the Dallas Cowboys, their 5-foot-7-inch running back, Joe Morris, darted for 181 yards in each game. His 880 yards this season rank second among National Football League rushers behind Eric Dickerson's 1,141 for the Los Angeles Rams. And when the Giants go against the Eagles in Philadelphia today, look for Little Joe to be carrying the ball again. And again and again.

title: JUDGE'S YEARS WITH U.S.: FROM MALCOLM X TO BERLIN
description: As he looks ahead to retirement from the Federal bench, Judge Herbert Jay Stern looks back at a long career that has taken him from the investigation of Malcolm X's killing in New York to his role as judge of a special American court in West Berlin.

title: Bright Day For John Jay
description: Despite the cold rain and the muddy fields, most Westchester players and coaches trudged out to the fields yesterday and played football like it ought to played - sometimes.

title: U.S. STUDENTS GAIN INSIGHTS ON SOVIET TRIP
description: ''I expected a lot of gray,'' said 12-year-old Jill Kirkpatrick. ''I didn't expect all the colorful buildings. I expected people to be less friendly. I've been excited the whole time I've been here to get home and tell what it's like.''

title: AQUACULTURE'S CLASSROOM BY THE SEA
description: SLOSHING into gooey mud and chilly water, seven students embarked on the first high school aquaculture program in the state.

title: Catholic Schools Deep in Passing
description: Last Sunday's Catholic High School Football League quarterfinal playoff game between Holy Cross and Chaminade featured the league's version of Dan Marino versus Ken O'Brien. Both teams were well armed for the shootout: Holy Cross had scrambling Joe Falco going against Brian O'Sullivan of Chaminade.

title: A Generation of Neo-Puritans
description: FOR better or for worse, the college students of the 1980's speak for a generation of neo-Puritans. No other label can account for the two contentious and apparently contradictory chants that have swept across campuses recently. On the one hand, there is the cry of activists seeking the removal of investments in South Africa: Hey hey, ho ho There's blood on your portfolio On the other hand, there is the call of the pre-Yuppies: No more sweaty rallies No more LSD Society owes a turbo Porsche To me, me, me The recent festivities for the 350th anniversary of Harvard University provided a vivid example of the gap between the two camps. The scene: a black-tie anniversary dinner for proud alumni and select student representatives. Suddenly protesters arrive, preventing the guests from entering the hall and chanting, ''If you want to digest, you'll have to divest.'' And there it is: the spectacle of clean-cut students in dinner jackets angrily facing off with their less carefully tailored but more morally indignant peers. Eventually the president and trustees of Harvard decide neither to buck the protesters nor to summon the police. Instead, they send out for pizza and donate the $200,000 dinner to the homeless.

title: Francine I. Chase Is Bride of Norman Weisman
description: Francine Iris Chase, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira S. Chase of Edison, N.J., and Norman B. Weisman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weisman of Annapolis, Md., were married yesterday. Rabbi Yakov R. Hilsenrath, assisted by Cantor Henry Butensky, performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: Uncommon Scents
description: Some customers prefer apricot; others choose orange, or a spicy combination of apples and cinnamon. But vanilla remains the all-time favorite.

title: Montclair Rolling on Horn's Running
description: Leroy Horn rushed for 219 yards and a touchdown as Montclair State defeated Jersey City State, 21-7, yesterday in heavy rain at the Tidelands Athletic Complex in Jersey City.

title: A Sense of Direction
description: IT WAS OUR FIRST REAL FIGHT.

title: STAMFORD TO STAGE U.S. PREMIERE OF BUSONI'S ''TURANDOT'
