description: THE American premiere of ''Turandot,'' not Puccini's masterpiece but a version of the same Carlo Gozzi play completed about seven years earlier by Feruccio Busoni, will be staged this week in Stamford.

title: In The Purlieus of Extinction
description: PEEPING IN THE SHELL A Whooping Crane Is Hatched. By Faith McNulty. Illustrated by Irene Brady. 58 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: FOR A RADICAL REFORMER, RESEARCH IS POWER
description: Perched in the office of Chester E. (Checker) Finn Jr. at the United States Department of Education in Washington is an inflatable green dinosaur. He keeps it there, he cheerfully explains, as a symbol of the education establishment - slow-moving, resistant to change and, for that reason, in danger of extinction.

title: LANDLORDS SAY TIME WILL FILL VACANCIES
description: ESTIMATES of vacancy rates in Stamford office buildings that range from 17.6 percent to 27.4 percent hardly worry leasing agents or property owners.

title: THE FINE, PAINSTAKING ART OF ARRANGING A MAJOR EXHIBITION
description: SUZANNE DELEHANTY, director of the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York at Purchase, believes art exhibitions should be ''connected to something accessible.'' In ''Soundings,'' the 1981 show she organized for the museum, objects intrigued viewers with both an aural and visual dimension. Creations resembling chairs and beds challenged perceptions in ''Improbable Furniture,'' a 1977 show Ms. Delehanty curated for the Institute of Contemporary Art at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: DANCE: ALUM, GUIMOND AND MUJICA
description: RICK GUIMOND presented a big blustery dance, and Manuel Alum and Damelia Mujica offered brief, introverted works on Thursday night as part of the North-South Dance Festival at Taller Latinoamericano. Although the program ought to have been pleasantly varied, it proved not so attractive in reality as it seemed in prospect.

title: WITH LANDSLIDE OVER, REAL RACE MAY BEGIN
description: The conventional wisdom holds that Mario Matthew Cuomo - fresh from a record-breaking re-election and facing a wide-open Democratic field - is a sure-fire Presidential hopeful.

title: Recycled Grandeur
description: The neon guitar on Spring Street pulses red, green and blue in the window of Urban Archaeology, New York's most sophisticated architectural junkyard. The eight-foot-plus sign, a relic from the Popps Music Store of Dayton, Ohio, once owned by a man named Poppadopoulos, may suggest 1950's rock-and-roll, ''but the mechanism says it's 1930's,'' says Gil Shapiro.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CONVENIENT HUNAN RESTAURANT
description: ALTHOUGH restaurants offering Chinese cuisine continue to open in the county with a regularity for which, no doubt, all are grateful, places offering distinctive cooking have become increasingly rare. When, more than a dozen years ago, those restaurants starring Hunan-Sichuan cuisine entered the county, they generated a storm of interest. The earthy dishes, many lively with spicy heat, brought to the dining table excitement theretofore lacking in the prevalent and bastardized Cantonese fare. Since then, Hunan-Sichuan places have overloaded the county's dining-out resources, and while lean pickings once made every opening a major culinary event, too much of a good thing has become the same thing, and mediocre renderings of this popular cuisine have left many palates jaded and ready for the next culinary wave. While few would reject a turn at a Mongolian fire-pot or a bowl of shredded swallow-skin soup, at this point most would settle for an assortment of juicy dim sum, long overdue in these parts.

title: ANDREA MICHELLE KAYE WED
description: Andrea Michelle Kaye, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Kaye of Toms River, N.J., was married last night to Richard Mark Finn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Finn of White Plains and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard Hammerman performed the ceremony in the ballroom at 24 Fifth Avenue.

title: NO PROGRESS AT VIENNA
description: BECAUSE the Soviet-American summit meeting in Iceland had ended ambiguously, Secretary of State George P. Shultz hoped to use his meeting here last week with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to clarify whether the two sides were moving toward agreements on arms control. But after two days of talks, the situation remained unclear.

title: Penn St. Goes 9-0, Barely
description: While a bidding war is being waged by three bowls to see which one can land what would amount to a national championship match between Penn State and Miami, the undefeated Nittany Lions almost forgot their part of the scenario today. Playing against a Maryland team that had split its first eight decisions, Penn State barely averted a tie and came close to being defeated.

title: 'Carmen' in Dance and Dylan on Tour
description: Hard to Handle Bob Dylan with Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. CBS/Fox Video Music. 60 minutes.$29.98.

title: METRO-NORTH BASKS IN PROGRESS
description: IN 1983, when Peter E. Stangl was named president of the newly created Metro-North commuter railroad, he took over leadership of a train system that was notorious for delays, overcrowding and poor conditions.

title: DANCING FROM ROCKVILLE CENTER TO CITY
description: TIMOTHY CONBOY is not your typical boy who grew up in Rockville Centre.

title: Fears of a Coup By the Military Increase in Manila
description: Fears of a coup to oust President Corazon C. Aquino increased in the Philippines last week.

title: JUROR'S CONSCIENCE FACES SCALES OF JUSTICE
description: ''GREGARIOUSNESS is the haven of mediocrity,'' a line my late father claimed to have come upon in ''Doctor Zhivago'' years ago, delighted his large and gregarious family then, and for a long time afterward. It kept us from taking ourselves too seriously, we thought, and from growing too large for our breeches.

title: CRIME
description: Gregory Mcdonald has been having fun with the last two titles in his popular Fletch series. ''Fletch Won'' came out in 1985. There are several shades of meaning in the title. Fletch did win. But ''won'' also can be read as ''one.'' And in a way the book really is Fletch One, because chronologically it would be the first in the series.

title: WEDTECH ADMITS FORGING INVOICES FOR $6 MILLION IN FEES FROM U.S.
description: The Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx defense contractor at the center of an investigation into possible political corruption, acknowledged yesterday that it had forged $6 million in invoices submitted to the Federal Government in 1981 and 1982.

title: A NOT VERY PRETTY PICTURE OF THE CITY
description: AFTER nine months of publicity and six weeks of testimony, the Government has finished painting its portrait of corruption in New York City's Parking Violations Bureau. It was not pretty.

title: East Islip Reaches 6-0
description: East Islip rolled to a perfect 6-0 record in League 3 by beating the Bellport Clippers, 17-12, in an intense defensive battle. The victory gave East Islip the regular season division championship.

title: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life On The Court
description: What can you do when an Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights unfairly attacks Justice Brennan of the Supreme Court, a man bound to silence by his integrity and his high office? You feature the Justice in The New York Times Magazine.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: It is colder now. There are many stars. They are drifting. . . . The leaves are falling.* NEW JERSEY looks like Lindbergh's triumphant return carpeted with autumnal ticker tape. Now what? A score of years has passed since the laws were changed in Whippany, thus ending one of autumn's most cherished rituals: burning leaves.

title: COLLECTION OF CONTRADICTIONS
description: A few blocks from Dublin's busy O'Connell Street, the Abbey Theater last summer was offering John B. Keane's ''Sive,'' which concerns the suicide of a poor rural girl sold by her guardians into a profitable marriage with a lecherous old man. The guardians are meant to be unsympathetic but not purely evil: how much, after all, can love count for in the midst of scarcity?

title: FROM HUDSON, GOOD NEWS FOR DEMOCRATS
description: PETER SHAPIRO'S loss to a Democrat-turned-Republican in the Essex County Executive race, the victory by the Republican candidate for County Executive in Bergen County and the ease with which the state's 14 Congressional incumbents won new terms are the snapshot impressions of the 1986 elections.

title: DORAL CORP BUYS ARROWWWOOD
description: CITICORP has sold Arrowwood of Westchester to the Doral Hotel Corporation for more than $60 million. According to Sam Haigh, Arrowwood's manager, Doral will assume ownership of the resort and conference center before the end of the year.

title: WICKES TO BUY COLLINS & AIKMAN FOR 1.16 BILLION
description: The Wickes Companies, a diversified retail and manufacturing conglomerate, said today that it had agreed to acquire the Collins & Aikman Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial and automotive fabrics and specialty products based in New York City, for $1.16 billion in a cash merger.

title: POINTS OF DEPARTURE
description: THE RAILWAY STATION A Social History. By Jeffrey Richards and John M. MacKenzie. Illustrated. 440 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50.

title: A Life On the Court
description: Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court of the United States believes that the law, whether promulgated by a court or by a legislative body, can somehow address any difficult problem (''A Life on the Court,'' by Jeffrey T. Leeds, Oct. 5).

title: COMMUNITY BOARDS ARE LINK BETWEEN NEIGHBORHOODS AND CITY BUREAUCRACY
description: On 25th Drive in Flushing, Queens, a street light was out. On 40th Road, a playground doubled as a haunt for drug dealers. Throughout Flushing, business and housing are booming, due in large part to the influx over the last five years of some 80,000 Chinese and Korean immigrants.

title: SUFFOLK TO VOTE ON STEEL-JAW TRAP BAN
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature is expected to vote this week on a bill that would ban the use of steel-jaw traps to capture animals. If approved, it would be the first ban of the widely used traps in the state.

title: Wrapping a Winning Package
description: THE details tell a lot about the 8-1 Jets, their record unsurpassed in the N.F.L., their seven-game winning streak the longest in the league this season, the national attention becoming more intense.

title: Why Thoreau Went to Walden
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: CARLO BERGONZI AND PIERO CAPPUCCILLI
description: CARLO BERGONZI and Piero Cappuccilli were welcomed by their friends at Avery Fisher Hall Wednesday night. These friends were not assembled in great numbers (gaping empty spaces marked this large auditorium), but their admiration for two venerable Italian opera singers was more than warm; rather, heated to the point of hysteria.

title: No TV, But Check Out The Paintings
description: REMBRANDT TAKES A WALK By Mark Strand. Illustrated by Red Grooms. Unpaged. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $14.95.

title: CORRUPTION IS BROTHERLY IN PHILADELPHIA
description: BOLD pictures of beefy men on the courthouse steps, shielding their faces behind their coat sleeves, are appearing on the front pages of local newspapers so frequently that they have become something of a joke to a blase public. ''Tacky, tacky, tacky,'' wrote one columnist. It is, as the cartoonist Tony Auth recently pointed out, the 20th-century equivalent of the medieval stocks, putting public officials on public display.

title: Roly-poly Fun and Feasting
description: THE RANDOM HOUSE BOOK OF MOTHER GOOSE Selected and illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 176 pp. New York: Random House. $14.95. (All ages)

title:
A TOUCH OF HOME ABROAD;
In The Vineyards of Chianti
description: I write early in the morning, usually beginning at 5:30. For a month last summer I did it in a very old farmhouse among the vineyards of Castello di Brolio. When I left, I wasn't sure I would be able to write again anyplace else.

title: IS SEPARATE STRONGER?
description: HOW NATO WEAKENS THE WEST By Melvyn Krauss. 271 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: BROOKE ASTOR, PHILANTHROPIST, STILL BROOKE RUSSELL, WORDSMITH
description: BROOKE ASTOR spends many weekends in Westchester, writing. In a glass-walled room in the southwest corner of her house overlooking the Hudson River, with pad and pen bathed in sunlight, she has turned out thousands of words. The work, she says, is ''a joy.''

title: DO NOT APPROACH THE BENCH MIRACLE ON GRUB STREET
description: THE INVISIBLE BAR The Woman Lawyer in America 1638 to the Present. By Karen Berger Morello. Illustrated. 271 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: After A Struggle, Wilkins Is Finding His Form
description: Until Tuesday night, Gerald Wilkins didn't know what, or whom, to blame for his problems since the start of the season. The coach? His teammates? The arduous schedule? ''All I knew was that I wasn't myself,'' he says.

title: TEACHERS TO MEET IN SHORE SESSIONS
description: APPROXIMATELY 35,000 of its 119,000 members are expected to attend the annual convention of the New Jersey Education Association here Thursday through Saturday.

title: Rangers Hold off Flyers
description: In the midst of these trying days for the Rangers, Phil Esposito requires watching. This afternoon, he looked happy, and he looked grim. He shouted. He stood and sat, then remained standing for the final 10 minutes. He had seen all this before and was afraid of the same old ending.

title: NEIGHBORS SAY ECOLOGY SCHOOL WOULDN'T FIT
description: The Institute for Social Ecology, an organization that espouses harmony between man and nature, has struck a decidely discordant note with its prospective neighbors in the central Vermont town of Rochester.

title: 'Carmen' in Dance and Dylan on Tour
description: Big City Comedy With Billy Crystal, McLean Stevenson, John Candy, Martin Mull, Margaret Trudeau, Tim Kazurinsky, Fred Willard. Produced by Carolyn Raskin.

title: PARTIES WITH A PURPOSE
description: For Future Doctors Nov. 9 - While the number of blacks applying to medical schools has increased as have their admission scores, the proportion of entering black students has declined over the past decade, according to a recent study. The National Medical Association, a group of black physicians that seeks to address that disparity, is holding ''an afternoon of cabaret'' benefit at the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center. The Tony Award winner Ron Richardson will entertain. Cocktails at 1 P.M. followed by a dinner-dance and entertainment until 6 P.M. Tickets $60, at the door. Lighting the Way Nov. 11 - The atmosphere at the Plaza's grand ballroom will hark back to 1906, the year The Lighthouse, which has become the nation's largest multiservice agency for the visually impaired, was founded. Peter Duchin and George Shearing will provide music at the white- and black-tie benefit, which starts with cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by dining and dancing. Tickets $300, or $50 for dancing alone at 10 P.M., from 212-355-2200, extension 183. For Pets and Humans Nov. 11 - The nonprofit Animal Medical Center has begun construction of a radiation therapy unit for pets that will also provide collaborative radiation studies with the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. A black-tie dinner-dance to benefit the new unit starts with 7 P.M. cocktails at the Pierre. Tickets $350, from 212-997-0100. Exalted Gathering Nov. 12 - For the first time in its 182-year existence, the New-York Historical Society on Central Park West at 77th Street will have a kosher dinner.

title: Liverpool Wins
description: Liverpool, the defending champion, took over the lead in the First Division of the English League soccer standings today with a 3-1 road victory against Queens Park Rangers. Nottingham Forest, the former leader, lost at Coventry City, 1-0. Liverpool moved into first place over Forest by virtue of goal difference.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE'LL PRESS FOR CHANGES IN U.S. BUDGET PROCESS
description: President Reagan said today that he would make revision of the Federal budget process his top legislative priority next year, comparing it to his successful crusade for tax revision this year.

title: New York Gave This Marathoner's Feet a Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: STAINED GLASS AT BARRON ART CENTER
description: OF ALL the crafts developed in the past to enrich architecture, and which now have been adopted by contemporary artists, stained glass is the one that seems most lost without attachment to a building.

title: Cab Jumps Curb in Midtown, Seriously Injuring Pedestrian
description: A pedestrian was struck and seriously injured by a taxi that jumped a curb in midtown Manhattan yesterday.

title: GARDEN CLASSICS THAT PROVIDE INSTRUCTIVE READING
description: One evening while strolling the harborside of a Rhode Island resort, we fell into the gravitational field that surrounds secondhand book shops. At length, we emerged, laboring under the weight of a half dozen gardening classics and relieved of several season's seed money.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''They expect us to go back in there tomorrow and keep up the party.'' Edmund Siniarski, a worker at G.M.'s Fleetwood Assembly plant in Detroit, after the company announced plans to close 11 plants and lay off about 29,000 employees.

title: AQUINO SAYS AIDE VOWED TO AVERT COUP
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile had promised to ''do his best'' to avert a coup during her four-day visit to Japan next week.

title: Miss Riordan Is Bride Of Kenneth M. Epstein
description: Kathleen A. Riordan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Riordan of New York, Quogue, L.I., and Miami Beach, was married at the Pierre Hotel in New York yesterday to Kenneth M. Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Epstein of Fair Lawn, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Associate Justice Bentley Kassal of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, First Judicial Department.

title: Making An Operatic Hero of Goya
description: For many years, Placido Domingo has wanted someone to write an opera on the life of Goya so that he could sing the role depicting his Spanish countryman. And for many years, Gian Carlo Menotti has wanted to write another major opera to ease some of the pain he suffered from the poor reception accorded his last one, ''Juana, La Loca.'' And for many more years, Martin Feinstein has craved to draw the music world's attention to his young but rocketing Washington Opera. On Saturday night, the tenor, the composer and the impresario will all get their wish with the premiere of ''Goya.''

title: JUDICIARY POST CLEARED FOR BIDEN
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that he would take over the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, clarifying the probable lineup of key chairmanships when the Democrats assume control of the Senate next year.

title: REYKJAVIK WAS A SHOCK AT 10 DOWNING STREET
description: ''THANK God for Gorbachev and S.D.I,'' a key official remarked, voicing the reaction of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her advisers to what they saw as the dangerous might-have-beens of the accords their closest ally seemed ready to embrace at the Reykjavik summit.

title: There's More to MacNeil/Lehrer Than Covering The News
description: ''The Story of English,'' currently being shown on the Public Broadcasting Service, is nothing if not ambitious; nine hours of television documentary on a subject relatively remote to a popular audience, offering a mix of linguistics, history, autobiography, sociology, poetry and theater - not to mention cinematography.

title: BAYMEN STYMIED BY STATE'S TRANSPLANTING OF WRONG CLAMS
description: THE ban on the taking of striped bass because of PCB contamination dealt a severe blow to Long Islanders who make a living on the water. Then the destruction of the bay scallops by algae blooms added to their woes.

title: ALWAYS READY FOR THE RIGHT WRONG MAN
description: STYLE AND SUBSTANCE A Comedy of Manners. By Judith Martin. 274 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95.

title: COURT IS ASKED TO DEFINE POWER OF THE POCKET VETO
description: OFTEN when the 99th Congress considered a tax increase or a big spending bill, President Reagan warned, ''My veto pen is inked up and ready to go.'' Now that Congress has adjourned, Mr. Reagan does not have to wield his pen. By simply withholding his approval he can keep a bill from becoming law, and last week he used this pocket veto on several measures.

title: INTRASTATE RAIL LINK FOR TOWNS ION SHORE
description: THE Clamdigger route, which carried rail passengers to the shoreline towns east of New Haven until 1971, is being resurrected in an attempt to ease traffic congestion in the area, state officials say.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Year of the Italians
description: Italian-American cuisine is out; Sicilian, Piemontese and Roman cucina are in. Giorgio Armani is to the male sports jacket what Poole of Savile Row was to the waistcoat. Luciano Pavarotti tops the charts. And in government, Americans of Italian descent made up in 1986 for what political scientists once called their ''late arrival at the forefront of the New York political scene.''

title: WALKING THE TIGHTROPE IN GUATEMALA
description: WHEN GUATE-mala's new civilian President, Marco Vinicio Cerezo Arevalo, announced in September that he would begin distributing unused land to migrant farm workers, many Guatemalans were thunderstruck. Mr. Cerezo, in office less than a year, was defying an age-old taboo. The last Guatemalan president who dared tamper with his country's feudal land-tenure system - Jacobo Guzman Arbenz, 32 years ago - was overthrown for his trouble. In the years since, a succession of military cliques has ruled Guatemala with an iron hand, murdering thousands and suppressing talk of reform with a savagery that made the country an international pariah. Last year, faced with a deepening economic crisis and growing international pressure, the officers finally allowed a free election. To no one's surprise, the popular Christian Democrat, Vinicio Cerezo - whom right-wing death squads had several times tried to assassinate - won overwhelmingly.

title: NONPROFIT GROUPS FEAR NEW TAX LAW
description: A leading New York philanthropy recently invited 238 lawyers to lunch and, along with fruit cup and skewered beef, gave them a message: If your clients contemplate a big gift to charity, tell them to do it before the end of the year to get maximum benefits before the tax law changes.

title: MODERN TRIANGLES
description: THE New Studio Theater in Lindenhurst is presenting the Broad Hollow Players' production of ''Beyond Therapy,'' Christopher Durang's droll look at modern romance.

title: OTHER HELP FOR LUPUS
description: In the Oct. 5 article ''Center Treats Lupus Sufferers,'' no mention was made about the Lupus Foundation of America's Long Island-Queens Chapter. For almost 30 years, our chapter has provided comprehensive support services to our members, which number 1,400 in the Nassau, Suffolk and Queens areas.

title: Eight Welfare Monitors Are Suspended by City
description: The Human Resources Administration has suspended the eight workers who monitor attendance by welfare recipients at drug-treatment centers after an internal investigation revealed that the workers had failed to make required on-site inspections, although they asserted they did.

title: 'I Actually Thought We Would Revolutionize the Industry'
description: I WRITE books for children, filled with the images I've accumulated over the years, with stories I've heard from my father and my grandfather. Many take place in the Harlem of my youth. The names of boyhood friends, Binky, Light Billy, Clyde, creep into the stories, and memories of them and of summer days playing endless games of stoopball next to the Church of the Master on Morningside Avenue keep the stories ever alive for me. I'm drawn to the eternal promise of childhood, and the flair of the young for capturing the essence of life.

title: Cable TV
description: The most rewarding new film event of the week on cable is not the arrival of ''A Chorus Line'' - a letdown - but the screen debut of the British actress, Miranda Richardson, in the compelling, downbeat drama, ''Dance With a Stranger'' (1985). The import can be seen on Saturday over Bravo at 8 P.M. and 2:30 A.M.

title: Nora M. Jordan Is Married
description: Nora Margaret Jordan and W. Allen Reiser, 1983 graduates of the Duke University School of Law and associates in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, were married in Cleveland yesterday. The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Angels Roman Catholic Church.

title: Your Right Not to Get an Education Is Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: STANDING UP TO PARIS AND BITBURG
description: AUTONOMY AND SOLIDARITY Jurgen Habermas Interviews. Edited by Peter Dews. 219 pp. New York: Verso/Schocken Books. Cloth, $27.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: BRAZIL TAKES A LOOK INSIDE ITSELF, HOPING TO FILL IN THE BLANKS
description: IN THE early 1970's, when Brazil's ruling generals ordered the construction of a highway network across the Amazon Basin, images of straight brown lines stretching into a horizon of dark-green undergrowth became a symbol of the country's pioneering spirit and commitment to development. The generals believed that colonization of the Amazon was essential to guaranteeing Brazil's sovereignty over a vast, isolated region other nations might one day covet. They also thought the highways would provide access to the Amazon's mining and agricultural resources and could ease the plight of Brazil's poorest region by drawing migrants from the arid northeast to more fertile land.

title: RETHINKING CLUMPS AND VOIDS IN THE UNIVERSE
description: Astrophysicists closing in on the grand structure of matter and emptiness in the universe are ruling out the meatball theory, challenging the soap bubble theory and putting forward what may be the strongest theory of all: that the cosmos is organized like a sponge.

title: MEMBERS OF CLERGY LEARN MORE ABOUT CANCER TO AID PATIENTS
description: MEMBERS of the clergy from Westchester and six nearby counties met recently with staff members from the County Medical Center to discuss communication and confidentiality during cancer treatment. The discussion was part of a special program to help clergymen and clergywomen to learn more about cancer.

title: Dance
description: Dance Theater of Harlem performs and teaches ballet. It also throws a kind of indoor block party on the second Sunday of every month. Sunday is its first open house of the new season.

title: Waiting for 'Goya'
description: There has been such a demand for tickets for the Washington Opera's sold-out premiere of ''Goya,'' the opera by Gian Carlo Menotti, that a natural question occurred: What about the Presidential Box? Mr. Reagan is not known particularly as an opera fan and is therefore unlikely to be in the audience on opening night Saturday. But Martin Feinstein, general director of the opera, said these seats had already been spoken for. Queen Sofia of Spain will occupy the Presidential Box, listening to the Spanish tenor Placido Domingo sing the role of Goya, perhaps Spain's greatest painter.

title: Teaching the Teachers in Black Schools
description: BY any measure, black education in South Africa is in crisis. In 1984, only 11.3 percent of graduating secondary school students scored well enough on matriculation exams to qualify for admission to universities, down from 14.9 percent four years before, according to the Department of Education and Training. Violent pressure from radical youths who tie education to an oppressive government have kept many students from schools in Soweto and other black townships. And most black teachers are sorely underqualified: One recent survey determined that 80 percent of black secondary school teachers had themselves never received the equivalent of a high school diploma.

title: WOOD PLANES: SMOOTHING WITHOUT CUTTING TO THE QUICK
description: WHEN handled with a reasonable amount of care a sharp, properly adjusted wood plane is still one of the best tools the do-it-yourselfer can use to smooth down a rough piece of wood, or to trim and shape a piece of wood to specific dimensions.

title: American Modernism Comes Home
description: Traffic was not very lively when, 35 years ago, Joan Washburn entered the field of 20th-century American art. ''People were just warming up to the work of the Ashcan School - Sloan, Glackens and Prendergast,'' she recalls, ''and that was largely it.''

title: Owners' Change of Pace in Option Year
description: THE news reports can be confusing. One day a club announces it won't exercise the option in a player's contract for 1987 and the next day, or a few days later, it announces that the player has signed a new contract for 1987. The Atlanta Braves and Ted Simmons have done it, the Oakland A's and Dwayne Murphy have done it and other clubs and players will play that game in the next few weeks or months. What does it mean?

title: DAUGHTERS OF THE ISRAELIS
description: THE FLAME BEARERS By Kim Chernin. 276 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: DON'T RUN AFTER GROWN-UP CHILDREN
description: DESPITE Norman Rockwell paintings of large, convivial families sitting down to big holiday dinners with Mother, starched apron covering ample bosom, setting down the turkey platter in front of beaming Father, it's just not that way any more.

title: Terrie LoCicero Wed To Alan B. Kaufman
description: Terrie J. LoCicero, the manager of media relations at the New York University Medical Center, and Alan B. Kaufman, a partner in the New York law firm of Friedman, Leeds, Shorenstein & Armenakis, were married yesterday at City Hall. Justice Stanley Sklar of the State Supreme Court officiated.

title: Link to Met Past Leads to Wilson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DANA FOUNDATION GIVES AWARDS TO 9 ACHIEVERS
description: Nine people, including Nancy Reagan, have been named as the first winners of the Charles A. Dana Foundation's awards for ''pioneering achievements'' in health and education.

title: MEXICO AND SOVIET FORM CLOSER TIES
description: Mexico and the Soviet Union are in the process of establishing closer relations, and the Mexican Government, concerned that the new diplomatic initiative is being misunderstood in Washington, is seeking to reassure the United States.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a review Oct. 19 incorrectly described Alfred W. Crosby's ''Ecological Imperialism: The Biological Expansion of Europe, 900-1900.'' The book has an index.

title: SENIOR VOLUNTEERS OFFER HELPING HANDS
description: ON a recent Tuesday morning at the Hillside School, an elementary school in Hastings, 82-year-old Anna Salvo helped a group of youngsters from Ann Colombo's fifth-grade class sew up their sock puppets. Each week, eight to 12 people from their mid-60's to early 80's, come to the school to work on sewing projects with the children in grades one through five.

title:
FOCUS: Tucson, Ariz.;
Growth in The Desert: A Dilemma
description: AS this city's hot, sunny climate, spectacular desert scenery, healthy economy and expanding cultural offerings contine to lure retirees and young people, residents are realizing that seemingly endless growth is beginning to destroy the very qualities that have made the city such an appealing place.

title: Spin Me Some Gold!
description: RUMPELSTILTSKIN By the Brothers Grimm. Adapted and illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky. Unpaged. New York: E. P. Dutton. $12.95. (Ages 4 and up)

title: Yankee Grapes Are Sour
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: No Kidding
description: THERE are no more college kids at Hofstra University. Just 11,000 men and women, please.

title: U.N. Cuts Back In Budget Crunch
description: The United States, pressing for cuts in the international bureaucracy, is withholding part of its usual contribution to the United Nations, and last week Secretary General Javier Peres de Cuellar seemed to acquiesce. He informed 11 senior aides that their contracts would not be renewed at the end of the year.

title: James Kase Wed To Helene Miller
description: Helene Jodi Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Miller of Great Neck, L.I., and Miami, was married last night to James Howard Kase, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Kase of New York. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson and Cantor Barbara Horowitz officiated at the Harvard Club of New York.

title: Peruvian Candidate Slain On Eve of Election
description: Hooded gunmen from the Maoist guerrilla movement Shining Path killed a candidate for the Huancayo Town Council today, a day before nationwide municipal elections, the police said.

title: HERRICKS CENTER MAY LOSE ITS HOME IN FORMER SCHOOL
description: AS ELDERLY residents played cards while waiting for lunch one day recently at the Herricks Community Center, toddlers from the day-care room pranced into the cafeteria to visit.

title: NEW ENGLAND FISHING CUTS INTO TUNA SUPPLY
description: Parts of the North Atlantic have resembled vast parking lots in recent summers as boatloads of fishermen crowd in, hoping to earn a few thousand dollars for an hour's work.

title: Federal Impasse Over Nutrition
description: SOME of the nation's top scientists were reported in irreconcilable conflict last year over the amounts of vitamins and minerals that are essential in the human diet.

title: Pace of Condos Picks Up in Westchester Survey by County Finds They Total Third of New Units
description: MORE than a third of all dwellings built in Westchester County from 1982 to 1985 were condominiums, and the rate of their construction is speeding up, according to a new survey by the County Department of Planning.

title: 'The Creative Edge': Honing Provocative Profiles
description: Being regarded as America's greatest living novelist can't be much fun; the title is too weighty. Saul Bellow, however, carries the burden gracefully. His concerns have always been moral and literary, and as a public figure, he has distinguished himself by declining to join gangs, cabals or cliques. Mr. Bellow, who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1976, seldom appears on television, is not often interviewed and generally comports himself not as a celebrity but as a writer. He is the subject at 10 tonight of the Channel 13 series ''The Creative Edge.'' Mr. Bellow sits on a sofa and answers questions; occasionally, he reads from his 1982 novel, ''The Dean's December.'' As television, this is not visually compelling. On the other hand, Mr. Bellow does have something to say.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Bidemmi Sizes Us Up
description: CHERRIES AND CHERRY PITS Written and illustrated by Vera B. Williams. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 4 and up)

title: Problems With Penn South
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Enrile in Pledge to Aquino

title: Dr. Dora Samet Bride Of Neal H. Attermann
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Fair Lawn, N.J., last evening Dr. Dora Samet, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Samet of Brooklyn, was married to Neal H. Attermann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Attermann of Maplewood, N.J. Rabbi Zev Segal performed the ceremony.

title: THE LAST SERIOUS DEBS
description: When I was in college and law school in the seven years immediately preceding World War II, I was a constant witness of the last sweeping whirls, the convulsive dying eddies of the great New York debutante parties. Of course the party survives technically to this day, but it is a much modified, more modest affair, usually given by a group of parents for daughters in college with more on their minds than just ''coming out.''

title: BANKS SURGING TO THE ISLAND FOR THE DEPOSITOR'S DOLLAR
description: LIKE mushrooms after a fresh spring rain, bank branches are sprouting up all across Long Island.

title: THE DEATH OF THE BALL TURRET GUNNER
description: PAPER DOLL By Jim Shepard. 228 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: The Wedding Gift Had Tusks
description: SULEIMAN THE ELEPHANT Written and illustrated by Margret Rettich. Translated by Elizabeth D. Crawford. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $11.75. (Ages 8 and up) A TOURNAMENT OF KNIGHTS Written and illustrated By Joe Lasker. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $12.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: Caldwell Still Unbeaten
description: Tom Wickham completed a 25-yard touchdown pass to Kyle Shenk with 2 minutes 6 seconds left to play and lifted unbeaten Caldwell (7-0) to a 16-14 victory over West Milford yesterday in Caldwell.

title: Nonesuch Seeks To Break Down Musical Barriers
description: Robert Hurwitz, head of Nonesuch Records since 1985, remembers April 8, 1986, as an extraordinary day. He spent the afternoon in RCA recording studio A with the World Saxophone Quartet, the virtuoso new-jazz group, as it played the final takes on an album of Duke Ellington's music, lovingly transformed. That evening, he returned to Studio A for the opening session of a second Nonesuch project - the soprano Teresa Stratas singing Kurt Weill's theater music. Both albums have just been released. For some label heads, the transition might seem jarring; for Mr. Hurwitz, it made perfect sense. ''There will never be another Ellington record or another Weill record like these,'' he said proudly. ''There's so much personality coming through the music, it's astonishing.''

title: Emily Dickinson
description: To the Editor: Either The Times or Prof. William H. Shurr was being funny in the Letters on Travel (Sept. 28), or my 1927 edition of ''The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson'' edited by her niece Martha Dickinson Bianchi is very out of date. That edition of the beautiful poem ''I taste a liquor never brewed . . .'' has nothing about manzanilla in it.

title: Why I Still Treasure 'The Little House'
description: IN October of 1945, for my 4th birthday, I was given a plaster doll, a tin suitcase and a copy of ''The Little House'' by Virginia Lee Burton.

title: 'Soul Man' Is Slick and Funny, but Little Else
description: Anyone who imagines that the 80's are a decade without personality would be well advised to see ''Soul Man,'' a comedy that could not possibly have been made at any other time. Indeed, it's hard to imagine an era in which this film's very premise - that a rich white boy could masquerade as black in order to collect a scholarship to Harvard Law School - wouldn't have raised a few hackles somewhere. But ''Soul Man'' is funny, and although it's a hit with predominantly white audiences, blacks who come to see it appear to be laughing too. They are easily disarmed by a film that has less to do with racism than with ambition, and that works so hard to make sure that its audiences, like its characters, never think.

title: NEW AMBIANCE IN GROCERY SHOPPING
description: A PRODUCE stand at a Westport carwash eight years ago was the simple beginning of what was to become the Hay Day Country Markets, already a chain of three stores that sell exotic foods and also offer classes on how to cook them.

title: Knicks Fall, 105-102
description: So much for the resurrection.

title: Arkansas Stopped
description: Baylor's aroused defense held Arkansas to just two first downs in the second half today and its quarterback, Cody Carlson, provided the key plays for a 29-14 Southwest Conference upset.

title: Meet My Whatsit
description: IF JESSICA LANGE attends, wrote Personalities columnist Chuck Conconi in The Washington Post last month, speculating on the appearance of movie stars at a glittery premiere, ''then her significant other, Sam Shepard, who is also in the film, won't be far behind.''

title: THE SUPERMARKETER OF BOOKS
description: HARRY HOFF-man sounds insulted. He can't understand why book publishers don't pay more attention to him.

title: Never Read On An Empty Stomach
description: ACCORDING to Dr. Elliott J. Howard, a cardiologist whose specialty is stress, strong negative emotions cause the body to produce hormones at a much higher rate than normal, and such overproduction can be a strain on the heart. In ''Health Risks'' (The Body Press, Tucson, Ariz.), he says psychiatrists at Duke University found that highly cynical or hostile people are five times more likely to suffer a heart attack than sanguine types. People who are ''hot reactors,'' who literally take things to heart, are especially vulnerable.

title: High Lead Levels In Drinking Water
description: The health and economic benefits of reducing the amount of lead in public water supplies would far outweigh the costs, according to a draft report released by the Environmental Protection Agency last week.

title: Offsetting Losses On Rentals
description: THE Federal tax revision has generated a number of new concepts that are likely to have a direct impact on property owners. Among the most significant are ''active participation,'' to define the way rental property is administered, and ''passive income'' and ''portfolio income,'' to classify the handling of investment-property profits and losses for tax purposes.

title: JOB SECURITY, EFFECTS OF STRESS EXAMINED
description: AS mergers and acquisitions increase among companies in the county, so does the level of stress among employees. And the fear caused by mergers and acquisitions and by management and worker layoffs is contagious, said Dr. Carlton Rosenzweig, a psychotherapist.

title: Night Games In New York
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Article 502186 -- No Title
description: William Harlow, 43 years old, paralyzed after he fell from a truck, has been awarded $9.7 million in damages by a Suffolk Superior Court jury that found Massachusetts General Hospital negligent in treating him. After the jury delivered its verdict Monday, the hospital said it would appeal. Mr. Harlow was injured Feb. 11, 1982, in the fall from his fuel delivery truck.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS ARE HIS LABORATORIES
description: THE assignment for each team of eighth-graders at the Central Park East Secondary School in East Harlem was to investigate some aspect of the American Revolution and to write a report about it. Zawadi Powell and three of her friends decided the Boston Massacre seemed interesting, so they looked it up in some encyclopedias and put what they learned into a rap song that they performed for their classmates. It began: TO TRANSFORM his ideas into reality, Mr. Sizer formed the Coalition of Essential Schools, an organization of 10 secondary schools that are restructuring themselves in line with his ideas. The coalition, which is based in Brown's education department in Providence, R.I., and has a budget this year of more than $400,000, is funded by the Carnegie Corporation and the Danforth, Exxon and other foundations.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ABOUT HOMEWORK
description: TO HELP parents become more effective in aiding their children with their homework, here are some commonly asked questions, with answers that represent the opinions of prominent education experts, psychologists and psychiatrists - taking into account that every parent-child relationship is different and that every child has a different school experience. Q. Is it a good idea to help young children with their homework every night, or does it encourage dependency? A. Most experts believe that a parent should be involved with a young child's schoolwork on a daily basis. They suggest that the best way is to talk over the day's activities with the child. Since independence is the ultimate goal, the parents of a very young child may want to look over his homework with him, but they should expect the child to answer the questions himself. If the child is anxious or puzzled about what to do, parents can help him review the instructions and think through the process in order to get the answer.

title: When to Turn to a No-Frills Law Firm
description: IN 1972, two California lawyers, Leonard Jacoby and Steven Meyers, came up with the idea of a neighborhood clinic to provide legal services at affordable prices. Five years later, when the Supreme Court ruled that attorneys could advertise, J. & M. became the first law firm to promote itself on television.

title: SURVEYING THE EPIC STONES OF ANATOLIA
description: A huge wooden horse, a grotesque, modern Turkish gift to beware of, guards the entrance to the site of ancient Troy, or Ilium, stifling in the visitor's mind any vision of that epic deception that his imagination left free might have conjured up. It's like a Disney fantasy that falls flat when imposed on the real thing.

title: Not Bad for a Staid Stock
description: For investors who shy away from second-tier stocks, there may be nothing more appealing than a component of the Dow Jones industrial average with steady increases in earnings and stock price.

title: NEW DECOR AND NEW DIMENSIONS
description: THE Great Dane in Huntington has changed hands. Although no hint of Viking presence remains on the menu, economics requires the new owners, both of whom have been working in the kitchen at Restaurant Zanghi in Glen Cove, to retain the name printed on the awning.

title: FOR THE DEMOCRATS, MORE CLOUT BUT SOME RISK
description: WITH the Senate majority recaptured, the Democrats regained last week the chairmanship of all committees and the ability to set the legislative agenda. But their edge, 55 seats to 45, gives them far from an automatic majority on every issue. Senator Patrick J. Leahy is a Vermont Democrat who won re-election last week and is likely to become chairman of the Agriculture Committee. Senator Richard G. Lugar is an Indiana Republican whose seat is up in 1988 and who is leaving his post as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. Steven V. Roberts talked with them about the impact of last week's elections. Excerpts follow. Question. With 55 seats in the Senate, the Democrats have an important platform for articulating party ideas and party programs. After six years of being in the minority, what are you going to do with it?

title: Group To Aid Hispanics
description: IN AN ATTEMPT to increase opportunities for Hispanic-American students in higher education, representatives of 20 colleges have formed the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities.

title: Berkeley
description: Berkeley is a city that became a symbol for a generation. The Free Speech Movement - the first campus revolt of the 1960's - began here on the University of California's largest campus, focusing the attention of the nation on this city of 120,000 on the east side of San Francisco Bay.

title: FOR EDDY THE CANDIDATE, LAST STAND HAD LONG ODDS
description: THEY said it could not be done. They were right, of course. And during most of the campaign, Roger W. Eddy knew it. But there were moments - brief ones, to be sure - when it all seemed grandly possible.

title: Best Seller: November 9, 1986
description: Fiction

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: GEORGE ORWELL: The War Commentaries. Edited by W. J. West. (Pantheon, $18.95.) From December 1941 until March 1943, when it finally seemed that the Allied forces would prevail, George Orwell wrote a weekly commentary for the BBC on the progress of World War II. His reports were broadcast to India by Indians and purported to provide an Eastern perspective on the war (though by the end of 1942 Orwell had decided to put his name on them). The series was conceived as part of an effort to counter Axis radio propaganda, which was exacerbating already difficult British-Indian relations in the attempt to woo India away from the Allies. It must have been a tough job for a man of Orwell's beliefs and temperament despite the knowledge that subjugation to the Axis powers would hurt India far more than a few years of continued British rule. He had to submit to the censor, follow the British Ministry of Information's guidelines on a number of issues and skirt the delicate questions of Indian independence (which he wholeheartedly supported) and Britain's crackdown on the Indian Congress leaders. He had to overcome his strong distrust of the Soviet Union and present it as an admirable ally; he had to use wartime euphemisms like calling retreat the ''strategic sacrifice of territory'' - the newspeak he later warned of in ''Nineteen Eighty-Four.'' Though the bulk of his commentary is detailed analysis of the situation on various fronts, battle by battle, Orwell does touch on the issues of propaganda and censorship, presaging the themes of much of his later writing. W. J. West, who edited an earlier volume of Orwell's literary broadcasts, has included those portions of the commentary scripts that did not make it past the censor; they include Orwell's reports of political dissent within wartime England.

title: ABOUT THE MANDATORY VERBAL THRESHOLD
description: NEW JERSEY legislators have an imperative to lower the state's automobile-insurance rates, the highest in the country. And as you are reminded every time you get a bill from your insurance company, the issue has not yet been resolved.

title: In Montreal, Where to Find What's Au Courant
description: When Don Johnson, detective, heartthrob and fashion plate of television's ''Miami Vice,'' sported a wardrobe by Parachute this fall, Montreal's garment industry felt a tremor. The city's roots in the garment industry date from the 17th century and today clothing accounts for more than 40 percent of all manufacturing jobs. That tradition, plus the fashion and style of the primarily French-speaking metropolis, have nurtured a highly competitive and creative community of designers of men's and women's clothes.

title: DATA UPDATE
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing Units)

title: NEWSPAPER AD MAKES A SOVIET PITCH FOR ECONOMIC PARTNERS
description: The Soviet Union, trying to sell itself as a potential economic partner, put a four-page advertising section into the Friday issue of The International Herald Tribune.

title: Wanting the World to Be Different
description: PAGEANT By Kathryn Lasky. 221 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: THE LESSONS OF THE SWAN
description: AT the end of the road, where we rent a little beach cottage on the East End, is a large salt pond where a pair of swans have been raising six cygnets. Last year there were six babies too, but only four of them survived, the other two having fallen prey either to the snapping turtles that snatch them from below or the sea gulls that swoop down from above.

title: U.S. AWACS PLAN OFFENDS INDIA AND PAKISTAN
description: A preliminary decision by the United States to send early-warning radar planes to Pakistan has created irritations in Islamabad and outright anger in India.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: THE MAN WHO TRIED TO BURN NEW YORK. By Nat Brandt. (Syracuse University, $19.95.) Shortly before Election Day, 1864, eight Confederate soldiers entered New York incognito.

title: Students > at > Brown > to > Vote On Proposal to Oust Reagan
description: Brown University students, who attracted attention in 1984 when they asked the school to stockpile suicide pills in the event of a nuclear war, will vote on a referendum calling for the impeachment of President Reagan.

title: Melange of Greens Grown in France
description: Some say mesclun. Others say mesclum. Some insist that this fashionable Provencal salad is a blend of a dozen different greens, all sown, grown and picked together. Jean and Yvonne Tabo, maraichers, or market gardeners, who were among the first to grow it commercially in France, are categorical: it's called mesclum. According to them, it's nine or 10 different greens, each grown in separate rows, then tossed together in approximately equal proportions when picked. And if you want each of the greens to have the right texture and flavor, you pick them when they're very small and very young.

title: DEALING WITH IRAN SAID TO UNDERCUT CREDIBILITY OF U.S.
description: Administration officials said today that the reports about Washington's secret involvement in arms shipments to Iran had caused serious credibility problems for the United States with key countries around the world.

title: KEEP CITY PARKING IN MUNICIPAL HANDS
description: NEW HAVEN ranks highest of the state's cities for its parking system. For 35 years, the nonprofit municipal system has provided convenient reasonable parking.

title: TROUBLES STIR IN HAITI AFTER A QUIET SUMMER
description: The Rev. Breneville Garcia stood at the window where a bullet ripped through the wire screen a few inches above his head on Friday.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Newton, Mass.;
The Last Farm Yields to Condos
description: SEVEN five-story condominiums are cropping up in the fields of what was once a 17-acre farm, the last sizable one left in this Boston suburb.

title: A Canadian Alien?
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Away From It All
description: TAKING A SABBATICAL, that extended period of rest that I've always associated with graying, overwrought professors, had never entered my mind. I'd just completed my 12th cookbook in 15 years. This last book, ''Fearless Cooking for Crowds,'' involved the testing, tasting and writing of hundreds of quantity recipes. I'd been buying, transporting, storing, cooking, cleaning up, living, breathing and eating tremendous amounts of food for almost two years, resulting in a 328-page volume for my publisher and a 30-pound weight gain for me.

title: Kathryn Kelley Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Kathryn Anna Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Kelley of Saddle River, N.J., and York Harbor, Me., to John Gerard Perkins Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Perkins of Fitchburg, Mass., took place yesterday at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Stephen Geckeler performed the ceremony.

title: More Details of What NASA Knew
description: Reports on the shuttle Challenger have turned up a thousand clues to which people knew what and when, but it was disclosed only last week that the leader of a space agency inspection team noted heavy ice on the launching pad a few hours before liftoff and said, ''The only choice you've got today is not to go.''

title:
GARDENING;
BULBS FOR INDOOR WINTER BLOOM
description: FORCING spring bulbs for indoor winter bloom does require a bit of effort, but there is nothing difficult or tricky about the procedures involved.

title: MANAGUA HOLDS A PARADE TO SHOW ITS RESOLVE
description: For the first time in recent years, the Sandinista Government staged a full-scale military parade today to show off its troops and weapons.

title: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
description: To the Editor:

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ROLE MODELS
description: JULIE ROTTA is 3-feet-6-inches tall.

title: Nancy E. Rau, Broker, Wed to Gavin R. Arton
description: Nancy Elizabeth Rau, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Rau of St. Louis, was married in New York yesterday to Gavin Rendell Arton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rendell Arton of Shelly Bay, Bermuda. The Rev. Dr. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: IN HOT-AND-COLD MARKET, SOME ARE CAUGHT WITH 2 HOUSES
description: THE rampaging real-estate market of six months ago has slowed to a crawl in Fairfield County, driving down prices and leaving some anxious residents with two homes - one they bought in the spring and another that they have not been able to sell.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Mr. Urban Renewal SOME people refer to him as ''Mr. Urban Renewal.'' But Hector Gayle of Great Neck, the executive director of the Town of North Hempstead Community Development Agency, says that although he is flattered by the title, his work for the last 20 years ''has not just been urban renewal but community development too.''

title: Arms for Iran. What? For Whom?
description: What is America's policy toward terror, Iran and Syria? At the moment, the landscape is littered with contradictions.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: City in Boston: An Idea Lives On

title: WHERE MUSIC IS EVERYTHING
description: WHAT more euphonious jangle than that of a conservatory practice room? Stand in the hallways of the Juilliard School, the Mannes College of Music, the Curtis Institute or the New England, Peabody or San Francisco conservatories and listen. A protean tintinnabulation, built upon centuries of musical history, fills the ear. Pianists pace through Bach fugues slowly and deliberately; a trumpeter plays the terse opening motto of Mahler's Fifth Symphony over and over; sopranos ''eee'' and ''ahh'' like melodious space creatures while a composer hammers out bold, dissonant chords, searching for the proper finale to a new work.

title: TAMILS REJECT A SRI LANKAN OFFER IN PEACE TALKS
description: Despite progress in narrowing their differences, negotiators trying to end the guerrilla war in Sri Lanka were set back this week when guerrilla spokesmen rejected proposals offered by the Sri Lankan Government.

title: HOW A 'CHAMBER THEATER' GREW TO FILL THE ORCHESTRA
description: Four hours before the curtain went up on the first performance of the first play of the season, Lynne Meadow looked around at the work going on in her new theater two floors below street level. ''This just seems so appropriate,'' she said. ''We started out with construction and here we are, 15 years later, with construction, starting from scratch.''

title: ACCENT ON THE PIANO IN 7 PROGRAMS
description: ONE focus over the next fortnight is on the piano. Today, for example, Jeanne Farewell plays Beethoven, Prokofiev, Chopin and Poulenc at a 7:30 P.M. recital at the Unitarian Universalist Society in West Redding (438-4281). Then on Tuesday at 8 P.M., the Van Cliburn Competition winner, Andre-Michel Schub, appears with the Cologne Radio Orchestra under Gary Bertini at Bushnell Hall in Hartford (246-6807).

title: SEEING ACTIVISM IN ACTION
description: NEW BRUNSWICK residents saw firsthand last summer the tactics of the man whose hunger strikes forced President Reagan to open a shelter for Washington's homeless.

title: STUDY URGES FIGHT FOR STATES' POWER
description: An Administration report charges that the Supreme Court has systematically undermined state sovereignty for more than 50 years and proposes a strategy to correct what it calls an ''erroneous judicial reading'' of the Constitution.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SHAKER STYLES An exhibition of Shaker crafts that have not been publicly displayed before may be seen at the Eli Whitney Museum, Whitney Avenue and Armory Street, Hamden, through December. It was organized by Theodore Johnson and Arnold Hadd of the Sabbathday Lake Shaker community in Maine.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MEALS-ON-WHEELS
description: Before Meals-on-Wheels of White Plains started its Saturday delivery service, some of the elderly clients had to ''make do'' by saving a sandwich from the preceding day or by relying on a friend or relative to help out. Since Oct. 18, however, elderly shut-ins can now receive two meals on Saturday, prepared in the dietary department of St. Agnes Hospital and delivered by volunteer drivers.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Renaissance in Medallic Art
description: With little or no fanfare, fine-art medals appear to be enjoying a renaissance in this country. Interest in medallic art seems to be rising. Today's scenario differs fundamentally from that of the early 1970's, when mass-produced medals, made of silver and marketed in sets, were in vogue. The emphasis now is on distinctive indviidual medals whose value is artistic, not intrinsic. In future years these medals will be identified not so much with the mint that produced them, but rather with the artist who designed them.

title: Indiana Prepares for Recount In Razor-Thin Congress Race
description: Certified results showed a Republican Congressman won re-election Tuesday by 66 votes, and Secretary of State Edwin Simcox today ordered the state police to impound voting machines in northern Indiana's Third District.

title: AIDS Victim Gets Tests
description: A teen-aged AIDS victim, Ryan White, who battled successfully for the right to return to class despite his illness, was listed in satisfactory condition today at Riley Hospital for Children, a spokesman said. Ryan, 14 years old, was admitted Monday for medical tests, according to Mary Sangemino of the Indiana University Medical Center, which includes the Riley hospital . Ryan, who lives in Kokomo, contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome from blood products used to treat his hemophilia.

title: A Painful Round of Cuts for G.M.
description: G.M. is shutting 11 plants in the United States and laying off many of the 29,000 workers at those plants. The move was not unexpected, though the magnitude surprised some analysts, and the company hopes the shutdowns will help it to regain a competitive edge in the auto market. The 11 plants account for 10 percent of G.M. production vehicles in North America, but the chairman of G.M., Roger B. Smith, said the remaining plants will become more efficient as its $10 billion modernization plan proceeds. Analysts said the moves should result in a stronger G.M., but warn that G.M. still must make cars that are attractive to consumers, rather than rely on incentive plans to attract buyers.

title: Cello Recital by Wiley
description: The cellist Peter Wiley, a former principal cellist of the Cincinnati Symphony and recipient of the 1985 Avery Fisher Career Grant, will give his only New York recital of the season, today at 3 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall.

title: THE WHISTLE BLOWERS' MORNING AFTER
description: CHARLES and Jeanne Atchison live near the Cowboy City dance bar on a gravel street in a peeling white and gold mobile home. Weeds sway in the breeze out front. It's a street with a melancholy down-on-one's-luck feel about it. The town is Azle, Tex., a tiny speck on the periphery of Fort Worth.

title: A Symbolist Who Redrew The Frontiers Of Reality
description: In the receiving line at the Museum of Modern Art a place of great honor is reserved for Odilon Redon, the painter, pastelist, draftsman and printmaker who was born in 1840 - a year after Cezanne - and lived well into the years of World War I. When we follow the beckoning finger of Rodin's John the Baptist and walk into the museum's long sequence of painting and sculpture galleries, whom do we find on the threshold? Cezanne is there by right, and in bulk. But, immediately to our left, it is Redon who greets us first - and so directly that we can imagine to ourselves the diffident, invalidish little bow with which he does it.

title: Canadians Take Top Two Spots in Grandprix
description: The Canadians, who won the Nations' Cup here on Wednesday, finished first and second in the $40,000 Mercedes Grandprix last night at the National Horse Show.

title: U.S. PROSECUTING COCAINE CUSTOMERS IN SEATTLE
description: The United States Attorney here has begun to prosecute people suspected of being customers of a major cocaine distribution network with the aim of drying up demand for the drug.

title: MUSIC: NORDIC CHAMBER ORCHESTRA
description: THE Nordic Chamber Orchestra is a clearly well-financed New York organization devoted to the music and performers of Scandinavia. Founded and conducted by Goran Staxang, a Swedish organist and choirmaster at the Church of Sweden here, the orchestra put on an interesting, venturesome but not entirely successful ''musical tribute to Sweden'' Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall. The program consisted of three rarely heard 20th-century Swedish compositions as well as Shostakovich's Concerto No. 1 for piano, trumpet and strings, which served as a showcase for two Swedish soloists, Staffan Scheja and Hakan Hardenberger. There were also Swedish soloists in some of the other music - the fine baritone Hakan Hagegard, the young soprano Anne Christine Biel and the actress Viveca Lindfors.

title: THE SILENCE IN THE EMPTY NEST IS DEAFENING
description: THE KITCHEN counter is the first shock. It is so clean, so devoid of toast crumbs or peanut-butter smudges, that I am jolted. And when I open the cabinet to reach for the Raisin Bran, no telltale flakes spill into my hands.

title: MUSIC: THREE CONCERTS OF CONTEMPORARY WORKS
description: IT has been a bounteous week for contemporary music in New York. On Monday night, the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music - or League-ISCM, as it is mercifully abbreviated - presented a program of chamber music at the Symphony Space. On Tuesday, the Group for Contemporary Music began its 25th-anniversary season at Merkin Concert Hall where, on Thursday night, Parnassus, a chamber ensemble under the artistic direction of Anthony Korf, also presented a concert.

title: A CLERGYMAN FIGHTS TO FREE THE INNOCENT
description: For the last six years, James C. McCloskey has dedicated his life to seeking justice for those unjustly convicted of crimes, and this week he won his third victory when a man serving a life sentence was exonerated and released.

title: Woman Takes Baby From Mother's Bedside
description: A woman who said she was a hospital worker took a day-old boy from his mother's bedside, the authorities said Friday.

title: A Plant That Glows in the Dark
description: What do you get when you cross a tobacco plant with a firefly? Not a cigarette that lights itself, a team of scientists from the University of California, San Diego, reported last week, but an otherwise normal plant that emits a faint but constant light.

title: GUITAR: JOHN HOLMQUIST
description: IF the quality of the music John Holmquist played at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night had matched that of the performances, his guitar recital could have been an outstanding event. His desire to focus attention upon little-known composers - contemporary and otherwise -was admirable, and none of the pieces he settled upon was reprehensible, but the assortment he ended up with seemed unsubstantial at best.

title: UNION SCANDAL IDLES SOME POLITICIANS
description: THREE months before national elections, West Germany's trade unions are in the headlines and in trouble. And that is very bad news for the Social Democrats, the opposition party that is trying to convince itself and the country that it can oust Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition Jan. 25. Already in dismal shape, the Social Democrats are finding their historically close ties to the unions an electoral albatross.

title: AN ACCOUNT OF WAITING AND WAITING
description: ''I'VE got jury duty,'' I said to an office friend. ''That's a shame, what a waste of time,'' he replied.

title: Space for Shows
description: What do an old grimy Consolidated Edison power station and a maker of bright, colorful sportswear have in common?

title: ROCK: R.E.M., WITH MICHAEL STIPE
description: THE Felt Forum's ''dance concert'' setup -in which ground-floor seats are removed for standing room - nearly caused a casualty Thursday night. A few bars into R.E.M.'s encore, the band's vocalist, Michael Stipe, stopped singing and went to help lift a stunned-looking girl from the crush of people near the stage. Mr. Stipe went backstage with the girl, who apparently had fainted; he returned to announce that she might have a broken rib, then ended the show with a subdued version of the Velvet Underground's ''Femme Fatale.'' (Chris Hansen, Madison Square Garden's head of security, said Friday that the girl had had an asthma attack.) It was an uncomfortable ending for a superb concert. R.E.M., a four-man band from Athens, Ga., is the pride of rock's alternative circuit; it built a reputation in clubs and on college radio before more commercial outlets began paying attention. The band's songs pile idiosyncrasy on eccentricity. They take the guitar riffs of 1960's folk-rock and garage-rock, assemble them in asymmetrical ways - with unexpected shifts of key, odd-length verses and choruses, extra bridges - and then add Mr. Stipe's lyrics, delivered in a grizzled voice.

title: VERMONT SCHOOL CHIEF DENIES EMBEZZLING $20,000
description: The former superintendent of the Bennington school district, George Sleeman, has pleaded not guilty to 47 felony charges after an investigation of the district's $2 million deficit.

title: Montana Returns With Sackful of Questions
description: JOE MONTANA is expected to start today for the San Francisco 49ers. Think about that a moment. Here's a man who nine weeks ago ruptured a disk by twisting his body awkwardly as he let go a pass in the opening game of the season. With unforgiving pain in his back and increasing numbness in his leg, he was advised by doctors that only surgery would correct the problem. With no small amount of anxiety, he agreed to have the operation, which was performed Sept. 15 in St. Mary's Hospital in San Francisco. That was 55 days ago. Today, he will face the St. Louis Cardinals, an event that would be dramatic no matter who the 49ers were playing.

title: LISA IN WONDERLAND
description: Some time later there was a song on all the jukeboxes on the Upper East Side that went 'but where is the schoolgirl who used to be me,' and it if was late enough at night I used to wonder that. I know now that almost everyone wonders something like that, sooner or later and no matter what he or she is doing, but one of the mixed blessings of being 20 and 21 and even 23 is the conviction that nothing like this, all evidence to the contrary notwithstanding, has ever happened to anyone before. Joan Didion--''Goodbye to All That'' Lisa Edelstein, a nice girl from a New Jersey suburb, is explaining how she got to be Lisa E., New York's reigning Queen of the Night, Girl of the Moment, new Edie Sedgwick and top ''celebutante'' of 1986.

title: Susan F. Guggenheim Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Felice Guggenheim, a daughter of Shirley E. Guggenheim of Tenafly, N.J., and New York and the late Herbert Guggenheim, was married last night at La Belle Epoque in New York to Robert Lawrence Plotz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Plotz of Brooklyn and Chilmark, Mass. Rabbi Simkha Weintraub performed the ceremony.

title: Small Is Mind-cry-able
description: THE RETURN OF THE INDIAN By Lynne Reid Banks Illustrated by William Geldart. 189 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: CLUES TO ANCIENTS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Evidence of a 6,000-year-old Indian village has been uncovered in this town settled by the Pilgrims in 1620, and it is said to be the first such site found in Massachusetts.

title: Bowie Hurt Again
description: WHEN Sam Bowie, Portland's 7-foot-1-inch center, complained of pain in his right leg during the exhibition season, the Trail Blazers' coaches and trainers shrugged him off as just another player with a sore leg. Bowie was allowed to skip practice as a precaution, but nobody ordered an X-ray or other detailed examination.

title: A PROFESSIONAL'S OPINION
description: TRUMAN By Roy Jenkins. Illustrated. 232 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: WILD STYLE
description: Look at the clothes in fashion magazines. Vivienne Westwood's hooped skirts and baby-doll dresses, for example. Or David Cameron's scuba suits.

title: Days Dwindle in Lions' Bid to See Some Light
description: THE players crowded into a dressing room in the basement of Davis Varsity House, at the north end of Dartmouth's Memorial Field. There was mud on their legs, and the game had not yet started.

title:
GARDENING;
BULBS FOR INDOOR WINTER BLOOM
description: FORCING spring bulbs for indoor winter bloom does require a bit of effort, but there is nothing difficult or tricky about the procedures involved.

title: SIX TO WIN: 18,21,24,36,45,47
description: A steady drizzle failed to dampen Lotto fever yesterday in New York City and elsewhere in the state as people stood on long ticket lines for a chance to win the $24 million jackpot, the third largest in state history.

title: HOT FRM THE GRILL IN NEW CAANAN
description: IF you wanted to chart the expansion of Connecticut's restaurant scene in recent years, you might look at New Canaan as an example. Ten years ago there were just two real restaurants, other than luncheonettes and modest snackeries. Today there are nine - a significant, perhaps predictable increase for a Fairfield County town of 20,000 or so.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
James Joyce Rides High in Tulsa
description: When the James Joyce Museum in Dublin wanted to reproduce one of the author's neckties to sell as a fund-raiser recently, it turned in an unlikely direction for help - to Tulsa, Okla. Stephen Dedalus may never be as well known in Oklahoma as Will Rogers, but a Joycean literary presence has been growing steadily and impressively in a city that is trying to make its image mean more than just oil wells.

title: Bedtime For Hulks
description: THE DALLAS TITANS GET READY FOR BED by Karla Kuskin. Illustrated by Marc Simont. 41 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Headliners; An Insider Punished
description: Ira B. Sokolow, who made money on Wall Street the new-fashioned way, was sentenced to a year and a day in Federal prison last week. Mr. Sokolow, a 32-year-old former vice president in the mergers department at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, now Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., pleaded guilty to having sold inside information about pending corporate takeovers to Dennis B. Levine, who in turn pleaded guilty to making $12.6 million on illegal stock trades. Mr. Levine paid Mr. Sokolow $125,000 for information used as a basis for some of the illegal transactions. In sentencing Mr. Sokolow, Federal District Judge John F. Keenan said, ''By your criminal acts you have eroded public confidence'' in the securities markets, ''and you really didn't need the money.''

title: LONGING FOR A DOG WEARING SUN GLASSES
description: TEN years ago, I was in my station wagon chauffeuring my 3-year-old to the local nursery school. My golden retriever sat aristocratically in the front seat next to me. My daughter sat in the back seat. She wore her best clothes and seat belt. The dog proudly wore a pair of sunglasses.

title: Jenny Morgenthau Is Bride Of E.R. Anderson, Attorney
description: Jenny Morgenthau, a daughter of Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, and the late Martha Pattridge Morgenthau, was married at her father's apartment in New York yesterday to Eugene R. Anderson, a son of the late Ruth Anderson of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Andrew E. Anderson of Weiser, Idaho. Justice Sidney H. Asch of the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, First Judicial Department, performed the ceremony.

title: DANISH SEAMEN'S UNION TELLS OF ARMS SHIPMENTS
description: A global watch on shipments of arms to the Persian Gulf indicated last spring that ''many thousands of tons'' in increased American-made weapons were quietly being sent to Iran, an executive of the Danish Seamen's Union said today.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: JOE & MARILYN: A Memory of Love. By Roger Kahn. (Morrow, $16.95.) He's been the man's man since he first strode into center field at Yankee Stadium 50 years ago; she was every man's woman until her death in 1962.

title: MY ROMANCE WITH MONTAUK: 14 RENTED HOMES IN 16 YEARS
description: MY ROMANCE with Montauk - with the ocean, with the fishing boats and even with the crowds at Gosman's Dock on a Saturday night in summer - is in its sixteenth year now.

title: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Contrary State of Campus Love
description: A FACULTY member romancing a student at most colleges may risk breaking a heart.

title: Can the German Calm Last Much Longer?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Oct. 12 about the formal installation of Vassar College's ninth president misidentified her. She is Frances Daly Fergusson.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Wages Won't Catch Up

title: SUNY HAS PLANS OR GETTING TO THE TOP
description: IN JANUARY 1985, an independent commission of educators and business and political leaders used blunt language to describe the two principal problems facing the State University of New York. The nation's largest university system suffered so much from ''overregulation,'' the panel said, that administrators found it difficult to get a roof fixed, let alone meet educational objectives. Moreover, the commission's report said, SUNY's standing in research and graduate and professional education was ''well behind that of leading public universities in other states and leading independent universities in New York.''

title: SENATORS SPLIT ON BID PLAN FOR TRIDENT
description: CONNECTICUT'S two Senators are at odds over the future of a lucrative submarine program, a dispute that is certain to affect the state's defense industry.

title: GUIDELINE GIVEN ON TRACKING BLOOD DATA
description: HOSPITALS and community blood banks in New Jersey received detailed guidelines from Trenton last week on how to trace blood transfusions that may have involved AIDS-tainted blood.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Posthumous Furniture An auction, says Don Mitchell, takes on moral drama when we reflect that it is the furniture of someone's life that's being sold, that someone was happy or sad, lived and died, surrounded by these things. This is from ''Living UpCountry'' (Yankee). Auctions make for entertaining drama as well as bargains. In the most common variety of summer auction, somebody has died and his estate is being settled; the auction converts all wordly possessions, no matter how precious or mundane, into coin of the realm. Weepy kin are apt to be dispersed among the crowd, watching memories sold to disrespectful strangers, but the general atmosphere is apt to be celebratory. A carnival: hot dog vendors, cars parked on the grass, cheerful citizens sitting in lawn chairs facing the front porch. In the house, a squad of muscled teenagers wrestles stuff out the door in no particular order. Kitchen range, rocking chair, pickling crock, mattress, chain saw. Each is duly made the property of the highest bidder; when the contents of the house are sold, sometimes they sell the house. By day's end, one person's life's possessions have been divvied up and redistributed as swiftly as a stolen sports car in some urban chop shop.

title: Faint Stirrings in the Secondary Stocks
description: THE secondary stocks that have lagged behind the market over the last year may be about to have their day, according to some analysts. Corporate insiders - the officers and directors who enjoy a generally favorable vantage point for judging business prospects - have gone on a buying binge among the smaller companies, particularly those trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

title: Project for Learning Disabled
description: The state is planning to establish regional centers for college students who suffer from learning disabilities that prevent them from succeeding in traditional classes.

title: TAIWAN FLU VIRUS IS ISOLATED IN U.S.
description: The new influenza strain that health officials warned about in August has arrived in the United States with the first reported cases of the 1986-87 influenza season, the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta report.

title: Best Sellers: November 9, 1986
description: Fiction
