title: CPR FOR INFANTS: AN ADULT CONCNERN
description: KENNETH POPPER was juggling his 4-month-old daughter, Mallory Samantha, on his shoulder on a recent Monday evening while managing to pay close attention to Anne Dooley, a volunteer instructor of a course in cardiopulmonary resuscitation of infants.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: IN THE WAKE OF 'BIG BANG';
Can Wall St. Still Afford Its Specialists
description: BRITAIN'S recent deregulation of its securities markets, the ''Big Bang,'' has been billed as a catching-up with the United States. It is that, and more. The London Stock Exchange not only ended fixed commissions and membership restrictions, as our exchanges did more than a decade ago, but took decisive steps to adapt to the new technological and competitive realities of the world securities markets. If the New York Stock Exchange fails to match the British reforms, it risks losing business, particularly in well-capitalized issues of international interest.

title: Problems With Penn South
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Impact of Digital Audio Tape Worries Some
description: Insiders of the audio trade are laying odds that the next major advance in sound reproduction - Digital Audio Tape, or DAT for short - will be launched by next summer. Technophiles quiver with anticipation.

title: Q AND A
description: Co-op Tax Deductions Question: As a co-op owner, I had two deductions for mortgage-interest payments under the old income-tax law - the interest on the mortgage I took to buy my apartment, and the portion of my monthly maintenance payment that goes toward servicing the co-op corporation's blanket mortgage. Will those same deductions be allowed under the new tax code? . . . D. S., Forest Hills, Queens Answer: According to Andy Falke, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, you will still be entitled to both deductions under the new tax code. He added, however, that for mortgages taken after last Aug. 16, including refinanced loans, the deductible portion of the interest will be limited to an amount no larger than the cost basis of the unit plus the cost of improvements. An exception is allowed for home-equity loans in which the money is used for medical or educational expenses.

title: For the Schools, Some Basic Work
description: The Metropolitan Transit Authority is not often mentioned as an example of how to run things, but it was when the Board of Education found that deferred maintenance had left its many marks on the schools as it had on the subways.

title: MRS. KEAN HONORED ON AID TO RETARDED
description: WHEN the state chapter of the Association for Retarded Citizens asked Deborah Bye Kean in 1984 to serve as honorary chairman of the newly created Governor's Council on the Prevention of Mental Retardation, ''we didn't know what to expect from her,'' said Glenna Gundell, director of the association's community programs.

title: NAKASONE'S POPULARITY ON THE WANE
description: As this month began, Yasuhiro Nakasone accomplished something that no Japanese Prime Minister had managed in 18 years: he entered his fifth consecutive year in office.

title: Ospreys From Maine Flown South on Jets
description: Two young ospreys rescued in the summer have been flown south for the winter aboard Eastern Express and Eastern Airlines planes.

title: AT&T POLICY
description: It is company policy that all employees have a right to work in an environment free of discrimination, which encompasses freedom from sexual harassment. ATT prohibits sexual harassment of its employees in any form.

title: How Australia Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: SLAMMING VISION INTO HIGH GEAR
description: WORKING SPACE By Frank Stella. Illustrated. 177 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $14.95.

title: AS DEMOCRATS REVEL, GOP IS CONDUCTING POST-MORTEM
description: AS Connecticut Democrats basked in their sweeping victory in the state elections last week, the Republicans headed back to the drawing board.

title: New G.M. Layoffs Announced
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would permanently lay off 1,300 hourly workers later this month at its year-old Buick City assembly plant at Flint, Mich.

title: REVISION AND LIFE: TAKE IT FROM THE TOP- AGAIN
description: IHAVE been asked to write something for a textbook that is meant to teach college students something about writing and revision. I am happy to do this because I believe in revision. I have also been asked to save the early drafts of whatever I write, presumably to show these students the actual process of revision. This too I am happy to do. On the other hand, I suspect that there is just so much you can teach college students about revision; a gift for revision may be a developmental stage - like a 2-year-old's sudden ability to place one block on top of another - that comes along somewhat later, in one's mid-20's, say; most people may not be particularly good at it, or even interested in it, until then.

title: Banks Meets Coach's Expectations at Last
description: The best outside linebacker in the National Football League this season may play for the Giants, and despite his eye-opening season it may not be Lawrence Taylor on the right side. Instead, it may be Carl Banks, who in his third professional season has become a destructive force on the left side.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET (And Everything Else You Need to Know About Football). By John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Villard, $16.95.)

title: ONCE A NEW YORKER...
description: I moved to the Hamptons when I first came to New York a decade ago, before the farm fields there began sprouting houses instead of potatoes. But on a bitter, wintry night around a solitary restaurant table, when everybody was grousing about the lack of anything going on, the late Truman Capote said to me, ''Look, why don't you forget all this Walden Pond stuff and move to Manhattan? Live high and hard, and remember everything you hear and see. You won't regret it.''

title: A Link Between City and Builders
description: ''T HESE homes are all sold,'' says the handwritten sign on a construction trailer at 145th Road and Arthur Street in Springfield Gardens, in southeastern Queens. Then the sign reads, ''For more information, call (212) 561-2001.''

title: Comeback for the Cameo: The More the Merrier
description: YOU remember the cameo. It's been stuffed in the top drawer of the bureau for ages, with the treasures grandmother left.

title: Lletters for Yyoungsters
description: ABC The Museum of Modern Art: New York. By Florence Cassen Mayers. Unpaged. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $9.95. (Ages 3 to 7) ABC The Museum of Fine Arts: Boston. By Florence Cassen Mayers. Unpaged. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $9.95. (Ages 3 to 7) HAVE YOU EVER SEEN . . . ? An ABC Book. Written and illustrated by Beau Gardner. Unpaged. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $9.95. (Ages 3 to 7)

title: GREENBURG NATURE CENTER ASKS SUPPORT OF RENOVATION PLAN
description: THE Greenburgh Nature Center, the 33-acre nature preserve off Central Avenue, has presented a master plan to the Greenburgh Town Board that calls for a $965,000 four-phase series of projects to renovate and improve the center's manor house and grounds. The center is requesting that the town provide funds for the major portion of the project.

title: After Brontosaurus Moves Out
description: DINOSAURS DIVORCE A Guide for Changing Families. Written and illustrated by Laurene Krasny Brown and Marc Brown. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $13.95. (Ages 4 and up)

title: PRESERVATION CONCERNS OF WATERFRONT GROWTH
description: THE state's waterfront towns and cities, their unique assets and their special problems, will be the focus of a daylong conference on Friday at the Seamen's Inne in Mystic.

title: AS MIDWEST'S FARMERS FACE DISASTERS, NEW ENGLAND'S 'GET BY'
description: Tilling the rocky soil of New England is not the way to make a fortune.

title: IN PRAISE OF TEACHERS
description: THOUGH I AM IN MY 21ST year as a professor at New Mexico State University, I wonder if I've stopped thinking of myself as a teacher. Don't I lament to my wife Stephanie that the more productive I become as a writer, the less time I have for communicating whatever it is that has impelled students to try to learn from me?

title: 9-0 Miami: Testaverde Hits for 4 Bull's-Eyes
description: Perhaps this time next season, Sal Genilla will be holding court at weekly gatherings with the news media, recounting once more his first game at Pitt. He will mention the steady rain that made the football slick and his hands less nimble. He will talk about the challenge of playing against the No. 1 team in the country, led by a quarterback who would make an ideal model if the Downtown Athletic Club ever decided to recast the Heisman Trophy.

title: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
description: To the Editor:

title: OPPOSITION IN KOREA BACKED INTO A CORNER
description: BELEAGUERED opposition party members took heart last week when one of their leaders, Kim Dae Jung, challenged the Government, saying he would not run if it would hold direct presidential elections.

title: PROBABLE HEADS OF SENATE PANELS
description: LABOR AND HUMAN RESOURCES

title: Mrs. Horton Defends
description: In the next few months bridge journalists around the world will be voting for the 1986 Player-of-the-Year in a contest organized by the International Bridge Press Association and sponsored by the Royal Viking Line.

title: A REVUE FOR THE MUCLEAR ERA MOVES FROM STAGE TO FILM
description: When the writer-director JoAnne Akalaitis was first approached to make a film from her award-winning play ''Dead End Kids,'' an Off Broadway hit performed by the avant-garde company Mabou Mines at the Public Theater during the 1980-81 season, she flatly refused. ''I'm not one of those theater artists who wants to recycle stuff, turning plays into movies into videotapes,'' Ms. Akalaitis said recently. ''I don't believe in making icons of your work.''

title: G.M. to Close 11 Plants That Employ 29,000
description: The General Motors Corporation has been making too many cars with too many workers in too many obsolete factories, according to industry analysts, and it reported a third-quarter operating loss of $338.5 million.

title: HIS QUEST IS TO DISCOVER THE ESSENCE OF GLASS
description: If ever a man was born to his fate it was Harvey Littleton. This major artist in the medium of glass was responsible for bringing the field of studio glass into existence in 1962. Before then it had been thought that one man, outside a factory with its big furnaces and array of tools and teams of workers, couldn't manipulate molten glass on his own. Mr. Littleton thought otherwise.

title: Looking Behnd the Proposition 48 Image
description: THE practice of setting lower admissions standards for athletes than for other students has become commonplace. As a result, athletes with extremely limited verbal and mathematical skills have become a standard feature at almost all Division I schools. Under the best of circumstances, marginal students such as these would have difficulty with college-level work. When they are also expected to meet the high-pressure demands of college sport, it is not surprising that they often fail to make satisfactory academic progress. The low graduation rates of Division I athletes have become a national scandal.

title: Buying a Car
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Side Of Gentle Bats
description: BATS, said Dr. Merlin D. Tuttle, are not eerie, ugly, rabid menaces. Bats are ''gentle, clean and intelligent.'' They ''have the misfortune of being mostly shy and active only at night, and as a result they're misunderstood, feared and persecuted.''

title: Verbatim; Setting Standards
description: 'I believe we have deeper cultural problems that demand our attention. . . . High on the list, one would find a problem that is sometimes captured with the term ''corpocracy,'' a reference to large-scale corporate America's tendency to be like the Government bureaucracy. ...

title: Army Ends Slide, Sets Back Air Force
description: Tory Crawford, the Army quarterback, had a big game today, and the result was a 21-11 victory over Air Force that was satisfying to the Cadets for several reasons.

title: MORE SERVICES LIKELY FOR VICTIMS OF AIDS
description: RECENT public and private initiatives promise to improve the health and social services available to New Jersey AIDS patients, enabling some who have been hospitalized for months to return to their communities.

title: Sarah Moore Plans to Wed D. C. Winton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dongan Reynolds Moore of Westport, Conn., and Quechee, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Reynolds Moore to David Carpenter Winton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weber Winton of Fairfield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: WHO ARE THE HOMELESS? 'WE ARE ALL AT RISK'
description: New Brunswick sees a housing activist in action. Page 6.

title: Hope Ann Bachow Weds A.P. Winters in Cherry Hill
description: At Congregation Beth El in Cherry Hill, N.J., yesterday Hope Ann Bachow and Alan Peter Winters were married by Rabbi Howard Kahn. The couple's parents are Mrs. Sidney Barron of Cherry Hill and the late Mr. Bachow, and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Winters of Teaneck, N.J.

title: BUYING AT HOME IS REALLY NO BARGAIN
description: THE other day I found in my mailbox, along with other pieces of unsolicited materials, an envelope addressed to Mr. Carl H. Reker. Since my husband has been dead now for two years, I did not hesitate to open it.

title: Rev. Gordon L. Kidd, Minister to Roosevelts
description: The Rev. Gordon L. Kidd, who ministered to the Roosevelt family as rector of St. James Episcopal Church in Hyde Park, N.Y., for 20 years, died Thursday at his home there. He was 88 years old.

title: Jazz
description: An unusual opportunity to hear a widely acclaimed jazz musician who rarely performs in public will begin on Thursday when Dr. Ron Odrich, recognized by fellow musicians as a jazz bass clarinetist virtually without a tear, begins playing a series of weekly late afternoon sessions.

title: MEAD'S MEANING
description: QUEST FOR THE REAL SAMOA The Mead/Freeman Controversy & Beyond. By Lowell D. Holmes. Illustrated. 209 pp. South Hadley, Mass.: Bergin & Garvey. $29.95. IN 1983 Derek Freeman published his book ''Margaret Mead and Samoa: The Making and Unmaking of an Anthropological Myth,'' in which he claimed to have exposed what he has called a wholesale deception unmatched in the history of the behavioral sciences. He was referring to Mead's fledgling field study that won popular fame as ''Coming of Age in Samoa'' (1928). Systematically demolishing Mead's methods, findings and characterization of Samoan culture, Mr. Freeman drew a portrait of an aggressive, violent, sexually inhibited Samoa that contrasted dramatically with Mead's version. His purpose in this had less to do with understanding Samoa than with the unmasking of the ''cultural determinism'' supposedly perpetrated by Franz Boas on all of American anthropology - and on the public at large. By undermining the details of Mead's classic case illustrating how culture can shape the experience of adolescence, Mr. Freeman professed to be restoring the balance in the nature-nurture debate.

title: EUROPEANS DIVIDED ON ARMS FOR IRAN
description: Reaction in Europe has been varied to reports that the United States provided military spare parts to Iran and secretly negotiated with Teheran in efforts to free American hostages in Lebanon.

title: NONFICTION: IN SHORT
description: Wolf Uecker's ART NOUVEAU AND ART DECO LAMPS AND CANDLESTICKS (Abbeville Press, $75) is a collector's dream if you happen to collect lamps and candlesticks. Though most of us may wonder why the author chose to present them exclusively, it is impossible not to admire Jacques Hartz's outstanding photography.

title: Moving Officers To Curb Police Corruption
description: As 12 police officers and former officers from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn were arraigned last week on corruption charges that included the theft and sale of drugs, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward announced sweeping departmental changes aimed at heading off such situations.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'THANKSGIVING IN THE COUNTRY'
description: THERE are still farms in once all-rural Hunterdon County, and incentives to keep them, but highways and corporate relocations continue to bring in growing numbers of commuters. The county is also a haven of second-home ownership, of the weekend pied-a-terre and the gentleman's farm.

title: Amherst Captures Little Three Title
description: A senior split end, John Tucci, caught Paul Foye's 3-yard pass for the decisive touchdown with nine seconds to play in the first half as Amherst edged Williams, 10-7, in the country's oldest small-college rivalry for the Little Three championship today.

title: Charles Farr Jr., Investment Aide, Weds Ms. Miller
description: At St. James Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday Laurie Jo Miller and Charles Sims Farr Jr. were married by the Rev. Hays H. Rockwell. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merle R. Miller of Huntington Station, L.I., and the bridegroom is a son of Mr. Farr of New York and the late Mary Randolph Rue Farr.

title: Q AND A
description: Mexico by Bus Question:How can I get information about intercity bus service in Mexico? Are there any government-run accommodations? S. B., Brooklyn

title: Backing Away From Disinvestment
description: AS pressure for disinvestment by American corporations builds at home, many here are wondering exactly what the future of social responsibility spending will be.

title: Ronald Pruner, Lawyer, Marries Elizabeth Grant
description: The Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth McLean Grant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barrett Grant of Greenwich, to Ronald Mark Pruner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pruner of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Walter Waggoner, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: A MARSHALL PLAN FOR THE 80'S;
'Recycling' Surpluses to the Third World
description: THE world economy is in serious trouble, wracked by major tensions that threaten to derail what the World Bank already calls ''hesitant recovery.'' Tuesday's election demonstrates that the precarious health of this recovery is also uppermost in the minds of millions of Americans, whether they earn their livings in older, smokestack industries, new high-tech companies or family farms.

title: AN INNOVATIVE PATH TO RECOVERY
description: WHEN Federal officials evaluated distressed urban areas around the country in 1981, Newburgh, N.Y., topped the list. In terms of the scale of its economic suffering and the impoverishment of its 24,000 residents, the old Hudson River manufacturing city was considered to be in the most desperate need of help.

title: Holy Cross (9-0) Earns Title
description: Gordon Lockbaum had two touchdowns today, including the tie-breaker late in the fourth quarter, as Holy Cross won the Colonial League's inaugural title with a 17-10 victory over Bucknell.

title: SHAPIRO CRITICIZES PARTY FOR DEFEAT
description: The biggest story in New Jersey's elections this week was not who won, but who lost.

title: TWO BIG BROKERS END 'DISCUSSIONS'
description: The board of directors of the E. F. Hutton Group said yesterday it had had ''preliminary discussions'' with Shearson Lehman Brothers, another major brokerage house, but that the talks had ended and it was not expected they would resume.

title: Art
description: In every age there are artists who work in what appears to be a timeless idiom - one that taxes no one's understanding and can never give offense. When the artist in question is Italian, and his work contains a melodious, sun-warmed and easy-going quality with a slightly sardonic intelligence, then we may be sure that he will make his way.

title: Violence Erupts Anew in Haiti
description: The leader of Haiti's provisional Government, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, warned in June that the country was ''on the edge of anarchy.'' But things were quiet until late summer, when violent crime increased and business stagnated.

title: Kenyan Reporter Sentenced
description: A reporter for The Standard, one of Kenya's major newspapers, has been sentenced to four years in jail for joining the outlawed leftist group called Mwakenya and failing to report the publishers of seditious pamphlets. The journalist, Mugo Theuri, was sentenced Friday after pleading guilty to the two charges.

title: An Even Dozen
description: Next Friday the United Nations Postal Administration will issue what promises to be one of its most attractive assets. The set consists of 12 stamps that reproduce the creations of prominent 20th century artists.

title: THE BALI QUESTION
description: ''Where is your husband?'' It was the second question every Balinese asked me.

title: JOHN HENRY GETS A FINAL SEND-OFF
description: John Henry, swaybacked and potbellied but feisty as ever, made his final farewell appearance when he was paraded into the winner's circle tonight as part of Meadowlands Race Track's 10th anniversary celebration.

title: Judging Hospitals On Performance, Not Equipment
description: The notion that a hospital should be judged by the quality of care it provides may seem obvious, but that has not been the standard criterion in the United States. A hospital is accredited if its management and equipment make it capable of offering effective care, regardless of whether it actually does so.

title:
ART;
THE 'POTENT IMAGE' AT THE MORRIS MUSEUM
description: ''THE POTENT IMAGE,'' the current exhibition at the Morris Museum here, is absorbing to look at, but a slippery one to assess. Potency in art, like beauty, may be in the eye of the beholder.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FURNITURE IN PROVIDENCE

title: ULTIMATE TEST FOR JIGSAW FANS
description: Stephen K. Richardson loves to get hate mail. He is delighted when his customers call, screaming and swearing. He is ecstatic when they threaten revenge. How else, he asks, smiling sweetly, can he know they are satisfied?

title: Black Rock's Bow to Bath
description: The old Bullard Company factory, once a world leader in the production of machine tools and employing as many as 5,000 workers, was a landmark in the Black Rock section of Fairfield, Conn., for almost 70 years before it was permanently closed earlier this year in the face of foreign competition. Now a small group of Fairfield and Westport lawyers and business people have banded together under the name of Windsor Green Associates to turn it into a 300-unit condominium.

title: Andrew Jackson Gains Title
description: Andrew Jackson (8-1) took two giant steps forward in the rain yesterday by beating Bayside for the first time in the school's history, 18-0, and claiming its first Queens Division A Championship.

title: WHAT RESEARCH WAYS ABOUT HOMEWORK'S VALUE
description: ALTHOUGH findings of early research into the effect of homework on a child's academic achievement were inconclusive, recent studies suggest that spending more time on homework can pay rich dividends in higher grades and test scores.

title: BARBARA KRIEGER TOILS FOR THE VINEYARD THEATER
description: WHEN Barbara Zinn Krieger first saw the room, it was a musty little space in the basement of a building with a couple of old bicycles sitting in one corner.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: SHATTERED SILK. By Barbara Michaels. (Atheneum, $15.95.) Remember Nancy Drew, plucky teen-age heroine of the fine 30's mystery series by Edward Stratemeyer (under the name Carolyn Keene)? The ''slim sleuth's'' adventures with her chums Bess, George and Ned provided the high point in literary suspense for millions of American girls.

title: FICTION: IN SHORT
description: ELLEN BRAY. By Jane Julian. (Morrow, $16.95.) One wants to praise a novel as readable and energetic as ''Ellen Bray.'' Set in a copper-mining community in 19th-century Cornwall, the story evokes time and place and treats the miners' hardscrabble lives seriously.

title: COMPUTER PREVIEW OF COSMETIC SURGERY
description: THROUGH the help of a computer, Dr. Julian Henley , a New Haven plastic surgeon, says he can show his patients what they will look like after cosmetic surgery - before they go in the operating room.

title: MIRACLE ON GRUB STREET
description: THEODORE DREISER At the Gates of the City 1871-1907. By Richard Lingeman. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: ON THE WRITE-IN FRONT, A BITTERSWEET DEFEAT
description: AS Dick Stewart sees it, he was defeated by two opponents in his bid for probate judge of New Canaan.

title: NEW PROGRAMS INSISTING ON PARENT INPUT
description: SCHOOL DISTRICTS around the nation are creating special programs to encourage parental involvement in their children's education.

title: Rare Stamps' Finder Is Not Their Keeper
description: A Maryland judge has ordered the finder of more than $150,000 worth of rare stamps to return them.

title: Startling Images From A Young Choreographer
description: A choreographer who makes you think and feel at the same time and who makes you conscious of both processes is rare. Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, born in 1960 in Belgium, turns out to be a member of that special breed.

title: Growing Up Hopeful
description: THE PURPLE COAT By Amy Hest. Illustrated by Amy Schwartz. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) A NEW COAT FOR ANNA By Harriet Ziefert. Illustrated by Anita Lobel. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: 'Bit-Picking'
description: To the Editor:- ''Shattering the PC's RAM Barrier'' (The Executive Computer, Oct. 5) refers to the ''inexactitude of convenience'' of the ''supposedly punctilious computer industry'' in its approximation of a megabyte as one million bytes when it is actually 1,024,000 bytes. As long as the issue is raised, we think it is not ''bit-picking'' to point out that a megabyte is actually 1,024#2 or 1,048,576 bytes. NANCY and YONAH WILAMOWSKY Brooklyn, Oct. 12

title: ANOTHER HUMAN DRAWN TO THE SPIDER'S WEB
description: The article on the spider in the Oct. 5 Long Island Weekly [ ''The Summer I Was Drawn Into the Spider's Web,'' Opinion Page ] came to my attention and created quite a bit of interest. We come from spider country and boy, do we have spiders.

title: Patricia M. Maroni Engaged to Julian A. Saldanha
description: Patricia M. Maroni, director of corporate communications at the Javelin Software Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., and Julian A. Saldanha, a vice president and senior consultant in the Bank of Boston's corporate banking division, plan to be married Dec. 13.

title: Maria Therese Iacullo Wed to Donald A. Bird
description: Maria Therese Iacullo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hannibal R. Iacullo of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Donald Allport Bird, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Bird of New York. The Rev. Edward R. P. Kane performed the ceremony at the St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Gettysburg Hotel Is Sold
description: The Gettysburg Hotel, home to dignitaries for 160 years, including President Eisenhower, was sold Friday at a sheriff's sale. The building, now a burned-out shell, was bought along with two other buildings for $850,000 by Conewago Contractors Inc. of Hanover, Pa. The hotel became an apartment building after closing in 1964 and was gutted by fire Feb. 10, 1983.

title: Atlantic Salmon Still Fight For Survival
description: PURSUED throughout its range by commercial netters, anglers, poachers and native Indians engaged in subsistence fishing, the hard-pressed Atlantic salmon is returning to some New England rivers from which it was absent for more than a century. But in Canada, the commercial harvest of the species has been substantially reduced.

title: A Life On High Court
description: I was appalled by Justice Brennan's remarks about ethnic and cultural diversity of Supreme Court justices.

title: Miss Maxwell Married To a Fellow Physician
description: The marriage of Dr. Patricia Anne Maxwell to Dr. Scott Alexander Joseph took place yesterday at Temple Israel in Memphis. Rabbi Harry Danziger performed the ceremony.

title: Racing Tips on Videotape
description: THERE they are, all the elements that led to my wholly undistinguished career in racing. There are the red and blue Formula Fords that I drove five years ago. There is sandy-haired Gilbert Pednault, my instructor. The Laurentian Mountains are in the distance, and the asphalt track is covered with skid marks where the rubber failed to erase people's mistakes. This time, though, all of it is in my living room.

title: The Fitness of Woit's Warriors
description: GALE SAYERS wondered if he'd ever play again. In 1969 in Chicago he was attempting to come back from knee surgery the previous year and regain his one-time greatness as a Bear running back. A friend had suggested that Dick Woit might help him. Woit ran an unusual -some might say iconoclastic, even eccentric - fitness class.

title: SINGERS AIM GIBES LEFT AND RIGHT
description: CAN you judge politics from the results of last week's elections? Or can you judge it from the songs ''Love Me, I'm a Liberal'' and ''One Million Lawyers and Other Disasters?''

title: THE POWER OF RAISING YOUR VOICE FOR A JUST CAUSE
description: MOTHER and Father didn't quarrel. No, never.

title: MERRY JAPES OF OLD BOYS
description: THE JOKE OF THE CENTURY By David Hughes. 223 pp. New York: Taplinger Publishing Company. $14.95.

title: Wetland Designation On S.I. Is No Blessing
description: To the Editor:

title: HAZARDOUS WSTES: CONTROLLING SOURCES
description: SOME DAY, the hundreds of known hazardous-waste sites in New Jersey may all be cleaned up. But will there be hundreds more to take their place?

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Boutiques and Arts, Demos and Edibles Gift Galaxy '86 of the Young Men's Christian Association of White Plains and Central Westchester opens Wednesday at 6 P.M. and is open until 9 o'clock that night - with wine tasting, a modestly priced supper, silent auction and a raffle for a trip to Rome and other prizes - and continues Thursday and Friday, including lunch for $5 a day served by Y.W.C.A. volunteers. There is no charge for admission any day or evening.

title: 'Carmen' in Dance and Dylan on Tour
description: Garden Way's Joy of Gardening Compact Gardens, Small Spaces and Containers Magic Video Publishing 30 minutes. $14.95

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S true that anyone over the age of 20 is often considered quaint and prehistoric by teen-agers, but quaint and prehistoric though these oldies may be, there's no denying that they've contributed a fair amount to the world - moral positions, concepts, ideas, inventions - that have not only changed mores already, but will affect and influence the thoughts and lives of future generations.

title: A London Flat of One's Own
description: Think of accommodation in London, and its many luxury hotels like Claridge's or the Connaught come to mind, with their air of old-world elegance complete with afternoon tea, antique interiors and liveried staff.

title: Nofziger Faces Ethics Inquiry
description: Lobbying by Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's former political director, is under scrutiny in a state and Federal investigation of a military contractor's swift growth.

title: PARADE IS DROPPED FOR LACK OF CROWDS
description: RUTH CONGDON remembers the large crowds that turned out for the old Armistice Day parades in downtown Hartford in the years immediately after World War II.

title: ARE THERE REALLY TOO MANY AMERICAN BILLIONAIRES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Ann Gill, a Buyer, Wed to Robert W. Evans
description: Patricia Ann Gill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bernard Gill of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to Robert Winthrop Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold M. Evans of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Patrick E. Brown, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Walter A. Bell Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King.

title: A MODEST PROPOSAL
description: We were born in the same neighborhood within a few months of each other, the Chrysler Building and I, and for me that Art Deco swordfish in the sky will forever call to mind the good things of a New York long gone.

title: NO MORE 9 TO 5
description: Lynn Hazlewood was tired of bossy employers, of hours so long there was no time to spend the money she earned, of headaches that regularly punctuated her stressful days. So, she built up her savings account, paid all the bills and fled her job as production manager at Rolling Stone magazine, striking out for a life of freedom and independence , a life as a freelance graphic designer.

title: Contras Plan Assault by Radio
description: The Nicaraguan rebels plan to use a powerful new radio station to promote their anti-Sandinista ideas. Reagan Administration officials said last week that the 50,000-watt AM station would be as powerful as any in the United States and would cover all of Nicaragua.

title: HAMDEN PUBLICATION BRINGS THE LATEST ART TO LIFE
description: ''COMMUNICATION for the creative mind,'' is the way Joseph Cardella describes Art/Life, the publication he issues each month from his home in Hamden. Unlike more well-known arts magazines, however, Art/Life does not feature stories about painters and sculptors, exhibitions, galleries and trends in the art world. Instead, each page is itself a work of art.

title: FEDERAL BOOKSTORE IN MALL NEAR KANSAS CITY HAS IT, WHATEVER
description: Looking for the latest copy of ''Dietary Goals of the U.S.?'' Need the ''Pocket Guide to Chemical Hazards'' right away? Or ''Time and Frequency: Theory and Fundamentals'?'

title: AFRICA WRITERS NOTE HAZARDS OF THE TRADE
description: Seated in a Harlem restaurant, East Africa's most prominent writer recently raised his glass in a quiet salute to West Africa's most prominent writer.

title: CONGRESS PLANS TO INVESTIGATE COVERT POLICIES
description: Members of Congress said today that they would investigate whether the Reagan Administration had used the White House staff to circumvent Congressional restrictions on foreign policy and covert operations.

title: Reagan's Revolution Ended?
description: The results of the 1986 Senate election are already being heralded as marking the end of the Reagan revolution in American policies. With a Democratic gain of eight seats, commentators have widely hailed these victories as a rejection of the President's policies and a demonstration that his coattails have gotten considerably shorter. But most of us who advise Democratic candidates for state and national office know that this is not really the case.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Mets And Yanks Go for Free Agents?
description: The Mets, while being world champions, should learn from Kansas City and Detroit and not sit on their laurels of the year past. But it would be foolish to dip into the free-agent market when good trades can make this team an even stronger one.

title: RELIVING THE CIVIL WAR, WITH FERVOR
description: ''IN his quest to 'Destroy the enemy's will to resist you in any manner possible,' did Lincoln recklessly tamper with soldier morale in tossing out the popular McClellan?''

title: COUNTY VOTERS RETURN INCUMBENTS TO OFFICE
description: FOR Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, it was an election night very different from two years ago.

title: Giving a Push fo Film Processing
description: A STUDENT of mine has been photographing in Grand Central Station, capturing the movement of passengers and passers-by across the huge central hall. This is no easy task, since the light inside the station is not exactly what is found on Jones Beach. Even with a relatively fast black-and-white film, such as Kodak's Tri-X, his shutter speeds can run into seconds.

title: Man in Houston Is Wounded By Tripping Own Booby Trap
description: A man who was burglarized at least 10 times in recent years was seriously wounded Thursday when he accidentally tripped an illegal booby-trapped shotgun he had rigged in his home for burglars, the police said.

title: 2 FACES RUNOFF VOTE FOR GOVERNOR IN VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: The Nov. 18 runoff election for Governor of the United States Virgin Islands is pitting a wealthy former judge and legislator against a populist legislator who seeks to loosen American ties to this Caribbean territory of 110,000 people.

title: STATE MEDICAL BOARDS DISCIPLINED RECORD NUMBER OF DOCTORS IN '85
description: The state agencies that discipline physicians revoked a record number of licenses for incompetence or other problems last year, almost 60 percent more than in 1984, a new report shows.

title: Misappliance
description: MOLLY'S NEW WASHING MACHINE By Laura Geringer. Illustrated by Petra Mathers. 32 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor: I found that the Sept. 14 article by Mary Lee Settle on Hong Kong helped me to redefine a short stay I had there last December, and I regret that I had spent not enough time searching its past and too much time shopping. Of course, this is what tourists do in Hong Kong (and elsewhere), but a caveat appears to be in order.

title: LIGHTING UP BY WORKERS IS FALLING OFF
description: SMOKERS are finding it increasingly difficult to light up in Connecticut workplaces, as more and more private and public employers are curbing or banning smoking.

title: Your Congress at Work
description: President Reagan took office asserting that, when it came to government, less was better. How is he doing? The following table shows a marked decline in the total number of recorded votes in the House of Representatives and the Senate in the last 10 years; it starts with the four Carter Administration years, 1977-80, for comparison with the years since Mr. Reagan moved into the White House in 1981:

title: Help Is Beginning to Flow For Part-Time Students
description: THEY are ''the wave of the future'' for higher education, according to the leader of a national coalition seeking to improve the lot of the nation's 5.5 million part-time students, but until recently they have enjoyed only a trickle of financial aid. Now help is on the way. Under the newest five-year extension of the Federal Higher Education Act of 1965, part-time students pursuing undergraduate degrees, no matter what their age, will be in line for Federal benefits through the awards known as Pell Grants. The new benefits take effect in the 1989-90 academic year, when the maximum Pell Grant will be $2,700 a year. (It will grow $200 a year thereafter, to $3,100, in 1991.) As they are for full-timers, grants are restricted to students whose family income is under $30,000. In addition, the new law provides nontraditional students with more aid through College Work-Study and Opportunity Grants, which will be raised from a maximum of $2,000 to $3,000 a year.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Los Angeles; 3 Governments In a Joint Venture
description: THE site is a prime piece of real estate on First Street, flanked by City Hall, the County Courthouse and the Los Angeles Times Building, and the development plans for it are not surprising: a 20-story, 600,000-square-foot speculative office building. What is surprising is the development team: the general partner is the County of Los Angeles, with the City of Los Angeles and the State of California as limited partners.

title: Aviator Authors
description: I flew a P-38 in World War II and remember how it felt to be solely responsible for your fate. Of course, navigation devices have improved, and flying an F-14 today is not the same as flying The Spirit of St. Louis, but the similarities are greater than the differences.

title: From Cottage to Castle: A House Hunter's Guide
description: Imagine a European vacation, far from the hotel crowds, in a villa on the Riviera, a town house in London or Paris, a rustic cottage in the Cotswolds or even a sprawling, 15th-century castle or chateau. Although Europeans have long spent summer holidays in rented homes and apartments throughout the Continent, it is only recently that renting vacation properties abroad has caught on with Americans.

title: 50 YEARS ON THE TELLY: THE STORMY, WONDEROUS WORLD OF BBC
description: Britain's gnawing hunger for retrospection is of Proustian proportions; historical confections of past glory are always being sugared up and nibbled at somewhere in the land. Now comes the most toothsome and caloric backward glance of all - through the mass looking glass, the telly. Fifty years of television are being celebrated in a monthlong feast by the British Broadcasting Corporation, the grand institution, at once hoary and ethereal, that some call Auntie and others call the Beeb, and that most, it seems, must call controversial.

title: AGRICULTURE CLASS ENROLLMENTS DROP
description: The stark images of struggle and hardship on the American farm are causing extensive problems for agricultural universities in the New York region.

title: Cornell Topples Yale, 15-0
description: Marty Stallone, a senior quarterback, completed a 41-yard touchdown pass to Chris Hahn, and Tom Aug made three field goals to give Cornell a 15-0 victory over Yale today.

title: CHURCH REBUFFED IN MURRAY HILL ZONING FIGHT
description: The Community Church of New York, one of Murray Hill's oldest institutions and an early leader of social action by religious groups, has been rebuffed in a bid to escape new zoning proposals aimed at preserving the low-rise architectural character of the community's side streets.

title: A Test For the Democrats
description: The Democrats have come back to Washington proclaiming their victory in the Senate elections and promising to cooperate with the President during his last two years in the White House.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
New-House Sales And Prices Surge
description: BUILDERS complain that they have to pay a king's ransom for land, planners worry about the water supply and civic groups fume about traffic. Nevertheless, the Island's home-construction industry has entered a new surge of growth.

title: Making Peace With Local Militants
description: Two weeks ago, Pace College in Soweto shut its doors. Dogged by continuing student violence, poor attendance, erratic tuition payments from parents and a drop-off in corporate sponsorship, the secondary school for black youths closed to ''formulate a new direction,'' a spokesman said.

title: TOWNS DUMPING TIRE PROBLEM IN POND
description: WHEN the Hamden tire pond began business eight years ago, few towns wanted to pay the $5-a-cubic-yard fee to dump worn-out tires there.

title: Junior Ms., Tough and Smart
description: BRAVE IRENE Written and illustrated by William Steig. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) FLOSSIE & THE FOX By Patricia C. McKissack. Illustrated by Rachel Isadora. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Mary G. Murphy To Become Bride
description: Mrs. John Bunworth Murphy of Forest Hills, Queens, and Margaretville, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Mary Gabriel Murphy to H. Joseph Escher 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Joseph Escher Jr. of North Hollywood, Calif. The wedding is planned for January.

title: Salvadoran Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL AND THE BOMB: MEGATONS OF AMBIGUITY
description: If Israel does have nuclear weapons, as so many military experts believe, under what conditions might it use them? Could it deploy them tactically, in the context of a ground war with one of its Arab neighbors? Or would it use the bomb only as a last-ditch weapon should Israel ever find itself on the verge of destruction?

title: THE SELLING OF MICHAEL JORDAN
description: THE AIR INSIDE THE DARKENED gymnasium is heavy with the heat of an uncommonly prolonged North Carolina summer. Smoke from some tin containers placed around the basketball court lends a touch of mystery to the scene.

title: Keeping Roommates Happy
description: THE relationship between college roommates is one with fragile beginnings, fraught with potential disaster. How are strangers, barely out of adolescence and thrown together by a computer, supposed to coexist peaceably in one cramped room?

title:
DINING OUT;
IN QUEST OF JAPANESE SPECIALTIES
description: NOT LONG ago, when one wanted to pop out for a light, casual meal, one headed on automatic pilot to the local Chinese restaurant. But now with the growing popularity of Japanese fare, little neighborhood restaurants with sushi bars are offering the fresh and attractively presented dishes of another part of the Orient as alternatives to moo shu pork and fried rice.

title: CONCERT: MUSICAL ELEMENTS
description: MUSICAL ELEMENTS, a contemporary music ensemble, is marking its 10th anniversary this season. The most notable shift in new non-commercial music during the decade has probably been the fresh vitality of certain ideas previously associated with musical conservativism - simplicity of structure and texture, tonal harmony, open avowal of poetic and emotional connotations -and Tuesday's program at the 92d Street Y was, in that sense, fully in step with the times.

title: A DISSENTING VOICE: CATHOLIC THEOLOGIAN DAVID TRACY
description: AS THE NA-tion's 293 Roman Catholic bishops gather for their annual meeting today in Washington, they are intensely pre-occupied with an issue that crackles like St. Elmo's fire around the formal agenda. It is the nature of authority: the pope's, as the head of the church; theirs, as teachers with him of Catholic doctrine, and that of the American Catholic Church. The bishops will also ponder the claims to authority of theologians, particularly those like the Rev. David Tracy of the University of Chicago who roam the intellectual frontiers of their discipline, often returning with new interpretations of old teachings.

title: Springsteen's Live/1975-1985' Is Loaded With History
description: 'Bruce Springsteen & the E Street Band Live/1975-85'' (Columbia 40559; LP, cassette, compact disk), a massive five-record retrospective album that arrives in stores tomorrow, represents an unprecedented event in popular recording. A three-and-a-half-hour, 40-song career summary, recorded over a 10-year period in clubs, concert halls and stadiums across the United States, it is the sort of anthology one expects to be released late in a performer's career, or posthumously.

title: Irish Protestant Group Says It Planted Bombs
description: An outlawed Protestant group took responsibility today for planting four explosive devices in Dublin and warned that it would step up its bombing campaign unless the Irish Government abandoned an accord with Britain.

title: AT CITY SHELTER, JOYFUL NOISE FOR WOMAN WHO FOUND A HOME
description: After five months without a home, Connie Johnson, a student at Long Island University, had finally found an apartment where she and her 15-year-old son, James, could live. But first, there was thanks to give. ''I've been part of your family since June,'' Ms. Johnson said yesterday to the people she has called her family, 100 homeless people in the auditorium at St. Catherine's, a city-run shelter on the Lower East Side. ''This is a gift to you to say I love you.''

title: A Strategic Retreat On Tuition Costs
description: SINCE the early 1980's colleges have been raising their tuition at roughly twice the rate of inflation. Now even a well-armed consumer, the Air Force, has decided it would rather switch than fight.

title: U.S. Aide Urges Seoul To Compromise on Crisis
description: A senior United States official said today that he had urged the South Korean Government and the opposition to negotiate a compromise to resolve the political crisis and that he remained optimistic about a peaceful solution.

title: A WOMAN'S BEST FRIEND
description: JUST BARBARA My Story. By Barbara Woodhouse. Illustrated. 189 pp. New York: Summit Books. $16.95.

title:
ART;
VIEWS OF THE EARLY U.S. LANDSCAPE IN WADSWORTH ATHENEUM SHOW
description: THE exhibition of American landscapes titled ''Views and Visions'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford examines a period that the curator, Edward Nygren, calls a ''neglected area.''

title: 3 INDICTED OFFICERS SAID TO AGREE TO AID PROSECUTORS
description: At least three of the 12 police officers facing charges in the 77th Precinct corruption scandal have agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, according to law-enforcement officials familiar with the case.

title: Bricktown Medical Mall
description: A year ago the 120-bed Brick Hospital opened on Route 88 near Laurelton Circle in Bricktown, N.J. Then Brick Township set up a Bricktown Hospital Support Zone in the area around the hospital.

title: Exeter Tops Andover, 15-0
description: In the 106th renewal of their rivarly, Phillips Exeter Academy shut out Phillips Andover, 15-0, at Andover's home field yesterday.

title: Children of Affluence
description: As a clinical psychologist who treats adolescents, I see the aftermath of upper-class permissiveness and sophistication. It is apparently easier to give children their own Visa card than to spend quality time with them, teaching them the values of limitations and responsibility versus freedom.

title: RETHINKING THE VALUE OF INTELLIGENCE TESTS
description: JUDY is a bright-eyed 4-year-old who stays by herself during playtime in her class at the Eliot-Pearson preschool on the campus of Tufts University in Medford, Mass. Anyone who watched her might think Judy is a bit of a wallflower and certainly behind her more gregarious peers in social development. But when a researcher asks Judy to play the Classroom Game - which is actually a test of social perceptiveness - her apparent indifference to her classmates' social lives falls away. Judy, it turns out, has a level of social intelligence far beyond that of most of her classmates.

title:
GARDENING;
BULBS FOR INDOOR WINTER BLOOM
description: FORCING spring bulbs for indoor winter bloom does require a bit of effort, but there is nothing difficult or tricky about the procedures involved.

title: Suspect in Spy Case Is Released on Bail
description: A former Air Force sergeant, Allen John Davies, who is suspected of trying to pass military secrets to Soviet agents was freed on $200,000 bail Friday.

title: Martha Hartman Becomes a Bride
description: Martha Susan Hartman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Theodore Hartman of Lubbock, Tex., and Timothy Metcalf Schutte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Schutte 3d of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. L. McD.

title: 143 VEITNAM MEMORIALS, VAST AND SMALL, RISING AROUND NATION
description: Veterans Day, whose observance has been blurred by the country's deep ambivalence about the Vietnam War, is being given a new ration of pride, patriotism and energy by veterans of the nation's longest war, which was its only major military defeat.

title: MEN, CREATING WOMEN
description: AMERICANS born before World War II may well share with me one of the disquieting memories of childhood - a hermaphrodite (or ''morphodite,'' as the creature was often called). With the obese and the anorexic, the hairy and the bald, they were features of freak shows at carnivals and fairs. One might even come to your town, rent a vacant building and set up its own little private exhibit. Your father might ask you one evening after supper if you'd like to take a walk. You'd accept his hand, stroll through a mild evening to the drugstore, eat a cone of cream; and then he might say, ''Want to see something strange?''

title: Walker Gets Life And Judge's Scorn
description: John A. Walker Jr., whose spy ring enabled the Soviet Union to decode more than a million Navy messages, was sentenced to life in prison last week by a Federal judge who urged that he never be freed.

title: ALCOHOL'S EFFECTS ON WOMEN STUDIED
description: THOUGH state residents and officials are quite knowledgeable about alcoholism, the treatment of female alcoholics still falls short of what is needed, a study by the the Junior League of Stamford-Norwalk has concluded.

title: 'No Dents' - and Not Many Riders
description: New York's subways are everywhere abused as a netherworld of crime and filth, but among city residents it is the sunlit public buses whose popularity is falling strikingly. While subway ridership has leveled off at a billion passengers a year, the number of bus riders has continued its historic decline and now stands at about 500 million -just over half what it was in the mid-1960's.

title: REFLECTIONS IN A WRITER'S EYE
description: I once had a brief encounter with an intellectual ape.

title: Ms. Pilelsky Wed To Fellow Lawyer
description: Ellen Barbara Pilelsky, an associate at the New York law firm Liddle & O'Connor, was married last night to Roy D. Oppenheim, an associate at the New York law firm Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. Rabbi Nathan Coburn performed the ceremony at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Affirming and Dissident Visions of America
description: Fifty years ago this month the first issue of Life magazine appeared on American newsstands.

title: HOUSING: PARLEY TO OPEN FRIDAY
description: LEGISLATORS and policy makers from across the country will meet Friday and Saturday at the Busch Campus Center of Rutgers University to discuss housing affordability and homelessness.

title: TOWARD A PRACTICAL HOUSING POLICY
description: OWNING a home has always been an integral part of the American dream, a goal for which Americans have saved and sacrificed, a symbol of family security and success.

title: A PHONE PLAN FOR THE DISABLED
description: EVERY Wednesday at 2 P.M.Ann, Sol, Chuck, Irwin and

title: Deterrence Or Defense?
description: Robert S. McNamara, one of the seminal thinkers of the nuclear era, sharply disputes the theory that a limited version of President Reagan's strategic defense plan, designed only to protect U.S. missile forces, would strengthen deterrence and improve nuclear stability.

title: POWER STRUGGLE SEEN IN SUFFOLK G.O.P.
description: A YEAR of change - and very likely turmoil - is virtually assured for the Suffolk County Republican Party as a result of Tuesday's elections, political experts agreed last week.

title: AFTER 4 DECADES, A REUNION OF THANKS
description: For more than two-and-a-half years, as the Nazis occupied Poland, the Radza sisters and their parents escaped death hidden beneath the wood-plank floor of a Catholic family's home in the small town of Nowy Korczyn.

title: 19th-Century Art And Architecture
description: In every great city there is an art gallery that comes on like an old-style private house.

title: JERSEY CITY HOUSING AID SOUGHT
description: STATE and Federal aid to construct low- and moderate-income housing in this city of 223,532 is sought in a resolution now before the Assembly Committee on Housing and Urban Policy.

title: All-Star Sponsor
description: MAJOR league baseball, which has been without a corporate sponsor for the fan balloting for the annual All-Star game since the Gillette Company ended its 16-year run in 1985, has a new sponsor, one that recalls the origins of the game in 1933.

title: THE 'POOR' BRONFMANS' BILLIONS
description: THEY are known as the ''other''

title: People Express Loss
description: People Express Inc., the debt-ridden airline that is in the process of being acquired by the Texas Air Corporation, reported a loss of $112.9 million for the third quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A $27,000 reward, raised by family, friends and donations from the community, is being offered for the safe return of a newborn boy taken from his mother's arms as she lay in a hospital bed.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 10, 1986: MONDAY Household Intl Inc Pitney-Bowes Meredith Corp Wallace Computer Serv TUESDAY Champion Spark Plug Mickelberry Corp Cleveland-Cliffs Inc Sears, Roebuck Hammermill Paper Staley Continental Inc International Paper Triton Energy McDermott Intl WEDNESDAY CBS Inc Gerber Products CSX Corp Massmutual Inc Invstr Current Income Shs Quaker Oats Co Esselte Bus Sys Suntrust Banks Fireman's Fund USG Corp Foote Cone & Belding THURSDAY Advest Group Inc Mapco Inc Arvin Industries Pacific Amer Inc Shs Chemical New York Corp Sabine Corp Colgate-Palmolive Singer Co Cooper Tire & Rubber Stop & Shop Cos Dow Chemical Wal-Mart Stores Louisiana Gen Svcs FRIDAY Chelsea Industries Revco D S Inc Eastman Kodak Co

title: O'Brien's Toughness
description: AFTER the Jets trotted out for the second half, Wesley Walker happened to look up at the message board. Ken O'Brien, he learned, had completed 16 consecutive passes. And on the Jets' first series following the kickoff, Walker caught a 12-yard pass, the quarterback's 17th consecutive completion, three short of tying the National Football League record set four seasons ago by Ken Anderson, the Cincinnati Bengals' quarterback. On the next play, the Jets' wide receiver cut toward the goal line, but David Croudip batted the ball away. When the Jets' next huddle formed, Walker turned to O'Brien.

title: BEARS ROLL 23-3; FLUTIE MAKES DEBUT
description: Walter Payton, playing with a dislocated toe, rushed for 139 yards and Mike Tomczak ran for one touchdown and passed for another today to lead the Chicago Bears to a 23-3 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: POP: FELA ANIKULAPO KUTI'S AFRO-BEAT
description: FELA ANIKULAPO KUTI, the dissident Nigerian songwriter and band leader, gave a triumphant concert Saturday night at the Felt Forum. It was his first New York show since 1970 and the first New York appearance of his band, Egypt 80 - 20 musicians, 4 backup singers and 6 dancers. It was also proof that 18 months in a Nigerian prison, on charges that were later dismissed, had not stopped Mr. Kuti or his music. (Mr. Kuti was arrested Sept. 4, 1984, as he and the band were leaving for an American tour; he was released this April.) As outspoken and defiant as ever -he even performed past the 11 P.M. curfew imposed by union overtime fees - Mr. Kuti gave his music a hard-edged authority. He is a charismatic, eccentric performer, part musician and part public figure; between songs, he casually addressed the audience as ''man'' while underlining the messages in his lyrics. He is also, at the age of 48, a taut, well-muscled, almost feline dancer.

title: Bridge: Gluttony at the Card Table Is Understandable at Times
description: Of the numerous sins committed by bridge players at the card table, only four are deadly: pride, anger, sloth and gluttony.

title: HUTTON EXPLORES SALE OF UNIT
description: The E. F. Hutton Group capped nearly 20 hours of board meetings over Friday and Saturday and the breakdown of talks on selling the brokerage house to Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. with an announcement yesterday that it had elevated its president to the role of chief executive officer and was exploring a sale of its life insurance operations.

title: MILITANTS SINK 2 OF ICELAND'S WHALING VESSELS
description: Militant environmentalists boarded two of Iceland's four whaling ships early today and opened key sea valves, sinking the ships in Reykjavik harbor, a leader of an antiwhaling group said.

title: COLUMN ONE: POLITICS
description: Personal or Philosophical?

title: SMOOTHING HOLIDAY CONFLICTS
description: IN 1984 Diane Ettinger, a San Francisco computer programmer, and her husband, Robert, a marketing executive, argued over how to celebrate Thanksgiving.

title: America's Cup II
description: How often we're reminded of the comfy way that big money mixes nowadays with big-time sport. Take the other night, when Eileen Bond's chauffeur drove her to the international airport in Perth, Australia, so she could pick up from a British Airways flight a gift of silver that she wanted to give her husband, Alan.

title: TRADITION, OLD FEARS, MAO'S IDEA
description: For more than a century, many of the residents of this tiny borough in the heart of the Pennsylvania Dutch farm country ended the day by toasting one another at the bar in the Lenhartsville Hotel.

title: GIANTS PUT A CLAMP ON EAGLES
description: Yes, the Giants won. No, they did not win pretty. In a rough game marked by enough punching and shoving and elbowing to satisfy a hockey crowd, the Giants outlasted the Eagles, 17-14, today. The Giants carried a 17-0 lead into the fourth quarter, then surrendered two touchdowns. In the final minute, Tony Galbreath of the Giants insured the Giants' victory by leaping and catching an onside kickoff.

title: WEST SIDE HIGH: LAST CHANCE TO LEARN
description: Edward A. Reynolds - ''Ed'' to his students - does not look or act much like a normal high school principal.

title: OLD MONEY WOES HINDER NEW BRITISH THEATER
description: In his small, cluttered office, Max Stafford-Clark described the budgetary bind facing the English Stage Company in appropriately theatrical terms. ''If we cut salaries any more, the staff would all have rickets,'' said Mr. Stafford-Clark, the company's 45-year-old artistic director.

title: LAWYER ELECTED TO LEAD MONTRAL, BEATING MAYOR'S CHOSEN SUCCESSOR
description: Jean Dore was elected Mayor of Montreal by a large margin today, according to nearly complete returns.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Celcor Inc., Englewood, N.J., a diversified telecommunications company, said its president, Charles Arslan, had resigned for personal reasons. Robert Edwards, chairman and chief executive, will add the title of president.

title: DANCE: NORTH CAROLINA TROUPE PERFORMS
description: THE New Performing Dance Company offered a chilling look at insularity in a program presented on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio. Durham, N.C., where the company is based, is hardly an outpost of dance.

title: People
description: * Francis X. Houghton has joined Biederman & Co. as executive vice president.

title: 2 Protestant Ministers Are Being Held in Seoul
description: Two Protestant ministers are being held for questioning in connection with anti-government remarks, the police said today.

title: JAPAN'S ECONOMIC ROLE SEEN IN BETTER LIGHT...AS BAKER, PRAISING TOKYO, CRITICIZES BONN
description: Over the past year or so, the Reagan Administration's once harsh attitudes toward Japan and its economy have mellowed considerably, according to Administration officials and private analysts. And in some respects, they say the Administration now considers Japan a more reliable, more essential partner in economic policymaking than its historic allies in Europe.

title: LIFE IN AN OFFICE PARK: A MIX OF GOOD AND BAD
description: William Cole, an executive at Johnson & Higgins Inc., and Margie Woodard, his secretary, are growth corridor colleagues. Were it not for the hours each day they spend in cars, trains and mini-buses, they would be delighted with their new corporate address, just off Route 1 in Princeton.

title: W.H.O. UNDERLINES AIDS THREAT
description: The public health gains being achieved by the World Health Organization in such fields as malaria control, child vaccination and health care facilities in developing countries may be undone by the rapid spread of AIDS, according to Dr. Jonathan M. Mann, who heads the organization's program of AIDS control.

title: Gelco Ruling On Buyback
description: The Gelco Corporation can proceed with its plan to repurchase up to 6 million shares of its common stock, or 46 percent of the company, a Federal District Court in St. Paul ruled on Friday.

title: Advertising; Wells, Rich Unit Sells Emotion
description: THE management of Wells, Rich, Greene Worldwide knows that the future belongs to the sizzle, not the steak, and is rushing to meet it.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SALVADOR REBEL DEFENDS THE USE OF LAND MINES
description: A Salvadoran guerrilla leader today defended the insurgents' use of land mines, saying they had proved to be an effective weapon against Government forces.

title: BACK TO ENVIRONMENTALISM
description: Last week's elections demonstrated that the environmental movement as a political force in the United States has come of age.

title: Market Place; More Retail Linkups Seen
description: AS the dust settles on the $3.6 billion merger between the Campeau Corporation and the Allied Stores Corporation, one of the largest retailers in the United States, investment bankers, analysts and merchants are asking, ''Who's next?''

title: AQUINO INSTRUCTS MILITARY TO BLOCK ANY COUP ATTEMPT
description: President Corazon C. Aquino announced Sunday that she had instructed the military to block any attempt at a coup while she is seeking financial aid in Japan and called on the people to take to the streets in her defense if necessary.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 27 about an engineering company that specializes in underground construction incorrectly described a historic source and method of distribution for water in New York City. Wooden mains distributed water in Manhattan in the early years of the city, and an aqueduct brought water from Nassau County into Queens and Brooklyn, but the two systems were never connected.

title: WESTCHESTER EMBROILED IN GARBAGE-FEES BATTLE
description: The increases started over the summer. They were large, but not large enough to drive anyone out of business.

title: 100TH CONGRESS LIKELY TO TAKE UP NEW APPROACHES TO FARMING CRISIS
description: Severe restrictions on how much grain farmers can grow and more aggressive sales of American farm products overseas will be pushed by newly elected members of the Senate and Congressional leaders from rural states when Congress reconvenes next year.

title: INSIDE
description: Egypt's Premier Dismissed Prime Minister Ali Lutfi of Egypt, who had failed to straighten out the economy, was replaced by Dr. Atef Sedki, another economist.

title: DR. FRED OLSEN, INDUSTRIAL CHEMIST, ART COLLECTOR AND SCHOLAR, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Fred Olsen, a leading industrial chemist who helped revolutionize the manufacture of gunpowder in World War II and went on to become a noted art collector and student of the pre-Columbian Arawak people, died Nov. 2 at his home in Guilford, Conn. He was 95 years old.

title: Nuclear Woes Bring Shifts at Gulf States
description: The Gulf States Utilities Company has realigned its management to cope with the enormous regulatory and financial difficulties that have beset the company because of its River Bend 1 nuclear plant.

title: Sinatra Undergoes Intestine Surgery
description: Frank Sinatra underwent nearly two hours of surgery today for an inflammation of the large intestine that forced him to cancel an engagement in Atlantic City and return home, a spokesman said.

title: Accounts
description: * The Standard Oil Company, Cleveland, to Wyse Advertising, for corporate advertising.

title: MONTANA RETURNS WITH STYLE
description: With his surgeon watching closely from the sidelines and a near-capacity crowd in Candlestick Park cheering his every move, Joe Montana returned to work today.

title: LAWYER SAYS FRIEDMAN MAY TESTIFY FOR DEFENSE
description: The lawyer for Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, said yesterday that he was ''leaning in favor of calling'' his client to the stand in his own defense in the Federal trial stemming from New York City's corruption scandal.

title: U.S. SHIPPED HEAVY WATER TO ISRAEL
description: Israel received four metric tons of heavy water from the United States in 1963, just as Israel began to operate a nuclear reactor where it is suspected of having produced materials for nuclear weapons, according to a report based on Government documents.

title: SHULTZ EXAMINING HOW TO KEEP SYRIA FROM TERROR ROLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz conferred at his home today with key State Department aides to discuss what further steps the Reagan Administration might take to discourage Syria's involvement in terrorist activities.

title: Books: Plains Geology
description: RISING FROM THE PLAINS. By John McPhee. 214 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95. It would almost be unfair to make notes while reading one of John McPhee's fascinating books that explore some out-of-the-way corner of the American landscape and its inhabitants. They are comparable to Joseph Mitchell's model writing on the Mohawk Indians or the bottom of New York Harbor or any other subject that he has mined for nuggets of information. Among professional writers, there is an added pleasure in watching how authors in their class construct their factual narratives. By covering New York and America like some foreign country, they set a very high standard of originality for writers and readers.

title: STAGE: 'MUMMY'S TOMB'
description: AMONG the mysterious ingredients of ''Murder in the Mummy's Tomb'' are the accents. They are mighty slippery. A couple of allegedly English accents have never crossed the Atlantic. A couple of allegedly German accents are straight out of Weber and Fields. And there's an allegedly Egyptian accent that can have been produced only by the consorting of a World War II movie's Japanese villain with a waiter in a dairy restaurant.

title: Mormon Leader Recuperates
description: Ezra Taft Benson, the president of the Mormon Church, has been released from a hospital after surgery to implant a pacemaker, a church spokesman said. The 87-year-old Mr. Benson, who was released Friday, was ''doing fine,'' said the spokesman, Jerry Cahill. Mr. Benson became president of the Mormon Church, its 13th, on Nov. 10, 1985, following the death of Spencer W. Kimball, who was 90.

title: O'BRIEN BURNS ATLANTA
description: Throwing short, throwing long, throwing across the field or to the sidelines, the Jets' Ken O'Brien flirted with two National Football League records today. They were about the only things he failed to achieve in another glittering victory.

title: JAPAN'S NEW COAL POLICY SEEN AS DEATH BLOW FOR THE INDUSTRY
description: When it was announced recently that the Takashima coal mine would be closed, the news took on a significance far beyond the loss of more than 1,000 jobs.

title: Semiconductor Layoffs
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it would reduce its worldwide work force by 500 employees over the next few months.

title: Send a Language Corps To Embassy in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Galli Associates
description: Anthony P. Galli, who set up a public relations office of Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt in Princeton, N.J., earlier this year, has spun it off from the corporation. It will be known as Galli Associates, and Galli is keeping his previous clients. All was done in a civilized and amicable manner, he said.

title: Cindy Forman and Eric Weissler, Attorneys, Wed
description: The marriage of Cindy Forman, an associate at the New York law firm Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, to Eric C. Weissler, an associate at the New York law firm Loeb & Loeb & Hess, took place yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Mark Golub performed the ceremony.

title: Al Unser Jr. Wins; Rahal Takes Title
description: Al Unser Jr. took the lead when Roberto Guerrero ran out of fuel on the final lap of the season-ending Nissan Indy Challenge here today, while Bobby Rahal clinched the Indy-car season championship.

title: Fela Anikulapo Kuti's Afro-Beat
description: FELA ANIKULAPO KUTI, the dissident Nigerian songwriter and band leader, gave a triumphant concert Saturday night at the Felt Forum. It was his first New York show since 1970 and the first New York appearance of his band, Egypt 80 - 20 musicians, 4 backup singers and 6 dancers. It was also proof that 18 months in a Nigerian prison, on charges that were later dismissed, had not stopped Mr. Kuti or his music. (Mr. Kuti was arrested Sept. 4, 1984, as he and the band were leaving for an American tour; he was released this April.) As outspoken and defiant as ever -he even performed past the 11 P.M. curfew imposed by union overtime fees - Mr. Kuti gave his music a hard-edged authority. He is a charismatic, eccentric performer, part musician and part public figure; between songs, he casually addressed the audience as ''man'' while underlining the messages in his lyrics. He is also, at the age of 48, a taut, well-muscled, almost feline dancer.

title: Glenpatrick Water
description: Perrier, watch out. Daniel O'Brien, president of Glenpatrick Products of the Bronx, has started importing Glenpatrick Springs Pure Irish Water from Clonmel in County Tipperary.

title: FOREIGN RIVALS WORRY PAPER COMPANIES
description: Executives of American paper companies remain cautious about the outlook for an industry they contend is still threatened by a high level of imports in some product lines and worldwide overcapacity in other areas.

title: New Pressures Against Chile
description: In late 1984, Congress directed the Office of the United States Trade Representative to weigh the labor policies of all developing countries in granting them duty-free privileges under the Generalized System of Preferences.

title: Don't Expect Iran to Woo 'Satan'
description: The Iranian Government, facing grave difficulties at home, has had obvious reasons to seek a deal - but a strictly limited one - with the United States.

title: U.S. Admiral Has China Talks
description: Adm. J. A. Lyons, commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, met today in Peking with Defense Minister Zhang Aiping as part of the Navy's port call to China, the official New China News Agency said. The port call at Qingdao by three American warships is the first to China since 1949, when the Communists took power.

title: WARD, DEFENDING TRANSFERS, CALLS SOME OFFICERS 'BANDITS'
description: Asking for a moment of silence for a police officer who apparently took his own life and later calling Brooklyn officers charged with corruption ''bandits,'' Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday pledged to invoke harsh measures against officers who stage job actions in response to new anti-corruption measures.

title: FROM POLITICS BARELY A PAUSE: CANDIDATES ALREADY LIVING '88
description: Welcome to the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: Melissa Turner Weds V.W. Goett
description: Melissa Anne Turner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick L. Turner of New York, Sands Point, L.I., and Treasure Cay, the Bahamas, was married yesterday to Vincent William Goett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary Goett of Paradise Valley, Ariz., and Calgary, Alberta. The Rev. Andrew Jenks performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Maria Goretti Church in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Wincenc, Flutist, And Lehwalder, Harpist
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has several rooms appropriate for concerts and, on Friday night, Carol Wincenc and Heidi Lehwalder chose a pleasing, resonant one to play a program of music for flute and harp.

title: ISLANDERS WIN FIRST ON ROAD
description: The Islanders divested themselves of the heavy burden of losing on the road with a 4-3 victory over the Sabres tonight for their first victory of the season away from home.

title: Brazilian Stock Fund
description: The Brazilian Securities and Exchange Commission approved on Friday the creation of a Brazil fund through which foreign investors will be able to buy stocks in Brazilian companies, according to the commission's president, Luiz Octavio da Motta Veiga. The fund is expected to attract $100 million to $200 million and is scheduled to start operating in four months. Mr. Motta Veiga described the fund as ''the first step towards the internationalization of the Brazilian market.'' He said the next step would be for leading Brazilian companies to be quoted on the London stock market, which he expected to happen toward the end of next year.

title: ASIAN-AMERICANS PRESS TO GAIN POLITICAL POWER
description: Asian-Americans, California's fastest-growing ethnic minority, are starting to assert themselves in an effort to gain political power proportionate to their rising population.

title: DANCE: THOMAS MARTONE
description: THOMAS MARTONE danced his first three solos to pop music by Oregon, Steve Winnward and Weather Report, in a program of dances performed on Friday night at St. Marks Church. Audience members were invited to provide their own music for the fourth and last solo.

title: 'OLD STOMPING GROUNDS' SUIT THIS EISENHOWER
description: She calls it ''my old stomping grounds.'' And like many who have seen Washington first-hand, from the inside, and then moved away, she has found it difficult to stay away.

title: Argerich Cancels Recital
description: The pianist Martha Argerich has canceled her Nov. 30 Avery Fisher Hall recital and the balance of her concert schedule for the 1986-87 season, Lincoln Center has announced.

title: PANEL ON EDUCATION URGES RISE IN COLLEGE-EDUCATED
description: A national commission headed by former Education Secretary Terrel H. Bell called today for an effort to nearly double the number of college-educated adults by the turn of the century.

title: APPEARANCE MEETS REALITY AT THE ASTOR PLACE SUBWAY STATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Repairs Are to Begin On Bridge Over I-84
description: Repairs are to begin Monday on a bridge over Interstate 84 that was ordered closed after a half-inch-wide crack was found in a steel support, according to state transportation officials.

title: Old School, New Museum
description: Washington gets a new museum today when the 114-year-old Charles Sumner School, five blocks north of the White House, is dedicated by District of Columbia officials as a public education museum. The school, named for the abolitionist Senator from Massachusetts, was the scene of the first high school graduation of black students in the district in 1877. Its many possessions include first-edition McGuffey Readers and minutes noting the election of Thomas Jefferson in 1804 as the first president of the Board of Trustees of Public Schools of Washington and Georgetown.

title: Helms vs. Lugar
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the outspoken conservative from North Carolina, has roused some consternation among Republican colleagues on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by threatening to reassert his seniority rights in the next Congress and depose Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the panel for the last two years, as senior committee Republican.

title: What Price Fame?
description: Celebrity can cut two ways, of course, and according to his attorney, it cut against Joe Pepitone last month when the former Yankee was sentenced to six months in jail for two misdemeanors: possession of Quaaludes and of drug paraphernalia.

title: Bowie's Season Apparently Over
description: Sam Bowie, the Portland Trail Blazers' center, will undergo surgery on his right leg and will probably miss the rest of the season.

title: YEN'S RISE FORCING TOYOTA TO TRIM SALES
description: Top executives of Japan's largest automobile company are responding to the rapid increase in the strength of the yen with a program their American counterparts might recognize: an attack on overhead and an appeal for Government help.

title: INDIA ARRESTS SEVERAL TOP LEADERS OF SRI LANKA SEPARATIST GUERRILLAS
