description: In a major rebuff to Tamil separatist insurgents in Sri Lanka, India placed several top Tamil guerrilla leaders under house arrest today at their base of operations in the southern Indian city of Madras.

title: An Offshore Solution for Nuclear Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: COGHLAN TRIUMPHS
description: Eamonn Coghlan, representing the New York Athletic Club, yesterday won the Metropolitan Athletics Congress senior cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park. Coghlan, an Irishman who now lives in Rye, N.Y., overtook John Crooke of Nazareth, Pa., with a half mile remaining in the 6.2-mile race and won in 33 minutes 7 seconds. Crooke finished 20 yards behind in 33:12.

title: 2 WINNING TICKETS SOLD FOR $24 MILLION JACKPOT
description: Money may not be everything, but it is about to become a big part of the lives of at least two people and possibly their tax advisers.

title: Baltimore Agency Gets Home Loan Account
description: The Earle Palmer Brown agency in Baltimore has been named to do advertising for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The corporation's former agency was J. Walter Thompson, Washington.

title: Lovestruck
description: Last week a 700-pound moose, made restless by the mating season, strolled into a pasture in Shrewsbury, Vt., where he found a red and white cow named Jessica. He also found love.

title: BALLET: A TRIBUTE TO DENISE JACKSON
description: DENISE JACKSON, a dancer whose stage presence has been blessed with an especially gracious manner, has decided to retire. She became a member of the Joffrey Ballet in 1969 and until this weekend was the only remaining dancer in the company who had joined before the 1970's.

title: ADMIRERS GATHER IN A TRIBUTE TO GOODMAN, KING OF SWING
description: ''It began with Benny Goodman,'' the musical historian George T. Simon wrote in ''The Big Bands,'' his definitive history of the swing era. ''He and his clarinet created a kind of identity that hadn't existed before, providing an aura of glamour and personality and excitingly superb musicianship that set the mood and the pace for a dozen glorious years.''

title: Cuomo's Turn
description: Mario Cuomo won 65 percent of the votes in New York, but his campaign drew much criticism. Mean and selfish, I called it in a column after the election. That comment brought a telephone call from Governor Cuomo.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: English Yes, Xenophobia No
description: English is now the official language of California, so mandated last week by an overwhelming majority of the state's voters. It's a worthy goal, but there's danger that it will be pursued in an unworthy way.

title: Drop Seen In Business Donations
description: Charitable contributions from American companies are likely to decline in 1986, the first such drop in 16 years. Moreover, a number of leaders in corporate giving say the downward trend is likely to continue.

title: EUROPEANS WILL MEET TODAY ON SYRIA
description: Two weeks after it failed to get agreement from its European partners on a set of measures against Syria, Britain will try again Monday at a meeting here of the 12 Foreign Ministers of the European Community.

title: Fetal-Rights Case Attacks Civil Liberties of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: POLES TAKE NOTE OF HUNGARY'S REVOLT
description: About 500 people gathered at a Roman Catholic church in this Warsaw suburb today to mark the 30th anniversary of the Hungarian uprising with a mass and a ceremony that was much more passionately outspoken than any Hungarian observance of the revolt.

title: Mother Charged In Baby's Death
description: A 20-year-old woman was charged with throwing her newborn son to his death from a second-floor window, the police said yesterday.

title: For G.O.P., a Committee Jinx
description: It is beginning to look as if the Republicans are jinxed with respect to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. There has been only one Republican chairman since the early 1950's, Roger W. Jepsen, and Iowa's voters promptly turned him out of the Senate when he sought re-election in 1984.

title: PRACTICES CITED IN SEATTLE REBUKE ARE COMMON IN U.S. CATHOLICISM
description: Many practices for which Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen of Seattle was reprimanded by the Vatican are common across the United States, Roman Catholic officials say.

title: MARKETS OPEN TUESDAY
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be open as usual tomorrow. However, many banks, government agencies and some businesses will be closed in observance of Veterans Day.

title: Mississippi Double-Team
description: At various times in Washington history, more or less by chance, a single state has suddenly found itself in a position of great influence when two or more of its politicians win major elections or move into powerful Congressional posts. This happened to Masssachusetts when John F. Kennedy was President and John W. McCormack was Speaker of the House and to Texas when Lyndon B. Johnson was Senate majority leader and Sam Rayburn was Speaker.

title: OPEC Panel Meeting
description: Ecuador has offered to be the site of a meeting of an OPEC price-fixing committee, Fernando Santos Alvite, the Deputy Energy and Mines Minister, said today. The official Kuwaiti news agency, Kuna, earlier had quoted the Kuwaiti oil minister as saying the committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was scheduled to meet by the end of this week in Ecuador. Mr. Santos Alvite said of the report: ''They apparently have accepted our proposal.'' He said the meeting was scheduled for Nov. 14-15.

title: Two More Bodies Recovered From Shetland Islands Crash
description: Divers recovered two more bodies and searched in stormy weather today for the missing rear section of a Chinook helicopter that crashed in the North Sea, killing 45 people.

title: TV SUBJECTS SHARE LIVES WITH MIXED FEELINGS
description: Real people whose stories have been told in television docudramas often have little to do with the production of the films. But in two new movies to be shown this week - ''Unnatural Causes,'' tonight on NBC, and ''The George McKenna Story,'' tomorrow on CBS - the people who inspired the films had a close, ongoing involvement with the productions. They were in the unusual position of being collaborators in television versions of their life stories, and they have some mixed feelings about the experience.

title: PROSECUTOR FINDS POLICE CASES HARD, BUT NEEDED
description: Long before the corruption scandal broke in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, Charles J. Hynes traveled to 73 station houses in nine months, encouraging police officers to report abuses and assuring them that they were not being singled out for attack.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: WITH OBSESSIVE DETERMINATION, SEOUL SETS THE STAGE
description: AFTER two relentless years, the outdoor electric sign near City Hall no longer flashes the number of days left until the Asian Games. That quadrennial event finally came, then decorously went, in early October.

title: Washington Watch; The Geography Of Trade Woes
description: THE failure of the currencies of Canada and the newly industrialized countries of Asia and Latin America to rise against the dollar is causing heightened concern about the durability of any improvement in the trade deficit.

title: SALT II Deserves to Live
description: Tomorrow is Veterans Day, honoring those who died in one of the most senseless conflicts in modern history, World War I. This year, there may be one more senseless death to mourn - that of the SALT II treaty.

title: Treasury's Audit Option Threatens Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Financings Limited to Bill Sale
description: Today's regular weekly auction of Treasury bills is the only government sale scheduled this week, leaving government securities dealers free to concentrate on distributing the $29 billion of notes and bonds auctioned last week.

title: McEnroe Takes Five-Set Final
description: John McEnroe defeated Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia in five sets today to win the $940,000 European Community Championship.

title: Goodyear Chief's Moves 'Painful and Difficult'
description: Long careers are the rule at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. Robert E. Mercer, chairman and chief executive, has been there almost 40 years. The waters have been far from placid but nothing like the roiling sea that has erupted since Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French investor who holds 11.5 percent of Goodyear's stock, moved to gain control of the company.

title: WHAT THE BIG BOYS DO
description: WHEN the basketball coach at Erie Community College in Buffalo was discovered recently to have helped along the eligibility of some players by tampering with their recorded grades, he had a ready answer. He was doing it for them.

title: Chicago Is Canceling Its Datacom Contract
description: The city has canceled its $8 million contract with a scandal-tinged bill-collection company and will take over the handling of overdue parking tickets itself, city officials said.

title: LAKERS DESTROY KNICKS, 111-88
description: At last, something good can be said about the Knicks' arduous excursion through the western regions. It's over.

title: BRITISH RIDERS WIN TEAM TITLE
description: The British equestrian team slipped past the United States and claimed the international team championship yesterday on the final day of competition at the 103d National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. The British managed it in understated fashion, as the four riders actually won only one of the nine classes that counted toward the award.

title: CANADA'S ALICE MUNRO FINDS EXCITEMENT IN SHORT-STORY FORM
description: ''I never intended to be a short-story writer,'' says Alice Munro, leaning back and laughing in a chair in her publisher's office. ''I started writing them because I didn't have time to write anything else - I had three children. And then I got used to writing stories, so I saw my material that way, and now I don't think I'll ever write a novel.''

title: America II Stays In Tie for Lead
description: America II and New Zealand scored easy second-round victories in the America's Cup challengers' series today and remained tied for the lead.

title: Mattel Expects '86 Profit Drop
description: Mattel Inc., the world's second-largest toy company, after Hasbro Inc., said Friday that it expected 1986 profits to be significantly lower than last year's, largely because of lower demand in the United States and a higher-than-normal effective tax rate.

title: Catching Up
description: * Jocks 3, Opponents 3. That's how it went in the political arena last week. If you missed the Election Day results, the returns were these: The three sports-figure winners were Jack Kemp, the erstwhile quarterback whom the voters of upstate New York's 31st Congressional District sent back to Washington; the old right-hander Jim Bunning, another Republican, who'll join Kemp there as a rookie Congressman from Kentucky, and Tom McMillen, the former pro basketball player, a Democrat whose first-time Congressional race in Maryland was so tight that he wasn't declared the victor until two days after the voting.

title: Outdoors; Bird-Hunting Etiquette
description: THERE'S no time for indecision in ruffed grouse and woodcock hunting, nor is there much opportunity for the courtesies of the duck blind.

title: G.M.'S CUTS REFLECT A LONG-TERM TREND
description: When the General Motors Corporation said last week that it would close 11 plants, affecting 29,000 workers, industry analysts noted that the world's largest auto company had plenty of worries, such as high per-car production costs and declining consumer enthusiasm for its products.

title: EGYPT REPLACES PREMIER OVER FAILURE TO SOLVE ECONOMIC PROBLEMS
description: Prime Minister Ali Lutfi was dismissed today after failing in his mandate to straighten out Egypt's chronically troubled economy.

title: Man Kills Wife And Himself
description: A 45-year-old Queens man shot and killed his wife in their apartment during a marital dispute yesterday, and then fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: Merrie Davis Becomes Bride
description: Merrie L. Davis, a daughter of Jeanette Richards of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Eugene B. Davis, was married yesterday to Fred L. Goodman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol S. Goodman of Wilmington, Del.

title: 3 Chicagoans Slain at Party
description: Gunmen who burst into a birthday party here killed three guests and wounded another Saturday night.

title: RANGERS BEATEN BY NORDIQUES, 6-5
description: Perhaps this would be a bright night for the Rangers, the night they would come from behind and ward off the talk of dismissals and trades. They seemed about to finish what would have been their finest weekend of the season.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC MEMBERS IN SOLOS
description: MOST major orchestras have some sort of ''Members' Night'' occasionally, in which regular players step out of the band to stand in the soloist's spotlight. Usually, as was the case in the New York Philharmonic's current brace of concerts, such programs are also an occasion for hearing little-known, offbeat items from the concerto repertory.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Little Red Raider
description: When Tyrone Thurman was a little guy - well, a littler guy - back in Midland, Tex., he learned about somebody he just had to see. ''This young lady,'' he recalls, ''told me there was this dude at Midland Junior College who was 5 foot 6 and could do a 360-degree slam dunk.''

title: KODAK MAY CUT STAFF
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which recently announced that an increase in profits was the result of a cost-cutting program, said Friday that it might make additional staff cuts. Kodak recently reported that its third-quarter profits increased by 6.9 percent, to $263 million, on a 7.8 percent rise in sales, to $3.48 billion.

title: Cholera Causes Warning On Crab and Shrimp
description: Federal health officials, concerned over 13 cases of cholera on the Gulf Coast, have urged that crabs and shrimp be cooked thoroughly to eliminate any contamination.

title: Wickes Plans Collins Offer
description: The Wickes Companies plans to begin a cash offer of $53 a share, or a total of about $1.16 billion, for the Collins & Aikman Corporation, a manufacturer of industrial and automotive fabrics and specialty products based in New York City.

title: Required Reading
description: Dealing With Moscow Excerpts from ''Grappling with the Bear: A Strategy for Dealing with Moscow,'' an article by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, in the fall issue of Policy Review, a magazine published by the Heritage Foundation:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1986
description: Companies

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Wade Boggs won the American League batting title this season while sitting out the final weekend with an injury, it reminded me of a similar situation that confronted another great left-handed-hitting Red Sox player, Ted Williams. What were the circumstances then? That situation occurred in 1941 and was a bit different because Williams, who already had the batting title locked up by more than 40 percentage points, was shooting to preserve a .400 batting average, and the only injury he faced would have been to his pride. After Williams went 1 for 4 on the next-to-last day of the season, dropping his average from .4009 to .39955, Manager Joe Cronin of the Red Sox offered to bench him for the season-ending doubleheader in Philadelphia so Williams could finish with an average that would be acceptable as .400 after being rounded off.

title: Iraqi Planes Reportedly Hit 2 Tankers in the Persian Gulf
description: Iraqi warplanes attacked two supertankers in the Persian Gulf today, shipping sources said.

title: Jill S. Pershan Is Bride Of Royce Adam Levien
description: At Temple Emunah in Lexington, Mass., yesterday Jill Stacey Pershan, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Peter S. Pershan of Lexington, was married to Royce Adam Levien, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Roger Levien of Weston, Conn.

title: NAVRATILOVA IN FINAL
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova battled back in a second-set tie-breaker to gain a 3-6, 7-6, 6-4 semifinal triumph over Pam Shriver tonight in the Virginia Slims of New England tournament.

title: WASHINGTON TIMES PUBLISHES TRANSCRIPT OF CHIRAC REMARKS
description: The Washington Times today published what it said was a full transcript of an interview conducted by its editor in chief with the French Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, which has become the subject of controversy.

title: CREDIT MARKETS JOLTED BY FEDERAL MONETARY SUMMARY
description: The credit markets, already reeling from a heavy supply of new Treasury securities, were jolted late Friday by a reminder that Federal Reserve monetary policy is a two-edged sword that can send interest rates higher as well as lower.

title: KHOMEINI DISCOUNTS REPORT ON STRIFE
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, brushing aside reports of a power struggle among his followers, said today that his Islamic revolution was entrenched in Iran.

title: Canadas Alice Munro Finds Excitement in Short-Story Form
description: "I never intended to be a short-story writer,'' says Alice Munro, leaning back and laughing in a chair in her publisher's office. ''I started writing them because I didn't have time to write anything else - I had three children. And then I got used to writing stories, so I saw my material that way, and now I don't think I'll ever write a novel.''

title: A Show of Strength
description: Now that the fall elections are over, the tempo is picking up in the Presidential arena. Today, according to Republican Congressional sources, five of New Hampshire's 10 Republican county chairmen will endorse Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York. Under party rules, sitting chairmen cannot endorse a primary candidate, so all five will first resign their party posts to emphasize their strong Kemp support.

title: Barbara Ann Kessler Is Married to a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Barbara Ann Kessler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kessler of Freeport, L.I., to Lawrence William Koltun, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Koltun of New Orleans, took place yesterday at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi Sam Glaser officiated.

title: Vienna Schubert Trio At Symphony Space
description: The Vienna Schubert Trio's Wednesday evening concert at the Symphony Space was first class. Throughout the evening, one felt the influence of many hours of rehearsal, yet the playing was never merely learned.

title: HAMBURG VOTERS DEAL BLOW TO SOCIALITS
description: In a stunning reverse three months before national elections, the Social Democratic Party lost its clear majority of parliamentary seats and its position as the biggest party in the city-state of Hamburg.

title: AGENDA: NOV. 10, 1986
description: Summing Up in Trial on Mafia

title: HOCKEY'S TURMOIL PUT ASIDE, BECK IS PURSUING A NEW LIFE
description: BARRY BECK leaned his burly shoulders against the curved slats of the cedar hot tub. The sun was sinking behind the mountains, and the evening ferries were gliding in and out of the slip at Horseshoe Bay. His bull terrier puppy, Dino, was slapping his tail against the deck facing the inland sea. The air smelled like pine trees.

title: New Roman Catholic Hymnal Aimed at Black Parishioners
description: A new Roman Catholic hymnal aimed at making worship services and music more meaningful to black parishioners will be published early next year, church officials say.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Our organization has the full right to sink the whalers because Iceland is violating the moratorium.''

title: LEFTIST FILIPINOS VOW TO FIGHT COUP
description: As tensions in Manila continue to rise despite the efforts of President Corazon C. Aquino to put an end to persistent rumors of an impending coup, left-wing groups say they are preparing to take to the streets to thwart the military if necessary.

title: ROSE BOWL AT LAST FOR ARIZONA STATE
description: Most of the Arizona State players had been there before, in position to go to the Rose Bowl if they won their last game, only to lose the game. So they were not too excited when the Sun Devils' offensive coordinator, Jim Colletto, entered the locker room early Saturday night to announce that Stanford had just upset U.C.L.A., 28-23.

title: SUFFOLK POLITICIANS BRACE FOR BATTLE ON EXECUTIVE
description: In the days after the Nov. 4 elections, Suffolk County politicians have begun to brace themselves for what could be an impassioned struggle to select a new county executive.

title: ELECTIONS IN PERU BOLSTER PRESIDENT
description: The governing left-of-center party scored a solid victory today in municipal elections across Peru. The results were interpreted as a vote of confidence in President Alan Garcia.

title: 4 Shot, 2 Fatally, As Party Ends
description: Two men were killed and two others were seriously wounded early yesterday when shooting erupted at the end of a birthday party in a restaurant in Flushing, Queens, the police said.

title: Mary C. Lenio Is the Bride Of Andrew Edwin Schnog
description: Mary Catherine Lenio and Andrew Edwin Schnog were married yesterday at Anthony's Pier 9 in Newburgh, N.Y. Msgr. Robert E. Moore and Rabbi Charles Davidson officiated at the interfaith ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. John Lenio of Wallkill, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Schnog of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Doubt on Deal by DeLorean
description: A key witness in the Federal racketeering trial of John DeLorean presented evidence that cast doubt on a purported loan agreement that is critical to the former auto maker's defense.

title: LAZAR FIRM SAID TO FILE FALSE PAPER
description: A real-estate development firm in which Michael J. Lazar was a partner submitted an apparently fictitious document to Federal, state and city agencies that cleared the way for permanent public financing of a $6.8 million apartment building in Brooklyn, according to governmental records.

title: FROM SIDELINE TO SPOTLIGHT
description: Elvis Patterson sat on a wooden stool in front of his stall at Veterans Stadium, slowly unwrapping what seemed to be miles of tape and bandage.

title: Mobil Gasoline Pullback
description: The Mobil Corporation said Friday that it was withdrawing from the sale of gasoline and diesel fuel in all or parts of seven states because the operations were not profitable.

title: Karen Akers Performs At the Ballroom
description: Karen Akers is not resting on her laurels as a cabaret singer. Despite all the acclaim that she has received in recent years, she has managed to bring just a bit more finesse to her current performance at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, where she is singing through Saturday.

title: Child and Couple Beaten to Death
description: A couple and their 13-year-old grandson were found beaten to death last night in their apartment in the Tompkins Park section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Jill B. Freeman Is Married To Thomas David Gottlieb
description: Jill Beth Freeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Freeman of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas David Gottlieb, a son of Bobbie Gottlieb-Marcus of Rye, N.Y., and the late Robert Gottlieb.

title: A Second Reactor Is Restarted at Chernobyl
description: A second Chernobyl reactor shut down after the nuclear plant's disaster has been restarted for tests, Soviet press organizations reported today.

title: Topics: National Pastimes; McMoscow
description: A Pizza Hut on the banks of the Neva? Golden arches before the Kremlin's gleaming domes? Maybe so. Pepsico Inc. is negotiating a deal that could put 100 Pizza Huts in the Soviet Union.

title: Dutch Close Canals To Block Rhine Pollution
description: Dutch engineers closed sluices and locks today to protect the country's extensive inland waterways from contamination by toxic waste flowing down the River Rhine after a spillage at a Swiss chemical plant.

title: WEDTECH SAYS U.S. AGENCY RULED OUT FORGERY PENALTY
description: Officials of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that has admitted falsifying $6 million in Government invoices, said yesterday that the Defense Department met with the company's auditors in 1983 and assured them that it would not penalize the company for the forgeries.

title: DENVER OFFICIALS TAKE AIM AT THE AIR
description: After a year of study and debate, local officials are putting the finishing touches on proposals constituting the most concerted planning effort yet to deal with Denver's notorious air pollution problems.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Calendar of Events in The Home Section on Thursday gave incorrect hours for the Val Cushing exhibition at the Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, in Greenwich Village. The correct hours are 1 to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays until Nov. 22.

title: City to Prepare Plan for Addicts
description: The city's Health Commissioner said yesterday that his department had been given approval by state health officials to develop a proposal for distributing clean needles to intravenous drug addicts on a limited basis to reduce the spread of AIDS.

title: Bobby Nunn, 61, Dies; Member of the Coasters
description: Bobby Nunn, a founding member of the doo-wop group the Coasters, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 61 years old.

title: Before the Frost
description: November is hurry-up time for dutiful gardeners. Hurry up and get those tulips in the ground, the garden advisers command, so they can start growing roots.

title: 3d Elections Board Approves North Carolina Race Results
description: A third county elections board certified the re-election of Representative Howard Coble, a Republican, to the House, sending the matter to the North Carolina Board of Elections.

title: CHARGERS STUN BRONCOS, 9-3
description: Rolf Benirschke kicked three field goals and Jeffrey Dale intercepted two John Elway passes deep in San Diego territory, sparking the Chargers to a 9-3 victory over the Denver Broncos today.

title: Bond Sales Rise Again
description: Sales of U.S. savings bonds totaled $1.39 billion in October, the highest amount since the end of World War II, the Government reported Friday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAUS: A Survivor's Tale. By Art Spiegelman. Illustrated. 159 pages. Pantheon. Paper, $8.95. ART SPIEGELMAN'S ''Maus:

title: Recipient of Artificial Heart Returns to His Factory Job
description: Thomas Gaidosh, who received an artificial heart a year ago and then had a human heart transplant, is back on the job driving a forklift.

title: Grace & Rothschild Has Hospital Account
description: Grace & Rothschild's fourth account is Mount Sinai Hospital of New York City, which will soon be getting the first multi-media advertising campaign in its 134-year history.

title: STUDENTS PLAN 'SAFE SOCIALS'
description: Instead of hanging out at bars, on street corners or the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on weekends and evenings, the students who attend preparatory schools in New York City may soon be taking boat rides, holding parties and film festivals and going on ski trips. These activities would be organized by members of the schools, which are attended by about 10,000 students in the 8th through 12th grades. Their parents would be asked to provide financial help and social resources.

title: BUSINESS GROWTH ON HIGHWAYS AROUSES FEAR OF CHAOS IN JERSEY
description: The state of New Jersey, flush with economic growth, is emerging as the nation's most important center of ''growth corridors,'' in which business expansion is inextricably tied to the Interstate highway system, according to urban planners and government officials.

title: U.S. STEPS UP STUDY OF TREASURY MARKET TRADING
description: The Justice Department is escalating its investigation into possible violations of antitrust law stemming from the exclusive trading arrangements in the Treasury market between government securities dealers and a handful of brokering firms, industry sources said.

title: THE ELECTION OVER, CHICAGO AWAITS 'THE' ELECTION
description: Now that they have finished with those races for obscure offices like Governor and United States Senator, Chicago's politicians and voters are getting down to what is regarded locally as really important: the struggle for the Mayor's office.

title: FLIGHT INSURANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture on Oct. 11 in Column One (Stories of the City), with a report about the visit of Winston Churchill's daughter, Lady Soames, to her grandmother's Brooklyn birthplace, was identified incompletely. She was shown at Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School, where she presented a statue of her father.

title: New Soviet Song on Human Rights
description: Listen: There's a new Soviet refrain on human rights emanating from the conference in Vienna to review compliance with the Helsinki accords. Sure, there's a problem for people who want to leave, says Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, but it's a trifling bureaucratic matter - and in fact we're issuing some new regulations. Besides, human rights is a worse problem in the United States because, and this refrain isn't new, getting a job is also a human right. He therefore audaciously proposes a conference in Moscow where everybody's record can be scrutinized.

title: Timothy Sullivan, 69; A Judge in State Court
description: Timothy J. Sullivan, a State Supreme Court Justice in White Plains for the last 12 years, died of cancer Saturday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 69 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Dr. Lynne Sussman Weds Phillip Hyde
description: Dr. Lynne Sussman, an assistant professor at Worcester (Mass.) State College, and Phillip W. Hyde, the cultural planner for the Lowell Plan of the City of Lowell, Mass., were married yesterday at the Ralph Waldo Emerson Inn in Rockport, Mass., where Rabbi Neil Kominsky and the Rev. Thomas R. Smith, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: 'You've Got a Deal!'
description: ''I have heard you are a very sharp man,'' said the ingratiating Alexsandr Yakovlev, Secretary of the Communist Party's Central Committee, to Charles Wick, director of the U.S. Information Agency, as they entered into negotiations on Oct. 11 at the Saga Hotel in Reykjavik.

title: Miss Weitzner Marries A. E. Lewin, a Lawyer
description: Marina Weitzner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Weitzner of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew E. Lewin, a son of Kurt I. Lewin of New York and the late Olga Gruss Lewin. Rabbi Arnold Sher, assisted by Cantor Raymond Gilbert, performed the ceremony at the Cobb's Mill Inn in Weston, Conn.

title: I'm Sweets Surges To Win Busher
description: I'm Sweets scored her third career stakes victory in the Busher Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday and did it the same way she won the first two -surrendering the lead in midstretch and then fighting back to reassert herself in the final strides.

title: But Cars Are Cleaner
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL MIAMI DOLHINS VS. BROWNS, at Cleveland, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. SQUASH: Loews U.S. Open Women's Championship, Park Ave. Squash and Fitness Club, 3 Park Ave., finals, 6:30 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight)

title: FOOTBALL PLAYER, 17, DIES AFTER INJURY
description: Billy Rideout, a 17-year-old high school football player from Central Islip, L.I., who lapsed into a coma after suffering a head injury in a game three weeks ago, died yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown, L.I.

title: BALLET: BOSTON'S 'COPPELIA'
description: Many American ballet companies have ''Coppelia'' in their repertories. But few stagings can be as unusual as the new production that the Boston Ballet danced Saturday afternoon and evening at the Wang Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Revere Rescuer Battles To Save Takeover Bid
description: Two years ago, Revere Copper and Brass Inc. hired Hugh H. Williamson 3d to restore the company's luster. The celebrated maker of cookware and other metal products was about to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after nearly two years and was seeking a new course.

title: NBC FILM ON AGENT ORANGE DISPUTE
description: IN this country's time-honored movie tradition of the little guy doing battle with Government or corporate bureaucracies, ''Unnatural Causes'' presents the case for the Vietnam veterans who are demanding redress for their exposure to the herbicide Agent Orange. The television movie on NBC at 9 tonight makes no pretense of being a documentary. Total balance is beside the point. This is drama with a point of view, and the producers make the most of the opportunity, leaving no doubt as to who their heroes and villains are. And that is what makes ''Unnatural Causes'' riveting.

title: Phyllis Malamud Wed To Matthew Clark Jr.
description: The marriage of Phyllis Malamud, a general editor and the editor of the My Turn column of Newsweek magazine, to Matthew A. Clark Jr., a senior writer and the medicine editor of Newsweek, took place yesterday at the Players Club in New York. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony.

title: CHUCKLES: FROM RED TO BLACK
description: When Nabisco bought the Chuckles Company -maker of the familiar red, yellow, black, orange and green sugar-sprinkled candies - in 1970, the company was the leader in jellied confections.

title: 2 HOUSES AND THEIR MEMBERS: SEE HOW THEY RUN
description: Last Tuesday, 28 Senators ran for re-election, and seven of them were defeated. In the House, 391 members sought a new term, and only six definitely lost their seats. If recounts in several districts confirm these results, the re-election rate of House incumbents this year would be 98.4 percent, apparently the highest in history.

title: KANSAS TAKES ON NEW IMAGE: DAYS AT THE RACES, AND MORE
description: Having voted yes on three ''sin issues,'' Kansans will soon start going to the dogs, a lot of people here are saying, though opinions differ on whether that is good or bad.

title: Convict at Center of Dispute Hurt in California Car Wreck
description: William Archie Fain, a murderer and rapist whose release from prison in 1983 produced a statewide outcry, suffered a broken neck and other injuries in a car wreck but was in stable condition at a hospital today.

title: Contras Reportedly Kill Five In Attack at Managua Farm
description: United States-backed rebels killed five people, including two women and a child, when they attacked a farm 60 miles northeast of the capital, Nicaragua's Defense Ministry said today.

title: ISRAEL CONFIRMS IT IS HOLDING MISSING NUCLEAR TECHNICIAN
description: Israel confirmed today that it had apprehended a missing nuclear technician who sold a British newspaper what he said were the secrets of an underground Israeli atomic bomb factory in the Negev.

title: 21 Are Reported Killed In Philippine Store Fire
description: A fire raged through a department store on Mindanao island before dawn today, killing 21 people asleep inside, including the owner's three children, a military report said.

title: Andrea Dee Paradny Weds Dr. S.R. Reiter
description: Andrea Dee Paradny, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Paradny of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Stewart R. Reiter, a son of Dr. Frederick Reiter of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Dr. Dorothy Intrater Reiter. Cantor Meir Berger performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan.

title: A.T.&T.'S OLIVETTI PRESENCE.
description: When A.T.&T. bought a quarter of Europe's largest computer maker three years ago, the idea was to garner some of the skills that Ing. C. Olivetti & Company had in marketing office equipment.

title: U.S. SAYS EX-SYRACUSE MAYOR IS A SUSPECT IN AN EXTORTION SCHEME
description: For the first time, Federal prosecutors have disclosed that they suspect a former Syracuse mayor of participating in an extortion scheme and of depositing proceeds from it into foreign banks.

title: Immigrants to Be Moved To Minimum Security
description: Federal officials have announced plans to move some of the Cubans being held at the United States Penitentiary here to a minimum-security prison to prepare them for parole.

title: Reagan Names 2 to Bank Posts
description: President Reagan announced Friday that he was making two recess appointments to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, an agency that has lacked a quorum to make policy decisions for the last three weeks.

title: Common Thread
description: In less than three seasons, ''The Cosby Show'' has become an American institution. Consistently top-rated, it enabled a struggling network to vault to the top of the heap and, just this week, drew the highest price ever paid for syndicated reruns - a reported $210,000 an episode.

title: SEX EDUCATION: PUTTING THINGS IN CONTEXT
description: Family-life specialists say that more parents than ever are talking with their children about sex. But some experts say the conversations may only be superficial.

title: 2 UNEMPLOYED MEN ARE ARRESTED
description: Two unemployed men in Rochester were accused yesterday of mounting what the police there called the worst crime spree in years, a 48-hour skein of murder, robbery and arson that left five people dead and a city of 280,000 terrorized.

title: Canada to Aid Brand Drugs
description: Canadian pharmaceutical manufacturers pledged millions of dollars in new investment last Friday as a result of a Federal Government promise to act to protect brand-name drug makers from generic competition.

title: Now That's a Switch
description: When members of Citizens for America, a conservative political organization supporting President Reagan, are given a daylong briefing at the White House Thursday, one participant will be the actress Morgan Fairchild. Only last week, she appeared at a victory celebration for Senator Alan Cranston, a liberal Democrat for whom she had ardently campaigned. A Citizens for America spokesman, asked whether the actress was a conservative, said, ''She is now.''

title: Appearance Meets Reality at the Astor Place Subway Station
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Noted in Brief; Narciso Yepes Plays A Guitar Recital at Met
description: The interpretive style of Narciso Yepes and the curious 10-string guitar on which he plays share certain qualities. There was something outsized in both of them at his recital at the Metropolitan Museum Thursday night.

title: U.S. to Examine Fujitsu Deal
description: A Government group that examines foreign investments in the United States decided Friday to review the proposed sale of 80 percent of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation to Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, according to Administration officials.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PICTURE PACT Despite grave differences in other areas, the United States and the Soviet Union are actually cooperating in the field of photography, vis-a-vis, in a United Nations project.

title: CHINESE AS IT'S WRITTEN: WILDLY DIFFERENT STROKES
description: Cao Xianzhuo is worried.

title: THEATER: 'SWAN SONG,' MYSTERY AND MUSIC
description: THE idea of a backstage comedy-thriller arouses expectations that ''Swan Song'' gradually deflates - despite the efforts of Tony Tanner as director and actor. Written by John Greenwood and Jonathan Levi, ''Swan Song'' is playing its dastardly, but loaded, game at the Mazur Theater.

title: Turkey Linking Shiites To Terrorist Activities
description: Turkish authorities have linked the Islamic Holy War organization with the murder of a Jordanian diplomat here last year and possibly with the attack last September on an Istanbul synagogue.

title: AQUINO GETS JAPAN'S PLEDGE OF SUPPORT AT START OF TRIP
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines, starting a four-day visit, received a pledge from Japan today that it ''would not spare its support to the new nation-building efforts'' of her Government.

title: HUGE CHEMICAL SPILL IN THE RHINE CREATES HAVOC IN FOUR COUNTRIES
description: A huge discharge of toxic chemicals into the Rhine is confronting Europe with one of its worst ecological disasters in recent years.

title: CLOSE ASSOCIATE OF STALIN WAS 96
description: Vyacheslav M. Molotov, one of Stalin's closest aides and a member of the Soviet leadership from 1921 to 1957, died Saturday at the age of 96, the Government press agency Tass announced today.

title: CONFERENCE CONFRONTS THEATER'S TROUBLED TIMES
description: The business half of show business convened 50 miles from Times Square last weekend for the first time to address fundamental problems confronting the industry both in New York and across the country.

title: Chimps Use Plant as Drug
description: As daylight breaks over the African savanna, chimpanzees of Gombe National Park squat and grimace, rolling around in their mouths leaves of a shrub called Aspilia, a plant with apparently no nutritional value.

title: Purchases Cited In Borg-Warner
description: The Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has increased his holdings of stock in the Borg-Warner Corporation, according to Wall Street sources, who also believe that someone else may be accumulating shares in the company. Mr. Jacobs recently told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he owned 5.29 million Borg-Warner shares, or 6.1 percent of the outstanding stock.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Eugene F. Kennedy, 82, Dies; Noted Designer of Churches
description: Eugene F. Kennedy, an architect known for work on Roman Catholic schools and churches and one of the designers of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington, died Friday at New England Deaconess Hospital. He was 82 years old. Mr. Kennedy, who retired in 1984, also designed the front doors and part of the altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York and the Cathedral of Mary Our Queen in Baltimore.

title: Triple Threat
description: Jason Frost, a 205-pound junior at New Miami High School in Hamilton, Ohio, has good reason to believe that on football Saturdays two years from now, he'll be playing somewhere on scholarship.

title: U.N. Assembly Votes Anti-Pretoria Measures
description: The General Assembly today adopted eight resolutions on apartheid, including measures calling an oil embargo and mandatory sanctions against South Africa and condemning ''the continuing and increasing collaboration of Israel with the racist regime.''

title: GUARDIAN PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK ADDICTS LEAVING CITY FOR TREATMENT
description: Growing numbers of middle-class New Yorkers addicted to cocaine are showing up at private treatment centers here and in other cities around the country. Many say they traveled thousands of miles because the New York area lacked residential drug treatment they could afford.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions Sunday about the planned purchase of Collins & Aikman by the Wickes Companies misstated the per-share price. It is $53.

title: David Summers, Actor And AIDS Coalitionist
description: David Summers, an actor and cabaret singer who was active in the homosexual rights movement and in AIDS education, died as a result of acquired immune deficiency syndrome Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 34 years old.

title: CAVALIER HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $30,000.

title: TURNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1985 are restated to reflect a reduction in pension expense.

title: WERTHEIM TO STUDY OFFERS FOR LAMSTON
description: M. H. Lamston Inc., a leading variety store chain in New York City, has retained an investment bank to consider proposals from companies interested in buying the 52-year-old retailer.

title: Postmark: Utopia
description: Think Dick Vermeil misses coaching?

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bangladesh Strife Flares As Martial Law Ends
description: The Government ended four years of martial law today, but violent protests broke out against a new law preventing any legal challenge to the nation's ruler, President H. M. Ershad.

title: BROAD CHANGES IN POLICE URGED BY KOCH PANEL
description: New York City's Police Department suffers from serious management problems and should adopt a comprehensive set of changes in the way officers are recruited, trained and promoted, a special mayoral committee said yesterday.

title: TRIAL OF TWO IN THE SLAYING OF TROOPER OPENS IN JERSEY
description: State and defense attorneys gave sharply differing accounts today of the killing of a state trooper in a shootout when he stopped a car on Interstate 80 in Warren County five years ago.

title: ARGENTINA PROTESTS GENE-SPLICING TEST BY A U.S. CONCERN
description: The nation's oldest biomedical research institution said today that it participated in experiments in Argentina last summer involving field testing of genetically engineered vaccines for animals without the knowledge or approval of the Argentine or United States Governments.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEDICAL STERILIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Statesmen and Satire
description: For obvious reasons, the unmentionable weighed most on Common Market foreign ministers when they met here yesterday on terrorism. That was America's deals with Iran. If there weren't so much human and national distress involved, the Reagan White House could be accused of unfair competition with the humor columnists when it comes to satire.

title: KNICKS' STIRLING STAYS UPBEAT
description: In the wake of disheartening five-game road trip in which the Knicks lost four times and were blown away twice, Scotty Stirling, the team's general manager, said again yesterday that it was ''far too early'' to consider whether Hubie Brown and his coaching staff deserve a ''vote of confidence.''

title: Bird-Plane Collisions
description: Japan's All-Nippon Airways has discovered that by menacing-looking eyes painted on the engine intakes of its jet aircraft frighten away birds and prevent collisions.

title: BRALORNE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and because after preferred dividend requirements there are no share earnings.

description: The Defense Opens Its Case

title: Standard Oil Arranges $5.5 Billion Credit Lines
description: The Standard Oil Company said yesterday that it had arranged bank lending facilities totaling $5.5 billion with a 46-member group of foreign and domestic banks.

description: b-Net loss

title: LAURELS AT AN AUSPICIOUS TIME FOR GYORGY LIGETI
description: American critics, foundations and Government agencies understandably promote living American composers, in part because of the fixation on dead Europeans at our standard classical-music programs. But this can have the curious effect of cutting off American audiences from the latest developments in European new music.

title: Remembering Gary Hayes
description: In his relatively brief life, Gary P. Hayes had such impact on the movement to improve law enforcement practices that a dinner in his memory the other night drew speakers from a broad spectrum of American politics.

description: Following is the text, as translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press, of a statement issued by the Revolutionary Justice Organization today about French hostages it is holding:

title: Carbide Financial Chief Puts in a Busy Year
description: J. Clayton Stephenson, Union Carbide's chief financial officer, has put in a busy year. First, in January, the company financed an exchange offer that proved successful in warding off a takeover threat by the GAF Corporation. Then, last week, it announced a big recapitalization plan intended to ease some of the problems created by the exchange offer.

title: OMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEWBERY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: JASPER JOHNS PAINTING BRINGS RECORD PRICE
description: Jasper Johns's boldly colored and Expressionistic ''Out the Window,'' from 1959, was sold last night for the highest price ever paid at auction for a work by a living artist and for a post-World War II painting.

title: SWAMPLAND SUPER ODDS: 15-1
description: Shhhh. Quiet, please. The Jets and the Giants are trying not even to mention the possibility of getting to Super Bowl XXI, much less getting there together. They don't want to jinx their chances. They don't want their coaches and players looking too far ahead. Play 'em one at a time, remember. So they're downplaying the Super Bowl idea, hoping it'll happen when nobody is looking. As if that were possible.

title: LASER RECORDS RAINDROP AS BIG AS A DIME
description: FLYING above the volcanic coast of Hawaii, buffeted by a tropical storm, a team of cloud physicists armed with laser and computer has recorded what may be the largest raindrop ever measured.

title: BETA PHASE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.M. Shutdown In South Africa
description: The General Motors Corporation's South African unit closed its two Port Elizabeth plants today as a strike by 2,000 workers entered its third week and disrupted plans to introduce a new car.

title: INSIDE
description: Europe Acts Against Syria Britain won support from 10 of its 11 European Community partners for a ban on new arms sales and other measures against Syria.

title: Schools Feed Students A Diet of Junk Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Chance for Open Trade
description: In the midst of continued handwringing over the United States' trade deficit, a relatively unnoticed event offers this country at least one last chance to keep alive the goal of an open trading system. The event was the September agreement of 74 trade ministers at Punta del Este, Uruguay, to launch a new four-year round of multilateral trade negotiations - only the third in the last quarter century.

title: DEBATING USE OF S.A.T. TESTS
description: A WEEK ago, the paperback ''Cracking the System'' appeared on The New York Times list of best sellers in the ''advice and how-to'' category.

title: END OF ARMS PACT IS PUT OFF BY U.S.
description: Administration officials said today that the United States would not breach the limits of the 1979 treaty on strategic arms this week, as it had been expected to do.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credit of $598,000, or 19 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss Both latest periods' pre-tax income included a gain of $22,211,000 on the sale of the ownership interest in the Sonesta Beach Hotel and Spa in Southampton, Bermuda. The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock dividend distributed to shareholders on July 7, 1986.

title: Soviet Trade Bloc Meets in Moscow
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and Communist Party leaders from nine Soviet allied countries today held the first formal summit meeting of the Comecon trading bloc since June 1984.

OIL GROUP CITES PRICE FALL'S PERILS
description: The nation's leading oil industry association said today that, at the nation's peril, the Reagan Administration and the public were ignoring the ''serious implications'' of this year's extraordinary drop in oil prices.

title: Space Agreement Reported
description: Negotiators for the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed on 16 cooperative space ventures, including the exploration of Mars, an industry magazine says.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: WITH A FIERY PEN, BUSH PILOT FIGHTS FOR AMAZON
description: In his days as a frontier pilot, when he too exploited the Amazon, lifting rubber, amethyst and gold from the jungle, Apolonildo Brito never thought he would worry about the felling of trees or a new wave of leprosy.

title: The Monument That Is Arlington
description: It is tradition, explains Specialist Donovan L. Upchurch, one of the tall, spit-and-polish Army sentinels who guard the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery. Even the most frigid night provides no excuse for mishandling a ceremonial spin of a 9 1/2-pound M-14 rifle.

title: 543 IN TOWN HAIL ITS SON THE GOVORNER
description: Amid the drift of red and yellow leaves and the scent of chicken farms, there is a certain neighborly wonderment in the air here. And so this afternoon, while Guy and Helen Hunt were away on a short vacation, Herman (Rubber) Martin and 8 or 10 of the other boys -there are not that many Republicans here - went up on the Hunt farm and raked the leaves, tied some yellow ribbons up and hung a banner of greeting for this weekend: ''Welcome Home Governor Hunt.''

title: PRATT HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $3,889,000 for the quarter and $4,163,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $2,093,000 for the quarter and $2,142,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax benefit of $27,000. c-Net income and includes tax benefits of $5,000 for the quarter and $303,000 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. BISHOP URGES A PAPAL AUDIENCE ON 'DISAFFECTION'
description: The president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops today warned of ''a growing and dangerous disaffection'' between some American Roman Catholics and the Vatican, and said he was seeking an audience with the Pope to discuss the tensions.

Making Low Salaries For Making Lives Better
description: ''Excuse me,'' said Sandy Oliva, pulling out a tuna fish sandwich. ''Mind if I eat lunch?'' It was 5 P.M.

title: TYLER'S RELEASE STARTLES 49ERS
description: Somewhat lost in the euphoria last week over the pending return of Joe Montana to the San Francisco 49ers was the sudden release of Wendell Tyler after three and a half seasons with the club.

title: McMillen Confident
description: Tom McMillen said he expected to be the next Congressman from Maryland's 4th District, but he stopped just short yesterday of proclaiming victory.

WESSEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Dow Gains 5.76; Volume Slackens
description: Influenced by a strengthening bond market, stock prices rose slightly yesterday as Wall Street snapped a two-day slump despite reduced trading volume.

title: EMPLOYEE GROUP SUES TO BAR EASTERN MERGER
description: A group of Eastern Airlines employees filed suit today to block a meeting at which shareholders are expected to approve a $676 million takeover offer by the Texas Air Corporation.

title: 'THE GEORGE McKENNA STORY,' A MOVIE ON CBS
description: SCHOOLS, especially schools in what are called the inner cities, are riddled with problems, the most obvious being high truancy and dropout rates. Occasionally, a news documentary will tackle the subject, bringing home the urgency of the situation. Television entertainment, on the other hand, is virtually addicted to being upbeat and prefers to take an inspirational approach whenever possible. This season's uplifting example of how even one determined person can presumably make a difference is ''The George McKenna Story.'' Based on fact, the television movie is on CBS at 9 this evening.

title: CHALLENGE FOR N.I.H.: TAKING SUCCESS INTO NEXT 100 YEARS
description: IT began as a one-room public health laboratory on Staten Island in 1887, when American medicine lagged in the fundamental discoveries that Louis Pasteur and other bacteriologists were making in Europe and when taxpayer financing of medical research was a revolutionary social experiment.

title: Minister Won't Reopen Unlicensed Boys' Home
description: A judge approved an agreement today between a fundamentalist minister and the state that will allow the minister to avoid jail, but prevent him from operating a boys' home without a license.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $30,618 for the quarter and $44,269 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $11,567 for the quarter and 9 months.

Software as a whole, for word processing, database management or other purposes, offers such a diverse assortment of features that the average user is overwhelmed by them. Most of those wondrous functions remain unused long after the rudimentary elements of a program have been conquered and become well-worn.

title: VISUAL GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Q&A
description: Q.Why do mockingbirds imitate other birds? A.Scientists believe that mockingbirds imitate the calls and songs of other birds to discourage these birds from settling in the mockingbirds' territory by making it appear heavily populated. The mockingbird's vocal chords, called the syrinx, can produce a wide variety of sounds. A typical mockingbird has 250 to 350 songs in its repertoire. Most songs are direct repetitions of other birds' songs, but some are original improvisations. The male mockingbird uses its repertoire of songs to attract females, according to Dr. Kim Derrickson, a postdoctoral fellow at the Smithsonian Institution. A female mockingbird will choose the male with the largest repertoire because he is most likely to have the most territory, Dr. Derrickson said. For this reason, mockingbirds are constantly expanding the number of songs they sing, he said. Mockingbirds can imitate sounds made by other animals, such as the bark of a squirrel, and can also reproduce the sounds of inanimate objects such as fire alarms, dripping water or the squeak of a washing machine. Q.How is urine tested for signs of drug use? A.The most widely used screening method is enzyme immunoassay, in which the urine sample is mixed with reagents used to detect specific drugs. The mixture is placed in a spectrometer, which measures the amount of light the mixture absorbs. The degree of absorption indicates the presence or absence of the drug. Radioimmunoassay, using radioactive substances, is another popular screening method.

title: STAGE: 'SPACE WALK,' A PHANTASMAGORIA
description: EARLY in Alan Mokler's phantasmagorical play ''Space Walk,'' a gas-station attendant named Joe (Paul Zimet) suddenly recognizes on television a woman he recently saw in a local liquor store. Amazed, he calls to his wife, Dora (Nancy Mayans), and they excitedly videotape her and then just as excitedly replay what they've taped. The scene is one of many comic vignettes in a postmodern miracle play about the technological wonders of contemporary life that most of us take for granted.

title: DANCE: KENNETH KING IN 'ZARATHUSTRA'S RETURN'
description: KENNETH KING has often incorporated spoken texts into his dances and, over the years, he has created a whole gallery of imaginary characters he loves to portray. Because ''Zarathustra's Return,'' which he offered Sunday night in the parish hall of St. Mark's Church, consisted of virtually nothing but text, he accurately referred to it in his program notes as a play. A dramatic monologue, it consisted of statements both about and by the 19th-century philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche.

In the unannounced meeting, Mr. Barry asked the United States Government to determine if, as had been reported, Americans had gone into Iran on an arms-for-hostages mission, carrying Irish passports.

description: The Rhode Island Superior Court began an investigation today into possible criminal wrongdoing in the office of Attorney General Arlene Violet, whose defeat in last week's election was widely ascribed to reports of misconduct.

description: Financial help for undergraduate jazz students at the New School for Social Research will soon be available through the John Haley (Zoot) Sims Scholarship Fund, named for the saxophone player, who died last year.

description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states may require the death penalty for all murders committed by prisoners serving life sentences without the possibility of parole.

description: Saudi Arabia's King Fahd renewed a call today for higher oil prices and was reported to have sent a message to Iran, a traditional rival within OPEC, expressing his readiness to cooperate on the organization's affairs.

description: Ron Guidry, who was a free agent five years ago, joined his fellow Yankee co-captain, Willie Randolph, as a free agent yesterday. Seven other players filed, raising to 66 the number of free agents who can begin signing with any of the 26 clubs tomorrow. Today is the final day eligible players can become free agents.

title: ALLIED SECURITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Crazy Eddie Chief Reduces His Stake
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the consumer electronics retailer, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Eddie Antar, had sold 1.5 million shares of the company's common stock.

description: Six months ago the lives of most Americans were, if not complete, at least not impaired by failing to know who Vanna White is. Today it seems Miss White is everywhere, and those who don't know of her are, well, nowhere.

Son Seized in Fatal Beating Of Parents and His Nephew
description: The 20-year-old son of a couple who were beaten to death along with a grandson in their Brooklyn apartment on Sunday night was arrested yesterday and charged with the three murders .

title: McConnell Wins Women's Squash
description: Alicia McConnell of Brooklyn Heights defeated her closest rival, Sue Cogswell of England, last night, 10-15, 15-11, 15-12, 15-9, to capture the Loews United States women's squash-racquets championship.

description: Two elderly men were critically injured last night in their Greenwich Village apartment in a smoky blaze that was apparently touched off by a cigarette, the police said.

description: The GAF Corporation has sold more than half of the stock it held in the Union Carbide Corporation, according to Wall Street sources.

description: Osnat Burdman spent much of Saturday night and Sunday drinking champagne with her husband and calling the telephone number of the New York State lottery every 15 minutes to listen to a recording of her winning combination: 18, 21, 24, 36, 45 and 47.

title: A. JAMES SPEYER, AN AUTHORITY ON MODERN ART, IS DEAD AT 73
description: A. James Speyer, one of this country's leading experts on contemporary American and European art, died Sunday at Billings Hospital at the University of Chicago. He was 73 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: DARMAN CATCHES A BIT OF FLAK
description: In a speech on Friday, Richard G. Darman, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, criticized big corporations for being bloated, risk-averse, inefficient and unimaginative and for not spending enough on research and development. Corporate executives were paid too much for doing too little, he suggested. Perhaps the unkindest cut was his likening corporate culture to the Federal Government's bureaucracy.

description: Bill Yeoman, who built the University of Houston into a football power and led the Cougars to four Southwest Conference titles, said yesterday that he would resign at the end of the current season.

title: CONSUMER AIDE'S BIG MAC LEADS TO GIFT SHIFT
description: Terrence M. Scanlon, a member of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, took his three sons to a McDonald's restaurant last week on a visit that led to Big Macs for his boys and an agreement by the chain to assure that small toys are no longer given to parents of small children.

description: To the Editor:

Chairman Of Collins Leads Sale
description: In the early part of the century, Willis G. McCullough recognized that the interior of a new invention, the automobile, could be enclosed with a roof and upholstered much like the contents of a living room. Nearly 80 years later, the company that was built on that idea is being sold for $1.16 billion.

title: Early Life Form Found
description: The discovery of living reeflike columns in waters of the Bahamas has opened new questions about the evolution of life on earth more than three billion years ago. The columns, called stromatolites, are formed when blue-green algae, actually a type of bacteria, collect sediment that becomes cemented together into rock, with living organisms continually adding a layer on top.

title: BRITAIN WINS SUPPORT ON SYRIA SANCTIONS
description: Britain finally won support today from 10 of its 11 partners in the European Community for a ban on new arms sales and other limited measures against Syria.

Bobby Layne, a Hall of Fame quarterback, is in stable condition at a hospital in Pontiac, Mich., where he is being treated for an undisclosed ailment. . . . The Washington Capitals sent their goaltender, Al Jensen, to the Binghamton of the American Hockey League.

title: MacNeil-Lehrer on Tape
description: The National Archives has acquired 1,800 half-hour videotapes of ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Report'' broadcast over the Public Broadcasting Service from 1976 to 1983. The tapes were a gift from the Museum of Broadcasting in New York City, which kept a set for its own use. The Archives' audio-visual section already includes motion pictures made by the Federal Government over the years and news and documentary recordings from National Public Radio and CBS.

It is probably the most technologically advanced search now under way for signals from other worlds.

A few hundred computer companies, ranging from behemoths like I.B.M. to mom-and-pop outfits, push their wares to distributors, retailers, industry analysts and the rumpled group nevertheless known as the press.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 1 about a City Council committee recommendation to rename part of East 43d Street for David Ben-Gurion misstated the position of Ann Leggett of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee. She did not propose naming a street for Yasir Arafat, although she said that to do so would strike an appropriate balance.

title: MAINE'S MUSICAL DELEGATION LEAVES FOR MOSCOW
description: There was no more than the ordinary element of pandemonium for any large group about to fly abroad: a few delays, a few mishaps, mostly just nervous eagerness. ''The gizmo that transfers the luggage broke down,'' said Nancy Habersat Caudle, who had organized the voyage from a little town in Maine to the Soviet Union, ''and they threw it in the street.'' But the group that assembled Sunday at Kennedy Airport's Aer Lingus terminal was more than a little unusual.

description: The Anchor Hocking Corporation, a maker of household packaging and hardware products, said its board had rejected a $330 million takeover proposal from the Newell Company on the ground that it was not a firm offer. The company said that, after consulting with its financial and legal advisers, its board reached that conclusion because the proposal was open-ended, lacking in commitment and potentially detrimental to shareholders.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: VOYAGERS TO THE WEST. A Passage in the Peopling of America on the Eve of the Revolution. By Bernard Bailyn, with the assistance of Barbara DeWolfe. Illustrated. 668 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30. AT the time of the Declaration of Independence nearly one American in 10 had arrived in British North America within the previous 15 years. After the war of 1756-60, with French rivalry no longer a threat, there had been a sharp increase in the rate of immigration to the American Colonies: the figure of some 221,500 new arrivals for the period 1760-75 compares with an estimated 700,000 for the entire century and a half before 1760.

description: ROBERT was at a cooking class baking a cake when he saw Timothy walk by. Robert came out of the kitchen to shake Timothy's hand.

description: In secretly initiating a plan of not only talking to a nation accused of terrorism but also supplying arms to it, the Reagan Administration has undercut key policy objectives and left allies and Arab moderates bewildered about the gap between the Administration's public statements and its private action, according to United States officials.

title: SMOKING POLICY DEBATED
description: IT has been two decades since the Surgeon General alerted the nation to the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, leading to health warnings on cigarette packs and in advertisements. But the question of what more, if anything, should be done to discourage smoking remains cloudy. There are calls for prohibition, for a ban on advertising, for much higher taxes on cigarettes, for suits against their makers.

description: Anger Along the Rhine

title: Eugene Rachlis, Editor, Author and Publisher
description: Eugene Rachlis, a book publisher, author and magazine editor, died Monday of cardiac arrest at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gencorp's Job Changes Signal Military Focus
description: Gencorp Inc., which makes tires and runs radio and television stations, signaled yesterday that its major growth lies in missiles and military electronics as it named Jack L. Heckel president, effective Jan. 1.

title: Spring Reprise
description: The latest in sports-related video is, believe it or not, an hour-long compilation of highlights and lowlights called ''The Best of the U.S.F.L.'' It's being put out by an aptly named company: Halcyon Days Productions.

title: The Supply-Side Hostage Policy
description: The White House is erecting its thickest stone wall since the Nixon years to fend off questions about the blundering arms-for-hostages deal with Iran. Further, President Reagan's aides imply that the press is somehow to blame for divulging secrets that were leaked or blurted by the feuding ayatollahs of Teheran. It's all a dangerous response to a flaming embarrassment.

title: CIVICS LESSON A LA FRIEDMAN
description: A large entourage arrived here from the Bronx today to lend moral support to Stanley M. Friedman as he took the stand in his own behalf after being pummeled by prosecutors for six weeks in the case entitled, dauntingly, United States of America v. Stanley Friedman.

title: 5 People Die in Buffalo Fire
description: An overloaded outlet supplying electricity between two apartments started a fire early today that killed five people in a two-family home, the authorities said. It was the city's deadliest blaze since a 1983 propane explosion killed five firefighters.

title: ITALIAN JUDGE DOUBTS BULGARIANS' ALIBIS
description: An Italian court document made public today contends that three Bulgarians who were acquitted after having been tried for plotting to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981 provided suspicious alibis.

title: Great Moments in French Fries
description: Before McDonald's existed, 5 percent of America's potato crop was consumed as french fries; now it is 25 percent. McDonald's plumbed the potato's secrets, perfecting the type (No. 1 Idaho Russet), the curing (three weeks), the storage (cool) and the cooking oil (vegetable oil and refined beef fat).

title: AGENDA: Nov. 12, 1986
description: Policy on Homeless Meets Resistance A coalition of Bedford-Stuyvesant community groups in Brooklyn will ask a Federal judge to halt the placing of homeless people in the north and central parts of the borough. Last Friday the judge temporarily blocked the city from opening a shelter in the Sumner Avenue Armory. The coalition is arguing that the city has discriminated against largely black neighborhoods by concentrating shelters for the homeless in them. 11 A.M. Federal District Court, 225 Cadman Plaza East, Brooklyn A Piece of the Conrail Action About two dozen Wall Street brokerage firms, vying for a spot on the team that will handle the largest public stock offering ever held, will find out today whether they made the first cut. The Department of Transportation is expected to narrow to 12 the list of brokerages it may ask to manage its $1.7 billion sale of Conrail. The final group of four to six, to share an estimated $80 million in commissions and fees, will be announced next week. Sharing a Cab The Taxi and Limousine Commission is expected to approve a six-month experiment in group riding for passengers wishing to go from the Upper East Side to the financial district in lower Manhattan. The program would give formal approval to a system that has long existed illegally. 10 A.M. Bureau of Standards and Appeals, 161 Avenue of the Americas

title: Theater Project Gets $1 Million Grant
description: The Women's Project, at the American Place Theater, has received a grant of $1 million from the playwright Sallie Bingham and the Kentucky Foundation for Women.

title: Rolling to Victory
description: Bo Field, a 58-year-old waitress from Kearny, N.J., and her husband, Robert, have held season tickets to the Mets' games for a quarter-century, and from her seat right behind home plate Mrs. Field has long since grown accustomed to spurring her favorite team by waving signs that say ''Now'' and ''Charge.'' Before the recent World Series, though, the commissioner's office prohibited the brandishing of banners behind the plate, an area that NBC would be picking up regularly with its left-center-field camera. ''I wasn't about to disobey,'' Mrs. Field says, ''so I just sat there while the Mets were losing the first two games.''

title: They Ain't the Aints
description: Look who's 5-5 and climbing in the N.F.C. West. It's the New Orleans Saints, who've never finished above .500 but have now won four of their last five games and in the process jeopardized a streak that has lent them their greatest distinction.

title: MUNICIPAL MUSIC: A SYMPHONY MARKS ITS 15TH YEAR
description: The New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra has a name that doesn't exactly sing.

title: STAGE: 'DUCHESS OF MALFI'
description: NEXT to ''The Duchess of Malfi,'' John Webster's prototypical Jacobean tragedy, the goriest fright movies seem bloodless and the machinations of the most desperate soap opera villains look innocent.
