title: Baker Presses For Growth
description: THE Reagan Administration has made continued economic growth the focus of its fiscal and monetary policies. Its commitment to fend off a recession has been intensified by the increasingly close financial integration of the United States and the rest of the world - and by the danger that a breakdown in growth would pose to the world's banking and trading system. As one senior Administration official put it, ''We are in a life-and-death struggle to preserve the world economy.''

title: ANGER ALONG THE RHINE GROWS AFTER CHEMICAL SPILL
description: In the week since a chemical fire sent millions of gallons of poisoned water into the Rhine, noisy street demonstrations have erupted across Western Europe.

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Judgment Call On a Good Deed
description: To Kay Yow, coach of the North Carolina State women's basketball team and of the American squad that triumphed at the Goodwill Games in Moscow last July and again at the world championship tourney there in August, it was just a series of coincidences that reflected God's mysterious ways. To the executive director of the Amateur Basketball Association of the United States, which has designated Ms. Yow as 1988 Olympic coach, her role in those coincidences has put both his organization and the United States Olympic Committee in a ''very embarrassing'' position.

title: PROVIDENCE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

FOOD & FITNESS;
Avoiding Fatty Snacks
description: Nutritional hypocrites, ''nutricrites'' for short, are parents who tell their children not to eat fatty, sugary snacks, and then come home from work and have a martini, cheese and crackers, peanuts and some mayo-sour cream dip.

title: WICKES BUYING SIEGLER
description: In another bold step, the Wickes Companies agreed tonight to buy Lear Siegler Inc., an aerospace, automotive and industrial conglomerate, for about $1.7 billion.

title: Unilever Lifts Earnings 38%
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch household products company, said today that its third-quarter net income grew 38 percent, to the equivalent of $264 million, from $191 million a year earlier, based on currency exchange rates of Sept. 30, 1986.

title: VATICAN II HELPED TRANSFORM CLERIC
description: Two months after Raymond G. Hunthausen was appointed a Bishop, Pope John XXIII convened the Second Vatican Council. The council, which lasted from 1962 to 1965, not only transformed a firmly traditional Roman Catholic Church as no other event for centuries, but it also transformed the Bishop.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Grand Hand-Me-Downs Planned Parenthood's annual china, silver and crystal sale begins tomorrow and continues through Saturday. The selection of merchandise - all used, but in good condition - includes these Italian sterling salad servers, for $60.

title: Chip Market Up Modestly
description: The depressed United States semiconductor market showed a modest improvement in October, according to industry figures released today by the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group.

title: KEY RATES
CORRECTIONS.
description: Because of a mechanical error, a report in the Business People column yesterday about leadership of the Collins & Aikman Corporation was duplicated in some copies, appearing once under a heacdline about the Union Carbide Corporation. The omitted Union Carbide article is printed today, on page D2.

title: FAIRMONT FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $27,000 and $75,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a tax credit of $392,000. c-Includes realized investment gains of $526,000 and $540,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $532,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW WEAPON EMERGES IN THE WAR ON POTHOLES
description: In war, the military strategist Clausewitz counseled, the men who design the firearms can be as important as those called upon to fire them.

title: Nash Direct to Open As Independent Agency
description: Nash Direct is a new independent direct marketing agency that will officially be opening its doors at 747 Third Avenue on Dec. 1.

title: I.B.M. AND HITACHI IN NEW ACCORD
description: Setting aside a bitter four-year dispute, the International Business Machines Corporation and Hitachi Ltd. said today that they had reached an agreement that apparently eases the penalties imposed against Hitachi for its theft of I.B.M. technology.

title: Ex-Newton Worker Testifies He Warned NBC on Report
description: A former agent for the Nevada Gaming Board who later worked for Wayne Newton, the entertainer, testified Monday that he had warned two employees of NBC News that they were incorrect in trying to link Mr. Newton to members of organized crime.

title: Drilling Rigs Rise
description: The number of working oil and gas drilling rigs in the United States rose for the third week in a row to 874, up 14 from the 860 total posted last week, Hughes Tools Company officials said. Last year at this time, the count totaled 1,895, Hughes officials said. The rig count hit a low of 663 in July.

title: ULTIMATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FRIEDMAN DENIES CORRUPTION ROLE
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, took the witness stand here today and denied each of the Federal Government's charges against him, while offering a description of influence and connections in New York City politics.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $100,000. The company said the latest third quarter includes an $8.5 million non- operating charge, which includes $2.9 million related to expenses and provisions for contingencies arising from the sale of the Air Shields division to Vickers Plc. The remainder of the charge includes reserves for losses anticipated to be incurred before completion of the company's restructuring program.

title: Recalling a Difficult Lesson From 'Backwoods of China'
description: The present popularity of bridge in China is of recent growth, but there were a few pioneers half a century ago who learned the game through contact with the West. One such episode was recalled recently by Pete Wurzburger of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: GAF Carbide Sale
description: The GAF Corporation confirmed today that it had sold more than half of the stock it held in the Union Carbide Corporation.

title: BYRD ASSURED OF TOP SENATE POST AS RIVAL PULLS OUT
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia was assured today of becoming the Senate majority leader in the next Congress when Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana announced that he was dropping his bid for the job.

title: Gooden 'Proud' Father
description: In a statement released by the Mets at the Knick game last night in Madison Square Garden, Dwight Gooden, responding to newspaper reports, acknowledged that he has a son and that the wedding planned Saturday with his friend from high school, Charlene Pearson, was off for the time being. ''I have an 8-month-old son and I'm proud of him,'' the statement said.

title: U.S. TO PERSEVERE WITH IRAN MOVES, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: President Reagan has decided to persevere through unpublicized Iranian contacts to seek the release of the two American hostages held by a pro-Iranian group in Lebanon, Administration officials said today.

title: Ouster at London Stock Firm
description: The head of stock trading for Morgan Grenfell & Company, a leading British merchant bank, was forced to resign Monday after an investigation by the firm found that he had violated its rules on improper dealing.

title: Late Remembrance
description: Long after the fading of immediate issues, noble and ignoble, that provoked conflict, war memorials serve to commemorate the people who fought and died. Americans have done a good job of honoring those from all its wars save one: the Korean conflict of 1950 to 1953.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $57,800,000 primarily from a gain on the exchange of Itel Rail debt for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $600,000 for the quarter and $7,700,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes an extraordinary charge of $2,100,000. The company said the third quarter results reflect the contribution of Railcar Leasing operations to the consolidation cash flow of Itel for the first time since 1983. The company said the latest revenue reflects the acquisition of Great Lakes International in December 1985.

title: Hutton Link Is Ruled Out
description: The two top officers of the E.F. Hutton Group told employees yesterday that Hutton would not resume its merger talks with Shearson Lehman Brothers, and that they intended to keep the firm independent.

title: CHANNEL 7 CHANGES TIME OF NETWORK NEWSCAST
description: Channel 7, citing competitive pressures, will move ABC's ''World News Tonight'' with Peter Jennings out of its 7 P.M. time period next month and replace it with the highly rated game show ''Jeopardy.''

title: Greyhound Workers To Vote on Contract
description: Workers at Greyhound Bus Lines have been asked to ratify a two-year contract in voting that could last until Dec. 8.

title: Why All the Fuss About Self-Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: A Chip That May Open The Way to the Future
description: If there is a star of this show, it is the 80386 microprocessor built by the Intel Corporation. The chip's appearance is hardly awe-inspiring - flat, black and roughly the size of a matchbook - yet many computer analysts here say it is the platform upon which the future of the industry rests.

title: KANEB SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,374,000 for the quarter and $19.3 million for the 9 months. The periods also include writedowns of assets of $9,012,000 for the quarter and $106,405,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $217,000 for the quarter and net from discontinued operations of $11,444,000 for the 9 months.

title: MIAMI IN A SQUEEZE FOR ORANGE BOWL
description: Sam Jankovich, Miami's director of athletics, indicated that the Orange Bowl is still a possible bowl choice for the undefeated Hurricanes, although he did not admit to pressures being applied to keep the No. 1 team in the nation at home on New Year's Day.

title: KNICKS 111 SUNS 105
description: If there should come a time when the Knicks become a respectable basketball team once again, they will be able to look back to a moment last night at Madison Square Graden that may have inspired it.

title: Perry Named Coach
description: Gaylord Perry, who three months ago declared bankruptcy on his 400-acre peanut and soybean farm, has been named the first baseball coach at Limestone College, a liberal-arts college of about 300 students in northwestern South Carolina. Perry, 48, who pitched for eight teams in a career that ended in 1983 with a 314-265 record, will also oversee the school's summer baseball camp and take part in fund-raisers.

title: China Price Rise
description: China is pushing ahead with increases in prices of key consumer goods despite promises of a freeze following discontent over inflation last year. Since September, China has lifted state price controls on more than 750 items, including milk products, drugs, shoes, clothes, bicycles and color television sets as part of a campaign to revamp its cumbersome fixed-price system. Western diplomats said today that the Government had carefully timed the increases to coincide with record bank savings, a rise in incomes and faster industrial growth that would touch off an increased flow of goods to the market.

title: Don't Weep for Philanthropies
description: Saturday marks the first National Philanthropy Day, proclaimed by Congress to celebrate the extraordinary willingness of Americans to contribute time and money to help others.

title: Dr. Leona Libby, 67; Worked on Atom Bomb
description: Leona Marshall Libby, a scientist who worked on Enrico Fermi's first nuclear reactor, died Monday at Saint John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., after a long illness. She was 67 years old and lived in Marina del Rey, Calif.

title: Salvadorans Assail President
description: Students today burned an effigy of President Jose Napoleon Duarte dressed as Uncle Sam when he visited the National University. They accused him of being a puppet of the United States. ''It is not the first time I have been insulted, but my Government will never take action against freedom of expression,'' Mr. Duarte said.

title: Declining Intimacy
description: TOTHELIVINGSECTION:

title: LIGHT AIR DEFLATES CONNER BOAT AGAIN
description: Dennis Conner's Stars & Stripes lost today for the third time in the current series of races in the America's Cup challenger series, losing to White Crusader by 2 minutes 18 seconds.

title: Odysseus on 2 Cylinders
description: Washington has a varied and inexhaustible supply of tourists, but few like Alain Chaix. He is a 35-year-old former high school teacher from Toulouse, France, who has spent 5 1/2 years driving a two-cylinder Citroen Deux Chevaux around the world.

title: Japanese Chip Curb Has a Limited Impact
description: It has been three months since the United States established trade rules intended to prevent the dumping of certain types of computer chips on the American market by the Japanese. As it turns out, several manufacturers exhibiting at Comdex said, the effect hasn't been so dire as expected. The cost of dynamic random access memory chips, or DRAM's, that modern computers are hungry for nearly doubled as a result of the agreement, but the manufacturers had feared they would face fivefold and sixfold surges when the agreement was reached.

title: Stock Prices Close Narrowly Mixed
description: Airline shares were hammered down yesterday in an otherwise narrowly mixed stock market. Despite the broad and steep decline in the airline issues, which sent the Dow Jones transport index plunging 8 points, to 836.63, the industrial share average closed up 3.66 points, at 1,895.95.

title: AFTER WARNING, BOMB IS FOUND IN QUEENS CLINIC
description: A dynamite bomb was found yesterday in a Queens medical clinic where abortions are performed after the police responded to an anonymous telephone caller.

title: King Clancy Is Dead at 83; N.H.L. Hall of Fame Member
description: King Clancy, a former defenseman, referee and coach in the National Hockey League and a member of the league's Hall of Fame, died of cardiac arrest Monday, two days after going into shock following surgery for the removal of his gall bladder. He was 83 years old.

title: FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $291,000 and $8,894,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After a charge of $111,000 from a tax credit reversal for the quarter and a tax credit of $843,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest quarter results include pre-tax charges of $351,000 on the sale of businesses and $3,300,000 on the disposition of a product line. The company said the latest 9-month results include a pre-tax gain of $26,014,000 on the sale of businesses and a pre-tax charge of $3,300,000 on the disposition of a product line.

title: AQUINO STEPS UP HER CAMPAIGN IN JAPAN FOR AID
description: From the banquet hall of the Imperial Palace to the aisles of a Ginza department store, President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines stepped up her campaign today to reassure Japanese political leaders and business officials that she had brought stability to her country.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized capital gains of $720,876, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,373,894, or 44 cents a share, for the 9 months and extraordinary credits of $822,603, or 16 cents a share, and $2,208,448, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes realized capital gains of $232,814 for the quarter and $724,254 for the 9 months.

title: Tribble Arrested
description: Brian Tribble, accused of supplying the cocaine that led to the death of Len Bias, the Maryland basketball star, was arrested in Washington on speeding and drunken-driving charges, according to Sgt. David Thompson of the District of Columbia police. Tribble was arraigned and released.

title: Report Cites Atrocities In War in Afghanistan
description: A United Nations human rights report on Afghanistan, made public today, cites widespread atrocities by Government and Soviet troops.

title: How to Save Farms in the Middle
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDWEST ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FOOD IRRADIATION FIGHT CENTERS ON JERSEY
description: Inside heavily shielded industrial buildings up and down the state, tons of spices are being bombarded with bursts of gamma radiation that rid them of some fungi and germs.

title: Tell Me No Coattails
description: The shabby state of American education may be measured by the large amount of misleading talk devoted recently to the President's coattails. Ignorance about Presidential coattails seems to be almost universal even among those who ought to be learned, if not wise, about such things.

title: 180 REPORTED DROWNED IN SINKING OF FERRY BOAT OFF COAST OF HAITI
description: A 50-foot ferry boat sank off Haiti's west coast today, and at least 180 people drowned while 20 were rescued, the United States Embassy reported.

title: Toying With Genes, and Argentina
description: The Wistar Institute in Philadelphia has long been a pioneer in developing new vaccines. But when it went to Argentina to test a new, genetically engineered vaccine against rabies in collaboration with the Pan American Health Organization, it neglected to insure that Argentina was informed. The authorities there had understandable cause, when they learned of it, to stop the experiment. They called it a ''violation of ethical principles.'' It is at the very least a poor way to do science, let alone win friends.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Paris dispatch on Oct. 24 about efforts to obtain the release of French hostages in Lebanon gave an incorrect account of Foreign Minister Jean-Bernard Raimond's meetings with Iran's Foreign Minister during the United Nations General Assembly. The Iranian, Ali Akbar Velayati, indeed appeared, and Mr. Raimond met with him twice, for a total of eight hours.

title: Those Angry Democrats
description: The race for the governorship of Arizona, which was won by Evan Mecham, a maverick Republican, with less than a majority of the vote, is causing reverberations in Washington. National Democratic leaders are not concealing their anger at Bill Schulz, a Democrat who ran as an independent and got 26 percent of the vote, almost certainly depriving the Democratic candidate, Carolyn Warner, of victory.

title: LOUISIANNA PULLS BACK ON NURSING HOME CUTS
description: Hundreds of elderly people facing possible eviction from Louisiana nursing homes have been given a temporary reprieve. Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said Monday that he would delay until January the cuts in the state's health care budget that he had ordered to take effect Saturday.

title: A Hearns Challenge
description: Thomas Hearns, who feels he should have been given a rematch with Marvelous Marvin Hagler, will skip over the middleweight division and go after a piece of the light- heavyweight championship. Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager, said by telephone from Phoenix that he had agreed verbally with the promoter, Bob Arum, for a Hearns challenge to Dennis Andries of Britain for the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title sometime in February at Las Vegas, Nev., or Atlantic City. Arum said from Las Vegas that he had received a message from Greg Steene, Andries's manager, accepting the fight.

title: Futures Are Mixed
description: While the Treasury securities market was closed for the Veterans Day holiday, there was light trading in the financial futures markets, but no significant price changes.

title: CASE IS SEVERED FROM BRIBE TRIAL
description: Judge Whitman Knapp today removed Marvin H. Bergman from the Federal trial stemming from New York City's corruption scandal, and said he would decide later whether to dismiss the charges against him or to order him to stand trial separately.

title: U.S. POLL SHOWS MORALE HURT IF EX-CONTROLLERS RETURN
description: Nearly all the air traffic controllers discharged for taking part in a 1981 strike have an interest in getting their old jobs back, but more than half those who replaced them said morale would suffer, a Government report says.

title: REAGAN AIDE LINKED TO ARMY CONTRACT WITH BRONX CONCERN
description: A White House aide pressed the Army to negotiate a 1982 contract with the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor that is now the center of several investigations, according to a Small Business Administration memorandum.

title: ARNONE'S INGENIOUS STAGE SETS
description: In the second scene of ''The Highest Standard of Living,'' a few set pieces indicating a ferryboat are cleared from sight as a room looms from the darkness, growing larger as it moves downstage to fill the proscenium in the perfect theatrical equivalent of a cinematic zoom. It's the sort of coup de theatre one generally sees in a Mike Nichols production but rarely in the downscale, shoestring environs of Off Off Broadway. Indeed, that caroming of the technically suave off the aggressively informal is precisely what gives the scene its sexy, gimcrack appeal.

title: MAFIA COMMISSION TRIAL HEARS PERSICO SUM UP
description: Carmine Persico, acting as his own lawyer, argued in a summation yesterday that the prosecution had presented ''no direct evidence'' against him in a two-month trial focusing on a ruling commission of the Mafia.

title: 9-Nation Bond Index by Salomon
description: A new bond index measuring the government securities markets in nine countries, including the United States, Japan and Britain, was announced yesterday by officials at Salomon Brothers.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results are converted from Philippines pesos at prevailing rates for each period.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Analysis From Chief Of Esquire
description: Phillip Moffitt, a young and respected magazine industry executive, told his peers in the business today that they have been off target in two important areas of communication: to their advertisers and to their readers.

title: NONSTICK PANS: THE NEW BREED
description: Nonstick pans have greatly improved since the early days of Teflon, which appeared in the 1960's. The first nonstick coatings became instantly popular for their cooking applications and ease of cleaning despite substantial limitations - they scratched easily if a metal utensil was used and food stuck to the exposed surfaces. They also tended to wear out after a year or so of heavy use.

title: A Test: Do Microbes And Politics Mix?
description: Years from now, when historians determine the watershed events in the Federal Government's project to fashion rules for the biotechnology industry, one meeting almost certain to be regarded as pivotal was the one held last Jan. 3 at the National Science Foundation.

title: U.S. and Poland Hold Talks in Vienna
description: The United States and Poland have resumed high-level contacts in a sign of a possible thaw in relations that were frozen after the crackdown on Solidarity and the imposition of martial law five years ago.

title: G.M.'S JOBLESS NET: HOW SAFE?
description: When General Motors announced last week that it would close 11 plants employing 29,000 workers, many labor experts predicted that the innovations in the auto workers' contract might make their fate different from that of most jobless factory workers.

title: BRIDGEMAN'S NEXT ROLE IS AT THE TABLE
description: Representatives of the National Basketball Association and the National Basketball Players Association have agreed to begin formal negotiations in January on a new collective-bargaining agreement, according to representatives of both sides.

title: Life in the Sea
description: TOTHELIVINGSECTION:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I THINK it is fair to say that the fish most in demand on the coastal areas of this country -and even inland if it is shipped by air - is fresh tuna. Diners will find it served in elegant restaurants as well as casual ones outfitted with a charcoal grill and an imaginative chef. This trend is fascinating because even a decade ago or less fishermen with freshly caught tuna could barely give it away. A recent news account stated that in 1975, 9,800 pounds of tuna were fished from Long Island waters, bringing fishermen $3,558 or about 30 cents a pound. A decade later, 798,771 pounds of tuna were fished from those same waters. That haul brought $1.86 million on the New York docks, an average value of $2.33 a pound, according to the National Marine Fisheries Service. This year the expected dollar value is expected to double or triple, according to Christopher Smith of the Suffolk County Sea Grant Program.

title: WINE TALK
description: There are not many people in the world who can call home from the office and say: ''There will be one more for lunch. Let's have a bottle of Bollinger, a '75 Trotanoy and a Petrus '64.''

title: CHANGE OF STYLE HELPS JENNINGS SUCCEED
description: The football fields do not tilt downhill for the Jets this season; it only seems that way. One player who has been providing that illusion is the 34-year-old punter who has learned a newfangled way of doing things.

title: Zouk, New Musical Amalgram, a Hit
description: IN black American slang, it's called ''juke.'' In the French Antilles, it's pronounced similarly but spelled ''zouk.'' In both cases, it's a verb meaning ''to party.'' But in French-speaking areas of the Caribbean and Africa, ''zouk'' is also the name of the latest pop music sensation. ''Zouk la Se sel Medikaman Nou Ni,'' people are singing (''Zouk Is the Only Medicine Man We Need''). The song of that name, recorded in Paris by the Antillean group Kassav, has sold more than 100,000 copies. Now Kassav is coming to New York, for a performance at Roseland on Nov. 21.

title: Fire on Soviet Cruise Ship
description: The Tass press agency said today that two crew members were killed when a fire broke out aboard the Soviet cruise ship Turkmeniya off the Pacific coast with 300 schoolchildren aboard.

title: Pasta and Cheese Owner Wears Developer's Hat
description: Henry A. Lambert is a successful real estate developer whose pesto sauce and chicken pot pies have well-heeled New Yorkers standing in long lunch lines and crowding into gourmet food shops.

title: Travels With Djerejian
description: Edward P. Djerejian, who has been foreign affairs deputy to Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, is now heading back to the State Department, where he enlisted as a career Foreign Service officer in 1963.

title: CHICAGOAN GIVES $6.9 MILLION FOR A SCHOOL OF PUBLIC POLICY
description: The University of Chicago announced today that Irving B. Harris, a businessman and trustee, had made a gift of nearly $7 million to help establish a graduate school for public policy studies.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,797,000 and $14,420,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $6,649,000 for the quarter and $21,554,000 for the 9 months.

title: NEW CHIEF OF BISHOPS
description: Several years ago when Dignity, a religious group for homosexuals, invited Archbishop John L. May to a service in St. Louis, he accepted - but to pray, not to share communion.

title: Topics: Monuments; The Survivor
description: Vyacheslav Molotov, the last of the Old Bolsheviks and a 30-year lieutenant to Stalin, is dead at 96. It was Molotov the diplomat who gave the world the Nazi-Soviet nonaggression pact that carved up Poland, made World War II inevitable and finally dashed the hopes of many a European Leninist.

title: Carbide Financial Chief Puts in a Busy Year
description: J. Clayton Stephenson, Union Carbide's chief financial officer, has put in a busy year. First, in January, the company financed an exchange offer that proved successful in warding off a takeover threat by the GAF Corporation. Then, last week, it announced a big recapitalization plan intended to ease some of the problems created by the exchange offer.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $1,691,000 for the quarter and $7,525,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $1,399,000 and $4,919,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After realized investment gains of $1,280,000 for the quarter and $3,780,000 for the 9 months.

title: KLECKO TO HAVE SURGERY
description: The injuries to Joe Klecko and Marty Lyons, defensive-line anchors, are more severe than the Jets feared, they learned yesterday.

title: Hino Diesel Trucks Gets American Agency
description: Hino Diesel Trucks (U.S.A.), Orangeburg, N.Y., has named Muller Jordan Weiss to be its first American agency.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GERMAN UNIONS FORCED TO KEEP A FAILING VENTURE
description: In a serious defeat, West Germany's powerful labor movement has been forced by West German banks to buy back a nearly bankrupt real estate company weighted with nearly $8.5 billion in debt.

title: CIRCLE EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $75,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $39,000 and $84,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Asteroid Named for U.S. Girl
description: Minor planet No. 3147, an asteroid between Mars and Jupiter, has been named Samantha Smith in memory of the American girl who visited the Soviet Union in 1983 to campaign for better relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: So Be It
description: TOTHELIVINGSECTION:

title: DANCE: WAGONER COMPANY
description: DAN WAGONER is a good cook. Take a tablespoonful of ballet here, add the merest dashes of Paul Taylor, Twyla Tharp and Roadrunner, baste it all with a healthy splash of May wine, and you have Mr. Wagoner's individualistic style of dance. It is an eccentric style, which makes its limitations clear. But in the gala benefit performance last night that opened a weeklong season by Dan Wagoner and Dancers at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Wagoner plumbed the vein as affectingly as ever, in a meditative and exuberant evening of new dance. And what a pleasure it is to see dance that takes itself neither too seriously nor too lightly.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Citymeals Fund-Raisers For the fourth year in a row, Citymeals-on-Wheels has turned to restaurants to participate in fund raising - 3,500 of them, throughout the five boroughs. During Restaurant Week, which starts Nov. 17, the owners of all these restaurants will be asking customers to join them in helping feed the homebound elderly. Along with the check, diners will receive envelopes for their Citymeals-on-Wheels contributions, which can be made in cash, by check or charged to American Express. This month, American Express will also donate 3 cents to Citymeals-on-Wheels every time the credit card is used in a New York City restaurant.

title: OIL GROUP WARNED ON IMPORT FEE
description: The head of Mexico's national oil company told an oil industry conference today that a United States oil import fee - or equivalent measures - would provoke retaliation by many of America's trading partners, not just oil producers, and would harm American export industries.

title: FREMANTLE CAN TASTE THE CUP
description: The residents of Fremantle tend to look at losing the America's Cup the way San Francisco sees earthquakes: something that may happen sometime in the future.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: GOLF PGA TOUR: Isuzu Kapalua International, Kapalua Golf Club, Maui, Hawaii (Television - ESPN, 4 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS. BUFFALO SABRES, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) DEVILS VS. DETROIT RED WINGS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.)

title: MOTORIST RUNS DOWN SIX POLICE OFFICERS, CRITICALLY INJURING 1
description: Six police officers were injured early this morning, one critically, while they were directing traffic around the scene of an accident in Kew Gardens, Queens. They were struck by a car driven by an off-duty correction officer, who was also injured, the police said.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest first quarter figures include the results of Comdial Technology Corp., which was acquired in November 1985.

title: Air-Fare Pact Fails in Europe
description: The European Community transport ministers failed today to reach agreement on limited measures for liberalizing Europe's heavily protected air transport industry that would cut the high cost of flying in the region. The British Transport Secretary, John Moore, said an accord on British proposals designed to increase competition and to give travelers ''a better deal'' was blocked by a split on the crucial issue of cheap-fare plans.

title: POLICE SLOWDOWN BRINGS SHARP DROP IN TRAFFIC TICKETS
description: In the first three days of a citywide work slowdown to protest new anticorruption measures, New York City police officers wrote 91 percent fewer traffic tickets than in the same period last year and made 27 percent fewer misdemeanor arrests, according to statistics released yesterday.

title: Complaints Lead To Drug Arrests
description: An undercover police operation in a Brooklyn high school led to the arrest yesterday of five young men on charges of selling cocaine, the police said.

title: PENNEY, JC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $35 million for debt restructuring.

title: Daughter of Emigre Allowed to Visit Him
description: The daughter of David Goldfarb, a Soviet geneticist who emigrated last month after the American industrialist Armand Hammer intervened, said today that she had received permission to visit her ailing father in New York.

title: Malaysia Loss In Tin Venture
description: Malaysia has acknowledged that it lost 209 million ringgit, or $80 million, in a bid in 1981 and 1982 to corner the world tin market and prop up an export industry that later collapsed.

title: A Physicist and the Global Industries He Envisions
description: FOR a man whose life has been in the future, Gerard K. O'Neill is finding that his time may have come.

title: Buy Me Some Peanuts and Caviar
description: Everybody thought Ted Turner was wacko for underwriting the Goodwill Games in Moscow last July, losing $10 million-$15 million by bringing motoball to the Western world.

title: When U.S. Policy Is Kidnapped
description: Political kidnappings pose, in the starkest possible terms, the conflict that may exist between government responsibility for individual citizens and government responsibility for the national interest. The controversy surrounding the release of David Jacobsen from captivity in Lebanon illustrates both the temptation and the danger of letting the humanitarian concerns take precedence over larger political considerations.

title: ISLANDERS' STREAK ENDS IN OVERTIME
description: Kelly Hrudey didn't like the way the Edmonton Oilers erased an entire evening of equality between two hard-working teams and won this game, 3-2, on an unattractive play two minutes into overtime tonight at Nassau Coliseum.

title: HIGH FEES FOR GUEST LECTURERS STIR ARGUMENT AT CAROLINA UNIVERSITY
description: For officials at the University of South Carolina, it began as a matter of academic strategy: To gain national visibility, they would hire well-known public figures as lecturers and part-time teachers.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,295,000 from settlement of a lawsuit for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Indiana Town Loses 985 I.B.M. Jobs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, as part of its continuing efforts to cut costs, said yesterday that it would close its parts distribution center in Greencastle, Ind., and reassign the center's 985 employees.

title: NETS 114 CELTICS 110
description: At times tonight, the Nets ran the fast break the way Coach Dave Wohl envisions it should be executed. But before they were able to complete their 114-110 upset of the Boston Celtics and record their second victory in six games, the Nets had to fight off a stiff challenge in the closing minutes.

title: Ex-E.S.M. Official Dead
description: The former controller of the failed E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. has committed suicide, police said today. The police said Henry Earl Riddel, 68 years old, apparently died Monday night. Mr. Riddel had pleaded guilty last month to mail fraud and conspiracy and was sentenced to three years in prison for his part in disguising the investment firm's losses.

title: TOP STATE COURT ALLOWS INMATE TO SHUN HAIRCUT
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that a Rastafarian inmate who has not cut his hair for 20 years cannot be compelled to shed his four-foot-long dreadlocks.

title: ITALIANS LOOKING INTO ARMS FOR IRAN
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi ordered an inquiry today into the possibility that a small Italian port was used for United States arms shipments to Iran without the knowledge of the Italian Government.

title: JOHN J. KENNY
description: John J. Kenny, chairman and founder of the J. J. Kenny Company, a municipal-bond broker in Manhattan, died Friday at his home in Plandome, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the year-earlier 9-month results reflect a pre-tax gain of $1,330,000 in the second quarter from the sale of a building. The effect on net income amounted to $1,115,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: World War II Seamen Deserve a Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN FRANCISCANS TOAST BAY BRIDGE ON REACHING 50
description: This city today began toasting a bridge that altered its skyline, shaped its history and fundamentally changed the way people here live.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report yesterday in Column One (Police and Law) about a draft report on court backlogs incorrectly described the status of a plan to add 23 judges to New York City courts. Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders have agreed to the plan, but the Legislature has not yet voted on it.

title: MUSIC: NYGAARD AND THE JUPITER SYMPHONY
description: JENS NYGAARD and the Jupiter Symphony opened their season with an all-Beethoven program Monday at Alice Tully Hall. Unadventurous programming is a frequent topic for complaint in the musical world, but it is possible to suspect that unadventurous performance of the works programmed is what the complainers really mean. Here were two standard works - the Second Symphony and the Fourth Piano Concerto (preceded by a short march from ''King Stephan'') - but one never thought, ''Oh, that again,'' because the playing and the conducting were fresh.

title: INTERNATIONAL AMERICAN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $560,000, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of a tract of land which had been acquired for investment and resale. c-Includes a tax credit of $110,000.

title: SHIPMENTS TO IRAN: THE LEGAL ISSUES
description: The White House counsel was never consulted as the National Security Council, operating with the approval of President Reagan, supervised shipments of military materiel to Iran over the last 18 months, according to past and present White House officials.

title: FEW SEE HOMOSEXUAL VETERANS GROUP'S PARADE DEBUT
description: The sparse crowds at recent Veterans Day parades in Manhattan were generous compared with the smattering that turned out yesterday in the pouring rain.

title: Denton Not Conceding Alabama Senate Race
description: Senator Jeremiah Denton said today that he would investigate possible ''illegal procedures'' in last week's election before deciding whether to concede to Representative Richard C. Shelby.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Judge Drops Conviction To Save Widow's Benefits
description: A state judge has withdrawn a manslaughter finding against a woman in the death of her husband, saying she was doing so to preserve the woman's eligibility for Social Security benefits.

title: 'STIFFS' AND 'REPTILES' FETE JERSEY LEGEND
description: For more than 30 years, the Fat Man, also known as Frank J. Perretti, has cheered up friends and customers of his hole-in-the-wall restaurant here with his own brand of insulting humor, calling them ''stiffs,'' ''reptiles'' and sometimes less gracious names.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $12,295,000 and $32,875,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss of $1,120,000 for the quarter and $3,736,000 for the 9 months from early retirement of debt. c-Includes realized investment gains of $7,603,000 for the quarter and $17,234,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings for 1986 are restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in May 1986.

title: Astronomers Preparing Survey of the Heavens
description: Scientists working on the first detailed map of the heavens in more than 35 years say they expect to help chart the locations of galaxies, stars, quasars and asteroids that have not been seen before.

title: CHINESE GET WALL ST. GUIDE TO CAPITALIST ROAD
description: A mere 200 yards from the marble mausoleum housing the embalmed body of Mao Zedong, the talk today was of zero coupons, the dynamic management of assets and liabilities and legitimate portfolio vehicles.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PLAYS FROM QUEBEC Up in Montreal, a metropolis of 3 million people in the Province of Quebec, New York's French-speaking neighbor on the northern border, there are 50 theaters, a source of demand that apparently attracts scripts by a legion of playwrights. Four, judged to be of the top-drawer category, will be shown in our city, in English translation, in a ''Festival of New Plays From Quebec,'' which arrives today at the Ubu Repertory Theater, 149 Mercer Street, near Prince Street, in SoHo.

title: L.I.U. TO FACE HARTWICK IN N.C.A.A. SOCCER
description: Long Island University, Seton Hall and Hartwick College are among the 23 teams that begin play this week in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's national soccer tournament.

title: 18th-Century Gold Box Is Sold for $1.1 Million
description: An 18th-century diamond-studded gold box made in 1755 for Frederick the Great was sold yesterday at Christie's in Geneva for $1.1 million, the highest price ever paid for a gold box.

title: SCOTT IS BEST, IN SPLIT DECISION
description: Mike Scott of the Houston Astros, who went from mediocrity to brilliance once he learned how to throw the split-fingered fastball, was named today as the winner of the Cy Young Award as the National League's best pitcher.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Mike Flanagan, pitcher, to a one-year contract.

title: BUMPER CROP OF BRAND NAMES
description: To most consumers, Sunkist means oranges, Chiquita means bananas and Dole means pineapples.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $282,163 from early retirement of debt. The company said the latest 9-month includes a gain of $908,717, or 12 cents a share from the sale of properties. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9 months includes gains from the sale of properties of $1,162,909, or 18 cents a share and $1,280,929, or 20 cents a share, respectively. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effective Sept. 1.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about reactions to a Treasury official's criticism of big business misidentified two executives. Gerald Greenwald is chairman of Chrysler Motors, and William F. Glavin is vice chairman of the Xerox Corporation.

title: How High Is High?
description: TOTHELIVINGSECTION:

title: A Sneak Preview Of Computer Products
description: The annual fall Computer Distributors Exposition, which opened in Las Vegas Monday, is the industry's biggest gathering and symbolically the start of its new year. An estimated 92,000 manufacturers, dealers, retailers, office information managers and onlookers, from every continent except Antarctica, are in town this week for the show, expecting to get a sneak preview of the products that will be in the stores in 1987.

title: Sabatini Defeats Soviet Player
description: Sixth-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina gave Larissa Savchenko of the Soviet Union a tennis lesson with a 6-0 first-set victory tonight and then held on to score a 7-5 second-set triumph in an opening-round match at the $150,000 Slims of Chicago championships.

title: Biaggi Counts His Words
description: What member of the House appeared most frequently in the Congressional Record in the past two years? That debatable honor has been claimed by Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, who either delivered or inserted in the Record 597 speeches in the 99th Congress (1985-86). Mr. Biaggi says his nearest challenger was Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of upstate New York, with 536 floor statements.

title: Garner and Shepherd Set Beef Council Pitch
description: The Beef Industry Council of the Meat Board and the Cattlemen's Beef Board has named James Garner and Cybill Shepherd as spokesmen for its consumer print and network campaign, ''Beef . . . Real Food for Real People.''

title: Merchandise Chief Appointed by Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's No. 1 retailer, named Michael Bozic, a 45-year-old Pittsburgh native, as chairman and chief executive of Sears Merchandise Group, which had $26.5 billion in revenues last year.

title: Insurers Can Do Better on Mental Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ SEES LATIN SHIFT ON NICARAGUA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had found ''changes of opinion and judgment'' among Latin American countries that were leading to greater sympathy for United States policy toward Nicaragua.

title: True Figures Rank U.S. High in Road Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 CENTRISTS WIN IN VOTE TO HEAD BISHOPS IN U.S.
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops today elected two centrist Archbishops from the Middle West to lead them for the next three years, rejecting candidates from the liberal and conservative wings.

title: Higher Costs, Smaller Parties
description: Money used to flow freely at Comdex. In the old days - which in this business means two or three years ago - companies thought the computer boom would last forever and they spent money accordingly.

title: Man Run Over By Freight Train WALDWICK, N.J. (AP) -
description: A 63-year-old man was killed yesterday when he was run over by a Conrail freight train while he was sitting on the tracks at the train station here, the N.J. Transit police said.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: PEOPLE sometimes ask: Who would you like to meet most in the whole world, if your press pass magically opened doors and was not just a meaningless rectangle of laminated plastic with a bad picture of you in one corner?

title: 8 States Will Upgrade Schools
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett will help Governors of eight states to choose 16 school districts to carry out major revisions aimed at upgrading the nation's educational system, the Education Department said Monday.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1986
description: The World

title: Pension Refund to Pentagon
description: The FMC Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to give the Government some of the money it gets from ending its $400 million-plus pension plan.

title: Judge Cuts Award In Pipeline Suit
description: The Midcon Corporation said a Federal district judge in Cheyenne, Wyo., had reduced a jury award against its subsidiary, the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America. Judge Clarence Brimmer cut the award to $549 million from $724 million.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THIS letter, slipped under the door of the Brookhaven (L.I.) Free Library, was found the morning after a Halloween holiday spree that had left trees and lampposts on the library grounds festooned with yards of billowing toilet tissue: Dear Library Personnel:

title: Housing Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT A. NYE
description: Robert A. Nye, a poet and critic, died of a heart attack Nov. 4 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: FILIPINOS 'TALKING OUT' WAYS TO AVERT A CRISIS
description: Envoys crisscrossed Manila today between the Defense Ministry and the palace in an effort to defuse a Government crisis that has raised fears of a coup.

title: TROUBLED TIMES FOR MOZZARELLA MAKERS
description: Vicenzo Citro talks about his water buffaloes like another man might about his pet basset hounds. ''They may not be beautiful on the outside,'' observes Mr. Citro, who has devoted the past 30 years to making mozzarella cheese from their milk, ''but it's what they've got on the inside that counts.''

title: VIETNAM IS A FOCUS FOR VETERANS DAY
description: Veterans of the nation's wars were remembered in the rain here today in sharply different ceremonies.

title: WALDHEIM, OSTRACIZED, CUTS LONELY FIGURE IN PRESIDENCY
description: Since being elected President of Austria in June, Kurt Waldheim has been one of the loneliest political figures in Europe, shunned by ambassadors and statesmen and effectively unable to travel abroad because of the lingering doubts over his war record.

title: S.E.C. to Remain Member of C.F.A.
description: Ending much of the uncertainty surrounding television contracts for next season, the Southeastern Conference voted yesterday to remain a part of the College Football Association.

title: STAGE: 'STARDUST,' A POP SONG REVUE
description: IT'S not unusual for pop songs to embrace the moon and stars as all-purpose romantic symbols, but the lyrics of 87-year-old Mitchell Parish have always shown a special attachment to glinting heavenly orbs. ''Star Dust'' (1929), Mr. Parish's most famous lyric, may be the definitive pop expression of this kind of skyward-looking romanticism. Fittingly, the song is both the title and a recurrent refrain of an amiable new revue celebrating Mr. Parish's work, presented by Theater Off Park, at St. John's Episcopal Church in the Village.

title: Coffee Prices Plummet To a Three-Month Low
description: Coffee futures plummeted to a three-month low today after Brazilian growers began offering discounts on exports.

title: TYSON FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,604,000 from the disposal of vessels, including the value of related unexpired charters.

title: Official Quits At Salomon
description: Peter Gottsegen, the London-based head of international corporate finance for Salomon Brothers, has resigned effective at the end of the year, Salomon's executives were told yesterday.

title: Ford Tractor Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would close its last agricultural tractor plant in the United States by 1988 and transfer all tractor operations to Europe. Ford said the closing of the 12-year-old plant in Romeo, Mich., would cut costs and reduce capacity in the troubled agricultural tractor industry. The jobs of 650 hourly and 175 salaried workers would be eliminated, Ford said, but the division's headquarters would remain in Troy, Mich.

title: JACKSON CRITICIZES DEMOCRATS AS SNUBBING HIS SOCIAL IDEAS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson tonight denounced what he called the ''blatant attempts'' of the Democratic Party to exclude his ideas for political and social changes from the party's agenda.

title: BOMBS IN SOUTH AFRICA WOUND 20
description: At least 20 people, mostly blacks, were reported wounded today when two bombs exploded in a small town in Natal Province.

title: MUSIC: JOHN NAUMAN, PIANO
description: LISTENING to John Nauman play the piano at Alice Tully Hall Friday evening, words such as ''fastidious'' and ''delicacy'' kept passing through the listener's mind. Said another way, Mr. Nauman - a Juilliard graduate and recent winner of the American Music Scholarship Association competition - came as a welcome respite from the histrionic young thumping that has reached these ears recently.

title: L.I. Must Have Its Fair Share of Environmental Bond Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the results do not give effect to the debt rescheduling agreement entered into Sept. 5, pending shareholder approval of arrangements contemplated by the agreement Nov. 25.

title: RESENQUIST PAINTING SELLS FOR RECORD PRICE
description: James Rosenquist's ''F-111'' painting - the largest artwork ever auctioned - was sold last night for almost 100 times the price paid to the artist when it was acquired in 1965 by the Robert C. Sculls. The painting, one of 44 artworks auctioned from the Scull collection, was among nine that established records at auction for artists in a sale that brought the highest total for a single-owner collection of post-World War II art.

title: WHITE FOE OF BOTHA TELLS U.S. TO GET INVOLVED
description: South Africa needs the United States to engage rather than disengage from the country to end apartheid, the leader of South Africa's official parliamentary opposition party said yesterday.

title: REPORT FINDS SCANT GAIN AT THE H.R.A.
description: Almost two years after a mayoral commission outlined sweeping changes for the New York City Human Resources Administration, social service experts say key changes have not been made.

title: California Official Assaulted in Her Home
description: An intruder carrying an ax broke into the home of California's Secretary of State, March Fong Eu, robbed her, beat her and dragged her through the residence by her hair, a spokesman said today.

title: Seeing Visa Denials as Plan to Manipulate Debate
description: The Rev. Edicio dela Torre does not seem especially threatening to the American way of life. He is a leftist priest from the Philippines who speaks pensively of needs in his country for land redistribution, social justice and the democratization of the Roman Catholic Church. Jailed twice for a total of nine years under Ferdinand E. Marcos, when he was President, he was freed last March under the amnesty for political prisoners declared when Corazon Aquino became President.

title: An Imperfect Fit
description: TOTHELIVINGSECTION:

title: CONCERT: COMPUTER MUSIC
description: THE Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics at Stanford University probably counts as this country's leading computer-music facility - although the composers and technicians at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of California at San Diego might dispute that claim. Under John Chowning's direction, the Stanford center has been in the forefront of computer-music research and composition for years, and helped plan the facilities in San Diego and at Pierre Boulez's Ircam center in Paris.

title: 2 Philippine Phone Issues for Cable
description: The Chase Investment Bank announced that it would privately place $44.6 million of debt securities for two Philippine telephone companies, to finance their share of a new trans-Pacific fiber optic cable.

title: CHIRAC THANKS SYRIA FOR ITS HELP
description: Two Frenchmen, held hostage for months in Lebanon, were released today and handed over to the Syrian authorities. They arrived in Paris this evening.

title: U.S.-JAPAN TRADE GAP A RECORD
description: Japan's surplus in trade with the United States hit a record $5 billion in October, the Finance Ministry said today, but this news did not alarm American economists.

title: State Seat Belt Law Repealed
description: Nebraskans have repealed the state's mandatory seat belt law by a margin of about one-tenth of 1 percent, according to an unofficial vote count completed today.

title: Union to Ask Workers To Reject Dock Pact
description: Leaders of Baltimore's five International Longshoremen's Association locals said today that they would ask about 3,000 members to reject the latest offer by local managers, adding that they are prepared to strike next week.

title: In Showtime's 'Picnic,' Classic Gets New Look
description: WILLIAM INGE'S ''Picnic,'' which had its Broadway premiere in 1953, is being given a revival on Showtime and, despite some misguided tinkering, the play comes through beautifully. The pay-cable presentation, first shown on Monday, will be repeated several times, the first being Saturday afternoon at 3.

title: Station's Sale Off
description: The Providence Journal Company has canceled its plans to sell WPHL-TV, a Philadelphia UHF station, having failed to find a buyer willing to pay the $100 million asking price.

title: FORSTER'S 'MAURICE' BECOMES A MOVIE
description: The manuscript of ''Maurice,'' the homosexual love story E. M. Forster wrote in 1914 and then suppressed for 56 years, bore a characteristically quizzical note in the novelist's own hand when it was discovered in his rooms at King's College here after his death in 1970. ''Publishable,'' it said, ''but worth it?''

title: G.E. Will Close TV Tube Plant
description: The General Electric Company said today that it would close its manufacturing plant for color television tubes in July 1987, eliminating 655 hourly and 135 salaried jobs in Syracuse.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $249,000 for the latest quarter and $321,000 for the year-ago period.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE K's were exhausted.

title: MICE FOR STUDYING DOWN'S SYNDROME
description: Scientists have developed the first animal models for Down's syndrome, an advance they say should greatly help research on the severe genetic disease that is the most common form of mental retardation.

title: Fidelity OTC's New Strategy
description: REPLACING an eminently successful mutual-fund portfolio manager is a tough assignment. But Morris J. Smith, who took over the helm of the Fidelity OTC Portfolio on July 1, has settled in to meet this challenge.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 12, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: G.M. to Recall 89,000 Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation said Monday that it was recalling about 89,000 Buick and Oldsmobile models for inspection of a power steering hose that could leak and cause an engine compartment fire. The company said it was not aware of any injuries or accidents stemming from the improperly placed hose on its 1986 models. Owners of the Buick Electra and the Park Avenue and the Oldsmobile 98 models were asked to take them to dealers for a free inspection.

title: SOUTHERN JEWS ACT TO RESCUE A PAST
description: The Jewish bride and groom, Nashville, Tenn., 1890, stand intently before the camera, the bride's veil pushed back, the groom's eyes dark-set beneath the black bowler hat. In a second photograph, Memphis, Tenn., 1925, a gaunt, boy dressed in Purim costume holds a drum. And in a third photograph, undated, a Confederate memorial rises high above a DeKalb, Miss., town square, a stone soldier looking off into the distance. On its base, among the names memorialized, are those of two DeKalb brothers: Aron and Jacob Rosenbaum.

title: OTHER AIRLINES TO FOLLOW
description: Continental Airlines today announced lower fares on certain flights originating in Chicago and Houston, and other airlines quickly said they would match the prices.

title: Southwest Air Control Radars In Power Losses on Same Day
description: Radar controlling high altitude air traffic from the Texas Panhandle to southern California was knocked out by a power failure for 40 minutes last week, and another radar was down for more than two days.

title: FOR M'LORD AS A MONIKER, WHO'LL GIVE $15,000?
description: The parade of the great pretenders ended today with the final gavel in the auctioning of 120 lordships of the manors - aristocratic titles covering a millennium of English history - picked up by mere commoners and foreigners with cash in hand and grandeur in mind.

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New York's Petulant Police
description: They may be New York's finest, but this is not their finest hour: in response to Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's stern and wholly justified response to indictments of officers for corruption, city police are conducting a petulant job action. They ought to be the first to join in assuring the public that their sympathies lie with honor.

title: Reviving Manhattan Ladies Mile
description: LADIES MILE is the name given an irregular retail strip that extended from 14th to 23d Streets in Manhattan and had its economic heyday between the turn of the century and World War I. On a stretch of the shopping route that ran along Sixth Avenue between 18th and 23d Streets such major retailers of the day as Siegel-Cooper, B. Altman, Adams Dry Goods and Hugh O'Neill built huge, ornate department stores to serve the city's emerging upper-middle class.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You will never hear talk of arms deliveries or finance in relation with the release of our hostages.'' - Foreign Minister Jean-Bernard Raimond, of France. [ A9:1. ]

title: Trademark Suit at Ford
description: A former car-racing champion, Carroll Shelby, has accused the Ford Motor Company of trademark infringement and has filed a suit asking $30 million in damages, court officials said today.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances In Home Heating; New Units Are Smaller, Less Costly
description: THE clunky, inefficient home heating plant is beginning to disappear.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
People
description: * Frank Macina has been promoted to executive vice president, director of Middle West operations of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson.

title: The Iranian Tangle
description: The last thing President Reagan needs in the final two years of his Presidency is a running fight with the Democratic majorities in Congress over the conduct of foreign policy. Yet he is now in danger of encouraging, even of provoking such a partisan struggle with his secret efforts to trade weapons to Iran for American hostages in Lebanon.

title: A SAMPLING OF FINE SHERRIES: TASTE AND BODY FOR ALL PALATES
description: Sir Alexander Fleming, discoverer of penicillin, reputedly said, ''If penicillin cures illnesses, sherry resuscitates the dead.'' Though evidence of such resurrection seems to be lacking, admirers of dry sherry can confirm its appetite-quickening powers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1986
description: International

title: Some Who Were Excluded
description: Following is a list of some people whose visa requests have been turned down in recent years. The reason for an exclusion is usually not given in detail by the State Department or the Justice Department's Immigration and Naturalization Service, but a general provision of the McCarran-Walter Act that allows the Government to exclude for reasons of national security is often cited.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes after-tax charges from the early extinguishment of debt of $1.27 million and $3.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, an after-tax gain of $1.3 million for both the quarter and year resulting from the termination of pension plans, and an after-tax gain of $1.9 million from the sale of land for both the quarter and year.

title: L.I. Man Killed By Police Car
description: An unmarked police car struck and killed a Long Island man who darted in front of the car near his home, Suffolk County police said yesterday.

title: STAGE: 'ANNIE WOBBLER'
description: FROM his East End trilogy through ''Love Letters on Blue Paper'' and on to ''Annie Wobbler,'' Arnold Wesker has pursued an individual creative path, eschewing theatrical fashion. Even as he expands his stylistic range, he continues to deal with basic questions of family, friendship and mortality. Though his plays have remained popular in Europe, his reputation in America is largely historical. While it is difficult to forget John Osborne, it is easy to neglect Arnold Wesker. Both, however, are pioneering playwrights who broke down the door of English drawing room comedy.

title: Indicted Queens Judge Is Suspended With Pay
description: New York state's highest court today suspended the administrative judge of the State Supreme Court in Queens, who had been indicted on charges that he lied to a grand jury about his role in a cable television company's efforts to get a franchise in Queens.

title: BULLS DEAL HAWKS FIRST LOSS, 112-110
description: Michael Jordan had 34 points to help deal the Hawks their first defeat of the season. The teams are tied atop the Central Division at 5-1.

title: More About Gums
description: TOTHELIVINGSECTION:

title: Msgr. G.J. Schultheiss, Assistant to Spellman
description: Msgr. Gustav J. Schultheiss, a former chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died Saturday at St. Francis Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhasset.

title: Boeing Jet Orders
description: The Boeing Company received orders for one 747-300 from Cathay Pacific Airways of Hong Kong and two 737-300's from Southwest Airlines Company of Dallas.

title: MASSACHUSETTS PLANT FACES FINE FOR RELEASE OF UNTREATED WASTES
description: A Federal grand jury here has indicted a subsidiary of the Emhart Corporation on criminal charges of dumping toxic metals into the sewer system of New Bedford, Mass.

title: FOR AMERICAN TABLES, A RUN ON RABBIT
description: Rabbit has become a coveted main course for the nation's dinner tables, as evidenced by its new-found prominence on restaurant menus and in its move from restaurants to supermarkets and grocery stores and on into home kitchens. Once confined to specialty food shops, fresh whole rabbit and frozen pieces can be found in stores such as Grand Union, Food Emporium, Kings Supermarket in New Jersey and Balducci's.

title: A BRANDY TO RIVAL COGNAC
description: Robert Leaute (accent aigu first and second e), a master Cognac maker, is on a crusade to convince his French colleagues that they should take notice of an American interloper, a California brandy that he helped create.

title: RABIS PROBLEM IN WESTCHESTER
description: Health officials have brought in emergency supplies of rabies vaccine and tried to track down as many as 50 people, including schoolchildren, who may have touched a rabid dog.

title: Cutting Fish Fillets
description: Being an avid fisherman and one who demands the freshest of seafood from my local market, I prefer to buy whole fish rather than precut fillets. For one, whole fish are easier to assess for by checking their eyes, gills and flesh for freshness. Whole fish also tend to hold up better under handling and transportation, and most importantly, they have better flavor.

title: NORTH CAROLINA BAPTISTS SEVER TIES TO WAKE FOREST
description: North Carolina Baptists voted to sever formal ties to Wake Forest University today, ending decades of dispute over academic freedom and moral constraints at the church-related school.

title: Defense to Act In Park Slaying
description: The lawyer for Robert E. Chambers Jr., who was indicted in the strangling of 18-year-old Jennifer Dawn Levin in Central Park last summer, said yesterday that he would ask the judge to dismiss the indictment because of ''improprieties'' by a prosecutor.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: PITCHERS, CATCHERS TOP BASEBALL LIST
description: Baseball teams seeking a starting pitcher can sign, starting today, Jack Morris, Jim Clancy, Ron Guidry, Tom Seaver and Steve Carlton. Anyone needing a catcher has its pick of 12, including Lance Parrish, Rich Gedman, Bob Boone and Ernie Whitt. A team looking for players at other positions can sign Tim Raines, Andre Dawson, Bob Horner, Doug DeCinces, Gary Ward, Willie Randolph, Ray Knight, Brian Downing, Dave Kingman and Reggie Jackson.

title: Rose Leaves Roster
description: To protect a younger player, Pat Pacillo, a 23-year-old pitcher from Seton Hall, 45-year-old Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds player-manager, has taken himself off the 40-player winter roster and will not be eligible to play until May 15. The move will not expose Rose to being claimed by another team, and it will do nothing to end his playing career.

title: EX-CONVICT VOWS HE WILL SERVE GOD
description: Jack (Murph the Surf) Murphy, who played the violin, won a trophy for surfing, stole the Star of India sapphire and committed a murder, said today that he would spend the rest of his days working for God.

title: KATHERINE K. BROWN
description: Katharine Kennedy Brown, for many years a member of the Republican National Committee from Ohio and the committee's vice chairman from 1944 to 1952, died Monday at Kettering Hospital in Dayton, Ohio.

title: A DAY'S TOLL SHOWS CONTRAS' ABILITY TO STRIKE
description: Last Friday was just another day at war in central Nicaragua, a day when sudden and violent death claimed a family of poor peasants at a remote cooperative and a prominent Sandinista activist who was driving along a country road.

title: ADVANCED GENETIC SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter and 9 months revenue include the first $2 million of the $11 million five-year research agreement concluded on Sept. 30, 1986 with Du Pont Co.

title: FIBER OPTICS: A BOOM SLOWS
description: Almost overnight, fiber optics has gone from one of America's hottest new industries to yet another high-tech business experiencing growing pains.

title: Ford Set to Invest In Michigan Plants
description: The Ford Motor Company said it plans to invest $171 million in two southeast Michigan plants for the manufacture of newly designed alternators and starters.

title: 150 OFFICERS AT THE SERVICE FOR O'REGAN
description: More than 150 police officers, many from the beleaguered 77th Precinct in Brooklyn, gathered today at the funeral of Officer Brian F. O'Regan, who apparently shot himself to death rather than face trial on corruption charges.

title: CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Amnesty International To Get Album Royalties
description: ''Rock for Amnesty,'' an 11-song album that will benefit Amnesty International, will be released worldwide today by Polygram Records, it was announced by John G. Healey, executive director of Amnesty International U.S.A. The album will include an exclusive recording by Sting of ''Strange Fruit,'' a song associated with Billie Holiday, and a new version of Howard Jones's ''No One Is to Blame.'' It will also include British and American hit singles by John Cougar Mellencamp (''Pink Houses''), Paul McCartney (''Pipes of Peace''), Tears for Fears (''I Believe''), Elton John (''Passengers'') and Bryan Adams (''Tonight''), as well as Dire Straits' ''Brothers in Arms'' and Peter Gabriel's ''Biko,'' dedicated to the late South African activist.

title: Disney's Profit Advances 51%
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it earned $81.1 million, or 59 cents a share, in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Sept. 30.

title: NEW HAVEN'S 'OTHER' TEAM
description: When Greg Ortman was at Glen Ridge High School in New Jersey, he was, by his own admission, not much of a student. ''I fooled around a lot,'' he said. ''I was having a good time. I didn't study.''

title: Yields Are Flat or Off
description: Confusing signals on future interest rates largely froze yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit, while yields on money market mutual funds slipped slightly in the week ended yesterday.

title: KANEB ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writedown of $11,439,000. Comparative results were not available because the company was formed Feb. 7, 1986.

title: POLAND CENSORS CATHOLIC PLEA FOR PEOPLE'S GROUPS
description: In a move reflecting new tensions between church and state in Poland, Government censors have blocked publication of an article in an independent Roman Catholic journal.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1986
description: Companies

title: CALLS DEALS VITAL; He Tells Congress
description: In a meeting with Congressional leaders, President Reagan today for the first time personally acknowledged sending military supplies to Iran, according to Administration officials. He also defended the action as necessary for establishing ties to moderate elements there, they added.

title: JEWELRY AND QUILTS
description: ''20th-Century Design - International Jewelry Symposium,'' Haft Auditorium, Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street, at Seventh Avenue, 212-760-7254.

title: KAHANE MAY BE FADING, BUT THE IDEAS GAIN GROUND
description: After reaching a pinnacle last summer, Rabbi Meir Kahane's popularity has fallen drastically in recent Israeli public opinion polls.

title: Cornelia Watts Perry Is Dead; Communications Consultant
description: Cornelia Watts Perry, a vice president of Communispond Inc., a communications management consultant in Manhattan and Los Angeles, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59 years old.

title: SWISS WILL PAY COMPENSATION FOR SPILL
description: Switzerland formally accepted responsibility today for a major chemical accident that poisoned the Rhine River, saying it was ready to pay compensation to other affected countries.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error in some copies yesterday, an article in The Living Section about the history of Southern Jews omitted two lines in the first sentence of the fifth paragraph. The sentence should have read: To those unfamiliar with the vast weave of Southern Jewish history, random images might seem improbable: four Jewish youths plopped down on the edge of a field in 1910, their faces half-buried in watermelon slices; an advertisement for the opening of a Memphis delicatessen, Rosen's, with the blessing of the building announced for 3 P.M. and a ''6-Foot Salami Cutting'' for 3:30.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: RUSS BERRIE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERA: THOMSON WORK, '4 SAINTS IN 3 ACTS'
description: IT'S fortunate that Virgil Thomson has lived to such a venerable age (he'll be 90 years old on Nov. 25), since his five-year milestones trigger productions of his best-known works. This is good for him, presumably, and it's certainly good for us. Right now, his best-known work of all, the opera ''Four Saints in Three Acts,'' is enjoying a production by the Opera Ensemble of New York. It opened last night at the Lillie Blake School and continues Wednesday and Friday evenings and Sunday matinees through Nov. 30.

title: Soviet Defense Minister Ill
description: Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, confirmed today that Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov, who missed last week's Revolution Day parade, was ailing.

title: CIRCLE FINE ART CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TEST DRUG FOR ALZHEIMER'S EASES SYMPTOMS BUT EXPERT URGES CAUTION
description: An experimental drug for Alzheimer's disease significantly improved the memories of a small group of people treated in a preliminary study and temporarily reduced the symptoms of this devastating illness of old age, sometimes dramatically, according to the study.

title: 200 FEARED DEAD OFF COAST OF HAITI
description: As many as 200 people are missing and believed dead in the sinking on Tuesday of a jammed coastal ferry, which went down in rough seas near here.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
On Negative Ads
description: Attacking negative political television commercials has become popular sport. As a practitioner of this questionable art (my firm created the advertising in several elections this year and used some ''negative spots''), I am convinced that most of the current debate misses the mark.

title: RECITAL: DAWN UPSHAW
description: DAWN UPSHAW, at present one of this country's finest sopranos and full of promise for the future, sang a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday as first-prize winner of the 1985 Walter W. Naumburg Vocal Competition. Having been a Young Concert Artists winner of 1984 and having already made her Metropolitan Opera debut, Miss Upshaw is no stranger to the New York musical public, and the recital drew a sizable audience.

title: SECURITY TAG SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Export Funding
description: The Private Export Funding Corporation is offering $100 million of 7.30 percent notes due Jan. 31, 1992, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. The corporation, whose notes are rated triple A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's, provides financial assistance for United States exports through its purchases of installment notes, which are guaranteed by the Export-Import Bank.

title: END IS THE MEANS FOR BROTHERS
description: George Martin is a retired civil-service commissary worker from Fairfield, Calif., north of San Francisco. He and his wife, Janie, are flying to Minneapolis this weekend for a reunion with two sons, two daughters and two daughters-in-law.

title: DANAHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $967,000 and $3,575,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $1,601,000 for the quarter and $5,079,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Net income c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $155,000 and an extraordinary gain of $2,541,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

description: Evidence is growing that the underground groups that have taken hostages in Lebanon are more concerned with serving Iranian interests than any other goals, Arab diplomats say.
