title: AGENCY SEEKS RETURN RED WOLVES TO CAROLINA
description: More than 80 years after it disappeared from the Eastern seaboard, the red wolf came home today to coastal North Carolina, the first step in an effort to put back into the wild an animal that now exists only in zoos.

description: The Wickes Companies, by agreeing to purchase Lear Siegler Inc. for $1.7 billion, is entering major new businesses in electronics and aerospace.

description: b-Includes a non-recurring net gain of $2,682,000 from the termination of two pension plans for the quarter and 6 months, and after a charge of $4,533,000 from the retirement of debt for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a charge of $2,097,000 from the retirement of debt. The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October 1986 and both year-ago periods were restated to reflect the adoption of statements of Financial Accounting Standards Nos. 87 and 88.

description: IN another life Dan Scully would probably come back as a car.

title: Tar Baby Strikes Again
description: One difference between French appeasement and American appeasement is that France pays ransom in cash and gets its hostages back while the U.S. pays ransom in arms and gets additional hostages taken.

title: SOVIET SAYS IRAN ARMS DEALS ARE PROOF OF U.S. SUBVERSION
description: The Soviet newspaper Pravada said today that reported United States attempts to trade arms for hostages were proof of an effort at subversion in the Middle East.

title: Tax Court Orders Trial Over Rothko Estate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -

title: Reagan Discusses Iran
description: President Reagan has refused for two weeks to discuss reports about secret deals with Iran, saying that to do so might jeopardize the safety of American hostages still being held in Lebanon. But he did discuss them yesterday, in a luncheon with three journalists.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $613,000 for the quarter and $2,139,000 for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago third quarter net reflected a loss from Pottery Barn Inc., which was discontinued as of Feb. 1. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split efective Aug. 1.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $200,000 for the quarter and $310,000 for the 6 months. The company said the 1985 sales include $56,000 for the second quarter and $508,000 for the 6 months relating to an industrial laser subsidiary that was divested by the company in September 1985.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Allied Said to Study Merger of 2 Chains
description: The Allied Stores Corporation is considering merging its two Florida store divisions - Maas Brothers in Tampa and Jordan Marsh in Miami - as a move to cut overhead and create a unified retail organization in that state, trade sources said yesterday. Allied recently agreed to a merger with the Campeau Corporation, a Toronto-based developer.

description: THE trumpet player Mark Morganelli, whose quartet played at the Citicorp Atrium on Tuesday, brought the sounds of early Miles Davis to the audience that gathers for the free jazz concerts presented there four days a week at 5:30 P.M.

title: OUTSPOKEN JUDGE CAUSES CLAMOR IN COURT
description: Extra seats were added today to the front of the overflowing courtroom for Judge Whitman Knapp's wife, Ann, and some of his friends. ''We wanted to see Judge Knapp in action,'' said Nathaniel Rogers, one of the friends.

title: Pepsi Says It Will Sue Coca-Cola
description: Pepsico Inc. yesterday accused the Coca-Cola Company of improperly inducing a fast-food chain to switch from serving Pepsi products to Coke.

title: Oil Reserve Purchase
description: The Energy Department announced a plan to buy 65,000 barrels a day of crude oil from Petroleos Mexicanos for the Strategic Reserve.

title: Dockworkers' Union Rejects New Contracts
description: Union locals representing about 3,500 longshoremen here and in Delaware rejected proposed local and national contracts today, setting the stage for a possible strike next week.

title: MUSIC: HUGO LARGO
description: WITH two basses, a fiddle, no drums and songs that float and drone, Hugo Largo plays a dreamlike species of New York rock - lullabies for post-moderns. At Dance Theater Workshop's ''New Song'' series Monday, its set, inexplicably titled ''Blageny and the Cherubim,'' drew on dance and performance art, but its songs would be eerily memorable even without visual aids.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Korean Ship Captain Arrested by U.S. Agents
description: Federal agents today arrested the master of a South Korean fishing boat after a United States magistrate signed a warrant accusing the man of assaulting an American fisheries observer in international waters.

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest 9-month includes after-tax writedowns of $18.6 million of oil and gas properties, an after-tax gain of $8.5 million from settlement of a lawsuit and a $1.4 million federal income tax benefit.

title: PIANO: ANTHONY DE MARE PRESENTS NEW WORKS
description: ANTHONY DE MARE gave a stimulating program of new piano music Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, part of the Young Concert Artists debut series. Before the music began, Susan Wadsworth, the series director, came on stage to speak wonderingly about how ''rich'' this program was in contemporary music. She seemed bemused that this marvelous present had fallen into her lap.

title: LORIMAR ENDS DEAL ON STATIONS
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, the big West Coast entertainment company, said yesterday that it had terminated a $1.42 billion agreement to buy six television stations from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of New York, the nation's biggest management buyout firm.

title: FOREIGN STUDENTS WELCOMED
description: THANKSGIVING, Christmas and Hanukkah are traditional days of hospitality, days for inviting stray friends and the distant fourth cousin home for the holidays. Foreign students, one of the most neglected groups during this time, may not be destitute although they may often be alone.

title: MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,296,000 for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,453,000 for the quarter and $23,418,000 for the year.

title: Treasury Issues Up Modestly
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, with most of the gains coming in the last few hours of trading, after a day of generally light activity.

title: Shelter Injunction Extended
description: A Federal judge yesterday extended a restraining order forbidding New York City and the state to open any new homeless shelters in Brooklyn until a hearing is held next Thursday on a civil-rights suit. The judge, John R. Bartels of Federal District Court, extended the injunction issued last week at the request of a coalition of community groups that charged that most of the shelters in the borough were in black and Hispanic neighborhoods.

title: UP TO 25 ARE KILLED AS IRAQI WARPLANES RAID IRAN
description: Iraqi warplanes struck deep into Iran for the second consecutive day today and reports in Teheran said as many as 25 people were killed in early morning raids.

title: CABLEVISION, RUNNER OF RISKS
description: Long known in the cable television industry as highly innovative players, the Cablevision Systems Corporation and its founder, Charles F. Dolan, are now a part of the controversy seemingly endemic to that business.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1986
description: The World The C.I.A. was directly involved in the arms shipments to Iran, the Reagan Administration said for the first time. A spokesman said the National Security Council ran the operation with the C.I.A.

title: U.N. RIGHTS REPORT ON IRAN DERIDED AS MEANINGLESS
description: The United Nations issued a report on human rights in Iran on Tuesday, and Western diplomats, Iranian opposition groups and human-rights advocates immediately criticized it, saying it failed to document widespread torture and executions carried out by the Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: New York City Bus Passengers Know Why Ridership Is Down
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'PROGRESS,' A COMEDY
description: Following Michael Frayn's ''Benefactors'' and Simon Gray's ''Common Pursuit,'' Doug Lucie's ''Progress'' is the third bitter comedy of disillusionment to migrate from the 1983-84 London season to an American production. Visitors to the Long Wharf Stage 2 will quickly discover why Mr. Lucie's uproarious but mean play is the tardiest of the trio to arrive. Originally produced at the Bush, a small London fringe company perched above a pub, ''Progress'' is so misanthropic it makes the typical decline-of-England threnody seem as rosy as ''Brideshead Revisited.'' ''People - that's what wrecks all our plans,'' concludes the utopian 1960's architect of ''Benefactors'' after his dreams of beneficent social change collapse. By contrast, a 1980's liberal in ''Progress'' argues rather more darkly that ''the only creatures worth pitying on this earth are animals'' because people are too ''stupid'' to ''want to get better.''

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains from the sale of securities of $558,000 for the quarter and $2,450,000 for the 9 months. c-After gains from fluctuations in the market value of a Ginnie Mae futures contract of $223,000 for the quarter and $1,671,000 for the 9 months. Gains were also included from the sale of securities of $4,182,000 for the quarter and $7,239,000 for the 9 months.

title: State Penalizes Zaccaro $1,500
description: John A. Zaccaro has been fined $1,500 by the State Insurance Department for ''a minor infraction,'' a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: 12 Brokerages Vie For Conrail Deal
description: The Transportation Department named the 12 brokerage houses from which it will select four to six firms to serve as co-lead managers in the public sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation. The roster included all of the firms that have played a major role in the Conrail sale debate during the last two years.

title: Consolation Prizes
description: If Mike Schmidt wins the National League's Most Valuable Player Award next week, he'll have achieved an unprecedented feat. The Phils finished 21 1/2 games out of first place this year, and no m.v.p. in either league has ever come from a team that wound up so far behind the league or division champion.

title: Platinum Again Drops As Gold Holds Steady
description: Platinum futures continued to slump on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, plunging $13 an ounce after a decline of $20 in the previous two sessions.

title: WARD SAYS SLOWDOWN BY OFFICERS HAS WORSENED AND MAY BE ILLEGAL
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that a citywide work slowdown by officers had worsened, that it was threatening public safety and that it appeared to violate the state law banning job actions by municipal employees.

title: DISNEY, WALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITE HOUSE SAYS EX-AIDE LINKED TO PACT WAS VOLUNTEER
description: An official who was reported to have pressed the Army to negotiate a 1982 contract with a Bronx military contractor was identified by the White House yesterday as an unpaid staff member in the Office of Political Affairs.

title: Stamps and 'Star Trek'
description: The television series ''Star Trek'' started 20 years ago and lasted in network broadcasts for only two years. But it has endured in reruns ever since, and its fans are persistent missionaries, to the point even of petitioning for a postage stamp that would depict the series' spacecraft, the starship Enterprise.

title: ROADRUNNER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss is after a pre-tax provision of $5,879,000 for losses on property dispositions.

title: TAMPA LOVES ITS NEW FAME IF NOT THE TRAFFIC
description: A few local executives still cringe remembering when, in the early 1970's, a delegation from Tampa went to New York to sell bonds and sought to tell an octogenarian bond trader where Tampa was.

title: Rizzo Readies Political Move
description: Frank Rizzo, the city's flamboyant Mayor in the 1970's, quit his consulting job with the Philadelphia Gas Works today to get ready for another possible run for the office. The 66-year-old former Mayor did not say that he would run for the office next year but said, ''It's a possibility.'' He added: ''I'm not trying to play cat and mouse but that's the way it is in politics.''

title: SWENSEN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax provision of $1,975,000 for doubtful long-term notes receivable for the quarter and 9 months. Swensen's said the year-ago 9 months results included earnings from operations of two ice cream manufacturing facilities that were disposed of in June 1985. These earnings totaled $281,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding for the prior year restated to reflect 2-for-1 common stock split on May 30, 1986.

title: INFIRM RELATIVES' CARE: A NEW WOMEN'S ISSUE
description: SHE is the middle-age daughter of a frail mother, the wife of a bedridden husband, the daughter-in-law or perhaps the niece of a disabled woman who can no longer feed or dress herself. When a woman has an aging infirm relative, the chances are that it is she - not her brothers or her husband or a male relative - who will have to assume responsibility for the care of that individual.

title: Talking Deals; Buying Back, And Buying Off
description: NO deal irks Wall Street's speculators and investors more than when a company ends a takeover challenge by buying back a corporate raider's stock at a premium. The maneuver enriches the raider but leaves other holders following a parade that is no longer going anywhere. The maneuver, dubbed ''greenmail,'' has been largely in remission since Walt Disney Productions touched off an outrage by buying off Saul P. Steinberg a few years ago.

title: CALLS DEALS VITAL; Secret Dealings Have Made Use Of Complex Net
description: The secret movement of American military equipment to Iran over the last 18 months was accomplished through an international network of ships, planes, middlemen and companies, according to American and Israeli officials, participants and Iranian dissidents.

title: CUB FAN PRAISES A FEW METS
description: In the sunny chill, no roses bloomed in the Rose Garden, only a few marigolds and too few Mets who were there to accept President Reagan's congratulations. Fourteen players, two coaches and four members of the World Series champions' front office had formed a backdrop on a small outdoor stage for the President, who was wearing a brown suit the shade of a pitcher's mound.

title: Touches of Class
description: This Saturday an Englishman named Ronald Oldham is going to make dinner reservations at a fashionable New York restaurant. He thinks his chances of getting a good table are high, since he has just dropped $13,500 for the privilege of calling himself Lord Risworth.

title: OXOCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of $30,958,472 for the latest period, compared with writedowns of $30,439,515 for the year- ago period from the company's oil and gas properties full-cost pool. The latest 9 months also includes additional asset writedowns of $2,713,754, compared with $13,860,888 in such writedowns for year-earlier period.

title: COACHLESS CELTICS BEAT COACHLESS BUCKS
description: Kevin McHale scored 29 points and Robert Parish had 25 tonight as the Boston Celtics overcame Larry Bird's first-quarter ejection to defeat the Milwaukee Bucks, 124-116. Boston won its 44th consecutive home game and ended Milwaukee's three-game winning streak.

title: WASHING ANTIQUE LINENS IN TENDERNESS
description: WHEN it comes to caring for antique bed and table linens, said Jean Ellis, ''Everybody has their own way.''

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: HOLIDAY CORP. PLANS RESTRUCTURING
description: The restructuring bug hit the Holiday Corporation yesterday, with the hotel and casino concern disclosing that it planned to pay its shareholders $65 a share in cash and still permit them to keep ownership in 90 percent of the company.

title: THE THIN-SKINNED ANTON CHEKHOV
description: ANY contemporary playwright who thinks he is alone in feeling paranoiac should read ''Chekhov,'' Henri Troyat's masterly new biography (published by E. P. Dutton). Though Chekhov could withstand physical deprivation and severe illness, in one area he was extremely vulnerable, and that was in his attitude toward the judgment of others about his art. He took everything to heart, especially rejection.

title: Irish to Soften Schedule
description: Going into Saturday's game against Penn State, Notre Dame has a 4-4 record that Gene Corrigan, the athletic director, attributes to a schedule that has been too tough for the Irish to handle. In an interview with The Toledo Blade, Corrigan said the Irish will begin to schedule more games against teams ''we feel we have a lot in common with.''

title: McEnroe Loses to Cash
description: John McEnroe's return to singles play in Britain after a 17-month absence lasted just over two hours today as he was eliminated from a $375,000 indoor tournament in the first round.

title: HONG KONG PONDERS THE PRICE OF DEMOCRACY
description: Martin Lee is a thin, bespectacled barrister who -according to some of his critics -threatens Hong Kong's prosperity and even risks bringing class war to this normally apolitical British territory.

title: Nomura May Shift Top U.S. Officers
description: Nomura Securities International Inc., the American subsidiary of the world's largest securities firm, is expected to reassign its top two officers, sources at the firm said yesterday.

title: Advertising; Start-Ups, Excitingly Dangerous
description: The annual American Magazine Conference ended its three-day meeting today by examining the most exciting, daring and dangerous aspect of publishing: the start-up.

title: PORT AUTHORITY CHIEF EXPECTS RISES IN TOLLS AND FARES TO CROSS HUDSON
description: The chairman of the Port Authority said yesterday that he expects automobile tolls at his agency's Hudson River bridges and tunnels and fares on PATH trains to rise in January.

title: Why Do Abortion Foes Make Bomb Threats?
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP COURT IN JERSEY DISBARS 4 LAWYERS FOR MISUSING CLIENTS' MONEY
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today disbarred four lawyers who said their alcoholism or drug addiction had caused them to misappropriate clients' funds.

title: A Turning Point On the Abortion Issue?
description: After long years on the defensive, advocates of abortion rights are cheering the results of last week's elections. They say that the victory of pro-choice candidates for the Senate and House of Representatives, as well as the defeat of several anti-abortion measures on state ballots, strengthens their movement not only to resist further erosion, but to regain the initiative on such issues as public financing of abortions for poor women.

title: Queen Opens Parliament; Early British Vote Seen
description: Queen Elizabeth opened Parliament today and outlined a light legislative program for the coming year, fueling speculation that the Conservative Government would call an early election next summer.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Waived Juan Bonilla, infielder. Added Billy Ripken and D. L. Smith, infielders; Chris Padget, first baseman, and Greg Talamantez, pitcher, to their roster.

description: In seeking an alliance with the Government to help establish a base price for oil, the nation's third-largest oil company has touched off a fresh debate that could force the Reagan Administration to end its ''hands off'' oil policy, several analysts said today.

title: CBS SEEN RETAINING RECORD UNIT
description: The board of CBS Inc. indicated yesterday that it was not interested in selling the company's record operations, according to sources close to CBS.

description: Stanley Salvigsen, the chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, and two of his colleagues have left to establish their own money management firm.

title: ICEE-USA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SKYWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Q & A
description: Q. The oak parquet floor in our living room was originally stained a dark walnut with a Minwax stain. New stain has been added in places as necessary over the years to cover worn areas. Now the wood no longer absorbs the stain. A. Each time the Minwax stain-sealer (it is actually a colored or pigmented sealer - not just a stain) was applied, the excess should have been wiped off with rags. Apparently this was not done in your case. You might try rubbing the worn spots with steel wool, then wiping with a clean rag before applying more Minwax. If the Minwax is not absorbed, try lightly sanding those areas to increase porosity (this may lighten this section more than the rest of the floor, so test first in a little corner). If this doesn't work, then the whole floor will probably have to be re-sanded. Q.In the co-op apartment we recently purchased, the hot-water pipes run through the back wall of our two main closets. In one closet it gets so hot that the clothes feel hot. Management says it can't help us. Is there a way to insulate the closets and have them look presentable? A.Your best bet is probably to apply one-inch-thick sheets of Styrofoam or similar rigid foam-board insulation to the back wall of the closet, then cover this with a half-inch layer of gypsum board (required by the fire code). The foam insulation boards, which are sold in building supply outlets, can be applied with a mastic adhesive.

title: VAGARIES OF AIR HOLD PERILS FOR FURNITURE
description: ONE hears from time to time that the wood in furniture is alive, that it breathes and it needs nourishment. Actually, wood dies the moment the tree is felled, although from then on it will forever be on the move, imperceptibly for the most part, trying to adjust itself to the moisture - or lack of it -in the surrounding air. Perhaps that is what is meant by ''living and breathing.'' The idea in seasoning wood is to lower its moisture content so it is more or less in equilibrium with the atmosphere around it, thus preventing shrinking and swelling. Early woodworkers, mindful of wood's behavior, cut their lumber in planks of generous thickness, believing the denser and harder the wood was, the better its chances of resisting shrinkage, splitting and warping. But that did not seem to be so. In the case of oak, the only modifying effect to its future health was the result of splitting the wood into planks along its line of natural cleavage, or sawing it radially - cutting inward toward the center of the log - rather than straight sawing.

title: The Right Priority for Human Rights
description: Which is it on human rights? Does the Reagan Administration believe that arms control and other issues should come first in its dealings with the Soviet Union? Or does it believe there can be no real progress on arms control without improvement in Soviet behavior on human rights? The Administration appears to have flip-flopped, now favoring linkage, a position powerfully reinforced by prominent Soviet emigres. The tangle needs clearing up before it obstructs progress on both issues.
