title: Jacobs Lifts Stake
description: The Minneapolis-based investor Irwin L. Jacobs confirmed that he had raised his stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation to 7.4 percent, or 6.46 million shares, from 6.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs did not amend his previous statement that he might seek control of the Chicago-based diversified manufacturer.

title: ROWLEY-SCHER REPROGRAPHCS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Malawi Says Thousands Are Fleeing Mozambique
description: Thousands of people, many suffering bullet wounds, have fled to Malawi after fighting in neighboring Mozambique between troops of the Marxist Government and pro-Western rebels, the Malawi press agency said today.

title: Former Sergeant Finds Army Lax on Munitions
description: The Army's handling of munitions is so lax that it is relatively easy to steal large amounts of supplies, a former Army supply sergeant, who was charged with doing just that, said today.

title: 48 JEWISH NOBEL LAUREATS HONORED
description: Elie Wiesel, winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, and Isaac Bashevis Singer, winner of the 1978 Nobel Prize in Literature, were joined last night by Shimon Peres, Israel's Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, in a ceremony honoring 48 living Jewish American Nobel laureates. The event coincided with the 60th anniversary convocation of the Jewish Academy of Arts and Sciences, held at the New-York Historical Society on Central Park West.

title: The Tribunal in the Hasenfus Case
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMBERLINE SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
U.S. SPENDING PRIORITY ON WILDLIFE IS ASSAILED
description: Except for game animals valued by hunters, American wildlife is ''in serious trouble,'' according to a report released today by the Defenders of Wildlife, a Washington-based conservation group.

title: Talks Reported By Husky Oil
description: Husky Oil Ltd. said today that talks were under way about a possible ownership change, confirming market speculation that one of Canada's major oil and gas companies is a likely takeover target. Husky and its associate

title: EGYPT'S LEADERS ASSAIL I.M.F. CALLS FOR REFORM
description: Egyptian leaders voiced defiance today of International Monetary Fund pressures for reform of the country's chronically troubled economy.

title: 5 Injured in Pakistan Rioting
description: At least five people were injured today in rioting that flared in Karachi immediately after the authorities lifted a curfew. The police said 14 people were arrested after Pathans from North West Frontier Province threw stones at Mohajir immigrants leaving for work in the city's Orangi suburb early today.

title: BMC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $57,588,000 for the quarter and $58,230,000 for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month results include a pre-tax gain of $1,524,000 from the reversal of a reserve to move a manufacturing facility, and the 9-month also includes a pre-tax gain of $1,100,000 on the sale of a license agreement.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: On the Road to Triumphs Past, Time Out for Lunch
description: Members of a history class from Seiden Junior High School in Centereach, L.I., enjoying a box lunch in Battery Park. They stopped there on their way to Liberty Island for a look at a major piece of America's history. Also history is yesterday's relatively mild weather; today is expected to be cold and windy with the low temperature in the low 20's. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

title: Cornell Financing
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority is offering $149.7 million of refunding bonds on behalf of Cornell University, through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: Why Fear Foreigners' Free Speech?
description: Though it bears the names of others, the spirit of Joseph McCarthy lives in the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act, specifically that section that forbids letting people, even visitors, into the country if they hold offensive views. It's high time for Congress, having finally reformed the law by barring illegal workers, to strike from it the fear that America might be infected by foreign ideas.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''On this occasion the bishops of the United States wish to reaffirm unreservedly their loyalty to and unity with the Holy Father.''

title: NEW WORLD PICTURES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $495,000.

title: Aquino, in Sermon, Warns the Communists
description: President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines delivered a church sermon today and used it to warn that she would wage ''the good, the honorable, the moral fight'' against Communist insurgents should reconciliation attempts fail.

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $237,679 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $49,044 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $332,780 and $156,508 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the share earnings are not available because earnings subsequent to Dec. 31, 1982, benefit the preferred shareholders until preferred stockholders' equity equals or exceeds the liquidating and mandatory redemption values.

title: OCCUPATIONAL URGENT CARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Atlanta Rapid Transit In $170 Million Offering
description: The Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority is offering $170 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 7.15 percent for the 2016 maturity and 7.11 percent for the 2006 issue.

title: JAZZ: LOUIS BELLSON
description: THE quartet the drummer Louis Bellson is leading at Carlos 1, Avenue of the Americas between Ninth and 10th Streets, through Sunday, is the kind of polished and swinging group one would expect of this inventive and experienced drummer.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A book review on Nov. 6 of Renata Adler's ''Reckless Disregard'' misattributed garbling in a sentence from page 208. The book's publisher, Alfred A. Knopf Inc., reports that the density of the passage resulted from two typographical errors in the published version. The sentence should have read: ''With this answer, if Halevy's presence (and his apparent readiness to say anything at all, as if factual matters were a thing of barter, or of haggling in a souk) were not already so disorienting, Time's whole position fell, perhaps not for the first time, to smithereens.''

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Saturday about the tentative agreement between striking freelance musicians and a consortium of New York orchestras misidentified one orchestra. The Queens Symphony, not the Queens Philharmonic, was involved.

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Revenue represents royalty income and share earnings are in units.

title: Exit Line
description: John Gutekunst, Minnesota football coach, when asked to name his greatest concern going into 101,701-seat Michigan Stadium this Saturday: ''Getting out.''

title: Mead-Ampad Deal
description: The Mead Corporation and the Ampad Corporation said that they had reached an agreement for Mead to acquire Ampad, an office paper supplies company, for about $117.9 million, or $22.50 a share.

title: Five Piano Recitals
description: ''Pianists' Choice,'' a five-part series of solo recitals at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, begins Monday with an appearance by Joaquin Achucarro.

title: USF & G Notes
description: The USF & G Corporation, an insurance concern, is offering $100 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.20, to yield 9 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A by S. & P., the notes yield about 1 5/8 percentage points more than 10-year Treasury notes. The notes are not callable for seven years.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
International Red Cross Name Change Is an Act of Anti-Jewish Rejection
description: To the Editor:

title: AGENDA: NOV. 13, 1986
description: Makeup Artist Trial

title: Britoil Plans Sale
description: Britoil, the privatized British oil and gas conglomerate, said it was putting up for sale its American assets, bought three years ago for $157 million.

title: A TRIBUTE TO COPLAND
description: Before the start of Tuesday night's National Symphony Orchestra concert, the composer Aaron Copland was honored for being the recipient of a Congressional Gold Medal.

title: GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 9 months. The company said in the latest quarter it paid $450,000 to settle litigation.

title: RECALLING SUMMER 1943
description: IF you have any recollection of the American pastiche during World War II, watch ''Our World'' at 8 o'clock tonight. It is evocative. If you have no recollection, watch it anyway. It is living, breathing history. The one-hour ABC program puts our past in perspective.

title: Gimbels, the Snail And the Tilted Arc
description: One Last Sale

title: Ericsson Sees Recovery
description: The Swedish telecommunications group Ericsson said today that it is on the road to recovery after a difficult period and hopes its information systems division will break even next year. Earlier this year the company laid off 4,800 workers worldwide.

title: Parker-Hannifin
description: The Parker-Hannifin Corporation is offering $100 million of 9.45 percent debentures due in 2016 at a price of 99.80, to yield 9.47 percent, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. Rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S. & P., the debentures yield about 1.6 percentage points more than the 9 1/4 percent Treasury bonds due in 2016. The 30-year debentures are not refundable for 10 years and are subject to a sinking fund beginning in 1997 that will retire 95 percent of the issue by maturity and result in an average life of 20 1/2 years.

title: Lomas & Nettleton
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, one of the largest mortgage bankers in the country, said it would buy the Union Life Insurance Company of Little Rock, Ark., for $52.5 million.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,028,000 and $4,338,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $71,000 for the quarter and $6,029,000 for the 9 months.

title: IN WINTER, GEOMETRY AND COLOR PERSEVERE
description: THE fall puts all our gardens to the test. It lays bare their bones. After the frosts have stripped the trees of leaves, and withered to brown relics the clumps of annuals and perennials, what are you left with for the barren months? Will the bright winter sun, low-angled in the sky, show you plants revealing as much, or more, of their beauty in their winter dormancy? When snow blankets the view from the windows of the house do the white mounds look like a garden at all, or would a used-car lot look as comely under the neutral covering?

title: Some Holders of First Interstate Oppose Its Offer
description: Some large shareholders of the First Interstate Bancorp said today that they oppose the bank's offer to buy the ailing BankAmerica Corporation because it will hurt First Interstate's stock performance.

title: Skiing Is a Big Topic on Home Cassettes
description: Over the years, learning how to ski has become easier as instruction methods have improved along with skis and boots. Now it appears that anyone with a video cassette recorder can make the next great step by learning to ski at home - even in the middle of summer.

title: 4th Woman to Receive Artificial Heart Rests
description: The fourth woman to receive a Jarvik-7 artificial heart was alert, smiling and able to squeeze the hands of members of her family today after receiving the device to save her life until a human heart donor could be found.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Lessons of the Wollman Rink
description: New York City bungled the job of reopening Central Park's Wollman Skating Rink for six years, wasting millions. Then last June, city officials said it would take two more years to correct the mistakes and complete the job.

title: '78 WORK BY BACON IS SOLD
description: Francis Bacon's ''Seated Figure,'' a 1978 painting showing two men -one crouching, one in profile in suit and tie against a gloriously colored background - was sold last night at Christie's for the highest price at auction ever achieved for a work by the British artist.

title: BRIDGE: A HAND FROM OCTOBER 1936 GETS FRESH LOOK IN MAGAZINE
description: Few periodicals can look back half a century in their files and find something that a modern reader will find of great interest.

title: Cubans Said to Arrest Five Rights Activists
description: The Cuban Government has arrested five human-rights activists and expelled two European journalists who interviewed one of them, a human-rights group and relatives of those arrested charged yesterday.

title: SCHOOLS ADD GREEN THUMB TO SCIENCE
description: THE students at Green Acres, a public school here, often lunch on salads, which is not unusual. But the ripe tomatoes and crisp fresh lettuce are among several crops the children grow themselves, in soil they analyze for nutrient content and fertilize with compost they produce on the site, all in an innovative elementary school science program called Life Lab.

title: Advertising; Tracy-Locke Account
description: After a five-way competition, Tracy-Locke, Dallas, has picked up the business of APT Managed Health Care Partnership of Dallas, a new nationwide health care and financing organization. The new account promises more than a million in billings.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: UNIVERSAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months' loss was primarily attributable to a one-time charge of $716,000 taken in the first quarter and related to a contractual obligation to the former chairman of the company.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $6,917,000 gain on the debt restructuring of an affiliated company. c-Net loss

title: REINS ON CITIZENSHIP? FRENCH DEBATE CHIRAC BILL
description: The Government formally proposed a new law today that, if adopted by the Parliament, would change the definition of who is a French citizen.

title: RHINE POISONING STRETCHING 185 MILES
description: Scientists said today that roughly 185 miles of the Rhine River, from Basel, Switzerland, to Mainz, West Germany, had suffered serious ecological damage as a result of the accidental release of poisonous chemicals.

title: ANTI-WHALING GROUP NAMES ICELAND SABOTEUR
description: The head of a militant environmental group identified a 22-year-old Californian as one of two people responsible for sinking two Icelandic whaling ships and sabotaging a whale-meat processing factory in Iceland over the weekend. He said the other person, whom he would not fully identify, was a British citizen.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1986
description: The World

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $846,000 and $1,360,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: A Flawed Immigration Law
description: If laws could really alter market forces or curb the ups and downs of labor supply and demand, then the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, signed last week by President Reagan, might have worked. In reality, those flows cannot be easily toyed with, and the legislation will not be effective - although it may take time for this to become evident.

title: IRAN ENVOY DENIES DEAL ON HOSTAGES
description: The highest ranking Iranian official in the United States strongly denied today that his Government was involved in trading American hostages for military equipment. But he made it clear that Iran would welcome better relations with the United States.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS RESTITUTION FEES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that convicted criminals may not avoid making court-ordered restitution payments to victims of their crimes by declaring bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the Federal Bankrupcy Code.

title: U.S. ISSUES GUIDES ON CURBING DATA
description: The Reagan Administration has issued new guidelines to Federal agencies on restricting the release of a broad range of Government data that are unclassified but considered ''sensitive,'' a high-ranking Defense Department official said today.

title: MYERS, L E CO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEVILS BREAK LOOSE AND END SLUMP
description: The Devils, winning for the first time in five games, capitalized on defensive lapses by the Detroit Red Wings tonight to post a 5-3 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: ANDAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $13,431,000 and $13,451,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, relating to the sale of Andal's interest in Kinney System Inc., and extraordinary gains of $4,802,000 for the quarter and $8,276,000 for the year from the partial use of tax carryovers and termination of an employee pension plan. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $168,000 for the quarter and $358,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $150,000 and $353,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the partial use of tax carryovers and termination of an employee pension plan.

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Move by Phelps
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, said it would move its corporate headquarters from New York to Phoenix by May 1987. Phelps Dodge's president, G. Robert Durham, said the move was intended to make the company's management more efficient. Phelps Dodge currently has regional headquarters in Phoenix, employing about 150 people. Mr. Durham said Phelps Dodge either would place on early retirement or lay off all but about a dozen of its approximately 100 employees in New York and would hire replacements in Phoenix.

title: Readings of Works By Quebec Playwrights
description: A free series of staged readings featuring works by playwrights from Quebec is being held at the Ubu Repertory Theater, 149 Mercer Street.

title: New York City Bus Passengers Know Why Ridership Is Down
description: To the Editor:

title: MODERN CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Strength Is Weakness
description: Nothing Ronald Reagan has done as President has so troubled Americans as his bargaining for the release of hostages in return for arms shipments to Iran. That, at least, is the feeling I get from conversations with people who have admired and supported the President.

title: AMERICAN HEALTHCARE MANGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
5-YEAR-OLD ATLANTIC MAGAZINE CASE IS POSTPONED
description: A five-year-old libel suit by the former editor of the Atlantic magazine against its new owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, was postponed today, and the judge in the case said he doubted the former editor could win the suit.

title: HANDYMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $700,000 for the quarter and $1.2 million for the 9 months on the sale of real estate. c-Includes a gain of $3.9 million on the sale of real estate.

title: A Borough Filled With Brilliant Gems of Urban Architecture
description: It is over the bridge or through the tunnel, but in some ways Brooklyn is more entitled than Manhattan to call itself the heart of New York. This is, after all, the borough more New Yorkers live in than any other; it stretches from the gracious brownstones of the Heights to the sprawling slabs of Starrett City, and in between are neighborhoods of such vivid character as Park Slope, Red Hook, Flatbush and Williamsburg. Brooklyn has become more and more important to the city's cultural life, and its renewed neighborhoods are now more richly diverse than ever before. On pages C24 and C25, several Times writers explore Brooklyn on the rise.

title: A HANDEL WORK
description: The Sine Nomine Singers and Baroque Orchestra, under the direction of Harry Saltzman, will present Handel's ''Alexander's Feast'' tomorrow night at 7:30 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: Five New Yankees
description: The Yankees have purchased the contracts of five of their minor league players and added them to the major league roster.

title: PHOENIX AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $689,000.

title: PACERS GO LONG TO BEAT THE NETS
description: For years it was easy to map a defense against the Indiana Pacers, whose offense was basically going inside to their big men. Their outside shooting was a long shot.

title: SUNSHINE-JR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAJOR LEFTIST LEADER IS FOUND SLAIN IN PHILIPPINES
description: A political leader who headed both a major leftist party and the nation's largest labor union was found slain today, and party members immediately blamed the military for the killing. The country's top military officials denied the accusation.

title: Civil Rights and Newspaper Boxes
description: This is a news-hungry town, a place where information is power, and perhaps nothing underscores that more than the colorful clusters and long lines of newspaper vending machines found on just about every major corner.

title: SPORTSMAN'S GUIDE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: The directors and the shareholders of the Cleveland Indians yesterday approved the sale of the team to Richard and David Jacobs, who are real estate developers. The sale, which must be approved by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, 10 of the 14 American League teams and 7 of the 12 National League clubs, was for $34 million, according to The Cleveland Plain Dealer. . . . . . . The Atlanta Falcon center, Jeff Van Note, at 40 the oldest player in the National Football League, said he will retire at the end of the season because he's ''tired of playing.'' He is in his 18th season and has played in 240 games.

title: A Bustling Scene On a Bevy of Stages
description: DANCE and theater in Brooklyn are a matter of institutions and adventures. The Brooklyn Academy of Music, an institution par excellence, celebrates its 125th anniversary this year. But there are vital younger institutions like the BACA Downtown Center for the Arts, now 20, and the Thelma Hill Performing Arts Center, a 10-year-old mecca for black dance and music. College-affiliated performing arts series have helped to make theatergoing a family and neighborhood affair. And for the adventurous, there are more than 60 dance groups and some 50 theater troupes based in Brooklyn that offer performances, readings and lectures throughout the season.

title: Reagan Envoy Describes Trip
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser to President Reagan, last night branded as fiction many of the bizarre details in Iranian accounts of his secret four-day mission to Iran last spring.

title: People
description: * Arthur T. Zimmerman has been named senior vice president for the business-to-business group at Gilbert, Whitney & Johns, Whippany, N.J.

title: U.S. TO CUT ARMS AID TO ALLIES, SOME WITH AMERICAN BASES
description: The Reagan Administration, responding to Congressional reductions in foreign aid, is about to announce cuts in military assistance to some close allies, including nations that provide important bases for American forces.

title: Off We Go, Again, on Fighter Planes
description: The largest centrally managed economy in the world, outside the Soviet Union, is run by the U.S. Defense Department. Hating the discipline of free markets, the Pentagon bureaucracy insulates its contractors from competition. They in turn lobby Congress to keep paying the bills, and the services continue to buy gold-plated weapons. Two recent decisions by Air Force Secretary Edward Aldridge demonstrate just how tight the loop is.

title: 'Shogun' Rule Changes
description: Access to the Tokyo bond market for some non-Japanese companies is increasing as Japanese banks waive certain financial requirements imposed in the past.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The View From the Bench
description: When the Giants play the Minnesota Vikings Sunday in Minneapolis, Joe Morris will probably carry the ball 25 to 35 times. On just about every carry, Maurice Carthon will probably block for him.

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A-S reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Novo said the figures were converted into dollars from Danish krona at the exchange rate of 7.64 krona to the dollar as of Sept. 30, 1986. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt.

title: NASA WITHHOLDS PHOTOS OF CHALLENGER CABIN
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would not make public photographs of wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin because the pictures would be ''exceedingly disturbing'' to the families of the seven astronauts who were aboard.

title: No Rate Shift By Bonn Seen
description: Senior West German bankers say their central bank is unlikely, despite a recent interest rate accord between Tokyo and Washington, to alter key lending rates before national elections in January.

title: ARTISTIC GREETINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRELAND WINNER WITH KNOCKOUT
description: Mark Breland, the undefeated welterweight from Brooklyn, achieved his 16th victory when he knocked out Orlando Orozco of Caracas, Venezuela, last night at 1:46 of the second round at the Felt Forum.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A SATISFYING dinner for two in Manhattan for less than $25 is as rare as free on-street parking at midday - at least in settings where you can sit at a table and use utensils. Indian Cafe, on 95th Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, is just such a place. This diminutive restaurant serves better-than-average Indian food in an unembellished but clean and friendly environment.

title: SKATING SNOWMEN AND THE CIRCUS COME TO TOWN
description: THE Halloween jack-o'-lanterns may not even be thrown away yet. Thanksgiving's turkeys are still alive and gobbling. But should one be so foolish as to presume it's still autumn, this weekend should banish any such delusions. The Christmas season has arrived.

title: Puerto Rico's Fresh Caribbean Breeze
description: By most accounts, including President Reagan's, the Administration's Caribbean Basin Initiative has been a disappointment. New hope for the troubled region now appears from an unexpected source - Puerto Rico.

title: GAF HAS A STAKE IN BORG-WARNER
description: A takeover attack against the Borg-Warner Corporation broke out yesterday along a second front as the GAF Corporation disclosed that it now owns 4.9 percent of the manufacturing and services concern plus an option to buy an additional 4.7 percent, for a total of 9.6 percent.

title: EXPERTS FAULT U.S. RULES ON LEAD IN DRINKING WATER
description: Proposed Federal restrictions on lead in drinking water are insufficient to end the country's ''lead epidemic,'' an environmental toxicologist said today.

title: ART: 'INTERPRETIVE LINK,' VIEW OF PIVOTAL MOVEMENT
description: ''T HE INTERPRETIVE LINK: Abstract Surrealism Into Abstract Expressionism, Works on Paper 1938-1948,'' at the Whitney Museum's Equitable Center branch (787 Seventh Avenue, at 52d Street), rehearses a moment in art that is both legendary and still vital. It is the moment when a number of American and European artists, isolated in New York by World War II, liberated abstraction from the grip of Cubist-derived geometry by parlaying the ideas gleaned from Picasso, Miro and the automatist drawing of Surrealism into a new kind of painting, soon to be called Abstract Expressionism. It is a moment that we seem never to tire of delving into in pursuit of new data, new insights and that elusive phantom, the whole story.

title: BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $200,000 and $2,383,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and after an extraordinary tax loss of $564,000. The company said effective Jan. 1, 1986, it adopted the provisions of FASB No. 87 Employers' Accounting for Pensions to conform to new requirements. This change had no material effect on net income for the three or nine-month periods ended September 30, 1986.

title: MID-STATE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (OCALA, FLA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Emigre's Marrow Found Usable for Brother
description: Israeli doctors have found that the bone marrow of a Soviet woman and her Israeli brother are compatible, but they said it might be too late to save the brother's life.

title: BRUCE, ROBERT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CARLA BLEY QUINTET
description: The composer-keyboardist Carla Bley and her quintet will perform tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M., with no late set Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: CITY ACADEMY FOR CASEWORK MIRED IN DELAY
description: More than two years after agreeing to establish an academy to train caseworkers to handle the rising volume of child-abuse and neglect complaints, the Koch administration has yet to open the institution.

title: Wedding Bells
description: ''I want to go all out when I play for Sweden, but I can't do that so close to the wedding,'' said Mats Wilander, expressing his regrets at not being able to help his country defend its Davis Cup title in the final against Australia next month because he is preparing for his marriage to Sonya Mulholland Jan. 3. The final is scheduled for Dec. 26-28.

title: Mandatory Drug Tests Upset For Police and Firefighters
description: Mandatory drug tests for all Chattanooga firefighters and police officers violate their constitutional protection against unreasonable searches, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: Concerts and Recitals in CHurches and Halls
description: Duke Ellington advised his listeners to take the A train, calling it the fastest way to get to Harlem. It's also one of the best ways of getting to Brooklyn, but several bridges, tunnels and, indeed, several other trains will also do the trick.

title: Metromedia Radio
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved the sale of nine of the Metromedia Broadcasting Corporation's major-market radio stations.

title: ART: POLKE ON DISPLAY
description: PAINTING can never be just another activity, nor, probably, just another art. Sigmar Polke, whose recent abstract paintings are on view at the Mary Boone-Michael Werner Gallery (417 West Broadway, at Prince Street) through Nov. 29, is among the most important of those artists busily painting today after having cleared for themselves a wider turf on which painting, if not disqualified, was only one game. But you either paint or you don't paint; and even if you sought only to make anti-paintings, you might get hooked. Polke's new abstractions may be outrageous, but they are also impressive paintings, almost whether he likes it or not.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day last Saturday with an article about the historic domination of the car market by General Motors misstated the size of Ford Motor's staff, using information supplied by that company. In 1980, Ford's salaried work force in the United States totaled 76,000, and in 1985 it was 69,000.

title: Rare Reds
description: As the Reds contemplated the makeup of their 40-man winter roster in recent days, there was considerable debate among Cincinnatians as to whether Pete Rose, part-time player, full-time manager and all-time legend, should occupy a spot that might otherwise be given to one of several young prospects. In the end, Rose elected not to put himself on the roster. But if the Reds had chosen to be devious, they might have found room for him and 40 others at the same time.

title: A Republican Shuffle
description: William I. Greener 3d is leaving his post as Deputy Chief of Staff for Political Operations at the Republican National Committee to take a job in private business. His successor, effective Jan. 3, will be Christopher J. Bowman, now deputy executive director of the National Republican Congressional Committee.

title: New Fodder in PAC War
description: Advocates of limiting the amount of money that political action committees can contribute to Congressional candidates may have acquired a dramatically strengthened argument from House election results last week.

title: OFFICERS EXPLAIN WHY TRANSFERS UPSET THEM
description: On the precinct house steps and on the neighborhood blocks that have become so familiar to them over the years, police officers yesterday denounced the department's plan to transfer groups of officers to new precincts each year.

title: ISSUES CAUTION
description: Governor Cuomo warned a group of publishers and advertising executives yesterday that if the press did not regulate itself, the Supreme Court might restrict news organizations' freedom.

title: Emanuel P. Lewis Dies at 83; A Lender to Textile Concerns
description: Emanuel P. Lewis, who served the textile industry for many years as a leading lender, or factor, died of Alzheimer's disease Tuesday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hoyt Pleads Guilty
description: LaMarr Hoyt of the San Diego Padres, the 1983 American League Cy Young Award winner with the White Sox, pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor drug counts before a United States magistrate in San Diego yesterday and agreed to spend at least 60 days in jail, pay a fine of up to $5,000 and forfeit his 1986 Porsche 944.

title: Big Losers of 1986?
description: In the 1986 elections, numerous senators and governors lost their offices, the President's party lost control of the Senate, the Republicans lost their momentum toward party realignment, and out in Kansas a frog named Agnes lost by 3 to 1 as a write-in candidate for Douglas County Commissioner.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $2,761,000 for the quarter and $144,349,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes investment gains of $37,200,000 and $107,554,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: FRENCH CONCERN TO BUY UNION CARBIDE BUSINESS
description: The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its agricultural chemicals business for $575 million in cash to the Rhone-Poulenc Group, the French chemical producer.

title: A Library of Medicine Turns 150
description: Three hundred guests, among them 32 Nobel laureates, will gather at the J. W. Marriott Hotel here Tuesday evening for a black-tie dinner toasting one of this country's little known treasures.

title: Nov. 1-10 Car Sales Rose 5.7%
description: New-car sales by United States manufacturers from Nov. 1-10 rose 5.7 percent from the corresponding period last year, the companies reported today.

title: STOCKTON SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A.M.C. BETS ON BIGGER CARS
description: The American Motors Corporation, the perennial also-ran of the auto industry, could be headed either for a turnaround or for its last hurrah when it introduces a new line of midsize cars next fall.

title: Racing Notebook; STATE RAISES ANTE FOR STAKES
description: The New York Racing Association is increasing its stakes purses by $3.87 million next year, with the biggest chunk of it going to make the Travers Stakes at Saratoga and the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Belmont Park $1 million races.

title: AUCTIONS
description: OLD MASTER prints - Rembrandts, Durers, Van Dykes and Piranesis - will be auctioned next week at Sotheby's and Christie's in sales that offer an unusual bounty of works by these and other artists. The sales come less than a year after the Duke of Devonshire sold 300 Old Master prints from the Chatsworth Collection in a landmark auction last December at Christie's in London.

title: Scholastic Inc.
description: Scholastic Inc., well known for its publishing activities directed at both students and teachers, has established a Teacher Magazine Network to help advertisers reach that beloved segment.

title: Group Withdraws Bid for Scholastic
description: Scholastic Inc., the educational publishing and television programming company, said that a management-led investor group had withdrawn its offer to acquire the concern for $50 million. David A. Boillot, Scholastic's general counsel, said the deal fell through after the investor group failed to reach an agreement with a special committee appointed by Scholastic's board to review the bid.

title: M/A COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $59,285,000 for the quarter and $35.1 million for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $4.1 million for the quarter and year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $789,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $4,965,000 for the year. The 1985 periods have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain of $5.7 million representing interest on a tax refund, a gain of $2.2 million under a Trans-Alaska Pipeline settlement and a $3 million reduction in interest expense due to the recomputation of amortization of the deferred gain related to the prior restructuring of Tosco's bank debt. c-Net income and after a pre-tax charge of $1 million.

title: Bonanno, 41, Is Sentenced
description: Joseph C. Bonanno Jr., 41 years old, the son of a one-time organized crime leader, has been sentenced to four years in Federal prison for taking part in a fraudulent investment scheme. The sentence was imposed Wednesday for his conviction in May on eight counts of fraud and conspiracy for defrauding investors of $250,000.

title: TRIANGLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $535,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings and shares outstanding for the year-ago periods were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend in December 1985.

title: BEYOND PARLEY, BISHOPS STIR DISPUTE
description: Although the country's Roman Catholic bishops overwhelmingly approved their pastoral letter on ''Economic Justice for All,'' the report is anything but noncontroversial in the broader American political arena.

title: KEY RATES
TRANSCRIPT OF REMARKS BY REAGAN ABOUT IRAN
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1986
description: Companies

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a charge of about $2.5 million related to the company's unsuccessful bid for Storrer Communications Inc. The company said the third quarter loss was due to the company's 25 precent share in the losses of Group W Cable Inc., which was $5,218,000.

title: O'Connor Cuts a Rug
description: Dignity aside, some of her senior colleagues on the Supreme Court are old enough to have mastered the Charleston when it was the ballroom craze of the 1920's, but Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor clearly is not. The other evening at the Chevy Chase Club, however, the Justice and her lawyer-husband, John J. O'Connor, were the focus of considerable extralegal interest on the dance floor as they performed a spirited but entirely proper version of the heel-kicking Jazz Age dance.

title: LVI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $249,000 and $749,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $398,000 for the both quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $278,000. The company, formerly Lehigh Valley Industries Inc., acquired Inco Inc. Oct. 31, 1985.

title: OPEC PANEL TO TACKLE PRICING
description: A three-member pricing committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries begins meeting today in Quito, Ecuador, charged with finding a way to raise the price of a barrel of oil by about $3, to $18.

title: Study of U.S. Hospitals Calls 40% of Admissions Avoidable
description: Forty percent of all hospitalizations in the United States could probably be avoided, and cost-sharing insurance plans apparently do nothing to prevent such waste, researchers said Wednesday.

title: EATERIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CHILDREN OF WAR BEGIN PEACE TOUR
description: Arn Chorn yesterday described his experience as a child in Cambodia under the Khmer Rouge. He told how, as a 9-year-old, he had been forced to carry a gun and fight in Cambodia's civil war, forced to ''watch thousands of people be killed.''

title: IRE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,987,000 on the sale of the company's stock holdings in Heritage Federal Savings & Loan for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9-month also includes a pre-tax gain of $749,000 on a similar stock sale in the second quarter.

title: MEDITRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in October 1985. The year-ago figures are not available.

title: Breaking the Ice
description: Brett Hull, son of the legendary Bobby Hull, scored his first National Hockey League goal last night and it gave the Calgary Flames a 4-3 victory over the Hartford Whalers. Hull, a rookie, scored 7 minutes 15 seconds into the final period, breaking a 3-3 tie.

title: U.S. LAUNCHES MUSEUM SATELLITE
description: A $13 million Air Force satellite that spent eight years as a museum piece was launched today on a twice-delayed mission meant to improve communications between ground stations and other spacecraft.

title: POLICE SEEKING WOMAN'S NAME IN FRAUD CASE
description: The flimflam always started with the name - Christina Onassis, the name of a sister the late Greek shipping tycoon never had.

title: THE SCREEN: 'GOODBYE'
description: TOM HANKS is utterly out of place in the Israeli romance ''Every Time We Say Goodbye,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, for at least two reasons: because there's something so innately comic about him, even in solemn surroundings, and because he has so much more energy than the film does. As directed by Moshe Mizrahi (''Madame Rosa,'' ''I Love You Rosa''), this love story is mostly notable for its strained, awkward small talk and its long, long pauses.

title: SOME AT FIRST INTERSTATE PREFER TO AVOID A FIGHT
description: Several directors of the First Interstate Bancorp appear to be against a hostile tender offer to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation and a proxy fight to try to unseat BankAmerica's board.

title:
Preserving Security in Europe;
Elimination Of Missiles Is Unsound
description: If implemented, the mutual proposal at Reykjavik to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear missiles from Europe would undermine the foundation of our allies' security.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the homeless mentally ill misidentified Katherine Falk.

title: KAYPRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Brokerage, Agency In Venture
description: EDWARD N. NEY, who was involved in many successful acquisitions during his 15 years as chief executive of Young & Rubicam, is now going to be offering that expertise to the rest of the business world.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Britain's Answer to the Phone Paradox
description: This has always been the Catch-22 of utility regulation: If rates are linked to the cost of providing services, the utility will have no reason to strive for efficiencies that hold down costs. Indeed, the higher the cost, the more the utility is likely to be able to add on for profit. Yet to sever the link between price and cost gives the utility an incentive to gouge the public.

title: Court Delays License For Ohio Nuclear Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission issued a full-power operating license for the Perry nuclear power plant today, but a Federal appeals court put the license on hold a few hours later.

title: Dining Out Guide: New, Uptown
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, #206 East 60th Street (838-0440) - **(Nov. 15, 1985) Some of the best California- and Southwestern-style food around is available at this exuberant new Upper East Side spot.

title: TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After pre-tax writedowns of $77.3 million for the quarter and includes writedowns of $130.3 million, after taxes, for the year. c-After pre-tax writedowns of $28.1 million for the quarter and includes writedowns of $106 million, after taxes, for the year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LEARNED PIGS & FIREPROOF WOMEN. By Ricky Jay. Illustrated. 340 pages. Villard Books. $29.95.

title: At Restaurants, From Neapolitan Dishes to Middle Eastern Delicacies
description: Manhattanites are generally wary of seeking out restaurants in the mysterious boroughs, or at least those establishments they can't see from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. That's just fine to the two-million-plus residents of Brooklyn - makes it easier to get a table.

title: Accepting His Fate
description: Coach Jim Criner said yesterday that he was leaving the school and its football program with his ''head high.'' Criner was dismissed two days before Iowa State officials were scheduled to defend the school before a National Collegiate Athletic Association panel on 44 charges of rules violations.

title: U.S. ISSUES GUIDELINES TO RESTRICT RELEASE OF 'SENSITIVE' INFORMATION
description: The Reagan Administration has issued new guidelines to Federal agencies on restricting the release of a broad range of Government data that are unclassified but considered ''sensitive,'' a high-ranking Defense Department official said Wednesday.

title: Yes, Rotate the Police
description: Good for Police Commissioner Ward of New York City and good for the police union for their willingness to work out differences over his plan to rotate officers among precincts. He might have been more collegial and consulted the union in advance. The union could have been less touchy about the plan; it is a sound way to fight corruption. For the parties now to be talking may well spare the city a useless confrontation.

title: BLAIR, JOHN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $53,049,000 for the quarter and $32,343,000 for the 9 months, and the 9-month also includes an extraordinary loss of $12,090,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,328,000 and $11,042,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: AIDS VIRUS FOUND IN 2 IN SEX CLUBS
description: The AIDS virus has been detected in two Minnesota women belonging to sex clubs whose promiscuous members appeared to be largely unaware that their multiple sexual encounters put them at high risk for the disease, Federal health officials said today.

title: UNAUTHORIZED MESSAGES CLUTTER POLICE RADIO
description: Emergency radio frequencies used by the police were jammed with static occasionally and sprinkled with negative remarks about Commissioner Benjamin Ward during the police slowdown, according to photographers, scanner buffs and others who monitor the broadcasts.

title: HUTTON'S CHIEF PLANS LAYOFFS
description: Robert P. Rittereiser, the newly appointed chief executive officer of the E. F. Hutton Group, said yesterday that to improve the brokerage firm's profitability he would concentrate on cutting costs, partly through staff layoffs. Hutton has 17,000 employees.

title: Preserving Security in Europe; NATO Can Hold Its Own
description: The possibility of deep cuts in nuclear arsenals opened at Reykjavik has renewed fears of Soviet non-nuclear superiority in Europe. Today, powerful voices from right and left argue that elimination of nuclear arms would leave the Western alliance prostrate before overwhelmingly superior Soviet conventional strength. While nuclear weapons contribute to deterrence, the non-nuclear military balance is not so bad as people think. Dire claims of Soviet conventional strength must not be allowed to prevent the United States from engaging in arms control that could reduce nuclear weapons, save money and stabilize the nuclear balance.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $374.6 million, to $234.98 billion, for the week ending Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. All three fund categories showed slight gains. Assets of the 92 institutional funds rose $184.6 million, to $66.47 billion; assets of the 191 general-purpose funds gained $128.5 million, to $64.05 billion, and the 92 broker-dealer funds increased by $61.5 million, to $104.45 billion.

title: Fast Lane Magazine For The Man Under 30
description: The business card identified the man as Andy Kowl, editor and associate publisher of Fast Lane Inc., Timonium, Md. And as he proferred it, quite conservative in his three-piece suit and neatly cropped beard, he said that the magazine, to be issued for the first time at the end of March, will be for men under 30.

title: PRESIDENT WILL SEEK ALTERNATIVES TO SYSTEM OF BUDGET PREPARATION
description: The White House will propose important changes next year in the way the Government prepares the Federal budget, a process the Administration as well as its critics in Congress say has failed, according to officials.

title: ART: JOHN McCRACKEN, 20 YEARS OF SCULPTURE
description: JOHN McCRACKEN has been welcomed back to New York in style. The 52-year-old artist was nationally known in the late 1960's and early 1970's, when his smoothly finished, monochromatic planks, resting upright against walls like adaptable doors, helped define the Minimalist esthetic. But McCracken all but disappeared from view in the mid-70's, when he left New York and returned to his native California, and the general impression has been that his best work was past.

title: JOHN ADAMS LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,000 and $102,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a realized investment gains of $1,000 for the quarter and a realized investment losses of $7,000 for the 9 months.

title: BERNARD WALDMAN
description: Bernard Waldman, a physicist who observed the explosion of the atomic bomb at Hiroshima from an airplane, died Wednesday while hospitalized for cancer in Sanford, N.C., the University of Notre Dame said today. He was 73 years old.

title: THE OPERA ENSEMBLE HAS FUN WITH 'FOUR SAINTS'
description: WHEN the saints go marching across the stage of the Lillie Blake School Theater this weekend, the operatic spotlight of New York will focus on a small company organized seven years ago in borrowed office space with pay phones. This month's nine performances by the Opera Ensemble of New York of the Gertrude Stein-Virgil Thomson opera ''Four Saints in Three Acts'' mark one of the season's most ambitious operatic revivals. Coinciding with the 90th birthday of its composer, Virgil Thomson, on Nov. 25, the production, directed by John J. D. Sheehan, designed by Rouben Ter-Arutunian and conducted by Paul Dunkel, is an exercise in what Mr. Sheehan called ''pageantry and tableau.''

title: A NEW ICE AGE STARTS AT WOLLMAN RINK
description: It took more than six years to make the ice for the reopening of the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park yesterday, and the New Yorkers who tried it out said it was fine.

title: A CITY EFFORT TO HALT RISE IN HOMELESS
description: Facing eviction, Carmen Lugo, a single parent with two small children, went to Housing Court in the Bronx to arrange to tell a judge why she had not paid her rent for four months.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FINAL DRAFT OF BISHOPS' LETTER ON THE ECONOMY
description: Following are excerpts from the third and final draft of a 115-page pastoral letter, ''Economic Justice for All: Catholic Social Teaching and the U.S. Economy.'' The Church

title: U.S. SAYS IT MET IRANIANS ON THE RETURN OF ASSETS
description: American and Iranian financial officials met two weeks ago in The Hague to discuss the return of nearly $500 million to the Teheran Government, Treasury officials reported today.

title: CONCERN'S FRAUD DISCLOSURE DISPUTED
description: A Federal official who oversaw audits of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor, said yesterday that he was unaware the company had forged $6 million in invoices submitted to the Federal Government in 1981 and 1982.

title: IRAN ARMS DEALS HURT PROSECUTION
description: The recent disclosure of secret United States Government dealings with Iran has complicated Justice Department prosecutions in cases involving arms smuggling to the Iranians.

title: Westchester Issue
description: Westchester County, the only local government in New York State to be rated Aaa by Moody's, is offering $32.2 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Roosevelt & Cross. Yields on the bonds range from 3.50 percent in 1987 to 4.60 percent in 1991, 5.45 percent in 1996, 6.05 percent in 2001 and 6.25 percent in 2006. The bonds are rated AA+ by S.&P.

title: BROADWAY
description: LISTEN to this for a plot: a writer down on his luck who gives up his career and becomes involved with a funeral parlor that was once a chicken 'n' ribs place, and an actor who turns up at the funeral emporium because he thinks he's going to an audition.

title: STARS & STRIPES HANDLES TOUGH WIND LIKE A BREEZE
description: Stars & Stripes took advantage of blustery winds on the America's Cup course today to defeat America II by 1 minute 31 seconds as the second set of challengers' trials came to an end. The 17- to 27-knot breeze was the kind of heavier weather that Stars & Stripes seems to like best.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DOW SAGS BY 31.50 POINTS TO 1,862.20
description: Speculators pulled out of many supposed takeover stocks yesterday, and the rest of the market fell with those stocks, giving Wall Street its worst drop in more than two weeks.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $3,170,000 for the quarter and $9,668,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $2,738,000 for the quarter and $5,648,000 for the 9 months.

title: WOMEN TO FIGHT SMOKING
description: A nationwide campaign to discourage women from smoking is being undertaken by the American Medical Women's Association. The campaign will be the first concerted effort by women who are physicians to tackle smoking as a problem of particular concern to women, according to officers of the 10,000-member organization.

title: MCNEIL EAGER TO MAKE HIS OLD GAINS
description: Could Freeman McNeil's career be over, just like that? He conceded today that the thought had concerned him only a few weeks ago.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about New York City's plan to install water meters in houses misidentified the organization headed by John J. Gilbert 3d. He is president of the Rent Stabilization Association, not the Rent Guidelines Board.

title: His Way Her Way
description: Frank Sinatra is a favorite at the White House, having been chosen to produce and headline entertainment programs at both the Reagan inaugurals. When Kitty Kelley's warts-and-all biography of the singer, ''His Way,'' hit the best-seller list last month, one White House secretary took the book to work but tactfully wrapped it in the jacket of the latest novel by William L. Buckley, a conservative writer who is also very popular with Mr. and Mrs. Reagan.

title: UNITIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Salinger Book Delayed
description: Publication of a biography of J. D. Salinger was delayed yesterday at least until Tuesday.

title: Prize to Economist At Bank of America
description: The Bank of America may be having a difficult year, but its chief economist, John O. Wilson, is riding high among his prognosticating peers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Named Tom Kotchman manager of Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Sri Lanka and India To Talk on Rebellion
description: President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India will hold talks in the southern Indian city of Bangalore on Saturday to see if they can persuade Tamil separatists fighting for an independent state in Sri Lanka to negotiate an end to the conflict.

title: Andrea B. Cohen Is Married to Lester F. Samuels
description: Andrea B. Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Cohen of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married in New York last night to Lester F. Samuels, a son of Mrs. Jay P. Samuels, also of Hewlett Harbor, and the late Mr. Samuels. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony at the Hotel Pierre.

title: STATE ASKING HOSPITALS TO ADD PSYCHIATRIC BEDS
description: The State Office of Mental Health, trying to ease overcrowding in emergency psychiatric units in New York City's municipal hospitals, will ask several private hospitals to begin or expand treatment of emergency psychiatric patients.

title: FRANK GERVASI
description: Frank Gervasi, a painter of landscapes and cityscapes of New York and Texas, died Tuesday at the Brewster Memorial Hospital in Alpine, Tex., near his home in Marfa, Tex. He was 91 years old.

title: Best Bets
description: Ten former N.F.L. head coaches were asked yesterday which teams they thought would make it to the Super Bowl, and the responses should please New Yorkers, at least those who prefer a green color scheme to blue.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: HOPES were sparked for gastronomic improvement along the Upper West Side's quiche belt late this summer with the opening of Fandango, a capacious California-style grill restaurant featuring a compelling and colorful menu. Four recent visits indicate that, for the most part, the smartly conceived food surpasses the drab local competition. As too often is the case, though, blundering service drags down the chef's best efforts - it's like giving Walter Payton the football behind an offensive line of cheerleaders.

title: QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $630,000 from the settlement of the company's claim against the Government of Iran.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Atahualpa Yupanqui, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (840-2824). A South American folk hero returns to New York tonight. More than four decades ago an Argentine guitarist-poet named Hector Roberto Chavero renamed himself Atahualpa, after the last chief of the Incas and Yupanqui, after the 15th-century founder of the Inca empire. Through the years, Mr. Yupanqui, who is now 78 years old, wrote and collected songs about the natural beauty of Argentina and the lives of the people who lived there; he became a major star in Europe as well as South America, and spent some years living in Paris. Some of his songs, about the contrast between rich and poor, became a basis for the Latin American ''nueva cancion'' (''new song'') movement, which uses traditional forms to make political statements - sometimes directly, sometimes metaphorically. At his New York debut concert, three years ago at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Yupanqui was in fine voice; his guitar pieces, based on traditional Argentine zambas and milongas and chacareras, sounded brand-new. And the response of his longtime fans is affectionate, verging on reverence. Tonight at 8; tickets are $20 and $25. Atahualpa Yupanqui will also perform tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Tarrytown Music Hall at 13 Main Street in Tarrytown, N.Y. (914-631-3390), with tickets from $15 to $18, and Sunday at 6 P.M. at the Park Theater, 560 32d Street in Union City, N.J. (201-865-6980), with tickets from $12 to $18.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for 13wk to Sept 27
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $216,000 for both the 13 weeks and 26 weeks. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,000 for the 13 weeks and a loss from discontinued operations of $22,000 for the 26 weeks.

title: CJI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago 9-month figures include the results of Rowe International Inc. since June 1, 1985. The company said there were no 1985 share earnings because the preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: STAGE: REDDIN'S 'STANDARD OF LIVING'
description: IT'S impossible to talk about Keith Reddin without making him sound like just the young writer that the American theater is always seeking but almost never finds. In his three full-length plays seen in New York - ''Life and Limb,'' ''Rum and Coke'' and now, at Playwrights Horizons, ''Highest Standard of Living'' - Mr. Reddin has shown no hesitation about tackling what used to be called ''the big issues.'' Yet as a sometime actor, he has the theatrical wisdom to avoid the documentary agitprop style that makes most American political theater a dreary chore. People hallucinate in Mr. Reddin's comedies, and from their dreams rise socio-cultural-political connections. Before David Lynch directed the film ''Blue Velvet'' or the critic Thomas Hine coined the term ''populuxe'' to describe the social implications of 1950's kitsch, Mr. Reddin, in ''Life and Limb,'' was peeking behind the ''I Love Lucy'' sunniness of booming, Eisenhower-era America to disinter the buried bodies, filthy secrets and official malfeasance of the new cold war consumer state.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $2,780,000 for the quarter and $4,090,000 for the 9 months, from the exchange of the company's 11 percent subordinated notes into common stock. c-Includes non-recurring pre-tax charges of $34 million and $10,875,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said it took a one-time charge of $34 million in the third quarter relating to the restructuring of its Bojangles' subsidiary.

title: L.I.R.R. Reaches Pact With Its Largest Union
description: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and the largest of its unions have reached agreement on a four-and-a-half-year contract, officials announced yesterday.

title: F.B.I. May Have Found Abducted Newborn
description: A baby believed to be the newborn taken from his mother's arms in Sellersville, Pa., last week was found alive today, and a man and a woman have been arrested in connection with the case, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has announced.

title: TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest 9-month loss is after a $14.7 million after-tax writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: CONCERT: GYORGY LIGETI
description: THE Merkin Concert Hall attracted a full, enthusiastic house Wednesday night for what was billed as ''An Evening with Gyorgy Ligeti.''

title: Your Congress at Work
description: Although the Capitol is largely untenanted now, members of the newly elected 100th Congress will make cameo appearances there at least twice before they get down to actual lawmaking in January. Senators will hold caucuses Nov. 20 to choose party leaders and committee chairmen and ranking members of committees for the next two years.

title: The Forecasts: Weak Growth
description: CONCERNS about the strength of the economy were on the rise this week. The dollar fell on expectations of weak data on producer prices and industrial production. The stock market wobbled inconclusively, with some investors hunting for bargains and others alarmed about plant closings and layoffs. The bond market rallied on hopes that the signs of economic weakness would cause the Federal Reserve to ease credit policy and drive down interest rates.

title: INSITUFORM SOUTHEAST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $73,000 and $151,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: GRACE PALEY HONORED AS STATE AUTHOR
description: New York State today named its first state author, the short story writer Grace Paley.

title: N.A.S.D. Rule Proposed
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed rule changes today to allow the National Association of Securities Dealers to issue standards for companies listed on its over-the-counter market, without seeking Federal approval beforehand.

title: HAITI PLANS TO REPLACE MANY ENVOYS BECAUSE OF TIES TO DUVALIERS
description: The Provisional Government said this week that it planned to replace most of its envoys worldwide because of their links to the deposed Duvalier dictatorship.

title: 2 Ex-Aides of Reagan Rebuked on Criticism
description: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, has accused two former officials of the Reagan Administration of cashing in by criticizing President Reagan.

title: CONTACTS WITH TEHERAN: IRANIAN WAS KEY FIGURE
description: The secret talks between Iran and the United States began more than a year ago, when a consultant to the National Security Council met an Iranian expatriate businessman, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of an atomic scientist on Wednesday referred to her incorrectly. She was Dr. Leona Marshall Libby; Marshall was her name by a previous marriage.

title: PIONEER FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $130,000 for the quarter and $826,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $133,000 for the quarter and $208,000 for the 9 months.
