HAGEGARD AND BLEGEN
description: The baritone Hakan Hagegard and the soprano Judith Blegen will present joint recitals at the 92nd Street Y tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 3.

title: SCREEN: 'STREETS OF GOLD'
description: KLAUS MARIA BRANDAUER is a good, resourceful, sturdy actor (''Mephisto,'' ''Out of Africa'') but he can't gracefully carry claptrap like ''Streets of Gold,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters. Nobody could.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $44,442 for an accounting adjustment and a tax credit of $46,000.

title: Getting There
description: Fifteen train lines wind their way to Brooklyn from Manhattan, crossing under or over the East River. They are the Nos. 2 and 3 on the West Side IRT line; the Nos. 4 and 5 on the East Side IRT line; and the A, B, C, D, F, J, L, M, N, Q and R trains.

title: GASDIA LEAVES MET CAST
description: Cecilia Gasdia, the Italian soprano, has the flu and has returned to Italy, the Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday. She was replaced in performance of Gounod's ''Romeo et Juliette'' last night by Diana Soviero. Ms. Soviero, who was scheduled to sing some later performances of the role, will also take the part in Monday night's performance.

title: Shares Offered In British Venture
description: Thousands of investors lined up outside a London bank for the chance to buy shares in the entrepreneur Richard Branson's Virgin organization, which started out in the pop music world but whose diversified units now include an airline.

title: DATAMARINE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5,300 for the quarter and the year includes a tax credit of $67,700. c-Net loss The company said the 1985 year results are restated to include Stephens Engineering Associates acquired earlier this year.

title: Psychiatric System Can't Solve the Problem of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ELECTRO FUNDS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results include Complete Management Systems, acquired in April 1986.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company said the year-ago 9-month results include Holt Renfrew which was sold in April 1986.

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Trial for Custody Of Baby Delayed
description: A judge said yesterday that he was delaying for nearly two months the trial of a surrogate mother fighting for custody of the child she agreed to bear for a couple for $10,000.

title: INSIDE
description: Revlon Bids for Gillette Revlon made an unsolicited offer to buy all shares of Gillette, another famous brand name, for $65 a share, or about $4 billion. Page D1.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch in some copies yesterday about the meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops misstated an area in which Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen was rebuked by the Vatican. He was accused of permitting sterilizations, not abortions, at Catholic hospitals.

title: INTERVIEW ACCURATE, CHIRAC SAYS
description: The office of Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, in a reversal, today conceded the accuracy of an interview in which he said he was told a plot to blow up an El Al jet was hatched by Israeli agents and Syrian dissidents.

title: 6 3/4% Merrill Notes
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is offering $250 million of extendible notes due in 1990 with an initial interest rate of 6 3/4 percent and a price of 100, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. After two years, the investors may put, or redeem, the issue at par, or accept a new interest rate selected by the issuer. The notes are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: ZEMEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $62,000 from reversal of tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $14,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $81,000 from the reversal of tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $261,000 for the 9 months.

title: AN ANGRY FATHER'S ACT OF DESPERATION
description: ONE month ago, the father walked into Jeff Moeller's law office on Main Street here and told the story of how his boy was kicked off the high school football team.

title: Play It Again, Baseball
description: Up to this point, this fuddy-duddy has resisted acquiring a video cassette recorder, on the theory that if we were meant to select movies for our own homes, God would have put a popcorn machine in the den.

title: Joseph H. Murphy, 69, Ex-Tax Commissioner
description: Joseph H. Murphy, the New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance during the Rockefeller years, died Wednesday at Crouse-Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse, after suffering a heart attack a week earlier. He was 69 years old and lived in Fayetteville, N.Y.

title: Pop Music in Parks, Bars and on the Streets
description: Brooklyn is the borough many of New York's finest jazz and pop musicians call home. There are no prestigious showcase clubs like Manhattan's Ritz and Bottom Line for pop and rock, or its Village Vanguard and Sweet Basil for jazz. Brooklyn's musical life is more informal. It is played out in the parks, the streets, the specialty record shops and neighborhood bars, as well as in performing venues in Prospect Park and at St. Ann's Church.

title: Hicks & Haas To Buy Squirt
description: Hicks & Haas said that it had agreed to buy the domestic business of Squirt & Company, the leading producer of grapefruit-flavored soft drinks.

title: JUDGE BARS PLAYING MANES TAPE AT TRIAL
description: The lawyer for Stanley M. Friedman sought unsuccessfully today to play for a Federal jury the videotaped interview in which Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, admitted lying about his suicide attempt last January.

title: SPEAR FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NICARAGUA PRESS SAYS HASENFUS ISN'T LIKELY TO GET QUICK PARDON
description: A report in a pro-Government newspaper today said that the Government was unlikely to issue a quick pardon for Eugene Hasenfus, the American air cargo handler who was the sole survivor of a plane crash in southern Nicaragua on Oct. 5.

title: SWISS SCHOOLS: LEARNING HOW TO LIVE WELL
description: High above Montreux, on what the Swiss call their Cote d'Azur, the Villa Pierrefeu Finishing School looks out over the peaceful vista of Lake Geneva, the Chateau de Chillon and the towering French Alps. That bucolic view defines an image of Swiss tranquillity and goes to the very heart of why thousands of students come to this country each year to study.

title: YANKEE COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $4,045,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes a loss of $123,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MESA MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
CITING 'SCANDAL,' BISHOPS INSIST U.S. DO MORE FOR POOR
description: The country's Roman Catholic bishops today adopted a pastoral letter declaring that current levels of poverty in the United States were ''a social and moral scandal.'' They said the Government must do much more to create jobs and help poor people.

title: Labor's Post-Election Champagne Is Semi-Flat
description: While most people who worked to elect a Democratic majority in the Senate are now enjoying the warm afterglow of victory, John Perkins is brooding.

title: 'Brat Farrar,' Josephine Tey Mystery
description: HAVING just failed to plumb the potential of a P. D. James novel, ''Shroud for a Nightingale,'' public television's ''Mystery!'' is now turning to a story by Josephine Tey, the Scottish author who died in 1952 at the age of 56. As noted by Vincent Price, the series' host, Miss Tey was greatly admired by Alfred Hitchcock. In any event, her identity puzzles seem more compatible with a television dramatization than do, so far, the psychological explorations of Ms. James. Beginning tomorrow at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, ''Brat Farrar,'' the BBC's three-part adaptation by James Andrew Hall, turns out to be a modest but worthwhile diversion for mystery buffs.

title: ROLAND HILL
description: Roland Hill, the designer and art director who designed Sleeping Beauty's Castle at Disneyland and worked on such films as ''Captain Horatio Hornblower'' and ''20,000 Leagues Under the Sea,'' died Monday in Woodland Hills.

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR IN MAFIA TRIAL SUMS UP CASE
description: A prosecutor declared in the final summation of a major racketeering trial yesterday that a ruling Mafia commission had authorized murders, conducted loan sharking and extorted payoffs.

title: The Post-Mortem Throws New Light on a Bad Break
description: In team play slams are pivotal. ''Good slam hits bad break'' is a common scenario and causes the declarer to mutter about the injustices of fate.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $451,000 gain from sales of securities.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KINCK VS. BUCKS, at Milwaukee, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M.) BOSTON CELTICS VS. BULLS, at Chicago, 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) GOLF PGA TOUR: Isuzu Kapalua International, Kapalua Golf Club, Maui, Hawaii (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.) HOCKEY RANGERS VS.

title: Leaseway Accord On $602 Million Bid
description: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation said yesterday that an investor group had agreed to acquire the diversified car-hauling and truck-leasing concern for $51 a share, or about $602 million.

title: Not So Fast With That Federal Bonanza
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleveland-Cliffs Chief
description: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. said that M. Thomas Moore, its president, would also become chief executive at the end of the year upon the retirement of Samuel K. Scovil, who remains chairman. Mr. Moore, 52 years old, became president and a director in July. He joined Cleveland-Cliffs in 1966. Mr. Scovil, now 63, joined the company in 1950 as an iron ore salesman. The company produces iron ore, contracts for oil and gas drilling and produces hardwood lumber.

title: GOTTSCHALKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net realized investment gains of $6,633,809 for the quarter and $29,928,835 for the 9 months. c-Includes net realized investment gains of $1,990,515 and $2,709,936 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $138,000 for the quarter and $414,000 for the 9 months.

title: STATISTICS TELL TALE OF THE OPPORTUNISTIC
description: The Jets have the best record in the National Football League, 9-1, but do they get the most for their efforts? The answer may surprise you. Unsatisfied that the league's principal means of measurement, yards produced and given up, most accurately reflects teams' ability week by week, Steve Hirdt of the Elias Sports Bureau set out several years ago to get a better reading.

title: National Philanthropy Day
description: The country's 800,000 nonprofit philanthropic organizations will have their day Saturday, which has been designated by Congress as National Philanthropy Day. The observance is to be a time for remembering the schools and churches, cultural centers and hospitals, youth groups and all the other associations that help Americans and non-Americans.

title: People Express Shifts Deadline
description: People Express Inc. said yesterday that it had extended until today the deadline for obtaining creditors' approval of a change in the airline's debt structure, a key condition of its acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation. The extension came after

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 1
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 30, 1985.

title: OUTPUT CUT NOT NEEDED TO LIFT PRICE, IRANIAN SAYS
description: Iran's oil minister said today that OPEC did not need to cut its oil output of 17 million barrels a day to increase prices to $18 a barrel.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 14, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE SCREEN: 'DECLINE'
description: ''The Decline of the American Empire'' was shown as part of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 27. The film opens today at the Paris, 4 West 58th Street. DENYS ARCAND'S ''Decline of the American Empire'' isn't easy to know at first.

description: b-After tax credits of $310,000 for the quarter and $430,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Arthur Young Official To Work for Simon
description: Alfred W. Roberts, a vice chairman at Arthur Young & Company, the Big Eight accounting firm, is leaving to work as the chief financial officer for William E. Simon, the wealthy businessman and former Treasury Secretary.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1986
description: The World

title: Article 841086 -- No Title
description: Revlon Group Inc. has begun an unsolicited bid of about $4 billion to acquire the Gillette Company, a company well known for products ranging from Trac II razors to Papermate pens.

title: The Due-Process Costs Of Higher Court Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes tax credits of $54,753 for the quarter and $105,376 for the 6 months.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Directors have often looked on both sides of the Atlantic in their search for the right leading lady. But those searches pale in comparison to one just undertaken by Alixe Gordon. She has traveled to Honolulu, Vancouver, Hong Kong, Peking and Shanghai - and even enlisted the help of the Chinese Deputy Minister of Culture.

title: P.S.C. Affirms A-Plant Decision
description: The State Public Service Commission refused yesterday to consider overturning its decision that utility customers be charged no more than $4.16 billion for the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant on Lake Ontario near Oswego.

title: AL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The the latest 9-month figures include the results of operations of Parmad Pharmaceuticals Inc. beginning on May 29, 1986. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the retroactive effect of the May 1986 3-for-2 stock split.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Gene Lees and Roger Kellaway, Upstairs at Greene Street, 101 Greene Street (925-2415). The pianist Roger Kellaway has made frequent appearances as both accompanist and soloist at the Greene Street Cafe. Tonight, for the first time in New York, he will be joined by Gene Lees, a lyricist and singer with whom he has been collaborating for a dozen years. Mr. Lees, who has been the editor of Down Beat magazine and drama critic of The Louisville Times, is also a novelist and now publishes a monthly Jazzletter. He has written lyrics to the music of Antonio Carlos Jobim (''Quiet Nights of Quiet Stars''), of Bill Evans (''Waltz for Debby'') and of Charles Aznavour (''Formidable!''). His English adaptations for musical settings of poems written in Polish by Karol Wojtyla, who is now Pope John Paul II, have been recorded by Sarah Vaughan in an album called ''The Planet Is Alive . . . Let It Live.'' Songs he has written with Mr. Kellaway, which appear on a recently released album, ''Leaves on the Water,'' will make up part of their program tonight. They will give one performance at 8 P.M. for a $12.50 entertainment charge and a $10 minimum.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LISTEN, AND YOU CAN HEAR A HOLY WAR NEXT DOOR
description: The evenings are chilly now in this dusty old city on Pakistan's northwest frontier, and people say that soon the cold weather will again curtail the fighting in the rugged hills of neighboring Afghanistan.

title: VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Tax That Is No Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD TERRORISM: A REPORT TO NATO PAINTS A DARK PORTRAIT
description: A draft report prepared for lawmakers from the 16-member Atlantic alliance concludes that international terrorism is becoming more sophisticated, increasingly sponsored by Middle Eastern countries and deadlier each year.

title: SATIRIST WAS HAILED IN FRANCE
description: Thierry Le Luron, a satirist and impersonator who was among the most celebrated show-business personalities in France, died of intestinal cancer here this morning. He was 34 years old.

title: ATLANTA PAPERS GET A NEW EDITOR
description: Bill Kovach, the Washington editor of The New York Times, will become editor of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution on Dec. 1, the publisher of the Atlanta newspapers said today.

title: Cannon Discloses Inquiry by S.E.C.
description: Cannon Group Inc. said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was broadening its investigation into the film company's financing and accounting procedures.

title: METRO DATELINES;
description: Two well-dressed thieves stole more than $500,000 worth of gems and gold yesterday from a jeweler in midtown, the police said.

title: Mecir Is Upset Indoors
description: Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden eliminated fourth-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-4, today in a $375,000 indoor tournament.

title: Yeh Chu Tang Is Dead at 78; Ex-Manufacturer of Textiles
description: Yeh Chu Tang, a former textile manufacturer, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CENSURED ARCHBISHOP QUIETLY DEPARTS FOR SEATTLE
description: Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen quietly departed for his church in Seattle today, leaving behind a conciliatory statement thanking the nation's Roman Catholic bishops for listening to his side in his struggle with the Vatican.

title: AFTER 10 MONTHS FAMILY GETS A HOME
description: Donald McLaughlin, 19 years old, now has walls on which to hang his art work. Jermain, 3, and her sister, Erica, 5, have a place to put their play table. And their mother, Emma, now has a place to call home.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $10,395,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $10,510,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $592,000 for the quarter and $1,760,000 for the 9 months. The company said there were no share earnings for the latest periods because the preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HOMELESS BROUGHT TO SHELTERS IN RECORD COLD
description: The first cold weather emergency of the season was declared late yesterday by the city's Health Department, enabling the police to bring to shelters homeless people found huddled on the city's streets.

title: Puerto Rican Parade
description: The 10th Puerto Rican Discovery Day Parade will be held Sunday in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn. The procession of floats, marching bands and clowns begins at 1 P.M. at 60th Street and Fifth Avenue and continues down the avenue to 39th Street. The parade is sponsored by local civic organizations and businesses.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States has not swapped boatloads or planeloads of American weapons for the return of American hostages.'' - President Reagan. [ A8:5. ]

title: Long-Stem Rose
description: Sonny Smith, Auburn basketball coach, recalls that it took an upset of St. John's in the N.C.A.A. tournament last spring to draw the news media's close attention to Chuck Person: ''He had been blossomed all year. They just didn't check the blooms out.''

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $5 million due to the remaining costs of defending against a hostile takeover bid by General Electric Co. Plc for the quarter and 6 months. British General Electric is not related to the General Electric Co. of the United States. Dollar amounts have been translated from pounds sterling at the rate of one pound equals $1.43, which was the approximate exchange rate as of Sept. 26, 1986. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE New York Public Library on 42d Street has become one of the best party-givers in town. Where else, for instance, do you get a miniature Roman forum as a centerpiece on your table? Two hundred and fifty formally attired guests showed up for the library's sixth annual fund-raising Literary Lions dinner honoring 21 authors. Among them were Joseph Heller, Alistair Cooke, Nora Ephron, James Reston, Joyce Carol Oates and Theodor Geisel (Dr. Seuss).

title: Canada Plans to End Sanctions Against Soviet
description: Canada plans to lift the limited sanctions it imposed against the Soviet Union six years ago after Soviet troops swept into Afghanistan, because the sanctions have not worked, Joe Clark, the Secretary of State for External Affairs, has announced.

title: What U.N. Can Learn From U.S. Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: THE PREMIERE OF 'KEQROPS' BY XENAKIS
description: FOR nearly 30 years now, ever since he helped Le Corbusier design the Philips Pavillion at the 1958 World's Fair in Brussels, Iannis Xenakis has been an avant-gardist to reckon with. As a composer, Mr. Xenakis has turned out a steady stream of works that attempt to bring musical and mathematical theories together. Despite the fact that his pieces could hardly be more scientific in their concepts, the results too often sound purely random, as if dictated by coin-tossing.

title: Interest Rates Hold Steady
description: Interest rates were unchanged to slightly lower yesterday, and were little affected by the Federal Reserve's late afternoon announcement of slightly faster money supply growth than was expected for October.

title: U.S. REPORT ASSERTS ADMINISTRATION HALTED LIBERAL 'ANTI-FAMILY AGENDA'
description: A report issued today by a Reagan Administration panel on the family asserts that ''two liberal decades'' frayed the fabric of American family life, bringing increased crime, illegitimate birth, drug use, teen-age pregnancy, divorce, sexually transmitted disease and poverty.

title: WARD AGREES TO DELAY HIS PRECINCT TRANSFER PLAN
description: Police and union negotiators reached a temporary agreement yesterday that officials said would delay Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's plan to reassign officers to deter corruption and end a six-day citywide work slowdown by officers protesting the plan.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA RAILROAD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERA: 'FOUR SAINTS' BY THOMSON AND STEIN
description: IT'S fortunate that Virgil Thomson has lived to such a venerable age (he'll be 90 years old on Nov. 25), since his five-year milestones trigger productions of his best-known works. This is good for him, presumably, and it's certainly good for us. Right now, his best-known work of all, the opera ''Four Saints in Three Acts,'' is enjoying a production by the Opera Ensemble of New York (an article appears on page C33). It opened Wednesday night at the Lillie Blake School and continues Wednesday and Friday evenings and Sunday matinees through Nov. 30.

title: DEMOCRATS DISPUTE REAGAN VIEW ON IRAN DEALINGS
description: Several Democratic members of Congress said tonight that despite President Reagan's assertions to the contrary in his speech, they still believe that the United States swapped arms with Iran for the release of American hostages.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $5.2 million for the quarter and 9 months from the utilization of federal tax capital loss carryforwards. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $1.2 million from the utilization of federal tax capital loss carryforwards. The latest quarter's net includes an after-tax gain of $38,292,000 from the sale of the company's entire holding of $100 million principal amount of U.S. treasury bonds.

title: 'Star Wars' Benefits Are an Illusion With Mirrors
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY LAWS BEAR ON DEALS
description: Several laws bear on American arms shipments to Iran, and the question of whether any have been violated has still to be resolved by legal experts.

title: Gorbachev to Visit India
description: India announced today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, would pay a four-day visit, beginning Nov. 25. ''Both sides attach great importance to the visit as a significant event in the shared objectives of both our countries and leaders to strengthen international peace and cooperation,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Deb Kumar Maitra, said.

title: AGENDA: NOV. 14, 1986
description: Mafia Commission Trial

title: Rolland Smith Named Co-Host of New Show
description: Rolland Smith, a former news anchor and former chief correspondent of WCBS, Channel 2, in New York, was named the co-host with Mariette Hartley of the untitled new morning program that will replace the ratings-troubled ''CBS Morning News'' in January, network officials said yesterday.

title: Arleigh Williamson, Founder Of S.I. Community College
description: Arleigh B. Williamson, an educator and the founder of Staten Island Community College, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center on Staten Island. He was 98 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: RANGERS MAKE A MOVE AT LAST
description: After a month of rumors and uneasiness among the Rangers, Phil Esposito finally made a trade today - not the blockbuster deal he had promised -and then he made what was for him an unusual declaration. ''I want everything to settle down,'' he said.

title: U.S. Increases Armament For Its Border Agents
description: Citing increased violence along the 2,000-mile border with Mexico, the United States Border Patrol is arming its agents with 1,000 Army M-14 assault rifles and will supply them with two armored personnel carriers, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today.

title: ISRAELI'S ASIA TOUR DRAWS ISLAMIC ANGER
description: A visit to Southeast Asia and the Pacific by President Chaim Herzog of Israel has stirred protests from Islamic organizations in the region and caused a diplomatic scuffle here over who invited him.

title: CAMBODIAN FOLK TUNES
description: The Society for Asian Music (362-3366) will present a concert of Cambodian Folk music Sunday at 2:30 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Uris Auditorium, Fifth Avenue at 81st Street. Tickets are $8 ($6 for students and the elderly)

title: Art Shows in Familiar and Unexpected Places
description: Art shows are not as easy to come by in this sprawling borough as in cosy, prodigal Manhattan. There is the glorious Brooklyn Museum, to be sure, but after that, what? No SoHo, no TriBeCa, no Madison Avenue - in short, no gallery ''scene.'' Yet Brooklyn actually has a lot to offer in the way of exhibitions, and part of the fun is seeking them out. The viewer must be willing to travel far and wide, stalking the shows with sharpened eyes and a borough map. A tip: they will mostly be found at university galleries and alternative spaces. Here are some highlights of a recent tour:

title: Cocaine, Tests And a Challenge
description: Three members of the Colorado football team have told university police investigators that they used cocaine last summer. The school says it plans no disciplinary action against them, however, because a tightened testing program adopted in August shows that neither they nor other Colorado athletes have used drugs this season. ''We're not here to deal with past mistakes,'' says Athletic Director Bill Marolt. ''We're here to deal with future growth and improvement.''

title: ARMS NOT 'RANSOM'
description: President Reagan, under intense domestic and international criticism, tonight defended what he called his ''secret diplomatic initiative to Iran'' and vigorously denied that the United States had sought to exchange weapons for American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Malaysia Lifts Temporary Ban On Asian Wall Street Journal
description: The Government today lifted a ban on The Asian Wall Street Journal and expulsion orders against two of its reporters.

title: Ex-Mayor Told To Reveal Data
description: A former Mayor of Syracuse must allow a Federal grand jury to seek information about his foreign bank accounts in connection with an investigation into allegations of an extortion scheme, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Tennstedt, Ill, Cancels
description: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt has suffered a throat inflammation and canceled all his engagements through the end of this year, including his scheduled appearances conducting Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' at the Metropolitan Opera next month, the Metropolitan announced yesterday. For the first four performances on Dec. 10, 13, 17 and 20, he will be replaced by Christof Perick. The conductor for the final two performances will be announced later.

title: Woodlands and Exotic Gardens
description: IN the heart of New York's most populous borough, Prospect Park and its verdant partner, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, wander over nearly 600 acres of meadows, woodlands, waterways and an array of theme gardens. Here in Brooklyn's great backyard are also historic houses and sculptures, a zoo and skating rink, a Japanese garden and a horticultural collection that chaperones one through eons of botanical history. Although the blossoms and greenery of warmer days have given way to autumn's chill, both Prospect Park and the Botanic Garden remain refreshing respites from the city's concrete and bustle.

title: Festivals And Fairs
description: Today Bryant Park Craft Show, 42d Street, from Fifth Avenue to Avenue of the Americas. Clothing, leather goods, porcelain, ceramics, sculpture. Today, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Antiques Fair and Sale, Hyatt Regency Hotel, 1800 East Putnam Avenue, Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: BOWL WARS: STAKES GO UP
description: If Penn State and Miami meet in a bowl game New Year's Day to decide who is No. 1 in college football, the price of oranges is likely to increase.

title: HUSTON PROTESTS COLORING OF 'FALCON'
description: Seated in a wheelchair and cradling his oxygen tank in his arms, John Huston today denounced the ''colorization'' of his classic film, ''The Maltese Falcon,'' by the Turner Broadcasting System.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $12.1 million for the 9 months.

title: Ex-Official in Louisiana Indicted in Oil Deal
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the former Secretary of the State Department of Natural Resources in connection with helping to obtain a state oil lease for a company in which he had a secret interest.

title: Arms Control, Seriously
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is going to Washington this weekend and the key issue will be the aftermath of Reykjavik. Her central private message to President Reagan is to be ''Ronnie, how could you do this to me before my elections?'' according to senior British officials.

title: BATTERY PARK CITY GETTING 3 MORE HOUSING PROJECTS
description: The development of Battery Park City received a major push forward last week with the selection of three developers for prized property in a new neighborhood called Battery Place.

title: STOCKHOLDER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCREEN: 'TRICHEURS,' FROM BARBET SCHROEDER
description: THOUGH Barbet Schroeder is probably best known as the producer of Eric Rohmer's films, including the series called ''Six Moral Tales,'' he's also a singular director in his own right. His output as a director hasn't been large - seven features since 1969 - but each has expressed very particular concerns that, compared to those of less imaginative, less independendent film makers, seem almost elitist.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday LAST OF 'CANDIDE' The last week of the New York City Opera season features Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide,'' and there are still some fourth-ring tickets available for performances this weekend. Tonight's concert begins at 8 o'clock, with matinees tomorrow at 2 P.M. and Sunday at 1 P.M. and a final performance Sunday at 7 P.M. Tomorrow night's program is sold out. Fourth-ring tickets are $7 and $10. The place is the New York State Theater. Information: 870-5570. ANIMATION FESTIVAL New York University's Tisch School of the Arts is sponsoring an Animation Festival Benefit tonight, with proceeds going to the Gay Men's Health Crisis and its support services for persons with AIDS. The 90-minute program, which will be shown at 7 and again at 9 P.M., features 16 films. The selection, which ranges from the funny to the poetic, includes ''Bambi Meets Godzilla,'' ''The Rug,'' ''Tango,'' ''Sundae in New York'' and ''Thank You, Masked Man.'' The screenings will be held at the Loeb Student Center's Eisner Lubin Auditorium at 566 La Guardia Place. Tickets are $12 ($5 for students.) Information: 598-2027.

title: British Aerospace Pact
description: British Aerospace said today that it had won a contract worth $:1 billion, or $1.41 billion, from the British Government to build an air defense system capable of guarding against Soviet short-range nuclear missiles. The company's chairman, Sir Raymond Lygo, said he expected the contract for the Rapier 2000 system, including mobile missile launchers, to generate an additional $:2 billion in exports and provide work for about 10,000 people.

title: Blacks Meet With Revlon
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and other black leaders met with executives of Revlon Group Inc. yesterday and demanded that the company sever its ties with South Africa. Revlon executives had called the meeting to seek to end a two-week boycott organized in protest of comments in Newsweek.

title: MODERN MUSIC
description: Speculum Musicae will present works by Gyorgy Ligeti, Charles Wourinen , Stefan Wolpe and others at Wave Hill. 675 West 252d Street, in the Bronx, Sunday Afternoon at 3. Admission is $7 for Wave Hill members; $9 for nonmembers. Information: 549-3200.

title: IZVESTIA PROPERTY IN U.S. IMPOUNDED
description: A typewriter and other tools of the trade used by a Soviet reporter in Washington were seized by United States marshals today as they began attaching Soviet Government assets to pay off a libel judgment won by a California man.

title: Landing Damages Jetliner
description: A Delta Air Lines jumbo jet landed hard at Newark International Airport yesterday and caused ''substantial'' damage, the National Transportation Safety Board said. The Lockheed L-10ll with 130 people came in at 12:16 P.M. on a flight from Atlanta.

title: Holiday's Plan: The Unknowns
description: THE Holiday Corporation's sweeping $2.8 billion recapitalization proposal announced Wednesday raises a number of questions that individual and institutional shareholders are not accustomed to facing. The questions include what price Holiday's stock should trade at now in light of the coming restructuring, and what it will be worth next year, once the plan, still subject to shareholder approval, is completed.

title: GIFFORD-HILL & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $270,000 and an extraordinary tax benefit of $900,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,368,000 and $10,981,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WHY PRESIDENT ENDED SILENCE ON IRAN POLICY
description: The attempt tonight by President Reagan and other top aides to justify publicly their secret policy shift on Iran came in response to almost universal criticism in the foreign policy and political community.

title: Time for Diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Rourke Seeks 8% Budget Rise
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke yesterday proposed a $774.3 million budget for 1987 that is 8 percent higher than last year's and has an average 4.2 percent property tax increase that will vary from community to community.

title: Ailey Troupe Pulls Out Of Dance-Center Effort
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has withdrawn from a coalition of dance groups trying to convert a building at Broadway near 19th Street into a nonprofit center for dance. Two other dance companies, who were challenged along with the Ailey troupe to raise $4.4 million by Dec. 15 to assume control of the building, have so far received $3.4 million in pledges and loans.

title: Rono Is Arrested
description: Henry Rono of Kenya, who set four world distance-running records eight years ago, has apparently been using his speed afoot for less distinguished purposes in recent months. ''He's a marathon man, running from bank to bank, pulling flim-flams,'' said Rudolph Eger, a Ridgefield, N.J., detective after Rono, 34, was arrested in Hackensack and held in the Bergen County Jail on charges of theft by deception in connection with robberies at at least five branches of Oritani Savings and Loan in northern New Jersey.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. In Washington, a protester denouncing Zionism threw fake blood at Rabbi Meir Kahane. 2. Residential drug treatment centers. 3.

title: New Wrinkles In Tax Swaps
description: ARNOLD SMITH, a retired plumbing contractor in Albany, purchased $50,000 worth of units in a municipal bond unit investment trust five years ago. But recently he sold those units for $59,000 and used the proceeds to buy into another municipal bond unit trust.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on sales and exchanges of assets of $49,715,000 for the quarter and $140,838,000 for the 9 months, and after an extraordinary charge of $22,529,000 from an unfavorable jury verdict for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a pre-tax charge of $1,123,000 for the quarter and a pre- tax gain of $2,802,000 for the 9 months, both from the sales and exchange of assets.

title: Acid Rain Measure By Stacy V. Jones
description: University Patents Inc. of Westport, Conn., announced that it would make commercially available an invention patented for it this week that measures the two main pollutants that cause acid rain. Patent No. 4,622,105, granted to Prof. Wayne L. Worrell of the University of Pennsylvania and Q.G. Liu of Philadelphia, covers a method of measuring sulfur dioxide and sulfur trioxide.

title:
PATENTS;
Honors for Japanese Inventor
description: AJAPANESE inventor who may hold more patents than anyone else, is to be honored by the Inventors Clubs of America at a ceremony in Atlanta on Monday.

title: HEALTHPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AN OPEC PANEL URGES PRICE RISE TO $18 A BARREL
description: The main pricing committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries recommended tonight that the group raise prices by $3 a barrel, to $18, and return to setting fixed rates for petroleum.

title: Bonanno, 41, Is Sentenced
description: Joseph C. Bonanno Jr., the 41-year-old son of a onetime organized crime leader, has been sentenced to four years in Federal prison for taking part in a fraudulent investment scheme. The sentence was imposed Wednesday for his conviction in May on eight counts of fraud and conspiracy for defrauding investors of $250,000 in a scheme that involved the marketing of historical wall posters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1986
description: Markets

title: Why It's So Hard to Think About West Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $9,000. c-Net loss

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FOUNDED SEVENTEEN, EDITOR OF MAGAZINES
description: Helen Valentine, founder and editor in chief of Seventeen and Charm, the trend-setting magazines for teen-age girls and working women, died Wednesday in Miami at the home of her daughter, Barbara Hertz. She was 93 years old and lived in Miami.

title: HAL ROACH STUDIOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $161,043 for the quarter and $573,156 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Nomura Fills U.S. Jobs
description: The Nomura Securities Company, the world's largest securities firm, announced in Tokyo yesterday that its board had nominated Masaaki Kurokawa to serve as chairman, and Katsuya Takanashi as president, of Nomura Securities International, the firm's American subsidiary. The announcement, which had been expected, is subject to shareholder confirmation on Dec. 19. Mr. Kurokawa will succeed Yoshio Terasawa as chairman. Mr. Takanashi will replace Akira Shimuzu as president. The subsidiary is based in New York City.

title: NETWORK SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $3,000 for the quarter and $14,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months also includes a gain of $1,123,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-After tax credits of $53,000 for the quarter and $130,000 for the 9 months.

title: Beech-Nut Pleas
description: Beech-Nut Nutrition Inc., two of its executives and three suppliers pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they marketed apple-juice for babies.

title: SYNBIOTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TSO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Speech Called Political Ploy
description: Hojatolislam Khamenei's denial today that the United States had engaged in secret diplomacy with Iran's Government was interpreted by diplomats and experts on Iran as a way for him to distance himself and Teheran from the United States.

title: 4 NEW LAWS CITED IN BTTLE AGAINST GOVERNMENT FRAUD
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that four laws passed in the closing days of the 99th Congress would significantly enhance the Government's ability to discover, punish and deter fraud and waste in Federal programs, particularly those involving military contracts.

title: SEARS GETS INTO VIDEO SHOPPING
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, yesterday announced its entry into video home shopping.

title: Surgery for Brett
description: George Brett, the Kansas City Royals' third baseman, will undergo shoulder surgery next week in Los Angeles and then will undergo two to three months of rehabilitation. He is expected to be ready by the opening of spring training. Brett injured his right shoulder July 1 while diving for a ground ball in a game against the Seattle Mariners, and reinjured it Aug. 29 diving for a ball against Milwaukee.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 9 months include writedowns of $12 million and $66 million, respectively, on oil and gas properties. The company said the year-ago 9-month includes writedowns of $12 million on oil and gas properties.

title: MEESE WILL AVOID THE NOFZIGER CASE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has removed himself from the Justice Department investigation of a former White House official, Lyn Nofziger, and his ties to a Bronx military contractor, the department said today.

title: Alcoa to Buy TRE In $330 Million Deal
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the TRE Corporation, a maker of advanced aerospace and home products, for $46.38 a share, or about $330 million.

title: FROM LEGEND TO INSIDE TRADER
description: Ivan F. Boesky once compared himself in an interview to an artist who saw more in the world than the ordinary person - ''nuances, particularities, colors that are probably heightened beyond what they might have been.''

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Suspect's Past: 37 Convictions
description: The woman charged with obtaining expensive lodging, meals and clothing by posing as a sister of the late Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis has been convicted 37 times since 1952 for various ''con games,'' the police said yesterday.

title: Search for Killer Recalled at Trial
description: State police officers were expecting to find three Hispanic men when they caught up with a getaway car three hours after the killing of Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco, a state police detective testified yesterday.

title: CHANGE ON BROADCAST BOARD
description: William Lee Hanley Jr., a New York City oil executive, yesterday was elected chairman of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: OPERA: JOAN SUTHERLAND AS ELVIRA IN 'I PURITANI'
description: This is the kind of night it was: when Joan Sutherland made her first entrance in ''I Puritani,'' the Metropolitan Opera House resounded with such a prolonged stomping, screaming ovation that the performance came to a dead halt. La Stupenda, as opera history will know her, finally gave up, left the stage and returned to start over, allowed at last by her happy fans to take on the persona of Bellini's famously unstable heroine, the on-again, off-again madwoman Elvira.

title: S.M.U. FOOTBALL MAY FACE 2-YEAR BAN
description: Albert Reese, a senior tight end for Southern Methodist University, was suspended today from playing against Texas Tech University Saturday after a report was published saying that he has not paid rent for an apartment where he has lived since last May.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MERCURY A KEY CONCERN IN RHINE SPILL
description: Environmental officials and non-government activists have expressed increasing concern over a compound of mercury that was among the chemicals and dyes washed into the Rhine River during a fire at a chemical plant in the Swiss city of Basel on Nov. 1.

title: Gen. William W. Ford, Artillery Commander
description: Brig. Gen. William Wallace Ford, former commander of the 87th Division Artillery in Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army in Europe during World War II, died Sunday in Danbury Hospital after suffering a stroke the day before. He was 88 years old and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: VIDEO LIBRARY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: IDC SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $73,000.

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRADE WINDS REVIVE RANGERS
description: If you run a hockey team and you want to guarantee that for one night your club will perform far ahead of itself, then you do a simple thing: You make a trade.

title: OVERCROWDED SHELTERS SCRAMBLING TO AID SOUTHWEST'S COLD HOMELESS
description: Jean Vanderdoes never tries to hide her pain when she remembers sitting in the living room of her $105,000 home watching the plight of Houston's homeless on television last winter.

title: POLICE AND UNION IN NEW TALKS ON TRANSFER PLAN
description: New York City police and union negotiators began a new round of confidential talks yesterday aimed at resolving their dispute over Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's plan to rotate patrol officers among precincts.

title: Relieve Poverty With More Poverty?
description: A new report by the Reagan Administration's interdepartmental Working Group on the Family says welfare benefits ''are indexed to the cost of living.'' That's wrong. It also says states offering the highest welfare benefits experienced the greatest increases in rates of child poverty. That's not entirely right, either. In the Reagan Administration, inaccuracies appear to have a virtue, however: they reinforce the idea that the blame for poverty rests on liberalism, and on the poor. It requires audacity - or relentless ignorance - to parade such loaded arguments as serious social policy.

title: BOROUGH LEADERS STUDY SHELTER PLAN
description: As the season's first freezing temperatures sent 9,654 homeless people into municipal shelters Thursday night, the Borough Presidents of Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island were studying 16 new shelter sites proposed by the Koch administration.

title: A Vietnam Devaluation Is Third in 2 Years
description: Vietnam has devalued its currency for the third time in less than two years, indicating a continuing failure to curb rapid inflation or solve other economic problems.

title: Minoru Yasui, 70, Activist In Japanese-American Rights
description: Minoru Yasui, an Oregon native who pioneered the fight for the rights of Japanese-Americans in World War II, died Wednesday of cancer in a hospital here. Mr. Yasui, a retired lawyer, was 70 years old.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $584,000 for the quarter and income of $1,090,000 from discontinued operations for the 9 months. c-Included pre-tax writedowns of oil and gas properties of $23 million.

title: Trader Quits Under Fire
description: The brother of the chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange has resigned from a small futures trading and clearing house after he misappropriated about $1.3 million in funds from client accounts.

title: Past Federalism and Present Purists
description: ''The last 200 years have witnessed the evisceration of federalism as a constitutional and political principle.'' That's the lament of a sub-cabinet committee report commissioned by Attorney General Edwin Meese. The 90-page report, from a group of Administration scholars, has finished 15 months of research urging a return to the pure federalism of our Founding Fathers.

title: LOCKHEED SHARES UP $8 ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
description: Lifted by takeover rumors and a general rise in aerospace and electronics stocks, the stock of the Lockheed Corporation rose $8 a share today to close at $55.25.

title: CALIFORNIA VOTERS CALLING HALT TO UNCONTROLLED CITY GROWTH
description: In California, where civic boosterism and unbounded community expansion have been pursued with a kind of religious fervor since the Gold Rush, citizens are increasingly forcing a limit on urban growth.

title: Hirohito and Aquino: Matter of Interpretation
description: Unintentionally, Corazon C. Aquino's visit to Japan this week highlighted the keen sensitivity that lingers in Japan about any reference to Emperor Hirohito and his views of World War II.

title: Helms to Battle Lugar For Senate Panel Post
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina is asking his Republican colleagues to install him as the ranking minority member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in the next Congress, setting off a struggle with Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the panel's current chairman.

title: MMI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IRAN'S PRESIDENT REBUTS REAGAN, DENYING THERE WERE CONTRACTS
description: The President of Iran took issue with President Reagan today, denying that his Government had held talks at a diplomatic level with the United States.

title: AQUINO PLEDGES TO SEEK KILLERS OF LEFTIST
description: President Corazon C. Aquino called for calm today and opened a Government investigation into the killing of a prominent leftist leader, saying she would seek the culprits ''whatever the political cost.''

title: Sanford's Seniority
description: Terry Sanford will be formally sworn in Dec. 10 as North Carolina's new Senator; so far as is known, the 12 other freshman senators elected this month will be sworn in Jan. 6. That puts Mr. Sanford one notch ahead of his classmates, giving him such benefits as a better choice of offices, a higher ranking on committees and an earlier choice of a seat in the Senate chamber.

title: Goodyear Talks Held on Unit
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is having preliminary talks with several companies interested in buying its aerospace company, which was put up for sale just last week in an attempt to escape a takeover attempt by Sir James Goldsmith.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $704,000.

title: Chad Says It Downed A Libyan Fighter Jet
description: Chad said today that its armed forces had shot down a Libyan fighter plane and killed 200 Libyan soldiers in fighting in the northeast of the country.

title: BERKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $129,000 loss on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $1,195,000 for the quarter and $931,000 for the 9 months, a gain on a sale of discontinued operations $8,243,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and a tax benefit credit of $1,713,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the latest 9-month includes a non-recurring pre- tax charge of $1,501,000. The company said the 1986 figures include the results of B&E, acquired in May 1985.

title: Squeeze the Pomegranate Until Limp
description: To the Editor:

title: Blast From Nuclear Test Is Felt Miles From Site
description: A nuclear weapon that was detonated in a test in the Nevada desert today sent shock waves through some buildings in Las Vegas.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Noting that since he became general manager of the Cincinnati Reds two years ago, the groundwork had been laid for a championship season, Bill Bergesch signed a one-year extension to his contract. Bergesch, who formerly worked in the front office of the Yankees, has acquired Buddy Bell, Bo Diaz, Max Venable, Bill Gullickson and John Denny for the Reds since assuming his duties. . . . Tony Sibson, the British Commonwealth middleweight champion, has withdrawn from a scheduled defense against Errol Christie Dec. 3 in London because of a pinched nerve. . . . Stefan Edberg and Joakim Nystrom of Sweden became the third and fourth players to qualify for the eight-man field in the Nabisco Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden Dec. 3-8.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the earnings for the latest quarter and 6 months are based on income after provision for income taxes in the amount of $1.2 million, or 9 cents a share in the quarter and $2.9 million, or 21 cents a share in the 6 months. There were no such provisions in the year-earlier periods.

title: METS' MAGIC: SALE WORTH $100 MILLION
description: After weeks of negotiations, the chairman of the Mets, Nelson Doubleday Jr., and the club's president, Fred Wilpon, signed a contract yesterday to buy Doubleday & Company's 95 percent interest in the Mets at a cost of about $95 million.

title: MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
RETAIL SALES PLUNGE 5%
description: Retail sales plummeted 5 percent in October as consumer spending continued to be buffeted by wide swings in automobile sales, the Commerce Department said today.

title: AT O.A.S., MANY REJECT THE CONTRAS
description: A meeting of the Organization of American States here has convinced many United States officials that for others it can be logical both to disapprove of the Nicaraguan Government and still oppose the rebels who are fighting to overthrow it.

title: YOUNG PUT AT RISK BY OTHERS' SMOKE
description: An expert committee of the National Research Council reported today that passive smoking was a clearly established health risk for infants, young children and the nonsmoking spouses of cigarette smokers.

title: WESTBRIDGE CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $247,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $1,314,000, or 31 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes capital gains of $674,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $678,000, or 16 cents a share, for the 9 months. Both latest periods also include an $11.9 million pre-tax writeoff of previously deferred acquisition costs and a $2 million pre-tax unusual charge from the settlement of a lawsuit.

title: TOWN FIGHTS LILCO EVACUATION CENTER
description: In what could be a significant challenge to the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, Hempstead's highest elected official announced today that he was seeking to bar the Long Island Lighting Company from using its own building here as an evacuation center.

title: Takeover Stocks Surge As Dow Rallies by 11.39
description: Stock prices rallied yesterday on a new wave of takeover and restructuring news, allowing Wall Street to recover some of the losses from the previous session.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wynn Nathan Is Dead; A Consultant to RKO
description: Wynn Nathan, worldwide television marketing consultant to RKO Pictures in Manhattan, died after heart surgery Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital in Milwaukee. He was 63 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $354,000 for the latest quarter, $271,000 for the year-ago quarter, and $2,299,000 for the latest 9 months. c-Net loss

title: U.N. Chief Protests To Afghan Over Fight
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has protested to Afghanistan's chief delegate over an attack against Afghan opposition leaders visiting here last week. The attackers were identified as four members of the Afghan Mission.

title: WILFRED AMERICAN EDUCATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Penn State Facing Big Test From Irish
description: Things are just right for another Notre Dame upset. It probably won't happen.

title: Noah Tops Kriek
description: Helped by 11 aces, third-seeded Yannick Noah of France defeated Johan Kriek, 7-6, 6-4, today and earned a semifinal spot in the $375,000 Benson and Hedges grand prix tennis tournament.

title: REAGAN SIGNS BILL ON DRUG EXPORTS AND PAYMENT FOR VACCINE INJURIES
description: President Reagan today signed a comprehensive health bill designed to promote exports of prescription drugs and to compensate children injured by vaccines.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION UNCHANGED
description: Industrial output failed to show any improvement in October as cutbacks in automobile production held back gains in other areas, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: U.S. MINERALS EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,000 and a loss of $117,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $10,000.

title: A BERLIN MARRIAGE: ART AND MACHINE
description: An 18-inch-high silver tankard from which Kaiser Wilhelm II once drank stands at the entrance of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum's new exhibition, ''Berlin 1900-1933: Architecture and Design.'' It introduces visitors to the Victorian baroque taste that reigned in Germany at the turn of the century - escutcheons, laurel wreaths and scrolled leaves cover every inch of the mug.

title: Schumer's Glory
description: Sometimes glory is more fleeting than even legend has it. Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat, won re-election with 93 percent of the vote and didn't even have a Republican opponent.

title: MORINO ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $127,000 from an accounting change.

title: Ward and Police Union Compromise But Tension Over Transfers Remains
description: The uneasy truce between the Police Department and the police union came about this week because it had to, because both sides realized they were heading for a dangerous confrontation that threatened to get out of control.

title: BOOTHE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERSICO FOR THE DEFENSE: ENLISTING EARTHY CHARM
description: When Carmine J. Persico Jr., reputed boss of the Colombo crime family, strode to the lectern this week and began his closing arguments, he offered a rare sight in Federal District Court: a defendant acting as his own lawyer.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 6 about two former White House officials, James E. Jenkins and Lyn Nofziger, and their ties to the Wedtech Corporation gave an incorrect figure, supplied by the Federal Office of Personnel Management, for the minimum salary at which ranking Government officials were subject to scrutiny by an independent counsel in 1982. It was $60,662 a year, not $77,200.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM PARTNERS L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After writedowns on oil and gas properties of $3,960,000 and $66,330,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After writedowns on oil and gas properties of $9,900,000 for the quarter and $43,560,000 for the 9 months.

title: Allied Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said that its board had agreed to sell its five regional shopping centers to the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian developer with which Allied recently agreed to a merger. The sale of the centers to a Campeau subsidiary, Campeau Corporation (U.S.), is subject to the consummation of the $3.6 billion merger.

title: UNITED SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Divestments Hit Royal/Dutch Shell
description: Union pension funds and church groups have divested their portfolios of more than $12.4 million in Royal Dutch/Shell Group stocks and bonds because of the multinational energy company's role in South Africa. The divestments were announced on the eve of coordinated protest demonstrations scheduled for Saturday at Shell facilities in Houston, Boston, Washington and Birmingham, Ala., and in nine foreign countries.

title: Wedtech Says It Faces Major Quarterly Loss
description: The Wedtech Corporation, under a series of investigation, announced Thursday that it was facing ''substantial and material'' losses in the third quarter and would not be able to file its quarterly report on schedule.

title: NOTRE DAME PICKS ITS 16TH PRESIDENT
description: The University of Notre Dame today named as its 16th president the Rev. Edward A. Malloy, a specialist in ethics who is a former basketball player for the Fighting Irish.

title: GAF IS LIKELY TO CAUSE BORG TO REVAMP FASTER
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation will probably speed up its restructuring efforts to help resist any takeover move by the GAF Corporation, Wall Street analysts said today.

title: LYNDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COONEY'S ROLE: RELUCTANT HERO
description: The thump-thump heard throughout San Francisco last May 31 was not Tony Bennett's beating heart. The sound was Gerry Cooney's eight-ounce mitts landing with increasing impunity on the target areas of poor Eddie Gregg.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Soar
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities soared yesterday, partly because falling yields this week brought out more retail investors, and partly because of unusual events in the Chicago bond options market.

title: LORI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,183,000 and $2,175,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $17,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary gains of $1,673,000 and $3,042,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: J.P. INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: Clerics Say President Vows A Major Drive to Curb Smut
description: Representatives of 200 American religious leaders said today that they had won President Reagan's commitment to make a national anti-pornography campaign a major priority of his Administration.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After an extraordinary credit of $8,077,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $1.7 million from the sale of unprofitable properties. c-Net income

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
To the Loser Belongs Some Spoils
description: Everybody told me I wouldn't win. Everybody told me I was crazy. Well, they were right. And wrong. I didn't win. But I wasn't crazy.

title: Vera Soloviova, 95, Actress And Student of Stanislavsky
description: Vera Soloviova, a Russian-born actress and teacher who studied with Stanislavsky, died Sunday at the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Plains, N. J., of a stroke suffered earlier in the week. She was 95 years old and lived in Denville, N. J. Miss Soloviova was accepted in the Moscow Art Theater at the age of 17 and was among those chosen to be part of the First Studio, Stanislavsky's historic experiment to test his new system.

title: Westminster Bank Post
description: The National Westminster Bank said in London that Thomas P. Frost, 53 years old, would become group chief executive July 1 on the retirement of Philip Wilkinson, who will become a deputy chairman. Mr. Frost, who joined the bank in 1950, has been a deputy group chief executive since February 1985 and earlier was chief executive of the National Westminster Bank U.S.A., which has about 140 branches in New York City, Long Island and Westchester County.

title: Platinum Falls Limit; Gold Drops Below $400
description: Platinum futures fell by the daily limit of $25 an ounce today as speculators continued to sell contracts in a fast-moving market. Gold retreated below $400 an ounce.

title: Bridge; Hand in Jersey Event Gave Pointer in Picking Contract
description: Show a player a pair of hands and one would think he would be able to select the most desirable contract. But there are some tricky points involved. Has the bidding helped the opening leader in making his selection? And what is the method of scoring?

title: William Ridgway Dies at 79; Former Insurance Executive
description: William C. Ridgway Jr., retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Crum & Forster Group of insurance companies, died Wednesday at his home in Short Hills, N.J., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Grazing: Taster's Choice Of Savory Small Meals
description: Eating styles have changed dramatically in this country over the last 50 years. Gradually large meals have become passe. First big breakfasts became small breakfasts or no breakfasts at all. Then big lunches were replaced by big dinners.

title: Dr. George Bach Dies at 72; Began Psychotherapy Group
description: Dr. George R. Bach, a clinical psychologist who was founder and director of the Institute of Group Psychotherapy in Los Angeles, died of heart disease Tuesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 72 years old.

title: Mechanic Decertified After Helicopter Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has revoked the certification of a mechanic who it said installed the wrong pulley and clutch in a helicopter that crashed last month, killing a radio traffic reporter.

title: Marie C. Shlora Wed To Matthew M. Misisco
description: Marie Clare Shlora, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Shlora of Rye, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Matthew Mahon Misisco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Misisco of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Quogue, L.I. The Rev. William Warren performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: WHITE HOUSE, EXPRESSING 'OUR OUTRAGE,' IMPOSES SEVERAL SANCTIONS AGAINST SYRIANS
description: The White House announced several economic and political sanctions against Syria today, saying they were ''to express our outrage'' against reported Syrian involvement in an attempt to blow up an Israeli airliner in London.

title: SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
MILD INFLATION RISE SEEN
description: The Government's indexes of prices that producers charge for their products showed a mixed pattern in October that suggests a mild pickup in inflation, Labor Department data showed today.

title: REAGAN STAND CRITICIZED BY LAWMAKERS
description: President Reagan's defense of the White House's secret policy of conducting talks and sending military equipment to Iran continued to draw criticism today from Republicans and Democrats.

title: Books of The Times; Troubled Relationships
description: COLLECTED STORIES, 1948-1986. By Wright Morris. 274 pages. Harper & Row. $17.95. ''In the taxi to Manhattan,'' writes Wright Morris in one of the best stories in this volume, ''Hazlitt was moved to chat a bit with the driver, but the Plexiglas barrier between them seemed intimidating. Through the tinted windshield, as they approached the city, the October evening skyline was like the opening shot of a movie. Hazlitt had often told his wife that if the sun never rose he might like city living. In the car lights the streets glittered like enamel. It pleased him to note, as they drew near the Plaza Hotel, the horse-drawn hacks lined up along the curb. One of the drivers was a young woman with pigtails, frail as a waif. She held a leather feed bag to the muzzle of her horse, whose pelt shone like patent leather where the harness had worn off the hair.''

title: LIBERTY FETE COST $11 MILLION
description: New York City spent $11 million for the four-day Statue of Liberty centennial festivities over the July 4 weekend, city officials said yesterday.

title: Eton Journal; Playing Fields Looking Greener to British Parents
description: ''I see there are now more Etonians than Estonians in the Cabinet,'' the nonagenarian Lord Stockton - known as Harold Macmillan in his Prime Ministerial days -was reported to have commented archly at his club early this year. His remark came after the resignation of a member of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government who happened to be Jewish.

title: Cuomo Plans Address On the Role of Media
description: Governor Cuomo, who recently complained that the news media ''made me look bad,'' said today that he would deliver a major address later this month on ''the role of the press in a democratic society.''

title: HONEYWELL TO BUY SPERRY AEROSPACE
description: Honeywell Inc., the Minneapolis-based computer and controls company, said today that it had agreed to purchase the Sperry aerospace group of the Unisys Corporation for $1.03 billion in cash.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in October.

title: Herbert W. Klotz, 69, Ex-Commerce Official
description: Herbert W. Klotz, an Assistant Secretary of Commerce in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, while driving home to McLean, Va., from Washington. He was 69 years old.

title: MAN IS KILLED IN UPSTATE BRIDGE COLLAPSE
description: A one-lane steel bridge collapsed in the Chautauqua County town of Hanover this morning, sending a truck and its construction crew into a creek 100 feet below and killing the driver.

description: Some of the biggest stars in harness racing competed in four rich Breeders' Crown races at Garden State Park tonight, and all of them lost.

title: 3 MONITORING SITES PICKED ON A-TEST
description: A private American group opposed to nuclear testing and a team of scientists from the Soviet Union have selected three sites in California and Nevada where they plan to establish seismic monitoring stations to record earth tremors caused by nuclear weapon tests.

title: Court Disbars Ex-Legislator
description: John M. Skevin, a once-powerful Bergen County lawmaker who served 10 years in the State Legislature, was disbarred yesterday by the State Supreme Court for misappropriating clients' funds.

title: PRETORIA SAYS IT KILLED 39 IN RAID AGAINST NAMIBIA REBELS IN ANGOLA

description: A former mental patient who barricaded himself inside his mother's house for three days was shot and killed tonight by police officers who stormed the house after blowing a hole in the roof.

description: Just two weeks after Ronald O. Perelman, the New York investor, said he wanted to gain control of the Transworld Corporation, the hotel and food services company decided that it would rather liquidate itself.

description: LOCAL DISASTERS New York is a town that has undergone many disasters, physical and emotional. Tomorrow at 11 A.M., Gerard R. Wolfe, an architectural scholar, leads a walking tour for the 92d Street Y through the scenes of some of our town's more prominent upheavals.

title: THE NAZI WAR CRIMINAL WAS 90
description: Erich Koch, the Governor of East Prussia in World War II, died Wednesday in a Polish prison while serving a life sentence for Nazi war crimes, the Polish authorities announced today. He was 90 years old.

title: JOHN W. HARGIS
description: John W. Hargis, the first black to receive an undergraduate degree from the University of Texas, died Thursday at his home.

title: Cuban Is Stowaway On a Freezing Flight
description: A Cuban wearing light clothes hid behind a plane's nose wheel to reach the United States, and the meager heat of electronic equipment may have saved his life as the plane flew at freezing altitudes up to 39,000 feet, officials said today.

Garret FitzGerald, the Irish Prime Minister, put his name to an accord assuring British rule in that province as long as a majority there so wished. And Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister, agreed to consult the Irish Republic in addressing the grievances of Ulster's 600,000 Roman Catholics.

title: NEW HEIGHTS, AND DANGERS, FOR CHEERLEADERS
description: It has become a fixture at college sports events and some high school games. Forming a human pyramid, cheerleaders stand in ranks on each other's shoulders with one, generally a nimble young woman, perched triumphantly at the top. Then she dismounts in what appears to the gasping crowd as a death-defying leap to the arms of catchers waiting below.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday ranking National Football League teams by efficiency misstated the number of yards gained by the Chicago Bears this season, and the error affected two other statistics as well as the Bears' ranking in the chart. The Bears have gained 3,358 yards, giving them an offensive factor of 6.7 and an overall efficiency factor of 2.4. That places Chicago first among the 28 teams and drops New England to second place at 2.3.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe Wednesday for RabbitPojarski, accompanying an article on the new popularity of rabbit on American dinner tables, failed to list as an ingredient one cup of heavy cream. The cream is added to the meat after the bread crumbs.

title: Laborites Hold District
description: The opposition Labor Party held the depressed Knowsley North district in a special parliamentary election Thursday, but its majority was less than in the previous election, results showed today.

title: BANK AMERICA'S GOAL: $24-A SHARE BOOK VALUE
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it hoped to increase the book value of its stock by about $3, to around $24 a share, through a corporate restructuring program.

title: Enough Silence on Indonesia Executions
description: The Government of Indonesia recently executed nine political opponents who had been imprisoned for some 20 years in connection with a 1965 coup attempt. Now the Government may proceed to execute 16 more prisoners. In the absence of Indonesians' right to criticize these actions, the international community, particularly the United States, should shout its abhorrence of these executions.

description: The Devils not only beat the Pittsburgh Penguins by 5-4 here tonight, but they also discovered a line that may take some pressure off the team's primary unit.

description: The defense rested its case today in the Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and three co-defendants, having called seven witnesses and introducing, at the last minute, more than a dozen documents.

HUNTHAUSEN TO PRESS FOR TETURN OF FULL POWERS IN ARCHDIOCESE
description: Raymond G. Hunthausen, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle, said today that he wanted his full pastoral powers restored and that he saw no need to change the way he governed the Archdiocese before he was censured two months ago.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. Who is this member of the Israeli Parliament, and what happened to him? 2. Growing numbers of middle-class New Yorkers are traveling thousands of miles to facilities in other cities around the country for something that is exhorbitant in New York but affordable elsewhere. What is it? 3. Scientists are ruling out the meatball theory and the soap bubble theory in favor of the sponge theory. What do the theories concern? 4. ''The issues raised here touch on the relationship between the local churches and the Universal Pastor,'' said a document, written in secrecy. What document is it and what did it conclude? 5. Since it was bought last June from a conglomerate, sales are up by 31 percent at the company bearing the same name as the familiar red, yellow, black, orange and green candies it makes. What company is it? 6. Roughly 185 miles of a river have suffered serious ecological damage, a result of the accidental release of poisonous chemicals from one of the four countries through which it flows. Identify the river and the country responsible for the damage. 7. Record stores reported record sales as customers lined up to buy a new album. What album is it? 8. A Government agency with a normally advisory role has been actively involved in the recently disclosed shipment of arms to Iran and in other paramilitary operations.

title: WRITING HOLOCAUST MEMORIES
description: Aharon Appelfeld, author of the acclaimed new novel ''To the Land of the Cattails,'' posed his own rhetorical question: ''Is there a danger of the Holocaust being overtold in literature?'' Without pausing, he responded: ''The answer is 'no.' The Holocaust is a central event in many people's lives, but it also has become a metaphor for our century. There cannot be an end to speaking and writing about it. Besides, in Israel, everyone carries a biography deep inside him, including myself. I write about individuals more than about the Holocaust.''

title: BISHOPS' PARLEY: A BOW TO THE POPE, BUT DISSATISFACTION IS EXPRESSE, TOO
