Hunthausen of Seattle: Should they support the Vatican's disciplining of him or support a suffering colleague whose shortcomings some consider no more serious than many of their own?

title:
PATENTS;
A Protective Shield For Laser Beams
description: A transparent protective shield for injurious laser beams has been invented for the Barnes Engineering Company of Stamford, Conn.

title: Hold That Curtsy
description: Queen Sofia of Spain is in Washington this weekend for the premiere of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera ''Goya,'' and one of the more glamorous events surrounding the opening was a dinner at the National Gallery of Art, which mounted a show of paintings by (who else?) Goya.

title: Expand the Right to Work at Home
description: Every President has worked at home since James Madison first moved into the White House. If Presidents can work at home, why is that right denied to other Americans? The answer is the Homework Rule of the 1938 Fair Labor Standards Act, banning the sale of certain items made or worked on at home. Wisely, Secretary of Labor William Brock wants to change the rule. He can do so administratively.

title: GIANTS OUT TO STOP KRAMER'S BOMBS
description: If the Minnesota Vikings are to beat the Giants Sunday in Minneapolis, they will probably have to do it with Tommy Kramer's long passing.

title: Suns 127, 76ers 97
description: Rafael Addison, a rookie from Syracuse, scored 22 points in his first start as a pro and helped Phoenix end a four-game losing streak.

title: Ferocious Bear
description: Mark Bortz, an offensive guard for the Chicago Bears who earlier this season poked a teammate, William (Refrigerator) Perry in the eye during a practice, whacked Henry Waechter so hard Thursday that the defensive lineman suffered either a dislocated or broken jaw. Yesterday, the Bears were waiting for X-rays to determine the exact nature of the injury, which is not expected to sideline Waechter tomorrow against the Atlanta Falcons. ''I think Henry can play with it,'' said Coach Mike Ditka. ''He just can't eat good.''

title: O'Reilly at the Helm
description: Terry O'Reilly, a former right wing and captain of the Boston Bruins, put aside his job as a television commentator at Bruin games on Nov. 5 to serve with Mike Milbury as interim co-coach of the team after the dismissal of Butch Goring. Yesterday, O'Reilly's departure from the broadcasting booth was extended as he was named the team's head coach for at least the remainder of the season. John Cunniff, a scout for the Hartford Whalers for the last two years, was hired to serve as O'Reilly's assistant, and Milbury, a defenseman, will be a player-assistant coach.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of $27,960,000. c-Net income The company said there are no 1985 share earnings because preferred dividend requirements exceeded income.

title: Urge to Build Towers Will Drive Out the Jobs New York Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Cadet at the Citadel Leaves Over Harassment
description: A black cadet whose room was invaded by five white cadets dressed like Ku Klux Klansmen has left the Citadel, the South's historic military academy, because of harassment.

title: Shamrock Outlook
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation expects to record a loss in the fourth quarter but should become profitable in the first quarter of 1987 and remain profitable throughout the year, William H. Bricker, chairman and chief executive, said. He said continuing low energy prices plus difficulties in the refining and marketing unit would cause the loss in the current quarter. Diamond Shamrock, which lost more than $600 million in 1985, lost $97.9 million in the third quarter.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $2,780,000 for the quarter and $4,090,000 for the 9 months, from the exchange of the company's 11 percent subordinated notes into common stock, and the quarter is also after a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $34 million relating to the restructuring of its Bojangles' subsidiary. c-Includes non-recurring pre-tax charge of $10,875,000. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: FUGITIVE CAUGHT AFTER CAR CHASE IN L.I. STAKEOUT
description: A fugitive wanted as the head of a mob drug ring was arrested Thursday in Suffolk County, where authorities said he and his wife had been living under assumed names for as long as two years, The fugitive, Anthony Aiello, 45 years old, of Queens, was spotted in a pizza restaurant in Patchogue and arrested after a car chase that reached speeds of 90 miles an hour, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Helmsman Saved After Collision
description: The impact of a collision today between two Australian boats in the America's Cup trials tossed a helmsman overboard and punched a 2-foot hole in his boat.

title: Carlin C. Weidlein Weds in Pittsburgh
description: Carlin Cutler Weidlein, a daughter of Mrs. Davis Carlisle Burroughs Jr. and John David Weidlein, both of Pittsburgh, was married there yesterday to Jan Stephens McCoy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Allen McCoy of New Alexandria, Pa. The Rev. John Fetterman performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Wonderful, but Who Needs It? In 1932, the 33-year-old Vladimir Nabokov, using the pen name Sirin, gave a ''literary reading'' to a packed house in Paris. This description, by another Russian emigre, of that performance is quoted in ''VN: The Life and Art of Vladimir Nabokov'' (Crown), by Andrew Field. For me the sight of an extremely thin young man with, or so it seemed, a concave chest and the fleshy nose of a boxer, wearing a wondrously shabby smoking jacket, and reading things he cared passionately about to people who were hostile to him, for me this sight had something glorious and triumphantly heroic about it. I gladly began to take his side. . . . It was one against all, and he was winning. You had to be for him, and I found myself whole-heartedly wishing him to prevail. All this was in spite of the fact that Sirin combined the cultural level of writers like Kafka and Joyce . . . with the vulgarity of a second-rate movie actress.

title: NATO LEGISLATORS ASSAIL IRAN DEALS
description: NATO legislators reacted with shock, sorrow and anger today to disclosures that the United States had secretly sent arms to Iran, and they urged the allies to take a tough stand against terrorism.

title: A Good Man Going
description: One recent afternoon, not long after most members of the 99th Congress had departed to campaign or to rest, Senator Charles McC. Mathias, Republican of Maryland, was in his office pondering such details as sans-serif type and boldface caps for a redesigned Congressional Record.

title: SPOCK AMONG THE WOMEN
description: DURING a course in writing fiction I took some years ago, the professor made a statement that was meant, I am sure, to console those women among us who were over 30 years old and had not yet sold a work of fiction. She pointed out that women commonly broke into print in their 30's, rather than in their 20's, as men often did. Men, she said, write in the linear style recognized as fictional narrative at a much earlier age than women, who must learn linear narrative slowly and with much greater difficulty. Published works that experiment with narrative form are the privilege of the later years of recognized creative genius.

title: COMING UP ON 50 -- HALF A CENTURY -- WITH ANTICIPATION
description: I'M MARKING a milestone with this birthday. I'll be 50 years old. That's five decades. Or two score and one decade. Or half a century. Or two generations and more.

title: Edwin Meese's Agenda
description: Attorney General Meese prides himself on ''providing law enforcement that is not just vigorous but compassionate.'' He also believes that the ''biggest victory'' of the Supreme Court's 1985-86 term was its upholding of the Georgia antisodomy law - a law that provides prison sentences for certain acts of private, consentual lovemaking.

title: Veteran Ends Hunger Strike
description: A Vietnam veteran who vowed not to eat or drink until efforts were made to rescue veterans reportedly imprisoned in Southeast Asia ended his 49-day fast Friday. The veteran, Ed Gino Casanova, said he decided to resume eating after he received telephone calls from several people, including an aide to John Cardinal O'Connor, Archbishop of New York.

title: CRIME
description: The World Series madness is over, and now is the very height of the football season. What better time for a pair of books about offense, defense, T and I formations, scrimmage, laterals and murder? Namely: LIFE'S WORK by Jonathan Valin (Delacorte, $14.95) and MURDER AT THE SUPER BOWL by Fran Tarkenton with Herb Resnicow (Morrow, $15.95). On the title page of the Tarkenton book is another credit: ''Concept by Bill Adler.''

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
EAST ORANGE IS GETTING BACK ON ITS FEET
description: THROUGH the middle of the 1960's, East Orange, an old Essex County community, enjoyed a reputation as a town where wealthy people wanted to live and companies longed to do business. But the 1967 race riots that devastated nearby Newark pushed it into economic decline.

title:
ART;
MYSTERIOUS FIGURES BY SCANGA AT WESLEYAN
description: IT is not unusual to hear that a major sculptor haunts flea markets to find objects for his work. But when the artist in question is Italo Scanga, the things he finds - picture frames, a wooden shoe, a chair leg and old guitars - go toward the construction of figurative works that almost seem human.

title: New Projection Television Model Succeeds in Sharpening Image
description: Two new items of video equipment, each in its own way, rise to the challenge posed by the current increase in video performance standards. They tackle the situation from opposite ends. One advances the limits of technology, the other enables the rear guard to catch up.

title: COMPETITION DESPARATE FOR PITTSBURGH SCHOOLS
description: Mark Abelman has what it takes: the determination to stand outside for six days and six nights and a shocking-orange snow suit to keep him warm while he does so.

title: Professional Aid On a Work Contract
description: Since a contract is a legal document, there is reason to consider having a lawyer write it or review one submitted by an architect or contractor. The City Bar Association, telephone 382-6628, makes referrals for lawyers and specialists in construction law.

title: O'ROURKE REFLECTS ON HIS POLITICAL FUTURE
description: NOT long after his historic defeat in the gubernatorial race, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke was sitting in his office, remembering his early boyhood days in Chicago when Edward J. Kelly was mayor.

title: DEFENDING DOGMA AND THE POOR
description: AFTER a four-day meeting here marked by high tension, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops went home this weekend with a dual pastoral order: to heal a rift in the church and to encourage public response to the plight of the poor.

title: 14 KILLED, 41 HURT IN TAIWAN QUAKES
description: Two earthquakes shook Taiwan today, killing 14 people, most of them under a collapsed building, the police said. At least 41 people were injured.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Information on Help
description: A new service providing free information about health and social-assistance programs will begin Dec. 1 at New Rochelle Hospital. The program is called Area Centers for Entitlement Specialists. It offers assistance to area residents who are eligible to receive Medicare, Medicaid, Social Security benefits, food stamps and county-sponsored services for the elderly. Staffed by volunteers, most of whom are retired social-service professionals, the group acts as a clearinghouse for people who have specific needs, but do not know where to turn for help.

title: WRITERS PROTEST DEPORTATION CASE
description: A deportation order against a writer here because of her political writing has stirred a group of prominent American authors to action and has intensified debate over the country's immigration law.

title: Bettors Get 2d Chance
description: A court has given 11 Saratoga Race Course bettors a chance to collect winnings for tickets on a horse that was wrongly disqualified. State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Torraca said stewards were wrong in refusing to make Allumeuse the winner of the Aug. 2 thoroughbred race.

title: David C. Sills Is Wed To Miss Hirshleifer
description: Lori Hirshleifer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hirshleifer of New York, was married last night to David C. Sills, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Sills of New York and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the Regency Hotel in New York.

title: IN PRISTINE WATER MILL, THE SPECTER OF DEVELOPMENT
description: AT a time when preserving open land has become a priority for state, county and town officials, many Water Mill residents are angered that nearly 225 acres of open land are expected to be developed for housing in the next few years.

title: Next Week; Will the Jets And Giants Reach the Super Bowl?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: 3 TOWNS EYE ZONING CHANGES
description: IN an effort to slow a commercial and residential building boom, officials of the Towns of Smithtown, Islip and Brookhaven are reviewing recommendations for major changes in their zoning codes.

title:
ART;
EXPERIMENTING WITH THE PURITY OF PASTELS
description: PASTEL is among the most attractive of art media, but by no means the easiest to handle. Its luminosity is legendary, and its purity of color was particularly inspiring to the Impressionists, who popularized the use of pastel in modern times.

title: CRITICISM ON IRAN AND OTHER ISSUES PUT REAGAN'S AIDES ON DEFENSIVE
description: With the White House facing criticism of its Iran policy and its handling of foreign affairs, two of President Reagan's advisers have mounted a strong defense of their competence and the role they have been playing.

title: REPLACING BLOOD WITH PATIENT'S OWN
description: IT takes Dr. William Thomas Stillwell, chief of orthopedics at St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown, four to six hours to do to a total hip revision. In that time a patient can lose 10 to 20 pints of blood. The average body holds 12 pints.

title: Remembering the Year, the Month, the Minute, the Moment
description: I stubbed out my last cigarette at about 10:15 on the last Sunday morning of May 1976. I was 34 years old and had smoked since before my 16th birthday- more than half my life. In all that time I had only twice tried to quit entirely.

title: Getting Firm Rule Over the Phone
description: RELIEF for telephone users bothered by nuisance callers was promised with a device patented for A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories in May.

title: Islanders Get 5 in 3rd To Top North Stars
description: Mike Bossy scored two goals and set up two others, and the Islanders scored five third-period goals tonight in a 7-3 triumph over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: RESORTS WARY ON IMPACT OF CASINOS
description: NEW noncasino hotel and motel construction here and in nearby communities, plus newly developed casino marketing plans aimed at attracting ''family business,'' will combine to have an adverse affect on many Shore resorts, according to some officials.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
GROWING UP WITH ALCOHOL
description: It's 4 o'clock on an autumn afternoon, and six children are talking about liquor. It's a subject with which they might not be expected to be so familiar -- the oldest one, after all, is only 10 years old -- but these children are different. These children have parents who are alcoholics.

title: Jewish Student Slain In Jerusalem's Old City
description: A Jewish student was stabbed to death today near the seminary he attended in the Old City of Jerusalem, and three Arab suspects were arrested, the police said.

title: HOLIDAY MEALS AWAY FROM HOME
description: THERE are times when the thought of preparing an elaborate holiday meal loses its charm - especially when you have done it for years on end. If you have ever toyed with the idea of leaving the cooking to others, this might be the year to do it.

title: Major developments in Federal-state relations
description: 1824 - Gibbons v. Ogden. Supreme Court says Congress has broad power to regulate ''commercial intercourse''; strikes down New York law granting steamboat monopoly to a private company operating between New York and New Jersey.

title: BIOTECH'S STALLED REVOLUTION
description: THE CHAIN-LINK FENCE THAT ONCE SUR-rounded the chunk of farmland the size of a football field just outside of St. Charles, Mo., is down now. Elm Point Road is quiet. Nothing exists to indicate that, on this stretch of Missouri River bottomland owned by the Monsanto Company, history was to have been made.

title: CAMPUS SCENES: STUDENTS SEE THE LIGHT AT END OF LIBERAL ARTS TUNNEL
description: The crowded seminar was discussing a French Protestant pastor named Andre Trocme, who in World War II helped inspire a village in southeastern France to hide thousands of Jewish refugees. Trocme, who died in 1971, was not only a deeply moral leader, said the professor, Philip P. Hallie, but he was also exasperating, demanding, a man who courted violence. The pastor was wonderfully pertinent to Professor Hallie's classroom emphasis on ''flesh and blood'' people in ''life and death'' situations.

title: A Wall Street Giant Falls to the S.E.C. Over Insider Trading
description: Ivan F. Boesky floated high among the risk arbitrageurs, who speculate on the ebb and flow of corporate mergers and takeovers. Just in the last year, drawing on a billion of his own and investors' dollars, he bought into such major takeover targets as USX Corporation, Union Carbide Corporation and Sperry Corporation, whose stock he snapped up to the tune of $364 million.

title: Hans Stauffer Is Dead; Led Chemical Concern
description: Hans Stauffer, who retired in 1967 as president of the Stauffer Chemical Company after 47 years with the concern, died Friday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Steinbrenner Stops Spending
description: Whoever would have thought that baseball would see the day when George Steinbrenner wouldn't want to win. Based on remarks the Yankees' owner has made in recent weeks, some people, in and out of baseball, wonder if that unlikely day has arrived. Not so, the owner protests.

title: Ohio State Wins 9th in Row
description: Vince Workman had two touchdowns and 172 yards on 29 carries and Matt Frantz had three field goals to give Ohio State its ninth consecutive victory, a 30-17 trouncing of Wisconsin today in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: RACE BALANCE ORDERED IN KANSAS CITY SCHOOLS
description: A plan for specialized academic programs in Kansas City public schools, ordered by a Federal judge, will create one of the nation's most far-reaching and expensive programs to desegregate schools by attracting students to ones that are now segregated, educators say.

title: SHUTTLES SWEAT FOR EDGE AS AIR BATTLE HEATS UP
description: John Hayes, an investment banker with a home in Washington, is a convert to the Pan Am Shuttle. ''They practically hand-carry you out of your cab, they're so eager to please,'' he said of the staff.

title: Mark K. Follender Wed To Caryn Elise Liebowitz
description: Caryn Elise Liebowitz and Mark Kenneth Follender were married last evening at the Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Center by Rabbis Judah H. Washer, Simon Glustrom and Israel Grama. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward Liebowitz of Mahwah, N.J., and Judge and Mrs. David B. Follender of Teaneck, N.J.

title: A PARI OF HONG KONG CLASSICS
description: Hong Kong sits like a golden egg beneath the slowly rousing China goose. In this landscape of jade-green hills rising from the China Sea and ringed by a necklace of skyscapers lies a treasure island of shopping and unbridled growth, the duty-free open market of the world.

title: Brother, Can You Spare A Question?
description: WHY ARE TO-day's women so unhappy in their relationships with men?'' writes Cary McMullen to the editor of The New York Times. ''The experts you cite mostly beg the question by saying that women should not feel this way . . . .''

title: Shaping Up for 2 Mayoral Races
description: Neither Harold Washington, the first black Mayor of Chicago, nor W. Wilson Goode, the first black Mayor of Philadelphia, has enjoyed a trouble-free debut, and both can expect to struggle for re-election next year. Both are now getting a better idea of who their opponents might be.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: Last call to plant bulbs. . . . Leaves should be removed from the lawn so it is clean for winter. Winter Ahead

title: Those Cheering Democrats
description: The National Democratic Club on Capitol Hill was holding its traditional election night party, and the largely male crowd of party loyalists, contributors and lobbyists cheered each report of a strong Democratic showing for the Senate or House. But to the surprise of some celebrants, the loudest demonstration of the evening came with the announcement of a Republican victory in the Eighth Congressional District of Maryland.

title: Planting Bulbs Takes On Aspect of Thoughtful Game of Chess
description: On a recent Sunday afternoon, a friend hefting a large paper bag stopped by. ''I have your bulbs,'' she said cheerfully. ''I must have got to you in a weak moment.''

title: Officially Historic
description: The hamlet of Pound Ridge received its long-awaited National Historic Register designation on the last day of 1985, but scheduling difficulties kept an official celebration from taking place. Now the town plans to remedy that: a gala celebration is planned for Saturday, with town and county officials on hands, walking tours, a photography display, museum and library visits, balloons, hayride shuttles, antique fire engines, gourmet bake sales, balloons and free gifts of white pine seedlings to commemorate the day.

title: UNBOOGALOOABLE
description: THE ENDLESS SHORT STORY By Ronald Sukenick. 132 pp. New York: Fiction Collective. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: STATE AGENCY SUED ON AID TO THE HOMELESS
description: ALTHOUGH the state's Department of Human Services has begun a $4-million-a-year program to shelter the homeless, the Department of the Public Advocate, in three class-action suits, has attacked Human Services, saying it is not doing enough.

title: Walter H. Sutton Wed To Eleanor S. Campbell
description: Eleanor Saltonstall Campbell, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Levin H. Campbell of Cambridge, Mass., was married there yesterday to Walter Harris Sutton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvah W. Sutton of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Gary Keisling, a Christian and Missionary Alliance minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Parish Church.

title: Melinda Mitchell, John Shumway Jr. Are Wed in Jersey
description: Melinda Mitchell, a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don G. Mitchell of Summit, N.J., and John David Shumway Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Shumway of Cheshire, Conn., were married yesterday in Summit. The Rev. Allen A. Tinker performed the ceremony at Christ Church (United Church of Christ.)

title: 30 TONS OF POISON ASSAULT RIVER LIFE
description: FOR two weeks, 185 miles of the Rhine has suffered a poisoning that much of the river's life could not survive. Now the poisons - more than 30 tons of herbicides, pesticides and mercury washed from a Sandoz AG warehouse by fire hoses - are on the river bottom or in the North Sea, taking paths that experts cannot discern.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: PHILANTHROPIC ACADEMY
description: IT'S something of an art-world popularity contest: the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters each year sends out requests to 75 art museums around the country and asks them what painter they would most like to have added to their collections.

title: An Unexpected Find At Maryland College
description: A time capsule discovered in the cornerstone of a 63-year-old University of Maryland building has provided more questions than answers.

title: MEXICAN PESSIMISM IS FOUND IN SURVEY
description: More than half of all Mexicans believe that Mexico's economic troubles are so profound that the country will never recover, a New York Times Poll has found.

title: BREAKFAST IS NOT THE TIME FOR BOMBAST
description: DON'T get me wrong. Some of my best friends are serious classical musical lovers -in fact, I'm one myself. But not at breakfast.

title: AMERICAN FIRST: A DOUBLE STANDARD
description: As a politically active Asian-American myself, I was delighted to see your report on Robert Machida's candidacy for the State Senate [ Oct. 26 ] . And yet something was disturbing.

title: Dance
description: Two choreographers bursting with energy these days are Lar Lubovitch and Igal Perry. Over the years, Mr. Lubovitch has choreographed all sorts of dances -from the slick to the solemn, from the sassy to the serene.

title: Christine M. Colby to Marry
description: Announcement of the engagement of Christine Marie Colby to John Peter Giraudo, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Giraudo of San Francisco, has been made by William Egan Colby of Washington and Barbara Heinzen Colby of Arlington, Va., parents of the future bride. The wedding is planned for June 6.

title: Verbatim; On Past Mistakes
description: 'I attended Jewish weddings. My family doctor in New York was a Jew. . . This is my misunderstanding with some of my friends in America, in New York especially.

title: SRI LANKAN TO OPPOSE DEPORTATION TO STAY IN U.S.
description: For Kandiah K. Navaratnam, a 35-year-old American-trained agronomist from Sri Lanka, the news from the Immigration and Naturalization Service was bad. He was told to pack up his wife and son, pull up roots he has put down in six years as a Government-financed graduate student in Virginia and return to his native land.

title: Broadcast TV
description: For worthy film fare this week, regular television has it all over cable's methodical schedule of repeats. There's the network premiere of the multi-Oscar winning ''Terms of Endearment'' (1983), a perceptive drama of mother-daughter tensions with Shirley MacLaine, Debra Winger and Jack Nicholson - Sunday at 9 P.M. on NBC.

title: Recent Sales
description: Cornwall, Conn. $210,000 Yelping Hill 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old stone summer house; no heat, pastoral views, 8 acres; taxes $1,500. Danbury, Conn.

title: REPRESENTATIVE JOHN GROTBERG DIES AT 61 AT HIS ILLINOIS HOME
description: John E. Grotberg, a first-term United States Representative from Illinois, died yesterday at his home in St. Charles, Ill. He was 61 years old.

title: Fresno East
description: There's nothing like a network television event to break the bonds of political partisanship. Tonight, to celebrate the premiere of the CBS satirical mini-series ''Fresno,'' two Democratic Congressmen from that area of California, Tony Coelho and Richard H. Lehman, and one Republican, Charles Pashayan Jr., have commandeered a Washington law office for ''A Fun-Filled Evening of Tribute to Fresno,'' which promises to feature big-screen television sets and raisins in both solid and liquid form.

title: Howard Ruff, Redux
description: Howard Ruff, the Utah-based financial adviser, earned his ''gloom and doom'' label with a 1978 best seller, ''How to Prosper During the Coming Bad Years.'' The label really rankles, he says, claiming that after most of his predictions came to pass by 1982, he switched gears and became bullish on the bond and stock markets.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: DO'S AND TABOOS AROUND THE WORLD. Edited by Roger E. Axtell. A Benjamin book. John Wiley & Sons. 183 pages. $9.95.

title: I.R.A. Change Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Church-Music Complaint

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GEORGIA MUSIC By Helen V. Griffith. Illustrated by James Stevenson. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Getting In on New Issues
description: WHEN Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Group decided to make its initial public offering last July it employed three of Wall Street's leading underwriters - the First Boston Corporation, Shearson Lehman Brothers and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. - and offered almost 24.5 million shares at $16 to $19 each. But after two months of steady decline, only 15 million shares were sold for about $10 each.

title: CHILDREN'S SUMMER: MOTHER'S REPLY
description: I was not impressed by Ann Waitz's critique of my recent essay, ''Summer With the Children - Not as Planned'' [ Opinion Page ] in her letter to the editor on Oct. 12.

title: Music
description: It is a week of interesting song recitals. Two of them, unfortunately, are on Sunday afternoon, but listeners with sufficiently fast legs and enough enthusiasm can make it to both.

title: Accountability for Sale, Cheap
description: In today's intellectual marketplace, the concepts of accountability and responsibility are shabby and out of fashion. Discounted goods, they are for sale cheap.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MOON. By James Herbert. (Crown, $14.95.) Jon Childes isn't looking for trouble, but he can't help seeing it. Each time he is made faint by dreamy, ghastly images of a corpse being desecrated or a body hacked up, Childes reads in the next morning's paper about just such wretchedness taking place exactly the way he sensed it.

title: New Orleans
description: This is the year of the river in New Orleans. The lower Mississippi is quite a bit older than the city, but you'd never guess it by observing the crowds on the river banks acting as though they've made a brand new discovery. The reason for the excitment is the new development spurred by the 1984 World's Fair.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORTS;
N.F.L. a House With Structural Faults
description: THREE weeks ago an arbitrator struck down Commissioner Pete Rozelle's plan to test randomly all National Football League players twice for drugs during the regular season. In the aftermath of this decision, and in the light of some statements made by the arbitrator, it became clear how the organizational shortcomings of the N.F.L. and other sports leagues hinder solutions to the drug problem and other problems facing organized sports.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 16, 1986
description: Fiction

title:
INVESTING;
A Money Manager's Roller Coaster Ride
description: RON DARLING, pitcher for the world champion New York Mets, calls pitching a ''roller coaster ride through the land of confidence.'' He could just as well be describing the art of investing on Wall street, which also has a way of bruising egos.

title: WHEN SOCIETY IS THE HANDICAP
description: ''GIVEN time, the hurt will heal. With support and caring and love, the harshness of ignorance will surrender to me its pathetic pose.''

title: Patricia C. Green To Marry Dec. 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Strong of Bradenton, Fla., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Colleen Green, to William McNeir Richmond, the son of Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn and Mrs. Benjamin F. Leaman of Chester Springs, Pa. The wedding is planned for Dec. 27.

title: BLASS FACES FIGHT OVER KEY POST
description: POLITICS is the fastest way to go from 'Who's Who' to who's that,'' Gregory J. Blass said last week.

title: Crawford Goes Rolling Along
description: Tory Crawford, a junior quarterback, kept the scoreboard lights blinking at Michie Stadium today as he led Army to a 56-48 victory over Lafayette that left both teams with 5-5 season records.

title: Biotechnicians Study Abroad to Avoid U.S. Rules
description: To bypass what one scientist called the ''unclear and inordinately slow'' process of winning Government approval for tests of geneticially engineered microbes, at least two research groups have gone abroad to conduct field experiments.

title: District Curators: Avant-Garde's Avant-Garde
description: ''The whole tenor of cultural life in a city can be very much affected by the work and dedication of one or two people,'' said Philip Glass, the musician and composer. ''I think Washingtonians owe a lot to District Curators.''

title: INSIDE
description: A Dirge for the Rhine About 200 mourners held a funeral march in Basel, Switzerland, for ''Fluvius Rhinus, died Nov. 1'' after a chemical spill.

title: CORRECTION
description: A concert review on Nov. 2 about the American Chamber Opera misidentified an accompanist. The pianist for ''The Seven Deadly Sins'' was Ronald Fracker.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The bottom line is they can't avoid oversight. When the National Security Council staff steps outside its role of being an adviser and becomes an executor of foreign policy and the transferer of arms, clearly they fall into our jurisdiction.''

title: Einstein College Aims To Raise $90 Million
description: The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University tonight will formally begin a five-year drive aimed at raising $90 million.

title: Montclair St. Rolls
description: Montclair State routed Glassboro State, 42-14, yesterday at Upper Montclair, N.J., for its sixth straight New Jersey State Conference championship and a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Divison III playoffs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Pro Basketball Chuck Person, a rookie, hit a 3-point goal at the buzzer last night to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 104-103 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks in Indianapolis. The Bucks, who rallied from 12 points down, took the lead with three seconds to go on a short jump shot by Paul Pressey. After a timeout, Person, a 6-foot-8-inch forward from Auburn, inbounded the ball to Herb Williams, then got it back and fired the winning shot from 33 feet out. . . . Robert Parish scored 34 points and Larry Bird added 26 to lead the Boston Celtics to a 118-111 victory over the Detroit Pistons in Pontiac, Mich. Adrian Dantley scored 41 points for Detroit. . . . In Dallas, Mark Aguirre scored 17 of his game-high 25 points in the first period to power the Mavericks to a 111-96 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers. Aguirre sat out the last 18 minutes. . . . The Utah Jazz got 15 fourth-quarter points from Carey Scurry and Mark Iovaroni, both coming off the bench, in a 111-103 victory over the Denver Nuggets.

title: A Premium on Prompt Action
description: AS if successful investing were ever as easy as it may seem to the uninitiated, the most sweeping tax-overhaul legislation in American history has just made the job even harder. The new tax code calls for a comprehensive rethinking of one's entire strategy - and puts a premium on prompt action. And, compounding the difficulty, it will bring profound, largely unpredictable changes in the $4 trillion United States economy.

title: 'Cookie-Cutters'
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography
description: In the 1960's and early 70's, Lee Friedlander's black-and-white photographs sketched a complex urban world of disarray and alienation. In the last decade, however, the 52-year-old photographer's work has evolved toward a more serene, contemplative stance.

title: Edwin Meese's Agenda
description: Though it is true that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has come under much criticism for leading the Reagan Administration's civil rights retreat, his views on criminal justice deserve much greater scrutiny than they have received (''Mr. Power,'' by John A. Jenkins, Oct. 12). Mr. Meese says he gets support from law-enforcement officials ''because I am willing to speak out on issues which are key to protecting the public.'' In fact, the Meese ''anticrime'' program amounts to a very familiar wish list: expand pretrial detention and eviscerate protections against coerced confessions and illegally obtained evidence.

title: MEESE AIDE ASSAILS THE PRESS AND LAW SCHOOLS ON COURTS
description: A top Justice Department official today denounced what he called liberal media and elite law schools as propagating an ''overblown myth'' that courts should engage in ''liberal social reform'' in the name of constitutional interpretation.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MODERN ROMANCES. By Judy Lopatin. (Fiction Collective, Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95.) Judy Lopatin's first collection of stories trains a quirky, agile intelligence on the New York-Paris axis, locating romance in hospitals, opium dens, law firms, movie theaters.

title: THE SERIES: ONCE JUST ISN'T ENOUGH
description: There was an argument on the train one night recently, an argument that spread from seat to seat until about 20 strangers were shouting or expounding or just waving their arms. It had to do with the Mets, of course. People wouldn't get quite so heated, weeks after the World Series, about the fine points, like whether Dave Johnson should have had Wally Backman bunt in the sixth game. No, this was a more basic question: Why weren't the Mets at their best in postseason play - or were they?

title: Toy Exhibit Draws on Life in New York
description: When Lawrence Scripps Wilkinson surveys the turn-of-the-century toy vehicles he has collected for more than 25 years, he sees the regal stance of high-stepping horses, the aristocratic shaping of a Hansom cab, the meticulous detailing of a hook and ladder truck and the balloon-like stacks on steam locomotives.

title: AIDS Insurance
description: INSISTING that insurance against AIDS was actuarially and economically sound, a California insurer appeared to be alone in offering such a special policy last year.

title: Favorites, Freshmen and Faces in the Crowd: Some Teams, Players and Coaches to Watch This Season
description: The Top 20 This season's Top 20, ranked in groups of 5, as selected by William C. Rhoden of The Times. The Top 5 Louisville: In deference to last year's national championship season, the Cardinals get a courtsey nod over North Carolina. Loss of Billy Thompson hurts, but Denny Crum has excellent returning talent, led by the 6-foot-9-inch sophomore center Pervis Ellison. Backcourt must play well for Cardinals to reach Final Four again.

title: Morocco
description: To the Editor: Readers of Judith Miller's article, ''From Soup to Stew, A Gastronome's Oasis'' (Travel, Aug. 31), may be interested to learn that Zette Guinaudeau, author of the Moroccan cookbook mentioned in the article, is also the author and publisher of ''Fez: Traditional Moroccan Cooking'' (Edition Z. Guinaudeau, 7 Parc de Bearn, St.-Cloud, France). This edition includes recipes for the dishes mentioned by Judith Miller, as well as some that were not.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
BUFFLEHEAD
description: Bucephala albeola Size: Thirteen to 16 inches.

title: Ms. Pamela Sebastian to Wed
description: Pamela T. Sebastian, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, and Dr. Gerald A. Ridge, an internist in practice in Bronxville, N.Y., plan to be married New Year's Eve. The future bride, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sebastian of Chicago Heights, Ill., graduated from Arizona State University and received a master's degree in journalism and English from the University of Illinois. Dr. Ridge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Ridge of Boston, graduated from Harvard College and the University of California at San Francisco School of Medicine.

title: Tainted, Tinted Movies
description: Anyone who sees many movies on television is already accustomed to not getting the real thing. Films are chopped and shortened to accommodate commercials. Wide-screen films are cut to fit the tube. Now comes the colorization of black-and-white to enhance its commercial value. Movie artisans are up in arms; movie lovers should be.

title: TRY PHEASANT FOR A LITTLE FLIGHT OF FANCY
description: SOMETIMES, when you are cooking for two people, it can be fun to prepare a special dish that takes a little extra effort. Roast guinea hen or pheasant, stuffed with fresh chestnuts, for example, or duck breasts served with thin homemade potato chips that have been fried in duck fat. Or quail, the tiny cavities filled with tarragon-mushroom stuffing, braised in white wine. The sort of chores that become tedious when you are cooking for a large number of people (like peeling chestnuts or frying endless batches of potato chips) are easy to handle in small doses. And the meal that results is something of a celebration.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: ROOSEVELT: UN-ARTY DESPITE ITS ARTISTS
description: THIS Monmouth County community has been the home of artists since shortly after Ben Shahn discovered it while painting a mural for its elementary school in 1936.

title: Red Seal's Chief Seeks New Luster
description: Not long before the West German publishing and record company Bertelsmann bought RCA Records this year, RCA's Red Seal division - devoted to classical music -brought in Michael Emmerson as president. Mr. Emmerson expressed confidence the other day that RCA and its German owners were committed to the record business and said that he was making long-term plans to bring the label out of the doldrums into which it had slipped.

title: DANCE TROUP FLOWERS IN ACADEMIC SOIL
description: NORMAN WALKER is the first to point out that his relationship with Adelphi University is ''something special.'' There aren't many choreographers who have what is essentially their own dance company, yet don't have to worry about things like finding the money to stay alive.

title: ARE FETAL RIGHTS EQUAL TO INFANTS'?
description: THE question of whether a fetus is a person, with all the legal and civil rights that status entails, is at the heart of a growing debate on the responsibilities women have to their unborn children.

title: AN EDITOR ON THE TRAIL OF THE ''GOOD STORYTELLER''
description: LAST year while vacationing on the beach at Westhampton, not long after leaving Doubleday as executive editor and not long before joining Random House as a vice president and senior editor, Kate Medina began reading the manuscript of a first novel submitted by an agent in behalf of a Texas housewife named Kathleen Koen.

title: OLD MAN ELOQUENT
description: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF CONGRESSMAN JOHN QUINCY ADAMS By Leonard L. Richards. 245 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: GREECE SEEMS OF TWO MINDS ON U.S. RELATIONS
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's discomfiture over the setback suffered by his Socialist Party in municipal elections last month appears to non-American diplomats here to have heightened his Government's ambiguity over relations with Washington.

title: Stepping Back And Letting It Fly
description: THIS is the season college basketball steps back to the future. Fans who may get the impression the players are overly concerned about their shoelaces being tied should be advised that all the staring at sneakers and backpedaling will be an effort to locate the 19-feet-9-inch line, which separates a 3-point field goal from the traditional 2-pointer.

title: SWIMMER, 17, COMPETES AS HER SCHOOL'S ''TEAM''
description: RARELY, if ever, has a high-school athlete in the state gone to the lengths that Meredith Milliken has this fall to compete in her sport.

title: RISING RENTS WORRY MERCHANTS
description: RISING rents on Seventh Street in Garden City, one of the key shopping districts, are causing many merchants to re-evaluate the future of their businesses and prompting concern among residents about the changing character of the area.

title: A SPECIAL PROBLEM OF ELDERLY VICTIMS
description: In the faces of the elderly victims, the detectives see their mothers and fathers, or even themselves 20 years from now.

title: Letting It All Go Right To Their Heads
description: THE old story about the guest who leaves the party with a lamp shade on his head is being revised. In the updated version the party guest is a fashionable woman with a keen sense of humor, and she arrives with something wild on her head.

title: The Uses of Lip-Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale Victory Comes At Brink of Defeat
description: Yale scored a touchdown, a conversion and a field goal on an improbable sequence of plays during a span of 64 seconds near the end of the game against Princeton today. The 11 points that resulted gave the Elis a 14-13 victory.

title: UNION AND POLICE CONTINUE TRANSFER NEGOTIATIONS
description: The Police Department and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association continued behind-the-scenes negotiations yesterday over Commissioner Benjamin Ward's plan to transfer thousands of officers among precincts annually as a means of combating corruption.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption on page 17 of the Arts and Leisure section today mentions an incorrect theater for ''Tangos: The Exile of Gardel.'' The film opens Friday at the Cinema Studio, Broadway at 66th Street.

title: New Caledonia Clashes Leave 14-Year-Old Dead
description: Separatists and pro-French militants clashed today, using guns and rocks, in the coastal town of Thio, killing a 14-year-old and wounding about 12 people, the police said.

title: ARTIST SPECIALIZES IN TRICKING THE EYE
description: CHRISTIAN THEE'S Weston house appears to be a typical colonial with interesting furnishings. But appearances can be deceiving. And that is what Mr. Thee is famous for.

title: Small Condos
description: To the Editor:

title: Software For Investors
description: FIND the right stock, and an investment in a personal computer and stock market software can pay off handsomely. But that is not to say the process is effortless. Personal computers do not have the artificial intelligence capacities to replace human analysts.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco;
Creating Street Fit for a Parade
description: THIS city has never had anything like a Champs-Elysees or a Pennsylvania Avenue. Parades here have had to use Market Street, a street lined with less-than-prize-winning architecture and with not much of a civic view at either end. Now city planners and some developers want to make a respectable thoroughfare out of broad, historic Van Ness Avenue, which runs from below City Hall to Aquatic Park on the Bay.

title: Democratic Dimensions
description: Professional men and women, independent Democrats in their 30's and 40's, will gather in Washington from 15 states today for a conference designed to encourage a new generation of party leadership. Organized by New Democratic Dimensions, a New York-based group established in 1981, the meeting will include consideration of establishing a new national organization of Democrats that would be critical of ''mindsets from the past'' while favoring candidates who offer ''new expressions of deep-seated values'' and ''innovative solutions to challenges old and new.'' Organizers are elated that the Democratic national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., has agreed to speak at the conference luncheon tomorrow.

title: Is a College Football Playoff Needed?
description: People have lost their perspective when referring to anything to do with the purpose of college. It is there for reasons of preparing youth for the real world ahead; it is not there to name national champions or, worse yet, to provide a profit for our nation's television networks. College has existed to benefit those who wish to make use of it as a valuable resource.

title: THE WOMAN WHO HATED WOMEN
description: THE HOUSE OF MIRTH THE REEF THE CUSTOM OF THE COUNTRY THE AGE OF INNOCENCE By Edith Wharton. 1,328 pp. New York: The Library of America. $27.50.

title: DOTTY AND DISORDERLY CONDUCT
description: THE WELL By Elizabeth Jolley. 176 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95. WOMAN IN A LAMPSHADE By Elizabeth Jolley. 229 pp. New York: King Penguin/Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: 'Fresno'- A Comedy That Must Read Better Than It Plays
description: How do you parody something that is already ridiculous? That's the question looming over, and gradually smothering, ''Fresno,'' the five-part mini-series getting a two-hour premiere on CBS at 9 tonight (the four remaining hourlong chapters will be broadcast tomorrow through Thursday, starting at 8 each evening). ''Fresno,'' subtitled ''The Raisin Capital of the World,'' is that rare television commodity: a comedy mini-series. Created for MTM Productions by Barry Kemp, who is also the executive producer and head writer, the production is a sendup of nighttime soaps. Think of the wine country in ''Falcon Crest'' or the fashion exhibitions in ''Dynasty'' or the greedy schemes in ''Dallas.'' Taking a bead on most of the cliches, ''Fresno'' blasts away with a cast of first-rate comic actors, headed by Carol Burnett, Dabney Coleman and Charles Grodin. A network press release reflects the somewhat labored satirical tone:

title: A Doctor's Despair
description: Jack L. Mayer's heart-wrenching article ''Time Out'' (About Men, Oct. 19), about caring for the rural poor in Vermont, reminds me of the first verse of the 40th Psalm: ''Beatus qui intelligit super egenum et pauperem'' (Blessed is he that understands the needy and the poor).

title: East of Hartford, the Building Rush Is On
description: THE tobacco and corn fields on the flatlands east of Hartford have become an explosive new growth area. Single-family houses, condominiums, rental apartments, office buildings and shopping centers are rising at a pace that observers say is unmatched elsewhere in Connecticut.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: REDEEMING THE TIME: A People's History of the 1920s and the New Deal. By Page Smith. (McGraw-Hill, $34.95.) With this eighth volume of ''A People's History of the United States,'' the historian Page Smith ends his sweeping chronicle of America, told in terms of the people who shaped events and those who only lived through them.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE AFRICANS: A Triple Heritage. By Ali A. Mazrui. (Little Brown, $29.95.) In spite of its title, the companion volume to the current PBS series of the same name is not an overview but an argument.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Food Bazaar, Plus 27 Vendors Estherwood's Elegant Boutiques, the seventh yearly preholiday shopping spree at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, is Wednesday from 10 A.M. to 5 P. M.; Thursday 10 A.M. to 9 P. M. and Friday 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., including luncheon daily from noon to 2 at $7 each.

title: Industry Needs Incentives Not To Pollute
description: A WELCOME consensus is emerging within American scientific and business circles that man-made chemicals are depleting the upper atmosphere's protective layer of ozone. The question now is not whether to restrict the use of the chlorofluorocarbons (C.F.C.'s) that are causing the depletion but how to restrict their use, and how soon. These questions are central to the negotiations on ozone protection scheduled for Geneva next month.

title: AGED POPULATION EXPECTED TO GROW
description: A REVISED discussion draft on the state economy discloses that current trends indicate that by the year 2000 14.3 percent of New Jersey's population will be at least 65 years old.

title: Last 52 U.S. Soldiers Withdrawn From Bolivia
description: The last contingent of United States soldiers who were sent here last July to help in a crackdown on cocaine trafficking left Bolivia today when 52 American soldiers and three Black Hawk helicopters were flown to Panama aboard transport planes.

title: SALE OF PLAYGROUND PROTESTED
description: THE last remaining open space in the Village of Rockville Centre is a section known as Dusty Acres, where for almost 50 years local youngsters have practiced football and soccer. But its days as a playground seem numbered.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about renting a flat in London listed an incorrect 800 telephone number for the St. James' Court. The correct number for toll-free calls from the United States is 800-223-9868.

title: Raisa Gorbachev Appointed To a Cultural Fund in Soviet
description: Raisa M. Gorbachev, the wife of the Soviet leader, has been elected to the governing body of a new cultural organization, the newspaper Sovetskaya Kultura said today.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: PHILHARMONIC BACK With the musicians' strike over, the Long Island Philharmonic gets back to the business of making music today. Joined by the Canadian Brass and under Christopher Keene's customary baton, the orchestra plays Bach and Musssorgsky, and goes it alone with Ravel and David Diamond. The concert is at 7:30 P.M. at the Tilles Center on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville. For ticket information call 626-3100.MALLET MUSIC

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article about guidance counseling in Education Life last Sunday misstated the date of the English Composition Achievement Test and some of its requirements. The test is given in December; it includes the multiple-choice format common to all Achievement Tests and a 20-minute essay.

title: A Long History of Joining Grows Longer
description: IS there a businessman alive who doesn't belong to at least one association? As far back as 1835, when Alexis de Tocqueville wrote, ''Americans of all ages, all conditions,a nd all dispositions constantly form associations,'' Americans have been joiners. Associations have proliferated faster in the United States than in any other country in the world.

title: ONCE-RARE ALLIGATORS LUMBER ACROSS DIXIE
description: THE alligator, decreed rare and endangered only 19 years ago, has come back with a vengeance across the South, from the brackish coastal lowlands of the Carolinas to the swamps of southeast Texas. Wendell Neal of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service concedes that no one has tried a census: ''All I can say is, we got lots of gators, they're in good shape and they come in all sizes.''

title: The Stuff of Legends
description: MY NAME'S ROCK Starr. I'm a legend in my own time. Underneath, though, I'm just a guy who loves my Mom and have forgiven my Dad for splitting before I was born and turning into a boozy old philanderer now on his fifth divorce.

title: PARENT PRESSURE CITED AS HARMFUL
description: Many parents are pushing their very young children too hard to perform academically, and that is causing increased problems of stress and depression among the children, two prominent experts warned here Friday.

title: WHEN LIVVIE CAN'T READ
description: PRIVATE SCORES By Anne Tolstoi Wallach. 354 pp. New York: NAL Books/New American Library. $17.95.

title: Turkish Cypriots Celebrate
description: Turkish Cypriots celebrated the third anniversary of their declaration of independence in northern Cyprus today, and Greek Cypriots ended two-days of protests in the south of the divided island.

title: Tina Howe Writes A Love Story Set on A Beach
description: Under a searing summer sun, an ethereally beautiful young woman is lying on a New England beach. Fragile and neurotic, she has come to pull herself together after a disastrous love affair. Hovering nearby is the beach's lifeguard, aching from a romantic debacle of his own, who has developed an intense infatuation with her.

title: BOSTON DELAYS WATER DIVERSION PLAN
description: Forty-eight years ago, the small central Massachusetts towns of Dana, Enfield, Greenwich and Prescott were evacuated and flooded to create the 38-square-mile Quabbin Reservoir for metropolitan Boston.

title: SNAPSHOTS: THE BEST ARE THOSE UNTAKEN
description: I often think that Eastman Kodak must have been thrilled at the development of the Boeing 707, the first successful commercial jet. It promised that, in the space of a two-week vacation, people could crisscross Europe - even the whole globe - while snapping away at all the places they thought they'd never see. The 3 or 4 rolls of the ordinary vacationing couple burgeoned to 10 or 12. Most people, I suspect, have several albums culled from these photographic extravaganzas and, like me, they drag them all out once in a while to try to regain the sense of traveling in the real footsteps of Marco Polo or the imaginary ones of Sir John Mandeville.

title: JUNIOR LEAGUE IS SPONSOR FOR ANTIQUES SHOW
description: AFTER five years of such fund-raising projects as tag sales and auctions, the Junior League of Central Westchester has redirected its energies and decided to sponsor a major antiques event.

title: Budget Process Is Re-Examined
description: Few people in Washington - and not many elsewhere, for that matter - would disagree with Alfred H. Kingon's observations on the budget process. ''The system as it now exists is just not working,'' said President Reagan's Cabinet secretary last week.

title: EUROPE MIRED IN BICKERING OVER WHO DUMPS WHAT
description: IN one way, European countries had an easy time of it last week, pointing fingers at Switzerland for its admitted role in the latest poisoning of the Rhine. But a longer look at the continent's record suggests that everybody has generated pollution that has often become somebody else's problem.

title: Standard Rules Set by Boards
description: Boards of directors generally set house rules for renovations and, in large buildings, require a renovator to sign a formal alteration agreement that is intended to protect the financial interests of the building and its residents.

title: CAN STATES ACT WITHOUT FEDERAL PERMISSION?
description: SINCE taking office, President Reagan has often proclaimed his desire to ''curb the size and influence of the Federal establishment'' while trying to increase the role of state governments. In 1982, he proposed to rearrange responsibilty for welfare, Medicaid and food stamps as part of a ''new federalism'' initiative widely protested by the states. And last week the Administration issued a report on federalism, asserting that the Supreme Court had systematically undermined state sovereignty for more than 50 years. Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, discussed these issues with Assistant Attorney General Charles J. Cooper, who headed the group that prepared it, and Herman Schwartz, a professor of law at American University in Washington, D.C.

title: Penn St. Rallies to Top Irish
description: Threatened with its first defeat of the season and trailing Notre Dame midway in the third period, Penn State rallied to beat the Irish, 24-19, before a crowd of 59,075 today.

title: 400 Protest Harassment Of Black Cadet at Citadel
description: About 400 demonstrators marched through the streets of Charleston today to protest the racial harassment of a black cadet at the Citadel.

title: LAWMAKERS TO PRESS REAGAN AIDES TO EXPLAIN THE IRAN ARMS DEALS
description: Members of Congress said today that they were preparing to confront the White House and demand that President Reagan's foreign policy advisers explain their dealings with Iran.

title: Jersey Radon Test Praised
description: A program to apply radon-removal techniques in New Jersey homes has cut levels of the radioactive gas by more than 98 percent, according to officials.

title: BLOOD BANKS ACT TO REASSURE DONORS
description: THE chances of getting a disease from a blood transfusion are less than the chances of being hit by a bolt of lightning, say blood-bank officials on Long Island.

title: Dances of Intense Stillness
description: A decade ago, at Japan House, New York followers of underground dance were stunned by an extraordinary performance of intense stillness, of stark minimalism. The dancers were Eiko and Koma, who had recently come from Tokyo and who have remained here, performing mostly in New York lofts and teaching at summer festivals.

title: 'DATE RAPE' ON CAMPUS, A CONCERN AT WESLEYAN
description: THOUGH they say they would never sexually abuse a woman, some men at Wesleyan University may have done just that. They have committed ''date rape,'' an assault that is getting a lot of attention on the Middletown campus this year.

title: NEW CONGRESSIONAL LEADERS HOPE TO CLOSE THE AGENDA GAP
description: SENATOR J. BENNETT JOHNSTON was direct in announcing that he was withdrawing from the race for Senate majority leader. ''I do not believe I have the votes,'' the Louisiana Democrat said.

title: ROBERT CRAY'S BLUES EMBODY A DIFFERENT, MODERN IDEA
description: In an America that television and airplanes had yet to homogenize, the blues bore testimony to a strikingly specific sense of place. It emerged in the few hundred miles of the Mississippi Delta and then traveled with its practitioners north to the ghettos of Memphis, St. Louis and Chicago. Far from harming or limiting the music, this kind of isolation infused the blues with its power, its passion, its acute and aching detail.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Education Life last Sunday about music conservatories overstated the Juilliard School's enrollment. There are 730 students in the music division, 75 in the dance division, 75 studying theater and 250 graduate students.

title: Energy Alternatives Still Cure Oil Dependency
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
GETTING THE BEST OUT OF AN OLD PIANO
description: LIKE the ivory in old piano keys, the availability of specialists capable of undertaking repair and restoration of the instrument is dwindling.

title: K. C. Harris Wed To Miss Bellamy
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y., yesterday Susan I. Bellamy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bellamy Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married to K. Carter Harris, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Kenneth Harris of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Roger Schellenberg performed the ceremony.

title: PIPELINE GAS: INDEED THERE IS NEED
description: AS I hike through the hills near my home, I can put myself in the place of those who oppose the Iroquois pipeline. Like many residents of Connecticut, I visit the woods often and find myself refreshed by the natural surroundings of our beautiful state.

title: In Indianapolis, Colts Going Nowhere Fast
description: THIS is a tale of two teams and how youth, inexperience and depleted ranks have produced the 0-10 record the Indianapolis Colts bring into today's game against the 9-1 Jets at Giants Stadium.

title: Lincoln Remains Uhdefeated; Jackson and New Dorp Gain
description: Three of the four Public School Athletic League quarterfinal games yesterday were cliffhangers, with Lincoln, Wagner, Jackson and New Dorp advancing to the semifinals next week.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HAVENS TO PERFORM

title: A NEW LEADER EMERGES FROM SHADOW OF MANES
description: AS Education Secretary William J. Bennett posed recently for photographs with third graders of Public School 98 in Douglaston, Queens, a Federally designated exemplary school, an aide to Queens Borough President Claire Shulman suggested that she get into the picture.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Sales Devices; Right From the House's Mouth
description: LAUREN HAYES was taking a midweek drive last August on a quiet residential street near her in-laws' home in Dunn, N.C., when she saw a ''For Sale'' sign outside a vacant, cedar-sided comtemporary on North Orange Avenue. The house seemed smaller than what she was shopping for, but the sign advised her to tune her car AM radio to a special frequency to hear more about the property.

title: A CONTEMPT FOR DANGER
description: THE LITTLE VIRTUES By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by Dick Davis. 110 pp. New York: Seaver Books. $13.95.

title: TWO VISIONS FROM ARRABAL'S WORLD
description: The provocative Spanish playwright Fernando Arrabal enjoys telling the story of a recent dinner with his fellow dramatist Eugene Ionesco: ''Ionesco looked at me piercingly, and uttered in his slow voice: 'Arrabal, you and I are considered the young theater vanguardists, but if you add our respective ages, it comes to 130.' '' Ionesco's remark was not hyperbole. At the age of 54, Arrabal has maintained his status as a perennial enfant terrible of the stage.

title: DIFFICULTIES SEEN FOR OPEC'S EFFORTS TO RAISE PRICES
description: The move by key oil exporters here to raise petroleum prices by $3 a barrel, to $18, was lauded by industry analysts today as an attempt to stabilize the market. But they said the move faced many difficulties and was unlikely to succeed without sharp cuts in production.

title: RUNAWAY YOUTHS: A CHANGING PROFILE
description: WHEN Beaver ran away from home in the 1950's television show ''Leave It to Beaver,'' viewers knew that his departure was staged and that the Beaver would return to the Cleaver family in time for the next episode.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DISCOURSE AT TRINITY Trinity College in Hartford has several programs on its agenda this week, beginning at 8 P.M. Tuesday with Tony Bill, an actor, director and producer. He is to talk about filmmaking, show excerpts from a rough cut of his film in progress, ''Five Corners,'' and preside over a screening of ''My Bodyguard,'' which he directed.

title: SECURITIES PENALTY MAY ALTER TAKEOVER GAME
description: The announcement on Friday that Ivan F. Boesky, Wall Street's largest and best known speculator in takeover stocks, had admitted to illegally profiting from inside information could make it more difficult for financial entrepreneurs to take over voting control of major corporations.

title: Psychology of Taking Risks
description: ''I TAKE risks in my career, but not with my money,'' said Katherine Pope, executive director of the Women's Ensemble, a New York theatrical company. Ms. Pope recently sold her Manhattan co-op at a profit of nearly half a million dollars. She put $100,000 into an annuity that will mature when she is 60. The rest is in two bank accounts.

title: Lori Wachter Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Wachter of Woodbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lori Susan Wachter to Dr. Hal Steven Wolfson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Wolfson of Brooklyn. Miss Wachter, a recreational therapist at Beth Israel Hospital in New York, graduated from Boston University, from which she also received a master's degree in therapeutic recreation. Dr. Wolfson, who graduated from Brooklyn College and the New York University Dental School, served as a lieutenant in the Navy.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ZONE OF FIRE. By Conrad Detrez. Translated by Lydia Davis. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) ''The revolution is no longer a matter of the heart,'' a militant Sandinista journalist explains four years after the revolution.

title: Hostetler Will Take Any Job He Can Get
description: IF Jeff Hostetler is a quarterback, what was he doing deflecting a punt last Sunday that led to the Giants' first touchdown against the Philadelphia Eagles?

title: Bridge-Collapse Cause Cited
description: State officials confirmed today that overloading caused a bridge collapse Friday that killed one man and injured two others. The officials said a crane that crossed the bridge just before the collapse weighed about 14 tons, almost twice the posted limit for the bridge. The 183-foot bridge was to be replaced in 1988 at a cost of $800,000.

title: America's Native Legacy
description: AFTER YEARS OF SEEK-ing out food secrets from China to India, Sweden to Brazil, Americans have matured and come home to discover a rich culinary heritage in their own backyards. With a little research, it is apparent that more than half of the foods we eat, and many of our methods of preparation, owe their origins to the American Indian. Creative chefs are unabashedly borrowing these ideas and translating them into contemporary dishes.

title: WHAT ARE NUCLEAR WEAPONS GOOD FOR?
description: BLUNDERING INTO DISASTER Surviving the First Century of the Nuclear Age. By Robert McNamara. 212 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95.

title: Some Tense Talk On Police Transfers
description: For the New York City Police Department and for the city itself, it was the kind of week Mayor Koch must have had in mind when he told a police officers' benevolent group last Sunday, speaking of the corruption scandals and what they had brought, ''You can come to the edge of weeping.''

title: Delusion of Democracy
description: Turnout in the 1986 election was low, so low as to create the danger illustrated by the drunk under the streetlight. A cop comes along and asks what he's doing down there on his hands and knees. ''L-l-looking for my wallet.'' The cop offers to help: ''Where, exactly, did you lose it?'' The drunk points up the street. ''Then why are you looking here?'' the cop asks. ''Because the light's better.''

title: Debora L. Toffey Engaged to Marry Richard Puckette
description: The engagement of Debora Lynn Toffey to Richard Charles Puckette has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. James Toffey of New Vernon, N.J., and Kennebunk Beach, Me. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles McDonald Puckette 4th of Scotia, N.Y.

title: IRANIANS RAID A CARGO VESSEL
description: Iran launched a missile attack on a cargo vessel in the southern Persian Gulf today as a fire raged on one of its offshore oil platforms, a day after a long-range strike by Iraqi jets.

title: Linda Bernstein Wed To Daniel L. Brockett
description: At the Union Church in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., yesterday Linda Karen Bernstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Bernstein of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married to Daniel Lawrence Brockett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Brockett of Nelson, Ohio. The Rev. Robert Dorer, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: WOMAN TAKES LITERACY COURSE TO RURAL MASSACHUSETTS
description: Lindy Whiton wanted to teach illiterates to read, but figured college was not the place to do it.

title:
MUSIC;
ORCHESTRA ADDS PERFROMANCE SITES
description: THE New Philharmonic of New Jersey, under its music director, Leon Hyman, will open its 1986-87 season next weekend with a ''Wholly Mozart'' program and a new series of subscription concerts.

title: NEWCOMER'S MENU BROAD IN SCOPE
description: THE significance of the name of the new restaurant in Centerbrook, Pelican, eluded us, so we asked our waiter. ''It's the name of one of the owner's boats that he sails around the Caribbean,'' he told us.

title: SKIRTING CREDIBILITY'S BORDER IN SEARCH OF A MIDEAST DEAL
description: IN the soothing tones that have lubricated his entire Presidency, Ronald Reagan sidestepped the carping politicians, columnists and diplomats last week and took his case on Iran directly to the American people. In 12 minutes on television, he offered his version of a remarkable 18 months of secret diplomacy and arms sales to a country that his Administration had denounced as a font of terrorism and anti-American fanaticism.

title: Police in Punjab Kill 3
description: The police killed three Sikhs in a gunfight today, and a local leader of the governing Congress Party was shot dead in the Punjab, the authorities said. The Sikhs, suspected of being members of the etremist Khalistan Commando Force, were killed in a 30-minute battle near Batala. The Press Trust of India news agency identified the dead politician as Sampuran Singh, 50 years old, who was the local leader of Talwandi Bhai, a village near Firozpur.

title: The World of 18th Century Dance Comes Back to Life
description: What's new in dance? The 18th century, for one thing. Dancers and historians are attempting to restore both the letter and the spirit of 18th-century productions. And certain aspects of those works seem surprisingly in tune with contemporary sensibilities.

title: Cuomo Disputes The Press Again
description: In his first major speech in New York City since his re-election Nov. 4, Governor Cuomo glanced back into the kitchen last week and said he had not liked some of the heat.

title: HUSSEIN TO SHARE 'POWER' WITH ISRAEL
description: ABDEL Majid el-Zir, a Jordanian civil servant who has been running health programs here for 20 years, is a symbol of the developing alliance in which Israel and King Hussein of Jordan are jointly trying to undercut the Palestine Liberation Organization on the West Bank and in Gaza.

title: Data Update: November 16, 1986
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars) Sept.Sept.85Change New York#385.0 #450.2-14% New Jersey#338.6 339.3-1% Connecticut#198.8 122.5#62% Source: F.W. title: PRESIDENTIAL PROCLAMATION ON THANKSGIVING
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Thanksgiving Day proclamation: THE WHITE HOUSE By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation

title: In Politics by TV, Money Does All the Talking; Make Air Time Free
description: To the Editor:

title: WALL STREET JOURNAL PROVIDES A GLIMPSE OF 3-SECTION PAPER
description: Revving up for a three-section paper, The Wall Street Journal gave a glimpse of it last Monday with a section headlined Markets and Money, the probable title for the new third section.

title:
GARDENING;
TO FRUIT, HOLLIES NEED AGE AND MATES
description: A COMPLAINT frequently aired by gardeners is that their holly fails to produce fruit. This is a great disappointment since the primary reason for planting hollies is that of having their attractive red fruits for fall and winter display both indoors and in holiday decorations.

title: COSTS AS WELL AS WATER ARE FLOWING THROUGH THE WEST
description: BENEATH a serrated mountain horizon south of here, men and giant machines are creating a 375-mile network of dams and pipelines that by 1997 will carry a cascade of additional water to this fast-growing city. It is a familiar tableau in the West. Since the 1920's, the Federal Government has spent billions of dollars on great engineering projects that have transported water hundreds of miles, turning wasteland into cities and deserts into lush fields.

title: Goodbye Transit Aid?
description: Beneficiaries of some Government programs expressed private relief when the Democrats recaptured control of the Senate, believing that they will prove less stingy with Federal financing than the Republican majority of the past six years. But supporters of urban mass transit did not share this optimism.

title:
OPPORTUNITIES AND PITFALLS;
Real Estate Takes It On the Chin
description: ALTHOUGH the writing has been on the Congressional walls nearly two years, real estate investors were not prepared for the blow lawmakers dealt them with the passage of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Real estate's historic tax lures are vanishing, changing decisively the way investors should behave.

title: Some Bad News For Nuisance Callers
description: ''C LASS'' is a service for anyone who has ever heard a ringing phone and fumbled with door keys, dashed into the house, dropped the groceries and stepped on the cat - only to pick up the phone and hear the receiver click. Subscribers to ''CLASS'' - more formally known as Custom Local-Area Signaling Services - can, by pressing two digits, be reconnected to the phone that last called. They can also get selective call forwarding, distinctive rings identifying specific callers, call screening and call tracing.

title: 'Crocodile Dundee': All-Australian Film, All-American Values
description: ''Crocodile Dundee'' according to a recent issue of Variety, is ''nifty'' in Kansas City, ''wrestling fine'' in New York, ''chewing loudly'' in Los Angeles and ''grinning'' in St. Louis. In Chicago it's ''munching'' and in Washington, D.C., ''heroic.''

title: WHEN WINDOWS 'SWEAT': THE 3 SOLUTIONS TO CONDENSATION
description: ''WHAT can I do about my windows constantly 'sweating' and dripping water during cold weather?''

title: Anna Darling Knipe Is Wed to Michael D. Donahue
description: Anna Darling Knipe, the daughter of Mrs. Allen Salvesen of Boca Raton, Fla., and Timothy Wetherill Knipe of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael David Donahue, the son of Evelyn Wood and Thomas J. Donahue, both of Norristown, Pa. The Rev. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony at the the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes: Truffaut's 'Girls'
description: English Folk Heroes, Vol. 2 (The Table Round and Beowulf) Donald Thompson, producer MCA Home Video 30 minutes. $14.95

title: NATHALIE RESNIKOFF
description: Nathalie Resnikoff, honorary national president of AMIT Women, a national women's Zionist organization, died of cancer Nov. 8 at her home in Manhattan. She was 76 years old.

title: Stocks: Time to Take Gains?
description: WITH the most sweeping tax legislation in postwar history on the books, Wall Street's focal point has moved from the nation's economy, interest rates and corporate profits to the impact of the tax law. The overwhelming opinion so far is that the effects will be great, with the less favored treatment of capital gains steering investors toward high-dividend, low-risk stocks and away from the more chancy, low-yield ones.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are days when envy can't be avoided. It isn't because of Chanel suits, sable coats, long fingernails or the perfectly coiffed hair that indicates a daily visit to or from a hairdresser - sorry, hair stylist. It isn't even because of the car and driver that one knows are hovering somewhere near, although goodness knows such transportation might be worth a pact with the devil.

title: ADS WITH THE DUSENBERRY TOUCH
description: THE scene: A group of high-powered executives assembles for a meeting. One of them looks out the window and notices something strange going on in the parking lot. Some ''hotshots from finance'' are carrying computers from their cars into the building. Does the company allow employees to take its computers home, an executive asks. No, he is told. These people are bringing their own computers to use in the office. Theirs can produce ''killer forecasts'' with stunning graphics that the company's computers cannot match. What's the name of this extraordinary computer? Finally, the product is identified: Apple Computer's Macintosh.

title: Lynne Queenan, Publishing Executive, Will Marry PhilipBeauregard in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Thomas Queenan of Washington and Jefferson, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carrie Lynne Queenan, to Philip Henry Michael Beauregard, a son of Mrs. Dillon-Smyth Crocker and the late Henry George Beauregard, both of Washington. A May wedding is planned.

title: RIGHTS GROUP DEPICTS ARMY ABUSES IN LIBERIA
description: Gen. Samuel K. Doe, the Liberian President, ''has sanctioned an undercurrent of lawlessness and random brutality'' by the military since he took power in 1980, a New York-based human rights group said last week.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE decision by President Reagan to veto reauthorization of the Clean Water Act of 1971 could cost New Jersey $50 million in Federal grants for sewer construction in 1987, according to Nicholas Binder, assistant director of construction grants administration for the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: WOMEN IN JOURNALISM: A GLOBAL PERSPECTIVE
description: Lesley Stahl of CBS News told a skeptical woman from West Germany that yes, she could balance a child and a career in journalism.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
An Affair of the Heart
