description: BY NOW, I'M USED TO IT.

title: Israel Says It Has Ex-Nuclear Aide
description: The mystery of Mordechai Vanunu's whereabouts ended last week when the Israeli Government confirmed that it had detained the former nuclear technician, who gave a British newspaper detailed information on a secret installation in the Negev desert. The Government did not explain how Mr. Vanunu had gotten from London, where he was last seen Sept. 30, back to Israel, but it is widely believed that he had been abducted by agents of the Mossad secret service.

title: McCarthyism on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAMLESS JUXTAPOSITION AT NABISCO
description: ALTHOUGH the claim is often made that some works in craft materials are really art, too rarely is that assertion tested by exhibiting such works on equal terms with painting and sculpture. More often than not, efforts to present such a mix compromise one side of the equation or the other.

title: OFFICIALS CITE 44 FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 44 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Dr. Susan Lichter Will Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lichter of New York and North Salem, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Susan Leigh Lichter, to Dr. Ezra Deutsch, a son of Dr. Lawrence Deutsch and Dr. Ruth Freed Deutsch of Englewood, N.J. The wedding is planned for April.

title: SOVIET FAMILY LEAVES AGAIN
description: An emigre family of five that returned to its Soviet homeland complaining about life in the United States headed back to America today after six days in Moscow.

title: POSTINGS: In Middletown, Conn.; 325 Affordables
description: Midway between Hartford and New Haven is Middletown, Conn., covering 43 square miles along the Connecticut River. Long associated with its reputable resident, Wesleyan University, the city is now being eyed by developers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE COUNT-DUKE OF OLIVARES: The Statesman in an Age of Decline. By J. H. Elliott. (Yale, $29.95.) Don Gaspar de Guzman, the Count-Duke of Olivares (1587-1645), was the principal leader of the Spanish Empire, the most powerful political body in Europe, during the Thirty Years War.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
Bringing Lee Harvey Oswald to 'Trial'
description: After 23 years of inquiry and speculation, what new truths can be determined about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy? While ''On Trial: Lee Harvey Oswald,'' a five-and-a-half-hour ''television event'' coming to Showtime this week, promises no major revelations, the producers of this speculative exercise believe that it may help clarify some of the details of that tragic incident for today's viewers.

title: ...WHILE IN DUBLIN, STREETS ARE QUIET
description: Threats from Protestant extremists in Northern Ireland to bomb the Irish Republic out of its adherence to the landmark treaty it signed a year ago with Britain had the visible effect today of discouraging shopping on Dublin's main thoroughfares.

title: The Battle Over Drug Testing
description: Judge Irving R. Kaufman's overview of the drug-testing battle just begins to hint at the potential human cost of random urine testing when he gives examples of employees unfairly accused of drug abuse because of ''false positive'' tests (''The Battle Over Drug Testing,'' Oct. 19). As a consultant to drug-rehabilitation programs, I know that even the best labs have a 5-10 percent error rate.

title: A SAD BASEL OFFERS DIRGE FOR 'FLUVIUS RHINUS'
description: About 200 mourners, including a handful of students from Basel's Conservatory of Music, held a funeral march here today for ''Fluvius Rhinus, Died Nov. 1'' in a symbolic gesture that goes some way toward defining the mood of this city that is suddenly and deeply in conflict with itself.

title: Big Deals: No Big Deal
description: Richard Darman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, has his doubts about the efficiency of big business. Still, there is little likelihood that the Government will try to stop the current wave of mergers.

title: Economic Uncertainty Opens Opportunities to Investors
description: FOR the better part of six months, the American economy has teetered along on a low-growth path, confounding the forecasters who were certain a pickup was just around the corner and surprising those who saw the next bend in the road as recession.

title: With a Crew, A Voyage In Luxury
description: The true test of the soul is bareboat sailing: No crew, just you and your boat against the elements. For the purist, there is no alternative. For the faintly impure, however, there is another option: crewed-boat chartering.

title: Taking the Joy Out of an Old Job
description: IN 1969, an operator's day was spent poking and pulling cords in and out of jacks, punching time clocks to determine how long calls lasted, or, in the case of directory assistance operators, flipping through listings.

title: DONOR'S CONCERN FOR CHILDREN BRINGS $5 MILLION GIFT TO YALE
description: When Irving B. Harris was born 76 years ago, his jubilant father sent a telegram to a friend: ''A $10,000-a-year-man has just been born.''

title: NASSAU TAX RISE STIRS DEBATE
description: CRITICS of Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell's proposed 1987 budget, which includes an 8.7 percent increase in property taxes, noted last week that it was proposed at a time when Long Island's economy continues to prosper.

title:
GARDENING;
TO FRUIT, HOLLIES NEED AGE AND MATES
description: A COMPLAINT frequently aired by gardeners is that their holly fails to produce fruit. This is a great disappointment since the primary reason for planting hollies is that of having their attractive red fruits for fall and winter display both indoors and in holiday decorations.

title: MURDER, THEY WROTE
description: BY 8 A.M., TWO HOURS before final arguments would begin in Robert O. Marshall's murder trial, every seat in the Mays Landing, N.J., courtroom had been filled and a line was forming outside. As murder trials go, this one seemed to have everything. Marshall, a prominent insurance broker and the father of three sons, was accused of hiring a hit man to kill his wife so that he could collect $1.5 million in life insurance and continue an extramarital affair with the vice principal of a local high school.

title: THE RICH GET BETTER
description: MEDICAL CARE, MEDICAL COSTS The Search for a Health Insurance Policy. By Rashi Fein. 240 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20.

title: I MARRIED A GENIUS
description: ZORINA By Vera Zorina. Illustrated. 311 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: Making The Phone Info Into a P.O. Box
description: DEBBIE FIELDS, the Mrs. Fields of cookie fame, talks to the managers of each of her 350 cookie shops at least twice a week. But their phones never ring. And she dictates only one message each time.

title: HOLDING ON TO TECHNICAL TALENT
description: IF the 3M Company had not for years offered its employees a dual career ladder, it might not be offering customers Post-it Notes, those ubiquitous little self-stick note pads that in six years have become a top-selling office-supply product.

title: JOHN WOLBARST
description: John Wolbarst, the retired managing editor of Modern Photography magazine and a former vice president of the Polaroid Corporation, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital here.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dallas;
Redesigning the Design District
description: IN 1953, in discussions with local manufacturers' representatives, Trammell Crow was asked to build what amounted to a shopping center for the design industry. With several similar businesses at a single site, they reasoned, they would attract more customers than if they were scattered throughout the city.

title: PERMANENT HOUSING FOR HOMELESS FAMILIES
description: ABOUT 40 poor families now living on the street, in motels and in apartments from which they are being evicted are waiting to find out if they will be among the 10 chosen to move into the state's first apartment building designated solely for the homeless.

title: Peace March Ends In Rally at Capital Park
description: Thousands of weary marchers and joyous supporters joined today in singing the folk anthem ''This Land Is Your Land'' to end the eight-month, 3,600-mile Great Peace March for Global Nuclear Disarmament.

title: BRAZIL, IN TRANSITION, VOTES FOR CONGRESS
description: In a key stage of this country's gradual transition from military dictatorship to full democracy, more than 60 million Brazilians voted today to choose a new Congress that is to pave the way for the first direct presidential elections since 1960.

title: BANKS, UNDER DEREGULATION, ARE APPLYING FOR BRANCHES
description: USING a new law, banks are stepping up their applications to set up branches in dozens of Connecticut communities previously closed to outside banks.

title: The New Appeal of Bonds
description: THE bond rally, fueled by falling interest rates and low inflation, continues its steady pace, although experts expect the rosy economic picture to dim somewhat as summer approaches. But the restructuring of the nation's tax system adds new appeal to the bond market for a broad group of investors. Tax revision has also complicated the market for municipal bonds, creating new opportunities for astute investors.

title: LEONYD RZHEVSKY
description: Leonyd Rzhevsky, a Russian writer and literary scholar who taught Russian literature in this country since his arrival from Sweden in 1963, died of a heart attack Thursday.

title: LUBOVITCH, DESIGNER OF DANCES
description: LAR LUBOVITCH first came into contact with dance as a college student in Chicago, his hometown. The occasion was a performance by the Jose Limon Dance Company. When the curtain went down, Mr. Lubovitch went backstage and buttonholed the first dancer he found. ''What should I do?'' he asked. ''I want to dance.''

title: WAYS OF THE BEDOUINS IN A DESERT MUSEUM
description: When a friend first mentioned that Kibbutz Lahav in the northern Negev had established a Bedouin museum, it struck me as a contradiction in terms. The idea of encasing the traditional accouterments and folk art of a nomadic people just didn't seem quite right. After all, the very essence of Bedouinism is impermanence - a constant movement across the sands of both time and space.

title: TEAMS HELP YOUTHS HANDLE CRISIS
description: ON Oct. 3, 1979, a tornedo struck the town of Windsor.

title: LIVELY MAYOR IN LINE FOR A NEW HEART
description: Mayor John E. Reardon, who is better known here as Jack, stepped out of the elevator, strode down the hall and briskly entered his City Hall office, looking nothing like a man who had learned the odds had increased that he would soon become the country's first Mayor with a transplanted heart.

title: PENGUIN PRESENTS ''SANTA ANITA '42''
description: DON'T expect yet another Neil Simon revival or the umpteenth production of ''Pump Boys and Dinettes'' at the Penguin Repertory, an enterprising 10-year-old professional company having its first year-round season.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE PINK TRIANGLE: The Nazi War Against Homosexuals. By Richard Plant. (New Republic/Holt, $19.95.) In February of 1933, less than a month after Hitler became Chancellor of Germany, the Government banned pornography and homosexual-rights organizations. A month later, the SS arrested a prominent homosexual activist and shipped him to a concentration camp. Two months after that, Nazi-incited thugs destroyed the Institute of Sexual Science in Berlin, run by Magnus Hirschfeld, a prominent sexologist, Jew, homosexual and Social Democrat. So began the Nazi campaign against male homosexuals (lesbians, for reasons that remain obscure, were largely spared), which persisted until the end of the war. Heinrich Himmler, chief of the SS, directed the campaign in the firm belief that homosexuality was a contagious evil, a threat to procreation and the future of Germany. Thousands of homosexuals were murdered outright or remanded to concentration camps, where they bore the mark of the pink triangle sewn on their uniforms. Trumped-up charges were also used by the Nazis to eliminate troublesome political opponents. Yet some prominent homosexuals, like the actor Gustaf Grundgens, on whom Klaus Mann based his 1936 novel ''Mephisto,'' remained close to the regime and prospered under the Nazis. These are very murky historical waters, and as Richard Plant takes pains to point out, reasonably exact information on the campaign is virtually impossible to come by. He estimates that between 5,000 and 15,000 accused homosexuals died in concentration camps, but available statistics are conflicting, and much archival and research material remains under wraps in East Germany and the Soviet Union.

title: Kathleen Grady Plans Wedding
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Grady of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Monica Grady to Thomas Francis Skelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Skelly of Westwood, Mass. The wedding is planned for January.

title: Julia E. Guttman Weds B.S. Cohen
description: Julia Evans Guttman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Guttman of Bethesda, Md., and Benedict Simms Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mark Cohen of Brentwood, Tenn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Robert M. Norris performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Bethesda.

title: HOW 3 INSIDER DEALS WORKED, AS DETAILED BY U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from the insider trading complaint made by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Ivan F. Boesky. The excerpts describe the circumstances behind Mr. Boesky's trading in three of the seven takeover situations cited in the commission's complaint and the involvement of several New York investment bankers, including Ira B. Sokolow of Shearson/Lehman American Express, Robert M. Wilkis of Lazard Freres & Company and Dennis B. Levine of Drexel Bernham Lambert. NABISCO BRANDS

title:
GARDENING;
TO FRUIT, HOLLIES NEED AGE AND MATES
description: A COMPLAINT frequently aired by gardeners is that their holly fails to produce fruit. This is a great disappointment since the primary reason for planting hollies is that of having their attractive red fruits for fall and winter display both indoors and in holiday decorations.

title: PRESERVING THE PAGES OF HISTORY
description: ''MR. von Wedell will open his soda-water fountain next week. All who want a good drink should go and try it.''

title: What's Wrong in the White House?
description: At last, the President has at least brought the Iran mess out into the open. His public statement, though defensive and incomplete, belatedly launches a damage-control effort. But the larger signs remain unmistakable: The Reagan Administration's foreign policy is coming unglued.

title: HOSPITALS EXTEND CARE INTO HOMES
description: FEWER and fewer hospital patients in Connecticut are healthy enough when they are discharged to be independent when they return home, according to health and hospital officials in the state.

title: MAYOR SHUNS THE PRESS: RESULT IS HEADLINES
description: The Mayor of Magnolia, Del., has asked that reporters not cover town meetings unless they call in advance and ask for an invitation.

title: Insuring An Orderly Meeting
description: A MAN in the back row kept jumping up and calling the presiding officer a nincompoop. Another continually interrupted the debate by shouting ''Green!'', emphatically voicing his preference for having the lobby painted kelly green while almost everyone else favored periwinkle blue. Meanwhile, a third member of the audience quietly collected support for dismissing the superintendent.

title: WITH ''INFORMANCES,'' THE STAGE GOES TO THE AUDIENCE
description: ''TO turn the world at large into a stage'' is a motto -and a mission - of Affiliate Artists, a not-for-profit organization that produces and designs performing arts programs. It presents artists in unlikely settings, from corporate conference rooms to factories and fire stations.

title: Mets Raising Ticket Prices
description: There is apparently a price to be exacted for the success of the Mets. Ticket prices are going up and there will be no more general admission seats.

title: Miss Apruzzese Plans to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Lynn Marie Apruzzese and James Fenelon Des Marais has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Apruzzese of Mendham, N.J.

title: Miss Rice to Wed Steven P. Voight
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anton H. Rice 3d of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Atwood Rice, to Steven Paul Voight, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Voight of Westport, Conn.

title: James Clement Clark Marries Elyse Billera
description: St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elyse Francesca Billera, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Billera of Summit, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., and James Clement Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Clark of Short Hills. The Rev. Richard Rento performed the ceremony.

title: TRACING HARTFORD'S HISTORY
description: Writing a history of Hartford was a ''great labor of love'' for Ellsworth Strong Grant, he said, because he wrote it with his wife, Marion, and because they both cherished the city.

title: A Duty to Sellers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: LINDA GOLD
description: LINDA GOLD always appeared to be striving toward some grand heroic gesture in the solos she danced Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. But no such gesture was ever made. Therefore, though blessed with a quiet intensity as a performer, she was frustrating to watch.

title: NICARAGUAN COURT CONVICTS AMERICAN OVER AID TO REBELS
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the American air-cargo specialist whose arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua Oct. 5, was convicted today and sentenced to 30 years in jail by a Nicaraguan tribunal.

title: AMERICA AS A MONUMENTAL GAMBLE
description: THE CYCLES OF AMERICAN HISTORY By Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. 498 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: Turgeon Recovering
description: SYLVAIN TURGEON, the Hartford Whalers' leading scorer last season, underwent successful surgery for an unusual abdominal injury that has bothered him for three years. Turgeon was operated on for one and a half hours at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford and doctors found the problem that had been suspected all along: ''a defect in the transversalis fascia with herniation of fatty tissue.''

title: Kathleen Gold to Wed
description: Kathleen Marie Gold, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Gold of Hauppauge, L.I., and Scott Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Singer, also of Hauppauge, plan to be married. Miss Gold, a promotion manager for the ''Donahue'' show in New York, graduated from Pepperdine University. Mr. Singer, who graduated cum laude from the University of Miami in Coral Gables, Fla., expects to graduate in May from the American University's Washington College of Law.

title: In Politics by TV, Money Does All the Talking
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW $30 MILLION MAIL FACILITY TO SPEED THE 22c LETTER
description: THE United States Postal Service, with its eye on the future and its hand on its wallet, is replacing its makeshift Hicksville Post Office with a new $30 million facility on Route 110 in Melville.

title: MEETINGS SET ON ANIMAL PULLS
description: THE draft-animal associations in the state have agreed to discuss with animal-welfare groups proposals to prevent injuries to animals at horse- and ox-pulling events.

title: Ms. Crichton, Author, Wed
description: Jennifer Crichton, a daughter of Judy Crichton of New York and Chilmark, Mass., and Robert Collier Crichton of Cuttingsville, Vt., was married yesterday to David Allen Emil, a son of Arthur D. Emil of New York and the late Jane Allen Emil. Justice of the Peace Elizabeth Ann Bryant of Chilmark performed the ceremony at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown, Mass.

title: Motivating New Yorkers To Save Water
description: Mayor Koch called it a ''heavy lift,'' but to other New Yorkers it may come as more of a wrench. Despite opposition by the Rent Stabilization Association, the Mayor announced last week that he is going through with a 10-year plan to install a water meter in every residential building. What's more, it appeared that only the Water Board - appointed by the Mayor - would have to approve.

title: Berlioz's 'Romeo' Conducted by Muti and Dutoit
description: Shakespeare's plays have proven highly variable in their susceptibility to musical treatment. Although many composers have tried, for instance, no one yet has made an entirely persuasive operatic statement out of ''The Tempest.'' But ''Romeo and Juliet'' is another story. A short list of major composers who have successfully addressed themselves to this eternal love story would include Bellini, Gounod ( whose version is currently in the Metropolitan Opera's repertory), Tchaikovksy (a tone poem), Prokofiev (a ballet) and, not least, Berlioz.

title: Selecting a Cruise Ship That Meets Health Standards
description: When is a cruise liner sanitary enough to pose no risk to passenger health? What must be done to make sure it remains that way? And how much does the public need to know about all this - or have a right to know - in selecting a cruise?

title: ALTERNATIVES PROPOSED FOR WASTE DISPOSAL
description: I cannot relate to the despair of Richard T. Dewling, Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, over the public's unwillingness to ''trust me, believe me'' on the siting of hazardous-waste and garbage incinerators. He cites a ''tenth of a quadrillion of TCE,'' which doesn't sound very threatening.

title: What's New in Telephone Service
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS companies, wrestling for market share in a hotly competitive industry, are trying to distinguish themselves with scores of new services. And they are getting a good reception from corporate and private clients alike. The consumers are seeking phone systems at home that are as sophisticated as the ones they have at their offices, while the business executives are looking for ways to pare clerical staffs and cut phone bills. ''Companies are more and more aware of how much they spend on telecommunications,'' said Robert B. Bertman, marketing manager of network products at the Rolm Corporation.

title: Roundtable: Experts Voice Optimism on the Market
description: In the last four and a half years Wall Street has enjoyed one of the strongest bull markets in postwar history, but the individual investor has been reluctant to get involved. Now, with the upheaval in tax laws and anxieties over the market's wide price swings, uncertainties are compounded. What is the market outlook, and what strategies should individuals follow? Jan M. Rosen and Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times staff asked three leading Wall Street professionals to discuss these questions. They are: Laszlo Birinyi Jr., vice president in charge of equity analysis for Salomon Brothers Inc.; John M. McCarthy, co-managing partner and chief investment officer for Lord Abbett & Company, which manages more than $9 billion in mutual fund and pension fund assets, and Gary N. Yalen, senior vice president of the Irving Trust Company. QUESTION: Let's start with a brief question directed to each one of you. Gary, what's the portfolio mix today of the personal trust accounts that your bank manages, in terms of stocks, bonds and cash?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Ballet Readied
description: The dance division at the State University of New York at Purchase is buzzing with activity these days as it prepares for the preholiday performance of ''Coppelia,'' its first three-act ballet.

title: Jury Chosen
description: A jury of four women and two men has been chosen in Mineola District Court for the trial of Dave DeBusschere, a former Knicks team executive and basketball star, on a charge of driving while intoxicated. The 46-year-old Garden City, L.I., resident was arrested in West Hempstead July 1 as he drove home late at night.

title: Sabotaging the Khmer Rouge
description: To the Editor:

title: PERU CRACKS DOWN AGAIN ON REBELS OF THE SHINING PATH
description: DURING his election campaign early last year, Peru's Social Democratic President, Alan Garcia, argued that the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla movement was the result of the Government's having neglected impoverished Indian communities for generations. Upon taking office, he therefore stepped up public investment in the Andean sierras, formed a peace commission to negotiate with the rebels and even risked confrontation with the armed forces by punishing officers blamed for several massacres of alleged guerrilla sympathizers.

title: PEERS HELP FAMILIES COPE WITH DRUG PROBLEMS
description: ON THE day of his only daughter's 18th birthday, Richard walked through the door of his central Jersey home to confront a harrowing and unforgettble scene:

title: Joy Over Boesky's Woes
description: In the wake of last Friday's announced $100 million insider-trading settlement between arbitrager Ivan Boesky (pictured) and the Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall Street found reason for optimism.

title: HAS SCANDAL DERAILED KOCH'S AGENDA?
description: GOVERNING any large city in the United States may be ''an exercise in perpetual crisis,'' as Felix G. Rohatyn, head of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, puts it. But only New York's Mayor Koch, beleaguered by municipal corruption scandals since the year began, has faced all these crises and problems in recent weeks:

title: SCHOOL'S FATE DEBATED
description: CITING the need to preserve parkland and provide space for local organizations in Huntington Town, a community group is pressuring Harborfields School District officials to let voters decide on the future of the former Little Plains Elementary School.

title: Winter Wedding For Ms. Wickser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Dikeman Chapin Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Chapin's daughter Alexandra Wickser to John H. Ballantine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ballantine Jr. of Brewster, N.Y. A February wedding is planned. The future bride, a daughter also of the late Robert Livingston Wickser of New York, is a vice president of Howard J. Rubenstein Associates Inc., a public relations agency in New York.

title: The Non-Savers
description: To the Editor:

title: LOBSTER-TRAP WAR OFF BOSTON HARBOR
description: Nature, technology and a hard economy conspire at this time of year to raise tensions between the lobstermen who comb the ocean bottom and the fishermen who drag the seas for codfish and flounder.

title: Fullback Leads Bergen Catholic
description: Tom Kearney set a school record for rushing yardage in a single season yesterday when he led Bergen Catholic to a 24-8 victory over Teaneck in Oradell.

title: TO FIGHT DRUG USE, FIND THE SOURCE
description: IN 1985, more than 10,000 hospital emergency-room visits were related to cocaine and this year the number is expected to be considerably higher. While the demise of only a few famous people is brought to the public's attention, the annual number of deaths linked to drugs competes with that from AIDS.

title: Buying Silver and Stones in the Southwest
description: Shopping for Indian jewelry is as much a part of experiencing the American Southwest as driving into the burning stillness of the desert or sampling fry bread and blue cornmeal tortillas. Few jewelry fanciers can resist the myriad arrays of sterling silver rings, bracelets, necklaces, earrings, concho belts, buckles and watchbands studded with turquoise, coral, ivory or shells. The best examples are hand-crafted and show not only skill and painstaking effort, but also something of the artist's soul.

title: HELP OF COURTS SOUGHT FOR LEARNING DISABLED
description: The world of the learning-disabled child - clouded by frustration and failure in school - often descends into an orbit of crime, courtrooms and prison, according to law-enforcement studies. Society's efforts to help usually stop at the schoolyard gate.

title: THE DEAF ARE DIVIDED ON THE FILM ''LESSER GOD''
description: ''CHILDREN OF A LESSER GOD'' is a film based on Mark Medoff's 1980 Tony-award winning play about deafness. The deaf have some things to say about it.

title: THE PRIME OF LIFE
description: THE GREAT AMERICAN MAGAZINE An Inside History of Life. By Loudon Wainwright. Illustrated. 443 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. LIFE The First Fifty Years 1936-1986. Illustrated. 319 pp. Boston: Little Brown & Company. $50.

title: Barbara Serating to Wed
description: The engagement of Barbara Lynn Serating, a legal assistant at the New York law firm of Becker Ross Stone DeStefano & Klein, to Theodore R. Shiffman, a partner in the firm, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Serating of Little Neck, Queens, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Shiffman of Flushing, Queens. His marriage ended in divorce.

title: After 2d Day of Deliberation, No Verdict by Mafia Trial Jury
description: A jury ended its second day of deliberations without a verdict yesterday in the 10-week-old Mafia commission trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Singing The Praises of 'Low Tech'
description: THE annual fall Comdex (Computer Dealers Exposition), held last week in Las Vegas, Nev., is probably still the largest and most influential of the personal computer trade shows. But unlike the exhibitions of previous years, where new products, real and envisioned, provided a steady stream of newsworthy topics, this one kept the hundreds of journalists in attendance tripping over the same two stories, one about the 386's, the other about desktop publishing.

title: Reagan Signs Bill To Help Exports Of Medicines
description: After weeks of deep division in the Administration and heavy lobbying by drug manufacturers, physicians and groups representing children and the elderly - and with what he called mixed feelings - President Reagan last week signed a comprehensive health bill designed to promote exports of prescription drugs and to compensate children injured by vaccines.

title: John Jay Wins To Stay Unbeaten
description: When J.F.K. and John Jay met yesterday, it was almost as if the scene had been scripted as the dramatic finale in a screenwriter's vision. John Jay, a public school, and J.F.K., a Catholic school, are rivals sharing the same turf in upper Westchester.

title: Jennifer Feldman To Become Bride
description: Judge and Mrs. Martin Leach Cross Feldman of New Orleans have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Pulitzer Feldman, to Steven Paul Lund, a son of Virginia Lund Callaway of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Paul Martin Lund. An April wedding is planned.

title: NEW HAVEN WEIGHS LIMITS ON RADIOS
description: Joseph Crisco was in church when he decided to propose an ordinance limiting the playing of radios in public here.

title: Honolulu
description: To the Editor: I can see why most people think it is so expensive to go to Hawaii. There are many hotels and places to eat much less expensive than those listed in the article in the Travel section of Aug. 3.

title: 'THREE CHEERS FOR GOOD MARKS': WRITERS ON THEIR PRIZES
description: Tomorrow night at a Waldorf-Astoria gala, the American Book Awards will be presented for the best book of the year in two categories, fiction and nonfiction. The authors, chosen by writers and critics, will be called on to say a few words as they join a distinguished company of winners of National Book Awards, which were founded in 1950 and succeeded by the American Book Awards in 1980. (Next year the name will revert to the National Book Awards.) In these excerpts from past acceptance speeches, some major writers offer more than their thanks. WILLIAM FAULKNER, 1955 For ''A Fable,'' Fiction.

title: The Non-Savers
description: To the Editor: The parents of the baby-boomers, the last generation to save, are now in peril of losing their jobs as companies cut back, merge, or disappear. The 60's generation was not into saving; they were not even into working.

title: Explosion Kills a Man Opening His Car Trunk
description: A Brooklyn man was killed early yesterday by an explosion of undetermined cause as he opened the trunk of his car.

title: Janet duPont Wed to William Hoglund
description: Janet Attwood duPont, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Attwood of New Canaan, Conn., and Block Island, R.I., was married yesterday to William Stewart Hoglund, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stewart L. Hoglund of Las Vegas, Nev., and Glacier Park, Mont. The Rev. Dr. Russell J. Davis, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Riverside Church.

title: ART-HUNGRY PUBLIC CROWDING MUSEUMS
description: MOST of Connecticut's art museums are enjoying a boom year, drawing both large crowds to their ''blockbuster'' exhibits, and increasing numbers of visitors to their permanent collections.

title: Retirement To Require Rethinking
description: IF you are one of the millions of Americans setting aside money for your retirement, there is a good chance that the new tax law will make you rethink your strategy.

title: COUPLE IN HELICOPTER ESCAPE ARE ARRESTED AT SHOPPING MALL IN WEST
description: A man who hijacked a helicopter 10 days ago and flew to a Federal prison where he picked up a female inmate was captured today along with the woman, Federal officials said.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS: HOW BIG A CUT?
description: ABOVE THE CLOUD of controversy that surrounded the ''presummit'' meeting in Iceland last month between President Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, one shared vision seemed to float clear: a world freed from the fear of nuclear war. It is the vision behind the Strategic Defense Initiative that Mr. Reagan has pushed so hard. It is also the hope underlying Mr. Gorbachev's proposal last January for phased elimination of the world's nuclear arsenals by the year 2000.

title: ONCE, HE WAS CHIC
description: REEL POWER The Struggle for Influence and Success in the New Hollywood. By Mark Litwak. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: U.S. STUDY INDICATES CHILD SUPPORT IS LAGGING
description: The majority of divorced, separated and single mothers face a future rearing children with no financial help from the fathers, new Census Bureau statistics indicate.

title: CAN DIRECTORS BE JUDGES?
description: A DECADE ago, when company officials were sued by shareholders, they had two choices: they could settle the complaint out of court or brace themselves for litigation. Now, corporations are increasingly using a third option - special litigation committees, usually composed of outside directors, who weigh the merits of the complaint and recommend to the court whether to dismiss the suit or follow it up.

title: '66 Irish Huddle Again
description: ''It was some season,'' said Nick Eddy as he and 65 other members of the undefeated 1966 Notre Dame football team gathered for a weekend reunion.

title: ONCE UPON A TIME, THERE WERE MONSTERS
description: MY MOTHER'S SABBATH DAYS A Memoir. By Chaim Grade. Translated by Channa Kleinerman Goldstein and Inna Hecker Grade. 416 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOOP'S PROGRESS. By Chuck Rosenthal. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) In this, the year of the immigrant, Chuck Rosenthal offers a decidedly unromantic version of the American melting pot.

title: DINNER IN THE CRYPT
description: THE INJURED PARTY By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. 309 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: Made in America, Managed By Japan
description: REPEATEDLY in recent years, American executives have stood by and watched, sheepishly, one would hope, as Japanese companies took their failing plants and unproductive and uncooperative workers and turned them into rousing successes. In these increasingly common examples of what I call the ''Japanese paradox,'' all the excuses that American executives trot out to explain their failures - the ''overvalued dollar,'' high labor costs, restrictive union work rules, government regulation - are irrelevant.

title: Books From The Times
description: ARCHITECTURE, ANYONE? By Ada Louise Huxtable. (Random House, $27.50.) In 1982, after serving as architecture critic of The New York Times for many years, Ada Louise Huxtable, then a member of the editorial board, was appointed a MacArthur Fellow.

title: COUNTY AWAITS BOND ACT'S BENEFITS
description: OFFICIALS, environmentalists and preservationists in the county are elated over passage of the $1.45 billion environmental bond act, which voters approved by a wide margin in the election earlier this month.

title: POSTINGS: Condos Plus in Poughkeepsie; On Vassar's Land
description: Andrew Jackson Downing, the 19th-century landscape artist who designed the grounds of the White House and the Capitol, also landscaped a lesser-known property - about half of a 44-acre estate in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., once owned by Matthew Vassar, the college's founder and eponym.

title: Susan Carleton Clancy Wed to R. W. Mann Jr.
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York yesterday Susan Carleton Clancy, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Clancy of New York, was married to Robert Wellesley Mann Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mann of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. Stephen Gregory performed the ceremony.

title: HAITI UNIONIZING PROMPTS DISMISSALS
description: Hundreds of Haitian factory workers have been dismissed from their jobs in an attempt to crush fledgling labor unions that have been trying to organize since the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship nine months ago.

title: The Tortuous Route to Renovation
description: RENOVATION is is a dirty word in cooperatives and condominiums. Boards of directors, management companies, neighbors and, of course, the apartment renovators themselves all loathe the noise, the dirt and the sheetrock in the hallway. Not to mention the expense.

title: 'THE MANKIEWICZ STORY,' AT COLUMBIA
description: Defiant as ever, Joseph L. Mankiewicz returned to Columbia University's Hamilton Hall, where he studied 60 years ago.

title: Comings and Goings
description: COACHES Jean Perron of Montreal, Michel Bergeron of Quebec and Bob Johnson of Calgary will combine to coach the National Hockey Legaue All-Stars against the Soviet national team in February. Although the two games will be played under N.H.L. rules, it has not yet been decided whether 5-minute overtime or Stanley Cup sudden-death overtime will be used.

title: LAMENT FOR THE IMPENDING DEATH OF A QUIET FIELD
description: THIS is an epitaph to a field. I realize that in this day and age, a mere field does not carry all that much weight. In fact, more often than not, it is looked upon as a waste of space. Every year, there are fewer and fewer of them. And very soon, a field that I came to know will be among the memories.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
'WHISTLE-BLOWER' LAW IS INTRUSIVE
description: THE state's Conscientious Employee Protection Act represents an unprecedented and unwarranted intrusion into the workplace. Unprecedented because it goes far beyond the ''whistle-blower statutes'' in effect in other states, and unwarranted because employees are amply protected under existing law.

title: The Utilitarian Tripod, Little Changed by Time
description: IN the nearly 150 years that photography has existed, photographic equipment has undergone enormous changes. Cameras, originally wooden boxes of considerable bulk, are now sleek, battery-operated marvels of metal and plastic. Lenses have gone from simple and slow to speedy and compact. Flexible film has replaced glass plates.

title: EVEN PRINCIPALS HAVE NEED OF A KINDLY SHOULDER TO LEAN ON
description: EVERYONE need someone to talk to, even school principals - or especially school principals, considering their demanding role in the school and community. That is the premise of a movement under way in the county and elsewhere to bring school principals and other administrators together, both formally and informally, for mutual inspiration and support.

title: From Farmer To Collegian
description: FARMERS forced to give up their livelihoods because of the ailing farm economy were invited to enroll at a Kansas college tuition-free for a year to pursue new careers.

title: CAN SALOMON BROTHERS LEARN TO LOVE JUNK BONDS?
description: THIS is bonus season at Salomon Brothers, when department heads at Wall Street's largest investment bank gather behind closed doors to judge their staffs and parcel out millions of dollars in year-end checks.

title: PLANNING AHEAD FOR FRAGRANT FLOWERS
description: The end of autumn's colorful display and a lawn littered with fallen leaves signals many things to gardeners.

title: PIGEON FANCIERS PREPARE THEIR CHARGES YEARLONG FOR RACES
description: HE calls them his ''race horses of the air,'' balls of feathers eighing less than a pound each and capable of flying 600 miles nonstop in 12 hours.

title: Boat-Slip Owners Buoyed by Soaring Resale Prices
description: WHEN David and Ruth Musher want to get away from their frenetic social lives and careers on the East Side of Manhattan, they drive up to City Island in the Bronx and spend a few hours away from ringing telephones aboard their 26-foot sailboat, the Voyager.

title:
EDUCATION WATCH;
ON CATHOLIC COLLEGE BOARDS, 'LAY PEOPLE, THANK GOD'
description: THE University of Notre Dame named a new president last week for the first time in 35 years. At the end of the school year, the Rev.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: REMEMBRANCE OF GAMES PAST: On Tour With the Tennis Grand Masters. By John Sharnik. (Macmillan, $19.95.) John Sharnik, an executive at CBS Sports, offers a vision of tennis wrapped in the same haze of boyish youth as baseball is for many American men.

title: Denise Collier Is Wed
description: Denise Kathleen Collier, a vice president of Solters Roskin Friedman Inc., a public-relations firm in New York, was married yesterday to Raymond Martin Vorce 3d, the director of external reporting in the controller's office of the Singer Company in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Robert L. Ficks 3d officiated at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, Conn. Mrs. Vorce is a daughter of Virginia Collier and the late William J. Collier of Cleveland. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vorce Jr. of Boxborough, Mass.

title: 100TH CONGRESS IS EXPECTED TO PUT ENVIRONMENT AT TOP OF PRIORITIES
description: The 100th Congress, with a leavening of conservation-minded freshmen in the Senate's new Democratic majority, is expected to aggressively pursue a broad environmental agenda.

title: OPERA: JOAN SUTHERLAND IN 'PURITANI'
description: THIS is the kind of night it was: when Joan Sutherland made her first entrance in ''I Puritani,'' the Metropolitan Opera House resounded with such a prolonged stomping, screaming ovation that the performance came to a dead halt. La Stupenda, as opera history will know her, finally gave up, left the stage and returned to start over, allowed at last by her happy fans to take on the persona of Bellini's famously unstable heroine, the on-again, off-again madwoman Elvira.

title: Penn Thwarts Harvard Rally
description: Having won only two of eight games while enduring its first losing season since 1979, Harvard did not loom as a formidable threat to unbeaten Pennsylvania today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE KILLEEN. By Mary Leland. (Atheneum, $12.95.) In this stirring first novel, the Irish writer Mary Leland explores the legacy of hate that polarizes her nation.

title: Car and School Bus Collide
description: A car and a school bus carrying members of a high school band collided today, killing the driver of the car and injuring 38 band members.

title: Maryland to Rebuild Clipper
description: Maryland will contribute $1 million to help build a replacement for the Pride of Baltimore, a clipper ship that sank in a storm last summer, killing four crewmembers, Gov. Harry Hughes said Wednesday. He said Baltimore would contribute $500,000 for construction of a replacement vessel and the Pride's board of directors would raise another $3 million to cover the vessel's operating costs.

title: A Latecomer
description: The United States Postal Service released the oft-delayed 5.5-cent Star Route Truck issue on Nov. 1 in Fort Worth, Tex.

title: At The Helm, With Engine Trouble
description: Sunday. I'm standing at the wheel of a 37-foot cutter tied to a dock at the tip of St. Vincent, its bow pointed toward the Grenadines, on a bareboat charter - which means that my friends and I will sail the boat ourselves - but it's not without trepidation that I stand here. The trouble is that I'm not a big-boat sailor. This relatively small cruiser, with its engine and berths, weighs 10 times as much as the sailboat I race on Long Island Sound all summer, which has no power except the wind.

title: BILL ON JAILING JUVENILES IS ASSAILED
description: JUVENILE-JUSTICE workers say that a bill pending in the New Jersey Assembly that would let judges sentence juvenile offenders to adult jails for terms up to 18 months reflects a pervasive ''get tough'' tone established by the Reagan Administration.

title: Laying Out the Facts About American Music
description: To anyone who writes for a living, a library of reference books acts as a life-support system.

title: A Directive on 'Sensitive' Data
description: The guardians of Government data face a difficult task. If they classify too much information, counterintelligence experts say, no one will take the designation seriously.

title: A Near Miss Aloft Stirs New Alarm
description: A near miss in clear skies north of Atlanta last week has renewed questions about safety in the air and communications with the ground. In the unusual incident, a stuck cockpit microphone blocked a radio frequency and prevented an air traffic controller from warning two Boeing 727 jetliners that they were on a collision course.

title: THE TEARS AND TRAGEDY OF AIDS
description: ''THE simple fact is that we know very little about acquired immune deficiency syndrome,'' a chorus of doctors tells the questioning victim in ''As Is,'' William Hoffman's powerful drama currently being performed by the Arena Players Repertory Company.

title: Holly Anne Penwell Weds
description: Holly Anne Penwell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delos Penwell of Worthington, Ohio, was married yesterday to Mark Edwards Hess, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Hess of State College, Pa. The Rev. Riley Jensen performed the ceremony at the Central Presybterian Church in Summit, N.J. Mrs. Hess is a sales manager for the Lifetime division of Hearst/ABC-Viacom Entertainment Services in New York. Mr. Hess is a general manager for Kingston (N.Y.) Cablevision, a division of Telecommunications Inc.

title: Some Concern For Students
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CONTRIBUTIONS KEEP THE CONCERTS FLOWING
description: TICKET prices continue to rise in most concert quarters, but as the Pleasantville Chamber Music Society readies its 10th season, the admission charge remains the same: free.

title: WELFARE STUDY REAGAN SOUGHT SKIRTS BIG SHIFT
description: A White House policy team, under a mandate from President Reagan to devise ''real and lasting'' improvements in the nation's welfare system, has stopped short of recommending fundamental changes, according to many people familiar with the proposals.

title: In Politics by TV, Money Does All the Talking; Unanswered Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: West Islip Shuts out Melville
description: The West Islip Lions (8-0) rolled over Ward Melville, 37-0, in the first round of Suffolk County playoffs. The victory extends their winning streak to 18 games. Joe Prevosto, a running back, paced the Lion offense, running for 205 yards on 14 carries. Steve Dorn, the linebacker, had 11 tackles, two sacks and an interception.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: 37-1 Shot Takes International
description: Lieutenant's Lark, a 37-to-1 shot who finished ninth in the Breeders' Cup Mile two weeks ago, was in front every step of the way and led an all-American finish of the $600,000 Washington D.C. International today at Laurel Race Course.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes: Truffaut's 'Girls'
description: Moiseyev Dance Company: A Gala Evening V.I.E.W. Video 70 minutes. $59.95.

title: AGENCY ACTS TO INCLUDE LOVERS IN ETHICS RULES
description: A New York City agency is adopting new conflict-of-interest rules to prevent officials from recommending that city contracts be awarded to their lovers and other unrelated members of their households.

title: JAZZ AMATERUS JOIN FOR ''HAPPY MUSIC''
description: BILL GRAY of Darien could have lived in the New Orleans of the 1920's when all a jazz musician needed was an instrument and a good ear.

title: Now Dallas Is Having Second Thoughts
description: Many parents here map out their sons' football careers early, postponing first grade a year so the boys will be bigger and stronger. Churchgoers grumble at preachers if Sunday services run past opening kickoffs of Dallas Cowboy games.

title: DATA BANK: November 16, 1986
description: THE ECONOMY Gross National Product III Q'86 II Q'86 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $3,683.3 $3661.4 $3,603.8 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate,1982 dollars, in percent 2.4 4.1 Corporate After-Tax Profits II Q'86 I Q'86 Year Ago In billions, annual rate $138.0 $126.7 Industrial Production Index Oct. Year Percent change, monthly and year to year#0.0#0.1#1.3 ousing StartsSept.AugustYear Ago Thousands of units, annual rate#1,680#1,818#1,653 ew Orders for Durable GoodsSept.AugustYear Ago By manufacturers, in billions$108.98$103.84$106.64

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CERTAIN KINDS OF LOVING. By Nancy Zaroulis. (Doubleday, $15.95.) Nancy Zaroulis' fourth novel, a domestic drama about the erratic courtship of a sweet 32-year-old divorced woman with four children and a moody 35-year-old Vietnam veteran, is as sugary as a hot fudge sundae.

title: A TIME BOMB IS TICKING IN SOUTH KOREA
description: LATE LAST MONTH, FOLLOWING one of the year's most violent clashes in Seoul between protesters and the police, more than 1,000 university students were arrested for protesting against their country's military dictatorship and what they see as American connivance. Such incidents have been common in South Korea, but there was a startling occurrence in May. Before a university crowd of 3,000 who had gathered to hear a speech by a prominent critic of the Government, a student shouted denunciations of domestic dictatorship and ''American imperialism,'' set himself on fire and jumped from the fourth-floor balcony of a campus building. He died four hours later. Suicide as a form of political protest would have been unimaginable a few years ago, but so far this year, there have been six such incidents, the latest only 10 days ago.

title: In Politics by TV, Money Does All the Talking; The Voter Anatomized
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebecca Susan Hafitz To Wed Anthony Hull
description: Dr. and Mrs. Julius J. Hafitz of Lambertville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rebecca Susan Hafitz to Anthony Edward Hull, the son of Edith Silberstein of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Edward M. Hull of New York.

title: Some Concern For Students
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rink Resurrected; Trump Triumphant
description: Frederick Law Olmsted would probably not have approved of the Wollman Memorial Rink, intruding as it does on the naturalistic landscape he designed, but ice-skaters have always liked it, and last week, thanks to Donald Trump, the developer, they were again gliding and gamboling in the southeast corner of Central Park.

title: ERASING THE PAST: EUROPE'S AMNESIA ABOUT THE HOLOCAUST
description: MORE THAN 40 YEARS have passed since the end of World War II. Yet despite a widespread desire to suppress the nightmarish memories of the war and the Holocaust that accompanied it, shadowy events from that past continue to haunt Europeans.

title: Cashing In On Changes In Currencies
description: LAST March, Bret J. Davis, 31 years old, decided to change his investment strategy. Mr. Davis, a director of a medical laboratory in Brooklyn, who had previously dabbled in I.B.M. and some other blue-chip stocks, as well as a domestic mutual fund, moved everything to the Fidelity Overseas Fund, a mutual fund that currently is heavily invested in Japanese securities.

title: A CHARACTER ACTOR REACHES CULT STATUS
description: NOW IS THE SEA-son of Harry Dean Stanton's content.

title: Vikings Warm to Burns, and Success Follows Quickly
description: WITH a pinch of tobacco wedged under his lip, his feet propped on a table and a wide smile creasing his face, Tommy Kramer looked as if all was right with the world. Perhaps it was. Outside the Minnesota Vikings' training facilities here, a blustery wind made 9 degrees feel like minus 35, according to the weather bureau's computations.

title: 9 Steelers Face Fines
description: DAVE EDWARDS of the Pittsburgh Steelers, a safety nicknamed Rambo, has been fined $1,500 by the National Football League for making a late hit during a game with the Cincinnati Bengals Oct. 26 that the Steelers won, 30-9. Eight of Edwards's teammates were fined a total of $3,200 and an undetermined number of Bengals also drew fines for what happened after Edwards hit Tim McGee, a wide receiver, with a forearm on a pass play near the end of the game.

title: Gold Making A Comeback
description: GOLD fever is again infecting many investors, despite or perhaps because of the extraordinary price volatility of all precious metals in recent years. This year, for example, gold has ranged from a low of $295 an ounce to a high of $445. Since 1975, when Americans were once again permitted to own and trade in bullion, gold has ranged from a low of $195 in August 1976 to a record $850 in January 1980.

title: DESIGN JAM STALLS EXPRESSWAY WORK
description: The contractor rebuilding a key portion of the decaying Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, the site of some of the city's most excruciating traffic delays, says it has stopped almost all construction because of a dispute over engineering designs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about the Columbia University football team last Sunday incorrectly stated the won-lost record the current senior class had in six games as freshmen. The 1983 freshman team won two games and lost four.

title: Stock Alerts
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: KRONOS QUARTET
description: THE Next Wave Festival and the Kronos Quartet would seem to be made for each other, so it was a little surprising that Friday night's program at the Lepercq Space of the Brooklyn Academy of Music constituted the quartet's Next Wave debut. But the Kronos players made up for their late arrival on this particular scene with a flash.

title: PANEL IS TOLD OF 'QUIET CRISIS'
description: ADDRESSING a sparse audience on a recent rainy day here, the Assistant Commissioner for Natural Resources of the state's Department of Environmental Protection described to a policy panel the ''quiet crisis'' of the state parks.

title: OUTDOORS BASICS HELP SOME TROUBLED YOUTHS
description: SAILING down a river, hiking up a mountain and milking a cow are some of the ways a Westport therapist helps troubled children of the wealthy deal with their problems.

title: Q AND A
description: Botswana Question:My husband and I plan to visit Botswana. What is the least expensive way to fly there, how long will it take and whom do we contact to find out about safaris, hotels and visas? - M. B. P., Rochester, Mich. Answer:There are a number of ways of flying to Botswana in south-central Africa but there is no one route from the United States that is clearly cheaper than another. An advance-purchase fare via Europe to Harare in Zimbabwe (from which a local airline is taken to Maun in Botswana) or by way of Johannesburg is the best rate that can be obtained, and, from New York, will cost around $2,000, round trip.

title: 100 Ill After Dining At Hall in Cleveland
description: More than a 100 people who attended a banquet at the Cleveland Convention Center fell ill this evening, apparently from food poisoning, and were taken to hospitals, the authorities said.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Ideology always takes second place to money.'' Melvin A. Conant, oil consultant, on plea by Chevron for Government oil-price supports.

title: MUSIC: KIRI TE KANAWA IN CONCERT
description: THE musicians of the New York Philharmonic were playing for themselves on Wednesday night. This Avery Fisher Hall event was to benefit the orchestra's pension fund, and not only did its wind soloists trot out their creamiest displays of virtuosity, there was also an unusual buoyancy to the string ensemble and a delicacy of touch and togetherness - all stage-managed with great care by the Philharmonic's music director, Zubin Mehta.

title: The Opening to Iran: Part Burden, Part Responsibility
description: As President Reagan now describes his overture toward Iran, it is an optimistic bet on Iran's moderation.

title: Big Winner on a Small Scale
description: AYEAR ago Jim Butterfield, the Ithaca College coach, needed a quarterback to back up the senior starter, Steve Kass, who was having problems with a kidney ailment. Butterfield turned to inexperienced Mike Middaugh, who did so well that he was elected co-captain for this year's team.

title: Enough Chances For Red Sox
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Show of Fury Over Whaling
description: A group opposed to whaling took several million dollars worth of vengeance in Iceland last week, sinking two ships and wrecking a whale-oil processing plant.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: E. MUNCH AT DARTMOUTH ''Encounter in Space: Double Images in the Graphic Art of Edvard Munch,'' a traveling show of drawings, woodcuts, etchings and lithographs, is currently in residence at the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H.

title: Headliners; Color in Classics
description: It wasn't enough for John Huston that the bird stayed black. Mr. Huston appeared before reporters last week to denounce the Turner Entertainment Company for broadcasting a ''colorized'' version of one of his best-known films, ''The Maltese Falcon.''

title: POSTINGS: 42 Into 9 for TriBeCa; CONDOS WITH 'SUPPORT
description: ''Originally, they housed butter, eggs and the extensive refrigeration systems needed to preserve them. But by mid-spring, nine brick buildings in TriBeCa will house film-makers, investment bankers, lawyers and other professionals, not to mention their support systems - saunas, steam baths, tanning rooms and exercise equipment.

title: Sailing Turning Smoother for New Zealand
description: A new map has begun to surface in obscure places around town. It shows the waterfront of Auckland, New Zealand, its offshore islands, and the open sea.

title: Masterworks of Van Gogh From His Final Days
description: There is no way for ''Van Gogh in Saint-Remy and Auvers'' to be anything but a great success when it opens to the public at the Metropolitan Museum Nov. 25 after a series of previews for members and others this week. There never was within living memory a van Gogh exhibition that did not spread happiness and draw an overflow crowd. An exhibition devoted entirely to the early, penumbrous, poverty-ridden years in Holland might perhaps deter a few visitors. But when we come to the later southern years all that a museum has to do is to borrow some pictures, put them on the wall, hang out the shingle and count the gate. A groundbreaking show like this one is an altogether more challenging undertaking, and one that in this case would seem to be assured of a triumphant success.

title: OPPOSITION LEADER IN SINGAPORE JAILED AND LOSES HIS SEAT
description: The leader of Singapore's parliamentary opposition has been sentenced to a month in prison and stripped of his seat in the country's legislature.

title: France to Restrict Immigrant Rights
description: The rights of immigrants in France are under attack at a time of double-digit unemployment and exploitation by far-right politicians of ill will toward Arabs and black Africans. Last week, the conservative Government decided that the French-born children of immigrants would no longer become citizens automatically when they grow up.

title: Not-So-New Concept
description: There's nothing new under the sun. History repeats itself. Plus ca change, say the French.

title:
DINING OUT;
PASTA IN A FRIENDLY ATMOSPHERE
description: TUCKED away in a quiet corner off the Bronx River Parkway, Pagliaccio draws a friendly clientele. On crowded evenings the dining room assumes the ambience of a club. The bar and lounge areas are jollier still. One feels that everyone knows everyone else here - there's kissing and waving and hand-shaking galore - and if they don't, they will before the evening's out.

title: U.S. WILL RESUME INSPECTIONS OF CRUISE SHIPS
description: Half a year after dropping regular sanitary inspections of cruise ships, a Federal health agency has announced that the inspections will resume Jan. 1.

title: WHITMAN SCHOLARS TO MEET IN CAMDEN
description: THE universality of Walt Whitman's works, which, scholars say, has become highly accentuated in the last decade, will be the topic Friday when professors from the Soviet Union, China and Austria join five of their American colleagues in a daylong conference at Rutgers-Camden.

title: Leslie Embs Has Wedding
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan yesterday, Leslie Doreen Embs, a daughter of Sallie W. Embs and Lowell D. Embs, both of San Antonio, was married to Charles Cozad Bradford 3d, a son of Mrs. Joseph D. Harnett of Pepper Pike, Ohio; North Palm Beach, Fla., and Southampton, Bermuda, and Mr. Bradford Jr. of Naples, Fla., and Pointe au Baril, Ontario. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FORTY ACRES AND A GOAT: A Memoir. By Will D. Campbell. (Peachtree Publishers, $14.95.) The author of the novel ''Brother to a Dragonfly'' here presents his memoirs, most of which center on his work in the civil rights movement.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Rehnquist Alters Restrictive Deed Chief Justice William H. Renquist and his wife, Natalie, have removed a clause in the deed to their summer house in Greensboro, Vt., barring its lease or sale to ''any member of the Hebrew race,'' the Greensboro town clerk's office said Thursday.

title: A YEAR LATER, BELFAST MARKS ACCORD WITH FURY...
description: This day was a mere anniversary amid all the centuries of lethal Irish conflict, but it was marked in two starkly different ways.

title: Icahn and Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE PUSHES GAS-TAX RISE TO REPLENISH ROAD FUND
description: THE Kean administration has been trying to enlist the support of county officials behind a plan to raise the tax on gasoline by 5 cents a gallon. The purpose is to bolster the Transportation Trust Fund, which is expected to run out of money a year earlier than planned.

title: Has the TV Family Grown Up Since 'Father Knows Best'?
description: Families, from the 1950's Andersons of ''Father Knows Best'' to today's Huxtables in ''The Cosby Show,'' have always been the home turf of situation comedies. But this fall season has found the family - often in unconventional configurations - moving into an unprecedented share of prime-time territory, thanks in large measure to the overwhelming success of ''The Cosby Show'' and its Thursday-night partner on NBC, ''Family Ties,'' currently television's No. 1 and 2 rated series. At least 10 new programs built around family life made their debut this autumn on the three networks, joining 12 returning situation comedies that also center on hearth and home.

title: Hopkins Stops Brunswick Streak
description: Hopkins (8-1) defeated Brunswick (7-1), 22-7, to capture the Fairchester League Championship and end Brunswick's winning streak at 31 games.

title: 'SHOW ME ONE PAGE IN ''ANNA KARENINA'' THAT CONTAINS AN IDEA'
description: Rotten reviews have happened to some of the best books and authors, and here are a few of them. In determining the best books and authors I let history have the final say. Each of these books has lasted for at least 25 years, and some have been respected for centuries. I have included not only periodical reviews but critical essays, diary entries, letters and reported conversation. I have quoted from original documents, when available, but often a review digest, a critical text edition or a biography was the source of the bad blurb. Ulysses By James Joyce, 1922 I finished Ulysses and think it is a misfire . . . The book is diffuse. It is brackish. It is pretentious. It is underbred, not only in the obvious but in the literary sense. A first rate writer, I mean, respects writing too much to be tricky. - Virginia Woolf, in her diary

title: A Private Library
description: LIBRARIES HAVE ALWAYS BEEN an integral part of Brooke Astor's life, whether the well-known New York philanthropist and writer reads in them or makes them the object of her considerable generosity, as she has with the New York Public Library. The handsome library in her Park Avenue apartment attests to her lifelong commitment to literacy and learning. The room is a Baedeker to Brooke Astor -filled with objects and books that reveal her past. Eclectic in its high style, it is a thoroughly comfortable room designed in the 19th-century tradition by the interior designer Albert Hadley. The room centers on the great built-in bookshelves, detailed in brass, which line the walls from floor to ceiling. They contain more than 3,000 volumes, many of them in their original, 19th-century Moroccan bindings.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
GOOD TEACHING: AN UNDEFINABLE ART
description: A MAJOR revision in teacher certification in Connecticut is now taking place. Significant and dramatic changes in the training and certification of teachers are occurring in teacher-training institutions and public school systems throughout the state and the nation.

title: In Print, on the Air, Sexual Practice Is Like a Fast-Food Menu
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Strategies From the Pros
description: STRIKING it rich in the stock market has never been easy.

title: PLINKING AWAY AT FEDERAL GUN CONTROL
description: IT is the first of its kind in nearly two decades, a mail-order catalog for ammunition. ''The Law Has Changed,'' proclaims the catalog, issued by a new discount outlet in Milwaukee called Worldwide Ammo Inc. ''As of November 15, you may buy ammo directly . . . without retail record-keeping.''

title: THATCHER REPORTS REAGAN AGREEMENT ON A-ARMS ISSUES
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher agreed on arms control ''priorities'' today that pointedly omitted any mention of the American proposal to the Soviet Union that would abolish all ballistic missiles in 10 years.

title: JAPANESE BUSINESSMAN IS KIDNAPPED NEAR MANILA
description: The branch director of a Japanese concern, one of the largest companies doing business in the Philippines, was kidnapped today by armed men outside a country club south of Manila, the police said.

title: FOCUS: Vail, Colo.; Strength at The Top of The Market
description: HOMES here are commanding more than $1 million, and buyers are bulldozing them to build bigger and better ones. Rundown commercial properties are going for $11.2 million, and a penthouse condominium without carpet, kitchen cabinets or plumbing and lighting fixtures sold for a record $519 a square foot.

title: Fidel Castro's Years As a Secret Communist
description: For those who supported the Cuban revolution in its early stage, the revelation made by Tad Szulc in his article ''Fidel Castro's Years as a Secret Communist'' (Oct. 19) will be a serious blow to their innocence.

title: 13-YEAR-OLD VOTE MAY OUST A MAYOR
description: Call it fate or simply bad luck, but the past has come back to haunt Mayor Paul M. Marcincin.

title: 5 Die in Plunge in the West
description: Five teen-agers driving through rough terrain plunged down a 20-foot embankment, landed upside down in five feet of water and drowned, the police said today. A fur trapper checking his traps made the discovery Friday in a rugged section of an industrial park sometimes used by off-road vehicles, Detective Sgt. Charles Harper said.

title: AMERICANS TRAIN AFGHAN GUERRILLAS AS MEDICS
description: Three years ago, Gay-LeClerc Brenner, a lawyer, and her husband, Robert, a private fire investigator, quit their jobs in Sacramento, Calif., to find something to do, as she put it, ''for the good of other people.''

title: Court Allows Ex-Soldier To Sue Over Injury
description: For the first time, a Federal appeals court has ruled that soldiers have the right to sue for injuries not connected to their military service.

title: Cartwirght Adds Late Spark
description: It was expected to be his most telling test of the season, an indication of just how much two years away from the game had taken from him. If Bill Cartwright was not yet capable of achieving the heights he'd attained before four stress fractures in his left foot sidelined him for two seasons, Moses Malone, the tireless rebounder, would certainly let him know.

title: LOVE OF WINE RIPENS INTO A BUSINESS
description: AMONG Connecticut's most successful wine merchants are Martin and Barrie Robbins-Pianka, a husband and wife team whose marketing activities emanate from their store, Spiritus Wines, on Main Street in Hartford.

title: INSIDE
description: Ozone 2 American scientists and business leaders are convinced that certain manmade chemicals deplete the atmosphere's ozone layer and threaten health. How should next month's world conference in Geneva tackle the problem? Business Forum.

title: The Perils of Raising Rich Kids
description: AFTER years of scrimping and hard work, you and your family are enjoying the fruits of your labors and have an income in the high six figures. Each of your three children can expect a comfortable inheritance. But now vexing questions arise about how to spend your wealth so it will enhance, rather than inhibit, their development.

title: Michigan Beaten on Last Play
description: Chip Lohmiller kicked a 30-yard field goal as time ran out today as Minnesota stunned Michigan, 20-17, in a Big Ten Conference game.

title: Wide Range Of Strategies Emerging
description: WITH the Tax Reform Act of 1986 now officially law, the race has begun by investors to adjust their financial affairs to the new rules of the game and take advantage of some year-end opportunities created by the transition from the old to the new system.

title: Picking Stocks Is Kid Stuff
description: SEVENTEEN-YEAR-OLD David Allee of Manhattan told his mother he was ''afraid to look'' at how his stocks were doing after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 141 points during one week in September. When David mustered the courage to check prices, they confirmed his prowess as a stock picker: None of his holdings had lost even a point, and one had actually risen. Still, he said, ''that drop really scared me,'' and he decided to take profits in Mattel, which he had held since he was 13.

title: Colleen D. Green Plans to Be Wed To F. C. Everett
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Edward Green of Amston, Conn., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Colleen Deborah Green, to Franklin Charles Everett, a son of Charlotte Sonja Everett of Arosa, Switzerland, and San Diego and the late William Greenough Everett. A May wedding is planned.

title: Nancy Ann Zarett To Marry a Doctor
description: Nancy Ann Zarett, an associate at the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and Dr. George William Niedt, a fellow in the division of dermatopathology at New York Hospital, plan to be married in February.

title: IRAQ DENOUNCES U.S. FOR SECRET SHIPMENTS OF WEAPONS TO IRAN
description: Iraq denounced President Reagan today for secretly supplying arms to Iran, its enemy in the Persian Gulf war.

title: A Political Killing In the Philippines Enrages the Left
description: The killing of a prominent leftist leader in the Philippines last week stirred fears of public disorders and of a military coup.

title: Chasing Double Digits
description: BOND funds have been the darlings of investors in the last few years, since interest rates have fallen and cut the return on certificates of deposit and money market funds.

title: Recent Sales
description: Dix Hills $350,000 495 Wolf Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 70-year-old Normandy; fireplace, sunporch, large deck, tile roof, 2 acres; taxes $3,800.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Guatemala in The Times Magazine last Sunday misstated the surname of a former President.

title: More Companies Feel Perelman's Bite
description: Ronald O. Perelman cut a wide swath through the business world. On one front, the chairman of Revlon offered $4.1 billion for Gillette, a move analysts say would combine complementary product lines if it goes through. On another front, Transworld said it would liquidate rather than be taken over by a group led by Mr. Perelman, which had acquired 15 percent of the food services and hotel company. But a member of Mr. Perelman's group received a separate option to buy Transworld's Hilton International hotels unit, a crown jewel. Mr. Perelman has been a busy man lately: Last year he led a fierce and successful battle for control of Pantry Pride, he recently sold his 5 percent stake in CPC when that food company resisted his overtures, and he has agreed to buy the Max Factor, Almay and Halston cosmetics lines from Playtex.

title: SUFFOLK COUNTY VOTES TO BAN STEEL-JAW LEG TRAPS
description: Steel-jaw leg traps used to catch animals would be banned in Suffolk County under a bill approved this week by the County Legislature.

title: AN ITALIAN FIXTURE IN EAST HILLS
description: LA PRIMAVERA in East Hills, at one time a highlight of the Long Island restaurant scene, has not aged gracefully.

title: TAIWAN URGED TO PERMIT OPPOSITION ROLE IN VOTING
description: A group monitoring human rights in Asia has urged the Taiwan Government to allow a newly formed opposition group, the Democratic Progressive Party, to take part in elections next month ''without restrictions, harassment or threats of future prosecution.''

title: 8 IN INDIANA PLAN TO ADMIT ELECTION FRAUD IN PLEA AGREEMENT
description: Eight Democrats will plead guilty to vote fraud charges as part of plea agreement filed Friday, the United States Attorney's office here said.

title: PAN MUSIC IS SWEET IN TRINIDAD
description: The local people call it the greatest show on earth. Carnival in Trinidad, celebrated the Monday and Tuesday before Ash Wednesday, is an appropriate prelude to Lent. For 48 hours the nation devotes itself to pageants, parties and dancing in the streets. Day and night thousands of costumed revelers bump and shake. And, all along, the harmonic hammerings of steel bands feed the frenzy.

title: Teams Play Coachless Tie
description: Something was missing today as a 21-yard field goal by David Treadwell on the final play of the game gave Clemson a 17-17 tie with Maryland, enabling the Tigers to clinch the Atlantic Coast Conference championship.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: SOLSTICE, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Berkley, $3.95.) Monica Jensen, a young, recently divorced teacher at a boys' boarding school in Pennsylvania, and Sheila Trask, a widowed artist who is somewhat older, develop a complicated friendship that will become a voyage of discovery for both. Joyce Carol Oates's ''disturbing and unsparing'' novel ''taps deeply into our experience,'' Rebecca Pepper Sinkler said in The Book Review in 1985. The author, ''never squeamish about looking into the dark places of the soul, has aimed a powerful beam into that shadowy chamber.'' Obelisk/Dutton has reissued Ms. Oates's novel CYBELE ($7.95), in which a restless and self-destructive insurance executive plunges into a series of degrading extramarital affairs. One reviewer in 1980 called it ''a devastating, unrelenting study.''

title: Simply Knowing That a Loved ONe Has Alzheimer's Can Help a Family
description: NATIONAL Alzheimer's Month is a time to alert the general and professional community to the critical importance of early diagnosis. Although small consolation to the many thousands of families struck by this insidious disease, knowing early can at least alleviate some of the excruciating emotional pain this illness causes.

title: Nuclear Plant Is Shut Down
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant was taken out of service today for the second time in nine days when workers discovered a faulty pump, a Con Ed spokesman said. But the spokesman, John McCann, said the problem at the Westchester County plant caused ''no leak, no release of radiation, and no danger to the public or plant personnel.''

title: THE DANCE: JUILLIARD ENSEMBLE
description: IT seems as if just about everybody is performing ''The Envelope'' by David Parsons these days. Both the Juilliard Dance Ensemble and the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel offered the dance this weekend, with Juilliard going first in a performance on Friday at the Juilliard Dance Theater that seems likely to be a standard-setter for the work.

title: Vacationers Look Beyond the Beach
description: A more active breed of vacationer is flocking to the Caribbean and the Bahamas these days. More and more of the islands' visitors are spending less time sunning on the beach and at least part of their stay either pursuing some pastime or learning one - scuba diving or tennis, perhaps, or hiking forest trails. And those going to the islands will find that service to a number of them is being increased by both American and Eastern Airlines.

title: Eyewitnesses in America
description: I WAS BORN NEAR LVOV, IN RUSSIA. I WAS the oldest, almost 12 in 1941. My twin brothers were 6. My father owned a tavern. When the Germans came in June 1941, mobs broke down our door. My great-aunt was killed and my mother was beaten up. The cats were stabbed, with their insides hanging out. I went back to the house to get shoes for my brothers and a German was stuffing one of our goblets into a valise.''

title: Two Zeroes on Display
description: AFTER 10 weeks of a football season, anything adding up to zero is either very good or very bad. One zero represents all the victories the Indianapolis Colts have accomplished this year - as if some giant Chesapeake Bay crab had vengefully wrapped his pincers around the franchise that fled Baltimore in the middle of the night in 1984.

title: Recent Sales
description: Belvedere $109,000 Foul Rift Road 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old split-level; patio, fireplace, family room, full basement; taxes $1,240. Edgewater $194,900 14 River Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 3-year-old town-house condominium; garage, cathedral ceilings, monthly charges; taxes $1,926.

title: PROPOSAL FOR OFFICES AND MALLS NEAR RETIREMENT HOME IS OPPOSED
