description: BROOKHAVEN Town officials are in the middle of what may become the second major dispute with real-estate developers this year.

title: The Issue: Reagan's Judgment
description: It's easy to understand the uproar in Washington over President Reagan's swapping spree in Iran, but it's hard to understand why anybody here is surprised. He has been playing these covert games for almost six years; the only difference now is that he's getting caught.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
RAMSEY
description: EACH day in Ramsey, the stillness of morning is broken by the sound of a N.J. Transit train pulling into a small, unadorned station in the center of the borough.

title: The U.S. Can't Do The Job All Alone
description: THE potential for depletion of atmospheric ozone - and resulting increases in levels of ultraviolet radiation - is a real environmental concern. It is not, however, the impending crisis that some would have us believe. The best scientific evidence shows that, at current use levels or emissions, the substances most often tied to ozone depletion pose no imminent threat to health or the environment.

title: TEACHINGS OF 'RAMTHA' PULL HUNDREDS WEST
description: George Hain, a millionaire businessman from Cheyenne, Wyo., attended a seminar in Colorado last year and listened to a slender blonde woman, J. Z. Knight, who says a 35,000-year-old-man, ''Ramtha,'' uses her body to speak words of wisdom.

title: Budget Price Is No Bar To Quality Gift Buying
description: Santa Claus must be an audio fan. His deputies south of the North Pole send me letters around this time of year, urging me to forgo audio news coverage for a while and come to the aid of Christmas shoppers. What they want is specific buying suggestions.

title: Arkansas Stops Texas A & M
description: Greg Thomas helped Arkansas keep the ball from explosive Texas A&M and the Razorbacks kept the Aggies out of the end zone twice in the fourth quarter today for a 14-10 victory.

title: Futures And Options And Anxiety
description: TUMULTUOUS moves in stock prices, induced in part by the way large institutions dart in and out of the stock, futures and options markets, have left many individual investors feeling they had little recourse but to watch the value of their holdings rise like a rocket one day, only to sink like a stone the next. The recent daily swings have undeniably been scary. But professionals contend that investors should not be unduly upset.

title: WILTION CONSTABLE ASKS FOR TAX-COLLECTION JOB
description: COLLECTING taxes has always been one of the most onerous, and difficult, tasks for municipalities. Although some communities use deputy sheriffs and collection agencies to collect personal property taxes, most tax collectors do not go beyond imposing liens when it comes to real-estate taxes.

title: Investor Profiles: How Three Respond to the Tax Law
description: For years, financial planning strategies in large part have involved finding ways to shelter income from taxes. Now, as people digest details of the newly enacted tax legislation, they are beginning to think about how it will change their investment practices. Here, three investors talk about what investments they have made, their philosophies and the expected impact of the tax revision law. Ready to Change Strategy LAWRENCE D. MENCONI Jr., a 41-year-old businessman from Inverness, Ill., has every reason to be pleased. His company, Midwest Litho Arts Inc., a color-separating business that he started with several partners six years ago, is doing well - it pulled in about $4 million in revenue last year. He and his wife, Annette, are building a new house, with groundbreaking tentatively scheduled for March.

title: God and Man in Jail
description: According to one of the judges who in the 1960's sentenced the champion surfer Jack (Murph the Surf) Murphy on charges including murder, he was unqualified ''ever again to be in a free world with a law-abiding society.'' Paroled last week after serving 16 years, the 49-year-old Mr. Murphy reported a spiritual turnabout more acrobatic than the feat for which he is best known.

title: FOOD FOR THE HOLIDAYS: FRESHNESS PREVAILS ALONG WITH BACK-TO-BASICS APPROACH
description: This year's holiday food offerings seem to reflect the American movement that is taking us back to basics. For the most part honest, uncontrived place in the county's food shops. Fresh wild mushrooms have replaced the dried, and the county's greengrocers are rich with the luxury of fresh procini and chanterelles. Fresh herbs appear everywhere. Homebody items such as kale ane squash and cranberries ready for stringing or easy cooking are climbing popularity charts. Contrivance is out. A potato looks like a pototo, and chocolate looks unmistably like chocolate. The romantic simple and straightforward are back, and not a moment too soon in our busy lives.

title: 'REPENTANCE,' A SOVIET FILM MILESTONE, STRONGLY DENOUNCES OFFICIAL EVIL
description: ''I made the film so that this would never happen again.''

title: Maryland Takes the Pieces and Puts Them Together: Wade Inherits Staggering Task
description: BOB WADE stopped five feet inside the room and made a quick inspection.

title:
DANCE;
PREMIERE OF A DANCE CITYSCAPE
description: THE Bag Lady camps on the curb, marking her territory with plastic shopping bags.

title: MT. SINAI IS FACING STATE PENALTIES
description: Mount Sinai Medical Center has been cited by the state for performing an unauthorized heart transplant earlier this year.

title: A NEW LOOK IN BALLET PARTNERS
description: The mystique of the ballet partnership has long been a subject of wonderment and speculation in the world of classical dance. Lorca speaks of duende, that special excitement that ''works on the body of a dancer like a breeze on the sand -announcing the constant baptism of newly created things.'' On the ballet stage, the vision of two dancers creating a perfect oneness is an elixir that places the viewer in a dream state. Two bodies in motion shape a rightness of spirit, of physicality, of mutual trust, of shared impulse.

title: LOCALITIES LOOK TO STATE TO FILL VOID IN BUDGETS
description: COUNTY and local governments, faced with the loss of millions of dollars in Federal aid and the prospect of cutbacks in public safety and other services, are looking to Trenton for help.

title: Lions Slide Toward Spot In Record Book
description: Columbia, which for three seasons had shared the role of the nation's worst major college football team, took sole possession yesterday. The Lions were routed by Cornell, 28-0, at Lawrence A. Wein Stadium, extending their losing streak, the longest in the nation, to 30 games. They are four losses short of the major-college record. Columbia last won a game in October 1983. Northwestern, which lost 34 consecutive games between 1979 and 1982, holds the record for a major program.

title: French Defense as a Barometer
description: The French Defense was the barometer of how Andrei Sokolov was doing in his final candidates match with Artur Yusupov in Riga, the Soviet Union. The 23-year-old Russian started by losing to his compatriot's French in Games 1, 3 and 9; only after he learned to cope with it - in games 11 and 13, both of which he won - did Sokolov take the lead and go on to win by 7 1/2-6 1/2.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Speculating in Tax Liens to Seize a Home
description: HELENE McCANN has owned her three-bedroom Cape Cod in Floral Park for 33 years, raising six children and, after her husband died in 1969, struggling to meet rising home-ownership costs.

title: Accord in Rhode Island On Toxic Waste Cleanup
description: Federal and state agencies have filed a $5.8 million settlement in Federal District Court here with 51 companies for the cleanup of what is considered to be one the most hazardous waste sites in the nation.

title: LEVELING OFF IN GROWTH EXPECTED AT NEWARK AIRPORT
description: BY THE turn of the century, more than 50 million airline passengers - six times New Jersey's current population - are expected to pass through Newark International Airport each year.

title: Cornelius J. Chapman Jr. Marries Laura Day Craig
description: Laura Day Craig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew B. Craig 3d of St. Louis, and Cornelius J. Chapman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chapman of Sedalia, Mo., were married yesterday. The Rev. Rose Ann Olmstead, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Covenant in Boston.

title: Dial-a-Prayer, Perhaps
description: A Department of Defense study has concluded that 40 percent of the long-distance calls made on its phones to numbers outside the department were ''unofficial,'' that is to say, personal. Everything at the Pentagon involves a lot of money, and personal phone calls are no exception. ''Unofficial use of the Federal Telecommunications System during the first quarter of 1985 cost the Department of Defense an estimated $4.5 million,'' the study reported.

title: REFUGEE TO GET NEW MURDER TRIAL
description: A Laotian refugee convicted of murdering his wife in a jealous rage must get a new trial, the state's top court has ruled, saying the judge should have allowed testimony about the ''stress and disorientation'' of assimilating into American life.

title: Russell Appel Marries Michelle Lieb, a C.P.A.
description: Michelle Ivy Lieb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lieb of Upper Brookville, L.I., and Russell Appel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Appel of Kings Point, L.I., were married in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan last evening. Rabbi Ephraim Wolf, assisted by Rabbi Robert Widom, performed the ceremony.

title: BEIRUT GROUP URGES U.S. TO TAKE 'WIDER STEPS' TO FREE THE HOSTAGES
description: Islamic Holy War, a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem group, urged the United States today to take unspecified ''wider steps'' to gain the freedom of hostages it is holding.

title: Lillypilly Berries And Vintage Wines
description: True or false: There is no such thing as authentic Australian cuisine.

title: AT UCONN, MUSEUM OUTGROWS ITS SPACE
description: THE William Benton Museum of Art at the University of Connecticut opened its doors on Nov. 15, 1966, in a converted dining hall called the Beanery. This week, the museum will culminate a semester-long observation of its birthday with a party on Saturday and the launching of a $3.5 million building campaign.

title: Women In the Ice Age
description: Whew! Women lose again! Paleolithic sex objects (''Artistry of the Ice Age,'' by John Noble Wilford, Oct. 12)! Though Mr. Wilford ends his article on a positive note (''In the beginning of humanity, there was joy''), he follows standard ''modern'' thought: women are inferior to men and were not primary shapers of mankind's history. Upper paleolithic caves similar to men's clubs? Female ''Venus'' figurines as prehistoric pornography? The theories Mr. Wilford states sound more like the conclusions of a Stone Age Meese Commission. ABBY FELS New York City

title: Sheila Casey Wed to John Christensen
description: Sheila Marie Casey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Winn Casey of Westwood and Edgartown, Mass., was married yesterday to John Gordon Christensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Christensen of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. John Philbin performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: A Doctor's Despair
description: The tragedy of Dr. Mayer lies in his despair. His kind of caring is desperately needed by so many.

title: 'AS IS': A DRAMA ABOUT AIDS
description: ''AS IS,'' by William M. Hoffman, opened Off Broadway in March 1985, followed a month later by Larry Kramer's ''Normal Heart.'' These remain the theater's two major plays about AIDS thus far.

title: Susan Beth Brooks Engaged to Bradley I. Ruskin
description: Mrs. Milton M. Brooks of Rockville Centre, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Susan Beth Brooks, to Bradley I. Ruskin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Ronald Ruskin of New York and Burrville, Conn.

title: Ms. Moore Weds Kevin N. King in San Francisco
description: At Grace Cathedral in San Francisco yesterday Meridee Anne Moore, a daughter of Gwendolyn Walsh of Saratoga, Calif., and Glenbrook, Nev., and Robert A. Moore, of San Jose, Calif., was married to Kevin Neil King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil King of Boulder, Colo. The Rev. Roy Strasburger performed the ceremony.

title: The Shift From Shelters
description: GEORGE O. HAGGARD Jr., a furniture manufacturer in Bean Station, Tenn., has been investing in tax shelters for about six years. But because of the overhaul of the nation's tax code, he is changing his posture in regard to these limited partnership investments.

title: A WAR FOUGHT TWICE
description: THE EXILE OF SERGEANT NEN By Stephen Fleming. 186 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $14.95.

title: NESCONSET STRIP AT ISSUE
description: SMITHTOWN officials are preparing to face protests from property owners along Smithtown Boulevard as major rezoning is considered this month and next.

title: POSTINGS: 'Participatory Art'; Musical Chairs on Third
description: Outdoor sculptures in New York City tend to jazz up the facades of buildings with bold, modern statements that are visually captivating. But a new public display in East Midtown should provide an aural respite for pedestrians from the continuous cacophony of construction and cars.

title: U.S. IS SLOW TO REACT AFTER POLAND'S AMNESTY
description: John Davis, the charge d'affaires at the United States Embassy, has dedicated a monument to American boxers who were killed in a plane crash here six and a half years ago.

title: Nets Hold a Give-Away Night
description: In an effort to reduce the turnovers and get more offense out of his guards, Coach Dave Wohl moved Otis Birdsong into the big guard slot tonight. The change did not help the turnovers or shooting. The Nets, in their worst second-half showing of the season, were soundly beaten by the Atlanta Hawks, 109-90, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: SELLERS AND BUYERS PREPARE FOR A BONANZA OF ARTWORKS IN WEEK'S AUCTION
description: ART works valued at more than $110 million - the largest offering of art ever staged anywhere -will be auctioned this week. Buyers and sellers - spurred by changes in the tax laws that take effect Jan. 1 and lured by opportunities in a booming art market - are expected to help set new records in a series of sales at Sotheby's and Christie's, starting tomorrow night.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ''THIS is the time of year,'' said James J. Barry Jr., director of the state's Division of Consumer Affairs, ''when the holiday spirit carries us into stores. And when we are rushed, we are more apt to be careless.''

title: Miss Boyne Is Married To Jeffrey G. Nardozza
description: Maureen Ellen Boyne, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew X. Boyne of West Hartford, Conn., and Jeffrey Gerard Nardozza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Nardozza of Bayside, Queens, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert D. Bergin performed the ceremony at St. Peter Claver Roman Catholic Church in West Hartford.

title: CORRECTION
description: The About Cars column in last Sunday's Sports section misstated the telephone number for Nutmeg Productions, supplier of a videotape on automobile racing. The number is 800-847-4741.

title: Pitt Passes By Rutgers, 20-6
description: Joe Felitsky, the third starting quarterback in three weeks, passed for 259 yards and a touchdown and Jeff Van Horne made two field goals to lead Pitt to a 20-6 victory over Rutgers today.

title: A C.E.O. Replies
description: To the Editor:

title: Fame and Fortune
description: She spoke Greek, identified herself as an Onassis and was keen to reward the kindness of strangers. All of this tended to inspire confidence in Rowena Riggs Powell, the police in Englewood, N.J., said last week after they charged her with theft by deception. Ms. Powell, calling herself Christina Onassis and saying she was a sister of the late Greek tycoon Aristotle Onassis, began a trail of deceipt in Houston, police said, writing bogus checks of five and six figures to clinch real estate deals and demonstrate her ''wealth,'' then charging thousands of dollars in hotel and restaurant bills to gullible businessmen.

title: St. Gall
description: To the Editor: Paul Hofmann's article (Travel, Sept. 28) describing the charms of St. Gall, Switzerland, and its long history of lace making brought back poignant memories.

title: THE SCOOP FROM HELEN HAYES
description: 'The Front Page'' is back in town, and what a calliope call that must sound to the generations of newspaper people who fell in love with the game the moment after the curtain opened on those gorgeous mugs cutting up the cards and cutting down the pols in the Press Room of the Chicago City Hall and County Building. If there was a way to get a computer print-out of the newsmen and women who got the bug from ''The Front Page,'' it's odds-on we'd find almost everybody who meant anything in the profession, and plenty we never heard of, like the guards and tackles who work the rewrite bank. Plus a few who turned up later in the ivory towers of the Fourth Estate, light years away from the wisecracking, get-that-story-or-die bunch who barrel their way through Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur's American classic. Somehow, wherever it may have ended, the dream started in that gouty, smoky dustbin of a press room with its window-view of the gallows.

title: Miami Goes 10-0; Auburn Falls 20-16
description: Vinny Testaverde passed for two touchdowns, after Miami's lead slipped to 10-3 late in the third quarter, as the unbeaten Hurricanes defeated Tulsa, 23-10, for their 10th victory tonight.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
ON PAYING FOR ROADS
description: STATE transportation capital expenditures in New Jersey are financed primarily through the medium of the Transportation Trust Fund Authority Act, which Governor Kean signed into law on July 10, 1984.

title: Smoking's Effects On Nonsmokers
description: A new Government report appears to give ammunition to both sides in the growing battle over passive smoking.

title: Rehnquist Rejects an Appeal By the South African Airline
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist rejected an emergency plea today from South African Airways to prevent the Reagan Administration from cutting off the airline's connections with the United States.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN ATTEMPT AT BEING OBJECTIVE
description: WE HAVE been criticized at times for writing unfavorable reviews, the implication being that, if there is nothing good to say about a restaurant, than nothing should be said. In point of fact, there are many restaurants that are never written about; usually, if we visit one and find that it is below standard, we do not return and do not write anything about it.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WHEN a history of John Wiley & Sons, called ''One Hundred and Seventy-Five Years of Publishing,'' was being written, it was noted, said W. Bradford Wiley, the company's chairman and former chief executive officer, ''that we hadn't said very much about our books.''

title: AY, EVERY INCH A KING
description: ON ACTING By Laurence Olivier. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Margaret Dickey Married in Capital
description: Margaret Stevenson Lynch Dickey and Alexander Cooper Tomlinson were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church, Georgetown, in Washington by the Rev. Sanford Garner. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John J. Lynch of Cotuit, Mass., and the late Mr. Lynch. Mr. Tomlinson is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander C. Tomlinson of Haddonfield, N.J.

title: Fidel Castro's Years as A Secret Communist
description: Fidel Castro's successful game of deception may be written off as bygone history - but only at our own peril.

title: 4,256 and 311 and 548 Equal '87
description: PETE ROSE agreed to remove himself from the Cincinnati Reds' roster for now, but he'll be eligible to return on May 15 at age 46.

title: CREATING AN URBAN NEIGHBORHOOD
description: IT doesn't hurt a land planner to be something of a social philosopher. Peter Calthorpe is both.

title: SOVIET RATIFIES NUCLEAR ACCIDENT CONVENTIONS
description: The Soviet Union has ratified two international conventions on nuclear accidents, but said it would not be bound by a provision allowing a government to take a dispute to arbitration or to the International Court of Justice.

title: CORRECTION
description: An art listing last Sunday in The Guide, section 2A, gave incorrect hours for an exhibition of paintings by Russell Connor at the Grand Street Gallery, 93 Grand Street. It is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 6 P.M.

title: STATE COURT TO DISCERN VALUE OF A 'GREEN CARD'
description: Is a ''green card'' marital property, and if so, what is its value in a divorce settlement?

title: MUSHROOM HUNTING: WILD PASSION
description: ''LIKE most Americans I knew only two mushrooms; the one that grew in between the lettuce and the scallions on supermarkets shelves, the other a mushroom cloud,'' said Sara Ann Friedman, a self-professed ''obsessed mushroom nut'' from Brook lyn.

title: THESE PIONEERS WANT CABLE TV
description: THE NEW HEARTLAND America's Flight Beyond the Suburbs and How It Is Changing Our Future. By John Herbers. 228 pp. New York: Times Books. $19.95.

title: 'BETRAYAL' IN FAIRFIELD IS PINTER ABLY DONE
description: IS there a proper way to play Pinter? Can American actors portray characters who have been described as ''indelibly English?'' Should they abandon their American accents and affect an English one for the occasion?

title: GROUP-HOME PLAN CHALLENGED
description: HOMEOWNERS in many communities where houses have been converted to facilities for the disabled have challenged those facilities and the state agency that licenses them.

title: COHALAN EMBATTLED ON BUDGET CAP
description: ALTHOUGH he will don the robes of a State Supreme Court justice starting in January, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan seemed like anything but a lame duck last week.

title: DEALING WITH IRAN: HOW EXPERTS SEE IT
description: President Reagan's decision to authorize unpublicized talks with Iranian officials and send them some weapons and spare parts has touched off a major dispute involving United States foreign policy and has prompted a heated debate that has transcended the usual partisan divisions in Washington. Mr. Reagan has angrily denied reports that he traded arms for American hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militants. Many of his critics challenge this assertion. Some experts who have followed the United States-Iran relationship, ranging from former Directors of Central Intelligence to scholars, were asked these questions: Is it good or bad to trade military supplies for hostages? What are the pros and cons of making such overtures to the Iranians? And what are the prospects for the United States to restore and improve its ruptured relations with Iran? Here are excerpts from their replies: SHAUL BAKHASH Professor of Government George Mason University

title: Mutual Funds Riding High
description: MUTUAL funds are an increasingly popular way for individuals to invest in the equities or bond markets. Investors can take advantage of the diversity offered by a large organization, while minimizing risks. There are more mutual funds today than ever, and it is easier to invest in one or switch from one to another than it has ever been. The industry, buoyed by the recent bull market, has reached a pinnacle of efficiency and sophistication. Although not every fund has performed admirably, many funds provide substantial returns to investors.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON HEATING AID
description: AS MUCH as $54 million may be spent this year on energy assistance and conservation programs for disadvantaged New Jerseyans - as well as those who just want to spend less for heat this winter - but state and local officials question whether enough of the poor and elderly are actually being helped.

title: GOING BEYOND THE LIMIT WITH STRATEGIC ARMS
description: THE Air Force has equipped 130 planes to carry cruise missiles, the advanced, low-flying intercontinental nuclear weapons, and plans to have another one ready before long. In military terms, the increase to 131 planes will hardly mean much. But adding one more cruise-equipped plane will, unless other American weapons are dismantled, push the United States over one of the limits set forth in the second strategic arms treaty of 1979. And that will be a political shot heard round the world.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SISTERS TO PERFORM

title: PLASTIC, AND OTHER NEW ANXIETIES
description: ALMOST everyone freely admits they suffer from at least one of the wide variety of phobias afflicting modern man. Usually, a phobia does not interfere with our daily lives and it is thought that many of our fears can be traced to the human species' instinctive struggle for survival.

title: The Battle Over Drug Testing
description: Judge Kaufman referred to a false-positive reaction caused by ibuprofen, the pain-relief ingredient in Advil.

title: Devils, Up by 2, Settle for Tie
description: In an emotional and physical game marked by 39 penalties, the Devils and the Bruins fought to a 5-5 deadlock tonight at Boston Garden.

title: THE JOYS OF EAST END WINTERS
description: FALL brings some of the most glorious months of the year on the East End. A few weeks after Labor Day, the town sighs with half-strangled relief.

title:
GARDENING;
TO FRUIT, HOLLIES NEED AGE AND MATES
description: A COMPLAINT frequently aired by gardeners is that their holly fails to produce fruit. This is a great disappointment since the primary reason for planting hollies is that of having their attractive red fruits for fall and winter display both indoors and in holiday decorations.

title: Championing Print in a TV World
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, Robert Burton, president of ABC Publishing, a division of the broadcasting company, held a meeting with a dozen high-level executives from his staff. As he glanced around the room, he chuckled mischievously. ''We've got too many vice presidents again,'' he cracked. ''We're going to have to make some changes.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Anniversary for a Popular Dime
description: Americans in general, and numismatists in particular, tend to take the Roosevelt dime for granted.

title: Social Events; HELP FROM SOME FOR MANY
description: or the Mission Society Nov. 17 - A champion rope-jumping team and other performers will be featured along with cocktails, dinner and dancing starting at 6:30 P.M. in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The black-tie evening will benefit the New York City Mission Society, which has offered a wide range of programs for families and children since 1812. Tickets, $350, from 212-997-0100. British Fair Nov. 17 - The Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York will hold its 66th annual fair from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West 51st Street. There will be Christmas puddings, mincemeat, jellies, jams, woolens and crockery and many other British imports and locally created items for the holiday season. A light luncheon will be served. The event benefits the Victoria Home for Retired Men and Women in Ossining, N.Y. No admission charge. Information: Anita Summer at 516-333-4822. Theatrical Evening Nov. 17 - Cocktails at 7 P.M., dinner at 8 and a ''star-studded cabaret'' at 10 will mark the annual benefit and 18th season of the Circle Repertory Company and help support its American Play Development Program. The event is at the Greene Street Cafe, 101 Greene Street, near Prince Street. Tickets, $250, from 212-691-3210. Brooklyn Doubleheader Nov. 19 - The Brooklyn Museum's department of decorative arts will benefit from a 6-to-10 P.M. preview of ''Modernism: A Century of Style and Design, 1860 to 1960'' at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street.

title: In Politics by TV, Money Does All the Talking; What's in a Label?
description: To the Editor:

title:
ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
The Dissenting Charles Moore Gets Show of His Own
description: CHARLES Moore, the 61-year-old architect who has long startled the architectural establishment with iconoclastic designs, has until recently avoided one of the more awkward moments in the career of a life-long dissident - a major retrospective. But last month the Williams College Museum of Art in Williamstown, Mass., opened an exhibition to devoted to his work. Moreover, ''The Architecture of Charles Moore: Buildings and Projects 1949-1986'' (through Dec. 28) was held in an addition to the museum designed by the architect himself. The buildings with which Mr. Moore surprised and sometimes outraged the profession have settled into history, and are now contemporary classics.

title: Ann Elisabet Williams Wed to Stanford Singer
description: Ann Elisabet Williams, a daughter of Lisbet Williams of Brooklyn and the late Dr. John M. Williams 3d, was married yesterday to Stanford Scott Singer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd I. Singer of New York. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title:
OPPORTUNITIES AND PITFALLS;
The Lure of Tax-Deferred Annuities
description: WHEN the dust clears after tax revisions, investors in droves will be looking for new ways to shelter income. And variable rate annuities are sure to be one of the preferred ways. They combine the advantages of mutual fund investing with the tax deferral of insurance.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: What greater delight than a glorious book about a glorious book? SULEYMANNAME: The Illustrated History of Suleyman the Magnificent (National Gallery of Art/Abrams, $75), edited by Esin Atil of the Center of Asian Art at the Smithsonian Institution, is a splendid facsimile edition of the priceless - and inaccessible - 16th-century illustrated chronicle of the sultanate of Sulayman, which is housed in the Topkapi Palace Museum Library in Istanbul, Turkey. Thanks to Mrs. Atil's scrupulously researched and beautifully organized critical commentary, it is also a handbook of Ottoman imperial history.

title: Electionomics
description: The bigger-than-expected Democratic victory in Congress could well have a positive impact on the economy in the next two years, says Allen Sinai, chief economist for Shearson Lehman Brothers. Both parties will be under pressure to ''fix'' the economy, he says, in time for the Presidential elections in 1988.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Bidding For Bachelors MICHELLE WRIGHT of North Babylon is getting ready for the big date with a nice young man from Southold, Jeff Witherspoon . Miss Wright, a 27-year-old Sperry Corporation engineer, decided to go out with Mr. Witherspoon, a 26-year-old advertising account executive, because ''he's cute,'' she said.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
A Revolution on the Keyboard Is in the Making
description: When the pianist Rebecca La Brecque performs at Merkin Concert Hall tonight some listeners may simply shrug their shoulders, but others will surely hail the evening as the latest benchmark of what seems to be a revolution in the making. Ms. La Brecque will be playing pieces for the unusual combination of piano and electronic keyboard synthesizer - instruments that have come to represent warring camps in the battle for the hearts, minds and dollars of the musical consumer.

title: Uganda Reports Attacks By Rebels in North
description: The Kampala radio said today that Ugandan rebels had mounted a series of attacks against Government troops in northern Uganda but suffered heavy casualties.

title: Recent Releases Of Video Cassettes: Truffaut's 'Girls'
description: Two English Girls Starring Jean-Pierre Leaud, Kika Markham and Stacey Tendeter; directed by Francois Truffaut. 1972. Key Video. 130 minutes. $59.98

title: Adirondack Snowshoeing, New Guinea Picture Taking
description: Winter Respite In Upstate New York When winter mantles the Adirondack wilderness with snows, a rustic lodge set on a tranquil mountain lake will become the base for a series of explorations - sometimes by ski, sometimes by snowshoe - of the remote landscape of peaks and rills and forests. At day's end, a crackling fire, hot showers, a sauna, dinner and a comfortable bed await the participants.

title:
THEATER;
The Business of Broadway: A Theater Owner's View
description: Is the theater dead? Is Broadway to go the way of vaudeville and the minstrel show?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 17, 1986: MONDAY FPL Group Inc San Diego Gas & Elec NAFCO Fin Group Williams Cos TUESDAY Acco World Corp Harsco Corp Anchor Hocking Corp Hayes-Albion Corp Armstrong Rubber Kellwood Co Briggs & Stratton Longs Drug Stores Coleman Co Mohasco Corp Duquesne Light Ohio Edison WEDNESDAY Amer Intl Group Morse Shoe Bowater Inc Norstar Bancorp Chesebrough-Pond's Northrop Corp Combustion Engineering Pacific G & E GEICO Corp Savannah Elec & Pwr Johnson Controls Stanley Works Kansas Pwr & Lt USAir Group THURSDAY Air Products & Chem Fruehauf Corp Ametek Inc Greyhound Corp AmSouth Bncrptn Halliburton Co Butler International Insilco Corp Carson Pirie Scott Lone Star Indus Champion International Perkin-Elmer Continental Corp NY Tracor Inc Dresser Indus Union Pacific Corp Florida Progress Corp Wyle Labs FRIDAY Aetna Life & Casualty Fay's Drug Co Alexander&Alexander Sv General Electric Bairnco Corp IC Industries Barnes Group Kansas City So Indus Campbell Soup (US) Reynolds Metals Donaldson Co South Jersey Indus Edwards (AG) Inc Texas Utilities

title: For Academia, an All-Star Cast
description: The University of South Carolina shells out hundreds of thousands of dollars for token appearances by what seems like the entire cast of ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous.'' And when the story gets out, the administration of this state-financed school refuses to admit how much it spent until a judge orders disclosure . . .

title: DANCE: BATSHEVA TROUPE FROM ISRAEL
description: THE Batsheva Dance Company of Israel is a vibrant and good-looking young troupe with a wisely chosen repertory of new modern-dance pieces. The chief problem with Batsheva's weekend visit to the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, to judge by Saturday night's performance and its enthusiastic reception, was that it was too brief.

title: A KEY IN MANILA: ACTIVIST OFFICERS
description: In the class of 1971 at the Philippine Military Academy they engaged in food fights in the cafeteria. Last February they joined a military revolt that is now referred to here as a miracle.

title: BRONCOS OVERWHELM CHIEFS
description: Gerald Willhite scored three touchdowns, including one on a 70-yard punt return, and the Denver defense forced two fumbles to set up quick first-quarter scores as the Broncos whipped the Kansas City Chiefs today, 38-17.

title: Flatterer Wins 4th Time
description: For the fourth straight year, Flatterer today won the $60,000 Marion DuPont Scott Colonial Cup steeplechase. The 7-year-old gelding outdistanced a nine-horse field, which did not include Census, the Breeder's Cup champion.

title: 'EYE' MARKS 200 REPORTS ON DANCE
description: THE ''Eye on Dance'' celebration of its 200th program, to be broadcast tonight at 9 on Channel 31, is a special that no one interested in dance should miss. With only an hour to suggest the range of interviews and dance excerpts recorded over six years, the program seems slightly episodic at first, leaping briskly as it does from ballet to modern dance to ethnic to popular to video dance. But Celia Ipiotis and Jeff Bush, producers of the weekly dance journalism series and of this special, have chosen very well.

title: A 6-LANE ROAD WOULD REPLACE WESTWAY PLAN
description: A state panel charged with finding a successor to New York City's aborted Westway project will recommend construction of a six-lane highway on the West Side of Manhattan between the Battery and 42d Street, panel members disclosed today.

title: BRITAIN SPEEDS UP A LAW ON INSIDERS
description: Over the weekend the British Government rushed into effect legislation to combat insider trading and mounted an investigation into an insider-dealing scandal that emerged last week.

title: COMPUTER TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Net income

title: Cyanide Pills at Sunbelt State
description: THERE was an emergency meeting yesterday at Sunbelt State University regarding the latest scandal in college football.

title: King Clancy, 1903-86
description: One bright Toronto morning only three weeks ago, he strode into his office at Maple Leaf Gardens and gave his customary performance. He danced a little jig, he hummed a little tune, and he chirped good morning to two seated secretaries who were watching him with wide smiles. At age 83, King Clancy was still bubbling over with impish joie de vivre.

title: Topics: Remedies and Rewards; Family Values
description: The kidnapping of Phillip Worthington is the sort of story that strikes fear in any new parent. One-day-old Phillip was abducted from a Pennsylvania hospital a week ago by a woman in a white laboratory coat who came to his mother's bedside and told her she was taking the child for medical tests.

title: Woman Gets Heart To Replace Jarvik-7
description: A 28-year-old woman who lived for five days with a Jarvik-7 artificial heart as an interim life-saving measure received a human heart early today and was listed in critical but stable condition, doctors said.

title: RANGERS LEAD, 5-1, BUT LOSE
description: The Rangers were left banging their sticks on the bench, in despair and probably in disbelief. For of all the difficult games in their perplexing season, none was worse than this. When Edmonton scored its final goal, James Patrick said he looked away.

title: A SKIRMISH INVOLVING A PACIFIST
description: Colman McCarthy, although an avowed pacifist, is something of a political arsonist. Whether in his syndicated newspaper column or in a lecture hall, Mr. McCarthy's espousals of leftist ideas - on everything from civil disobedience to vegetarianism - rarely fail to ignite a reaction.

title: Ex-Captive Is Opposed To Arms for Hostages
description: The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, an American priest who was released by kidnappers in Lebanon, said today that it would be better for other American hostages to stay in captivity than be freed in return for United States arms shipments to Iran.

title: FOREIGN INVESTORS IN CHINA SKEPTICAL
description: The foreign business community - faced with a number of unprofitable joint ventures - wants more from the Chinese than the measures announced last month that include lower taxes, reduced charges for labor, land and raw materials and greater freedom in hiring and firing employees.

title: KIM IL SUNG, AT 74, IS REPORTED DEAD
description: South Korea announced today that North Korean loudspeakers along the border had reported that Kim Il Sung, the North's leader, had been shot to death.

title: Destination Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTAINER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $60,368 for the quarter and $119,899 for the 6 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 24.

title: Jeffrey Gabel Marries Joan Rachel Bernstein
description: Joan Rachel Bernstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bernstein of West Hartford and Westbrook, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Gabel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Gabel of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbis Stanley Kessler and William Cohen officiated at Temple Beth El in West Hartford.

title: 'THE AIDS SHOW' ON 13
description: TONIGHT at 10 o'clock, Channel 13 is offering ''The AIDS Show,'' an hourlong documentary by Robert Epstein (''The Times of Harvey Milk'') and Peter Adair (''Word Is Out''). The subject is, of course, the disease that has been generating headlines around the world, but in the title's case, AIDS is also an acronym for Artists Involved with Death and Survival.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: MUSIC: WAVERLY CONSORT
description: ON the Iberian Peninsula, medieval Roman Catholicism made both public politics and private passions intensely active parts of its church. In the 12th and 13th centuries, the Virgin Mary and St. James became competing rallying points for political power in what is now Spain and Portugal.

title: PHIL SIMMS'S BIGGEST PASS
description: NEARLY three weeks ago, when Al Toon and Wesley Walker of the Jets were emerging as the National Football League's most feared wide receivers, the Giants were struggling without their two damaged wide receivers, Lionel Manuel and Stacy Robinson.

title: SYMBION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rail Merger Before I.C.C.
description: The Union Pacific Corporation has asked for Government approval to buy the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad, known as the Katy line, for about $110 million.

title: Where the Red Cross Symbol Comes From
description: To the Editor:

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes net of $216,441 from the company's former Canadian unit, Maynard Energy Inc., sold Oct. 29, 1985. c-Includes net of $700,693 from the former Canadian unit. The year-ago periods' revenue includes revenue of $2,099,498 for the quarter and $6,835,274 for the 9 months, both from the Canadian unit.

title: RISING REPRESSION SWELLS THE FLOW OF JEWISH EMIGRATION FROM IRAN
description: Persecution of Jews in Iran has reached such intensity that hundreds of them have joined a much larger exodus of Moslem Iranians fleeing the country, according to refugee officials here.

title: Fidelity's President Taking Cabot Post
description: Samuel W. Bodman is leaving the presidency of the FMR Corporation, a financial services holding company that includes the big Fidelity group of mutual funds, to be president and chief operating officer of the Cabot Corporation.

title: Richmond Wins
description: Tim Richmond pulled away at the end to win the Winston Western 500 Nascar race today, closing the season with his seventh victory.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LILLIAN HELLMAN: The Image, the Woman. By William Wright. Illustrated. 507 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Satellite Co., Rockville, Md., named Ben L. Jarvis senior vice president of operations and engineering, commercial division.

title: New York Agenda
description: City Sports Panel A bill that would create a City Sports Commission - a five-member panel to attract and keep professional sports teams in New York City -will come up for review by the City Council's Committee on Governmental Operations. Approval is expected. 250 Broadway, 23d-floor hearing room, 1 P.M. Installing Water Meters Plans to install water meters in all New York City residences over the next 10 years, announced last week by Mayor Koch, will be the subject of a City Council hearing.

title: As for Gephardt . . .
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, another Democrat thinking about 1988, will move a step closer to active candidacy today when his backers notify the Federal Election Commission that they have formed the Gephardt Presidential Exploratory Committee.

title: Washington Watch; View on F.T.C.'s Role
description: Daniel Oliver, the former journalist who since April has been chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, complains that the nation's trade deficit has received so much media attention that many people mistakenly think his agency is mainly responsible for dealing with import and export policy.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter loss is after a charge of $339,000 from expenses in connection with work force reductions.

title: EPITAPH FOR A COMIC: HE CAPTURED THE GALLIC SOUL
description: ''Why Not the Pantheon?'' was the rather unusual headline in the serious, sober Le Monde last week.

title: ANDROS ANALYZERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Topics: Remedies and Rewards; Impacted
description: Starting in 1970, Federal agencies were required formally to evaluate the effects of their proposed projects in Environmental Impact Statements. These have created red tape, but also raised important red flags.

title: VOLCANO ERUPTS IN JAPAN
description: An island volcano erupted Saturday for the first time in 12 years and was shooting coloumns of molten lava hundreds of feet into the air today, Japan's Meteorological Agency said.

title: U.S. SAID TO ISSUE SUBPOENAS LINKED TO BOESKY TRADING
description: The Justice Department last Friday served subpoenas on at least 10 Wall Street professionals in a widening investigation of the insider trading scandal that forced Ivan F. Boesky to pay $100 million for illegal stock speculation, according to an industry source.

title: Lear's Magazine Set For Women Over 40
description: A general interest magazine for moderately affluent women over 40 will make its bow next August under the editorship of Frances Lear, who has long been professionally active in the field of women in the workplace. It will be named, simply, Lear's.

title: ROCK 'N' ROLL: IGGY POP RETURNS TO THE RITZ
description: IGGY POP, hard rock's answer to Rudolf Nureyev, returned to the Ritz Thursday with a vociferous band, feral choreography and a mixed batch of songs. Since the late 1960's, James (Iggy Pop) Osterberg has been rock's wild man, snarling through songs and leaping, twisting and twirling across stages as his bands pound away. With the Stooges (under the name Iggy Stooge) and then on his own, Mr. Osterberg came up with punk-rock before the term existed; nearly 20 years later, his rockers still sound perfectly up-to-date.

title: Catholic Woman Dies Amid Ulster Strife
description: An elderly Roman Catholic woman collapsed and died after her home was attacked early today during renewed outbreaks of violence by Protestant opponents of the British-Irish accord, the police said.

title: Quake Jolts Greek City
description: A moderate earthquake shook this northern Greek city early today, but no injuries or damage were reported, the police said. A spokesman for the seismological unit at Salonika University said that the tremor, which measured 4.3 on the Richter scale, occurred at 12:18 A.M. and that its epicenter was 28 miles east of the city, in the Lake Volve region.

title: Bombay Stock Stoppage
description: Nearly 400 brokers refused to trade on the Bombay Stock Exchange on Friday, and some brokers said the exchange may have to close indefinitely because trading has been crippled by seizure of stock certificates in income tax raids last month. It was the fourth time this month that large numbers of brokers refused to trade, after the Indian Government started tax raids on the offices of brokers on Oct. 22. More than $6 million worth of share certificates, cash, gold, silver and jewelry were seized in a weeklong series of raids that were aimed at finding untaxed wealth.

title: BERBICK EQUIPPED TO DEFEND HIS TITLE IN ARRAY OF ROLES
description: IN the summer of 1985, Don King, the boxing promoter, was in Las Vegas, Nev., feeling apprehensive and lowdown about a tax evasion case the Government was about to bring against him.

title: University to Study Limits on Outsiders' Pay
description: The University of South Carolina board will consider limiting pay for visiting professors after the disclosure that Jihan Sadat, widow of the slain Egyptian leader Anwar el-Sadat, received hundreds of thousands of dollars, the chairman of the board of trustees said.

title: WORRY ON BUDGET ACCOUNTING PLAN
description: Some of the accounting changes under consideration by the Reagan Administration for the Government's own bookkeeping could be confusing, politicized, abused and, in general, inferior to the existing procedures, industry experts say.

title: THE DANCE: WAGONER'S 'SONGS'
description: CHOREOGRAPHED in 1976 and revived by Dan Wagoner and Dancers on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Wagoner's ''Songs'' is a dance about songs and most of it is set to recordings of familiar 19th-century music.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LOOKING BACK The primacy of New York in experimental theater is exemplified by such companies as the Wooster Group, one of that hardy group of iconoclastic units whose challenge of traditional concepts of drama began in the tumultuous 1960's. The Wooster Group may have been more hardy than most that burgeoned in those years because it is still around and is today starting a retrospective that will carry it into early next year.

title: HOPES STIR AGAIN FOR LOW RATES
description: The credit markets seem to have shrugged off the possibility, raised a week ago, that the Federal Reserve might adopt a less-generous monetary policy, and are instead anticipating that stable to lower rates will be needed to sustain the economic recovery that will enter its fifth year next month.

title: ANATOMY OF THE DRUG ISSUE: HOW, AFTER YEARS, IT ERUPTED
description: More than any time in memory, America this year has erupted with concern about illegal drugs.

title: GASTINEAU JOINS THE WOUNDED
description: Some things never seem to change. The Jets win a game. The Jets lose a defensive player with an injury. It happened again today. They beat the Colts, 31-16, and lost Mark Gastineau with a sprained left knee. How long will he be out? Coach Joe Walton said the team would have a better idea Monday.

title: Washington Watch; Using Silver as Collateral
description: The World Bank says it is studying a proposal by the Idaho Congressional delegation to require that silver producing nations use silver as collateral for future loans.

title: How to Administer Covert Operations
description: If nothing else, recent events - particularly the air intrusion into Nicaragua that left Eugene Hasenfus a prisoner, and the still obscure Iran arms deal - show by implication that the ''rogue elephant'' C.I.A. of the 1960's is now well and truly tamed. The White House has declared that C.I.A. operatives were involved in the Iranian mission, but it was current or retired employees of the National Security Council who were reportedly in charge of both operations.

title: LEXICON
description: It's no secret (or, to put it another way, the information has not been compartmented) that people in the Pentagon don't talk like the rest of us.

title: American Airlines Planes Nearly Collide in Texas
description: Two American Airlines jets, one climbing, the other descending, came within a half mile of each other because of ''possible operation error,'' the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: JUSTICE CHIEF SEES NO HASENFUS PARDON
description: The Nicaraguan Justice Minister says he opposes any pardon for Eugene Hasenfus, the American air-cargo handler who was sentenced to 30 years in jail Saturday after admitting that he helped fly weapons to anti-Government rebels.

title: Minoru Yasui, 70, Activist In Japanese-American Rights
description: Minoru Yasui, an Oregon native who pioneered the fight for the rights of Japanese-Americans in World War II, died of cancer Wednesday at a hospital here. Mr. Yasui, a retired lawyer, was 70 years old.

title: UPROAR OVER IRAN: WHAT IS KNOWN AND WHAT REMAINS TO BE LEARNED?
description: A succession of senior Administration officials have sought in the last few days to quell Congressional and public anger over Washington's dealings with Iran.

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERA: MENOTTI'S 'GOYA' IN WASHINGTON PREMIERE
description: The world premiere of ''Goya,'' Gian Carlo Menotti's effort to make opera out of the chiaroscuro career of the Spanish painter, had almost everything going for it. The Washington Opera's lavish production, unveiled this evening, is said to have cost a million dollars, certainly not a guarantee of success but an indication that the usual shoestring approach to new music would not be a hindrance this time. No less a Spanish artist than Placido Domingo took the title role and a renowned Spanish conductor, Rafael Fruhbeck de Burgos, was in the pit. The audience could hardly have been more glamorous in Washington's terms: Queen Sofia of Spain shared the center box with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the Administration's point man for the occasion. Many other diplomatic, political and social celebrities turned out, too, including such opera fans as Senator Bill Bradley and Senator Gary Hart. The nation's capital, agog with anticipation, became a veritable Goya hotbed: exhibits of his paintings and etchings opened at the Corcoran and National galleries, for instance.

title: CITY'S HOMELESS: PROTRAIT OF A GROWING AND VARIED POPULATION
description: As more and more men, women and families come into the city's shelter system, officials have been amassing facts and figures about who the homeless are, where they come from and why their numbers grow so relentlessly.

title: Chief Is Also Chairman At Transformed Zayre
description: The Zayre Corporation, marking its final transformation from a family-dominated company, has announced that Maurice Segall, president and chief executive, will also assume the chairman's post, effective Feb. 1.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL UNABLE TO AGREE ON HOW BEST TO CHART NEW COURSE
description: Members of the United States Civil Rights Commission are deeply split over proposals to expand the panel's role in reducing race and sex discrimination.

title: Jews Riot in Jerusalem At Funeral for Student
description: Jews angered by the slaying Saturday of a religious student set fire to an Arab store and smashed car windows today as they marched in a funeral procession through the Old City in East Jerusalem to a cemetery on the Mount of Olives, the police said.

title: TURNER EQUITY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparable year-ago figures are not available because it went public in July 1985.

title: In Camera, On Camera, Off Camera
description: Federal District Judge Whitman Knapp made a regrettable remark last week about Stanley Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, that did not necessarily threaten the fairness of the New York City corruption trial in New Haven but says something about how the public is treated at such trials.

title: ARBITRAGERS FACE THE SPOTLIGHT
description: The mystifying downfall of Ivan F. Boesky - the dapper, undisputed king of the Wall Street arbitragers -has shocked, saddened and, some say, given a certain amount of perverse satisfaction to other Wall Street professionals.

title: MEXICANS, IN A POLL, SAY THEY CONSIDER U.S. TO BE A FRIEND
description: Although relations between the Governments of Mexico and the United States have been strained in recent months, a large majority of Mexicans consider the United States to be a friend and look with envy toward its democratic system of government and strong economy.

title: CHAIRMAN SAYS WICKES FACES 'TOUGHEST' TASK
description: Sanford C. Sigoloff, chairman and chief executive of the Wickes Companies, said that the upcoming integration of the retailing, apparel and automotive company with Lear Siegler Inc. and the Collins & Aikman Corporation would rival Wickes's earlier Chapter 11 reorganization in complexity and scope.

title: Outdoors: Fish Fanfare at Fulton
description: IF decades of angling have led you to believe that you are expert at identifying fish, a visit to Fulton Fish Market will disabuse you of that notion.

title: Karyn Matza Is a Bride
description: Karyn Andrea Matza, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Matza of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary Neil Silverhardt, the son of Estelle Silverhardt of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Aaron Silverhardt of Hewlett, L.I. Rabbi Melvin Sirner performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N.Y. Mrs. Silverhardt is a registered nurse at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. Her husband is an auditor for Coopers & Lybrand, accountants in New York.

title: AMERICAN CONSUMER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BECOMING A STEPMOTHER: A WRITER'S STORY
description: Lisa wanted a horse desperately, so desperately she said she would give up Christmas for three years to get one.

title: Bring On the Makeup
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy's decision to choose the chairmanship of the Labor and Human Resources Committee rather than the Judiciary Committee next year may provide a significant political assist, after all, for Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, who is considering a run for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: Bomb Is Found In Stadium Seats
description: Cleanup crews found a bomb in the seats of Cyclone Stadium following Iowa State's football game with Kansas State.

title: Civil Rights Case Is Settled In Department of Agriculture
description: The Department of Agriculture has announced that it has dropped all disciplinary charges against its highest-ranking black woman and will continue her employment at the agency.

title: BALLARD MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Carolyn J. Mooney Is Married to Eric D. Berkman
description: Carolyn Jeanette Mooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel T. Mooney of Winchester, Mass., was married yesterday to Eric David Berkman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Berkman of Huntington, L.I. Cantor David Shneyer performed the ceremony at the Oxon Hill (Md.) Manor.

title: NO 'NEW LAW' SEEN IN BOESKY PENALTY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission broke no new legal ground in its action against Ivan F. Boesky, according to securities experts, although the size of the arbitrager's $100 million insider trading penalty was unprecedented.

title: THEATER: 'CHRISTMAS SPECTACULAR'
description: THERE are all sorts of Christmases past to be revisited at ''The Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' which opened Friday night at Radio City Music Hall.

title: ADVANCED MANUFACTURING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Nam June Paik Video And New Music at 4D
description: An evening of video art and new music, including a new video by Nam June Paik and music by John Cage, is scheduled tonight at 8 at Club 4D, 605 West 55th Street.

title: Homeless Man Dies of Burns
description: A homeless man who was seen dripping wine on his clothing and striking matches was fatally burned in a subway station in this section of Brooklyn yesterday, the police reported. The police said it was unclear whether the man's death was an accident or a suicide.

title: PRAGMA BIO-TECH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Authorities Find Body Of Drug Agent's Wife
description: The body of a Federal drug agent's wife was found today, two days after she disappeared from her office, the police said.

title: SIOBHAN McKENNA IS DEAD; ACTRESS KNOWN FOR ST. JOAN
description: Siobhan McKenna, a pride of the Irish theater whose vivid Joan of Arc captivated Broadway audiences in 1956, died of a heart attack yesterday after surgery at the Black Rock Clinic in Dublin. She was 63 or 64 years old and a resident of the Irish capital.

title: Paris Ballet to Return With New 'Cinderella'
description: The Paris Opera Ballet will return to the Metropolitan Opera House for a one-week engagement in June. The company will present Rudolf Nureyev's new production of ''Cinderella'' in performances from June 15 to 20.

title: Next for the Hudson, a Toxic Cleanup
description: To the Editor:

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $48,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Susan B. Marder Becomes Bride of a Medical Student
description: Susan Beth Marder, the daughter of John Gerald Marder of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Barbara Sand Marder of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Steven Zelouf, the son of Betty Zelouf of East Northport, L.I., and Victor Zelouf of Manila. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: PATRIOTS STUN RAMS AT 0:00
description: Irving Fryar pulled down a tipped pass from Tony Eason in the back of the end zone as time expired today, giving the New England Patriots a 30-28 victory over the Los Angeles Rams and spoiling what had been a memorable debut by the Rams' Jim Everett.

title: ENERGY OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Article 463386 -- No Title
description: The depressed price of oil has reversed many of the wildcatters' rags-to-riches stories, and Texas has a new folk hero: a gem dealer who paid $10 for a stone he says is a record-size star sapphire worth about $2.5 million.

title: CABARET: ANGELA BOFILL
description: WHEN the Bronx-born singer and songwriter Angela Bofill released her first album more than seven years ago, she revealed herself as a jazz-fusion musician of unusual freshness and vitality. Performing her own lush, sprawling ballads in a big brash voice that contained a strong undercurrent of childlike impulsiveness, Ms. Bofill displayed an appealing ingenuousness along with the potential to develop in any of several directions.

title: SAMSON ENERGY CO LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writedown of $15,058,000 on oil and gas properties.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 17, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FIRST FEDERAL BANK NH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE AGENCY TO INVESTIGATE SALE OF MILK
description: The State Investigation Commission has begun an inquiry on how the Department of Agriculture and Markets regulates the selling of milk in New York State, according to the commission chairman.

title: For a Better Understanding of Mexican Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: MECHTRON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NAVRATILOVA WINS FINAL
description: Martina Navratilova applied constant pressure with her trademark serve-and-volley game today to register a 7-5, 7-5 victory over Hana Mandlikova and capture the $150,000 Virginia Slims-Chicago tennis title.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL SAN FRANCISCO 49ERS VS. REDSKINS, at Washington, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 9 P.M.) HOCKEY DEVILS VS. RANGERS, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M. WPAT 930, 7:20 P.M.) TENNIS VIRGINIA SLIMS CHAMPIONSHIP, at Madison Square Garden, 6 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight)

title: INMAC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
No Verdict Yet In Mafia Trial
description: A third day of jury deliberations ended without a verdict yesterday in the Mafia commission trial.

title: Beech-Nut Challenged Gerber's Assertions
description: Gerber Products was one of the six advertisers who had challenges to their advertising assertions resolved in October by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. In two challenges, a competitor said Gerber had implied the use of ''all natural ingredients'' when such was not the case, while another said that pediatricians sought advice from the company.

title: 4 AT DORRIAN'S BAR ACCUSED OF SERVING ALCOHOL TO MINORS
description: Four employees of Dorrian's Red Hand, an Upper East Side bar where Jennifer Dawn Levin spent the hours before she was slain, were issued summons over the weekend for selling and serving liquor to minors, the police said.

title: Hiding Behind the Budget Mess
description: ''This year's budget fiasco'' proves something is terribly wrong, President Reagan says and he declares budget reform a legislative priority for 1987. He's certainly right about the fiasco part. Congress dawdled and dithered all year over appropriations, then patched together a trillion-dollar resolution filled with tricks that make the deficit look smaller than it will be.

title: AIDS Week in Connecticut
description: Connecticut is preparing for AIDS Prevention Week, which is to begin Monday and will emphasize discussions of the facts known about AIDS. Gov. William A. O'Neill set aside the week for the programs, including conferences and vigils, and has called for ''immediate, effective programs of information and prevention.'' State figures show the current number of adults diagnosed as suffering acquired immune deficiency syndrome in Connecticut has reached 311, of whom 189 have died.

title: BPI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BRAZILIAN VOTERS BACK RULING PARTY
description: The centrist party that for two decades led opposition to Brazil's military regime appeared today to have won a sweeping victory in this country's first national elections since civilian rule returned here last year.

title: Guidelines on Ethics, Inquiries on Election
description: Rules for Party LeadersWith the Federal racketeering case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, expected to go to the jury this week, the Democratic State Committee is about to consider new ethical guidelines for party leaders.

title: DEL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Net loss The company said it did not report fiscal 1986 fourth quarter share earnings because the weighted computation of shares outstanding was performed at year-end only.

title: SHULTZ DECLARES HE OPPOSES GIVING MORE ARMS TO IRAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was opposed to sending any more military equipment to Iran, but he conceded that he could not speak for the Reagan Administration on this issue.

title: AMERICAN LEARNING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There are no 1985 share earnings because the company went public in August.

title: S. B. Sheinwald Wed To Cheryl Sue Gelfand
description: Cheryl Sue Gelfand, a daughter of Deputy Inspector and Mrs. Elson Gelfand of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Bert Sheinwald, a son of Sondra A. Sheinwald of Woodridge, N.Y., and the late Norman Sheinwald. Rabbi Robert Benjamin performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: MUSIC: LIZ STORY, PIANIST
description: THE so-called new-age musical movement of pop-folk-classical hybrids has already produced a major star in the solo pianist George Winston. Liz Story, who appeared at the Bottom Line last Tuesday evening, also offers new-age keyboard music that defies category, but it is somewhat more elevated and technically accomplished than Mr. Winston's folksy noodlings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1986
description: The World

title: TEXANS FOLLOW THE FOXHOUND'S SONG
description: There was a time not long ago when Hinkel Schillings, Bearkat Partin, Johnny Lightfoot and all the other fox hunters around here found themselves contemplating a notion as baffling and unnatural as dominoes without spots.

title: ASSAD REJECTES TERROR CHARGES AND STRESSES FIGHT FOR OCCUPIED LAND
description: President Hafez al-Assad rejected charges today about Syrian complicity in terrorism and vowed that his country would continue its support for the struggle to recover Arab land occupied by Israel.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $212,148 and net realized capital gains of $5,418 for the quarter, and the 9-month includes net realized capital gains of $66,900.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz on whether he could speak for the Administration on Iran. [ A1:6. ]

title: FAMILY BACK IN U.S. AFTER SOVIET TRIP
description: An immigrant family that returned to their Soviet homeland a week ago arrived back in the United States last night, saying they was here to stay.

title: Hofstra Goes to Playoffs
description: Hofstra was one of four Eastern teams selected yesterday for the Division III football playoffs that begin Saturday. The Flying Dutchmen, who lost only to Wagner in 10 games this season, will be the host team against Montclair State (9-1), while Union (9-0) plays Ithaca (9-0) at Schenectady, N.Y.

title: LONDON HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PERU ECONOMY BOUNCES BACK
description: This month, in order to meet an unexpected surge in domestic demand for textiles, the Peruvian Government struck a blow against its new export drive by suspending all cotton sales abroad. Yet, it announced the decision quite cheerfully.

title: Daughter Of Cuomo Hurt
description: The 24-year-old daughter of Governor Cuomo received minor injuries in a car accident at an Albany intersection Saturday night, the police said.

title: The Secret Agent
description: Who is this fellow that Ronald Reagan trusts more than his Cabinet secretaries? History will want to know what sort of man was able to persuade his President to turn away from a lifetime of straight dealing.

title: CORPORATIONS GEAR UP FOR CONSTITUTION PARTY
description: At a recent dinner party Warren E. Burger asked the president of a big food company in mock seriousness why it did not put a copy of the Constitution into every box of its breakfast food.

title: The White House Network
description: The White House informed the television networks Friday which of its representatives would appear on each of yesterday's news and interview programs, part of a continuing circumstance that has chafed the programming executives.

title: CLOSING ARGUMENTS DUE IN CITY CORRUPTION TRIAL
description: Closing arguments in the Federal trial stemming from New York City's corruption scandal and the judge's instructions, all to be heard this week, could influence the outcome as much as the testimony that preceded them.

title: Head of Ansa Software Likes Building Business
description: In joining Ansa Software last week as president and chief executive, Ronald S. Posner says he is actually indulging in his favorite hobby: building a new business.

title: Catching Up
description: * Jeff George, widely rated the nation's top freshman football player when he became Purdue's quarterback this fall, is nearing the end of a season that has been little short of outright disaster: a 2-8 record for the Boilermakers (whose only victims have been the outmanned teams from Ball State and Northwestern), one concussion, one back injury that kept him on the sideline for a fifth straight game when Purdue met Iowa on Saturday, and 12 interceptions in the three and a half games he's been able to play. You'd think all that would be enough for one year, but there's more.

title: MUSIC: CARLA BLEY'S SEXTET
description: ALTHOUGH Carla Bley has ostensibly been a member of the jazz avant-garde for the last 20 years, her compositions, arrangements and performances with her big band have reached out and communicated with listeners who have heard in her work similarities to the big-band traditions established by Duke Ellington and Gil Evans.

title: CLAVELL: KING OF COMMERCIAL FICTION?
description: On the day ''Whirlwind'' was published, James Clavell expressed relief that one of the most talked-about books of recent times - a book for which he was paid a record-breaking $5 million advance - was now largely behind him.

title: MICHAEL CROFT
description: Michael Croft, who founded Britain's National Youth Theater 30 years ago, died Saturday at Whittington Hospital in London of a heart attack, hospital officials said. He was 64 years old.

title: CALGENE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the revenue gains resulted from expansion of its funded product development corporate partnerships; product revenue from Agro Ingredients, acquired in May; and an increase in interest income resulting from the company's initial public offering in July.

title: WHERE THIEVES AND BETTER TIMES ARE AWAITED
description: It was, one recent afternoon, the usual noisy, smoky scene in the lawyers' lounge at the District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide on Wednesday misidentified the director of ''Passover,'' a comedy being presented by the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y. The director is Louis W. Scheeder; Stanley Brechner is the company's artistic director.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCOTT INSTRUMENTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Meeting Seeks to End Fighting in Sri Lanka
description: A seven-nation meeting of South Asian national leaders opened today with intense efforts by India and Sri Lanka to resolve the protracted ethnic strife in Sri Lanka.

title: An Embassy Protest
description: Members of A.F.L.-C.I.O. building trades unions will hold a protest demonstration outside the Japanese Embassy at noon today in an effort to promote more hiring of union workers at a Toyota plant being built in Kentucky. The unions are considering another such rally in Lexington, Ky., on Dec. 7, the anniversary of the 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: HOW STATE WILLS SPEND NEW ENVIROMENT FUND
description: On Election Day, New York voters approved, by a 2-to-1 margin, a $1.45 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act, which will provide $1.2 billion for the cleanup of hazardous waste sites and $250 million to buy forest land and help urban parks. Following is a series of questions and answers on how that money will be spent: The Cleanup Q. How many hazardous waste sites are there?

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a gain of $620,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the quarter and year.

title: Washington Watch; Plea by Zaire On Debt Seen
description: ZAIRE, the third most populous country in Africa, has been praised by both the United States and the International Monetary Fund as a prime example of a country willing to bite the bullet of economic reform.

title: Gillette Silent On Revlon Bid
description: The Gillette Company said yesterday that it had no comment on an unsolicited takeover bid for $65 a share, or a total of $4.1 billion, made by the Revlon Group last week.

title: Boats Disqualified After Collision
description: Both South Australia and Steak'n Kidney were disqualified by a protest committee tonight in the aftermath of a collision during an America's Cup preliminary race Saturday.

title: JAPANESE CHIP MAKERS FALTER
description: For the first time since Japan became a world power in microelectronics, its semiconductor industry has badly faltered, amid evidence that Japanese manufacturers are now paying the price for the strategies they used to defeat many of their American competitors.

title: EDISON CONTROL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BURGUNDY WINE PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: Prices of new Burgundy wines fell by up to 50 percent, and sometimes more, today at the 126th annual auction of wine from the vineyards of the Hospice de Beaune. This should mean lower prices for the consumer when this wine is bottled next year and starts to come on the market.

title: Consumer Fraud Has a Happy Viennese Ending
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF SAN FRANCISCO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WALL STREET IS STILL A TAKEOVER BATTLEGROUND
description: While speculators may be more cautious in the wake of the Government's action against Ivan F. Boesky on Friday, Wall Street is likely to remain active in the next few weeks.

title: 500 PACK A RURAL GYM FOR HUNTHAUSEN'S MASS
description: To offer mass today, Archbishop Raymond G. Hunthausen walked down an aisle in a packed high school gymnasium as babies cried and flashbulbs popped.

title: Airline Vote Is Extended
description: People Express Inc., the financially troubled airline, said yesterday that it had extended until today the deadline for obtaining creditor approval of a change in the airline's debt structure, the second such extension in a week. Under the terms of the airline's acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation, 85 percent of the company's debenture holders must approve of the changes.

title: FOR 'GOYA' OPENING, CAPITAL BECOMES A BRILLIANT CANVAS
description: ''Goyamania'' seized Washington this weekend as Queen Sofia of Spain and a host of notables from Madrid, London, San Francisco and points in between gathered here for Saturday night's world premiere of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Goya'' at the Washington Opera.

title: BRIEFS
description: DEBT

title: A Trade War With Canada?
description: Nowhere outside the United States is there more consternation over this country's increasing protectionist temper than in neighboring Canada. While American farmers, textile manufacturers, automakers and others are in economic trouble, much of it induced by cheaper foreign imports from overseas, the world's richest and most mutually beneficial trade relationship - between Canada and the United States - is being dangerously strained by the protectionist backlash.

title: FUGITIVE LOVERS ARE BACK IN JAIL
description: A pair of fugitive lovers, reunited in a helicopter escape from prison, were tracked down by agents who monitored a checking account used to pay for their wedding rings, the authorities said today.

title: No Retreat Is Seen on Bank's Bid
description: The management of the First Interstate Bancorp is expected to recommend to its board of directors on Monday that the company proceed with its bid to acquire the BankAmerica Corporation, numerous industry sources said this weekend.

title: NATO'S COOPERATIVE APPROACH ON WEAPONS DEVELOPMENT
description: In an experiment in cooperative weapons development, European and United States arms manufacturers are preparing to join forces to design and build advanced military equipment that includes airborne radar and ''clever'' shells that hunt their target.

title: U.S. Office For French Agency
description: APPARENTLY unable to find a good stateside acquisition deal, Roux Seguela Cayzac & Goudard, France's third-largest agency, is opening an office of its own here today with a nucleus of high-priced American talent.

title: FIRST FAMILY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes a one-time charge of $2,550,000 from store closings.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1986
description: The Boesky Case

title: MUBARAK STRESSES EFFORT FOR FUTURE
description: President Hosni Mubarak today acknowledged the overwhelming economic challenges facing Egypt but spoke with pride of building ''from scratch'' institutions ranging from a sewer system to a free press.

title: LIFE AT THE TOP MOVES UP IN FILLY PICTURE
description: Life at the Top ran herself into the muddled 3-year-old filly championship picture with a front-running victory over her elders in the $233,600 Ladies Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: GV MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company had no revenue in the year-ago quarter and 9 months.

title: Again, the Imperium
