description: Day by day we learn more about the web of deceit and folly spun by the Reagan White House. And day by day the real import of the Iran affair - the abuse of the office of President - looks more dangerous.

title: Full Selection of Treasury Bills Due
description: Treasury financing this week includes new bill issues due in 3, 6 and 12 months, as well as two-year notes. Also, dealers in Government securities expect the Treasury to announce plans this week for a five-year note auction Nov. 26 of about $8.25 billion.

title: WEST SIDE SITES TO BE WEIGHED AS LANDMARKS
description: Sumptuous limestone row houses cascading regally toward Riverside Park, a movie theater whose billboard facade epitomizes Art Deco exuberance, a suave little office building that predates mid-Manhattan's glass towers by two decades - these and more than 100 other Upper West Side buildings will be considered tomorrow for landmark status.

title: REPORT SAYS SOUTH STILL LAGS IN EDUCATION AND JOBS
description: Despite its glittery cities and new suburban sprawl, the South remains the nation's poorest and most illiterate region, and still must do more to improve the quality of its public education and to bring new jobs and skills to small towns and rural areas.

title: AFRICA OPENING DOOR TO MORE AIDS RESEARCH
description: In a dramatic reversal, some African nations are beginning to acknowledge the impact of AIDS and to allow international experts to visit so they can track the spread of the disease closely and give advice about preventive steps.

title: WHO GETS TO SWITCH THE CHANNELS?
description: IT all started with the garage door.

title: EMPI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $57,000.

title: OLIVER'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ST. MARK'S 'A FREE PLACE,' CELEBRATES ITS REBUILDING
description: The first winter after the fire, the young workers had to shovel the snow out of the sanctuary of St. Mark's-in-the-Bowery Church. The roof had fallen in and only the walls and the great steeple remained.

title: GIANTS SNEAK BY, 22-20; ALLEGRE KICK IS DIFFERENCE
description: Good teams find ways to win. The Giants, who have established themselves as a good team, found a way to win today, even though their defense was generous and Joe Morris's running was ordinary.

title: Market Place; Street Awaits Boesky Impact
description: HOW will the stock market react today to the news - announced late Friday afternoon -that Ivan F. Boesky, Wall Street's largest speculator in takeover stocks, has agreed to pay a $100 million penalty for illegal insider trading?

title: FILM CELEBRATES BBC'S 50TH BIRTHDAY
description: ON Nov. 2, 1936, the British Broadcasting Corporation began the world's first regularly scheduled television service. One newspaper, The Daily Telegraph, sniffed: ''Novelty appeal will soon pass. What then?'' The answer: just about everything, from entertainment and news to sports and the arts. Whether for good or ill, ''the Box'' is undoubtedly here to stay. And the BBC, sometimes called the Beeb or Auntie, is busy these days celebrating its 50th birthday, even as a few clouds gather on its horizon. Among other events, a special exhibition at the Museum of Broadcasting will run through the end of January. And Channel 13 is setting aside several Monday evenings at 11 o'clock for a sampler of BBC productions.

title: NAVRATILOVA NOW WITHOUT PEER OR RIVAL
description: SHE is playing against a faceless opponent now, a young phenom in a ponytail or braids who will emerge in the coming years and invite comparisons to the best tennis players of all time. Or perhaps Martina Navratilova has peered across the net at Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini, and determined that they have the stuff of champions. It is to her advantage then, to stunt their growth while she still can.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID SOUTHERN LEBANON
description: Israeli warplanes attacked suspected Palestinian guerrilla bases near the southern Lebanese port of Sidon today, and a Palestinian statement said there had been many casualties and extensive damage to property.

title: Bridge: For Light Opening Bidder, Hopeful Move Can Pay Off
description: An old argument, never likely to be resolved, concerns the precise standards that are appropriate for a minimum opening bid of one.

title: Washington Watch; Proxy Process Studied
description: The United Shareholders Association has commissioned a study of the corporate proxy process.

title: Trial Business Is Done Much Too Leisurely
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS SNEAK BY, 22-20
description: In what appeared beforehand on paper to be their easiest game of the season, the Jets were forced today to battle to one of their grittiest victories.

title: State Tax Cuts Asked by Panel
description: A business lobbying group called yesterday for state tax cuts to prevent Federal tax changes from raising the state taxes of New Yorkers.

title: THEATER: 'ROOTS,' FAMILY ON A FARM IN ENGLAND
description: IN ''Roots,'' Arnold Wesker gives us a bickering, baffled, sometimes belligerent, always believable family of farm workers in the north of England. His achievement here is to show the Bryants simultaneously as individuals, as a family and as victims of an economic and social system far beyond their comprehension.

title: One Left From No. 2
description: ''Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio?'' Well, Tommy Amaker's rendition of ''Mrs. Robinson'' may substitute the lyrics, ''Where have you gone Johnny Dawkins, Mark Alarie, Jay Bilas and David Henderson?''

title: ALLEGRE TAKES IT IN STRIDE
description: Raul Allegre was not surprised that he had kicked five field goals today. He was not surprised that his 33-yard field goal with 12 seconds remaining gave the Giants a 22-20 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: CUTS IN RESEARCH FUNDS SEEN IMPERILING NUCLEAR SAFETY STUDY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission may be unable to complete a key reassessment of the risk of severe accidents in a satisfactory manner because of cuts in its research budget, according to an internal memorandum by the agency's executive director.

title: I.B.M. Site Is Bombed In West Germany
description: A bomb explosion heavily damaged an International Business Machines Corporation research center today, but caused no casualties, the police said.

title: GONZALEZ, IN CUBA CITES ACCORD
description: Spain and Cuba are in agreement on such issues as Central American peace efforts and the Falkland Islands, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain said here today after long talks with the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.

title: William B. Meyer Dies at 61; Headed Real Estate Concern
description: William Blair Meyer, a New York real estate developer and president of the Cord Meyer Company, died of cancer Saturday at the home of his daughter in Katonah, N.Y., where he was recuperating from a hospital stay. He was 61 years old and had residences in Manhattan, Southampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Mike Scott of Houston was voted the National League Cy Young Award last week after a season in which he had an 18-10 won-lost record. Have any other pitchers earned the award during a season in which they failed to win 20 games?

title: JETS STOP ISLANDERS, 3-1
description: Ray Neufeld scored off a scramble near the goalmouth in the third period tonight to give the Winnipeg Jets to a 3-1 victory over the Islanders.

title: HOMELESS IN THE CITY: A DAY ON THE STREETS
description: John-Ed Croft calls them ''cardboard condominiums.''

title: Accident Causes Amtrak Delays
description: An Amtrak passenger train struck an unoccupied truck that was parked alongside the track yesterday, delaying by several hours passengers traveling to Niagara Falls, the authorities said.

title: BEARS STRUGGLE PAST FALCONS, 13-10
description: Mike Tomczak bounced back from a dismal first half and the Chicago defense held Atlanta without a first down for the first 23 minutes of the second half today as the Bears rallied from a 10-0 deficit and defeated the Falcons, 13-10.

title: Washington-to-Atlanta Shift for Thompson
description: J. Walter Thompson, U.S.A., is shipping all of its accounts in the Washington office to its Atlanta office and turning the office in the capital into what it calls a field service office that can maintain contact with accounts, but not create advertising.

title: Blood Sport
description: Given the chaos into which the game degenerated, it's hardly surprising that the rival coaches aren't agreed on exactly what happened. Just about all that's certain is that an early-round match of the N.A.I.A.'s national soccer tournament was marred by a series of brawls that left several players bleeding and sent two to the hospital, taking the trend toward belligerent play in amateur soccer a number of fights and injuries beyond the previous pale.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: LEGAL HURDLES SEEN IN EFFORT FOR DISCLOSURE OF IRAN AFFAIR
description: Congressional investigators would have an uphill legal battle if they sought to force President Reagan's national security adviser or other White House aides to testify about arms shipments to Iran, legal experts said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Nuclear Study Imperiled Research budget cuts may hamper a Federal reassessment of the risk of severe nuclear accidents, an internal agency memorandum said.

title: Officials Look for Cause Of Illnesses at Banquet
description: Eighty-nine people at a banquet became so sick they had to be hospitalized, and the police said today that it could be days before health officials determined if food poisoning was the cause.

title: FEAR SLOWS AIDS FIGHT IN SUBURBS
description: AIDS, until recently seen mainly as a disease of the cities, has become a serious and growing problem in the communities surrounding New York, according to health officials.

title: SPARROW ROLE IS LESSENED
description: Just as it was too early to condemn the Knicks completely, it is not yet time to praise them. Bill Cartwright is emerging as the team's essential player. Patrick Ewing, though he still longs to play center, is feeling more comfortable at forward. Kenny Walker, the rookie forward, is growing confident and stronger. And Gerald Wilkins is making fewer mistakes while becoming the team's liveliest performer.

title: PRODUCER WILL HEAD FOX STUDIO
description: Leonard Goldberg, a longtime television executive and producer, was named president and chief operating officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation today.

title: Loyola Eliminates Virginia in Soccer
description: Loyola of Baltimore scored the only goal of the game on a header by Chris Webbert with 13 minutes 59 seconds to play to eliminate Virginia from the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament at Charlottesville, Va., yesterday.

title: Reform at Human Resources Depends on Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: BUSONI'S 'TURANDOT'
description: At its best, Ferruccio Busoni's music transcends worldly tumult to evoke a vaporous aura of mystery and serenity. Simultaneously learned and original, it makes its appeal to the mind rather than to the passions. Its movement is stately and formal, its humor mostly ironic. In the operas, Busoni's characters function as symbols in musical allegories rather than as vital, full-blooded human beings involved in vital, full-blooded human pursuits. It seems fitting, somehow, that this questing, deeply serious creator should have chosen ''Dr. Faustus'' as his last opera - and that he should have left it incomplete.

title: FIESTA BOWL, NBC SCORE NO. 1 COUP
description: The Sunkist Fiesta Bowl and NBC achieved college football's biggest commercial coup in years when the University of Miami agreed to meet Penn State in that game Friday night, Jan. 2, if both teams finish the regular season undefeated. The game would be for the national championship.

title: DINOSAUR FOSSILS FOUND IN ANTARCTICA
description: WITH the first discovery of dinosaur fossils in Antarctica, now it can be said that the great reptiles in their prime were a truly global phenomenon. Their fossils have now been found in all the earth's large land masses.

title: KEY RATES
Delay in Rooney Case
description: Rooney, Pace Inc. said that it had received a stay of the sanctions imposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission pending its appeal of a ruling related to Sequential Information Systems Inc. The S.E.C. had ruled that the firm could undertake no underwritings for two months and no conditional underwritings for six months. In addition, Randolph K. Pace, the firm's president, was barred from association with any broker dealer for three months.

title: SATURN'S MAKERS PLANS SLOW BUILDUP OF SALES
description: Saturn Corporation cars will probably be sold only in California and other areas with high import penetration when they are first introduced in the early 1990's, officials of the General Motors Corporation subsidiary said today.

title: WINDMILL HITS ROAD FOR A NEW START
description: Motorists on Northern Boulevard did a double take yesterday in Douglaston, Queens. Heading west on the boulevard was a windmill.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Greetings To J. Walter Thompson
description: The Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. is getting all of the advertising business from the American Greetings Corporation of Cleveland.

title: 2 Mortgage Offers Top $590 Million
description: Two offerings of collateralized mortgage obligations totaling nearly $600 million were made yesterday. Both issues are backed by Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation participation certificates and rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: EASTMAN KODAK TO BUY FOX PHOTO
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, moving to safeguard its basic photographic business, agreed yesterday to acquire Fox Photo Inc. for about $95.5 million.

title: The Voice, and Ears, of America
description: When Charles Wick took over the U.S. Information Agency five years ago, his commitment to fighting Communism was clearer than his commitment to advancing truth. To his credit, he has come to see that the two go together. Mr. Wick is talking to the Russians about some interesting reciprocal radio. If he can enlarge the terms of the discussion, he could help improve a relationship too often shaped by misinformation.

title: Ted Bundy Wins Stay From U.S. Appeals Court
description: A Federal appellate panel in Atlanta early today halted the execution of Theodore Robert Bundy less than seven hours before the suspected mass murderer was to die for the slaying of a 12-year-old girl.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: New Ideas for the M.T.A. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority today will update its citizens advisory committee on long-range plans to improve service and will seek ideas from the public. Some chief concerns are low ridership on certain subway lines and parking problems at many commuter rail stations of Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road. Noon, M.T.A. headquarters, fifth floor, 347 Madison Avenue, Manhattan.

title: IRANIAN OFFICIALS PORTRAYED AS UNITED IN THEIR EFFORT TO EXPLOIT U.S. ARMS FUROR
description: Contrasting statements by Iranian officials about secret American arms shipments to Iran do not indicate basic disagreements, diplomats here and other Iran experts believe. On the contrary, they said, Iranian officials seem united in their eagerness to exploit the controversy for domestic and foreign consumption.

title: Make Insiders Think Twice
description: Competitors used to wonder whether Ivan Boesky was really better at the high-risk game of stock arbitrage, or just luckier. Neither, it turns out. He won by rigging the wheel. He has confessed to illegal insider trading, has paid a record $100 million in penalties and still faces a possible prison sentence for a felony.

title: 8,000 Strike Delco Indiana Plant
description: Nearly 8,000 members of the United Auto Workers went on strike today at the Delco Electronics plant in a dispute over transferring some work to operations in Mexico.

title: Business and the Law; Employer Role In Insider Suits
description: THE $50 million damage fund that is to be created out of Ivan F. Boesky's illegal profits should prove a tempting target for a wide variety of shareholders and companies claiming losses because of Mr. Boesky's insider trading.

title: PARTIAL BAN IS URGED ON FLIGHTS IN GRAND CANYON
description: The Interior Department proposed today that aircraft be barred from part of the Grand Canyon, but it stopped short of seeking to ban all flights below the rim.

title: UNION VALLEY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $281,000 from termination of a pension plan.

title: TAFT TO SELL 5 STATIONS AT A LOSS
description: As evidence of the decline in the value of independent television stations, Taft Broadcasting has agreed to sell its five independent stations to TVX Broadcast Group Inc. for $240 million, or about $300 million less than the company originally expected the stations would fetch.

title: BEAR STEARNS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary items from the creation of an irrevocable trust to provide for the redemption of notes for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the year-ago figures include the results of Bear, Stearns & Co., the predecessor partnership, restated as if the partnership had been conducted as a corporation for those periods.

title: ARGUMENTS HEARD IN IRAN ARMS TRIAL
description: A Federal Judge in New York deferred a decision yesterday as to whether Government documents relating to arms shipments to Iran would be subpoenaed as evidence in a trial.

title: 700 CABS SNARL TRAFFIC IN PROTEST ON FARES
description: More than 700 taxicab drivers blocked highways and streets in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens in a slow-moving rush-hour parade yesterday morning. The demonstration heightened tensions in a longstanding dispute between the taxi industry and Mayor Koch, who threatened to punish the participants.

title: ALATENN RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEALTHCARE SERVICES OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: SCITEX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: INVENTORIES SHRINK 0.3%
description: Business sales soared 2.9 percent in September, the biggest rise in more than six years, while business inventories shrank a smaller-than-expected three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Quadriplegic Wins Boardwalk Right
description: A quadriplegic woman who has earned thousands of dollars by playing an electronic keyboard with her tongue won the right yesterday to solicit donations on the Boardwalk.

title: Lomas & Nettleton In Deal for Mnet
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation, one of the country's largest mortgage banking concerns, said it had agreed to buy Mnet, a retail financial services company, for $300 million in cash and securities. The companies said that the deal was subject to approval of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: E&B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Guardian of Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST INTERSTATE PUSHES BID
description: The First Interstate Bancorp today decided to press ahead with its efforts to acquire the ailing BankAmerica Corporation.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3,042,000.

title: Brazilian President Confers With Cabinet
description: President Jose Sarney conferred today with senior ministers to discuss important economic changes after a landslide Government victory in national elections.

title: Swiss Jobless Rate 0.7%
description: Switzerland's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate stood at seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, unchanged from September, the Government reported today. It was the lowest October rate in four years. A year ago, the rate was eight-tenths of 1 percent.

title: HOSTAGE ENVOY IS CRITICAL OF PUBLICITY
description: Terry Waite, the Anglican Church envoy involved in hostage negotiations in the Middle East, said today that his task had been made ''immeasurably more difficult'' by the disclosure of American arms shipments to Iran. But he said he did not personally feel he had been exploited by the Reagan Administration.

title: INSIDE
description: An Echo of World War II The Supreme Court agreed to review a case involving Federal liability to pay damages to Japanese-Americans interned in World War II.

title: A.T.&T. IS SEEKING TO LOWER RATES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had asked the Federal Communications Commission to let it reduce the price of interstate long-distance telephone service by 8.1 percent on average, beginning Jan. 1.

title: PERSICO, HIS SON AND 6 OTHERS GET LONG TERMS AS COLOMBO GANGSTERS
description: Long prison sentences were imposed yesterday on Carmine Persico, his son and six others convicted in June as leaders of the Colombo family of the Mafia.

title: SAGE ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: TAKEOVER STOCKS FALL SHARPLY
description: The shock of the widening insider trading scandal created a somber mood on Wall Street yesterday, with stocks involved in takeover situations being sold wildly while the bulk of the market moved lower in a more gentle fashion.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,281,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: EMPLOYERS GET PARTIAL VICTORY ON RELIGIOUS LEAVE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that employers may satisfy their duty to accommodate their employees' need to observe religious holidays by making any reasonable proposal that avoids conflicts with the employees' work obligations.

title: LEFTISTS ON STRIKE IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: Leftist activists entered the political struggle today with a general strike that shut down some public transport and slowed work at some factories in Manila and other areas outside the capital.

title: SOVIET FAMILY, BACK IN JERSEY, REBUILDING LIVES
description: After a brief and fitful odyssey to their native Soviet Union, members of the Gonta family returned to their sparse apartment here today and began reconstructing the lives they had abandoned a week ago.

title: Marriott in Polish Deal
description: The Marriott Hotels Corporation has joined with the Polish airline LOT and an Austrian company to establish the first joint venture in Poland under a law passed last April, the official P.A.P. press agency reported. The joint venture will complete the construction of the LOT terminal in Warsaw. The joint venture law was passed last April to attract Western capital.

title: Fairchild Jet Plan
description: Fairchild Industries said it was seeking a partner among aerospace companies for its T-46 trainer jet project.

title: Blast at U.S. Agency In California Injures 2
description: A small bomb in a bouquet of flowers exploded in a downtown building today, injuring two women and damaging an office of the General Services Administration, the police said.

title: 600 Unionists Rally At Rutgers for Raises
description: About 600 members of three Rutgers University employee unions walked off their jobs and rallied here yesterday to protest what they called stalled contract talks.

title: British Air Net Is Down 29.9%
description: British Airways reported today that earnings declined by 29.9 percent in the first half from the period a year ago, in part because of fears of terrorism.

title: U.S. MOVES TO BLOCK LAWYER
description: The Justice Department today moved to disqualify the defense attorney for a reputed organized-crime figure because of a potential conflict of interest and court-ordered electronics surveillance in the lawyer's offices.

title: Belgian-Born Writer Wins Goncourt
description: Michel Host, a Belgian-born writer who teaches Spanish through correspondence courses, was named winner today of the Prix Goncourt.

title: REAGAN SAYS IRAN WON'T GET MORE ARMS
description: President Reagan said today that he had ''absolutely no plans'' to send more arms to Iran, and the White House urged United States allies to refrain from shipping weapons to Teheran as well.

title: G.M. and Ford To Cut Output
description: The nation's two largest auto makers said today that they would cut fourth-quarter production from earlier estimates.

title: MARIEL BOATLIFT FIGURE ORDERED DEPORTED TO CUBA
description: The man who touched off the Mariel boatlift from Cuba six years ago by ramming the bus he was driving through the gates of the Peruvian Embassy in Havana has been ordered deported from the United States by a Federal immigration judge here.

title: SYRIA IS IMPLICATED
description: The trial of two Palestinians charged in a bombing here opened today with a reading by the judge of pretrial testimony implicating Syria and its embassy in East Berlin.

title: Gillette Sues To Stop Revlon
description: The Gillette Company filed suit in Federal District Court in Boston yesterday in an attempt to block the Revlon Group Inc. from buying more Gillette stock. Revlon and its chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, already own 14 percent of Gillette's shares, and on Friday announced a $4.12 billion takeover bid for that company.

title: THE DANCE: ROGER TOLLE AND TROUPE
description: ROGER TOLLE AND DANCERS offered a gentle program Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. Yet Mr. Tolle's dances were not gentle in the same way. One was gently sad; two others were gently happy.

title: NEW TACTICS TRANSFORM WILDLIFE CONSERVATION
description: THIS year, some 90,000 tusks of African elephants are being exported to Asia for carving into figurines and jewelry.

title: IN ANTARCTIC ICE, CLUES IN QUEST FOR LIFE ON MARS
description: PERENNIALLY frozen Antarctic lakes with little green patches of ice are helping scientists develop new ways to look for life on Mars.

title: Maleeva Wins In Straight Sets
description: This is the way the game is played on the public courts, where the nets sometimes sag in the middle and weeds grow through the cracks on the baseline. Tennis can be an adventure when a couple of recreational players meet on a Saturday afternoon and the advantage belongs to the one receiving serve.

title: Big Pistachio Crop Seen
description: The California pistachio crop is forecast at a record 70 million pounds, more than two and a half times last year's harvest, the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burger King Corp., Miami, a subsidiary of the Pillsbury Co., named Anthony M. Lavely president of Quik Wok, an oriental fast-food chain that is also part of the Pillsbury company.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $361,000 for the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $659,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The company said results include provisions of $5 million in the latest quarter and $8 million in the latest 9-month for future operating losses of an unconsolidated subsidiary and Chapter 11 costs. The company said results include charges of $4,360,000 in the year-ago quarter and $18,051,000 in the year-ago 9-month for equity in unconsolidated subsidary's loss.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect dividends and discounts on non-convertible preferred stock for the 9 months ended Sept 30, 1986, and 1985 of $1,095,000 and $964,000, respectively; for the third quarter of 1986 and 1985 these amounted to $365,000 and $321,000, respectively.

title: Laurence, Charles Adds Several Active Brands
description: Nine months ago Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson was assigned a new products job by Thompson Medical Company.

title: NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLICE TAKING ACTION ON BARS SERVING YOUTHS
description: A crackdown on under-age drinking in New York City bars has generated scores of police summonses this fall and a new climate of caution among those who serve liquor to young people, state and city officials said yesterday.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
11 Down, 5 Down to Go
description: Now 0-11 after their loss to the Jets on Sunday, the Indianapolis Colts are on track to join a woefully select group.

title: Paris to Repay Part of Loan Made by Iran Under the Shah
description: France announced today that it had agreed to repay Iran $330 million of a $1 billion loan made years ago by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Progress on Longshore Pact Is Reported in Philadelphia
description: Negotiators representing shippers and longshoremen reached agreement on several major issues today after union members agreed to extend their contract deadline to Friday, a union spokesman said.

title: ROCOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN CONSUMER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $225,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: DROPOUTS BY MINORITIES ARE TERMED 'EPIDEMIC'
description: Dropout rates for minority students in New York State public schools have reached ''epidemic'' proportions, ranging as high as 62 percent for one group, according to a report released yesterday by a task force of black, Hispanic and American Indian educators.

title: BAKER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1,392,000 for the quarter and extraordinary income of $88,608,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included writedowns of $3.5 million for the quarter and $15.5 million for the 9 months on oil and gas properties. c-Included a writedown of $12.4 million for the quarter and 9 months on oil and gas property.

title: Virgil and 'Star Wars'
description: Everybody needs a motto, no less the Army Strategic Defense Command, which is working on President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' program.

title: Pregnant Women Warned on Vitamin
description: The State Health Commissioner yesterday disclosed evidence suggesting that pregnant women should avoid ''excessive'' doses of Vitamin A and should take supplements of the vitamin ''only after consultation with a physician and after a full dietary history.''

title: ALZHEIMER'S: PROGRESS IN THE MIDST OF DESPAIR
description: WHEN scientists battling untreatable diseases become excited about small gains and preliminary findings, the despair and urgency felt by victims and their relatives can lead them to greet the news with perhaps unrealistic expectations.

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1 million and $1.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: ALL EYES ON SHULTZ
description: In talking publicly about the possibility he might resign, Secretary of State George P. Shultz appears to have swayed White House policy on Iran in his direction, at least for the moment.

title: Bloom Assigned Brands With $5 Million Billings
description: An interesting potpourri of products is dropping into the cornucopia of brands served by the New York office of the Bloom Agency as the result of the acquisition of the Gold Seal Company by Airwick Industries, already a client.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: A Blow to Rights in Cuba
description: In August, Antonio Frias Sosa, a 17-year-old student who worked for the Cuban Human Rights Committee, was arrested in Havana by Fidel Castro's security police. His crime: possession of a copy of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and 25 United States dollars. Hours after the arrest, his corpse was delivered to his parents with the explanation that he had committed suicide.

title: HELM RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $114,000. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $117,000 for the quarter and $299,000 for the 9 months. d-After net from discontinued operations of $40,000 and an extraordinary credit of $200,000.

title: Interco Makes Bid To Buy Lane Co.
description: The Lane Company said that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer valued at $482 million from Interco Inc., a diversified consumer products company based in St. Louis. Lane, a furniture maker based in Altavista, Va., disclosed the offer despite a letter from Interco stating that that if the offer was disclosed prematurely Interco would feel free to withdraw it.

title: M.B.I.A. Will Revamp Into Single Organization
description: The Municipal Bond Insurance Association, the largest insurer of tax-exempt bonds, is planning a corporate reorganization to create a single company to replace the current association of five large insurance companies.

title: PRETORIA POLICE DISPERSE G.M. STRIKERS
description: South African policemen used dogs and whips today to break up a gathering of striking workers at the General Motors plant in Port Elizabeth, witnesses said.

title: Israel Sets a Trial Date For Nazi Camp Guard
description: An Israeli Supreme Court judge today set Jan. 19 as the opening date for the trial of John Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian-born American, on war-crime charges, his defense lawyer, Mark O'Connor, said.

title: Northrop Cancels F-20 Fighter Plane
description: The Northrop Corporation, which recently lost a bid to sell its F-20 fighter to the Air Force, said today that it would halt spending on the plane and write off about $250 million on the program this year.

title: DOCTOROW AND LOPEZ WIN U.S. BOOK AWARDS
description: E. L. Doctorow's ''World's Fair,'' a novel of boyhood during the Great Depression, and Barry Lopez's ''Arctic Dreams,'' an account of his travels in the Arctic Circle, won the American Book Awards last night as the best works of fiction and nonfiction published between Nov. 1, 1985 and Oct. 31, 1986.

title: Arrested as Drunk, Driver Had Had a Stroke
description: A man accused of driving while drunk was held in police custody for about 60 hours before doctors diagnosed him as having suffered a stroke, The Philadelphia Daily News reported today.

title: TOTAL ASSETS PROTECTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $101,454. c-Net loss

title: BALLOONIST HAS HIGH HOPES BUT NO ILLUSIONS
description: FIVE times since 1980, balloonists have tried and failed to make the first nonstop balloon flight around the world. Three of the veteran pilots who made these attempts have been killed in crashes, and many balloonists now believe that the lure of entering the record books is outweighed by the risk of disaster.

title: 'PENALTY PHASE' LOOKS AT PROBLEMS OF A JUDGE
description: WHAT are the responsibilities and limitations connected with being a criminal-courts judge? The question is explored with rare clarity in ''Penalty Phase,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 this evening. The script was written by Gale Patrick Hickman, himself a judge in Orange County, Calif. Obviously, Judge Hickman's firsthand experience has given him sharp insights into what he sees as the pertinent issues. His expertise, together with Tony Richardson's astute direction, make ''Penalty Phase'' an unusually absorbing dramatic venture.

title: Gap in Math Proof
description: Under intense questioning from topologists gathered in Berkeley, Calif., a British mathematician has acknowledged a ''gap'' in his announced proof of one of the most important outstanding problems of mathematics, the Poincare conjecture.

title: 150 Arrested in Kenya
description: More than 150 members of a Seventh-day Adventist splinter group have been arrested for preaching that the world will end Nov. 27 and urging children not to attend school and women to leave their husbands, the Kenya News Agency said today.

title: HERPES VIRUS IMPLICATED IN CLOGGING OF ARTERIES
description: The same herpes virus that causes fever blisters may produce changes in artery walls that could aid in the formation of artery-clogging deposits, a researcher said.

title: CENTRUST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Include a pre-tax gain of $155,677 on the sale of property and equipment. c-Include a pre-tax charge of $81,376 on the sale of property and equipment.

title: BRIAN O'NEILL
description: Brian O'Neill, a retired Air Force colonel who won the Distinguished Service Cross in World War II, died Friday at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, N.J. He was 75 years old and lived in Neptune.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CALL it the British invasion, 1986 style. Last week, the British designers Alistair Blair, Jasper Conran, Wendy Dagworthy, John Galliano and Katharine Hamnett were in New York selling their spring collections. But at night, at least, it seemed the English had come less for work than play.

title: THEATER: 'OH COWARD!' IS REVIVED
description: SIR NOEL COWARD'S talent to amuse came in diverse guises - from three-act comedies to autobiographies to offstage repartee - but he was perhaps at his wittiest in his theater songs. The musical anthology ''Oh Coward!,'' which was revived last night at the Helen Hayes Theater, demonstrates this linguistic limberness, Sir Noel's ability to match words with music behind a screen of wry emotional detachment.

title: HEALTH CLINICS EXPAND INTO INTERMEDIATE SCHOOLS
description: With complaints ranging from sore throats to thoughts of suicide, students at Intermediate School 52 in the Inwood section of Manhattan have been flocking for the last month to a new suite of pink-walled cubicles in the school - a modern medical clinic that contrasts with the dingy hallways and classrooms.

title: Zahringer Best Again
description: George Zahringer 3d, who made area history last year by becoming the first man to win the Met Amateur and Met Open in the same year, has made history again by becoming the first golfer to win the Metropolitan Golf Association's Amateur Player of the Year Award five times.

title: PRESIDENT SIGNS SWEEPING PUBLIC WORKS BILL
description: President Reagan today signed the first comprehensive public works bill in 16 years, significantly changing how harbor and waterway projects are selected and financed by increasing the share paid by state and local authorities.

title: NORTH KOREANS SAY KIM IL SUNG GREETED VISITORS
description: North Korea reported today that its leader, Kim Il Sung, greeted a foreign group this morning. The report, also carried by the Chinese press agency, was apparently intended to dispel rumors that Mr. Kim had been killed.

title: Lucky Stock Filing
description: The New York-based financier Asher B. Edelman and a group of companies he controls disclosed that they control a 5 percent stake, or 2.6 million shares, in Lucky Stores Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman said he ''intends to await further developments'' before deciding whether to contest Lucky's restructuring plan. Last week, the retail chain based in Dublin, Calif., said it would buy back 28 percent of its common stock for $40 a share in an attempt to block the bid. Mr. Edelman bought the stock at prices ranging from $24.50 to $35.75 a share, and he also holds options to buy 116,000 shares.

title: Leaders of Afghan Guerrillas Say Soviet Attacks Continue
description: Afghan guerrilla leaders here said today that Soviet and Afghan Government Air Force jets bombarded and rocketed rebel positions in Nangarhar Province today as ground forces pounded the insurgents' fortifications with artillery and tanks.

title: Bond Yields Fall Modestly
description: Yields on Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly yesterday, while short-term interest rates were unchanged to slightly higher.

title: Ford Says Profits Meet Projections
description: The Ford Motor Company's 1986 profits will be reduced by the loss of tax credits under the tax revision law, but will otherwise be in line with Wall Street analysts' projections, according to the company's president, Harold Poling. Analysts estimate that Ford's full-year earnings will average about $11.25 a share, or nearly $3 billion.

title: STATE STARTING AN INVESTIGATION OF CLASH AT MASSACHUSETTS U.
description: The chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Amherst today began a formal investigation of a fight two weeks ago involving several hundred students that may have been rooted in racial tensions.

title: ELECTION VICTOR ACCUSED ON PAST
description: A month ago, Mike McGrath was earning most of his income driving a cab, but since being elected Minnesota's next Treasurer he has been accused of hiding that fact and misrepresenting his career.

title: AT ABC, THE HANGOVER EXTENDS TO JAN. 2
description: NBC's plan to show the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl in prime time on Jan. 2 brings to mind an image: The scene is the waiting room of the United States Patent Office, where a man holding his invention of a long-burning candle is seated next to a man with a light bulb.

title: BONN AIDE FOCUSES ON A-ARMS LINKAGE
description: The White House and the West German Defense Ministry sought today to link nuclear arms-control proposals put forth by the Reagan Administration at the Iceland meeting with parallel steps to balance other forces of the Atlantic alliance and the Warsaw Pact nations.

title: 60 Are Killed in Snowstorm In Mountains of North India
description: At least 60 people have died in a sudden snowstorm that swept mountains above Srinagar in northern India, news agencies said today.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6.2 million for the quarter and $12.2 million for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 18, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on Chad at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: STUDYING PHILANTHROPY
description: AS a field of scholarship, philanthropy has been largely unmapped terrain -''the least understood aspect of our national life,'' says John G. Simon, a professor of international law at Yale University.

title: Hoops and Hurts
description: Magic Johnson complains that the Lakers' Sunday night victory over Sacramento was a little too physical: ''I'm going home to watch the Rams and Raiders highlights, and hope I see someone who got hit harder than I did.''

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,134,000 for the quarter and $11,441,000 for the 9 months and a loss of $4,760,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,373,000. d-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $5,444,000, a gain of $4,404,000 on the sale of discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $948,000. The were no share earnings for the year-ago 9 months because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income of $2,840,000 and $12,937,000 from equity in the company's Chromalloy American subsidiary for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and income of $5,016,000 and $10,921,000 from Sun's discontinued graphic arts business. The latest 9 months also included a loss of $3,719,000 from discontinued operations of Chromalloy American. c-Includes income of $450,000 and $568,000 from Chromalloy American for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss of $501,000 and $2,796,000 from certain discontinued operations of Chromalloy American for same periods, respectively, and income of $4,405,000 and $8,886,000 from the discontinued graphic arts business, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $111,000 for the quarter and year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and $1,504,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: TRANSIT CHIEF IS PROPOSING 5% CUT IN JOBS
description: The Transit Authority, seeking to improve subway service and consolidate underused bus routes, yesterday proposed an employee reorganization that would trim the agency's work force by 5 percent.

title: Cancer and Transfusions
description: A study of almost 500 patients with rectal or colon cancer has found that recurrence and death rates were higher among those who received transfusions of whole blood rather than red blood cells during surgery.

title: Advertising; TV Show Spawns Magazine
description: SOME people in the supermarket tabloid business will tell you that Robin Leach, host of the television show ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,'' was inspired by the tabloids to create the show. He had been a writer for two of them.

title: U.S. SAYS BRAZIL PASSES JAPAN ON IMPORT CURBS
description: Brazil has displaced Japan as the non-Communist country most closed to imports, according to a new inventory of global trade barriers by the Reagan Administration.

title: Back Aboard the 1988 Presidential Express
description: The 1988 Presidential campaign, interrupted for a few months by the 1986 elections, is back on track, and the likely contestants are once again fair game for those who set early expectations, handicap the aspirants and write the scenario for choosing the next President.

title: Study Looks At Bell Units
description: A consultant's report to the Justice Department on competition in the telephone business fails to make a strong case for ending court-imposed business restrictions on the regional Bell companies, trade and Government sources familiar with the study said.

title: Infallibly Poor
description: ''The church speaks infallibly on faith and morals. But it does not claim to speak infallibly on economics.'' So said Patrick Buchanan, the White House communications director, in subtle criticism of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops' pastoral letter on poverty and the economy.

title: GASTINEAU LOST UNTIL PLAYOFFS
description: Even the seemingly indestructible Mark Gastineau has been victimized by the Jets' extraordinary string of serious injuries.

title: 15 Arrested in C.I.A. Protest
description: The police arrested 15 people on the University of Colorado campus today as officers using nightsticks and the chemical Mace scuffled with hundreds of demonstrators trying to stop student recruitment by the Central Intelligence Agency. More than 300 people took part in the demonstrations, staged outside a campus building where C.I.A. recruiters interviewed 83 students.

title: VANBIESBROUCK EFFORT WASTED
description: Until there were 8 minutes 17 seconds left tonight, John Vanbiesbrouck had held the Devils to only one goal. The Rangers had two goals, and seemed on their way to a victory.

title: BLACK HILLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: AT RENAULT, LEADER WORKED FOR REVIVAL
description: Georges Besse, the head of the Renault automobile company who was shot dead tonight, devoted himself in the past year to the struggle to revive the famous nationalized company.

title: H. Southwood-Smith, Times Audit Director
description: Harrington O. C. Southwood-Smith, corporate director of internal auditing of the New York Times Company, died of bone marrow cancer yesterday at Hackensack (N.J.) Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Hackensack.

title: MUSIC: ANONYMUS
description: ''THE PLAY OF ROBIN AND MARION'' dates from the late 13th century, and its light, delicate portrayal of amorous knights and shepherds was first seen in Naples, even though the language itself is the Picard dialect of early French.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $44,000 and $485,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $1,910,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and tax benefits of $2,641,000 for the quarter and $7,700,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $250,000 and $672,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $3,314,000 for the quarter and $7,549,000 for the 9 months.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: America's Cup Kevin Parry, the Australian industrialist, moved closer to his goal of defending the America's Cup. Both his boats, Kookaburra II and Kookaburra III, won their races off Fremantle, Australia, yesterday. Kookaburra II defeated South Australia by 4 minutes 10 seconds in a 17-to 24-knot sea breeze. Kookaburra III beat Alan Bond's Australia III by 2:07. Bond's newer 12-Meter, Australia IV, beat Steak'n Kidney by 3:20. But the victory was overshadowed when a protest was upheld and Australia IV lost a victory over Kookaburra III. The decision widened Kookaburra III's lead over Australia IV in the round-robin trials to 25-18.

title: Senators on the Move
description: For several years Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the Republican chairman of the Budget Committee, and Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida, its ranking Democrat, have been among the closest collaborators in Congress. So fully have they consulted and cooperated in running the committee that budget-followers have come to believe the two Senators actually think and behave alike. Which may account for both of them currently being involved in moving their homes from the Washington suburbs to Capitol Hill, presumably to be closer to committee headquarters.

title: POINDEXTER WILL MEET INFORMALLY WITH LAWMAKERS
description: In an apparent effort to avoid a clash with Congress, the Administration said today that President Reagan's national security adviser would hold informal meetings with two Congressional intelligence committees that are looking into American arms shipments to Iran.

title: REDSKINS OUTLAST 49ERS IN MARATHON
description: The Washington Redskins and San Francisco 49ers finished one of the longest regulation games in National Football League history well past midnight, with the Redskins prevailing, 14-6.

title: Chicago Episcopalians Sign Pact With Catholics
description: The leaders of the city's Roman Catholic and Episcopal churches have signed a covenant affirming their doctrinal similarities and their intention to work together.

title: Lack of Smoke Alarms Cited In Buffalo Fire That Killed 5
description: The landlord of a house that burned last week, killing five people, was charged today with violating an ordinance requiring smoke detectors, officials said.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $347,000 and $325,000 for the latest and year- ago quarters, respectively.

title: A Scare at Campobello
description: For a time, one of the victims of the Federal budget-balancing law was Franklin D. Roosevelt's retreat at Campobello, which was dealt a double whammy.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS VOW TO CURB MILITARY BUDGET
description: The ascendancy of Democrats to control of the Senate has all but eliminated the already dim prospects of substantial growth in military spending next year, according to members of the committee that determines how much money the Pentagon may have.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on Friday about arms smuggling to Iran misidentified Jonathan Marks, a figure involved in a Federal case in New York. Mr. Marks is a defense lawyer, not a judge.

title: A $10 Million Boesky Estate
description: For the last decade, Ivan F. Boesky has lived in secluded splendor in a Georgian mansion on more than 100 acres of woodland in upper Westchester County.

title: U.S. Should Do Better In Paying for U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: INDUSTRY'S OPERATING RATE DOWN
description: The operating rate of American industry fell in October to the lowest level since 1983, the Government reported today. Activity in the mining industry hit a record low, and manufacturers continued to suffer from foreign competition.

title: HEAD OF RENAULT IS SHOT TO DEATH NEAR PARIS HOME
description: The president of Renault, the state-owned auto maker, was shot to death tonight in front of his home, the police said. The assailants escaped.

title: Gas Leak Sickens 73 At Garment Factory
description: Seventy-three people were treated for nausea and other ailments yesterday because of a carbon monoxide leak at a Brooklyn garment factory, the authorities said.

title: 'IS ANYBODY OUT THERE?'
description: SORRY, no extraterrestrial creatures appear on tonight's edition of ''Nova'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock. ''Is Anybody Out There?'' has to do with the means being used to send and receive signals to and from outer space, on the chance that such beings exist. That's by no means uninteresting, but an hour is apparently more than the subject requires and the filler material does not make for fascinating viewing.

title: Backyard Garden
description: When Robin Ficker moved his family into a spacious colonial home on a 1.75-acre plot in Potomac, Md., three years ago, the backyard was, quite literally, a big attraction. Just gazing out over it was enough to fill any homeowner with dreams of recreational grandeur: There was more than enough room for both a swimming pool and a tennis court.

title: A SPECIAL WAY WITH LINGERIE
description: Fernando Sanchez started his business 13 years ago with what was then a revolutionary concept. He adapted the separates way of dressing, usually associated with sportswear, to lingerie. And he went a few steps further. Many of the pieces he designed could be worn for sleeping, as underwear or for lounging. Some could even be worn to parties at home or at a friend's home.

title: Moscow's Memory Hole
description: The report from Moscow said Vyacheslav Molotov was buried after funeral services at Novodevichi Cemetery in the presence of a small group of family and friends. He was 96. No Soviet officials attended and foreign journalists were kept away by the police.

title: Colleges Need Scholar-Teachers and a Direction
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This event confirms once again that all our forces must unite against terrorism, without flinching and without compromise.'' - President Francois Mitterrand, on the slaying of Georges Besse, chairman of Renault. [ A1:1. ]

title: Farm Loan Setbacks Seen
description: Two-thirds of nearly 600 agricultural bankers surveyed by the American Bankers Association reported a deterioration in their farm loan portfolios between mid-1985 and mid-1986, according to a survey released today.

title: South Africa Emigration Poll
description: Eighty-one percent of urban white South Africans have no desire to emigrate, according to an opinion poll that was published today.

title: Bowl-Bid Strategy: No Delay of Game
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has set Nov. 22 as the date for extending bowl invitations, meaning no signed agreements can be made before then. This, however, does not preclude informal agreements.

title: Students Admit To Bomb Prank
description: Four Iowa State students admitted today they planted a smoke bomb in Cyclone Stadium during a football game, but said the ''funny prank'' was not intended to stir up the major commotion that ensued.

title: Israeli Helicopters Attack Palestinians
description: Israeli helicopter gunships struck today at Palestinian targets on the outskirts of the southern Lebanese port of Sidon.

title: BAKER J INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,596,000. The company said they went public June 5, after 11 months as a privately held concern and the latest 9-month share earnings and year-ago net figures are on a pro-forma basis.

title: BCI Will Sell Americold
description: The BCI Holdings Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Americold refrigeration business to a buyout group formed by Kelso & Company, a private investment banking firm, for $480 million.

title: UNIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $6.7 million of oil and gas properties.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOESKY SAID TO AID INQUIRY BY TAPING OF WALL ST. TALKS
description: In cooperating with a Federal investigation of illegal insider trading on Wall Street, Ivan F. Boesky allowed his conversations with other senior investment industry figures to be electronically recorded in recent weeks, according to several sources with knowledge of the inquiry.

title: New Byline in Town
description: For a long time, friends say, Lally Weymouth has wanted to write for The Washington Post. But that has been blocked because her mother is Katharine Graham, the chairman of the board, and the family has been chary, lest it be accused of nepotism, since another of Mrs. Graham's children, Donald, is the publisher.

title: The Shift on Iran: Sound, Courageous
description: The Reagan Administration should receive a bit more bipartisan praise and less condemnation for its secret efforts to rebuild relations with Iran. Whether or not all aspects of the policy-making process or the tactics involved in implementing the strategy were correct, the Administration has been making a rational, even courageous, attempt to deal with pressing problems and opportunities offered by events in the Persian Gulf.

title: Moody's Raises Detroit Rating
description: Detroit's general obligation bond rating has been raised by Moody's Investors Service to the investment grade of Baa from Ba, city officials announced yesterday.

title: Who Voted for 'Character'?
description: The midterm elections of 1986, our pollsters told us, were to be about ''character.'' Candidates would not be carried to victory by conventional concerns -anxiety about the economy or tensions abroad. The candidates best able to demonstrate personal integrity, conviction and determination -regardless of ideology - would win.

title: Footnote To Forefront
description: As childhood friends in Houston, they had faced each other across a net time and time again.

title: Careers; The Lure Of Investor Relations
description: IN a bustling period of mergers, leveraged buyouts and other competition for capital, there is a growing need for people skilled at investor relations.

title: PLAN FOR SEARS STRESSES PRODUCT MIX, LOW COST
description: Michael Bozic, the recently named chairman and chief executive of the huge Sears Merchandise Group, today outlined his plans to reinvigorate the company's sluggish retailing operations.

title: Supreme Court's Constitutional Case Is Weak
description: To the Editor:

title: LONDON EXCHANGE MAY BAR BOESKY
description: The London Stock Exchange is considering blacklisting Ivan F. Boesky by publicly declaring him ''not a fit and proper person,'' a senior exchange official said today. The step, if taken, would caution member firms against dealing with the Wall Street financier who agreed to pay a $100 million penalty for insider trading abuses.

title: GANDHI ENDORSES SRI LANKA STAND ON STRIFE
description: In a significant spur to the negotiations to end the guerrilla war in Sri Lanka, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India today endorsed the Sri Lankan Government's proposals for a political settlement with the Tamil insurgents.

title: HUTCHINSON TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $61,000.

title: Protest Strike Disrupts Business in Haiti
description: An anti-Government strike crippled most business activity in the capital and provinces today and protesters set up burning roadblocks along key roads, radio reports said.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $467,000.

title: Authorities Find Body Of Drug Agent's Wife
description: The body of a Federal drug agent's wife was found Sunday, two days after she disappeared from her real estate office, the police said.

title: Towers, Perrin Sets Top Shifts
description: Quentin I. Smith Jr., 59 years old, said yesterday that he would retire as chairman and chief executive of Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby, one of the nation's leading management consulting and reinsurance firms, on Jan. 1, 1988.

title: S.E.C. Names Head Of New York Office
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named Kathleen A. Warwick yesterday to head its New York regional office.

title: A Postgame Fete Gone Flat
description: It's become an American rite of triumph: Super Bowl and World Series winners breaking out case after case of champagne and proceeding to raise so much Cain that TV's interviewers now routinely drape themselves in towels before the postgame give and take. All Coach Whitey Budreckas did was provide two bottles of the bubbly for his players after they won a conference championship game three weeks ago, but now he wishes he hadn't.

title: AMERICAN SETS DEAL FOR AIRCAL
description: American Airlines, which has fiercely resisted the industry's acquisition trend, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy AirCal, a leading West Coast carrier, for $15 a share, or about $225 million.

title: NICARAGUAN, IN U.S., HINTS AT PARDON FOR HASENFUS
description: The Vice President of Nicaragua, here for a conference on emerging democracies, hinted today that a presidential pardon was a possibility for Eugene Hasenfus, an American sentenced to 30 years for his role in flying military supplies to United States-backed insurgents.

title: Taking the Rap on the Rhine
description: Switzerland's open acceptance of responsibility for the chemical poisoning of the Rhine River brings a redeeming feature to that disaster. With so much environmental damage to three downstream nations, reparations sound abstract but a threshold of accountability has been crossed.

title: K Mart's Profit Increases 12.7%
description: The K Mart Corporation's profit in its fiscal third quarter rose 12.7 percent, to $87.3 million, or 66 cents a share, from $77.4 million, or 60 cents a share, a year before. Sales for the 13 weeks ended Oct. 29 totaled $5.69 billion, up 8.9 percent from $5.22 billion, the nation's second-largest retailer reported today.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERELMAN: MOVING UP QUIETLY
description: After the Wall Street spotlight shifted to Ivan F. Boesky's downfall last Friday, it was easy to overlook Ronald O. Perelman, who describes himself as a very private man but who had just had a very public week.

title: BOSTON U. FOCUSES ON DISINFORMATION
description: Early in his career, as a Czech intelligence operative known as Ladislav Bittman, Lawrence Martin says, he helped alter old Nazi files and then dumped them into a lake near the West German border. A few days later, a Czechoslovak television crew supposedly investigating ancient legends of the lake dredged up the documents and used them to depict some top West German politicians as war criminals.

title: RENAULT CHIEF: A FIX-IT SPECIALIST
description: Georges Besse, president of the state-run automobile maker Renault, was known throughout French industry as a plain-spoken man with a knack for turning around failing companies.

title: ON BOATS AND BEARS AND BONES
description: When narcotics agents in Mississippi raided a cabin cruiser on the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway last spring, they found no cache of drugs. But the 34-foot boat had been stolen, and there were illegal automatic weapons on board.

title: LANDS' END INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The results are on a pro forma basis and the company went public last month.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net income The year-ago revenue restated for the effect of discontinued operations.

title: Husky Quits Talks
description: Canada's Husky Oil Ltd. said it had adjourned negotiations with a Hong Kong company concerning its future ownership and had not set a date to resume the talks. A spokesman, Joan Dennis, confirmed a published report that Husky's chairman, Robert Blair, met last week with Simon Murray, managing director of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., a Hong Kong-based trading company controlled by the financier Li Ka-Shing. The report in The Financial Post said Mr. Murray had also met with board members of Nova, an Alberta corporation that owns 57 percent of Husky.

title: CHARITY LINKS SEVERED AS A RESULT OF INQUIRY
description: For many years, Ivan F. Boesky has not only given generously to charities, universities and cultural activities, but also involved himself personally in their operations. Now, he is severing at least some of his links to several prominent institutions.

title: Paccar Considers Takeover of Trico
description: Paccar Inc. disclosed it had acquired a 17.2 percent stake in Trico Industries and said that it might seek control of the oil-drilling equipment maker. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Paccar said that it planned to acquire ''an undetermined number of additional Trico shares'' and that it might propose ''a merger or other business combination.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Standard Inc. said it would sell its two sheet-fed printing businesses to investor groups led by the management of those businesses. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Country people often speak of grasshoppers spitting tobacco juice. What is this tobacco juice? A.When handled or disturbed by predators, a grasshopper excretes digestive fluid from its mouth.

title: Lockheed Falls In Heavy Trading
description: The Lockheed Corporation, which has been rumored to be a takeover candidate, repeated today that it knows of no reason for the recent climb in the price of its stock. The stock, in turn, slipped $2.875 today in heavy trading to close at $52.375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. NUGGETS, at Denver, 9:30 P.M. (Radio - WNEW 1130, 9:30 P.M.) LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS.

title: DEFENSE MINISTER AT SUPREME SOVIET
description: Defense Minister Sergei L. Sokolov, who missed key meetings because of illness, showed up today for the opening of the fall session of the Supreme Soviet.

title: ACCOUNTS OF WITNESSES DIFFER IN SLAYING OF TROOPER
description: Five witnesses to the 1981 slaying of a state trooper testified today, offering sometimes conflicting descriptions of what happened.

title: Denial of State Parole To McGivern Upheld
description: A judge upheld yesterday the decision of the State Board of Parole in January to deny parole to Gary McGivern, who was granted clemency by Governor Cuomo on a murder conviction.

title: Soccer Accident Kills a Boy, 13
description: A 13-year-old youth from Westport has died from injuries sustained in a collision with another player in a youth soccer league game, the authorities said.

title: TAKEOVER INQUIRIES BY CONGRESS SEEN
description: The insider trading case against Ivan F. Boesky will touch off broad inquiries during the next Congress into whether new legislation is needed to rein in corporate takeover activity, top Congressional aides and officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission predicted today.

title: Put Seat Belts in Cabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Chess: Seattle Grandmaster Wins U.S. Championship Match
description: Yasser Seirawan has won the 1986 United States Championship in Estes Park, Colo. The 26-year-old Seattle grandmaster scored 10 1/2-4 1/2 in the 16-player round-robin tournament to capture the $5,556.80 first prize.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $7.6 million for the settlement of a disputed Army contract. This charge was partially offset by the company's sale of a parcel of land for $5 million resulting in a pre-tax gain of $3.7 million.

title: SAINTS, AT 6-5, NO JOKE NOW
description: Can there actually be talk of the New Orleans Saints, now 6-5, making the playoffs?

title: LIONS' DEMISE
description: In the overall standings of Ivy League athletic competition, Columbia has finished third or better in six of the last eight academic years. Football has not been the ''semi-professional racket,'' that Columbia Spectator editorials suggested when Reed Harris was editor in the early 1930's and the Lions were building toward a Rose Bowl victory, a ''gigantic sideshow, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.'' The Presidents' Agreement of 1954 placed football programs firmly in the control of academic authorities. ''King Football,'' the title of Reed Harris's book, cannot claim Low Library in its sovereignty.

title: AUTODESK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
IRAN DENIES LAND-ROVER BID
description: The Heavy Industries Ministry today denied reports that Iran is negotiating to buy Land-Rover vehicles from Britain.

title: HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUDGET REQUESTS OF MOST AGENCIES EXCEED '88 LIMITS
description: Only two Federal agencies have submitted budget requests that comply with the limits suggested by President Reagan for the next fiscal year, Administration officials said today.

title: That Isn't Grime; That's Michelangelo
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina Offers End To Falkland Hostilities
description: Argentina said today that it would formally end hostilities with Britain if Britain drops a 150-mile ''protection zone'' around the Falkland Islands, where the two nations fought a 74-day war in 1982.

title: A SOVIET PLAY EXPORTS GRIM DRAMATIC VISION
description: When Aleksandr Gelman's play ''Face to Face'' opened here three years ago, the playwright received a series of angry letters complaining about its savage portrait of a conniving, weak-willed Soviet construction boss and the vengeful wife who believes he crippled their son.

title: Bridge: Use of the Weak No-Trump Has Been Gaining Popularity
description: For the past three decades there has been a steady increase in the use of the weak no-trump. A survey in 1980 showed that one-third of American experts use it, and the number has probably risen slightly since then.

title: THE FIRST STEP IS OFTEN THE HARDEST
description: LEARNING to deal with personal computers involves a series of steps; for most people, an extended plateau stretches after each. For would-be users of the I.B.M. PC and compatible machines, the most difficult of all these steps is probably the very first, mastering MS-DOS, the system that operates the computer itself.

title: MADELINE N. BLOCH
description: Madeline N. Bloch, a frequent volunteer in Democratic campaigns on the state and national levels, died Sunday in a Woodbury, Conn., nursing home.

title: LEONARDO'S 'CHILD WITH A LAMB' SELLS FOR RECORD
description: Leonardo da Vinci's ''Child With a Lamb,'' one of very few works by the artist in private hands, was sold last night for a record at auction for an artwork by the artist, and the highest auction price in America for an Old Master drawing.

title: LUCKY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $564,000 for the quarter and $1,511,000 for the 9 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $6,976,000 for the quarter and $24,192,000 for the 9 months. Both year-ago periods are restated for discontinued operations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1986
description: The World

title: A.T.&T. Danish Venture
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it had formed a joint venture with the Nordic Cable and Wire Works of Denmark to manufacture fiber optic products. A spokesman for A.T.&T. declined to say how much money the company would invest in the venture, in which it holds a 51 percent stake. She said the operation would not affect A.T.&T.'s domestic production of fiber optic products, which are used in telephone communications. A.T.&T. said the venture would take over Nordic Cable's plant in Broendby, near Copenhagen.

title: PROMOTING 'SUBVERSION'
description: LARGELY unnoticed by the public, a new movement of collaboration between high school teachers and college professors has begun to stretch across the country, ''subverting'' the traditional separation between school and college.

title: INDIANA CITY GRAPPLES WITH LOSS OF I.B.M. PLANT
description: Each of them remembers exactly what he was doing when it happened. Dan Doan, the bank president, was relaxing at home. Gerald Warren, the Mayor, had just returned to his office from a memorial service. And Gary Lemon was standing in a cafeteria line when a friend rushed up.

title: ANGOLA REBELS SAID TO OPEN NEW FRONT
description: United States-backed guerrillas have opened a new front in their 11-year-old war against Angola's Marxist Government, military and diplomatic sources said here today.

title: Olajuwon's Big Deal
description: Akeem Olajuwon, who established himself last season as pro basketball's most dominant young center, signed a contract yesterday with the Houston Rockets that will keep him with the team through the 1997-98 season and pay him a total of $30 million, making him one of the highest paid players in the league.

title: Polluted Denver Begins 3d 'Better Air' Campaign
description: With $30 million in Federal highway funds at stake, Denver today inaugurated its third annual Better Air Campaign, hoping to reduce the 1,540 tons of carbon monoxide pumped into the city's air every day.

title: FOCUSING ON THE HOMELESS
description: The Partnership for the Homeless began a week of neigborhood canvassing and fund raising yesterday to call attention to the plight of the city's homeless.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain from the expensing of fees for a proposed exchange offer of $267,000. c-Includes a charge of $13,101,000 from the expensing of fees for a proposed exchange offer.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: 'A Lawyer's Lawyer' To Watch Boesky Firm
description: Gerald F. Rath, the Boston lawyer chosen by the Securities and Exchange Commission to be special compliance agent for the Ivan F. Boesky Company, was described by a colleague yesterday as ''a lawyer's lawThe colleague, David Boch, went on to describe Mr. Rath as ''a person who demands high-quality work, who pays great attention to detail, who thinks quickly on his feet and is pretty articulate.''

title: CARBIDE GIVES DETAILS ON ITS SABOTAGE CLAIM
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, denying any liability for the Bhopal disaster, yesterday released fresh details of its claim that sabotage caused the 1984 gas leak.

title: Driver in Hit-Run Fined in New Case
description: A former New York City police sergeant, convicted last January of driving a police car while he was drunk in the hit-and-run death of a psychologist in Manhattan, has been fined a total of $350 for an unrelated charge of speeding and driving while impaired.

title: MUSIC: KRONOS QUARTET
description: MOST of the music the Kronos Quartet brought to the Brooklyn Academy of Music Sunday afternoon hovered in a state of self-induced hypnosis. Jon Hassell's ''Pano da Costa,'' ''White Man Sleeps'' by Kevin Volans and Guus Janssen's ''Streepjes'' all seemed happy and relaxed in their small static world -where musical ideas renounce development and are content to circle again and again back to their beginnings.

title: Europe Eases Capital Curbs
description: Finance ministers of the European Community today approved a significant step toward ending curbs on movement of capital within the bloc.

title: Gaining a Victory To Look Back On
description: FOR the last hour, the team bus had been quiet. The players had finished all the Devil Dogs and Yankee Doodles, washing them down with a gallon of Coke. Most had put on their Sony Walkmen and were staring out the window, watching the Thruway go by in the dark.

title: AFTER BIG PLAY, GIANTS HAND OUT GRADES
description: If the Giants faced Sunday's desperation pass play 100 times, said Phil Simms, they might make it five or six times. On Sunday, they made it, and it enabled them to beat the Minnesota Vikings, 22-20, on a field goal with 12 seconds left.

title: MORE U.S. CHANGES ON ARMS PROPOSED
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz appeared to propose a further retreat today from the American offer to eliminate all nuclear ballistic missiles in 10 years.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $2,332,481, or 29 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Mazzilli First to Sign
description: Lee Mazzilli, the prodigal son of the 1986 Mets, became the first member of the team to sign a contract for 1987 yesterday, and the signing at Shea Stadium was not only sentimental but also painless for the Mets.

title: INDIAN POINT BACK IN SERVICE
description: The Indian Point II nuclear power plant was back in service this morning after being shut down last weekend for repairs to a water system, a spokesman said. The spokesman, John McCann of Consolidated Edison, which operates the plant, said the reactor began producing electricity at 7 a.m. The reactor had been removed from one of three safety injection pumps, he said.

title: POWERFUL NEW CHIPS
description: AMONG the acres of interesting gizmos and gadgets on display last week at Comdex, the big computer exposition in Las Vegas, Nev., were several new desktop and portable computers that are likely to be popular in 1987. 80386 Computers The Intel 80386 microprocessor is an awesome little critter, far more powerful than other chips now on the market, and Intel says about 200 companies are planning to use it in one way or another. The debut of the 386 inspired industry leaders to grand oratory - if only the speakers were as fast as the chip - but in the end it was apparent that at least for now the 386 is strictly for power users and trendy people with fat bank accounts.

title: Market Place; Lowering Price Of Coke Bottler
description: WHAT could shape up as the largest initial public offering of stock ever made in the United States - 71.4 million shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises - is like any new issue in that the price should be tailored to insure a good reception.

title: ATKINSON, GUY F CO OF CALIF reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WELFARE HOTEL: ONCE GILDED, NOW GRIM
description: Lunch was served in the once-grand ballroom of the Prince George Hotel. Amid the ornate columns, below a gilt ceiling, Kathleen Greenwood pointed to a stack of foil containers.
