''Who wants seconds on lasagna?'' she called to the 150 mothers and small children who ate silently at long metal tables.

title: JUSTICES TO HEAR PLEA ON INTERNMENT OF JAPANESE-AMERICANS
description: More than 40 years after its much-criticized decisions upholding the Government's wartime detention of Japanese-Americans, the Supreme Court agreed today to review a Government appeal disclaiming any liability to pay them damages.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Business Day on Friday about Union Carbide's plan to sell its agricultural chemicals business misstated the company's sales. Carbide's 1985 sales were $9 billion; its 1986 sales are estimated at $7 billion.

title: RESHAPING FASHION: THE YOUNG DESIGNERS
description: Suddenly, New York's young designers are in fashion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: 'MACBETH' SET IN JAPAN The ubiquitous appeal of Shakespeare is attested to by the fact that, no matter what the actors are wearing or what scenery they play in front of, the words register with all sorts of audiences. Indeed, it has become a traditional theatrical challenge. Starting today, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater brings ''Shogun Macbeth'' to Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street (245-2660).

title: Despite Uncertainty, A Familiar Greeting
description: Greetings from the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, to the East German leader, Erich Honecker, were reported today by the East German press agency.

title: IN THE INCAS' LAND, A WAR FOR THE PEOPLE'S HEARTS
description: Wearing layers of clothes against the winds that sweep across the Andes, 30 Quechua-speaking men and women carved at a steep slope almost 12,000 feet above sea level. Under their hoes, farming terraces began to take shape, much like those used by their Inca ancestors.

title: N.A.S.D. CHAIRMAN
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. said yesterday that Joseph R. Hardiman, managing director and chief operating officer of Alex, Brown & Sons Inc., Baltimore, had been named chairman of ith board of governors for 1987. Mr. Hardiman succeeds David W. Hunter, chairman of Parker/Hunter Inc. of Pittsburgh.

title: May to Sell Horne
description: The May Department Stores Company, which recently merged with the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, said it would sell the 15 Joseph Horne Company department stores to a group of Pittsburgh investors headed by Robert O'Connell, Horne's president and chief executive. The Horne stores, which had 1985 sales of $209 million, had been previously owned by Associated. The division has 3,000 employees.

title: 2 Shot in a Dispute With Prison Guard
description: A New York City corrections officer shot and critically wounded two Baldwin, L.I., men early yesterday after they threatend him with a four-inch knife, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1986
description: Markets

title: NATURALIST AND BIRD WATCHER
description: Farida A. Wiley, a self-taught naturalist and guide to generations of Central Park bird watchers, died at a nursing home Saturday in Melbourne, Fla. She was 99 years old and had moved from New York to Melbourne about two years ago.

title: ABC NEWS TO ADJUST PAY OVERSEAS
description: ABC News, seeking to cut the cost of its overseas news-gathering operations, will soon impose measures that will in effect reduce the pay of foreign correspondents and others by 7 percent, according to network officials.

title: HAZLETON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income of $32,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $57,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $843,000 on the sale of assets.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in some copies Saturday of Gelsey Kirkland's autobiography, ''Dancing on My Grave,'' misidentified the drug to which she said she became addicted. It was cocaine, not heroin.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Net loss The company said that for the latest quarter it had equity in the net income of its Teleprobe Systems Inc. affiliate of $86,000, compared to last year's equity in the net loss of Teleprobe of $612,000; Teleprobe is 35 percent owned by TII Industries.

title: BELASCO THEATER AIR RIGHTS LEASED TO GIVE BUILDER 11 MORE STORIES
description: Development rights from the Belasco Theater have been leased by the Shubert Organization to the builders of a midblock tower directly behind the theater, it was announced yesterday.

title: People Express Plan Approved
description: People Express Inc. said yesterday that after extending its deadline twice it had received the necessary approval of its creditors for a change in the airline's debt structure.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Brian Tribble, accused of supplying the cocaine that caused the death of the basketball star, Len Bias, has been given a trial date of March 16 in Maryland. . . . Tony Robinson and Kenneth (B.B) Cooper, two former football players at the University of Tennessee, reported to the Knox County penal farm in Tennessee yesterday to begin serving sentences for cocaine-related crimes. Robinson, a former quarterback, must serve 90 days and Cooper, a fullback, 150 days. . . . Jeff Ruland, the Philadelphia 76er center, will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow for a right-knee injury and is expected to be out two weeks. . . . Jack Harbaugh has been dismissed as football coach at Western Michigan after compiling a five-year record of 25-27-3.

title: Hollings Has Plans for Commerce
description: When Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina replaces John C. Danforth of Missouri as chairman of the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee, the change will be more than a switch from Republican to Democrat.

title: Loss for Quiet Enjoyment of Co-ops and Condos
description: To the Editor:

title: Layne Status Worsens
description: Heavily sedated in a Lubbock, Tex., hospital, Bobby Layne is conscious but in ''very critical'' condition. The 59-year-old pro Hall of Fame quarterback drove himself to Methodist Hospital early Saturday, later undergoing surgery to control bleeding in his esophagus.

title: COMSTOCK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $2,533,000. c-Net income

title: MARANTZ CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a $1.9 million writeoff due to the bankruptcy of a major customer. The latest 9 months' results also reflect currency transaction losses of $759,000.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $696,000 for the quarter, and for the 9 months includes a tax credit of $47,000. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $284,000 and $1,518,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $665,000 and $1,579,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Hunter Is Fatally Shot
description: A 47-year-old Parksville man, Kenneth L. Sanders, became the first Sullivan County hunting fatality in at least three years when he was shot in the head while hunting in a wooded area near his home, the state police said. They said the hunter's body was found on Monday by hunters from a nearby camp.

title: TACO VILLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOOK OF THE TIMES
description: THE COMPLETE PROSE OF MARIANNE MOORE. Edited and with an introduction by Patricia C. Willis. 723 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/Viking. $24.95.

title: Study Urges An Oil Tariff
description: American oil imports are averaging 5 million barrels a day, the highest level since 1981, according to a Harvard University study released today that called for a $10-a-barrel tariff to reverse the trend.

title: SOLAR CYCLES FOUND IN BANDS OF ROCK
description: SOMEHOW - just how, nobody knows - the regular 11-year rhythm of sunspots seems to have left its imprint in rocks created hundreds of millions of years ago in southern Australia.

title: SOVIET HAS MAJOR STAKE IN ANY PYONGYANG SHIFT
description: The Soviet Union, which has nurtured closer ties with North Korea in recent years, withheld comment today on conflicting reports of political turmoil in that country.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,890,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $2,905,000 and $6,883,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Texas Air, Eastern In Merger Defense
description: The Texas Air Corporation and Eastern Air Lines Inc. urged a Federal judge to ignore opposition to their planned merger by an employee group, saying Eastern would be placed ''back in the throes of financial desperation'' should the deal fail. In a 90-page document filed in Federal District Court, the airlines said that public interest should be the court's principal consideration.

title: The Case for Keeping the Rural Third World to Scale
description: To the Editor:

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: In the Field of Fire
description: My daughter-in-law who lives in what used to be the country just telephoned in panic. Dozens of pickup trucks were parked along the roads in her neck of the woods, gunfire was crackling all over the landscape and her dogs were yelping in terror.

title: GILLETTE'S STOCK PRICE FALLS $7.25
description: The stock price of the Gillette Company fell more than $7 yesterday, reflecting the market's uncertainty that the Revlon Group and Ronald O. Perelman, Revlon's chairman, could raise the capital for its $4.25 billion attempted takeover of Gillette.

title: Away for the Holidays
description: When bowl invitations are formally extended Saturday, most of the colleges on this list will be adding to the totals shown.

title: Times When Success Comes With Psychological Strength
description: Some good players have a psychological weakness: they are reluctant to make a play that, however correct, may result in them looking foolish. Such players would have difficulty with the diagramed deal, played recently in a regional Swiss team championship in Lancaster, Pa.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES ILLINOIS WESLEYAN - Announced that Donald (Swede) Larson had resigned as football coach.

title: New Judge in Chicago Is Jailed for Contempt
description: A newly elected judge in Cook County Circuit Court, Joseph E. McDermott, was found in contempt of court and jailed today for failing to testify before a grand jury in the investigation of corruption in the county court system.

title: MOVE TO HEAL BLACK MUSLIM RIFT APPEARS TO BE UNDER WAY AMID PRESSURES
description: An effort to heal the divisions that caused a decade-long split appears to be under way in the Black Muslim movement, which has characterized whites as ''devils'' and urged creation of a separate black nation within the United States.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1986
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: BRENNAN FOCUSES ON HIGH COURT AND THE STATES
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., in an address at the New York University Law School last night, lauded a series of Supreme Court decisions in the 1960's that interpreted the 14th Amendment as applying the Bill of Rights to the states.

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,308,000 and $4,266,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $841,000 for the quarter, and the 9 months includes income from discontinued operations of $775,000 and a gain of $266,000 on an exchange offer.

title: WIXKES BID FOR SIEGLER MAY BE OFF
description: In a sudden reversal, the Wickes Companies said tonight that its planned $1.7 billion acquisition of Lear Siegler Inc.may be terminated because Wickes has been unable to arrange its bank financing.

title: Allegheny Divests
description: Allegheny International Inc., the troubled consumer and industrial products concern, said it had sold two subsidiaries to Group Financial Partners, a Louisville, Ky., holding company, for undisclosed terms as part of its divestiture program.

title: Mayor Koch Calls the Cabs
description: New York City's taxi cartel wants a fare hike, and plans to make traffic miserable until the demand is met. Mayor Koch insists that any fare increase be linked to a long-overdue increase in licensed taxi service. This sensible stand deserves support.

title: Who's in Charge Anyway?
description: During the Bay of Pigs disaster, President Kennedy, irritated by the opposition of the State Department, turned on Ambassador Charles E. (Chip) Bohlen and demanded to know, ''What's wrong with your department?'' Bohlen replied, ''You are, Mr. President!''

title: Answering the Unasked About Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Driving Message Home
description: Justice Department employees have come up with a new bumper sticker for their cars: ''States Do It Better/Give Federalism a Chance.''

title: Brazil Speaks
description: Political confusion seemed likely last weekend when 70 million Brazilian voters confronted a complicated ballot that lumped gubernatorial, congressional and constituent assembly elections together. Yet the electorate spoke with remarkable coherence.

title: A Ray of Hope for Agreement on Nuclear Arms
description: The fact that the Democrats will control the Senate and House in the next Congress could conceivably boost chances for an American-Soviet agreement on nuclear weapons.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Details Drug Cartel Prosecutors say little was left to chance by a vast South American cocaine ring, whose members were indicted in Miami.

title: NERVOUS MARKETS PLUNGE ON FEARS OF WIDER SCANDAL
description: The repercussions of the insider trading scandal rocked Wall Street yesterday. The stock market and parts of the bond market suffered heavy losses in response to the fear that has gripped the securities business over how high and how far the scandal will reach.

title: ASHTON-TATE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: America's Cup

INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After securities gains of $2,000 for the quarter and $886,000 for the 9 months. c-After securities losses of $38,000 for the quarter and securities gains of $69,000 for the 9 months.

title: Palestinians in Mountains Bombard Shiites in Beirut
description: Palestinian gunners entrenched in the mountains above Beirut pounded Shiite Moslem positions in the southern suburbs today with rockets and artillery.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $527,700 for the quarter and $542,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,160,500 and $1,786,565 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago results were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Junk Bonds' Stir Concern
description: THE taint of scandal at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., now a central focus of the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading case, has alarmed many participants in the market for high-yielding, low-quality securities, or ''junk bonds,'' where prices declined steeply yesterday.

title: ALTERNACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $47,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the 9 months.

title: Development Bid
description: The Development Corporation of America, a home builder and real estate developer, said it had received an $89 million bid from the Miami-based Lennar Corporation, another home builder.

title: CABBIES' COALITION CALLS A TRUCE IN FARE PROTEST
description: A coalition of taxicab drivers yesterday called a truce in their protests against the Koch administration after city officials agreed to meet with the group's leaders tomorrow.

title: 10 Political Words That Dare Not Speak Their Name
description: Back in the early 1970's, the comedian George Carlin titillated adolescents with a racy monologue about ''The Seven Words You Can't Say on Television.'' Working as issues director in a recent, unsuccessful Congressional campaign, I discovered that politics has its own forbidden lexicon. While TV taboos relate predictably to sex, most (but not all) political taboos hark to the discredited doctrine of liberalism. To spare future campaign workers my painful lesson, I submit a handy guide to ''The 10 Words You Can't Say in Politics.''

title: MOVE TO DEREGULATE MARKETS CONTINUES
description: The Reagan Administration plans to press ahead with efforts to deregulate the financial markets despite views in Congress that the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading affair illustrates a need for tighter control.

title: Where Punishment Does Not Fit The Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Hanky-Panky
description: General Manager Jim Finks of the New Orleans Saints, a real juggler when it comes to the use of language and N.F.L. strictures, on the 21 penalties that were called in Sunday's victory over St. Louis: ''We're not allowed to comment on the lousy officiating.''

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $184,000 for the quarter and $839,000 for the 6 months.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $7,718,000 for the quarter and $27,185,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $2,678,000 for the quarter and $12,318,000 for the 9 months. The company said that adoption of a change in pension accounting increased latest quarter net by 5 cents a share and latest 9 months' net by 15 cents a share.

title: Lucky Will Buy Shares at $40 Each
description: Lucky Stores Inc. said that its board had approved its plan to purchase up to 14,375,000, or 28 percent, of its common shares, for $40 each. The move was announced after the close at the New York Stock Exchange, where Lucky's share price fell $1.25 today, to $32.75.

title: MONTANA IS KEPT OUT OF STEP
description: Knowing that these were no ordinary Joes they were facing Monday night, the Washington Redskins knew they had to try something different.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A bidding error at a $600 million auction of Texas tax and revenue anticipation notes yesterday resulted in the award of about $300 million of the notes to a group of underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Reagan News Session To Be Broadcast at 8
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: TEMCO HOME HEALTH CARE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it accounted for a number of one-time expenses in the latest third quarter, including increased insurance premiums, adjustment to estimated labor costs and the costs associated with hiring additional sales personnel.

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: FINANCING OF CAMPAIGNS MAY NOW GET OVERHAUL
description: It often takes years for an issue to ripen on Capitol Hill. Public opinion gradually coalesces, legislators begin to focus their attention, and a bill finally gathers enough momentum to navigate a legislative labyrinth that was designed to be difficult.

title: O'Neill Will Reshape His Administration
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said yesterday that he will accept the resignations of quite a number of top state officials when he shapes his administration for the next four years.

title: PANEL TO ASK BILLIONS IN OUTLAYS TO PRESERVE OPEN SPACES IN U.S.
description: A commission appointed by President Reagan has drafted a multibillion-dollar program that is aimed at protecting the nation's remaining open spaces for future generations.

title: People
description: * E. Michael Roche has joined Backer & Spielvogel as general manager, senior vice president, of the Huntington Beach, Calif., office.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect the positive effect of a change in accounting for pensions.

title: S.M.U. Granted Delay
description: Acting on a request by Southern Methodist University, the National Collegiate Athletic Association''s Committee on Infractions has agreed to delay consideration of the school's appeal of its probationary status. Lonnie Kliever, a faculty representative, said the school was putting off its appeal until new charges are ''fully investigated and finally resolved.''

title: Woman's Work
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BankAmerica Bill Weighed
description: The Speaker of the California State Assembly is considering special legislation that would allow out-of-state institutions to bid for the BankAmerica Corporation, a spokesman for the legislator said today.

title: ALLEGRE PART OF CLUB NOW
description: When the Giants made Ali Haji-Sheikh their kicker in 1983, they thought they were set for a decade. But nagging injuries and shaken confidence ended Haji-Sheikh's career as a Giant this summer, and now Raul Allegre has become the Giants' kicker for the present and presumably the future.

title: The Smoking Wars
description: Sidney and Dean Overall, a husband-and-wife team from St. Simons Island, Ga., found themselves at loggerheads because she smokes and he does not. They say their experience has persuaded them that no amount of regulation will resolve the conflict between smokers and nonsmokers.

title: PUNTA GORDA ISLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CONFUSION OVER WITHHOLDING SEEN
description: The Internal Revenue Service presented a new and longer W-4 wage withholding form today that more than 100 million American workers will have to complete within the next several months.

title:
FOR THANKSGIVING, TWO FEASTS, TWO TRADITIONS;
A Penchant for Savory Meats And English Baked Puddings
description: ''IN our feasting, we should keep separate two guests: body and spirit,'' advises Gervase Markham in ''The English House-Wife'' published in 1614. The Puritan Thanksgiving, now such a part of traditional American culture, was not in its original form the glut of turkey and high prayer we now associate with it. Turkey and religion were very much in the background during the 1600's.

title: Showdown, Yes, But No Sitdown
description: Just about everybody involved in Saturday's nationally televised Big Eight showdown between Oklahoma and Nebraska, including the coaches, seems to agree with Dick DeVenzio that in the big-money sport of college football, it's the college football players who get shortchanged.

title: Harry Taylor Sr., 92, Real-Estate Executive
description: Harry A. Taylor Sr., chairman of one of New Jersey's oldest real-estate companies, Frank H. Taylor & Son Inc., died Monday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 92 years old.

title: CONTRA WAR IS BUILDING ALONG BORDER
description: Nicaraguan guerrillas are being pressed hard by the Nicaraguan Army along the Honduran border, according to Western and rebel officials.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Printouts; Tokyo Yellow Pages On a 3 1/2-Inch Disk
description: For years, computer manufacturers have been talking about the imminent arrival of CD-ROM, compact disks that can hold more than 540 million characters of data in ''read-only'' memory. Grolier Publishing has already put an encyclopedia with 30,000 entries on one disk, but other consumer applications are rare.

title: JORDAN LIVING COACH'S DREAM
description: Doug Collins, the rookie coach of the Chicago Bulls, has found someone who shoots the ball as much as he would have liked to.

title: NORTH JERSEY MAYOR CLOSING IN ON TENURE RECORD
description: Mayor Frank E. Rodgers is closing in on the record for longevity in office for a mayor and no one in this town of 12,492 doubts that he will capture it.

title: New Chairman Set At Fallon McElligott
description: Patrick R. Fallon, president of the magical five-year-old Fallon McElligott shop in Minneapolis, has stepped up to chairman to make way for Steven A. Sjoblad in the president's pew.

title: CHARLES OF THE RITZ SOLD TO YVES SAINT LAURENT
description: Yves Saint Laurent has agreed to purchase Charles of the Ritz from the Squibb Corporation for more than $600 million.

title: 'NEWPORT JAZZ '86,' A SPECIAL
description: ''JAZZ is not an entity but a bunch of individuals,'' observes the ever-articulate Gerry Mulligan in the television special ''Newport Jazz '86.''

title: A GOOD LISTENER, CORNELL'S COACH MAKES POINT OF 2
description: Maxie Baughan is comfortable now as Cornell's football coach and is enjoying his first winning season, a season that will end Saturday against Penn in a game for the Ivy League championship.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures converted from new Israeli shekels.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Printouts; The Philharmonic Adopts a Computer
description: The New York Philharmonic is in the first movement of a project to enter into computer files all performance data in its 144-year history. The project, dubbed SOLI, for Symphony Orchestra Library Information, is believed to be the first of its kind in this country.

title: EXPERTS PROPOSE CHILD INOCULATION
description: An international group of medical experts called yesterday for the immunization of all infants in Africa, Asia and Latin America against hepatitis B, which they said caused more than one million deaths a year. A drastic reduction in the price of the vaccine has for the first time made mass immunization feasible, they said at a New York news conference.

title: Woeful Nets Lose To Nuggets, 125-112
description: Alex English scored 43 points, his high for the season, and Mike Evans came off the Denver bench to provide a crucial fourth-quarter lift as the Nuggets defeated the slumping Nets tonight, 125-112.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A SPECIAL SESSION OF ARMS TALKS DUE
description: Some senior American and Soviet arms negotiators plan to meet in Geneva in early December for a special session of the arms talks, Administration officials said today.

title: TAKING FRESH LOOK AT CASTING
description: In ''Shogun Macbeth,'' Lady Macbeth and the three witches were all Asian.

title: Norway Closer To Gas Sale
description: Norway appeared headed today toward compromise with France in a dispute over Norwegian plans to sell natural gas to Western Europe. The plan to develop the huge

title: Multi-Hatted
description: The Cypriote Ambassador to the United States, Andrew J. Jacovides, already a very busy person, is zipping along in high gear. He was re-elected recently as a member of the International Law Commission, which meets in Geneva, finishing in the top 10 of the 34 people elected.

title: PUMP FOR INSULIN IS PUT IN DIABETIC
description: Doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital today announced the first successful implant of an insulin pump developed through space technology. They said the device could help the million insulin-dependent diabetics in the United States.

title: EVERGOOD PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income The company said the latest 9-month loss includes a tax credit of $63,243.

title: Judge Won't Dismiss Bergman Fraud Case
description: Judge Whitman Knapp announced today that he would not dismiss mail fraud charges against Marvin H. Bergman, the former law partner of Donald R. Manes. Mr. Bergman's case was separated from that of the other four defendants here last week.

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,559,000 for the quarter and $9,829,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,531,000 for the quarter and $11,213,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $16,000 and $262,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain of $7,876,000 for both periods, and also includes for the quarter a $5,417,000 writedown of assets. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $191,000 and $631,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: MONDRIAN PAINTING IS AUCTIONED FOR RECORD PRICE
description: Mondrian's ''Composition in a Square With Red Corner,'' the artist's largest complete painting, sold last night at Sotheby's for an auction record for a work by the artist and the second-highest price for a 20th-century painting.

title: Talks Moved to Detroit In Indiana U.A.W. Strike
description: A walkout by about 7,700 members of the United Automobile Workers union at Delco Electronics entered its second day today and negotiations were moved from Indiana to Detroit.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE bamboos could be a tip-off. You pass them as you go up the winding drive through the park. They grow along the edge of the beautiful little lake and, at first, you might think they just happened to be there. Then you realize that an artist has been at work. The bamboos are in harmony with the still water, the stately chestnut trees and the arch of the tiny bridge over which your car must pass. It's almost, well, Oriental.

title: The High Cost Of Dishonesty
description: THE case of Ivan F. Boesky, the most famous of the arbitragers, has hit the stock market hard. And the Boesky affair raises serious questions about the integrity of the markets.

title: Nattering Nabobs
description: Coach John Robinson of the Los Angeles Rams, on his rookie quarterback, Jim Everett: ''He's just one guy on our team, and if we start looking at one guy as the reason we win or lose, then we're fools. We'll let the media do that.''

title: POLITICIAN SLAIN OUTSIDE MANILA
description: A conservative politician was shot to death today along with his driver and a companion in an early-morning ambush, the police said.

title: LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECALLING THE SPANISH WAR The Spanish Civil War erupted 50 years ago, a bloody struggle that was a preview of World War II, which was to follow shortly. The Civil War, between the elected democratic government and the rebel military forces, aroused passions at home and abroad. Its echoes reverberate today, particularly in New York in this anniversary year.

title: U.S. DETAILS WORKINGS OF VAST DRUG RING
description: With drug factories deep inside South American jungles and pamphlets containing tips on how to keep nosy neighbors away from ''stash houses'' in suburban America, little was left to chance in the operation of what Federal officials described today as the largest drug-smuggling ring in the Western Hemisphere.

title: KOREANS LOOKING FOR EXPLANATIONS
description: Despite clear evidence that the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, is alive, a mystery lingered today over the origin of earlier assassination reports and the possibility that they grew out of a continuing power struggle in his Communist nation.

title: Olympic Accord Seen
description: ''I can tell you that I now have the assurance that all the Socialist countries will be present in Seoul,'' the International Olympic Committee president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, told reporters in Albertville, France, after returning from a conference in East Berlin attended by the sports ministers of 19 Communist countries, including North Korea. He described Cuba's agreement to be host to the 1991 Pan American Games in Havana as ''very good news for the Olympic movement.''

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 1986 3-for-2 stock split.

title: RELIGIOUS SURGE BY 'BABY BOOMERS' IS FOUND
description: As they take on more traditional family roles and values, the once-rebellious older members of the ''baby boom'' generation are returning to churches and synagogues, a new study shows.

description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

KOSTA NADJ
description: Kosta Nadj, a retired general, died today after a short illness, the radio announced. He was 75 years old. A veteran of the Spanish Civil War, he was a leading commander of Tito's Communist guerrillas in World War II.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $19.6 million for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the extraordinary charge is for the preminum paid on the purchase of about $300 million of outstanding long-term debt. The company said the latest quarter results reflect a higher effective income tax rate and an increase in the charge for the LIFO inventory accounting method. The higher tax rate reduced third quarter earnings by $4.7 million, or 5 cents a share.

title: YOUTH CHARGED IN A FATTAL FIGHT AT HOUSE PARTY
description: A 16-year-old high school football player was charged with manslaughter today in the death of a former teammate after a fight at a house party Saturday in this northern Fairfield County town.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sep 30
MTV in European Network Venture
description: MTV Networks Inc., which is a unit of Viacom International Inc., said it had joined the Mirror Group Newspapers and British Telecom in beginning a video music network in Europe. Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, is publisher of Mirror Group Newspapers.

title: Alfred Burin Is Dead; Oldest Customs Broker
description: Alfred Burin, chairman of the Globe Shipping Company of Jersey City and the oldest customs broker in the United States, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. Last March 24, he celebrated his 100th birthday on the NBC-TV program, ''The Today Show.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: George Brett underwent surgery on his right shoulder to alleviate pain that caused him to miss 38 games and he is expected to be ready for the start of Kansas City's season. . . . Dana Kirk, who was dismissed as the Memphis State basketball coach in September with 30 months remaining on his contract, has received a lump-sum settlement of more than $170,000, the university said. . . . Randy Williams, a junior quarterback at Kansas State who was benched after fumbling on the second play from scrimmage against Iowa State last Saturday, has quit the team.

title: RETRIAL OF CONSPIRACY CHARGES IN JONESTOWN CASE NEARS END
description: On the eighth anniversary of what has come to be known as the Jonestown massacre, closing arguments began today in the conspiracy retrial of Larry Layton, the only person ever charged in this country with criminal acts in connection with the events surrounding that day.

description: b-Includes writedowns of oil and gas properties of $1.7 million in the quarter and $8.2 million in the 9 months. c-Net income and was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Guilford to Be Sold
description: Debron Investments P.L.C., a British investment company, said it had agreed to acquire Guilford Industries, a maker of fabrics for office interiors, in a cash transaction valued at about $95 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1986
description: The World

title: STRIKE AT G.M. FACTORY IN SOUTH AFRICA COLLAPSES
description: A three-week strike at General Motors collapsed today as workers streamed back after an ultimatum to return or be dismissed.

title: O'KEEFFE EXHIBITION PLANNED
description: The National Gallery of Art announced today that it would mount a major exhibition of the works of Georgia O'Keeffe next year to mark the centennial of the artist's birth. It will open at the National Gallery and be shown later at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Dallas Museum of Art.

description: Anyone whose fingers have accidentally become stuck together while working with Krazy Glue knows how quickly and tenaciously it bonds skin. However, there is little practical benefit in gluing one's finger to one's ear when trying to fix an earring.

title: How Arbitrage Is Practiced
description: Arbitrage, a legal and sophisticated method of investment, has been practiced for years.

description: Elsewhere among the senior citizens, Donald B. Miller, 60 and for many years chairman and chief executive of the Rumrill-Hoyt agency, is being promoted to president and chief executive of Media General Broadcast Services on Jan. 1.

description: Charles A. Whittingham, 56, publisher of Life magazine ever since it came back as a monthly eight years ago, is going to retire in glory at the end of the year, the magazine's 50th anniversary year.

Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in October.

description: The Metropolitan Denver Sewer Disposal District No. 1 is offering $126 million of various sewer revenue bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Included in the financing are about $111.6 million of refunding bonds and $14.4 million of improvement bonds.

title: LANDLORD SENTENCED FOR BRIBERY
description: A 27-year-old Bronx landlord was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison for offering a bribe to a tenant. The tenant had charged that the landlord and a hired ''enforcer'' beat him to force him to pay his rent.

title: AT COCOLAT, THE TRUFFLE IS NOT A TRIFLE
description: TEN years ago this month, Alice Medrich tucked her brown curls under a crisp pastry chef's hat and began creating chocolate desserts. For three days she and a friend worked almost continuously to meet a 10 A.M. Saturday deadline. When she finally unlocked the doors to her new little bake shop, Cocolat, in Berkeley, Calif., chocolate desserts filled every display case. Though the opening was a little late, just before noon, it did not matter. Nobody was there anyway.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months' nets reflect a pre-tax gain of $108.6 million from the sale of property in Los Angeles, a pre-tax gain of $32.2 million from the sale of remaining notes received in connection with a sale of the company's Washington, D.C. location and a pre-tax gain of $8.6 million from the sale of a relocated store in Pittsburgh. The quarter and 9 months' nets also reflect a pre-tax charge of $124 million related to costs of May Department Stores' merger with Associated Dry Goods Corp., which was approved by shareholders Oct. 3, and a pre-tax charge of $50 million to reflect anticipated costs of correcting inventory excesses at Associated D.G. divisions. The latest 9 months' results reflect a first quarter, pre-tax charge of $5.2 million related to the closing of department stores and a first quarter gain of $4.6 million from funds received in connection with the sale of the company's downtown Washington, D.C. location in 1985. Results reflect May Department Stores' acquisition of Associated Dry Goods as a pooling of interest and assume that the companies have been merged since inception.

title: UNITED STATES TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: JERSEY RIVERSIDE PLAN GAINS MOMENTUM
description: It has been nearly three years since Hartz Mountain Industries unfurled its blueprints for Lincoln Harbor, a 45-acre mixed-use waterfront development on the west bank of the Hudson River in Weehawken, N.J. Until now, however, the only building activity that has gone on there has been construction of a pier restaurant on the north end of the site and reconstruction of the former Seatrain facility at the south end of the property.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A TRAGEDY of modern medical care is that, even in an age of virtually instant communication, it often takes years to get the word out about new life- and limb-saving treatments to the people who could most benefit from them. One of these is laser therapy for an insidious disorder called diabetic retinopathy, the leading cause of new cases of blindness among American adults. Some 600,000 people already have early stages of this condition and could lose their sight if it is not detected and promptly treated.

title: JUDGING FINE WINES BY THEIR PRICES
description: WINE drinkers and gift givers who understand wine pricing and do comparison shopping, especially those who buy in volume, can save hefty sums between Thanksgiving and New Year's Eve. On a standard cocktail party or dinner item such as California sauvignon blanc, discounts can save consumers as much as $25.99 a case. But consumers should weigh the low prices discounters offer against the range of services regular merchants provide, wine industry sources say.

title: The Met Museum
description: As part of its $36 million renovation of Shea Stadium, New York City plans to erect seven huge panels bearing multicolor action paintings of baseball players this winter. The panels, each measuring 60 feet wide and 90 feet high, will be put up over the stadium's gates and will cost $100,000 apiece to install and $40,000 more to decorate.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $2.9 million from business restructuring costs. c-Net income and includes a gain of $811,000 from an accounting change for the 9 months.

RETURN IS SOUGHT BY TAIWAN EXILES
description: A Taiwan opposition figure, barred from re-entry last week, hopes the United States will deport him to Taiwan.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
Year-Round Squash
description: THE most important nutritional characteristic of squash may be its seasonal inevitability: after the summer of the Zucchini Imperative comes the Butternut Mandate, which more or less coincides with the House of Pumpkin.

description: President Reagan will seek to defend his secret contacts with Iran at a nationally televised news conference on Wednesday night. But the deeper issue that has seized the White House is the effect of the crisis on the President's final two years in office.

title: SEABROOK A-PLANT IN EVACUATION FIGHT
description: A Massachusetts Congressman and the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission clashed sharply today over whether the staff was giving inappropriate help to the Seabrook nuclear plant in considering whether to shrink the zone for which it must plan for emergency evacuations.

title: A Rise in Working Rigs
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States rose to 910 this week from 874 last week, Hughes Tools Company officials said. It marked the fourth consecutive weekly increase. A year ago, the count stood at 1,942, the officials said.

title: Not What They Seem
description: 1.London Streetscape This tea cozy, modeled after Liberty of London's stately Tudor flagship store, is quilted cotton in shades of brown, rust and gold.

title: IMPROVED SHRIVER IS 6-3, 6-1 WINNER
description: There are times when life on the tennis tour can feel like being on a treadmill, always moving but never making progress. Running in place may be fine for someone such as Martina Navratilova, the No. 1 woman player in the world, who has the luxury of creating her own challenges these days. But for Pam Shriver, getting nowhere fast became a habit she finally decided to break.

description: Hearing on Gypsy Cabs

title: BARBECUE COMES A-CALLING
description: Knives were being sharpened on a Japanese whetstone, baling wire was being bent to resemble huge hairpins and a table was being set up in the dappled shade of gold-leafed trees. Preparations were afoot for the roasting of an 80-pound pig.

title: BODEGAS FIND PROSPERITY AMID CHANGE
description: ALMOST every day old-timers, often sporting Panama hats, gather outside the Sabater Grocery to play dominoes and discuss the latest soccer match.

title: CONCERT:MUSIC BEFORE 1900
description: THE Music Before 1800 series, directed by Louise Basbas and in residence at the Corpus Christi Church (529 West 121st Street), is an excellent example of what can be accomplished by supplementing a limited budget with love, taste, diligence and determination. This listener always looks forward to spending a Sunday afternoon at Corpus Christi, and this week's concert did not disappoint.

description: Mesa Limited Partnership said that it had agreed to exchange $83.5 million in oil and gas properties for a majority interest in the NRM Energy Company L.P., a Dallas-based oil and gas limited partnership. The transaction, which would give Mesa about 54.4 percent of the voting control of NRM Energy, is subject to approval from NRM unit holders.

title: LAROUCHE BENCHING ASSESSED
description: He has been traded, he has been demoted, he has been a star, a savior to more than one franchise, and he has alternately excited his coaches and disillusioned them.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE taste or the appreciation of one food or another is the most subjective of experiences. I reflected on this recently when dining out and someone at my table ordered quail with figs. Later, a friend remarked to me that she considered the combination of meat and fruit to be ''absolutely barbaric.'' Nor was she dissuaded one bit when I reminded her that two classic French dishes were duck a l'orange and sole veronique, which has a white-wine sauce with grapes.

title: Rono Freed on Bail
description: Henry Rono, the Kenyan runner who held four world distance records in 1978, was freed from a Bergen County jail on $5,500 bail Monday night.

title: Iran Now Shadows Reagan With Carter
description: To the Editor:

title: HONDURAS HUNTS LEFTIST BAND
description: The Honduran Army is pursuing what it describes as a small band of leftist guerrillas in rough mountains about 120 miles northeast of the capital of Tegucigalpa.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. %?%?Special Political Committee -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. title: Bradley's Dream Year
description: ''It was truly a dream-come-true year for me,'' said Pat Bradley yesterday when she was honored with three major awards by the Ladies Professional Golf Association. Miss Bradley, the first female golfer to surpass $2 million in career earnings, won five tournaments this year, including three grand-slam events, and swept the triple crown of awards -the Rolex Player of the Year, the Vare Trophy for best stroke average and the Mazda L.P.G.A. Series points title.

title: U.S. BILL ON ARTIST'S RIGHTS IS DEBATED
description: In a crowded meeting room in Manhattan yesterday, artists, art critics, lawyers and a United States Senator discussed a Federal bill under which artists would have the right to collect royalties on the resale of their works and to sue the owner of an artwork if it were destroyed or altered in a way unacceptable to the artist.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are based on Class A common stock outstanding.

description: A salesman for an electronic taxi meter company was indicted in Federal court in Brooklyn yesterday in a case that charged Jay Turoff, the former chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, with fraud.

title: Revere Takes $203 Million Bid
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc., the maker of aluminum and brass products that traces its roots back to the American patriot Paul Revere, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by an investment group for $203 million.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Ways to Give Thanks At Thanksgiving there is an outpouring of generosity. This year, for example, city firehouses are collecting food contributed by the public to distribute to the needy.

title: GREEN MOUNTAIN POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
California Suspect Held In Bouquet Bombing
description: A man identified by the police as the one who delivered a booby-trapped bouquet that injured two women was arrested today at a country house that he is said to have shared with the estranged husband of one of the victims.

title: Judge Upholds Order To Remove 12 Floors
description: A state judge yesterday upheld a city ruling that a building under construction on East 96th Street was 12 stories taller than zoning permits.

title: Guidance for Workers In Filling Out New W-4
description: In filling out the new W-4 form, taxpayers will be given a four-page package that includes line-by-line instructions for figuring exactly how many withholding allowances they can claim. Here are some general guidelines:

title: London Acts on Boesky
description: The London Stock Exchange placed conditions today on its members' dealings with Ivan F. Boesky. Until the exchange's ruling council receives more information on the restrictions placed on Mr. Boesky in the United States, member brokers must contact stock exchange officials before conducting any transaction on his behalf.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances in Jukeboxes; CD's, Video Giving Them A New Lift
description: THE jukebox is going through its biggest technological changes since 45 r.p.m. platters began to replace 78's in 1950. The coin-operated music business, depressed for more than a decade, is bursting forth again with such jazzy innovations as laser videos, compact audio disks and videotapes.

title: Virtues of Innocence
description: ''If we did not have such a thing as an airplane today, we would probably create something the size of NASA to make one. It's a good thing the Wright brothers didn't know any better when they made the machine fly.'' - H. Ross Perot, Chairman of Electronic Data Systems Corp., speaking to Fall Joint Computer Conference in Dallas earlier this month.

title: Jury Selection Begins In Slashing of Model
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of a Manhattan man accused of hiring two of his friends to slash the face of a fashion model.

title: APPEALS COURT BARS CHINATOWN BUILDING TILL EFFECT IS STUDIED
description: The state's highest court ruled yesterday that New York City, before approving a building project, must study what impact it would have on a neighborhood's character and whether it would tend to displace low-income residents.

title: PORTS OF CALL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRENUPTIAL DECREES UP, PRENUPTIAL TRUST DOWN
description: LEO and his fiancee have not gone to the altar yet, but already, it looks as though his first marriage rules his feelings about his next one. In Leo's view - a view that is clearly colored with bitterness - his first wife took him to the cleaners when they were divorced two years ago. He says that as part of the settlement he gave her their $300,000 house so that the children would not have to move. Soon after, he recalls with anger, she moved the children into a smaller place, sold the house and kept the proceeds.

title: Asset-Backed G.M.A.C. Notes

description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,778,000 and includes a reversal of federal income tax benefits of $583,000 applicable to prior three quarters of fiscal year 1986. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,296,000, a loss from partial disposal of discontinued operations of $1,441,000 and an estimated loss on disposal of remaining discontinued operation of $2,000,000, and also includes a reversal of federal income tax benefits of $583,000 applicable to prior three quarters of fiscal year 1986. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $13,000. e-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $896,000. Results for 1985 do not include the All Channel Products division, which was acquired Aug. 3, 1985.

description: Don Mattingly, the Yankee first baseman who played all but six innings in his team's 162 games this past season, said he had ''mixed emotions'' about placing second yesterday to Roger Clemens of the Boston Red Sox, who pitched 254 innings in 33 games and was named the American League's most valuable player.

title: TEST FOR SHUTTLE TERMED A SUCCESS
description: Five astronauts boarded a space shuttle today for the first time since the Challenger disaster, but the mock countdown aboard the shuttle Atlantis was halted 25 seconds short of the simulated engine firing by problems with computer software.

title: The Case for Keeping the Rural Third World to Scale

title: Knicks Talk About Free
description: Wayne Embry, the general manager of the Cleveland Cavaliers, said yesterday that he had spoken with Scotty Stirling of the Knicks last week concerning the possibility of the Knicks' obtaining World B. Free, the free-agent guard. ''He said the team opinion on World was mixed, and that he'd get back to me,'' Embry said.

title: Chip Trade Group Votes To Plan Co-op Venture
description: The main trade group representing American semiconductor manufacturers established a committee today to plan a cooperative manufacturing venture aimed at restoring the industry's ability to compete against the Japanese.

title: RICHARD ARMITAGE, PRODUCER AND AGENT, DIES
description: Richard Armitage, a talent agent who made his debut as a theater producer with the hit revivals of ''Me and My Girl'' in London and New York, died Monday at his home in Stebbing, near London, following a heart attack. He was 58 years old. Mr. Armitage was chairman of Noel Gay Artists Ltd., one of London's biggest talent agencies. Until two years ago, he was best known for having discovered the future television personality David Frost when he was an undergraduate at Cambridge University.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $1,097,000 from equity in the loss of an affiliate.

description: ''It's complete panic. It really is alarming and, unfortunately, until it's all out in the open as to exactly who is involved, which individuals are involved and which firms are involved, it's going to be mass confusion in the investment community.''

description: A leftist extremist group claimed responsibility today for the slaying of the president of Renault.

description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper fell, as the bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 5.790 percent, down from 5.836 percent last week. The accepted bids were all at the average rate.

title: Spokeswoman
description: The State Department appears to be making a concerted and visible effort to overcome its image as a bastion of white male dominance.

title: Stuffing a Whole Fish
description: AT this time of year I usually prepare baked stuffed fish, accompanied by autumn vegetables. I created a stuffing recently for a whole salmon by combining bread crumbs, dried mixed herbs and bits of shrimp.

description: A mistake by an air traffic controller nearly caused two American Airlines planes to collide near the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, Federal Aviation Administration officials said today.

description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has asked President Reagan for a firm commitment not to provide more military equipment to Iran and to agree that future diplomatic contacts with Teheran have State Department participation, Administration officials said today.

title: A Spicy Blend of Caribbean And Black-American Flavors
description: AS an American holiday, Thanksgiving's universality must lie in its ability to welcome succeeding generations of immigrants to these shores. Brooklyn's parkways glide past long-established and overlapping enclaves of Haitians, Barbadians, Jamaicans, Panamanians and Trinidadians among other immigrants from the West Indies. Come Thanksgiving, many of them proudly round up family members for sit-down dinners that are distinctive proof of their adaptability and heritage.

title: Niche Seen For Small Agency
description: AT an age when most advertising people are former advertising people romping about the greens and courts, Howard W. Chalk, 64 years old, is putting his name on an agency's door for the third time.

title: MING DISH AUCTIONED FOR RECORD $1.3 MILLION

description: A witness testified today that he watched the driver of a car stopped by a state trooper five years ago aim and fire at the trooper.

title: MEESE AND THE SUPREME COURT: HE DEALS WITH CRITICS BY SOFTENING HIS REMARKS
description: Amid the furor that often follows Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's critiques of the Supreme Court, a pattern has emerged: Critics denounce what they consider the radical implications of his remarks. Aides say the critics misconstrued his real meaning. And Mr. Meese clarifies his remarks in ways that seem to remove some of their initial sting.

description: Britain today rejected Argentina's offer of a formal end to hostilities in exchange for a lifting of the 150-mile ''military protection zone'' Britain has imposed around the Falkland Islands.

description: Ivan F. Boesky, even after paying $100 million to settle insider trading charges, remains a very rich man. His financial and real estate holdings could amount even now to as much as $200 million, an analysis shows.

description: The funeral of Thierry Le Luron, the comic known for his acid-tongued impersonations of French politicians, was attended today by many of his targets, including Prime Minister Jacques Chirac and the former President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing. A crowd of 5,000 packed the streets outside the Madeleine Church in central Paris to hear the service relayed over loudspeakers. Mr. Le Luron died last week at the age of 34.

title: Florida Killer Granted Stay of Execution
description: A Federal appeals court granted a stay of execution to Ted Bundy today just six hours before he was to be executed for killing a 12-year-old schoolgirl. The Florida Attorney General's office later appealed to the Supreme Court to overturn the stay.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 1
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on the early exinguishment of debt of $14,341,000 for both the 13 weeks and 39 weeks. The company said during the 13 weeks ended Nov. 1, 1986, it repurchased $160,350,000 of 10 1/4 percent sinking fund debentures due to 2010, $86,095,000 of 10 5/8 percent sinking fund debentures due 2013, $28,010,000 of 11 percent Euronotes due 1990 and $22,590,000 of 10 1/8 percent Euronotes due 1995. These repurchases resulted in an extraordinary loss of $14,341,000, net of income tax benefit of $14,527,000, or 29 cents a share. title: A STAMP FOR ELMS? OR MILLER?
description: Glenn Miller and Elvis Presley, their fans will tell you quickly, have little in common musically. But years after their deaths, they are together, nominated again in a long-standing effort to get postage stamps issued in their honor.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income and includes for the 6 months a net gain of $64,037,000 from the sale of the company's beverage subsidiary and an extraordinary loss of $9,947,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change. The company said the latest quarter results include a pre-tax charge of $8,373,000 from the proposed sale of Allegheny's building services unit and a pre-tax charge of $2.5 million to increase reserves for doubtful accounts as a result of adverse economic conditions being experienced by the company.

title: Mark R. Shedd, 60, Educator
description: Mark R. Shedd, the former commissioner of education in Connecticut and superintendent of schools in Philadelphia, died of leukemia Monday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 60 years old and had lived in Yarmouth, Me., since 1983.

title: Mortgage-Backed Unit At Drexel Lures Retiree
description: Robert F. Dall, who initiated a major Wall Street industry when he did the first mortgage-backed securities deal in 1977, has joined Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as a senior vice president after a stab at retirement.

title: The Rock and the Hard Place
description: The whole football-watching nation held its breath Monday night as Joe Montana's scrambling put him in the same awkward position in which he suffered a herniated disk earlier this season. In only his second game since his rapid recovery, Montana turned to pass across the field, but this time he thought better of it, and hunkered down into a less vulnerable posture.

title: WRITERS' HUNGER: FOOD AS METEPHOR
description: WHEN I was interviewed by a friend who is a well-known food specialist, it quickly became clear that we operated from different sensibilities while speaking the same language.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $1,869,000 and $5,028,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $412,000 and $836,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: BALLOONING: ODD SHAPES TAKE TO THE SKY
description: KELLOGG'S newest good-will ambassador is 54 feet tall, and has 13-foot ears and a 25-foot nose. It is a hot-air balloon in the shape of Tony the Tiger that the company is using to promote its products. Tony is one of a number of odd-shaped balloons for which companies have spent from $35,000 to $100,000. Levi's, for instance, owns a pair of floating blue jeans, Winston a pack of cigarettes and Westinghouse a ''flightbulb.''

title: Noranda Sets Mine Merger
description: Noranda Inc., one of Canada's major mining companies, agreed in principle today with three partners to merge their interests in the Golden Giant gold mine and form a new public company.

title: DANCE: 'BLOOD' PREMIERE BY LAR LUBOVITCH TROUPE
description: LAR LUBOVITCH, one of the few choreographers capable of generating genuine excitement nowadays, proceeded to do just that again at the City Center last night: his dance company opened there with a gory little premiere called ''Blood'' and two very fine earlier works.

title: U.S. URGES JURY TO CONVICT 4 IN CITY SCANDAL
description: The Government's chief prosecutor asked a Federal jury today to convict Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and three co-defendants, telling the jurors, ''These defendants, in their quest of money and big dollars, said, 'The public trust, the public good, be damned.' ''

title: Article 970186 -- No Title
description: The World Bank today released $300 million in emergency loan funds to Mexico in the first installment of a complex rescue package that could total $12 billion.

title: Topics: Democracy at Work; Prejudicial
description: Patricia Lara, a reporter for Colombia's largest newspaper, El Tiempo, was denied entry to the United States last month under sections of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act that exclude persons likely to behave prejudicially to American interests. During five days in Immigration Service custody, she demanded to know the reasons for the charges but received none.

title: Simon Skosana, Homeland Chief
description: Simon S. Skosana, Chief Minister of KwaNdebele, who dropped plans to accept nominal independence for his black homeland after scores were killed in violence, died Monday after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: DOROTHY ALEXANDER, BALLET FIGURE
description: Dorothy Alexander, founder of the Atlanta Ballet, America's oldest ballet company, and a pioneering figure in the American regional ballet movement, died of cancer Monday in an Atlanta hospital. She was 82 years old.

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Gershwin Is Lauded In Capital
description: WITH a well-dressed and obviously well-off audience listening attentively to Gershwin, it might be just a normal evening at a nightspot like the Algonquin's Oak Room. But this session is taking place in the East Room of the White House, and that is why it's on public television tonight at 9 (airing in the New York area on Channels 13, 21 and 49). Heretofore, ''In Performance at the White House'' has focused largely on classical music, using an established performer to introduce younger artists. This season, with John Musilli as executive producer for Camera Three Productions, the series is offering tributes to composers of American show music. Also on tap: the scores of Rodgers and Hart, Harold Arlen and Cole Porter.

title: Who Should Speak for Afghanistan?
description: A bizarre ruckus occurred at the United Nations when leaders of the Afghanistan resistance came to speak at a recent correspondents' lunch. They were attacked and pummeled by ''diplomats'' representing the Kabul regime, which owes its survival to the presence of 120,000 Soviet troops. The episode raises an interesting question: By what right does Kabul speak for Afghanistan in the General Assembly in the first place?

title: FOR CERTAIN, NO. 99 IS OUT
description: ''I'll believe it when I see it,'' Don Shula said on Monday, when told that Mark Gastineau will not face the Dolphins next Monday night.

description: It was noon at the shelter for homeless men in the Bedford Avenue Armory in Brooklyn. Near the metal detectors at the front door, a young security guard was ousting a man in a too-small camel's-hair coat for the third time.

title: FILM: 'EYES ON PRIZE,' RIGHTS STRUGGLE
description: THE nobility of America's civil-rights struggle comes through with the directness and strength of a spiritual in ''Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years, 1954-1965.'' An early look at this moving documentary, which is to be shown on public television in January and February, can now be had at the Film Forum 1.

title: GOODYEAR AND SIR JAMES SQUARE OFF
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier, charged today that management of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, his latest takeover target, had ''lost its way,'' squandered hundreds of millions of dollars and now sought Government protection from the consequences of its ill-conceived diversification.

title: THEATER: 'THE HANDS OF ITS ENEMY'
description: IN ''Children of a Lesser God,'' a Broadway hit of 1980, the playwright Mark Medoff spoke up for the right of deaf people to dignity, fulfillment and nonverbal eloquence. In ''The Hands of Its Enemy,'' his first play since then, Mr. Medoff reunites with his deaf leading lady of the previous venture, Phyllis Frelich, but to less noble ends. If there's a coherent, overriding point to the new work at the Manhattan Theater Club - and don't bet on it - maybe it's that deaf people can be as undignified, destructive and, yes, loud-mouthed as everybody else. In Mr. Medoff's Act I climax, the heroine blurts out a four-letter word that takes us a very long way from the benign ''water'' with which Helen Keller broke her silence in ''The Miracle Worker.''

description: Former Vice President Paulo Muwanga was charged today with the kidnapping and murder of two Ugandans who disappeared five years ago during the administration of President Milton Obote. Mr. Muwanga pleaded not guilty.

title: Guinness Kidnapper Jailed
description: Brian McNicholl, the last of four men convicted of kidnapping Jennifer Guinness, the wife of John Henry Guinness, a banker, was sentenced today to 12 years in prison. He was convicted Monday of kidnapping and firearms charges. Judge Dominic Lynch said he accepted police evidence that Mr. McNicholl's role had been to provide a house to detaining Mrs. Guinness.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IN 1971, The New England Journal of Medicine reported the discovery of a connection between a rare form of cancer in young women and a synthetic estrogen called diethylstilbestrol. The drug, which became known familiarly as DES, had been given to pregnant women thought to be in danger of miscarrying, and the cancer was occurring in some of their daughters. It was not until two years after the first reports that I found out I was one of the young women at risk.

title: DANCE: EIKO AND KOMA IN BROOKLYN
description: THE dances of Eiko and Koma seldom last long. ''New Moon Stories,'' which they presented Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, lasted barely more than an hour. Yet it consisted of four separate works: three older pieces that the Japanese-born dancers and choreographers offered in revised versions and a totally new dance commissioned by the academy. Dancegoers who watched their clocks could have pointed out that the four works were soon done. But anyone who watched the stage could have seen that Eiko and Koma danced as if they had all the time in the world.

title: Hill, Holliday Becomes A 2d LJN Toys Agency
description: The New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos has been named by LJN Toys as its second agency, and its assignment is to promote five high-tech electronic toys, including Photon, a laser gun. The budget will be about $15 million.

title: Revlon Is Confident On Drexel's Funds
description: The Revlon Group said yesterday that Drexel Burnham Lambert had provided assurance that it would be able to provide the bulk of the financing for Revlon's proposed $4.12 billion takeover of the Gillette Company.

title: CONCERT: CINCINNATI COMPOSERS
description: WE hear much talk of ''uptown'' and ''downtown'' styles of new music, occasionally even of ''East Coast'' and ''West Coast'' composers. The fact that there is a great deal of music being written between the Hudson and the California shore was eloquently brought home to Christ and St. Stephen's Church Tuesday night with a program of works featuring the Cincinnati Composers' Guild.

title: The Case for Carter and Clemens
description: In baseball, most judgment calls are more objective than subjective, even for the most subjective rooter. Ball or strike. Safe or out. But no matter who is awarded the Most Valuable Player plaques each year, the subjective voting invariably stirs the coals in baseball's hot stove. Seldom have the coals burst into flame as they did now. And in one man's opinion, Gary Carter deserved to win in the National League instead of Mike Schmidt, but Don Mattingly did not deserve to win in the American League instead of Roger Clemens.

OPERA: 'ROMEO' AT MET
description: DIANA SOVIERO'S performance in ''Romeo et Juliette'' Monday at the Metropolitan Opera, where she has been filling in as Juliet since Cecilia Gasdia fell ill and returned to Italy, was not as successful as admirers of her work at the City Opera and elsewhere might have expected. In part this is a matter of suitability for the role: both Miss Gasdia and Miss Soviero have flourished mostly in the Italian repertory, but the combination of stultifying years-ahead casting and improvisation to fill the few gaps that arise leaves the Metropolitan with one hand tied behind its back when it comes to putting new singers into the most appropriate roles.

title: At UMass, A Pitch for Calm
description: One night three weeks ago, right after the last pitch of the World Series, hundreds of students at the University of Massachusetts campus in Amherst poured out of their dormitories. Most of them were frustrated Red Sox fans, some were celebrating Met fans, and many were soon engaged in brawling, beatings and vandalism that are still under investigation by the university police and an outside fact-finder appointed by the school's chancellor, Joseph Duffey. Ten students were injured, one so badly that he has had to wear a neck brace and use crutches.

title: SIX POLICE OFFICERS SHOT IN BRONX WHILE TRYING TO MAKE AN ARREST
description: Six police officers were shot, four seriously, while attempting to apprehend a murder suspect last night at an apartment in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx.

title: STAGE: FROM TINA HOWE, 'COASTAL DISTURBANCES'
description: IN his brilliant lighting for Tina Howe's new play, ''Coastal Disturbances,'' the designer Dennis Parichy has captured the entire spectrum of weather known to habitues of New England beaches in August. Mr. Parichy graces the horizon of Tony Straiges's sand-carpeted set not merely with the blinding sunniness of midday but also with the frail pink cumulus clouds of dusk, the chilly mica silver of a lost rainy afternoon and the pale, smoky blue of a foggy dawn. Not that a catalogue of colors tells the whole story. What lifts Mr. Parichy's work beyond decoration and into poetry is his ability to unfurl the transitory sky that hasn't yet determined what's going to be. It's that blank canvas of heaven, pregnant with the volatile possibilities of precipitous change, that gives the beach its true romance.

description: Doug Sulliman scored with 1 minute 17 seconds remaining tonight to lift the Devils to a 4-3 victory over Detroit.

title: Illusion and Reality
description: The Iran affair illuminates a crucial element in President Reagan's political success, just as it may finally fail him. That is his phenomenal sense of how a policy should be made to appear in order to play well in the country.

title: THE SOUTH KOREAN VERSION: WHAT THE LOUDSPEAKERS SAID
description: The rumors, now dispelled, that Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, had been assassinated were based largely on announcements by North Korean loudspeakers at the border. Here are excerpts, provided by the South Korean Government, from loudspeaker announcements said to have been made by North Korea over three days. The loudspeakers were said to have been positioned at points along the Korean demilitarized zone, most of them in the western sector near the truce village of Panmunjom. Sunday

The National Council on the Aging will announce today that the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation has provided $3.8 million to underwrite this program, called Family Friends, for four years.

title: Buffalo to Get Quake Center Despite Plagiarism in Report
description: Parts of a winning proposal to build an earthquake research center in Buffalo were copied from already published materials, but the offense was not serious enough to reverse the award, the National Science Foundation says.

title: CERAMICS DISPLAY: SERENITY, ENERGY
description: THE bowls and bottles of Lucie Rie are forms of classic serenity, glazed in muted tones. Ralph Bacerra's oversized boxes and plates are energetic, covered with dizzying patterns in vibrant chromas. The works of the two ceramic artists, on display at the Garth Clark Gallery, seem poles apart but there are underlying parallels. Both artists are meticulous craftsmen, setting firm objectives for themselves. Uninhibited impulse is not permitted to play a role.

title: STAGE: 'CIRQUE IMAGINAIRE'
description: THE circus comes in three guises - three-ring, one-ring and ''Le Cirque Imaginaire,'' the fanciful creation of Victoria Chaplin and her husband, Jean Baptiste Thierree. In this show, which opened Tuesday at the Triplex Theater, Miss Chaplin, the third of Charlie Chaplin's daughters, stands in for an entire troupe of aerialists, equilibrists and wire-walkers. She also plays tame and wild animals, which she evokes through the chimerical use of costumes and masks. Singly, Mr. Thierree represents all the clowns. Together, they are a complete, portable toy circus.

title: Festival Will Mount 3 Shakespeare Plays
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival will present ''Titus Andronicus,'' ''Much Ado About Nothing'' and ''Love's Labour's Lost'' next summer at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, Joseph Papp, producer and founder of the free Shakespeare in the Park program, announced yesterday.

title: C.I.A. Begins Training 70 Nicaraguan Rebels
description: An estimated 70 Nicaraguan rebels recently began receiving United States-sponsored training in what was the first direct American support of the rebels in two years, the rebels' spokesman here said today.

title: 'IT HAD TO BE YOU': THE LOEBS CELEBRATE 60 YEARS TOGETHER
description: ON Nov. 19, 1926, The New York Times carried a front-page story on George Bernard Shaw's accepting the Nobel Prize in Literature but refusing the $40,000 that went along with the award (he said he had quite enough for his needs and likened the prize to a life belt thrown to a swimmer who had already reached shore). Inside the paper, under Social News, there was a one-column account of the previous day's wedding of 20-year-old Frances Lehman to 24-year-old John Loeb at the Park Avenue home of her grandfather Adolph Lewisohn.

title: RHEOMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Buyout Talks End at Beverly
description: Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest operator of nursing homes and long-term care facilities, said that discussions between the company, based in Pasadena, Calif., and a group of executives about a leveraged buyout had ended.

title: Teresa Berganza Recital Canceled Due to Injury
description: The mezzo-soprano Teresa Berganza has canceled her recital of Nov. 28 at Alice Tully Hall because of an injured eardrum that will prevent her from flying for at least two months from her home in Spain, Lincoln Center has announced. Refunds will be granted, or tickets may be exchanged for seats to a recital by Christa Ludwig and James Levine on April 12 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: BankAmerica Suitor Is Busy
description: The First Interstate Bancorp has begun talks with Citicorp and possibly some other banks that might be interested in buying assets that First Interstate would want to sell if it gains control of BankAmerica, banking sources said.

title: CITY BALLET: 85TH SEASON
description: THE New York City Ballet opened its 85th season on Tuesday at the New York State Theater with glitter, some good dancing and a thank you. The expression of thanks came at the start of the evening, as Peter Martins, who directs City Ballet with Jerome Robbins, stepped to the front of the curtain to welcome the audience and dedicate the evening to the late Mae L. Wien, a generous patron of the company. The benefit audience was fairly glittery. But the real glitter came when Sean Lavery and Patricia McBride sidled out onto the stage in an excerpt from George Balanchine's ''Who Cares?,'' followed by Darci Kistler giving a dream of a performance in Balanchine's ''Symphony in C.''

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: In the absence of breaking developments to indicate where interest rates are headed, yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: MOVIE MAKER'S TRIAL AFTER 2 1/2 MONTHS
description: Lea Purwin D'Agostino made a notable announcement to reporters covering the ''Twilight Zone'' manslaughter trial the other day. Two and a half months after the start of the trial of the movie director John Landis and four others, the prosecutor said she had reached the halfway mark in presenting her case. She plans to call 100 witnesses in all.
