title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Rises 9.42 Points
description: An uneasy sense of calm returned to Wall Street yesterday as investors, while still treating takeover stocks like pariahs, began buying shares of some nonspeculative, blue-chip issues.

title: UTILITY'S TENUOUS TURNAROUND
description: In a year at the helm of the Consumers Power Company, William T. McCormick Jr. has generally won praise for steering the nation's 14th-largest utility away from financial disaster. But many skeptics contend that a vital element of the company's turnaround may yet elude him.

title: CITY ESTIMATE BOARD ORDERED TO ESTABLISH ONE-MAN, ONE-VOTE
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the structure of New York City's powerful Board of Estimate violates the Constitutional principle of one-man, one-vote, and ordered the city to change the board's method of voting.

title: Ford Motor Credit Offers 8% Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of 8 percent noncallable notes due 1996 at a price of 99.45, to yield 8.081 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: DARWIN W. BOLDEN
description: Darwin W. Bolden, a former national executive director of the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, died of a heart attack last Thursday while waiting for a bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal. He was pronounced dead at St. Clare's Hospital.

title: IMMINENT RATE CUT DOUBTED
description: The environment for a new reduction in interest rates has improved over the last two or three months, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Manuel H. Johnson, said today. But he indicated that another reduction was not imminent.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS A STAY FOR BUNDY
description: The Supreme Court refused today to overturn a stay of execution granted Ted Bundy just six hours before he was to have been executed Tuesday for the slaying of a Florida schoolgirl.

title: 17 MICHIGAN CONCERNS TO PAY BIG POLLUTION FINES
description: The State of Michigan has imposed heavy penalties on 17 companies over the issue of discharging pollutants into state waters in the last three years at levels exceeding state and Federal limits.

title: CLOUD OVER TAKEOVER STOCKS
description: For now at least, shock waves from the fall of Ivan F. Boesky, Wall Street's biggest speculator in takeover stocks, appear to be splitting the equity market in two - separating the ''deal,'' or takeover, issues from the vastly larger list of companies outside that category.

title: Navistar Pensions

The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation also agreed not to impose a lien on any assets pending a trial, Navistar said. In 1981, the agency sought a $125 million lien aganst Navistar, which was then known as the International Harvester Company.

STARTING KINDERGARTEN A BIT OLDER AND WISER
description: ''I WAS amazed,'' said Rachel Yarmolinsky, whose son recently started kindergarten at a private school on Manhattan's West Side. ''He turned 5 last June, and he is one of the youngest in his class. We've gone to a birthday party every weekend since school began - in each case, for a classmate who was turning 6. More than half the class will be 6 by January.''

title: Rolls-Royce, G.E. End Pact

First Chicago Chooses 'Doer' as Vice Chairman
description: When the First Chicago Corporation elected William J. McDonough vice chairman last week, it was in recognition of his mastery of the bank's nuts and bolts. In his new post, Mr. McDonough, who will retain his position as chief financial officer, will be in charge of strategic planning, credit and systems management, accounting, economic research, treasury and human resources. The 52-year-old Chicago native was also elected to First Chicago's board.

title: REAGAN AND LAW: ISSUE OF 'TIMELY' NOTICE
description: President Reagan contended at his news conference tonight that he had a legal right not to inform members of Congressabout secret intelligence operations ''until such time as I believe it can safely be done.''

title: NIXON SUGGESTS AIDE TO BE BERGEN COUNTY SHERIFF
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, who has lived in Saddle River since 1981, has stepped into local political affairs. He has written to Bergen County's two top Republicans to appoint a part-time security aide to be county sheriff.

title: THE HANDYMAN SPECIAL TAKES LOVE OF LABOR
description: ONCE upon a time, a house that was a bit frayed around the edges was called a handyman special and was sold at a lower price to people who liked to keep a screwdriver and a paintbrush in hand. Now, however, the term refers to houses that are not just frayed. They often require their buyers to forgo their nights, weekends, vacations, spare cash, books, movies, television, mental clarity, cleanliness, friends and matrimonial harmony.

title: Gorbachev Loosens the Screws a Bit
description: Former Soviet dissidents and refuseniks have noted an abrupt change of attitude among Soviet diplomats in recent weeks. Instead of stonewalling questions on human rights, the officials speak of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new policy of openness and cite well-publicized releases of dissidents, including that of my father, David Goldfarb, last month. Yet for a careful observer, these gestures, however welcome, can hardly signify a change in Soviet policy. Mr. Gorbachev should follow through on his rhetoric and announce the release of political prisoners and grant Jewish refuseniks the right to emigrate.

title: Q AND A
description: Q.Rug tape is most helpful in keeping my rugs in place temporarily, but the bathroom and bedroom floors now have black streaks and blotches of old tape. How can I remove these remnants? A.A plastic scraper - the kind for scraping a freezer - should remove most of the tape. If this is difficult, soften the tape remnants by heating with a hair dryer. Remove any sticky residue with a rag saturated with rubber-cement thinner (sold in art supply stores). Lighter fluid can be used, but it is highly flammable, so use proper precautions. Dry-cleaning fluid often works, too.

Muhammad Ali, 44 years old, was married in Louisville, Ky., to Lonnie Williams, 28. It was the fourth marriage for the former heavyweight champion.

title: VIDEO CASSETTES FOR HOME REPAIRS: INFORMATIVE TO USELESS

title: Tsk-Tsk on Torture at the U.N.
description: A few weeks ago in the village of Vardavard on the outskirts of Karaj, a town near Teheran, a 16-year-old boy, Bijan Talebi, was murdered by a mob of Moslem fanatics. His mangled body was thrown into a garden and police certified that death was caused by beating. When his family sought justice, the authorities treated them as the criminals, arresting the boy's mother, brother and a cousin. They are now in solitary confinement in Teheran. Why? Because the Talebis are Bahais, a faith stigmatized as heretical by the Islamic rulers of Iran.

description: Each ADR represents five shares of common stock. Results for the latest year are calculated using a conversion rate of 156 Japanese yen to each U.S. dollar; the conversion rate used for the prior year was 237.10 yen to each dollar.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF URGES AID CHANGE
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett said today that ''skyrocketing'' costs for higher education would make fundamental reform of the Federal student aid program essential.

title: Town Judge to Appeal Effort to Dismiss Him
description: An upstate town justice, who faces the prospect of being removed from office for neglecting his duties, has decided to appeal his case to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: Steinberg Move
description: The New York investor Saul Steinberg, operating through his Reliance Group Holdings, bought 3.5 million shares in Mercury International Group, increasing his stake to an estimated 13.5 percent and prompting speculation that he intends a takeover. Mercury includes Warburg's merchant bank and has emerged as one of Britain's four biggest security houses. It has said it believed it should remain independent without a dominant shareholder.

title: Boesky Terms: Too Lenient?
description: FROM all appearances, when Ivan F. Boesky agreed to pay Uncle Sam a stunning $100 million to settle insider charges against him, both parties thought they had gotten a good deal.

title: Missouri Agency In Mortgage Issue
description: The Missouri Housing Development Commission is offering $100 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.60 percent for an issue due 2018 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $1.6 million writedown of certain rental equipment for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Their Trade Horrors - and Ours
description: Argentine exporters aren't allowed to buy marine insurance from foreign insurers . . . India bans imports of most manufactured consumer goods . . . Norway prohibits apple imports until its own apples run out . . . The BBC limits foreign television shows to 12 percent of its air time.

title: CANNON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: CABARET: RIAT GARDNER
description: ALTHOUGH Rita Gardner first sang the cycle of 1920's songs that Will Holt has organized as ''Say It With Music'' five years ago, it is only in the last year that there have been opportunities to bring it to a fine polish. After a single performance at St. Peter's Church early in the year and two weeks at the Ballroom in September, it has returned to the Ballroom, 253 West 28 Street, for a run that will continue through Dec. 27.

HOME UNITY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in October.

title: ELWAY KEEPS HIS PASSES OUT OF THE WRONG HANDS
description: If John Elway was not born with a silver spoon in his mouth, it might have been a silver football in his hands.

title: Listening to Music With the Eyes
description: EVERY serious concertgoer has experienced that lonely moment of dissent rising against a wall of vigorous approval. ''Were we at the same concert?'' is the customary refrain. Two recent experiences give new freshness to the question.

title: CONFUSION OVER IRAN
description: In justifying his decision to make secret arms sales to Iran, President Reagan acknowledged today for the first time that the moves had been ''deeply controversial'' among his top aides.

TRC COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Borough President To Give Arts Awards
description: A ceremony marking the first presentation of the annual Manhattan Borough President's Awards for Excellence in the Arts will be held Tuesday at 8 P.M. at City College, Davis Hall, Convent Avenue and 134th Street. The winners will be announced that night.

title: School Board Adopts New Consent Form
description: The Board of Education yesterday approved a new parental consent form listing prescriptions for contraceptives as one service available to high school students who use health clinics in nine city schools.

title: SOVIET TO PRINT MORE NABOKOV WORKS
description: The Soviet Union plans to publish more works by Vladimir Nabokov, who until three months ago had never appeared in print in his homeland, the official press agency, Tass, said today.

title: Late Night . . .
description: At radio station WKRC in Cincinnati, they were sitting around talking Tuesday about the tedious length of Monday night's football game -3 hours 48 minutes - when somebody got an idea. Why not have Dave Lee, a disk jockey locally renowned for his abilities as an impressionist, call Pete Rozelle's office and issue a complaint in the voice of Forrest Gregg, the Green Bay coach?

title: FOR SOME SENATORS-ELECT, CAPITOL HILL ORIENTATION IS A HOMECOMING
description: A group of 11 Democrats and 2 Republicans, newly elected to the Senate, began their orientation on Capitol Hill today. For the most part, they were well prepared, and unawed.

title: Love From, Howard
description: The 11-year-old Boy Scout wrote to his scoutmaster, ''I was glad to get your letter and I hope I can come to your camp next year and bring my friend Dudley Sharp. I have joined the Y.M.C.A. and like it very much.

title: PRAXIS PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chase Manhattan Picks Chief Financial Officer
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had promoted its controller, Michael P. Esposito Jr., to chief financial officer.

title: AUTOSPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: THE Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered an appealing concert Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall, and an observer not used to hearing the society's programs in their third and last performance had to wonder if the polish reflected the in-public practice the musicians had enjoyed in the previous concerts. Ordinarily, when society performances err, it is in the direction of a certain perfunctoriness, highly competent professionals batting out the music without the optimum degree of command or deeply practiced sensitivity. On Tuesday, the closeness of ensemble and deftness of technical execution proved very winning.

title: Everglades Guardian
description: Gov. Bob Graham of Florida will make his first Washington appearance as a Senator-elect tonight when he receives the 1986 Conservationist of the Year Award of the National Parks and Conservation Association. Senator-elect Graham, whose victory two weeks ago helped the Democrats regain Senate control, is being recognized for ''his leadership in protecting and restoring the eco-system of Everglades National Park.'' The award will be presented at the association's annual dinner at the Capital Hilton Hotel by its board chairman, Stephen McPherson, who is a grandson of the first director of the National Park Service.

title: Form With Function, on Display
description: ''In the past several years I've notices that artists and sculptors, who normally do not design furniture or anything functional, have turned to making objects for the home as an extension of their art,'' said Rick Barnett, director of the Hal Bromm Gallery. Mr. Barnett, far left, and his guest curator, the sculptor Barbara Sahlman, near left, have arranged a show of furniture by artists, called ''Home Sweet Home,'' at the gallery. Russell Sharon's paper-covered lamp, painted with a tree ($100), stands next to them.

title: Motorized Tricycles Studied
description: Restricting use of all-terrain vehicles by children, improving rider training and requiring better suspensions could help reduce accidents involving the popular motorized tricycles, staff members of the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today.

title: MUTUAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in September.

title: Forklift at Airport Kills Cargo Handler
description: A forklift ran over a cargo handler and killed her yesterday at Newark International Airport, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: Boston Symphony Director
description: The Boston Symphony announced the appointment yesterday of Kenneth Haas as managing director of the orchestra effective March 16. Mr. Haas, for the last 10 years the manager of the Cleveland Orchestra, succeeds Thomas W. Morris, who resigned in January.

title: Pro Corp. Changes Line
description: A century-old toothbrush maker is leaving the business to focus on making plastic moldings. The Pro Corporation, formerly the Pro-phy-lac-tic Brush Company, will lay off 80 people, its director of administration, Robert F. Ulm, said Monday.

title: Alaska Air in Pact To Buy Horizon
description: Alaska Air Group Inc. said it had agreed to buy Seattle-based Horizon Air, one of the nation's largest regional carriers, in a cash deal valued at about $68 million.

title: DEMOCRACY CALLING: IT'S WOMEN'S NEW SELLING JOB
description: When democracy returned three years ago, many people worried that it might become just another of the pendulum swings that have marked Argentina's political life for half a century.

title: GOLDMAN'S JAPAN TIE IS CLEARED
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it had approved a $500 million equity investment by the Sumitomo Bank Ltd. of Japan in the Wall Street firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company, after both concerns had agreed to substantial changes in their original agreement.

title: HERS
description: I AM uncertain whether it is the land or the people inhabiting the land that gives one the conviction of belonging to a particular place.

ARYT OPTRONICS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Intermountain Power Expands Bond Offering
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, a Utah institution, is tentatively offering $492 million of refunding revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: MOYERS WILL SEVER CBS TIE
description: After weeks of arduous negotiations involving top corporate management at CBS, Bill Moyers told his colleagues at CBS News yesterday that he was, after all, cutting his professional ties with the network.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FILM: 'TANGOS: THE EXILE OF GARDEL'
description: ''Tangos: The Exile of Gardel'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 8. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: BRITISH INVESTIGATE BOESKY TIE
description: In a broadening of the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading inquiry overseas, British authorities have begun gathering information on the trading activities of London-based investment firms linked to the Wall Street speculator, British Government and stock market officials said today.

title: FIRST LIBERTY FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $151,000 from distribution of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock.

title: Ira Berger, 46, Is Dead; A Dean at Law School
description: Ira Berger, dean of public affairs at the New York Law School and former president of Gay Men's Health Crisis, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. HEALTH CHIEF OFFERS PLAN TO COVER CATASTROPHIC ILLNESS
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today proposed a wide range of new Government programs and tax incentives for individuals and private industry to provide or purchase insurance for catastrophic illnesses.

title: Dailey Goes to Minors
description: Quintin Dailey, a four-year veteran of the Chicago Bulls, has signed a contract with the Jacksonville Jets of the Continental Basketball Association. Dailey, 25, entered a drug-rehabilitation program twice during the 1985-86 season, and was suspended by Chicago after the second admission. Dailey's contract with the Bulls, which reportedly paid him $325,000 a year, was not renewed.

title: KEITHLEY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
USG Plans A Buyback
description: The USG Corporation, the diversified building products concern that has been the target of several takeover rumors, said today that it planned to repurchase up to 20 percent of its common stock outstanding.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: RODIME PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results have been translated from pounds sterling to dollars using the Sept. 30 exchange rate of 1 pound is equal to $1.44; earnings figures are based on U.S. G.A.A.P.

title: CONSUMER SPENDING OFF SHARPLY
description: Personal spending in the United States plunged 2 percent in October, the biggest drop in 27 years of record-keeping, following an auto-buying spree in September, the Government reported today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: PAUL THEROUX'S adventure novel ''The Mosquito Coast'' has a much bleaker vision than the movie directed by Peter Weir and starring Harrison Ford. But even with some of the more acerbic qualities of the book's antihero, Allie Fox, toned down, it took more than three years for the producer, Jerome Hellman, to raise the money to shoot a movie that most studio executives found simply not sufficiently ''high-concept.'' What is high-concept? ''It has absolutely no meaning, as far as I can tell,'' Mr. Hellman said. ''I guess it's an idea that can be expressed in a sentence so simplistic that there is no chance of confusion, and it probably entails an upbeat ending. If we had been willing to have Allie emerge a changed man who learned from his experience and took his family back to New England, we would have had no trouble.''

title: How to Focus on the Homeless
description: One man spent days marching up and down Broadway, tormented by the voice of Ho Chi Minh. A woman who believed she was a cop stood for years on a Manhattan corner, vigorously directing traffic. Another man, terrified of the Mafia, cowered in trash at the bottom of a stairwell.

title: RAIDERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Marcus Allen burst 28 yards off right tackle for a touchdown with 6 minutes 27 seconds left in overtime tonight, giving the Los Angles Raiders a 37-31 victory over the San Diego Chargers.

title: THE DANCE: DAVID GORDON'S PICK UP COMPANY
description: DAVID GORDON offered an ultimately very satisfying dance experience on Wednesday, when he and his Pick Up Company opened a four-performance engagement as part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Here was a weaving together of a highly developed and refined humanism with the minimalism of the postmodernist era in which Mr. Gordon came of age as a choreographer and performer. Mr. Gordon has merged the theatrical and the abstract to make a theater without words. There is sometimes a slight monotony to the repetition in his dance, and occasionally it is off-putting in its persistently ironic overtones. But Mr. Gordon's dance is a rich, warm and rigorously plotted weave, and his vision a grand and comic one.

title: TORO COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Riding the City Parks On a Rented Mount
description: The beauty of autumn is only a gallop away with a horseback ride through most of the city's public parks. Most stables offer guided rides and steeds for solo exploring.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1986
description: The World

title: GLOBAL PROGRAM AIMS TO COMBAT AIDS 'DISASTER'
description: The World Health Organization announced today that it had begun the first coordinated global effort to combat AIDS, a disease it described as ''a health disaster of pandemic proportions.''

title: WORLD BANK APPROVES A LOAN FOR CHILE
description: The executive board of the World Bank approved a $250 million loan to Chile today despite strong objections by human rights groups and Democratic members of Congress.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1986
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: Bridge: When Bid Is One No-Trump, What Is Enough for a Raise?
description: A player with a balanced hand and about 19 high-card points usually bids a suit and then jumps in no-trump. But that assumes that his partner has shown some strength.

title: Vatican's Letter Respects Homosexuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Shovels in the White House
description: Forget the embarrassing bumbles President Reagan committed in his news conference Wednesday; they'll soon be corrected. The bigger news concerns two sensible steps he took to contain the Iran fiasco - and, more important, the larger move he did not make. He still must put his White House in order.

title: 'There's No Joy in Mudville'
description: At a meeting with a European dignitary in the Oval Office the other day, Ronald Reagan smiled as his visitor remarked that these must be a difficult days around the White House.

title: A PARLAY WITHOUT PRECEDENT
description: These are the top seasons they're surpassing:

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: BISTRO-STYLE restaurants are the rage this fall, perhaps in reaction to over-or chestrated new American cuisine or just a yearning to get back to basic soul-warming food. Among the latest to appear is Brasserie Bijou, formerly Ruelle's, on Columbus Avenue at 75th Street. With a glass-enclosed sidewalk cafe, two levels separated by a grand staircase and lots of palm trees and Gallic knickknacks, it sports a bustling and festive air that approximates its French counterparts.

title: SCREEN: 'AMERICAN TAIL'
description: ''AN AMERICAN TAIL'' is Don Bluth's second animated theatrical feature - after ''The Secret of N.I.M.H.'' (1982) - and the first such children's film to open with a pogrom and to end with an entire species being forcefully ''relocated.''

title: TIME TAKES A NEW APPROACH
description: In a move that would make Time Inc. a major player in the women's magazine field, the giant magazine publisher has agreed to buy a 50 percent interest in McCall's and two other monthly publications, Working Woman and Working Mother.

title: The 'Little Ferry That Worked' Has Not Sunk
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 CONVICTED IN A DRUG SCHEME USING EAST RIVER SWIMMERS
description: Nine Colombian nationals were convicted yesterday in Brooklyn of being part of a cocaine-smuggling operation that used swimmers, who sometimes spent up to nine hours in the cold waters of the East River, to retrieve drugs lowered overboard from Colombian ships.

title: Partners Get 4.8% of Lear
description: AFG Partners, anticipating the failure of the Wickes Companies' $1.7 billion bid to acquire Lear Siegler Inc., said today that it had bought a 4.8 percent stake in the aerospace, automotive and manufacturing company.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 7.3%, TO A RECORD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 31.9 million shares, or 7.3 percent, in the month ended Nov. 14, to a record 469.1 million shares. The previous high, a revised 437.2 million shares, was set Oct. 15. The short interest for the period a year earlier was 262.8 million shares.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEW YORK HOPES TO LEARN FROM RINK TRUMP FIXED
description: Anthony B. Gliedman, the former City Housing Commissioner, had been in his new job less than three weeks when his new employer, Donald J. Trump, called him into his office on the morning of May 22.

title: JAPAN YIELDS TO U.S. ON CHIPS
description: Under pressure from United States Government officials, the Japanese Government has ordered Japan's semiconductor makers to raise sharply the price of chips they sell to Southeast Asia, South America and Europe, industry officials here said today.

title: PERPETUAL SAVINGS BANK FSB reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $894,000 for a pre-payment penalty on retirement of debt. c-Includes a gain of $3,698,000 related to a Federal Home Loan Mortage Corp. stock distribution and a tax credit.

title: HASIDIC FESTIVAL
description: The 18th Israeli Hasidic Festival with music based on biblical verse and dance, will be presented this weekend at Hunter College, Park Avenue at 69th Street.

title: Egypt to Raise Oil Price
description: Egypt, which has supported an OPEC call for higher oil prices, said today that it would raise the price of its crude oil by up to $1.60 a barrel for the last 10 days of November.

title: F.D.I.C. Denies Assistance Request
description: BancTexas Group Inc. said today that Federal regulators had denied requests for financial assistance made by two concerns attempting to buy the bank holding company.

title: STAGE: 'SHOGUN MACBETH'
description: VICTORIOUS in battle, the general is awarded the title Ryoshu of Akita. Almost immediately he is consumed by ambition and activates a plot to become Shogun himself. With the incitement of his wife, he begins to slaughter his way to the crown. In the background, uttering dire incantations, are ''three weird Yojos.''

title: Chrysler Plans Rebates, Rate Cuts
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it will offer cut-rate financing or cash rebates on several truck models and its Aries and Reliant compact cars beginning Friday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review on Wednesday of the documentary ''Eyes on the Prize:

title: SAFETY TEST OF SPACE SHUTTLE MOST EXTENSIVE IN PROGRAM
description: In a test today prompted by the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, a simulated fuel leak in the shuttle Atlantis set off a emergency evacuation of the launching pad, complete with an astronaut faking injuries.

title: Treatment for Rono
description: Henry Rono, the distance runner who has been charged with four counts of theft by deception in New Jersey in a suspected flim-flam scheme to dupe bank tellers out of cash, has entered an alcohol rehabilitation center, according to his agent, Tracy Sundlun, who is also president of the Metroplitan Athletics Congress. Sundlun said that Rono, who set four world records in 1978, entered the center Tuesday night to combat a drinking problem and ''would be there a mimimum of four weeks and possibly as long as six weeks.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Dart & Kraft Inc., Northbrook, Ill., said it would officially change its name to Kraft Inc.

title: DINKINS REJECTS KOCH SHELTER PROPOSAL
description: The Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, yesterday refused to accept four sites suggested by the Koch administration for new homeless shelters. Instead, he proposed a plan to rehabilitate city-owned apartments as temporary housing.

title: JETS WON'T MEET PRICE FOR FRED DEAN
description: Although the Jets' starting defensive line is out with injuries and Dan Marino is looming, the club was unwilling to accede to contract demands by Fred Dean, once a top pass-rusher in the National Football League.

title: Advertising; Esty to Report To Saatchi
description: The William Esty Company, which was acquired by Ted Bates Worldwide in February 1982, will no longer report to that company, but to Saatchi & Saatchi, the British-based holding company that bought Bates in August.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Hockey

title: KOCH TO NAME PANEL TO REVAMP THE BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that in the wake of a Federal Court decision finding the Board of Estimate's makeup unconstitutional, he would appoint a commission to recommend changes in the city's most powerful panel.

title: Stocks Up Broadly; Dow Adds 34.03
description: The stock market staged a broad advance yesterday, as investors focused on blue-chip equities and showed renewed confidence in the prospects for recently shunned takeover targets.

title: LEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: ISRAELIS EXPELLING A U.S. PROFESSOR
description: The Israeli authorities have revoked the work permit of a Palestinian-American university professor who published a poll that found widespread support for Yasir Arafat among West Bank Arabs.

title: TO ERR IS HUMAN, BUT TO CORRECT SELLS PAPERS
description: The two daily newspapers here, rivals for years in an expensive war of survival, are now crusading against some internal villains: human error and printed mistakes.

title: F.D.I.C. Sells Bailout Stock
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that it had recouped $247 million, or $50 million less than it expected only a month ago, from the sale of 50 million shares of the Continental Illinois Banking Company.

Attention 'Jane Doe'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Women of Valor' on CBS, About Prisoners of War
description: ''Women of Valor,'' an old-fashioned World War II drama, or, better, a melodrama with traces of postwar revisionism, takes to CBS Sunday night from 9 to 11. It is designed as a tribute to the 104 courageous Army and Navy nurses who fell prisoner to the Japanese in the Philippines and, while it holds the eye, it is in many ways a sort of updated, almost one-dimensional war epic of 40 years ago.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: Share earnings are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split on June 27.

title: VICON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: REPORTER FAULTED ON REAGAN QUERIES
description: A reporter for Radio Marti, a station operated by the United States for broadcasts to Cuba, was removed from her White House assignment today after asking President Reagan two questions at his televised news conference on Wednesday.

title: ART: RODRIGO MOYNIHAN
description: RODRIGO MOYNIHAN'S third show of paintings at the Robert Miller Gallery is his first in the gallery's new premises at 41 East 57th Street. Those pristine and all but windowless white spaces point up the delicate precision of his procedures in still life. They also give a particular sharp emphasis to the sudden notes of strong pure color that sing out from time to time.

title: BROADWAY
description: LISTEN to this combination - Jerome Robbins, Leonard Bernstein and John Guare -and then cross your fingers. The three men are working on a musical theater project, and there's no need to say that the few people who know about it are hoping, hoping that what's now being explored will actually happen.

title: COWBOYS ON REDSKINS' TRICKS
description: Among the interested viewers of the Washington Redskins' 14-6 victory over San Francisco Monday night were several Dallas Cowboys coaches. One of them, Jim Myers, was particularly intrigued by the antics of Dexter Manley and Darryl Mann, the Redskins' defensive ends.

title: Electronics Purchases
description: Gadget-loving Americans bought $15.3 billion worth of consumer electronic equipment, mostly imports, during the first nine months of the year, the Electronic Industry Association said today.

The year-ago periods covered 14 weeks and 27 weeks and are pro forma, reflecting the acquisitions of the company's Canadian and United Kingdom subsidiaries and the company's reorganization in 1985 as if they had occurred at the beginning of the periods.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * British Printing and Communication Corp. appointed James T. Sullivan to the new post of executive vice chairman, responsible for worldwide print operations.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: WANDERERS in lower Manhattan's cultural dens - through some of the newer art galleries and alternative exhibition spaces in particular - have in recent years increasingly encountered the unusual work of the collaborative team Kristin Jones and Andrew Ginzel.

title: Itel Acquisition
description: The Itel Corporation, the Chicago-based transportation and dredging company led by the Chicago investor Samuel Zell, said it had agreed to acquire Anixter Brothers Inc. for $14 a share, or $500 million in cash. Anixter, based in Skokie, Ill, supplies wire and cable products to the telecommunications and cable television industries. In the fiscal year 1986, it reported net income of $22.7 million, on revenues of $656.4 million.

title: Gillette Seeking Kidder Subpoena
description: The Gillette Company has added Kidder, Peabody's name to the list of arbitrage and stock-trading firms it is seeking to subpoena in its attempt to combat a takeover bid by the Revlon Group Inc. The company had previously asked for subpoenas for six firms - Ivan F. Boesky & Company L.P.; Drexel Burnham Lambert; Bear, Stearns & Company; Jefferies & Company; Ernst & Company, and Gruss & Company - on the ground that they might have received advance knowledge from Revlon of that company's takeover intentions.

title: Advertising; MMB/Kornblum Gets Wellan's, a Retailer
description: Wellan's, a regional retail company based in Alexandria, La., has selected the MMB/Kornblum agency in far-off Toronto over an agency in New York to handle its more than $1 million in billings.

title: ...AND A JEFFERIES EARLY BIRD
description: When Harold C. Simmons concluded last August that he could take command of NL Industries by buying enough shares on the open market to gain a controlling stake, it was Jefferies & Company that sold the Dallas investor the stock in a matter of minutes.

title: Advertising; A Political Void Filled By Cleaner
description: AGAINST the backdrop of a dazzling array of advertising creativity awards, the stars of Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey revealed, yesterday morning, the name of the replacement for Andrew O'Rourke, defeated Republican candidate for governor - and their first lost account.

title: DREXEL PLEA FOR CALM
description: Frederick H. Joseph, chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert, said yesterday that he had been meeting with the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, asking for help in quelling rumors that the firm is a target of a criminal investigation.

title: NEW YORK POLICE IN CITYWIDE HUNT FOR GUNMAN WHO SHOT 6 OFFICERS
description: The New York City police mounted a citywide manhunt yesterday for a 20-year-old gunman wanted for seven murders and a series of drug robberies this year and the wounding of six officers Wednesday night in a blazing shootout in a Bronx apartment where he was hiding.

title: DONALD TRUMP GETS 9.6% OF BALLY CORP.
description: Donald Trump, the New York real estate developer, said yesterday that he had bought 9.6 percent of the Bally Manufacturing Corporation, the world's largest maker of electronic games and an operator of casinos and health clubs.

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $267,000 for the quarter and $324,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $92,000 for the quarter and $730,000 for the 9 months. Helionetics filed for Chapter 11 protection last July.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SIX-YEAR-OLD Pesca has always been puzzling to me. It has so much going for it: a coolly elegant cafe atmosphere wrapped in shades of salmon-pink; handsome nautical artwork; a comely clientele and a well-conceived all-seafood menu. Food quality, though, bobs and weaves like a marlin on a long trawl line.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SERVICE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $372,000 and $1,992,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $26,000 and $1,795,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,650,000 and $11,886,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: South Korea Frees 413 in Protest Case
description: Prosecutors today dropped charges and freed one-third of the 1,275 students arrested for taking part in four days of violent anti-Government and anti-American protests.

title: Top Tandem
description: When four women's field hockey teams gather in Norfolk, Va., this weekend, the one from the University of North Carolina will be going for a small place in history as well as an N.C.A.A. championship. A title for Coach Karen Shelton's top-ranked Tar Heels would, it's believed, mark the first time that a husband and wife have led their squads to national crowns in the same year.

title: REPUBLIC PICTURES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ratings Revised For Auto Makers
description: Duff & Phelps Inc., a Chicago-based rating service, has lowered debt ratings of the General Motors Corporation and its finance subsidiary, while raising ratings of the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and their finance subsidiaries.

title: Other U.S. Mismeasures Of the Poor Population
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Sports Pages yesterday, with an article about Mike Schmidt's selection as most valuable player in the National League, listed his career statistics incorrectly. He has 7,292 times at bat, 1,347 runs, 1,954 hits, a .268 batting average, 352 doubles, 57 triples, 495 home runs and 1,392 runs batted in.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HEWLETT-PACKARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KING WORLD PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
A Political Patronage Complaint
description: Senior State Department officials have often chafed at but said little about the White House's prerogative to choose political loyalists instead of career diplomats as ambassadors overseas.

title: Political Donations Top $111,000
description: Ivan F. Boesky emerged as one of the Republican Party's financial elite in the years before he became the central figure in Wall Street's biggest-ever insider trading scandal.

title: PILKINGTON BID MADE BY BTR
description: The industrial conglomerate BTR, one of Britain's most active takeover bidders, began an offer today for the Pilkington Brothers glassmaking company worth $:1.16 billion, or $1.64 billion.

title: WILL PEKING BE MRS. GRUNDY TO NAUGHTY COLONY?
description: Negotiations to return this sleepy Portuguese enclave to China are presenting Peking with the ticklish question of how and when to embrace a territory prospering on vice.

title: 2 Mortgage Issues By Merrill Lynch
description: A $500 million issue of collateralized mortgage obligations, equally divided into fixed and floating rates, was offered yesterday by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Tokyo to Curb Tool Exports
description: Japan has tentatively agreed to curb its machine tool exports to the United States as part of a broad American effort to shield its war-making ability from reliance on foreign tools, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Market Place; The Skepticism About Avon
description: THE management of Avon Products Inc. surprised Wall Street early this month by stating the existence of some problems at its Foster Medical division, which provides medical equipment for home use. On Nov. 7, when the market first responded to this disclosure, Avon's shares fell $2, to $31.25.

title: LAYOFFS AT G.M. IN DELCO STRIKE
description: The General Motors Corporation laid off 33,350 people in seven states today because of a strike at a Delco Electronics plant that might soon force the nation's largest automobile maker to close most of its assembly facilities.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $198,000 and $535,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Overlooked U.S. Votes Against Parochial Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY TRYING TO NAVIGATE PAST $300,000 BILL FOR FERRY BOATS
description: Two new ferryboats are carrying passengers between Staten Island and Manhattan, but the city still owes more than $300,000 for them.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK BYRD FOR SENATE POST
description: Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia was chosen today as the Senate leader of the Democratic majority for the 100th Congress, and he immediately urged President Reagan to send his budget to Capitol Hill early in January, a month ahead of schedule.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EXPERTS SAY U.S. ARMS SENT TO IRAN CAN PROVIDE MAJOR STRIKING POWER
description: Although President Reagan called them purely defensive, the American missiles sent to Iran would provide that country with significant striking power in its war with Iraq, military experts said today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''PURE flash,'' Elizabeth de Cuevas, the sculptor, said of her silver dress and jacket. That could also describe the turnout at the Spanish Institute's ninth-annual Gold Medal Gala. Sequins, ostrich feathers, war medals and enough jewels to pay Ivan F. Boesky's penalty filled the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Wednesday night.

title: The Man at the Gate
description: The football coach had entered the office of the dean of admissions to plead his case about the high-school senior he was fervently recruiting.

title: Johnson Of Clippers Injured
description: Marques Johnson of the Los Angeles Clippers was carried from the court on a stretcher tonight and taken to a local hospital after colliding with a teammate, Benoit Benjamin, during a game with the Dallas Mavericks.

title: INVESTOR SUIT FILED
description: Nearly a week after settling insider-trading charges against him, Ivan F. Boesky offered an apology yesterday in a face-to-face meeting with some of his investment partners, according to lawyers who attended the meeting.

title: IRANIAN DEAL LED TO 2,200 MISSILES, A LAWMAKER SAYS
description: The House majority leader said today that Israel, acting with the approval of the United States, had shipped Iran 2,008 TOW anti-tank missiles and at least 235 Hawk antiaircraft missiles, a quantity of weapons much greater than previously acknowledged.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $181,000 and $7,074,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $104,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $665,000 for the 9 months.

title: RUSSIANS PRESSING AFGHAN CAMPAIGNS
description: A report on human rights in Afghanistan asserts that despite the Soviet Union's announced withdrawal of 8,000 of its 120,000 troops, military operations there seem to have intensified.

title: 50 YEARS OF JAZZ ARTISTRY IN 8 HOURS
description: WITH an eight-hour schedule and a roster of about three-dozen brilliant performers whose styles range from swing to salsa to modern jazz to blues, ''Jazz Finds a Home'' sounds like a one-day jazz festival. The concert, which will begin Sunday at 2 P.M. at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium, is actually a benefit for three organizations involved with the homeless: Boys Harbor, Women in Need and Habitat for Humanity. From 5 to 8 P.M., ''Jazz Finds a Home'' will also be a radio broadcast by WKCR-FM (89.9), the Columbia University station, which is sponsoring the concert with the Columbia Community Volunteer Service.

title: CHANGING OF GUARD IN RJR NABISCO JOB
description: RJR Nabisco Inc.'s chief financial officer, Gwain H. Gillespie, has resigned to ''pursue other opportunities,'' the company said yesterday. He is being replaced by Edward J. Robinson, who is chief financial officer at the company's Nabisco Brands Inc. unit in Parsippany, N.J.

title: ART: '8 FRENCH PAINTERS' IN EXHIBITION AT P.S. 1
description: WITH all the attention that has been focused this fall on museum exhibitions involving French Conceptual Art, a show of contemporary French painting has sneaked into town almost unnoticed. Yet ''Preview: Eight French Painters,'' at P.S. 1, is important. It is a complement to ''Angles of Vision: French Art Today,'' the 1986 Exxon International Exhibition at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, and ''A Distanced View: One Aspect of Recent Art From Belgium, France, Germany and Holland,'' at the New Museum of Contemporary Art. If ''Preview'' is the most conservative of the three shows in content, it is the most radical in its ability to shed light on the general art situation.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AN extraordinary eight-inch-tall gray-white marble neolithic goddess - a majestic seated figure with the right leg folded over the left and the hands meeting under the breast - will be auctioned from the collection of the estate of James Johnson Sweeney, the art historian and museum director, on Monday at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. The small figure, which has an encrustation of lime, is one of several important works in the antiquities sale taking place at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We stand nakedly in front of a very serious pandemic as mortal as any pandemic there ever has been.

title: WOBURN FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are not available for 1985 due to the bank's conversion to a public company in June 1986.

title: 2 FILM SERIES EXPLORE JEWISH LIFE
description: Organizers of one film series wanted to explore Jewish heritage and identity from a modern perspective.

title: SUSPECT TO SISTER: 'I'M GOING TO SHOOT THEM FIRST'
description: A few weeks ago, Regina Lewis asked her brother, Larry Davis, why he had to keep bringing guns into her South Bronx apartment. His answer: The police were after him.

title: NEW YORKER TO DESIGN HOLOCUST MEMORIAL
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Council announced yesterday that the New York architect James Ingo Freed of I. M. Pei & Partners had been selected as the principal architect of the national Holocaust Memorial Museum, to be built in Washington on a site adjoining the Mall.

title: OIL LOSSES IN TEXAS SEEM TO BRING ITS FIRST NET EXPORTS OF POPULATION
description: Long a magnet for families seeking economic opportunity, Texas appears to have begun to lose population to other states, probably for the first time in the 150 years since it gained independence from Mexico.

title: Dana Kirk Indicted
description: Dana Kirk, the former Memphis State basketball coach, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on 11 counts of tax evasion, filing false income tax returns, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Kirk, who was dismissed by Memphis State on Sept. 17, had helped make the school a national basketball power.

title: FIRST FINCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THEATER: HORTON FOOTE'S 'LILY DALE'
description: HORACE ROBEDAUX is a typical specimen of polite young Texas manhood, circa 1909. As played by Don Bloomfield in Horton Foote's ''Lily Dale'' at the Beckett Theater, he has pink cheeks, glistening eyes, pomaded hair and a toothy, ingratiating grin that spreads reflexively whenever he isn't earnestly answering whichever ''ma'am'' or ''sir'' has addressed him last. Although Horace is a lapsed Episcopalian, there's the sweetness of the choirboy in his kindly, modest demeanor. His tightly buttoned dark suit is soiled, and his existence is the solitary, straitened one of a clerk in a provincial dry-goods store, but somewhere, somehow, there is faith.

title: Shift at Occidental
description: In a cost-cutting move, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it would consolidate its domestic and international oil and gas operations, which have posted dismal operating results during the oil industry slump. T.D. Jenkins, 59, chairman of the Occidental Oil and Gas Company, Occidental's international operation, ''has elected to take early retirement,'' but will remain as a consultant, the company said. The new chairman and chief executive of the combined operation is David A. Hentschel, 52, who holds those same positions with Occidental's domestic subsidiary, the Cities Service Company.

title: Ex-Chemical Engineer Taking Bacardi Private
description: Managing a liquor business was a new challenge for Manuel L. del Valle when he became president of the Bacardi Corporation seven years ago, but he learned quickly. And when the San Juan, P.R., rum maker goes private in the near future, he will remain as president and chief executive.

title: Koch Gives Response To Reagan on Hotels
description: Mayor Koch and a state official responded yesterday to President Reagan's question this week about why someone did not build houses for homeless families instead of paying exorbitant rents to welfare hotels.

title: THE DANCE: IGAL PERRY AND PERIDANCE TROUPE
description: IGAL PERRY, an Israeli-born teacher and choreographer, founded his small New York company, the Peridance Ensemble, two years ago. Given the amount of dance activity in this city, it is not always easy to catch up with every new group that appears.

title: Drexel Confident Of Holiday Deal
description: The Holiday Corporation, which is seeking to raise $2.7 billion to finance a restructuring, said yesterday that a number of banks had expressed interest in providing financing and that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., its financial adviser, had reaffirmed that it can arrange the financing.

title: NEW CHEMICAL ACCIDENT SENDS A CLOUD OVER BASEL
description: The fourth industrial accident in Basel in three weeks sent an acrid chemical cloud over the city today, officials said.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 21, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 6 MONTHS AFTER DRIVE, GRANTS FOR HOMELESS BEGIN
description: As rising numbers of homeless people prepare to face winter, the Hands Across America organization today announced the distribution of its first grants from last spring's nationwide hand-holding campaign against homelessness. The grants totaled $576,665.

title: Economic Scene; Boesky Fallout: Some Benefits
description: IT usually takes a specific event to crystallize and expose a generally bad situation. That was the effect that Watergate had on the imperial Presidency. And that is the effect the Boesky affair is likely to have on ''junk bonds,'' the extraordinary degree of debt creation involved in corporate mergers and the spread of corruption in financial markets.

title: ADVANCED INSTITUTIONAL MANGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: French Link Lebanese To Strasbourg Attack
description: A French judge has formally accused George Ibrahim Abdallah, the Lebanese extremist whose imprisonment prompted terror bomb attacks here two months ago, of involvement in the attempted murder of an American diplomat in Strasbourg in 1984, it was announced today.

title: Iranian Crticizes Khomeini
description: A former Iranian Prime Minister reports that senior Iranian officials, Cabinet members and religious leaders have urged the Ayatollah to consider a nonmilitary solution to the war.

title: CHEMCLEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $216,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $803,407 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes extraordinary credits of $311,000 and $573,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said there are no 1985 9-month share earnings because the company went public in October 1985. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June 1986.

title: Securities Study Suggested
description: Fderal District Judge Stanley Sporkin will propose today that the Securities and Exchange Commission respond to unsettled conditions in the stock market by ordering a special study of the nation's securities markets, like one made in the early 1960's by Milton H. Cohen. Judge Sporkin's former service as head of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division is likely to add weight to his suggestion.

title: SANTA FE SETS CUTBACKS AND $914 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation announced a major restructuring yesterday that will lead to a write-off of $914 million in the fourth quarter and major cutbacks of its railroad employees, equipment and trackage.

title: PRIEST PROTESTS UNIVERSITY ACTION
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran, who was disciplined this summer by the Vatican for his views on sexual issues, said today that his name had been removed from class schedules at the Catholic University of America and charged that the omission amounted to an improper suspension.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Dawkins on Injured List
description: The Nets, who have lost their last four games and eight of their last nine, placed Darryl Dawkins, the 6-foot-11-inch center, on the injured list yesterday and reactived Pace Mannion, a 6-7 guard. Mannion, who played with the Utah Jazz last season and was signed as a free agent, had been on the injured list since the start of the season.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: c-Net income

title: STAR OF 'ROUGE BAISER': CHARLOTTE VALANDRY
description: France's newest film star is an 18-year-old woman with an innocent smile but bedroom eyes, whose professional discovery sounds like a Hollywood legend from the 40's except for the absence of a drugstore soda fountain.

title: DELAY SEEN ON AUTO AIR BAGS
description: The Transportation Department has tentatively decided to allow automobile makers more time to equip cars with automatic restraints for front-seat passengers as long as they put driver-side air bags in additional cars, Government sources said today.

title: Bullets Lose a Guard
description: The Washington Bullets said that Frank Johnson, a starting guard, had broken a small bone in his left foot for the fifth time, including four times in the last two years, putting his career in jeopardy. Johnson, who averaged 12.3 points and 4.3 assists in the team's first 10 games, suffered the injury while driving to the basket early in the third quarter of Wednesday's 119-105 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Volvo Profits Down
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish car maker and Scandinavia's biggest corporation, said yesterday that profits in the latest quarter fell, and future earnings are expected to suffer if the dollar continues to fall.

title: Precious Mettle
description: On reflection, two recent news accounts that seem to have jewelry in common in fact have more to do with the taking of risk.

title: KHOMEINI RULES OUT LINK WITH U.S. AND ASSAILS IRANIANS WHO SEEK TIES
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ruled out reconciliation with Washington today, saying any Iranian officials who seek to improve relations are ''Satan-oriented.''

title: AT BERLIN TRIAL, CLASHING VIEWS OF ARAB CLUB
description: A succession of Arab witnesses gave wildly conflicting testimony today when they were asked about the political orientation of the German-Arab Friendship Society here that was destroyed by a bomb eight months ago.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HEALTH MANAGEMENT ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PHILIPPINE LEFTISTS HOLD HUGE MARCH
description: In the largest and boldest show of strength by the Philippine left in memory, tens of thousands of marchers, carrying red flags and chanting revolutionary slogans, joined a daylong funeral procession through Manila today.

title: CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $98,000 for the quarter and $336,000 for the 9 months. The company said the latest third quarter loss includes a one-time charge of $1,682,082 for a settlement of litigation and the latest 9-month loss includes a one-time gain of $1,295,195 from termination of a sale-leaseback.

title: RHODE ISLAND'S LATEST INVESTIGATION
description: In the midst of scandal piled upon scandal, Rhode Island is now investigating possible misconduct in the office of its chief prosecutor, the Attorney General.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July. The company said the latest quarter and year include a pre-tax charge of almost $2 million related to a union work force reduction in the company's telephone directory operation. Offsetting the charge was a $1 million pre-tax gain from the sale of real estate, credits resulting from the change in accounting for pensions and a favorable tax rate attributable to capital gains plus investment credits on recently installed directory equipment.

title: SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Named Al Goldis director of scouting and player development. BASKETBALL

title: A Senseless Farm Policy
description: Not long ago, the Federal Government announced the largest program in history for paying farmers not to grow corn, sorghum, barley and oats. The cost to taxpayers? About $1.5 billion, maybe more. That's on top of the $25 billion already spent on commodity support programs this year.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Orders Jet Inspections After the discovery of a broken wing spar on a Delta L-1011 jumbo jet, the Government ordered inspections of about 100 similar planes.

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After a writedown of $4.5 million on the value of inventories. c-Net income

title: John Rewald Wins Prize For Cezanne Biography
description: John Rewald, the art historian and authority on Impressionism and post-Impressionism, has won the 1986 Mitchell Prize for his book ''Cezanne: A Biography,'' published this year by Harry Abrams. The $10,000 prize, established in 1976 by Jan Mitchell, a businessman and art collector, is awarded annually for an outstanding book in English that contributes to ''the study and understanding of the visual arts.''

title: INDOOR SOCCER REVIVED ON L.I.
description: Erasing the image of the Arrows - the team they replaced - may be the biggest problem the New York Express will face in its first year in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: 'FIREWALKER'
description: ''FIREWALKER,'' which opens today at the Warner Twin and other theaters, is a bargain-basement imitation of films on the order of ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'' and ''Romancing the Stone.'' It stars Chuck Norris in what his associates describe as ''the first comedy role in his action-packed career.''

title: HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges from the writedown of assets of $7 million for the quarter and $21 million for the year, and includes gains from the sale of securities of $4,393,000 for the quarter and $14,534,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes gains from the sale of securities of $322,000 for the quarter and $5,749,000 for the year.

title: A 7-Vehicle Accident Brings Tunnel Delays
description: Traffic in the Lincoln Tunnel was delayed for an hour in the evening rush period yesterday by a seven-car pileup in an eastbound lane that resulted in injuries, none of them serious, to several people.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Days Dwindle to a Precious 3
description: As New York racing staggers toward its winter of insignificance, two final weekends of meaningful races loom at Aqueduct. The Remsen tomorrow and the Demoiselle on Sunday and then the Vosburgh a week from tomorrow end the year's menu of Grade I events.

title: MODERNISM AT A SHOW OF ANTIQUES
description: MOST of the styles represented in ''Modernism: A Century of Style and Design, 1860 to 1960'' - New York's newest antiques and decorative-arts fair - have been collected enthusiastically for at least a decade. Until now, however, no collectibles bazaar has presented the extraordinary range of 19th- and 20th-century works by major European and American designers and craftsmen that are on view and for sale at this show. Modernism remains through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street.

title: MAXWELL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Smoking Law Didn't Hurt Nassau's Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,394,959 from a debenture exchange offer, a tax credit of $1,250,000, and a pre-tax gain of $3,407,406 from the sale of stock. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $203,170.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $1.97 billion, to $236.99 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: A LAWYER IN GRAFT TRIAL CALLS PROSECUTION UNFAIR
description: The lawyer for Lester N. Shafran, the former director of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, told a Federal jury today that the Government had been determined to bring corruption charges against Mr. Shafran even before it had evidence and that it had proceeded against him even though it never found that evidence.

title: Street Player Licenses Eased by New Orleans
description: The City Council has cut to $20 from $100 the cost of a new license required of street performers after an appeal by a man who danced to Louis Armstrong's trumpet.

title: GENOVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
ART: A COLLABORATION, TIM ROLLINS AND K.O.S.
description: IN their current exhibition at Jay Gorney Modern Art (204 East 10th Street), Tim Rollins and K.O.S. continue their unusual artistic collaboration, now nearly four years old. Rollins is an artist in his own right, but he also teaches art at Intermediate School 52 in the South Bronx. K.O.S., or Kids of Survival, is a group of his present and former students - artistically talented but poor teen-agers, many of whom have participated in the Workshop for Art and Knowledge, an after-school program initiated by Rollins in 1982.

title: Pope Is Welcomed in Fiji In Roast Pig Ceremony
description: Pope John Paul II was welcomed here today with the presentation of whale teeth and a roasted pig.

title: Slain Officer's Wife Cannot Get Benefits
description: A woman who accidentally shot and killed her husband, an off-duty police officer, is not entitled to collect workers' compensation benefits for his death, the state's top court ruled yesterday.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend declared Oct. 29 and payable Nov. 28.

title: SATOR STILL A MAN ON THE SPOT
description: Ted Sator was steady in front of the cameras and the microphones. He stood firm, his blue eyes did not waver in the strong, white lights and he said all the right things: ''I'm proud of these guys,'' the Rangers' coach said. ''We're working hard. We're showing character.'' Sator did not know most of these people, the Edmonton reporters who were curious to know how the coach from New York was handling the pressure. Eventually they dispersed and Sator took a walk. He turned left and he stood in a darkened part of a corridor adjacent to the Rangers' locker room. ''I've never seen anything like it,'' he said.

title: JERSEY TAX BREAK REPEAL IS URGED
description: The Kean administration today promised municipal officials more state aid if they succeed in pressuring the Legislature to repeal a homeowners tax break enacted last year.

title: REIN ON SHIITES SEEN
description: Iran has appointed a new Ambassador to Lebanon in what appears to be a move to tighten control over Moslem fundamentalist militants in this country.

title: Federal Jury Studying Maker of Contraceptive
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating possible criminal conduct by the maker of the intrauterine contraceptive device Dalkon Shield, according to a Justice Department memorandum.

title: AGENDA
description: Traffic Alert

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. BULLS, at Chicago, 8:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) NETS VS. LOS ANGELES LAKERS, at Inglewood, Calif., 10:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio -WNEW 1130, 10:30 P.M.) HOUSTON ROCKETS VS.

title: WORKERS AT MENTAL HEALTH CENTER CHARGED WITH ABUSING PATIENTS
description: Four employees at a state center for mentally retarded adults in Dutchess County were arrested on charges of selling drugs today and 10 others were arrested on charges of abusing patients, officials said.

title: CITY AND POLICE UNION REACH AGREEMENT ON NEW TRANSFER PLAN
description: New York City police and union negotiators reached a settlement yesterday in which Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward abandoned his plan to rotate a fifth of patrol officers each year. They agreed instead to regularly transfer new officers among precincts and to shift the assignments of senior officers without having them change precincts.

title: American Ventures To Purchase Butler
description: Butler International Inc., an aviation and contract-services company, said it had agreed to be acquired by North American Ventures Inc., based in East Hartford, Conn., for $140 million.

title: HEADEN RESPONDS AS PARCELLS YELLS
description: In 1983, Andy Headen's rookie year with the Giants, Coach Bill Parcells talked one day with Danny Ford, Headen's college coach at Clemson. ''How's he doing?'' said Ford. ''Fine,'' said Parcells.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Reappearance in Argentina
description: Democracy is not something imposed from above. In Argentina now, it's being nourished by change at the grassroots. At the intersection of Florida and Lavalle Streets, Buenos Aires's Speakers' Corner, citizens practice the fine art of hearing out those with whom they passionately disagree.

title: SHRIVER RALLIES PAST MANDLIKOVA
description: It had been a long time between meaningful victories, according to Pam Shriver, the best authority on the subject. She may continue to be a crowd pleaser - awkward enough to remind weekend hackers of themselves - and to hold a prominent spot in the rankings, but numbers have a way of lying sometimes. There was no sense kidding herself, Ms. Shriver decided, the opportunity to make a run at the top players was slipping away.

title: GOODYEAR BUYS OUT GOLDSMITH
description: Sir James Goldsmith yesterday abandoned his bruising pursuit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, but he did so at a profit of about $93 million.

title: College Football Notebook; Any Bowl Game Will Do for Holy Cross
description: If there is a bowl game needing a colorful team with a star player, then it should call Holy Cross, collect. The Crusaders, one game away from the first unbeaten, untied season in the college's history, would gratefully entertain a bowl invitation.

title: Reagan on the Dodge
description: Not since his stumbling performance in his first debate with Walter Mondale in 1984 have Americans seen President Reagan so uncertain, so tongue-tied and so inept as they saw him in his news conference on Iran. Or so deceptive, some in Congress and elsewhere would add.

title: Beneficial Meeting
description: The Beneficial Corporation said it had called a special shareholder meeting for Dec. 23 to consider a liquidation plan. Beneficial, which said in August that it was considering selling the company or restructuring, said it wants to adopt a plan that would enable it to take advantage of tax benefits available if it completes a liquidation in 1987. Analysts said Beneficial, a financial-services concern based in Wilmington, Del., was still seeking to be sold in one piece, if a deal could be completed by the end of the year to beat tax changes that would make a sale less lucrative after 1986.

title: Marvel Comic Deal
description: The Marvel Entertainment Group, the largest comic book publisher in the United States, has been acquired for about $50 million by New World Pictures Ltd., a television and theatrical production and distribution concern. The merger is intended to increase Marvel's accessibility to the television market and provide New World with a supply of characters for potential use. Cadence Industries, Marvel's previous owner, is involved in publishing, pharmaceutical products, theater operations and writing instruments.

title: REGIONAL SYSTEM IS FORMED TO ATTACK TRAFFIC TIE-UPS
description: New York, New Jersey and New York City formed a regional traffic-control system today to speed coordinated attacks on highway tie-ups and congestion in the metropolitan area.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kenny Easley, the Seattle Seahawks' strong safety, will have two bone spurs removed from an ankle joint, will be placed on injured reserve and will miss the remainder of the season. Paul Moyer will start in his place against the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday. . . . Zoran Jovanovich, Louisiana State U's 7-foot-1 center, drove his car into a tree in the rain and had to be cut free from his automobile, Baton Rouge police said yesterday.

title: Airborne Rejection
description: The Airborne Freight Corporation said its board had rejected as inadequate a $172 million takeover bid from TNT Ltd., an Australian freight transporter, and adopted a stockholder rights plan to discourage corporate raiders.

title: U.N. Vote Adopts Resolution Rebuking U.S. on Libya Raid
description: The General Assembly adopted a resolution today condemning the United States raid last April on Tripoli as a violation of international law.

title: British Sugar Sale
description: Ferruzzi, the Italian food and farms group, said it had agreed to buy 70 percent of British Sugar Corporation, Britain's monopoly beet sugar refiner.

title: NEW MADISON AVE. SHOPS ADD TO THE LUXURY QUOTIENT
description: Each season brings new shops to Madison Avenue with new points of view on fashion. Three of the newest boutiques couldn't be more different, but they do have one thing in common: luxurious wares.

title: Nude Dancing Bans Rejected
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld lower court rulings that local bans against nude dancing in night clubs as morally offensive are unconstitutional.

title: Frey in Cubs' Booth
description: Jim Frey, who was dismissed as manager by the Cubs during the past season, has taken a job as a radio analyst for WGN in Chicago, which broadcasts Cubs games. Frey made the move after he turned down an offer to manage the Minnesota Twins next season.

title: THE FALL'S BEST MOVIES RATE A G, FOR GROWN-UPS
description: THERE isn't a single film in town this weekend in which a hot young daredevil flies or boxes or hoofs his way to glory. Nor is there anything about college boys who throw the wildest party in the state of Georgia. Not a single alien being turns up in anyone's bedroom closet, and the only epic prom scene in captivity concerns a middle-aged mother. This may be disappointing to the adolescent audience, but for post-teen-age viewers (or thoughtful ones of any age), it's wonderful news. The grown-up moviegoer's Christmas has come early this year.

title: TECHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BIOTECH CAPITAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Assets represents total assets. Net income represents net assets.

title: BOOKS CF THE TIMES
description: SPORTS SPECTATORS. By Allen Guttmann. 236 pages. Columbia University Press. $24.95. IN recent years sporting events have often been marred by outbreaks of hooliganism, but modern spectator violence pales in comparison with the kind of bloodshed that chariot-racing provoked in the Byzantine Empire: in the worst recorded instance - the rioting in Constantinople in A.D. 532 - an estimated 30,000 lives were lost. Nowadays sport attracts an immense amount of publicity, but it was hardly suffering from neglect in 1869, when The New York Times devoted all but one of its front-page columns to reports of a boat race in London between crews from Harvard and Oxford (which was said to have been watched by around a million people).

title: Advertising; French-U.S. Agency Sets Up Business Unit
description: HCM/New York, the office here of the French-American joint venture agency, has established a unit called HCM/Special Markets that will handle corporate and business-to-business advertising and sales promotion. It is starting off with $11 million in billings drawn from the parent office.

title: Summit Talks Face Changes
description: The seven countries attending the annual Western economic summit meetings have agreed to changes that will give their finance ministers more influence in the preparation for the meetings and will probably result in a greater emphasis on economic topics, according to officials.

title: BILLS OUTLINED TO DEREGULATE MILK LICENSING
description: The State Agriculture Commissioner appeared before the State Investigation Commission yesterday to discuss enforcement of the state's milk licensing law and said future commission hearings would also concern the apple juice industry.

title: Advertising; Billboard Announces Control of Back Stage
description: Billboard Publications, which already has seven titles, yesterday announced both the acquisition of a majority position in Back Stage and its plans to begin a new mass-circulation, rock-oriented quarterly called Inside Tracks on Dec. 1.

title: UNIVERSITY GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SCREEN: 'THE BOY WHO COULD FLY'
description: THE title character in ''The Boy Who Could Fly'' is a boy who can't do anything else, an autistic teen-ager who has been traumatized by his parents' death in a plane crash. His way of coping with this tragedy is to simulate flight on the roof of his house, a habit that is at first quite disconcerting for the new family next door. A widow (Bonnie Bedelia) and her two school-age children, they have moved there in the wake of their own calamity. The film shows how 14-year-old Milly (Lucy Deakins), still getting over the loss of her father, approaches Eric (Jay Underwood) with a sweetness and compassion unlike anything he has ever known.

title: Student Is Charged In Family Slayings
description: A 21-year-old college student from Queens has been charged with the murders of his grandmother and his godfather at the family's home in Astoria nearly three years ago, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Richland, Wash., on Oct. 24 about radioactive emissions in the 1940's and 1950's at the Hanford plutonium plant misstated the position of the Hanford Education Action League, a Spokane-based group. It favors ending operations at the plant until cleanup operations are demonstrably effective.

title: Slight of Hand
description: Coach George Karl, after the Golden State Warriors triumphed in his return to Cleveland, which dismissed him last March: ''Finally, I slapped the hand that bit me.''

title: GOLDMAN IN KEY ROLE ON CONRAIL
description: The Transportation Department yesterday chose Goldman, Sachs & Company to lead a group of six investment banking houses in managing the sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: 12-STORY RENTAL HOUSING IS BUILT IN THE EAST VILLAGE
description: Despite a dearth of building sites, stiff zoning restrictions and rising construction costs, a private builder has moved ahead with that most unusual of Manhattan commodities - a midrise market-rate rental apartment house.

title: SPECTRUM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The prior year earnings were favorably impacted by a one-time reduction of $857,000, or 19 cents a share, in income taxes from a change in the tax rate of the company's life insurance subsidiary.

title: The Trade Issue Heats Up
description: Two months before the Democratic-controlled 100th Congress convenes, the politically explosive trade issue appears headed for the top of the agenda. Representative Jim Wright of Texas, who is expected to become Speaker in January, has served notice that the House will take up the same trade bill it passed last May, one that a third of House Republicans supported but President Reagan strongly opposed and threatened to veto.

title: WHITE HOUSE 'FLABBERGASTED' AT McFARLANE COMMENTS THAT IRAN DEAL WAS MISTAKE
