description: Senior White House officials were described today as ''flabbergasted'' and ''incredulous'' at comments by Robert C. McFarlane, a central figure in dealings with Iran, who said sending military equipment was a ''mistake.''

title: The Name Of the Game
description: Time was when the bowl games were showdowns for big-name colleges with imposing regular-season records. Time was also, of course, when there were just a handful of bowls and plenty of such colleges to go around.

title: TYSON BEATS TOUGHEST FOE: HIMSELF
description: From the time Mike Tyson was a street-tough 13-year-old from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, he has moved inexorably toward the moment Saturday night when he steps into the ring here against Trevor Berbick and fights for the World Boxing Council's heavyweight crown.

title: A RENOVATED ROSELAND
description: Dancers will kick up their heels this weekend amid new carpeting, lighting and sound equipment at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,960,000 and an extraordinary credit of $1,688,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,690,000 and $378,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the latest 9-month net from discontinued operations represents proceeds from the 1986 termination of a pension plan of an operation discontinued in 1985. Also included in the 9-month is Artra's interest in Rosecraft Inc. since June 4, 1986, when it was acquired by Lori Corp. The company also said included in the year-ago 9-month is Artra's interest in R.N. Koch Inc. since Feb. 8, 1985, when it was acquired by Lori Corp., which is 70.4 percent owned by Artra.

title: ERLY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $3,000 for the quarter and $1,215,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter includes a $4.5 million gain on the transfer of Packaged Brands to Comet American Marketing, a newly formed joint venture. The company said the year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Printed in Japan
description: Over at national A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters, officials aren't paying much attention to a letter received from the publisher of ''A Day in the Life of America,'' a coffee-table book of photographs. The Benjamin Company of Elmsford, N.Y., had suggested that the labor federation might want to buy a number of books for holiday gifts for its executives. From labor's viewpoint, there was one small objection: The book, while indisputably American in content, was printed in Japan.

title: ARBOUR GETS A PRESENT FROM ISLANDERS
description: The evening began with a salute to the man who guided the Islanders to four straight Stanley Cup championships in the course of 13 seasons, their former coach, Al Arbour. So it was fitting that Mike Bossy alluded to those winning seasons when trying to explain how the Islanders managed a 6-4 victory tonight despite an erratic performance against Toronto at Nassau Coliseum.

title: REPORT ASKS STATES TO SET SMOKING AGE AT 18
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in a report to Congress on smoking and the nation's health, recommended today that all states ban the sale of tobacco to anyone under 18 years old.

title: U.S. ORDERS INSPECTIONS OF JET WINGS AFTER CRACK
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that, as a result of the discovery of a broken wing spar on a Delta Air Lines Lockheed L-1011 jumbo jet, it was ordering prompt inspections of almost 100 similar planes operated by United States carriers.

title: WREN ENSEMBLE
description: The Wren Ensemble will present a concert of 17th- and 18th century chamber music on original instruments, tonight at 7:30 in the landmark Friends Meeting House at 15th Street and Rutherford's Place, between Second and Third Avenues.

title: HAROLD ARLEN RECALLED WITH SONG AND DANCE
description: Lena Horne and Tony Bennett sang. Harold Nicholas danced. Bobby Short crooned, and it was hard to keep from tapping one's feet.

title: 'THANKSGIVING PROMISE,' ABC MOVIE
description: OVER the next several weeks, television will be busy serving up holiday ''family entertainment'' specials, some old and repackaged as ''classics,'' some new and hoping to become classics next year. The parade gets under way Sunday evening at 9 o'clock on ABC with, appropriately enough, a new TV movie on ''The Disney Sunday Movie.'' Walt Disney might have been pleased with ''The Thanksgiving Promise.'' It is not only about a big, close family; it was made by, and stars, a big and evidently close family.

title: ONE MAN, ONE VOTE: DECADES OF COURT DECISIONS
description: ''People, not land or trees or pastures vote,'' former Chief Justice Earl Warren wrote in 1964 in one of a series of cases that created the principle of one man, one vote.

title: ISRAELI GUNSHIPS ATTACK SOUTHERN LEBANESE PORT
description: Israeli helicopter gunships, escorted by jet fighters, attacked the port of Sidon in southern Lebanon today.

title: Wollman Rink Scorecard
description: CITY: 12 YEARS 1974: Parks and Recreation Department begins planning overhaul of Wollman Rink. Fuel prices are rising, so refrigeration system using liquid Freon in steel tubing is chosen over traditional system of brine in heavy iron pipes. Estimated annual savings: $20,000.

title: Warranties on Mobile Homes
description: The Federal Trade Commission decided Wednesday to drop its 11-year rule-making effort for mobile home warranties after concluding that Federal regulation was unnecessary and would only increase costs for mobile home buyers.

title: BAIRD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DEMAND BY EUROPEANS HELPS LIFT GOLD IN U.S.
description: The dollar rose in thin trading yesterday. Currency dealers said it traded in a narrow range and was not affected by Commerce Department reports that American personal income rose four-tenths of 1 percent while personal spending fell a record 2 percent in October.

title: BEHIND AGCA'S GUN
description: Ever since Pope John Paul II was shot in May 1981, arguments have raged about who, if anyone, might have been behind Mehmet Ali Agca, the man with the smoking gun. A sorely beset Italian jury supposedly by acquitting all of the gunman's alleged accomplices: three fellow Turks and three Bulgarians. Many took this to mean that the jury had found them innocent. It didn't.

title: College Theater Festival Gets a Grant From NBC
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday a $450,000 grant to the American College Theater Festival, an educational program of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The grant, to be paid over three years, will account for about one-quarter of the total festival budget, according to Robert C. Wright, chairman and chief executive officer of NBC, and Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the Kennedy Center and founder of the festival.

title: Nicaraguan Gets Appeal To Free Hasenfus
description: The Nicaraguan Vice President, Sergio Ramirez Mercado, heard appeals here today for the release of Eugene Hasenfus during a visit to the jailed American's home state.

title: The Value of Proxies
description: Both President Reagan and his former national security adviser Robert McFarlane have sought to compare dropping in on Iran, with military house gifts, to the Nixon Administration's secret diplomacy with China.

title: Not Guilty Plea Given in Deaths of 6
description: A man from Browns Mills pleaded not guilty to charges he killed six people, including two children, with a stolen state police cruiser.

title: SHULTZ SAID TO SEEK NEW GROUND RULES ON POLICY ROLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz believes that his views on dealing with Iran have been largely endorsed by President Reagan, but he is now pressing for ground rules that would give the State Department a leading role in any future contacts with Iran, State Department officials said today.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writedown of $8.6 million. c-Net income Share earnings are in units.

title: U.S. Consumers Content
description: The American consumer is relatively content despite a sluggish economy, the University of Michigan said in a study today.

title: POP: 'TIL TUESDAY AT THE RITZ
description: AIMEE MANN, the lead singer, chief songwriter and bassist of the Boston pop group 'Til Tuesday, combines a cool punkish look with a searching lyric sensibility that harks back to folk-oriented singer-songwriters of the 1970's. In the group's most interesting song, ''Coming Up Close,'' Ms. Mann describes a romantic epiphany after driving through the cornfields of Iowa with a friend and listening to a tape of Bob Dylan's music.

title: COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $2,609,000 from the restructuring of the company's European industrial operations for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Includes a non-recurring gain of $897,000 from the sale of stock received from GCA Corp. in the company's 1982 sale of Tropel.

title: NRM ENERGY CO LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'JUNK BOND' PRICES STRENGTHEN
description: Weaker investor demand and a much larger than expected increase in the nation's basic money supply caused a modest drop in Treasury note and bond prices yesterday.

title: America's Industries Are Buffeted by Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Rita Gardner, ''Say It With Music,'' The Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). The stylish, tongue-in-cheek cabaret revue starring Rita Gardner, who created the role of the Girl in ''The Fantasticks,'' interweaves amusing quotations from Dorothy Parker and F. Scott Fitzgerald with pop songs of the 20's to create a lighthearted portrait of that decade through the eyes of a prototypical debutante. In the journey from innocence to disenchantment, Ms. Gardner's ironic-romantic attitude, Buddy Barnes's rollicking piano and Will Holt's brisk direction blend into an effervescent entertainment. Shows are tonight and tomorrow night at 9. Tickets are $15 and there is a two-drink minimum.

title: MARIO BOTTA EXEMPLIFIES LESS IS MORE
description: THERE is but one work by the Swiss architect Mario Botta in the United States, and it is not a complete building but an interior, a showroom recently finished for International Contract Furnishings at the International Design Center in Queens. Mario Botta is no less important for the small size of his oeuvre here - after all, one project is more than many architects of international repute have built in New York. And with the opening at the Museum of Modern Art this week of a major exhibition on Mr. Botta's work, there may be more Botta buildings in store.

title: Homicide Charges Dismissed For a Yugoslav Ship Captain
description: A Michigan judge today dismissed two charges of negligent homicide against a Yugoslav freighter captain accused in the deaths of two fishermen in Lake Michigan.

title: Dining Out Guide: Thanksgiving
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMBASSADOR GRILL, #1 United Nations

title: CCX NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STAR AND HER FRIENDS SHINE
description: Lord and Taylor, bedecked in its traditional holiday finery - banks of pointsettas, Christmas trees, garlands and gingham - was the setting for an intimate party for old friends honoring one of their own, Barbara Walters. There were confessions of crushes, jokes about age, songs of tribute and a lot of embracing.

title: MUSIC: HINDEMITH AND BEETHOVEN BY PHILHARMONIC
description: UNTIL Paul Hindemith's death in 1963, perhaps a dozen of his orchestral works were heard with some regularity on programs in this country. Now it is a rare event when one turns up, as it did last night when the New York Philharmonic played the three-movement ''symphony'' suite drawn from ''Mathis der Maler,'' his opera about the life of the Reformation painter Matthias Grunwald. As one who recognizes the high professionalism and instrumental efficiency of Hindemith's works but finds his thematic ideas shortwinded and his music generally thicknecked and clumsy, I do not much regret his current absence from the repertory. However, the ''Mathis'' triptych is not only well made, in the usual Hindemith style, but also still holds a certain mystical appeal and deserves an occasional hearing.

title: TERRANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $128,016 from forgiveness of debt. c-Net loss

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: City Officials Delay Adding Locked Park
description: Responding to criticism of the locked gate on a community garden, city officials last night withdrew for further study their plan to take over the plot as part of the park system.

title: S.E.C. IS UNDER FIRE IN LETTING BOESKY SELL OF HOLDINGS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission came under intense criticism today for letting Ivan F. Boesky sell close to half a billion dollars in stock days before settling his insider-trading case.

title: FASTER NUCLEAR EVACUATIONS WITH FEWER PEOPLE PROPOSED
description: New studies of the spread of dangerous radiation after accidents at nuclear power plants may suggest faster evacuations of fewer people, scientists at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission say.

title: GRUSON LEAVING POSTS ON BOARD OF TIMES CO.
description: Sydney Gruson, vice chairman and a director of The New York Times Company, gave up both positions yesterday after a 50-year career in journalism that included tours of duty as a war correspondent, foreign correspondent and foreign editor of The Times.

title: America's Cup; One Boat Retired By Bond
description: Australia III was retired from America's Cup racing today, but not without one last burst of glory.

title: Environment Reorganized
description: The new Democratic majority has reorganized the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works, creating a subcommittee responsible for the Federal program to clean up toxic wastes as well as overseeing environmental legislation. The new subcommittee is headed by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, who intends to examine very closely the Environmental Protection Agency's management of the cleanup programfinanced by the Superfund.

title: DREXEL 'JUNK BOND' WIZARD...
description: When a relatively unknown corporate official needed money recently to acquire a company, he did what many others have done before him. He traveled to the mecca of ''junk bonds'' - also known as the Beverly Hills office of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Appeal on Vermont Measure
description: The National Organization for Women is seeking a new vote on a proposed equal rights amendment to the State Constitution in some areas of Vermont because it believes abuses may have contributed to the measure's defeat.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Tim Berne Quintet, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sporting an alto saxophone sound that's appealingly dry and plangent, and a conversationally bluesy style, Tim Berne is finally getting some recognition at home after a decade of worthy record releases on European labels. His group, featuring the trumpeter Herb Robertson, is playing its first major New York club engagement this weekend, anticipating the release early next year of an album for Columbia. Show times Friday and Saturday are about 10 P.M. and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M., with a $12 cover charge and $6 minimum. On Sunday, shows are at 10 P.M. and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $10 with a $6 minimum.

title: Minute by Minute, The Train Gets Late
description: IT is a question as old as suburbia itself:

title: Concession in Maryland
description: Robert Neall, the Republican candidate in Maryland's Fourth Congressional District, conceded defeat Wednesday, declining to seek a recount in the race he lost to Tom McMillen, the Democrat, by 428 votes out of more than 129,000 cast. ''The votes were checked and counted very much to my satisfaction,'' Mr. Neall said of the Nov. 4 results. Mr. McMillen said he was ''glad that it's over and that now we can really begin the transition.''

title: Washington's Governor Would Scrap Welfare
description: Gov. Booth Gardner is seeking to eliminate welfare and establish an experimental corporation for five years to emphasize work, education and healing of rifts in families.

title: FILM: 'UNHEARD MUSIC'
description: IN ''The Unheard Music,'' a documentary about the Los Angeles-based punk band X that opens today at the Waverly, one member of the group recalls reading a review of the Ramones, who are grand old men of this musical genre. The review said they played too fast, their songs were too short and contained only three chords, they never resorted to guitar solos and their songs were ''dumb.'' ''All those sounded like real positive things to me,'' says X's guitarist, Billy Zoom, and his music bears that out.

title: ROSE'S STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Ford Offers New Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer low-interest financing or a $300 rebate on 1986 and 1987 Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx models in response to a similar offer announced earlier by the Chrysler Corporation.

title: KLOSS VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $861,000.

title: Nets Lose Again, 111-95
description: James Worthy scored 26 points and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar added 12 points and 10 rebounds tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers won their eighth straight game by defeating the Nets, 111-95. The Nets, who have the worst record in the league, fell to 2-9.

title: Stamped In, Stamped Out
description: The Citizens Postage Stamp Advisory Committee met yesterday, as it does periodically, to sort through some of the people and subjects nominated for commemoration on postage stamps.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $153,000, a tax credit of $2,701,000 and includes a pre-tax gain of $12,481,000 primarily from the sale of the company's interest in Sea-Land Corp. after an attempted acquisition, and also includes a charge of $3 million for an additional management fee payable to Contran Corp. with respect to LLC Corp.'s acquisition activity. Contran Corp. holds 42 percent of LLC Corp.'s outstanding common stock. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $36,000 and a tax credit of $497,000. The figures for 1985 have been reclassified to reflect the discontinuance of the company's wire and wire products operations.

title: How to Resuscitate the Senate?
description: One ex-Senator, three about-to-be ex-Senators and one whose Senate career is still going strong after 32 years got together the other day to talk with unusual candor about whether there is hope for the United States Senate.

title: GREENERY REHABILITATION GROUP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After a $226,000 charge related to the accelerated payment of debt.

title: TRANSPORTATION DEPT. URGES DELAY IN AIR BAG RULE
description: The Department of Transportation today proposed extending by as many as four years its deadline for installation of automatic restraint systems, such as air bags, in passenger cars. It also modified its restraint requirement.

title: Man, Trapped by His Books In July Quake, Is Dead at 87
description: An elderly man who was trapped for 12 hours July 13 after thousands of books toppled on him in an earthquake has been found dead in his hotel room, the authorities said today.

title: 40,000 Pieces of Mail (and Peace of Mind)
description: Out for a Stroll

title: RUSTY PELICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes a $176,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said that an increase in insurance costs, amounting to more than 2 cents a share in the latest quarter, adversely affected the quarter's results.

title: COMMUNITY NATIONAL BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gains from the termination of a pension plan of $280,000 for the latest 9-month, and an extraordinary gain of $117,000 from the sale of real estate for the year-ago period.

title: ENS BIO LOGICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said that as a result of a transaction effective Sept. 26 with Rose Co., its third quarter financial statements have been prepared in accordance with reverse takeover accounting rules. Due to the change in accounting resulting from the takeover of Rose, comparable share earnings for the year-earlier periods are not available. All figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. AND EUROPE DISCUSS SPACE STATION CONFLICTS
description: Leaders of the European Space Agency and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration met yesterday in Washington to begin talks aimed at overcoming critical differences over sharing the costs and responsibilities for the space station project, American and Western European officials said.

title: MEDICINE SHOPPE INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SATURDAY NEW QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: JAZZ: THE TIM BERNE QUINTET
description: Tim Berne, an alto saxophonist who is fast becoming one of jazz's most innovative composers, has unveiled a new quintet for his first major New York club engagement (through tomorrow night at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South). Like the Henry Threadgill Sextet, David Holland Quintet and World Saxophone Quartet, Mr. Berne's group improvises within postmodern structures - pieces that are quick-changing, intelligent and emotionally rich.

title: MORRISANIA TORN BETWEEN HARD TIMES AND HOPE
description: Cleveland Brock huddled in the rattling wind yesterday and said no, living in the Morrisania section of the Bronx was not as bad as his friend was saying.

title: Wall St. Saw a Tough 'Arab'
description: Ivan F. Boesky has become the symbol of a fast-money era: a time when high-stakes mergers make front-page news and turn Wall Street deal makers into multimillionaires.

title: Wilson, Barrett Lecture
description: Mookie Wilson of the Mets and Marty Barrett of the Boston Red Sox asked University of Massachusetts students yesterday to put behind them a brawl that followed the final game of the World Series. ''In life there's some things you can't change,'' Wilson told an assembly.

title: Germans Block Missile Site
description: Demonstrators protesting the presence of nuclear missiles in Europe blocked a road to a United States Air Force cruise missile construction site today for a second straight day.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $107,000 and $164,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $386,000 and $656,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: JUDGE'S CHARGE TO JURY ON WITNESS CREDIBILITY
description: Following is an excerpt from the formal instruction given by Judge Whitman Knapp to the jury today in the trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and three co-defendants: As I've told you, you are the ultimate authority as to what facts have been proven in this case. In exercising your authority in this regard, perhaps the single most important thing you must consider is the credibility of the witnesses who appear before you.

title: Letter: On Agriculture Policy; Farmers Need Off-Farm Income
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 908986 -- No Title
description: The controversy over the Reagan Administration's policy toward Iran grew more heated today with reports that Iranian officials had paid at least $12 million for a shipment of 2,008 American-made anti-tank missiles and that the money had been deposited in a Swiss bank account.

title: GRAND AUTO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Truce Is Shattered In Southern Lebanon
description: Gun battles broke out today near Palestinian districts in southern Lebanon, shattering a three-week-old truce between the Palestinian guerrillas and their Shiite adversaries.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $113,000 for the quarter and $118,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $476,000.

title: How Should History Be Taught?
description: Western civilization is under attack on many fronts. One stage for heated battles is the otherwise peaceful, if often soporific, college faculty meeting. Long before the recent release of a Carnegie Foundation report on college curriculums, many faculties had begun debates on the form and content of Western civilization ''core'' courses, on the need to find effective ways of introducing students to ''essential knowledge,'' as the Carnegie study puts it, ''to connections across disciplines, and in the end, to application of knowledge to life beyond the campus.''

title: THE DANCE: 'BOLERO' BY IGAL PERRY
description: In this age of repetition in both music and dance, Ravel's ''Bolero'' has a hallowed place as the granddaddy of the genre. There is a difference, however, between being an original - as Ravel was in this respect - and being an imitator.

title: FOR WARD AND UNION, STALEMATE RISK LED TO DEAL
description: The agreement that resolved the dispute over Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's plan to rotate senior patrol officers was reached because neither side wanted to prolong a potentially dangerous stand-off, both police union and New York City officials said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Off and Skating in Brooklyn Brooklyn's only outdoor ice-skating rink opens its 27th season today.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: New Soviet Human-Rights Song Is Off-Key
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
A Wrench for Using In Confined Spaces
description: Gerald M. Shirley, president of the Aldshir Manufacturing Company, Mount Vernon, N.Y., believes the ratchet wrench for which he got patent 4,622,870 this week fills a need that has existed more than 100 years. He says his wrench is the first to combine simplicity, versatility, durability and great strength with low production cost.

title: HUNT GROWS FOR SUSPECT IN SHOOTOUT
description: The hunt for the suspected killer who shot and wounded six police officers in a Bronx apartment Wednesday night spread across the nation yesterday as rewards totaling $15,000 were offered for the capture and conviction of the fugitive.

title: Swiss Company Pledges 'Gigantic' Effort on Rhine
description: The chief executive of a Swiss chemical concern pledged today to organize and finance a ''gigantic'' campaign to clean up chemical damage to the Rhine River.

title: Odell Retiring
description: Bob Odell, the football coach at Williams College for the last 16 years, will retire at the end of the academic year, ending a 40-year college coaching career, including 29 as a head coach.

title: ORIENT-EXPRESS HOTELS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-After a provision of $17 million for losses on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: 30 Hurt as Mexico Police Stop Opposition Parade
description: Thirty people were hurt and at least 20 arrested Thursday when the police fired tear gas to break up an opposition party parade, officials said.

title: Nuclear Plant Cleared to Reopen
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to authorize the reopening of an Ohio nuclear plant closed for nearly 18 months after extensive breakdowns of safety-related equipment.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: Noon - Martina Navratilova vs. Pam Shriver, semifinal.

title: OFFICIALS DISCOUNT TALK OF TOP-LEVEL SHAKE-UP
description: President Reagan met today with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger as officials sought to dampen reports that a high-level shake-up loomed in the White House because of the controversy over arms shipments to Iran.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HEARINGS WERE DELAYED 4 TIMES FOR SUSPECT
description: Larry Davis, the suspect in the Wednesday shooting of six police officers, has remained out of jail for 10 months while a hearing on possible probation violations was postponed four times.

title: Siegler Studies Restructuring
description: Lear Siegler Inc. said today that it had retained the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs & Company to evaluate the possibility of a leveraged buyout or recapitalization.

title: FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes charges from loan and lease losses of $21,108,000 for the quarter and $26,368,000 for the 9 months. c-After a charge of $87,572,000 from losses of unconsolidated banking subsidiary.

title: Rehnquist Is Elected To Smithsonian Post
description: The Smithsonian Institution announced today that William H. Rehnquist, the Chief Justice of the United States, had been elected chancellor of the institution's governing board, the regents.

title: DISNEY'S MOUSE OF MARKETING
description: At the news conference before the International Children's Peace Prize ceremony in Disneyland, Misha Sokolov, the Russian boy, was droll and funny as translated by his interpreter; Dawn Balady, the American winner from New Jersey, sang the peace song she had composed for the contest, and Mickey Mouse kept patting and kissing Jihan el-Sadat.

title: For Charities, A Benefactor
description: On Wall Street, Ivan F. Boesky was known as a man with a ferocious desire to accumulate wealth and make a name for himself, and when he confessed to violating insider-trading rules, many of his peers said they were not surprised.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: OAK HILL SPORTSWEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BOOTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income

title: GENERAL AERO PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS OF ARANSAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company converted to capital stock from a mutual savings company in April.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball

title: 'The Whole Trick Is Angles'
description: When he approaches, his shoulders seem to arrive before he does. As he moved through the Las Vegas Hilton, people stepped back silently to let those shoulders pass. After he went by, their eyes followed him, as if mesmerized by this 20-year-old boxer with 25 knockouts in his 27-0 record. Usually only a heavyweight champion of stature projects this primitive aura, but it already surrounds Mike Tyson, who will be trying to dethrone 33-year-old Trevor Berbick tonight for the World Boxing Council title.

title: CIRCUIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Northern California Jolted by Earthquake
description: A moderate earthquake shook northern California today, causing minor damage but no injuries.

title: Harvard Scientists Retract Publications On Medical Finding
description: Researchers at Harvard University have retracted publications concerning the discovery of a substance that had been depicted as greatly stimulating the immune system. They said in a letter published today that the data were ''not reproducible and are incorrect.''

title: U.S. BARS DEPORTATION OF ALIENS CLAIMING AMNESTY
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has instructed its employees to suspend the deportation of illegal aliens who appear to qualify for legal status under the new immigration law.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
KEY RATES
OPEC Seen Over Quota But Market Unaffected
description: Unconfirmed reports circulated yesterday that the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait are producing above the quotas set by OPEC. Each is said to be producing 250,000 barrels a day over quota, at 1.2 million barrels.

title: DON'T STOP AT ROTATING POLICE OFFICERS
description: Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward have proposed a new policy for rooting out corruption among New York City's ''finest.'' Their plan is based on circular reasoning.

title: WALKER ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes writedowns of $14.1 million on oil and gas assets for latest 9 months and $4.3 million for year-ago period.

title: NATIONWIDE CELLULAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHULTZ ACKNOWLEDGES ROLE IN TALKS ON IRAN OPERATION
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz acknowledged today that he took part in two ''full-scale discussions'' with President Reagan and other top advisers before Mr. Reagan signed a secret directive in January permitting the sale of arms to Iran.

title:
PATENTS;
An Energy Treatment Of Cancer
description: AN Illinois surgeon's campaign against cancer was marked by the issuance of two patents to him this week. Dr. Robert T. Gordon, who serves in the Lutheran General Hospital at Skokie and on the faculty of the University of Illinois in Chicago, has invented a method of treating diseased cells with electromagnetic energy.

title: Marques Johnson Hurt
description: Marques Johnson of the Los Angeles Clippers suffered a bruise on his spinal cord in Thursday night's game against the Mavericks and is expected to be sidelined two to three weeks.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a net loss from scheduled service of $21,154,000 and $48,960,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, a loss on disposal of scheduled service operations of $27,892,000 for both periods, and for the latest quarter, a reversal of a tax credit of $2,650,000. c-Net income d-Includes a gain of $341,000 on termination of pension plan for both periods, a net gain from scheduled service of $3,886,000 for the quarter and a net loss from scheduled service of $5,064,000 for the 9 months.

title: British Gas Stock Priced
description: The British Government began its bid today to woo more than 4 million Britons into buying shares in British Gas, the state gas monopoly that is to be sold to the public next week in the biggest share issue ever.

title: TV: STORY OF SAM HOUSTON, ON CBS
description: Being slipped into the CBS schedule in a bit of a hurry (I had to watch a work print that, in addition to lacking color adjustments and music, contained scenes in which a director could still be heard shouting at the extras), ''Houston: The Legend of Texas'' tackles a larger-than-life figure from American history with verve and what might be called responsible imagination. Sam Houston (1793-1863) was a complicated character and, to this day, interpretations about various events in his life are open to debate.

title: BRAZIL INCREASES PRICES TO SLOW CONSUMPTION
description: The Brazilian Government today announced anxiously awaited measures to cool consumer demand. It wants to prevent fast growth from disrupting a nine-month stabilization program.

title: ALBANY ACTS TO CUT SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES
description: Regulations prohibiting smoking in most indoor public areas were unanimously approved yesterday by the New York State Public Health Council, pending public hearings next month. The regulations would also require employers to set aside smoke-free areas for workers who request them.

title: CINEMA: 'THE WRAITH' TEEN-AGE ACTION FILM
description: The greatest suspense in ''The Wraith,'' which opened yesterday at the National and other theaters, is generated by the problem of how the writer-director, Mike Marvin, will work a word like ''wraith'' into the dialogue. It wouldn't be common parlance under the best of circumstances, let alone in a teen-age action film filled with car races.

title: TBC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 COUNCIL MEMBERS AMONG 7 INDICTED IN CHICAGO INQUIRY
description: Seven people, including two Chicago Aldermen, were indicted here today on Federal charges of corruption, fraud, extortion and illegal arms dealings.

title: Article 755886 -- No Title
description: The British and Commonwealth Shipping Company, a diversified concern headed by John Gunn, a financier, has agreed to buy Exco International P.L.C. in a deal valued at $948.2 million. Exco is a London-based money-brokering company that Mr. Gunn founded and ran until last year.

title: Connors Out Of Masters
description: Jimmy Connors fought off 2 match points tonight before falling to Scott Davis, 6-2, 6-2, in the quarterfinals at the Houston Shootout.

title: Brawl to Be Studied
description: Brian O'Neill, executive vice president of the National Hockey League, has requested films of Thursday night's fight-filled game between the Bruins and the Montreal Canadiens at Boston Garden to assess whether he will take disciplinary action. Referee Andy van Hellemond assessed 124 minutes in penalties, and 8 players were ejected after a bench-clearing brawl late in the second period of a game the Canadiens won, 3-1.

title: PHOTO OF A LOST VAN GOGH SUNFLOWER
description: The assignment was sunflowers. And the photographer David Douglas Duncan delivered not only pictures of sunflowers, but a photograph of a painting of a sunflower that has surprised and delighted art historians.

title: A Hotel Is Not a Home
description: Instead of spending thousands of dollars for hotel accommodations, ''I wonder why somebody doesn't build them a house for $37,000,'' President Reagan said when he read in this newspaper about some homeless New Yorkers named Motta. Keeping Ms. Motta and her four children in two tiny, mouse-ridden hotel rooms costs the public $1,150 every two weeks.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3.3 million from a repayment of long- term debt for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $3,256,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $1,835,000 for the quarter and extraordinary gain of $7,388,000 for the 9 months.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $15,451,000 from the writedown of oil and gas properties and other non-recurring charges of $310,000. c-Net income

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF AUSTIN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BOESKY WAS ALLOWED TO SELL STOCK TO AVOID ANY PANIC, S.E.C. SAYS
description: The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission today defended the agency's action in permitting Ivan F. Boesky to sell $440 million in stocks while he was negotiating his insider trading settlement with the commission.

title: Penn State Nears Perfection
description: If undefeated Penn State beats Pitt today, it will solidify the planned Fiesta Bowl match Jan. 2 for what would amount to the national championship between Miami, currently ranked No. 1, and the Nittany Lions, ranked No. 2.

title: S.M.U. PRESIDENT, CITING HEALTH, RESIGNS AMID SPORTS DISPUTE
description: L. Donald Shields, president of Southern Methodist University in Dallas since 1980, resigned today, capping a tumultuous week at a university facing mounting pressure because of allegations of continued recruiting violations in its athletic program.

title: G.E. WILL CLOSE TRANSFORMER UNIT
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would stop building large transformers - the huge machines that regulate voltage for electricity generating stations -in the United States. It also said it would combine its transformer operations in Canada with those of Westinghouse.

title: NORTH AMERICAN SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a credit of $874,360 resulting from a dividend paid by the federal home loan bank board in the form of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock and a tax credit. Share earnings for 1985 are not available; the bank went public in December 1985. Share earnings for 1986 reflect a 10- percent stock dividend paid in September.

title: RIVER OAKS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a $9,852,000 loss from discontinued operations and an $11,200,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $1,740,000. Prior year results are restated to reflect discontinued operations; the company also said that revenue in fiscal 1986 was derived principally from its financial services subsidiary, Bedford Financial which was organized in the final quarter of fiscal 1985 and completed its first full year of operation in 1986.

title: Stella Standard Dies; Wrote 10 Cookbooks
description: Stella Standard, an author of 10 cookbooks, died of a heart attack Thursday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BOTHA SAYS SANCTIONS SERVE SOVIET INTERESTS
description: President P. W. Botha said today that American economic sanctions against South Africa only served the interests of the Soviet Union.

title: JORDAN'S LAST 18 LEAVE MARK ON KNICKS
description: For much of the evening Michael Jordan seemed merely mortal. But the time finally came tonight when the gifted third-year guard transformed the court into his own stage, scoring the Bulls' last 18 points of the game.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about United States Supreme Court decisions that created the principle of one man, one vote misidentified the Chief Justice under whom the Court ruled on another issue, abortion, in Roe v. Wade.

title: Yanks May Ask John for an Encore
description: Tommy John resigned as pitching coach of the University of North Carolina baseball team yesterday, creating the possibility that he will resume his pitching career with the Yankees next spring.

title: Flash in Sky: Rocket Debris?
description: A streak of light seen in the night sky from Tampa to Jamaica was apparently produced by debris from a Soviet rocket re-entering the Earth's atmosphere, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: FOES OF SANDINISTAS DEFIANTLY HAIL 'MARTYR'
description: If there is a name not to mention in this country, it is probably that of Jorge Salazar Arguello.

title: Home, School and Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Appoints Reporter
description: Mayor Koch yesterday named a reporter, George Artz of The New York Post, to serve as his fifth press secretary. Mr. Artz, who has been with The Post since 1969 and has worked as the paper's City Hall bureau chief for the last 14 years, will replace William Rauch on Dec. 15. Mr. Artz will earn $85,000 a year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1986
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: GRAF BEATS MALEEVA IN 3 SETS
description: If Manuela Maleeva's face were a weather map, the forecast would be for rain. She has a Pagliacci look in victory and defeat, an expression that suggests she has just been given some bad news. Most of the time, it doesn't really convey how the No. 8 player in the world feels. Last night, however, it more than fit the mood, and there probably isn't an actress on Broadway who was suited to play Maleeva's part any more than she.

title: RANGERS RESPOND WITH A COMEBACK
description: For one night, the Rangers did for Phil Esposito what they could not do for Ted Sator. After falling behind, they went ahead in wild style and stayed ahead. Tony McKegney, whom Esposito the general manager had acquired just last week in a trade, scored four goals tonight to give Esposito the coach an 8-5 victory over the Canucks in his debut behind the bench.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I find on the basis of what I've heard, and I'm not saying what I've heard, that this whole operation, its genesis and the carrying out of it was incredibly clumsy and amateurish.'' - Senator Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Democratic leader, discussing contacts with Iran. [ 1:6. ]

title: 4 Students Get Awards Named for Times Editor
description: The first Seymour Peck Scholarship and Creative Awards were presented to four City College students last night in a ceremony in the Eugenia Room of the Sardi Building. The awards were established as a memorial to Mr. Peck, a former New York Times Culture Editor and a City College alumnus, who was killed in an automobile accident in January 1985.

title: L.I. Woman Arrested In Slaying of Husband
description: An East Meadow woman was arrested today on charges of hiring three men to kill her husband in exchange for promises of about $2,300 each, including a television and a video cassette recorder, the police said.

title: Curbs Weighed By the C.F.T.C.
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission will meet next week to consider barring commodity exchange employees from trading certain futures or options.

title: STEEL TALKS BREAK OFF BETWEEN USX AND UNION
description: Negotiations between the United Steelworkers of America and the USX Corporation broke off today and leaders of both sides said they expected the 113-day labor dispute to continue to be a costly and protracted struggle.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 5
V.A. Mortgage Rate Cut to 9%
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it would lower the maximum interest rate on Government-backed V.A. mortgages by half a percentage point, to 9 percent, the lowest it has been in eight years.

title: VMS SHORT TERM INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEXICAN AIR FARES RISE
description: Domestic air fares in Mexico increased by up to 40 percent today because of increasing costs, the Transport and Communications Ministry said. Both national carriers, Aeromexico and Mexicana, raised their fares, the third such increase this year and another setback for Mexicans trying to cope with their nations 100 percent inflation rate.

title: REGENTS SUGGEST INCREASE IN AID TO POOR SCHOOLS
description: The State Board of Regents yesterday proposed a new program to increase aid to needy school districts as part of a general increase in aid to schools.

title: Miracle on the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: ANOTHER OPENING, BUT WHAT A SHOW
description: Glen Rice and Garde Thompson scored 6 points each in a 14-0 surge opening the second half to spark Michigan to a 115-107 victory tonight in an opening-round game of the Coca-Cola N.I.T. Classic. The Wolverines trailed by 53-51 at halftime, but held the Braves scoreless until Hersey Hawkins made a layup at 3 minutes 43 seconds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: PHILIPPINE MILITARY ISSUED DEMANDS TO AQUINO
description: The armed forces Chief of Staff said today that he gave President Corazon C. Aquino a set of military demands last week as part of a move to block a planned coup.

title: ESPOSITO RUSHES IN, DROPS SATOR AND TAKES OVER
description: From the moment Phil Esposito became general manager of the Rangers, it was widely thought that sooner or later he would dismiss Ted Sator as coach. He did it sooner.

title: GOVERNOR HAS PINCHED NERVE
description: Governor Cuomo's doctors have diagnosed a pinched nerve in his neck that causes discomfort in his shoulder and back and that often produces a tingling sensation in his right hand, his office said yesterday.

title: SANDWICH CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes $20.2 million in net proceeds from the sale of 1,820,833 shares of common stock on July 15, 1986. The company said the share earnings data is not meaningful since the bank converted from a mutual to a stock organization in July 1986.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $24,397 from the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial on Tuesday concerning liability for chemical accidents gave the wrong first name for the chairman of Union Carbide Corporation. He is Warren Anderson.

title: RULING IS LIKELY MONDAY IN FIGHT FOR EASTERN AIR
description: The fate of a last-minute union effort to prevent Texas Air Inc. from gaining control of Eastern Air Lines was put in the hands of a Federal judge yesterday.

title: TRIANGLE HOME PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ROYAL PALM SAVINGS ASSOCIAION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Who Rules New York?
description: The Federal Court ruling that New York City's Board of Estimate violates the constitutional mandate of one person, one vote sends a powerful but not surprising shock wave. Mayor Koch has acted responsibly in moving to appoint a charter revision commission to search out remedies.

title: A Date to Debate
description: Joan Claybrook, the consumer activist who heads the group Public Citizen, and Richard K. Willard, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the civil division, will argue proposed changes in laws on damage suits at a debate in Washington Dec. 4. Miss Claybrook says she hopes to complete the debate this time.

title: PRIMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Drop in Participants In Antismoking Drive
description: Five million fewer people participated in the 24 tobacco-less hours of this year's Great American Smokeout than last year, preliminary figures showed. It was the first drop in the program's 10-year history.

title: Trump to Acquire 20% of Alexander's
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, will acquire 20 percent of the stock of Alexander's Inc., the retail store chain with valuable real estate holdings.

title: F.C.C. STUDIES 'INDECENCY' ON RADIO
description: After eight years, the issue of complaints about ''indecent'' language on radio has abruptly re-emerged as a concern of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday recalling the career of Ivan F. Boesky described his membership in the Harvard Club incorrectly. He was eligible as a member of the visiting committee of the School of Public Health at Harvard, to which he was a substantial contributor; the club did not act in response to a donation.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $500,000 from an insurance settlement and $500,000 from an employee termination.

title: CITICORP CUTS CREDIT CARD RATE
description: In what appears to be a breakthrough in credit-card interest rates, Citicorp will cut the rates on some credit cards to 16.8 percent from 19.8 percent. However, it will increase the annual fee on those cards to $50 from $40.

title: Dozens of Blue Whales Appear in Monterey Bay
description: Researchers have been astounded by the unexpected appearance in Monterey Bay of dozens of blue whales, the world's largest living creatures, scientists said today.

title: SEOULD HAS NO TAPE TO BACK REPORTS
description: South Korea's Defense Minister said today that the military did not have tape recordings of North Korean loudspeaker broadcasts that were said to have reported the death of the North Korean leader this week.

title: FINGERPRINTS TIE DEFENDANT TO CAR STOPPED BY TROOPER
description: After two weeks of trial, testimony today for the first time placed Richard C. Williams in a 1977 Chevrolet Nova the day a state trooper was killed after stopping the car.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Arco Critical of Insider Suit
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that a lawsuit filed against Arco's former chairman, Robert O. Anderson, and others was ''without merit.'' The suit accuses Mr. Anderson of using inside information to acquire valuable deep drilling rights in Texas from the company.

title: Padres for Sale
description: Joan Kroc, the owner of the Padres, has confirmed reports the team was for sale and promised she would take every legal step available to keep the club in San Diego. ''We would consider any serious offers that meet the criteria,'' said Kroc, who added that there was no timetable for selling the club, for which she is asking $50 million. Kroc said she wanted to devote her entire efforts to the various philanthropic and social causes with which she is involved.

title: A Time Bomb In New York Courts
description: A time bomb is ticking in New York State's judicial system. Its explosive ingredients are two well-intentioned reforms that promised speedier, fairer justice but are delivering delay and chaos. Those reforms are the six-year-old divorce law and a new system of assigning judges to cases.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture of Abbey Lincoln in Weekend yesterday with an article about a jazz concert at Columbia University was published in error. The university changed its program, and she will not appear in ''Jazz Finds a Home'' tomorrow.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.M. REACHES TENTATIVE PACT TO END DELCO STRIKE
description: The General Motors Corporation and Local 292 of the United Automobile Workers today reached a tentative agreement to end a strike at an Indiana plant that has produced widespread factory shutdowns and layoffs of factory workers.

title: REAGAN PLANS FOR HOLIDAY
description: President and Mrs. Reagan will spend Thanksgiving Day at their California ranch with family members, the White House announced today. The announcement said they would be joined by the President's brother, Neil and his wife, Bess; the Reagan's son, Ron, and his wife, Doria; and the President's daughter Maureen and her husband, Dennis. The spokesman, Larry Speakes, said the President's son Michael and daughter Patti would spend the holiday with their in-laws.

title: ONEIDAS' LAND CLAIM REJECTED BY U.S. JUDGE
description: A Federal district judge rejected today a claim by Oneida Indians to nearly six million acres that they contend were illegally purchased by the state in the 1780's for $16,500.

title: INAMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary after- tax gain of $12,636 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss and includes extraordinary after-tax gains of $3,431 for the quarter and $45,087 for the 9 months. The 9 months' loss if also after a loss of $219,512 on disposal of property.

title: ISREAEL AIDE TRACES U.S.-IRAN DEALINGS
description: A senior Israeli official said today that the sale of American arms to Iran grew out of Israeli links with the Khomeini Government dating to 1979.

title: LYNN LOESSER
description: Lynn Loesser, a former theatrical producer, died Wednesday at New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: School in Tennessee Bars Play About Anne Frank
description: Hawkins County school officials, stung by a lawsuit over textbooks alleged to be ''anti-Christian,'' has refused to allow a stage production of ''The Diary of Anne Frank.''

title:
PATENTS;
A Way to Make Fuel Out of Newspapers
description: Albert J. Zulkowitz of Woodmere, L.I., says he is legally blind, but his eye trouble has not kept him from inventing a method of making fuel from newspapers.

title: BINGHAM RETURNS TO SHADOWS
description: If it happened on Broadway, Guy Bingham might have become a star. But in football, he goes back to the bench.

title: MERET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $1,938,338 from debt restructuring.

title: Two Books by Victor Mollo Add to an Entertaining List
description: The world's most prolific bridge writer is no doubt England's Victor Mollo. His 29 books are all entertaining, and most of them are available from Barclay Bridge Supplies, 8 Bush Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573.

title:
PATENTS;
A Deadlocking Latch For Securing a Door
description: A one-inch deadlocking door latch, patented this week, is described by its inventor as making a door as secure against thieves as a dead bolt would.

title: OSHAWA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a net gain of $4,023,000 from the sale of one property, provisions for additional costs on the closing of another and a reduction in the carrying value of a third property. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Thanksgiving: Carryout Option
description: Invitations to Thanksgiving dinner are often accompanied by a request: Please bring a sweet-potato casserole, cranberry relish, dessert.

title: Hallmark Ordered To Pull Card Line
description: A small company that contends its successful line of greeting cards was copied by Hallmark Cards Inc. has won a Federal court injunction ordering the giant company to pull the disputed cards from shelves. Federal District Judge Jim Carrigan has ordered Hallmark to pull the 83 cards of its Personal Touch line from store shelves while a $50 million lawsuit brought by Blue Mountain Arts of Boulder, Colo., is resolved.

title: SKIES TURN BRIGHTER FOR GIANT RECEIVER
description: Bobby Johnson smiled at the wonder of it all.

title: SERVICE NEEDS OF ALIENS BRING WORRIES ON COSTS
description: State and local officials around the country say the $1 billion a year the Federal Government has pledged for social services for illegal aliens who gain legal status under the new immigration law may fall far short of the need.

title: In Love With Love
description: THE COMPLETE LYRICS OF LORENZ HART. Edited by Dorothy Hart and Robert Kimball. With an appreciation by Alan Jay Lerner. 317 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COKE BOTTLER'S RECEPTION ON WALL ST. DISAPPOINTS
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the bottling company 49 percent owned by the Coca-Cola Company, went public yesterday, but the results were disappointing, Wall Street executives said.

title: U.S. AIDE DISPUTING OTHERS OVER STANCE ON MISSILE BAN
description: A senior Defense Department official today disputed statements by other high-level Administration officials that the United States had backed away from its proposal to Moscow to ban ballistic missiles in 10 years.

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $1,819,000 from the writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Seafood Inspection Advocated
description: IT has been 80 years since Upton Sinclair described the filthy conditions that pervaded the Chicago meatpacking industry in ''The Jungle'' and moved the nation to pass its first Pure Food and Drug Act to systematically inspect the beef and pork eaten by consumers.

title: AUSTRALIA TRIAL LEADS LONDON TO ORDER INQUIRY INTO SECURITY LEAKS
description: A sharp political ricochet from an Australian courtroom, where Britain's highest civil servant has been subjected to severe cross-examination for four days, has forced the Government to order a police investigation of leaks by former high officials in its secret service.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect the issuance of 1,000,000 additional shares of common stock on July 8, 1986, and 139,600 shares on July 9, 1986.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MARIN IN MINIATURE The artist John Marin (1870-1953) was an American watercolorist with a feeling for big scenes, scenes that could be New York cityscapes or quiet seascapes, all interpreted with his special, modern vision. But the Marin show now at the Kennedy Galleries, 40 West 57th Street (541-9600), is evidence that big scenes do not necessarily need large frames.

title: Tallying Total of Exemptions
description: A FORM that many employees have not seen in years will be taking on new importance in the coming months as the Internal Revenue Service tries to make sure that the Government receives a steady flow of tax revenue.

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $171,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss

title: DEALINGS WITH BOESKY RESTIRCTED IN BRITAIN
description: The London Stock Exchange today put restrictions on members who deal with Ivan F. Boesky and any firm or individual connected with the Wall Street speculator, who is at the center of an insider trading scandal.

title: PRESIDIO OIL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Preferred dividend requirements for the latest quarter were $452,397. It exceeded the net income, therefore, no share earnings.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: A thousand construction workers demonstrated yesterday outside a meeting of Japanese Government and business officials to protest the use of non-union labor to build a Toyota assembly plant in Kentucky.

title: Kemp to Form Committee
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York will announce next month the formation of a committee to explore his running for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination. ''There will be, before the end of 1986, an exploratory committee announced,'' a spokesman, John Buckley, said today.

title: PINETREE COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $17,743 and $45,694 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively.

title: Goldsmith Deal Raises Greenmail Issue Again
description: The question of whether the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company paid Sir James Goldsmith greenmail flared up anew yesterday.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $908,000 which relates to retroactive elimination of investment tax credit under the new tax law.

title: BOB EVANS RESIGNING
description: Bob Evans, a sausage producer who founded a restaurant chain bearing his name, is resigning as president and director.

title: CORRUPT UNIONS TO BE THE TARGET OF JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Federal law-enforcement officials, encouraged by this week's guilty verdicts in the Mafia commission trial in New York, say they will broaden efforts against labor unions controlled by organized crime.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: Lawyers for a makeup artist accused of hiring two men to slash the face of a fashion model asked the judge yesterday to forbid what they termed ''inflammatory'' before-and-after photographs of the model, Marla Hanson.

title: Asylum Sought
description: Andrea Holikova, a Czechoslovak tennis pro who won the women's junior Wimbledon title in 1985, said she would formally file for political asylum in the United States ''in a couple of weeks.'' Holikova is ranked 116th in the world.

title:
PATENTS;
A Device to Prevent Oars Getting Loose
description: An oarlock that keeps oars safely in place on rowboats is the subject of patent 4,623,315, granted this week.

title: FEDERATED REPURCHASES A 4.6% BLOCK
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and other retail chains, said yesterday that it had repurchased nearly 2.2 million of its shares from a single investor that it declined to identify. The block represented about 4.6 percent of the company's outstanding stock.

title: Long Rest for Short
description: The left knee of Purvis Short, a Golden State Warriors forward, will be placed in a brace, and he could be out of action for six weeks.

title: 3 Nations Agree on a Venue For Inquest on Machel Crash
description: Officials from South Africa, Mozambique and the Soviet Union are to meet in Zurich on Tuesday to examine the cockpit voice recordings from the plane in which President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique was killed, Swiss and South African officials said today.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: b-After a charge of about $150,000 for additional income taxes due to the elimination of the investment tax credit as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes a gain of $2,445,000, or 61 cents a share, from the sale of nine stores less the cost for the closing of one store.

title: MOVE SEEN TO HIRE TOP LAWYERS
description: Two of the nation's most famous criminal lawyers have been approached by representatives of Michael Milken, the force behind ''junk bonds,'' to represent him in the Government's continuing investigation into the activities of Ivan F. Boesky, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: BONDS SOLD IN CHINA
description: Thousands of Shanghai citizens lined up to buy $7 million worth of bonds on Thursday, their first day of issue, an official newspaper reported.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: The state Supreme Court refused yesterday to grant Mary Beth Whitehead temporary custody of the daughter she bore eight months ago under a surrogate mother contract with a Tenafly couple.

title: BRIEFS
description: Acton Corp., Acton, Mass., will sell its Utah community antenna television assets to the Insight Communications Co. for $24.5 million. Borg-Warner Corp., Chicago, said a group of investors led by Irwin L. Jacobs had raised its stake in the company to 6,660,000 shares, or 7.7 percent, from 7.4 percent. First Interstate Bancorp, Los Angeles, announced that its subsidiary, the First Interstate Bank of Oklahoma, had acquired the failed Norman Bank of Commerce of Norman, Okla.

title: Reagan Sees Haitian; Aid Package Discussed
description: President Reagan met today with Haiti's interim leader, Gen. Henri Namphy, and discussed a $100 million American aid package.

title: Yacht's Removal Draws Praise
description: Alan Bond's decision to remove from the America's Cup defenders' trials Australia III, which won this year's 12-Meter world championship, was hailed as the right move by the yacht's skipper and rival teams.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Group Denies It Feeds Contra-Aid 'Pipeline'
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: THE CITY BALLET IN 'INTERPLAY ' AND 'AGON'
description: Certain ballets may be works by 20th-century choreographers to 20th-century music. Nevertheless, they remind us that, back in the Renaissance, ballet developed out of social dance forms. Two such ballets are Jerome Robbins's ''Interplay'' and George Balanchine's ''Agon,'' which the New York City Ballet danced for the first time this season on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. Both glorify social occasions.

title: GIVE THE KODIAK BEAR A BREAK
description: Appeals to the primitive still abound in our society. A case in point is a brief article in a recent issue of one of a breed of high-gloss fun and fashion magazines for the urban animal.

title: Mary Davis Morris, 73, Editor of Dictionaries
description: Mary Davis Morris, a lexicographer who with her husband, William, edited dictionaries and wrote a syndicated column on word origins and usage, died of pulmonary arrest Thursday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.

title: AIDS: Opportunity for Wider Public Education
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tips on Wall Street Turn To Phone Taps and Subpoenas
description: ''I CAN feel it when I walk down the street,'' the executive vice president of one of Wall Street's largest brokerage houses said yesterday. ''The neighbors look at me, wondering if maybe I'm one of those crooks who work on Wall Street.''

title: California Club Loses Ruling on Hiring Policy
description: A California appellate court has struck down a ban on hiring women at a summer encampment maintained by the exclusive Bohemian Club, whose members include President Reagan and Vice President Bush.

title: Abrams at Jazz Center
description: The pianist-composer Muhal Richard Abrams will lead a quartet tonight at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, below East Fourth Street (505-5660). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. Tickets are $10.

title: BERNARD JAFFE
description: Bernard Jaffe, a member of the physical sciences departments of New York City high schools for many years and a writer on the history of science, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital, Vineyard Haven, Mass. He was 90 years old and lived in Oak Bluffs, Mass.

title: In Vermont, a Saga of Moose and Men
description: To the Editor:

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FEWER FARM LABORERS
description: The number of hired farmhands this fall is down 4 percent from a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. Surveys made during the week of Oct. 12-18 showed an estimated 975,000 hired workers on American farms, down from 1.015,000.

title: Poverty, Not Rent Regulation, Is the Enemy of Sound Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $79,000 for the quarter and $117,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $20,000 and $35,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Prices of Treasury Bonds Rise
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds climbed yesterday, despite profit taking by day traders late in the session. Dealers said the cashing in of profits came after prices weakened just before the close of the Treasury bond futures market in Chicago.

title: TRAINING FOR CONTRAS: THE MATTER OF EXPECTATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration says the first group of about 70 Nicaraguan rebels has started training under American instructors at an undisclosed site in the United States. But as the program begins, there is concern at the Pentagon that eagerness by Administration hard-liners to show early results from renewed United States aid to the rebels may push them to try too much too soon. The result, many officials fear, could be to risk an early defeat by Nicaraguan Government forces.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (KALAMAOO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIAGNOSTIC VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss
