title: LOWE'S COS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONTINENTAL MEDICAL SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $103,000. There are no 1985 results because the company began operations in March.

title: 32.90 GAIN LIFTS DOW FOR WEEK
description: A week that started out disastrously for Wall Street as it reeled from the impact of the insider trading scandal ended up not so badly after all, as stock prices posted their second consecutive big gain yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Planning Tests for Steroids
description: The National Football League plans to begin testing players for steroid use in 1987, a published report said today.

title: High Jinks On Baltic Avenue
description: Those who know little about financial markets except what they can glean from news of the Ivan Boesky scandal may be surprised to learn that arbitrage has long been a perfectly respectable occupation.

title: MARATHONER'S TEST FINDS DRUG
description: A leading finisher in the New York City Marathon has tested positively for use of a drug. A second sample of that runner's urine specimen, taken shortly after the completion of the race on Nov. 2, will also be tested within a week for possible drug content.

title: Wick Calls for Candor
description: The person in charge of promoting America's message abroad, Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, has made a strong statement in favor of complete candor.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cuomo and the Press: Time of Tension
description: Governor Cuomo's press relations have grown increasingly tense over the last four weeks, according to both journalists and administration officials, as Mr. Cuomo has accused some reporters of intentionally distorting the truth to make him look bad.

title: THRIFT SHOPS ARE UPDATING THEIR IMAGE
description: In the window are antique beaded bags, a Mary McFadden pleated evening dress and assorted silver serving pieces. On a pale peach wall inside the store is a display of evening shoes by Charles Jourdan, Maud Frizon and Walter Steiger alongside leather gloves and alligator bags. An aisle carpeted in gray leads past terrazzo-topped counters holding real and costume jewelry, Saint Laurent scarfs and Calvin Klein sweaters.

title: Armco Withdraws Planned Debt Offer
description: Armco Inc., a financially troubled steelmaker, said that it would withdraw a proposed $300 million offering of convertible debt securities because of the generally unfavorable condition of the high-yield bond market and the depressed price of its common stock.

title: Pennzoil to Lay Off 330 More Workers
description: The Pennzoil Company, a diversified energy concern with headquarters in Houston, said that it would permanently lay off about 330 employees in its oil and gas division by early December. The company, which employs about 1,750 in the unit, said that 130 of the workers would be eligible for an early retirement program.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: City and state officials filed a lawsuit yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, seeking to overturn a United States Agriculture Department requirement that restaurant allowances paid to homeless families living in welfare hotels be counted as income in order to determine their food stamp allocations.

title: FRIEDMAN CASE GOES TO JURY AFTER 8 WEEKS
description: A jury received this evening the Government's case against the Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley M. Friedman, and three co-defendants on charges stemming from a New York City corruption scandal.

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Gerber said it capitalized $108,000 in the latest quarter, and $383,000 in the latest 9 months, as the result of a change in the method of accounting for computer software.

title: INTERFACE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures are adjusted to reflect the acquisition of Nematron Corp. in February 1986 and a 5-for-4 stock split in June 1986.

title: Federal Miracle: Paying for Pork
description: Addicted: that's what Congress has been for two centuries to feeding out of the pork barrel -voting public works paid for by taxpayers everywhere to benefit the districts of influential Congressmen. Typically these have been overpriced, environmentally destructive dams, harbors and inland waterways that bring in lucrative contracts and plentiful jobs.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Missile Offer Affirmed A senior Pentagon official denied that Washington had backed away from a proposal to eliminate all ballistic missiles over the next 10 years.

title: AWAKE IN A NIGHTMARE
description: EL YAQUI By Douglas Unger 300 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: No Headline
description: ''I THINK the bird has just a great future,'' said Fred Jaindl, talking about the turkey. ''It's a super bird. Low in fat. Low in cholesterol. Tender. Juicy. Succulent. I think the turkey has more potential for growth than any other animal. I'll eat anything made of turkey. I'll eat a turkey hot dog and I won't eat a beef hot dog. I like a turkey hamburger, even though it's a little lighter in color. It's just a great bird.''

title: VOLUNTEERS LINK ART AND BUSINESS
description: THREE years ago, Michael J. Buglio, founder and director of the New Jersey Pops, needed help balancing the budget and raising funds. He wanted to expand the board of trustees and knew he would need the help of someone with business expertise.

title: Susan E. Fine Weds Arnon A. Mishkin
description: The marriage of Susan Ellen Fine, the vice president of development for Olympia and York Properties, to Arnon Absalom Mishkin, a general editor at NBC News, both in New York, took place last night. Rabbi Ben Zion Gold performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston.

title: CONCERT: THE PHILIP GLASS ENSEMBLE AND GUESTS
description: THE Philip Glass Ensemble has become a fixture of our concert life. But Friday evening's concerts at Avery Fisher Hall - two of them, both sold out, as usual - were different, or at least the second half was.

title: Flames Surge in 3d To Top Rangers
description: Phil Esposito flew 3,000 miles the other day to make a coaching change. He and the Rangers enjoyed one thrilling night, and then here this evening they had an uncomfortable realization: The problems they had under the old coach have not lifted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Horse Racing Favorite's Day: Java Gold, ridden by Pat Day, scored a 2 3/4-length victory in the $242,800 Remsen Stakes for 2-year-olds yesterday at Aqueduct. It was the first stakes victory for the Virginia-bred son of Key to the Mint and the Nijinsky mare Javamine and it came in his seventh career start. Talinum, the second betting choice, was the runner-up, 3 1/4 lengths ahead of Drachma, who led through the first six furlongs. Java Gold earned $172,680 after traveling the mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:49 3/5. He paid $3.20 for $2 to win as the favorite. Uncle Cam, who was to have been the starting highweight with 122 pounds, was scratched in early afternoon. It had been reported earlier that his owner, George Steinbrenner, was displeased with the conditions of the race, which required his horse to concede from five to nine pounds to his rivals. Java Gold shadowed Drachma to the far turn, where he moved to challenge. Talinum also moved to contention but was no match in the drive. Regal Togs, Butterfield Road, Lights and Music, Wordy and King's Galley completed the order of finish.

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Yentl'' (1983) is here. Barbra Streisand fans can rejoice that their idol's singular showcase will have its primetime television debut Saturday at 8 P.M. on Channel 11.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Times Magazine last Sunday with an article about nonfiction murder books described the results of a criminal trial incompletely.

title: Riding Out a Storm on Wall Street
description: MANY investors, apparently shaken by the implications of Wall Street's spreading insider trading scandal, made a flight to quality last week, shunning takeover stories in favor of solid blue-chip stocks. And while many takeover stocks eventually recovered a bit from ''Boeskyitis,'' money managers were quick to point to a number of issues they consider safe harbors in these still-nervous times.

title: USE OF LAND CREDITS
description: AN Assembly committee is considering legislation that would encourage the adoption of a little-used land-use planning tool for protecting agricultural and environmentally sensitive lands from development.

title: 16-YEAR-OLD IS CONVICTED IN FANTASY-GAME SLAYING OF BOY, 11
description: A 16-year-old boy was convicted Thursday of killing an 11-year-old playmate while acting out a role from the fantasy game Dungeons and Dragons.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Some artists and critics consider marginal art - the art of the socially dispossessed, the naive, the provincial - an alternative to modern art's preoccupation with form and to the commercialism of the art business. RUSSIAN SAMIZDAT ART (Willis Locker & Owens, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95) - ''samizdat'' referring properly to underground Soviet literature and its distribution - presents and discusses both avant-garde efforts in the Soviet Union and Russian art in exile. In either guise, as a response to repression or as an engage emigre art addressing political and moral issues supposedly shunned by greedy, timid Western artists, samizdat art is promoted by Rimma Gerlovina and Valery Gerlovin - emigres who, along with John E. Bowlt and Szymon Bojko, have contributed essays to this book - not for what it is but for whom it claims to confront. The art's actual interest comes entirely from its Russian context. Vagrich Bakhchanyan's poster portrait of Lenin and a young girl, titled ''Lolita,'' cleverly conflates Russian and American ideas of Lenin while commenting wryly on the nature of successful emigre art and its official Soviet counterpart. But most of the work illustrated is only another provincial expression of late modernism, learned in part from American art magazines - colorful illustrations pored over in Moscow kitchens while comically doomed attempts are made to translate murky art prose. Is Soviet samizdat art an expression of dissidence or merely nonconformism? A dissident stance is hard to maintain in New York, where ''official art'' was drained of political content generations ago.

title: FOUNDATION IS A 'LIFELINE' FOR BRONX GARDEN PROJECT
description: The young trees are leafless, the trunks snugly wrapped in burlap. But already Jarard Lordhal is looking ahead to spring, when the half-acre plot in the South Bronx will be crowded with gardeners of all ages - toddlers, teen-agers, the elderly.

title: Impact of New Tax Law
description: THE Tax Reform Act of 1986 will eliminate the deductibility of almost all consumer-credit interest payments. As a result, homeowners are turning their attention to the equity loan, one of the few remaining ways to buy on credit and still deduct the interest costs from taxable income.

title: FAMILY VIOLENCE LAW HAS 'GROWING PAINS' BUT IS CHANGING ATTITUDES
description: CONNECTICUT'S new family violence law makes it as much a crime to hit one's spouse as to beat up a stranger.

title: Northwestern Surprises Illini
description: John Duvic made three field goals, including two in the final 85 seconds, to give Northwestern a 23-18 upset of Illinois today for the Wildcats' best record in 13 years.

title: Big Time Sarah
description: The blues shouter Big Time Sarah will perform tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: THE CASE FOR AN S.E.C. IN BRITAIN
description: NOT one but two two insider-trading scandals have unsettled London's financial community during the past two weeks. The case of Ivan F. Boesky, whose interests included a British investment fund, came just a few days after Geoffrey Collier, a former top stock trader at a leading London merchant bank, was forced to resign for improperly using confidential information for personal trades.

title: MOVING FOR A MONTH TO A SUBURB IN THE SUN
description: For those of us who do not own summer homes but like to vacation as though we did, renting a bungalow, cottage, condominium, villa or chateau, depending on the pocketbook, has always been the answer. And what is true for the Hamptons, the Jersey Shore, Cape Cod or Martha's Vineyard, my family discovered last summer, is also delightfully true for Hawaii.

title: Social Events; In the Holiday Spirit
description: Fiesta at Sotheby's Nov. 24 - The Salvadoran American Federation and the International Rescue Committee are holding a fiesta and a showing of Latin American art to raise money for emergency earthquake relief in El Salvador. The benefit, from 7 to 11 P.M., will be at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. Tickets, $100, from 212-489-8420. Busy Benefit Nov. 24 - From 6 P.M. to 2 A.M., there will be jazz, comedy, magic, jugglers, mimes, clowns, dancing, singing, a buffet and cash bar at the Palladium, 126 East 14th Street. The evening will benefit the Negro Ensemble Company, which produces new works by black playwrights. The troupe is celebrating its 20th anniversary. Tickets, $35 from 212-575-5860 or $40 at the door. 'Smile' and a Party Nov. 25 - The Helen Keller Manhattan League for the Blind maintains numerous programs for children, including a summer camp and a Braille library. An 8 P.M. preview performance of the new musical ''Smile,'' followed by a black-tie supper dance at Le Club, 313 East 58th Street, will benefit the league. Tickets for the entire evening at $80, $100 or $125 - or $90 for the party alone - from Margery Rice, 212-758-2122. Virgil Thomson's 90th Nov. 25 - Virgil Thomson's 90th birthday will be celebrated at the Plaza Hotel, starting with cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by dinner, musical and spoken tributes to the composer, and dancing. The black-tie evening will benefit the 10-year-old American Composers Orchestra, which has performed over 60 premieres of new American musical works, two of which have won Pulitzer Prizes.

title: Did James Buchanan Deserve His Nobel?
description: To the Editor I would hope that ''Why Government Got Out of Hand,'' (Forum, Oct. 26), itself full of ''empirical record,'' stereotyped phraseology, and personal expressions, is not indicative of Dr. Buchanan's scientific work.

title: Penn St. Goes 11-0 In Romp
description: After an easy 34-14 victory over Pittsburgh today to complete its second straight undefeated and untied regular season, Penn State announced it would play Miami in the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl the night of Jan. 2 if Miami wins its last regular-season game, against East Carolina Thursday night.

title: Siemens' Past
description: To the Editor:

title: N.C. State Triumphs
description: David Robinson of Navy had a 26-point second half today, but college basketball's new 3-point goal helped North Carolina State beat the Middies, 86-84.

title: Changing Attitudes
description: The later results showed a significantly higher endorsement of equality between spouses, according to Prof. Karen Oppenheim Mason of the University of Michigan, who analyzed the data for the university's Population Studies Center. Moreover, Professor Mason said last week, between 1977 and 1985 support for greater equality grew in every subgroup questioned. ''It's not just some pocket of weirdos,'' she said. ''It's very uniform in the population - old people and young, married people and unmarried people, every group.''

title: New Dorp, Lincoln Lose in Upsets
description: The Public School Athletic League's only undefeated team in the regular season, Lincoln, and the defending champions, New Dorp, lost semifinal games yesterday to Jackson and Wagner, who will meet next Saturday in the Division A championship at Midwood at 1 P.M. Wagner defeated Jackson, 24-20, in the first week of the season.

title: The Live-in Sitters in Our Life
description: MY latest live-in baby sitter just arrived with her pet rabbit and its cage that occupies one-fifth of her bedroom. She also informed us that she calls an astrologist every day so we shouldn't be surprised at the recurring phone number on the phone bill.

title: TAX REFORM: LET'S BROADEN EXEMPTIONS
description: I heartily agree with the Nov. 9 Opinion Page article ''New York Needs Tax Reform, Too.'' Of the many valid approaches to that goal Arthur J. Kremer mentions, my particular favorite is reduction of the sales tax.

title: THE GAME
description: THE game would not determine a championship. It wasn't rife with tradition like the one being played Thanksgiving Day against Iona Prep. The bleachers held fewer than 350 people. But when the sun shown through steely clouds, and the band beat out a march and a handsome quarterback for New Rochelle High School made a run for the end zone, it was great football, pure and simple.

title: Tracking a Rock Group By Computer
description: ''I USED to use a Roladex and lunch hours for networking,'' said Lisa Carlson, a computer consultant at the Metasystems Design Group, a consulting firm in Arlington, Va. Now, she simply punches a few numbers onto a keyboard to reach professional colleagues. ''With electronic networking, you're not limited to five lunches a week,'' she said. ''You can maintain relations with hundreds of people all over the world.''

title: CALLING 'TIME OUT' ON GROWTH
description: SINCE World War II, real-estate development has meant growth, and growth has meant progress, and progress has been equated with good things on Long Island. But now, traffic jams and problems with air, water and garbage are causing some changes of heart.

title:
ART;
LUMINOUS IMAGES BECKON IN 5 CENTURIES OF DRAWINGS
description: DURING the early Renaissance the ability to draw images implied divine power. Respect for fine drawings has remained an unbroken tradition, and rightly so, for there is no experience quite like that of following a line skimming and gripping the surface as it reveals an artist's first inspiration. We feel close to the creative process at this point.

title: CHARLESTON OPENS A RETAIL COMPLEX
description: Michael Smith had second thoughts two and a half years ago as he looked at the downtown decay bordering the weed-strewn lot chosen as the site for the Omni Hotel at Charleston Place.

title: MIXED SIGNALS EMERGE FROM BRAZIL ELECTION
description: After elections last weekend gave the governing party control of both houses of Congress and all but one of Brazil's 23 states, opposition critics began warning that the country's new democracy was in danger of becoming a political monopoly.

title: How Not To Succeed At Musical Banter
description: Someday, when they have finished tape-recording and cataloguing all the languages, dialects and subdialects in the world, anthropologists might profitably turn their attention to banter. No, not Bantu. I am talking about banter, the glib conversational filler that certain persons can toss off brilliantly but that others never get the knack of. Banter comes in three basic types: spontaneous, planned or rehearsed and ex post facto. In that order of cleverness.

title: FEWER VOLUNTEERS, MORE INNOVATION
description: THE ladies who used to lunch are more apt to be brown- bagging it at the office these days. With so many women now in the work force, questions arise over who is filling the traditional roles these women used to play.

title: Reagan Needs a Hand
description: The main question here now is not how President Reagan got into this latest mess in Iran, but how he's going to come out of it as an effective leader of the nation and the alliance.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Prudential Insurance Company's latest proposal for developing Lee Meadows into an office park has not won the endorsement of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, but the company is getting closer.

title: IN LONDON, MUSICALS OF ALL VINTAGES
description: There are too many musicals in London. That at least is the opinion of the critics.

title: WAR ON THE PEOPLE
description: NUNCA MAS The Report of the Argentine National Commission on the Disappeared. Introduction by Ronald Dworkin. Illustrated. 463 pp. New York: Index on Censorship/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50. TORTURE IN BRAZIL A Report by the Archdiocese of Sao Paulo. Translated by Jaime Wright. Edited by Joan Dassin. 238 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $10.95. ''N UNCA MAS'' -never again. This is the cry of the Argentine people as they return to political democracy and attempt to come to terms with the fact that in their country, with its long tradition of Western culture, over 9,000 people ''disappeared'' during the rule by military juntas between 1976 and 1983. The Brazilians echo the cry in ''Brasil: Nunca Mais,'' the original title in Portuguese of ''Torture in Brazil,'' as they also return to political democracy and assess the systematic torture and abuse of human rights under military rule from 1964 to 1985.

title:
DINING OUT;
CREATIVITY IN A POLISHED SETTING
description: AUBERGE Maxime is one of a small handful of county restaurants that have made and continue to make food preparation a fine art. In the kitchen of this charming restaurant in the highlands of North Salem, the chef and owner Bernard le Bris has for the past eight years coaxed and carved, combined and arranged splendidly fresh and interesting ingredients into beautifully and creatively wrought dishes.

title: Headliners; Back in the Political Fray
description: There was a time when a nod from Richard M. Nixon might have won just about any Republican appointment for just about anybody. But that time ended more than a decade ago, so Republicans in Bergen County, N.J., were surprised when the former President mounted a small campaign in support of Robert Re, the chief of police in Ho-Ho-Kus and a sometime security consultant to Mr. Nixon, who lives in Saddle River.

title: Tarheels, Gumshoes And Bluestockings
description: In his article ''In a New York Minute'' (On Language, Oct. 19), William Safire instructs us that the noun ''roundheel'' could never, despite what dictionaries say, refer to an individual, ''. . . if only for the simple reason that people have two heels, and an easy mark would be called a roundheels.''

title: SEARCH OF MOORS STIRS SPECTER OF OLD MURDERS
description: The police and packs of eager, yelping dogs specially trained in cadaver hunting are roaming the moors of Saddleworth once again as the country watches irrestibly, as much for reasons of nostalgia as for criminal suspicion.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONE BIG BED. By John Krich. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) Early middle-aged radical Berkeley film critic finds happiness with young, wise, barely English-speaking Chinese artist in this Zeitgeist-busting novel that invokes enough film references to warrant description as ''The Big Chill'' meets ''Morgan!'' Despite some very funny lines (''Sex with Darlinda was a bit like haggling over a rug with an Afghan trader''), the effect of this inordinately busy novel, peppered throughout with non sequiturs posing as aphorisms and a constantly ticking narrative clock, is more wearying than kaleidoscopic.

title: CELLO: MISCHA MAISKY
description: MISCHA MAISKY, a cellist who emigrated from Russia to Israel in 1972, plays music in the grand manner, as befits a student of both Mstislav Rostropovich and Gregor Piatigorsky. Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art he gave the first of two programs devoted to the six Bach Cello Suites - the final concert, tomorrow night, will consist of the Suites Nos. 3, 2 and 6, in that order.

title: Stages Adjust Season, Canceling and Adding
description: ALTHOUGH two elaborate productions in the state's theater season have been canceled, some star-studded substitutions and new plays are adding something different to local stages.

title: Verbatim; Patronage Abroad
description: 'A disturbing trend is the use of Foreign Service positions for political patronage. . . . Years ago, generals were commissioned on this basis. No one today would argue for appointing a political supporter to command the 24th Infantry Division, although in peaceful times, and with a good deputy, the division would probably survive as well as our embassies. . . . Seeing the quality of some of those judged worthy or capable of serving as ambassador, it is painful to recognize the lack of respect this implies for our profession.' Ronald I. Spiers

title: Glowing Dancers, Essential Aykroyd
description: Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' Starring Horst Gebhardt, Deiter Schloz, Inge Uibel, Magdalena Falewicz, Hermann Christian Polster. The Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig conducted by Gert Bahner. V.I.E.W. Video. 156 Minutes.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: EARLY AMERICAN COOKING Three historic kitchens in upstate New York, Sunnyside in Tarrytown, Philipsburg Manor in North Tarrytown and Van Cortland Manor in Croton-on-Hudson are bustling with demonstrations of early American cookery this month.

title: Q AND A
description: Conversion Negotiators Question: Our building is in the process of a noneviction conversion to cooperative ownership, and the tenants have elected a committee to negotiate with the sponsor. If they reach an agreement on prices and other matters, must it be put to a vote of all the tenants? Also, what is the period within which a noneviction conversion must be completed? . . . T. L., Manhattan Answer: There is no requirement in state co-op and condominium conversion laws that tenants be allowed to vote on agreements made on their behalf by elected negotiating committees, according to David Fishlow, a spokesman for the New York State Attorney General's Office. However, written agreements among tenants or a contractual agreement that specifies that negotiated agreements will be submitted to a vote are legally binding and can be enforced in court.

LAST year, $260 million in tolls was collected on the Garden State Parkway and New Jersey Turnpike, but $1.2 million was lost on the 173-mile parkway - where more than half the booths are automatic - through cheating.

title: Next Week; Should games be played on artificial turf?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: 'Enclave for Rich' Envisioned in the Sound
description: STRENGTHENED by money from Japan and a new design team from Manhattan, the developer Bruce C. Stark says he hopes to start work late next year on a long-expected luxury island community on Davids Island off New Rochelle, N.Y., in Long Island Sound.

title: Son May Evict Father, 81, Over Rent, Judge Says
description: A judge has ruled that a man may evict his 81-year-old father from his house for failing to pay rent.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: How to Make an Interesting Mess Whatever else its virtues may be, abstract art does provoke picturesque speculation. In ''Working Space'' (Harvard University), Frank Stella fluently pontificates on contemporary painting. Much of abstract painting today has lost touch with the fullness and mobility of the pictorial space of the past in a mistaken effort to locate art in the novel exclusivity of technique, thus fulfilling the most (and probably lowest) common definition of abstract painting, which suggests that knowledge of abstract painting is knowledge of how to make an interesting mess. . . . By 1970 abstract painting had lost its ability to create space. In a series of withdrawals, it began to illustrate the space it had once been able to create. The space in abstract painting, in a certain sense, became more advanced - more abstract, if that is possible. It was no longer available to feeling, either emotional or literal. This fulfilled one of modernism's great dreams: the space in painting became available to eyesight alone, but unfortunately not to eyesight in a pictorial sense, but to eyesight in a literary sense. In a word, it became available to the eyesight of critics rather than that of artists. . . .

title: SCRIBBLING IN SUSSEX
description: THE SIXTH CONTINENT A Literary History of Romney Marsh. By Iain Finlayson. 240 pp. New York: Atheneum. $15.95.

title: TOPICS
description: AT breakfast not long ago I looked out the window in time to see a small flock of purple grackles alight upon my lawn. Then another flock, and another.

title: Glowing Dancers, Essential Aykroyd
description: The Best of Dan Aykroyd Directed by Dave Wilson. Warner Home Video. 57 minutes. $24.98.

title: Mets Help Skydiver
description: THE skydiver who floated onto the Shea Stadium infield at the start of the sixth game of the World Series and landed in hot water says some Met players have gone to bat for him as he battles criminal charges.

title:
GARDENING;
WINER PROTECTION AGAINST RODENTS
description: SQUIRRELS, rabbits and mice often wreak havoc on garden plants as they forage for food during the winter months. There are certain preventive measures that can be taken, however, although sometimes with uncertain results.

title: Douglas, Wyo., Residents Want Gallows to Stay
description: Residents of this central Wyoming town have decided that an Old West gallows, the symbol of frontier justice, should remain on display as a tourist attraction.

title: Reformers From The Corporate World
description: Crystal Nix's article describes Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Cornell graduates who gave up high-paying and high-powered positions to serve the poor, and this is a positive sign.

title: After Eruption, Quakes Jar Japanese Island
description: Dozens of earthquakes shook the nearly abandoned island of O-shima into early today, but the lava flow from a spectacular volcanic eruption slowed after threatening the main town and forcing 11,000 people to flee.

title: VIETNAM WAR REPORTERS REMINISCE AT REUNION
description: It was a reunion, so there were the usual embraces, jokes and snapshots. But because it reunited the reporters and photographers who covered the Vietnam War, the celebration was tempered by sobering thoughts of the war and commemorations of those who died in the crossfire.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OPERATION GARBO: The Personal Story of the Most Successful Double Agent of World War II. By Juan Pujol with Nigel West.

title: 'HOW IS IT FAR IF YOU THINK IT?'
description: SELECTED POEMS #1958-1984. By John Wieners. Edited by Raymond Foye. Foreword by Allen Ginsberg. Illustrated. 317 pp. Santa Barbara, Calif.: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $12.50.

title: No-Risk Arbs Meet Risk Justice
description: Wander into a Federal courtroom in Manhattan one day next year and, if you can get a seat, you might see an earnest lawyer, standing beside a well-dressed defendant, imploring the judge not to send his client to prison. The defendant will be Ivan Boesky, and his lawyer might say something like this:

title: Insuring Against A Costly Illness
description: A wide range of programs to protect millions of Americans against the costs of catastrophic illness were proposed last week by the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;
Film Dramatizes Book About a Counterterrorist Team
description: When George Jonas's ''Vengeance'' was published in 1984, its truthfulness immediately came under fire. The book purported to tell the inside story of a team of agents of Mossad, the Israeli secret service, who had been commissioned to murder Arab terrorists in revenge for the slaughter of 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich. Critics questioned the reliability of the book's facts, as well as its method of using fictional techniques to reconstruct dialogue and add drama to incidents.

title: Robin Reeves to Wed Gregory
description: Prof. and Mrs. Thomas C. Reeves of Glenside, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Louise Reeves to Gregory Jannig Zorthian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Zorthian of Washington and New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: The Mating Game
description: WHAT IS IT WITH some people in the wine business? They go out of their way to make their lives more difficult. Not to mention ours.

title: Trading Clients and Fighting Loneliness
description: BUSINESS networks originally evolved to bring people from the same field together to tackle common problems or exchange information. But now a whole new breed of business networks is cropping up in which people from unrelated fields exchange tips on where and how to find new business.

title: Leslie Harwood To Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lowell Harwood of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Harwood, to Stephen A. Ehrlich, the son of Shirley A. Goodman of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Milton M. Ehrlich of White Plains. An April wedding is planned.

title: DEFENSE SEES A GAIN IN TRIAL OVER FILM DEATHS
description: The defense in the trial over three deaths in the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' says testimony by a special effects technician undercuts the prosecution's contention that flying debris was the primary factor in a fatal helicopter crash on the set.

title: GIANTS AND GIANT-KILLERS
description: THE DEAL OF THE CENTURY The Breakup of AT&T. By Steve Coll. 400 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95. BIG BLUE IBM's Use and Abuse of Power. By Richard Thomas DeLamarter. 393 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $22.95.

title: OPEN HOUSE AT ANTIQUES SHOPS
description: Antwerp and Amsterdam, two of Europe's most intriguing cities for antiques shopping, will be even more alluring in weeks ahead, as many dealers open their doors for extended hours during special events.

title: MAN SHOOTS HIMSELF AFTER SIEGE
description: In a tense, three-hour scene, more than 50 police officers surrounded a downtown Brooklyn building yesterday when a man barricaded himself in a 15th-story apartment after shooting a woman.

title: Burying Infants In Potter's Field
description: MANY infants who die in New York City are buried in unmarked graves in Potter's Field, the Coalition for the Homeless reported.

title: E.P.A. Sets Final Pollution Rules
description: In an effort to improve the quality of the air and the lot of polluters, the Environmental Protection Agency last week announced its final guidelines for the trading of pollution allowances.

title: SWISS LOOK TO TIGHTER REGULATION AFTER SPILL
description: The accidental dumping of about 30 tons of agricultural chemicals and dyes into the Rhine during a fire near here on Nov. 1 is expected to lead to tightened regulation of Switzerland's important chemical industry, according to officials in industry and the Government.

title: FOCUS: Investment; Japanese Plunge Into U.S. Realty
description: ONE of Japan's biggest exports these days is investment capital. In record numbers, Japanese banks and financial concerns are investing in the commercial real-estate market throughout the United States, focusing most recently on the West Coast.

title: Devils Defeated, 6-2
description: The Devils had their five-game unbeaten streak snapped as the Minnesota North Stars scored a 6-2 victory tonight. Ron Wilson and Dino Ciccarelli scored second-period goals 14 seconds apart for Minnesota.

title: Penn Wins Ivy League Title With Perfect 10
description: Penn captured the Ivy League title for the fifth consecutive year with a 31-21 victory over Cornell today and completed a perfect season for the first time since 1904.

title:
EDUCATION WATCH;
THE ONE-ROOM SCHOOL IS SAVED IN NEBRASKA
description: THE white paint has long since started to peel, the flagpole is bent and the outhouses are now storage sheds. But the one-room school here still has three students, and hundreds like it in Nebraska have won a reprieve - for a time - from the forces of consolidation.

title: Money Manuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Jackets: A Measure of Men
description: I HAVE always felt that a tweed sports jacket and slacks are the only proper dress for a proper man. I have almost always been able to dress in this fashion, but once doing so got me into an embarrassing situation, and once the wearing of a tweed jacket partially caused me to make a change that greatly improved my life.

title: North Rockland Wins in Overtime
description: North Rockland defeated Scarsdale in sudden-death overtime after tying the game with less than 2 minutes remaining to capture Friday night's A-division bowl game, 30-27.

title: Signs of Adulthood in a Teen-Age Son
description: IT has been a long time since I've given much thought to the passage from child to adult, having traveled that route myself almost 30 years ago. But now, with a 16-year-old son, I have the opportunity to experience the process again, albeit vicariously, and the fuzziness of the lines of demarcation seems to be the only easily defined aspect of the process.

title: John W. Kern 4th Engaged to Wed Kate C. Murdoch
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Murdoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kate Cullens Murdoch to John Worth Kern 4th, a son of Nancy Park Kern of Bethesda, Md., and Judge Kern 3d of Reno.

title: William A. Falk Wed To Anne M. Whitten
description: The Chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Mathews Whitten and William A. Falk. The Rev. Francis X. Duffy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: DATA BANK: NOVEMBER 23,1986
description: THE ECONOMY Gross National Product III Q'86 II Q'86 Year Ago Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions $3,687.3 $3,661.4 $3,603.8 Real G.N.P. Growth Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent 2.9 0.6 4.1 Corporate After-Tax ProfitsIII Q'86II Q'86Year Ago In billions, annual rate $144.0 $138.0 $133.4 Industrial Production IndexOct.Sept.Year Percent change, monthly and year to year 0.0 0.1 1.3 Housing StartsOct.Sept.Year Ago Thousands of units, annual rate 1,648 1,652 1,784 New Orders for Durable Goods Sept. title: FOR WILDLIFE, THE TIMES ARE VERY GOOD
description: FOR outdoors enthusiasts, fall is a season of beauty; for hunters, a season of bounty.

title: Break for Coleman
description: A National Collegiate Athletic Association committee agreed yesterday to reduce the ineligibility of Norris Coleman, the Kansas State University basketball star, from 27 games to 14, meaning he would miss the first 12 games of this season. However, the ruling is conditional on Kansas State forfeiting the 16 games it won last season in which Coleman, a forward, played, and on Coleman's repaying the financial aid he received while ineligible.

title: Counting Money
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMO SAYS A BIAGGI AIDE INTERVENED ON PACT
description: A top aide to Representative Mario Biaggi called the Federal Small Business Administration in 1981 on behalf of Wedtech, a Bronx military contractor that had hired a law firm associated with the Congressman, according to a Government memorandum.

title: AVIATION AGENCY MEDICAL CHIEF IS ASKED TO RESIGN
description: The Federal Aviation Administration's top medical officer is being accused by pilot groups and airlines of approving scores of pilots for service despite doubts about their fitness.

title: CHRISTMAS SEASON: AN EXPANDABLE FEAST
description: IT'S the Sunday before Thanksgiving, and in New Haven, a 45-foot Christmas tree has been set up on the Green since Election Day.

title: Glowing Dancers, Essential Aykroyd
description: Pete Townshend's Deep End Atlantic Video. Stereo. 87 minutes. $29.98.

title: A Question of What's Held Hostage in Linkage
description: To the Editor:

title: SOMEBODY HAS TO WEAR THE GORILLA SUIT!
description: IT all began at a vestry meeting at Christ Episcopal Church in Tarrytown, when a vote was taken to approve the expenditure of $100 for a gorilla suit to help promote the Annual Fall Fair.

title: Tax Records Stolen
description: Using photographic technology that reduces mountains of bureaucratic paper to miniatures known as microfiches, Canada filed the vital records of 16 million taxpayers on a small pile of cards. Compact as they were, an unauthorized person easily scooped them up - no one seems to know why - and made off with them late last month.

title: Betsy Trefts to Marry Dr. D.S. Johnson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Sharpe Trefts of Shaker Heights, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter C. Elizabeth Trefts to Dr. David Scott Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip A. Johnson of Exeter, N.H. The wedding is planned for April 25.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Michigan Gathers Roses
description: Back East, Joe Morris might have thought he was watching Giant game films. There was Morris, shooting through the holes, straining for the extra yards, making touchdowns, carrying the team on his abbreviated back. Only this Morris was wearing Michigan colors. His name was Jamie, and he is going to the Rose Bowl.

title: Finding Mid-Priced Values
description: Having rummaged through the bargain basement last week, we change venue for our pre-Christmas shopping list, moving up to the mid-priced ranks. With almost every manufacturer jostling for space in this popular price range, we have cut through the crowd by the dogged application of two selective principles. 1. We looked for models that in at least one vital aspect rose above the norms of their class. 2. We didn't let clever features and other technical window-dressing outweigh essential musical considerations.

title: Voters And High-Tech Politics
description: After reading Steven V. Roberts's article ''Politicking Goes High-Tech'' (Nov. 2), I was left even more depressed by the spectacle that our electoral process has become. Those of us who take the writings of ''The Federalist,'' de Tocqueville, the Founding Fathers, etc. seriously must feel this is a monstrous betrayal of what American democracy is all about.

title: The Nightmare's Over at Last
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PIECES OF GINGHAM, PIECES OF LIFE
description: I HAD just returned from a country-craft fair when I saw the package at my doorstep.

title: How the 'Me' Generation Struts Its Stuff
description: WHEN a handful of Hurricane football players stood at midfield and taunted Brian Bosworth before the Miami-Oklahoma game a few months back, sportsmanship seemed to hit another low. In the Year of Cocaine and amid concern about jocks who visit the classroom maybe every other Tuesday - not to mention the Miami players' unique acquaintance with the Dade County Sheriff's Department - the last thing college football needed was a No. 1 football team with no class.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Christmas Plates, Seagull Dinnerware The Royal Copenhagen Porcelain Corporation's yearly sale at the North White Plains headquarters has been held for seven years, always the weekend not immediately after Thanksgiving, but the following Saturday and Sunday; this year, that is Dec. 6 and 7, from 11 A.M. to 5 P. M. First-quality and discontinued lines are included, plus Bing & Grondahl porcelain wares - collector's items, Christmas plates and seagull dinnerware. Markdowns are 30 percent and more.

title: Article 949386 -- No Title
description: A NEW program financed by the state's largest utility will help hundreds of families in five cities make their homes more energy efficient.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: STEAMBOAT IN A CORNFIELD By John Hartford. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers. $10.95. (Ages 8 and up)

title: Toothbrush Maker Layoffs
description: The Pro Corporation, which has been making toothbrushes for a century, is getting out of the business and will concentrate on making plastics, the company has announced. The concern, formerly known as the Pro-phy-lac-tic Brush Company, will lay off 80 employees at its western Massachusetts plant by March, a spokesman said. The company will turn its attention to plastic moldings, the concern's main money maker for the past decade, the spokesman said Monday.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FOOD, AMERICAN-STYLE According to Mrs. T. J. Crowen, author of the ''American Lady's System of Cookery,'' New York, 1857, Thanksgiving dinner consisted of the following: ''A roasted turkey of uncommon size should occupy the middle of the table; on one end let there be a cold boiled ham, and at the other, fricaseed chicken or a roast pig. With the turkey, serve mashed potatoes and turnips, boiled onions and dressed celery or other salad, and applesauce. Near the ham placed fried or mashed potatoes and pickles or mangoes; and with the pig or fricasee, the same as with the turkey.''

title: Colorization- A Spectrum of Opinion
description: To the Editor: Vincent Canby's attack on colorizing films was the best piece on that subject yet [ ''Colorization Is Defacing Black and White Film Classics,'' Nov. 2 ] . The long-range effect of colorized films on preservation efforts and on education is yet to be felt.

title: STATE TV NETWORK CHIEF NOMINATED
description: ROBERT G. OTTENHOFF of Upper Montclair has been nominated by the New Jersey Public Broadcasting Authority to be executive director-general manager of New Jersey Network, the state's public-broadcasting television system.

title: Ina Brenner Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Ina Helene Brenner to Richard Douglas Wallman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Wallman of North Bellmore, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morris I. Brenner of Woodmere, L.I. Miss Brenner and her fiance graduated from George Washington University. She is a communications assistant for Spaulding & Slye, a real-estate developer in McLean, Va. He is a banking consultant with Price Waterhouse & Company in Bethesda, Md.

title: East German's Escape Fails
description: An East German man tried to escape to the West by hiding in a West German truck traveling through East Germany, but he was discovered and arrested by guards at a border crossing, the West Berlin police said today. According to the police, the truck driver said that he did not know the man was aboard and that the East German must have climbed into the truck at a rest stop. The driver was released after eight hours of questioning.

title: LADIES MILE PLAN KINDLES A DEBATE
description: THE proposal for a Ladies Mile Historic District in Manhattan has for the first time obliged New York City officials to consider the effect of an areawide landmark designation in a business section that is undergoing sweeping economic change and rapid job growth.

title: U.S. TO TAKE 'FRESH LOOK' AT SHOREHAM EMPLOYEE TRAINING
description: THE Nuclear Regulatory Commission has announced plans for another in a series of special investigations of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: The Eternal Fruitcake
description: TO EXPLAIN WHY I had anticipated this year's Thanksgiving with unaccustomed pleasure, I must first explain that I own a house in Nantucket. No, I am not disgustingly rich and chic. Quite the opposite. The house cost a paltry few hundred dollars back in the Bronze Age when the only rich people seen in Nantucket were cheapskate millionaires from Cincinnati who abhorred both chic and overpriced real estate.

title: Christine Scorese Weds J.V. Schnell
description: St. Gabriel the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Christine Marie Scorese and John Vincent Schnell. Msgr. Edward F. Kavin performed the ceremony.

title: We Weren't Looking For a Quick Fix
description: CRITICS of the Agency for International Development and the American foreign economic assistance program are adept at shrill rhetoric. The reality of the United States aid effort, however, is far different from what we hear.

title: PSYCHOCHEMISTRY
description: THE FABRIC OF MIND By Richard Bergland. Illustrated by Kati Bromley. 202 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: In 103rd Meeting, Harvard Overcomes Yale
description: The sun, seldom seen here lately, shone on the 103d Harvard-Yale game today and especially on the Crimson in a dramatic second half. The team that had won only two games this season and had lost its last four, turned on the Bulldogs and won, 24-17.

title: BLACK BOWLER WINS
description: George Branham 3d became the first black champion in the history of the Professional Bowlers Association when he downed top-seeded Mark Roth, 195-191, in the title game today of the $200,000 Brunswick Memorial World Open.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOOSIERS: The Fabulous Basketball Life of Indiana. By Phillip M. Hoose. (Vintage Books, Paper, $7.95.) In Indiana residents vie for positions on the local school board so they can dismiss a losing basketball coach.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CEREMONY: An Anthropologist's Misadventures in the African Bush. By Nigel Barley. (Holt, $15.95.) These days the popular American conception of tropical Africa seems to derive from either the romanticized landscapes in the film version of ''Out of Africa'' or television footage of the desperate confinements of the Ethiopian famine camps.

title: Article 103886 -- No Title
description: The Indian Government said today that it would seek a minimum of $3 billion from the Union Carbide Corporation as compensation for the gas-leak accident at Bhopal in 1984 that killed more than 2,300 people.

title: Jazz
description: Swing, be-bop, salsa and all kinds of modern jazz will be part of a marathon benefit jazz concert on Sunday - an eight-hour show called ''Jazz Finds a Home'' at Columbia University's Wollman Auditorium, Broadway at 115th Street. From 2 to 10 P.M., dozens of musicians will donate their performances to raise money for three organizations dealing with the problem of homelessness - Habitat for Humanity, Women in Need and Boys Harbor, Inc. The concert is sponsored by WKCR (89.9 FM), the Columbia University radio station, and by Columbia Community Volunteer Services.

title: Henry James's 'Hugh Merrow'
description: To extrapolate from the gently suggested sexual ''glimmer'' between Merrow and Mrs. Archdean the idea that James was ''pressing himself to decide his own sex'' and, further, that his inability to ''fling himself past the threshold of the erotic into the very birth canal itself'' prevented him from concluding the story is unwarranted. To insist on such a reading is to ignore the faceted suggestive power that Ms. Ozick has recognized in Henry James's work elsewhere. If ''Hugh Merrow'' had caused Mr. James such ''insupportable psychological pressure,'' then surely he might have burnt this fragment along with all other revealing documents. JAYNE TYRRELL Wayne, N.J.

title: BROOKFIELD
description: FROM the early 1700's until about 20 years ago, Brookfield was a hard-working farm community scattered across 20 square miles of rolling hills. Even the Revolutionary War was remote from its quiet precincts, where the pressing issue was how much land the Connecticut community could prevent neighboring towns from claiming.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
PUMPKINSEED
description: Lepomis gibbosus Size: Averages 5 to 8 inches; 10 inches exceptional.

title: Steelworker Is First to Have Artificial Heart in Wisconsin
description: A steelworker was doing ''as well as we could hope'' after receiving an artificial heart to keep him alive until a human heart is available for transplant, according to one of his doctors.

title: ASSESSING O'ROURKE'S BUDGET
description: WHEN is a proposed 4.2 percent tax increase not a 4.2 percent tax increase?

title:
DINING OUT;
FOLLOWING THE TRAIL OF THE YUPPIE
description: AS A RULE, where yuppies go, trendy restaurants are sure to follow. But in gentrifying Jersey City, with its influx of young professionals, it is surprising that so few dining places of any interest have opened.

title: Robin Ellen Hanna to Wed Seth Mahlon Chilton in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Hanna of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Ellen Hanna to Seth Mahlon Chilton, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Neal W. Chilton of Lawrenceville, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: 4 BUSINESSMEN SAY SAUDIS ABUSE AMERICANS
description: Four American businessmen, three of whom say they were held prisoner while working in Saudi Arabia, have called for a Congressional investigation into imprisonment and abuse of Americans living there.

title: Grace E. Sharples, a Fashion Editor, Weds M.T. Cooke Jr., an Asian
description: Grace Eisenbrey Sharples, a fashion editor at Glamour magazine, and Merritt Todd Cooke Jr., a visiting scholar at Columbia University's Southern Asian Institute, were married yesterday at the Quaker Meeting House in Haverford, Pa. The ceremony was performed under the care of the Haverford Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends.

title: Researchers Cover Up A Link to Minute Man
description: A cellar thought to be part of the home of a Revolutionary War captain was covered after archeologists removed artifacts that they hope will aid in their identification efforts.

title: Alison G. Robbins Will Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Robbins of New York, Bedford, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Gwen Robbins, to Dr. Howard Gould, a son of Susan Gould of Brookline, Mass., and Dr. Lawrence Gould of Boca Raton, Fla., and Casco, Me. An April 11 wedding is planned.

title: Topics; Radio Overactive; Her Master's Voice
description: Should President Reagan be questioned by a Federal employee at a White House news conference? It happened last Wednesday, when he was asked about breaking diplomatic relations with Nicaragua by Annette Lopez-Munoz. She works for Radio Marti, which is operated by the Voice of America, whose rules prohibit correspondents from asking questions at televised Presidential news conferences.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Gaithersburg, Md.; Narrow Escape From an Error
description: THE developers of the Washingtonian Center, one of the most ambitious suburban mixed-use office and residential projects in the country, have just had a close brush with a bureaucratic bungle here on the expanding fringe on the nation's capital.

title: GAVE BIRTH TO 5 IDENTICAL GIRLS
description: Elzire Dionne, who gave birth to quintuplets 52 years ago and was thrust into the glare of worldwide publicity, died yesterday at North Bay Civic Hospital in North Bay, Ontario.

title: Another Mark for Palmer
description: Paul Palmer, the tailback in his final college game, compiled 171 yards today to set the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-A single-season record for all-purpose yardage in leading Temple to a 29-22 victory over Rutgers.

title: 14 PENALTIES ISSUED BY E.P.A. IN A NORTHEAST DUMPING CASE
description: Fourteen companies and municipal departments in three states have been penalized about $3,000 each for failing to tell the Federal Environmental Protection Agency whether they had sent hazardous waste to a disposal company linked to illegal dumping in Massachusetts and New Hampshire, the agency says.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Jets And Giants Reach the Super Bowl?
description: The consensus is that although both teams have a strong chance of making the Super Bowl, the Jets enjoy the better odds.

title: Melissa Zwanger To Wed on Jan. 3
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Zwanger of Massapequa Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Zwanger to Evan Philip Oster, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Oster of Long Beach, L.I. A Jan. 3 wedding is planned.

title: Andrea J. Gimesh to Wed
description: Andrea J. Gimesh, the director of community services at the Dairy Council of Metropolitan New York, and Mark Seiden, an associate at the New York law firm of Reidy & Gogick, plan to be married Jan. 31. The future bride is a daughter of Dr. John Gimesh of Fayetteville, N.C., who has announced her engagement, and of Faye McArthur of Cary, N.C. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Seiden of Smithtown, L.I.

title: Early Risers With Passion for Photos
description: AS one who went into the newspaper business because it let me sleep late in the morning, I was astonished to find myself in a McDonald's on Wantagh Avenue at 8 A.M. on a recent Sunday.

title: PROJECTS TO PROTECT WETLANDS AND STREAMS
description: TWO projects now under way are expected to further protect some of the county's environmentally sensitive areas from the pressure of development - the completion of a wetlands map and the reclassification of streams.

title: Getting Even With Ivan
description: If you sold stock to Ivan F. Boesky when he knew something that you did not, you could collect restitution from a $50 million damage fund that the Securities and Exchange Commission is creating from Mr. Boesky's ill-gotten gains. But just how that will work is anyone's guess, analysts say.

title: The Forces Of Good and Evil
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Classical Music
description: There is a lot going on this week that will attract followers of the major music institutions and personalities, but a concert offering the opportunity to size up promising young talent before it becomes well known can also be recommended.

title: NUDES ASCENDING A TRIANGLE
description: THE BACHELORS' BRIDE By Stephen Koch. 270 pp. New York: Marion Boyars. $18.95.

title: Ban on Walking Of Pit Bulldogs
description: AFTER a series of incidents in which pit bulldogs had bitten or mauled people, Lynn, Mass., adopted an emergency ordinance in June. It forbade owners to walk pit bulls on the street, even on a leash, and banned the sale of the breed.

title: Bergen Catholic Reaches Final
description: Bergen Catholic reached the championship of the North Jersey Parochial Division A playoff yesterday with an 18-0 victory over St. Joseph's of Montvale in the first round before 3,000 in Oradell.

title: PLANS FOR CONSTITUTION'S BIRTHDAY BEGIN TO TAKE SHAPE
description: With $22.5 million in the bank and a new three-year extension of its mandate from Congress, the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution has taken its first steps, in private, to finance a long-running 200th national birthday party for the Constitution and the Bill of Rights.

title: AVOIDING A FALL: TIPS ON BUYING AND USING LADDERS SAFELY
description: ALTHOUGH injuries resulting from falls off a ladder are unfortunately a fairly common occurrence, almost all these accidents can be avoided if a few basic safety rules about how to carry, climb or use a ladder of any kind are followed.

title: MANCHESTER ROAD RACE CELEBRATES 50th YEAR
description: LAST Thanksgiving Day, the temperature in Manchester was 36 degrees at 10 A.M. and a cold rain was pouring down - a miserable day for running. But that did not keep 5,600 people from participating in the Manchester Five-Mile Road Race, an event that has slowly grown since the first one was run in 1927.

title: A BOOM IN BENFACTORS FOR N.Y.U.
description: LAURENCE A. TISCH, Leonard N. Stern and Lewis Rudin never had much desire to see their alma mater again after they graduated from New York University in the 40's and 50's. They certainly never expected to come back to campus the way they have, as benefactors and members of the board of trustees.

title: CHALLENGES AWAIT YONKERS MANAGER
description: AS the newly appointed Yonkers City Manager, Nicholas DeSantis, is likely to face his first major challenge very shortly as the city tackles the problem of finding a long-term solution to its financial problems.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS CONFRONT ISSUE OF TEEN-AGE DRINKING AND SPORTS
description: WHEN the Irvington Bulldogs defeated the Bronxville Broncos recently, completing their first undefeated football season in nine years, student reaction was surprising mute.

title: Informal Elegance in New Haven
description: DEFINING ambiance in a restaurant is not always easy. But the moment you step into the dramatic, black and white brasserie called Bruxelles in New Haven, you feel drawn to its smart yet informal style.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEM REPAIRS PRODUCE MIXED RESULTS
description: Five years and billions of dollars after the Transit Authority began restoring the city's mass-transit system, gleaming new subway trains are riding on miles of newly rebuilt track, but few stations have been modernized.

title: THORPE: 50 YEARS OF DIENES' WORK
description: AT THE entrance to the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery here, a Distinguished Service Award affixed with a seal from Rockland County is made out to Sari Dienes, ''whose life work reminds us that art is often discovered where it is least expected.''

title: Sweeney Tops Flutie Mark
description: Kevin Sweeney broke Doug Flutie's major-college career passing record with a 11-yard toss to Stephen Baker in the second quarter of Fresno State's 14-7 victory over Utah State tonight.

title: SHOSTAKOVICH AND STALIN STAR IN A REVUE
description: When Paul Schmidt was first approached about writing a music-theater piece on the life of the Soviet composer Dmitri Shostakovich, the writer-actor-Russian scholar made one request. ''I told them I didn't want any samovars,'' Mr. Schmidt said. ''Or any old ladies wearing babushki on their heads.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KAY BOYLE; Artist and Activist. By Sandra Whipple Spanier. (Southern Illinois University, $22.50.) Sandra Whipple Spanier, who teaches American literature at Oregon State University, has written a splendid study of Kay Boyle, who has had one of the most up-and-down careers of 20th-century American writers.

title: THE PAGAN OF AMHERST
description: EMILY DICKINSON By Cynthia Griffin Wolff. Illustrated. 638 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Early Court Ballet in France Was Varied and Lively
description: To think of court ballet in France is to think of Louis XIV, the Sun King, resplendent in his costume of Apollo. But it could be argued - as it has been by certain scholars - that the apogee of court ballet occurred during the reign of Louis XIII, a monarch who was as apt to personify a demon as a deity.

title: AUSTRIA, ITS ECONOMY FRAGILE, ELECTS PARLIAMENT TODAY
description: Austrians will decide on Sunday who will govern the country for the next four years, and a coalition of the two largest parties is likely for the first time since 1966.

title: Baldwin Routed By Hempstead
description: The Hempstead Tigers (9-0) continued their march toward their third consecutive Nassau County Conference 1 championship with a 20-6 semifinal victory over Baldwin (5-4).

title: DANCE: HANNAH KAHN
description: HANNAH KAHN is a musical choreographer with a sense of craft, a thoughtful sensibility and a keen eye for skilled and personable dancers. All those elements came into play in ''Array,'' a dance performed on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where Hannah Kahn Dancers performs again tonight.

title: A Fourth Way for Development
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PENALIZES COPTER CONCERN IN FATAL CRASH
description: Federal aviation officials have grounded cargo flights by the New Jersey-based helicopter company whose aircraft crashed into the Hudson River a month ago, killing a traffic reporter for WNBC radio.

title: 'Nazi Hunter'- Snared In the TV-Film Syndrome
description: To report that ''Nazi Hunter'' is a better-than-average made-for-TV movie is an ambiguous compliment, on the order of recommending one fast-food hamburger over another. But just because it is a superior version of the form - a more substantial story, a reasonably literate script, two good performances in the lead roles - it demonstrates how difficult it is for any such show to rise above its station. The two-hour production can be seen on Channel 7, tonight at 9.

title: GOD, SEX AND PIRATES
description: THE COLLECTED ESSAYS OF CHRISTOPHER HILL Volume Three: People and Ideas in 17th Century England. By Christopher Hill. 340 pp. Amherst: University of Massachusetts Press. $27.50.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CONFRONTING REVOLUTION: Security Through Diplomacy in Central America. Edited by Morris J. Blachman, William M. LeoGrande and Kenneth E. Sharpe. (Pantheon, Cloth, $22.95.

title: MANY CUISINES IN A TINY SPACE
description: AFTER dining at M'Norah in Massapequa Park, one wonders how it is able to fit so many cuisines into such a tiny space. The storefront restaurant, done in pale pink with delicate flower and vegetable motifs stenciled on walls as borders, barely seats 30, but it offers a menu of Thai and French specialities, with some Italian, Japanese and American thrown in for good measure. The chef, who is Thai but likes to cook French food, is talented enough to make it all work surprisingly well.

title: HEATING-AID FUND STALLED IN TRENTON
description: NEW JERSEY has $105 million in oil overcharge funds to spend on reducing heating costs for the public, but the divided Legislature may not be able to agree on how to spend it before the heating season is over.

title: ARABS BITTER OVER SHIPMENTS TO IRAN
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to supply arms to Iran through Israel has damaged United States policy in the Arab world and sharply undercut American credibility among centrist Arab rulers, according to Western and Arab sources.

title: CARVING UP THE BOARD OF ESTIMATE'S TURF
description: AFTER reigning more than a century as New York City's most powerful government body, the Board of Estimate has been found unfit for the job.

title: '21 Mansion and Land Sold
description: Gray Craig Estates, the 77-acre retreat of the Standard Oil heirs Margaret and Archbold van Beuren, has been sold to a group of investors. The announcement Wednesday did not mention the price. The English manor-style house, built in 1921, was sold to Gray Craig Estates, an association made up of Michael Rondeau of Equity Ventures Inc. of Warwick, Robert Kempenaar of Kempenaar Real Estate of Middletown, and Alexander F. Grande of Nelson Pond Inc. in Portsmouth.

title: Court Expands Development Rule
description: The price of privilege went up last week for real estate developers in New York City.

title: Furniture of a Great Architect
description: The first exhibition in New York of Antonio Gaudi's eccentric furniture, on view at the Allan Stone Gallery, 48 East 86th Street, through Dec. 19, seems as unfinished as the Spanish architect's masterpiece -the spired Sagrada Familia Church that dominates Barcelona's skyline.

title: Lockbaum Not Quite Enough
description: THE young woman taking the $1.15 at the toll booth on the Mass Pike claimed she was not Gordon Lockbaum. The man selling blueberry muffins outside the stadium maintained he was not Gordon Lockbaum. The little boy distributing purple Holy Cross flyers insisted he was not Gordon Lockbaum, although he would not mind growing up to be him.

title: UP WITH THE GRASS ROOTS
description: THE COMMON GOOD Its Politics, Policies and Philosophy. By Marcus G. Raskin. 369 pp. New York: Routledge & Kegan Paul. $22.50.

title: Accord in Two Cities Averts Dock Strike
description: Negotiators have reached tentative agreement on a three-year contract for about 3,500 longshoremen here and in Wilmington, Del., averting a strike that would have begun today.

title: Gretzky Gets Fastest 500
description: Wayne Gretzky scored three goals, including the 500th of his National Hockey league career, and had two assists tonight as the Oilers beat Vancouver, 5-2.

title: 4 CHARGED IN SALES OF TAINTED LIVESTOCK FEED
description: Four officers of a feed supplier were indicted on charges of selling contaminated livestock feed that forced farmers earlier this year to dump hundreds of thousands of gallons of milk in Arkansas, Missouri and Oklahoma.

title: Hicksville
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Medals and Shows
description: Yale University's Elizabethan Club is observing its 75th anniversary and has authorized the issuance of a medal to mark the occasion. The club was founded in 1911 so Yale students could gather in a stimulating environment for worthwhile conversation. As its name suggests, the students discuss Elizabethan literature and art. However, the club's purpose is far broader: It seeks to foster ''free and unaffected discussion'' of every subject in which its members may have an interest.

title: Nancy Edelstein to Wed
description: The engagement of Nancy Bess Edelstein to Richard Glenn Spiro has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Edelstein of Manhasset Hills, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Spiro of Wantagh, L.I. Miss Edelstein is a senior at Princeton University. Mr. Spiro, a magna cum laude graduate of Princeton, class of '86, attends the Columbia University School of Law.

title: OLD-FASHIONED VIRTUES, BOHEMIAN VICES
description: BLUEBEARD'S EGG And Other Stories. By Margaret Atwood. 281 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: Arizona St. Suffers First Setback, 34-17
description: Chuck Cecil returned an interception a school-record 100 yards for a touchdown today as Arizona upset previously unbeaten Arizona State, 34-17.

title: HAMPTONS HOUSES: THEMES OF ESCAPE AND EXPRESSIONS
description: THAT the towns on the South Shore of the eastern end of Long Island were originally settled by colonists from Massachusetts in the 17th century, and existed for nearly 300 years as essentially farming communities, seems increasingly irrelevant to their future. For these towns contain the sought after and most valuable ocean frontage on the East Coast of the United States - sought after because it is a landscape of startling beauty, valuable because it is roughly a hundred miles, or two hours' drive, from New York City. It is the presence of the beaches, then, more than the area's past, that has shaped the current identity of East Hampton, Southampton, Bridgehampton and the other communities that are known collectively as the Hamptons.

title: IRANIAN ARMS DEAL SEEN AS OPENING FOR DEMOCRATS
description: The Reagan Administration's secret provision of arms to Iran creates a major opportunity for Democrats to ''reassert'' themselves on foreign policy issues as they head toward the 1988 elections, a pollster told Democratic leaders here today.

title: Jazz Top Nets, 96-78
description: Kent Benson, John Stockton and Thurl Bailey sparked a 21-2 Utah burst in the first 9 minutes of the fourth quarter tonight, and the Jazz went on to defeat the Nets, 96-78.

title: Heather F. Twidale to Marry in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Twidale of Geneseo, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Heather Frances Twidale to Bruce Gordon Kennedy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Kennedy of New York. The wedding is planned for August.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SERENADE'
description: ''SERENADE'' was once again all sighs. The first ballet George Balanchine created in America, ''Serenade'' received its first performance of the season by the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Uncertainties Soften Occupied-Apartment Market
description: WITH an advertising blitz two and a half years ago, a number of entrepreneurs created a new retail market in New York City for an unusual real-estate product: Cooperative or condominium apartments in converted buildings that are occupied by rent-regulated tenants who have the right to remain indefinitely.

title:
MUSIC;
SOUTH JERSEY ORCHESTRA GROWS
description: SAMUEL MUNI, founder and conductor of the South Jersey Symphony Orchestra, grew up on a farm near Vineland, and for the first 11 years of his life, he said, ''I never went to a live classical concert.''

title: World Drive on an AIDS 'Pandemic'
description: Only a year ago, Dr. Halfdan Mahler, the head of the World Health Organization, cautioned against exaggerating the danger of AIDS.

title: Colorization- A Spectrum of Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: KREMER IN RACE FOR SPEAKER
description: ASSEMBLYMAN Arthur J. Kremer of Long Beach has reached a critical stage in his campaign for Assembly Speaker, probably the second or third most powerful position in the state.

title: HOW WALL STREET BRED AN IVAN BOESKY
description: ''The avarice of mankind is insatiable.'' - Aristotle

title: The Garfagnana
description: To the Editor: One of the fascinating aspects of travel is how two people can view the same place in very different ways. When I read A. Alvarez's article on the Marble Mountains of the Garfagnana (Travel, Sept. 7), I was intrigued with his description of Castelnuovo Garfagnana because we have just returned from a two-week stay only a few miles from Castelnuovo.

title: Reagan Panel's Open Space Plan Alarms Officials
description: The President's Commission on American Outdoors, appointed by President Reagan and led by a Republican, has, it developed last week, drafted proposals that are alarming Administration officials.

title: Correction
description: An article Nov. 16 on the resurgence of East Orange incorrectly characterized the American International Group. It is an insurance company, not an insurance brokerage.

title: CAN 'PEOPLE POWER' CONTEND WITH FIREPOWER?
description: THE dominant television images here in recent days were of stiff and sometimes mutilated bodies laid out on mortuary tables and surrounded by grieving relatives.

title: MEXICO, TOO, HAS WORRIES OVER NUCLEAR SAFETY, COSTS
description: FOR 16 years, Mexico has been building a nuclear power plant, its first, despite growing evidence that it no longer can afford nuclear power.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Winston-Salem, N.C.;
A Lively Beat For Downtown
description: W. J. CASH, the Southern historian, once described this city as ''tobacco-stinking Winston.'' While the smell of North Carolina's leading cash crop still wafts through downtown, Winston-Salem's aging cigarette mills now have some olfactory competition.

title: Task Force Plans Heir to Westway
description: The 22-member West Side Task Force emerged from a mountain retreat last week with agreement on a six-lane thoroughfare to replace -at last - the West Side Highway between the Battery and 42d Street. Members cautioned, however, that ''at last'' will not be anytime soon.

title: SLAMMING THROUGH LIFE
description: LILLIAN HELLMAN The Image, the Woman. By William Wright. Illustrated. 507 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 23, 1986
description: Fiction

title: HATCHERY'S STRIPERS SENT ON THEIR WAY
description: BRUCE FRIEDMANN dipped his net into the muddy water of the Hudson River, releasing hundreds of striped bass. Spawned and raised at the Hudson River Striped Bass Hatchery in Verplanck, these three-inch fish instinctively schooled and were gone.

title: Whalers Get 5 in 2d To Down Islanders
description: One team woke up, the other didn't, and the Hartford Whalers continued a three-year tradition of profiting by their visits to Nassau Coliseum with a 6-3 victory tonight. The Islanders had hoped to assemble their first three-game winning streak, but a lackadaisical defense and drowsy offense helped Hartford to a five-goal second period.

title: PISTONS' THOMAS FACING A FINE
description: Isiah Thomas, a Detroit Pistons guard, will reportedly be fined $1,500 for punching Dudley Bradley fo the Bucks in a Nov. 8 game in Milwaukee, a National Basketball Association official said today.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MUSEUM SHOPPING

title: Deep Discounts on Flights Abroad
description: A recent telephone inquiry brought word from Japan Air Lines that the lowest round-trip fare between New York and Tokyo was $1,229. But among Manhattan travel agencies that specialize in selling air tickets at a discount, Maharaja Travels quoted the cost of a New York-Tokyo round trip at $550, Lan-Si-Aire quoted $549 and Sudo Tours and Apex Travel quoted $529.

title: State Panel Votes To Curb Smoking In Public Places
description: Friday was a black day for smokers in New York State who made it through the American Cancer Society's ''Smokeout'' Thursday with their habits intact.

title: TRAPPED IN MY ROOM BY 2 UNINVITED GUESTS
description: IT was a beautiful day in late summer, and we had just moved to Long Island.

title: Daniel M. Crown to Marry Ellen Podell Next January
description: A Jan. 31 wedding is planned by Ellen Taylor Podell and Daniel M. Crown, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Bertram L. Podell of New York, have announced. Mr. Crown is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Crown of Chicago.

title: Relics in Spain, Wine in the Wilderness
description: New Museum Houses Roman Art

title: HUNT FOR POLICE-SHOOTINGS SUSPECT WIDENS TO AT LEAST 5 OTHER CITIES
description: Heavily armed authorities hunting the man suspected of killing seven people this year and shooting six police officers in the Bronx last week searched possible hideouts in New York City yesterday and posted stakeouts here and in other cities, but there was no sign of the fugitive.

title: BEFORE THE FREEWAY, THERE WAS U.S. 11
description: ''Bring me a bedspread if you see a pretty one,'' my aunt called after me as I departed on a recent automobile trip. At first I was puzzled. What possessed her to make such a mundane request? Then I remembered - as she must have - our family odysseys during the Great Depression, when a common sight along the highways had been little roadside stands piled high with gaudy chenille bedspreads, the proprietor displaying her prize creations on a clothesline - perhaps a sky-blue spread with pink roses as big as cabbages or, for the unreconstructed, a double-bed version of the Stars and Bars of the Confederacy.

title: DISCOVERING THE LOW-RISE SIDE OF OAHU
description: Waikiki is 40 miles and a world away. Washed by some of the most celebrated and daunting winter surfing waters in the world, Oahu's north shore - the other side of the island - holds onto a piece of Old Hawaii. It is a 20-mile stretch of piney ironwoods, coconut and mango trees, the leafy profusion concealing narrow lanes where elegant beach homes face the sea. There's also a quaint country town with art galleries and fine dining, polo grounds and, on the northernmost tip of the island, one extravagant resort hotel complete with golf, tennis and swimming pools.

title: WOMEN ARTISTS WILL HAVE THEIR OWN MUSEUM
description: WHEN ''Women Artists 1550-1950'' opened at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art 10 years ago, female artists, long neglected by art historians and museum curators, took it as a victory. But while the feminists cheered, the rest of the art world remained skeptical.

title: NEW USE SOUGHT FOR LANDFILL WITH 'FANTASTIC VIEW'
description: ''THIS is a diamond in the rough,'' said Jay Pitti as he hiked across the top of the Merrick landfill. He pointed out clover, wild daisies, sage and wood sorrel that had grown to cover most traces of the dump in the three years since it was closed.

title: Dana L. Belshe Bride Of Sydney Thayer 4th
description: Dana Leigh Belshe, a daughter of Mrs. Charles B. Lansill of San Francisco and Thomas A. Belshe of New York, was married yesterday to Sydney Thayer 4th, a son of Mrs. Robert P.
