Sherwin of Strafford, Pa., and Mr. Thayer 3d of Coatesville, Pa. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: TAXICAB REGULATION FROM MANY DIRECTIONS
description: CITY Councilman Sal F. Albanese gazed benevolently across the Council chamber last week at the chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, Gorman Gilbert. ''Mr. Gilbert,'' he said, ''you inherited a mess.'' Mr. Gilbert only smiled in return, perhaps the best strategy in the midst of a week that heralded large changes in the way New York City's taxicabs operate.

title: AUTO WORKERS APPROVE PACT
description: Delco workers whose strike at a key plant idled more than 37,000 General Motors employees nationwide overwhelmingly approved a new contract today, a union offical said.

title: SMALL HOSPITALS FORM INSURANCE COMPANY
description: TEN small Connecticut hospitals have formed their own insurance company in an effort to control costs.

title: Cathy Dudas Weds
description: Cathy Jean Dudas and Stephen Lowell Coggins were married yesterday at St. Thomas the Apostle Byzantine Catholic Church in Rahway, N.J., by the Rev. John Zeyack. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Dudas of Edison, N.J., is a manager of programming finance for Home Box Office. Mr. Coggins, a radio personality known as Steve O'Brien on WYNY-FM, is the son of Lieut. Col. Thomas M. Coggins, U.S.M.C., retired, of Panama City Beach, Fla., and Kathleen Lowell Cave of Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: AT LITCHFIELD GAME FARM, TURKEYS OF PRIVILEGE
description: WHILE thoughts of turkeys this time of year are most often concerned with the stuffing and roasting and eating of them, at Paddling Ponds, a wild game farm in Litchfield, the bird occupies a privileged position.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Office Growth; Building Boom Is Near an End
description: THE last decade was a record time for commercial developers, and oh, what a time it was. It is estimated that of all primary office space in the country, more than a third - about 1.3 billion square feet - was built in the 10 years starting in 1975. New office towers seemed to be springing up on every downtown lot, and city watchers were left to wonder who would ever fill all that space.

title: A Museum in L.A. Shapes A Modern Collection
description: Today should be a happy day for the Los Angeles County Museum, for it marks the opening to the public not only of the big new Robert O. Anderson building, designed by the New York firm of Hardy, Holtzmann and Pfeiffer, but of what is in effect a new museum of modern art, complete with a very large space for temporary exhibitions. (That space is devoted through March 8, 1987, to a mammoth survey of abstract painting and its antecedents, organized by Maurice Tuchman of the County Museum and entitled ''The Spiritual in Art,'' after Vasily Kandinsky's seminal book of the same name.) For those who know something of Los Angeles, this is a remarkable, and in some ways almost a resurrectional, occasion. Not so long ago Los Angeles underwent some startling changes. Norton Simon took his European paintings, which were on loan to the County Museum and had been expected to stay there, and put them in the Pasadena Museum, which was renamed the Norton Simon Museum and forthwith became, inch for inch, one of the finest museums in the country. The Getty Museum became very rich indeed, and was thought of as a potential predator that could tell every other museum to get lost. The soon-to-open Museum of Contemporary Art, which had seemed to be too ambitious in a freaky way ever to survive, proved able to look after itself in circumstances no matter how fraught and demanding. In short order, the County Museum was thought of as a place that had lost a great collection, could never compete with the Getty in the market and was so bottom-heavy in its physical appearance that it would also lose out to the Museum of Contemporary Art when it was a question of moving fast and traveling light.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: NEW JERSEY has gained 444,000 jobs since 1979, establishing a 14.7 percent growth rate for the period, according to a report by the Federal Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: JERSEY SEEKS TIGHTER CURBS ON SMOKING
description: Officials in New Jersey, where some of the nation's toughest curbs on smoking are already in effect, are seeking new ways of discouraging the use of tobacco products, especially among children and teen-agers.

title: Venetian Lunch
description: To the Editor: In the ''What's Doing in Venice'' article of June 8, Harry's Bar was described as extremely expensive (lunch for two could cost $100) and the author said that a good tourist lunch could be had at the Ridotto Restaurant, complete with wine, for under $15 a person.

title: Maureen B. Strack Weds
description: Maureen Bernardette Strack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Strack of Oceanside, L.I., was married there yesterday to Bernard Joseph Kilkelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Kilkelly Jr., of Flushing, Queens. Bishop John R. McGann performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Kilkelly is a certified public accountant for the New York accounting firm of Buchbinder Stein Tunick & Platkin. Mr. Kilkelly is an account supervisor at Leyden Communications, a public relations concern in New York.

title: ISABELLA ROSSELLINI ASSESSES THE ROLE THAT HAUNTED HER
description: In the most controversial scene in the year's most controversial movie, ''Blue Velvet,'' an alluring if unhinged nightclub singer named Dorothy Vallens (Isabella Rossellini) is forced to enact an elaborate sadomasochistic sex ritual - replete with strange incestuous allusions - that she doesn't wholly dislike. Dorothy's ''attacker,'' the totally demented Frank (Dennis Hopper), alternately becomes her depraved child and despot father in the bizarre game that entangles both of them - as well as the sash of Dorothy's blue velvet robe. ''Dennis says that is not a rape scene; it's our love scene,'' says Ms. Rossellini, laughing. And, quoting from the subservient Dorothy, she hastens to add: ''O.K. sir, O.K. Frank.'' ''Blue Velvet'' is Ms. Rossellini's fourth film, but it is the first that offers her a role strong enough to display the star quality of an impeccable movie pedigree. Born to Ingrid Bergman and Roberto Rossellini in 1952, just three years after their adulterous affair scandalized the world, Ms. Rossellini is no stranger to controversy. She says she was aware that playing Dorothy could be potentially damaging, but that she saw it essentially as ''a role I was haunted by and felt I wanted terribly to try.''

title: Dr. L. Pat Robinson Is Wed to Rabbi in Englewood
description: Dr. L. Pat Robinson and Rabbi Stephen Chaim Listfield were married last night at Temple Emanu-El in Englewood, N.J., where the bridegroom is the spiritual leader. Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum, president emeritus of the Jewish Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony.

title: A Political Hack?
description: Somewhere deep inside, Mike McGrath, the Treasurer-elect of Minnesota, must have known it would get out.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Of Rogues and Rates Wall Street's latest and perhaps greatest insider-trading scandal may have a silver lining: lower interest rates.

title: OFFICIALS SAY C.I.A. KNEW LITTLE OF IRAN WHEN ARMS SALES STARTED
description: The United States began its covert arms shipments to Iran despite scant American intelligence about its internal political situation, according to Government officials.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ITALIA PERVERSA. Part One: Stalin's Orphans. By Richard Appignanesi. (Quartet/Salem, $17.95.) Only a supremely self-confident or foolhardy novelist would dare start a trilogy with his protagonist's funeral.

title: NEW HOFSTRA CHAIRMAN KEEPS EYE ON ENERGY
description: ''THE operation was a success, but the patient is dying,'' said Frank G. Zarb. The 51-year-old Mr. Zarb, the former Ford Administration ''energy czar,'' who lives in Manhattan and Oyster Bay, was criticizing national energy policy and expressing fears of a new energy crunch.

title: MAORIS WANT POPE TO APPOINT BISHOP
description: Maori tribesmen made a powerful political statement today by rubbing noses with Pope John Paul II. The affectionate gesture came during a ceremony designed both to welcome the Pope to this country and to promote what the Maoris call their ''renaissance,'' a drive for increased cultural autonomy and political power.

title: Rulon Jones, a Model Defensive End, Is Tackling His Roots
description: THE day before the 1980 National Football League college draft, Rulon Jones heard a rumor that didn't exactly thrill him: The Cleveland Browns intended to take him on the first round. ''Nothing against Cleveland,'' he said the other day. ''But that wasn't too exciting.''

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We're lean and mean, but it would be wrong to say we haven't been wounded.'' Robert E. Mercer, Goodyear chairman, on the successful fight against Sir James Goldsmith.

title: Man Denies Threat to Reagan
description: An unemployed man who kept a bullet marked ''For you Mr. President'' pleaded not guilty Friday to charges that he threatened President Reagan on a campaign tour in October. The man, Robert Nelson Jr., 23 years old, of Tacoma, Wash., on parole for charges including armed robbery, has been held without bond since his arrest. The day before a Reagan visit to Spokane, Secret Service agents found a single .38-caliber bullet in Mr. Nelson's room in a motel.

title: FOR GIRLS IN DANCE COMPANY, ATTITUDE IMPORTANT AS APTITUDE
description: IT is Saturday morning, and 21 young women are following the instructions of an exacting teacher. ''Left hand on the barre, please,'' he calls out, as the pianist plays music from ''Carmen.'' ''Stretch it out a little more, don't arch back. I'm seeing a lot of distortion.''

title: Whistle Blowers
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDIS, TO DEVELOP TEHERAN TIES, ARE SAID TO BE SENDING IRAN FUEL
description: Within the last few months, large shipments of fuel refined in Saudi Arabia have been shipped by commercial American traders across the Persian Gulf to Iran, which urgently needs the fuel for its war with Iraq, according to oil traders and oil experts.

title: PALACE OF THE LAST HAWAIIAN KING
description: David Kalakaua, the last of Hawaii's kings, was a man of large appetites. A great eater and drinker, he once hosted a feast for some 5,000 people. An accomplished composer and poet in his native tongue, he so loved traditional music and dance that he revived the hula, over loud protests from influential missionary families who had been trying for decades to suppress it. He was the first ruler of any nation to sail around the globe, calling on 11 heads of state, from Japan to Britain. Midway through his turbulent reign he commissioned a palace to be built in Honolulu, Italianate in style, with balustrades, two floors of pillared porticoes, a chandeliered reception hall and copper-lined bathtubs encased in wood.

title: NEW CAMPUS CRAZE: AGE
description: PAMELA C. COCCHIA of Norwalk was an administrative analyst with Control Data Corporation when, she recalls, she ''reached a point where I wasn't getting anything out of what I was doing.'' So at age 37, Mrs. Cocchia packed her bags and moved into a dormitory at the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title: A Problem of Public Comfort
description: Someone strolling through Times Square one recent weekday noon would have seen a man urinating against the TKTS booth at Father Duffy Square and a woman squatting in the gutter at Broadway and 43d. If the stroller had entered the subway at Seventh or at Eighth Avenue, there would have been a choking stench. Why has the Crossroads of the World become a public lavatory?

title: Romantic Gestures In Paris
description: AS IT OFTEN DOES WITH CREA-tive people, inspiration comes to Jean-Louis Riccardi in the middle of the night. Rather than perfect a few measures of music or reach for a pen, however, he moves furniture around his two-room apartment, creating what he calls ''interior landscapes.'' These are romantic rooms, places that the designer hopes will make people feel depayse, uprooted or out of their element.

title: Sellers Race to Meet Tax Deadline
description: LENDERS are cranking out mortgages, managing agents are being swamped by financial and social references and lawyers are adding such novel stipulations to sales contracts as: ''If closing does not occur by 11:59 P.M. Dec. 31, this deal is null and void.''

title: Laura Bryant Wed to Bryan Mulligan
description: Laura Elizabeth Bryant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Bryant Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church there yesterday to Bryan Vincent Mulligan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Mulligan of Massapequa, L.I. The ceremomy was performed by Abbott Matthew K. Leavy, a cousin of the bridegroom, who is head of St. Anselm's Abbey and president of St. Anselm's College in Manchester, N.H., assisted by the Rev. Robert F. Rausch, a cousin of the bride.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: TRAIN CLUB SHOWS The Model Railroad Club in Union opens its Christmas show Friday, and the Bergen County Railroad Club will open its annual operating show in Waldwick the same day.

title: New Pitching Equation: Many Strikeouts Means Few hits
description: IF anyone ever doubted that a strikeout pitcher can be the most difficult for a batter to hit, the 1986 performances of a group of pitchers in each league should eliminate the doubts.

title: Jews in Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: W.C. Ughetta Jr. Wed in Delaware To Margaret Cist
description: The marriage of Margaret Conway Cist, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John David Cist of Wilmington, Del., to William Casper Ughetta Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ughetta of Corning, N.Y., took place yesterday in Greenville, Del., in Christ Church Christiana Hundred. The Rev. Dr. Adam Lewis, the Episcopal rector, performed the ceremony.

title: SCULPTURE BREAKS THE MOLD OF MINIMALISM
description: This has been a November to remember for sculpture. There may never have been as many good sculpture shows in one city at one time. Together they sum up the last 25 years. And they suggest that sculpture in the United States is at its most critical juncture since Minimalism, with its hard edges, seamless surfaces and primary forms, charted a new, American sculptural course and in the process boxed and walled in every alternative.

title: BUSINESS ASKED TO SPUR SPECIAL-NEEDS ADOPTION
description: CURRENTLY in Connecticut, 113 children with special needs await adoption, and an adoption counselor in Hartford is looking to corporations to help increase the adoption rate for these children.

title: Colorization- A Spectrum of Opinion
description: To the Editor:

title: AMTRAK ROLLS PAST SHUTTLES IN NUMBER OF RIDERS
description: Between New York City and Washington, where airline ''shuttle wars'' are the talk of the travel business, Amtrak is carrying more passengers daily than any of the airlines with which it competes. And ridership is increasing on the Metroliner high-speed trains between the two cities.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: 8 Are Convicted Of Running Mafia 'Commission'
description: Carmine Persico, boss of the Colombo crime family, called the prosecution's case a ''bus trip'' through ''tinseltown,'' but the jury was convinced. Mr. Persico and seven co-defendants were convicted in Federal District Court in Manhattan last week of operating or helping operate a New York-based Mafia ''commission'' that adjudicated disputes throughout the United States.

title: Recent Sales
description: Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $460,000 29 Judson 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 22-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, 20- by 40-foot pool, den, sun deck; taxes $9,662. Hartsdale, N.Y. $265,000 5 Birchwood Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old frame Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, pool, alarm system, 1/2 acre; taxes $5,770.

title: LEGISLATION WOULD RETURN CONTROL OF ARMS SALES TO CONGRESS
description: The uproar over secret arms deliveries to Iran has given new impetus to proposed legislation that would require direct Congressional approval for all sales of sensitive weapons, according to the bill's supporters.

title: Angola Rebellion Nears Oil Fields
description: Angola said last week that the United States-backed guerilla rebellion has spread to its northern provinces near Zaire. Not far away, in Cabinda, American, Italian and French oil companies produce most of the country's foreign earnings. Col. Antonio dos Santos Franca, the armed forces Chief of Staff, said 230 guerillas had been killed from January to September.

title: Q AND A
description: Music at Sea Question:Are there any music cruises now that the Paquet line's Mermoz is apparently no longer doing them? - E. H. C., Montreal Answer:Several music cruises are planned, including one aboard the Mermoz in the Mediterranean next summer. An official of Sun Line Cruises, which has represented Paquet French Cruises in this country since it closed its Miami office last May, said that Paquet's 30th annual Music Festival at Sea will start on the Mermoz on Aug. 28. It will be a 10-day voyage from Toulon (France) to Toulon. The names of the artists are not yet available, and neither are the rates, which are likely to start at about $3,000 a person, double occupancy, and not include air fare. Making reservations well in advance is advised, since the ship's music cruises are usually heavily booked.

title: TYSON WINS W.B.C. CHAMPIONSHIP
description: Mike Tyson made history tonight.

title: POSTINGS: Reborn to the Manor; For 'Pre-Retirees'
description: Monroe Township in Middlesex County, N.J., is becoming the adult-community capital of the country. The development of a fourth such community, called Whittingham and geared toward ''pre-retirees'' aged 48 and older, is just starting there.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FRIEZE. By Cecile Pineda. (Viking, $16.95.) Call it karma or original sin, but for Cecile Pineda's characters, the given of life is suffering, and deliverance is possible only through the violent dismembering of the worldly self. Her elegiac first novel, ''Face,'' nominated for a 1985 National Book Award, told of a barber from a Brazilian slum whose face is grotesquely mutilated, and the solitary anguish of reconstructing it. The major character of her new novel is Gopal, a stone carver in 10th-century India, whose dissolution of self is more gradual at first and thus more deceptive. After losing the wife he cherishes to the shadows of her own dream world, he is conscripted by a dynastic prince to travel to Java to carve 120 friezes of Buddha's life for the shrine of Borobudur (still standing today), whose construction devoured the lives of thousands of laborers. Ms. Pineda is convincing in her description of the passion and hubris that fuel Gopal's carving of the sacred friezes but also blinds him to the close, hot breath of danger around him; she makes the act of savagery that forces him to recast his life both horrifying and believable. Unfortunately, the novel suffers from her insistence that Gopal lead a pointedly metaphorical life: she names his first, dreamily seductive wife Maya, the Sanskrit term for the illusions from which we must detach ourselves to gain true enlightenment; Borobudur is a not too subtle symbol for the pridefulness and cruelty of this world.

title: FINDING THE SPACE FOR THANKSGIVING
description: THANKSGIVING is fast approaching and like the proverbial farmyard turkey I am beginning to quake. In my extended family - now numbering 24 hearty, hungry souls - it is a tradition that I ''make'' Thanksgiving.

title: ON THE SCENE WITH A MOBILE UNIT
description: POLICE officers at the accident scene on Stuyvesant Avenue found the heavily damaged car lying in eight inches of water and wedged between the walls of a storm sewer 12 feet below the street.

title: CORRUPTION TRIAL: A CLASH OF TACTICS
description: The prosecution and defense used different tactics in the Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and three co-defendants on corruption-related charges.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Reverse-Mortgage Programs Widening
description: FRESH opportunities to tap home equity are opening up for elderly homeowners who find themselves living in increasingly valuable houses, yet struggling to pay for their upkeep.

title: Villainy Returns (Heh! Heh!) To Work Its Wonders
description: The oblivion-bound action film ''Quiet Cool,'' about murderous marijuana farmers in the Pacific Northwest, contains just one interesting feature: a trio of silent, scowling villains whose hair is dyed black, white and red, respectively, and who glide through the film on motorcycles, making trouble. There's nothing terribly imaginative about their motives or their methods. But their mere appearance is enough to suggest a degree of cleverness, even if nothing else about the film matches it. Sometimes a stylish villain, or in this case three of them, can work wonders. The right villain can do anything, from establishing a film's sophistication and setting its visual style to using a few quick, well-chosen strokes to determine its moral tone.

title: Miss McIntosh, a Lawyer, Is Wed to James Galvin 2d
description: Colleen Mary McIntosh, an associate at the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, and James Vincent Galvin 2d, a claims representative with the Allstate Insurance Company, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Lourdes Chapel at St. John's University. The Rev. Thomas Tuite performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: UNDER THE SPELL
description: THE PRINCIPLE OF HOPE By Ernst Bloch. Translated by Neville Plaice, Stephen Plaice and Paul Knight. 1,420 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $95.

title: The Great Gap Between Congress and Judges
description: Much of what Congress does affects the Federal judiciary, if only by making more work for judges. And much of what judges do when they scrutinize Federal law necessarily affects Congress.

title: FAITHS JOINING TO CELEBRATE THANKSGIVING
description: A growing number of Christian and Jewish congregations are planning to join together this week to reflect on America's bounty - and its hungry -in community Thanksgiving services.

title:
GARDENING;
WINTER PROTECTION AGAINST RODENTS
description: SQUIRRELS, rabbits and mice often wreak havoc on garden plants as they forage for food during the winter months. There are certain preventive measures that can be taken, however, although sometimes with uncertain results.

title: THE THANKSGIVING (OR WAS IT CHRISTMAS?) THAT CAME IN JULY
description: IN 1947, my wallet would contain one of Joe Knibbs's grease-stained $10 bills, which he would carefully unfold and toss onto my desk. An Old Bridge junkyard owner, he was my first ''paying'' client.

title:
ART;
ORIENTAL SHOW: ECLECTIC BUT SLIM
description: THERE are, to be sure, many beautiful objects in the current exhibition at the Sarah Lawrence College Gallery in Yonkers. But ''Women in Oriental Art: Han Dynasty to the Present,'' subtitled ''Two Thousand Years of Far Eastern Art,'' seems as slim as the cluster of painted orchid leaves on display that bears the seal of Tzu Hsi, the Dowager Empress.

title: A Heavy Dose Of Reality
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NORMAN ROCKWELL RARELY SAT AT MY TABLE
description: A COUPLE of years ago, on a travel-writing assignment in Kenya, I had Thanksgiving dinner at a table for one at the Mount Kenya Safari Club. The food was delicious, but I had to clear lumps in my throat a few times. My husband was home in New York and my children were scattered, but it wasn't missing them that made me feel sad. I was musing about the holiday and trying to analyze why it had rarely been a happy ''Happy Thanksgiving'' for me over the years.

title: Fast-Sell Syndrome
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENCE AGAINST HOMOSEXUALS RISING, GROUPS SEEKING WIDER PROTECTION SAY
description: Attacks on homosexuals appear to have increased sharply around the nation in the last three years as homosexuals have become more vocal in their pursuit of civil rights and more visible because of publicity surrounding the spread of AIDS.

title: CAR ACCIDENTS: SOLVING THE PUZZLES
description: IT was 4 A.M. on Oct. 5 when Detective Nick D'Avanzo got a telephone call at his home notifying him that a car had struck a utility pole in Hicksville, L.I. The passenger was dead, and the driver was being arrested on charges of driving while intoxicated.

title: Japanese Combs Crafted From History
description: In the middle of the Gion District of Kyoto, the center of the city's geisha world, a narrow, three-story, tile-roofed building is wedged between glittery coffee shops, trendy boutiques, elegant restaurants and souvenir shops.

title: STATE AND U.S. CLASH ANEW ON MEDICARE
description: THEY are stocked with life-saving medications and machines, manned by highly trained paramedics and equipped with radios that transmit a heart attack victim's electrocardiogram to doctors miles away.

title: BIRTH WITHOUT DOCTORS
description: A MIDWIFE'S STORY By Penny Armstrong and Sheryl Feldman. 228 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.95.

title: Columbia's Streak: 31 Losses
description: In the stands at Wien Stadium, the fans in the small crowd leaped and screamed. In the north end zone, where many of the football players in Columbia blue had just raced, the Lions surrounded Homer Hill, who had just scored a touchdown on a 64-yard pass.

title: Counting Money
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW DO YOU GIVE COUNTRIES CONFIDENCE IN THEIR FUTURES?
description: BARBER B. CONABLE Jr. became president of the World Bank last summer at a time of expanding influence. The bank has a prime role in the plan initiated 13 months ago by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d to mobilize capital for developing countries that agree to open their economies to trade and investment. Last week, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, as it is formally called, decided unanimously to release $300 million of the $2 billion it has committed this year to Mexico for a program to improve trade competitivness and reduce import barriers. It also lent $250 million to Chile, despite appeals from human rights groups opposing the move. At his office near the White House, Mr. Conable, a former Republican Congressman from upstate New York, discussed his priorities last week with six journalists from foreign publications and Clyde Farnsworth of The New York Times. Excerpts from their talk follow. Question. What will follow the Mexican loan? Answer. There will be follow-on loans of various sorts, and it's all dependent on the kinds of cooperation that are apparent in the Mexican Government now, and that involve a good deal of political courage on their part. Q. Isn't Mexico a special case? A. It's a very tough case because it's become so dependent on oil. They didn't have effective and efficient productivity to fall back on in other areas when the oil price went to nothing. Mexico has had some political instability in the past, too. Q. What is the United States' financial role? A. The U.S. supports the International Development Association with less than $1 billion.

title: CANADA RESCUES 5 SOVIET DESERTERS HELD BY GUERRILLAS IN AFGHANISTAN
description: Five deserters from the Soviet Army have been brought to Canada in a secret Government mission after being held captive by Afghan guerrillas for about three years, newspapers reported today.

title: HALPIN'S MARGIN OF VICTORY
description: In the article concerning the upcoming Suffolk County Executive race [ ''Power Struggle Seen in Suffolk G.O.P.,'' Nov. 9 ] my attention was drawn, in particular, to the election results of Assemblyman Patrick Halpin and the correlating analysis. With due respect, both are wrong.

title: SMOKEOUT ACTIVITIES ATTRACT TEEN-AGERS
description: THERE was a time, in the not-too-distant past, when the billows of smoke that arose from the parking lot behind the high-school gymnasium, on the evening of the school dance, meant that the teen-agers who gathered there were sneaking drags on cigarettes. But when smoke rose from the parking lot behind the gym of Mercy College last weekend, the hundreds of teen-agers gathered there were, instead, throwing packs of cigarettes into a roaring bonfire before attending a 1950's-style sock-hop inside the building.

title: Miss Michels Is Wed To Arthur P. Manso Jr.
description: Martha Jane Michels, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Herman Douglas Michels of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Arthur Paul Manso Jr., the son of Mrs. Manso and the late Mr. Manso of Mechanicville, N.Y. The Rev. George McCray performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church.

title: Dona Carter To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger D. Carter of Falls Church, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dona Marie Carter to Charles Darlington Irwin, the son of Maj. Charles J. Irwin, U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Irwin of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: Glowing Dancers, Essential Aykroyd
description: Shall We Dance Starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers.1937 RKO Home Video. 109 minutes. $29.95.

title: ATTEMPT TO OUST PHILIPPINE LEADER REPORTED BLOCKED
description: Dissident soldiers supporting Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile threatened to take over the National Assembly building and declare a rebel government today, but called off their plan after a plea by Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the Chief of Staff, military sources said.

title: Ward and P.B.A. Reach Agreement
description: The perception in some quarters was that New York City Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward had buckled under pressure, but feelings throughout the city were bound to include relief. Faced with the possible resumption of a six-day police slowdown and the threat of a mass march on City Hall by police officers, Mr. Ward abandoned last week his plan to transfer a fifth of the department's patrol officers each year.

title: POSTINGS: Along the Norton; A 'Missing Link' for Stamford
description: Ever since the recent emergence of Stamford, Conn., as a corporate mecca, some critics have bemoaned the city's ''9-to-5'' nature, arguing that employees flee the city when they leave work.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Living Under Shadow of Doubt
description: THE draftniks hooted and cackled, and the ESPN announcers smirked that spring morning in 1983, when Commissioner Pete Rozelle virtually did a double-take as he looked at the name:

title: Reformers From The Corporate World
description: Whatever the underlying motives or needs of the new reformers, it is reassuring to see people reaching out to others (''The New Social Reformers,'' by Crystal Nix, Oct. 26).

title: IN WAKE OF ELECTION ROUT, NEW YORK G.O.P. WILL MEET TO WEIGH ITS FUTURE
description: New York State Republican leaders will try to pick up the pieces tomorrow when they meet for the first time since their resounding defeat by Governor Cuomo in the November election.

title: MOORE GROUP SOLD TO KANSAS CITYANS
description: George Ablah, the Wichita, Kan., real estate and oil investor who in the last decade had acquired the world's largest collection of sculptures by the late English artist Henry Moore, has sold the 57 works that make up the core of his collection to the Hall Family Foundation of Kansas City, Mo. Neither the foundation nor Mr. Ablah would comment on the price, but it is reported to be in the neighborhood of $20 million.

title: Knicks Lose Without Ewing
description: The Knicks' plight gets more puzzling with each game. They were at home last night, so there was no road to blame. They started off well by doing all the right things - shooting, rebounding, playing good defense and dominating the Golden State Warriors in every phase. They even led by 16 points midway through the second period.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: GALBRAITH ON THE BOESKY SCANDAL;
A Classic Case of 'Euphoric Insanity'
description: In his 1954 book ''The Great Crash 1929,'' John Kenneth Galbraith provided a memorable portrait of one of the most notorious figures in Wall Street history. That was the patrician Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange from 1930 to 1935, who was convicted of grand larceny in 1938 (for using other people's stock as collateral for his own loans).

title: 22 Rebels Reported Dead In Sri Lanka Clashes
description: Government forces killed at least 22 Tamil guerrillas and captured 60 more in an urban battle Friday and today and in a sweep through the countryside, military officials said.

title: Humanity Comes First
description: To the Editor:

title: Yukica Wins Finale
description: David Gabianelli threw four touchdown passes and Dartmouth kept Princeton out of the end zone in a 28-6 victory that ended Joe Yukica's career as football coach of the Big Green.

title: Centrists Win in Brazil
description: The centrist party that for two decades led the opposition to Brazil's military regime won a landslide victory last week in the first national elections since the return of civilian rule in 1985. It was the most sweeping victory in the country's electoral history, giving the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party control of the governorships in all 23 states.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
AQUEDUCT HIKE
description: When the first trickle of Croton water emerged in New York City on June 22, 1842, it was hailed with a civic festival. The water, clean and plentiful, was the culmination of five years of labor by 3,000 to 4,000 immigrant workers and the answer to the city's cholera epidemic and raging fires.

title:
MUSIC;
LIVINGSTON ORCHESTRA TO PLAY WITH HARP QUARTET
description: THE Livingston Symphony Orchestra will open its 31st season Saturday night with a free program designed for a large stage and with a quartet of harpists as guest soloists.

title: SECRETARY BENNETT AND THE COLLEGES SQUARE OFF ON COSTS
description: IN a speech at Harvard University last month, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett attacked the quality of education offered by Harvard and other universities. Last week he riled another audience, composed of representatives from universities and financial institutions, by assigning them some blame for the ''skyrocketing'' costs of college tuition.

title: TOWARD A 'SUPER LIBERAL STATE'
description: THE CRITICAL LEGAL STUDIES MOVEMENT By Roberto Mangabeira Unger. 128 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: REAGAN'S LONELY DEFENSE OF A DEAL WITH IRAN
description: AT a dinner for Senate Republicans the other night, President Reagan cracked a joke. ''I'm glad to be out of Iran,'' he said. Unfortunately it is not proving that easy for Mr. Reagan to put Iran behind him. Despite a nationally broadcast speech 10 days ago and a news conference last week, the President has so far seemed unable to convince politicians or the public that the policy of secretly selling arms to Iran, which apparently led to the release of American hostages in Lebanon, was wise or correct.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NO HERO FOR THE KAISER By Rudolf Frank. Translated by Patricia Crampton. Illustrated by Klaus Steffens. 222 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $13. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Reagan, Senators And a Mystery
description: WHEN 94-year-old Daisy Eden O'Dell died in Santa Monica, Calif., on April 30, 1983, she left a $600,000 estate and a curious request.

title: A TOLL-COLLECTOR'S LOT IS NOT AN EASY ONE
description: IT WAS on a Friday the 13th, in September 1985, that Al Blazienski was working in his tollbooth on the Garden State Parkway when an approaching Lincoln Continental burst into flames. A man and a woman were trapped inside.

title: Inside the African National Congress
description: The stepped-up violence of African National Congress activities not only admits defeat, but causes the outside world to applaud South Africa's attacks beyond its borders on what are now accurately perceived as terrorist strongholds (''Inside the African National Congress,'' by Mark A. Uhlig, Oct. 12).

title: Cream of the Crafts in New Haven
description: THE Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven is an inviting place, the high window of its two-storied gallery ablaze with light to show off bright quilts and weavings, gleaming silver and pewter, pottery, stuffed toys, baskets, wooden bowls, furniture, jewelry and all manner of handmade items. It is a sure sign that the annual Celebration of American Crafts is under way. The 18th edition of this invitational juried exhibition and sale, which runs through Dec. 23, offers the work of some 200 craftsmen from around the country.

title: Miss Karmin Wed To E. D. Strauss
description: Elizabeth Anne Karmin and Emanuel David Strauss, who are both lawyers in Boston, were married last evening at the Cosmos Club in Washington. Rabbi Gerald Serotta performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a review Nov. 2 of James Laughlin's ''Selected Poems, 1935-1985'' misattributed a quotation. The lines translated as ''Traveller, there is no road, the road is made when we walk on it'' are by the Spanish poet Antonio Machado.

title: Julie Ann Olson Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James E. Olson of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Ann Olson, to R. Bruce Paterson, the son of Mrs. Edward Jost of Ormond Beach, Fla., and the late Thomas B. Paterson.

title: The Handball High
description: I WAS INTRODUCED TO THE GAME of handball back in 1960, in St. Louis, where I was studying for the priesthood.

title: GRIM STEEL TOWN TURNS BLEAKER IN PACT DISPUTE
description: More than 80 taverns once lined the main avenue here, a mile-long stretch of houses and shops that ends at the entrance of the USX Corporation's Edgar Thomson Works. On paydays, it is said, the sidewalks often overflowed with steelworkers taking advantage of the endless opportunities.

title: SOVIET FINISHING LARGE RADAR CENTER IN SIBERIA
description: The Soviet Union has completed the construction of buildings to house a large new radar center in central Siberia, according to American Government experts.

title: Fuel-Oil Deals Questioned
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigar's Place
description: To the Editor: While in Europe recently, my wife and I were frequently overwhelmed by cigar smoke in some of the finest restaurants, such as L'Oasis in Brussels where five of six people at the next table created blue clouds of fragrant Cuban smog during our very expensive (and otherwise excellent) main course. When our famous chef dropped by to inquire as to our satisfaction, we protested.

title: FEEDING CROWDS OF DINERS EVERY DAY
description: WHEN Ruediger Flick orders 1,000 turkeys, it must be Thanksgiving.

title: Insiders, Ultimate and Otherwise
description: It sounded outrageous, letting Ivan Boesky, the Wall Street manipulator, bail out his fellow investors immediately before the explosive disclosure of his long trail of illegal trading. The Securities and Exchange Commission argues that the shock to securities markets would have been worse if the Government hadn't allowed this ultimate inside deal. Final judgment on the commission's extraordinary grant of grace needs further information. What's not in doubt is the vice and damaging spread of insider trading.

title: FOR A NIGHT, JACK PAAR STEPS BACK IN TIME
description: Jack Paar came into Manhattan early on a recent Sunday morning to tape an NBC television special called ''Jack Paar Comes Home.''

title: EMMA, FLAUBERT AND THE PLEASURE PRINCIPLE
description: THE greater the role that rebellion, violence, melodrama and sex, expertly combined in a compact plot, have played in a novel, the greater its appeal has been to me. In other words, the maximum satisfaction that a novel can bring me is to arouse, as I read, my admiration for this or that revolt against the established order, my anger at some stupidity or injustice, my fascination for melodramatic situations, for excessive displays of emotion that Romanticism seemed to have invented. ''Madame Bovary'' is chock-full of these ingredients, they are the four great rivers that irrigate its vast geography, and the distribution of these contents in the novel reveals the same careful balance as its formal structure.

title:
GARDENING;
WINTER PROTECTION AGAINST RODENTS
description: SQUIRRELS, rabbits and mice often wreak havoc on garden plants as they forage for food during the winter months. There are certain preventive measures that can be taken, however, although sometimes with uncertain results.

title: BONES ARE BURIED IN MOHAWK-METHODIST RITE
description: Six human bones, believed to be anywhere from 100 to 500 years old, were buried yesterday under one of the city's oldest churches in a ceremony that mixed Methodist hymns and Mohawk prayers.

title: The Philharmonic's Archivist at Work
description: ''We have thousands of hours of Philharmonic recordings, scores marked by Gustav Mahler, the minutes of a meeting held to plan the first post-Toscanini season, and some 1,500 cubic feet of different papers,'' Barbara Haws, the archivist and historian for the New York Philharmonic, said recently. ''Now the problem is to order it, to make it all accessible.''

title: Did James Buchanan Deserve His Nobel?
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL SORTS ITS INTERESTS IN OUTCOME OF GULF WAR
description: THE reports that Israel was shipping arms to Iran to help secure the release of American hostages and for its own foreign policy considerations have rekindled debate in Israeli defense circles over whether Israel wants Iran or Iraq to win the Gulf War.

title: Diplomacy on Foot
description: Very modestly, in the last paragraph of its monthly newsletter, the New Zealand Embassy points out that its Ambassador to the United States, Sir Wallace E. Rowl-ing, completed the grueling New York City Marathon Nov. 2.

title: RESTORATION, WITH AN EYE TOWARD BUTLERS, MAIDS AND COOKS
description: ''IN terms of research in historic house museums, there's a lot more work to be done in the area of domestic life from the servant's perspective and the backstairs aspects within large houses,'' Anne-Marie Demetz said one recent morning as she stood in the kitchen at Lyndhurst, the Gothic Revival mansion on the banks of the Hudson River in Tarrytown.

title: BOARD SEEKS TO EASE PACT WITH CON ED
description: THE Board of Legislators last week authorized county officials to begin steps to seek modification of a contract with Consolidated Edison that the legislators say is costing Westchester taxpayers upward of $9 million a year in extra energy costs.

title: Cus D'Amato's 20-Year-Old Champion
description: AFTER only 20 years 4 months and 22 days, Mike Tyson needed only 5 minutes 35 seconds last night to justify what his late mentor, Cus D'Amato, told him several years ago.

title: A NARCOTICS AGENT LIMNS ''THE SYSTEM''
description: WHEN ''The Hero of New York,'' T. Glen Coughlin's first novel, was published last summer, the young man from Freeport was concerned about how his colleagues at a Federal narcotics enforcement agency would react. His fellow agents, he worried, could become self-conscious about working with someone who might be writing down everything they did or said for another book.

title: 'God Bless You' Signs Removed From Buses
description: Holiday fund-raising signs from the Salvation Army saying ''Sharing is caring - God bless you'' have been removed from city buses because of the religious reference.

title: TOP YOUNG PERFORMERS IN CONCERT
description: TWO interesting concerts this afternoon put the emphasis on youth. At 2:30 at the Westport Town Hall are the finals of the 14th annual Young Artists Competition, sponsored by Performers of Connecticut. Pianists and string players will be vying for several cash and performance prizes, and the proceedings are open to the public, with tickets available at the door. Call 227-8998 or 226-1394.

title: FOR VIENNESE, ANOTHER U.S. ENVOY TO TALK ABOUT
description: The Reagan Administration has done an admirable job of sending high-profile ambassadors to Austria - ambassadors who give the Viennese something to talk about.

title: Louisiana St. Stops Notre Dame, 21-19
description: Tom Hodson, a freshman, passed for three touchdowns and Henry Thomas, the nose guard, helped keep Notre Dame's offense out of the end zone until the final 3 minutes 32 seconds as Louisiana State prevailed tonight, 21-19.

title: TO ITS CREATORS, 'SMILE' WAS ALWAYS A BEAUTY
description: Six years, eight producers, two workshops, three book writers, two lyricists, two choreographers and more than $4 million after it originated as a gleam in a producer's eye, the musical ''Smile'' will finally arrive on Broadway tomorrow night at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week: If the day is mild, apply anti-desiccants to valued evergreens. . . .Cut to the ground stalks of rudbeckia, peonies, hostas, astilbes, phlox, monarda and other perennials. . . . Last call to plant deciduous trees. First Frost

title: Inventing a Patent Manual
description: Finding out how to apply for a patent on an invention seems to require almost as much persistence and ingenuity as producing the invention in the first place.

title: Barbara Jean Connolly and William F. Comly Wed
description: At St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., yesterday Barbara Jean Connolly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Connolly of Floral Park, L.I., was married to William Fenimore Comly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Comly 2d of Lambertville, N.J. The Rev. John J. Denninston, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Robert Duncan, a Presbyterian minister.

title: DONOVAN TRIAL SIDESHOW: LAYING BLAME FOR DELAYS
description: After eight weeks of testimony in the fraud trial of former United States Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and eight others, the prosecutor says he is only halfway through his case, and the two sides are blaming each other for delays.

title: Lionel Hampton
description: The vibraphonist Lionel Hampton will lead his big band tonight at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30; there is a $20 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $10 charge at the bar.

title: ZION'S GREAT PERSUADER
description: CHAIM WEIZMANN A Biography. By Norman Rose. Illustrated. 520 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $24.95.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $119,000 1344 Illinois Avenue 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; fireplace, finished basement, sun porch, 1-car attached garage; taxes $2,900. Commack $165,000 19 Larry Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; finished basement, patio, in-ground pool, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800.

title: UPROOTING OF BLACKS RESUMES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's white rulers seem to have revived a policy of removing blacks from one place to another, despite earlier promises that the practice had been stopped, according to civil-rights activists and those affected by the policy.

title: Carolyn G. Lewis And Bruce Quinn Exchange Vows
description: Carolyn Gambrill Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Moody Lewis Jr. of Devon, Pa., and Landgrove, Vt., was married yesterday at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church to Bruce Michael Quinn, a son of Mrs. Bernard J. Quinn of Garden City, L.I., and the late Mr. Quinn.

title: INSIDER TRADING: A MATTER OF TRUST
description: GARY LYNCH, director of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a rule of thumb for defining illegal insider trading. If an investor has reason to suspect - only suspect - that a stock tip is based on private corporate information and that the stock price would be affected if the public knew about it, it would probably be illegal for him to trade in the stock.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: FOUNDATION AND EARTH (Doubleday, $16.95) is Isaac Asimov's 340th or 3,400th book, or something like that. I suspect that no one, including Mr. Asimov, really knows how many books of fiction and nonfiction he has created in his 66 years, although I am inclined to believe Doubleday's claim that this new novel is the hundredth Asimov title to appear under that imprint. More important than mere numbers, anyway, is the ambitious feat of creation that Mr. Asimov has embarked on in recent years. In novels like ''Foundation's Edge'' (1982), ''Robots and Empire'' (1985) and now ''Foundation and Earth'' he has been linking his most important science fictions - the Foundation trilogy, the stories of detection set in the early Galactic Empire and the robot stories - into a single time- and space-spanning work of epic proportions. This would be a titanic labor under any circumstances; it is made still more remarkable by the fact that Mr. Asimov is returning to pick up threads of plot and nuances of character that he dropped, in some instances, as far back as four decades ago.

title:
ART;
UNORTHODOX ARTIST HAS RETROSPECTIVE
description: IN her retrospective exhibition at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill, in Rockland County, Sari Dienes does something out of the ordinary by hanging the several certificates of recognition she has garnered in recent years from institutions in this state and abroad. This display is perhaps the most establishment feature of her whole show.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: INDIAN FEASTS Strictly speaking, an ''Indian Thanksgiving Feast'' has little to do with the Thanksgiving Day we traditionally mark. But since this holiday turns the public's thoughts to Indians, says Doug Winkler, a naturalist at the Garvies Point Museum and Preserve in Glen Cove, it's when nature study sites like his usually introduce visitors to Indian life. So today from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., the preserve, on Barry Drive, shows how the first Long Islanders commemorated their fall harvest: making pottery, building fires and cooking what they reaped. There'll be food sampling; a demonstration of atlatl, an Indian throwing stick; a native-plants walk, and lectures and films on tool technology. Admission is 25 cents. On Friday, the Museum of Long Island Natural Sciences takes visitors to Hoyt Farm in Commack, where from 1 to 3 P.M., under the guidance of that institution's Indian experts, there'll be a similiar ''Native American Thanksgiving.'' Call 632-8230 for registration information. Finally, next Sunday, the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary in Oyster Bay ends the holiday weekend with its family program devoted to Indian lore and life. Call 922-3200 for information. 19TH-CENTURY HOLIDAY Meanwhile, at Old Bethpage Village Restoration, it's Thanksgiving Day business as usual as the ''residents'' of this historic enclave do their mid-19th-century holiday thing. Today and Friday through next Sunday, the villagers pay attention to their fall food preparation, with a special eye toward making their Thanksgiving Day dinner as authentically 1850-ish as possible, complete with the proper foods and table settings and homespun entertainment.

title: '88 HOPEFULS ALREADY BUSY IN RAISING FUNDS FOR OTHERS
description: Two years before the election, 13 Presidential prospects are already active on the fund-raising circuit and have collected millions of dollars through federally registered political action committees.

title: MAGICAL 'BARNUM' AT THE PAPER MILL
description: ''BARNUM'' is not one of the American theater's super musicals. However, from the looks, sound and feel of it at the Paper Mill Playhouse, this could well be the greatest show on earth.

title: THE MAN OF THE HOUSE
description: EARLY LAST MONTH, Speaker of the House Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. banged his gavel for the last time to recess the House of Representatives and retire from the most powerful job in Congress. His successor, to be chosen on Dec. 8, will almost certainly be Representative James Claude Wright Jr., a 63-year-old Texan who has sought power ever since com-ing to Congress 31 years ago.

title: Shriver Just Misses In Navratilova Test
description: The match was a test of wills as well as friendship. Pam Shriver had every intention of showing Martina Navratilova that her makeover was not a cosmetic change - six easy ways to improve your game - but a new found resolve to find her rightful place among the best players in the world.

title: THE SUNBELT STILL LAGS BEHIND ITS NEIGHBORS
description: Among the group's findings on the state of the South were these:

title: NICARAGUA HAS A PROBLEM PRISONER
description: ON a clear morning over southern Nicaragua seven weeks ago, members of a small Sandinista anti-aircraft patrol looked skyward in astonishment. There in broad daylight, only about 3,000 feet above them and coming down, was a lumbering cargo plane, the type used for secret rebel supply runs.

title: New Campaign
description: THINGS haven't always gone smoothly for Herb Brooks since he coached the United States hockey team to victory at the 1980 Olympics, and at times he has seemed to be his own worst enemy. Hired as the coach of the Rangers in 1981, he managed to lead the team to the playoffs three years in a row, but his tenure was punctuated by so many squabbles with players that he was dismissed halfway through the 1984-85 season.

title: BEST SELLER: NOVEMBER 23, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Did James Buchanan Deserve His Nobel?
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: $3 Billion Sought on Bhopal India declared that it would seek at lease $3 billion from Union Carbide for the gas leak that killed 2,300 people in 1984. Page 17.

title: SOUTHERN AUTHOR
description: The author William Bradford Huie, who wrote a series of books about the South of the civil rights era as well as the acclaimed ''The Execution of Private Slovik,'' died, apparently of a heart attack, today at his office in Guntersville. He was 76 years old and had residences here, in Guntersville and in Scottsboro.

title: Reformers From The Corporate World
description: The new social reformers have learned a great lesson: one cannot always help by writing a check.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE EPISODE. By Richard Pollak. (New American Library, $16.95.) Daniel Cooper, an epileptic reporter for a New York daily, awakens one morning from his first grand mal seizure in 25 years unable to remember the events of the preceding day - the day when a goon for a shady real estate developer Cooper has been investigating is murdered, and Cooper's friend, Calhoun Bledsoe, a black Harvard-trained lawyer and rent-strike leader, disappears.

title: U.S. BUDGET RULES ISSUE IN NEW HAVEN SUIT
description: A NEW HAVEN suit against the Reagan Administration could help decide who has the ultimate control over budget making.

title: Beethoven by Perahia and Schnabel
description: Having completed the cycle of Mozart piano concertos, Murray Perahia is now turning his attention to the Beethoven concerted works, with a recording of the Piano Concertos Nos. 3 and 4 (CBS IM 39814), both with the Amsterdam Concertgebouw conducted by Bernard Haitink.

title: Deficit-Cutting, Round One: A $38 Billion Gap
description: In the first skirmish of the struggle to cut the deficit for the 1988 fiscal year, Federal agencies have submitted budget requests that were $38 billion over target. Only the Departments of Energy and Education matched the spending levels recommended by the White House; all the rest said they needed more.

title: Glowing Dancers, Essential Aykroyd
description: Chef Paul Prudhomme's Louisiana Kitchen J2 Communications. Volume I-32 minutes, Volume II-36 minutes. $19.95 each.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GROUP GAIN JEWISH TREASURES
description: When the American Jewish Historical Society received an oval tin canister last month from the widow of Rabbi Edward Klein of New York, ''We found it to be a 146-year-old time capsule of previously unknown documents,'' says Dr. Nathan M. Kaganoff, the society's librarian and a Hebrew scholar.

title: LIBRARIANS SEEK WAYS TO SAFEGUARD THEIR CRUMBLING BOOKS
description: CRUMBLING the brittle pages of a book in her hand, Jan Merrill-Oldham scattered tiny, dry scraps of paper over her office floor. From nearby shelves, she hauled books with collapsing bindings and discolored pages.

title: To Overhaul the Rules on Lookout Procedures for Foreigners
description: To the Editor:

title: Voltaire's Dictum Is Odd Ex Cathedra
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S not difficult to spend money, and sometimes it's not even painful, assuming the money is there to spend. Of course, that proposition doesn't always apply because there are a surprising number of people who believe that it's easier, and less traumatic, to spend money that they don't yet have, and maybe never will.

title: SCHOOL FOR GIFTED: WHERE S.A.T. IS JUST ANOTHER TEST
description: AT the age of 1, Estelle Guilekas was too busy to take naps like the other toddlers in the neighborhood. She was reading books - voraciously.

title: Jennifer Ehrhard, Hospital Official, Plans to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Louis Edward Ehrhard Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Wright Ehrhard to Alan Hammond Nichols Jr., a son of Mrs. John P. Renshaw of Hillsborough, Calif., and Mr. Nichols of San Francisco. A March wedding is planned.

title: TO THE FAR RIGHT OF APARTHEID
description: THE EMBLEMS EVOKE MEM-ories of evil. In a circle of white surrounded by red, a kind of three-legged black swastika seems inspired by the principle totem of Nazism. The scarlet banners on the stage of Durban City Hall provide the setting for a huge silvery eagle, cobalt blue under the spotlights, perched on the same three-legged symbol.

title: FOR THE HOMELESS, HOLIDAY MEALS
description: IN THE darkened corridor of the Salvation Army Community Center here, William Lovett plays an out-of-tune piano whose sound echoes through the makeshift cafeteria.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Dressing for the Occasion ''THIS is definitely a different type of clientele - there's no screamers here,'' said Anthony Bua of Port Jefferson as he surveyed the crowd at the Suffolk Offtrack Betting Corporation's special Tel-a-Race center in Hauppauge. Mr. Bua, who said he had seen his fair share of the inside of OTB parlors, was impressed with the atmosphere and accouterments of the Hauppauge OTB facility.

title: Drug Test Issue Halts Customs Agent Hiring
description: The United States Customs Service said Friday that it was instituting a hiring freeze for 3,000 positions the the campaign against incoming narcotics because a Federal judge had overturned the agency's employee drug testing program.

title: Oklahoma Rallies and Earns Berth in Orange Bowl
description: It was a comeback fitting for such a long and emotional rivalry. Struggling for most of the contest, and down by a touchdown with just over four minutes remaining, the Oklahoma Sooners snatched the Big Eight championship from the grasp of the Nebraska Cornhuskers today with a furious rally that ended in a 20-17 victory before 73,198 shocked spectators.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ARTS AT SARAH LAWRENCE
description: Since it first brought the actor Ben Kingsley to the Sarah Lawrence campus in 1983, the O'Neil Fund for Enrichment of the Arts has sponsored the appearance of distinguished performers in theater, music and dance at the Yonkers college each year.

title: ANGOLAN WAR TAKING A TOLL ON CIVILIANS
description: In a gaily decorated nursery here, a pegboard hangs with miniature pink sweaters and miniature blue jackets.

title: DEALERS SEEK OLD TREASURES FROM EUROPE'S COUNTRY MANORS
description: WHILE most antique dealers buy at local estate sales and auctions, there are others who go abroad, develop sources and ship quantities of items direct from Europe. Shoppers seek them out for their specialties.

title: MAking the Most of Margin Accounts
description: A BY-PRODUCT of two recent financial developments - falling interest rates and a rising stock market - has been an increase in the use of margin account buying, or borrowing against one's stock portfolio.

title: Observing The Formalities
description: EVENING CLOTHES USED to be ''like Fords,'' a fashion critic once observed. ''It was a point of pride that the model was seldom changed.''

title: Buying a Fur
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY DISPLAY OF ART GIFT ANGERS ALLENTOWN RESIDENTS
description: On Philip I. Berman's antique Marquis of Bath partners desk here is a small wood plaque telling visitors, ''Be reasonable: Do it my way.''

title: DAY CARE IN WORKPLACE TO BE TRIED IN STAMFORD
description: SINCE their son, Tommy, was born three years ago, Michael and Carol Dosdall have placed him in three different day-care settings, ranging from a day-care center to leaving him at home with a baby sitter. But recently the sitter told the Dosdalls she was getting another job, so their day-care search has begun again, ''for the fourth time,'' said Mr. Dosdall with a tired sigh.

title: BUILDING PLANS DISPUTED
description: THE owner is in Ireland, and the building inspector has retired to Florida, but actions taken by both men before they left Tarrytown have, in the words of one resident, ''torn this town apart.''

title: BLACK, WHITE, MEAN AND LOONY
description: JUJITSU FOR CHRIST By Jack Butler. 208 pp. Little Rock, Ark.: August House. $14.95.

title: From Ghent, a Mustard Known in Napoleon's Day
description: Beyond its art and architectural treasures, the Belgian city of Ghent is famed as a center of traditional Flemish cuisine. And today, with ''la cuisine de grand-mere'' enjoying a renaissance in Belgium, as well as in the rest of Europe and the United States, it has become a visiting spot for those interested in fine food.

title: A SPECIAL THANKS ON THANKSGIVING
description: FOR most people, Thanksgiving comes only once a year, but the Inkster family of this Gloucester County community celebrates the spirit of Thanksgiving every day.

title: Headliners; Back in the Arms of the Law
description: It could be that after their criminal convictions, Ronald J. McIntosh and Samantha Dorinda Lopez were simply trying to make honest people of each other. Mr. McIntosh and Miss Lopez, lovers who recently staged a flashy prison escape in a hijacked helicopter, were recaptured last week when they arrived to pick up wedding rings at a California shopping mall. Mr. McIntosh had paid for the rings with a check from an account Federal investigators were monitoring. The authorities had been pursuing the pair since Nov. 5, when Mr. McIntosh, having escaped from one Federal prison, hijacked a helicopter and plucked Miss Lopez from another prison. As they were driven away separately last week, Mr. McIntosh leaned out of a car window and yelled, ''I love you!''

title: CONGRESS WEIGHS TAKEOVER CURBS IN EFFORT TO STEM INSIDER TRADING
description: A wave of Congressional action is building to curb attempted takeovers of America's largest corporations in the wake of the Ivan F. Boesky insider-trading scandal on Wall Street.

title: S. Frank Raftery, 68, Painters' Union Chief
description: S. Frank Raftery, a former president of the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades, died Thursday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Outdoors; Deer Guidebook Is a Trophy for Hunters
description: ONE cannot learn to be a successful deer hunter from books, but they will help the neophyte avoid obvious mistakes and often remind the veteran of some aspect of deer behavior that he had forgotten.

title: SNAPSHOT OF A BILLION YEARS
description: RISING FROM THE PLAINS By John McPhee. 214 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: Playing Politics
description: Combining the play with the politics of the game is an undertaking that, however meritorious, isn't calculated to do anything good for one's play. Yet that is what Lev Alburt has done.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CAREER NETWORKING
description: IN the old days, before personal computers and the Women's Movement, networking was primarily a male activity, undertaken in all-male social and dining clubs. But now computers can electronically link hundreds of strangers via bulletin boards, and women are breaking down the barriers of the once-male domains. The result is a profusion of professional networks through which men and increasingly women of all occupations trade business cards, information, advice and referrals.

title: A Postal Card
description: The United States Postal Service will issue a 14-cent postal card Dec. 12 to commemorate the 350th anniversary of the National Guard. The first day of issue ceremony will be held at Faneuil Hall in Boston, Mass.

title: Sir James Cashes In His Goodyear Chips
description: Sir James Goldsmith ended his bid for Goodyear after the company agreed to buy back his shares at a $93 million profit for the British financier, a sum that had some analysts intimating greenmail. Sir James, in fact, said he was getting a good price - $49.50 a share. Goodyear also said it would buy back 40 million shares at $50 each; Sir James had offered $49 a share. The buyout surprised analysts, since days earlier Sir James had told a Congressional committee that Goodyear was squandering funds and that he could rescue it. Goodyear's chairman, Robert E. Mercer, who had been fiercely resisting Sir James, countered that people like Sir James are plunderers.

title: IN SEARCH OF SOLIDARITY IN PITTSBURGH
description: OUTSIDE the entrance to the Edgar Thomson Works, the sprawling USX Corporation plant here, Ralph Rich recalled the great steel strike a generation ago, in 1959, when a million blue-collar workers were idled for 116 days and many people across the country feared that the walkout would trigger a recession. Only an order by the United States Supreme Court got the plants back in operation.

title: GNOME OF VIENNA
description: THE AFTERNOON SUN By David Pryce-Jones. 214 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title:
ART;
TAKING RISKS ON SCULPTURE
description: THE six sculptors whose works are featured in the current exhibition at the Sabbeth Art Gallery of the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove all happen to be women, but their sex has little to do with their art. One questions whether it is indeed appropriate to single out women for a show of this kind, except that it serves to remind us of the fact that three-dimensional forms of expression are attracting more and more female artists.

title: 6-LP Set, 'The Voice,' Samples Sinatra Years on Columbia
description: The coincidence is curious, so let's get it over with quickly:

title: ASKING CHILDREN QUESTIONS
description: FOR AS long as most of us can remember, children have been asked the mind-numbing question, ''What do you want to be when you grow up?''

title: FOR FUN, ADULTS TURN TO MUSIC LESSONS
description: AFTER working all day at Aetna Life and Casualty in Hartford and then taking graduate courses at night, Joanne Gillen is ready to call it a day.

title: FRANKENSTEIN MEETS THE ARENA PLAYERS
description: SINCE Mary Shelley wrote her brilliant frightmare ''Frankenstein,'' her long-suffering creature has been the subject of at least 10 movies ranging from the Boris Karloff version to films with titles that speak for themselves, such as ''Frankenstein Meets the Space Monster.''

title: DATA UPDATE: November 23, 1986
description: VALUE OF REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS (in millions of dollars) JuneMayJune 85 -------Bronx#74.68 57.07#39.80 Brooklyn#2 31.59#196.24#143.95 Manhattan#388. 44#456.10#335.56 Queens >239.31#339.35#204.85 Staten Island#90.28 91.98#78.99 Total 1024.30#1140.73#803.14 Source: Survey Data Security Corp. MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES(Averages)

title: TREATED WATER STUDIED
description: A STUDY of a United States Geological Survey pilot program indicates that treated sewage water could be recharged into the ground water for drinking in Nassau County. But the study found that the cost would be high.

title: IMMIGRATION LAW SET OFF DISPUTE OVER JOB RIGHTS FOR LEGAL ALIENS
description: A dispute has erupted over a key provision of the new immigration law, which for the first time prohibits employers from discriminating against legal aliens.

title: CITADEL'S CADETS FEELING EFFECTS OF A KLAN-LIKE ACT
description: Late Friday, as on every Friday, the cadet corps of The Citadel gathered on the parade field, and as the shadows of the battlements atop the barracks were cast toward them by the setting sun, they flashed their rifles, lowered the American flag, and white or black, marched to ''Dixie.''

title: JURY DELIBERATES IN FRIEDMAN CASE
description: A jury began deliberating today in the Federal case against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and three co-defendants on charges stemming from the New York City corruption scandal. At 5 P.M., after seven hours, the jury recessed for the day.

title: Monsignor Farrell Is in Metro Bowl
description: Monsignor Farrell, the Catholic High School football champion, has two weeks to celebrate its league championship and prepare for the Metro Bowl, where it will face the winner of the Jackson-Wagner P.S.A.L. final next Saturday.

title: 44 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 44 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Hits and Errors
description: THOMAS JEFFER-son, who preferred to be remembered on his gravestone as an author, fighter against religious intolerance and educator (not as George Washington's Secretary of State or as President of the United States), is being falsely accused of a serious grammatical lapse. I rise to his defense.

title: KINNOCK PREPARES FOR A U.S. MISSION
description: Neil Kinnock, who hopes to lead the Labor Party back to power in the coming year, is about to do a little campaigning in the United States. He will try to persuade Americans that his party's promise to remove all nuclear weapons from Britain could serve the interests of the Western alliance.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
OPERA THRIVES ON LIBRARY STAGE
description: If opera doesn't catch on as a staple of suburban culture, it won't be because the Island Lyric Opera hasn't tried to convert the wary. For the last nine years, the small company has had voices, costumes and sets - and has traveled from local library to local library spreading the word and the music.

title: Bringing Home A Slam
description: The extent of bridge activity in the Soviet Union, which officially frowns on the game, has always been a minor mystery. Some light has been shed in the past two years by Uno Viigand, an expert from Estonia, an area with a bridge tradition.

title: SYNCHROTRON AND HIGH-TECH
description: MORE than 30 high-technology companies descended on the Brookhaven Laboratory's National Synchrotron Light Source recently to discuss major manufacturing artillery and a fight against Europe and Japan for international dominance in the supercomputer market, which is expected to become a major industry the 1990's.

title: Head of Renault Murdered in Paris
description: As Georges Besse, the president of Renault, approached his home in the Montparnasse section of Paris last week, two young women with pistols shot him to death and fled on foot, according to witnesses.

title: ARTFUL L.A.
description: IN A BURST OF CIVIC EUPHORIA tinged with skepticism, the slowly maturing metropolis of Los Angeles seems about to take a great leap forward as a center for contemporary art. With a largesse that befits a city its size, it has spawned not one, but two new facilities for the art of our time, at last contributing to the worldwide museum explosion that has planted new buildings for new work in cities from Fort Lauderdale to Cologne to Tokyo. Today, in fact, the Los Angeles County

title: ABUSE FOUND IN OLDER COUPLES
description: A new study of family violence and older Americans has found that the elderly are much more likely to be physically or verbally abused by their spouses than by their children.

title: Defending Diesels
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TOWN EVERYBODY LOVES TO HATE
description: CITY OF NETS A Portrait of Hollywood in the 1940's. By Otto Friedrich. Illustrated. 495 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $25.

title: POSTINGS: Conversion; 1890's Into 1980's
description: The Dixon Ticonderoga Company moved its worldwide headquarters out of Jersey City two years ago, but the company, the nation's leading maker of writing instruments, which set up shop there in 1847, apparently left an indelible impression.

title: Brussels
description: To the Editor: I think it would be worth adding the Museum of Antique Instruments to an itinerary in Brussels (Travel, Aug. 17).

title: Recent Sales
description: Jackson $101,900 56 Vermont Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; fenced-in yard, garage; taxes $1,980. Long Valley $159,900 332 Fairmount Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 17-year-old contemporary; wall-to-wall carpeting, family room, patio, wooded lot; taxes $2,178.

title: STUDY IN CONTRASTS: 2 NICARAGUAN COURT CASES
description: On Wednesday afternoon, two prisoners were being interviewed in the offices of the People's Anti-Somocista Tribunal here. Both are charged with aiding the rebels, but their cases could hardly be more different.

title: POSTINGS: For Tudor Fanciers; E. 55th Offering
description: Space in midtown office condominiums sells for $350 to $400 a square foot, but if a company wants a distinctive architectural presence for itself in that part of town, the price can zoom to $600 a square foot.

title: FOR RUMANIA, A VOTE TODAY ON MILITARY CUTS
description: Rumanians from age 14 up will vote Sunday in a national referendum on Nicolae Ceausescu's decision to reduce military spending by 5 percent.

title: BROOKHAVEN SET TO LAUNCH NEW EXPERIMENTS WITH BRIGHTEST LIGHT
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN proposed $18.6 million for this fiscal year's budget for the National Synchrotron Light Source at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, but what the President planned, Congress does not always provide.

title: CAN ARTISTS CONTROL THE WORK THEY'VE SOLD?
description: THE art collectors Ethel Redner Scull and Robert C. Scull bought Jasper Johns's painting ''Out the Window'' in 1960 for $2,250. Two weeks ago, Mrs. Scull sold it at auction for $3.63 million, the highest amount ever paid for a work by a living artist.

title: Art
description: The best exhibition of Conceptual Art in New York this fall is at the New Museum of Contemporary Art through next Sunday. It is called ''A Distant View: One Aspect of Recent Art from Belgium, France, Germany and Holland.''

title: Iran Won't Blow Over
description: Stay the course, Mr. President. Tough out all this noise about Iran. Thanksgiving will be upon us and with the holidays, people will forget. Keep saying you were right to try. Stick by Don Regan and John Poindexter; otherwise your critics will start choosing your Cabinet. Remember, Mr. President, standing firm has always worked for you. And look, according to ABC News, 62 percent of the people still trust you.

title: BALTIMORE MOVES TO SAVE ITS FOLKLORE
description: In the cries of this city's street vendors, who still haul produce on horse-drawn wagons past downtown office towers, Elaine Eff hears the cry of a folk tradition.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Yonkers High-Rises
description: IN response to concerns from environmental groups, the developers of a proposed high-rise condominium and retail complex on the Hudson River in Yonkers have redesigned the project.

title: A FEW OUT-OF-THE-ORDINARY SOURCES FOR GARDENING GIFTS
description: Holiday wish lists, better known as mail-order catalogues, offer gardeners all sorts of enticements. A special selection provided here outline some of the unusual gifts or tools available by mail or purchase that might just fit under or near the tree.$ CLAPPER'S CHRISTMAS CATALOGUE, 1125 Washington Street, West Newton, Mass. 02165. Classic English garden furniture made of solid teak is featured. The wood is durable and weathers to a soft silver-grey. Benches, arm chairs, dining tables and folding steamer chairs are offered. Furniture painted with a white oil paint is also available as are hand tools, aprons and a child's riding tractor.

title: Topics; Radio Overactive; The President, for $1.90
description: President Reagan is a new subscriber to A.T. & T.'s ''900'' call-in service, which permits someone with something to say to make it available for a fee. For $1.90, any radio station, or citizen, can call 1-900-410-8255 and pick up the President's five-minute weekly radio broadcast each Saturday at 12:06 P.M. Eastern time.

title: REFUGEE PROBLEM PERPLEXING CANADA
description: Like the United States, which recently enacted landmark immigration legislation, Canada finds itself wrestling with severe refugee and immigration problems.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: LETTER FROM PRAGUE- VOICES OF A CAPTIVE CITY
description: I WAS on my way to Prague. The visit, early this year, was my first. It was, in part, a private pilgrimage - members of my family had lived there in the 1920's - and in part, a continuing exploration of the state of Czechoslovak literature since Soviet tanks had rolled into the capital in August 1968. As a naturalized American born to Russian emigres in Paris, I have long been concerned with the problems of exile, dissent and the life and work of artists under repressive regimes. And since the Russian invasion, Prague has become a symbol of artistic repression. Yet there is also evidence that a sense of identity and pride has arisen among Czechoslovak writers at home and abroad, a countercurrent of literary vitality, humor and defiance.

title: PRINCETON CENTER PLANS ON HOLD
description: PLANS for a $2 million Center for Jewish Life at Princeton University were put on hold last week with the announcement that Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street trader, had withdrawn a $750,000 pledge to the university.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Saudis and Iranians have reached an agreement that covers oil, an understanding that extends to a broader geopolitical context, the Iran-Iraq war.'' - Bijan Mossavar-Rahmani, former member of the Iranian delegation to OPEC. [ 20:3. ]

title: SUDDENLY, A SLEEPY S.E.C. IS WIDE AWAKE
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission flexed its muscles and pummeled Wall Street with subpoenas last week in another indication that the balance of power between the Government and the financial community is changing.

title: Uncovered Catastrophic Ills of the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: About Cars; Appeal Still Great For Monte Carlos
description: FOR '87, shoppers are going to find a narrower choice in the showrooms, but the gaps will not be widely apparent. While 32 of last year's models have disappeared, 289 variations remain, and they span a greater range than ever.

title: CAN CHRISTMAS BE 'LOST'?
description: ''NOW I've lost Christmas!'' said 12-year-old Laurie, pouting in the chair on the opposite side of my desk. For the third time in a week, she had disrupted her class and her parents had been called with the news of a three-day suspension from school.
