title: Glowing Dancers, Essential Aykroyd
description: Tango Created and choreographed by Oscar Araiz. V.I.E.W. Video. 57 minutes. $49.95.

title:
GARDENING;
WINTER PROTECTION AGAINST RODENTS
description: SQUIRRELS, rabbits and mice often wreak havoc on garden plants as they forage for food during the winter months. There are certain preventive measures that can be taken, however, although sometimes with uncertain results.

title: Separating the Women From the Girls
description: ''PROBABLY enough time has passed since the women's movement started to separate the girls from the women as far as networking goes,'' said Nancy Ford, president of the International Alliance, an association of women's organizations that has just started taking individual members. ''Networks that were started on a flimsy basis have faded away. The networks remaining are here to stay.''

title: Henry James's 'Hugh Merrow'
description: Thank you for publishing Henry James's story ''Hugh Merrow,'' with Cynthia Ozick's interesting commentary, ''A Master's Mind'' (Oct. 26).

title: Whistle Blowing
description: To the Editor:

title: TAIWAN SETS ITS SIGHTS ON WESTERN CAR BUYERS
description: TEH NAN WU is a busy, happy man these days. He manages the Horsy Industrial Company, which operates a small auto parts factory about 20 miles south of Taipei, and his business is hopping. The increase in the value of the Japanese yen has made the Japanese parts that Taiwanese companies usually use very expensive, and has sent manufacturers here scrambling for locally produced components.

title: Cheap Shots Go Unpunished
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Measured Words From the Vatican
description: American Catholics have been worrying aloud for months about the rift between their leaders and those in Rome, but Pope John Paul II made it clear last week that he is not one for airing differences. ''I don't talk, I don't say,'' he replied when pressed for comment about relations between the Vatican and liberal elements in the American Church. ''Sometimes one creates divisions, divisions which don't exist.''

title: Let the Light In
description: To the Editor:

title: Cigars' Place
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the article about cigars and their place in a fine French meal (Travel, Oct. 19). I, too, have been a party to that ritual, merely by being seated in proximity to the cigar smoker. While I am confident that the smokers in question have enjoyed their after-dinner smoke, it has on many occasions ruined a meal for me.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AFRICAN SLAVERY IN LATIN AMERICA AND THE CARIBBEAN. By Herbert S. Klein. (Oxford University, $22.95.) The 12 million Africans brought to North and South America between 1500 and 1860 were essential to the success of plantation economies of the region, and Herbert S. Klein's ''African Slavery in Latin America and the Caribbean'' presents a much needed survey of an institution in no way peculiar to the antebellum South.

title: IN BUSINESS TO TREAT CANCER
description: SITTING IN HER JEF-ferson, La., home, Dale Armand mused on the cancer that had plagued her for seven years. Diagnosed as having breast cancer in 1979, she had undergone a single mastectomy and two years of chemotherapy at the M.D. Anderson Hospital and Tumor Institute of the University of Texas, in Houston, a leading institution for cancer research and therapy.

title: Theater Sells Air Rights
description: The owners of the Belasco Theater, lately often unable to fill the space inside the Broadway house, have found a ready market for the space above it. The Shubert Organization announced last week that it had leased the Belasco's 124,000 feet of unused air rights - the difference between the existing building and the maimum the law would allow on the site - to the builders of an office tower behind the theater.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: IT WAS warm, but nobody could have mistaken it for anything less than a morning in November. Two days of rain had washed autumn out of the hillsides. Browns and grays held all the high ground now.

title: Nancy Morris and Kevin Miller to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Adams Morris Jr. of Plandome Manor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ford Morris to Kevin deWolf Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Hodges Miller Jr. of Munsey Park, L.I. The wedding is planned for April.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SUDDEN FICTION: American Short-Short Stories. Edited by Robert Shapard and James Thomas. (Gibbs M. Smith/Peregrine Smith, $18.95.) It has been widely reported that ours is a society with a diminishing attention span, that modern culture caters to an audience wanting instantaneous entertainment.

title: Gregg Borri Wed To Ms. Williams
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York yesterday Elizabeth Louise Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Wesley Williams of Syracuse, was married to Gregg Joseph Borri, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tullio Joseph Borri of Cranford, N.J. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: JAPAN: THE SPIRITUAL SIDE
description: AT DAWN, THE HOUR OF PRAYER, in the presence of the Buddha's image and amid the sounds of bells, cymbals and chants, the monk Shunko Fukami finds his mind wandering. ''I think about wanting a cup of sake,'' he says. ''I think about my girlfriend.'' He thinks, too, about the small, declining temple he has been assigned to head and all the work to be done before he descends from the mountaintop monastery of Senshu-Gakuin to what he calls ''the earthly world down there.'' The dimly lit prayer room is filled with monks chanting the mantras that are the essence of the universal Buddha's teachings. Still, Fukami's mind wanders, when his concentration lags, when he cannot find his path to the Middle Way - to the level of nothingness, to paradise in this world where all extremes disappear. The monastery, high on Mt. Koya in central Japan, is far removed from the earthly world. Yet the distance is deceptive. The earthly world is a place of desires, but desires are also to be found on the mountaintop. There, however, they exist alongside the tenets of the Shingon-Buddhist faith.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
A Hinterland Yields to Housing Needs
description: FRAMED by the Kittatinny Mountains in the farthest reaches of northwestern New Jersey lies Sussex County, encompassing 528 square miles and 24 communities. Until the late 1940's, the county, long dominated by thick woods, farmland and lakes, was a summer resort where small, flimsy bungalows hugged the edges of lakes.

title: Bringing Thanksgiving Home
description: AMERICAN cooking and ingredients now have a prestige and acclaim that seemed almost unthinkable a decade ago.

title: TEHERAN APPARENTLY GOT BARGAIN
description: The price paid by the Iranians for anti-tank missiles appears to be significantly lower than the usual price for the weapons, judging the Army's testimony to Congress on weapons costs.

title: Henry James's 'Hugh Merrow'
description: In 1899, during the time that Henry James was working on the themes of loneliness, childlessness, sexual ambiguity and lost experience that figure in ''Hugh Merrow,'' he acquired a sculpture of a young boy. He discovered this work in the Roman studio of the sculptor Hendrik Christian Andersen, one of the ''artistic young men'' that he ''was at various times attracted to.''

title: Sarah C. Cecil Weds a Fellow Writer, C. S. Williams, at Her Parents' Home
description: Sarah Carter Cecil, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Cumming Cecil of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Sewall Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Sewall Williams of Waitsfield, Vt., and Small Point, Me. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed an Episcopal ceremony at the Cecil home.

title: Raccoon Coats Are Still Going to the Game
description: GONE forever are the single-wing formation and leather helmets. But those who yearn for college football the way it used to be might find solace among the fans of Yale, who haven't forgotten how to dress for a fall gridiron classic.

title: JOE CACACI, PLAYWRIGHT, DOES THINGS THE UNUSUAL WAY
description: IT is not usual for a new playwright to negotiate the rights to his own play, but then Joe Cacaci, a producer-actor-director who recently turned playwright, does not do things the usual way.

title: London
description: ''A sad tale's best for winter,'' Shakespeare advised his countrymen. And, lo, Londoners have one in the timelessly sad expression on the face of the Lindow Man. He is an archeological aberration, an ancient murder victim found well preserved in a bog three years ago in the county of Cheshire and now the museum cynosure of this season. Garroted and as pained looking as a Munch portrait, Lindow Man is packing the British Museum. Visitors are advised to join the family crowds to eavesdrop (''Who did it, Mum?'') as much as to see poor Lindow. He rests, freeze-dried, amid a fine display of the finds of British archeologists in the past 40 years, one of the richest periods of all, it turns out, and well worth the $2.25 special charge in this great and otherwise free museum.

title: North Korea's Leader Survives Death Reports
description: North Korea and South Korea do not say much to each other, and when they do communicate it can be hard to know who is telling the truth.

title: A Federal Finger of Blame
description: The Reagan Administration recently issued a report on federalism that denounced encroachments by the national Government on the states. But something was missing.

title: The Bowl Calendar
description: Sat.Dec. 13 California Bowl At Fresno, Calif. Miami (O.) (8-3) vs. San Jose St. (9-2), 5:30 Sat. Dec. 20 Independence Bowl At Shreveport, La.

title: Restoring Lost Heritage
description: For 50 years, beginning before 1900, traveling experts from the Library of Congress recorded on wax cylinders the songs, dances and stories of many American Indian tribes in their communities. Now, after long years in the vaults, the library's American Folklife Center has had this music and these narratives electronically filtered and transferred to cassette tapes, which are being distributed to a new generation of the tribes that produced them, one that is often keenly interested in =reviewing its historical heritage.

title: Ms. Young Plans January Wedding
description: Maj. Gen. Kendall Salisbury Young, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Young of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Howland Young to Charles Edward Skupien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Karol Skupien of Chicago.

title: SKETCHING THE WYETH DYNASTY
description: Jamie Wyeth, a barefoot 40-year-old in khaki shorts, shirt, vest and paint-stained apron, greeted a visitor a few weeks ago with his characteristic open grin. Sunlight flooded the enclosed porch of his summer home on Monhegan Island off the Maine coast, where, the day before, spray from breakers crashing against the rocks of Lobster Cove had coated the windows with salt. It was a Wyeth scene if ever there was one.

title: Man Slain in Arizona After Shooting 3 Officers
description: A man was shot to death Friday after shooting three police officers, commandeering a car from a 79-year-old woman and holding a 6-year-old boy hostage in a house here for four hours, the authorities said.

title: CAROLINA LAKE BED YIELDING ANCIENT CANOES
description: Almost every time Michael L. Dunn waded into Lake Phelps over the last year it seemed he stumbled onto dugout canoes made by Indians more than 2,000 years ago.

title: CHINATOWN PREPARES A SHELTER FOR THE TEMPORARILY HOMELESS
description: Doris Koo vividly recalls a three-alarm fire that gutted a tenement at 54 Eldridge Street, leaving two people dead and 125 homeless on Jan. 21, 1985, one of the coldest nights of the year.

title: Hmm, What About G.M. + Exxon?
description: THE news on Ivan F. Boesky notwithstanding, mergers and acquisitions (M. and A.'s) and leveraged buyouts (LBO's) will probably remain the hot trend on Wall Street for a couple more years. It's taken for granted that these transactions require nerves of steel and the mind of Morgan the pirate. They also call for the financial acument of Morgan the banker, which entails a lot of number crunching. And these days it also means tying all the data up in nice little bundles of reports so some institution can justify issuing more of that lead-edged paper known as junk bonds.

title: A Costly Cover for a Failing Policy
description: THE dominant theme of foreign aid policy during the Reagan era has been conditionality, the idea that aid should be linked to recipient countries adopting free-market policies. The Administration is right to believe that free markets would solve many of the third world's problems, but wrong to believe that America can or should underwrite free-market policies for other countries.

title: Philadelphia Opera Prepares Audiences
description: The Opera Company of Philadelphia has scheduled a series of events to help audiences prepare for the December performances of Benjamin Britten's ''Death in Venice,'' an opera based on the novella by Thomas Mann.

title: Reading the Way to Picture-Taking
description: IN the dark ages 20 years ago, when I started to learn about photography, the present network of photographic education existed only in rudimentary form. If one wanted to find out about using the tilts on a view camera, metering for the shadows and developing for the highlights, or improving one's sense of composition, the easiest way was to read about it.

title:
ART;
3 ARTISTS' ''SUGESTED IMAGES'' AT DUMONT'S AURORA GALLERY
description: IT IS difficult to define in advance what goes into making a progressive art gallery, but certainly risk-taking is one of the components.

title: MUSIC: MODERN WORKS FROM FRANCE
description: LIKE the Museum of Modern Art and its Vienna 1900 exhibition earlier this fall, another art museum is using music to help define a specific European culture. This time it is the Guggenheim; the subject - ''Angles of Vision: French Art Today.''

title: BRITAIN'S WHOLE EARTH GURU
description: DISCOVERING A nest of gleaming technology deep in the countryside can be a delightful surprise, much like finding a flower bed in the middle of a busy city. Not far from a river in St. Giles-on-the-Heath, a hamlet on the Cornwall-Devon border in southwestern England, stands the laboratory of James E. Lovelock, a white, windowed cabin attached to his house and patrolled outside by half a dozen peacocks. A phalanx of spectroscopes, radiation detectors and microcomputers set incongruously in a fragrant meadow, the lab seems like a probe sent to unravel the secrets of nature.

title: A SPONSOR FOR THE TEACHER?
description: NOW that educators have honed in on why Johnny can't read, it's high time they understood why Johnny can't stay awake in class. After 13 years as a classroom teacher, I know why. ''The Cosby Show'' is No. 1 and we teachers don't even make the top 20.

title: Fumbles Trip Up Hofstra
description: Hofstra demonstrated again today that it is an outstanding second-half team, scoring three late touchdowns against Montclair State. But that finish proved unavailing: Three fumbles by the Flying Dutchmen led to a 21-0 Indian lead before Hofstra mounted its unsuccessful comeback late in the third quarter.

title: Alice Tenney to Wed Bernard Wiesenberg
description: A February wedding is planned by Alice Tenney and Bernard Wiesenberg, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Warren S. Tenney of Rye, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Wiesenberg is the son of Marion Walldorf of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Herbert Wiesenberg.

title: The Shovel Brigade
description: One of the least admirable, if often effective, traits of the Reagan White House has been its preoccupation with the appearance rather than the substance of things. But it was nevertheless rare and revealing to hear Donald Regan, the bumptious chief of Presidential staff, admit and even boast of this public relations approach.

title: Not His and Hers -- Ours
description: ON the third day of our second honeymoon (second for him, second for me, first for the two of us together), my husband and I found the Connecticut house we had dreamed of: small, near enough to the water so that portholes would have seemed appropriate, far enough from the neighbors so that shades did not, and almost affordable.

title: LEGISLATORS STUDY WAYS TO STIMULATE PRODUCTIVITY
description: WITH the opening of the 1987 General Assembly still more than a month away, the new House and Senate leaders are already considering ways to make the legislature more productive.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: WORLD'S FAIR, by E. L. Doctorow. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) E. L. Doctorow's hybrid of novel and memoir is told from the point of view of Edgar Altschuler, a boy growing up in the Bronx in the 1930's, and follows him from babyhood through age 9, when he visits the World's Fair of 1939. As an amalgam of fiction, biography and oral history, the novel ''has a fractured and inconsistent feel to it,'' David Leavitt wrote here last year. But in the ''breathtaking final 100 pages,'' he said, Edgar's meticulous account of the fair is ''dizzying in its specificity,'' and Mr. Doctorow ''conveys perfectly the extent to which a fair becomes a world unto itself.'' THE SOCIAL HISTORY OF THE MACHINE GUN, by John Ellis. (Johns Hopkins University, $8.95.) John Ellis traces the development of the machine gun from its beginnings in the 1860's to the trenches of World War I and into the gangster haunts of Al Capone, Baby Face Nelson and the Barker gang - who, we are told, really did carry theirs in violin cases. Arguing that the history of technology is inseparable from social history in general, Mr. Ellis weighs the machine gun's impact on weaponry, warfare and society in 19th- and 20th-century Europe and America, and suggests that it precipitated the modern arms race. In 1976 our reviewer, Trumbull Higgins, called the book ''a brief but brutal tract for our times.'' FROM THE FIFTEENTH DISTRICT, by Mavis Gallant. (G. K. Hall, $5.95.)

title: Carol A. Morrison Plans to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Morrison of Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Anthony Morrison to Robert David Shiels, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marion Shiels of Fort Worth. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE 'NUTCRACKER' CASTS ITS SPELL ONCE MORE
description: IN LATE October, when audition notices for ''The Nutcracker'' are posted, the atmosphere in ballet studios takes on a frenzied and delerious quality.

title: GROUPS TO HEAR 'CHILDREN OF WAR'
description: IN honor of eight teen-age representatives of the 1986 Children of War Tour due here this Thanksgiving week, town officials of Greenwich, Stamford, Norwalk and Darien have proclaimed it ''Children of War Week.''

title: The Syrian Terror Machine
description: The sandstorm kicked up by the Iranian affair threatens to obscure the central question concerning international terrorism: who stands behind it?

title: LOOKING AT ROME FROM INSIDE OUT
description: When in Rome if you really want to do as the Romans, you might begin by staying in a housekeeping apartment instead of a hotel. It may not be easy to get a pleasant apartment just for a week or two. Try anyway.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Vermont Maps For Rare Species VERMONT has put endangered species on the map.

title: NEW WAVE OF DISCONTENT UNSETTLES VIRGIN ISLANDS
description: BEYOND the world defined by hordes of cruise ship passengers descending on the duty-free bargains in sun-dazzled waterfront shops, the people of the American Virgin Islands are trying to digest the results of last week's election, the most divisive in the territory's recent history.

title: REVISED CRITERIA FOR PRINCIPALS ARE CRITICIZED
description: THE mood was decidedly negative as 700 members of the New Jersey Principals and Supervisors Association, at their annual convention here this month, discussed a key component of a proposal by the state's Department of Education to revise licensing requirements for their profession.

title: EAGER ALIENS ARE SEEKING DETAILS ON NEW AMNESTY LAW
description: MANY of the illegal aliens in Connecticut, a group concentrated in Fairfield County and estimated to number as high as 10,000, want to know how to gain legal status under the new Federal immigration law. Experts do not yet know what to tell them.

title: ACTOR GOT START IN SPEAKEASIES
description: Scatman Crothers, best known to television viewers as Louie the garbage collector on ''Chico and the Man,'' died of cancer today. He was 76 years old.

title: 3 UPSTATE COUNTIES MAY QUIT M.T.A.
description: Three counties in the Hudson Valley - Dutchess, Orange and Rockland - are considering withdrawing from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority because they say they are paying too much for the rail service they receive.

title: JERRY COLONNA, 82, COMIC AND BOB HOPE'S FOIL
description: Jerry Colonna, a comic actor whose trademarks were his wide, rolling eyes, walrus mustache and bellowing, opera-lampooning voice, died of kidney failure Friday at the Motion Picture and Television Country House and Hospital in Woodland Hills. He was 82 years old.

title: Greenwich Beaten By New Canaan
description: Tom Mazzella directed three first-half scoring drives and the New Canaan defense limited Greenwich to 92 total yards as the Rams advanced into the Fairfield County championship by beating Greenwich, 19-6, in Greenwich yesterday. The Rams (8-3) will meet the winner of a late game between Brien McMahon of Norwalk and top-ranked Trumbull High School.

title: Turkish Consulate Is Bombed in Australia
description: A car bomb exploded outside the Turkish Consulate early today, killing one person and injuring another, the police said.

title: Brooke Baldridge Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dickson B. Baldridge of Wilmington, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Brooke Bayard Baldridge, to Daniel Gregory Pelizza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Pelizza of Wallingford, Conn. Miss Baldridge, a graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, is a business analyst for the Travelers Insurance Company in Hartford, where her fiance, a graduate of the University of Hartford, is a systems analyst.

title: COMPANIES SET TO FIGHT IMPORT CURBS
description: FOREIGN-owned companies operating in Connecticut and domestic companies exporting products overseas are getting ready to resist efforts when Congress reconvenes in January to use trade restraints to cut the nation's imbalance.

title: Dar Robinson, Stuntman, Dies
description: Dar Robinson, the holder of more than 21 world stunt records, died Friday while filming a stunt for the movie ''Million Dollar Industry,'' a film spokesman said. He was 39 years old.

title: Syria Is Linked To Berlin Bombing
description: The purported Syrian connection to terrorism was explored again in court testimony in Europe last week.

title: ENVOY ASSERTS U.S. MISLED THE IRAQIS ON IRAN SHIPMENTS
description: The State Department apparently misled the Iraqi Government for years about Israel's arms shipments to Iran, according to Iraq's Ambassador in Washington and accounts from present and former American officials.

title: LEARNING ENGLISH FROM A CO-WORKER
description: WHEN Maria Poprawski first came to this country from Poland, the only words she could say in English were ''Good morning'' and ''How are you?'' That was five years ago. Today Mrs. Poprawski speaks nearly fluent English, with only the barest of hesitation, and she is looking forward to earning her nursing license.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WILD BLUE. By Walter J. Boyne and Steven L. Thompson. (Crown, $19.95.) This is a behemoth novel that tells of six Air Force officers, all obsessed with flight.

title: WATER PROBLEMS EMERGING ACROSS ISLAND
description: WATER conservation, a concern long as foreign to water-rich Long Island as energy conservation once was, has risen to the top of the public agenda because of signs that ground-water aquifers in densely developed areas are being drawn down faster than nature can fill them back up.

title: THE CURSE OF ISADORA
description: Isadora Duncan has long been tutelary patron of American ''modern,'' ''post-modern,'' ''post-post-modern'' dance. Idiosyncratic free-flowing movement, frequently considered the alternative to classic academic ballet, now tries to salvage its casual improvisation by plugging multimedia, speech and cinema, while masters and mistresses of this etiolated exercise imagine themselves not dancers alone, but dance designers and stage directors. The exposure of a private personage's unique sensibility has merged into an almost faceless morass of small mutations.

title: BRINGING A VISION OF 'NUTCRACKER' TO THE SCREEN
description: Could a ballet be a movie? Should a ballet be a movie? Didn't the requirements of one form violate those of the other? These disquieting questions occurred to me when the possibility of a ''Nutcracker'' movie finally became a certainty. They did not, however, shake my conviction that ''Nutcracker'' is the exception to every rule; it is not a proper ballet (ask any dancer) but rather a delightful mishmash of fairy tale, mime and dance all threaded through with perhaps the best ballet score ever composed. Interpreters had to take liberties with it - historically, they always did. With the right director, there was every good reason to try to make a movie. And with Carroll Ballard, who directed ''The Black Stallion,'' committed to the project, we were in the best of hands.

title: Cigar's Place
description: To the Editor: I much appreciated Gordon Mott's hymn to the glories of the after-dinner cigar.

title: VERSATILE WAYS TO FILL THE TURKEY'S MAIN HOLIDAY ROLE
description: DOES anyone consume turkey for turkey's sake at Thanksgiving? In my experience, the turkey's major role is one of handy receptacle for the stuffing. A good stuffing to fill the bird - and, indeed, to overflow it so that again as much must be baked alongside in a casserole - is the most eagerly awaited part of a Thanksgiving dinner in our house. Rarely are there leftovers.

title: Richard Madden Weds Paula Mooney
description: Paula Diana Mooney and Richard James Madden were married yesterday at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York by the bride's uncle, Acting Judge Carmine C. Marasco of New York County Civil Court.

title: Silver Coin Sales to Begin
description: The United States Mint, which has been impressed by the runaway success of its new American Eagle gold coins, will start selling silver bullion coins today. Based on early projections, it appears the new American Eagle silver coins will also be highly sought after.

title: The Hollow Center
description: Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, a man not given to easy rhetoric, was talking about President Reagan's dealings with Iran. ''I think the President was not fully aware,'' he said, ''or informed, or capable of assimilating all the information his staff gave him.''

title: Sharon Jacobs Is the Bride of Dr. Andrew Goldenberg
description: At Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., yesterday Sharon Jacobs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo H. Jacobs of Long Beach, L.I., was married to Dr. Andrew Goldenberg, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Goldenberg of Bloomfield, Conn.

title: GROUP OF BLACKS WANTS TO ELECT MORE OFFICIALS
description: More than 200 elected officials, community activists and others, gathering in a daylong convention in Brooklyn, called for stepped-up efforts to bolster political representation for the black community in New York City.

title: Litigation on Litigation
description: As head of the Public Citizen Litigation Group, one of the progeny of Ralph Nader, Alan B. Morrison can normally be observed, in and out of the courts, flailing away at the giant corporations in behalf of the common man. But, in a case the Supreme Court has agreed to hear on Mr. Morrison's petition, involving Louisiana's right to deny nonresidents admission to its bar, Mr. Morrison has been joined by his normal adversaries.

title: Margaret Mills, Piano, At Merkin Concert Hall
description: Margaret Mills's piano recital last Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall was most notable for two world premieres - Richard Wilson's ''Intercalations'' and Anthony Newman's ''Variations and Fugue on B-A-C-H'' - both commissioned by the pianist.

title: J.P. McCONNELL, EX-AIR FORCE CHIEF OF STAFF, DIES
description: Gen. John Paul McConnell, retired, a former Air Force Chief of Staff and vice commander of the Strategic Air Command, died of cancer Friday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 years old.

title: U.S. VOICES PRAISE FOR AQUINO ACTION
description: The Reagan Administration moved quickly today to reaffirm its ''strong and unequivocal support'' for President Corazon C. Acquino of the Philippines and for her decision to dismiss Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile.

title: A Citicorp Deal Is Overturned
description: A Federal Court of Appeals has set aside an order by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation that would have let Citicorp acquire the National Permanent Bank in Washington.

title: Jackson Meets Students At Citadel for Talks
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met today with about 30 black cadets at The Citadel to discuss recent racial problems at the state-supported military school.

title: Peter Scott Posner Wed To Patricia A. Firestone
description: Patricia Anne Firestone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Firestone of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I., and Peter Scott Posner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Posner of Cedarhurst, L.I., and Manhattan, were married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony.

title: Books; Crossed Stars
description: JOE & MARILYN. A Memory of Love. By Roger Kahn. 269 Pages. William Morrow. $16.95. WHEN Roger Kahn was covering the Brooklyn Dodgers for The New York Herald Tribune, a pitcher named Billy Loes was famous for his theory that he never wanted to win 20 games in one season because then everybody would expect it of him all the time.

title: CRACK BURDENING A JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: From precinct houses to prisons, the criminal justice system in New York City is bulging and straining to cope with the rise of crack.

title: CUBANS GUARD U.S. OILMEN IN ANGOLA
description: Oily orange flames burned from Chevron's offshore wells here and a Cuban officer watching from a distance allowed a trace of a smile to cross his face.

title: SUNTRUST'S FLORIDA AMBITIONS
description: Here at the gleaming skyscraper headquarters of Suntrust Banks Inc., the bank holding company's top executives often wondered whether Suntrust's Florida banking operations could be even remotely as successful as its Georgia bank.

title: Market Place; Analysts Differ Over A.T.&T
description: ''A FLIGHT to quality'' is how Wall Street experts explained the strong rally in blue-chip stocks late last week in the wake of a widening Government investigation into the insider trading scandal. Earlier, the entire market was rocked by the news that Ivan F. Boesky, the biggest speculator in takeover stocks, had agreed to return $50 million in profits and pay a $50 million penalty for illegal insider trading.

title: Albert Frank Agency Adds 3 New Accounts
description: Albert Frank-Guenther Law has announced three recently won accounts: Bear, Stearns & Company, the investment banker, for which it will be doing ''tombstone'' advertising; Frank B. Hall Insurance, which previously handled its own advertising, and Tropich, an Argentine winery that will be introducing its products in the United States.

title: ESPOSITO BLASTS THE BIKES
description: PHIL ESPOSITO has a theory about why the Rangers have run out of gas so often this season. It was not because the players couldn't stand Ted Sator, not because they were going through the motions, and it certainly wasn't because of lack of talent.

title: REAGAN FRIENDS SAID TO ASK CHANGES
description: Some longtime political supporters of President Reagan have discussed how to engineer high-level staff changes at the White House and in the Cabinet in the hope of repairing political damage that he has sustained because of Washington's dealing with Iran, a close confidant of the President said today.

title: A Chance At Arms Control
description: Americans traveling abroad since the midterm elections, as I have been doing, are besieged with questions about the impact of the results on American foreign policy. Yet we Americans cannot agree among ourselves on whether foreign policy issues affected the election outcome and how President Reagan's political fortunes will fare in the next two years.

title: Doing Business in China
description: Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, who recently led a Senate delegation to China, found that, in business relations, the Chinese appear to have a strong preference for dealing with Americans over the Japanese. The reason, he wrote in his report on the visit, is that even though the Japanese invest much time, effort and manpower in their Chinese sales efforts, they do not set up joint ventures or share technology.

title: IN THE LONG RUN, IT'S MARTIN
description: George Martin describes himself as ''an old man,'' and in the world of pro football perhaps that is so. He is the Giants' oldest player by age, 33, and seasons of service, 12, both unimportant facts in the last minute of the first half here today.

title: NEW DEFENSE CHIEF HAS RIGHT RESUME FOR THE JOB
description: Rafael M. Ileto, who became Defense Minister of the Philippines today only minutes after President Corazon C. Aquino accepted the resignation of Juan Ponce Enrile, has in many ways been preparing for this job all his professional life, according to those who know him.

title: IN APPALACHIA, SANTA EXPRESS IS ON TIME
description: On a long, high curve outside Bartlick, Va., where the railroad winds through steep canyons smudged with black seams of coal, a woman and two small girls squatted below a narrow rock ledge this morning, tending the dying embers of a trackside fire and waiting for Christmas to come to Appalachia.

title: MICHAEL LEE
description: Michael Lee, a former member of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board and a former sports editor for The Long Island Press, died Saturday night at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN ROSILY FOR LIFE AFTER REAGAN
description: At a Democratic Party meeting humming with a sense of regained momentum and political opportunity, Paul G. Kirk Jr., the party's national chairman, today predicted the dawning of the ''post-Reagan era.''

title: The Domesday Milestone
description: It may have escaped your attention, but the English-speaking world is currently observing the 900th anniversary of the Domesday Book, a sort of combined census, tax roll, land survey and history that William the Conqueror ordered up 20 years after the Battle of Hastings to find out just what and whom he had conquered.

title: L.I.U. ELIMINATED
description: Hartwick and Long Island University proved one more time this afternoon how differently teams sometimes perform when it is time for the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: 2 British Copters Rescue 28 From Sinking Ship Off Ireland
description: Two British helicopters braved snow, rain and 70-mile-an-hour winds to rescue 28 men from a sinking freighter off southern Ireland today.

title: Debate on Debates
description: As the 1986 election recedes into history, the debate over who will run the 1988 Presidential debates is already under way. From early evidence, this sponsorship contest may turn out to be more competitive and arresting than some of the political television that results.

title: Tyson Era Is Now
description: MIKE TYSON'S vocabulary is often as violent as his fists. In discussing his second-round knockout of Trevor Berbick, the new World Boxing Council heavyweight champion talked about how ''I was coming to destroy'' him and ''every punch had a murderous intention.'' Those phrases reflect the flames of his fury. But his lispy, little-boy voice somehow softens their heat. Instead of being repelled, most of his listeners seem to smile at the savage charm of this 20-year-old man-child who has led boxing into a new era. His era.

title: A NEIGHBORHOOD DIVIDED
description: The windows are shuttered tight at the Good Hope Carry-Out at 1350 Martin Luther King Jr. Avenue in the capital's economically depressed Anacostia section. Graffiti scrawlers have used the restaurant's walls as a billboard for their own views and, some say, those of many local residents.

title: 5 Die in Kashmir Avalanche
description: Five people died in an avalanche in Kashmir State, the United News of India reported today, raising the nine-day storm death toll to at least 65. At least 60 people were killed Nov. 14 when a blizzard lashed the Zoji La Pass in Kashmir.

title: TEXT OF AQUINO'S SPEECH
description: Following is the text of President Corazon C. Aquino's announcement today on national television that she was dismissing Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile and asking the rest of her Cabinet to resign:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SIGNS OF THE TIMES

title: 'DREAM BOWL' A GAME AWAY
description: ''What's wrong with moving the Fiesta Bowl?'' said Jim Tarman, Penn State's athletic director, shortly before Bruce Skinner, the executive director of the bowl, announced Saturday that the Nittany Lions would play Miami there - if it remains undefeated - in prime time Jan. 2.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1986
description: The World

title: DESPITE REAGAN ASSERTION, AIDES SAY IRAN STILL PROMOTES TERRORISM
description: Despite President Reagan's assertion that there was no recent evidence of Iranian-backed terrorism against Americans, officials in his Administration say they believe that Iran continues to use terrorism as an important component of its foreign policy.

title: 30.1% Rise In Machine Tool Orders
description: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 30.1 percent in October from the disappointing levels of September, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: BOYS HARBOR: FULFILLING FOUNDER'S DREAM
description: Boys Harbor started 50 years ago as a summer camp for a dozen young victims of the Depression. Today, it is a year-round preschool, after-school and summer program for more than 2,500 underprivileged New York City children each year. But what is really remarkable about Boys Harbor Inc., the Harbor for Girls and Boys, is not its growth or its longevity but the fact that the force behind it is not a social agency or government, but one man.

title: A Minor Detail
description: Like most other recruits who've ever been offered athletic scholarships, Mark Vanelli thought the one he was given in 1980 to play right wing on the Northern Michigan hockey team was for four years. Before his sophomore season, he found out otherwise. He was told that he wasn't good enough to make the squad that year and that his scholarship wouldn't be renewed.

title: Helicopter Plucks Two From a Prison in Rome
description: Two armed men hijacked a Red Cross helicopter, forced the pilot to fly it over a prison courtyard and hoisted two inmates to freedom today, the police reported.

title: Fremantle's Fashions
description: At the America's Cup goings-on in Fremantle, it's getting so that you can't tell the off-hours sailors without a scorecard. And the scorecard had better feature full facial photographs.

title: ACT ONE: CHICAGO, THE FINE ART OF CONDUCTING FEDERAL CASES
description: The Federal indictments of seven Chicagoans on municipal corruption charges is but the first round in what is expected to be yet another long series of charges and ensuing trials. If this case, code-named

title: TOYOTA ADJUSTS ITS STRATEGY
description: On paper, the outlook at the Toyota Motor Corporation is anything but rosy these days. The company is forecasting a 2.3 percent decline in car shipments in the current, 1987, fiscal year and a 4.8 percent drop in revenues. Profits could fall to one-third of their level in the 1986 fiscal year that ended June 30, top executives warn.

title: Hewlett Shows Gain of 23.6%
description: Buoyed by strong international sales and improved order growth, the Hewlett-Packard Company said on Friday that its latest quarterly earnings rose 23.6 percent, to $157 million, or 62 cents a share, from $127 million, or 50 cents a share, a year ago.

title: ZALE TAKES AN OFFER OF $525 MILLION
description: The Zale Corporation, the nation's largest jewelry retailer, gave up a 10-month fight yesterday and agreed to be acquired by Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto and Swarovski International Holdings of Zurich for $50 a share in cash, or a total of $525 million.

title: What the S.A.T.'s Can Do for, and to, a Student
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRIA'S 2 BIG PARTIES SET BACK IN VOTE
description: Voters handed a major setback today to Austria's two largest parties, while a small nationalist party that recently moved sharply to the right achieved stunning gains.

title: Traders Await Economic Sign
description: With Treasury bond yields stuck in the middle of the trading range that has prevailed since April, credit market participants are still waiting for economic developments that are decisive enough to push interest rates either higher or lower.

title: Foul Odors Reported In Jersey and on S.I.
description: Foul odors spread over Staten Island and Bayonne, N.J., yesterday morning but dissipated several hours later, authorities said. As of last night, the sources of the odors had not been determined.

title: NAVRATILOVA WINS IN FINAL
description: If the paper listing all her accomplishments were shredded, there would be enough scraps to give Martina Navratilova a ticker-tape parade. Victories are an obsession, records a means of insuring that people will never be able to talk about the best in women's tennis without mentioning her name. Navratilova's year ended on a winning note yesterday, and the closing credits might have read: To Be Continued.

title: A Panel Divided On Estimate Board
description: A panel named by Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo to study the causes of city corruption is ending its inquiry split on a key issue: whether the Board of Estimate should be restructured.

title: REDSKINS STAY EVEN; COWBOYS SMOTHERED IN FIRST HALF
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -

title: FIGHT ON TRANSFERS MARKS A CONTRAST BETWEEN POLICE GROUPS
description: In the police union's two-week battle against the department's anticorruption plan, minority police groups supported Commissioner Benjamin Ward, pointing up longstanding differences with the predominantly white union.

title: MIAMI POLICE ARE SHAKEN BY THEFT OF SEIZED DRUGS
description: The theft of a quarter of a ton of marijuana from a supposedly secure place in the Miami Police Department compound has shaken the beleaguered police force and stunned the community.

title: MUSIC: CAGE VIA ZEITGEIST
description: THE weather was not kind last Thursday night to the cause of contemporary music.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES AND SENATORS CRITICIZE SHULTZ ON THE IRAN AFFAIR
description: Pressure mounted today for President Reagan to disclose more details of his Administration's dealings with Iran, and new criticism began to focus on Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: NEW RULES ON C.P.A.'S SUGGESTED
description: New C.P.A.'s would have to have master's degrees, existing C.P.A.'s would have to return to school for one week a year and all C.P.A. firms would have to undergo peer review under new membership criteria proposed by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants.

title: AIDS HOT LINE IS EXPANDING AND MOVING SITE TO NEW YORK
description: A private agency is taking over the Government's national AIDS hot line, which gets about 30,000 telephone calls a month, expanding the service and moving the switchboard from Atlanta to Manhattan.

title: 2 SYSTEMS OF BILINGUAL LEARNING, BUT WHICH IS BETTER?
description: In a fourth-floor classroom at Martin Luther King High School in Manhattan, 19 students, all recent immigrants to the United States, were analyzing Emily Dickinson's poem ''A Word.'' Though the students came from countries as far-flung as Cambodia, Haiti, Afghanistan, Mali, Uruguay and Yemen, no language other than English was spoken at any time.

title: Afghan Tribal Leader Named Acting President
description: Afghanistan announced the appointment today of Haji Mohammad Chamkani, a little known tribal leader, as acting President. He replaces Babrak Karmal, who relinquished the largely ceremonial post three days ago.

title: WILLIAM B. HUIE, 76, SOUTHERN AUTHOR
description: William Bradford Huie, who wrote a series of books about the South of the civil rights era as well as ''The Execution of Private Slovik,'' whose setting was World War II, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his office in Guntersville. He was 76 years old. Mr. Huie was a newspaperman in Birmingham; editor of The American Mercury, a literary magazine, and a chronicler of the violence and trauma in the South of the 1960's.

title: THE HUNTER AND SEASONS OF A LIFE
description: I AM preparing for a deer hunting trip in northern New Hampshire without the excitement of previous years.

title: CONNALLYS AUCTION 126 OF THEIR HORSES
description: The horse sale at former Gov. John Connally's spread started half an hour late today to give those arriving by private plane a chance to find a hole in the overcast sky.

title: GULF STRATEGY: BOTH BIG POWERS GAIN
description: In justifying his secret arms deal with Teheran, President Reagan cited Iran's strategic importance and the Soviet threat not only to Iran but also to the entire Persian Gulf region.

title: PREMIER'S SON GETS POST IN SINGAPORE
description: In one of the strongest indications so far that the son of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew is being groomed for a leading role in politics - perhaps to succeed his father - the 34-year-old son was named today to the 14-member executive committee of the ruling political party.

title: NASSAU COUNTY ENDS HOME TAX-LIEN SYSTEM
description: The Nassau County Board of Supervisors has ended a much-criticized system under which a speculator, by giving the county money to cover a homeowner's delinquent tax bill, could gain exclusive rights to the title to the person's home.

title: HOWARD BAY, STAGE DESIGNER IN OVER 170 BROADWAY SHOWS
description: Howard Bay, an award-winning stage designer whose creations have been seen in more than 170 Broadway productions, died Friday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL JETS VS. DOLPHINS, at Miami, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 9 P.M.) OTHER EVENTS COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Coca-Cola N.I.T. Classic (Television - FNN-SCORE, 8 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Aqueduct, 12:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:15 P.M. and 11:15 P.M.) Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight)

title: SUSPICIOUS BLAZE AT PENTA HOTEL
description: A fire broke out in the subbasement of the Penta Hotel in mid-Manhattan last night, sending smoke through the lower floors of the building, according to Fire Department officials, who said the blaze was suspicious because it had begun in more than one location.

title: Zoning, After 70 Years
description: Last weekend marked the 60th anniversary of a landmark United States Supreme Court decision, Village of Euclid v. Ambler Realty Company, upholding the basic constitutionality of local zoning. This is also the 70th year since New York City enacted the country's first zoning ordinance, and the 25th since that original ordinance was replaced by a nationally influential successor. Such a coincidence of anniversaries calls for an evaluation of this central land-use control technique.

title: REDSKINS STAY EVEN; ALLEGRE KICK AT :006 TOPS BRONCOS
description: Last Sunday, when the Giants salvaged a fourth-and-17 situation with 72 seconds remaining and then kicked a game-winning field goal, you thought you had seen the ultimate comeback, right?

title: STAGE: WILDER REVIVAL, 'THE SKIN OF OUR TEETH'
description: WHEN ''The Skin of Our Teeth'' was first presented on Broadway in 1942, it represented the awakening of the American theatrical avant-garde as, inspired by ''Finnegans Wake,'' Thornton Wilder created an intellectual vaudeville about war and survival through the ages. Since then, the play has come to be regarded as a contemporary classic, though today that status seems to be questionable.

title: TYSON'S DOUBTERS BEING COUNTED OUT
description: A little more than an hour before Mike Tyson was to challenge for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship Saturday, he asked Jim Jacobs, his co-manager, ''How do you feel?''

title: ISRAELIS PRESSING LEADERS TO BARE IRAN ARMS ROLE
description: After days of silence, the Israeli leadership is coming under increasing pressure from the Israeli press and Parliament to explain exactly what role Israel played in arms shipments to Iran.

title: Jordan Suffering From Toe Injury
description: Michael Jordan, the leading scorer in the National Basketball Association and the main reason the Chicago Bulls are 7-3, may have a broken little toe on his right foot.

title: WRITING LETTERS OF CONDOLENCE
description: THEY are possibly the most difficult of all letters to write, the notes that convey sympathy to a friend or relative over the death of a loved one. How to express thoughts that can in any way assuage the grief of a survivor baffles many people.

title: THEATER: 'FACE TO FACE,' DRAMA OF MODERN RUSSIA
description: THE Russian soul is coming in for a beating at the Players Theater. Two souls actually.

title: STAGE: 'THE FRONT PAGE,' AT THE VIVIAN BEAUMONT
description: AS everyone who's seen ''The Front Page'' knows - and is there anyone who hasn't seen ''The Front Page''? -it's one play that will never receive a negative review in a newspaper. That's because Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur wrote about newspaper people as newspaper people liked to think of themselves and still do, no matter that humming computer terminals have replaced rattling typewriters, that the discovery of a ''love nest'' rarely merits an extra anymore, or that cities like Chicago no longer have eight dailies engaged in cutthroat competition for the big scoop. ''The Front Page,'' to borrow from Shea Stadium parlance, is newspapering like it oughta be. Not even a critic as uncompromising as Joseph Cotten's Jed Leland in ''Citizen Kane'' would be so foolish as to question the work - part farce, part melodrama, all cartoon - that is the Rosetta stone of his and his colleagues' romantic self-image.

title: DANCE: DAVID DORFMAN AT SCHONBERG THEATER
description: A WIRY dancer, David Dorfman created choreography that bristled with energy for the program by David Dorfman Dance on Saturday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Mr. Dorfman was especially concerned with the tensions of ambitious urbanites who feel they must be always on the go in order to get ahead. Therefore, his movement was both dazzling and disquieting.

title: FRANCE BEGINS SHIFT WITH GOBAIN SALE
description: France's Conservative Government will begin its ambitious privatization program Monday by offering shares in Saint-Gobain S.A., a state-owned glass and construction materials maker nationalized by the Socialists in 1982.

title: TAPING BY LEVINE CALLED PART OF U.S. INSIDER INVESTIGATION
description: An investment banker involved in the insider trading scandal and others secretly made tape recordings of conversations for Government investigators, according to Wall Street sources with knowledge of the investigation.

title: How Jefferson Moved To Cordon Off Slavery Kew Gardens Hills, N.Y., Nov. 13, 1986
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SAG HARBOR, TEMPEST OVER A 7-ELEVEN
description: Until recently, the residents of this former whaling village in eastern Suffolk County were united in their love of seclusion, sea breezes and stirring sunsets by the waterside.

title: Look Who's Bashing 'Corpocracy'
description: American business leaders have become ''bloated, risk-averse, inefficient and unimaginative,'' says the No. 2 man at the Treasury, Richard Darman. Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige adds that foreign manufacturers are beating Americans ''with technology that we invented, but failed to apply and follow through; worse, we've continued to make the same mistake over and over again.''

title: NASA's Way With Words
description: A group of English teachers have named the space agency and two space shuttle contractors as winners of the 1986 Doublespeak Award for deceptive or confusing language.

title: INSIDE
description: Fear at Plant in Angola Cubans are guarding an American-run Chevron oil complex in Angola against threats from South Africa and Western-backed rebels.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Shelters for the Homeless Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan and other opponents of Mayor Koch's proposal to build four new shelters for the homeless in each borough are to speak at a City Council committee hearing.

title: 'THE WYETHS: A FATHER AND HIS FAMILY,' ON 13
description: JUST when you think that stories about the Wyeths, their art, their world and their lives have reached saturation level, along comes ''The Wyeths: A Father and His Family,'' on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. today, to show that you're dead wrong. The one-hour documentary, the first in this season's ''Smithsonian World'' series, is wonderful. It is rich, layered and fairly bursting with life.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEARING THE CROSS: Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. By David J. Garrow. 800 pages. William Morrow. $19.95. DAVID J. GARROW'S huge

title: 116-DAY STRIKE AT USX AFFECTS ECONOMY LITTLE
description: For 116 days now, the steel operations of the USX Corporation have been idled, rivaling a strike in 1959 as the longest shutdown in the industry's history. But despite the closing of the nation's largest steel producer, there has apparently been little effect on the nation's economy.

title: '2-WAY' BILINGUAL STUDY: LEARNING A FOREIGN LANGUAGE
description: Her pen still poised, 9-year-old Keisha Kirkland examined ''shan,'' the Chinese character for ''mountain,'' which she had just written. At her side, Yvette Diaz, a fourth-grade classmate at Public School 1, on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, carefully wrote the character ''tian,'' for ''field.''

title: TAPPIANO TAKES DEMOISELLE
description: Tappiano, the most accomplished 2-year-old filly in the country, scored her third Grade I victory in five career starts with a six-length romp over Soaring Princess in the $174,900 Demoiselle Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: 24 YEARS LATER, CALIFORNIA MURDER WILL BE RETRIED
description: Opening arguments are scheduled here Monday in the retrial of a farm laborer who has spent almost 25 years in prison for a murder he says he did not commit.

title: BARCLAYS BANK REPORTEDLY PLANS TO DIVEST SOUTH AFRICAN HOLDINGS
description: Barclays Bank of Britain was reported today to be selling its South African interests to the Anglo American Corporation in one of the biggest divestment deals ever in this divided land.

title: YANKS TALK ON RHODEN
description: The Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates have reached agreement on a six-player trade contingent on the Yankees' ability to secure Rick Rhoden's approval for his part in the trade.

title: Washington Watch; Senators Focus On Trade Bills
description: COMPETITIVENESS is expected to be a key component of any trade bills that emerge from the Democratic majorities of the 100th Congress, according to legislators and their aides.

title: Morgan Stanley Partners
description: Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm, announced Friday that it had elected 32 new managing partners, three of whom are the first women to receive that title. They are Karen H. Bechtel, Catherine B. James and Marie-Elaine A. La Roche. Ms. Bechtel, 37 years old, is a merger and acquisitions specialist in the investment banking division. Ms. La Roche, 37, is director of marketing for the fixed-income division, and Ms. James, 34, is corporate finance officer for the insurance and financial service group.

title: Attention to Minorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Dies in Hit-Run While Offering Aid
description: A Waterbury man who had stopped to help a couple whose car had run out of gas was struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver on Saturday, the police said.

title: ESPOSITO PICKS UP THE SLACK
description: The Ranger rookies and some of the veterans sat with beers in their hands, listening, nodding their heads at Phil Esposito. The general manager told stories about how he had embarrassed himself at times and gotten over it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1986
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: Beth Sussman, Pianist, Weds W.S. Freiberger
description: Beth Barrie Sussman, a concert pianist and composer, was married last night to William S. Freiberger, a writer's assistant on ''The Cosby Show,'' an NBC television program. Rabbi Aryeh Gotlieb, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: Save It
description: The Senator with the largest cash surplus after a successful 1986 election campaign is probably Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee for the last two years. Aides say he has about $1 million left after spending $2 million in the primary and $1 million in the general election.

title: Appointing Judges
description: Excerpts from remarks by Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court at a recent conference of the Ninth Judicial Circuit in Sun Valley, Idaho, published by The Third Branch, the bulletin of the Federal Courts:

title: Enough Already
description: Three headaches demand attention: 1. The White House Headache. The truth is too awful to admit: Ronald Reagan, condemner of Desert One, basher of Qaddafi, exemplar of tall standing, turned out to be a softy on terrorism.

title: Ignored Again: Human Rights in Chile
description: The Reagan Administration worked hard last year toward a constructive human rights policy in Chile. Now it has undermined the effort by abstaining from a World Bank vote on a $250 million economic adjustment loan to Chile.

title: New Chief of Belo Cites Family's Role
description: The A. H. Belo Corporation, owner of The Dallas Morning News, has announced that Robert W. Decherd will become chairman and chief executive at the end of the year. Mr. Decherd is the great-grandson of G. B. Dealey, who founded The Dallas Morning News in 1885 and acquired the Belo Corporation in 1926.

title: Diversified Growth Would Improve All New York's Boroughs
description: To the Editor:

title: REXNORD PLAN SETS RESTRUCTURING
description: Rexnord Inc., a Milwaukee-based maker of industrial components and equipment, said yesterday that its board had approved an estimated $500 million recapitalization plan and a restructuring program aimed at increasing shareholder return and employee ownership.

title: CITY PROBATION 'OVERWHELMED,' GOODMAN SAYS
description: The State Senate's investigations committee has found that New York City's probation officers are ''overwhelmed'' and their supervision of criminals is ''a disastrous fiction,'' the panel's chairman said yesterday.

title: CARSON PATCHES UP TORN JET DEFENSE
description: BUD CARSON wears the forlorn look of a defensive coordinator without a defense, about to go up against Dan Marino and the Dolphins in the Orange Bowl tonight.

title: Bridge: Two From N.Y.U. Top Field In Collegiate Championships
description: A traditional event that has set many players on the road to stardom, the Intercollegiate Championships, was revived last week. In play Tuesday Jon Heller and Guy Doherty, representing New York University, scored 141 points out of a possible 200, the highest score anywhere.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1986
description: The World

title: Blackhawks Defeat Devils
description: Denis Savard collected his sixth career hat trick tonight, as the Chicago Blackhawks ended a seven-game streak without a victory by beating the New Jersey Devils, 5-3.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Bloom Said to Obtain American Stores Task
description: It is understood that the Bloom Agency has been named by the American Stores Company in Salt Lake City to do the advertising for both its Skaggs Alpha Beta and Buttrey's supermarket chains.

title: 8,000 'OWNERS' AWAIT SHARE OF CELTICS
description: As a coach, Red Auerbach won 938 games. As the general manager and club president, his draft choices and trades helped the Boston Celtics win 16 National Basketball Assocation championships since 1959. Now, at 69 years of age, Auerbach is ''selling'' the Boston Celtics.

title: China Also Seeks Capitalist Precedents
description: To the Editor:

title: Disorganizing Crime
description: ''Tell him the commission from New York -tell him he's dealing with the big boys now.'' Such overheard boasts sealed the convictions of eight organized-crime leaders in the ''commission'' trial that ended last week. Evidence for the existence of the ruling council for Mafia families turned out to be so compelling that the accused bosses and underbosses didn't even contest it. Instead, they unconvincingly denied membership.

title: Arietta Z. Livanos Dies at 77; Shipping Family's Matriarch
description: Arietta Zafirakis Livanos, matriarch of the leading Greek shipping families, died of a stroke Thursday in her apartment in London. She was 77 years old and a resident of Lausanne, Switzerland.

title: GRAF LIKES WAY PENDULUM SWINGS
description: The paradox surrounding Steffi Graf's year was that the better she played, the less opponents feared her. She began 1986 with modest goals, hoping to win her first tournament and break into the top-10 ranking. She ended it yesterday, No. 3 in the world and an eight-time winner, making a shambles of her own timetable.

title: Advertising; Promoting A Better World
description: FARHAD HORMOZI was not a flash in the pan. The former Iranian ad agency owner who was ever so briefly in the New York media in 1970 is back in town, less $5 million and armed with concrete plans to replace his blue-sky concepts.

title: DESERTED LIGHTHOUSES MAY BE RESTORED
description: From the bottom of the Hudson River came the message: ''The currents are a bit of a nuisance down here.''

title: Slaying of Texas Tire Dealer Reveals He Led Double Life
description: The slaying of a tire dealer has revealed that he had wives and children in both Dallas and Waco at the same time for nearly 30 years and that at least one other marriage ended in divorce, the authorities say.

title: Catching Up
description: * Bowing to pressure from yachtsmen who say the rapidly increasing costs of their high-tech sport require corporate dollars, the International Yacht Racing Union, as expected, decided last week to allow advertising on boats. In a concession to purists, however, the governing body imposed some restrictions, including plans to establish an advertising code designed to limit the impact of the decision.

title: Radio Marti Reporter To Fight Reassignment
description: A reporter for Radio Marti who was reassigned for questioning President Reagan at a news conference said today that she had changed her mind and would not resign. Instead, she said, she will ''fight this case.''

title: BRESLIN CANCELS SHOW IN DISPUTE WITH ABC
description: Jimmy Breslin, unhappy with ABC over its treatment of his late-night television program, has canceled his own show. Mr. Breslin, in a front-page advertisement in the New York Times today, told ABC that its services, ''such as they are, will no longer be required as of 12/20/86.''

title: NEW CURRICULUM: HIGH-TECH POLITICS
description: Political campaigns, which used to be organized around strategists' instincts and party organizations, have become a big business with the spending of millions of dollars. Now, a group of academics and political consultants want campaign managers to go to school to learn, among other things, how to spend the money wisely.

title: Account
description: * St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center to William Douglas McAdam.

title: Rev. Moon's Church Wins Diploma Right
description: The State Board of Regents has granted a provisional charter to a Dutchess County seminary run by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, allowing the institution to grant diplomas, officials said.

title: A Boesky Company Plans to Liquidate
description: Cambrian & General Securities P.L.C., the British investment fund formerly run by Ivan F. Boesky, has decided to try to sell its portfolio of stocks and liquidate the company, an adviser to the fund said today.

title: WHEN A PRESS BARON SUES, IT'S A SPECTATOR SPORT
description: The press baron stood fast in the witness box for days, a swashbuckler before the mast, suing for libel even as he was being sued and grinning in obvious exhilaration as he was questioned on the A-to-Z of British journalism: What is a front-page story? What is a freebie?

title: CHINA TEXTILE WARNING
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, warned Chinese leaders Friday that China's soaring textile exports to the United States might provoke protectionist legislation from the new Democratic-controlled Congress. South Carolina, a major textile-producing state, has been hard hit by imports.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank U.S.A., Wilmington, Del., a division of Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., named Robert K. Fredrickson president, effective Dec. 10.

title: Hong Kong, With Hotel Rooms to Spare, Pampers Its Guests
description: In the public washrooms of the lavish Regent Hotel here, attendants hover over the sinks, turning faucets on and off for guests, plying them with towels and anointing them with expensive cologne.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Even Hardball Has Rules
description: American views about espionage have changed considerably since that age of innocence when a code-breaking unit was shut down in 1929 by Secretary of State Stimson because ''Gentlemen do not read each other's mail.'' In the age of cold war, most people acknowledge the need to play hardball. Small countries may have the luxury of virtue; great powers are locked in a clandestine combat in which no mercy is expected.

title: NEW BREED OF HIGH-STAKES BUYER PUSHES ART-AUCTION PRICES TO LIMIT
description: A new species of auctiongoer -people of recently acquired wealth who have become high-stakes collectors of art - are responsible in large part for the series of record-shattering art auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's that took in more than $155 million in the last two weeks.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Joaquin Achucarro Performs Piano Recital
description: Joaquin Achucarro's piano recital last Monday night at Town Hall had much to commend it. Mr. Achucarro plays with authority, sensitivity and technical expertise; although not all of his performances were on the same level, the best of them made the program well worth attending.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Of late, my circumspection has been viewed as weakness, and my sincere attempts at reconciliation as indecision.

title: EXECUTIVES FAVOR CURBS ON 'RAIDERS'
description: Business leaders see the insider trading scandal on Wall Street as an opportunity to curb the power of the ''corporate raiders'' who have fought to take over many of the country's largest companies.

title: A.T.&T. FIGHTS PLAN FOR RIVAL OPERATOR SERVICE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been immersed in court battles with its former local telephone service subsidiaries over who should be the ''operator'' for long-distance calls that require assistance.

title: POPE, IN NEW ZEALAND, CONCEDES MAJOR BARRIERS TO CHRISTIAN UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II acknowledged today that ''real differences'' between Roman Catholicism and other churches are blocking progress toward Christian unity.

title: Chips and Antitrust Curbs
description: The Justice Department is expected to have a say about the semiconductor industry's plans for cooperative development of advanced chip technology. The industry's initiative, which follows protection won from the Reagan Adminstration against predatory Japanese pricing, still has to be fleshed out.

title: 7 Arrested in Drug Scheme
description: Drug agents have seized nearly $1.2 million in cash and arrested seven people in an undercover operation involving a scheme to sell a ton of marijuana, the Federal authorities said. Jim Bramble, resident agent of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, said the arrests Saturday ended a three-week effort to set up the sale of Thai marijuana for $2 million. He said the suspects came to a Reno motel with three duffel bags of cash for the sale.

title: MUSIC: MENDELSSOHN QUARTET
description: ONE way to insure unusual programs is to choose unlikely combinations of instruments. Saturday night's Merkin Concert Hall grouping of soprano (Beverly Hoch), trumpet (Stephen Burns), keyboard (John Van Buskirk), double bass (Gail Kruvand) and string quartet (the Mendelsssohn) found originality via two avenues.

title: FOR CHILD-CARE WORKERS, POVERTY-LEVEL WAGES
description: A new report on the wages and benefits received by child-care workers in New York State has found that many employees of preschools are paid less than zookeepers, hotel clerks and bartenders.

title: Group Raises Stake in Mesa
description: The Baupost Group Inc., an investment partnership based in Cambridge, Mass., said Friday that it had raised its stake in the Mesa Petroleum Company to 8.7 percent, or more than 5.9 million shares, from 7.1 percent.

title: Volcano in Japan Erupts And Another Subsides
description: Mount Mihara subsided today after a fiery eruption that forced 11,000 people to flee the small island of O-shima south of Tokyo late last week.

title: 'ASSIGNMENT AFRICA' ON 13
description: ''ASSIGNMENT AFRICA'' says that American journalists - especially television journalists - do not cover black Africa the way they should. In fact, the ''Inside Story'' special says, they hardly cover it at all. There is something to this. South Africa, the Arab states and Israel dominate news coverage; the great midsection of the continent is routinely ignored. ''Assignment Africa,'' on Channel 13 at 10 P.M., tries to tell us why.

title: 5-Year Notes Highlight Financings
description: In addition to today's regular weekly auction of bills, this week's Treasury financings include tomorrow's $8.25 billion auction of new five-year notes.

title: California Suspect Seized For Ax Attack on Official
description: A parolee charged in the ax attack and robbery of California's Secretary of State has been arrested after being tracked down by a German shepherd in Beverly Hills.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Retiring Chairman Sees Gains for Loehmann's
description: George J. Greenberg, who is retiring Feb. 1 as chairman and chief executive of Loehmann's, says that the off-price women's specialty chain ''is alive and well, and we'll continue to do better under the aegis of the May Company.''

title: Donna Isaacson Wed To Kenneth Frankel
description: The marriage of Donna Isaacson, a daughter of Ruth Isaacson of New York and Arthur Isaacson of San Pedro, Calif., and Kenneth Frankel, a son of Elmer Frankel of Cleveland and the late Doris Frankel, took place yesterday. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael performed the ceremony at the Hebrew Union College in New York.

title: AQUINO DISMISSES ENRILE AND MAKES DEMAND ON REBELS
description: An embattled President Corazon C. Aquino went on the offensive against her opponents today, first dismissing her belligerent Defense Minister and then giving Communist insurgents seven days to agree to a cease-fire.

title: DANCE: FROM OKINAWA
description: THE Asia Society has a habit of presenting dance and music programs that not only illuminate other cultures but suggest much about cultural evolution. The program presented by Sato Takako's Ryukyuan Dance Company of Okinawa on Friday at the society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium was an outstanding case in point.

title: A 'Graphic' Penalty For Drunken Drivers
description: A municipal court judge has begun to order chronic drunken drivers to the scenes of fatal car crashes involving intoxicated motorists and to send them along with medical examiners to notify victims' families.

title: A KEY PLAYER IN PHILIPPINES
description: The man who had come to be known here as ''Hamlet'' finally took sides Saturday night, and may have saved the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Diane Schuur Sings Pop-Jazz at Blue Note
description: Diane Schuur, the Seattle-born pop-jazz singer who has acquired a cult following through several albums on the jazz-fusion label GRP, is a vocalist of unusual warmth and power. The singer, who is blind, offers an odd but pleasing amalgam of musical influences.

title: EASON RALLIES PATRIOTS
description: Tony Eason's 13-yard touchdown pass to Greg Baty with 1 minute 40 seconds to play gave the New England Patriots a 22-19 victory over the Buffalo Bills today.

title: RAMS BEAT SAINTS IN SHOWDOWN, 26-13
description: Nolan Cromwell had two interceptions and forced a fumble and Mike Lansford kicked four field goals today as the Los Angeles Rams beat the New Orleans Saints, 26-13, to remain in first place in the National Conference West Division.

title: Orchestral Manoeuvres, Rock, at Radio City
description: At the turn of the 1980's, synthesizer-driven pop bands swarmed from Britain. Most of them used mechanical rhythms and unnatural sounds to suggest a dehumanized modern world. Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark, which came to Radio City Music Hall Wednesday, took a more cheerful view of things. With the blips and plinks of its electronic keyboards, the band accepted technology as a pop playground.

title: THE MOLDING OF MARCO BALDI
description: FOR much of his childhood in Sarre, Italy, Marco Baldi saw himself as a soccer player. Despite being 6 feet 6 inches tall at the age of 12, Baldi felt that if he was to make a national team, it would be as a goalkeeper.

title: R. D. Steele Wed To Liane Simon
description: Liane Elissa Simon, the daughter of Dr. M. Paul Simon of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Beatrice Lieberman Simon, was married yesterday to Robert David Steele, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Steele of Brooklyn. Rabbi Daniel Franzel performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza, a catering facility in Livingston, N.J.

title: FRENCH PROTEST EDUCATION PLAN
description: Thousands took to the streets of Paris today in the largest political demonstration since the conservative Government took power from the Socialists in March.

title: HARVARD AFFIRMS DISCLOSURE RULE ON STUDIES
description: Harvard University's president, Derek Bok, has reaffirmed a university policy prohibiting professors from engaging in research financed by Government agencies without disclosing the source of their money.

title: WHITE PHILADELPHIAN, 13, IS A MODEL TO THOSE COMBATING RACIST INCIDENTS
description: The courtroom crowd sat in shocked silence. ''Oh, my God!'' whispered Richard Keller's wife. Then she started to cry. Mr. Keller shook his head.

title: Two Teen-Agers Held In Attack on 7 Children
description: Two teen-agers were held today in connection with an invasion of a home in which six children were shot and another child's throat was cut, the police said.

title: 'TED KENNEDY JR. STORY,' A FAMILY BIOGRAPHY
description: THE phenomenon known as The Kennedys, encompassing a variety of profiles in courage, has been steadily served by television movies. The latest family biography, on NBC at 9 o'clock this evening, is devoted to ''The Ted Kennedy Jr. Story.'' The immediate subject is Senator Edward M. Kennedy's son, who, at the age of 12 in the mid-1970's, lost one of his legs to cancer. The broader canvas, however, provides another inspirational illustration of the Kennedy's family determination to survive and win, no matter the odds.

title: Auto Workers Returning At G.M. Parts Plant
description: Workers began returning to a parts plant today after a pact was reached Saturday in a strike that forced layoffs of more than 47,000 General Motors Corporation employees nationwide. G.M. officials, however, said they could not say when the layoffs would end.

title: Sobbing Wallace Bids Adieu To 1,000 of His Supporters
description: Gov. George C. Wallace sobbed openly Saturday as he bid farewell to more than 1,000 supporters.

title: LITIGATION, DEEP DEBT AND BIRTH
description: Lawsuits with religious overtones have disrupted the slow and easy life on Shaw Island, a beautiful, fir-forested refuge in the San Juan Islands off the northwest corner of Washington.

title: Orval Faubus Marries
description: Former Gov. Orval E. Faubus and a fifth grade teacher he met at a singles dance were married today in a public ceremony at a downtown hotel. It was the third marriage for Mr. Faubus, 76 years old, and the second for Jan Wittenburg, 43. Mr. Faubus was Governor from 1955 to 1966. He has since made three unsuccessful attempts to win the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: NEW TECHNOLOGY HELPS IN EFFORT TO FIGHT MAFIA
description: With the help of hidden cameras, secret bugs, infiltration by undercover agents and the testimony of turncoats, the authorities have obtained convictions against more than 800 members of the Mafia and crime family associates in the last five years.

title: LESSONS FOR 1988: SPEND WISELY AND BE NICE
description: Senator John F. Kerry says he was disturbed by the ''meanness'' of the political campaign that ended earlier this month. ''The really negative advertising turned a lot of people off,'' he said.

title: JURY REHEARING SOME TESTIMONY IN TRIAL ON GRAFT
description: The jury in the Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and three co-defendants spent its second day in deliberations today without reaching a conclusion on the charges stemming from New York City's corruption scandal.

title: RUMANIAN URGES ARMS 'GESTURE'
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu appealed today to President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to make ''a gesture'' toward the scrapping of nuclear weapons and an agreement on disarmament.

title: AGENCY URGES NO JAIL TERM FOR EX-OFFICIAL
description: The New York City Department of Probation has recommended that John J. McLaughlin serve no time in prison, according to lawyers and law-enforcement officials familiar with the case of the former city official whose trial last summer was the first to stem from the municipal corruption scandal.

title: Dividend Meetings
