description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 24, 1986: MONDAY American Express United Illuminating Crane Co United Industrial Disney (Walt) Co Watkins-Johnson NWA Inc TUESDAY Angelica Corp Ipalco Enterprises Bank of Boston Kansas Gas & Elec Becton, Dickinson & Co Medtronic Inc Belding-Heminway Merck & Co Brush Wellman Morgan Keegan Inc Certain-teed Corp New England Elec Sys E G&G Inc Pacific Tin Consol E-Systems Inc Reading & Bates Gap Inc Tucson Electric Pwr Interlake Corp Westvaco Corp WEDNESDAY Connecticut Nat Gas Ocean Drill & Explor KeyCorp Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt SATURDAY Lowe's Cos

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the last five seasons, five pitchers - Gaylord Perry (1982), Steve Carlton (1983), Tom Seaver (1985), Phil Niekro (1985) and Don Sutton (1986) - achieved their 300th victories. Who's next?

title: Glass Supplier To Louis XIV
description: Saint-Gobain was founded in 1665 as a supplier of glass to Louis XIV. It now has major operations in more than two dozen countries and conducts business in about 100 more.

title: MUSIC: PRISM ORCHESTRA IN BARRAQUE PREMIERE
description: JEAN BARRAQUE discovered Hermann Broch's visionary novel ''The Death of Virgil'' in 1955 and effectively consecrated the rest of his life to it. Barraque, a pupil of Olivier Messiaen who was already recognized as one of the most gifted young French composers, envisioned a massive musical setting of the novel in five books or fragments. Only three of these - ''Au Dela du Hasard,'' ''Chant Apres Chant'' and ''Le Temps Restitue'' were completed by the time of the composer's early death in 1973.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Slaying of Student
description: A 21-year-old man was arrested last night and charged with the predawn stabbing death of an out-of-town college student in Greenwich Village on Oct. 26, the police reported.

title: PRECIPITOUS DECLINE DISAPPOINTS SHULA
description: THE best they can do now is 10-6, and that's unlikely.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Mint Conditions
description: Last week Tom Monaghan, owner of the Detroit Tigers, acquired a 1931 Bugatti Royale Berline de Voyage. That's a car. He paid $8.1 million for it, and that's money. In fact, it's believed to be more money than was ever before spent on an automobile, the sum going to Jerry Moore, a Houston real estate developer, who had bought the Bugatti in June for $6.5 million.

title: WHAT THE S.A.T.'S CAN DO FOR, AND TO, A STUDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Anwar Nusseibeh, 74; Palestinian Moderate
description: Anwar Nusseibeh, a leading Palestinian moderate who was a former Defense Minister in Jordan, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 74 years old.

title: RIVAL PALESTINIAN FACTIONS ARE SAID TO BE DISCUSSING RECONCILIATION
description: A reconciliation effort between Yasir Arafat's wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Syrian-based Palestinian factions is under way, Palestinian sources said here today. If successful, it would change the political lineup in the Middle East.

title: Ted Bates Completes Acquisition in Spain
description: Follow this bouncing ball: The Ted Bates Group in Spain, part of Ted Bates Worldwide of New York, which is owned by Saatchi & Saatchi in London, has completed the purchase of all of Spain's Gropo Alas, which is made up of Interalas, an agency with offices in Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia and Bilbao; the Alas agency, a network of 13 local agencies, and Interdia, a media buying company in Madrid and Barcelona.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 30
23 1/2 Hours in Court: 1,636 Cases Later
description: With arrests and indictments up significantly this year, the day is long and arduous at the court complex on Centre Street in lower Manhattan.

title: Talking Business with Mittelstadt of GMF Robotics; The Troubled Robot Industry
description: Eric Mittelstadt has been president and chief executive officer of the GMF Robotics Corporation since the founding of the joint venture in 1982 by the General Motors Corporation and Fanuc, the Japanese machine tool maker. GMF sells a robot painting system developed and manufactured in the United States and other robots of its design manufactured by Fanuc.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''IT'S a Walter Mitty dream come true,'' said Geraldine Stutz, the former president of Henri Bendel, who has been named president and publisher of a new book publishing imprint, Panache Press at Random House, as well as an editor at large. She will work out of the office once occupied by Bennett Cerf, the company's co-founder.

title: One Postal Scandal Too Many
description: Though the Office of Government Ethics concludes that the chairman of the Postal Service Board of Governors committed a serious ethical breach, the White House ducks its obvious duty with talk of consulting the Justice Department about discipline. If the Chairman, John McKean, is not now prepared to offer his resignation, President Reagan ought to demand it.

title: Why So Late Seeing Red Over Colorization?
description: To the Editor:

title: ARNOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALL AMERICAN GOURMET reports earnings for 16wks to Nov 2
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $634,000. The company said as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, some of the investment tax credit recorded in the first 24 weeks of the current year had to be eliminated in the 16 weeks ended Nov. 2, 1986, reducing net income for the 16 weeks by approximately $200,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WINSTON S. CHURCHILL. Volume VII. Road to Victory, 1941-1945. By Martin

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: G.E. to Sell Gates Its Battery Unit
description: The General Electric Company said that it had agreed to sell its battery business to the Gates Corporation, and that after the sale it would sell rechargeable batteries made by Gates in the consumer market. G.E. said that although its industrial battery business has a world leadership position, it does not fit strategically with other G.E. businesses.

title: Worrell Top Rookie
description: Todd Worrell, who became the stopper of the St. Louis Cardinals bullpen and led the league with 36 saves, was an almost unanimous choice for National League Rookie of the Year, receiving 23 of 24 first-place votes in balloting by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Contras Hold Meeting In Costa Rica
description: Leaders of the United States-backed guerrillas who are fighting to topple the Nicaraguan Government assembled here today to draw up a program for a possible new government.

title: Rev. Michael Koonsman, 42, Ministered to Homosexuals
description: The Rev. Michael G. Koonsman, an Episcopal priest and a founder of the New York chapter of Integrity, an organization of homosexuals within the Episcopal Church, died Sunday at St. Luke's Hospital of pneumocystic pneumonia, a disease sometimes related to AIDS. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Conde Nast Changes Some of Its Publishers
description: Having ended October with the announcement of a new president of Conde Nast Publications, S. I. Newhouse Jr., the chairman, took another step yesterday and announced additional significant, but orderly, changes in the organization, effective Jan. 1.

title: New Diapers Cause Debate
description: Not everyone is so certain that superabsorbent diapers are a blessing. Judy Braiman-Lipson, president of the Empire State Consumer Association based in Rochester, and Philip Tierno, a microbiologist at New York University, have raised concerns with their charges that the new diapers absorb not only urine, but also body fluids needed to protect a baby's skin.

title: College Series: Everybody Wins
description: The controversial four-team, single-elimination format that was to have replaced the current eight-team, double-elimination setup at the College World Series in 1988 has itself been subjected to a single, but very effective, elimination. The newest format for 1988 and beyond is an eight-team, two-division, double-elimination preliminary followed by a do-or-die one-game final between the division winners.

title: On 'Caregivers'
description: According to the American Association of Retired Persons, five million Americans are ''caregivers,'' a recently coined term to designate people caring at home for unwell adults, usually relatives like spouses or parents, but for friends as well. Through such care, they avoid institutionalization.

title: U.S. SHUNNING SUIT ON ARMY VEHICLE
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not join in a lawsuit filed on behalf of the Government by a private citizen charging that the FMC Corporation misled the Army about the ability of the Bradley troop-carrier to cross rivers.

title: D'AMATO BLAMED IN TAKEOVER BILL DELAY
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who is the outgoing chairman of the Senate banking securities subcommittee, is being blamed by at least one colleague for thwarting legislation last year that would have curbed corporate takeover activity.

title: NATIONAL HEALTHCARE SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said latest results include a gain of $61,000 primarily attributable to the sale of the company's orthodontic practice.

title: AFRICA SPURS HARLEM BOOK COLLECTOR
description: Clarence L. Holte's eyes still sparkle as he scans the bookshelves that line nearly every room of his five-room Harlem apartment.

title: LEFT-HANDED UNIVERSE
description: WHEN Lewis Carroll's Alice stepped through the looking glass, she encountered a world wildly at odds with the simple reversal of images we have come to expect from mirrors. But weird though Alice's brush with an author's whimsy may seem, something comparable actually befell Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang 30 years ago, and many branches of science continue to reverberate from the shock.

title: GORBACHEV VISITING INDIA IN EFFORT TO BOLSTER TIES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives in India on Tuesday for a state visit that will be watched closely for signs of a further strengthening of India's economic and political ties with the Soviet Union.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $19 million for the extinguishment of unsecured notes for the quarter and $21,239,000 for extinguishment of long- term debt for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes restructuring charges of $194,700,000 for the quarter and $205,300,000 for the year.

title: Viaduct Repairs Nearly Completed
description: An $8.4 million repair program for the North Bergen Viaduct is almost complete and weekend motorists will no longer face extensive traffic delays because of the closing of that major artery leading to and from the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm not firing anybody.'' -President Reagan on reportshe plans cabinet changes. (A1:6.)

title: Fade Camerata Plays
description: The Fade Camerata left a mixed impression with its Thursday night program at Merkin Concert Hall. The musicians - the violinist Martin Agee, the cellist Christine Scafidi, the pianist and harpsichordist John Van Buskirk and the soprano Heidi Nitze - are all well trained, and they play together with unity and spirit.

title: Seasonal Cholesterol
description: This is the time of year when serum cholesterol levels start climbing toward their annual peak, according to a study presented last week to the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association. Researchers reported that the amount of cholesterol circulating in American bloodstreams tends to peak in winter and bottom out in summer.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A BIRTHDAY AT GRAFT TRIAL
description: Michael J. Lazar, the real-estate developer and former New York City transportation administrator, celebrated his birthday today by pacing and joking and pacing some more, inside and outside the Federal Courthouse at the edge of the New Haven green.

title: Goodyear Cuts 680 Staff Jobs
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, which last week deflected a takeover bid from Sir James Goldsmith, said today that it planned to cut 680 people from its corporate staff.

title: California English-Only Vote Faces Court Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: BREAST CANCER COST
description: Breast cancer treatment costs thousands of dollars more when doctors remove only the lump than when they remove the breast, a new study indicates.

title: THE FULL SKIRT: A TURNING POINT IN FASHION
description: The full skirt - sharply flared, ruffled or pouffed - has made a clean sweep of the leading fashion markets here and abroad for the spring season. Stores have already been testing consumer reaction with excellent results. The big question is, how long is it going to last? Is it an ephemeral fashion, like the Nehru jacket, or will it leave a lasting mark on the way people dress?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Saturday about proposed restrictions on smoking in New York State misstated the regulations for restaurants. A restaurant would be required to provide a nonsmoking area ''sufficient to meet customer demand'' according to the State Health Department. The size of the area was not stipulated.

title: WESTCHESTER JURY SEEKS HOLIDAY SEASON OFF
description: The jury in the longest trial in the history of Westchester County, a sexual abuse case that began in March, has presented the presiding judge with a list of holiday requests.

title: ALEKSANDR OSTROWSKI
description: Aleksandr M. Ostrowski, a prominent Ukrainian-born mathematician, died Thursday at his home in Switzerland.

title: GOTBAUM BOWING OUT AFTER 22 YEARS
description: Victor Gotbaum, for 22 years the head of the largest union of New York City workers, will turn over the leadership this week to his hand-picked successor, Stanley Hill.

title: German and Russian in Tie At International Tournament
description: The Biel International Tournament in Switzerland ended in a tie for first place between Eric Lobron, a 26-year-old West German grandmaster, and Lev Polugayevsky, a 52-year-old Russian grandmaster. Each scored 7-4 in the 12-player round-robin event.

title: Becket's Parlor Fells His Canterbury Heir
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury slipped and fell over the weekend, breaking two ribs, while inspecting an archeological dig at his Old Palace.

title: NEW WEAPONS IN DIAPER WAR
description: The great diaper war will never make the history books. But in the continuing battle for the $3 billion disposable diaper market the momentum has always gone to the marketing giant that has come up with the latest innovation.

title: Golden Oldies
description: When Mike Schmidt was named the National League's most valuable player last week, he joined this list: the oldest winners of major postseason awards in baseball history.

title: Eastern Vote Seems Likely
description: A Federal judge, citing the likely financial damage of further delays, today refused to block an Eastern Airlines shareholder vote set for Tuesday that is expected to approve the takeover of the airline by the Texas Air Corporation.

title: STATE DEPT. UPSET
description: President Reagan held an extraordinary two-hour meeting with advisers today to review the Iran situation as the State Department publicly denounced its isolation from decision-making on Iran and called on the White House to ''undo the damage quickly.''

title: Market Place; Gains Forecast For Gillette
description: THE stock market sent a clear message about what it thought of the Gillette Company's huge stock buyback program yesterday, as investors pushed the price of Gillette shares down by $10.75, to $45.875.

title: HOLIDAY AIR BOOKINGS SHOW SHARP INCREASES
description: Attracted by sharply discounted fares and longer holiday weekends, travelers are booking flights on most major carriers for the Thanksgiving-to-New Year's period in much greater numbers than last year.

title: New York's Environment Needs Conservators as Well as Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUTHS HELD IN MAJOR CRIMES TO GET DRUG TESTS IN CAPITAL
description: The Justice Department today announced a pilot program to test for drug use among juveniles arrested for serious crimes in the District of Columbia.

title: Bid for Ponderosa
description: Ponderosa Inc., which thwarted a takeover attempt earlier this year, said it was evaluating the New York investor Asher B. Edelman's disclosure that he had amassed an 18.5 percent stake in the restaurant chain and was considering acquiring the rest. Mr. Edelman has not specified a takeover price, but in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing made public today, he disclosed that he and seven investment groups in which he has an interest own 1.8 million of Ponderosa's 9.75 million shares outstanding. Ponderosa closed today at $24.875, down $1.625 a share.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Hearing on Immigrant Students Parents, teachers, lawyers, school administrators, child development specialists and children themselves will testify at a public hearing as part of a nationwide study of immigrant children in public schools. The hearing, headed by Guillermo Linares, chairman of Chancellor Nathan Quinones's Bilingual Education Committee, is organized by Advocates for Children of New York, a nonprofit group. 9 A.M.-5:30 P.M., City University Graduate School Auditorium, 33 West 42d Street, Manhattan Review of Tower Project A 74-story tower that would be built at 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets, using 800,000 square feet of air rights purchased from the owners of Grand Central Terminal is among the projects to be reviewed at a Landmarks Preservation Commission hearing. 9:30 A.M., 20 Vesey Street, Manhattan March of Dimes Campaign The Greater New York March of Dimes will announce a three-year campaign to combat the high incidence of underweight babies born in the city. Speakers include the New York City Opera director, Beverly Sills; the Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins, and the city's Health Commissioner, Dr. Stephen C. Joseph. 1 P.M., New York Hilton, Mercury Ballroom.

title: TRACKING A KILLER: SCIENTISTS COMBAT INFLUENZA OUTBREAK
description: NO one knows exactly where it began, but last winter a new flu virus appeared in Asia.

title: POLYDEX PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $768,751.

title: PETROLEUM INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FARMER IN JAIL OVER LOST COLLATERAL, A TRACTOR
description: One day late last spring, Duane Kruse says, he was out planting soybeans here in northwestern Illinois when sunset came. As usual, he parked his tractor in the field and went home for dinner. When he returned, Mr. Kruse says, the tractor was gone.

title: CLOUD OF ALUMINUM REPORTED IN MILKY WAY'S CORE
description: GERMAN astrophysicists peering into the core of the Milky Way report detection of a cloud of radioactive aluminum whose mass is roughly five times that of the Sun. The report of so immense a concentration of that short-lived substance, aluminum 26, is now a matter of some dispute, however.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $4,453,000 resulting from the prepayment of debt. c-Net income

title: G.M.-E.D.S. STRAINS INDICATED
description: A report that the General Motors Corporation unsuccessfully discussed selling all or part of its Electronic Data Systems unit to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company appears to indicate how difficult the process of combining E.D.S. and G.M. has been.

title: TWO CHILDREN ARE KILLED IN FIRE AT BROOKLYN DAY CARE CENTER
description: Two children were killed and six others were injured, some seriously, when a fire broke out yesterday in what officials called an unlicensed day care center in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: INDUSTRIAL ACOUSTICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jackson's On His Own
description: A player at the other end of his career, Reggie Jackson, was told yesterday, as expected, that he would not be offered a contract by the California Angels next season. The 40-year-old slugger is a free agent. . . . Tom Kelly, interim manager of the Minnesota Twins, was named to the post full time at a news conference in Minneapolis yesterday. Kelly, 36, compiled a 12-11 record after he replaced Ray Miller, who was dismissed in September.

title: New Publisher at The Post
description: Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News America Publishing Inc., said yesterday that Patrick Purcell had been appointed publisher of The New York Post.

title: CRUDE OIL PRICES SLUMP ON SAUDI OUTPUT STAND
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products slumped yesterday after news reports were received that King Fahd of Saudi Arabia had intimated that his Government would not cut oil production below its current level of 4.35 million barrels a day.

title: GROUNDBREAKER IN MATH
description: WHEN my oldest daughter, Genevieve, asked for a pocket calculator for school, my initial reaction was thoroughly negative. Granted, by junior high, students should have conquered the basics of arithmetic. But the argument that not being tied down to repetitive numerical calculation frees the student for more transcendent flights of mathematical exploration and conceptual understanding didn't wash with me. I've encountered far too many sales clerks who have insisted that four items variously priced at from 39 cents to 79 cents add up to some $6 or $7 with tax because that's what the calculator has asserted - never mind that conceptually the answer is so absurd it could result only from input error.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Appeals To Davis to Give Up
description: The N.A.A.C.P. said yesterday that it had offered to help in the safe surrender of Larry Davis, the 20-year-old fugitive sought for the shooting of six police officers who tried to arrest him in a Bronx apartment last week.

title: SCIENTISTS TAME WILD RICE, THE 'CAVIAR OF GRAINS'
description: AGRICULTURAL science, which has redesigned virtually every commodity commonly consumed in Western cultures, has tamed a once-scarce and highly romanticized gourmet food, wild rice.

title: WHERE HHE CITY COUNCIL OCCUPIES CENTER STAGE
description: Earlier this year, City Councilman Francis X. Rafferty introduced a resolution praising a local roofers' union for humanitarian acts and charitable contributions. At the time, the Federal authorities were investigating the union for alleged illegal gifts to judges.

title: A Rehnquist Oddity
description: William H. Rehnquist, the newly installed Chief Justice of the United States, is facing the prospect of voting on a Supreme Court case involving a lower court decision he was involved in two years ago.

title: AMPERE LETTERS SHOW FLOWERING OF YOUNG GENIUS
description: THE 19th-century French physicist Andre Marie Ampere had ample reason to choose for his gravestone the epitaph ''Tandem felix'' -Happy, at last. His father's execution in the French Revolution in 1793 left the young Ampere literally speechless for a year and in a prolonged state of deep depression. Later in his tortured life, he was plunged into recurring depressions by the death of his young wife, troubles with his two children and an unhappy second marriage.

title: Surgery for Johnson?
description: Marques Johnson of the Los Angeles Clippers is expected to be sidelined for at least three months because of an injury to his spinal cord.

title: ESPOSITO SEEMS SET ON CRISP
description: Early this afternoon, Phil Esposito, the Rangers' general manager and interim coach, leaned back in his chair and said, ''I want someone with an old-fashioned approach. I want someone who will follow through on the things that I'm doing. I want a guy who is his own personality and will talk.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1986
description: The Scandal on Wall Street

title: CIMCO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CAMERA PLATFORMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said there were no year-ago sales.

title: NUCLEAR POWER PLANT DISMANTLED
description: PIECE by laborious piece, about 200 workers here are taking apart a nuclear power plant in a project that could affect the price of electricity thoughout the country and the financial health of most major utilities.

title: BHA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are on a pro-forma basis.

title: HEVESI ENDORSES KREMER FOR SPEAKER
description: Assemblyman Alan G. Hevesi of Queens dropped out of the contest for Assembly Speaker yesterday and endorsed his neighbor, Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer of Nassau County.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Tokyo Women's Choir
description: Women's choruses have become a musical tradition in 20th-century Japan, and a group of about 60 such singers, selected from amateur organizations around Tokyo, came to Alice Tully Hall Saturday afternoon.

title: EQUITEX INC reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Net income represents net assets.

title: Bridge: The Death of Roger Trezel Ended a Great Partnership
description: One of the greatest partnerships in the history of the game was broken recently when Roger Trezel died in France at the age of 68.

title: Anti-Israel Fervor At Funeral
description: Arabs who attended the funeral of a prominent Palestinian moderate in East Jerusalem today sought to turn the gathering into a nationalist demonstration, shouting anti-Israel and anti-Jewish slogans as the funeral procession marched through the Old City.

title: SKIERS CUT OFF BY WASHINGTON FLOODS
description: Flooding caused by heavy rain and melting snow forced dozens of families from their homes today and blocked the only highway to a mountain resort where 1,000 weekend skiers were stranded.

title: Accountant's Ledger Can't Spur Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIA SAYS IT HAS SEIZED MAN WHO SOUGHT TO KILL POPE
description: A man carrying five firebombs was arrested today several hours before Pope John Paul II's arrival here and said later that he intended to assassinate the Pope, the police said.

title: Sears to Sell Back Hagemeyer Stake
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it had agreed in principle to sell back to Hagemeyer N.V. the 20 percent of the general trading company that it had bought 13 months ago. Sears said it would receive $31.1 million for the 770,000 shares.

title: Ex-Leader of Commune Gets 2-Year Sentence
description: The former Mayor of Rajneeshpuram, who provided investigators with vital information about crimes committed at what was the commune of a religious sect, was sentenced today to two years in prison.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A television review yesterday of an NBC drama, ''The Ted Kennedy Jr.

title: FOOD SELLERS OPPOSING SITE LOTTERY
description: For six years, Estela and Luis Genesoni have grilled sausages on 50th Street near the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, winning steady customers with their succulent sandwiches and working their way to the head of a vending line ruled by seniority.

title: SYRIA PRODS ITS ALLIES TO MOVE AGAINST THE P.L.O. IN LEBANON
description: Syria pressed its allies among the Lebanese leftists today to crush the Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon.

title: Silver Coins Sell Out Fast
description: The new American Eagle silver dollars were snatched up quickly by bulk dealers today, and the initial supply of 1.4 million coins was gone within hours, officials of the United States Mint said.

title: California English-Only Vote Faces Court Tests; Fear of Lingual Erosion
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Die at Health Home In Bacteria Outbreak
description: Three nursing-home residents died after an outbreak of salmonella that is suspected of having afflicted 24 residents, state health officials said yesterday.

title: The Real Boesky-Case Issue
description: The Ivan F. Boesky insider trading scandal looks like a great Congressional windfall. It will provide welcome opportunities for headlines, hearings and perhaps even more regulation. Washington thrives on such affairs. 'Tis more the pity, however, for the great problem disclosed by the Boesky matter is not abuse of trust or even greed. It is simply another case of poorly designed regulations generating perverse results.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
S.E.C. Defends Figures
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied published reports that Ivan F. Boesky's insider trading profits totaled more than $200 million.

title: A New Ballgame, and the Scoring Has Begun
description: Three weeks after the elections that shook up the Senate, some Republican leaders are worried that the White House is off to a rocky start with the new Congress. If things do not improve, they say, the Administration could face a number of bruising battles on Capitol Hill in the final two years of the Reagan Presidency.

title: Amax Deal Is Final
description: Amax Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of the 50 percent of Alumax Inc. that it did not already own from Mitsui & Company and the Nippon Steel Corporation of Japan. Amax said it had issued 4 million shares of 8.5 percent Alumax preferred stock, with a par value of $100 million, to Mitsui. Amax said it had also acquired remaining stock from Mitsui and Nippon Steel for $335 million in cash.

title: PERES WITHHOLDS DETAILS IN BRIEFING M.P.'S ON IRAN
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres appeared today before Parliament's Defense and Foreign Affairs Committee but declined to reveal precise details about Israel's participation in the arms-for-hostages deal with Iran, committee sources said.

title: CUOMO PANEL URGES INCREASES IN GAS TAXES AND BRIDGE TOLLS
description: Gasoline taxes would rise downstate, East River bridge and tunnel tolls would increase and New York City's subway, bus and commuter rail fares would be frozen for three years under a plan proposed today by Governor Cuomo's economic advisers.

title: Paying for Water, Drop by Drop
description: New York City consumes 1.4 billion gallons of water each day, which its water system can barely supply. Expansion means horrendous investment in new reservoirs or in mixing the gamier waters of the Hudson River with the pristine flows from the Catskills. It makes much more sense to reduce demand by persuading New Yorkers to use less water.

title: Ford, VW to Link In South America
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would join forces with Volkswagen A.G. in Brazil and Argentina to form a new company that would be known as Autolatina. The new organization, based in Brazil, will merge car, truck and credit operations.

title: TAKING DEDUCTIONS
description: MANY taxpayers try to deduct all or part of the cost of a home computer used for business. This annoys the Internal Revenue Service to no end.

title: A CLASSIC WAY WITH PLEATS
description: Mariano Fortuny y Madrazo died in Venice in 1949. His secret pleating technique, which made his Grecian-inspired silk gowns collectors' items, reputedly died with him. While designers such as Mary McFadden made pleated dresses that recalled Fortuny, none ever claimed to have reconstructed his process.

title: Verdict Due Tomorrow In Berlin Bombing Case
description: The prosecution demanded stiff sentences today for two Arabs who have confessed to placing a bomb at an Arab social club in West Berlin.

title: DEBATING CLASSROOM TECHNOLOGY
description: EDUCATORS are confused about the role technology will play in their future. Their views about computers range from enthusiasm to condescension and fear. Some predict that computers will ultimately replace books and significantly reduce the number of teachers; others consider such predictions either dangerous or plain wrong.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $93,018 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: Publisher Cuts Boesky Book
description: Holt, Rinehart & Winston, the publisher of ''Merger Mania,'' a book by Ivan F. Boesky about high-stakes stock arbitrage, will no longer sell or distribute the book.

title: A WINTER OF CABBAGES AND TRAFFIC JAMS AND RATS
description: A cold front, the television weatherman said, is moving in from Mongolia. Also moving in from the north - and the south, the east and the west - are cabbages, piles of cabbages, stacks of cabbages, molehills and mountains of cabbages, even carpets of cabbages.

title: TRANS WORLD MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Tribute to Kuhlau
description: Friedrich Kuhlau (1786-1832) was a Hanoverian kleinmeister who had himself naturalized a Dane to avoid military conscription. He spent most of his short life turning out tuneful chamber music, piano works and operas in Copenhagen. The concert series at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine paid him a bicentennial tribute Saturday with a generous program of chamber music for voice, strings, piano and, especially, flute in various combinations. There were three full-scale multimovement ensembles, an intriguing flute and piano divertissement in the form that would eventually be associated with Chopin's nocturnes, and songs, miniatures and excerpted movements -all of it composed with poise and flowing ease of invention.

title: Argentina, at U.N., Reproaches the British
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister accused Britain today of trying to ''expand its domination over waters under Argentine sovereignty'' by declaring a 200-mile controlled fishing zone around the Falkland Islands.

title: Phys Ed High
description: What kind of dominance could a high school establish on the football field if its curriculum held an unparalleled attraction for students who wanted to specialize in physical education? They're finding out in Cincinnati.

title: PUBLISHING: BELLOW JUMPS TO MORROW
description: EIGHT years and two books after moving to Harper & Row, Saul Bellow has a new publisher: William Morrow & Company. Next June, Morrow plans to publish Mr. Bellow's new novel, ''More Die of Heartbreak,'' which it describes as ''a probing examination of male sexuality and the dilemma of deeply intelligent men whose brilliant minds cannot save them from their own emotions.''

title: EMINENT LONDON ART DEALER
description: Sir Geoffrey Agnew, dean of London art dealers, former chairman of the family firm of Thomas Agnew & Sons and a figure familiar to more than one generation of museum directors, collectors and connoisseurs in this country, died of cancer Saturday in London. He was 78 years old.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A RULE THAT NEEDS CHANGING
description: Eileen Livingstone, the athletic director at Duquesne University, remembers going around campus last year, tacking up flyers and buttonholing students who looked like they wouldn't drown in a varsity swimming meet. Then early last spring, a few runners ''didn't show up for a track meet on a cold snowy day,'' Livingstone recalls.

title: Treasury Issues Are Up a Bit
description: While Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, uncertainty in the market caused a slight drop in the price of many corporate ''junk bonds.''

title: BRT REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 1-for-3 reverse stock split in August.

title: ASEA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said all dollar amounts are translated, purely for convenience, at the rate of exchange prevailing at the end of the third quarter of 1986: U.S. $1.00 is equal to SEK 6.86.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 1
REFUGEES ARRIVE IN LOS ANGELES FROM VIETNAM
description: There was no fierceness in their eyes today, no jaws set against adversity and attack in jungle blinds. The group of Vietnamese montagnard villagers who touched their first American soil at an airport here today looked more like tourists than former allies of American troops in Vietnam.

title: TROUBLED TIMES FOR EX-TRACK STAR
description: Henry Rono came running out of Kenya in 1976, a man of uncertain age and unparalleled ability. Now everything is a question mark, especially his future.

title: Iran Says Iraqi Bombs Killed 10 in Port Cities
description: Iran said today that Iraqi aircraft had bombed two Iranian ports today, killing 10 civilians and wounding 60.

title: EX-ENVOY TESTIFIED BEFORE GRAND JURY ON DEAVER
description: Richard L. Walker, a former United States Ambassador to South Korea, said today that he had testified before a Federal grand jury investigating the lobbying activities of Michael K. Deaver, a former White House aide.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $776,000 for the quarter and $1,447,000 for the 6 months.

title: FOREIGN ACCENT COULD HARM MASTERS
description: For the first time since its inception in December 1970, the Masters will not have an American in the field. Gene Scott, the tournament director, is hoping tennis fans will not use this as an excuse to stay home in record numbers when this year's Nabisco Masters begins at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 3. He might argue that although there are no Americans, there are a few local heroes in the event.

title: Coast Utility's Yield Is 8.80%
description: The Southern California Edison Company is offering $125 million of 8 3/8 percent first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at 95 1/2 to yield 8.80 percent.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. HOUSTON ROCKETS, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) NETS VS.

title: 4 FLU VIRUSES IN U.S.
description: With the arrival of A/Taiwan in the United States, it became necessary to cope with four different flu viruses: A/Chile; A/ Mississippi, B/Ann Arbor and A/Taiwan. Two vaccines are now available to prevent infection from these viruses.

title: DIAGNOSTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pro Football Notebook; MCMAHON MAY BE OUT AGAIN
description: Jim McMahon, the Chicago Bears' in-again, out-again quarterback who played Sunday for the first time in four weeks, may be lost for the season with a damaged shoulder, Coach Mike Ditka said yesterday.

title: IMPERIAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $526,000 for the quarter and $1,312,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $3,687,000 on settlement of subsidiary's indebtedness. Certain accounts in the 1985 periods have been reclassified to conform to 1986 classifications.

title: Fumes Send 30 to Hospital
description: A vapor cloud leaked from a chemical plant tanker today, sending up to 30 people to a hospital and forcing the authorities to evacuate nearby residents, officials said. Most of those taken to Hardin Memorial Hospital complained of headaches, sore throats and nausea, a spokesman said. Several hundred people in two trailer parks were evacuated for about an hour, and some roads were closed off when the cloud moved southeast from the Dow Corning plant, the police said.

title: 59 Arrested in C.I.A. Protest At Massachusetts University
description: One hundred students protesting Central Intelligence Agency recruitment at the University of Massachusetts occupied a building for six hours today before the police arrested 59 people, including Abbie Hoffman, the 1960's activist, and Amy Carter, daughter of former President Jimmy Carter, officials said.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,415,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $329,701.

title: IRAN, IN 6-YEAR SEARCH FOR ARMS, FINDS WORLD OF WILLING SUPPLIERS
description: During its six-year war with Iraq, Iran has bought more than $9 billion in arms from America's allies and enemies alike, according to a high-ranking Reagan Administration official.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GILLETTE DEAL ENDS REVLON BID
description: The Gillette Company said yester-day that it would pay $558 million to the Revlon Group to end the cosmetics company's vigorous pursuit of the world's largest manufacturer of shaving products.

title: BankAmerica Reaction Seen
description: The BankAmerica Corporation has begun to circulate a document that is sharply critical of First Interstate Bancorp's proposed merger, banking sources said today.

title: STATE TO ACQUIRE AN UPSTATE LAKE
description: The long saga of Lake Minnewaska seems to have ended. After 17 years of negotiations, the state has decided to take, by eminent domain, more than 1,200 acres of private land in Ulster County, including the 33-acre glacial lake, state officials said yesterday.

title: Unisys Will Sell Supplies Division
description: The Unisys Corporation said it would sell its international business forms and supplies division to an investor group led by the buyout firm of Clayton & Dubilier Inc. for $50 million in cash, plus notes of an unspecified value. The investor group, which includes managers of the division, has formed a new company, Nu-Kote International, for the acquisition.

title: Ex-Federal Official Sentenced to 4 Years
description: A former Labor Department official was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison for embezzling $430,000 from the benefit plans of two unions.

title: Barclays Unit Officers Say Move Retards Change
description: The South African directors of Barclays Bank of Britain said today that the withdrawal of foreign investment would retard prospects for racial change in their country.

title: Rug Cleaning Forces A School to Close
description: An elementary school in the township was closed indefinitely yesterday after parents complained that several children had become sick following the cleaning of rugs in the building.

title: Xerox Starts Institute On Training
description: The Xerox Corporation is spending $5 million as ''an investment in the future'' to start a nonprofit research institute that will use sophisticated computers to develop new approaches to learning, according to company officials.

title: 55 M.P.H. Speed Limit Is No Safety Guarantee
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PROPOSING DRILLING FOR OIL IN ARCTIC REFUGE
description: The Interior Department, setting the stage for a battle with conservationists, tentatively proposed today to allow oil drilling in a huge wildlife refuge on Alaska's Arctic coast.

title: Della Femina Receives Account for Condoms
description: Ansell International of Tinton Falls, N.J., has retained Della Femina, Travisano & Partners to advertise its Lifestyles condoms. According to the agency, there is a $2.5 million advertising budget.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
VENUS THEORY QUERIED
description: IN their observations of Venus, Soviet and American spacecraft have detected low-frequency radio emissions resembling those generated by lightning on Earth. Many scientists concluded that this meant there was lightning on Venus.

title: Illinois Attack Linked To Fear of Witnesses
description: Two teen-agers who broke into a neighbor's home Saturday were apparently trying to eliminate witnesses when they herded five children onto a bed and shot them after assaulting their sister, the police said today.

title: U.P.I.'S EDITOR QUITS, CITING A DISPUTE
description: Malcolm K. Hughes, editor in chief of United Press International, resigned from the struggling news agency yesterday after a dispute with the organization's new president, Milton R. Benjamin.

title: VICE CHAIRMAN LEAVES HIS POST AT HEALTH UNIT
description: The vice chairman of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation has resigned after refusing to tell a corporation committee how much, if anything, he is paying a private hospital for office space.

title: Marsh in Deal For Lippincott
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies Inc, the holding company for the world's largest insurance and reinsurance brokerage concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Lippincott & Margulies, a pioneer in corporate identity consulting.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: MOB FIGURES CHOSE TEAMSTERS' CHIEF, GOVERNMENT SAYS
description: Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno, the convicted boss of the Genovese crime group, and three associates were charged yesterday with carrying out a fraudulent scheme to select Jackie Presser as head of the teamsters' union.

title: GALACTIC RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: All figures are in U.S. funds. The company did not provide year- ago third quarter figures because it did not begin producing gold until this year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.I.T.

title: REAGAN AIDES SPLIT ON DRUG TESTS
description: President Reagan's advisers are deeply divided over how to carry out his order for drug testing of Federal employees in the light of court decisions suggesting that such widespread random tests are unconstitutional.

title: SIGMA DESIGNS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
North Korean Confirms Injury of a Leader
description: A North Korean official today dismissed reports of a power struggle in the Pyongyang leadership, but confirmed rumors that the country's third most powerful man had been incapacitated in an accident.

title: Fumes at Motel Kill One And Injure 5 in Nashville
description: A buildup of carbon monoxide gas killed one person and sent five others to the hospital over the weekend from the Opryland Ramada Inn, the authorities said today. More than 100 motel guests were evacuated.

title: BUNDY CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AGENCIES PROPOSING AN OVERHAUL OF WELFARE
description: An overhaul of welfare that stresses family stability and self-sufficiency by requiring recipients to work or get job training was proposed today by officials of state welfare agencies.

title: New Awards Tonight
description: Colleen Dewhurst will join David N. Dinkins in presenting the first annual Manhattan Borough President's Awards for Excellence in the Arts in a gala celebration and performance, free and open to the public, tonight at 8 at Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 134th Street. Awards will be given for outstanding contributions in the visual arts, literature, theater, film and video, music and dance. Reservations: 690-6900.

title: MILTON HEIMLICH
description: Milton Heimlich, the founder of Financial Aid for College and Technical Schools, a nonprofit service to aid New York City students, died Saturday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital after a brief illness.

title: STAGE: 'TIME OUT OF TIME'
description: CLIFFORD MASON touches on so many topical truths in his new play that you keep hoping against hope that ''Time Out of Time'' will take firm hold even as it becomes painfully plain that the work's dramatic grasp does not match its reach.

title: DONOHUE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After minority interest.

title: NEW TACK FOR BLACKALLER
description: The edge has been chiseled off the feisty side of Tom Blackaller. Unlike his 1983 America's Cup campaign, his attempt this time is with a boat with promise and a team that he can call his own.

title: 3 IN IRAN SMUGGLING RING RECEIVE PRISON SENTENCES
description: A Navy veteran and a divorced couple from Virginia were sentenced to prison today for their roles in a plot to smuggle an estimated $10 million worth of stolen F-14 jet parts to Iran.

title: NEOLITHIC CARVING SOLD FOR A RECORD AT AUCTION
description: A 6,000-year-old neolithic sculpture of a seated goddess - at eight inches tall, one of the largest known - was sold yesterday for the highest price ever paid at auction for an antiquity.

title: Dow Gains Another 12.51, to 1,906.07
description: While speculative issues remained in a steep dive on Wall Street, the rest of the stock market moved quietly toward record levels yesterday as trading volume eased but remained high.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter and year results include an after-tax accrual of $5.1 million to increase the company's environmental compliance, and a $6.5 million reduction of U.S. deferred income taxes related to undistributed earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JETS ARE DEFENSELESS AGAINST MARINO AND DOLPHINS
description: The Jets played their final Orange Bowl game against the Dolphins tonight, and it was like old times - the bad old times.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about investors in Ivan F. Boesky's limited partnership described one of them, the Liberty Service Corporation, incorrectly. It is not related to the Executive Life Insurance Company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Irving Fryar, the New England Patriot wide receiver who suffered a concussion in a car accident Sunday, was listed in satisfactory condition yesterday and will be hospitalized for an undetermined time. Fryar left the stadium while the game was still in progress, without the team's permission, after he was sidelined because of a separated shoulder. . . . The San Francisco 49ers are bringing back Wendell Tyler, the former starting halfback released three weeks ago, because of injuries to the team's running backs, Coach Bill Walsh says. . . . Dan Hampton, the All-Pro defensive end of the Chicago Bears, was arrested on drunken-driving charges early yesterday. . . . Gilbert Perreault, the first player drafted by the Buffalo Sabres when they entered the league in 1970, has retired for the second time this year, this time for good, he says.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VAN GOGH IN ST. REMY The Metropolitan Museum of Art has a wealth of art on view at a cost no greater than the price of admission, but among its biggest attractions in recent years have been the limited-visit exhibitions that call for purchasing separate tickets. The newest of these museum specials -the exhibition ''Van Gogh in St. Remy and Auvers'' - opens today.

title: A GALA FOR CARNEGIE HALL
description: With only three weeks to go before the reopening of Carnegie Hall, James D. Wolfensohn, the chairman of the board of the hall, Judith Arron, its general manager, and Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic, met yesterday to discuss final plans for a gala concert and party on Dec. 15.

title: Yanks, Rhoden Remain Apart
description: The Yankees need Rick Rhoden's approval to complete their six-player trade with Pittsburgh, but the two sides remained apart on their proposals yesterday. Rhoden was asking for a two-year contract extension at $1 million a year and the Yankees were offering one year at $800,000.

title: Peay Gets the Job
description: Francis Peay, the interim Northwestern University football coach, was named head coach on a regular basis yesterday, even though he had withdrawn his name from consideration last month.

title: COMPACT VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $450,000 for reduction of the litigation costs provision established Dec. 31, 1985. c-After an extraordinary charge of $180,000 for litigation costs and a tax credit of $13,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The company acquired Brooks Drug Inc., formerly Adams Drug Co., on Sept. 30, 1986; Vidamerica Inc. on Aug. 29, 1986; and Four Star International Inc. on June 28, 1986. The company said the latest third quarter includes three months of operations for Four Star International and one month of operations for Vidamerica, representing $4,452,000 in revenue, $187,000 in operating income and $10,000 in net income.

title: BURT'S BACK INJURY IS PAINFUL TO GIANTS
description: The Giants' glow over Sunday's 19-16 victory over the Denver Broncos with six seconds left was dimmed today by the back injury suffered by Jim Burt.

title: Bowled Over
description: Coach Dan Henning of the Atlanta Falcons, who are now 5-6-1 after a 4-0 start: ''We can't think about the playoffs. At this point, we wouldn't even accept a bowl bid.''

title: Mr. Social Security: Still a Fan
description: Wilbur J. Cohen was the first employee of Social Security 51 years ago, yet his only official tie to the system now is one he shares with nearly 37 million other Americans: He collects benefits from the program.

title: CONCERT: THE PITTSBURGH
description: FEW works walk the vague area between opera and oratorio with such sure-footed originality as ''La Damnation de Faust.'' In 11 scenes, Berlioz has created - with musical monologue and dialogue, with striking choral writing and with an intensely pictorial use of the orchestra - a personal re-creation of Goethe's ''Faust'' that can remain stationary on the concert stage and yet move the imagination great distances.

title: Unusual Background For Investment Banker
description: J. Gary Shansby, who generated controversy in 10 years as the chairman and chief executive of the Shaklee Corporation by his individualistic style of leadership, readily concedes that he is outside the mold of the typical investment banker. But his operating experience at Shaklee, he says, will be an asset in his new position as a general partner in Montgomery Securities, based in San Francisco.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for 1985 are restated to reflect a 10-percent stock dividend issued April 21, 1986.

title: HEADED N.L.R.B. UNDER TRUMAN
description: Paul M. Herzog, a lawyer, educator and philanthropist and former chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and had suffered a stroke a year ago.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE COMPANY (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings for both periods are restated to reflect a 6-for-5 stock split paid August 1986.

title: 'THAT SECRET SUNDAY'
description: AFTER a weekend of partying, four men are ready to leave a rented cabin when one discovers that his 17-year-old date is dead, apparently from a drug overdose. When her older sister, the only other woman present, drives off to find a doctor, two of the men chase her, pushing her off the road into a fatal accident and then burying her and the evidence in a lake. We then discover that all four of the men are policemen. So begins, not unpromisingly, ''That Secret Sunday,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 tonight.

title: New Immigration Law
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Die in Child-Care Center Two children died and six were injured in a Brooklyn fire at what authorities called an unlicensed day-care center.

title: PROSECUTOR SAYS REJECTION CAUSED RAZOR ASSAULT ON FASHION MODEL
description: A makeup artist accused of arranging the razor slashing of a 25-year-old fashion model last summer was frustrated over the model's rejection of him and enraged about her demands that he pay back money he owed her, a prosecutor told a jury in Manhattan yesterday.

title: World Trade Rise Put at 4%
description: World trade is expected to grow by a modest 4 percent this year, in part because of continued weakness in energy and commodities markets, the chairman of the 92-nation GATT said today.

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,000,000 for the quarter and $10,705,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $9,208,000 and $16,149,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: RITZ CARLTON OWNER FILES UNDER CHAPTER 11
description: John B. Coleman, the owner of the Ritz Carlton Hotels in New York and Washington, yesterday filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors' claims on his personal assets and the hotels.

title: Bankruptcy Step Taken By McLean
description: McLean Industries Inc., owner of one of the three major American-flag shipping lines, announced late yesterday that it had filed a petition for bankruptcy protection from creditors.

title: ADVANCED MAGNETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 1986 share earnings and shares outstanding comparisions with those of fiscal 1985 are not meaningful because Advanced Magnetics went public with an offering of 1 million shares of common stock in June 1986.

title: Security Council Aide Is Questioned on Iran
description: The Justice Department interviewed a National Security Council official over the weekend as part of an inquiry into arms shipments to Iran, a Federal law enforcement official said today.

title: Needless Offense To India
description: Just on the eve of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to New Delhi, the Reagan Administration has provoked intense anti-American bitterness in India by offering to sell Pakistan advanced Awacs planes with an electronic reach extending hundreds of miles into Indian territory.

title: TWO GROUPS CHARGE GOVERNMENT IS LAX ABOUT SPEED LIMIT
description: An automobile safety advocacy group and a consumer organization sued the Government today, charging that it failed to require states to enforce the national speed limit, 55 miles per hour, and neglected to impose fines.

title: Breaking the Logjam
description: The strategic weapons debate has broken wide open in the aftermath of Reykjavik. North Atlantic Treaty Organization officials and others have come to recognize that despite all their reservations, what was proposed there by President Reagan and General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev cannot be wiped away.

title: ARBITRAGE LOSS COULD BE A BILLION
description: Wall Street's arbitrage community suffered losses estimated as high as $1 billion as a result of sharp declines in the value of takeover-related stocks during the last week, traders said yesterday. The losses are regarded as the most severe in the history of the arbitrage business.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of $7,932,000 for the estimated cost of employee termination payments and writedowns of inventories and equipment for both periods, and for the 9 months includes a pre-tax gain of $895,000 from a fire insurance settlement. c-Net income

title: Careers; Colleges Aid Ousted Managers
description: WEEK by week the numbers of dimissed middle managers rise, and yet little attention to date has been paid by universities to the troubles of this growing group. Now a few, such as St. Joseph's University in Philadelphia and Washington University in St. Louis, have made tentative efforts to help. They have begun to encourage older managers to take courses in fields that still offer good job opportunies.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
METRO CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in September, and a shift from LIFO to FIFO inventory valuation.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What causes hiccups and what's the best way to obtain relief? A.Hiccups are sudden, involuntary contractions of the diaphragm. Although the exact cause of these spasms is unknown, many doctors believe the condition results from disruptions in the normal pattern of breathing that may occur while a person is laughing or coughing. Hiccups may also be caused by emotional disturbances or disorders of the chest or abdomen. Normally, hiccups last two to five minutes, but some chronic cases persist for months and even years. There is no full-proof method for relieving hiccups, according to Dr. Timothy Ives, who has conducted studies on chronic hiccups at the University of North Carolina Medical School. Dr. Ives said that in mild cases folk remedies such as drinking a glass of water without stopping for breath, sucking on a bitter lemon, breathing into a paper bag and eating a spoonful of sugar have proved effective because they break the spasms affecting the diaphram. For chronic cases, doctors prescribe a number of tranquilizing drugs such as chlorpromazine that have fast-acting calming agents that may also eliminate the spasms, Dr. Ives said. Q.What is meant by the term air quality and how is it determined? A.Air quality is an indication of the healthfulness of the air, based on the number of pollutants it contains. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation constantly monitors the air for six different pollutants: sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, particulates, lead and ozone.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $540,000 and is after a non-recurring after-tax charge of $6.9 million for locomotive inventory re-evaluation.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about complaints over ''indecent'' language on radio misstated an interpretation of a 1978 Supreme Court ruling on the subject.

title: Jackson Meets Students At Citadel for Talks
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met today with about 30 black cadets at The Citadel to discuss recent racial problems at the state-supported military school.

title: So Far So Strong in Manila
description: Abruptly, Cory Aquino has given the Philippines what it most needed: the smack of firm leadership. With the help of a loyal general, President Aquino has fired a disloyal defense minister and named a first-class successor. Her perils are by no means over, but she has won time and respect for the democratic cause.

title: Affiliated Offering
description: >Affiliated Publications, which publishes The Boston Globe, said yesterday that the Jordon Trust, which owns 30.5 percent of Affiliated's stock, would sell 350,000 shares in a public offering at a maximum price of $65.87.

title: New Banking Weekly
description: The American Banker, owned by Canada's International Thomson Organization, is bringing forth an offshoot called Banking Week, for financial service executives. It will have a circulation of 15,000 and will charge $3,168 for a four-color ad page and $2,400 for a black-and-white page.

title: UNLICENSED CENTERS INCREASING, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The day care center in Brooklyn where two children were killed in a fire yesterday is one of what state and Federal officials say is a growing number of unlicensed child-care operations across the country.

title: OIL-DRI CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in July.

title: Austrian Socialists To Try to Form Cabinet
description: President Kurt Waldheim will ask Chancellor Franz Vranitzky, a Socialist, to form a government, the President's spokesman said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $61,000 for the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $284,000 for the 9 months. c-After a charge of $170,000 for the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $132,000 for the 9 months.

title: THE AUDIENCE AS JURY
description: TELEVISION is tinkering with audience-participation gimmicks that could turn out to be the ultimate weapon in ''give 'em what they want'' marketing. The viewers, it seems, can have their say on how a program should end. Tonight at 9, for instance, NBC is offering the third sampling of an odd little exercise called ''You Are the Jury.'' This one, called ''The State of Ohio v. James Wolsky,'' dramatizes an actual murder trial while giving viewers an opportunity to call in their votes of guilty or innocent on special 900 telephone numbers (there is a charge of 50 cents for each call).

title: IVY COACHES SEEK SPRING PRACTICES
description: Several of the Ivy League's football coaches feel that the league's level of play has gone down sharply in recent seasons and the time has come to appeal to the university presidents for, as one of them put it, a ''signal of encouragement.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; Born-Again Steel
description: Saddled with aging plants and expensive labor, stagnant demand and aggressive foreign competition, the once-proud giants of American steel totter. LTV, the second largest, has declared bankruptcy in order to break its union contract and shed its underfunded pension plan. Bethlehem, number three, is reportedly eyeing a similar strategy. Number one, USX - formerly U.S. Steel - is enmeshed in labor conflict and is trying to edge out of the business before it is dismembered by corporate raiders.

title: ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,251,000 for the quarter and $8,342,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes a $220,000 tax credit.

title: MANILA WILL SHIFT DISSIDENT OFFICERS
description: The new Philippine Defense Minister said today that he would reassign rebellious officers associated with his predecessor and was investigating reports that a coup had been planned against President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: BALANCHINE LIVES ON IN DISCIPLES
description: One of the glories of ballet is the way each new development in the art is eventually absorbed into tradition. In our own time, the choreography of George Balanchine has profoundly influenced ballet, and the New York City Ballet, which he and Lincoln Kirstein founded, has become a great company. Now, dancers who once worked with Balanchine are directing companies of their own across the country. Balanchine's influence lives on - but in many different ways.

title: SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-Net loss

title: AQUINO'S ACTION: A VICTORY WITH STRINGS ATTACHED
description: In a single stroke, President Corazon C. Aquino has for the moment strengthed her hand against opponents on both the right and the left wings.

title: State Mortgage Agency Altering Disbursement
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, known as Sony Mae, is offering $333 million of tax-exempt bonds to refund outstanding bonds and to finance low-cost home mortages.

title: King Hussein Tells Delegates Of Being Duped on Iran Arms
description: King Hussein said Washington had urged him to help with an arms blockade of Iran only days before American arms shipments to that country were revealed, the leader of a Congressional delegation said today.

title: BUYING BY BOESKY IS REPORTED
description: Ivan F. Boesky's investment company has sparked further concern over what market sources say were its purchases last week of several takeover-related stocks. This may have allowed Mr. Boesky's firm to benefit from the steep price decline in many of these stocks that was caused by the news that he had settled insider trading charges and that the Government's investigation was widening to possibly include other Wall Street figures.

title: Pepsico Names 2 For New Groups
description: Michael H. Jordan, the president of Pepsico Inc., and Roger A. Enrico, the president of the Pepsi-Cola Company, were named yesterday to head new groups in a major reorganization of Pepsico's beverage and snack-foods business.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it didn't have any revenue in the 1985 quarter and 9 months.

title: To Jump or Jog?
description: The long-standing belief that jumping rope for 10 minutes can provide the cardiovascular benefits of 30 minutes of jogging has been disproved in a six-week study of 26 formerly sedentary volunteers. The 17 women and nine men who participated were randomly assigned to either jump, jog or remain sedentary.

title: 13 BLACK MINERS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA VIOLENCE
description: At least 13 black mine workers were slain over the weekend in politically inspired battles at one of South Africa's biggest gold mines, according to reports today.

title: INTELOGIC TRACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
PROSECUTOR PONDERS MERCY FOR A MERCY-KILLING DOCTOR
description: THE Prosecutor has much to think about between now and sentencing Dec. 19. Should he recommend prison for the popular Dr. Joe?

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Charles L. Gould, 77, Dies; Publisher in San Francisco
description: Charles L. Gould, publisher of The San Francisco Examiner for 14 years, died of cancer Sunday in Mills Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Reagan Considers Berlin
description: President Reagan is expected to go to Venice in the spring for the meeting of heads of state of the leading industrial nations. As long as he is in the neighborhood, why not a side trip to Berlin to participate in that city's 750th anniversary celebration?

title: Fed Plan on Banks' Real Estate Role
description: In a move that would override state banking laws and cause some banks to reduce large real estate operations, the Federal Reserve Board today proposed to let banks enter real estate development on a very limited basis.

title: COUNCIL PANEL OPPOSING KOCH OVER HOMELESS
description: A City Council committee created to recommend solutions to the problem of New York's homeless yesterday attacked the Koch administration's plan to build temporary housing at 20 sites scattered equally throughout the five boroughs.

title: People
description: * Joel Novak has joined the Goldhirsh Group as executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: ABC TELEVISION WILL DROP LATE-NIGHT PROGRAMS
description: ABC announced yesterday that it planned to get out of late-night programming. The announcement came a day after one of the network's late-night stars, Jimmy Breslin, said he was canceling his program himself.

title: 2 INTELSAT OFFICERS ARE PUT ON LEAVE
description: Intelsat, the cooperative of governments that runs the worldwide satellite communications network, placed its top two executives on ''administrative leave'' today after an outside auditor raised questions about a $1.3 million payment in connection with refinancing of a loan on the agency's new headquarters in Washington.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUFFTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued oil and gas operations of $8,030 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $423,163 for the year. c-Net loss d-After a loss from discontinued oil and gas operations of $584,034 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $443,185 for the year.

ALLSTAR VIDEO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Rumanian Vote Turnout Reported Nearly Perfect
description: All but 228 eligible Rumanians voted in the referendum Sunday to approve President Nicolae Ceausescu's decision to reduce Rumania's military spending, manpower and arms by 5 percent, the referendum commission announced today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary yesterday of Gen. John Paul McConnell, a retired Air Force Chief of Staff, carried an incorrect listing provided by the Air Force for his survivors. General McConnell and the former Sally Dean were divorced in 1970.

title: Body Care Inserts for Magazines
description: THE editorial staffs of Good Housekeeping and American Health are cooperating to produce an insert that will run in the May issues of both magazines with the title ''Body Be Beautiful.'' Unlike many recent similar events in publishing, this insert will not be an ''advertorial,'' but pure staff-created editorial supported by advertising.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 25, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Despite U.A.W. Settlement, Some G.M. Workers Are Idle
description: Assembly line workers today resumed production at General Motors Corporation's Delco Electronics plant after a six-day strike, but a parts shortage kept 15 other plants closed, idling more than 47,000 workers, the company said.

title: BARCLAYS PULLOUT: THE PRESSURE GREW
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said today that the decision to sell its South African unit had been made for ''basically commercial'' reasons. But the Barclays executives acknowledged that the move had also been deeply affected by the growing pressure worldwide against Pretoria's apartheid Government and against foreign businesses seen to be dealing with it.

title: TWO OFFICERS SHOT IN QUEENS AFTER DISRUPTING A ROBBERY
description: Two Port Authority police officers and a holdup man were seriously wounded in a shootout that erupted when the two officers and a colleague stumbled upon a robbery at a Queens diner yesterday morning, police officials said.

title: KNICKS' PROBLEMS CONTINUE TO MOUNT
description: Throughout the continuing miseries of the Knick season, the single image of hope - the carrot, so to speak - harbored by players, coaches and management alike was that by midseason, everything would be fine.

title: Bozell Named Agency for Dial
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Dallas, which handled Dial antiperspirant and deodorant brands on a project basis for the last two months, has now been officially named the agency for the $1.5 million account.

title: THEATER: 'SMILE,' A MUSICAL COMEDY
description: THE endearing passion to be found in ''Smile,'' the new musical at the Lunt-Fontanne, has little to do with beauty pageants, nubile teen-age girls, corrupted American values or any other subject that the show keeps claiming to be about. What clearly drives Howard Ashman, the author of the book and lyrics, and Marvin Hamlisch, the composer, is their deep affection for the lighthearted musical comedies of their youth - during the form's last, pre-rock-and-roll gasp of the late 1950's and early 1960's. In ''Smile,'' mementos of that sassy time can be found when its young women are gyrating in their dormitory cubicles (a la ''Bye Bye Birdie'') or delivering a comedy number before sinks in a washroom (''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'') or parading on a runway circling the orchestra pit early in Act II (''Hello, Dolly!''). And why not? As this Broadway season has demonstrated with a vengeance, there are many worse reasons to put on a show than sheer love of the musical's happier past.

title: UNION CARBIDE HEARINGS ARE SHIFTING TO BHOPAL
description: The legal battle over the thousands of claims arising out of the 1984 pesticide leak at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant in Bhopal, India, continued yesterday at a Federal appeals court in New York and will move to the courts in Bhopal tomorrow.

title: Electricity Bonds Of South Carolina
description: The Piedmont Municipal Power Agency of South Carolina is tentatively offering $350 million of electric revenue bonds through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: INSIDE
description: Takeover Action Swings Up A lull in merger activity abruptly ended, with billion-dollar offers for Chesebrough-Pond's, Borg-Warner and Carter Hawley Hale.

title: AUTO SALES IN MID-NOVEMBER INCREASED BY 6.4%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles rose by 6.4 percent in the Nov. 11-20 period from the corresponding period last year, the major manufacturers reported today.

title: VIENNA SIFTS CLAIMS TO NAZI ART CACHE
description: Austrian officials have begun sifting through 371 claims to a random collection of art objects confiscated by the Nazis during World War II and stored in Austria.

title: Music to His Ears
description: Robert Besen, the director of programs for the Concert Artists Guild in Manhattan, is obviously a man able to discern implications in a simple sports story that escape most readers. Of an item in these pages last week, announcing that the Hofstra University football team had been selected for the Division III playoffs, he wrote:

title: Chase Leasing Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Leasing Company, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, has agreed to acquire the Clark Equipment Credit Corporation for $191 million.

title: IN A SPEECH, CUOMO URGES THE PRESS TO POLICE ITSELF OR FACE RESTRICTIONS
description: Governor Cuomo, declaring that news organizations appear to be losing public favor, called on them last night to police themselves for abuses or face limitations on their freedoms by increasingly unsympathetic courts.

title: Women's League For Volleyball
description: The formation of a professional women's volleyball league for this spring was announced today.

title: TAMING THE N.S.C.
description: If any doubts remain that a totally unrestrained National Security Council has been running loose in the White House, yesterday's unceremonious departure of Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the N.S.C.'s chief of staff, and Lt. Col. Oliver North, an N.S.C. operative in the Iranian arms deal, should put them to rest. In its zest for covert operations, the N.S.C. staff has not only circumvented the State Department, the Central Intelligence Agency and Congress, but may have kept the President himself in the dark as well.

title: SUBCONTRACTING A KEY ISSUE FOR LABOR
description: Decisions by more and more companies to subcontract work to outside suppliers, including nonunion and overseas sources, have become a highly contentious issue in labor-management relations.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.2%
description: Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October as increases for new cars and auto financing overtook a fresh drop in energy prices, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Faust Anxious
description: Gerry Faust, the former Notre Dame football coach who led the University of Akron to a 7-4 record this season, is awaiting word from the N.C.A.A. if the Zips' plan to move to the big-school Division I-A will be approved. If not, Faust says he will seek work elsewhere. Because I-A coaches are allowed 25 more scholarships than 1-AA (95 to 70), Faust said his job at Akron was ''tougher, because you've got to teach them two positions.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Supermarket of Future Last week the Regional Conference on Food looked at the future of food marketing - and the future was now: a computerized pricing system with wired shelves and liquid crystal readouts showing prices for each item in the grocery store. That was just one of the new developments featured at the conference, which is sponsored by the Food Marketing Institute, a trade organization with 1,500 member companies that operate 17,000 retail food stores nationwide.

title: LIGHT WAVES ACROSS THE SEA
description: DEEP in the marshlands of New Jersey, engineers of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are piecing together the initial segments of the first trans-Atlantic underwater fiber-optic cable. When it is completed in 1988, at a cost of $335 million, the light-wave communication system will stretch 3,600 nautical miles from Tuckerton on the New Jersey shore to Britain and France, beginning a new era in trans-Atlantic data communications.
