title: FILM: 'MOSQUITO COAST,' WITH HARRISON FORD
description: WHEN, at the beginning of Paul Theroux's novel ''The Mosquito Coast,''

title: 1,000 TRAPPED SKIERS ARE FREED AS FLOOD VICTIMS RETURN IN WEST
description: Crews reopened a road today to free nearly 1,000 weekend skiers who were stranded for two nights near Mount Baker. They took the action as residents of flooded communities returned home after soggy weather that took two lives.

title: Real Estate; How a City Is Luring Industry
description: WHEN a busy rubber products plant in Shelton, Conn., exploded in 1975, a major source of employment and tax revenue for the city was lost. The B. F. Goodrich plant, as it was still called, had recently come under new ownership. Amid the smoldering ruins, the fortunes of the northern Fairfield County municipality did not look promising.

title: North Carolina Officers Search for Fugitive
description: More than 400 law-enforcement officers hunting a survivalist suspected in a series of robberies searched a rugged area of apple orchards and forest today after a deputy was ambushed and shot in the face earlier in the day.

title: THEATER: ODETS'S 'FLOWERING PEACH' AT FOLKSBIENE'
description: BEFORE anyone condescends to the Folksbiene Playhouse, New York's oldest stage company, a visit is recommended to this Yiddish troupe's bouncy new production of ''The Flowering Peach,'' the 1954 Broadway play in which Clifford Odets undertook a new recounting of Noah, his family and his ark.

title: McCONKEY'S DAYS OFF PAY OFF
description: If you were not listening closely you might not have heard it, and even if you were listening closely the line might have floated by.

title: New Haven Theater Wins Jujamcyn Award
description: The third annual Jujamcyn Theaters Award was presented Monday evening to the Long Wharf Theater of New Haven during a dinner at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: HOLIDAY FOR MARKETS
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of Thanksgiving Day. So will Government offices, banks and most businesses. The markets, Government offices and banks will be open Friday as usual, although some businesses will be closed Friday.

title: Terms Set for British Gas
description: Britain's Conservative Government took its boldest step yet in reducing the role of the state in Britain's postwar industrial economy when it announced the terms under which it would sell British Gas to the public. About 4 billion shares in the state-owned gas monopoly are being offered at $:1.35, or $1.91, each.

title: STATEMENT BY REAGAN AND KEY SECTIONS OF REMARKS BY MEESE
description: Following are a transcript of President Reagan's statement and exchange with reporters in Washington yesterday, as provided by the White House and transmitted by The Associated Press, and key sections of a news conference by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. CELTICS, at Boston, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) LOS ANGELES LAKERS VS. CLIPPERS, at Los Angeles, 10:30 P.M. (Television -WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) HOCKEY ISLANDERS VS.

title: Trade in the Works
description: The Washington Capitals announced yesterday that they planned to trade Bobby Carpenter, once their high-scoring center, as soon as possible. Carpenter, 23 years old, has not missed a game in his six seasons as a pro, a streak of 422 games.

title: REAGAN TELLS SHULTZ TO RUN POLICY ON IRAN FROM NOW ON
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was given control of American policy toward Iran by President Reagan today, ending the National Security Council staff's secret dealings, the State Department said.

title: Ulster Lurches Toward the Fate of Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospital Evaluations Must Be Made Public
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 L.I. Companies Fined in Bid-Rigging
description: Four Long Island companies, and five of their officers, were ordered yesterday to pay the state $2.6 million in damages resulting from bid-rigging on road repair contracts.

title: TOP LEGISLATORS PROMISE INQUIRY
description: Congressional leaders expressed astonishment today at the latest disclosures about United States dealings with Iran and vowed to investigate the Administration's actions.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY TAKING CUE FROM PROS
description: College hockey is becoming like professional hockey in its more base aspects, too much fighting, slashing, elbowing and high-sticking.

title: PANEL OPPOSES AWARDING WORK TO CONTRIBUTORS
description: Major campaign contributors should be barred from receiving city contracts approved by the officials they have contributed to, a joint state-city commission recommended yesterday.

title: The Facts Roar for Themselves
description: The most chilling disclosure at the White House yesterday was not any single fact but the evidence of a collapse of judgment and values. The dealings with Iran by White House cowboys turn out to be secondary facets of a more profound crisis. Poor policies and reckless aides can be replaced. Trust cannot, and now the powder trail runs right to the Oval Office.

title: ONE DRUMMER'S DREAM: A BIG BAND THAT'S BIG
description: BACKSTAGE conversation after Rolling Stones shows wasn't all fuel for the gossip mills. Conversations with the Stones' drummer, Charlie Watts, and bassist, Bill Wyman, often had a way of circling back around to one enduring standard of musical excellence - the rhythm section of the original Count Basie band. Listening to the late-1930's Basie recordings, with Walter Page playing bass and Jo Jones drums, the Stones' rhythm team would assert, ''Nobody's done it any better than that.''

title: Japanese Attempt To Make a Chip
description: When Japan's semiconductor makers wanted to produce a microprocessor, they just licensed the rights from American chip makers like Motorola or Intel. But recent disputes over technology theft have made American companies hesitant to share designs of their next-generation 32-bit chips, the cornerstone of new work stations and small computers. So Japan's chip makers have decided to make their own.

title: Oil-Price Slide Checked Despite Doubt on OPEC
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products moved sluggishly yesterday as oil traders worried that next month's OPEC meeting would fail to produce an agreement reducing the organization's output below the current level of 17 million barrels a day.

title: Goodyear to Take 4th-Period Charge
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $150 million to pay for restructuring moves taken to fend off a takeover bid from Sir James Goldsmith, the British-French financier. The charge, which means Goodyear could show a substantial loss in the fourth quarter and sharply reduced earnings for the whole year, is the latest fallout to hit the world's largest tire manufacturer since it undertook several measures this month to defeat the takeover bid.

title: Parents Sue School Board For Banning Textbook
description: Four parents have sued a county school board for banning a humanities textbook that contained modern adaptations of two classic stories.

title: Money, Money, Money
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of Ivan F. Boesky's insider trading practices has resulted in a spate of publicity for the investment bank-ing firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., some of whose officers have been summoned to provide information. Which may make readers of Washingtonian magazine less surprised when they read in the next issue that the second-largest money earner in the capital this year, with an estimated $2 million, was Ron Needelman, a Drexel Burnham broker. The only higher money earner in town, at $2.1 million, was Moses Malone, the high-scoring center for the Washington Bullets.

title: AUSCHWITZ SURVIVOR HONORED
description: Sigmund Strochlitz, a 69-year-old survivor of the Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen death camps who is now a civic leader in New London, Conn., was presented the International Elie Wiesel Remembrance Award last night in recognition of his ''dedicated efforts to keep alive the memory of the Holocaust.''

title: C.F.T.C. TRADING RULE
description: The commodity Futures Trading Commission voted unanimously today to prohibit employees of commodity exchanges and futures associaions from disclosing non-public information to the benefit of someone tradding futures, options or cash commodities on a C.F.T.C.-regulated exchange.

title: DURABLES ORDERS DOWN 6%
description: New orders for durable goods dropped 6 percent in October, the biggest decline in two and a half years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: RATES MIXED AT CITICORP SALE
description: Interest rates were mixed at Citicorp's weekly auctions of three-month and six-month commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 5.801 percent, up from 5.790 percent last week. It also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 5.685 percent, down from 5.740 percent.

title: Advertising; Alvin Ailey Campaign Is Set
description: USUALLY Davidoff & Partners, a $15 million-in-billings shop in Fairfield, Conn., is busily engaged in promoting such things as pizza eating at the local Domino's, shopping at the Norwalk factory outlet or banking at the Central Bank for Savings.

title: AN EXECUTIONER'S SONG: FRESH FOWL IS PROFITABLE
description: The line forms early in the morning these days outside Antzis Live Poultry Market in Harlem. The customers want meat - fresh meat.

title: CALIFORNIA BRACES FOR CHANGE WITH ENGLISH AS OFFICIAL LANGUAGE
description: California is preparing to translate into practical terms a new law making English the official language of the state, a measure that could lead to sweeping changes in the way schools do their teaching and the way the state conducts its daily business.

title: IN THE BRONX, A SENSE THAT JUSTICE HAS BEEN SERVED
description: Up the block from Bronx Democratic headquarters, Frank Lorenzo stood behind the counter of his candy store and thought about the Stanley Friedman who used to come in to buy cigars and kid around.

title: Coping With a Turkey
description: THE sheer size a Thanksgiving turkey allows even the most maladroit carver to rescue enough meat for the family, even if the carcass left behind looks as if it has been picked over by a pack of wolves. The simple carving technique pictured here yields neat portions with minimal struggle.

title: NEW FACE ON RESTAURANTS IS FRENCH, BUT HOW FRENCH?
description: THE new American cuisine - a genre that has enjoyed a short but intense life span in New York - is going the way of Tuscan, Sichuan and Cajun cooking. For every American restaurant that has opened during the last year, three times as many have started up with French menus or, at least, French names. Few of these restaurants are French in the sense that Lutece is French, but for various reasons restaurateurs have chosen increasingly to link themselves with France.

title: BANKAMERICA OUTLINES ITS OBJECTIONS TO MERGER
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, in a document that is being circulated to securities analysts, is preparing arguments that will allow it to reject a merger proposed by the First Interstate Bancorp or that will persuade regulators to reject it.

title: The Well Trashed Art
description: Ted Turner, tycoon, is having a batch of black-and-white movies ''colorized'' in order to maximize profits and is being severely criticized for it.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS ERRORS AT HANFORD NUCLEAR PLANT
description: A special team from the Federal Department of Energy said today that Rockwell International should have shut two plants at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation here when an internal auditor called for a shutdown for security reasons.

title: SISTER OF U.S. HOSTAGE IN LEBANON PRAISES REAGAN FOR HIS 'COURAGE'
description: A sister of an American captive in Lebanon, long a critic of Administration policy on the hostage issue, has written a letter to President Reagan in support of his Iran initiative and expressed ''a deep sense of shame'' that she had not spoken out sooner.

title: THE CHRONOLOGY
description: Jan. 10 - The police stop Donald R. Manes, the Queens Borough President, near La Guardia Airport at 1:50 A.M. Bleeding from cuts on his wrist and ankle, he undergoes surgery for three hours at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing. Jan. 13 - Mr. Manes tells the police he was kidnapped by two men who had been hiding in his car. Jan. 15 - Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the deputy director of the Parking Violations Bureau and a protege of Mr. Manes, is arrested on charges of extorting $5,000 from a company the bureau had hired to track down scofflaws. Jan. 20 - City officials cancel a $22.7 million parking bureau contract with Citisource Inc. for a hand-held ticket-issuing device, saying the company had misrepresented itself. Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, is a Citisource stockholder and director.

title: Shame and Stanley Friedman
description: To the end, Stanley Friedman, the Bronx political boss, has tried to portray himself as a canny wheeler-dealer trading on friendship and street smarts, but now the Federal jury in New Haven accurately calls him, among other things, a fraud. By corrupting New York City's parking agency, he dealt not in shrewd political favors but crude criminal bribes, not clever lawyering but corrupt influence. He and his associates stand convicted of plundering the city, exploiting the weaknesses they learned in public jobs that they turned into racketeering apprenticeships.

title: AFTER VERDICT, A HOTEL SCUFFLE
description: Soon after Stanley M. Friedman was found guilty of Federal corruption charges today, he and his wife had a fight with a part-time photographer for The Daily News. The police arrested all three for assault.

title: Editors' Note
description: Starting today, The Times adopts the spelling ''Beijing'' in place of ''Peking'' for the name of China's capital.

title: STAGE: 'BEDROOM FARCE'
description: When, at the end of Act I of ''Bedroom Farce,'' the lights go off in its three busy bedrooms, the play has yet to switch on much excitement. Not that the commotion so far has been unenjoyable or that, given Alan Ayckbourn's inventiveness as a framer of farce, further frolic will not be forthcoming. But the playwright does not seem to have really gotten into bed with his characters.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: HEADED PLANNING OF WESTWAY
description: Lowell K. Bridwell, a former Federal Highway Administrator who headed a planning group for the Westway project in Manhattan, died Friday at his home in Columbia, Md. He was 62 years old.

title: Tripped Up
description: As soon as Arizona State clinched the Pac-10 football championship and a bid to the Rose Bowl, many of the team's fans in the Tempe-Phoenix area were on the phone with their travel agents, booking flights to California for the New Year's Day game and return trips a day or so later.

title: The Truth at Last, Maybe
description: At least one thing is clear about this whole squalid arms deception. It could scarcely have happened with a President in charge of his Administration.

title: Kaiser Steel Delays Meeting
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation, in the midst of a battle for control of its six-member board, said that its annual meeting of preferred shareholders, which had been scheduled for today, would be adjourned until Monday and that the polls for election of directors would remain open until the close of business on Dec. 1.

title: Suffolk Legislators Fail to Override Veto
description: Warned that county jobs and programs would be cut, members of the Suffolk County Legislature reversed themselves yesterday and allowed $33 million back into the 1987 county budget.

title: Ohio Bus Strike Ruled Illegal
description: A state board ruled today that a 2-day strike by more than 600 bus drivers and mechanics was illegal, and the union president said workers would be back on the job by Friday. The State Employment Relations Board said its decision allowed the Central Ohio Transit Authority, whose buses normally carries 90,000 passengers a day, to hire replacement workers and dismiss striking workers, but the bus company said it did not intend to do either.

title: Sidney Goldstein Dies at 80, Ex-Counsel of Port Authority
description: Sidney Goldstein, who was general counsel of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for 20 years, died of a heart attack Thursday at his physician's office in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: South African Says Jet Tape Clears His Country in Crash
description: A South African investigator examining cockpit voice recordings from the plane in which President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique was killed said today that the new information supported his country's assertion that it was not involved in the crash.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''As I've stated previously, I believe our policy goals toward Iran were well founded.

title: SCREEN: 'NUTCRACKER'
description: THE joys of ''The Nutcracker'' are simple and seasonal: the fanciful settings, the soaring music, the seas of flying tulle. But ''Nutcracker: The Motion Picture,'' a new film version directed by Carroll Ballard and designed by Maurice Sendak, aims for something more. It's an ornate film that takes a sophisticated and ambitious approach to its material. And it shows why there's no good substitute for simply holding the camera still and letting dancers do what they do best.

title: Transfusion for New York's Lifeline
description: Even skeptical New York City subway riders have to agree that the transit system, once headed for collapse, finally seems to be coming back. Handsome new and renovated cars have vindicated investment under intelligent direction, at least on the lines on which they have been concentrated, notably the I.R.T. And aggressive efforts to regain control over track maintenance finally are paying off in reduced delays.

title: MANILA AND REBELS SAY CEASE-FIRE COULD BE SIGNED IN A DAY OR TWO
description: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino said tonight that it might be within two days of signing a cease-fire agreement with Communist rebels.

title: NEW DOUBT RAISED ON RESPONSIBILITY
description: The Reagan Administration's assertions that Israel made unauthorized arms shipments to Iran and that only two officials in Government knew that money was being diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels were immediately challenged today by knowledgeable officials, intelligence experts and members of Congress.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Mayor Koch's press secretary misidentified him.

title: NASDAQ SHORT INTEREST IS UP BY 3.5%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. reported yesterday that its short interest on Nasdaq stocks was up 6.7 million shares, or 3.5 percent, in the month ended Nov. 14, to 197.1 million shares.

title: LESSON IN ECONOMICS: LOW OIL PRICES - NO COFFEE
description: Muscovites, already enduring a Government crackdown on vodka consumption, face a new problem: a coffee shortage.

title: Article 807386 -- No Title
description: A dozen workers from a Union County electroplating plant today claimed one of the two winning shares in the state lottery's $6.3 million Pick-6 Lotto jackpot.

title: Hudson Transitway Is a Start on the Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BACKSTORY. Interviews With Screenwriters of Hollywood's Golden Age. By Pat McGilligan. Illustrated. 382 pages.

title: B51 Bus Route Made Official, With Trims
description: The B51 bus route, which has linked downtown Brooklyn and lower Manhattan on a trial basis since last year, has been made permanent, but with some cuts in service.

title: STORY ON GOVERNOR STIRS DEBATE IN NEW MEXICO
description: A monthly magazine here has been accused by other journalists of unfairness in arranging and publishing a psychological commentary on Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Oct. 22 misidentified a fish-oil product assigned to DFS Dorland Worldwide by E. R. Squibb & Sons. It is called Proto-Chol.

title: Kaiser Accepts Plan For New Company
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that it had agreed in principle with the British investor Alan Clore, its largest shareholder, to form a new holding company, with Mr. Clore as chairman. The agreement caps a 15-month takeover effort led by Joseph A. Frates, an investor from Tulsa, Okla., and an associate of Mr. Clore.

title: SOVIET WANTS KEY DISSIDENT TO EMIGRATE
description: The wife of a well-known dissident who has spent more than 20 years in prison, labor camps and internal exile said today that the K.G.B. had urged her to apply for emigration for her family.

title: PROSECUTORS EXPECT VERDICTS TO ADD VIGOR TO NEW CASES
description: The verdicts against Stanley M. Friedman and three co-defendants will clear the way for a new round of corruption inquiries, including some that have been held up pending the outcome of Mr. Friedman's trial, law enforcement officals said yesterday.

title: AMERICAN BRANDS IN MERGER BID
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., the maker of Vaseline, Pond's beauty creams, Ragu spaghetti sauce and other well-known consumer products, said yesterday that American Brands, the big tobacco company, had offered to buy Chesebrough for $2.8 billion in cash.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
CHOCOLATE, HOT AND COLD
description: WHAT made milk palatable for many of us as children was the added spoonful of cocoa powder or squirt of chocolate syrup and the fun of mixing it ourselves, stirring waves and blowing bubbles through our straws. And winter usually becomes more palatable to children and adults when there's a mug of hot chocolate before us.

title: DRINKABLE DOMESTIC NOUVEAU ARRIVES, BUT FANFARE IS SLIGHT
description: WHEN Beaujolais nouveau from France arrived in New York City, the wine-trade publicists painted the town purple. When the nouveau from North America arrived, however, not a drop of prose was spilled.

title: ARMY BARS CONTRACTS FOR AYER
description: Just weeks before the Army was scheduled to announce whether it was reassigning its $100 million recruitment account to N. W. Ayer or giving it to another agency, Ayer has been suspended from entering into any new contracts with the Army or any other agency of the executive branch of the Government.

title: Michigan Wins Battle On Authority on Schools
description: The Supreme Court of Michigan today left standing a ruling that the state can continue to regulate church-operated schools by requiring certified teachers and certain courses of study.

title: SAUDI ARMS DEALER LINKED TO IRAN PURCHASES
description: A Saudi Arabian arms dealer played a central role in financing the Iranian purchase of United States weapons, Israeli and American sources said today.

title: ISLANDERS DOMINATE PENGUINS
description: The Islanders, at least in the opinions of Denis Potvin and Kelly Hrudey, had been looking forward to tonight's game with the Pittsburgh Penguins, the first in a home-and-home series, because they viewed it as a vehicle to improve their self-image.

title: Fumes Send 30 to Hospital
description: A vapor cloud leaked from a tanker at a chemical plant Monday, sending up to 30 people to a hospital and forcing the authorities to evacuate nearby residents, officials said.

title: S.M.U. to Tighten Standards
description: The trustees of Southern Methodist University voted today to tighten admission requirements for football players, less than two weeks after allegations that a former and a current player had received improper payments and other benefits.

title: Clayton in Deal For O.M. Scott
description: An investment group led by Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York-based investment firm, said it would buy O. M. Scott & Sons, a leading lawn and garden products concern, for $150 million from its parent, the ITT Corporation.

title: F.C.C. DROPS A RESTRICTION AGAINST BELL CONCERNS
description: The Federal Communications Commission today dropped its rule requiring the Bell telephone companies to use separate companies to sell telephone equipment.

title: To Sit by the President Like a Sitting Duck
description: These are not easy days to be a sitting Vice President with aspirations for 1988.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Home Products Corp. said it would sell its E. J. Brach candy business to Jacobs Suchard Ltd., a Switzerland-based maker of confectionary and coffee products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SHAKE-UP DUE IN BRONX PARTY, DEMOCRATS SAY
description: The conviction of Stanley M. Friedman will touch off a shake-up of the Bronx Democratic leadership, Bronx Democrats said yesterday. But the leadership succession is not clear, they added, because so many of the borough's top Democrats are themselves under investigation.

title: Thanksgiving Chez Reagan
description: President and Mrs. Reagan will once again spend the Thanksgiving holiday weekend at their California ranch.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE developed what amounts to an absolute passion for pasta. Although we often ate pasta when I was a youngster in Burgundy, it was generally in the form of plain old spaghetti. Even when I was a chef in luxury restaurants in France and in America, pasta was rarely served. The exception on the menu was breaded pork cutlets a la Milanese, which is to say in the style of Milan. The cutlets were invariably served in the classic fashion, with spaghetti in a tomato sauce.

title: Boesky Library To Change Name
description: The Jewish Theological Seminary will change the name of the Ivan F. and Seema Boesky Family Library to the Library of the Jewish Theological Seminary, the school announced yesterday.

title: Two Games Too Lenient
description: In the Green Bay Packers' media guide, Charles Martin's nickname jumps out of his biographical sketch:

title: Rare Repeaters
description: Playoff entry has grown since 1970, when 8 of 14 teams qualified. It expanded to 10 of 18 in 1974-75, 12 of 22 in 1976-77 and to the present 16 of 23 in 1983-84. How the last 17 league champions have fared the following season:

title: THE LIMITED GAINS ALLY FOR CARTER BID
description: For the second time in two and a half years, The Limited Inc. has made a bid to acquire Carter Hawley Hale Stores, the largest West Coast retailer and the owner of Neiman-Marcus and Bergdorf Goodman. This time, however, in its $1.8 billion cash offer made yesterday, The Limited was joined by the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, the nation's largest developer of shopping centers.

title: Grey Will Close Its Minneapolis Office
description: Largely because of the loss last summer of the Northwest Airlines account, Grey Advertising will close its Minneapolis office Dec. 31, move the remaining accounts billing between $7 million and $8 million to the New York office and dismiss some 31 employees.

title: TALKS WITH RHODEN ARE GIVEN PRIORITY
description: The Yankees' effort to reach agreement with Rick Rhoden on a contract extension appeared to collapse last night, but the two sides then resumed their talks and revived the chance that Rhoden would join the Yankees and bolster their pitching staff.

title: No More Demagogues
description: To the Editor:

title: VIRGIL THOMSON'S 90TH BIRTHDAY PARTY
description: It is somewhat atypical of Virgil Thomson, who knows virtually everything and remembers most of it, that he does not know the hour of his birth on Nov. 25, 1896. ''Rumor,'' he said last night, ''has it sometime in early morning, but I have no direct evidence, and I didn't think to ask.''

title: INDIANS WELCOME GORBACHEV GLADLY
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi welcomed Mikhail S. Gorbachev today as a ''crusader for peace'' and began four days of talks that are expected to lead to increased Soviet military and economic assistance to India.

title: SCREEN: 'SOLARBABIES'
description: ''S OLARBABIES,'' which opens today at the Criterion, is set in some arid future time when there's hardly any water left on earth, when the world is ruled by ''the Protectorate,'' and when the only hope for mankind is something that looks like a large lightbulb (it's round and glows), called Bodhi.

title: WALTON CALM AFTER THE ROUT
description: As if to ward off the inevitable questions that follow a 45-3 thrashing by the Dolphins, Joe Walton adopted an interesting attitude today - pride.

title: Decoy Deer Catches Motorists Who Hunt
description: A stuffed deer has been blasted by shotguns and riddled by automatic rifle fire, but still helps state wildlife agents catch dozens of illegal roadside hunters.

title: Loan-Report Rules Stiffer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new accounting procedures today intended to improve the reporting of troubled loans - both foreign and domestic - by bank holding companies.

title: JACOBS MAKES BID FOR BORG
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, chairman of the Minstar Corporation, announced today that his company had offered to purchase the Borg-Warner Corporation for $3.6 billion or more.

title: HEAD OF IMMIGRATION SERVICE URGES EMPLOYERS TO OBEY NEW ALIEN LAW
description: Immigration officials urged employers around the country today to comply voluntarily with a new law that prohibits the hiring of illegal aliens.

title: WILDLIFE AND OIL RIGS: CAN THEY COEXIST IN ARCTIC?
description: The dispute over whether oil drilling should be allowed within Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is a classic example of how two opposing sides can look at an environmental question and arrive at different answers.

title: G.M., A.M.C. Offer Rebates
description: The General Motors Corporation and the American Motors Corporation each announced new rebate programs today.

title: Texas Utilities' Plants Delayed
description: The Texas Utilities Company said today that completion of its two Comanche Peak nuclear plants would be delayed at least until 1989, with its share in the total cost of the projects increasing $2 billion, to $6.7 billion.

title: How to Raise the Deficit by Cutting It
description: The Federal deficit for October appears to have shrunk to $25.3 billion, which is $1.7 billion less than last year. Does that mean Congress is finally turning responsible about budgeting? No.

title: THINKING MAN'S PLAYS CHOOSE OFF BROADWAY
description: Simon Gray's latest play, ''The Common Pursuit,'' opened last month a mile north and about 200 seats shy of the nearest theater in the Broadway district. A literate British drama by a playwright whose successes include ''Butley'' and ''Otherwise Engaged'' on Broadway and many Off Broadway stagings, ''Common Pursuit'' won warm notices for the production at the 499-seat Promenade Theater on West 76th Street.

title: Bridge: Last-Minute Check of Cards Was Post-Mortem Surprise
description: When a session of team play is over, expert players normally remember enough about any particular situation to settle post-mortem arguments. But on rare occasions memory does not provide quite enough detail.

title: Al Smith, Cartoonist, Dead; Drew 'Mutt and Jeff' Comics
description: Al Smith, the cartoonist who drew the ''Mutt and Jeff'' comic strip for nearly half a century, died Monday at a nursing home here. He was 84 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The American Television and Communications Corporation, a cable TV system operator controlled by Time Inc., is offering $300 million of debt equally divided between notes and debentures through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: MARTIN OF PACKERS SUSPENDED
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League notified the Green Bay Packers yesterday that Charles Martin, the nose tackle who slammed Jim McMahon of the Chicago Bears to the ground Sunday, would be suspended for two games without pay.

title: NO DAMAGE, MRS. REAGAN SAYS
description: Nancy Reagan today briskly dismissed suggestions that the President had been badly damaged by the growing turmoil in his Administration over the Iran arms affair.

title: UNLICENSED DAY CARE CENTERS ARE SAID TO BE COMMON IN NEW YORK
description: The unlicensed day care center in Brooklyn in which two children died on Monday is probably one of ''tens of thousands'' of such homes in the city, child-care advocates said yesterday.

title: OFFICIALS SEE NEW IMPETUS FOR REFORM
description: Many of the people who run New York City's government - and some of those who monitor them - predicted yesterday that the guilty verdict in the trial of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, would act as yet another impetus to reform.

title: BALLET: 'AGON' FROM '57
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE choreographed many works to Igor Stravinsky's music.

title: Three Are Promoted At Leo Burnett Co.
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago seems to value corporate titles more than most ad agencies. It is more begrudging about doling them out, however.

title: Shearson Joins Beijing Project
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. agreed yesterday with two Chinese partners to develop a one-million-square-foot office and residential complex in Beijing. The $150 million project, to be known as the Beijing American Express Center, will serve the diplomatic and foreign corporate communities.

title: NEW YORK TO ACT TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS AT JAILS
description: The city's Department of Correction will take a series of actions, from requiring sensitivity training for officers to installing a 24-hour command and control center for crises, to reduce violence, drug abuse and corruption in the jails, officials said yesterday.

title: Devices Gain In Range and Sophistication
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission will not comment on reports that it has used electronic surveillance devices in its widening investigation into insider trading. Experts say that there was little need to use fancy bugs, wiretaps or hidden video cameras once central figures like Dennis B. Levine and Ivan F. Boesky agreed to cooperate.

title: People
description: * Edward Lebar, Robert Nadler and Jerilyn Dack have been named senior vice presidents at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

title: ESTIMATED COST OF THE TRIAL
description: While the legal bills faced by Stanley M. Friedman and his three co-defendants and the Government's cost to prosecute them will dwarf the administrative expenses of holding the trial, an eight-week proceeding such as the one in New Haven can be expensive.

title: HOW SEXUAL POLITICS LED TO THE THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY OF 1863
description: THE family festival celebrated tomorrow has its origins in 19th-century sexual and sectional politics. Because women were assumed to be naturally pious, submissive, charitable and nurturing, their moral power was often their strongest currency. Proponents of a national Thanksgiving wanted the holiday to harness that moral power as well as their labor power.

title: Ruling Accepted
description: Norris Coleman, the Kansas State sophomore who was the top-scoring freshman in the nation last season with a 21.8 average, has decided to accept the National Collegiate Athletic Association's latest ruling reducing his ineligibility from 27 games to 14. ''It isn't fair, but I think it is best I accept it for several reasons,'' Coleman said, citing among the reasons the fact that he'll be able to play the major portion of the season and in the postseason.

title: HOUR OF HEROICS RELIVES MET YEAR
description: Amazing how much of the Mets' 1986 season - especially the late stages - was attended to with eyes closed.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Canseco Top Rookie
description: Jose Canseco, who batted only .240 but battered American League pitching for 33 home runs and drove home 117 runs, became the first member of the Oakland A's to win Rookie of the Year honors when he finished ahead of Wally Joyner of the California Angels in the voting announced yesterday. The 22-year-old outfielder, who also struck out 175 times, received 16 of 28 first-place votes and 110 points in the balloting involving two sportswriters from each of the 14 American League cities.

title: DANCE: BALLET ESPANOL
description: A NEW theater opened last night when Ballet Espanol de Madrid appeared at the John Houseman Theater. The company presented both traditional Spanish dances and works on Spanish themes created in a style reminiscent of contemporary ballet and modern dance. The choreography by Goyo Montero, the troupe's artistic director, had its problems. But the 13 dancers and three musicians looked perfectly at home on stage.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Deutsche Bank A. G. is offering in the United States bond market $200 million of 7.35 percent notes due in 1992, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: FILM: 'STAR TREK IV: VOYAGE HOME'
description: LIFE must get lonely when it's lived in the shadow of an indestructible 20-year-old hit. The mind must begin to play strange tricks. What other explanation can there be for ''Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home,'' a large, lavish and absolutely sincere mass-market entertainment about saving the whales? Even in the 23d century, where the characters originate before they time-travel their way back to present-day San Francisco, there must be a few remaining sequel plots that are a little less demented than this.

title: Bokassa Trial Scheduled For Appeals Court
description: The Government decided today to put Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the deposed self-proclaimed Emperor, on trial in the Central Appeals Court instead of the sports stadium where he crowned himself in 1977.

title: LEBANON FIGHTING CONTINUES
description: Heavy fighting broke out again today in southern Lebanon around Maghdusheh, a village near the port city of Sidon that Palestinian forces captured from Shiite militiamen on Monday.

title: Two Contestants Split Prize After 139 Days
description: After enduring 139 days of rain, heat and cold in a parking lot to win a new car by being the last person to have a hand on it, the last two contestants struck a deal Monday to share the prize.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Holiday Tomorrow Tomorrow is Thanksgiving Day. Following are holiday schedules:

title: PHILIPPINE MILITARY HEADING BACK TO THE BARRACKS
description: After days of threats and coup plots and angry divisions, the Philippine armed forces may at last be moving toward unification and professionalization, according to Filipinos and Western military analysts.

title: Those Who Study Dinosaurs Face Extinction
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Layoffs Continue Because of Lack of Parts
description: More than 58,700 General Motors Corporation workers were told to stay home today because of mounting assembly plant layoffs.

title: Israeli President To Visit West Germany
description: President Chaim Herzog announced today that he would make a visit next year to West Germany, the first by an Israeli President.

title: BCI to Sell Webcraft Unit
description: The BCI Holdings Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Webcraft Technologies Inc. unit to a group led by management and Riordan Freeman & Spogli, a Los Angeles-based merchant banking firm, for about $275 million.

title: RECITAL: TORKIL BYE ON FLUTE
description: TORKIL BYE, who played a recital Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall, is the principal flutist of the Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra. He plays with fluency, dexterity and a sweet, full tone.

title: PRICES DIP AMID BIG SUPPLY
description: Note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday as securities dealers digested $8.25 billion of new five-year Treasury notes and a heavy supply of new corporate and mortgage-backed issues.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL SAN DIEGO (NL) - Named Jack Krol manager of Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL

title: Decision Reversed
description: The New York State Court of Appeals, reversing two lower-court decisions, has dismissed a $105 million lawsuit by Ron Turcotte, the jockey left paralyzed from the waist down after a 1978 spill at Belmont Park.

title: American Express Offers 7 7/8% Notes
description: The American Express Credit Corporation is offering $250 million of 7 7/8 percent notes due in 1996, at a price of 99.40 to yield 7.963 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Economic Scene; The Outlook: Steady Growth
description: THE ability of the stock market to roll with the hard punch of the Boesky affair suggests that the slow but surprisingly steady expansion of the economy is likely to continue.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: NOV. 26, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 12:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Court Upholds Energy Dept. In a Nuclear Waste Site Case
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Department of Energy acted properly in selecting three locations in Tennessee as possible sites for storing radioactive wastes.

title: RANGERS' CHOICE IS DUE
description: The Rangers have scheduled a news conference this afternoon to announce the signing of their new coach, and it is not likely to be the expected choice, Terry Crisp. Instead, it appears the Rangers will promote Tom Webster, the coach of the Windsor Spitfires of the Ontario Hockey League.

title: THE PRESSURE IS ON AND SHOOTING IS OFF
description: At the comparable time last season, the Los Angeles Lakers, one of the National Basketball Association's best-shooting teams over the last seven years, were averaging 124.6 points a game and shooting .531 from the field. Despite a 9-1 record, the best in the league going into last night's game against the Atlanta Hawks, the Lakers were averaging 116.5 points and shooting .511.

title: BEVERLY HILLS DEBATES DEFICIT AND LOSES AN ART COLLECTION
description: In a dispute over school budget deficits that ranged from tastes in art to the falling price of crude oil, a major art collector has withdrawn from an agreement to donate his collection to create a new art museum here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1986
description: Companies

title: NEW LIVES AWAIT 209 MONTAGNARDS
description: The cupboard is stocked with cans of bamboo shoots, a 50-pound burlap sack of rice and a package of cookies. Upstairs, in one of the house's eight bedrooms, plastic bags containing toothpaste and shaving cream rest beside secondhand beds with matching green sheets and pillow cases, all awaiting 16 montagnard refugees from Southeast Asia in their new home on Friendly Avenue.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECYCLING Many of the larger cities in the United States have amassed in their downtowns architecture that is old and derelict. Nowadays, despite the heedless tear-down, build-anew tradition that continues, more attention is being paid to efforts to take worthy structures of yesteryear and refurbish them to current purpose.

title: Between the Lions
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIEDMAN IS GUILTY WITH 3 IN SCANDAL
description: A jury today returned guilty verdicts against Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader and long one of New York City's most powerful political figures, on all charges against him in the first Federal trial stemming from New York City's corruption scandal.

title: 'A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA,' ON 13
description: ON May 2, 1986 - an otherwise ordinary day - scores of photographers fanned out across the United States, taking pictures for a book, ''A Day in the Life of America.'' Camera crews, filming for a television program, followed some of the photographers. The program, handsome and ambitious, and also called ''A Day in the Life of America,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: COURT ALLOWS BUMPURS CASE TO BE TRIED
description: New York State's highest court reinstated a manslaughter charge yesterday against a police officer who killed a knife-wielding, emotionally disturbed woman during an attempt to evict her from her Bronx apartment in 1984.

title: 'THE YOUNG COMEDIANS' IS PRESENTED ON HBO
description: HOME BOX OFFICE'S equivalent of an electronic borscht belt is already marking its 10th birthday this season, and several comics can be sampled in an hourlong special called ''The Young Comedians All-Star Reunion.'' The show can be seen on the pay-cable service at 9 o'clock this evening.

title: Former Gulf Chief Retiring at Chevron
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that James E. Lee would retire as vice chairman at the end of the year. Mr. Lee, who will be 65 years old in December, joined Chevron in 1984 when that oil company acquired another oil giant, the Gulf Corporation, where he had been chairman since 1981.

title: CABARET: 'ALL HART' SERIES
description: ''ALL HART,'' the title of the series of programs that opened at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, last week for a run through the first weekend in January, refers to the lyricist Lorenz Hart. But since Mr. Hart wrote almost all of his lyrics to the music of Richard Rodgers, the series inevitably involves Mr. Rodgers as much as it does Mr. Hart.

title: OLAJUWON'S FALL ELEVATES KNICKS
description: The looks on their faces said it all. With 7 minutes 37 seconds remaining in the fourth quarter of their game against the Knicks last night at Madison Square Garden, eight members of the Houston Rockets and their two coaches stood watching in dazed disbelief as Akeem Olajuwon, the league's most dominating center, was aided from the floor. His face was distorted in pain.

title: 5 SOVIET DESERTERS IN CANADA SPURN INVITATION TO GO HOME
description: Five Soviet soldiers who deserted in Afghanistan said here today that Soviet diplomats here had told them they could return home without penalty.

title: FRENCH TOLERANCE OF EROTICISM FADES
description: Reactions to a deluge of erotic films, magazines and advertising suggest that the French may have reached the limit of their long tolerance of soft pornography.

title: 2d Suspect Arrested In Police Shooting
description: A 26-year-old Bronx man was arrested early yesterday and charged with participating in a robbery and a shootout at a Queens diner Monday morning that left two Port Authority police officers wounded.

title: NETS LOSE, 117-99
description: Alvin Robertson scored 21 points and Ed Nealy came off the bench to add 19 as the San Antonio Spurs routed the New Jersey Nets, 117-99, tonight. The loss was the seventh in the row for the Nets.

title: Dolphins Re-sign Shula
description: Don Shula, second in career victories in the National Football League, ended months of speculation yesterday by signing a new contract with the Miami Dolphins. Joe Robbie, the owner, gave no specifics on the length or terms of the deal.

title: Sale of Debentures Begun by Quebec
description: The Province of Quebec yesterday began offering in the United States bond market $300 million of 8 5/8 percent debentures due in 2026, at a price of 99.60, to yield 8.661 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The size of the issue was increased from $250 million proposed earlier.

title: Market Place; BUYING SPREE BY PROGRAMS?
description: USUAL market wisdom holds that stock prices should be under intense downward pressure between now and year-end because many investors will be pruning portfolios before the higher taxes on capital gains take effect Jan. 1. Moreover, institutional investors are expected to engage once again in profit taking to dress their balance sheets with cash on Dec. 31.

title: IRAN, ARMS AND NICARAGUA: COMPLEX LEGAL ISSUES RAISED
description: The disclosure today of an operation to provide Nicaraguan rebels with millions of dollars from sales of American arms through Israel to Iran, raises questions under several criminal statutes and other laws.

title: Air and Space, Restaurant and Anger
description: Once, in the once-upon-a-time world of Warner LeRoy, a crystal palace restaurant was to have risen at the National Air and Space Museum. It has not risen, and Mr. LeRoy is angry, to the extent that he is threatening to sue the Smithsonian Institution, which runs the museum, for $2.4 million. In response, the Smithsonian says, among other things, ''Baloney.''

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THIS is the story of a turkey, and the things she cooked for Thanksgiving dinner. It is not an easy story to tell. It includes a bulb baster, those useless little metal rods Julia Child uses for trussing and quantities of cheesecloth heretofore undreamed of. And butter - my God, the butter. Even now, a full year later, I can see my hands stretched before me, gleaming horribly like that cranberry jelly you get in a can.

title: Dow, Continuing Upturn, Rises 6.05
description: The Dow Jones industrial average moved closer to record levels yesterday as stock prices rallied despite some bad news about the economy.

title: New Yorker Newsletter Courting Travel Trade
description: The latest of the innovative devices to be wrought upon The New Yorker by its new publisher, Steven T. Florio, is a quarterly newsletter called The New Yorker at Large.

title: GUY REPP
description: Guy Repp, a longtime stage and radio actor, died Monday of cancer at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan.

title: Passing the Word On the Heisman
description: Paul Palmer of Temple and Brian Bosworth of the University of Oklahoma, two members of the Kodak All-America Football Team who were in New York yesterday to chat with the news media, agree that Vinny Testaverde, the University of Miami quarterback, not only will win the Heisman Trophy next month, but also that he deserves it.

title: Prepaid Parking For Newark Airport
description: A new service to allow travelers to pay their parking fees at Newark International Airport while still in its terminals began yesterday and officials said it would reduce delays at parking lot exits.

title: THEATER: JIM LEHRER'S 'CHILI QUEEN'
description: AT the local Chili Queen parlor in Lamery, Tex., the specialty of the house is something called a chilicicle. The invention of its enterprising young manager, Junior Denison (Paul Doherty), this inedible compaction of frozen chili on a stick is, in the mind of its creator, a sure ticket to success in the world of fast food. And in Jim Lehrer's play ''Chili Queen,'' the reddish glob of dirt-colored ice becomes a symbol of the inchoate dreams of East Texas working people with very limited expectations.

title: Report Cites Marathoner
description: The London Standard reported today that Antoni Niemczak of Poland had failed a drug test after finishing second in the New York City Marathon.

title: REAGAN SECURITY ADVISER AND AIDE ARE OUT
description: President Reagan said today that he had not been in full control of his Administration's Iran policy, and the White House said that as a consequence up to $30 million intended to pay for American arms had been secretly diverted to rebel forces in Nicaragua.

title: FROM SCHOOL CLINICS, FIRST-LINE HEALTH CARE
description: AN honor student at Julia Richman High School considered dropping out last September as he struggled to cope with his mother's addiction to crack. Another student suffered from undiagnosed sickle-cell anemia. A third missed more than a week of school each month because of severe asthma.

title: Leak of Radioactive Water Shuts Florida Nuclear Plant
description: The Crystal River nuclear power plant is expected to be out of service until mid-December after a leak of 830 gallons of radioactive water, officials of the Florida Power Corporation said Monday.

title: Ritz Hotel Owner Says His Assets Exceed Debt
description: John B. Coleman's step into bankruptcy court in an effort to hold onto his elegant hotels did not surprise either his creditors or his associates, who say he has been heading in that direction for most of this year. But Mr. Coleman said in his filing for reorganization that he had sufficient assets to satisfy all of his creditors.

title: U.S. Rejects Nutrasweet Ban
description: The Food and Drug Administration has rejected a petition to ban the artificial sweetener NutraSweet, dismissing a consumer group's concerns that it might trigger seizures or eye problems, it was disclosed Monday.

title: Hardly a Threat to Damascus
description: The Reagan Administration's sanctions against Syria may turn out to be a useful first step in giving pause to a regime accustomed to getting away with murder, but they hardly add up to a coherent or effective answer to the problems posed by Damascus.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: GEORGE K. had noticed a gradual loss of visual acuity in his left eye. More than two years ago, he'd had a cataract removed from that eye and a new lens implanted. Was this, too, becoming opaque, he wondered? He didn't wonder long, for his doctor had warned him not to ignore any changes in vision.

title: NEWS OF LAYOFFS DULLS G.E. CENTENNIAL IN SCHENECTADY
description: It was in 1886 that Thomas Alva Edison set up the Edison Machine Works here, giving birth to the General Electric Company and making Schenectady one of the country's most important manufacturing centers. But as the company's centennial year, 1986 is a flop.

title: WINE TALK
description: LIKE Eskimos who had been waiting for the spring ice to crack, wine enthusiasts around the world breathed a collective sigh of relief last week. After years of regular increases, Burgundy wine prices dropped drastically at the annual Hospice de Beaune auction in France. But the news from Burgundy begged an even more important question: Now what will happen in Bordeaux?

title: THE IRAN AFFAIR: A PRESIDENCY DAMAGED
description: After six years of seeming invulnerability, President Reagan has been grievously damaged by the crisis over secret arms shipments to Iran. With a unanimity rare in

title: PRETORIA FAULTED ON INTEGRATION STUDY
description: The Progressive Federal Party, the main opposition group in Parliament, boycotted a meeting of the Government-dominated President's Council today in a dispute over a report on segregated neighborhoods.

title: IRAN USES ITS F-4'S
description: Iraqi warplanes flew their longest mission in more than six years of war today, rocketing Iran's Larak Island oil export terminal in the southern Persian Gulf and setting two tankers ablaze.

title: U.S. MOVING TO EXPAND UNCONVENTIONAL FORCES
description: The briefing officer at the Army's First Special Operations Command ticked off accomplishments, then defects to be fixed. ''Based on the original plan,'' Lieut. Col. Andrew S. Dulina said, ''we're about halfway there.''

title: DEFINING THE GALLIC STYLE
description: WHAT distinguishes French cooking from all other cuisines? How much can we vary French cooking before it is no longer recognizably French? A great deal, say experts, as long as chefs retain their techniques and the food retains a certain je ne sais quoi. Julia Child, doyenne of French cooking in America ''In France cooking is a serious art form and a national sport. I think the French enjoy the complication of the art form and the cooking for cooking's sake. You can talk with a concierge or police officer about food in France as a general rule. It is not the general rule here. Classical cuisine, which I hope we are going back to, means certain ways of doing things and certain ways of not doing things. If you know classical French cooking you can do anything. If you don't know the basics, you turn out slop.'' Gerard Pangaud, chef at Aurora ''French cooking uses a lot of techniques, and it uses a lot of rules. For most of the cooks in France, the reference point is Escoffier. For example, you have a blanquette. There is an understanding between two chefs when they talk about blanquette. They know, for instance, that a blanquette does not have parsley in it. And if, in France, you served the blanquette differently from the way it used to be - should be - served, people would not like it. Here, there is not that weight of history, of French eating, behind every customer.

title: Poindexter and North Have Limited Options
description: Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, who resigned today as President Reagan's national security adviser, is eligible to retire with a pension, although military sources said he might try to return to active naval service through his friendship with the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1986
description: The World

title: CONTRA SUPPLIES: MYSTERY UNRAVELS
description: The disclosure that millions of dollars paid for United States arms sent to Iran were channeled through Swiss bank accounts to the Nicaraguan rebels may explain much of the mystery behind the covert program to supply the rebels, Congressional investigators and Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Shultz and His Job
description: Two days before President Reagan reported on television that he had authorized the sale of arms to Iran, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was interviewed for Washington Jewish Week, and some of the Secretary's answers, published in the tabloid the other day, cast additional light on his adversary relationship with the National Security Council and his adherence to the Administration policy of refusing to deal with terrorists.

title: ACTING SECURITY AIDE IS CALLED BRIGHT AND HARD-WORKING
description: Alton G. Keel Jr., who was propelled into the post of acting national security adviser today, is described by associates as a bright and hard-working staff man who provides indispensable support to his superiors but has seldom taken a visible leadership role himself.

title: DEFLATED STATE OF FOOTBALL
description: ''For those of you still with us.'' Al Michaels's phrase was easy on the ears. Coming at about 11:40 on Monday night, with less than eight minutes remaining in the Dolphins' 45-3 rout of the Jets, the words had the sound of a secret mantra. The meaning was that it was O.K. to turn off ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' the game had long ago been settled and there was no longer even a chance for the Jets to gain moral redemption. Relieved of the burden of watching - Al had intimated that only those with nothing else to do were still tuned in - one could escape the smell of the crowd and the roar of the greasepaint, perchance to contemplate substantial cosmic issues.

title: U.S. TO SELL CALIBRATION TOOL MADE OF SPHERES FROM SPACE
description: The National Bureau of Standards said today that it was selling a new educational tool made in space.

title: MOTOROLA, TOSHIBA PLAN A LINK
description: Two of the world's largest semiconductor manufacturers, Motorola Inc. and the Toshiba Corporation, said yesterday that they would jointly build a manufacturing facility in Japan and exchange a broad range of memory chip and microprocessor technology.

title: What, No Turkeys?
description: Not many Federal employees get a Christmas present from their boss, but Lynne Cheney, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has arranged a Thanksgiving present for her staff. Today she is distributing pocket copies of the Constitution to 250 people who work for the endowment. All of them, she says, ''should be particularly proud of our continuing role in encouraging our fellow Americans to give thoughtful consideration to this remarkable document.'' Since 1982, the endowment has spent $21 million on 339 projects involving the 1987 bicentennial of the Constitution.

title: A Monument More Lasting Than Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE ON THE POLICY CRISIS
description: Legal questions were raised by the operation involving the Nicaraguan rebels, including whether criminal laws had been broken. Page A11. The contra-aid mystery may be explained by the disclosure, Congressional investigators and Administration officials said.

title: The Judiciary Shakeup
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee, which will pass on all Federal court appointments of President Reagan's last two years in office, is getting a shakeup. When the Democrats take control of the Senate in January, the panel will be reduced to 14 members, from 18; as a result, applications of three conservative Republicans to join the committee have been rejected.

title: NOSTALGIA BY NIGHT AND COMFORT BY DAY
description: 1.Glitter of the Past For the party season, the Antique Boutique has a selection of one-of-a-kind, recycled evening clothes from glittery seasons past, going back to the 1930's.

title: TOYOTA AGREES ON UNION WORKERS TO CONSTRUCT A PLANT IN KENTUCKY
description: In a major victory for organized labor, negotiators for the Toyota Motor Corporation and 16 American building trades unions reached an agreement today calling for the hiring of union workers to construct an $800 million automobile assembly plant in Kentucky.

title: Continental Agrees To Settle 2 Suits
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said that it had agreed to settle two shareholder suits filed against it in connection with its near collapse in 1984.

title: MOVIE FARE THAT GOES BEYOND POPCORN
description: The lights were dim. In front of the bar, Marcie Green and Toshio Sone sat, enjoying quiet talk and imported beer at a table for two in lobby of a movie theater.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on Monday in Column One (Politics) misstated the number of votes received in 1982 by the New York State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan. The total was 2,714,832.

title: ISRAEL NOW SAYS IT SENT ARMS AT REQUEST OF U.S.
description: In its first official comment on the Iran affair, the Israeli Government announced early today that it had transferred arms to Iran ''upon the request of the United States'' and did not know that some of the payments for these weapons had been channeled to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: A Dieter's Holiday: Feasting on the Air
description: ''ALL right, people. That's enough. Please!''

title: Duarte Finds Democracy Threatened By Quake
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador said today that the destruction caused by an earthquake there on Oct. 10 threatened the ''consolidation of democracy'' in his country.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Salmonella Deaths Rise to 4 at Home
description: A fourth death has been linked to an outbreak of salmonella bacteria at a nursing home, the State Health Department reported yesterday.

title: Officer Sullivan's Second Shot
description: Welcome the New York Court of Appeals' decision to reinstate a second-degree manslaughter charge against a New York City police officer in the shooting death of Eleanor Bumpurs. The issues of deadly force and police procedure arising from this inflammatory case can be properly aired only in a jury trial.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams-Russell Co., Waltham, Mass., an operator of cable television systems, appointed Neil R. McHugh president and chief operating officer, replacing John J. Lynch, the acting president.

title: BORN AGAIN: HOFFMANN'S LOST TEXTILES
description: The day the original fabric designs of the Wiener Werkstatte were rediscovered is woven into Peter Backhausen's memory. The sinuous geometrics of Josef Hoffmann, the fanciful floral patterns of Koloman Moser were lying untouched until the mid-1970's in an old wooden cupboard in an empty office building on the Kaiserstrasse, the place that had once housed the drawing department of Johann Backhausen & Sohne.

title: FOR INDIANS, CELEBRATION AND SADNESS
description: When the children of the Shinnecock Indian Reservation of Southampton, L.I., talk of their ''two Thanksgivings,'' it is clear which one holds greater significance for them.

title: GANTOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
SURGE OF EXPORTS SHRINKS TRADE GAP IN SIGN OF CHANGE
description: In what many analysts called the first solid evidence of a turnaround in the trade deficit, the Commerce Department reported today that a surge in exports narrowed the deficit last month to its lowest level since August 1985.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 12
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter and 6-month includes amortization of deferred advertising expenses of $3,102,000 and $7,166,000, respectively. The company said the year-ago quarter and 6-month includes amortization of deferred advertising expenses of $1,160,000 and $2,700,000, respectively.

title: ... And an Ex-Associate Will Attempt a Rescue
description: Charles I. Hiltzheimer said he was asked Sunday night whether he wanted to become president and chief executive of McLean Industries, the big shipping line, as it hovered on the brink of bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Out of Zaire, With Paradox
description: Nguza Karl-i-Bond is a survivor, much like his boss, Mobutu Sese Seko, the President of Zaire for the last two decades.

title: PLAYMAKER NOW CHIEF OF 115,000: STANLEY WELDON HILL
description: Among the messages of congratulation that flooded in to Stanley W. Hill's office yesterday was a telephone call from William Kor, a man Mr. Hill had not seen in 38 years. ''Is this Stan Hill?'' Mr. Kor asked. ''The scrawny kid who played basketball?''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ANIMAL FARM If you have seen, heard and anticipate ingesting enough turkey to hold you for a while, you may be refreshed by a visit today to the Bronx Zoo, Fordham Road and Southern Boulevard, near the Bronx River Parkway (220-5197). There is not a Thanksgiving gobbler in residence among the 4,200 animals that represent 750 species and subspecies.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net loss

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $2.2 million from a depletion adjustment to the carrying value of oil and gas properties.

title: HERS
description: IT is reported that there is a 40-year-old woman, J.Z. Knight, in Yelm, Wash., who says she is the ''channel'' - the mouthpiece - for Ramtha, a 35,000-year-old man. I know the feeling well. Especially at 6:30 on Monday mornings when the alarm goes off.

title: DISCOUNTER PURCHASES B. DALTON
description: Barnes & Noble, the nation's leading book discounter and its third-biggest bookseller, has purchased B. Dalton, the nation's second-largest chain of bookstores, which has been faltering lately because of competition from discounters.

title: National Lampoon
description: Vestron Inc., a marketer of video cassettes, offered to acquire National Lampoon Inc. for $4 a share, or a total of about $6.4 million. The magazine publisher said, however, that its board had rejected the offer, saying the bid was inadequate. Matty Simmons, chairman, cited recent indications that the company's publishing businesses were turning around, as well as pending film and video cassette deals.

title: Governor Cuomo Changes the Subject
description: Though he won re-election by a historic margin, Governor Cuomo wound up the campaign sounding like a sore loser. He accused the press of conspiring to make him look bad and of hounding him about his reluctance to debate his opponent.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $180,000 from recovery of a loan previously written off. c-Net income d-Includes an after-tax gain of $330,000 from the sale of a manufacturing facility and certain product lines.

title: KEY RATES
PROSPECTS FOR MORE U.S. AID TO REBELS ARE SEEN AS BLEAK NOW IN CONGRESS
description: Members of Congress said today that the prospects for continued financing of the Nicaraguan rebels, already in doubt after the Democratic victory in the Senate, have dimmed further in the aftermath of disclosures about the diversion of secret Iranian arms money to the insurgents.

title: Finch, Tough Guy, Begins Tough Task
description: Mike Dunleavy remembers Larry Finch for his play on the basketball court, and because Finch once knocked out his teeth.

title: WICKES COS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $5,732,000 and $16,761,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and includes pre-tax gains from the sales of securities of about $31.5 million for the quarter and $34.5 million for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $24,684,000 and $27,895,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $620,000 for the quarter, and net from discontinued operations of $6,000,000 for the 9 months. The quarter also includes after-tax gains on retirement of indebtedness of $293,000, and on the reversion of excess assets after termination of certain plans of $7,447,000. Results for 1986 include the consumer and industrial products group, which was acquired effective July 31, 1985, and results for 1985 include the group operations from the effective date of the acquisition.

title: BROOKLYN HOUSING COMPLEX INVESTS IN GOOD HEALTH
description: On an oval concrete walkway the size of an outdoor running track, 65-year-old Harold Kirschman walks a ''victory lap'' at the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn. For Mr. Kirschman, the ''victory'' means triumph over the pain of angina attacks, the breathlessness that once slowed his steps and the fear that gripped him after triple bypass surgery three years ago.

title: Cuomo Says He Hopes Reagan Didn't Know
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the Reagan Administration was ''in collapse'' because of revelations about arms shipments to Iran and that he hoped the trail would end ''before it got to the very top.''

title: F. Murray Abraham To Say, 'Bah, Humbug'
description: Ebenezer Scrooge, in the person of F. Murray Abraham, will appear next Monday at 7:30 P.M. at a staged reading of Charles Dickens's ''Christmas Carol'' at the Marriott Marquis Theater, Broadway and 45th Street. The reading is part of a benefit for the Riverside Shakespeare Company and the Anglo-American School.

title: IT'S TIME TO CLEAN CHIMNEYS
description: ACCORDING TO legend, if a bride is kissed on the cheek by a chimney sweep, she will have good luck. Even shaking hands with a chimney sweep is supposed to bring good fortune. That alone may be reason enough to hire a chimney sweep, but also it is the season to have chimneys inspected and, if necessary, cleaned. Dianne Bangs of the National Chimney Sweep Guild, a nine-year-old trade organization in New Hampshire, recommends that all fireplaces be inspected at least once a year.

title: Carbide Wins On Dividends
description: A judge ruled today that the Union Carbide Corporation could pay dividends due Dec. 1, but he continued a freeze on the sale of the multinational company's assets in a case stemming from the 1984 gas leak that killed more than 2,000 people.

title: A WALL ST. LAWYER ADMITS INSIDER GUILT
description: Michael N. David, the last of the young Wall Street professionals charged with insider trading earlier this year, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy, mail fraud, wire fraud and obstruction of justice for his part in the trading ring.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $849,000 for the quarter and $5,791,000 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $446,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $5,262,000 for the quarter and $6,312,000 for the year.

title: A Job for a Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Irving Fryar, the New England Patriots' wide receiver who suffered a concussion during a car crash last weekend, was discharged from Massachusetts General Hospital but will miss Sunday's game against New Orleans. . . . Mark Liveric, a forward for the New York Express of the Major Indoor Soccer League, has been suspended by the team for one game for what it described as ''lack of effort'' in Friday night's 4-2 loss to Kansas City.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes income of $286,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $635,000 from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: WOOING OLDER CONSUMERS
description: Americans over 50 make up about a quarter of the population, but account for roughly half of the nation's discretionary spending and more than three-quarters of its wealth. And their numbers are growing. Small wonder, then, that companies are increasingly wooing older consumers. But while some - especially those involved in travel and health care - have marketed effectively to older consumers for many years, many others have not been so lucky. In fact, the more corporate America courts this business, the more it discovers what a tricky business it is.

title: U.S. LINKS SYRIA TO A DEFENDANT IN AN ARMS-SMUGGLING CASE
description: A man charged with conspiring to sell an advanced air navigational tracking system to countries in the Middle East had a contact in the Syrian Embassy here, a United States undercover agent testified today.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. to Exceed Arms Limits The Reagan Administration told members of Congress that it intends to exceed the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty on Friday.

title: ISRAELI DEFENDS ROLE IN U.S.-IRAN DEALS
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres went before Parliament today to defend Israel's participation in the Iran arms affair.

title: NODAWAY VALLEY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago 9 months includes an accounting change that increased net by $247,000.

title: THE SPURT IN FASHION SHOWS
description: One retail buyer remembers the year, not too long ago, when she wore through a pair of shoes traveling from one designer showroom to the next. She had scheduled a meeting for every working hour of her visit, and left with a hole in one sole, courtesy of the sidewalks of New York's garment center.

title: BALLET: 'LA SOURCE,' 'UNION JACK' AND 'GLASS PIECES'
description: IF one had to show the New York City Ballet's two master choreographers at their most atypical, Tuesday night's program at the State Theater would more than fit the bill.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ouster Move in Omaha Gets Enough Signatures
description: A petition to hold an election on ousting Mayor Michael Boyle from office has gathered enough signatures, according to an election official.

title: SAUDI REPORTEDLY ASKED THE ISRAELIS TO SELL ARMS TO IRAQ, TOO
description: Adnan M. Khashoggi, the Saudi billionaire who is said to have been a key intermediary in American and Israeli arms sales to Iran, offered late last year to have Israel sell arms to Iraq, according to Western officials and sources familiar with the weapon sales.

title: North Carolina Fugitive Is Killed in Gun Battle
description: A survivalist who was a bank robbery suspect, after eluding the police for three months, was killed today in a rugged stretch of mountains in a gun battle that left two police officers wounded.

title: MUSIC: SHUBERT AND MOZART CHORAL WORKS
description: DAVID LABOVITZ'S Choral Symphony Society, which offered an evening of Schubert and Mozart at Merkin Concert Hall last Sunday, made use of its small mixed chorus to present both versions of Schubert's ''Standchen'' -certainly one of the most sublimely lovely of all his works.

title: Faust Could Not Afford Any Lingering Moments
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Holiday Today Today is Thanksgiving Day. Following are holiday schedules:

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS SEEK TO CHANGE REGENTS' RULES
description: The State Education Department has set up new procedures to make it easier for private schools to seek exemptions from state curriculum and course requirements, school and state officials say.

title: Hope for New York City's Homeless?; The Issue Is Housing
description: As the debate rages over emergency shelter sites for New York City's homeless, the essential issue -affordable housing for all New Yorkers - is, as usual, being ignored. It is no exaggeration to say that there is a three-word solution to homelessness: housing, housing, housing. But as we scramble to open new shelters, the development of new housing and preservation of existing housing remains low on the list of priorities for our President, Governor and Mayor.

title: At the Tracks, Riders Beware
description: Last month a Florida appellate court upheld a damage award of $13 million to David Ashcroft, a jockey left paralyzed by a spill at Calder Race Course five years ago. The decision has led Calder, already plagued by insurance problems, to consider bankruptcy, and now other tracks, in an effort to avoid damage suits, are weighing a fundamental change in their relationship with jockeys.

title: PIANO: JEAN-PHILIPPE COLLARD
description: THE joy of hearing good music once again in the handsomely restored interior of Town Hall was undersored on Monday night by Jean-Philippe Collard's recital in the ''Pianists' Choice'' series. The French virtuoso appears to be able to do almost anything he wants at the keyboard, but flashy display was clearly not on his mind when he planned this program consisting of Schumann's ''Papillons'' and ''Kreisleriana,'' Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue and a group of six waltzes by Chopin.

title: Josef C. Dine Is Dead at 74; Worked in Public Relations
description: Josef C. Dine, who had a long career in public relations in broadcasting, died of cancer of the lymph glands Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 74 years old and lived on Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: TRANS WORLD MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: Corrected from Tuesday, Nov. 25, editions.

title: Yanks Get Rhoden For $1.35 Million
description: The Yankees have talked in recent weeks about the need to reduce their payroll, but they are so desperate for starting pitching that they decided it would be worth $1.35 million for one year to lure Rick Rhoden to New York.

title: Santucci Said to Fight Shift in Zaccaro Trial
description: The Queens District Attorney's office will oppose a planned request to move from Queens the trial of John A. Zaccaro on attempted extortion charges, according to Mr. Zaccaro's lawyer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Canada Petroleum Co., Calgary, Alberta, a unit of Amoco Corp., said elimination of the Canadian Government's petroleum and gas revenue tax and reductions in Alberta petroleum royalties would allow it to maintain total 1987 spending close to this year's level, despite low crude oil prices.

title: CALENDAR: DECORATING WORKSHOPS GALORE
description: Christmas Decorating Workshop, Boscobel Restoration, Garrison, N.Y. (off Route 9D), 914-265-3638.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUSH OR SHULTZ MAY VISIT MIDDLE EAST TO EASE CONCERN
description: The United States is considering sending Vice President Bush or Secretary of State George P. Shultz to the Middle East in an attempt to bolster American standing there, State Department officials said today.

title: Control Data Ends Ticketron Sale Deal
