description: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled an agreement to sell its Ticketron division to the investment firm of Allen & Company Inc. because it was unable to obtain regulatory approval in several states where the ticket service operates.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: FOOTBALL GREEN BAY PACKERS VS. DETROIT LIONS, at Pontiac, Mich., 12:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 660, 12:20 P.M.) SEATTLE SEAHAWKS VS.

title: National Music Camp Sets Scholarship Grant
description: The National Music Camp at Interlochen, Mich., the oldest such camp of its kind in the country, has announced the largest corporate scholarship grant in its 60-year history.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and the quarter includes a pre-tax gain of $2.4 million from the sale and leaseback of its headquarters facility.

title: Blankets That Sense Warmth
description: THE temperature dips to the teens. Your wife, or husband, who is always cold, cranks the electric blanket up past bake to broil and within an hour or two you awake to find that your legs have melted into the mattress pad and your back has acquired a rosy glow. Not fun.

title: DURO-TEST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 4 percent stock dividend payable Jan. 15, 1987.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
WILLIAM KIRWAN Jr.
description: William Kirwan Jr., former superintendent of the New York state police, died Monday at his home in Cohoes, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: REPORT SHOWS A DECREASE IN VOLUME OF OIL SPILLED SINCE 1983
description: The volume of oil spilled into seas and oceans around the world has decreased dramatically after reaching a four-year high in 1983, according to a report released this week by a Boston-based research organization.

title: PRINTERS TO JOIN WITH COMMUNICATIONS UNION
description: Members of the 134-year-old International Typographical Union have voted overwhelmingly to merge with the Communications Workers of America, the unions said today.

title: Of Holidays Past
description: TIFFANY & COMPANY has created vignettes that evoke the Christmas celebrations of British nobility at the turn of the century. Eight table and room settings include reproductions of furniture, linen, china, crystal, silver and rugs from Britain's stately homes, with some 18th-century antiques mixed in.

title: 2 Namibia Children Killed
description: Two children were killed and one was wounded today when a donkey they were riding near the Angolan border detonated a land mine. The South-West Africa Territory Force said the incident occurred near Nkongo.

title: DANCE: BEVERLY BLOSSOM IN SOLO WORKS
description: TIME has honed Beverly Blossom's gifts, evident in her early and equally irrepressible days in dance as a charter member of the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater. After three decades of performing in dance and theater productions, she is today one of the most impressive solo performers around. And the program she presented on Sunday afternoon at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace suggested she is also a witch, a magician and a consummate if irreverent revealer of the human heart.

title: NEW BLOOD TEST HELD TO DETECT CANCER EARLIER
description: Many types of cancer can apparently be detected in what may be early stages by a new type of blood test, a medical journal reports.

title: DeBusschere Acquitted
description: Dave DeBusschere, the former player and executive for the Knicks, was acquitted yesterday of a charge of drunken driving by a six-member jury in Nassau County District Court. The jury took 19 hours over three days to decide the case, which followed DeBusschere's arrest last July after a police officer said he had observed DeBusschere's station wagon moving erratically on a road in West Hempstead, L.I.

title: ULTIMATE ARBITER OF HILL AND VALE
description: MOUNT McKINLEY remains Mount McKinley, thanks to Ralph Regula.

title: What Liberal Arts Should Remember From Past; Women in the Sciences
description: To the Editor:

title: MANILA AND THE INSURGENTS AGREE TO 60-DAY TRUCE STARTING DEC. 10
description: Communist rebels and the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino agreed today to a 60-day cease-fire.

title: SWISS BELIEVE FLOW OF IRAN MONEY IS LEGAL UNDER THEIR BANK LAWS
description: Swiss Government officials said today that financial transactions by which payments from Iran for Western arms were passed through Swiss bank accounts to the Nicaraguan rebels were probably legal under Swiss banking law.

title: I.R.S. Files Claim Against McEnroe
description: John McEnroe owes more than $900,000 in back taxes, the Internal Revenue Service charges, but his lawyer said today the I.R.S. has incorrect information.

title: HOW TV IS COVERING THE IRAN STORY
description: WHEN President Reagan appeared on television at noon on Tuesday, announcing that he had not been ''fully informed'' about policy toward Iran, television became a major arena in which the new crisis would be acted out. What did the President know and when did he know it? The question, asked often on news broadcasts, drew its resonance from Watergate. The question went unanswered, but one thing became clear: television was in full-throated pursuit of a story.

title: Bridge: Was the Deal Constructed? Internal Clues Give Answer
description: Internal evidence often allows a literary sleuth to settle a debatable point in a text, and bridge historians can sometimes do the same. An example is the diagramed deal, which has often been credited to the Italian star Giorgio Belladonna.

title: F.C.C. Approves Sale Of WOR-TV to MCA
description: The Federal Communications Commission today announced its approval of the sale of a New Jersey station, WOR-TV/Channel 9, by RKO General Inc. to MCA Inc., the television program production and distribution company, for $387 million.

title: Youth's Lawyer Cites 'Mass Hysteria'
description: A 15-year-old boy charged with the attempted murder of a police officer in Central Park last July was arrested amid ''mass hysteria'' and was identified later in a police lineup by uncertain witnesses, a lawyer for the boy told a jury yesterday.

title: TUROFF IS CALLED A TARGET OF 2D INQUIRY
description: As Jay L. Turoff, the former New York City taxi chief, prepares to stand trial on fraud charges, prosecutors are continuing to seek a second indictment against him, officials familiar with the investigation say.

title: Smithsonian Gets Historic Linotype
description: Three of Ottmar Mergenthaler's early typesetting machines, which revolutionized the printing industry in the late 19th century, were presented to the Smithsonian Institution on Monday to mark the 100th anniversary of the Linotype machine.

title: Exit and Ecstasy
description: For three straight years, the football team at Millikin University in Decatur, Ill., has finished second to Augustana in the College Conference of Illinois and Wisconsin, each time facing the Vikings in a rugged showdown in the mud and coming up short in a game that made the difference. Augustana has gone on to Division III championships in two of those years and is currently in contention again, but Millikin has had only the empty solace of being perhaps the best team not to make the playoffs.

title: FRANCE TO END MOST PRICE CONTROLS BY YEAR'S END
description: France's conservative Government agreed today to lift most remaining price controls by the end of the year and to overhaul the country's laws on corporate competition.

title: ETZ LAVUD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income of $2,318,000 principally from a public offering of shares of the company's affiliate, Laser Industries Ltd. for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said all of the results were converted to dollars from Israeli shekels at the prevailing exchange on June 30 of one new Israeli shekel equal to $1.

title: Flood Alert Sought for Lakes
description: A United States-Canadian commission that says high water levels in the Great Lakes pose the threat of a ''possible emergency and extensive damage'' is recommending immediate efforts to improve flood warning and relief programs.

title: OUTGOING GOVERNOR IN NEW MEXICO BARS THE EXECUTION OF 5
description: In a dramatic Thanksgiving Eve move to thwart his successor, Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico today commuted the death sentences of all five men awaiting execution in the state, saying the penalty was ''inhumane, immoral and anti-God.''

title: Rockwell Acquisition
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said today that it had completed a previously announced merger with the Electronics Corporation of America, a Waltham, Mass., maker of photoelectric controls.

title: PANEL AGREES ON PARTS OF WEST SIDE ROAD PLAN
description: A state panel planning a replacement for the West Side Highway agreed yesterday on a design for large portions of a six-lane road between the Battery and 59th Street, panel members said.

title: Incomparable Pleasures of a Pomegranate
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: CRAY AND BAND PLAY BLUES
description: FROM a distance of two decades, the blues and soul of the 1960's start to blur, becoming a half-remembered style built on basic harmonies, economical narratives and, most of all, direct emotion. There are still some first-generation soul-blues singers around - Z. Z. Hill, Little Milton, Bobby (Blue) Bland - and now there's a one-man second generation: Robert Cray, who opened a two-night Bottom Line engagement last Friday. As singer, guitarist and sometimes songwriter, Mr. Cray and his band honor the verities of soul-blues by making the music sound heartfelt, natural and absolutely vital.

title: What the Secret War Has Cost
description: Though there's much for President Reagan's new commission to learn about the arms-to-Iran-for-hostages-plus-money-for-the-contras scandal, one thing is already clear. The price of the Overt Covert War against the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua has just risen. What's most alarming is not the money, perhaps $30 million so far disclosed, but the stealth. It further evidences President Reagan's determination to get his way on Nicaragua, despite public skepticism and despite law.

title: Yields Off On C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts slipped, and those on money market mutual funds rose for the week ended yesterday, as the banking and securities industries remain uncertain on the direction of interest rates.

title: SHADES OF '68 ON CAMPUS? (YES, BUT NOT SO RED)
description: The university in this Parisian suburb is a sprawling, drab complex of concrete buildings and dingy auditoriums that looks more like a fading suburban housing project than a seat of higher education.

title: FUNDS MAY HAVE AIDED REBEL AIR DROPS
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders said today that it was possible that some of the money secretly diverted from Iran arms sales may have been spent on supplies dropped to their forces by air. But they said they did not know who would have arranged for such flights.

title: Q & A
description: Q.I would like to clean the aluminum siding on our house. Every time someone brushes against this siding a white chalklike substance rubs off. How can the siding be cleaned and maintained? A.The chalking condition is not unusual on aluminum siding that has aged. In some cases it is merely a surface condition that will wash off; in others the paint or other finish is starting to erode or weather off.

title: MGM Official Leaving
description: Seymour Leslie, head of the MGM/ UA Home Entertainment Group. plans to leave the company. Mr. Leslie, 63 years old, said in a statement that he had declined to relocate to Los Angeles from New York when the company moves next year.

title: Soviet Medical Salaries Up
description: The salaries of Soviet physicians and other medical staff people, many of whom earn less than manual workers, are to be raised by an average of 30 percent this month. The Tass press agency said today that the increase recognized an imbalance between the pay of workers in manufacturing and non-manufacturing jobs. At present, a doctor may earn about half the average industrial wage.

title: DMI FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: b-After an unusal charge of $1,257,000 for the liquidation of an unprofitable subsidiary and the anticipated cost of a proposed litigation settlement. The company said the latest year loss is after charges of $6,152,000 related to the loss from the sale and estimated disposable costs of three of four wholly owned units.

title: IF IT'S UGLY AND SMELLS, IT'S A HIT IN TOY STORES
description: They look like visions in a childhood nightmare.

title: On Iran: No Guilt Here, But Plenty of Anxiety
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger usually conducts his morning meetings with his senior staff with a firm hand. He declares the agenda and steers the discussion.

title: LTV LOSES $2.08 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The LTV Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, said today that it had recorded a third-quarter deficit of $2.08 billion, the second-biggest quarterly loss ever for an American company.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $7,937,000. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month losses reflects downward revisions to estimates of net realizable value for certain inactive inventory and other assets totaling $11,333,000 and a $5,745,000 estimated loss that will result from the October delivery of the C-21A aircraft to the U.S. air force. The company said the latest 9-month loss was decreased by $1,431,000 from a change in accounting for pension plan.

title: PO FOLKS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter and year losses include a writeoff of $2,803,000 for the disposal of restaurants.

title: WORRIED ABOUT MALPRACTICE SUIT, PHYSICIAN IS AN APPARANT SUICIDE
description: A Long Island physician apparently took his own life Tuesday night, after what his family said was months of worry over what he viewed as a demeaning and frivolous medical malpractice suit.

title: 'Star Wars' Isn't Playing Well in the Suburbs
description: To the Editor:

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
16 Hall Projects Get Loan Pact
description: A loan restructuring agreement apparently has saved five partnerships of the embattled real estate syndicator Craig Hall from bankruptcy.

title: Wickes Profit Declines 3.3%
description: The Wickes Companies has reported earnings of $38.8 million, or 16 cents a share, in the third quarter, down 3.3 percent from $40.1 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago.

title: CARSON TAKES BLAME FOR JET PERFORMANCE
description: In an unusual admission for a coach, Bud Carson did some finger-pointing today - at himself.

title: PIANIST FIGHTS JOSTLING CHARGE AFTER SUBWAY ARREST
description: A prominent jazz pianist is embroiled in a court battle over a minor criminal charge that has already landed him in jail for 27 hours and caused him to miss two performances, one of them at the United Nations.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Include tax credits of $750,000 resulting from settlements with the Internal Revenue Service. The 9 months also included a non-recurring after- tax charge of $1,582,000 relating to special severance payments under the company's cost reduction program.

title: U.S. SHOE reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
General Cinema Rebuffs Offer
description: The General Cinema Corporation, the largest shareholder in Carter Hawley Hale Stores, said yesterday that it would not support the $55-a-share cash offer for Carter Hawley proposed Tuesday by a partnership of The Limited Inc. and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation.

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $7.8 million from reorganization of the company's wine and spirits business.

title: ADELPHIA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The fiscal 1986 results are restated.

title: 35 India Hangings in 3 Years
description: Thirty-five people were hanged for murder in India in the three years to the end of 1985, Parliament was told today. President Zail Singh allowed five appeals against death sentences.

title: Article 101486 -- No Title
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago has given $31 million to promote international conservation efforts.

title: SIGNS OF A 'BOARD' OF MIDDLEMEN EMERGE
description: Administration officials said today that the Justice Department was investigating people outside the Government who may have served as ''a board of directors of sorts,'' as a senior official put it, handling Iranian payments diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S PANEL
description: Edmund S. Muskie

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
description: b-Reflects a $136,000, or 2 cents a share, reversal of investment tax credits to conform with the 1986 Tax Reform Act.

title: CBS DELAYS ARMS COMEDY
description: CBS executives have decided that a movie scheduled for next Tuesday night, ''Deal of the Century,'' has a theme that comes uncomfortably close to current news events and have postponed it. The movie, starring Chevy Chase, is a satire about international arms merchants who run into difficulties in South America.

title: THE PRACTICAL GARDENER
description: ONE of the tidbits of information lodged in my mind ever since reading ''The Letters of E. B. White'' is that in the late 1930's, in addition to a beer-drinking dachshund named Fred he owned a rubber plant he called Hattie. Hattie and Fred came along with him on his annual trek by automobile to his country place in North Brooklin, Me., from his apartment in Manhattan. White considered Hattie as much of a house pet as he did Fred, even if she was considerably more taciturn.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $600,000 representing an income tax benefit from utilization of operating- loss carryforwards. c-Net loss d-Includes an extraordinary tax loss of $94,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax credit of $414,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding for 1985 have been adjusted for a 3-percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 6, 1986.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect the sale last month of the company's dental products segment. The year-ago quarter includes a $4.2 million non-recurring provision in nonoperating other expenses for a loss related to the dissolution of a diagnostics limited partnership.

title: GAF QUESTIONS JACOB'S BID FOR BORG
description: The GAF Corporation, which has said it might increase its 9.6 percent stake in the Borg-Warner Corporation, today questioned the seriousness of an offer by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, to acquire Borg-Warner.

title: Poindexter Street Planned
description: Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter's hometown plans to name a street after him despite his resignation as the President's national security adviser, Kenneth Hudson, a town board member, said today.

title: Another Coach: That's Show Biz
description: In the very heart of Madison Square Garden, if indeed it can be said that Madison Square Garden has a heart, is a gathering place known as the Hall of Fame Room.

title: Honors for 4 Judges And Ex-Prosecutor
description: A former prosecutor and four judges were honored yesterday by the Federal Bar Council, an association of prominent lawyers, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Markets Are Idle Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. So will government offices, banks and most businesses. The markets, government offices and banks will be open tomorrow, while some businesses will remain closed.

title: Dump Truck Kills Owner
description: The president of a Greenwich construction company died Tuesday after he was run over by a dump truck owned by his company. Pasquale Cecio Sr., 83 years old, president of the Cecio Brothers Inc., died at Greenwich Hospital after the accident at the company's equipment yard in Greenwich.

title: OTHER IRAN INQUIRIES WIDEN
description: Amid the crisis over secret dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan appointed a three-member panel today to investigate the role of his National Security Council staff.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $333,000.

title: Food Processor To Sell Three Units
description: The International Multifoods Corporation, a food processor and marketer, has agreed to sell three units as part of a previously announced restructuring.

title: PHILHARMONIC: UNFAMILIAR SYMPHONY
description: WHEN was the last time you heard a work by John Knowles Paine? Unless you are a music student or a dedicated seeker-out of musical Americana, you may not be aware of the name at all. He is not even as well-known nowadays as Horatio Parker or Dudley Buck, who at least survive in history books as the Yale composers whose old-fogeyism drove Charles Ives to commit his early masterpieces. Then what, you might have wondered, was Paine's century-old Symphony No. 2, subtitled ''Spring,'' doing on the New York Philharmonic's program last evening? Was Zubin Mehta revealing himself at last as a secret Paine addict, or was the Philharmonic's music director simply in a mood to paddle in the backwaters of American musical history? Hard to say, really, but the trip proved worthwhile.

title: 5 States Lose in Court Against 7 Oil Concerns
description: Five states today lost a decade-old antitrust battle against seven major oil companies.

title: NORTHVIEW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses of $55,000 for the quarter and gains of $469,000 for the 9 months from property site development and losses of $1,840,000 and gains of $12,070,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from investment activities. c-Includes a gain of $301,000 on investment activities. d-Net loss and includes gains of $275,000 from property site development and $4,579,000 from investment activities.

title: Newell B. Mack, 52, Is Dead; Visited Nuclear Area as Child
description: Newell B. Mack, an arms control advocate, died of cancer Nov. 17 at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 52 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: Soviet Bank Accounts Frozen In California Libel Judgment
description: More than $450,000 in Soviet funds were frozen Tuesday as part of a libel judgment won by a California businessman.

title: Dr. Deborah N. Platek Is Married to a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Dr. Deborah Nehama Platek, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Stanley Platek of Hewlett, L.I., to Martin Alan Oppenheimer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Oppenheimer of Englewood, N.J., took place yesterday in East Rockaway, L.I. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center, where he is the spiritual leader.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
METHODE ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Debt Repurchase At Hanover Bank
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced plans yesterday to repurchase $686 million of high-interest debt that it had issued in 1984 to finance its purchase of the CIT Financial Corporation, its financial services unit, from the RCA Corporation.

title: The Fault, Dear Brutus
description: In the political turmoil of the last 20 years the press has often been accused of destroying the President. The truth in every case has been what we see so clearly now: The President destroyed himself.

title: ROANOKE ELECTRIC STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TESTAVERDE MAY MISS GAME
description: Vinny Testaverde, Miami's star quarterback, fell off his motor scooter Tuesday evening in Coral Gables, Fla., and suffered scrapes and bruises that have put his status in doubt for the game tonight against East Carolina in the Orange Bowl.

title: Trading Is Mixed, But Dow Gains 4.64
description: Before investors departed yesterday for the Thanksgiving break, they bought enough blue-chip stocks to push the Dow Jones industrial average to within a few points of its record. But more issues declined in the session than rose.

title: Playtex Withdraws From South Africa
description: International Playtex Inc., a large American manufacturer of women's underwear, has withdrawn from South Africa and sold its interests to the company's local subsidiary, a local Playtex official said. But an official at the concern's headquarters in Stamford, Conn., said the move was not a protest against South African race policies and was part of a company restructuring program.

title: DOUBTS CLING TO PACIFIC ASSASSINATION VERDICT
description: Relaxed from hours spent fishing, the President of this tiny chain of Western Pacific islands, Haruo I. Remeliik, was dressed in a T-shirt and shorts as he drove home on the night of his assassination. It was just after midnight, June 30, 1985.

title: NASA PICKS SAFER BOOSTERS FOR PLANETARY FLIGHTS
description: Two and possibly three interplanetary spacecraft will be launched from the cargo bays of space shuttles using less powerful but safer boosters than originally planned, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: GREENMAN BROS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net income

title: 3 AGENCIES SAID TO HAVE RECEIVED DATA ABOUT IRAN MONEY TRANSFERS
description: The Defense Department, National Security Council and Central Intelligence Agency received messages intercepted over the last year suggesting that money from arms deals with Iran was being diverted to Nicaraguan rebels, according to knowledgeable officials.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MAN invented one of the first tools when he tied a rock to the end of a club and used it as a hammer. The hammer is still the one tool that almost everyone uses at one time or another. But hammers are often improperly used, resulting in damage and possible physical injury.

title: Reagan Phones Sister Of Lebanon Hostage
description: President Reagan told Peggy Say today that Administration officials would continue ''to do everything they can'' to free her brother, Terry A. Anderson, and other American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Dr. John C. Adams, 83, 2d President of Hofstra
description: Dr. John Cranford Adams, president emeritus of Hofstra University, died Monday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-After a loss of $308,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,536,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $279,000 for the quarter and a loss of $935,000 from discontinued operations for the 9 months. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 1. Results have been restated to reflect the discontinuance of the department stores segment, which was sold during the second quarter of 1986. The company said the inventory LIFO charge for the latest third quarter reduced pre-tax earnings by $1.2 million, compared with a $2.3 million reduction last year. In addition, third quarter earnings benefited from a 1 cent a share non-operating gain related to the sale of real estate. The company said its 1986 sales and earnings include the operating results of Angelo's Supermarkets, which was acquired Jan. 31, accounted for as a purchase.

title: A Committee Expands
description: The new Senate leadership has decided to expand the prestigious Foreign Relations Committee to 20 members from 17. The lineup used to be 9 Republicans and 8 Democrats; now it will be 11 Democrats and 9 Republicans.

title: Police Cruiser Crashes in Chase
description: A woman in a speeding car took police and state troopers on a wild chase Tuesday night through Westchester and Rockland Counties, evading an attempt to box her in and maneuvering a police cruiser into a rolling crash, officials said.

title: Morgan Mortgage Obligation Issues
description: Morgan Stanley Mortgage Trust is offering $250 million of collateralized mortgage obligations divided into five tranches, with some of the obligations called ''ascending-rate bonds,'' or ''arbs,'' featuring interest rates that escalate at periodic intervals.

title: Kirk's Response
description: ''I haven't done anything knowingly wrong.'' said Dana Kirk. ''There are two sides to everything.''

title: Coffee Consumption Up
description: The world is drinking more coffee, but prices are not expected to rise. Purchases by importers belonging to the International Coffee Organization, which accounts for 90 percent of world imports, rose during the 12 months ended Sept. 30 to 57.22 million bags from 55.88 million a year before.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's 375 money market mutual funds decreased $1.99 billion, to $234.97 billion, for the week ended Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Leader Is Elected At Key Nynex Unit
description: Frederic V. Salerno, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the New England Telephone Company, has been elected president and chief executive of the New York Telephone Company.

title: JERSEY DROPS PLAN TO MOVE RADON SOIL
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection today abandoned its plan to spread radon-contaminated soil from Montclair, N.J., in open areas in Vernon Township.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $38 million and $40,600,000 from early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month is also after a writedown of $380,000,000 for idling of the company's Aliquippa, Pa., steel works. The company said the latest third quarter and 9-month losses are after special charge of $2.1 billion for additional pension costs and the writedown of fixed assets, inventory, goodwill, debt discount and receivables. The company said the latest 9-month loss also includes a special charge of $535 million from the indefinite idling of four steel facilities, the rejection of the reserve mining partnership agreement and the writeoff of its investment in reserve Mining Co. and two other oil ventures.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SALVADOR DALI: A Biography. By Meryle Secrest. Illustrated. 307 pages. Dutton. $22.50.

title: POPE, IN TASMANIA, URGES RESPECT FOR WOMEN'S RIGHTS IN WORKPLACE
description: Pope John Paul II stood up for women's rights in the workplace today, calling on society to respect their dual role as workers and mothers.

title: MUSIC: RAFAEL PUYANA, HARPSICHORD
description: THE highlight of Rafael Puyana's harpsichord recital Saturday in the Blummenthal patio of the Metropolitan Museum came with that raucous and brilliantly characterized suite of Couperin, ''Les Fastes de la Grande et Ancienne Mxnxstrxndxsx.'' He played with the confident stride and full-bodied pacing for which he has been long noted, and after many invigorating details he ended with a deftly offbeat final cadence (falling a bit later than anyone could have expected).

title: Reagan Skips School
description: One of the many casualties of the Iran/Nicaragua problems at the White House this week was President Reagan's scheduled visit to an elementary school that was cited last week by the Department of Education as one of the best in the country.

title: Nazi Camp Guard Denies Israeli Charge
description: John Demjanjuk trembled in court here today as he denied being the sadistic guard who prodded Jews into the Nazi death chambers of Treblinka with a sword and turned on the gas that killed them.

title: McLean Chief's Gamble Has Failed to Pay Off . . .
description: Thirty years ago, Malcolm Purcell McLean revolutionized the shipping industry when he pioneered the use of container ships. But his latest effort to reshape the industry has run aground.

title: What Liberal Arts Should Remember From Past
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 2 FERNANDO ARRABAL PLAYS
description: IN the iconoclastic view from Fernando Arrabal's playwriting perch, the apocalypse is inevitable, but everything leading up to it is subject to accident. In ''The Architect and the Emperor of Assyria,'' the Emperor tells the story of playing pinball as a wager to prove the existence of God. In the game he reaches a record score of 999 - and then a drunk hits the machine and it goes ''Tilt!'' Life, as it were, is at a tilt for Arrabal. It is a vagary, and it is from accidents, no matter how tragic, that the playwright derives his pitch-black humor. In his plays, everything is assailable - especially religion and politics.

title: ON SUPERTITLES AND THE JOYS OF OPERA
description: THE New York City Opera has just completed its third full season of opera with English supertitles, and dozens of regional companies have adopted the device, which may be the most significant innovation in operatic performance since the introduction of directors from the theater world. But watching dozens of performances -and audiences - during those seasons has only deepened the reservations this operagoer felt at the outset.

title: DIVERSE EXCHANGE PLANS LURE STUDENTS FROM FARAWAY PLACES
description: JENNIFER SMITH, 21 years old, is a senior at Middlebury College. But last winter her campus was a game ranch on the Athi River in Kenya, where she worked on an experiment to learn whether ranching could maintain herds of wildlife while simultaneously providing meat for Kenya's cities. The program was sponsored by the Massachusetts-based School for Field Studies.

title: EXOTIC HOLLYWOOD INSTITUTION: LUNCH
description: For Hollywood agents, studio executives and movie producers, merely lunching in the trendiest restaurants five days a week is not enough. Status depends on who sits on the banquette opposite you.

title: The Spread
description: Kenny Rice, sports director at WTVQ-TV in Lexington, Ky., interprets the ''Play to Win NFL Contest'' sponsored by McDonald's: ''The rules are very fair. If the Bears win, you get a small order of fries. If the Colts win, you get a car.''

title: Lava in Hawaii Takes 2 Houses
description: A thin river of lava from the Kilauea volcano consumed two houses in its path today and officials feared that three more homes would also be destroyed. No injuries were reported.

title: Let's Take a Tip on Taxicabs From Mexico City
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENCE BRINGS SECT UNDER SCRUTINY
description: The man who would be the son of God is a member of the Better Business Bureau, has an eye for pretty women and is unwilling to dissociate himself from one of his disciples, a former defensive end for the St. Louis Cardinals who stands accused of murdering two men while doing God's work.

title: SANDINISTAS TALK OF WATERGATE
description: The official Sandinista newspaper compared the United States-Iranian arms deal to Watergate today, repeating charges that President Reagan must have known what was going on and should not be in office if he did not.

title: LeRoy Johnson Dies; Led Polygamist Group
description: LeRoy Johnson, the patriarch who presided for decades over a polygamist community on the Arizona-Utah border, has died at age of 98, a spokesman said today.

title: Linda Goldberger Wed To Peter E. Weissbrod
description: Linda Joy Goldberger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Goldberger of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Eric Weissbrod, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weissbrod of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Coconut Creek, Fla. Rabbi Aaron Landes, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: The company said the latest third quarter and 9-month earnings were reduced by $1,065,000, or 3 cents a share, because of a retroactive adjustment for federal income taxes resulting from new tax laws. The company said share earnings for all periods are based on current shares outstanding, and a previously announced 3-for-2 stock split will be distributed Nov. 28 to shareholders of record Oct. 31.

title: 48 ARE REPORTED KILLED AND 52 WOUNDED AS IRANIAN MISSILE HITS THE CAPITAL OF IRAQ
description: An Iranian missile devastated an entire block of a Baghdad residential district before dawn today, killing 48 people and wounding 52, the official Iraqi radio reported.

title: ANGOLAN LEADER WARNS ZAIRE ON SHELTERING REBELS
description: Angolan troops may pursue United States-backed rebels into Zaire if large numbers start using that country as a sanctuary, Angola's President said Tuesday.

title: GERMANY FUND reports earnings for As of Sept 30
description: Net income represents net assets. The company said it began operations on July 23, 1986. Net proceeds from its initial public offering of 7.5 million shares totaled $68,890,000.

title: A KENNEDY HOUSE AT ISSUE
description: A landowner who lives near the former summer home of President John F. Kennedy may go to court to halt high-society functions at the oceanfront estate, a lawyer said Tuesday.

title: Incomparable Pleasures of a Pomegranate
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY OFFICIALS SEEK ADVICE ON THEIR PAY
description: City Council leaders, with Mayor Koch's support, are preparing to create a special commission to recommend pay rises for themselves and other elected city officials.

title: Capitals Pushing Carpenter Trade
description: The Washington Capitals were trying to trade Bobby Carpenter today, one day after telling the former 50-goal scorer that his services were no longer needed.

title: Prices Fall in Germany
description: West German consumer prices in November show the sharpest year-to-year decline in more than 30 years, the Government reported today.

title: 2 ARABS GUILTY IN WEST BERLIN BOMBING
description: A West German court convicted two Arabs today in the bombing of an Arab social club here and upheld as ''credible'' their testimony implicating Syria and its East Berlin embassy in the outrage.

title: Thanksgiving at Track: For Early Birds
description: At 11 o'clock this morning, many New Yorkers will be observing such homey holiday traditions as watching the Thanksgiving Day parade, trimming the turkey or settling in for an afternoon of televised football. A few thousand diehard horseplayers, though, will be rooting home the first half of the daily double at Aqueduct.

title: Designated Thanker
description: For many Americans, it has been a year of abundance and nowhere more so than on Wall Street. Consider the bonuses, $200,000 and more, just dished out to young investment bankers and other yuppie yeomen of the 100-hour week. Their problem is there's too little time to enjoy the fruits. Andrew Feinberg, a New York writer, responded to that anomaly recently in The Times's Business section with a self-sacrificing proposal. He reasoned that with all those unspent dollars, there must be a market for vicarious spending. He would ride to the rescue of the work-worn wealthy and let himself be appointed as their Designated Spender.

title: BACK SPASMS STILL BOTHER BURT
description: When the Giants began practice today for Monday night's game against the 49ers in San Francisco, Jim Burt stayed home in Waldwick, N.J., because of back spasms.

title: L.I.R.R. Station Damaged in Blaze
description: A fire that may have been preceded by a series of explosions severely damaged 183 feet of the westbound platform of the Long Island Rail Road station here, and damaged a shelter, the police said yesterday.

title: Koch Chooses Ravitch To Head Charter Panel
description: Mayor Koch appointed Richard Ravitch, the former transit offical, to head a commission being formed in response to a Federal court ruling that the Board of Estimate's voting structure is unconstitutional.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes net gains from the sale of a building of $228,000 for the quarter and $921,000 for the year. c-After a net charge of $434,000 from writeoff of a unit.

title: TEHERAN'S LEADERS, DELIGHTING IN WASHINGTON'S DISARRAY, PULL TOGETHER AND POINT TO A MAJOR VICTORY
description: Iran's leaders are treating the growing foreign policy uproar here as a major diplomatic and propaganda victory, according to American officials, Arab diplomats, and experts on Iran.

title: NIEMCZAK, 2d IN CITY MARATHON, FAILS TEST
description: Antoni Niemczak of Poland, who finished second to Gianni Poli of Italy in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 2, was disqualified from the race yesterday by The Athletics Congress after two tests of his post-race urine samples tested positive for anabolic steroids.

title: Chesebrough Suitor Says It Has $3 Billion for Deal
description: American Brands Inc., the diversified tobacco company, said yesterday that it had arranged up to $3 billion in bank financing to carry out its proposed $2.81 billion acquisition of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., the consumer products and chemicals concern.

title: British Re-emphasize Ties to Falklanders
description: The Thatcher Government has restated its commitment to the Falklanders in the face of another defeat over the issue at the United Nations.

title: SMUCKER, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LATEST HURRAH FOR ESPOSITO
description: He shifted in his seat and scribbled notes and when Walt Poddubny of the Rangers just missed on a shot, his neck craned, his toes stiffened, and he said softly, ''Ah, that hurts.''

title: EWING AT CENTER, BUT CELTICS PREVAIL
description: Perhaps this was not the time to experiment. Hubie Brown, the Knicks' beleaguered coach, chose tonight to concede to Patrick Ewing's long-stated desire to play center rather than forward, where he has struggled since the start of the season. But Boston Garden has never been known as a laboratory for opposing coaches.

title: F.A.A. Says Airlines Follow New Safety Rules
description: All major airlines are in compliance with new safety regulations designed to improve chances of survival in fire and smoke aboard large airplanes, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: SELECTING A VCR FOR YOUR NEEDS
description: ANYONE buying a video-cassette recorder - VCR for short - can now choose from three different formats and roughly 200 different models, ranging in price from less than $300 to over $1,500. Buyers may well feel bewildered.

title: Hilton Seeks Hotel Chain
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said tonight that it was considering bidding for the Hilton International Company, a subsidiary of the Transworld Corporation that is for sale as part of the liquidation of some of Transworld's assets.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about the Walt Disney Company's aggressive new marketing policy misidentified the people shown. They were, from left, Jihan el-Sadat, widow of the Egyptian President; Dmitri Agrachev, an interpreter; Misha Sokolov, Soviet recipient of the International Children's Peace Prize; Dawn Balady, United States prize recipient; Patricia Montandon, organizer of the event, and Bonita Granville Wrather, chairman of the Wrather Corporation.

title: WEBSTER, COACH IN MINORS, NAMED TO SUCCEED SATOR
description: The week of midnight talks and early-morning dismissals, of ex-coaches being flown out hurriedly and prospective coaches being flown in, was over. Phil Esposito introduced the new coach of the Rangers yesterday and he said, ''Now I have someone with a hockey philosophy much closer to my own.''

title: UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After pre-tax gains of $4,566,000 and $8.3 million on the disposal of property for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After pre-tax gains of $512,000 and $3,785,000 on the disposal of property for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: LUXURY DEVELOPMENTS OFFER URBAN AMENITIES, COUNTRY-CLUB SETTINGS
description: WHILE the prototypical American home - a free-standing house on its own land - may still be the norm in many American suburbs, a new style of housing is changing both the suburban landscape and the way people live. Expensive architect-designed cluster housing developments are proliferating in towns around many major cities, offering the comforts and amenities of luxury urban high-rises in a country setting.

title: NEW HEARTS GIVEN TO TWO PATIENTS
description: An Arizona woman became the world's 29th known recipient of an artificial heart yesterday while at the same time surgeons gave an Indiana man a donor heart to replace the Jarvik-7 artificial heart that had kept him alive nearly five days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1986
description: The World

title: GANDHI AND GORBACHEV HOLD TALKS 4 MORE HOURS
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and Mikhail S. Gorbachev conferred here Wednesday for four hours and today signed a $1 billion economic aid package and accords on scientific and cultural cooperation.

title: Bokassa Trial Put Off After Turbulent Session
description: The trial of Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the former Emperor Bokassa I, was postponed until next month after the prosecutor said during a stormy four-hour opening session today that he needed more time to prepare the case.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
PRESSED FARMERS SHARE FAITH IN MEETING CRISES
description: In the back room of the King's Inn, ''a family restaurant'' on Highway 19, sat a group of men who had left their pickup trucks in the parking lot, rifles in the cabs. One had shot two deer in the russet and yellow woods and had brought their racks, eight points each, to show. Another friend, not a regular at this table, had shot himself on the back porch of his house three months ago.

title: U.S. TO EXCEED ARMS TREATY LIMIT TOMORROW
description: The Reagan Administration told members of Congress today that the United States would exceed the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty on Friday.

title: SOUGHT TO SILENCE CRITIC
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and his Inspector General have censured Navy Secretary John L. Lehman and other Navy officials for putting pressure on a military contractor to stop one of its executives from criticizing the Pentagon.

title: Lightning in Soviet Hurts 8
description: Eight Soviet soldiers were knocked unconscious when lightning struck the ground at their Caucasus mountain training range in Soviet Georgia, the official press agency Tass reported today. ''The fireball, about the size of a saucer, came flying toward a field kitchen, hit the metal frame of an awning, rebounded into the center of a group of soldiers and discharged,'' Tass said.

title: Only a Bay of Pigs
description: We can hope that the ransom scandal will turn out to be more of a Bay of Pigs than a Watergate. Here is Presidential guidance from a hand with a memory: 1. Reassess all recent advice from the N.S.C. staff. From the moment of the revelation of arms shipments to the discovery of diversion of profits to the contras (or whoever wound up with the money), you were misled.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Bond Insurance Market Has Three New Players
description: The bond insurance business continues to attract new participants, lured by prospects of rapid growth and an extremely low loss experience.

title: EDITED BOOKS ON JEWISH LORE
description: Nathan Ausubel, the editor of ''A Treasury of Jewish Folklore'' and other books of Judaica, died Sunday at his home in Callicoon, N.Y. following a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Up Modestly
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly in subdued activity yesterday as many investors and traders left work early for the holiday.

title: Packer Is Sorry
description: Even though Charles Martin, the Green Bay Packers' defensive lineman, is appealing a two-game suspension for slamming Jim McMahon of the Chicago Bears to the turf, Martin said yesterday that the penalty may not be out of line. On Tuesday, Commissioner Pete Rozelle suspended Martin without pay, saying Martin's action came when the play was clearly over.

title: FRIEDMAN SAYS HIS APPEAL WILL CITE REMARK BY JUDGE
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, said yesterday that he would appeal his conviction on Federal charges based on an ''injudicious statement'' by Judge Whitman Knapp and the judge's refusal to allow testimony Mr. Friedman believed was crucial to his defense.

title: FUNDS WOULDN'T GO TO SHOREHAM
description: The Long Island Lighting Company today requested a 5 percent rate increase for its 1 million customers.

title: A Perfect 10th
description: The nine such games to date:

title: Jon Bradshaw, 48, an Author And Esquire Magazine Editor
description: Jon Bradshaw, an author and a contributing editor of Esquire magazine, died Tuesday of a heart attack at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center, three days after collapsing while playing tennis. He was 48 years old.

title: Weill Issue's Big Following
description: BETTING on the jockey is a common strategy both at the track and on Wall Street. Late last month, investors did just that when they paid $857 million for 80 percent of the Commercial Credit Company in the third-largest initial public stock offering in United States history.

title: Indiana Conservative Seated on U.S. Court
description: Daniel A. Manion, whose qualifications as a judge were attacked by law school deans shortly after President Reagan appointed him to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, was sworn in today.

title: Hope for New York City's Homeless?; There Is No Quick Fix
description: The first thing that has to be said about the homelessness problem is that solving it is going to take time. There are no quick fixes in sight for getting people off the streets, out of the shelters and into private housing.

title: REGAN SAYS HE'S CALM ON IRAN FUROR
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, said today that he was responding to the storm over the arms-deal disclosures ''with equanimity.''

title: WALDBAUM TO BE SOLD TO A.&P.
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, continuing its two-year comeback as one of the nation's largest supermarket chains, agreed yesterday to purchase a controlling interest in Waldbaum Inc., the nation's 12th-largest supermarket operation, with 140 stores in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

title: MICRO MASK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $93,000 for the quarter and $294,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $154,000 for the quarter and a gain of $254,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
Staley Continental Depository Shares
description: Staley Continental Inc., a corn processing and food service company based in Rolling Meadows, Ill,, is offering three million shares of depository preferred stock with a 7 percent dividend at $50 a share through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Anti-Raider Move By Morton Thiokol
description: The board of Morton Thiokol Inc. has taken steps to shield the company's two pension plans from raiders who might seek to use the funds to help finance a hostile takeover. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Morton Thiokol said new amendments to the plans would bar any excess assets of the plans from reverting back to the company for a five-year period if any person or group acquired over 20 percent of the company's shares.

title: Clippers Seek Dailey
description: The Los Angeles Clippers said that they had made an offer to Quintin Dailey, the guard formerly with the Chicago Bulls, and that an agreement could be reached soon. ''He has not signed anything with the Los Angeles Clippers at this point in time,'' said Elgin Baylor, general manager of the Clippers.

title: Harvard Plans Wing for Fogg Museum
description: The Harvard University Art Museums today announced plans to raise $5.8 million for a new wing on the Fogg Art Museum. The new quarters will house permanently the collection of German paintings and sculptures of the Busch-Reisinger Museum.

title: South Africans Relent On Ouster of Red Cross
description: South Africa today reversed an expulsion order against Red Cross officials and said they could remain.

title: TWO FAMILIES PERISH IN FIRES AT HOME IN BROOKLYN AND NASSAU
description: Ten people - a family of five in Plainview, L.I., and a family of five living above a storefront church in Brooklyn - were killed in early morning fires yesterday.

title: Pontiac Fiero Cuts Cause 600 Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation will cut production on its Pontiac Fiero models and lay off 600 workers next year to avert the need for financing sales incentives on the sporty cars, G.M. officials said.

title: British Columbia Bank Takeover Set
description: The struggling Bank of British Columbia, in a widely expected move, said it had agreed to a takeover by Hongkong Bank of Canada, a unit of the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation. The bank, Canada's seventh-largest domestic bank, said Hongkong Bank would pay about $63.5 million Canadian ($45.7 million American) for most of its estimated $2.88 billion ($2.07 billion) of assets and would maintain the bank's operations.

title: BRONX INQUIRIES SAID TO BE GOING TO GRAND JURIES
description: Two Federal grand juries will soon begin hearing evidence in at least five corruption investigations centering on the Bronx, a city law-enforcement official said yesterday.

title: ISRAEL REPORTEDLY GOT MIXED SIGNALS FROM U.S. ON WEAPONS SALES TO IRAN
description: The United States has apparently sent Israel differing signals over the last seven years on the acceptability of arms sales to Iran. Sometimes Washington has vigorously opposed deliveries of weapons and spare parts to the regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and sometimes it has approved them.

title: PEOPLES SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company went public in October.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
CALIFORNIA COURT GETTING NEW CHIEF
description: Gov. George Deukmejian today nominated Associate Justice Malcolm Lucas, his former law partner, to succeed Rose Elizabeth Bird as Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court.

title: The 25th Amendment
description: A bipartisan commission sponsored by the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia has been formed to examine the parts of the 25th Amendment to the Constitution that deal with appointing a temporary President in case the incumbent is incapacitated.

title: PALESTINIAN-SHIITE BATTLES RAGING IN LEBANON
description: Pitched battles raged today between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen here and in southern Lebanon as fears grew of a full-scale Lebanese-Palestinian civil war.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
JAMES RIVER reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
'36 CHOWRINGHEE LANE' OFFERED ON 13
description: THE aging, unmarried schoolteacher lives alone in a modest apartment, getting a letter every once in a while from her married niece in Australia. She is lonely but wants to stay where she is. ''Why leave a place you've known all your life,'' she asks, ''and go away to a strange country in your old age?'' The scene could be set in New York, London or any other contemporary city, but this one takes place in Calcutta. The Indian film is titled ''36 Chowringhee Lane,'' and can be seen tonight at 11 o'clock on Channel 13's ''Channel Crossings,'' a series of television films from abroad.

title: ISLANDERS, DEVILS WIN ON THE ROAD
description: Ken Leiter and Mike Bossy scored 35 seconds apart in the second period tonight and Kelly Hrudey stopped 34 shots to help the Islanders defeat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 3-2.

title: RISKS FOR THE DEMOCRATS
description: Leading Democrats are worried that their party may waste the advantage it has clearly gained from the disarray in the White House by behaving, in the words of a Democratic leader in Congress, ''like so many apprentice Torquemadas.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Does the bank president know whether a teller in the bank is fiddling around with the books? No.'' - Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff. [ A9:3. ]

title: Skiers Get a Lift On Ticket Prices
description: Ask any group of skiers what their chief complaint about skiing is, and most will say, ''lift-ticket prices.''

title: ARCHITECTURE: 2 SHOWS OF DRAWINGS
description: IN a period of blockbuster exhibitions, the small show, with a few fine drawings that make a single point, can be a particular pleasure. In architecture, the regular home of such exhibitions is the Urban Center at 457 Madison Avenue, at 49th Street, where several intimate shows are usually up concurrently. At the moment, two small exhibitions of the work of three architects are in place at the Urban Center. The pencil drawings of Alessandro Anselmi, a Roman architect, are in the paneled lounge of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects (through Nov. 29); ''Recent Projects by Peter Eisenman and Jaquelin Robertson'' is in the second-floor corridor (through Dec. 12, sponsored by the Architectural League).

title: Alexander's Changes Tack
description: Alexander's Inc. said yesterday that it would abandon its plan to convert the company into a limited partnership and would postpone until at least 1990 the closing of its flagship department store at 58th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: CITY SELLING PROSPECT HEIGHTS PARCELS
description: The Koch administration plans for the first time to sell large clusters of abandoned apartment buildings it owns in a single neighborhood. But the plan has run into stiff opposition from community and housing groups, which say it will divide the neighborhood economically and racially.

title: After Friedman: Crowning a King
description: Operating in close to a political vacuum, Michael DeMarco, chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, the second most powerful position on the Council, emerged yesterday as a key participant - either as prospective county chairman, one of the kingmakers or both - in the manuevering to succeed Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic chair-man. Mr. Friedman was convicted Tuesday of racketeering, conspiracy and mail fraud.

title: Vietnamese Turn Over Remains of 3 War Dead
description: Vietnam today handed over what it described as the remains of three Americans missing in action in the Vietnam War, an American officer said.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 2
Sartre Screenplay to Get First Public Reading
description: ''The Freud Scenario,'' an unproduced screenplay by Jean-Paul Sartre, will be given its first public reading at Ubu Repertory Theater, 149 Mercer Street, Monday at 8 P.M. The work, which focuses on the period in Freud's life when he abandoned hypnosis to explore psychoanalysis, was commissioned by the director John Huston but never used.

title: Taft Broadcasting Stake Up to 13.1%
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, have raised their stake in the Taft Broadcasting Company to 13.1 percent, or 1.21 million common shares, from 11.3 percent.

title: Who's in Charge?
description: Exerpts from ''We Hold These Truths: Understanding the Ideas and Ideals of the Constitution,'' a new book by Mortimer J. Adler, scheduled to be published by MacMillan this year:

title: THATCHER CAUGHT IN 'SECRETS' WEB
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is being pressed to explain why her Government is not prosecuting a hereditary member of the House of Lords who was instrumental six years ago in arranging the publication of some of the supposed ''secrets'' she is now seeking to suppress.

title: Diner's Journal
description: MAN RAY was an expatriate American artist in Paris in the 1930's and 40's who became renowned for his haunting and technologically innovative photographs - some of which can be seen at a promising new bistro named after him in Chelsea. Opened just a month ago in a striking Art Deco setting formerly occupied by L'Express on Eighth Avenue between 18th and 19th Streets, Man Ray is serving some of the most ingenuous French bistro cuisine I have had in some time: spicy merguez sausage with chickpea salad, lustrous grilled loin of lamb in a garlic-infused sauce, outstanding cassoulet, and boiled short ribs of beef with winter vegetables and freshly grated horseradish. Dinner entrees range from $11 to $18.

title: OHIO RIVER BRIDGE CAUSES A DISPUTE
description: The City of Covington in northern Kentucky has $31 million and a dream of building a new bridge. What it lacks is the rather vital cooperation of the City of Cincinnati, across the Ohio River where the bridge would end.

title: ART BLAKEY AT MIKELL'S
description: The drummer Art Blakey will lead his Jazz Messengers quintet tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Sets are at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30; there is a $12 cover and a three-drink minimum.

title: Laughing at Reagan
description: A Washington adage holds that a President can successfully weather almost any amount of criticism, but when people begin laughing at him, watch out.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1986
description: The World

title: ARGENTINA DIVORCE BAN IS VOIDED
description: The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a 98-year-old law barring divorce in Argentina.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In what has become a Thanksgiving tradition, the Walter Camp Football Foundation, named for the former Yale player-coach who created the first all-America team in 1889, announced its 1986 selections yesterday, and, to no one's surprise, Vinny Testaverde of the University of Miami was named as the team's quarterback.

title: ORPHANAGES: RACIAL LINES DIVIDE MANY
description: This is a small town, by most standards, with only one post office, one elementary school and one block's worth of Main Street for its 8,405 people. Yet it has two orphanages, about two miles apart on the same winding two-lane road.

title: Dollar Dips In Europe
description: The dollar ended slightly lower today in quiet trading in Europe while the American markets observed the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: Woman Who Had Not Flown For Years Lands Plane Safely
description: A woman who had not flown for several years safely landed a twin-engine airplane with seven family members aboard after her husband suffered a fatal heart attack today, the authorities said.

title: Hanson to Acquire Kaiser Cement
description: Hanson Industries, the United States arm of Hanson Trust P.L.C., a company based in Britain whose holdings include Allders Department Stores and Imperial Tobacco, has agreed to acquire the Kaiser Cement Corporation for about $200 million, or $27.50 a share.

title: At South Street Seaport, The Other Half Beckons
description: The vision that converted South Street Seaport from a struggling fish market to one of the city's more lively shopping centers is only half realized, according to its developers.

title: Clean, Safe Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Store Where Intruder Died Is Found Burglarized Again
description: A frequently burglarized merchant who caused a furor by killing an intruder with a booby trap reported today that his store had been burglarized again.

title: BUSINESSMAN SAYS HE TIPPED OFF U.S.
description: An Oregon businessman said yesterday that he was told by Government intelligence sources early this year that the Defense Department was planning to buy weapons for Nicaraguan rebels with profits from the sale of arms to Iran.

title: 32 FIRES ARE SET OFF BY GAS MALFUNCTION IN TOWN IN EAST OHIO
description: A malfunctioning pressure regulator sent natural gas surging through pipelines today in this eastern Ohio community, setting off fires in 32 homes and businesses and causing at least $1 million damage, officials said.

title: Prison Calm After Inmate Dies
description: Guards searched a maximum-security unit for weapons today at the West Virginia Penitentiary after one inmate was stabbed to death and two others were wounded by fellow inmates.

title: IRANIANS' PLEAS FOR U.S. LETTERS ARE SHUNNED
description: The International Friendship League, a nonprofit clearinghouse for airmail correspondents, says it has received more than a thousand Iranians' requests to to correspond with Americans but it cannot find Americans who will write back..

title: HIGH CHOLESTEROL THREATENING MANY
description: Four out of five middle-aged American men run the risk of dying prematurely from heart disease because of unhealthy levels of cholesterol in the blood, Government scientists reported today.

title: Judge-Elect in Chicago Barred From Bench
description: A judge-elect jailed for contempt for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating judicial corruption may not take office for the time being, the Illinois Supreme Court has ruled.

title: MANUFACTURER ENDS PRODUCTION OF HEART VALVE
description: The manufacturer of a heart valve linked to 125 deaths has stopped production of the remaining models of the valve, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID PALESTINIAN BASES
description: Israeli jet fighters today attacked Palestinian positions near the southern Lebanese port city of Sidon in an area where Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Shiite militiamen have been engaged in clashes for the last week.

title: 'VAUGHAN WILLIAMS,' STUDY OF THE COMPOSER
description: IT would be easy enough to describe ''Vaughan Williams: A Symphonic Portrait'' as simply a chronological essay on the career and major works of one of the more outstanding English composers of this century. But, more to the point, this hourlong portrait was produced and directed - for British television's ''South Bank Show'' in 1984 -by Ken Russell, the maverick film director who, in fact, did some of his best work in his earlier years for television (''Song of Summer,'' ''Isadora''). Although ''Vaughan Williams,'' which will be shown on Channel 13's ''Creative Edge'' series Sunday at 10 P.M., is a relatively straightforward and fact-filled biography, Mr. Russell is still not about to settle for being commonplace.

title: Kemp Is Suiting Up
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, the former professional football star who has represented a Western New York district in the House for 16 years, is about to become an exploratory contender for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: OFFICIALS FEAR AIDE DESTROYED PAPERS ON IRAN ARMS DEAL
description: The Government has information indicating that Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, the dismissed White House aide, destroyed several documents from National Security Council files last weekend, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: STATE: 'ETIQUETTE,' A SPOOF OF MANNERS
description: IN the high-society milieu that is gently spoofed in William M. Hoffman and John Braden's musical revue ''Etiquette,'' the guests at a formal dinner party chatter demurely about gladiolus and the appalling conditions in Nepal.

title: Wedding Ring Retrieved From Tons of Garbage
description: Daniel Carey is not one to give up on sentiment, or a wedding ring lost in tons of garbage.

title: 'VAN GOGH' AT THE METROPOLITAN: PORTRAIT OF THE TRIUMPHANT ARTIST
description: THE first thing that needs to be said about Vincent van Gogh is that he has triumphed. He all but invented the Expressionist dream of painting and living at a level truer and deeper than the one at which society settles in. He believed that painting could become a new kind of bread and wine that everyone could share. One measure of his success is the degree to which his work attracts and sustains an ever broader range of people.

title: SOUTH ST. SEAPORT SING
description: A 25-foot tree will come to life with music this weekend at the South Street Seaport, at Fulton Street.

title: Three Children Die In Two San Diego Fires
description: Two sisters burned to death when their home near downtown became engulfed in flames around 7 A.M. today, and a predawn fire killed another child, the authorities said.

title: JANE'S SAYS IRAN 'WILL TAKE ANYTHING'
description: Iran has acquired arms from sources in numerous countries, often at above-market prices, and the United States arms transfers to Teheran ''were only the tip of the iceberg,'' Jane's Defense Weekly said today.

title: THEATER: 'TERMINAL BAR' FROM EN GARDE ARTS
description: ENTER the expression ''site-specific'' in the theatrical lexicon. It is the equivalent of ''on location,'' with a play staged in a particular, nontheatrical environment. The latest example is Paul Selig's ''Terminal Bar,'' and, for the occasion, a former automobile showroom in SoHo has been transformed into a last-chance saloon of the playwright's imagination.

title: G.M. CHIEF RETURNS FIRE IN SKIRMISH WITH PEROT
description: The war of words between the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, and the company's biggest stockholder, H. Ross Perot, appears to be escalating, with Mr. Smith trying to seize the initiative.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Illinois Jacquet Big Band, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, between 11th and Perry Streets (255-4037). When Illinois Jacquet brought his 16-piece big band to the Village Vanguard last July, he was known primarily for ''Flyin' Home'' -which he recorded with Lionel Hampton's band 45 years ago - and as the leader of his own small group for more than 40 years. He formed the big band after he gave a series of master classes at Harvard University in 1983. ''Their eagerness for the big-band music and their ability to grasp the essence of it made me realize that today's generation has not been properly exposed to the big-band sound,'' Mr. Jacquet said. His message seems to be getting across because his engagement at the Vanguard in July was the club's most successful week in its 51-year history. Mr. Jacquet's big band will be at the Vanguard again tonight through Sunday. Shows are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. with a third show tonight and tomorrow at 1 A.M. There is a $10 music charge and a $5 drink minimum.

title: A Byrd in a Hat
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the incoming Senate majority leader, blossomed forth this week in a magnificent broad-brimmed felt hat festooned with a ribbon of brightly colored feathers.

title: FEW CITY WORKERS CHOSE TO SWITCH HEALTH PLANS
description: Profit-making health maintenance organizations and other insurers competing for the health coverage of New York City employees fell far short of their enrollment goals for 1987.

title: Sojuzpushnina Fur Ads In Harper's Bazaar
description: The Soviet Government and Harper's Bazaar certainly make strange bedfellows, but the profit motive tends to bring that about.

title: RESIGNATION REJECTED IN BRAZIL
description: In the midst of a wave of nervousness about the direction of Brazil's economic policies, the powerful Finance Minister, Dilson Funaro, submitted his resignation Wednesday night, but it was immediately rejected by President Jose Sarney.

title: 3 Air Controllers Transferred After Off-Duty Drug Inquiry
description: Three air traffic controllers have been switched to duties unrlated to safety in an investigation into whether they used drugs off duty, officials said Wednesday.

title: 7-MILE RIVER OF LAVA DESTROYS 9 HOMES IN HAWAII
description: A seven-mile river of glowing hot lava from Kilauea Volcano destroyed more homes today, bringing to nine the number consumed in the last two days. The lava severed a highway and inched toward the ocean near this coastal community.

title: GUIDRY NOT SETTLING FOR RHODEN'S PAY
description: In reaching agreement with Rick Rhoden on a contract extension, the Yankees had hoped to induce Ron Guidry to sign a contract for the same terms. However, Guidry's agent said yesterday the free-agent pitcher won't accept the same deal.

title: Faltering Late in the Season
description: With the final quarter of the season looming, the Jets face four ominous games.

title: FIGURE IN BIRTH DISPUTE QUITS
description: Mary Ann Sorrentino, whose ex communication by the Roman Catholic Church became a national focal point in the debate on abortion, has announced that she is resigning as executive director of Planned Parenthood of Rhode Island. Ms. Sorrentino, who said she was writing a book she hoped to publish next year, said Tuesday that her resignation ''in no way represents any abandonment of my commitment to women and to their reproductive rights.'' in January a priest disclosed on a television program that she had been ousted from the church because of her work at Planned Parenthood.

title: Borg-Warner Bids Put Leader on Spot
description: Clarence E. Johnson, the chief executive of the Borg-Warner Corporation, is a man under pressure now, with his company a possible takeover target of two large concerns, the Minstar Corporation and the GAF Corporation. But Mr. Johnson has been a target before and walked away unshaken and unscathed.

title: Nevada-Las Vegas Looking for a Break
description: Few will argue that next March, Nevada-Las Vegas will represent the Pacific Coast Athletic Association in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The Runnin' Rebels have won four consecutive conference titles and are heavily favored to win a fifth.

title: On Tucking Nuclear Waste Under Earth's Plates
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgery for Salming
description: Borje Salming, a Toronto Maple Leafs defenseman, will be out indefinitely after undergoing facial cosmetic surgery that involved more 200 stitches to close a cut suffered Wednesday night against the Detroit Red Wings.

title: STATE DEPT. PLANS TO SCREEN FOR AIDS
description: Foreign Service applicants, officers and their dependents will be tested for the AIDS virus under a screening program expected to begin Jan. 1, State Department officials said today.

title: On Breaking, or Bending, or Ignoring, the Law
description: ''On great occasions, every good officer must be ready to risk himself in going beyond the strict line of the law when the public preservation requires it,'' Thomas Jefferson advised, justifying his unilateral purchase of munitions without benefit of Congressional approval. ''His motives will be his justification,'' he added.

title: DROUGHT ADDS A VICTIM: OYSTER CROP
description: It has been said here that south Louisiana's wetlands are so rich you can find oysters growing in the marsh grass, stuck to an old tin can or a chunk of wood. There is talk of oysters as big as dinner plates.

title: SIDNEY GROSS
description: Sidney Gross, a retired chairman of the department of journalism and mass communications at New York University, died of lung cancer Wednesday at New York University Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: FOR most of its nine years, Restaurant Raphael has been a demure and proper establishment that remained virtually unknown beyond its gilded quadrant around West 54th Street and Fifth Avenue. The starched and wing-tipped Paul Stuart types who claimed it as their lunch club seemed conspiratorial in their silence about it. Perhaps that is why during my three years of scouring Manhattan for noteworthy restaurants no one ever mentioned the place -until this fall.

title: EFFERVESCENT STANDARDS AVAILABLE AROUND CITY
description: MITCHELL PARISH'S lyrics for the imperishable pop standard ''Star Dust'' probably come as close as any to evoking the qualities that make a popular song endure. ''The melody haunts my reverie, and I am once again with you, when our love was new and each kiss an inspiration'' go words that nestle wistfully into Hoagy Carmichael's floating jazz-tinged music.

title: Asset Offer Made In India by Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation today offered to maintain assets worth more than $3 billion to meet any future court order of damages arising out of India's compensation suit against it for alleged responsibility for the 1984 gas disaster at Bhopal. However, Fali Nariman, the chief attorney for the corporation, argued before a Bhopal judge that the offer was valid for unencumbered assets and only if the court lifted an injunction preventing a vast financial restructuring.

title: SPECTATOR FALLS
description: The annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade was marred yesterday by the fatal heart attack of one of the marchers and the accidental fall of a spectator from a fourth-floor window ledge on Central Park West onto another spectator on the crowded sidewalk below.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: CHRISTMAS came early to the New York City Opera as it held its annual Holiday Ball at the New York State Theater. Guests, including Samuel J. LeFrak, Helen F. Boehm and Eve Muscio, did some early holiday shopping, bidding on china, jewels and a mink coat donated for the event.

title: Julie Weissinger Simon Wed to Henry M. Jaffe
description: Julie Weissinger Simon and Henry Miles Jaffe were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., at the home of Louis L. Jaffe, father of the bridegroom and professor emeritus at the Harvard Law School. James Vorenburg, dean of the Harvard Law School, who is also a Justice of the Peace in Cambridge, officiated.

title: NO QUESTIONING OF REAGAN SEEN IN JUSTICE STUDY
description: President Reagan will not be questioned in the Justice Department's inquiry into the unauthorized diversion of millions of dollars to the Nicaraguan rebels, the White House said today.

title: CITY'S SCHOOLS SEEK SOLUTIONS ON DROPOUTS
description: For most of last year, 16-year-old Jose Rios hung around his mother's apartment, went to a lot of movies and worked part-time at his uncle's wholesale beer store. He rarely went to school.

title: Markets Idle Yesterday
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Thanksgiving. Stock and commodity markets, Government offices and banks will be open today. Some businesses, however, will be closed.

title: Blind Passenger Ousted After Refusing Switch
description: A blind man was escorted off a USAir jetliner by the police and cited for defiant trespass after he refused to move from his assigned seat near an emergency door, the authorities said today.

title: JERSEY FAIR-HOUSING BID IS EXPECTED TO FALL SHORT
description: As cities, boroughs and towns begin submitting their first plans to meet state affordable-housing laws, officials say it has become clear that the number of low-cost houses built in New Jersey will be far smaller than originally envisioned.

title: 15 CAMBODIAN REFUGEES GIVE THANKS
