description: In the hearts of at least half of the guests at Valerie Oltarsh's Thanksgiving dinner last night, the meaning of the day was as deep as the difference between ''hell and paradise.''

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL NETS VS. MAVERICKS, at Dallas (Television - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M.; Radio - WNEW 1130, 8:30 P.M.). ATLANTA HAWKS VS. JAZZ, at Salt Lake City, Utah (Television - WTBS, 10:05 P.M.).

title: The Case for a Balanced-Budget Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: FISHBONE AT THE RITZ
description: The funk and ska band Fishbone will perform tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800), on a double bill with Hunters and Collectors. Hunters and Collectors opens at 11 P.M., with Fishbone about 12:30 A.M.; tickets are $13.50

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: IN ''Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years, 1954-1965,'' it's all there - from Rosa Parks, who was arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat to a white man, to the murder of 14-year-old Emmett Till (for speaking disrespectfully to a white girl in Mississippi), to the historic march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The critically acclaimed documentary on those events, which mesmerized the nation, is running at Film Forum 1 until next Tuesday.

title: Loss Expected By Dutch Bank
description: A troubled Dutch mortgage bank, Friesch-Groningsche Hypotheekbank, expects to lose about $50 million this year, it said today, in contrast to previous forecasts of a $5 million profit.

title: Officer Fined Over Tickets
description: William P. Holcomb, a supervisor in a city office that tracks down unpaid parking tickets, has been fined more than $1,500 after pleading guilty to 375 unpaid traffic citations. ''I just had a few other things to attend to and I just let them slip my mind,'' Mr. Holcomb, 60 years old, who is a lieutenant in the city marshal's office, said in court Wednesday. ''I feel disgusted.''

title: Of Theaters, Zoning And Falling Ceilings
description: An inspection of New York City's oldest theaters has been completed by the Buildings Department. The result is an encouraging ''all clear'' to any theatergoer who has been staring nervously upward since the ceiling of the 94-year-old Murray Hill cinema collapsed last July, sending three patrons to the hospital.

title: JERSEY WATERFRONT PROJECT SOLD FOR $120 MILLION
description: The ambitious but unfinished Harborside Financial Center on the Jersey City waterfront has been sold by its developers for more than $120 million to a Manhattan-based realty concern acting for a private pension fund.

title: LIONS STUNNED BY 83-YARD RETURN, 44-40
description: Walter Stanley went with his instincts and against orders. It was a winning move all the way. Switching signals on plans for a fair catch, Stanley returned a punt 83 yards for a touchdown with 41 seconds left, giving the Green Bay Packers a 44-40 victory over the Detroit Lions today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1986
description: International

title: Cracking Down, Catching Up: Trashed Trucks
description: With New York's Transit Authority finally cracking down on subway graffiti, the spray-can ''artists'' are seeking new canvas. New York City's all-white sanitation trucks are sitting ducks, and about a third of the city's 1,900-truck fleet has been defaced.

title: Milestone for Nelson
description: For the Milwaukee Bucks, the 122-103 victory over the Washington Bullets Wednesday night seemed a pretty routine affair, but for the Bucks' coach, Don Nelson, it was one of those milestones to remember.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MY MOTHER'S SABBATH DAYS. By Chaim Grade. Translated from the Yiddish by Channa Kleinerman Goldstein and Inna Hecker Grade. 397 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. CHAIM GRADE was one of the foremost Yiddish poets and novelists of his generation. (A number of his books have been translated into English, most recently the group of three novellas entitled ''Rabbis and Wives.'') He was born in Vilnius, in Lithuania, in 1910, and won a name for himself as a writer while still in his 20's. When the Germans invaded Lithuania - which had not long before been annexed by the Soviet Union - in 1941, he set out for the Russian interior but decided that it would be safer for his wife to stay behind; they both shared what was then a commonly held illusion that however grievous a threat the Nazis posed to able-bodied Jewish men, they would at least spare women and children. His widowed mother also remained in Vilnius.

title: 'Barnum,' With Lancaster, On CBS Sunday Night
description: If the term may be used without sounding like an epithet, ''Barnum,'' the television biography of the peerless showman to be shown Sunday at 9 P.M. on CBS, is good family entertainment.

title: Bronx Man Arrested In Death of Girl
description: The police arrested a Bronx man yesterday in connection with the death of a pregnant teen-ager with whom they said he had been smoking crack on an apartment-house roof. They accused him of stabbing her before she fell 12 stories to her death.

title: Yellow Fever Claims 500 Lives in Nigeria
description: More than 500 people have died in a yellow fever epidemic in eastern Nigeria, the state-run radio reported today.

title: New Jardine Holding Unit
description: Jardine Matheson Holdings Ltd. said its Hongkong Land Company unit would spin off its Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group and contribute its remaining interest in Jardine to a new investment company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Montreal Trustco Inc., Montreal, said it would buy the $250 million residential mortgage loan portfolio of Bank of America Canada. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paccar Increases Its Stake in Trico
description: Paccar Inc. disclosed that it had raised its stake in Trico Industries to just over 20 percent, or 1.68 million shares, from 17.2 percent.

title: Thanksgiving Leftovers
description: It's a day for leftovers. Nibble at the turkey drumstick. Reheat the gravy. Drop a potato pancake into a skillet. Finish the mince pie. And before you take a nap, chew on these Thanksgiving Day thoughts:

title: Regan Says Hospital Loses Equipment
description: A spot check has found that a ''substantial portion'' of the equipment at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn may be missing and more is being wasted there, according to the State Comptroller.

title: 'BIG BANG' KILLING A TRADITION
description: The first casualty of London's ''Big Bang'' appears to be the stock exchange trading floor.

title: 'FRONT PAGE' DESIGNER MOVES FROM THE DANCE
description: Willa Kim sized up the situation backstage at a recent dress rehearsal. Too many gray hats. The green tweed jacket needed to be beaten up. Black galoshes for the brown shoes. ''Finding 1920's galoshes is going to be difficult,'' Ms. Kim said to her two assistants, ''much less ones in the right size.''

title: Certain Numbers Can Kill
description: How many workers are killed, injured or become sick in the nation's offices and factories each year?

title: Governor Announces Grants To Aid Pregnancy Prevention
description: Community groups in seven areas of the state with high birthrates among teen-agers have been selected to receive a total of $1.9 million for programs to prevent adolescent pregnancies, Governor Cuomo said today.

title: SYRIA IS TERMED UNSETTLED ON TERRORISM AND IRAN
description: Revelations of Syrian involvement in international terrorism have left President Hafez al-Assad deeply embarrassed, according to Arab and Western diplomats.

title: Markets Ignore Iranian Crisis
description: THE crisis over the Reagan Administration's secret arms shipments to Iran and the dismissal of two key White House aides over the transfer of funds received from Iran to Nicaraguan ''contras'' has thus far had no perceptible effect on the stock market. This week investors pushed the Dow-Jones industrial average up to 1,916.76, just a bit below its record high of 1,919.71.

title: Cracking Down, Catching Up: Regained Ground
description: New York City has been losing millions in lost revenue because of its lax management of the commercial properties it takes through foreclosure and condemnation.

title: THE DINER: AN AMERICAN ART FORM
description: For dinner there was roast beef and mashed potatoes submerged in gravy, and for dessert your choice of Jell-O or rice pudding. The check? $75. Diner fare at benefit prices. Still, everyone managed to go home with that satisfied feeling that comes from sitting in a plastic booth, eating coleslaw out of a little paper cup and getting a decent meal that ordinarily costs a great deal less than $75 a person.

title: 3 IN SOUTH AFRICA FREED IN KEY TRIAL
description: A judge acquitted three of 22 blacks and freed six on bail today in the latest developments in South Africa's biggest treason trial in three decades.

title: WROTE OF LIFE WITH NOVELIST
description: Mary Hemingway, a foreign correspondent for Time and Life magazines during World War II and the widow of Ernest Hemingway, died early Wednesday morning at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. She was 78 years old.

title: QUIETLY, PLANS FOR AN EATERY IN PARK GAIN
description: More than 25 years ago, Huntington Hartford, the multimillionaire heir to the A & P fortune, offered to put up the money for a restaurant in Central Park's southeast corner. He won the city's support, but strong opposition rose from such diverse sources as Walter Hoving, the president of Tiffany & Company, and the Sierra Club.

title: SAUDIS DENY REPORT ON DEALER
description: Reports that the Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi arranged financing for Iran's purchase of United States arms are ''planted lies,'' the Government said today.

title: Hempstead Tops Long Beach for Title
description: Hempstead defeated Long Beach, 34-0, in the Nassau County Conference I championship yesterday, extending its winning streak to 29 games and virtually assuring itself of the Rutgers Cup, given to the best team in Nassau County each year.

title: JOBLESS TRUCKER DRIVING GIFTS TO GUATEMALANS
description: Christmas is nearly a month away, but an unemployed truck driver is setting off in a tractor-trailer rig that he will drive more than 3,000 miles to deliver food, medical supplies and toys to poor families in Guatemala.

title: JERSEY POLICE KILL MAN WHO WOUNDEd 2 OFFICERS
description: The Camden police killed a 23-year-old man yesterday morning after he grabbed an officer's gun in a holding cell and shot two officers, the police said.

title: THEATER: 'THE STRANGER'S RETURN'
description: AT the core of the Yiddish National Theater's drama, ''The Stranger's Return,'' which opened last week at the Triplex Theater 2, is the matter of intermarriage between Jews and gentiles and the problems that society and history can bring to such unions. In this decidedly old-fashioned but interesting piece by Miriam Kressyn and Michael Fried, inspired by an earlier work by the American Yiddish writer Leon Kobrin, the question is approached melodramatically with sympathy, with a conviction that such situations can be destructive to all concerned.

title: Pravda Says Kohl Tries To Revive Cold War
description: The Soviet Union fiercely criticized Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today, accusing him of showing hostility to Moscow and trying to revive the cold war.

title: BUTTERFLY SEEN IN NEW LIGHT BY SCIENTISTS
description: Robert Pyle says he is not easily impressed by ostentatious Lepidoptera displays.

title: THE PIANIST BOLET RIDES ROMANTICISM TO THE TOP
description: Jorge Bolet, who is filling in for an indisposed Martha Argerich at Sunday's Great Performers series in Avery Fisher Hall, could be reached for a telephone interview a few days ago only at the Ambassador Lounge in Kennedy Airport. He was on his way to London, will return in time for the Sunday concert, and shortly after that will take off on the first leg of a series of European performances and recordings. That alone is worth a story.

title: SCREEN: DOCUMENTARY ABOUT MOHTER TERESA
description: SINCE she received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979, Mother Teresa, the founder of the Missionaries of Charity, has become an international celebrity -the Albert Schweitzer of her day.

title: TESTS SAID TO SHOW NEW DRUG REVERSES INTOXICATION
description: Government researchers are testing a drug that quickly reverses or prevents the intoxicating effects of alcohol, and they say it could potentially be used to sober up drunken people or to treat those who suffer from alcholism.

title: 3 ONE-ROOM SCHOOLS THRIVE IN RICH COUNTY
description: Wealthy Marin County, known for hot tubs and luxury cars, also has three of California's seven one-room schoolhouses.

title: WOMAN THROWS HER 2 SONS FROM 4th FLOOR
description: After locking herself in her children's bedroom, a 28-year-old woman flung her two young sons out the window of their fourth-floor Bronx apartment early yesterday and then jumped out herself, the police said.

title: DANCE: 'FRESH TRACKS' OF NEW CHOREOGRAPHERS
description: SIMPLICITY won the day in Dance Theater Workshop's Fresh Tracks program of dance by new and little-known choreographers, which opened on Tuesday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. Mickey McLaughlin's ''Evanesce'' is a tender and combative dance for two women who might be childhood friends, adolescent sisters or adult lovers.

title: MUSIC: ALLIANCE FOR AMERICAN SONG
description: The Alliance for American Song presents some of the most consistently engaging programs in the city, with unusual repertory, diligent performances and scholarly program notes. Sunday evening's concert at Gustavus Adolphus Church, commemorating the centennial of the birth of the American composer John Becker, was not quite so even as programs the group has offered in the past, but its moments of genuine fascination made the afternoon worthwhile.

title: Defining 'A Charlie' For Revlon
description: IF Revlon and its new agency -Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos - have their way, the word Charlie will be as rife with positive meanings as nerd is with negative.

title: Orange, N.J., Layoffs Feared
description: Budget cuts necessitated by the loss of Federal revenue-sharing funds may force the layoff of 16 of this city's 96 police officers and 7 of its firefighters without immediate state assistance, city and state officials said today. Orange, with a population of 50,000, has a projected budget deficit of $1.8 million in 1987, said Carmine Capone of the State Department of Community Affairs.

title: Debt Halved, Romania Says
description: Romania has halved its hard-currency foreign debt since 1981 and believes it is on schedule to be free of debt by 1990, a senior Finance Ministry official said Wednesday.

title: LABEQUE SISTERS, PIANO
description: The duo-pianists Katia and Marielle Labeque will play a program of works by Bach, Bizet, and Albeniz at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Sunday night at 7.

title: Humpty Dumpty's Fall
description: The refrain is familiar, even haunting: ''The President must act to get this behind us so we can move ahead,''

title: INSIDER SCANDAL STIRS ETHICS DEBATE
description: The Boesky affair on Wall Street has sharpened the interest of political leaders, academics and other analysts in scrutinizing the priorities of American business. The issue of whether

title: Separate Taxi-Fare Increase From the Issue of More Medallions
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Sisters' of Sigma Chi Face Rebuke on Prank
description: Some Sigma Chi fraternity ''little sisters'' will be disciplined for dousing a student columnist with beer and shaving cream because he criticized fraternities in the University of Miami's school newspaper.

title: PENN STATE NEXT
description: Geoff Torretta, substituting for Miami's injured star quarterback, Vinny Testaverde, threw for 328 yards and three touchdowns tonight as the top-ranked Hurricanes beat East Carolina, 36-10. The victory assured a showdown between Miami and second-ranked Penn State.

title: Publisher Expects Sale To Aid Marvel Comics
description: Stan Lee, the publisher of Marvel Comics, says the $50 million sale last week of the Marvel Entertainment Group to a West Coast studio, New World Pictures, will give Marvel's stable of superheroes a wider exposure.

title: Bridge: 2 Top Player-Administrators Will Be Visible at Nationals
description: For some five thousand players, the Fall National Championships beginning here Friday represent 10 days of action to come. But for 25 administrators, each representing one of the American Contract Bridge League's districts, a week of hard work, with committee meetings and board meetings, is ending.

title: RETIRED GENERAL SAID TO BE BEHIND CONTRA FLIGHTS
description: An American who was a pilot on secret supply flights to Nicaraguan guerrillas says the chief pilot for the flights told him ''several times'' that a retired general, Richard V. Secord, was ''behind the operation.''

title: NEW 'PURITANI' LEAD
description: Francoise Garner will step into the role of Elvira in Bellini's ''Puritani'' tomorrow afternoon at 2 at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: The All-Ouch Brigade
description: Among all active N.F.L. quarterbacks, these have suffered the most career sacks:

title: COURT SHIFTS INQUIRY ON RHODE ISLAND OFFICIAL
description: The state's trial court on Wednesday halted its investigation of possible misconduct in the office of Attorney General Arlene Violet in favor of letting her successor conduct the inquiry.

title: Attack on Father Is Charged
description: A 16-year-old was charged today with hiring a classmate to shoot his father and make the killing look like a burglary.

title: At Game's End, Let It Begin
description: The way Harvey Peeler and Dick Lee see it, kissing your sister may be a tolerable enough ordeal if she lives out of state, but if she's right there in South Carolina, well, there ought to be a law against it. And since Peeler and Lee are both members of the South Carolina Senate, they plan to pass one.

title: SNAGS IMPERIL JAPAN'S DREAM OF WORLD'S FASTEST COMPUTER
description: Japan's campaign to build the world's fastest computers has run into technological obstacles and budget cutbacks that experts say have severely jeopardized the chances of any major breakthroughs.

title: LIFE IS TIDY (IF TEDIOUS) FOR VOLCANO'S DISLODGED
description: The Minato Ward Sports Center has been turned into a haven for the displaced, a temple of fitness given suddenly to fitfulness. Across the gymnasium floor sprawl hundreds of restless people, many squatting at overturned cartons that serve as tables, sipping green tea and wondering when they can go home.

title: 2 at Intelsat Deny Charges
description: Two senior executives at Intelsat, suspended from their jobs earlier this week, today denied any wrongdoing in connection with their authorization of a $1.3 million payment to two Arkansas mortgage brokers working on a refinancing loan for the agency's new headquarters here.

title: SANDINISTAS ASSAIL REAGAN
description: The official Sandinista newspaper said today that secret dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels was ''the tip of the iceberg'' of Reagan Administration mistakes. Barricada, the newspaper, also cited the invasion of Grenada, the bombing of Libya, failure to negotiate nuclear disarmament and backing of Nicaraguan rebels. ''We are at the start of the unmasking of the Reagan Administration,'' it said.

title: FAST START SOUGHT ON DRUG PROGRAM
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett said today that the Government was taking unusual steps to quickly begin a $200 million anti-drug program because of the ''the emergency nature of the drug problem'' among the nation's youth.

title: Fishermen Win Pollution Suit
description: Members of a fishing club have been awarded more than $4 million by a jury that found that the club's lake had been ruined by waste from an adjacent egg farm.

title: SENATORS' PANEL MAY SUBPOENA 3 EX-U.S. AIDES
description: A Senate committee has tentatively decided to subpoena three former White House officials said by the Reagan Administration to know about the diversion of millions of dollars to the Nicaraguan rebels, a Congressional official said tonight.

title: 4 Seized in a Protest At Yale Deer Hunt
description: Animal rights activists who performed a play mocking Yale University's Thanksgiving Day deer hunt were arrested yesterday for harassing hunters at the Ivy League school's forest, officials said.

title: AFTER KILLING, TENANTS BACK THE SUSPECT
description: The rain fell in sheets on St. Nicholas Avenue. Altagracia Nava sat inside the Rivera Funeral Home and watched vacantly as friends shuffled by to pay last respects to her 28-year-old husband.

title: Historical Times In Talks With Cowles
description: Historical Times Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., which publishes seven magazine titles with a total circulation of 1.25 million, announced earlier this week that it is negotiating to sell itself to the Cowles Media Company, located in Minneapolis.

title: THE 2 SIDES IN THE PHILIPPINES REMAIN WARY
description: Two men guarded a backdoor entrance to the hall where a cease-fire agreement was signed today, one of the guards in the uniform of an armed forces colonel, the other a Communist rebel, his enemy in the 17-year insurgency.

title: UNHAPPY MEMORY SPURS 49ers' CRAIG
description: Roger Craig will be at fullback for the 49ers Monday night when they play the Giants in San Francisco, hoping for something better. The last time he played against the Giants, it was, in his words, ''the game I want to forget.''

title: JAZZ TRIO AT CARLOS I
description: The saxphonist David Murray, the bassist Richard Davis and the drummer Joe Chambers are performing tonight through Sunday at Carlos I, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., and there is a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: IRANIAN WHO MET McFARLANE IS TIED TO TAKEOVER OF U.S. EMBASSY
description: The Iranians who met with President Reagan's former national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, included a former leader of the students who stormed the United States Embassy in Teheran in 1979, a former Iranian President said today.

title: Jets' Loss Is Balm for Patriots
description: Like a lot of other people, Pat Sullivan watched the Dolphins take apart the Jets, 45-3, Monday night and marveled at how Dan Marino, Miami's sometimes amazing quarterback, threw for four touchdowns and nearly 300 yards.

title: BASIE BAND AT BLUE NOTE
description: The Count Basie Band, conducted by Frank Foster, is appearing tonight thrugh Monday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. and there is a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $20 cover and a $5 minumum at tables, or a $10 charge at the bar.

title: MUSKIE OPPOSES HASTE
description: The White House is pressing members of a newly appointed Presidential panel investigating the National Security Council to complete a report within 30 to 45 days, but a member of the panel said today that a thorough inquiry could not be concluded so quickly.

title: INSIDE
description: Brazil Cabinet in Turmoil

title: Fifth Salmonella Death Reported
description: A fifth nursing home resident died today in what health officials are calling one of the most deadly outbreaks of salmonella infection in state history.

title: NORTH DAKOTA HONORS 1989 WITH 16 BISON
description: Sixteen bison have been transported to 900 acres of a nature preserve in central North Dakota to help celebrate the state's 100th birthday, which will be marked in 1989.

title: Antiques Expo Begins Tomorrow on 3 Piers
description: Hundreds of dealers from across the country and Europe will offer thousands of items this weekend at the Manhattan Antiques and Collectibles Expo, on Piers 88, 90 and 92, at the Hudson River from 48th to 55th Streets. Each of the three piers will feature different types of items, from Art Deco at Pier 88, to Americana at Pier 90 and classical antiques at Pier 92.

title: Stake in Seabrook
description: Eastern Utilities Associates said its new EUA Power Corporation unit had completed the previously announced purchase of 12.2 percent of the Seabrook nuclear power project in Seabrook, N.H., for a total of $173.7 million. It said it had paid $133.2 million for the plant and $40.5 million for fuel and would raise $225 million in financing.

title: ADOBE BUILDING: ITS BACK-BREAKING BUT EASY
description: Some compare it to sex. Others call it good exercise. Most who have tried it say Bob Nieman's course in adobe building is lots of fun.

title: AT NELL'S CLUB, MANY CALL BUT FEW ARE CHOSEN
description: Nell's is the newest hot spot in Manhattan. Each night at 10, the street in front of the club's unmarked black door at 246 West 14th Street fills with the haughty and the hopeful, pleading for permission to pay $5 to enter its comfortable Victorian rooms.

title: Cracking Down, Catching Up: Carding Teen-Agers
description: For many New York City teenagers who want to drink in bars, and for bar owners willing to take their money, the state law setting the drinking age at 21 amounts to a small inconvenience. Even before New York raised the age from 19, countless teen-agers had taken to carrying fake I.D.'s.

title: JET IN FATAL CRASH CALLED OFF COURSE
description: Federal investigators say the Aeromexico jetliner that crashed Aug. 31 after it was struck by a small plane, killing 82 people, was off its assigned course by about three miles, according to a published report.

title: John Paul Meets Australian Students
description: Pope John Paul met with the fourth graders of St. Leo's Parish School today, and the children's questions elicited a remarkably informal view of the pontiff.

title: CONCERT: MAYR REQUIEM BY THE CLARION SOCIETY
description: THE Clarion Music Society is now in its 30th season, and during much of that time its concerts have featured performances of unfamiliar music. Newell Jenkins, the founder-director of the organization, has long taken an active interest in the works of composers who do not figure among the big names of music nowadays.

title: Collectors of Films Back a Champion
description: What do a Federal law enacted by Congress in 1912 and the 1948 market status of a certain hair tonic have to do with Mike Tyson, boxing's hottest property and the new World Boxing Council heavyweight champion?

title: Hotel Reported In Boesky Snag
description: The sale of the posh Beverly Hills Hotel has been delayed, apparently by concerns that it might be snagged in widening litigation over the Ivan F. Boesky scandal on Wall Street, according to a report in The Los Angeles Times.

title: The Front of the Bus
description: When I was very young, my family often drove from our home in Memphis down to my grandmother's place in Greenville, Miss. Mommaw lived in a two-story house on Main Street. Using her home as a base, I would venture out to the levee, to the five-and-dime store and to the Marion Parlor for ice cream.

title: BARTIONE IN CONCERT
description: The baritone Ben Holt, who recently appeared in the opera ''X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X,'' will be the soloist with a chamber-music group Sunday afternoon at 3:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: SERENE SIMPLICITY AND FLEETING MAGIC OF THE SMALL CIRCUS
description: THE world grows more complex. Circuses grow simpler.

title: Canada Rare Fish Poisoned
description: More than 400 tropical fish valued at $60,000, some rare and considered irreplaceable, were poisoned Wednesday at the Vancouver Public Aquarium, the officials said today. The curator, Gil Hewlett, said he suspected a copper sulphate compound had been dumped into the water supply. The affected tank contained about 15 percent of the Aquarium exhibits, and fewer than 2 percent survived.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think I share the mood of the entire country. My curiosity is as great as yours as to what's going to happen.''

title: State College Sued In Drinking Death
description: A Spring Valley, N.Y., couple is suing the state and the State University of New York for $10 million, accusing the College at New Paltz of negligence for not preventing the alcohol-related death of their son.

title: Rhonda M. Held, a Lawyer, Is Bride of David P. Dupler
description: Rhonda M. Held, the daughter of Justice Gerald S. Held of New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Held of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday to David P. Dupler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving S. Dupler of Oceanside. Rabbi Simon Resnikoff performed the ceremony at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: Night Moves
description: Xavier McDaniel of the Seattle SuperSonics, after a 6-of-15 game against the Los Angeles Lakers: ''I'm heading home and going straight to sleep. If I dream, I'll dream about shooting myself. I'll probably miss.''

title: Recipient of Artificial Heart Alert, Awaiting Donor Organ
description: A woman remained in critical condition today while waiting for a human heart to replace the artificial device she received Wednesday, a hospital official said.

title: IRAN MONEY REPORTED DIVERTED IN '85
description: The first diversion of money from United States arms sales to Iran took place in late 1985, months earlier than acknowledged by the Reagan Administration, according to people here and abroad familiar with the transactions.

title: Funding Education in the Year 2000
description: My grandson Michael will start college in the year 2000. And when he graduates, he'll face a situation completely unlike that faced by previous generations of college students: he could owe upward of $100,000. Michael and his parents had better get ready: a dispassionate look at today's political and educational landscape suggests that nobody - governments, the educational establishment, the private sector - is going to do much to help them pay the bill. Parents and children would be ill-advised to wait for a miracle cure; they should learn now how to save and borrow.

title: Come Clean, Hold Firm
description: Fears are spreading around the world that Washington is headed for another Watergate. That is not in anybody's best interest, not the U.S., not allies and friends, not even the Russians if they can understand it, though Tass is taking a ghoulish pleasure in telling some lied of its own these days such as denying any Moscow involvement in arms shipments to Iran.

title: KRIEG LEADS ROUT AGAINST COWBOYS
description: Dave Krieg led Seattle to scores on its first four possessions today, running for one touchdown and throwing for two more to send the Seahawks sweeping past the struggling Dallas Cowboys, 31-14.

title: One Is Killed, 2 Hurt In Taxicab Crash
description: A freelance cab driver trying to foil three robbers in his back seat sped through two red lights early yesterday and smashed into a car, killing its driver and injuring two passengers, the police said.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday Danza Mexicana Strains of a marimba band and the voices of a Mexican marketplace will set the tone this weekend as Isabel Benet and Nunuma Performance Art, a multimedia dance-theater troupe, offer two ballets inspired by Mexican mythology, folklore and daily life. The performances, tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M., will take place at the Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street. Tickets are $7; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: (212) 924-0077. Brooklyn Philharmonic

title: 1936 SECRET IS OUT: DOCTOR SPED GEORGE V'S DEATH
description: As he lay comatose on his deathbed in 1936, King George V was injected with fatal doses of morphine and cocaine to assure him a painless death in time, according to his physician's notes, for the announcement to be carried ''in the morning papers rather than the less appropriate evening journals.''

title: How Prices Do on Days That Adjoin a Holiday
description: WILL the Dow Jones industrial average move into record territory today? If the history of trading on the day after Thanksgiving is any guide, there is a good possibility. Thanks to a late spurt on Wednesday, the Dow advanced five points, to 1,916.76, less than three points short of its high-water mark of 1,919.71 set on Sept. 4.

title: Borg S.E.C. Filing
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell its 2.7 percent stake, or 817,021 common shares, of Service Corporation International, the nation's largest funeral service and cemetery company. Borg-Warner will receive as much as $33.38 a share, or a total of $27.3 million, from the offering, according to the S.E.C. filing. The filing, made Wednesday, gave no reason for the sale, which was announced one day after the Minneapolis-based investor Irwin L. Jacobs offered to buy Borg for between $43 and $48 a share.

title: ART: GUNTHER FORG AND RENHARD MUCHA IN SHOW
description: A GROUP show at Luhring, Augustine & Hodes (41 East 57th Street, through Dec. 20) introduces the work of two young West German artists, Gunther Forg and Reinhard Mucha, in the company of Bernd and Hilla Becher, the man-and-wife photographer team, also West German, who have exhibited in this country since the early 70's. It is a sparse but intriguing exhibition whose whole may exceed the sum of its parts; its effect certainly emanates as much from the interaction between the works on view as from the individual art objects themselves. In total, the show points to a new generation of post- or non-Neo-Expressionist artists currently emerging in Europe and, through the presence of the Bechers, indicates the continuity between these artists and the more conceptually oriented Europeans who preceded Neo-Expressionism.

title: 5 Players Banned After Movie Role
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has ordered a three-game suspension for each of the five college basketball players who were paid for their performances in the movie ''Hoosiers.''

title: SCREEN: 'PORKY PIG IN HOLLYWOOD
description: PORKY PIG isn't commonly thought of as a man of many faces, or a performer with a widely varied acting style. But ''Porky Pig in Hollywood,'' a collection of cartoons opening today at the Film Forum 2, does what it can to remedy that impression. It presents the boyish Porky, the romantic Porky, even the daydreaming Porky whose reveries have a startlingly experimental side. Surely there's a Porky here for everyone.

title: State Audit Discloses Errors on Medicaid
description: The state Social Services Department made about $2.2 million in Medicaid overpayments to health-care providers in the six months ending March 31, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: Japan Output Index Off
description: Japan's industrial production index for October fell 1.9 percent (a preliminary figure) from the month before, to a seasonally adjusted 120.8, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said Wednesday.

title: At Least 10 Reported Killed In Iraqi Air Attacks on Iran
description: Iraq said today that its warplanes had attacked an Iranian oil terminal, a tanker in the Persian Gulf and military bases in western Iran.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: David and David/Peter Case, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880 or 228-6300). Slowly but surely, the story-song is making a comeback, challenging the eternal present tense of most pop lyrics with character studies, elliptical tales and full-fledged narratives. Los Angeles will show its literary - or is it cinematic? - side in tonight's double bill at the Bottom Line. David and David (whose last names are Baerwald, the lyricist-singer, and Ricketts, the composer-guitarist-keyboardist) write about the casualties of Tinseltown glamour in songs like their current hit, ''Boomtown.'' Like a latter-day Steely Dan, they wrap terse, catchy pop tunes around intelligently cynical lyrics. Peter Case, who used to lead a pop-rock band called the Plimsouls, now reaches back to the plainspoken folk style of Woody Guthrie for tales of hard times and desperate characters. Tonight at 8:30 and 11:30; tickets are $10.

title: Kettles Being Recalled
description: Imported copper tea kettles are being recalled by the wholesaler because their lead content could be dangerous to infants if the formula is heated in the kettle water, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday. It said the Frederick Wholesale Corporation of New York City was recalling approximately 4,000 nickel-lined kettles from South Korea in 21 states.

title: PIANO: WORKS BY DEBUSSY
description: THE pianist George Pludermacher chose an unusually challenging program for his Tuesday evening debut recital at the 92d Street Y - Debussy's set of 12 Etudes and Liszt's piano transcription of Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 in E flat (''Eroica'').

title: Beech-Nut Recalls Cereal
description: The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation is voluntarly recalling 6,051 cases of Stage-Two Mixed Cereal for infants because it may contain paint chips, the Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday.

title: NEW YORK AGENDA
description: Free Orthopedic Examinations Physicians from the Philadelphia branch of the Shriners Hospital for Crippled Children will be giving free orthopedic examinations to children up to 18 years of age. Riverside Child Health Station, 160 West 100th Street, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. Free Holiday Buses

title: Aggies in Cotton Bowl
description: Texas A&M rolled to a 16-3 victory over Texas tonight, securing the Aggies' second straight Southwest Conference championship and a berth in the Cotton Bowl.

title: Dining Out Guide; Old Standbys
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. LA COTE BASQUE, #5 East 55th Street (688-6525) - ***(Aug. 22, 1986) Old World charm and glamour are the hallmarks of this classic East Side French restaurant. The wraparound dining room glows with murals of coastal France, red leather banquettes, splendid flower clusters and a well-turned-out crowd. You might start with a puff pastry of buttery bay scallops in a rich fish-stock-and-cream sauce with Sauterne, or fresh foie gras seared and set among shiitake mushrooms and veal-stock sauce. Entrees include roast duck with pepper sauce; sweetbreads in a veal-stock sauce tinged with Madeira, or grilled seafood - sole, salmon or red snapper. The pastry cart offers vanilla bavarois with raspberry sauce, hazelnut dacquoise and chocolate mousse. Prix-fixe dinner, $48. Fridays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays, noon to 2:30 and 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. THE FOUR SEASONS, #99 East 52d Street (754-9494) - ***(Nov. 22, 1985) The palatial scale of this New York institution affords the luxury of privacy at well-spaced tables - the rosewood- paneled Grill Room is masculine and trim, and the glittering Pool Room is plush and romantic. The menu in the Grill Room is lean and spirited with starters of shrimp won tons in sharkfin broth and capon terrine.

title: Par for Mrs. Reagan
description: The Nancy Reagan Drug Abuse Fund is getting an unusual and potentially large contribution at the end of the year.

title: Report Seeks to Clear Sainthood Candidate
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Monterey has stepped up a campaign to have Father Junipero Serra canonized as a saint with a response to critics who say the founder of California's missions enslaved and whipped Indians.

title: Congress Should Extend Aid for Poor Families
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 28, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Store Chain Accused On Gasoline Content
description: The United States Environmental Protection Agency has charged Cumberland Farms Inc. with selling gasoline containing alcohol beyond the legal limit and has proposed that the chain of convenience stores pay a $520,000 administrative fine.

title: 'Conspiracy' by Supporters Of LaRouche Is Seen in West
description: A state investigation has found a ''complex organizational conspiracy'' in which political supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. were said to have acted illegally to place a referendum question on the Nov. 4 ballot.

title: MAN SLAIN IN HIT-RUN DISPUTE
description: A 23-year-old Long Island man was stabbed to death early yesterday in a fight that began with a hit-and-run car accident at a Suffolk County shopping center, the police said. A 19-year-old man was arrested in the killing, they said.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE route to Broadway is often long and circuitous for an out-of-town show. This one started in Stratford, Ontario, had a number of pit stops in various Canadian cities, went to London, is now in Toronto and will alight in Boston and Baltimore before setting down at City Center on Jan. 13.

title: FIVE, LIVES SPARED, HAIL ANAYA'S MOVE
description: New Mexico's five death row inmates have praised Gov. Toney Anaya as courageous and compassionate in commuting their death sentences, but the brother of a murder victim called the move ridiculous and shocking.

title: THRIFT UNITS POST SOLID PROFITS
description: In sharp contrast to the mediocre earnings being reported by the nation's biggest banks, profits at the largest savings-and-loan associations are booming.

title: EARLY SYMPHONY
description: John Knowles Paine's Symphony No. 2 in A (''Spring'') is said to be the first American orchestral work ever published.

title: CURBS ON ENDING LIFE SUPPORT ARE IGNORED
description: Court-ordered guidelines for deciding when to terminate aggressive medical treatment for terminally ill nursing-home patients are being widely ignored, according to state officials and medical experts.

title: PROFESSOR AND HIS PAST STUN NEBRASKA CAMPUS
description: To his colleagues at the University of Nebraska, Paul Stewart was a model professor. He was concerned about his students, courteous around the office and enthusiastic about his field of study: criminal justice.

title: EXPERTS WORKING TO REVIVE SOUTHERN EAGLES
description: A small network of ornithologists is quietly working to restore Southern bald eagles to domains that the birds had been forced to abdicate.

title: 2 Men Are Sentenced In Irish Weapons Deal
description: Two men convicted in a plot to smuggle 100 rifles and thousands of rounds of ammunition to the Irish Republican Army were sentenced today.

title: We Send Pinochet a Wrong Signal
description: Last week, the United States abstained in an important vote at the World Bank, effectively giving the bank a green light to proceed with a $250 million loan to Chile. With this, the Administration sent an unmistakable signal to Gen. Augusto Pinochet: in essence, we winked at his systematic abuse of human rights. Fortunately, Washington still has a chance to reverse itself - by voting against other pending multilateral loans and by supporting a resolution on Chile scheduled to come before the United Nations General Assembly today.

title: Former Tiger Arrested
description: Barbaro Garbey, a Cuban refugee who helped the Detroit Tigers win the 1984 World Series, has been arrested in Miami for possession of cocaine, the police said.

title: STATE AIDES SEEKING TO DROP A WATER CHLORINATION PLAN
description: State environmental officials are recommending that an upstate sewage treatment plant that empties directly into the New York City reservoir system be allowed to discontinue chlorination.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: PRELUDE TO CBS: TISCH AT CNA
description: A few days after Laurence A. Tisch won a bitterly contested takeover battle for the CNA Financial Corporation in 1974, he toured the company's new headquarters and came upon the chairman's stately suite with its marble staircase spiraling up to a private dining room.

title: A HAPPY DAY OF HEROES AND FEASTS
description: Something horrible happened to Superman yesterday.

title: GORBACHEV CALLS FOR 'STAR PEACE'
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, bringing his campaign against President Reagan's space-based missile defense program to India, said Thursday that ''what we need is Star Peace and not Star Wars.''

title: 3 SYRIAN ENVOYS EXPELLED BY BONN OVER BOMBING TIES
description: West Germany today ordered the expulsion of three Syrian diplomats and downgraded its relations with the Government of President Hafez al-Assad.

title: I.B.M. Buybacks
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's biggest computer company, has announced that it would buy back about five million shares of common stock and a series of debentures, in transactions valued at $1.1 billion. I.B.M.'s shares closed Wednesday at $126 on the New York Stock Exchange. I.B.M. said it would redeem all $500 million of its 10 1/2 percent debentures due July 15, 2015, at $1,093.60 per $1,000. The redemption is set for Dec. 29.

title: Threatening the Balance in Iran
description: For six years, the United States has seemed to pursue a steadfast policy in Mesopotamia, one intended to prevent an Iraqi collapse, to discourage other countries from providing arms to Iran and to press for a negotiated settlement of their war. All those goals have been imperiled by the American arms now known to have been shipped to Iran.

title: Bus Drivers End Strike But Warn of New One
description: City bus drivers returned to work today, restoring service after a three-day strike by 630 drivers and mechanics that was declared illegal by a state board.

title: Borden Buys Gioia For $72 Million
description: Borden Inc., which already sells pasta in 44 states and five regional markets, has purchased a 76-year-old Buffalo pasta maker from its British owner for $72 million, company officials said. The Gioia Pasta Company, founded in Fredonia, N.Y., in 1910, was sold to Borden by Ranks Hovis McDougall Ltd., officials said.

title: Takeovers Yes, Hold-Ups No
description: Corporate raiders: are they just the spiritual cousins of inside traders like Ivan Boesky, fast-buck artists who hobble capital formation and farsighted enterprise? Or are they the voice of free markets, scaring managers into paying more attention to the efficiency of their businesses and less to the size of their limos?

title: PAYING DOWNSCALE PRICES FOR UPSCALE EXTRAVAGANZAS
description: HOW little can you spend on a seat at the Metropolitan Opera? How about $5? There's a catch, however. You can't see a thing. The seat is at the Score Desk, an area in the nether reaches of the Met, set aside for music students who follow along with the score of that night's performance.

title: Who Said What and When
description: In the weeks since the disclosure of shipments of United States arms to Iran, a handful of top officials have tried to put the crisis to rest through public statements. Here are some of the statements in the unfolding of a crisis for the Administration. President Reagan / Nov. 13

title: SUBURBS RESISTING HOUSING FOR POOR
description: On Long Island and in many other New York suburbs, the battle to provide housing that poor and moderate-income families can afford is being lost, experts say.

title: PINE BELT A SURPRISE WINNER AT AQUEDUCT
description: Pine Belt, left to run on his own when a more highly regarded stablemate was knocked out with a morning cough, held off Scrimshaw by a neck to win the $92,100 Queens County Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: ART: SARDNIC HUMOR OF MAGRITTE ON DISPLAY
description: IT is 10 years, more or less, since Rene Magritte had a show of any size in New York, and there may well be a whole new generation of gallerygoers to whom his range, his ambition and his sardonic and unmistakably Belgian humor will come as a surprise.

title: BUTTERFLY SPECIES RETURN TO FLORIDA
description: Three species of Florida butterflies that were near extinction are on the rebound, including one that was pronounced extinct in the 1960's.

title: AUCTIONS
description: FOR more than a century, the nine drawings from ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' that will be auctioned at Christie's in London next Wednesday were thought to be works by John Tenniel.

title: POLICE SEARCH AN APARTMENT HOUSE FOR DAVIS
description: A heavily armed police task force last night evacuated and searched a South Bronx building where a brother of Larry Davis, the fugitive wanted in the shooting of six police officers, lives in a basement apartment, the police said.

title: G.M. Plan Set In South Africa
description: General Motors South Africa said an agreement in principle had been reached with its parent, the General Motors Corporation, on the previously announced local management buyout plan, effective Jan. 1.

title: Gen. Hugh Stockwell; Led British Into Egypt
description: Gen. Sir Hugh Stockwell, commander of British land forces in the 1956 British-French invasion of the Suez Canal Zone, died today. He was 83.

title: Irradiation Could Mean the End of Fresh Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: MANILA FORMALLY ACCEPTS ACCORD FOR 60-DAY TRUCE WITH INSURGENTS
description: The Philippine Government today formally accepted a 60-day cease-fire pact with a 23,000-strong Communist army that gives the military the right to respond to certain ''hostile acts.''

title: FRENCH STUDENTS FIGHT CHANGES WITH HUGE PROTEST
description: Tens of thousands of university and high school students marched through the heart of the capital and in 50 other French cities today to protest a Government plan to change the system of higher education.

title: Perth's Party
description: It was billed as the first America's Cup party held outside the United States in 137 years. That may sound like a milestone of no little grandeur, but the Royal Perth Yacht Club certainly proved equal to it Tuesday night, when more than 3,000 yachting officials, crewmen and hangers-on took in a cocktail soiree at the club's Crawley Bay grounds.

title: Ms. Loss Is Wed To Clark Johnson
description: Margaret Ruth Loss, a vice president and counsel for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, was married in New York yesterday to Harry Clark Johnson, a vice president of Citibank in New York. Judge Milton Pollack of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: COCAINE IS FOUND ON AVIANCA PLANE
description: The manifest on four boxes that arrived here Thursday night by air from Bogota, Colombia, said roses and carnations. But the United States Customs inspectors discovered that the boxes were filled instead with a total of 294 pounds of pure cocaine.

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results include a shoe retailing division disposed of in December 1985.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: The latest quarter and 9 months include a pre-tax charge of $33,000 related to the retroactive repeal of investment tax credits. The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid last month.

title: Seeking the Killer Quake's Architects
description: When Mexico City was hit by a devastating earthquake in September 1985, Raul Perez Pereyra was in a car a few blocks from his apartment building, taking his youngest son to school.

title: BOOKS FROM SERIES HELP PUBLIC TV
description: Critics often cite television as a prime reason that Americans don't read more, but public television has given rise to a highly competitive book publishing business - one complete with auctions, big advances, literary agents and authors tours.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
Computerland Founder Backed
description: A jury has decided that William H. Millard, founder of the Computerland Corporation, did not defraud two engineers when he sold them stock in a company that later went bankrupt. Joseph Killian and Bruce Van Natta charged that money used by Mr. Millard to start his computer franchise chain came from IMS Associates Inc., in which they had been promised stock options.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''This is a disgrace. Every document in the files of anyone who had anything to do with this should have been under lock and key from the moment it was decided there was a problem.''

title: ASTROTECH INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $11,251,000 associated with curtailment of space operations, re-evaluation of intangible assets applicable to certain operations, provisions for severance pay and other costs in restructuring its superalloy activities for the quarter, and an extraordinary charge of $14,667,000 for the year. c-Net income

title: SOUTH BOSTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes $1,675,000, or 35 cents a share, from special dividend by Deposit Insurance Fund of Mass. c-Includes $1,459,000, or 30 cents a share, from special dividend by Deposit Insurance Fund of Mass.

title: 2 Convicted in Police Killings
description: A Common Pleas Court jury that convicted Pedro Vega of murdering a policeman decided today that he should be sentenced to life imprisonment.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $446,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: Goring Donning Skates
description: Butch Goring, dismissed as the Boston Bruins' coach earlier this month, has signed a 25-game tryout contract as a player with the Edmonton Oilers. Goring said he would report to the Oilers' American Hockey League farm club in Nova Scotia to play himself into condition.

title: BACK TO BASICS AT QUAKER OATS
description: During the last 15 years, the Quaker Oats Company has struggled to diversify, trying everything from clothes and hardware to fast-food restaurants and video games. But with one notable exception - its Fisher-Price toy line - Quaker has kept coming back to the same conclusion: Its traditional name-brand packaged foods base is the company's only sure-fire source of growth.

title: SmithKline Stock Climbs After Offer
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation has said it would buy back up to 15 million of its 76 million common shares outstanding in an offer that could cost up to $1.44 billion.

title: Purdue Job for Meyer?
description: Ron Meyer, a former Purdue player and assistant coach who also coached the New England Patriots, is expected to be named coach of the Boilermakers, according to a report in The Indianapolis Star, which said an official announcement could be made Monday or Tuesday. Meyer would succeed Leon Burtnett, who has resigned after five years at Purdue.

title: Traditional Event Is Missing As the Fall Nationals Begin
description: The Fall National Championships, which began here this afternoon, represent a break with tradition. For 55 years the tournament has begun with the national mixed pairs, but that event has been moved to the Spring Nationals and it was the life master men's and women's pair championships that were the focus of attention today.

title: AQUINO DISMISSES 2 MORE FROM CABINET
description: President Corazon C. Aquino dismissed two more Cabinet ministers today, and the former Defense Minister, Juan Ponce Enrile, formally left his post, saying he did so without rancor or recriminations.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: Exxon Rejects Bids For Its Building
description: The Exxon Corporation has rejected as too low all of the bids that the company had received to buy its 54-story headquarters building on Avenue of the Americas between 49th and 50th Streets. But the company said yesterday that negotiations were continuing with some of the bidders.

title: Tulsa to Wisconsin
description: Don Morton, the Tulsa coach the last two years, was named football coach at Wisconsin yesterday, succeeding Jim Hilles, who served as interim coach this season after Dave McClain died of a heart attack last April. Morton, who had a 13-9 record the last two years at Tulsa, said he planned to bring seven assistants to the Big Ten school, whose Badgers had a 3-9 mark this season.

title: SEAHAWK OIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: FRIENDS RALLY AT COURT IN SUPPORT OF SUSPECT
description: About 25 neighbors of a Washington Heights man accused of killing a fellow resident in his building appeared in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday, saying they were there to offer him moral support and to try to win his release from jail.

title: JAZZ: AT THE BLUE NOTE, BASIE AND BYARD BANDS
description: The Count Basie Orchestra, playing its first full-week engagement in Manhattan since Frank Foster became its conductor in June, came into the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, on Tuesday evening under challenging circumstances. In an unusual booking as part of the Blue Note's current Big Band Festival, it shared the bandstand from Tuesday through Thursday with another Big Band, Jaki Byard's Apollo Stompers.

title: JAPANESE TRADE SURPLUS NARROWER
description: After many months of frustration in which the huge United States trade deficit continued to mount in the face of a falling dollar, recent figures seem to indicate to many that the long-awaited reversal has begun.

title: WEBSTER UNDER CLOSE WATCH
description: Tom Webster watched George McPhee settle into a chair today before he said anything. ''You're coming, right? ''

title: When an 'In Stock' Item Isn't
description: LOOKING at the video cameras advertised in last Wednesday's newspaper, a woman saw that Brothers Cameras, Electronics and Video was having a half-price sale. The Sony Auto Focus video camera that she wanted was offered for $895, half off its regular $1,790 price, and the advertisement said it was ''Guaranteed in stock.''

title: GIANTS HOPE DEFENSE BENDS, NOT BREAKS
description: In the last five weeks, the Giants' pass defense has been less than magnificent. In that stretch, it has allowed 325 yards to the Denver Broncos, 244 to the Minnesota Vikings, 159 to the Philadelphia Eagles, 306 to the Dallas Cowboys and 378 to the Washington Redskins.

title: Fishing Club Winner In Suit Over Pollution
description: Members of a fishing club have been awarded more than $4 million by a jury that found the club's lake had been ruined by waste from an adjacent egg farm.

title: PILOT FLYING ARMS TO CONTRAS HAD ACCOUNT AT A SWISS BANK
description: The co-pilot of a plane shot down last month while carrying arms to Nicaraguan rebels had a Swiss bank account. But the bank said today that the account had nothing to do with recent Iran arms shipments.

title: GINKGO FANS SEE DELICACY IN PUTRID TREE
description: An elderly Asian man was on his hands and knees in Central Park a few days ago, sifting through the slippery golden leaves beneath a ginkgo tree.

title: GREAT SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4.6 million from the sale of assets of a subsidiary for the quarter and the year includes a gain of about $3.7 million from the sale of mortgage loans. c-Net loss

title: JAZZ: WYNTON MARSALIS
description: The trumpeter Wynton Marsalis insists on understatement. In the quintet he's leading through Sunday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, every phrase is neatly tucked in, every arrangement carefully planned, every note burnished.

title: AND FOR ADULTS, TWO POPULAR GAMES
description: ''You buy a scarf from a discount store as a gift for a friend who is very label-conscious. You have an empty box from a trendy store.

title: Tarmac's Stake In Lone Star Units
description: Tarmac P.L.C. of Britain said it had agreed to buy a 60 percent stake in the Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina operations of Lone Star Industries, a major American cement producer. Tarmac, a construction and industrial holding company, said it had also bought an option to acquire the remaining 40 percent of the assets.

title: BRITISH SEE TRADE THREAT
description: Huge Japanese trade surpluses and record American defictis seriously threaten the world's free trade system, Britain's top trade official said today.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: A New York City Councilman has called for an investigation into security problems at homeless shelters and welfare hotels, saying assaults are common and drugs are sold openly.

title: What India's Gurkhas Might Hope to Win
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICO ACTS TO SPUR ECONOMY BUT CURB INFLATION
description: The Mexican Government is embarking on a delicate balancing act as it begins to use $12 billion in new foreign loans to restart the stalled economy while trying to curb inflation and high interest rates.

title: CHICAGO INDICTMENTS MAY FORESHADOW MORE CORRUPTION CASES
description: If a scale of per capita municipal corruption was ever invented, Chicago might rank no higher than many other American cities.

title: MUSIC: THOMAS MURRAY IN MENDELSSOHN RECITAL
description: Among the musical treasures spirited eastward at the end of World War II were some green books of organ music by Felix Mendelssohn that migrated from Berlin to Cracow. Some of the music had never been published, and an American scholar, William A. Little, went to Poland to study the texts and prepare an edition. Monday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Thomas Murray played a rewarding recital drawn mostly from these volumes.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: TV: 'ONE POLICE PLAZA,' STARRING ROBERT CONRAD
description: CBS Entertainment Productions is preoccupied with police plots these days, possibly as fodder for future series. Last Tuesday, the network offered a television movie called ''That Secret Sunday'' in which the key policemen were killers tracked down by investigative journalists. Tonight at 9, ''One Police Plaza'' offers still another batch of menacing men in blue, but this time the heroes are other policemen. They are all supposed to be members of the New York City Police Department, but the film was made entirely in Montreal.

title: Maybe Just Desserts
description: On ''Nightline'' Ted Koppel interviewed Lyn Nofziger and John Ehrlichman about what Presidents should do when things go wrong, but it was late and I forget what they said.

title: POND'S SAID TO SEEK HIGHER BID
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., which received a $2.8 billion acquisition offer from American Brands Inc. earlier this week, has been approached by other potential suitors, according to Wall Street sources.

title: BEETLE INFESTATION A BITTER ENVIRONMENTAL HARVEST
description: When thousands of acres of forestland was imperiled three years ago by an infestation of Southern pine beetles, it touched off a bitter battle between environmentalists and the United States Forest Service over the proper way to protect forests throughout the South.

title:
PATENTS;
Drug Compounds Treat Memory Deficiencies
description: Pharmaceutical compounds to enhance memory or correct memory deficiencies in animals and humans were patented this week for the A.H. Robins Company, Richmond.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split distributed May 26, 1986.

title: AFTER TAKING TOLL LAVA REACHES SEA
description: A black-crusted river of fiery lava from Kilauea Volcano sizzled into the sea today, but, contrary to Hawaiian legend, the eruption that began in 1983 showed no signs of ending, scientists said.

title: SHAMIR SAYS U.S. HAS NOT ASKED TO QUESTION ISRAELIS ON IRAN DEALS
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the United States had not asked the Israeli Government for permission to question Israelis in connection with the Iran affair. But he said that if such an approach was made, Israel would consider it.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Books: An Old Mystery
description: A MISSING PLANE. By Susan Sheehan. Illustrated. 201 pages. G. P. Putnam's

title: STATE DEPARTMENT TO BEGIN AIDS TESTING
description: Foreign Service applicants, officers and their dependents will be tested for the AIDS virus under a screening program expected to begin Jan. 1, State Department officials said today.

title: AT NEW AIDS TEST CENTER, LIVES ARE CHANGED
description: Mildred Johnson pulled a folder from the file drawer, arranged her face in a neutral but kindly configuration and led a young man into her office to deliver some terrifying news.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: A helicopter with a student pilot at the controls tipped over on the ground yesterday, rupturing a gas tank, setting the aircraft on fire and burning the student and the owner of the aircraft.

title: Saving Records Ordered
description: Officials at the White House and the National Security Council were ordered today to preserve all records about the diversion of profits from Iran arms sales to rebels in Nicaragua.

title: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and 9 months' losses resulted from a writeoff of the company's investment in its European construction products operations, and non-recurring charges associated with its industrial air pollution control division and coal water slurry research plant operations.

title: WALKER ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes charges of $14,123,000 and $4,268,000 from the writedown of oil and gas assets for the latest and year-ago 9 months, respectively. Results for 1985 reflect restatement of results of the 185 entities from which Walker Energy Partners was formed in November 1985.

title: MERRIMAC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
Jean Labatut Is Dead; Taught at Princeton
description: Jean Labatut, professor emertius of architecture at Princeton University, died Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J., after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Engine Fails on Delta Jet
description: A Delta Air Lines jetliner carrying 186 people made an emergency landing today in Amarillo after developing problems in an engine, officials said. Flight 796, from San Francisco to Dallas-Fort Worth made a ''normal, routine landing,'' a spokesman in Atlanta said. No one was reported hurt.

title: Drug Program Will Aid Pilots
description: The union representing most airline pilots announced Wednesday that it was undertaking a new program to help pilots with drug problems.

title: U.S. EMPLOYED A 'STING' SETUP FOR ARMS TO IRAN
description: The United States Government set up a major ''sting'' operation late last year, complete with a fraudulent bank account, to catch arms merchants dealing with Iran, according to court documents, bankers and officials involved in the case.

title: USACAFES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
REAGAN DRUG TESTING PLAN TO START DESPITE COURT RULINGS OPPOSING IT
description: The Administration is going ahead with its program of drug testing of Federal employees despite recent court decisions that such widespread random tests are unconstitutional and despite reservations among some top advisers to the White House.

title: 12 Hours of Schubert At Symphony Space
description: A free 12-hour presentation of music by Franz Schubert, featuring noted musicians, will begin Jan. 31 at 11 A.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: Investigators are trying to determine if jewelry and money were stolen from Jennifer Dawn Levin the night she was strangled in Central Park, according to United Press International. A prep school graduate, Robert E. Chambers Jr., has been charged in her murder.

title: IRAN, AFGHANISTAN AND CHILE CITED AT THE U.N. AS VIOLATORS OF RIGHTS
description: Members of the General Assembly adopted resolutions today expressing deep concern over violations of human rights in Iran and Chile, and over atrocities against civilians by Government and Soviet forces in Afghanistan.

title: West Europeans Fear Crisis Cripples Washington's Foreign Policy Ability
description: Governments in Western Europe and elsewhere are contemplating the possibility that the Washington crisis over arms sales to Iran may have crippled the Reagan Administration's ability to conduct foreign policy.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MEETING THE TWAIN

title:
PATENTS;
Method for Scanning And Reproducing Data
description: Iosif Baumberg, a refugee from the Soviet Union who lives in Brooklyn, has invented a method of scanning and reproducing information that is expected to benefit television. In the Soviet Union he was a scientist working with electronics and computers.

title: FOR THIS BITTER ITALIAN GREEN QUICK COOKING IS BEST
description: ''Is that spinach?'' asked one of the diners, pointing to a dish of cooked greens in the middle of our table.

title: Painting the Town
description: In 1944, as a 12-year-old schoolboy, Frank Wright bought two sheets of watercolor paper and took a trolley from his home in northeast Washington to Georgetown to paint George Washington's Headquarters (known today as ''the Old Stone House''). He had decided to try his luck as an artist and enter The Evening Star's annual calendar contest, for which 12 winners received $25 apiece.

title: Dow Dips 2.53 Points In Slow-Paced Session
description: Stock prices closed narrowly mixed yesterday on Wall Street, where volume sagged badly as many traders stretched out their holiday by taking off the day after Thanksgiving.

title: Israel Nuclear Technician Charged With Spying
description: An Israeli nuclear technician who is said to have disclosed Israeli nuclear secrets to a British newspaper was charged today with aiding an enemy during war and aggravated espionage, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Harris Trio Performs
description: The pianist Barry Harris will lead his trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Between 7 and 11 P.M. tomorrow Mr. Harris will perform solos. Admission is $8, or $5 for students and the elderly.

title: 2 Craft Festivals Set
description: Craft mavens can shop uptown and downtown this weekend at two festivals sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance.

title: Nancy Siracusa, Educator, Wed to James Sammartino
description: At St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Roselle Park, N.J., yesterday Nancy Siracusa, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter Siracusa of Elizabeth, N.J., was married to James C. Sammartino, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Sammartino of Elizabeth.

title: 166 Stations To Be Sold
description: The sales of 166 radio and TV stations were approved today by the Federal Communications Commission - just in time for sellers to qualify for favorable year-end tax treatment of their profits. It is the largest number of transfers ever approved on any one day, according to an F.C.C. spokesman, Maureen Peratino.

title: 4 Killed in Carolina Crash
description: A Navy van carrying marines and sailors back to their base after a Thanksgiving outing overturned on an interstate highway today, killing four people and injuring seven others.

title: Letter: On Health; Complacency About AIDS Is Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: At Last, a Westway Truce
description: In a praiseworthy compromise, a New York state and city commission has produced a tentative substitute plan for Westway, the defeated offshore replacement for Manhattan's collapsed West Side Highway. Give credit to Chairman Arthur Levitt and colleagues for achieving a constructive truce between pro- and anti-Westway partisans.

title: PROTESTS ENGULF BRAZIL PRESIDENT
description: Two weeks after leading Brazil's centrist governing party to a stunning victory in midterm elections, President Jose Sarney has suddenly become the target of bitter recriminations over his decision to start lifting a nine-month-old price freeze.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: MUSEUM OPENING IN PARIS
description: The Orsay Museum, which is being billed here as the most significant addition to the cultural life of France in nearly a decade, will be formally inaugurated by President Francois Mitterrand next week and is scheduled to open to the public on Dec. 8.

title: BALLET: DEBUTS IN 2 WORKS
description: Debuts in two major works occurred during the New York City Ballet's performance Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. When the dancers gathered in Jerome Robbins's ''Dances at a Gathering,'' there was a newcomer among them. Valentina Kozlova made her first appearance in one of the most unusual roles in this ballet to Chopin piano music.

title: SYSTEMS & COMPUTER TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $2 million reserve for losses on major custom software project, a $300,000 provision for other software contract losses, a $400,000 charge for severance and related expenses for a September reduction in personnel and a $200,000 charge pertaining to class-action litigation and related lawsuits. c-After a pre-tax charge of $15,483,000 from the settlement of class-action litigation and related costs. d-Net income

title: EDGE OF CHAOS: CAMELS AMID THE ROCKETTES
description: Pandemonium paid a visit backstage yesterday at Radio City Music Hall. George, a camel, stepped on the foot of a Rockettte; six sheep came off the elevator as three kings bearing gifts got on; human Christmas trees bumped into eight maids-a-milking at the water cooler, and an elf came down with the flu.

title: The Soviet Phase-Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Let's Stop Excluding Different Viewpoints
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASKETBALL KNICKS VS. CLEVELAND CAVALIERS, at Madison Square Garden, 1 P.M. (Television - MSG, 12:30 P.M. and 8:30 P.M.; Radio - WNBC 660, 12:50 P.M.). NETS VS. ROCKETS, at Houston, 8:30 P.M. (Radio - WNEW 1130, tape delay after Seton Hall-Columbia game).

title: Change in Participants At Richard Tucker Gala
description: There have been several changes in the roster of participants for the Richard Tucker gala tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall, according to a spokesman for the event.

title: Central African Vote Results
description: The voters have endorsed a new one-party Constitution under which Andre Kolingba will remain head of state for the next six years, it was officially announced here today. The Supreme Court President, Antoine Grothe, said 91 percent of the 763,451 voters backed the new charter in a referendum held a week ago.

title: NORTHEASTERN SUTNS LOUISVILLE
description: Reggie Lewis scored 4 of his 32 points in overtime tonight as unheralded Northeastern upset Louisville, the defending national champion, by 88-84 in the opening round of the ninth annual Great Alaska Shootout.

title: Teen-Ager Is Arrested In Poison 'Liquor' Case
description: A 19-year-old man was arrested today on charges he took car fuel to a party and passed it around as moonshine, poisoning eight people, including one who died, the authorities said.

title: Labeque Recital Postponed
description: The recital by the duo-pianists Katia and Marielle Labeque, scheduled for tomorrow at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College in the Bronx, has been rescheduled for April 10 at 7 P.M. Information: 960-8232.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $4,600 and $31,317 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a gain of $166,950 on extinguishment of debt and a tax benefit of $105,800.

title: U.N.L.V. BEATS BUZZER, TEMPLE
description: Since the 3-point basket at a distance of 19 feet 9 inches and beyond became part of college basketball this season, critics have complained the distance is too short.

title: Paris to Review Bill That Stirred Protests
description: The French Government agreed today to review an education bill that brought hundreds of thousands of students into the streets in the biggest youth protest since 1968.

title: Pilots' Accord At Flying Tiger
description: Flying Tiger Line pilots say they hope their agreement to give up a fourth of their salaries and $18.4 million in pension and other benefits will keep the world's biggest air cargo carrier from changing hands.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,092,702. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $297,745 for the quarter and $364,162 for the 9 months.

title: Cintra H. Huber Becomes the Bride Of L.P. McGauley
description: Cintra Hutchinson Huber, a vice president of the American Horse Shows Association, the national equestrian federation of the United States, was married yesterday to Lawrence P. McGauley, the president and chief executive officer of Douglas Elliman-Gibbons & Ives Inc., a real estate company in New York. The Rev. Kenneth Moore, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Stuart Kenworthy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: SAMUEL FISHMAN
description: Samuel Fishman, a Michigan labor leader long influential in Democratic politics in that state, died Thursday in emergency heart bypass surgery at Washington Hospital Center.

title: DYATRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $98,000 and $162,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $163,000 for the quarter and $393,000 for the 9 months.

title: METRO DATELINES
description: A man broke into his ex-wife's Manhattan apartment and held their 9-month-old son hostage in the bathroom before slashing the baby's neck and his own yesterday, the police said.

title: Battles Rage in Beirut; Syria Reports Cease-Fire
description: Heavy fighting continued today between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen in Beirut and in southern Lebanon despite an announcement in Syria that a cease-fire had taken effect.

title: Hockey Player Burned
description: Mark Reeds, a right wing for the St. Louis Blues, has discovered, so is popcorn.

title: Leucadia's Stake
description: The Leucadia National Corporation disclosed that it had acquired a 39 percent stake in Phlcorp Inc. and that it intended to seek control of the company.

title: Hubie at the Edge
GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1986
description: Companies

title: 3 IN FAMILY SLAIN BY MAN IN BROOKLYN
description: Three members of a Brooklyn family were killed and a fourth was wounded early yesterday morning by a gunman who fired a dozen or more shots and then sped away in a black car, the police said.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL PETE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the results for the year-ago fourth quarter and year have been restated to reflect a 1-for-10 reverse stock split and for certain reclassifications.
