title: You Don't Have to Sink Ships to Save Whales
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE BLOCK PROTEST IN SOUTH KOREA
description: Tens of thousands of riot policemen fired tear-gas canisters and pushed back crowds this afternoon to block a large rally that had become a major test of wills between the Government and the opposition.

title: ALLIED STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Net income and the 9-month includes a gain on the sale of a leasehold interest in a shopping center, which was partially offset by a one- time charge for the consolidation of operating divisions and store closings. On a net basis, these non-recurring items increased earnings in the 9-month by 41 cents a share. The company said the latest third quarter loss is after pre-tax expenses in connection with tender offers of $187 million, of which the net effect of these expenses was $113,050,000, and a tax credit of $47,750,000. The company said the latest 9-month loss is after the third quarter pre-tax expenses in connection with tender offers of $187 million, which the net effect of these expenses was $113,050,000. The loss also is after a tax credit of $12,775,000.

title: OFFICIALS INSPECT NURSING HOME
description: Health Commissioner S. Douglas Lloyd led a team of state investigators today into the Windsor nursing home where an outbreak of salmonella bacteria poisoning has been linked to the deaths of five elderly patients and the illnesses of 20 others.

title: Vote of No Confidence
description: Robert Irsay, owner of the 0-12 Indianapolis Colts, said he was not happy with Coach Rod Dowhower, who is in the second year of a three-year contract with a two-year option. Irsay made his comments in an interview in The Indianapolis News.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day on Wednesday misquoted the interest rate on a $150 million issue of seven-year notes of the American Television and Communications Corporation. The rate is 8 3/8 percent.

title: ST. JOHN'S CRUISES IN TOURNEY OPENER
description: For the last 12 seasons, St. John's has used the Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament as a momentum builder for the new season. Last night, the Redmen nearly propelled themselves into the middle of next week.

title: LOGIMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CANTERBURY PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 2 Texas Banks Sign Fed Pact
description: The two bank holding companies that have reported the biggest operating losses in Texas this year, the First City Bancorporation and the Interfirst Corporation, said they signed agreements with the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas last month to maintain certain lending, reserve and capital standards in their operations.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS UP BY 3.3%
description: Prices farmers get for raw products averaged 3.3 percent higher in November, the first increase in the monthly index since July, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 20 Planeloads of U.S. Arms Reported Flown to Iran
description: Sources in Iran say that as many as 20 planeloads of American weapons were delivered to Iran in May when President Reagan's former national security adviser visited Teheran.

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTORS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $72,787 and $217,117 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and realized investment gains of $343,854 and $632,080 for the same periods. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $420,027 and $1,224,039 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and realized investment gains of $1,148,813 and $1,117,323 for the same periods.

title: Tomorrow vs. Yesterday in Austria
description: Austrian voters have now reduced the standing of their two largest parties and so probably thrust them back into a partnership, the same grand coalition that ruled Austria for two decades after World War II. The voters also gave surprising boosts to two protest parties. The question now is whether the two leading partners can find the unity to confront the protest, attack Austria's economic difficulties and push back a nasty strain of ultranationalism. The prospects look good. The Socialist Party has governed Austria for most of the two decades since the grand coalition. The pre-election question in Austria was how great a bite the conservative People's Party, which gave Austria Kurt Waldheim as President, would take out of the Socialist Party, led by Chancellor Franz Vranitzky. As it turned out, the Socialists came out slightly ahead, but both major parties lost votes and seats in Parliament.

title: DEBATE ON TRADE DEFICIT: HAS IT REALLY IMPROVED?
description: After many months of frustration in which the huge United States trade deficit continued to mount in the face of a falling dollar, recent figures seem to indicate to many that the long-awaited reversal has begun.

title: CHRISTMAS SHOPPERS CLOG THE STORES
description: The tall gold revolving doors of the Trump Tower were spinning almost out of control yesterday. Shopper after shopper after shopper streamed in and out all day long.

title: Vandals, Penguins, Furs and Celebrity
description: Nothing makes Deputy Transportation Commissioner Samuel I. Schwartz see red as much as blacked-out traffic signs.

title: OIL CONCERN DEFAULTS ON SOME DEBT
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, the financially troubled energy company that has agreed to be acquired by Freeport-McMoran Inc., announced yesterday that it was in default on some debt payments and that it was considering filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL

title: INSIDE
description: Protest Blocked in Seoul Policemen fired tear-gas and pushed back crowds in Seoul to block a rally that was a test of wills between the Government and opponents.

title: INDEPENDENT BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
PATENTS;
Money Order Dispenser
description: AN automatic system of dispensing money orders at retail establishments, which should prove to be more secure than the manual method, was patented this week for Republic Money Orders Inc. of Dallas. Patent 4,625,275 was obtained by Lawrence G. Smith, a former consultant for the company.

title: Lucky Will Omit Quarterly Dividend
description: Lucky Stores Inc. plans to omit its fourth-quarter dividend and cut capital spending from $150 million to $100 million, the food retailer told shareholders in a letter this week. Lucky also disclosed that its board had approved about $9 million in ''golden parachute'' severance payments for 50 executives, The San Francisco Chronicle reported on Thursday.

title: British Gas Offer
description: More than a million applications have already flooded in from people seeking to buy shares in British Gas when Britain's Conservative Government sells the state-owned company to the public, postal officials said. On Monday, the Government announced that it would offer about four billion shares at $:1.35 each in the biggest share issue ever in London. The offer closes next Wednesday and special postal depots have been set up in two round-the-clock centers backed by extra staff, vehicles and planes to handle about six million applications.

title:
PATENTS;
Small Tumors Targets In Cancer Detection
description: David M. GOldenberg, founder and chairman of Immunomedics Inc., a biotechnology company in Newark, was granted a patent this week for a method of detecting cancer cells that could be important in cancer diagnosis and therapy.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE TELLS WHITE HOUSE TO SAVE IRAN FILE
description: Amid New indications that White House officials had destroyed sensitive documents, the Senate Intelligence Committee urged the White House today to retain all material relating to the sale of arms to Iran and the transfer of money to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Peru Seizes Drug Laboratory
description: A cocaine processing laboratory operated by traffickers armed with grenades and a mortar was captured today by the police in the northern Peruvian jungle. The police said they had arrested six traffickers who were armed with grenades and machine guns in the laboratory at Ramal de Aspusana, 325 miles north of here.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36.

title: Trouble Spots on the Roadways
description: According to the City Department of Transportation, among the most severe traffic trouble spots this weekend in the New York metropolitan region will be these: The Manhattan Bridge, where the Manhattan-bound upper roadway will be closed.

title: More Dignity for the Disabled
description: Four years ago, a Bloomington, Ind., couple made an anguished decision that was to touch off a national debate. In what they deemed to be his own best interest, they allowed their mentally retarded newborn son to die of starvation.

title: Family Identifies Woman With Artificial Heart
description: The world's 29th artificial heart patient was identified today as Betty Shields, 40, a critically ill Arizona woman whose husband made a plea to ''all her friends to pray for her.''

title: Mortar Shells Wound 39 Ulster Shoppers
description: Thirty-nine people were wounded Thursday night when mortar shells aimed at a police and army post crashed into a street crowded with shoppers, the police said.

title: Iran Says McFarlane Tapes Show Lie
description: Iran says it has taped conversations between the White House and Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, showing that President Reagan has ''lied'' to the American people, according to statements by an Iranian official and published reports here and in Bonn.

title: Jackie Robinson Stamp
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Panel Reports
description: Some University of Miami football players were unruly and were disrespectful to campus and municipal police officers in an incident outside their dormitory Sept. 24, and there have been other incidents involving individual players. But there has been ''no pattern of lawlessness or misconduct'' by the school's athletes, and they have not been given preferential treatment in academic or disciplinary matters, a university task force has concluded.

title: POLL BACKS ENDING LIFE SUPPORT IN SOME CASES
description: A vast majority of Americans surveyed support withdrawing life support under certain conditions from patients with little chance o ferovevy, caording to a poll published today by the American Medical Association.

title: FIRE POINTS UP DILEMMA OVER DAY CARE CHOICES
description: For the last four days, Thomas Baptiste has sat on his couch watching over and over again a videotape of his 2-year-old daugther, Tiffany, at a Halloween party. Tiffany, dressed in a pink leotard with wings attached, is a butterfly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: INTERNATIONAL CONSUMER BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said meaningful comparative results for 1985 are unavailable because the company began operations June 5, 1985, and initiated sales in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: Ryland to Buy Brock
description: Ryland Group Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the M. J. Brock Corporation, whose M. J. Brock & Sons Inc. unit is a California-based home builder, for $85 million in cash and securities. The purchase is subject to a number of conditions, including approval by Ryland's board, it said.

title: Slots in the Senate
description: The new Democrats in the Senate have received their committee assignments, and the big winner is Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota. He was the only freshman to win a seat on the powerful Finance Committee, which handles tax matters; he also got a spot on Agriculture, a key panel for someone from a farm state.

title: Colombia Oil Camp Raided
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked an oil camp and kidnapped two people in northeastern Colombia, a spokesman for the state-run oil company Ecopetrol said today. Dozens of rebels of the National Liberation Army raided the camp of the Colombian company Tecnicontrol near San Bernardo de Bata on Thursday, abducted two Colombian engineers and destroyed heavy machinery worth about $230,000.

title: TRANSIT AUTHORITY GOES A-COUNTING SPARE PARTS
description: It takes 4,473 kinds of screws to hold the Transit Authority together, along with 2,235 types of bolts, nuts and washers. The agency uses 244 different oils and greases, 228 varieties of paint, 829 electrical coils, 47 kinds of gloves, 940 light bulbs and fixtures.

title: Harness Driver Cleared
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has withdrawn its action instituted against a harness-racing owner-driver-trainer, Michel LaChance of Canada, involving what it termed his character and general fitness. The original action by the board suspending LaChance for failure to cooperate was overturned by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court last July.

title: TENANTS EVICTED FROM BUILDING IN COURT RULING
description: In an unusual ruling, a Manhattan Housing Court judge has ordered the eviction of tenants of a reputed West Side ''crack house'' at the request of neighboring homeowners and tenants.

title: The Game Of the Name
description: I used to think I had a disease because I can't remember people's names. I've discovered most everyone suffers from this complaint. Forgetting names is as widespread as the common cold - and possibly more dangerous.

title: Prices Stable in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were basically unchanged yesterday in extremely light trading, as many dealers and investors turned the Thanksgiving Day holiday into a four-day weekend.

title: DRUG-TEST ENTERPRISE IN TEXAS
description: An entrepreneur is selling drug-free urine for $49.95 a bag in a business that a civil libertarian says could grow as drug tests become more common.

title: THEODORE D. ELLSWORTH
description: Dr. Theodore D. Ellsworth, retired professor of retailing at the New York Unversity School of Business, died Nov. 21 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Zoning in New York City Has Hurt Manufacturing and Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: HAVE RAMS FOUND MAGIC ARM AT LAST?
description: You could look it up. Joe Namath played for them, and so did Ron Jaworski and Bert Jones. There was a Rhodes Scholar and a defector from the Canadian Football League. And there even was one who jumped to Canada - and back again.

title: ATTACKS ON 6 CHILDREN, LEFT FOR DEAD, BRING A SEARCH FOR CAUSES IN ILLINOIS
description: John and Joyce Wilbourn's eight children were watching television, all in a cramped bedroom, last Saturday when two teen-agers broke into the house through an old coal chute in the basement.

title: A Shark Story
description: Taking a break from a recent judicial conference in the South Pacific, an American delegate, Jack H. Olender, a Washington trial lawyer, went on an outing and found himself menaced by a great white shark that showed more than passing interest in his becalmed skiff off Queensland, Australia.

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $575,761 from the sale of assets of discontinued operations.

title: Two Die in the Chicago Cold
description: Two people believed to be homeless died Thanksgiving Day as they sought shelter from from below-freezing temperatures, the authorities said.

title: POP: REED SINGS
description: Maggi-Meg Reed, who sang on Tuesday evening at the Duplex, 55 Grove Street, brought her set of songs to a close with a panoramic bit that gave glowing evidence of her vocal range, her dramatic ability and her talent for pulling her audience into her act.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS OF ARANSAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $917,000 and $367,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,139,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $5,501,000 for the year. Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company coverted to a capital stock company in April. The company said the latest year share earnings are stated as if 3,860,000 common shares which were issued on April 8 had been outstanding during the entire period.

title: 5 DEFIANT ON AIRPLANE, FINED FOR REFUSING TO STOP SMOKING
description: Five men who refused to put out their cigarettes in an airplane's no-smoking section were each ordered to pay $115 in court costs and witness feed yesterday.

title: CUOMO IS EAGER FOR MEETING
description: Governor Cuomo today asked legislative leaders to meet with him early next week to schdule a date for a December resumption of the legislative session. The Governor said the session should be resumed as soon as possible so the state can deal with a fiscal package for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and fulfill a commitment to name 23 judges to the Court of Claims before Jan. 1. He has indicated he would like the Legislature to convene during the second week in December and no later than the third week.

title: Judge Backs Dunes Sale
description: A bankruptcy judge in Las Vegas, Nev., has approved the sale of Dunes Hotel and Country Club to a group of investors led by four executives of the hotel for $144.5 million.

title: TEXAS BORDER BANKS THRIVE
description: The economy has languished for four years here in the valley just north of the Mexican border, and unemployment remains stubbornly above 15 percent. But many local banks, flush with abundant deposits that flowed in from Mexican customers, remain healthy.

title: Suns Shift Centers
description: In a move involving 7-foot-1-inch centers, the Phoenix Suns have activated their first-round pick in last spring's draft, William Bedford, and placed James Edwards on the injured list for at least five games because of tendinitis in his left heel. Bedford underwent arthroscopic surgery Oct. 12 to remove bone chips in his right knee.

title: KEY RATES
FRENCH TO OVERHAUL MONETARY POLICY
description: France's new conservative Government continued its economic deregulation drive today as the central bank disclosed plans for a far-reaching overhaul of French monetary policy next year.

title: Johnson Seeking Raise
description: Less than a year after he signed a three-year contract, saying that money ''is not an issue,'' Davey Johnson is apparently not satisfied with the more than $300,000 he is scheduled to make as the Mets' manager next season.

title: Is Coolidge's Picture Coming Down?
description: As soon as he moved into the executive office, Ronald Reagan hung a portrait of Calvin Coolidge over his chair in the Cabinet room and proclaimed President Coolidge the model for his Administration. Some of the magic that surrounded Mr. Coolidge seemed at first to have rubbed off on Mr. Reagan.

title: Global Race In Second Leg
description: Titouan Lamazou of France, sailing in Ecreuil d'Aquitaine, is leading in the second leg of a 27,000-mile round-the-world solo yacht race, the South African Broadcasting Corporation reported today.

title: Levers and Wheels
description: THE MECHANIC MUSE. By Hugh Kenner. 136 pages. Oxford University Press. $13.95.

title: NOVICE CLIMBERS DISCOVER THE GUNKS
description: Brunch does not interest Cindie Lovelace, a Manhattan corporate lawyer. After a week of negotiating mergers and acquisitions on Wall Street, only one place, and one pursuit, beckons her.

title: Syrians, in Retaliation, Oust 3 Envoys of Bonn
description: Syria ordered three West German diplomats to leave the country today, a day after Bonn ordered the ouster of three Syrian envoys from West Germany.

title: Israelis and Arabs Meet
description: Without publicity, representatives of Israel met recently in Washington with representatives of Egypt, Iraq, Jordan and Turkey. The subject was the scarcity of water in the Middle East, a problem confronting all the countries, said Dr. Joyce Starr, a scholar who brought them together.

title: MONTCLAIR PASSER IN HIS BIGGEST ROLE
description: Walter Briggs, a senior at Montclair State College, has had the type of life most kids dream of. Not only has he become one of the best quarterbacks in Division III, but, at age 21, his professional acting career already includes a role in a feature film, parts in two off-Broadway plays and assorted television commercials.
