U.S. EXCEEDS LIMIT SET IN 1979 ACCORD ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: The United States exceeded the limits of the second strategic arms treaty today when a B-52 bomber, newly modified to carry cruise missiles, entered active service.

title: CATHOLICS DEBATE MORALITY OF CAPITALISM, U.S. STYLE
description: The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States, drawing on their faith's rich and at times paradoxical tradition of social teaching, have rekindled debate on a question that has divided the West for centuries: Is capitalism moral?

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: HOW TO STAY OUT ON BAIL WHEN YOU'RE OUT OF CASH? CHARGE IT!
description: A year ago, around Thanksgiving, an elderly couple went to the Morris County jail to try to make bail for their grandson, who was being held on a shoplifting charge.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $231,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,748,000 for the quarter and $3,561,000 for the 9 months.

title: Brunswick To Acquire Ray
description: The Brunswick Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Ray Industries for $350 million.

title: Police Find $2 Million In Suitcases at Airport
description: The police exploded a suspicious suitcase and found it contained nothing out of the ordinary, but two other suitcases checked at the airport by the same man were found to contain nearly $2 million in cash, the authorities said today.

title: Man Is Arrested in Slayings Of Two Americans in Liberia
description: The police have arrested a Baptist seminary graduate in connection with the killings of an American missionary and her 10-year-old daughter, authorities said today.

title: THE TOYS AT THE TOP OF CHILDREN'S GIFT LISTS
description: The telephone at Toy Park in Manhattan has been ringing ''like crazy,'' said Richard Burdick, the store's manager. The caller on the other end usually says just two words posed as a question: ''Lazer Tag?''

title: The Insurance Industry Puts One Over
description: Last June, the New York State Legislature passed laws that radically altered the legal procedures that allowed injury victims to seek compensation in courts for injuries they have suffered through the fault of others. The doctrine of joint and several liability, which dates to the Magna Carta, was modified to allow some wrongdoers to escape responsibility for their actions. Insurers are now allowed to spread out payments to victims and to invest money that rightly belongs to victims.

title: PANEL FINISHES HARASSMENT HEARING
description: Closed hearings on sexual harassment charges against the Bronx Surrogate, Bertram R. Gelfand, have been completed, participants in the hearings said yesterday.

title: MUSIC: ERIC CLAPTON BAND
description: Fans of Eric Clapton's guitar playing should be overjoyed to hear his new band - a stripped-down, four-man group that made its debut with two packed-to-the-rafters shows Sunday and Monday at the Ritz.

title: A Surgical Experience
description: As Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. Frank E. Young is a leader of American health policy.

title: SEISDATA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain resulting from reorganization of $10,909,000. c-Net loss

title: Stars Plan Appearances At AIDS Benefit Show
description: Hildegard Behrens, Leonard Bernstein, Marvin Hamlisch, Marilyn Horne, Bernadette Peters, Linda Ronstadt, Isaac Stern and Michael Tilson Thomas will take part next Sunday in ''Classical Evening for AIDS,'' a concert and dinner to benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research, at the Public Theater.

title: Associated Hosts
description: A Hong Kong investment firm, Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd., told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased an additional 50,000 shares of Associated Hosts Inc. for $428.5 million and now owns 367,000 shares, or 8.11 percent of its stock. Associated Hosts operates a chain of restaurants and hotels.

title: MAVERICKS BREEZE PAST NETS, 119-94
description: Mark Aguirre scored 26 points to lead Dallas to a 119-94 victory over the Nets tonight, the Mavericks' fourth straight triumph.

title: Times Mirror Magazine Deal
description: The Times Mirror Company has agreed to acquire Broadcasting magazine, a Washington-based industry publication, for $75 million. The acquisition is part of the

title: Fat Tony and the Bail Principle
description: Innocent until proved guilty: That principle is a cornerstone of the Constitution as many people understand it. But Congress trimmed on the principle two years ago when it authorized preventive detention for defendants thought to be dangerous. The Supreme Court, which now will review the new law, has a chance to reaffirm the importance of a right to pretrial release.

title: Credit Cards: No 'Free Ride'
description: FOR years, consumers have taken a free ride on their credit cards, buying one day and not having to pay until 20 to 30 days after receipt of their monthly card statements. Now, many cardholders are finding the free ride is over or not nearly so long as before.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INTERNATIONAL BIOTECHNOLOIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $115,000 in connection with the withdrawal of a proposed public offering.

title: NUI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RAILROAD POLICE SUE AMTRAK OVER HOMELESS EDICT
description: The union that represents the Amtrak railroad police has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan challenging the company's policy of requiring officers to eject ''homeless and undesirable people'' from Penn Station.

title: BRIEFS
description: Chase Manhattan Corp. said its futures subsidiary had been made a full clearing member of the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Rebecca Kolodny to Wed
description: Rebecca Sharon Kolodny and Steven Schwartz, who graduated with the class of '86 from Harvard University, where they were elected to Phi Beta Kappa, plan a summer wedding. The parents of the couple are Drs. Gerald and Nancy Kolodny of West Newton, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Schwartz of Montreal. Ms. Kolodny is a first-year student at the Harvard Medical School and her fiance a first-year student at the Harvard Law School.

title: Rehousing Single-Parent Families
description: AT this time of year, Anthony Puzio starts worrying about winter winds. One long side of his four-story rental apartment building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn faces north. Protection from the elements is the most important benefit that shelter must provide, and the old, wooden-framed windows at 50 Granite Street are frail defenders against the heavy winds that batter them.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Faceoff on Cash In New England

title: Stay for Homeless 'Nativity'
description: Federal District Judge John Penn granted advocates for the homeless a temporary restraining order Friday allowing a statue depicting a homeless family to stay on the grounds of the Capitol.

title: What's New for Children During the Christmas Season
description: Tonight, at the outset of ''Barnum,'' the CBS-TV film that unofficially marks the start of this year's holiday-season programming for children, Burt Lancaster, as P. T. Barnum, strolls through his circus. He greets the audience genially, allowing that they probably know him because of his famous assertion that ''there's a sucker born every minute.'' At the conclusion of the lavish two-hour production, which follows the master showman's life and career from 1810 to 1885, Barnum affirms his own genius, his perception of what had been there all the while. There were, he says, ''millions of people waiting to be formed into an audience. I invented the audience. I invented you.''

title: ACTOR, 12, ADDS TO LONG CAREER
description: ACTING came naturally to Jadrien Steel. It could not have come any other way. At the age of five months, he was, as it is said, ''discovered'' - in his baby carriage - by the executive producer and creator of the television series ''Ryan's Hope.''

title: THANKSGIVING OF ANOTHER ERA RECALLED
description: WHEN I was a boy growing up in Flushing, Queens, more than 50 years ago, a visit to Westchester was an exciting adventure and a rare holiday. There were no bridges to speed you over the East River. You took a ferry from College Point, at Powell's Cove near the present site of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, and you sailed across to Clason Point.

title: On the Pier at St. George
description: Bay Street Landing, a 40-acre waterfront community of co-ops and condos in St. George, S.I., has just received its first commercial tenant, a restaurant called Shanghai Red's.

title: NEW YORK COURT WORKERS HONORED FOR DEEDS
description: Michael Christiano dislikes making merely one sandwich - an idosyncrasy he says he picked up from his mother, who ''doesn't believe in making just one of anything.'' So he makes about 150 sandwiches and distributes them each morning to homeless men and women he sees on the way to work.

title: FRIENDS SAY OLIVER NORTH IS TAKING IT LIKE A SOLDIER
description: Oliver L. North, the Marine lieutenant colonel at the center of the crisis involving arms sales and aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents, was described by friends this week as being prepared to take the blame like a mixture of martyr and good soldier.

title: DELIVERING THE SOUTH
description: FEW THINGS ARE CERTAIN about the 1988 electoral campaign, just a few weeks after that of 1986 came to a close, but this much we know for sure: the South will be one of the principal cockpits - quite possibly the principal cockpit - in which the Republicans and Democrats will struggle for dominance at the start of the post-Reagan era in American politics.

title: Fined, but Defiant
description: CHARLES MANN, the Redskin defensive end, thinks it was a ''legitimate hit'' on the Packer quarterback, Randy Wright. National Football League officials, who reviewed the films of the Nov. 9 Washington-Green Bay game, say Mann's head-butting charge into Wright just after the quarterback had released a pass at the end of the second quarter was a clear violation.

title: STUDY FINDS WOMEN SLOWER TO QUIT SMOKING
description: A Federal study of smoking habits in 21 states and the District of Columbia indicates that more people than ever are trying to quit smoking but that women are doing so at a lower rate than men.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RAINBOW DRIVE. By Roderick Thorp. (Summit, $18.95.) Twenty years after the publication of his best seller, ''The Detective,'' Roderick Thorp has put together another gritty police novel that plunges the reader into the underbelly of crime in Los Angeles - a frightening world of corrupt politicians, drug dealers and addicts, sold-out cops, pornography and white slavery.

title: PORT AUTHORITY PLANS
description: LIKE the M.T.A., the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has drawn up a wish list of capital spending projects. Its executive director, Stephen Berger, has said that between $4 billion and $5 billion will have to be spent over the next five years to keep the authority's airports, bridges, tunnels, transit lines and docks in good condition. And the way to pay for the improvements, he said, is with higher fares, tolls, rents and fees.

title: KEAN AIDE TO PRESS FOR CLINICS IN SCHOOLS
description: BECAUSE the state should help troubled adolescents cut through the social services bureaucracy by offering health care in high schools, says the Commissioner of Human Services, school-based clinics will be a priority for his administration.

title: Article 717786 -- No Title
description: The Ford Foundation has begun a nationwide program that would attempt to prevent school dropouts by matching students prone to quit school with aid that would address their particular problems.

title: Photography
description: Every year scores of books of photographs are introduced by publishers large and small, and every year scores of them get lost in the shuffle. As a result, some photographers' efforts never receive the attention they deserve.

title: CROTON'S DRIVE FOR WEEKLY SUCCEEDS
description: THE Croton Cortlandt Gazette, a new weekly newspaper based in Croton-on-Hudson, may be the answer to what some residents had termed a ''crisis'' earlier this year. The newspaper is meant to provide local government and community news that village residents say they have missed for a year, according to the publisher.

title: CHINESE CRIME NETWORK REPORTED MOVING INTO AREAS OF U.S.
description: A small but growing underworld organization with bases in Taiwan and Hong Kong is beginning to move into areas of crime in the United States that were once controlled by the Mafia, Federal law-enforcement officials say.

title: A $1 BILLION WILD CARD IN THE IRAN DEAL
description: AS ONE who has studied the 1980 hostage negotiations with Iran, I find myself less shocked than others by the revelation that the Administration's arms deals with Iran may have had more to do with funding the contras than with springing the hostages. In my mind, if there was a trade for the hostages the ransom more likely involved the more than $1 billion of Iranian assets still held by American banks than the $50 million worth of arms that the Iranians are said to have bought from the United States. In fact, the movement of hostages this fall has coincided at least as much with the release of some of those assets as with the delivery of arms.

title: FINDING A JOY OF A DIFFERENT KIND
description: THE joy began when we turned off the new Montauk Highway onto the Old Montauk Road, and it reached it peak when we approached the highest point on that road and looked down at the vast and wrinkled sea and said, ''There it is!'' The joy lasted for the four days we stayed.

title: Classroom Takes Second Place
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Morgan Library Shows Off Its New Treasures
description: A look at the show of recent acquisitions at the Pierpont Morgan Library has convinced this visitor that the library has to be one of the best places in which to be walled up alive. (A set of pass keys would help, of course.) There would be books to read, drawings to look at, and music to hum in one's head for a long lifetime.

title: An M.V.P. Vote For Hernandez
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SURGEON STRESSES ROLE OF DONORS
description: THE calls come suddenly, usually in the middle of the night, but when Dr. Craig R. Smith has finished his latest heart transplant operation, and ''you see how well they do, it keeps getting you up every morning,'' he says.

title: SKILLS USED IN THEATER ARE BROUGHT TO SCHOOLS
description: TO Mary Hunter Wolf, founder of the Center for Theater Techniques in Education, acting is much more than learning one's lines. In fact, she says, the techniques actors use can help other professionals and young people become more disciplined as well as creative.

title: The American Wife
description: Ms. Fleming eloquently discusses the difficulties a modern American wife faces, but she shows little sensitivity toward men.

title: San Diego State Wins
description: Chris Hardy's running produced a touchdown and set up a field goal tonight as San Diego State won its first Western Athletic Conference title with a 10-3 victory over Bringham Young. The Aztecs (8-3 over all and 7-1 in the conference) also won their first berth in the Sea World Holiday Bowl, ending a nine-game losing streak to B.Y.U. extending back to 1976.

title: No-Frills Firms
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: It is about 10:30 on a Friday morning, and Robert Redford walks through a gaggle of technicians and saunters alone across an open field under a mountain sky that's so blue it almost sears your eyes. He walks about 30 yards, hands in his pockets, lost in thought, and then suddenly turns and peers at the scene in front of him like a painter inspecting a half-finished canvas.

title: Dreiser-Mencken Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: November Can Be Cruelest Month, Free Agents Find
description: ON the day before Thanksgiving 10 years ago, George Steinbrenner arrived at O'Hare Airport in Chicago. He wasn't traveling far from the airport, only to the Hyatt-Regency Hotel, so he boarded the hotel van outside the airport terminal.

title: Philadelphia Shelter Facing Money Woes
description: An emergency shelter founded by a young boy who was once moved to give his own blanket and pillow to a homeless man has itself fallen on hard times, the boy's father said Friday.

title: FRIEDMAN SUPPORTS ASSEMBLYMAN TO SUCCEED HIM AS BRONX LEADER
description: In what is likely to be his final action as Bronx Democratic chairman, Stanley M. Friedman, convicted last week in a Federal racketeering trial, has named a close associate, Assemblyman George Friedman, as his choice to succeed him, Bronx Democratic leaders said last night.

title: Moscow Promises More Aid for India
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi welcomed the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to India last week as a ''crusader for peace.'' Both men repeated their calls for sweeping arms control measures and their criticisms of President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' program.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ALWAYS A ROCKETTE
description: THE kicks are a little lower now, but not much. Their feet move a little slower, but still faster than most. Their faces sport no stage makeup.

title: Lucille Pendleton Wed in Stamford
description: Lucille Culbertson Pendleton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Embree Pendleton of Washington, was married yesterday to Hugh Van Seaton, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter Seaton of Mesa, Ariz., formerly of Urbana, Mo. The Rev. Ronald James performed the ceremony at the Turn of River Presbyterian Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: LAUTENBERG'S SUCCESSOR AT A.D.P.: AN OPEN, ON-THE-GO C.E.O.
description: WHEN Josh Weston knocked himself cold a while back by falling on his head while sawing off a tree limb at his home in Montclair, his wife, Judy, and four grown children were not the only ones upset.

title: 49ers' Rice Poses Tough Test for Giant Defense
description: JERRY RICE of the 49ers leads all National Football League pass receivers this season in yardage (1,281 in 12 games) and touchdowns (13) and seems headed for all-pro. He is averaging 19.7 yards a catch after a 1985 rookie season in which he averaged 18.9 yards and won several rookie-of-the-year elections.

title: Bronfman Billions
description: To the Editor:

title: GROTON WEIGHS NEW RULE ON PROTESTS
description: THE town of Groton, concerned about the deployment of its police force at demonstrations against nuclear vessels, will hold a public hearing on Tuesday on giving the Police Chief power to deny permission for such demonstrations.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: SURROUNDED BY MUSIC The 90-member Taghkanic Chorale is celebrating its 20th anniversary with an unusual holiday concert at 8 P.M. Saturday in Peekskill's restored Paramount Theater. Dennis Keene, the music director, has designed a 17th-century evening that is sure to enchant the audience.

title: THE DANCE: ISABEL BENET
description: MORE. One simply wanted more from Isabel Benet, the Mexican choreographer whose company, Nunuma Performanceart, presented ''Angel of the Markets,'' a program of two dances, Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Irish Score Victory On Final-Play Kick
description: In what amounted to an emotional one-game season for both teams, Notre Dame defeated Southern California, 38-37, here today with a field goal on the last play by John Carney.

title: From Lives of Promise To Life at a Dingy Hotel
description: The first impression of the room in the Prince George Hotel, the city's largest welfare hotel, is how small and dark it is. Jammed in are a bunk bed, a cot and a crib for 17-month-old Brett. The air is heavy with the traces of cigarettes smoked in despair and of futile wars waged with disinfectant.

title: FINDING A STRATEGY FOR BATTLING WINTER
description: WITH winter about to make its annual comeback, I remembered that last year I had to shovel snow only a couple of times. I put on the outdoor vest I had got for Christmas and finished the job after working just hard enough to break a light sweat.

title: AS HIS CHILDREN WATCH, MAN IS SLAIN AT A MANHATTAN GAS STATION
description: While his two daughters and two nieces looked on, a construction worker was killed Friday night when he tried to intervene in an argument at an upper Manhattan gas station, the police said.

title: Jaime M. Reich to Marry Avi Amara in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D. Reich of Kings Point, L.I., have announced that their daughter Jaime Meredith Reich and Avi Amara plan to be married Dec. 27. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Amara of Kiryat Gat, Israel.

title: CAN THE PAIN GET WORSE, AND IF NOT, HOW FAST CAN REAGAN RECOVER?
description: RONALD Reagan reached the nadir of his Presdency last week.

title: HASENFUS STIRS NICARAGUAN MEMORIES OF '09
description: Eugene Hasenfus, the air-cargo specialist whose arms-laden plane was shot down over Nicaragua last month and who was sentenced to 30 years in jail, is not the first American to be captured and punished for meddling in Nicaraguan revolutions.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: Last call to batten down the garden for winter. . . . Be sure the lawn is clear of leaves, mow it short if it is too long and spread fertilizer and lime if the grass has not been limed for several years. Surprise Snowfall

title: ANGLICAN MAVERICK TENDS TO OKLAHOMA FLOCK
description: The Bishop of London, a maverick prelate wary of the ecclesiastical ''club,'' is unrepentant after roiling the clergy of two churches with a visit far beyond his vineyard to Episcopal America, where he comforted an outcast priest in Broken Arrow, Okla.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CLASSES WITHOUT TESTS THE classroom was filling up. The teachers, Mary Ann Norcott and Barrie Zucal, joked with some of the students - Yetta Hess, Anna Feinstein and Edna Wardle - as other classmates, in wheelchairs or aided by walkers, slowly made their way to the main-floor meeting room.

title: FOR THOSE WITH A SONG IN THEIR HEARTS
description: COMMUNITY choruses are thriving in the county. From Yorktown Heights and Bedford in the north to Bronxville and Yonkers in the south, from Hastings-on-Hudson in the west to New Rochelle in the east, 18 singing groups are meeting and performing regularly. Almost 1,000 people are dues-paying members of these groups, not counting those singing in children's and college choruses or in the county's several opera societies.

title:
DINING OUT;
A VARIED MENU IN PLEASANTVILLE
description: WHEN the pacing's right and the kitchen's in top form, The Saute Cafe can deliver a meal that would impress the most exacting diners. Many things are done well here. For example, to prevent diners from filling up on bread, The Saute Cafe brings its excellent loaves, including a super garlic bread, with the first course. Fresh breadsticks and a pewter goblet filled with olives, celery and carrots suffice to stave off hunger while one waits for such delicacies as succulent Oriental dumplings called shao mai, these little pork and vegetable nuggets in a wrapping so light it seemed little more than gossamer. A lovely match of plump tortellini and cream, fresh asparagus and a creamy garlic vinaigrette, and a glowing Belgium salad of radicchio and endive made other satisfying appetizer choices.

title: VERMONT INCREASES EDUCATION EFFORT ON AIDS
description: The State Health Department is increasing its efforts to educate Vermonters about AIDS.

title: PROSECUTOR'S FILM STORY SNAGS MOLESTATION CASE
description: One of the nation's most widely publicized child molestation cases has been thrown into disarray because of information given to defense lawyers by a movie maker who wants to produce a film about the case.

title: Nevada-Las Vegas Wins in 2 Overtimes
description: A 21-foot jumper from the left of the key by Freddie Banks with 13 seconds remaining in the second overtime last night gave Nevada-Las Vegas a 3-point basket and a 96-95 victory over Western Kentucky in the final of Coca Cola N.I.T. Classic at Madison Square Garden.

title: Mia Lawrence, a Dancer, Is Bride of Ted Marcoux
description: Mia Lawrence, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Lawrence of New York and Purdys, N.Y., was married in New York yesterday to Edward Charles Marcoux, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Marcoux Jr. of Chardon, Ohio, and Block Island, R.I. Walter Lawton, leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel.

title: A NEW YORKER UP FOR SAINTHOOD
description: FOR MORE THAN TWO years now, the letters have been trickling in at a rate of 15 to 20 a week. They report in touching detail about jobs found, problems solved, illnesses overcome. A few correspondents relate stories of extraordinary cures. A retired New York City policeman whose son's eyes were severely damaged in a hockey accident writes that the boy's sight is now almost perfectly restored; one of the boy's doctors called it ''unexplainable.'' Another man reports that, although his grandson had battled ''terminal'' leukemia for eight years and doctors at one point had given the boy only a few days to live, he is now living the life of a normal teen-ager.

title: IN NASHVILLE, POINSETTIAS AND GLITTER
description: Sound of water splashing down miniature rock waterfalls and along a winding stream fills the indoor tropical retreat of Opryland Hotel's Conservatory with the restful voice of nature.

title: DATA UPDATE: NOVEMBER 30, 1986
A GARLAND OF CELEBRATIONS
description: Caroling, bell-ringing, candlelight, special dishes and good cheer abound at holiday time, giving even big cities the feeling of a small town.

title: SPORTS MEDICINE: A GROWING FIELD
description: WHEN Mark Gastineau's knee collapsed on the Meadowlands floor two Sundays ago, New York Jets fans cringed with the thought of limping through the rest of the football season without the services of another key player.

title: James Laughlin's Poems
description: To the Editor:

title: Freedom Party Gains in Austria
description: Playing to widespread concern about rising unemployment and the environment, Austria's small nationalist Freedom Party did well last week in parliamentary elections. Led by Jorg Haider, who attracted international criticism last year when he hailed a convicted Nazi war criminal as ''a soldier who had done his duty,'' the party won nearly 10 percent of the vote and 18 seats in Parliament.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ITEMS FROM BUSY HANDS Quilts, gingerbread and other old-fashioned things are beginning to dominate the scene as Connecticut prepares for Christmas. In West Hartford, a quilt that has been three years in the making and still is not finished will be on display at the Noah Webster House, 227 South Main Street. It is part of an exhibition titled ''Our Hands Are Never Idle,'' a showcase of unusual items produced by members of the Noah Webster Foundation and Historical Society. The quilt, when finished sometime next year, will be on permanent display. It features early scenes of buildings in the area, many of them no longer in existence, including the Old Town Hall, the Trout Brook Ice House, Goodman Green and the Noah Webster House itself.

title: POWER UNSHARED AND TOTAL
description: FIDEL A Critical Portrait. By Tad Szulc. 703 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: A FAMILY'S LOVE AFFIAR WITH YIDDISH FOLK MUSIC
description: Lin Yaldati is a 74-year-old woman who has been performing Yiddish songs of celebration, defiance and remembrance for nearly 50 years.

title: ANSWERING READERS' QUESTIONS ON COMMON REPAIR PROBLEMS
description: IN an effort to catch up on the backlog of mail received by this department, this week's column is again being devoted to readers' questions about common home repair and maintenance problems.

title: Children's Aid Society
description: Seventy-five years ago, when The New York Times started its Neediest Cases appeal, the Children's Aid Society already had a 58-year record of rescuing thousands of orphaned and abandoned children from the streets of New York.

title: SEASONAL CONCERTS BEGIN
description: BY next weekend the preholiday concert rush will be under way in the county, adding some sounds to what has been a somewhat quiet time (aside from today's Highlands Brass Quintet of West Point giving a 3 P.M. holiday program at the John Jay Homestead).

title: BUSH PLANS TO END HIS SILENCE ON IRAN
description: Vice President Bush, who has been all but invisible to the public since the crisis over arm shipments to Iran erupted, intends to make a public statement on the situation soon, perhaps next week, according to friends and associates.

title: A Stitch in Time
description: IT took a bit of ingenuity and some needle and thread, but basketball players at the Hebrew Academy in Miami and state athletic officials have worked out a temporary compromise in a conflict between court safety and religious duty.

title: Co-op Rejection
description: To the Editor:

title: A Legislator With Statehood on His Mind
description: The photograph on his newsletters and press releases, with his tie loosened and his shirt sleeves rolled up, depicts Walter E. Fauntroy as a hard-working, no-nonsense member of the House of Representatives.

title: Tire Change in Formula One
description: The Formula One grand prix teams usually spend the winter testing cars for the following season. But with Goodyear's announcement that it was ending its financial support, the sport of grand prix racing is, figuratively speaking at least, up on blocks. Coupled with the withdrawal of the only other maker of Formula One tires, Pirelli, which was announced earlier this fall, Goodyear's exit means that there is no source for tires for the world's premier racing series.

title: The Japanese Way With Skin
description: JAPAN is not a happy place for cosmetics manufacturers these days. The Japanese economy is stagnating and its overall population is aging - not good news for an industry that, in any country, depends upon affluent young people for sales.

title: Capitalist Edition Of Pravda for U.S.
description: ''T HERE'S a huge interest in things Russian,'' said Charles Cox, a retired publisher of television guides and religious periodicals. To capitalize on it, he planned to publish a daily edition of Pravda in English for distribution in the United States.

title: Islanders Fall Short In a Wild Shootout
description: It was a most unpredictable game. Just when the Islanders seemed to have revived to earn a 5-5 tie tonight, the Flyers claimed a 6-5 victory after Rick Tocchet scored his second goal of the night with just 32 seconds left.

title: PROPOSALS FOR DRUG TESTING: WHY INCLUDE TEACHERS?
description: NOW that the elections are over, perhaps sanity can return to the issue of drug testing.

title: POLICY ASIDE, AMERICA DOES BUSINESS AS USUAL WITH ANGOLA
description: AT independence 11 years ago, Angola's ''strategic minerals,'' oil and diamonds, fell into the hands of Communists. Ever since, the minerals have been extracted and purchased largely by Westerners, including Americans. The United States, which does not have diplomatic relations with Angola, is its largest trading partner.

title: STAGE: BIG APPLE CIRCUS'S ELEPHANTS AND AERIALISTS
description: ELEPHANT clowns, lighter-than-air trampolinists and, above all, the Flying Gaonas - happily, the Big Apple Circus is back in its heated tent in Lincoln Center. The theme this season is ''Carnivale'' as celebrated in New Orleans, Venice and Mexico. The Big Apple is, by definition, a tiny top. One can see the expressions on the faces of the aerialists - smiling but earnest - and the animals are almost close enough to touch, if one dared.

title: SUFFOLK BURSTS BUDGET CAP
description: THE SPENDING cap burst off the top of the 1987 Suffolk County budget last week, propelled by pressure from county employees threatened with job losses by County Executive Peter F. Cohalan.

title: NEW ORLEANS ENDING CUTBACKS THAT HELP ERASE ITS DEFICIT
description: Cutbacks in the Police and Fire Departments will end next week, and City Hall will be open five days a week again after a two-month reduction in services helped erase a $10 million budget deficit, officials say.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY SINGS

title:
GARDENING;
FITTING THE GARDEN FOR THE LONG WINTER
description: THE Thanksgiving holiday represents the end of the fall harvest and, at least symbolically, the end of the gardening season as well. However, there are a number of last-minute tasks that still can be undertaken, if not already done, weather permitting.

title: Strike Vote at Card Maker
description: Union members at the U.S. Playing Card Company, which makes the ''Bicycle'' brand, have scheduled a strike vote Sunday. Roger Witt, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Workers' local here, said the company was demanding pay cuts of 9 to 22 percent, was seeking to eliminate life insurance for those who retire and to limit company contributions to health insurance, was planning to move out of Norwood and had laid off 90 workers. The contract expired two months ago.

title: Kim Bartlett Has Wedding
description: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest was the setting in New York yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Kimberley Bartlett, a daughter of Peter B. Bartlett of Summit and Bay Head, N.J., and Elizabeth E. Bartlett of New York, to Gilbert Schaefer Kernan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Kernan Jr. of Grosse Point, Mich. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: The Problems of 'Goya' And The Problem of Menotti
description: The recent premiere of Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Goya'' in Washington provided rich, prolonged opportunities for reflecting on the composer's half-century career in opera. This listener, his curiosity fanned almost to the flaming point by months of advance publicity, would have preferred to be so riveted by the opera itself that woolgathering would be impossible. But events dictated otherwise. Faced with limping music and an equally lame text, even the most rabid Menotti fan would have been excused if his thoughts wandered.

title: FACING THE BLISS OF COMMUTING
description: ABOUT a year ago, I took a job at a magazine in New York, and was faced with the dread specter of commuting to the city. This was a possibility I had faced before, but jobs always came their way safely within Fairfield County's bounds.

title:
ART;
BETWEEN DREAM AND REALITY
description: ART based on personal experience often has a way of eluding interpretation by outsiders, particularly when the artist's subject matter is derived less from evident reality than from interpretive and basically unverifiable phenomena. Many signs may guide us toward understanding, but they are frequently cryptic and more than a little misleading.

title: To the Shores of Suicide: An Abused Wife's Story
description: There was a day not long ago when Margo S. dropped her two young daughters off at an aunt's home and hailed a taxi to the Hudson River.

title: WHY ASIANS SUCCEED HERE
description: THANK GOD FOR THE ASIANS,'' exclaims an earnest middle-aged man from Westchester County.

title: EASING THE BITE OF THE ALTERNATIVE TAX
description: THOUSANDS of individuals who think they are taking prudent steps to minimize their taxes may discover next year that they have outsmarted themselves. The reason is the alternative minimum tax, whose reach has been expanded to catch more taxpayers, and whose rate has been raised to extract more taxes from them.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ''Social acceptability is simply a state of mind,'' says 50-year-old Reuben Silverbird, an American Indian who was born in Albuquerque, N.M., and lives in Englewood. ''There are people who tend to forget that their own heritage was at one time or another questioned by others possessing narrow minds.''

title: SCHOOL IRKS NEIGHBORS
description: THE Wooden Shoe Nursery School II is tucked in the middle of a large old development of Cape Cod houses on the west end of Valley Stream, where it leases a small one-story building from the village's School District 30. But some area residents believe the school's setting is inappropriate.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Of Medals and Shows
description: The British Royal Mint has issued a special medal to commemorate the marriage of Britain's Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson. From a numismatic standpoint, this is the most important of the numerous coins and medals produced in recent months to honor the couple. The sterling silver medal is 44 millimeters, nearly 1 3/4 inches in diameter, which is larger than most coinage issued in conjunction with the wedding.

title: About Men; The Running of the Deer
description: HE CAME BY IN THE December afternoon, when the light was almost lost in the weather. His back was humped. His flag was down. When he swung his head to look back, I could see his rack. A big buck, walking, forcing himself to trot a ways, heading downhill to ease the pain the rifle slug had given him. Two orange men came behind him, lurching in the slush of the old snow, peering through the fog of the new. They saw him, ran sliding after.

title: One Man's Inspiration, 75 Years of Giving
description: On Christmas Day 1911, one of the have-nots of this city approached Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times. Mr. Ochs was out for a long stroll after a large turkey dinner, and it was somewhere between 75th Street and Times Square that he encountered this shabby mendicant.

title: ZOFIA GOMULKA
description: Zofia Gomulka, widow of the Polish leader Wladyslaw Gomulka and a leading Communist Party activist, died Friday, official newspapers reported today.

title: Recent Sales
description: Greenwich, Conn. $590,000 7-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 20-year-old Georgian colonial; Jacuzzi, marble foyer, 1 acre; taxes $4,482. Litchfield, Conn. 530,000 East Chestnut Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, contemporary; brook on property, swimming pool, 22 acres; taxes $4,698.

title: Japan
description: To the Editor: We recently returned from Japan, having taken a ''Mountains, Hamlets and Temples'' tour that was mentioned in the June 1 Travel Advisory column.

title: NO DOUBT ABOUT IT, RIZZO IS ABOUT READY TO SHAKE UP PHILADELPHIA POLITICS
description: Frank Rizzo is back. Again.

title: Yanks Open on Road
description: The Yankees' quest for the 1987 American League East championship will begin in Detroit April 6 with the start of a seven-game road trip against the Tigers and the Royals and end at Yankee Stadium Oct. 4 with the finale of a seven-game home stand against the Red Sox and the Orioles.

title: Music
description: There are several concerts of 20th century music taking place this week, at least four of which are worthy of serious attention.

title: A Drug That May Sober Alcoholics
description: Society no doubt could benefit from a drug that quickly reverses the effects of alcohol. But would such a substance encourage excess in drinkers who knew they could sober up in a matter of minutes?

title: TO BE OR NOT TO BE?
description: To the casual observer the change doesn't merit becoming an issue - the addition of the word ''hamlet'' to Bedford Village, so that it would become the Hamlet of Bedford Village.

title: A TREE THAT TOOK ROOT IN MY LIFE
description: GROWING up in a tenement in Jersey City and living most of my adult life in Manhattan didn't expose me to nature beyond the ubiquitous ailanthus trees that seem to thrive in dark alleys, nourished by soot from city chimneys. Nature was symbolized by the large plastic tree that ''grew'' in the apartment lobby, was seen in Western and Tarzan movies, was discovered during summers at camp and, finally, was observed briefly on the 72d Street bus, as I rode through Central Park.

title: Handmade Ornaments Crafted in New England
description: From heart to hand to tree is the nicest route for a Christmas tree ornament. In that spirit many a tree bears a child's red and green paper chain, while other trees display well-crafted handmade ornaments. Craftspeople in New Hampshire and Vermont are engaged in a new endeavor: making fine Christmas tree ornaments, often in addition to gallery-quality work in their medium. People have begun to collect these ornaments and to look for the artist's new designs each year. Such ornaments are available in woven grasses, porcelain, fabric and wood as well as pewter and blown and stained glass.

title: Navigator Earns Chance to Prove Her Skill Aboard USA
description: DORY VOGEL is a wisp of a woman compared with her counterparts, the America's Cup crewmen.

title: Ruth Clare Hinkson Married to A. Michael Lipper
description: Ruth Clare Hinkson, a daughter of William M. Hinkson of Birmingham, Mich., and the late M. Eleanor Jones Hinkson, was married yesterday to A. Michael Lipper, a son of Mrs. Walter Bishop of New York and the late Arthur Lipper Jr. Judge Damon J. Keith of the United States Court of Appeals performed the ceremony in his chambers in Detroit.

title: Japan's Shining Prince Turns 1,000
description: ATHOUSAND years ago, in Kyoto, the capital of ancient Japan, the Shining Prince wrote a letter to a lady he admired, Princess Morning Glory, to tell her of his grief on the death of his wife in childbirth. To reflect his sadness, the Shining Prince, called Genji, chose a paper the color of the gray rainy sky on that late fall day. Then, in graceful strokes of the brush, he said: ''When I look back upon an autumn fraught with diverse sorrows, I find no dusk dimmed with such tears as I have shed tonight.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NIGHT TRAIN. By Todd Walton. (Mercury House/ Kampmann, $17.95.) Todd Walton's fourth novel is a paranoid fantasy about the eternal struggle between those with creative power and those with political and economic power.

title: RUSSIA'S 'BLAT' MARKET THRIVES BY MOONLIGHT
description: MIKHAIL S. Gorbachev said it as well as anyone. ''Try to get your apartment repaired,'' the Soviet leader told party officials in Leningrad last year. ''You will definitely have to find a moonlighter. He will steal the materials he needs from a construction site.''

title: Senator Pressler Urges Resignation by Regan
description: Senator Larry Pressler, a Republican, called today for the resignation of the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, saying ''he epitomizes the arrogance of power'' and should have known about the secret transfer of Iranian arms-sale profits to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Ms. Doyle Weds Dr. G. N. Chapar
description: The marriage of Kathryn Ann Doyle, a social worker at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, to Dr. George N. Chapar, a psychologist at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Shrine of St. Elizabeth Ann Seton in New York. Msgr. James Wilders, assisted by the Revs.

title: NEW PERSPECTIVES FOR CANCER PATIENTS
description: THE idea started one evening late last spring when the members of the Woman-to-Woman support group of the American Cancer Society's Westchester division, talked about their feelings of isolation and the sense of being out of control of their bodies.

title: L.I. NEWLYWEDS IN CIRCUS SPOTLIGHT
description: WHEN Jon Weiss and Laura Litts were sweethearts at Centereach High School, they didn't think they'd wind up in the circus or get married in a gala ceremony while thousands of spectators looked on. But that's exactly what happened. Last May, when the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus appeared at Madison Square Garden, the two performers exchanged vows in a special wedding ceremony that was staged in Ring 2, just before the afternoon show. The bridegroom, who joined the circus as a clown in 1981, wore a tuxedo that dazzled with rhinestones and sequins. The bride, a dancer, wore a shimmery wedding gown and a headpiece of 300 baby feathers.

title: OUR UNEMPLOYMENT QUANDARY
description: They're closing down the textile mill across the railroad tracks Foreman said these jobs are going boys and they ain't coming back. - Bruce Springsteen THOSE lyrics, from a song written in 1983, might just as easily have referred to a steel mill or an automobile assembly line or a chemical plant. As the United States economy endured the wrenching recession of 1981-82 that wrung inflation from the system, the jobless rate surged to 10.7 percent, the highest level since the Great Depression, when a quarter of the work force was idled.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LOUHI Witch of North Farm. A Story From Finland's Epic Poem the ''Kalevala.'' By Toni de Gerez. Illustrated by Barbara Cooney. Unpaged. New York: Viking Kestrel. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 8)

title: Nancy Barnes Is Bride Of William T. Berkeley
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in New London, N.H., yesterday Nancy Elda Barnes, a daughter of Mrs. Willard R. Bischoff of Huntington, L.I., and Grantham, N.H., and the late Thomas G. Barnes, was married to Stephen Taylor Berkeley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Berkeley of Pawling, N.Y. The Rev. Louise Bela performed the ceremony.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: FOR POPE, A DAY TO SEE AUSTRALIA, NEARLY ALL OF IT
description: Pope John Paul II crisscrossed a continent and its cultures today. In the desolate outback, he defended the civil rights of aboriginal tribesmen, and then many miles later he opened the Christmas season by lighting an Advent candle in a stately town square.

title: Rulings On Rights In Co-ops
description: THE chance for a rent-regulated tenant in a New York City apartment to buy at the special insider price during a co-op or condominium conversion has long been a rare opportunity to reap a windfall profit.

title: ANIMALS' LAST HOPE IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Radcliffe Smith's large, weathered hands probe for burrs in the tangled fur of the Airedale terrier sprawled at his feet while several tail-wagging dogs pace excitedly around him.

title: COZY HOUSEHOLD ITEMS SHOW TOP QUALITY ARTISTRY
description: QUILTS are a major populist symbol on the order of apple pie, but they can also achieve the status of high art. The latter point is borne out decisively in ''200 Years of American Quilts'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford.

title: UP THE WALL WITH HAMLET
description: NORTHROP FRYE ON SHAKESPEARE By Northrop Frye. Edited by Robert Sandler. 186 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $17.95.

title: Brooklyn Bureau Of Community Services
description: Since its establishment 121 years ago, the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service has striven to help people reach financial and social independence. Building on pride and the desire to succeed, we have contributd to a healthier society by helping the stressed and overwhelmed to be more useful and productive.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Dollar's Decline

title: Elizabeth Frappollo Wed to J.S. DeMott
description: Elizabeth Russell Frappollo, the owner and executive editor of New Media Publishing of Arlington, Va., which produces subscription newsletters for the telecommunications and financial services industries, was married yesterday to John Stuart DeMott, an associate editor in the nation section of Time magazine. The Rev. Constance Coles performed the Episcopal ceremony at All Saints' Church in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Ginger Greene Weds Financial Analyst
description: The marriage of Virginia Wardwell Greene, a daughter of Mrs. Richard W. Wilde Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill., and Thomas A. Greene of Greenwich, Conn., to Benjamin Davis Williams 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams 3d of Pomfret, Conn., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest. The Rev. John Bellingham performed the ceremony.

title: Designer Dogs Have Their Day
description: LISTEN up, you canines out there. If your best friend is a New Yorker, you've got it made. Just look at these pictures.

title: Lapchick Tourney To St. John's Again
description: With a 75-65 victory over Youngstown State last night, St. John's captured its 12th straight Lapchick Tournament championship and recorded its 24th consecutive victory at Alumni Hall.

title: TOWNS CALLING HALTS TO GET A GRIP ON GROWTH
description: AN increasing number of towns are calling a halt to growth until they can strengthen their zoning controls.

title: PARAMOUNT CENTER'S PROMINENCE RISING
description: IT has been not quite five years since the 56-year-old movie palace known as the Paramount Theater in Peekskill entered its new incarnation as the Paramount Center for the Arts. Since its first season in 1982 with 10 events, the center's schedule has grown to encompass 40 events during the 1986-87 season. Beyond the the growing numbers, however, the center has received increasing countywide recognition as a focal point for cultural activities in the rapidly developing areas of northern Westchester and Putnam County.

title: Telephone Bill Clears Youth Charged in Mother's Death
description: A telephone bill has vindicated a physically handicapped teen-ager jailed for more than a month on charges of beeating his mother to death.

title: LEE WILEY SINGS SHOW TUNES IN A JAZZ SETTING
description: The relationship between jazz and the musical theater has always been surprisingly tentative and edgy. Except for a few composers - notably George Gershwin and Harold Arlen - those who wrote for the musical theater in its heyday had reservations about the treatment that jazz musicians gave to their tunes. They wanted them played straight and sung straight. This despite the fact that almost every major composer of musical comedy got slightly wealthier because at least one of their songs became a favorite of jazz musicians - Richard Rodgers's ''Lover,'' Cole Porter's ''What Is This Thing Called Love?,'' George Gershwin's ''I Got Rhythm,'' Vincent Youmans's ''Tea for Two.'' And it was jazz interpretations that changed ''How High the Moon'' from a pallid ballad to one of the most frequently played of all show tunes.

title: Man Confesses Killing 6 Homosexuals in Atlanta
description: A man charged with six counts of murder in a series of killings of homosexuals has confessed, the police say.

title: ELECTORAL PROCESS IS NOW CHANGED AND CHANGING
description: AFTER decades of relative stability, the way Connecticut chooses and votes for its political candidates is undergoing close scrutiny and some major changes.

title:
DANCE;
'CANTERBURY TALES' IN DANCE
description: REMEMBER when high school English teachers assigned Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales,'' with the admonition to read nothing but the Prologue?

title: Cable TV
description: Two films with cable premieres on Tuesday drew acclaim from Times reviewers. John Binder's raffishly amusing ''Uforia'' (1986) was deemed by Vincent Canby ''the most enjoyable movie of its kind since 'Repo Man' and 'Handle With Care,' both of which it resembles.''

title: METHANOL SERVED AS MOONSHINE TAKES SECOND LIFE
description: A second person has died from drinking toxic wood alcohol passed off as ''moonshine.'' It was the same batch that killed one youth and sickened others at a party here where it was served, the authorities said.

title: A 6TH PRESIDENCY IS FACING FAILURE
description: Both as campaigner and as President, Ronald Reagan has reminded us often of the words of the New England Puritan leader John Winthrop: we are ''as a City set upon a hill, in the open view of all the earth; the eyes of the world are upon us.''

title: HOW ARCHITECT WON A PRIZE
description: THE Princeton architect whose design for India's Indira Gandhi Center for the Arts recently won first prize in a competition in New Delhi almost was disqualified.

title: Photo Classes: Color Vs. Black and White
description: LAST week I went to a meeting of the photography faculty at the school where I teach, and the discussion surprised me. Instead of wrangling over coffee-machine privileges and office politics - the stuff of which faculty-meeting lore is made - we tackled a fundamental issue: has the time come to start teaching color photography to students before they learn black-and-white photography?

title: An Era Ends
description: After more than two decades as one of the bigs of big labor, Victor Gotbaum quit his job last week. In announcing his retirement as executive director of District Council 37, the largest union of New York City workers, Mr. Gotbaum, who turned 65 years old this year, said, ''Some of us hang around too long.''

title: January Wedding For Miss Holland
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Ficks Rowbotham of Dover, Mass., of the engagement of Mrs. Rowbotham's daughter Hillary Ann Holland to Russell Fogarty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Fogarty of Knoxville, Tenn., and Fort Myers, Fla. The wedding is planned for Jan. 17.

title: 'Moderate' Arabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Naive President, Machiavellian Iran
description: Of all the errors and mistaken judgments that contributed to the current crisis in the White House, among the most foolish was the Administration's belief was that it was dealing with Iranian ''moderates.''

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''So, while we've been occupied with the Iranian issue over the past two weeks, let's not forget that there are many other issues that concern us.

title: MISCONCEPTIONS ON LENAPE ABOUND
description: AMONG the widely circulated inaccuracies about the Lenape Indians is that there were none left in New Jersey by 1802.

title:
MUSIC;
CHAMBER ORCHESTRA TO MAKE ITS DEBUT
description: THE Wayne Chamber Orchestra, a new group concentrating on works by American composers, will make its debut Friday at 8 P.M. under Murray Colosimo.

title: The Giants Will Fail and Here's Why
description: IN the late 1970's, George and I used to watch the Giants' games from my apartment in Alexandria Bay, N.Y. The Giants were so bad that we actually closed the venetian blinds and turned down the sound so nobody would know we were in there, rather as if we'd just knocked off a Brink's truck and were on the lam. One day George brought along a girl who seemed much too young for him to be dating. I am not, however, a judgmental man and as all I had to do was steer her to a comfortable chair and mix three vodkas, I didn't think anything about it one way or another.

title: Don't Blame the Japanese
description: Mr. Christopher's article contains a misstatement concerning productivity in the American steel industry: it is that ''worker productivity at the five biggest American steel companies, for example, is almost a third lower than at their Japanese counterparts.''

title: Iowa Tops North Carolina St., 90-89
description: Brad Lohaus hit a free throw with two seconds remaining in overtime today to lift Iowa to a 90-89 victory over North Carolina State in the semifinals of the Great Alaska Shootout.

title: Leslie C. Dearing Plans to Be Wed To James Fleming
description: Leslie Church Dearing and James McVickar Fleming, 1982 graduates of the University of the South, plan to be married Jan. 10.

title: THE RACCOON MYSTERY: SURVIVAL IN THE SUBURBS
description: Raccoons have always been unwelcome guests in suburbia, bringing a touch of the woods to the land of neatly trimmed shrubs and manicured lawns.

title: DINOSAUR PARK IN TEXAS IS STRUGGLING TO SURVIVE
description: Had he called in a team of marketing consultants, it is quite possible Donald Bean would not have invested his life savings in building a roadside dinosaur park, here between Seven Oaks and Corrigan in the far reaches of East Texas.

title: COMPUTER IS CLASSROOM LINK
description: ALTHOUGH the students in a sociology course at Upsala College here have seen their professor only once since the first day of class in September, they continue to hold class discussions with the professor and take examinations.

title: FINANCE RATES PEAK INTEREST FOR A NEW CAR
description: WITH auto companies advertising seductive interest rates, I've been tempted to take a few test drives. My 1974 Duster may outlast another Connecticut winter, but its odds of survival decrease with every pothole I blunder into.

title: Miss Bressie Wed To Bruce Jackson
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Annette Bressie, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerry Lee Bressie of Oklahoma City, was married to Bruce Carver Jackson, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Jackson of Black Mountain, N.C. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read, minister of the church, and Dr. Jackson, a Baptist minister, officiated.

title: Delaware Advances by 51-17
description: Rich Gannon, the senior quarterback, ran for three touchdowns to lead Delaware into the Division I-AA quarterfinals with a 51-17 victory over William & Mary today.

title: Kuwait Dooms an Iraqi For Attempt to Kill Emir
description: One of five Iraqis charged with plotting to kill the Emir of Kuwait was sentenced to death today by a security court.

title: 'Die Fledermaus' at Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Die Fledermaus,'' by Johannn Strauss, will have its first performance on Thursday.

title: THE ARMY MAY HAVE MATCHED THE GOOSE
description: AN ounce of fine down will still keep a goose - or a person - warmer than the same amount of synthetic fiber, but that may not be true for long. The Army, which has for years investigated new ways to keep human beings warm, thinks it has finally come up with a material that is light and warm enough to replace down in everything from parkas to sleeping bags.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1986
description: THE WORLD

title: Randolph Topples Roxbury, 25-8
description: Matt Nardolillo completed 15 of 22 passes, one for a touchdown, and finished with 205 yards passing to send Randolph to a 25-8 victory over previously unbeaten Roxbury yesterday before 7,500 in Randolph.

title: From Door to Door
description: When the Democrats lost control of the Senate in 1980, the majority leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, obviously had to change the sign at his office door.

title: Kathryn Sloan to Wed A Physician in March
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Sloan of New York and Roxbury, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Kathryn Sloan to Dr. Larry Roth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Roth of Hallandale, Fla. A March wedding is planned.

title: Recent Releases of Video Cassettes
description: Amahl and the Night Visitors By Gian Carlo Menotti. With Teresa Stratas. Philharmonia Orchestra and Ambrosian Opera Chorus conducted by Jesus Lopez-Cobos.

title: Navah Cohen Weds Dr. Gabriel
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York last night Navah Cohen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Cohen of New York, was married to Dr. Gabriel Kaplan, a son of Drs. Ana and Alberto Kaplan of Buenos Aires.

title: CHIANG'S WIDOW, 85, IS STILL A FORCE IN TAIWAN
description: The widow of Chiang Kai-shek, still influential in Nationalist Chinese politics at 85 years old, is back and holding tea parties for selected officials after 11 years in the United States.

title: REAGAN REPORTEDLY SAT IN ON BRIEFINGS BY MEESE
description: Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's chief of staff, attended meetings this week in which Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d presented details about his inquiry into the Iran arms deals, according to Administration officials.

title: RABBITS AND WHAT THEY TELL US
description: I KNOW more rabbits than people in Remsenburg.

title: THOUSANDS OF POLICE BLOCK SEOUL PROTEST
description: The South Korean Government used the largest police mobilization this capital has ever seen today to block a scheduled opposition rally, and by so doing demonstrated both its ability and its determination to stifle dissent.

title: Carelessness on Hunting Trail
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GROWING FERNS INDOORS FOLLOWS OLDS TRADITIONS
description: It doesn't have flowers. It doesn't have edible fruit. Yet the fern is one of the most desirable house plants to grow.

title: FOR CONVENTION CITIES, CAMPAIGN NEARS AN END
description: WHEN New Orleans asked the Democrats the other day to postpone their evaluation visit, there was undisguised glee in Houston and Atlanta, the Louisiana city's main competitors for the 1988 Democratic National Convention. How could New Orleans play host to 20,000 people if it could not get organized enough to handle a 57-member committee, the others asked with mock concern.

title: Tools of The Trade
description: WHILE THE NUM-ber of makeup products needed to create an attractive look has been whittled down, the tools for applying those products are multiplying.

title: THE JOY OF MARRIAGE AND THE FEAR OF IT
description: AT the ripe, middling age of 32, I am, with some fear and trembling, considering embarking upon a second marriage. As I lie in bed long into the night sipping Sleepytime tea and posing to myself the eternal question, ''Should I or shouldn't I?'' I find myself thinking both about marriage in general, its fertile possibilities, its equally fertile liabilities, and also about the marriages I have witnessed over the years.

title: Deborah L. Grzelecki To Wed J. B. Rooney
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Grzelecki of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Lynne Grzelecki to John Brian Rooney, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brendan P. Rooney of Harrison, N.Y. A May 9 wedding is planned. The future bride is a media planner at FCB-Leber Katz Partners, a New York advertising agency.

title: PANEL, FAULTING ROLE OF POLITICS, SEEKS APPOINTIVE SURROGATES
description: Arguing that election to Surrogate's Court in New York State was nothing more than the ''rubber-stamping'' of candidates selected by powerful political leaders, a court-monitoring group urged yesterday that surrogates be appointed.

title: Press Club News
description: If a member of the National Press Club were to report on the event, the story might be headlined: ''Iron Curtain Aide Seeks Press Club Post.''

title: Disability Benefit For Racial 'Fear'
description: AFTER a former city sanitation supervisor in Louisville, Ky., won worker's compensation based on his contention that he was afraid to work with black people, the state declined to pay.

title: NONSMOKING POLICY IN NEW BRITIAN
description: On Oct. 19, the article ''Norwalk Weighs Barring Smokers From Police Jobs'' reported that ''the Norwalk Police Commission is considering making the city the first in the state to require new officers be nonsmokers.'' While I congratulate Norwalk on its efforts, the fact is that New Britain was the first in the state to weigh and adopt this policy.

title: A Fourth 'R' for an Over-the-Hill School
description: THE boarded-up windows and weed-choked yards of vacant schools have become an all-too-common eyesore on the suburban landscape in recent years.

title: LAVA ADDS TO HAWAIIAN LAND
description: An eight-mile river of 2,000-degree lava from Kilauea Volcano poured into the ocean today, shooting up hissing clouds of steam.

title: Emily Cohen Is a Bride
description: Emily Beth Cohen, the daughter of Gerald A. Cohen of Arlington, Wash., and Frances R. Burton of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married yesterday to Thomas Willis Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Van Ness Philip of Claverack, N.Y. Carl Ingraham, a retired county judge, officiated at the Somerset Inn in Troy, Mich. The bride is a freelance television associate director in New York and her husband is a development coordinator for the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City. Both are graduates of Vassar College.

title: The American Wife
description: Ms. Fleming trots out the Harvard-Yale-study statistics one more time, stating, ''If you're female and 30 and white and college educated, you have only a 20 percent chance of ever being wed . . . over 40, you can pretty much forget it.''

title: Sandra K. Davis Is Married
description: Sandra Kimbel Davis, a daughter of Mrs. Michael E. Traphagen of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Arthur Van Bibber Davis of Walnut Creek, Calif., was married at St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park yesterday to Gerhard Rolf Guy Rexroth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Klaus O. Rexroth of Northvale, N.J. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey, rector of St. Mary's, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Very Rev. James R. Leo, dean of the American Cathedral in Paris.

title: SERRA SAINTHOOD IS FACING CRITICISM
description: When Pope John Paul II visits California next year, many Roman Catholics expect him to declare that the Rev. Junipero Serra, a legendary figure in the state's history, was a miracle worker and is a candidate for sainthood.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SERVICE FOR THE DEAD. By Robert A. Anderson. (Arbor House, $16.95.) Robert A. Anderson, a Vietnam veteran whose previous novel, ''Cooks and Bakers,'' was also about the war, competently depicts combat situations, especially when he is patrolling a landscape of booby traps and snipers.

title: From Far And Wide
description: Never before have so many stamps been issued on such a wide variety of themes.

title: Miss Kornreich to Wed Robert Rieger in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Kornreich of Harrison, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Kornreich, to Robert James Rieger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Jerome Rieger of Newburgh, N.Y., and Boca Raton. An April wedding is planned.

title: ABOUT CIVIL WAR ROUND TABLES
description: Thanks for the fine tribute [ ''Reliving the Civil War, With Fervor,'' Nov. 9 ] to The Westchester Civil War Round Table, our comrades in arms to the north. Two points must be clarified: More than 100 such groups exist, not the 50 stated.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: FERRARI DEALER'S HEAVEN
description: MAYBE the traffic on Main Street here does not part for you when you are driving a $69,500 red Ferrari Mondial Cabriolet; it just seems that way.

title: Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn
description: For 87 years, Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn has advanced the social-service mission of the local church with compassion, understanding and concrete assistance. Wherever and whenever there is human need, there must be service.

title: Japanese Methods
description: To the Editor:

title: CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL LOSING REAGAN MAN
description: One of President Reagan's appointees is stepping down from the United States Commission on Civil Rights, saying the agency has ''lost its credibility'' and ''moral strength.''

title: Shiites in Beirut Close In On Palestinian Quarter
description: Shiite Moslem forces closed in on the Palestinian district of Shatila today behind a barrage of tank fire. Guerrillas burst from burning shacks and hurled grenades in last-ditch attempts to stem the onslaught.

title: RISING LAKE ERIE ALARMS BEACHFRONT RESIDENTS
description: For years after E. David Rebmann moved into his wood-frame cottage in 1970, he could watch the sunset from the sandy beach that stretched for 200 feet from his back door to Lake Erie.

title: Bird Watching in Israel, Butterfly Chasing in French Guiana
description: In Eilat, Gathering of Nature Lovers When spring comes to Israel in 1987, the Third World Conference on Birds of Prey will be held in Eilat, the country's southernmost town. Situated at the head of the Gulf of Aqaba, Eilat lies along a migration route where last spring more than a million birds of prey belonging to 30 species were counted - among them steppe eagles, steppe buzzards and black kites, not to mention migrating waders and water birds and local desert birds. For five days beginning March 22, the conference will offer a variety of lectures, workshops and field trips, as well as a festival featuring competitions in photography, painting, drawing, children's paintings and motion pictures devoted to birds of prey.

title: AN UPBEAT M.T.A. WANTS $8.3 BILLION
description: IN seeking approval for an $8 billion, five-year plan to rebuild the subways and commuter railroads, officials of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority had the benefit of a compelling argument: Without the money, parts of the system would soon collapse. The evidence - delays, derailments, decay - was all too apparent.

title: DEVELOPMENT CONFRONTS A 'SLEEPER': SHELTER ISLAND
description: BECAUSE of its relative inaccessibility, Shelter Island has not faced the extensive pressures for development that neighboring towns on the East End have had to cope with in the last decade. The 2,200 year-round residents of the town, which can be reached only by ferry from Greenport and Sag Harbor, have worked to maintain a low profile.

title: Webster Starts to Face the Pressure
description: He was driving across the border the other day, he said, on the way home to Windsor, Ontario, still pinching himself, already scheming plans for his Rangers, and opening night, and who he would play and what he would say to his new team. Then he reached the customs booth. The inspector in the booth looked at him and then at the newspaper he had been reading. Again, he looked up and down and the inspector pointed at the newspaper and said, ''Hey, you're this guy. You're Tom Webster.''

title:
DINING OUT;
COPING WITH A COPIOUS MENU
description: WORD spreads quickly when changes take place at a well-known and well-respected restaurant, particularly when a good chef is involved.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Artificial Ponds Create 'Waterfront' Lots
description: WITH only a limited amount of land still available along the Island's waterfront, builders have found an ingenious way to get the next best thing.

title: Time for Reappraisal
description: To the Editor:

title: LABOR JOINS DRIVE TO CUT THE COST OF STAYING WELL
description: LABOR officials are - reluctantly - out stumping with an increasingly familiar message: If health care costs are ever to be contained, ways must be found to cut expenses, even if it means sacrificing some employee benefits.

title: Barbara Wright Wed To R. Franklin Gay Jr.
description: Barbara Wright, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Wright of High Point, N.C., was married there yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the Friends Meeting House to R. Franklin Gay Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gay, also of High Point.

title: HALPIN EYED FOR TOP POST IN SUFFOLK
description: WHILE Republicans are still maneuvering over a candidate for Suffolk County Executive next year, Dominic J. Baranello, the Suffolk Democratic Leader, is supporting Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin of Lindenhurst for the nomination, according to Democratic leaders and others.

title: OPINION: DOES AN END JUSTIFY THE MEANS
description: HISTORY has demonstrated too often that the end does not always justify the means when it comes to ''protecting society,'' but this lesson has apparently been ignored.

title: Wall St. Specialists
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Combias Is Engaged
description: Lorie Ann Combias, a sales associate at Polo/Ralph Lauren in New York, and Thomas Gregory Holevas, an assistant vice president at First Boston Inc. in New York, plan to be married in February.

title: Opting for a Game
description: It is often thought, by those with no inclination or talent for them, that bridge and other intellectual games are a waste of time, of no value for the serious business of life. But there is now evidence to the contrary.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MEMOIRS OF FREDERIC MISTRAL. Translated by George Wickes. (New Directions, Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $10.95.) Frederic Mistral (1830-1914) is now almost unknown in America, but he was the bard of the French Midi in his own time.

title: Miss Tyler and Glenn Dulmage Are Wed in Capital
description: The marriage of Carol Lorraine Tyler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Wayne Tyler Jr. of Washington, to Glenn Bradbury Dulmage, a son of Fae Neavling Dulmage of Palm Beach, Fla., and Donald B. Dulmage of Millstone, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. William Hague performed the ceremony at Christ Epsicopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SWEEPING COBWEBS OUT OF MUSEUMS
description: SO PERSUASIVE have museum collections become as arbiters of excellence that the evolution of what has come to be perceived as ''museum quality'' has all but been forgotten.

title: MASSACHUSETTS AUDITOR FINDS WASTE IN MOTOR VEHICLE OFFICE
description: The Registry of Motor Vehicles is wasting many inspectors on clerical tasks instead of assigning them to keep highways safe because the agency does not have enough personnel, according to the state Auditor, John Finnegan.

title: BOOK OFERS ADVICE FOR THE 'SECURE' EXECUTIVE
description: A SLIM, gray hard-cover book titled ''The Secure Executive'' offers advice to those in the business world that many have been waiting to hear, according to the book's author, Steve Kahn of Greenwich.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A special train-bus excursion to a New York State ski resort will be operated by NJ Transit in January.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
Dix Hills
description: ON weekdays, when the tides of work and school have emptied the spacious neighborhoods of Dix Hills, tradesmen and landscapers roll in on wide roads to touch up houses and lawns that are already painstakingly tended.

title: Four Corners
description: To the Editor: In the Oct. 26 Letters to the Editor column, a reader stated the need for a good map of the Four Corners area of the Southwest. Such a map, entitled ''Indian Country,'' is published by the Automobile Club of Southern California.

title: A New Twist On Farmers' Debt
description: In the boom time of the late 1970s, farmers and banks bet on land, the former buying more of it with loans from the latter. Then the value of farmland dropped sharply, until many acres were worth far less than the debts owed on them. Crop prices fell, too, so that many farmers had neither enough cash to keep up their loan payments nor enough collateral to reimburse a bank that foreclosed. Despite huge Government aid programs, both farmers and banks have been going out of business at a record rate.

title: Topics: Tax/Attacks; Heavy Traffic
description: The morale of the city's 1,830 traffic enforcement agents has plummeted with high costs in professionalism and productivity. The turnover rate is 30 percent.

title: Headliners; A Second Trial
description: The California grand jury that indicted Booker T. Hillery Jr. on murder charges 24 years ago was empaneled with the intention of assembling ''a group of people of the better type,'' according to the Monterey County judge who selected its members. None of the jurors was black, and Mr. Hillery, who is, took exception.

title: METAMORPHOSIS OF A DEEJAY
description: ''I'M ALWAYS collecting material in the back of my head,'' Vin Scelsa said as he wheeled his Volvo around the scattered remains of Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City and down a back road toward Bayonne, his hometown.

title: COURT CHALLENGED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: How Massachusetts courts handle domestic violence cases has come under scrutiny because of assertions that a state court harrassed and failed to protect a battered woman whose husband has been charged with her murder.

title: CHRISTMASES PAST ENLIVEN PRESENT HOLIDAY SEASON
description: CHRISTMASES past will be the focus of holiday activities this month at historic sites and museums throughout the state. Candlelight tours, period music, special exhibitions and seasonal decorations will reflect 18th- and 19th-century traditions.

title: Public Horse-Trading
description: 'Even when free of venality, political horse-trading over contracts is a poor way to conduct the public's business.' State-City Commission on Integrity in Government, recommending the establishment of consistent contract procedures throughout the city government.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ENTERTAINERS AND THE ENTERTAINED: Essays on Theater, Film and Television. By John Houseman. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A meaty supplement to three volumes of autobiography produced by this veteran director, writer, producer and actor, ''Entertainers and the Entertained'' represents 40 years of thought from a man who avoided dilettantism by sheer force of talent.

title: MODERATE TO A FAULT
description: IKE His Life and Times. By Piers Brendon. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $21.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CONSTRUCTIVE PRAISE
description: The student body at Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose has reason to be proud of itself. A Westchester construction company recently sent a letter to School Superintendent Charles V. Eible and the Board of Education commending the student body and administration on the absence of vandalism during a $900,000 renovation of the school's outdoor athletic complex.

title: DEMAND UP FOR THE CLAM IN THE NORTH
description: For the last 17 years Marian Havlik has probed the muddy bottom of the upper Mississippi River in search of the elusive Higgins' Eye, a tight-lipped creature about the size of a squashed tennis ball.

title: U.S. Exceeds Limit Set in 1979 Arms Treaty
description: President Reagan said six months ago that he would do it, and last week he did.

title: RECYCLE UNWANTED MAIL-ORDER CATALOGUES
description: I would like to comment on the article ''Buying at Home Is Really No Bargain,'' [ Opinion page, Nov. 9 ] . All of those catalogues have one very important use in our household: recycling.

title: Elmont Offense Routs Lynbrook
description: The Elmont Spartans (8-2) captured the Nassau County Conference 3 championship with a 15-0 victory over the previously undefeated Lynbrook Owls (9-1).

title: BOOK CATERS TO BICYLCLING ENTHUSIASTS
description: ONE day in 1869, a Yale student named Karl Kron was riding down Dwight Street in New Haven on a ''bone shaker'' - a bicycle with clattering, wooden-spokewheels. Mr. Kron and his contraption startled a horse, which reared and bruised itself on the post to which it was hitched. Thus Mr. Kron caused the first horse-cycle accident recorded in this country and earned himself a paragraph in the Connecticut Bicycle Book.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston;
A 1930 Facade But 1986 Offices
description: THIS city's first major office condominium, the 24-story Landmark, is to open in the financial district on Dec. 11. Fitted for computer and telecommunication systems, the ziggurat structure with a three-story gold-tile roof is also New England's largest restoration, according to Antonia Pollak, director of the Boston Preservation Alliance.

title: Wall Street Week: More Damage, More Merger Bids
description: Wall Street waited last week for word of more scandal, assessed its losses from tumbling prices in takeover-related stocks, then picked up where it left off with a new spate of merger bids. Although prosecutors did not drop any new names, sources said that Dennis B. Levine and other investment bankers involved in the continuing insider-trading scandal had secretly recorded conversations and that more charges would result. Mr. Levine, a former executive at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was arrested in May.

title: SENOR URIAH HEEP
