description: TORQUEMADA By Benito Perez Galdos. Translated by Frances M.Lopez-Morillas. 569 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $25.

title: EFFORT TO EASE AIRPORT DELAYS FOCUSES ON NEWARK
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is stepping up its campaign against air traffic delays, paying special attention to Newark International Airport, which has the nation's worst record for on-time flights.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CHORAL GROUPS ACTIVE The University Glee Club of New York City, one of the oldest men's choral groups in the country, will appear at the John Harms Center in Englewood Friday evening; the next night, the Boys Choir of Harlem will perform at Snug Harbor's Veterans Memorial Hall, 1000 Richmond Avenue, Staten Island.

title:
INVESTING;
SELLING THE CELTICS
description: In September 1983, three businessmen - Don F. Gaston, Paul R. Dupee Jr. and Alan N. Cohen -paid $19 million to buy the Boston Celtics basketball team. This week, eager public investors are expected to price the franchise at about $130 million in the initial offering of units in a master limited partnership that will own the Celtics. Such a windfall for the team's current owners, say some skeptics, owes less to real appreciation in the team's value than to Wall Street's packaging skill.

title: Philadelphia Opera Schedule
description: The Philadelphia Opera has announced that Gounod's ''Romeo et Juliette'' will replace Boito's ''Mefistofele'' as the last production of the 1986-87 season, because of problems with artists' schedules.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
COMMON PERIWINKLE
description: Littorina littorea Size: To about one inch.

title: SOLVING THE PROBLEM OF MRS. VS. MS.
description: I enjoyed the ''Call Me Mrs., Please!'' article [ Opinion page, Oct. 19 ] and agree on most aspects of this subject.

title: PREVENTIVE DETENTION: PROPOSAL STIRS DEBATE
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S call, in his State of the State address last January, for denying bail to dangerous repeat offenders has inspired an Assembly bill that is raising an emotional debate over constitutional rights.

title: A GUSTO FOR DUMBO AND BALANCHINE
description: THE COMPLETE PROSE OF MARIANNE MOORE Edited, and with an introduction, by Patricia C. Willis. 723 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $24.95.

title: Wagner Leads Early, Tops Jackson for P.S.A.L. Title
description: The Public Schools Athletic League season came full circle yesterday as Susan Wagner defeated Andrew Jackson, 14-8, in the championship game at Midwood Field.

title: Past, Present and Future in the Iran Arms Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE THE SILENT NIGHT IS STILL HOLY
description: As night falls, there are lights everywhere you look, lights and trees and stars. Single white candles burn in each small windowpane of the old stone buildings on Church Street; a procession of hundreds of white-lighted Christmas trees marches down Main Street and across the Hill-to-Hill Bridge. Multipointed parchment stars, illuminated from within, hang over porches, and a white giant - more than 80 feet high at the longest of its eight points - glimmers across the valley from South Mountain. Christmas has come to Christmas City U.S.A., Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Syria Calls For Defeat of P.L.O.
description: In the Arab world, the United States and Israel are often identified as the worst enemies of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Last week, however, Syria once again declared itself an enemy of the P.L.O. and asked its allies among Lebanese leftists to crush the Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon.

title: Equal Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid the Plenty, Lives in Search of Sustenance
description: The Formica counter was so white, the apples so red, the veins in her hand as she touched one so blue, that it might have been some modern still life: three apples, one elderly woman, the 27th of the month.

title: CHICAGO DOES ITS JOB-HUNTING AT HOME
description: GUERNSEY Dell, a manufacturer of chocolate chips and other ice cream flavorings, will never rival General Motors' Saturn project in size. Nevertheless, when Chicago officials learned that the family-owned company might move to Georgia or New Mexico because it needed a larger facility, they leaped into action.

title: William Mulford Cooper, Film Maker, Exchanges Vows With Kelly Lee
description: Kelly Lee Dixon, a daughter of Gen. Robert James Dixon, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Dixon of San Antonio, was married yesterday to William Mulford Cooper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Cooper of Paris. The Very Rev. James Leo, dean of the American Cathedral in Paris, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel at Columbia University's Harriman Homestead in Arden, N.Y.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A TIME capsule that will be sealed for 100 years will be buried in a specially designed plaza on the banks of the Cohansey River when Bridgeton winds down its yearlong 300th birthday celebration.

title: Lucking Out On Homework
description: Besides running into a favorite customer - a player who habitually tanks against you - the biggest boon in a tournament that finds you somewhat off form is an opponent who unwittingly lets you play a sharp opening line for which you have done your homework.

title: Oil Drilling Urged In Arctic Refuge
description: Conservationists and the Reagan Administration began girding themselves last week for another great battle, this one over whether to allow oil drilling on a coastal plain in the 19-million-acre Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The Interior Department, in a draft report made public last week, has tentatively recommended such drilling.

title: EWING, KNICKS STUMBLE
description: Patrick Ewing has taken numerous shots to decide important games. Yet none may have had more ramifications than the free throw that bounced harmlessly off the back of the rim in the waning seconds yesterday afternoon.

title: RISING COSTS FOR HOMELESS CITED AS BOARD VIEWS BUDGET
description: The cost of housing Westchester's growing homeless population loomed as a major preoccupation last week for county legislators seeking ways to trim a proposed $744.4 million budget for 1987 that could mean a 10.6 percent increase in taxes.

title: Q AND A
description: Condominium Managers Question: The condominium where I live was converted from a rental building under an eviction plan nearly two years ago. A condition of the conversion was that a named firm be retained as the managing agent for the first three years. So far that company has been far from satifactory. It has changed the people responsible for our building at least three times, and there have been substaintial delays in important work. For example, an upgrading of the heating system that was supposed to have been done last summer will be delayed until next, resulting in higher heating bills this winter. Can the managing agent be fired during the period guaranteed in the conversion plan if it mishandles its job? Has any group of owners successfully sued a managing agent for damages when a poor management job cost residents money? . . . J. H., Manhattan

title: The American Wife
description: The article on ''The American Wife'' was fantastic. Now we need the reciprocal ''The American Husband.'' JEAN EMERSEN Seattle

title: Court Rules That Bumpurs Case Should Be Tried
description: The unsettling events surrounding the eviction of Eleanor Bumpurs, who was killed by police gunfire in her Bronx apartment in 1984, will finally be weighed by a jury. Reversing two lower courts, New York State's highest tribunal ruled last week that Officer Stephen Sullivan, before whose gun Mrs. Bumpurs fell, should stand trial on manslaughter charges.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: Although Bridgeton has a specially designed plaza in which to bury a time capsule so that its site will not be forgotten, the same cannot be said for Vineland, where mystery surrounds a centennial capsule buried in 1961.

title: HIGH COST OF INSURANCE CLOSES SOME ICE RINKS
description: THE elegant pastime of indoor ice skating may be in danger of disappearing in the state, according to the managers of several Connecticut rinks.

title: Deborah A. Auerbach Weds Hunter Reisner
description: Deborah Adele Auerbach, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Auerbach of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Hunter Scott Reisner, a son of Leo Reisner and Patti Reisner, both of New York, were married yesterday. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale Synagogue-Tremont Temple.

title: Testaverde: Winning One For His Family
description: IT was a blustery December afternoon as my fiance and I walked across the overpass leading to the Downtown Athletic Club in Lower Manhattan. You could feel Christmas and winter in the air, but for now the focus of our attention was on the club, where the 1985 Heisman Trophy would soon be presented. The candidates were impressive: Bo Jackson, the favorite, a running back out of Auburn; Chuck Long, a quarterback from Iowa; Lorenzo White, a running back from Michigan State, and Vinny Testaverde, my cousin and the quarterback at Miami.

title: SCHOOL SMOKING BAN DEBATED
description: AFTER six years of permitting students to smoke in a designated area outside Northport Senior High School, the Northport-East Northport Union Free School District is considering a controversial ban on students' smoking on school grounds.

title: BALANCING DIET AND PHILOSOPHY
description: FOR Kimberly Bright, the decision to create a macrobiotic education center in Fairfield County was a natural one. After all, she had been holding classes and cooking macrobiotic meals at her Fairfield home for eight years.

title: SURREALIST BRINGS HOME BACON
description: SALVADOR DALI By Meryle Secrest. Illustrated. 307 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $22.50.

title: HONG KONG MAGNATE GOES BACK TO HIS ROOTS
description: In the days before the Communist takeover in 1949, the merchants of this city were known as the shrewdest nail-tough traders in China. ''No market,'' the old saying went, ''is without Ningbo merchants.''

title: UNUSUAL AND SAVORY CHINESE FARE
description: QUEENS is the Island's Chinatown. The Queens Dumpling House in Rego Park is one to add to the list of small, unpretentious places for serious, well-prepared Cantonese and Sichuan food. It is a restaurant that does not require a knowledge of Chinese for ordering some of the more offbeat specialties.

title: Comings and Goings
description: VINNY TESTAVERDE, the Miami quarterback, has won the Walter Camp Trophy as the outstanding college football player of the year. . . . Carlos Carson, the Kansas City Chiefs' wide receiver who has been suffering from a sprained foot, has been placed on the injured reserve list and will be out for the rest of the season unless the Chiefs make the playoffs. . . . Brett Boggs may seem like somebody's dream of the perfect baseball player, presumably combining the skills of the former American League batting champion, George Brett, and the current champion, Wade Boggs, but there is nothing imaginary about the alliterative little slugger. He is the real newborn son of Wade Boggs and his wife, Deborah. . . . Tyrell Biggs, the 1984 Olympic heavyweight gold medalist from Philadelphia, will fight Renaldo Snipes of Yonkers in a 10-round bout Dec. 12 at Madison Square Garden that will be on the same card as the World Boxing Association heavyweight title bout between Tim Witherspoon, the champion, and Tony Tubbs.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) has received approval to begin a long-awaited study of the medical histories of workers exposed to dioxin at the former Diamond Alkali plant in Newark during the 1950's and 60's.

title: 2. THE ORIGINS OF THE PROBLEM
description: A few things are now clear about the Iranian debacle. We know that the National Security Council was transformed into the President's personal instrument for the conduct of foreign policy. We know that up to $30 million in Iranian payments for American arms was secretly diverted to rebel forces in Nicaragua. And there is hard evidence to suggest that well before the secret deal with Iran, the N.S.C., through the now resigned Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, was aiding and advising contra forces even though Congress had prohibited such assistance.

title: Classical Dance in Print
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Dr. Nathaniel Ross, 82, Psychoanalyst in City
description: Dr. Nathaniel Ross, a psychoanalyst, teacher and author who had been in medical practice in New York for more than 50 years, died Saturday at New York University Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: COMPUTER SYSTEM LINKS ART DEALERS ACROSS U.S.
description: A new electronic system that allows art dealers to view images of artwork for sale on a computer screen at the touch of a button has recently been installed at eight locations across the country.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BLUE-CHECKER CORKER AND ME. By Paul John Radley. (Ticknor & Fields, Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95.) Richard Montgomery Howard (Monte to his mates), the 12-year-old protagonist of this novel set in the fictional Australian town of Boomeroo, brings to mind other likable boy-heroes, most notably Tom Sawyer.

title: NEW HOMES FOUND FOR 2,162 FAMILIES IN MASSACHUSETTS HOMELESS PROGRAM
description: Janeen Morse of Cape Cod and her six children spent five years without a real home, including a year in motels, but they celebrated this Thanksgiving in a home of their own.

title: HIGHLANDS OF THE ALGARVE
description: Portugal is rightly proud of its southern Algarve coastline, a region famed for noble cliffs, smugglers' coves and beaches that are perhaps the sunniest in Europe.

title: Lights, Action, Law
description: While Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was in California the other day, he visited the television set of ''Family Ties'' and met Michael J. Fox. The Government official told the young actor that he had just written an article for the U.C.L.A. Law Review entitled ''Back to the Future,'' after the hit movie in which Mr. Fox starred. As they parted, the actor suggested Mr. Fowler might want to name his next law review article after the next Fox movie, ''Teen Wolf.''

title: SINGAPORE'S NEW BATTLE CRY: KICK THE HABIT
description: From the country that pioneered campaigns to banish spitting and tardiness comes a new drive: to eliminate smoking.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PORTRAIT OF THE ENEMY. By David Chanoff and Doan Van Toai. (Random House, $17.95.) David Chanoff and Doan Van Toai have assembled the recollections of a number of Vietnamese men and women who became involved in the 30-year struggle against the French, the Americans and a succession of United States-supported South Vietnamese governments. Mr. Chanoff's and Mr. Toai's subjects included soldiers and civilians, Communists and non-Communists, committed revolutionaries and nonpolitical Vietnamese who simply tried to survive their country's long ordeal of violence.

title: Trying To Keep Baggage From Going Astray
description: The scenario, though not typical, is common enough to have happened to many air travelers at least once.

title: VIRTUOSO SEEKS OUT HARPSICHORD FANS
description: IGOR KIPNIS of West Redding will go just about anywhere to get people to listen to his harpsichord, an instrument he believes is misunderstood.

title: Beth Tanner, a Bank Officer, Plans To Be the Bride of Peter M. Burrus
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Allen Clarence Tanner of Newport News, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Tanner, to Peter Michael Burrus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Preston Burrus Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 2.

title: REAGAN TELLS U.S. NOT TO OVERLOOK ISSUES BEYOND IRAN
description: President Reagan tried to draw attention from the Iran arms crisis today by urging Americans not to forget that ''there are many other issues that concern us.''

title: DANES - 'SOME OF THE WORLD'S BIG DOUBTERS'
description: WHEN Americans hear about Denmark, I imagine they think of Danish - those pastries that have nothing in common with anything Danish. Some, though, may think of such better Danish products as Hans Christan Andersen, Danish butter, ham and Hamlet and Victor Borge.

title: O'Connor to Set Aside More Time for Priests
description: John Cardinal O'Connor has promised priests in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York that he will be more accessible in 1987, according to a report in the archdiocesan newspaper, Catholic New York.

title: The Mid-80's Parable of the Toys and Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets' wners Support Wohl
description: With the Nets having lost eight straight games and managing just two victories in the first 14 games of the season, Coach Dave Wohl sounded like a man on the verge of quitting following a 119-94 loss to the Mavericks in Dallas Friday night.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Issaquah, Wash.; Preserving The Pastoral
description: ON one side is the future: 3,200 new homes, two office parks worth more than $200 million and the potential for 10,000 jobs. On the other side is the past: a quiet town with barely 6,000 residents, snuggled against the foothills of the Cascades with wide views of uncut forests and 14,410-foot Mount Rainier.

title: Starving the Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
MADISON: PHOTOGRAPHIC 'VISIONS' OF SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY
description: THE exhibition ''Southern Visions'' at the Schering-Plough Corporation here has nothing to do with anything below the Mason-Dixon line. It is a show displaying the efforts of photographers who have lived or worked in southern New Jersey.

title: EVERYTHING IS UNDER CONTROL
description: MISUNDERSTANDING MEDIA By Brian Winston. 419 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.

title: NOW, THE 24-HOUR STYLIST
description: It was 3 o'clock on a Tuesday morning, and the only thing moving on Michigan Avenue was an empty bus pausing at an empty bus stop. But inside a beauty shop next to a bar, across the street from the telephone company and just out of a scene from an Edward Hopper oil-on-canvas, there was the nonstop murmur of blowdryers and the snap of scissors on hair shafts.

title: Bonn, After Trial, Ousts 3 Syrians
description: Syria took another diplomatic whipping last week as a country that helps terrorists plot and execute attacks designed to kill innocent people in public places.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
American Image Makers
description: The art of illustration has advanced light years from Norman Rockwell's sunny visual homilies. Steven Heller, the editor of INNOVATORS OF AMERICAN ILLUSTRATION (Van Nostrand Reinhold, $39.95) and the art director of The New York Times Book Review, has been both catalyst and observer of the rise of new kinds of illustrators working in America.

title: CHEER UP, THE WORLD HAS ENDED
description: GOLDEN DAYS By Carolyn See. 196 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $15.95.

title: Don't Blame The Japanese
description: Having just returned from Japan, where I was privileged to be the only American advertising executive invited to speak at the World Congress II of Chemical Engineering, I was delighted with Robert C. Christopher's article ''Don't Blame the Japanese'' (Oct. 19). It certainly put the problem of United States-Japanese trade relations in perspective.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: So Fine It's Really Stupid It's a relief to know that the ego of the 20th-century painter is no more insistent than that of his 19th-century predecessors. This is Auguste Renoir describing his fellow painter Gustave Courbet in ''The Impressionists: Portraits and Confidences'' (Skira/Rizzoli), by Pascal Bonafoux. I saw a lot of Courbet. He was one of the most astonishing fellows I ever came across. I remember in particular one detail about his exhibition in 1867. He had had a sort of closet built from which he could keep an eye on his exhibition. When the first visitors arrived, he was getting dressed. To miss nothing of the enthusiasm which the public was bound to feel, he went down in a flannel waistcoat, without pausing to slip on the shirt which he was still holding in his hand. And Courbet himself, gazing at his own pictures: ''How fine they are! They look magnificent! So fine that it's really stupid!'' And he kept repeating: ''Yes, it's really stupid!'' It was he again who said, at an exhibition where his work had been hung near the door: ''How foolish, nobody will want to go any further!''

title: Courts to Condos
description: After realizing that tennis requires a lot of elbow room, and for only a few elbows, the owners of a 44,000-square-foot indoor tennis facility in Kinnelon, N.J., are maximizing the space, and their revenues, by creating office condominiums instead. They converted 22 units successfully in a first phase and now they are doing the rest, with 17 additional units to be finished by January.

title: SCENE-STEALING SANDY JOINS ANNIE
description: ''ANNIE,'' that charming musical with book by Thomas Meehan, music by Charles Strouse and lyrics by Martin Charnin, about the trials and tribulations of an orphan living the hard-knock life during the American Depression, is the holiday show at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: TOLKIEN TRILOGY DATES TO 30'S
description: I would like to call to your attention a misstatement that appeared in the article ''Tolkien's Tale of Hobbits Set for Shubert'' [ Oct. 26 ] .

title: PICK A CARD, ANY CARD, EVERY CARD
description: CREDIT card executives are rubbing their hands with glee now that the Christmas season has begun. Americans have always been big spenders at this time of year and more and more of that spending is being done via credit cards.

title: The American Wife
description: Anne Taylor Fleming's perceptive article struck a strong chord within me. The ''postliberation'' values (which might as well be recognized as preliberation values) seem to contradict so much of the learning of our youth. Is my generation doomed to repeat the mistakes of the past? Having missed out on the threat of a draft, are we fated to glorify Rambo? Was the possibility of sexual equality so frightening that we must cling to a past of discrimination? It saddens and frightens me to see the world of my adulthood fight to destroy the ideas and hopes of my childhood. JOHN GLENN 3d Oberlin, Ohio

title: Vermonters Open Hearts to Stanley Moose
description: ONE wonders why nearly 50,000 people journeyed to Shrewsbury, a hamlet in a sparsely settled section of southwestern Vermont, to witness a bull moose's monthlong courtship of a Hereford cow named Jessica.

title: ACTIVISTS ASSESS IMPACE OF RIGHT TO LIFE PARTY
description: IN its almost eight years as a formal political party, the Right to Life Party has had minimal impact on Westchester's elections, according to three activists involved with the abortion issue. The three disagree over why.

title: Abscam Figure Is Freed
description: Former Representative Richard Kelly, Republican of Florida, was released Friday after serving 13 months of a 6- to 18-month sentence for conspiracy and bribery involving the Federal Abscam investigation of political corruption. Mr. Kelly, who is now 63 years old, was among seven members of Congress involved in the investigation, in which covert Government agents posed as sheiks.

title: INDIA AND CARBIDE IN PACT ON ASSETS
description: India and the Union Carbide Corporation arrived at an agreement today that will clear the way for court action on a suit against the company arising from the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster.

title: More Homebuyers Seek Bridge Loans
description: ''MOST people said we did things backwards - that you're supposed to sell your house first and then you have money to look for another one,'' said Anne Owsianik. ''But that seemed backwards to us - selling your house and then rushing to buy something.''

title: MUSIC: VIRGIL THOMSON, 'PILGRIMS AND PIONEERS'
description: VIRGIL THOMSON'S 90th birthday celebration has moved across the East River for the weekend. Friday night, the Brooklyn Philharmonic, playing at the Academy of Music and conducted by Lukas Foss, remembered Mr. Thomson with a performance of his film music, ''Pilgrims and Pioneers.'' The same music was scheduled to be repeated last night with a third performance this afternoon at 2.

title: STUDENTS LEARNING SCIENCE BY EXAMPLE
description: THEY had spent two weeks making the model rockets.

title: CAMPUS RADIO EXPANDS
description: BY next summer, if all goes well at Long Island University's Southampton Campus, FM listeners in eastern Suffolk County will hear public radio network broadcasts for the first time from a Long Island station.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Philipsburg Enticement Spurs Seasonal Sales Philipsburg Manor of Sleepy Hollow Restorations has an event planned for the first evening of holiday shopping hours at its gift shop in North Tarrytown, which start Wednesday and Thursday from 5 to 9 P.M. and continue Dec. 10, 11, 17 and 18, with Christmas-tree decorations faithful to old traditions and free hot mulled cider and cookies.

title: BRITISH ALLIANCE, IN A SLUMP, PONDERS CHALLENGE: CAN THE CENTER TAKE HOLD
description: Some handicappers appraise the prospects of Britain's next election, which is generally expected within a year, with this rough calculation: Margaret Thatcher's chances of leading the Conservatives to a third straight victory look best when the prospects of the politically centrist third force known as the Alliance look worst.

title: BABY'S ENCHANTED LOOM
description: THE INFANT MIND By Richard M. Restak. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $18.95.

title: A SON WRITES ABOUT HIS BLACKLISTED FATHER
description: When Conrad Bromberg was a teen-ager, his father, the Hollywood actor J. Edward Bromberg, was blacklisted. Unable to find a job in films, the elder Mr. Bromberg moved his family from their 15-room house in Beverly Hills back to New York, where he had worked in the theater. Two years later, at age 47, he died of heart disease. Now the younger Mr. Bromberg, a playwright, television and film writer and former actor, has written a play about his father, and about the effect the blacklist had on his family.

title: Soviet Union Renews Its Call For Normal Ties With Albania
description: The Soviet Union today renewed its call for normalized relations with Albania, saying the 25-year-old estrangement of the two Communist nations was not natural.

title: Jacqueline Bikoff Is Married to Dr. Gregory Berk
description: At the Pierre Hotel in New York last night Jacqueline Shereen Bikoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bikoff of Sands Point, L.I., and New York, became the bride of Dr. Gregory Ivan Berk, a son of Beatrice Joy Berk of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Laurence Berk. Rabbi Martin Rosenberg and Cantor Jacob Yaron officiated.

title: RESISTING THE CALL FOR MORE REGULATION
description: THE recent rash of insider trading cases associated with corporate takeovers, culminating in the Securities and Exchange Commission's action against Ivan F. Boesky, has raised the specter of increased Federal regulation of the stock exchanges. Unless further, more-extensive revelations of market abuses are uncovered, however, new regulation seems unnecessary.

title: Recent Releases of Video Cassettes
description: Inside the Third Reich Directed by Marvin J. Chomsky. Embassy Home Entertainment. Five hours (two cassettes). $79.95.

title: CANADA'S LIBERAL CHIEF FACES PARTY TEST TODAY
description: John Turner, who led Canada's Liberal Party to its worst defeat ever in 1984, appeared today to be on the verge of winning a long campaign to retain his job as party leader.

title: CIVIL HEARING APPROVED IN DEATH OF HEIR'S WIFE
description: A Long Island oil heir who has declined for more than a year to cooperate in a police investigation of his estranged wife's slaying must face questions on the killing in a civil suit, a Nassau County judge has ruled.

title: BRITONS FETE FULBRIGHT AND HIS PROGRAM
description: Forty years after starting an international program that spawned 156,000 exchange students, J. William Fulbright has hardly returned here to play the cock-eyed optimist.

title: A BULL MARKET IN PRIVATE FORECASTS
description: WHEN the green masthead on Bob Eggert's newsletter changed to yellow last May, it was not a matter of artistic whimsy. Each month for the last decade, Mr. Eggert has averaged the forecasts of about 50 fellow economists to arrive at something almost antithetical to their diverse profession - a ''consensus'' on how the economy will look a year in the future. When the consensus shifts, so does the color of the masthead of the newsletter, ''Blue Chip Economic Indicators.'' Green is for go, or growth above 3 percent; yellow for caution, or sluggish growth, and red for recession.

title: The American Wife
description: I am frankly sick to death of hearing about the demise of the women's movement.

title: Where Are We Going?
description: The events of recent weeks have to make us wonder, not merely what's happening to the Reagan Administration, but what's happening to America. Where are we going?

title: THE LORD OF LA MANCHA AND HER ABORTION
description: DON QUIXOTE By Kathy Acker. 207 pp. New York: Grove Press. Paper, $7.95.

title: Teen-Agers at Work
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Buyout at The Book Counter
description: No one would expect the merger of two large chains to generate the same regret as the passing of a corner bookstore. But last week's announcement that Barnes & Noble, the country's No. 3 bookseller, was buying B. Dalton, the second-largest, did cause concern.

title: CRIME
description: Two of the more admired current British crime writers have new books: Reginald Hill, with TRAITOR'S BLOOD (Foul Play/Countryman, $16.95), and Robert Barnard, with BODIES (Scribners, $13.95). Both reflect the authors' professionalism; neither is up to their best.

title: LONDON WINTER SALES SPREE
description: Last winter my husband and I happened upon a new remedy for post-holiday slump. Having neglected to secure reservations on a subtropical island or snowy mountaintop resort, we impulsively packed our thermal underwear and gumshoes and on the second day of the New Year, boarded a plane for London. Our plan was to indulge ourselves with a week of theater and sentimental visits to old haunts. Serendipity led us to another cultural experience, the annual winter sales.

title: Vatican Museums
description: To the Editor: I am very pleased that Roberto Suro included information about current exhibitions at the Vatican in ''What's Doing in Rome'' (Travel, Nov. 2). The papacy and its enclave is the oldest of all Western institutions with an unbroken existence for almost 2,000 years.

title: Paradors and Bars
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed June P. Wilson's article on the paradors of Spain (Travel, Oct. 19) since I have stayed in many of them.

title: Noodle Soup, Dry Style
description: IN the soup business, the dry look is in - and Lipton's Cup-a-Soup no longer has a hammerlock on the market. The dehydrated soup sector has been rocked in recent years by explosive growth in Oriental soups swimming with ramen, or Chinese-style noodles.

title: Japanese Methods
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HURLYBURLY' IN MADISON
description: THE NOTES in the ''Hurlyburly'' program - they were written by Paul and Ellen Barry, artistic director and producing director, respectively, of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival - smack of an apologia.

title: Parents and Purple Prose: Let's Give Them A Break
description: IN August, a 13-year-old girl in Tustin, Calif., turned in her parents to the police because they were using drugs. Early this month, a 5-year-old girl in Beacon, N.Y., reported her mother for the same reason. While the course of the second case is not yet known, the first one brought offers for the child's story from at least a dozen movie production companies. The parents in the case have been released in their own recognizance and have agreed to seek counseling. The 13-year-old girl, who was described by the police as ''a little misty-eyed, a little reluctant to do this to her parents,'' was sent to a shelter for abused and abandoned children. When she said she missed her parents desperately, the authorities weighed the possibility of reprisal and then allowed her to go home.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: NOTES OF AN ANATOMIST, by F. Gonzalez-Crussi. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $4.95.) An essayist and a pathology professor at Northwestern University, F. Gonzalez-Crussi ''is something of a Charles Lamb,'' our reviewer, D. J. Enright, said last year. In a collection of essays on the human body - including offerings on embalming, child abuse, twins and male genitalia - Dr. Gonzalez-Crussi ''wears his pathologist's gown with a difference and his learning lightly.'' The pieces ''are essays in the old if not defunct sense of the term. They mix fact with speculation and gravity with humor, are rich in apposite and astounding anecdote and are elegant in expression.'' WHAT'S BRED IN THE BONE, by Robertson Davies. (Elisabeth Sifton/Penguin, $6.95.) Robertson Davies's novel draws a portrait of a wealthy and eccentric Canadian art authority and would-be painter, Francis Cornish, whose secret life as a forger is revealed only after his death. In The Times last year, Michiko Kakutani called the work ''an altogether remarkable - and ornate -creation.'' Penguin has also reissued three Davies novels in a single volume, THE SALTERTON TRILOGY: ''Tempest-Tost,'' ''Leaven of Malice'' and ''A Mixture of Frailties'' ($9.95), all revolving around the inhabitants of the university town of Salterton, Ontario. In these pages in 1955, Stuart Keate said that ''Leaven of Malice,'' about a misleading wedding announcement in the town newspaper, is ''full of zest, wit and urbanity.'' In the last novel, about an unusual inheritance, Mr. Davies is ''lavish with character and laughter, wise and perceptive about life and art,'' Edmund Fuller said here in 1958.

title: Chemical Warfare
description: THE pressure to stay competitive in the National Football League forces many players to violate league rules and their own moral codes by using steroids and other chemical substances, according to a former N.F.L. lineman who says he is writing a book on the subject.

title: CAR-INSURANCE COVERAGE IS CALLED 'THE BEST'
description: Regarding Assembly Speaker Chuck Hardwick's Nov. 9 article on car insurance, we have checked our bills lately and have found that the reforms of 1983 are working.

title: DEMOCRATIC PARTY ETHICS CODE URGED
description: Responding to New York City's corruption scandal, a panel of Democrats has proposed an unprecedented code of ethics for state Democratic Party officials that includes annual financial reports and a party ethics commission.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GORBACHEV: The Path to Power. By Christian Schmidt-Hauer. Translated by Ewald Osers and Chris Rombert. (Salem House, $15.95.) In his first year in office, Mikhail Gorbachev, according to Christian Schmidt-Hauer, the Moscow correspondent for the West German weekly Die Zeit, demonstrated ''an astonishing will to rule.

title: New Jersey Drops A Radon Plan
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection chose a quiet corner of the state when it made plans last spring for disposing of 14,000 drums of radon-contaminated soil. In response, the residents of Vernon Township in Sussex County organized huge rallies, filed suit and promised human roadblocks.

title: The American Wife
description: Ms. Fleming jumps without apparent cause from wifely confessions of infrequent sex to the accusation that many of these wives have only enough ''ego'' to ''brood and nag and withhold sex - the old female game.''

title: FOCUSED ON THE BODY
description: ROMAN NIGHTS And Other Stories. By Pier Paolo Pasolini. Translated by John Shepley. 134 pp. Marlboro, Vt.: The Marlboro Press. $14.95.

title: THIS OTHER EDEN
description: DIVINE LANDSCAPES By Ronald Blythe. Photographs by Edwin Smith. 254 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: Maureen Harrigan Engaged
description: The engagement of Maureen Harrigan and James T. Monaghan, 1984 graduates of St. Michael's College in Winooski, Vt., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Harrigan of Rye, N.Y., and Chatham, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Monaghan of Cumberland, R.I. Miss Harrigan is the production assistant at Stagebill Group Publications in New York. Mr. Monaghan is a credit analyst at the Bank of New England in Providence, R.I.

title: What the Buccaneers of Finance Have Done to the U.S. Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOT PATROL: REACHING BACK FOR NEW IDEAS
description: FOR many years, it was a common punishment to take a police officer out of a radio car and assign him to foot patrol. So when Officer Arthur R. Thode was called in by the Meriden Police Chief, Robert E. Kosienski, and told that he was going to be transferred from a radio cruiser to a foot beat, Officer Thode was bewildered.

title: Through a Tinted Glass, Darkly
description: The campaign against the so-called ''colorization'' of classic black-and-white films seems to be both worthy and popular, like the battle against illiteracy.

title: BROOKLYN COURT UNITS FOCUS ON CRACK
description: In many ways, the trial of Derrick Townsend on charges of possession of crack was like hundreds of others routinely held in the old, crowded Criminal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Saluting 100 Years Of Modern Design
description: New York's newest antiques and decorative-arts bazaar proved to be far more than a merchandising success last weekend. The show, ''Modernism: A Century of Style and Design, 1860-1960,'' attracted 13,000 people in its four-day run, which ended last Sunday. The show offered the largest assemblage of works at a fair from the periods represented -from the vehemently Victorian rococo revival to the sleek plastics of postwar modern.

title: New Post for Stennis
description: As befits a venerable institution approaching its 200th anniversary, the Senate has both working and honorary officers, and the President pro tem is a little of each. The Constitution names the Vice President as President of the Senate, but he is not there often because he can vote only in case of ties.

title: Cable Companies Upgrading Picture
description: Throughout the country, many video fans depend on cable services not merely for programs otherwise unavailable but also for a clear picture. This is true in fringe areas where broadcast signals are extremely weak as well as in cities where off-the-air reception is often hampered by tall buildings. Bouncing off the steel girders of such structures, the signals are reflected as if by mirrors, causing the screen to become populated with squadrons of ghosts.

title: DRIVEN TO MARTYRDOM
description: BEARING THE CROSS Martin Luther King, Jr., and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. By David J. Garrow. 800 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: THEME OF ZULU'S TOUR: SANCTIONS HURT BLACKS
description: The leader of South Africa's Zulus said the ban on many South African imports in a sanctions bill passed by Congress last month was reducing income to black farmers and agricultural workers.

title: 'I BELONG TO THE NONHUMAN'
description: A VOYAGER OUT The Life of Mary Kingsley. By Katherine Frank. Illustrated. 333 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: San Antonio
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Fulbright Feted in London J. William Fulbright, honored in London for the exchange program he founded, had gentle barbs for Britain and the superpowers.

title: Buenos Aires
description: People are always trying to equate Buenos Aires with someplace else, big pieces of it with Paris and Rome, small pieces of it with England. In mood, some neighborhoods and some of the people - taxi drivers, for example, in their monologues on the traffic - also evoke New York. But while it is true that many Europeans immigrated to create this city, it is slowly developing its own personality, which moves between great sophistication and great insecurity.

title: BALANCING THE HIGHEST OFFER AGAINST THE GREATEST GOOD
description: THE scene was not unusual, given the superheated nature of Manhattan development in recent years. Speaker after speaker took the podium in the Board of Estimate Chamber in City Hall last week to criticize a plan for a hotel, offices, a shopping mall and apartments in two towers - one of 67 stories, the other of 60 - on the site of the old New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle.

title: CONFRONTING PHANTOMS
description: WORDS IN COMMOTION And Other Stories. By Tommaso Landolfi. Edited and translated by Kathrine Jason. Introduction by Italo Calvino. 275 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Assessing Taxes For Airspace
description: WINOOSKI, Vt., may be small -its 6,500 residents fill one square mile - but it does not lack big ideas.

title: King's Swan, $13.80, Takes Vosburgh
description: King's Swan, the former claimer who beat Ogygian last spring, rallied after being passed by Love That Mac in the deep stretch to grind out a narrow victory in the $236,400 Vosburgh Stakes yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: THREE CHEERS FOR THE BOWERY GIRL
description: CITY OF WOMEN Sex and Class in New York, 1789-1860. By Christine Stansell. 301 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Belligerence to Follow
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
FITTING THE GARDEN FOR THE LONG WINTER
description: THE Thanksgiving holiday represents the end of the fall harvest and, at least symbolically, the end of the gardening season as well. However, there are a number of last-minute tasks that still can be undertaken, if not already done, weather permitting.

title: MORE SPACE FOR WHEELCHAIRS PROMISED BY BOSTON GARDEN
description: People who use wheelchairs may get improved access to Boston Garden next year through construction of several special platforms in a loge, according to a lawyer for the 62-year-old arena.

title: REBELS IN BURMA SAY RANGOON USES HERBICIDE AGAINST THEM
description: The Burmese Government, under a new opium eradication program, is spraying the crops and villages of a rebellious ethnic minority with an American-supplied herbicide linked to cancer in the United States, according to the rebels.

title: MAPUTO FEELS TIGHTER CRASP FROM PRETORIA
description: The shattered windows of the South African trade mission here have been boarded up, and new white paint has covered the vengeful words, like ''assassinator'' and ''racist,'' scrawled by demonstrators who believe Pretoria caused the plane crash that killed President Samora M. Machel.

title: FROM BRIGHTON TO BILOXI TO BROADWAY
description: Another season, another new Neil Simon play; it has been that way almost without fail since 1961. But ''Broadway Bound,'' which opens at the Broadhurst next Thursday, marks a significant departure both for Mr. Simon and for Gene Saks, the director with whom he has worked for more than two decades. For with ''Broadway Bound,'' Mr. Simon digs deeper and more keenly into his past than ever before, and what he has come up with bears little resemblance to the slapstick farces that have made up so much of his career, or even to the more ambitious recent works.

title: NEW YORK LAWYERS DONATE TIME TO THE NEEDY
description: Rhonda L. Brauer, an associate at a major Wall Street law firm, has spent 150 hours in the last year preparing immigration briefs on behalf of indigent Haitians and other political refugees.

title: Wines From Down Under
description: MAYBE it's because they captured the America's Cup in 1983 and some Americans are intent on getting it back. Or maybe it's because of the success of the movie ''Crocodile Dundee.''

title: STATEWIDE CELEBRATIONS FOR U.S. CONSTITUTION'S 200th BIRTHDAY TAKE SHAPE
description: A MOCK Constitutional Convention and an archeological dig are just two of the ways Connecticut is expected to celebrate the bicentennial of the United States Constitution. Though the celebration is to be held over five years starting in January, some of these events are already under way.

title: IN 24 HOURS, A CHANGED POSITION
description: ON Monday, President Reagan, discussing the growing scandal over arms sales to Iran, said, ''I am not firing anybody.'' On Tuesday, two key officials were gone.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Business Gains in Foreign Trade Zones
description: NEARLY a decade ago, two foreign-trade zones were established in New Jersey, each filled with the promise of promoting sluggish international commerce and local economic development. Since then, however, they have operated quietly and growth, though steady, has been slow.

title: WOOD STOVES FACING CURBS AS POLLUTERS
description: In the war against air pollution the new target is neither the smokestack nor the tailpipe but the chimney.

title: CALL IT FINNLAND?
description: WHITE TOWN DROWSING By Ron Powers. 313 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

title: United Jewish Appeal, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies
description: The family in years past was the source of help in times of trouble. Whether for food and shelter, emotional support, financial assistance or spiritual guidance, we were all taught to look to our own family for sustenance.

title: IRAN ARMS SALE DEFENDANT DEMANDS U.S. APOLOGY
description: One of the defendants on trial in Federal court in New York over the planned sale of arms to Iran said yesterday that he would oppose a dismissal of the charges against him even if the Government asked for it.

title: TESTIMONY IN AUSTRALIA EMBARRASSES THATCHER
description: An admission by the head of Britain's civil service that he misled an Australian court has embarrassed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and exposed an apparent rift in her Cabinet.

title: ECLIPSE OF PHILIPPINE RIGHT MAY HERALD NEW DAY FOR LEFTISTS
description: SATURNINO OCAMPO went partying Thursday night, meeting old friends in Manila in an open way that had been impossible for him as an underground Communist leader during the last 15 years. He had just signed a cease-fire agreement that, among other things, provided safe conduct for the insurgent negotiators he had led and their armed security men, and allowed them to set up offices in Manila.

title: NOURISHING THE SENSES IN LAMBERTVILLE
description: WHERE, under one roof, might you find a hiker's staff inspired by that of Teddy Roosevelt, an assortment of colorful clocks from Japan and a fuzzy hat created by a relative of the seamstress for the Swedish royal family?

title: AS TAX LAW LOOMS, MERGERS TAKE OFF
description: Merger fever returned to Wall Street, ending the brief respite that followed the insider trading scandal involving the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky. The new merger wave is apparently being spurred by the looming tax deadline: Once the new tax laws go into effect on Jan. 1, capital gains will be taxed at a higher rate, so corporations are eager to let shareholders make hay while the 1986 sun shines. Among the deals were these:

title: AVAILABLE CHORUSES AND WHERE TO CALL
description: The following selection of community choruses that perform regularly in the county lists the name of the director, where the chorus is based, how many members there are, the type of music sung, whether auditions are held for prospective members and a telephone number for inquiries.

title: Stratas Makes A Compelling Case For Weill's Songs
description: When Lotte Lenya, Kurt Weill's widow and the foremost exponent of his songs, anointed Teresa Stratas the keeper of the Weill flame, it was a decision that would have a profound effect on the way his music would be perceived and interpreted for years to come.

title: Dance
description: In its earliest days, Ballet Hispanico offered an outpouring of youthful high spirits tempered by the discipline of dancing. In the 16 years since it was founded, however, Ballet Hispanico has also become a repository for interesting new modern dance.

title: OPERA: NEW 'TOSCA' CAST
description: THE tenor Franco Bonisolli, who had been absent from the Metropolitan Opera's roster since a brief engagment some 15 years ago, is currently appearing there in ''Tosca.'' His performance Friday night was credible, but not as distinguished as the European reputation he has built in the meantime seemed to promise.

title: A Commitment To the Futurew
description: The generosity that has supported The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during its last 75 years has grown steadily. Regrettably, so has the need for help.

title: Ms. Estrich Wed To Martin Kaplan
description: The marriage of Susan Estrich, a professor of law at the Harvard Law School, to Martin Kaplan, the vice president of motion picture production at Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, Calif., took place yesterday. Rabbi Samuel Zaitchik performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Swampscott, Mass.

title: PENNSYLVANIA PREPARING TO END ITS CONTROL OF LIQUOR STORES
description: After two years of intensive debate over Pennsylvania's liquor system, lawmakers allowed the 1985-1986 session to end without making decisions concerning the Liquor Control Board, which controls state liquor stores.

title: NEW INTEREST FOCUSES ON INDIAN HERITAGE
description: ALMOST two centuries after most full-blooded Lenape Indians abandoned their native state for friendlier surroundings, New Jersey awakening to this long-ignored facet of its heritage.

title: Next Week; How Can N.F.L. Control   Violence?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Recent Sale
description: Albertson $218,500 90 Branton Place 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; den with skylight, finished basement; taxes $2,000. Dix Hills $186,000 11 Leroy Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old high ranch; central air-conditioning, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $2,700 Levittown $129,000 18 Rock Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; unfinished attic, attached 1-car garage; taxes $2,100 Mineola $220,000 243 Horton Highway 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; central air-conditioning, in-ground poll; taxes $2,300 Syosset $190,000 33 Georgia Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 27-year-old ranch; skylights, fireplace, new kitchen, carport; taxes $2,400 Wading River $194,000 Salt Meadow Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; fireplace, oak floors; taxes $2,300 OTHER AREAS West Milford, N.J. $144,900 107 Princecliff Lake Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, lakefront property; taxes $1,500 Litchfield, Conn. $530,000 East Chestnut Hill Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, cotemporary; brook on property, swimming pool, 22 acres taxes $4,698 Port Chester, N.Y. $335,000 123 Neuton Avenue 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 56-year-old Mediterranean stucco; 2 new kitchens workshop; taxes $3,400

title: The American Wife
description: There is nothing inherently ''prefeminist'' about women's renewed interest in marriage and child-rearing. The fact is, now that women in the 1980's no longer need to preoccupy themselves with gaining access to the realms of power - now they're there - they are pursuing more balanced lives, which include families or careers or, more often, both. KAREN PAGE Brooklyn

title: MEMORIES. BOASTS AND ANALYSES
description: DAILY HOROSCOPE By Dana Gioia. 87 pp. Saint Paul, Minn.: Graywolf Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $8. VICTIMS OF THE LATEST DANCE CRAZE By Cornelius Eady. Illustrated by Susan Micklem. 52 pp. Chicago: Ommation Press. Cloth, $18. Paper, $8. THE SKY AT ASHLAND By Michael Anania. 70 pp. Mt. Kisco, N.Y.: Moyer Bell Limited. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: THE ATHLETE'S LOSING GAME
description: THEY MAY BE BLOODY AND HURT AND losing, down and out today on ice or wood or turf. Yet the professionals of hockey, basketball and football feel fortunate and secure.

title: IRANIAN SAYS IRAQ GOT FOREIGN HELP
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament accused American officials today of lying in an attempt to cover up the growing scandal over secret arms sales to Iran, according to Iran's official Islamic press agency.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The Boesky thing gave Gillette more negotiating room, and they took every inch.'' -Jack Salzman, Goldman, Sachs analyst, on the buyback agreement with Revlon.

title: Governor Spares 5 Inmates'
description: Toney Anaya had promised that no one would be executed while he was Governor of New Mexico. Last week he did his best to avert executions during his successor's term as well.

title: 184 For The Bronx
description: If Manhattan is ground zero for today's construction explosion, one developer is making sure the rest of New York City gets some of the fallout. ''There's a big need in the four boroughs for private housing,'' said Irving Pergament, president of Prestige Properties and Development Company.

title: The Ever-Reigning Gratin
description: IN FRANCE, THERE ARE CERTAIN dishes that never fall from favor, and one of the most loved of all is the classic, humble gratin. As I travel from region to region, the familiar gratin, with its thick, crispy bubbling crust, appears and reappears, as cooks all over France continue to define and redefine a dish that is both thoroughly satisfying and universally appealing.

title:
GARDENING;
FITTING THE GARDEN FOR THE LONG WINTER
description: THE Thanksgiving holiday represents the end of the fall harvest and, at least symbolically, the end of the gardening season as well. However, there are a number of last-minute tasks that still can be undertaken, if not already done, weather permitting.

title: IMAGINATION FINDS WAY INTO MEAT DISHES
description: SERVING huge portions of meat at dinner parties is now as passe as tomato roses or parsley sprigs on the plate. In the interests of taste as well as health and fitness, we are eating more vegetables and less meat. But what meat there is, is being cooked in new and ever more imaginative ways.

title: NEW QUESTIONS RAISED ON PESTICIDE TEMIK IN SUFFOLK WELLS
description: A SCIENTIFIC dispute pitting the Union Carbide Corporation against Wisconsin health officials has raised new questions for residents of eastern Long Island whose drinking water wells are contaminated - or may be contaminated in the future - by the pesticide Temik.

title: Gary Heimberg Planning To Wed Amy E. Abrams
description: Announcement has been made by Susan Abrams of Elkins Park, Pa., and Neal Abrams of Jenkintown, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Amy Ellen Abrams to Gary Alan Heimberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Heimberg of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: CAN LOTUS MAKE JAPANESE EXECUTIVES LOVE PC'S?
description: JAPAN is the land of robot-run factories, software-controlled bullet trains and buildings like the Honda headquarters here, where computers track the movements of executives from office to conference room, automatically routing their calls to the nearest telephone.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 30, 1986
description: Fiction

title: LEARNING TO TAKE IT EASY
description: I HAD been over the North Fork so many times since I became a Long Islander that I thought this trip would be a breeze: from Baldwin take Merrick Road east through Freeport to the Meadowbrook to the Southern State to the Sagtikos to the Expressway to Riverhead and then to Route 25, all the way to the Fork; what's the problem?

title: PANEL ON BLACKS LABORS ON ADVICE FOR CUOMO
description: One year after Governor Cuomo appointed his Advisory Committee on Black Affairs, the group is making its first recommendations as they hope Mr. Cuomo will be especially sensitive to the concerns of blacks.

title: STUDY RECOMMENDS STEPS TO PROTECT OZONE LAYER
description: An environmental policy research center recommended today that steps be taken to reduce significantly the world's emissions of chlorofluorocarbons, which damage the atmosphere's ozone layer.

title: Jennifer Cohen Marries
description: Jennifer Beth Cohen, an associate at the New York law firm of Paul Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, was married at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York last evening to Steven Jeff Goldstein, a vice president and a partner of Saga Communications in New York. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Abbott Cohen of New York, and the bridegroom the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Goldstein of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Crane Kills Film Worker
description: A 30-ton crane plunged through the movable flooring of a Universal Studios sound stage Friday night, hurling a man to his death and slightly injuring another, the authorities said.

title: STATE INQUIRY INTO PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR TO RESUME
description: A state investigation of the Staten Island Public Administrator's office, stalled by a legal challenge, will resume under a judge's supervision.

title: An Urban Barn
description: LOFT BUILDINGS ARE USUALLY FOUND IN the grittiest sections of Manhattan. Built in the 19th century as warehouses, factories or sweatshops, their bulky facades and voluminous interiors shaped the hub of New York's commercial districts.

title: U.S. Alleges a Mafia Plot to Pick Teamsters Leader
description: Those who contend that the teamsters union has powerful ties to organized crime got new support for their case last week.

title: DAY BY DAY: THE U.S. ACCOUNT OF THE IVESTIGATION
description: The controversy over the Reagan Administration's secret sale of arms to Iran has increased with the disclosure that payments were diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels. Here are recent events in the investigation of the arms deal, as described by the Justice Department and Administration officials. Nov. 20 - Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and an aide review Administration testimony prepared for Congress about the Iran deal and notice gaps in the statements. Mr. Meese decides to seek an investigation to sort out the discrepancies.

title: FOR NEW MILFORD ILLUSTRATOR, SUCCESS MEANS KEEPING BUSY
description: GROWING up in New York City 40 years ago, Robert Giusti learned the techniques of graphic design at his father's knee, a situation that, while convenient, was not without its drawbacks.

title: Art Deco Touches
description: North Avenue is a major corridor in New Rochelle, N.Y., connecting the offices downtown and the residential areas to the north. But in the wake of recent downtown development, the route has become ''old, tired and in need of a bolstering,'' according to John L. Heller, the city's Commissioner of Development.

title: THE COORS BOYS STICK TO BUSINESS
description: WILLIAM AND JOSEPH COORS, the outspoken multimillionaire brothers who run one of the nation's largest brewing companies, seem to have a talent for igniting controversy.

title: Gay L. Hutto Engaged To William D. Greiter
description: Gay Lynn Hutto, a corporate associate at the Philadelphia law firm of Pepper Hamilton & Scheetz, and William Daly Greiter, the assistant to the president of Amev Holdings Inc. in New York, plan to be married Jan. 24.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY PLAYS WORK BY STEPHAN
description: THE ensemble known as Music Today, under the direction of Gerard Schwarz, began its Wednesday night program at the Merkin Concert Hall with music of 75 years ago - Rudi Stephan's ''Music for Seven Stringed Instruments.'' Stephan was one of several promising composers killed in what was then called ''the Great War'' - a generation that, as the poet Wilfred Owen observed, died like cattle.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SCUBA FOR DISABLED
description: SCUBA diving for the disabled may sound like a radical idea, but according to Dr. Ernie Feleppa, a master instructor for the Professional Association of Diving Instructors and education director for the Rye-based Scuba Sport Rites Club, the sport is actually well-suited for those with certain physical handicaps. In the water, Dr. Feleppa said, paralyzed legs become ''almost like a fishtail,'' hearing impairments are virtually meaningless and even blind people can ''enjoy the tactile sensation of the flora and fauna'' providing that they dive, for safety reasons, with a sighted partner.

title: DALAI LAMA'S A HIT AT TIBETAN FAIR
description: The goods ranged from goat-hair scarves (khati) and yak-butter lamps (choekung) to dharma buttons and copies of the official Dalai Lama comic book.

title: FATHER IS A PUZZLE TO HIS CHILDREN
description: MY children, I have been told, don't know me.

title: I AM LAPIDARY BUT NOT ERISTIC WHEN I USE BIG WORDS
description: ONE day in May I found on my desk my column, clipped from that morning's Washington Post, a red arrow - courtesy of my secretary - pointing to a footnote underneath the column. It read ''ERISTIC: (i ris/ tik) adj [ Gr. eristikos, d. erizein, to strive, dispute d. eris, strife ] of or provoking controversy, or given to sophistical argument and specious reasoning.'' I looked up to the corresponding asterisk in the text, and there saw my sentence, ''The action by Judge Robert Carter [ in fining the National Conference of Catholic Bishops for contempt ] has brought out a lot of smiles in judicial political circles (as a rule, you don't step up and fine the Catholic Church - or the Protestant, or Jewish churches - for failure to comply with eristic complaints.'' (The Abortion Rights Mobilization was suing to deny the bishops their tax deductibility, to which end it had persuaded the judge to subpoena the bishops' internal memos on abortion.) Meg Greenfield (The Post's editorial page editor) was rapping me on the knuckles, a quite unusual public reproach: I couldn't remember when last she had thought to help the readers of The Post to understand unusual words, however much time she needs to spend explaining unusual editorial positions. Dear Meg, I thought. The instincts of the Jewish mother just took over this time.

title: WHAT MAKES 'FLEDERMAUS' FUNNY
description: We Americans are going to have another try at ''Die Fledermaus'' next Thursday. It's not something we do very well these days - we don't handle its Middle European humor very deftly - so it will be interesting to see how the Metropolitan Opera's new production fares.

title: Topics: Tax/Attacks; Fiscal Footnote
description: A new report from the Treasury knocks the idea of a flat income tax -a simple single rate for all taxpayers. That's not surprising.

title: HOLLYWOOD EPITOME OF STYLE
description: Cary Grant, the dashing leading man who was one of Hollywood's biggest stars, died here late Saturday night in a hospital emergency room, his longtime attorney told a radio reporter early today. He was 82 years old.

title: RCA FIGHTS NAVY OVER AEGIS
description: THE Navy and a South Jersey company are locked in a dispute over competition in the multibillion-dollar Aegis ship-defense program.

title: Operation Not-So-Staunch
description: OPERATION STAUNCH'' has been the name of the Reagan Administration's policy, for the past two years, to deny arms to Iran. Staunch is a verb meaning ''to stop a flow,'' rooted in the Latin stagnare; water that has stopped flowing becomes stagnant.

title: JEWISH GROUP VOTES FOR SOUTH AFRICA DIVESTITURE
description: The Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America has called for all its members to divest themselves of their interests in all companies that do business in South Africa and do not comply with voluntary principles for involvement there.

title: Court Cuts Settlement In a Suit Against U.S.
description: An appeals court has cut in half a $6.3 million judgment against the Federal Government in a malpractice case involving the birth of a disabled child at an Army hospital in Tacoma, Wash.

title: MAN THE MESS MAKER
description: THE LAST EXTINCTION Edited by Les Kaufman and Kenneth Mallory. Illustrated. 208 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The New England Aquarium/ The MIT Press. $16.95.

title: 2,500-YEAR-OLD EGYPTIAN RETURNS TO BOSTON HOME
description: Padi, a 2,500-year-old mummy, has been returned to his home with shining teeth, restrung beads and his head back on.

title: CHARITIES SHORTHANDED IN SEASON OF GIVING
description: THE help-wanted list for volunteer workers is virtually as long as the list of social service agencies in the state.

title: Biographical Boredom
description: THEY SAY FRANK Sinatra is cross as a bear about having an unflattering best seller written about him, and I don't blame him. Kitty Kelley, the book's author, was originally going to write that book about me.

title: ON L.I., POCKETS OF HUNGRY PERSIST IN MIDST OF AFFLUENCE
description: ''I always have trouble feeding my children from the 15th of the month on. When you're out of money, there's the churches. I'll eat a meal there once or twice a week and take home food for the kids.'' - Denise J., a Wyandanch mother of two.

title: A JITTERY TUNISIA CRACKING DOWN ON DISSENT
description: Ahmed Mestiri, the leading political opponent of the Government of President Habib Bourguiba, was serene as he talked of how his political future appeared to be dead.

title: CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE URGE ACTION ON WASTE
description: The following is a statement on solid-waste disposal in Westchester County as propounded and ratified by eight of the county's Chambers of Commerce:

title: ATTRACTIVE EFFECT IN THE CAPTIAL
description: ONCE you pass the lively bar of Spencer's in Hartford and descend the stairs to the restaurant, you enter a fin de siecle world of frosted glass panels, ornate picture frames and well-napped, spaciously arranged tables. The effect is quietly romantic, evoking expectations of a leisurely, satisfying meal. Good service by an attentive, trained staff and a small but well-rounded menu enhance this first impression.

title: Ms. Adler to Wed A Fellow Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Adler of Riverside, Pa., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Cheryl Robin Adler to William J. Natbony, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Natbony of Boca Raton, Fla., and New York. The wedding is planned for May.

title: CHINA IS INVITED TO KIBITZ IN THE ARMS GAME
description: JUST days after President Reagan gave a final handshake to the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Reykjavik, Soviet and American officials hurried to give their versions to Chinese leaders.

title: COURIERS HELP PROVIDE BANKLESS BANKING
description: A COURIER service that allows customers to do their banking without having to go to the bank was started for one reason : survival in a highly competitive industry.

title:
FOCUS: Minneapolis;
Pumping New Life Into a Mall
description: BUSINESS and political leaders here are weighing bold steps to revive the Nicollet Mall, the pioneering eight-block pedestrian shopping plaza that saved downtown retailing in the 1960's and has fallen on hard times.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Games Be Played On Artificial Turf?
description: There are two things wrong with artificial turf. First, this season has provided adequate proof that drastic measures need to be taken to reduce the number of injuries in the National Football League. Injuries not only undermine the quality of the game, they also present a moral question for the football fan. Can we justify allowing human beings to be routinely mauled purely for the sake of entertainment? Incidental injury is expected in any contact sport, but injuries have now become a part of the game. Obviously, eliminating artificial turf will not solve the problem, but since there is ample evidence that the turf contributes to injuries, it would be an important first step.

title: New York Vs. London
description: ''W hen you're in London, you think that it is the capital of the musical world, that there are more high-quality concerts taking place than anywhere else in the world,'' the flutist Judith Pearce said recently. ''And then you come to New York and realize that this isn't neccessarily true.''

title: AFTER SHOW, SPOTLIGHT'S ON AUDIENCE
description: WAS this play ever produced on Broadway and how long did it run?

title: Rangers Tied in Debut for Webster
description: Just 16 seconds into the game, Jan Erixon shoved his elbow into Mario Lemieux's face. Later Lemieux struck his stick against Erixon's back. Phil Esposito had promised a return to an old-fashioned style of hockey with Tom Webster as the Rangers' coach, and that's what the Rangers delivered in Webster's debut tonight.

title: Redskins Show New Character
description: SOMETHING'S going on here. Has been for a couple of weeks. It's the Redskins.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MANY WATERS By Madeleine L'Engle. 310 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Community Service Society of New York
description: No one should be homeless. But to be a homeless family with a disabled child is to bear a burden few of us can fathom.

title:
GARDENING;
FITTING THE GARDEN FOR THE LONG WINTER
description: THE Thanksgiving holiday represents the end of the fall harvest and, at least symbolically, the end of the gardening season as well. However, there are a number of last-minute tasks that still can be undertaken, if not already done, weather permitting.

title: Wife of Rutgers Student Dies In University Dormitory Fire
description: A woman died early today in a fire in a Rutgers University dormitory that was apparently caused by faulty wiring in a lamp, the authorities said.

title: Monica Sieger Is Bride Of Nicholas Dombalis
description: Monica Sieger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pablo Sieger of Bogota, Colombia, was married there yesterday to Nicholas Constantine Dombalis, a son of the Very Rev. and Mrs. Constantine Dombalis of Richmond. The bridegroom's father, who is the dean of the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of Virginia in Richmond, and the Rev. Dr. Francis Wehri, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of Colegio San Carlos in Bogota, performed the ceremony at Santos Apostoles Church.

title: ONE HOUSEHOLD'S PROBLEMS VIEWED IN LIGHT OF HOMELESS
description: I MOVED recently, from a nice home in Ossining to a nicer home in Ardsley. I liked this house the moment I saw it; it is light, bright, airy and has two bathrooms, as opposed to the one we suffered with before. Still, it is not my dream house: The bedrooms are small, the family room won out over its use as a dining room and there are bugs in the basement.

title: Stacy Grier King And Hardin Fox To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Stacy Grier King to Hardin Andrew Fox, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Coburn Fox of Champaign, Ill., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Austin King of Riverside, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: EVIDENCE POINTS TO BIG SAUDI ROLE IN IRANIAN AND CONTRA ARMS DEALS
description: Emerging evidence shows a significant Saudi Arabian role not only in secret Iranian purchases of arms but also in the supply of military equipment to the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: 12 Die in Sri Lanka Clashes
description: Two policemen were killed today and seven others wounded when Tamil separatist guerrillas ambushed a police patrol in northern Sri Lanka, the Government said. On Friday, at least seven rebels and three civilians were killed in clashes with troops in the north and east, the Government said.

title: Q AND A
description: The Borghese Question:Is the Borghese Gallery in Rome still closed for restoration? Are pieces from the collection on view elsewhere, and where can I call for information? - M. F., Santa Monica, Calif. Answer:The second floor of the Borghese has been closed for restoration since February 1984, but the first floor has remained open. Sculptures and paintings from the collection have not been moved. Those in the galleries that have been sealed off will not be put on view until the work on the building is completed at some future but unknown date. Meanwhile, the first floor of the Borghese is open from Tuesday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. and on Sunday and holidays from 9 to 1. Admission is about $1.50.

title: Top Lineman
description: THE best interior lineman in college football is a defensive tackle who began his football career as a high school quarterback, according to the Football Writers Association of America, which named Jason Buck of Brigham Young as the winner of the 1986 Outland Trophy.

title: Fallingwater, at 50, Still Sums Up the 20th Century
description: Frank Lloyd Wright's Fallingwater, in actuality, is both stronger and gentler than in the photographs. There are a lot of photographs of it - it is perhaps the most famous house built in the 20th century - and so there are few who make the pilgrimage to visit it who do not have some sense of it already in mind.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: OZ IN PHILADELPHIA ''The Wonderful World of Oz,'' one of 14 books by L. Frank Baum, will be the subject explored Wednesday at 5:30 P.M. at the Philadelphia Art Alliance by Barbara S. Koelle, president of The International Wizard of Oz Club.

title: IN THE WEST, MUNICIPAL HEARTSTRINGS GO 'ZING! ZING! ZING!'
description: CLEARING its roads for the automobile after World War II, Sacramento ripped up the rails of an extensive trolley system that had served it since 1890. But trolleys will roll again in March, when the city plans to open the first leg of an 18.3-mile transit line to its northern and eastern suburbs.

title: CHAPIN FOR 2 ANTIHUNGER GROUPS
description: EFFORTS to combat hunger on Long Island received a boost last month when Sandy Chapin, widow of the singer and songwriter Harry Chapin, announced a major bequest to two antihunger organizations founded by her husband.

title: TRIAL TO HEAR FATAL FILM BLAST'S 'TRIGGER MAN'
description: A special effects technician is expected to provide key testimony Monday in the trial of five men for involuntary manslaughter in the filming of ''Twilight Zone: The Movie.''

title: PHONE CALLS LINK U.S. AIDES TO CONTRAS
description: Telephone records from Nicaraguan rebel ''safe houses'' in El Savador show a series of calls on the same days in September to the former White House offices of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, as well as to the company run by a retired general involved in dealings with Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Paramedics in Pittsburgh Strike Over Wage Issue
description: The union for almost 200 paramedics, saying it had ''exhausted all other means'' of trying to get a pay increase, has gone on strike.

title: Stephen Morisseau Weds Miss Delafield in California
description: Mary Lee Delafield, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Delafield of La Jolla, Calif., was married there yesterday to Stephen Byars Morisseau, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert E. Morisseau of New City, N.Y. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at St. James By-The-Sea Episcopal Church.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: AFTER THE BOESKY AFFAIR;
IF ANYTHING NEEDS REFORM, IT'S THE S.E.C.
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission has been criticized for letting Ivan F. Boesky off too lightly and for allowing the arbitrager to trade takeover stocks in the hours before the announcement of his $100 million penalty. Whatever the merits of these criticisms, they should not obscure the truly remarkable performance of the S.E.C. enforcement staff in the Boesky case. For the staff labors under antiquated and cumbersome procedures laid down in the ticker-tape era.

title: THE STAGE: MAX MORATH IN 'LIVING A RAGTIME LIFE'
description: ''IT'S our music that labels our history, more than our wars and our politicians,'' asserts Max Morath early in his one-man show, ''Living a Ragtime Life.'' Seated at a grand piano under a Tiffany lamp, and flanked by an Edison phonograph, the musicologist, storyteller and expert in turn-of-the-century Americana seems the very epitome of an old-time vaudevillian. But in reflecting with a sly ironic humor on our longing for ''the good old days,'' Mr. Morath is much more than a devoted nostalgist. He is a philosopher of American popular culture with Mark Twain's gift of gab and farsighted historical view. The picture he paints of the 1890's, ''when sex was dirty and the air was clean,'' is of a world that we might want to visit, but, he convincingly persuades us, we almost certainly wouldn't want to live there.

title: IN TOKYO, BAND-AID, LIVE-AID, LEMONADE
description: ''SO what is that food Ronald Reagan-san has on his desk?'' my Japanese uncle asked. After having been in Tokyo for a month I had grown accustomed to the new title and corresponding responsibilities as an authority on all things American. However lunch with my aunt and uncle was something not unlike a Q & A session on ''Face the Nation.'' ''Jellybeans,'' I replied. ''Ahh, jellybeans,'' he nodded.

title: THE TRILLION-DOLLAR PAPER TIGER
description: TO ARM A NATION Rebuilding America's Endangered Defenses. By Richard Halloran. 396 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $21.95.

title: The Return of 'Nutcracker'- An Eternal Balletic Verity
description: The winter holidays are approaching; so, everywhere, are productions of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: DRUG FOR A BLINDING INFECTION
description: An antibiotic that can be administered in a single dose to children whose eyes are infected with gonorrhea proved 100 percent effective in a new study, researchers say.

title:
CABEL TV NOTES;
National Geographic Tests New Waters
description: Beginning in 1965, and continuing for 20 years, the National Geographic Society was a stalwart and stable presence on broadcast television, producing sumptuous hourlong nature documentaries at a rate that averaged four per year.

title: 9 Blacks Freed In South Africa
description: South Africa's biggest treason trial in three decades has been under way for nine months in Delmas, a conservative, white-run settlement 45 miles east of Johannesburg, and is expected to continue for several more months.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE HOLIDAYS are coming, and so are the books. Following is a sampling of some recent works by New Jerseyans, about New Jerseyans or about the state:

title: The Right to Trust the Government
description: For three weeks now, the Reagan Administration has been fighting the wrong fire. The Iran-contra arms affair has created its most damaging crisis in six years. Startling contradictions surface in fundamental policies; White House staff members are caught up in flagrant embarrassments. Stunned, the public yearns for serious, credible explanation. Instead, Administration officials act like scared bureaucrats with something to hide.

title: PHYSICIAN'S STAND ON REGULATION ASSAILED
description: Dr. Sattenspiel sounds as if he is making a bid for profit, rather than a plan for better relations between patient and doctor.

title: Basque Business Bombed A Day Before Vote
description: A bomb believed set by Basque separatists exploded today at a car showroom, a day before voters elect a regional parliament.

title: X Factor In N.F.L. Violence
