description: LURKING beneath the surface like a nest of snakes, drugs is the X factor in National Football League violence. The unknown created by cocaine, steroids and amphetamines. Nobody talks about it much. Nobody has been able to do anything about it. But the players know drugs are a threat to the career of a drug user's victim perhaps even more than to the career of the drug user. And that threat will remain until the N.F.L. Players Association realizes that by protecting its drug users from drug testing, it exposes its clean members to the drug users' wide-eyed violence.

title: STUDENTS LATE, BUSES AT ISSUE
description: FOR Elissa Schwartz of Woodmere, the daily trip to a private high school in Manhattan is taking 20 minutes longer than it did last year.

title: THE PASSAGE ACROSS INDIA OF GORBACHEV
description: For nearly an hour, a group of unsmiling Soviet security men guarded the gates of a shopping emporium here while Raisa M. Gorbachev, wife of the Soviet leader, was inside buying a green and pink silk sari for her daughter.

title: THE CULT OF CEAUSESCU
description: THE FIRST QUESTION PEOPLE ASK WHEN THEY hear that you have just spent an hour with Nicolae Ceausescu is, ''How did he look?'' So it went with the hotel concierge, the restaurant waiter, the taxi driver, the travel-agency clerk and foreign diplomats in Bucharest. The implication of the question, and much of what is said in the police state that is Rumania deals in implications and inferences, was whether President Ceausescu has long to live. A year ago, he had been out of action for weeks, the rumor being that he had prostate cancer. But now, the 68-year-old leader seemed, to the nondiagnostic eye, more or less fit.

title: Sherrie L. Sandy To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Gresham Sandy of Roanoke, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sherrie Lynn Sandy, to Edward John Rollins Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rollins of Vallejo, Calif. The wedding is planned for May.

title: VERMONTERS TRY TO HELP FAMILY STAY IN U.S.
description: A family of Mexican immigrants facing deportation has won a battle in a fight to stay in the United States.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Racine, Wis.; A Catalyst On the Harbor
description: HOPES are running high in this southern Wisconsin city of 86,000 for the success of a $35 million project on the Lake Michigan shorefront. The city and Racine County have already begun their parts of the enterprise and a private developer will crank up its project early next year.

title: IN A ZONING QUARREL, IT'S BOZRAH VS. BOZRAH
description: THE town of Bozrah is embroiled in a lawsuit over a zoning matter. It cannot lose the suit and neither can it win it, since the town is suing itself.

title: KATHLEEN TURNER TRIED HER HAND AT 'CAMILLE'
description: All over the world she is famous as a movie star, having played the sizzling leading lady to men who range from William Hurt, Jack Nicholson and Michael Douglas to Steve Martin.

title: Social Events; All Around Town
description: Seeking Rehabilitation Dec. 1 - The Fortune Society, which helps former convicts re-enter society through counseling and job placement, is holding a 19th anniversary cocktail benefit at the Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street, from 5:30 to 7:30 P..M. Tickets, $50, at the door. Information: 212-206-7070. Landmarks Meeting Dec. 2 - The elegant Stanhope Hotel at Fifth Avenue and 81st Street is 60 years old and was recently refurbished. It will be the site of a benefit for the New York Landmarks Conservancy, created 13 years ago to protect, preserve and find continuing uses for notable buildings. The black-tie evening starts with 7:30 P.M. cocktails followed by a dinner-dance. Tickets, $500, from 212-874-4098. To Advance Research Dec. 4 - The Irvington House Institute is an independently supported series of medical research laboratories at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Rockefeller University that study diseases of the immune system. For the 31st year, the institute will hold an art and antique auction for its annual benefit. Cocktails at 6 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, followed by an auction of items ranging from jewelry, furs, a balloon flight and Super Bowl Weekend to a William IV carved mahogany metamorphic armchair and a pottery head from the Han Dynasty. Dinner and dancing follow. Tickets, $75 for cocktails and auction; $300 or $500 for the entire black-tie benefit, from 212-758-8250. Return of ''Fledermaus'' Dec. 4 - After an absence of 20 years, ''Die Fledermaus'' is returning to the Metropolitan Opera for a benefit evening.

title: POLITICIAN'S WIFE, TOUGHING IT OUT
description: PAT NIXON The Untold Story. By Julie Nixon Eisenhower. Illustrated. 480 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Recent Releases of Video Cassettes
description: Yellowstone in Winter Director and Photographer: Wolfgang Bayer. 60 minutes. $41.70 from Wolfgang Bayer Productions, Box 915, Jackson Hole, Wyo. 83001.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Sunday about proposed restrictions on smoking in New York State described incorrectly the regulations for restaurants. A restaurant would be required to provide a nonsmoking area ''sufficient to meet customer demand,'' according to the State Health Department. The size of the area was not stipulated.

title: Edie Hutter, a Researcher, Is Wed to Mark Neuberger
description: Edie Hutter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Hutter of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Mark Andrew Neuberger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Neuberger of New York.

title: Spicy Salami From Hungary
description: PERSUADING Americans that there is more to Hungarian cuisine than goulash has not been easy, but Terimpex, the Hungarian agency responsible for food exports, will not give up. It has chosen Hungarian salami to lead its American marketing efforts.

title: NEW JERSEY OPINION
description: For 13-year-old Chris Hill, an eighth grader at Linwood Middle School in North Brunswick, the routine of study and getting his homework in on time has been replaced with the day-to-day struggle of regaining his health and strength.

title: Fairfield Prep Wins by Shutout
description: Al Rosier of Fairfield Prep ran for two touchdowns as Prep scored 35 points in the first half and shut out Notre Dame of Fairfield, 42-0, in Fairfield County yesterday.

title: Ideas For Gifts When Price Isn't Key
description: What if your passion for music is so strong that only the best sound equipment can make you happy? As long as your finances are adequately supportive of your taste, you have no problem. But even dedicated audiophiles may balk at sheer profligacy. So, as our continuing Christmas shopping guide ascends toward the upper ranks of audio, we shall stop short of the rarefied regions where no costs are counted in the pursuit of perfection. Instead, we shall focus on first-rate equipment with the sensible proviso that cost and performance remain proportionate.

title: The American Wife
description: I can respond only from my point of view as a New York City surgeon and wife.

title: Met Fans Pay Price for Success
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SURROUNDED BY GLASS
description: THE MIRROR OF HER DREAMS Mordant's Need. By Stephen R. Donaldson. 642 pp. New York: A Del Rey Book/ Ballantine Books. $19.95.

title: LOCAL GOVERNMENT IN U.S. IS RESHAPED BY FEDERAL MOVES
description: The policies and processes of local government face substantial change because of Federal action on taxes and the budget deficit as well as court and Congressional challenges to local authority, according to officials at every level of government around the country.

title: CONSPICUOUS EXILE
description: END PAPERS Essays, Letters, Articles of Faith, Workbook Notes. By Breyten Breytenbach. 270 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95.

title: J. T. McKennan And Dr. Gordon Exchange Vows
description: Dr. Laurie A. Gordon, the chief medical resident at the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital, and James T. McKennan, a senior copywriter at Backer & Spielvogel in New York, were married yesterday at the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Boyd M. Johnson Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Illness's Toll: A Slide Into Poverty and Despair
description: Pearl K. knew something was wrong the morning she got up and tried to slip on a dress. During the night, her legs and arms had become so swollen that the dress did not fit.

title: Ms. Shaw to Wed H.H. Sprague 3d
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Shaw Jr. of Englewood, N.J., and Cornwall, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Patricia Campbell Shaw to Henry Hezekiah Sprague 3d, a son of Dr. Henry Hezekiah Sprague Jr. of Detroit and Lucy Ruffin Sprague of Tenafly, N.J.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are several thousand worse things than being trapped in an airline seat next to a verbose stranger, but at the time it doesn't seem possible. It's hard to imagine anything more deadly than uninterrupted hours during which someone you've never seen before, and never want to see again, fills you in on a life story so dull that it wouldn't even make a mini-series. Or, almost worse, having to endure an interrogation because the stranger has read a pop psychology book that says people like nothing better than talking about themselves.

title: That Same Old Sound
description: AT the risk of sounding repetitious: Boooooooo!

title: Colonel North Lives
description: Whoever its originators, the trick of using secret arms sales to Iran to finance secretly the rebels in Nicaragua seems to have backfired against President Reagan's desire to overthrow the Sandinista Government. But if that's so, might not Mr. Reagan be goaded into even more dangerous action in Central America?

title: CUTTING A FEW CONNECTIONS
description: THE latest buzzword in the fickle personal computer industry (remember such since discarded classics as ''heuristic'' and ''ergonomics''?) is ''connectivity.'' Besides presumably enriching the industry's vocabulary, the term points up what would be a crucial change in the destiny of the small computer in business. In a very real sense, the word negates the very concept of personal computing itself.

title: 'NOT JUST CONFUSED, JUST WILD'
description: ROBERT FROST HIMSELF By Stanley Burnshaw. Illustrated. 342 pp. New York: George Braziller. $19.95.

title: PRIVATE AIRFIELDS THREATENED BY SUBURBAN SPRAWL
description: Before World War II, meadows and woodlands encircled Ramapo Valley Airport and its small 2,200-foot runway.

title: Julia Hufferd Has Wedding
description: At the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., yesterday Julia Beach Hufferd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Beach Hufferd of Darien, Conn., and Jupiter Island, Fla., was married to Stephen Scott Kudenholdt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Alvin Kudenholdt of Elmhurst, Ill. The Rev. John W. Hart performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BLACKBALLED. By Michael Mewshaw. (Atheneum, $16.95.) In 1982, longing for a change of scenery and subject matter, Michael Mewshaw spent several months following the men's professional tennis tour.

title: OPPOSITION GREETS LATEST PLAN TO MODERNIZE COUNTY AIRPORT
description: A PROPOSAL to modernize Westchester County Airport with a new passenger terminal, a new taxiway and other facilities is running into strong opposition from neighboring residents.

title: A VOICE LIKE A LION'S ROAR
description: SAMUEL RAMEY HAS TWO strikes against him. First, he is a bass, and most starring operatic roles for men are sewed up by tenors because most composers, from Rossini to Puccini, have opted for the brilliance of the higher male voice. The second strike is Ramey himself: quiet, taciturn; socially, he borders on the awkward. His sentences run from ''Yup'' to ''Nope'' to ''I don't know.''

title: TEACHING JOB SKILLS
description: SINCE 1983, single women receiving Aid to Dependent Children assistance have been under a Federal mandate to seek or train for employment after their youngest child reaches the age of 6. A variety of governmental and private programs on Long Island are in place that provide assistance in finding jobs; two new training programs, one public and one private, are to begin early next year.

title: Jets' Favorite Figures Are 10-2, Not 45-3
description: WAIT a minute. The Jets are annoyed by people selling them short just because the club was trounced, 45-3, last Monday night.

title: OMAN HOLDS WAR GAMES AGAINST 'FANTASIA'
description: Precisely 28 minutes after they landed here to complete a 4,560-mile flight from England, six Tornado aircraft, four fitted for ground attack and two as fighters, roared off this island's air base and into Operation Swift Sword.

title: Miss Campbell to Wed James Bungerz in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Fred Campbell of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Campbell to James Sterling Bungerz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Bungerz of Allentown, Pa. An April wedding is planned.

title: The Certain Death Of George V
description: Royalty's abhorrence of the wrong publicity is nothing new, the British were reminded last week. It was reason 50 years ago for his physician to inject the dying King George V with enough morphine and cocaine to assure a death timed for announcement in the morning Times of London rather than the ''less appropriate evening journals.''

title: FLURRY OF YULE OFFERINGS SIGNAL START OF SEASON
description: AN extraordinary rush of musical activity is coming up, with one organization after another either trying to squeeze in one last program before the holiday break or hastening to unveil its own early Christmas programming.

title: Golfer Is Found Slain
description: Sarah Hunter, a professional golfer who disappeared in September, has been found strangled in a cornfield, according to the police. The body was found Thursday by William Andrus on a farm owned by his father, W. Otis Andrus. A deputy medical examiner, Paul Morrow, said Ms. Hunter had been strangled.

title: Miss Beal to Marry Sheldon Pennoyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Beal Jr. of Lincoln, Mass., and Squam Lake, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter Penelope Gay Beal to Sheldon Kellogg Pennoyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I. A July wedding is planned.

title: MENDHAM RECORDS A 300-YEAR LEGACY
description: ''THE POINT of this venture,'' said Ruth Smith, a Mendham Borough Councilwoman, ''is not just to document what we have, but to inspire other communities to do the same before it's too late.''

title: EMISSION FIGURES ELICIT DISBELIEF
description: As a retired chemist and occasional college mathematics instructor, I don't trust the estimated pollutant emission quantities in Jean Burnett's Nov. 16 letter about the proposed waste incinerator for Ocean County.

title: The American Wife
description: When I began to read Anne Taylor Fleming's article ''The American Wife'' (Oct. 26), I recognized myself.

title: COURT ASSAILS HOLDING OF 2 FOR YEAR WITHOUT TRIAL
description: A Federal judge has been ordered to set conditions to release two men held without bail for more than a year on charges involving a major Wells Fargo robbery in Connecticut.

title: A Danish Aid For U.S. Diets
description: FROM Denmark, comes yet another entrant into the continuous flood of substances to help people lose weight painlessly. This one is the Schering-Plough Corporation's Fibre Trim, a tablet that the pharmaceutical giant says contains only ground-up natural grains and grapefruit, orange and lemon pulp, and thus is safer than other diet aids.

title: NEW CENTER IS STUDYING MENTAL HEALTH OF AGED
description: A NEW center in Hartford is looking for clues to the mental problems of the elderly.

title:
FOUR LIVES: CHRONICLES OF PAIN, LOSS, AND, FINALLY, HOPE;
Children at Risk: So Fragile, So Resilient
description: Many of us who are parents, however comfortable and stable our lives, have experienced moments when, by virtue of one or another crisis, we suddenly realize how vulnerable a family's life can be.

title: UTILITIES BATTLE ENEMY NO. 1: THE TREE
description: AT any given time, approximately 150 customers of the Northeast Utilities Company are without electric power in Connecticut, and the reasons range from cars hitting utility poles to raccoons wedging themselves into transformers, utility officials say.

title: Today's Sports
description: Basketball Great Alaska Shootout At Anchorage, Alaska Television ESPN, consolation game, 7 P.M.; final, 9 P.M. Football Jets vs. Los Angeles Rams At Giants Stadium, 1 P.M. Television Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio WABC 770, 1 P.M. Broncos vs.

title: PHYSICIAN'S STAND ON REGULATION ASSAILED
description: Is it fair to regulate doctors? Yes it is. Physicians have demonstrated an inability to regulate themselves via their own ethical-conduct codes. They function in a highly regulated industry, but have not had much of the regulatory effort directed at their practice.

title: SMOKING IS BARRED AT BRIDGE MEETING
description: The finalists in two major events had to face some unfamiliar conditions at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here today.

title: REGULATING MILK SALES: ALBANY TAKES UP ISSUE
description: For half a century, a New York State law restricting who can sell one of the commonest of commodities - milk -has stood virtually unchanged. But when lawmakers return to Albany in January, they will be under new pressure to adopt rules increasing competition among distributors.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JAMES BROWN: The Godfather of Soul. By James Brown with Bruce Tucker. (Macmillan, $18.95.) Along with Chuck Berry, Little Richard and Ray Charles, James Brown is one of the most influential shapers of contemporary popular music. And in this surprisingly reserved autobiography he charts his life from the meager beginnings in rural Georgia to his induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame earlier this year. Born in Barnwell, S.C., in 1933, Mr. Brown, after his mother left when he was 4, was raised by his father and, later, an aunt who lived in Augusta, Ga. He was a better-than-average athlete but music became his early obsession and he formed his own trio by the age of 12. Poverty and a less than hospitable environment (his aunt ran a brothel), however, led him into a life of petty thievery, and at 16 he was sent to the Georgia Juvenile Training Institute. Released in 1952, he began to earnestly pursue musical ambitions. His career peaked in the late 60's, declined rapidly in the 70's with the advent of disco and numerous personal problems, then took off again recently with his exposure in movies such as ''Rocky IV.'' In recounting his story, Mr. Brown avoids lurid connections of drugs and sex with rock music. Instead he concentrates on the black performers' struggle to move from ''race'' recordings and the ''chitlin' circuit'' into the entertainment mainstream, the stress and excitement of extended tours (he sometimes played 350 one-nighters a year, thereby earning the sobriquet ''the hardest working man in show business'') and his friendships with legendary performers like Little Willie John, Elvis Presley and Jackie Wilson.

title: Antibiotics Made Jointly
description: IN the race to develop potent drugs to fight infections, American pharmaceutical companies are increasingly hooking up with their Japanese counterparts.

title: Who Will Care for the Boarder Babies?
description: Baby L., barely 2 months old, frets until a nurse comes to his Plexiglass bassinet and props him up with her hand. His skin, a variegated brown, is dry. His brown eyes, like saucers, lock into those of his rescuer, refusing to notice anyone else for fear he'll lose her attention.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bloomfield $145,000 68 Clark Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial, enclosed sun porch, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $2,033. Gillette $215,000 16 Cresswood Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, brick front; taxes $2,447.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FRICTION WITH THE MARKET'': Henry James and the Profession of Authorship. By Michael Anesko. (Oxford, $22.95.) In this well-written study of Henry James's adventures in the literary marketplace, Michael Anesko, an assistant professor of history and literature at Harvard University, provides new information and new insights.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A CUSTOM FALLS
description: Court custom is not observed in the trial here of two avowed revolutionaries charged with murdering a state trooper.

title: Texas Drops Akers as Coach
description: Fred Akers, who coached Texas to its first losing season in three decades, was dismissed today. Athletic Director DeLoss Dodds, who met earlier in the day with the school's Athletics Council, said Akers would be reassigned to other duties. He has five years left on a contract worth $91,600 a year.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Personal Finance column last Sunday, about margin loans, carried an incorrect byline. It was written by Carole Gould.

title: Alabama Misses Out on Sugar Bowl Bid
description: Auburn knocked archrival Alabama out of a possible Sugar Bowl berth today with a last-minute touchdown scored by Lawyer Tillman, who was trying to call time out before the ball was snapped because he had never run a flanker reverse before.

title: Manhattan Hotels Break the $200 Barrrier
description: THE era of the $200-a-night hotel room has dawned in Manhattan and the $300 room may not be far behind.

title: A Forgotten Childhood: 'They Gave Me Up'
description: Arthur P., who was born with shortened legs due to spina bifida - an imperfect closure of the spine - has bitter childhood memories. Although of normal intelligence, the 24-year-old spent his first decade at the Willowbrook State School for the retarded and disabled on Staten Island.

title: Ithaca Eliminates Montclair State
description: Montclair State, trailing by a touchdown, drove inside the Ithaca 30-yard line three times in the second half today but failed to score on all three occasions. Those squandered opportunities and a sensational performance by the Ithaca running back, Shawn Almeida, made the difference as the Bombers beat the Indians, 29-15, to win the Eastern Regional of the Division III playoffs.

title: GROWING OLD, GRACEFULLY OR OTHERWISE, IS A TOUGH ACT
description: The most touching scenes in Francis Coppola's ''Peggy Sue Got Married'' come when 45-year-old Peggy Sue, finding herself 25 years back in time, visits her grandparents. The old folks are played by Leon Ames and Maureen O'Sullivan with a kind of distracted affection, the way grandparents are often seen by kids, doting yet somewhat unconnected. But Peggy Sue is no longer a kid, and by the time we get into our mid-40's, connections with people in their 60's and over are being formed or reformed.

title: NORTH KOREA DAM WORRIES THE SOUTH
description: Ever since North Korea shocked its southern neighbor 36 years ago with a surprise attack, this nation has assiduously catalogued every conceiveable threat that could come from the North. Now they see a new weapon in their enemy's arsenal: water.

title: Catholic Charities, Archdiocese of New York
description: A family overwhelmed by emergency financial problems, a homeless pregnant woman in need of care and compassion, a homebound senior citizen without family to provide daily care, a young deaf person able to leave an institution for the first time and live in a halfway house are only some of the people who turned to the staff of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York for help in 1986. Each was helped and given the resources to overcome immediate problems and face the future better equipped to deal with life.

title: 4 Escape From Prison AIDS Unit
description: Four inmates who were being treated in the AIDS remission unit of Trenton State Prison escaped Saturday night, according to officials.

title: THE HERESY OF SELF-LOVE
description: DEPARTURES Memoirs. By Paul Zweig. Introduction by Morris Dickstein. 219 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ALL-GIRL FOOTBALL TEAM. By Lewis Nordan. (Louisiana State University, Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $9.95.) Lewis Nordan questions the line between inner and outer reality again and again in this stunning collection of short stories.

title: Topics: Tax/Attacks; Gold Christmas
description: Which business magazine do you read? Fortune rates the U.S. Mint's gold Eagle as the No. 1 ''Product of the Year,'' beating out Bruce Springsteen's new album, Pepsi Slice, Laser Tag and other, more serious creations. But Business Week warns of ''ridiculous'' prices.

title: The Moral Dilemma Of Fighting Terrorism
description: Say this for ''Sword of Gideon'': It makes an effort to break away from prevailing TV stereotypes. The 2 1/2-hour movie - which made its debut last night on Home Box Office and will be shown five other times throughout December on the pay cable service - begins as if it is preparing to be still another inspirational portrait of Israelis triumphing over terrorist enemies. The genre is perhaps best typified by a network production like ''Raid on Entebbe.'' In the case of ''Sword of Gideon,'' five men are recruited to form an ''anti-terrorist'' squad following the vicious murders of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich.

title: BURNING OF WASTE AT SEA CLOSER
description: THE INCINERATION of hazardous wastes off the coast of Cape May and three other sites in United States waters will move closer to reality when Federal Environmental Protection Agency officials prepare regulations to govern the procedure.

title: DISPUTE OVER ZONING BROADENS
description: EFFORTS by county planners to help communities broaden their zoning ordinances to accommodate recent court rulings have backfired, setting the stage for a major confrontation between county legislators and local officials.

title: In Italy, Risotto Gains on Pasta
description: It may come as a surprise to learn that Italy is the No. 1 producer of rice in Europe and one of its largest consumers, despite the fact that rice is not indigenous. (It was apparently brought to Italy by the Saracens during the Middle Ages, and not, as one might think, by the Crusaders or Marco Polo returning from Asia.) In Italy rice is cultivated almost exclusively in the plains of the Po and Ticino valleys in the north near cities like Mantua in Lombardy and Turin in Piedmont.

title: 'CHIDLREN OF WAR' PAY VISIT
description: NEARLY 500 students and teachers from the Westchester area sat in absorbed silence in the gymnasium of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry last Tuesday as eight of the 63 young people on the ''Children of War'' tour of the United States told their stories.

title: E.P.A. REVIEWING USE OF TBT, A PESTICIDE, IN MARINE PAINTS
description: THE HOTTEST topic in the marine sciences these days is tributyltin, or TBT, a tin-based pesticide added to paint used on boat hulls to repel barnacles and other growths.

title: Watches Stolen From Factory
description: Burglars cut a hole in the roof of the Bulova watch factory in Queens over the Thanksgiving holiday and made off with more than $250,000 in wristwatches, the police said yesterday. Employees said they had discovered that both the burglar alarm system and telephone lines had been cut in the building at 26-15 Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in Jackson Heights.

title: 47 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 47 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Miss McHale Engaged To Jonathan T. Biggins
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. McHale of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Holly Jean McHale to Jonathan T. Biggins, a son of Marie McGarvey Biggins of Wayne, Pa., and the late Robert A. Biggins. The wedding is planned for May.

title: WHAT'S HOT IN IMPORTED PRODUCTS
description: SOME of the hottest-selling consumer products in the United States today have foreign roots. Squeezable plastic ketchup bottles, toothpaste in a pump, diet-aid tablets made of natural grain and citrus fiber, all got their starts overseas, even though many were picked up by American manufacturers for fine-tuning.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A CANTOR'S OTHER ROLE: OPERA SINGER
description: IT'S been a while since Seymour Schwartzman put his split professional personality on the line. But come Saturday, he'll start the day as a hero, at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, watching two youngsters he trained chant their bar mitzvah ritual prayers, and end it at the Tilles Center in Brookville as a villain, the High Priest of Dagon in ''Samson et Dalila.''

title: Trying to Improve The City's Jails
description: Reaction was mixed and there was no great sigh of relief, but the city's Correction Commissioner, Richard J. Koehler, did say last week that his department was planning steps to try to improve conditions in the jails.

title: DEDICATED TO FIGHTING CANCER
description: ''THE majority of patients with breast cancer are now being cured, '' said Yashar Hirshaut of Lawrence. ''Brea st cancer has changed from a 40 percent cure rate to a cure rate that is probably approaching 70 percent.'' Yashar Hirshaut is a doctor specializing in internal medicine. His subspecialty is medical oncology -the medical aspects of caring for cancer patients. Cancer is a disease that the 48-year-old physician has been studying for nearly all his adult life, having spent the years from 1968 to 1985 on the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research; and these days he is combating it on a number of fronts.

title: A Controversial Visit
description: Israeli Prime Ministers have visited West Germany, and there has been other contact between the two countries. But when President Chaim Herzog announced last week that he was planning the first visit by an Israeli President, there was criticism from several members of the Israeli Parliament.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUP'S PLAN FOR VALLEY IN MONTANA STIRS FEARS AMONG RESIDENTS
description: Residents of Paradise Valley agree with members of the Church Universal Triumphant on one key point: There is something special about life here by the Yellowstone River in the shadow of the snow-covered mountains.

title:
INVESTING;
BRACING FOR YET ANOTHER 'WITCHING HOUR'
description: INVESTORS stunned by the trading scandals on Wall Street could be in for even more stock market convulsions. In three weeks, on Dec. 19, another ''triple witching hour'' will occur, when contracts on stock index futures, stock index options and individual stock options expire simultaneously.

title: ALVIN AILEY AND KANSAS CITY: THE ATTRACTION IS MUTUAL
description: If there were no such place as Kansas City, Alvin Ailey might have had to invent it. The Missouri city has served as both spark and stage for his choreographic imaginings and has left its mark on his company and its New York season, which starts Tuesday at City Center.

title: A BIG CONVICTION, BUT WILL THE CITY END UP MORE HONEST?
description: FROM the moment he was indicted on corruption charges last spring, Stanley M. Friedman, the leader of the Bronx Democratic Party, maintained that he was a victim of municipal-scandal hysteria - that he was a legitimate politician and lawyer who had played by the rules of power-brokering in New York City, and that the rules had changed in the middle of the game. Last week, a jury in New Haven disagreed, finding Mr. Friedman guilty on Federal charges of racketeering, conspiracy and mail fraud.

title: FURTHER REFLECTIONS AT ROSH HA-SHANAH
description: Further to Maurice Shire's response [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, Nov. 2 ] to Betty Krasne's ''Reflections at Rosh ha-Shanah,'' [ Westchester Opinion, Oct. 5 ] , Ms. Krasne could have obtained the information she needed about synagogues and services before leaving New York, in a pamphlet provided by the French Tourist Office on Fifth Avenue. Once in Paris, if she had been to the Marais district she would have seen kosher butcher shops (and other signs of Jewish life), where she could have made inquiries.

title: James M. Dowd Married To Judith Johnson Davis
description: Judith Johnson Davis and James Michael Dowd were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of Fairmount, N.J. The Rev. William L. Davis performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Earle H. Johnson of Wannamassa, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. John Dowd of Santa Barbara, Calif.
